column2: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz. -- "Hovenweep" the Indians called it, for In their language the word meant "deserted valley." Truly it was a deserted valley, the dust-blown ramparts of its crumbling towers, pueblos and palaces peopled only by the phantoms of a forgotten age.

Plans are being advanced rapidly for the entertainment, entitled "Fashion Portraits," to be held during the luncheon hour on Oct. 21 at the formal opening of the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Masters School Day Nursery.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Oct. 11 -- With wind and seas blasting them practically all the way, ten of the eighteen yachts that started in the New Rochelle Club's fifty-mile overnight race out around Stratford Shoal, between Bridgeport and Port Jefferson, managed to finish off here today, and the winner turned out to be George Lauder's big Class M sloop Windward.

With seventy-five debutantes of the current season having accepted invitations to dance cotillion figures at the Diamond Ball and Debutante Cotillion on the night of Oct. 24, final plans for the event are now being drawn up by several committees.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 11 -- Biological studies in the academic division of Johns Hopkins University will be pursued this year under a new organization and with new physical facilities. Professor Benjamin H. Willier, incumbent of the Henry Walters Chair of Zoology, will direct the research program in zoology, botany and physiology, which together will be centered upon what may be called "genetic biology," or the origin, development and nature of living things.

The evening performance on Nov. 3 of "Let's Face It," a new musical production of Vinton Freedley, scheduled to have its premiere on Oct. 29 at the Imperial Theatre, will be a benefit for Council House, one of the largest community centers of the city.

ABSECON, N.J., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Peter Page of Philadelphia tonight clinched a berth in the semi-finals of the Geist Memorial golf tournament, eliminating Spencer Overton of Baltimore, 1 up, in a match that went to the twenty-first green.

A COMBINATION of the tender care of a mother, the careful dosings of a family physiciaand the complete ministrs tions of an athletic trainer -- this the service given by Pan American Airways to its clippers after each arrival in New York.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 11 -- A replica of the Columbia Rose Bowl team that exploded a bombshell under Stanford threw another stalwart eleven in the Orange and Black of Princeton into confusion with the baffling cleverness of its stabbing, swirling spins and fakes today as the Lion mauled the favored Tiger by 21-0 in Palmer Stadium.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The highly touted Oklahoma Aggies took their time about getting started then piled up 28 points in the second half to smear Washington University, 41 to 12, in a Missouri Valley Conference opener today.
LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

For its eighth annual meeting the Connecticut Spaniel Field Trial Association has arranged the most ambitious program in its history. This year's competition again will be held in the covers of the Ingham Hill Game Farm in Saybrook, Conn., the dates being Oct. 30, 31 and Nov. 1.

BERLIN, Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- Nazi spokesmen said tonight that Panzer spearheads may already be almost within sight of Moscow's ancient spires, that the main German armies had pushed to sixty-five miles from the Soviet capital.

Columbus Day, recalling the discovery of a new world and the birth of a new way of life, should serve to unite all Americans in the fight to perpetuate democratic ideals, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday. The late Supreme Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis was eulogized.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct 11 (AP) -- Tennessee trotted out its only uninjured tailback, sophomore third-stringer named Walter Slater, and the 158-pound Providence (R.I.) youngster engineered the Vols to a 26-0 triumph over a game but outplayed Dayton University eleven today.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 11 -- The Northwestern powerhouse rolled to a resounding 41-to-14 triumph over Wisconsin today, taking advantage of all the breaks in its Western Conference debut before 40,000 spectators.
SALEM, N.H., Oct 11 (AP) -- Mrs. Frank Nugent's Espino Gold nosed out Mrs. Sam Orr's Us in the featured Jackson Handicap today at Rockingham Park in a race that saw the field bunched most of the way.
ATLANTA, Oct. 11 -- Notre Dame's well-oiled harvester mowed down a game but outplayed and outpassed Georgia Tech. squad today, 20-0, before 31,000 sunbaked fans.

OUT of the pine woods of Florida has come a first novel whose most distinctive quality is the capture of their turpentine-laden atmosphere. Like a drug, almost, it pervades the lives of the characters in the story.

The Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association has just issued its schedule for the 1941-42 season, which opens on Nov. 11 with interclub Class B team matches, and continues until March 13, when an invitation Class B tournament will close at the Apawamis Club.

The Jooss Ballet restored to its season's repertory yesterday after-noon another of the works from its first New York program back in 1933. This was Jooss's version of Ravel's "Pavane pour une Infante Defunte" which, as a dance piece, bears the simpler title of "Pavane." The company is at the Maxine Elliott Theatre.

ORONO, Me., Oct. 11 -- The University of Maine and the University of New Hampshire matched first-period touchdowns today, then settled down into a scoreless duel the rest of the way, the game ending in a 7-7 tie. Maine tallied first on Carl Goodchild's 24-yard romp, with Al Hutchinson drop-kicking the point.
BOSTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The educated toe of Clemson's Walter Payne gave the comeback hopes of Boston College a resounding kick in the seat of the trousers today.

George Pathy, general manager of the Alexandria Navigation Company, Egyptian ship operators, began last week a series of conferences and discussions with shipping and commercial interests in the United States regarding the eventual establishment of a regular Egyptian freight and passenger service between Egypt and the United States.

NOW that the sumac is red and the maples are turning, millions of Americans are oiling up their sporting guns and looking over their equipment, for the Fall hunting season is now getting under way, and in every one of the Eastern States and Provinces the prospects are better than they have been in several years.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Despite the fact that President Roosevelt's move for a declaration of religious freedom in Russia could only be universally acclaimed, it is very doubtful whether it can bring about any visible change in the status of religion in the Soviet Union.

The duck shooting season will open in New York State at exactly 6:13 A.M. this Thursday, and if you have obtained and signed your duck stamp, bought your license and reserved the services of a guide you should be in line for some fair broadbill and coot shooting.

"THANK You, America," is a new British short-wave feature at 7:55, E.S.T., on Sundays, Tuesdays and Fridays. This is a five-minute thank you note to the United States for war help to England, and the first program in this series was a thank you for American Red Cross aid.

PRFECTION of stainless steel, enamel and functional design has made the modern kitchen (at least the ones on display in showrooms) into a sort of Wellsiun laboratory -- all pristine efficiency and asepsis. From the point of view of work this is fine; no woman can look at the gleaming flush surfaces and the compact cabinets without wishing she had such a place to cook in.
TOKYO, Oct. 11 -- The Foreign Office announced today that "as a result of an agreement with the United States Government as regards dispatch of Japanese vessels to America,...

George Pathy, general manager of the Alexandria Navigation Company, Egyptian ship operators, began last week a series of conferences and discussions with shipping and commercial interests in the United States regarding the eventual establishment of a regular Egyptian freight and passenger service between Egypt and the United States.

NOW that the sumac is red and the maples are turning, millions of Americans are oiling up their sporting guns and looking over their equipment, for the Fall hunting season is now getting under way, and in every one of the Eastern States and Provinces the prospects are better than they have been in several years.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Despite the fact that President Roosevelt's move for a declaration of religious freedom in Russia could only be universally acclaimed, it is very doubtful whether it can bring about any visible change in the status of religion in the Soviet Union.

The duck shooting season will open in New York State at exactly 6:13 A.M. this Thursday, and if you have obtained and signed your duck stamp, bought your license and reserved the services of a guide you should be in line for some fair broadbill and coot shooting.

"THANK You, America," is a new British short-wave feature at 7:55, E.S.T., on Sundays, Tuesdays and Fridays. This is a five-minute thank you note to the United States for war help to England, and the first program in this series was a thank you for American Red Cross aid.

THIS week's editorial is by way of postscript to last Sunday's remarks about the novel and the direction which seems indicated as both probable and desirable if the art of fiction is to develop its potentialities still further.

KINGSTON, R.I., Oct. 11 -- The Women's Student Government Association at Rhode Island State College has taken as its special objective this year the making of the women's group on the campus into a unit of functioning democracy.

HOLLYWOOD'S hunt for new stars has become even more feverish this season: for now that block booking has been curbed, the picture industry will rely more than ever on the drawing power of its names at the box-office.
BERLIN, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique from Adolf Hitler's headquarters today:

The manufacturing industries of the United States, taken in the aggregate, show a considerable increase in combined net profits in the first half of 1941, compared with both the second half of 1940 and the first half of that year.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 11 (AP) -- An alert, hard-charging William and Mary squad toppled Virginia Tech, 16 to 7, before 12,000 spectators today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct 11 -- The Rutgers football team scored its third straight victory, defeating Lehigh, 16-6, in the Rutgers stadium today. A homecoming crowd of 10,000 watched the Scarlet start its quest to regain the little brass canyon, symbolic of Middle Three leadership, which it lost to Lafayette last year.

A COMBINATION of the expected influences acted to hold down retail volume in the week and the gain over last year fell well below the yearto-date average. "Beat-the-tax buying" was over and telephone and travel taxes became effective.

TIMONIUM, Md., Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- The Duke and Duchess of Windsor arrived here today in a private car attached to a special train for a visit with old acquaintances of the Duke and with girlhood friends and relatives of the Duchess.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The ever-increasing output of mystery and detective stories evidences their great popularity among all classes of readers. As an old shut-in, I have used them as an escape method from a host of anxieties and worries and have been struck by the great change in the style of writing by the authors of these mental diverters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Reports were circulated in diplomatic quarters today that conversations looking to a possible basis for negotiating an adjustment of fundamental differences between the United States and Japanese governments had been resumed since the recent return here from Tokyo of Kaname Wakasugi, Minister-Counselor of the Japanese Embassy, after long conferences with his government.
MUSIC by Muzak! You will find it in shops or restaurants and many other places. It is minus radio announcers, commentators, commercial ads, soap dramas and vocalists.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 11 -- The biggest problem of the new government of Australia is regarded as being that of man power, the supply of which may be replenished, it is expected, by such steps as the diversion of labor from luxury to war production, the employment of retired persons, the increased use of women workers and the increased mechanization of industry.

Shortages of materials became increasingly acute in numerous lines in the wholesale market last week, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

SOME years ago, when cycling was still an amusement and not a defense necessity and annually they would bring the fun to a grand climax with a six-day bike race in the Garden, there was one contestant who, as the years and the wheels rolled on, became as much a part of the spectacle as the odd-shaped pine board saucer itself.

THE lady who, ready for a tour of the West Indies when war was declared two years ago, said sadly, "Now, I'll never see a breadfruit tree," has long since dried her tears. For while some ships' that made the Caribbean circle are of necessity traveling other routes, enough remain in service to cover island ports where breadfruit trees still shake out their large glossy leaves.

Many problems relating to the rehabilitation of American cities will be discussed by speakers who have studied the civic difficulties of the present day at the first conference on city planning to be held under the auspices of the Urban Land Institute at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Mass., beginning Wednesday and continuing through Friday.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 11 -- Disposing of a large estate including realty at Old Westbury, L.I., and Aiken, S.C., the will of Thomas Hitchcock, sportsman and horseman who died at Old Westbury on Sept. 29, was filed here today. The will, dated Oct. 16, 1935, had four codicils.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 11 -- The Naval Academy football team made it three straight in its victory march today, crushing Lafayette, 41 to 2, with breaks aiding in three of its six touchdowns. Vice President Henry A. Wallace was among the spectators.

In contrast to widely held views as to the inevitability of a severe post-war setback, there are several reasons for hoping that the transition of industrial-machinery companies to a peacetime basis may be successfully made, Harry C. Beaver, president of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation, maintained in an interview last week.

HOLLYWOOD. THE Kozinsky Brothers, slot machine entrepreneurs, muscled into the movie racket because Cecil B. De Mill made them feel like mugs, an that made them very unhappy The way to crack the racket, they say, is to be sincere, and they recently cracked it with a $23,000 pictare called "Paper Bullets," which the Producers Releasing Corporation is distributing.

WASHINGTON. FIRST casualty of America's new war effort was Alexander Throttlebottom. When Henry Agard Wallace took over the Vice Presidency it was clear that Throttlebottom's days were numbered, and when Mr. Wallace took over the two key defense agencies the old gentleman just faded away.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Vanderbilt's powerful Commodores spotted Kentucky a safety and two touchdowns and then unleashed an aerial and ground attack to smash the previously unbeaten Wildcats by 39 to 15 today before a home-coming crowd of 12,000.

To the Art Editor: IN his "Bombshell" communications Mr. Kootz has in effect let out a healthy roar for better fare and better service. He has broken the bottle of emetic wine over the waiter's head and stuffed the boiled owl souffle down the chef's throat.

OTTAWA -- The airgraph system of communication has been adopted by the Canadian Postoffice Department and will be put into effect shortly on the transatlantic air route between all parts of the Dominion and the United Kingdom primarily for the benefit of overseas Canadian troops.

To the Drama Editor: THIS is to commend the recent report on Army entertainment by Private Louis M. Simon of Fort Foster, Me. The need is great, as he declares, for Army dramatic productions which would excel even slightly such claptrap as used to appear mainly in tanktown vaudeville.

Embattled N.Y.U. held the Texas Aggies to a 7-7 tie in the first half of their fracas at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. Then came the deluge. The hard-running, sure-passing backs from the Southwest ripped the game and the Violet to shreds for a smashing 49-to-7 victory.

Flashing a powerful running attack, James Monroe High School's football team registered its second straight victory yesterday, beating Seward Park, 16 to 6, in the second game of a scholastic doubleheader at Randalls Island before 5,000.

NEWARK, N.J. Oct. 11 -- Seeking to clarify the personal problems of young women from 17 to 25 years old, the Zonta Club of Newark has established a personal counseling service at the Newark Young Women's Christian Association.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 11 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 10:

The new cargo carrier American Packer, the last of five sister ships constructed for the Australia and Far East routes of the United States Lines was delivered to the company Friday by the builders, the Western Pipe and Steel Company.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

CHICAGO, Oct 11 -- The grain and soy-bean markets were engulfed today by waves of liquidating sales which carried wheat and soy beans to the lowest prices since Sept. 2, and corn to the lowest level since June 6. Stop-loss selling accelerated the decline, and while there were small rallies from time to time on short covering, the close was well toward the bottom for the day.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Unable to score a touchdown against Albright or Bucknell on previous Saturdays, Muhlenberg cut loose against Carnegie Tech today for an easy 26-to-6 victory.

THE game of gin rummy, which was popular in local bridge clubs from 1927 to 1932, and then for nine years was all but forgotten, recently has been revived, and a group of local clubs are endeavoring to agree upon a set of standard rules for playing the game.

LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Franklin and Marshall College, which surprised the football world by beating Dartmouth in 1940, opened its 1941 season today by halting Hampden-Sydney, 19 to 6, before 7,000.

DETROIT, Oct. 11 -- Announcement last week by Harry H. Bennett, Ford Motor Company personnel director, that the company would begin mass lay-offs immediately because of automobile production curtailment, heralded the beginning of a condition which the automobile industry, centered in this area, awaits with grave concern.

Guns for Merchantmen? To a Joint session of Congress on Feb. 26, 1917, Woodrow Wilson appealed for authority to supply American cargo ships with guns to beat off attacks by the U-boats of the Kaiser. An armedship bill was immediately drafted. It passed in the House, 403 to 13.

Representatives of the International Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians, a C.I.O. union known as the F.A.E.C.T., conferred in Washington last Friday with a group of Navy officials headed by Under-Secretary James V. Forrestal and Assistant Secretary Ralph A. Bard.

HOUSTON, Texas, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Tulane's hopes of an unbeaten season, skyscraper high after a glorious start, collapsed today as Rice Institute, outweighed eighteen pounds to the man, stopped the Green Wave's surge with a 10-9 victory.

To the Screen Editor: I was one of the privileged few who had an opportunity to see at a private showing the John Steinbeck film, "The Forgotten Village," barred, I cannot understand why, by the New York Board of Censors.

Two Erasmus backs answering to the names of Ben Raimondi and Dave Sadofsky are expected to go a long way toward bringing the Buff and Blue back to its lofty position in local schoolboy football circles. Both turned in bang-up showings in sparking Erasmus to a 14-to-0 success over its old Brooklyn opponent, James Madison High, at Ebbets Field yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Labor and student groups and Members of Parliament today joined in the growing clamor for British action on the Western Front -- a move that the British command, does not feel ready to make just now.

Assailing Mayor La Guardia as "a fair weather friend of labor," John J. Sullivan, a member of the State Executive Committee of the American Labor party, yesterday announced his support of the candidacy of William O'Dwyer, Democratic Mayoralty candidate, and expressed his "regret" that the American Labor party had endorsed the Mayor for re-election.

From the Canadian Minister of Supply, Mr. C.D. Howe, an administrator not given to overstatement, has come the prediction that by next year the Dominion's production of cargo ships may equal that of Great Britain. Canada now has one hundred and fifty plants turning out ships components.

Guns for Merchantmen? To a Joint session of Congress on Feb. 26, 1917, Woodrow Wilson appealed for authority to supply American cargo ships with guns to beat off attacks by the U-boats of the Kaiser. An armedship bill was immediately drafted. It passed in the House, 403 to 13.

Double taxation of income is not considered constitutionally objectionable; in fact it is generally employed by both the Federal and State Governments. Corporate earnings are taxed, for instance, to the corporation and, when distributed, also to the stockholder.

The perfect physical specimen, in whom all bodily structures are properly balanced, was described before the New York State Osteopathic Society yesterday as "a per- son unknown to the land of the living."

TOKYO, Oct. 11 -- In an age when war is no longer waged between armies and navies but between entire nations, it has become a commonplace to say that morale on the home front is just as important as morale among the troops at the fighting front.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Marquette University's Hilltoppers, conquerers last week of Wisconsin, were tripped, 13 -- 7, by an inspired Michigan State College team today before a home inaugural throng of 14,600.

TRENTON. POLITICIANS who sized up Governor Charles Edison of New Jersey as a man with a spirit so mild that he could be led by the hand wherever they chose have discovered to their consternation that he can't be led, that he refuses to be pushed around, and that he chooses to do the leading himself.
EXHIBITIONS of old photographic prints are fairly common; that now being presented by the American Museum of Photography, 338 South. Fifteenth Street, Philadelphia, is more than commonly interesting.

With $100,000 already contributed, the New York committee of Russian War Relief, Inc., 535 Fifth Avenue, launched yesterday a campaign in the city for $1,000,000 to be spent entirely for medical supplies to aid the Red Army and Russian civilians.
AUBURN, Ala., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Auburn outclassed the Louisiana Polytechnic Institute eleven today, winning, 34 -- 0, in the climax to a Dad's Day program which drew 8,500 fans.

An intercepted pass by Breece Brewer in the early minutes of the second half, broke a 7-7 deadlock and gave Hofstra a 13-7 victory over Brooklyn College yesterday at the Kingsmen's Bedford Avenue field before 4,000 fans.

SAVANNAH, Ga. -- This romantic old Southern port, where ligh-columned mansions, rich foliage and moss-laden oaks have charmed travelers for two centuries, is now an all-year-round resort, thanks to defense activity which has plumped an air base and camp In its midst and strengthened the garrison of its fort.

LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 11 -- Franklin and Marshall College is keyed to the national defense program, but is not unmindful of the fact that it exists primarily to train and educate young men in the liberal arts and sciences.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Civilization is in the balance, the President said in a letter read to the Seattle convention of the American Federation of Labor last Tuesday "and organizational rivalries and jurisdictional conflicts should be discarded." The convention greeted his words with cheers. In the course of the week half a dozen more jurisdictional conflicts tied up some of the most important segments of armament production.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The following foreign service changes since Oct. 4 were announced today by the State Department: Thomas M. Wilson of Memphis, Tenn., consul general at Calcutta, designated Commissioner of United States at New Delhi, India.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- All experts agree that the American transportation system, comprising railroads, bus and motor-truck lines, inland and coastwise water carriers, to say nothing of numerous air lines, is the most efficient on earth.

Even though you may be blessed with a complexion like a moonflower, this Fall you will probably conceal that lovely pallor. Your new tweeds, bright dinner dresses and accessories are bringing Autumn foliage into town and your face must harmonize with your frock.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- After being halted on the 1-yard line in the final minutes of play, Syracuse blocked a Holy Cross endzone punt, recovered for a touchdown and a 6-to-0 victory before 10,000 fans today in Archbold Stadium.

Further expansion of loans and discounts, smaller holdings of cash, slight declines in deposits and total resources, and little average change in holdings of government securities characterized the statements of the leading Wall Street banks for the quarter ended on Sept. 30.

A few months ago we were told that 43 per cent of the men examined for possible selective service were physically and mentally unacceptable. Colonel Leonard G. Rowntree, chief of the Medical Division of the Selective Service, now raises the percentage to 50. On the basis of this figure the President has called for a new program of rehabilitation.

ALL children and most of their elders love a kitten, for a youthful diminutive cat is an appealing pet whose composure, instinct for an effective pose and serene and unshakable determination to have its own way offer perpetual entertainment.

SAVANNAH, Ga. -- This romantic old Southern port, where ligh-columned mansions, rich foliage and moss-laden oaks have charmed travelers for two centuries, is now an all-year-round resort, thanks to defense activity which has plumped an air base and camp In its midst and strengthened the garrison of its fort.

Wherever Hitler hibernates, it isn't going to be pleasant. He has never felt the icy breath of Russia or the heat of the African desert. He has never known how very mean the temperature of Europe can be when almost the entire population is not only hungry but half-frozen.

The woodcock season will get under way in Southern New York and Connecticut on Wednesday, and although the large flights have not yet made an appearance the early starters should be able to locate a few birds with the aid of a good dog.

Fourteen years ago the late Dr. Ludwig Kast suggested to the New York Academy of Medicine that it should arrange for a series of lectures by leading authorities to summarize periodically, for the benefit of physicians in the metropolitan and outlying areas, progress made in the diagnosis and treatment of diseases.

ALBANY, Oct. 12 -- Upon learning of the death of Controller Tremaine, Governor penman today ordered the flags on all public buildings placed at half staff until after the funeral. He also paid this tribute:

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night gave the season's first performances to "The New Yorker" and "Scheherazade" at the Metropolitan Opera House, and lest there seem to be no element of novelty in this, let it be hastily added that in, the latter work Alexandra Danilova made her first appearance here as Zobeide.

ELIZABETH CITY, N.C., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Commodore Mervin Wescoat Sr. of Atlantic City manoeuvred his Antares to first place in a ten-mile race today and won the world championship for Moth type sail boats.

KOENIGSBERG, Germany, Oct. 12 -- By their victorious progress In Russia, Reichsfuehrer Hitler's armies are opening up new valuable markets for German industries after the war, according to an address delivered here today by Dr. Walther Funk, Reich Minister of Economics and President of the Reichsbank.

The United Hospital Fund and Visiting Nurse Association makes its sixty-third annual appeal tomorrow for contributions. Last year the sum of $1,157,323.75 was collected; this year the goal is $1,748,292.73. Unless the money is raised some seventy-five hospitals in the city's various boroughs will be unable to foster medical research on the now accepted scale, to train physicians and nurses and to care for the needy sick.

In a suicide pact, Mrs. Ina Regensburger, 42 years old, a nurse, was found dead early today in a seventeenth-floor room of a midtown hotel, and her husband, Frederick, 53, former Berlin physician, was found critically ill. The couple, German refugees, had taken an overdose of a sleeping potion.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Prices of wheat broke badly last week, dropping more than 6 cents a bushel from the high mark of the preceding week, and went into the lowest ground since the early days of September as the result of a wave of liquidation that carried all before it.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 12 -- A higher government crop forecast than anticipated was only one of several bearish factors which accounted for extreme losses of $3 a bale in cotton futures here last week. These losses were reduced about $1 on Friday, however, when it appeared that the market had been oversold and shorts took to cover and spot interests bought in the futures pit on dips to safeguard against later spot needs.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- General liquidation developed last week in the lard market on the Board of Trade and prices declined sharply to the lowest level since the middle of August, showing a loss of more than 114 cents a pound from the high price in September.

Because two unions have got into a jurisdictional dispute, and one is boycotting the products of the other, 70 per cent of the nation's entire light tank production is threatened. A Labor Board election was held under the Wagner act, but the union that lost refuses to abide by the result.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The Economist's index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, stood on Sept. 30 at 107.7, compared with 106.9 a fortnight before, 108.7 a month before and 98.7 on Oct. 8 last year.
MARCH FIELD, Calif., Oct. 12 -- Five and possibly seven men were killed in the crash of an Army B-23 bomber during a rainstorm in San Gorgonio Pass near Beaumont late today.
BERLIN, Monday, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Two spearheads of a new German offensive against Moscow were reported today to have driven to within about 100 miles of the Russian capital.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 13 -- The projected dispatch of three Japanese liners to American ports has given new impetus to Japanese hopes for an ultimate agreement with the United States on the larger issues as well. There is hope, in any case, of a sufficient agreement to prevent a war in the Pacific.

LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A suggestion that Britain and the Unite States guarantee Russia's Far Eastern frontier against Japanese attack to release the Red forces there, estimated at 450,000 men, emerged today in growing demands of the British press and public for active help to the Soviet Union.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12 -- Time helped the Washington Redskins defeat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 24 -- 20, today in a spine-tingling National Football League game which kept 18,733 persons roaring until the last.
KOENIGSBERG, Germany, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Economic Minister Funk declared today that Russia in an economic sense had been annexed to the "New Europe" and already has become a factor in the "New Order."

Even the Eskimos in the Arctic Circle are contributing toward the fight against Hitler because they feel strongly about "that bad man who is taking people away from their hunting grounds and making them work elsewhere," the Right Rev. Archibald Lang Fleming, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of the Arctic, reported yesterday in a sermon as guest preacher at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

BERLIN, Oct. 12 -- The principal topic of conversation last week in Berlin's financial circles was the level of stock prices which the government would consider to be "justified" under conditions of war.

DETROIT, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions gained their first National Football League victory under Coach Big Bill Edwards today when they crushed the Cleveland Rams, 17 to 7, before 26,481 spectators.

SITKA, Alaska, Oct. 12 -- An explosion in an underground dynamite magazine at the Sitka Naval Air Station just after noon today killed at least six service men, injured several persons in the near-by fishing village and damaged defense and private construction.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Captain Tom Colella scored one touchdown and set up another as the Canisius College football team played a 12-12 tie with Providence before 12,000 today.

ROME, Oct. 12 (U.P.) -- Newspaper dispatches from Zagreb, in the protectorate of Croatia, said today that five persons, including a German sergeant, were wounded in a gun fight and that in Travnik, Bosnia, thirteen alleged Communists were sentenced to death.
LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communiqud today:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The German radio "disposed of" by a United States patrol vessel last month in Greenland was located on the east coast not far from where the destroyer Greer clashed with a Nazi submarine early in September, it was understood here today.

NEW YORK Captain Lord Louis Mountbatten, R.N., Lady Louis Mountbatten and their daughters, the Honorable Patricia and Honorable Pamela Mountbatten; the Duchess of Roxburghe and Alan LennoxBoyd have been guests of Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt at her home, 640 Fifth Avenue.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Miss Jeanne Chandler of Woodside, L.I., 20 years old, has become the only woman on the engineering staff of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company here. Miss Chandler, a graduate of Purdue University, where she was an honor student, specializes in the study of heat reactions and turbines.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The recent announcement that the President will recommend expanding, strengthening and unifying the social security program is encouraging news and comes at the proper time. It is obvious that in a period of increasing national income it is wise to provide for future economic security.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- In a speech in which he reported on the British-United States-Russian meetings at the Kremlin, and asked British and United States workers for increased production, Lord Beaverbrook, Minister of Supply and head of the recent British mission to Moscow, declared tonight that the Russians believed the Germans had 30,000 tanks at the start of the Russian campaign and launched 14,000 in the current drive against Moscow.

With the 2,449,819 registration for this year's city election showing a decrease of 33,416 from that for the last Mayoralty election in 1937 and a 940,641 drop from the record registration for the Presidential election last year, William M. Chadbourne, campaign manager for Mayor La Guardia and his running mates, issued a statement yesterday declaring that it indicated the re-election of the Mayor in "an overwhelming victory."

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 12 -- The Bostwick Field polo team got four goals in the first period today and thereafter Aknusti waged a losing tattle at Bostwick Field. Pete Bostwick's side came through, 7 to 4, and the crowd of 3,000 was never in suspense over the outcome.

Peace that will insure independence to all nations and protect racial minorities is the hope of all Catholics, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York declared last night at the Columbus Day dinner of the Knights of Columbus of New York and vicinity in the Hotel Astor.

The completion of a new 200-car parking field, practice tee and fairway at the Clearview Golf Course, Queens, south of the Belt Parkway in Bayside, between Cross Island and Bell Boulevards, was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Dr. George Baehr, chief medical officer of the Office of Civilian Defense, called tonight upon every hospital in the United States capable of doing so to set up at least one emergency field unit of doctors and nurses trained to respond to the call of military, naval or police authorities in the event of a defense emergency or disaster.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 12 -- A Japanese attack on British or Netherland territories in the Far East would find cooperating British and Netherland air forces shifted quickly to the points in gravest danger irrespective of territorial frontiers, Vice Air Marshal Sir Robert Brooke-Popham, Commander in Chief of the British forces in the Far East, indicated in an interview here today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Near-record supplies of feed grains added last week to the bearish sentiment that developed in the corn and oats markets on the Board of Trade here and elsewhere. A report of the Department of Agriculture issued late on Friday placed the prospective corn crop at 2,623,000,000 bushels, the yield per acre being about the largest ever known.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 12 -- Max Schibanoff, former Franklin and Marshall tackle, booted two field goals before 10,000 fans tonight and the Jersey City Giants toppled the Long Island Indians, 6 -- 3, in an American Football Association contest.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Congressional battle on the Administration's proposal to arm American merchant vessels started twenty-four hours ahead of schedule today when Republican members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee protested against the official decision to hold brief secret hearings on the Neutrality Act revision.
A demand for large apartments In buildings on the East Side fea tured renting in the city over the week-end.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Heavy rains fell last week over a large part of the main grain belt. While they delayed the harvest of corn and soy beans, they were highly beneficial for the newly sown Winter wheat crop in the more Western States.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 12 -- Fire, raging for fourteen hours last night and today through one of New England's largest defense plants, that of the Firestone Rubber and Latex Company here, destroyed a huge stock of crude rubber as well as quantities of other defense materials.

THIS morning it is the great Fritz Thyssen's turn. Or maybe the phrase should read the late Fritz Thyssen's turn. Nowadays no one seems to know whether the famous German capitalist and steel baron is dead or alive. He was in France when the Nazis broke through fast year and according to some reports, was caught and handed over to the Gestapo.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Vice President Wallace in a Columbus Day address in Spanish to the people of Latin America tonight said that the only bases for true inter-Americanism are "economic cooperation and frank spiritual comprehension and understanding."

THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a draftee with two months' service I should like to refute Charles Nilson's argument that soldiers should have no trouble getting along on their allowances, since they were receiving food, clothing and quarters in addition. By my own experience as well as that of many of the men I have met, I should like to quote some actual figures on the average draftee's monthly expenditures.

Although, avoiding any fixed seies heading for the books except o describe them as "books about our people and our land," Knopf has been issuing for several years somewhat uniform group of regional books. There was "Let Me Show You New Hampshire," by Ella Bowles; "Connecticut, Past and Present," by Odell Shepard; "Our Southwest," by Erna Ferguson, and "Let Me Show You Vermont," by Charles E. Crane.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- For all practical purposes the "modified" rules issued yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission are just as dangerous to broadcasting as the original regulations promulgated in May, Neville Miller, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, charged today.

New Battle Dress "Women telephone operators, plotters and tellers at the air-raid filter and information centers" will be regularly enlisted in the Army if a suggestion made by Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons is adopted.
CAMDEN, S.C., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Still concentrating on fundamentals, the First Army will swing into a second week of field manoeuvres tomorrow to build up ability for a Blitzkrieg test next month.

The three Democratic city-wide candidates, District Attorney William O'Dwyer, nominee for Mayor; Lloyd Church, nominee for Controller, and Transit Commissioner M. Maldwin Fertig, nominee for President of the City Council, will begin today an intensive campaign calling for speeches virtually every day until the election on Nov. 4.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- With the Summer vacation season over, it is clear that seasonal factors are ceasing to count in the Bank of England's circulation, the main cause of the rapidly increasing total of circulation being the ever-advancing total of wages paid in war industries and to a lesser extent to rising prices.
As the situation of the Russian armies -- engaged in history's greatest battle -- continued to be critical over the week-end, the mounting demand for diversionary action increased in Britain.
MOSCOW, Monday, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique early today:
Daniel Levine and Carl Pilnick won in the third round yesterday and now lead with three straight each in their respective sections of the annual championship preliminaries at the Marshall Chess Club.

Football, in its first exclusive Saturday -- exclusive in the sense that there was no world series with which to share the uproar -- contributed a normal share of what are called upsets for want of a better name, in the type of score as well as the result, and continued the leavening process which annually results in thinning the broth.

Samuel Delberg bought for investment the six-story loft building on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 3539 Bond Street, near Lafayette Street, from the Brooklyn Savings Bank for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $51,000 for ten years.

Asserting that "the worker is a dangerous individual in the life of America today because he is without philosophy," the Rev. John P. Monaghan, a founder and director of the Association of Catholic Trade Unionists and pastor of the Church of St. Margaret Mary, Midland Beach, S.I., sounded a call for Christian leadership of labor by "men of conviction and idealism who will teach by example."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The number of women, workers In defense and non-defense industries has risen rapidly in the last few months.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Experiments in the use of trailer oil tankers are being conducted at the Stevens Institute of Technology here in an effort to find a means of alleviating the oil shortage in the Blast.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Dominated by the Russian war news, the stock markets reacted last week, but, despite the evident gravity of the situation, sentiment has been no more than merely chilled. There was room for a substantial setback in view of the pronounced buoyancy exhibited in recent weeks, but not the slightest sign of weakness.
The New York Americans defeated the Philadelphia Germans, 1 -- 0, before a crowd of 3,000 at Starlight Park yesterday in an American League soccer game.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 12 -- The Royal Air Force attacked Axis Mediterranean shipping Friday night and yesterday as the climax to a week of unusually effective convoy raiding. It damaged six ships and apparently sank at least one of them.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 (AP) -- La Salle College's football forces exploded two insurance touchdowns in the last quarter to crush Niagara University, 21 to 0, today before 6,000 fans.

In addition to "Flying Cadets," featuring Edmund Lowe, Peggy Moran and William Gargan, which opens this morning at the Rialto, this week will witness the arrival of four other new films. They are: ...

FORT WORTH, Texas, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Tom C. Penney, 32-year-old Lexington, Ky., former convict, today signed a statement admitting that he and another man fatally shot Miss Marion Miley, golf star, and her mother during a robbery Sept. 28 at the Lexington Country Club.

Last week, for the first time since the first week in August, the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices showed a decline, falling from 98.8 to 98.4. The decline was quite general throughout the list. The sharpest drop of the major group indexes occurred in semi-manufactured goods, where decreases took place in cotton yarn, raw sugar, paperboard and cottonseed oil.

ARMONK VILLAGE, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The Red raiders were turned back by the Blue defenders today, but succeeded in pushing a spearhead from Connecticut into this tiny Westchester community as the town of North Castle, in which Armonk lies, conducted its first civilian war manoeuvres in connection with national defense.

VICHY, France, Sept. 24 -- With an exhibition this week in the Vichy Museum of the works acquired by France, the exchange of art objects negotiated between the French and Spanish Governments has been completed.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was greatly interested in your expressions of horror, in Topics of The Times, over the rapidly growing list of -ee words. Isn't it too bad? I wonder where "the peepul" get such horrible words. Well, as Al Smith has said on other occasions, let's examine the record.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 12 -- On this Columbus Day the Football Dodgers discovered -- to their everlasting regret -- that the combination of Cecil Isbell -- no relation of Queen Isabella -- and Don Hutson is one to be respected and feared above all other aerial-minded outfits in the professional circuit.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The United States Navys capture of a secret radio station in Greenland was expected in some quarters today to be followed by an intensified hunt for other such transmitters or expeditions seeking to establish them.

With the bulk of holiday good purchases practically completed attention in the wholesale market last week turned to Spring staples and semi-staples. Retailers placed orders wherever mills or manufacturers were in a position to accept them and guarantee delivery.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 -- The Soviet High Command announced in a late night communique' that after several days of fierce battle the Red Army had abandoned the city of Bryansk, about 220 miles south-west of Moscow.

The dainty danseuse makes jams and jellies! The thought has all the delightful incongruity of a musical comedy scene. We can see her in our mind's eye-costumed in gay, starched gingham and a tiny beruffled apron-waltzing from cookstove to cupboard, executing a pirouette in the doorway where the sun makes a spotlight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today that offices maintained by the former Defense Contract Service at the Federal Reserve Banks and the branches to assist smaller business enterprises in obtaining defense contracts will be discontinued as soon as the new arrangements of the Division of Contract Distribution can be put into effect.

An OPM plan to speed construction of merchant and war ships ough. large-scale transfers of employed building trades mechanics to jobs as skilled shipyard workers has been dropped, despite willingness of A.F. of L. buildunions in this city to cooperate ough acceptance of a lower early wage scale than prevails on construction projects.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Two members of the Senate Foreign. Relations Committee -- Gillette, Democrat, of Iowa, and La Follette, Progressive, of Wisconsin -- charged today that the Administration was preparing the way for American entry into undeclared warfare by seeking revision of the Neutrality Act.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of Joseph B. Glebocki, 45 years old, of 7022 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn, as a city magistrate. Mr. Glebocki, who has been an assistant corporation counsel since Feb. 1, 1923, will be sworn in by the Mayor at City Hall on Wednesday.

Sites of major tournaments were decided yesterday as the annual two-day meeting of the executive committee of the United States Figure Skating Association was concluded at the Hotel Westbury. Some thirty delegates from New York, Boston, Chicago, Cleveland, Philadelphia, Hershey, Buffalo, Rye, New Haven, St. Louis and Colorado were on hand.

Last week was a period of unfavorable news. In particular, the succession of Russian reverses carried Stock Exchange averages down more than 2 points by Friday; they touched the lowest since June 17. The price then reached was not, however, the lowest of the year, nor was it altogether caused by Germany's invasion of Russia.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12 -- "The Immortal Idler," a story of Gioachino Rossini's Parisian years, has been purchased by Metro from Bruno Frank for Spring production. The tale deals with the thirty years in the composer's life -- following his creation of "William Tell" and "The Barber of Seville" -- during which he fought with the government over recognition of the pension granted by the Bourbons.
Investors showed a preference for housing properties in several deals reported in Brooklyn.

TOLEDO, Oct. 12 -- With the interunion dispute that has halted production of tank transmissions at the Spicer Manufacturing Company plant here still unsettled, speculation centered tonight around the steps the government might take to force resumption of normal operations if the conciliation conferences in Michigan failed to establish peace between the warring unions.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- If you have never written the last line of a limerick or composed a twenty-five-word statement to accompany the tops of six breakfast food boxes, here are some topnotch winners who say it is easy if you specialize.

Basing his knowledge of the religious situation in Russia upon a personal visit to that country a few years ago, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell explained in his sermon yesterday morning that there is no freedom of religion in Russia today in the sense in which the term is understood in America; there is freedom of religious assembly and religious worship, but religion may not be propagated or taught.

VICHY, France, Oct. 12 (U.P.) -- Paris dressmakers, drawing on their imaginations to make up for lack of material, have turned out some Autumn creations that, they contend, will maintain the city as the world's fashion center.

Carlo Morelli, Chilean baritone, gave a recital last night in Town Hall, under the auspices of the Inter-American Cultural Association, Inc. Mr. Morelli has made frequent appearances here with the Metropolitan Opera Association, which he first joined five years ago, but hitherto he had not given local concert-goers an opportunity to become acquainted with his gifts as recitalist, which proved to be of no mean order.

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 13 -- British, Dominions and Polish fliers of the Royal Air Force smashed at targets in Germany and German - occupied countries, and harassed Nazi shipping in the Channel and off the coasts of Norway and The Netherlands, in almost ceaseless raids through day-light and darkness over the weekend.
this week, it was disclosed today.

BERLIN, Oct. 12 (U.P.) -- The German official organ in Prague, the Neue Tag, reported in its Saturday issue, reaching here today, that the State police had confis- cated all radios in five towns of the protectorate of Bohemia-Moravia.

The hope of democracy is not in patriotism but in piety, and the supreme task of Christians today is to popularize righteousness, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, declared yesterday in that edifice.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 12 Five thousand World War veterans, including 1,500 members of the Rainbow (Forty-second) Division association, attended ceremonies here today at the unveiling of a monument in Rainbow Park memorializing the Rainbow Division, which trained at Camp Mills, opposite the present park, before going overseas.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Since the start of the government's plan for the concentration of industries about 144,000 workers have been released for other employment, according to latest figures available in London today. In addition, about 45,000,000 square feet of fac- tory space have also been released.

BERLIN, Oct. 12 -- The successes of the German arms on the eastern front last week failed to impress the German financial market, and if the Boerse developed a slightly firmer tone toward the end of the week this was attributed to internal factors operating within the stock market.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

America's destiny must be bound up in the rights and obligations that men owe to one another, the Rev. Dr. J. Valdemar Moldenhawer said yesterday in his sermon at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets.

VICHY, Oct. 12 -- Subscriptions to the 4 per cent loan of the national sinking fund were closed yesterday after having attained a total of 12,000,000,000 francs. The success of this operation was no surprise, for it offers important advantages to the Treasury and the new issue also is attractive to idle capital.

DETROIT, Oct. 12 -- Federal conciliators indicated tonight after another all-day conference with labor and company officials that a settlement seemed to be in sight in the labor dispute at the Hillsdale Steel Products Company plant in Hillsdale, Mich., which has threatened to tie up 70 per cent of the United States' light-tank production.

A letter from President Franklin D. Roosevelt congratulating the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York on its hundredth anniversary was received yesterday by Marshall Field, president of the society's board of directors, and read over the radio during the concert's intermission by Deems Taylor, commentator.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Martinette, veteran brown mare owned and jumped through the exhibition by Edward H. Newmark of Morristown, N.J., today won the jumper championship of the annual Fall Harrison horse show held on the grounds of the Kentucky Riding Stable.

The Polo Grounds debut of the New York Football Giants was a satistical success yesterday but hardly the artistic triumph that so many had been led to expect. The Giants vanquished the Philadelphia Eagles, 16 to 0, before the largest crowd ever to witness a home opener, 35,842, which included 5,000 service men.

WITH THE BRITISH DESERT FORCES, in Egypt, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A steady stream of American-made tanks, many of them "air-conditioned" and having rubber treads especially effective in desert warfare, have been moved into a forward area by British armored fighting units and may soon be thrown into battle in considerable numbers.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 12 -- The Newark Bears nosed out the Wilmington Clippers, 16 to 13, in an American Association football struggle today before a crowd of 4,500. It was the second Association triumph for the Bears.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- If present progress continues, research associates of the Textile Foundation working at the National Bureau of Standards will succeed in improving on the work of the sheep as a producer of wool, it was announced today.

FROM a bowl of roses, oranges and sugar, life has changed to a bowl of hemlock for Stanford, Boston College, Tennessee and Georgetown. The Palo Alto Indians drained the dregs of their "T" cup against Oregon State and the Eagles and the Hoyas have now imbibed their second galling dose. If misery loves company, no football team need ever worry about being lonely.

Moving nicely in the ring with Phil Prentice on the other end of the lead, the Canadian-bred Airedale terrier bitch Champion Rockley Riot Act, captured top honors last night in the Queensboro Kennel Club's sixteenth annual dog show at the Lost Battalion Building in Elmhurst.

With the automotive classification showing a sharp drop, advertising linage in newspapers of fifty-two cities measured by Media Records registered an increase of only 0.4 per cent for September over a year ago, as compared with an August gain of 4 per cent.

BERLIN, Oct. 12 -- Military observers here are of the opinion that a spearhead of the German invasion forces is less than ninety miles from the gates of Moscow. The progress achieved in the last forty-eight hours, German sources said tonight, has been possible because the Red-Army is able to offer only desultory opposition.

FEURA BUSH, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Prince of Crishall, a heavily marked liver-and-white dog which Arthur Coltart brought down from the Inver Kennels at Toronto, triumphed today in the open all-age stake for English springer spaniels, the only event in the second session of the tenth annual field trials of the Albany Spaniel Field Trial Club, being held at the Gallogly farm.

DETROIT, Oct. 12 -- M.W. Watson, of Topeka, Kan., president of the Associated General Contractors of America, declared here today that the Federal Government's new priorities ruling in the building industry may make 4,500,000 workmen jobless unless the code is redrawn.

Ray Bolger, whose last appearance on the Broadway musical stage was in "Keep Off the Grass" (May, 1940), will be co-starred with Jessie Matthews in "Lady Comes Across," the musical comedy by Fred Thompson and Dawn Powell, which George Hale is producing in association with Charles R. Rogers, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Morris S. Tremaine of Buffalo, who held the office of State Controller for nearly fifteen years, died here at 7:35 A. M. today of a heart ailment in St. Peter's Hospital. His age was 70.

More than 500 of 2,100 members of the Newsdealers Federal Labor Union, Local 22371, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, met yesterday and voted to begin a general strike against eight morning and afternoon newspapers in Manhattan, effective this morning.

Americans of all races, religious beliefs and political creeds gathered yesterday at many places in the city to honor the memory o the Italian explorer who claimed a new world for a Spanish king 449 years ago.
AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Oct. 12 -- The markets of the small Continental European countries last week displayed irregularity, with generally increased volume of trading and sharp fluctuations.

Operating on a day-and-night basis, the Board of Education emergency defense program, now entering its second year, has trained 50,000 men for industries vital to war production at a tots cost of $2,500,000 contributed b the Federal Government, it was disclosed in a board report mad public yesterday.

Age has brought about the retirement of Geoffrey Dawson, editor of The Times of London. He has been succeeded by R.M. Barrington-Ward, assistant editor of "The Thunderer" for fourteen years. There was a time when a change in the editorship of The Times would have been an event of international importance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Federal Power Commission published today its first statistical yardstick of electric utility costs, containing analyses of those costs based on a study begun in 1938 of 393 large companies comprising, on the basis of assets or revenues, more than 95 per cent of the nation's privately owned electric light and power industry.
BERLIN, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The following communiques were issued today by the Hitler Headquarters:

With Russia engaged in its present momentous struggle for existence as a nation, the all-Soviet musical festival presented yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, under the auspices of the New Masses, took on special significance. But even under ordinary circumstances a program that featured the American premieres of works by Sergei Prokofieff, Sergei Vassilenko, Valery Jelobinsky and other contemporary Russian composers of repute would arouse more than, ordinary interest.

After the substantial recovery in the previous week, cotton prices turned downward last week as selling pressure increased. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 45 to 56 points, in contrast to gains of 77 to 100 points in the previous week.

Add to the list of films opening this week "Target for Tonight," which is scheduled to arrive at the Globe on Friday. The short feature, which is being distributed in the United States by Warner Brothers, is a factual film showing an actual bombing raid over Germany and German-occupied territory by the R.A.F.

OTTAWA, Oct. 13 (U.P.) -- Tacit acknowledgment that Britain might have sent an expeditionary force to Archangel was given today by a military spokesman here, but official defense sources discouraged any conclusion that Canadians might have formed a part of the force.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 -- A recently developed method of research into the epidemiology of infantile paralysis, which multiplies one-hundredfold the laboratory experiments that can be carried out with funds raised in the President's birthday campaigns, was demonstrated publicly for the first time here today before doctors assembled at the seventieth annual meeting of the American Public Health Association.
Young women of society organized to aid the philanthropic projects of the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry-on-Hudson are active currently in a series of committee meetings, luncheons and fetes.

CHANGSHA, China, Oct. 12 (Delayed) (UP.) -- Foreign missionaries who were here during the four days of Japanese occupation of this capital of Honan Province early this month, told newspaper men today that the Japanese looted virtually every Chinese home and business establishment before retiring to their base in Yochow, to the north.

In the city of Changsha, deep in Hunan Province, American medical workers are easing the pains of death and restoring life for the thousands of Chinese who have been suffering constant airaids for the past two months as a result of Japan's new effort to take that key city.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 13 -- Reports circulating in foreign diplomatic circles here tonight indicated that Bulgaria, after having staved off German demands for entry into the war for more than two weeks, once more was slipping rapidly toward hostilities.

TOKYO, Oct. 13 -- A warning that the Japanese Government should "make peace in East Asia as early as possible" lest it be overtaken by peace in Europe, which would leave Japan exposed to combined pressure by the United States, Britain and Russia, was sounded yesterday by Kazmo Yukikata in the newspaper Kokumin, which claims close relations with the Japanese military.

The Democratic campaign managers began their detailed attack on the La Guardia administration yesterday with the release of a series of twenty-one charges directed against the city's Health Department. The charges were made by Dr. Emanuel M. Josephson, chairman of the Public Health Committee for the Election of O'Dwyer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Calling Treasury Secretary Morgenthau agriculture's "public enemy No. 1," Senator Bankhead of Alabama said today that members of Congress from farm States would oppose any attempt to clamp rigid price ceilings on agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Men in service will not receive adequate hospital care next year unless there is a decided upswing in the enrollment of the American Red Cross nursing ranks, Miss Mary Beard, national director of the American Red Cross Nursing Service, warned today.

VICHY, France, Oct. 13 -- "Peace terms may be very hard." "In twenty or twenty-five years France may again take her rightful place in a renovated Europe." These are passages from an address by General Henri Fernand Dentz, who commanded the French forces in Syria, delivered at Arles during the week-end when Admiral Francois Darlan, the Vice Premier, went there to confer decorations.

Although his Giants are in undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern Division of the National Football League with four straight victories, Coach Steve Owen will do considerable experimenting this week. He is not convinced that the team has been functioning as well as it can.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A $1,500,000,000 increase in the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's borrowing power, about two-thirds of which is intended to provide capital for an expansion of the country's steel production, won final Congressional approval today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- The new morning newspaper here will have its offices in The Chicago Daily News Building and will be printed on the Daily News presses, according to a statement today by Marshall Field, owner, and Silliman Evans, publisher.

Leaders in society and many other men and women prominent in artistic, professional and civic circles will compose the opening-night audience this evening at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre for the performance or the opera "Cosi Fan Tutte," which will usher in the initial season of the New Opera Company.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 11:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude pertoleum at the close of the week ended on Oct. 4 amounted to 246,144,000 barrels, according to data reported to the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the preceding week, this represents a decrease of 505,000 barrels, comprising a decrease of 983,000 in stocks of domestic crude, but an increase of 478,000 in stocks of foreign crude.

Labor party candidates for City Council seats announced yesterday a seventeen-point platform on which they will appeal for votes. It calls for collective bagaining on the city transit system and for the establishment of a City Consumers Bureau to protect citizens against misrepresentation as to quantity or quality in the sale of food or drugs.

DETROIT, Oct. 13 -- Leon Henderson, price administrator, told members of the Detroit Economic Club here today that industrial production in the United States, as a result of the defense program, is at a peak, and at the same time warned business men that any productive activity which interferes with the nation's arms effort "has two strikes on it."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today the agency intends to stamp out "political and large network pressures" aimed at nullifying the Commissioners' new chain broadcasting rules.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- During a conference with leaders of Congress today, President Roosevelt was assured that the second lease-lend act, carrying an appropriation of $5,985000,000 and already passed by the House, would quickly get favorable action in the Senate.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 13 -- The Radical party, the strongest political organization in Argentina, issued a manifesto today attacking Acting President Ramon S. Castillo in outspoken terms for his dissolution of the Buenos Aires Municipal Council by decree.

The estate formerly owned by Mrs. John H. Ross comprising a brick dwelling and nine and onehalf acres of land on Spring Valley Road, Harding Township, N.J., was sold to Albert N. Williams, president of the Western Union telegraph Company.

Because in many cases we have to take the Nazis' word for what happened we cannot be sure as to the exact characteristics of the civilian revolt which has been fermenting in Europe in recent weeks. When Premier Alois Elias of the Bohemian-Moravian Protectorate was found guilty of "preparation for high treason" nothing could really be known as to the extent of the "plot," or as to whether there was any plot at all.

The Federal Communications Commission announces a few modifications of the drastic regulations which were scheduled to go into effect in the radio industry. The commission has suspended its promulgated rule requiring the National Broadcasting System to dispose of one of its two networks; it has extended the licensing period from one to two years, and it has made a few changes in the rules covering contracts which individual stations are permitted to make with networks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Five of the chief United States officials charged with making or carrying out our foreign policy urged before the House Foreign Affairs Committee today revision of the Neutrality Act to permit the arming of merchant ships against sea and air attacks.

Though the House Committee on Foreign. Affairs has voted to consider at this time only the question of arming American merchant ships, a more important question made its appearance as soon as the committee's hearings began yesterday. This is the question of repealing the prohibitions in the Neutrality Act which now forbid our merchant ships to carry goods through "combat zones" and to belligerent ports.

The general strike called by the Newsdealers Federal Labor Union, Local 22371, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, against eight morning and afternoon newspapers went into effect yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

BERLIN, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Not merely two, but three powerful German columns, it appeared from Nazi accounts today, were striking forward toward Moscow's gates. The third -- aside from those based in the Vyazma and Bryansk vicinities -- was reported smashing to the southeast from the headwaters of the Volga River in the Valdai Hills toward the town of Rzhev and standing, by late reports, within 140 miles northwest of the metropolis.

Maplecrest Farm's Wise Niece, who ran in claiming races at Belmont without winning, was a pretty sharp surprise to 28,150 persons' at Jamaica yesterday as she led from start to finish of the $9,050 Correction Handicap to return $24.90 for $2.
Bill Dudley, Virginia's fleet halfback, is showing the way to the nation's football scorers as the season approaches the half-way mark.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- War Department officials reported today that mass production was now under way in a substantial number of the plants that make up the new $1,750,000,000 string of government - owned munitions factories.

Deciding last month he could not make up enough work in his studies to be graduated with his high school class, Samuel Iele, 16 years old, withdrew $18 he had in the savings bank and ran away from his home 32-50 204th Street, Bayside, Queens.

Lapses and surrenders of ordinary life insurance policies are setting a new low record and the 1941 lapse rate may drop below 3.8 per cent of the insurance in force at the beginning of the year, according to the Institute of Life Insurance.

TRENTON, Oct. 13 -- State Highway Commissioner E. Donald Sterner, whose six-year administration is being investigated by direction of Governor Charles Edison, confirmed today a report that he would resign, but said he would not do so before next Spring and not until he had been "completely vindicated" of the Governor's charges of waste and extravagance.

OPORTO, Portugal, Oct. 13 (AP) --The British colony here tonight heard reports that the British steamer Avoceta, 3,442 tons, which sailed for London last week, had been sunk with loss of all her ninety-four passengers and crew of seventy-eight.

DOWN deep in Plaquemines Parish, Louisiana, a hundred miles or so south of New Orleans and well along the Mississippi Delta toward the Gulf, there are a lot of odd sights, sounds and people -- how odd, the rest of us would never know except for explorers like E.P. O'Donnell.
The secondary or combat phase of the Army's far-flung air defense manoeuvres began yesterday with fifty-four bombing missions along the coast from Norfolk to Boston.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A trail which could lead to most important consequences in the field of labor relations and greatly reduce the work stoppages that now afflict the nation's defense program was opened by the Supreme Court today. When the court decided to review the constitutionality of the Wisconsin "employment peace" law the trail was opened.
SALEM, N.H., Oct. 13 (AP) -- New wagering records were set at Rockingham park today as a holiday crowd of 32,000 poured $640,605 through the pari-mutuel machines.

Mayor La Guardia, whose flair for dramatics is admitted by even, his bitterest opponents, was the star in a half-hour radio act broadcast by WNYC last evening from the Civilian and National Defense Exposition at Grand Central Palace, under the sponsorship of the Bureau for the Prevention of Juvenile Delinquency.

Friendly relations exist between Italians and Americans in Italy, William Phillips, United States Ambassador to Italy, said yesterday on his return here after a year's absence to confer with President Roosevelt. He arrived on the Yankee Clipper and was met at the seaplane base at La Guardia Field by Myron Taylor, who recently returned from the Vatican.

A property in the heart of the financial and insurance section of downtown Manhattan, the fivestory structure at 38 Pine Street, has been sold by the Mutual Life Insurance Company to the Hampshire Realty Corporation in a transaction negotiated by M. L.

Textile bag manufacturers, who have found increasing difficulty in buying both of their basic materials -- burlap and cotton cloth -- met here yesterday and exchanged views on the subject. In closed sessions at the Hotel Biltmore the Textile Bag Manufacturers Association held its quarterly meeting, which continues today and tomorrow.

VICHY, France, Oct. 13 -- The search for substitutes continues to develop in France on account of the dearth of standard commodities. While legitimate in some cases there are people who plead for more reflection, it was noted today.

Coach Lou Little disregarded his usual Monday custom of giving the Columbia varsity a day of rest as he put his Lions through a spirited two-hour drill at Baker Field yesterday. Passing plays, a phase of the game in which the Light Blue fared poorly in last Saturday's 21-0 victory over Princeton, were stressed, with Paul Governali at the pitching post as new tactics were employed.

The public fear that food price are rising abnormally was held warranted yesterday in a statement issued by Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America. Basing his statement on information contained in a recent study by the Bureau of Labor Statistics in Washington of all food prices since 1913, Mr. Willis said prices of food today are "little above the average for the depression thirties."
BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Oct. 14 -- Red Army forces in the central sector in Russia have evacuated the town of Vyazma, on the outer ring of the Moscow defense circle.

An outweighed and undermanned AH Hallows Institute eleven could do little to stop the power of the St. Francis Prep football team at Fordham Field yesterday. Coach Tut Maggio'S Brooklyn outfit scored in every period, making two touchdowns in the first quarter, one each in the second and third sessions and two more in the fourth to triumph by 38 -- 0.

BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- German armored units were in the town of Kaluga, southwest of Moscow, and along the Vyazma-Moscow highway they were about the same distance -- some ninety miles -- from the Soviet capital, it was reported in unofficial but well-informed quarters here tonight.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N. J., Oct. 13 -- Miss Margaret Glendenning Jones celebrated her one hundredth birthday here today by knitting wristlets for the British War Relief Society, explaining that "I hope the little bit I can do for my native England will help her win the war."

The American Mission to Lepers meets in a two-day session this week to review the work that it has done to alleviate the misery of a dreadful malady's victims and to honor a woman who takes her place beside Father Damien as an example of self-sacrifice. "Saint of Chandag," they call her in India.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Senate acted today to permit 3,000 to 5,000 of the naturalized Americans living abroad to retain their citizenship, which would have been forfeit, under the terms of the Nationality Act of 1940, if they were not in the United States by midnight tonight.

SEATTLE, Oct. 13 -- In the face of the referendum action of the International Typographical Union last Spring against rejoining the American Federation of Labor, delegates to the annual federation convention voted today to hold open the door, hopeful of the suspended union's eventual return to the fold.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Board of Trade of Kansas City, Mo., and other primary grain markets were granted today a Supreme Court review of a decision which dismissed their attack on an Interstate Commerce Commission order prohibiting the cities from having both a "through rate with transit" and a "proportional rate" on grain shipments.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The stock markets "were generally better today, a feature being the recovery in the speculative favorites in the oils and Kaffirs. Gilt-edged securities were steady with the 3 1/2 per cent war loan at u105 15/16.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13 -- Sixteen first-string players who fought a losing battle against Pennsylvania were limited to dummy offensive practice today, but the others on the Yale squad of sixty worked at full speed in contact practice. All the athletes came through the Pennsylvania game in excellent physical condition.

Many younger members of society, headed by the Misses Anne Rogers Benjamin and Marian Hodges, are active in the plans for the supper party, to be known as a China Clipper Cabaret, to be held on Saturday at the Automat Restaurant at Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street for the benefit of United China Relief.
LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Air Ministry said in a communique today:

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The arrival of cattle today in twelve leading markets was the largest In several years, most of the increase consisting of Western steers and fat native grassers. Total receipts in principal markets amounted to 117,300 head, against 92,700 a week ago and 101,000 a year ago.

The United States may aid Russia without betraying Christianity and democracy if she exacts, as a condition to such aid, acceptance by the Soviet of a policy of noncollaboration with atheistic communism, according to Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen.

State politics became inextricably entangled with the local Mayoralty campaign yesterday as leaders of the Republican, Democratic and American Labor parties began considering the dilemma to which they nave been placed by the death of Controller Morris S. Tremaine.

Some of the things that hairdressers think but do not say while laboring over milady's coiffure were disclosed yesterday when 6,000 delegates to the convention of the National Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association met at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court heard for nearly four hours today arguments on the right of newspapers or individuals to publish comment on court proceedings prior to a decision.
