MADISON, Wis., Oct. 13 -- Experimental evidence was offered here today that hardening of the arteries (arteriosclerosis), degenerative disease most commonly associated with old age, is not necessarily a part of the process of growing old, with indications that it may be prevented by a diet low in fats and by the administration of a recently discovered fat, utilizing a hormone named lipocaic.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Spokesmen for the country's railroads offered today a counter-proposal to the wage demands of 1,260,000 organized railroad employes, conceding part of the wage Increases asked by the employes as a condition to calling off their strike vote.
The smell of fresh paint mingled with that of the long-dry paint of old masters yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where extensive renovations were reaching ompletion.

W. Averell Harriman, head of the American mission to Moscow, in a broadcast to the United States over Columbia Broadcasting System from London last night, reported that Russian morale was excellent and expressed the conviction that, given the tools of war, Russia would fight on.
BERLIN, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

Northrop Aircraft, Inc., of Hawthorne, Calif., reported yesterday a net loss of $848,778 for the fiscal year ended on July 31. While it is the second year of the company's operations, no comparable figures are available for the preceding year because the period was characterized mainly by preparations to enter manufacture, the report said.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 13 -- It was learned here today that the British Government had refused visas to four Mexicans invited to Madrid by General Franco for the "Council of Hispanidad" opening yesterday.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Real estate tax assessments have been injected by Justice Church into the Mayoralty campaign, and properly so. Overassessment in New York is an evil of long standing, and not peculiar to the La Guardia group, but as the "ins" theirs is the responsibility for the continuance of this complacent policy.

Henry Epstein, Solicitor General of New York State, declared that "Federal taxation of State and local securities would be destructive of our political institutions, unconstitutional and unsound economically," in an address delivered yesterday before" the National Tax Association at St. Paul, Minn.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 13 -- Captain Robert Bruce Porper, an almost legendary figure in the old-time halibut fleet and veteran of half a dozen hazardous escapes in a 60-year career of deep-sea fishing, died today in the Marine Hospital at Brighton.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 13 -- Coach Tad Wieman today turned back the clock three weeks when he sent the entire Princeton football squad through practice in blocking and tackling, topped by a stiff scrimmage lasting an hour and a half.
NEW YORK Don Rodolfo Michels, Chilean Ambassador, and Senora de Michels have arrived from Washiagton and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

HILLSDALE, Mich., Tuesday, Oct. 14 --The attempt by Federal conciliation commissioners to settle the A.F.L.-C.I.O. dispute in the Hillsdale Steel Products Company plant, affecting the jobs of only twenty-six men, but threatening to tie up 70 per cent of the nation's tank production, ended in a stalemate early this morning.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest the article in THE TIMES of Oct. 12 by Mr. Disney, bridge engineer of the Canadian National Railways, wherein he says, "Our steel capacity can be doubled by increasing unit stresses."

FORT LAMY, Chad Territory, French Equatorial Africa, Oct. 13 -- This town, Chad's capital, is a scattering of mud huts and even more primitive dwellings constructed of bamboo. Their thatched roofs are either oblong or conical.

Rejecting the proposals of Democratic members of the City Council to reduce the sales and compensating use taxes to one-half of 1 per cent, or abolish them entirely. Mayor La Guardia wrote to the Council yesterday pressing for the immediate enactment of his bills to reduce the two taxes to a flat 1 per cent.
A number of persons well known in stage, radio and lecture circles were among those reported yesterday by brokers as having taken new residential quarters in buildings throughout the city.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 13 -- Amherst's football team resumed daily practice today with a light drill consisting of signal practice and kicking and passing. The Jeffs, buoyed up after Saturday's surprising triumph over a favored Bowdoin team, were in high spirits as preparation for the Rochester game on Saturday began.
John Kimbrough and Tommy Harmon will play in the New York Football Americans' backfield Sunday against Columbus in an American Football League contest at the Yankee Stadium.

In the greatest over-match since Jack Dempsey flattened Fred Fulton with one punch, Notre Dame meets Carnegie Tech at Pittsburgh on Saturday. This formerly was one of the big games of every campaign, but not any more.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- On the request of President Roosevelt, Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman of New York is investigating all the Federal agencies handling housing, both civilian and defense construction, with a view to making recommendations for coordinating the work of these agencies, centering administration and policy-making in the same hands and eliminating duplication, over-lapping and waste, it was learned today.
Georgia, Syracuse and West Virginia are coming to town this week to furnish the opposition in the three big attractions to be offered the local football clientele on Sat urday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 13 (U.P.) -- The Royal Air Force reported today that heavy British, bombers raided the Libyan ports of Tripoli and Bengazi on Saturday night, hitting docks and airplane bases.

Although lacking the stimulus of low temperatures, Columbus Day shopping here was active yesterday. Sales volume did not reach boom proportions, but, substantial gains over a year ago were reported by both department stores and specialty shops.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 13 -- The Portuguese steamer Corte Real, bound for the United States with an American physician among her six passengers, was sunk yesterday by a German submarine that towed the ship's lifeboats twenty miles toward the Portuguese coast and gave two boat-shy women and two children a U-boat ride.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Here are excerpts from the formal statements of Cordell Hull, Secretary of State; Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, and Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, presented today before the House Foreign Affairs Committee:...

Definite slackening of demand for leather, the first appreciable slowing down since the beginning of the war, was reported by tanners yesterday. They added that they believed the situation was temporary, but admitted that they had little more than wishful thinking to back up their belief.
When Guessers Assemble Pleas for national unity are heard on every hand, despite the fact that in Chicago no less than 600 newspaper and radio contest prize winners are meeting in convention.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- The Federal oil control program was assailed as being designed to aid the big companies at the expense of independent distributors at the opening session of the National Oil Marketers Association here today. The attack came from speakers and in a resolution offered from the floor shortly before adjournment this afternoon and referred thereafter to the committee on resolutions for formal action.

"There are prunes and prunes," according to a man who has just imported some especially beautiful ones from California to sell in his Manhattan store. The grading on the box reads 15-20, which means that the fruit is so large and luxuriant that it takes less than twenty prunes to make a pound.

MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 13 -- American Federation of Labor unions shut down the plant of the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation today at Pascagoula, Miss., by calling out all its members engaged in building ships.

BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- Annoyance at "British-fed rumors about German peace feelers" constitutes one of the main themes of the Berlin press today. They are once more called "ludicrous inventions" aimed at fooling the people at home into thinking that the Reich is exhausted and anxious or peace.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Oct. 13 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. G. J. Berenschot, Commander in Chief of the Netherlands Indies Army, and thirteen others were killed today in two airplane crashes.

A supper dance for the benefit of the Lord Mayor of London Fund, under the sponsorship of Mrs. George Seymour Repton, founder and chairman of Friends of Britain, Inc., will be held on Oct. 27 at Fefe's Monte Carlo, Mrs. Busch Greenough heads the general committee arranging the benefit.
BERLIN, Oct. 13 (U.B.) -- German sources claimed tonight that twenty-eight British planes were shot down in daylight operations over the Channel coast.

LONDON, Tuesday, Oct. 14 -- Britain intensified her aerial offensive on Germany's Western Front over Sunday night and yesterday with heavy bombing raids on Nuremberg, the Bavarian Nazi party stronghold; on Bremen and Boulogne, further attacks on German shipping off the coasts of the Netherlands and Norway and fighter and bomber sweeps over Northern France.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Representatives of fourteen Louisville brokerage concerns protested at a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing today against the Louisville Gas and Electric Company's application for permission to sell 150,000 shares of common stock direct to the general public.

DETROIT, Oct 13 -- Rehearsals of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, scheduled to begin today, were not held because eighty-one musicians walked out in a dispute between the Detroit Symphony Society and the Detroit Federation. of Musicians (A.F. of .L.).

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Miscellaneous supply contracts totaling $24,569,217 were awarded today by the War Department. The largest of these, for guns amounting to $6,755,791, went to the High Standard Manufacturing Company, of New Haven.

According to reports from almost every section of Maine, hunters in that State are enjoying the best bird hunting in several years, wits the list taking in grouse and woodcock as well as water fowl. Dick Reed sends this information.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 13 -- W. C. Hobson's Shine o'Night, away from the winner's circle since she won the Matron Handicap at Arlington Park last June 28, made good at the first asking over this track today and survived a photo finish to hang a neck defeat on the favored Joseph E. Widener's Misty Isle.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Ceiling prices below prevailing levels for prepared asphalt roofing products and building papers are being prepared by Leon Henderson, administrator of the Office of Price Administration, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A nation-wide attack on every aspect of industrial, consumer and governmental waste, with the primary purpose of saving and salvaging every pound of usable material for use of defense industries or to prevent shortages in essential goods for civilian uses, will be started at once by a new Bureau of Industrial Conservation set up by the Office of Production Management.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Oct. 8 aggregated $10,201,000,000.

Unless construction of railroad cars and locomotives is expedited, a serious drag is likely to be put on the entire defense program in the Autumn of 1942 by transportation difficulties, the National Association of Manufacturers warned yesterday in the first of five reports dealing with vital defense industries.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 13 -- The Duke and Duchess of Windsor waved and turned their smiles on more than 200,000 festive citizens here today who fought to watch the progress of the couple through the city streets from the City Hall, where the ducal pair received an official welcome from Baltimore.

Maxim Schapiro, Russian pianist, who made his debut here in 1927 and who subsequently toured in China and Russia and settled in San Francisco, returned to New York last night after an absence of eleven years and gave a recital at the Town Hall.

The 449th anniversary of Columbus's discovery of America, which fell on Sunday, was celebrated again yesterday -- the legal holiday -- by the Columbia Associations of city employes, who marched up Broadway from the Battery to Columbus Park, at Worth and Baxter Streets, where patriotic exercises were held.

Three hundred members of the Catholic Daughters of America were told yesterday that communism "is back again, bolder than ever," and were asked to oppose it vigorously. The plea was made by George A. Timone, chairman of the New York Chapter of the Knights of Columbus, at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

As the great battle before Moscow swirls across the "paths of glory" where Napoleon's army marched but to its doom a less epic but no less important struggle continues over the wide waters of the Western Ocean.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 13 (U.P.) -- Funeral services will be held here tomorrow for State Controller Morris S. Tremaine, one-time lumber yard tally-boy who was elected to high New York State office more times than any other person.

The board of directors of McKesson Robbins, Ltd., has addressed a letter to stockholders proposing to settle for $950,000 claims of slightly more than $1,000,000 made by their company against McKesson Robbins,. Inc.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 14 -- Despite stubborn Russian resistance, the Germans are maintaining their powerful drive -- at a slightly slower pace -- and have occupied Vyazma, which is about 130 miles west of Moscow on the main highway to Smolensk.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 13 -- Victor Mature, featured last season in the Manhattan production of "Lady in the Dark," today scored a victory in his battle with Hal Roach over salary increase and agreed to report next Monday to Twentieth Century-Fox for the leading role in "Highway to Hell."

In recent months the Securities and Exchange Commission has been showing increased concern over the persistent lack of "equity" (common stock) financing and the continued reliance by industry upon "debt" (bond) financing. Unless the flow of investment into common stocks can be increased there is danger of industry becoming overburdened with debt.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, charged last night that Mayor La Guardia had been a party to a preconceived plan of the Communists to have their Mayoralty candidate, Israel Amter, withdraw so the Communists could support Mr. La Guardia.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 -- Americans were urged today by Dr. Alexander J. Stoddard, Philadelphia Superintendent of Schools, to drop unduly critical attitudes and lay greater emphasis upon loyalty and the great achievements of this country.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- A mysterious voice, presumed to be of German origin, repeatedly interrupted programs of the British Broadcasting Corporation from some time after 8:15 until nearly 10 o'clock tonight. Listeners on the regular home service as well as programs for the fighting forces heard the uninvited speaker declare that Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden were unacceptable.

WASHINGTON, Oct 13 (AP) -- The Federal Government would contribute $436,919,000 toward highway improvements in the forty-eight States and possessions under a House Roads Committee bill which, Representative Robinsor of Utah said, would be reported out tomorrow.

Dry Goods Pressure Eases Dry goods wholesalers, still pressing for shipments of a number of staple lines, reported yesterday that their position was less acute than it was a month or more ago. New business from their retail accounts is holding up, but the insistent demand from retailers for spot shipment has eased off a little and wholesalers have been able to accumulate spot stocks of some goods.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 -- The building up of an effective health defense program with special emphasis on the need for integrating the work of professional and lay participants, was considered from many angles tonight Toy members of the Association of Women in Public Health.

Record advertising campaigns for two leading shirt manufacturers were announced yesterday. F. Jacobson Sons, Inc., made known a greatly enlarged magazine campaign, elimination of cooperative newspaper advertising with dealers and emphasis on the Jayson label as a policy, while the Man- hattan Shirt Company announced 'the most ambitious campaign in its history."

Gradually the New York public is finding it possible to piece together a more or less comprehensive mosaic representing the career of that remarkable artist, George Grosz -- German-born, and now an American. The Museum of Modern Art's limited retrospective opened last week and yesterday the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, opened an exhibition of the artist's water-colors and drawings, most of which were produced in the last decade.

Adaptations of styles of yesterday to the neckwear of tomorrow will be suggested by an exhibition of old and modern collars and cuffs that will open tomorrow in the Cooper Union Museum for the Arts of Decoration. Selected by a jury of fashion experts, this material also will demonstrate how designers may use American museums as sources of inspiration.

DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Completion of the Class AA baseball draft, announced today by the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, disclosed that eight players advanced by means of the annual selection.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission released today a letter warning certain securities dealers of failure to keep a record of the times of securities transactions as required by SEC rules. The letter, signed by the director of the trading and exchange division, said in part:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- All out cooperation with the nation's defense effort was pledged today by the organized women of the country, whose leaders in a three session conference, welcomed and addressed by Mrs. Roosevelt and General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, constituted themselves an advisory council of the Women's Interests Section of the War Department's Bureau of Public Relations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Roosevelt announced through a White House statement today that a constant stream of supplies was flowing to Russia from American ports and that "everything possible is being done to send material to Russia to help the brave defense which continues to be made."
West Twelfth Street claimed its thirty-third victim since the highway was built in 1930 when one man was killed and another injured seriously in a crash of their automobiles at 10 o'clock last night.

The New Opera Company, a group of young American singers working under European directors which owes its existence largely to Mrs. Lytle Hull, will open its first season tonight at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre.

Adhering to a promise of keeping its revivals here for four weeks only, the Theatre Guild will close "Ah, Wilderness!" at the Guild Theatre on Oct. 25, a halfweek short of the allotted period. On Oct. 27 the attraction will be presented at the Cass, Detroit, at an admission scale ranging downward from $2.20.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Roosevelt issued a statement saying that supplies to Russia are going forward in a constant stream. He conferred with Congressional leaders on the Neutrality Act and leaselend legislation.

The N.Y.U. football squad began preparing yesterday for its game with Syracuse on Saturday at the Yankee Stadium. Syracuse's 47-to-13 triumph over the Violet last year stood as the worst N.Y. U. setback since 1936 until the Texas Aggies improved on those figures with their 49-7 job three days ago.

Elimination of cobblestone pavements in many sections of Manhattan during recent years was cited last night by Edgar J. Nathan Jr., Republican-Fusion candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, as one reason for the return of a Fusion administration to power next month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Supreme Court granted to the government today a review of a decision holding that the Federal Anti-Racketeering Law does not apply to members of a union whom the government accuses of jumping on the runing boards of trucks entering New York City and demanding that union men drive the trucks in at a set rate of pay.

The New Opera Company, a group of young American singers working under European directors which owes its existence largely to Mrs. Lytle Hull, will open its first season tonight at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre.

The spearhead of the roaring, rumbling army of the tanks was reported well within 100 miles of Moscow yesterday as London "withheld comment" on reports that a British Expeditionary Force had been landed in Archangel.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 13 (Delayed) -- Naval authorities said today that German submarine packs, though "many times" within striking distance, had not sunk a single American-protected ship in the first three weeks that United States warships were known to have been escorting convoys to Iceland.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Chamber of Deputies unanimously disapproved the proposed colonization of Lower California by 100,000 semi-military Sinarquistas today after hearing charges that they were supported by the Axis and would constitute a "fifth column danger" to a strategic naval base within the United States naval defense zone.

The Wild West, in the colorful panoply of 175 cowboys and cowgirls of the sixteenth annual championship rodeo at Madison Square Garden descended on Bellevue Hospital yesterday morning, to the manifest delight of 3,000 patients and staff members.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 14 -- A new wave of arrests and executions is under way in Bulgaria in the Philoff government's desperate attempt to stamp out sabotage and disorders in the capital and the provinces, according to foreign military intelligence sources at Ankara tonight.

A challenge to the priorities system as represented in the OPM housing defense order 1192 which bans oil burners in defense housing construction along the Atlantic seaboard, was voiced yesterday by R.M. Sherman, general chairman of the defense emergency committee of the oil burner industry, at a special meeting held under the auspices of the Oil Burner Institute at the Hotel New Yorker and attended by about a hundred representatives in the industry.

Giuseppe Petitto, 63 years old, of 133 Fifty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, could not stand to be kidded and as a result of his fellow-workers' jokes yesterday one of them is dead after having been shot, another was taken to the hospital with scalp lacerations caused by an axe and a third was injured when he fell through a glass door trying to escape.

Mayor La Guardia and Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, were condemned in a report adopted by a City Council committee yesterday for having fostered favoritism and discrimination in civil service.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Austin Clark of Flushing and Southampton, L.I., gave a reception yesterday afternoon at Evergreen Lawn, their place in Flushing, to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of their marriage. Mrs. Clark is the former Miss Marguerite Dixon, doughter of Mrs. James Wyllys Dixon of Flushing and the late Captain Dixon.

A dose of their own medicine was administered to delegates to the convention of the National Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Picking victims at random from the afternoon session audience, leading hair stylists applied both criticism and scissors to produce up-to-the-minute coiffures.

ROME, Oct. 14 -- Italy is fighting for world-wide triumph of the Fascist idea, Roberto Farinacci said on Sunday in a speech at Crema, which the Regime Fascista publishes today. It is rare here to see emphasis placed on the international scope of fascism, but the speech also was interesting as an exhortation to strong-arm methods in internal affairs.

SEATTLE, Oct. 14 -- John P. Frey delivered a rebuke from the American Federation of Labor convention rostrum tonight to Rear Admiral C.S. Freeman for a press statement in which, Mr. Frey said, the admiral "regrettably injected himself and appeared to take sides" in the metal trades' controversy with a group of welders.

The New Opera Company made its debut last night, its first appearance on any stage. The Forty-fourth Street Theatre was packed with an audience of musical connoisseurs, leaders of fashion, all that betokens an eventful opening night in New York.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14 -- The national defense program is bringing to light the deficiency in health and welfare services for children in many localities, according to Dr. Martha M. Eliot, assistant chief of the Children's Bureau, United States Department of Labor.

The sixty-third annual appeal of the United Hospital Fund, sounding the theme of "A Light in a World Blacked Out," went out to New York last night as officials set a goal of $1,784,292 to be raised before Dec. 1 to help finance free medical and social services by the city's seventy-five voluntary hospitals.

A special loan exhibition of contemporary American water-colors opens at the Metropolitan Museum with a private view this evening and to the public tomorrow. The catalogue lists 121 items, fifty-one of which were sent on from Chicago, where they formed part of the twentieth international exhibition at the Art Institute.

Pre-season dope at C.C.N.Y. pointed toward unprecedented success for a Benny Friedman-coached team. With a plenitude of seasoned backs and a better-than-average line, this was to have been "the year." So far it hasn't been and indications at the moment are that it won't be.
LONDON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

If the present season is a success the New Opera Company will give a second season in the Spring in which American works will be included. Mrs. Uytle Hull, the company's founder, announced last night in a curtain speech at the opening of the company's first season at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre.

Buyer Registration Up in Week The number of out-of-town buyers reported in town last week was 760, against 707 in the previous week and 958 in the same period last year, according to THE NEW YORK TIMES listings. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 268, which compared with 503 for a week ago.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- The grain markets showed considerable weakness today in the early trading on the Board of Trade as a result of persistent liquidation and local pressure, but the selling movement quickly ran its course and later there was a strong rally on short covering.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 14 -- Threat of murky weather prevented a simulated bombing raid on the metropolitan area by way of Suffolk County tonight, but it did not deter the County Defense Council from staging its long-planned all-out blackout.

The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, one of the richest operating utilities in the East, announced yesterday that it would challenge the Securities and Exchange Commission in the courts over a recent SEC decision holding the Jersey utility to be a subsidiary of the United Corporation and the United Gas Improvement Company.

The barter system of overcoming shortages of essential materials by swapping surpluses, which was instituted a few weeks ago by the Toilet Goods Association, appeared yesterday to be spreading to other lines. Manufacturers of paint, varnish and lacquer were reported to be considering a plan by which members of the group would submit wants and offerings to a central point for clearing.

Miss Marion B. Bullard, debutante daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward A. Bullard of 55 East Seventy-second Street, gave a dinner last night at the Stork Club. Her guests included the Misses Ann Hare, Hope Carroll and Stella Richardson; Charles Renshaw, Harry McLain Smith, Donald Sage, Robert Holmes and William Adams.

The Knickerbocker Greys began their sixty-first season yesterday afternoon with 160 boys -- some still in knee pants -- at the 107th Infantry (Old Seventh) Armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street under the leadership of Lieut. Col. H.C.K. Mattison, United States Army Reserve.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 14 -- America will have "ample metal for the greatest defense production of all time," the National Academy of Sciences was told at its Autumn meeting today by Dr. Zay Jeffries, General Electric metallurgist.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Members of the National Association of Food Chains were told today by Holmes Baldridge, chief of the trial section, Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice, that the Government, through its food investigation program, is seeking to break down food distribution monopolies to the end that consumer diet may be improved, growers receive more and a prosperous future be assured "for efficient business men who rely on competition instead of monopolies."

Members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association crowded the finance committee room of the City Council at City Hall yesterday to express their approval of the Cohen-Kinsley bill, which would give policemen forty-eight hours off between tours of duty instead of the existing thirty-two hours.

CAMDEN, S.C., Oct. 14 (AP) -- First Army soldiers in the preliminary phases of a two-month manoeuvre in the Carolinas are "surprisingly healthy," surgeons said today after reviewing hospital records of the first two weeks.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation in a broadcast to the people of Europe announced today that it had a much more effective radio weapon in store to set in motion against the German "ghost" voice that yesterday and again today, interrupted the BBC programs.

Although Harper's expects a large response to its new $12,500 non-fiction contest, the editorial staff was somewhat surprised yesterday when it found itself with the first entry. The contest was announced just ten days ago, the closing date is not until May 1 and the entry, described as a "long diary," came by post from Wisconsin.

To the average follower of football, the landslide which hit New York University in the second half of its game with Texas A and M Saturday may have buried the Violets for the season, but Coach Mal Stevens's staff and the players are not in agreement.

Countess Jeanne von Bernstorff, 73-year-old American-born widow of the last Ambassador to represent Imperial Germany in the United States, denounced nazism and declared that she had "come aome to die" when she arrived here yesterday on the American Export liner Exeter.

Best Co. The board of directors of Best Co., New York department store, yesterday declared a dividend of 40 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Nov. 15 to stock of record on Oct. 25, 1941. Similar payments were ordered three months ago and one year ago at...

Donald M. Nelson, executive director of the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board, told a group of business men yesterday that the SPAB had prepared an order, one of the most drastic ever prepared, to curtail the production of hundreds of copper and bronze items, ranging from ash trays, lamps, andirons and doorknobs to bronze caskets and memorial plaques.

As the European situation became more critical, in the days before the war, Hitler on the one hand and the Russians on the other began a campaign of radio browbeating. German broadcasting stations were "jammed" by powerful Russian stations. The Germans retaliated with raucous laughter, and gibes at official pronouncements.

Erik, the Danish milliner who came to this country from Paris and London a little more than a year ago, is creating with the American woman in mind. In spite of this, the showing he held in his shop at 15 East Fifty-third Street yesterday afternoon was filled with an atmosphere that was Parisian.

A cranberry combine, affecting the popular bogberry in all the forms in which it is known to the consuming public, was alleged in an indictment handed up in Federal court here yesterday. According to attorneys of Thurman Arnold's anti-trust division of the Department ot Justice, who investigated the situation, between 400,000 and 900,000 barrels of cranberries are disposed of each year, in one way or another.
The victory by the Sanford Stud Farms' Vintage Port in the Sgt. Byrne Purse at six furlongs was the highlight of yesterday's racing at Jamaica witnessed by 10,963.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14 -- Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health of New York City under Mayor La Guardia, made a point-by-point reply in an interview here today to charges brought against his department yesterday by Dr. Emanuel M. Josephson, chairman of the Public Health Committee for the Election of O'Dwyer.

BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- By tonight, it was claimed here, the German Army had destroyed 300 full-strength, completely equipped divisions of the Russian Army and taken more than 3,000,000 prisoners since the beginning of the Eastern campaign less than four months ago -- a figure surpassing the total number of prisoners taken by the Germans in the four years of the World War.

If you can take the word of 119 football experts from every section of the United States -- a procedure that is not always safe -- the Western Conference is the nation's leading gridiron league at present and will offer this week's No. 1 game, Northwestern vs. Michigan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today a stipulation between itself, the Newspaper Guild of New York and THE NEW YORK TIMES disposing of the THE TIMES' case, decided by the board Aug. 24, 1940, and looking forward to concluding the proceedings of the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, where the board's petition to enforce the decision now lies.

SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of Ridgewood captured the last one-day tournament on the schedule of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association with 40, 42 -- 82 today over the north course of the Canoe Brook Country Club.

The waterfowl season will open tomorrow in the intermediate zone, which includes New York and all the States which touch our borders, and, according to the reports from Long Island Sound, Great South Bay and Barnegat Bay, the popular duck-shooting spots in this area, every guide has been booked.
NEW YORK Mrs. Vyvyan Drury of Nassau, Bahamas, has come to the Waldorf-Astoria after a visit with Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field at Caumsett, Lloyd Neck, Huntington, L.I.

SEATTLE, Oct. 14 -- The American Federation of Labor at its convention today brought into the open its drive for the removal of Thurman Arnold, head of the antitrust division of the Department of Justice, whom it denounced as "the most articulate and effective spokesman now representing the reactionary, anti-labor forces in this country."

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Italian hatred for Germans was described today by David Edge, a member of the party that returned to England with Sir Ronald Ian Campbell, former Minister to Belgrade, after internment in Italy. Speaking at a luncheon of the Overseas Club, Mr. Edge emphasized that Italy was a slave nation under the overlordship of the Germans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A statement by Admiral Harold R. Stark, Chief of Naval Operations, was made public tonight, revealing that the United States destroyer Greer was following the submarine which attacked it 175 miles southwest of Iceland on Sept. 4 and that the destroyer was told the position of the undersea ship by a British plane.

Baroness Katherine de Hirsch, whose husband is said to be a descendant of the Baron de Hirsch, who was famous during the last century as a philanthropist, has taken an apartment covering an entire floor in the building at 891 Park Avenue through Frances R. Jaffin, broker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee heard four Administration witnesses today urge speed in enactment of the second lease-lend bill for $5,985,000,000 for aid to countries fighting aggressors.

The country-wide campaign to raise funds for the erection of a suitable memorial to the late Dr. James Naismith, who invented basketball at "Springfield College in 1891, got under way yesterday at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

SINCE the Davis Cup was tucked away two years ago in an Australian silver vault for the duration, tennis sailing parties are few and far between and no one gets very excited when they go up the gangplank and the captain yanks out all the stops on the horn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull announced today that Laurence A. Steinhardt, United States Ambassador to Soviet Russia, had canceled for the time being his plans to return to the United States for consultations and would remain in Moscow.
ROME, Oct. 14 (AP) -- An Italian High Command communique said today:

A placid evening among the standard works of the repertory was offered by the Philadelphia Orchestra in the first of its ten concerts at Carnegie Hall last night. Eugene Ormandy, now firmly established as the conductor of the orchestra, directed Beethoven, Bach and Brahms, thus giving New York at least one program from the cycle devoted to the three B's that Philadelphia is hearing.

The new plant of the Hillside Hospital, consisting of four buildings erected at a cost of $600,000 on a tract of fifty acres at Union Turnpike and 263d Street, Queens, will be dedicated next Sunday afternoon, according to announcement by Sydney B. Erlanger, chairman of the dedicatory committee.
BERLIN, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The following communique was issued today:

BOSTON, Oct. 14 -- The first authenticated Nazi Operatives ever captured by an American armed force were brought to Boston today, their little ship escorted from the place off Greenland where it had fallen into the hands of the marines who last week seized a powerful Nazi-controlled radio transmitter.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Joe Louis, heavyweight boxing champion of the world, today passed his medical examination at Provident Hospital and thus became subject to immediate call for duty in the Army.

Trading was glow in the wholesale markets yesterday. Demand for steer hinds and ribs was good in the slaughter houses but other classes moved only fair to slow. Lamb prices were stronger, due mostly to scant offerings. Fresh pork prices were steady to sharply lower, veal and calf hindsaddles weak and other classes mostly unchanged in prices.
Warned by Scout George McCabe that Coach Wally Butts will bring an air-minded Georgia outfit to New York Saturday, Columbia's football forces polished their pass defenses yesterday at Baker Field.

Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., of Canada, and its American subsidiary, Hiram Walker Sons, Inc., producers of Canadian Club whisky, Ballantine's Scotch and other brands of liquors, plan an offering here of an issue of $15,000,000 of debentures, it was announced yesterday by H. C. Hatch, president and chairman of the boards of the two companies.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

A new Bureau of Industrial Conservation is to be set up within the OPM to revise Government specifications, avoid waste in industry, promote the use of substitutes, salvage material now thrown away, simplify manufacturing practices and more efficiently control the utilization of essentials.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 13:
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 -- Great Britain's first aircraft carrier, the 24,000-ton Furious, is in the Philadelphia Navy Yard for extensive repairs and a general overhauling, it was disclosed today.

The rationing of gasoline in New York City has completely broken down, it was charged yesterday by the executive board of the Gasoline Station Council of Metropolitan New York, the chief local organization of filling station proprietors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Fried chicken, Southern style, with hot biscuits and gravy, will be served to the soldiers on manoeuvres in South Carolina and the women of the country will hear about it as the result of the efforts of Mrs. Ovela Culp Hobby, head of the Women's Division of the Bureau of Public Relations of the United States Army.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Legislation which would enable them to operate their distilling plants on the production of industrial alcohol and on whisky at the same time, is sought here by distillers. A bill introduced in the House last week by Representative Everett M. Dirksen of Illinois is expected by distillers to make the dual-operation program possible.

LONDON, Oct. 14 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill in the House of Commons today admitted "anxiety" over the plight of Russia, but refused to make a statement or sanction debate on aid to Russia or the possibility of a British invasion of Europe.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14 -- On the way down to Princeton today we wondered if we'd find that Columbia had squeezed all the orange out of the Tigers' color scheme, leaving only the black.

Dissatisfied with the Rams' line play and defensive work in general, particularly with their failure to bat down or intercept more enemy aerials, Coach Jim Crowley sent Fordham through a strenuous two-hour practice yesterday on Fordham Field.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 14 -- An increase of more than 16 per cent in the number of members reporting higher commodity prices and of more than 70 per cent in the number reporting that they now are buying more than six months in advance of needs is noted in the monthly business survey report of the New England Purchasing Agents Association, released today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In answering Lin Yutang's challenge to the moral power of our civilization Leonard W. Cronkhite, in THE TIMES of Oct. 12, has in turn thrown a very real challenge to his fellow-countrymen.

After a week of partisan manoeuvring the City Council voted unanimously yesterday for Mayor La Guardia's bills reducing the sales and compensating use taxes from 3 and 2 per cent to a flat 1 per cent, with the prospect that the reduction will become effective on Oct. 27.

Thirteen local housing authorities sold yesterday $62,118,000 short-term notes, maturing at various intervals from five months to one year. Of the-toal, a banking group headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, bought $55,930,000, the remainder being taken by four other concerns.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z., Oct. 14 -- Dr. Arnulfo Arias, ousted President of Panama, who returned today from Cuba aboard the Honduran steamship Cefalu, has surrendered to the Panamanian police. It is believed that he will leave by plane tomorrow morning for Costa Rica, where he will reside henceforth.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Oct. 15 -- Moscow commentators acknowledged last night that the German invaders had reached two more key areas on the outer ring of the Moscow defense circle -- Mozhaisk, about sixty miles west of the capital, and the Kalinin region, nearly 100 miles northwest.

The National Bond and Share Corporation had net assets as of Sept. 30 of $7,782,220, according to a pamphlet report issued yesterday. These were equivalent to $21.61 on each of 360,000 shares outstanding, against $21.26 on June 30, last, and $22.20 at the end of last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 --The National Labor Relations Board has held, in effect, that the Ford Motor Company had no right to make a closed-shop contract with the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., covering all its employes, because the C.I.O. had been certified as the spokesman only for the employes in the River Rouge and Lincoln plants, and the question of representation as between the C.I.O. and the A.F. of L. was still open in other plants.

In this hour of Russia's deadly peril one would have to be cold-blooded indeed to pause for an analysis of communism or an inquiry into the character of Joseph Stalin. One's hopes and fears are with the Russian soldiers who after nearly four months of terrific fighting are still exchanging blow for blow with Hitler's massed legions.

The exhibition the Pittsburgh Steelers gave last Sunday in a final-period rally that just fell short of overtaking the Washington Redskins has made a strong impression on Coach Steve Owen of the New York Football Giants. That fact was indiacted by the pace at which the Giants were driven yesterday in preparation for an engagement with the Steelers on Sunday at the Polo Grounds.

Wall Street yesterday witnessed investment banking business done on a 33-cent basis as the Mellon Securities Corporation headed an underwriting syndicate which emerged successful at the competitive bidding sale of $8,927,000 of first-mortgage bonds of the Mississippi River Power Company, a subsidiary of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation.

To keep alive its credit in the United States, the French Government has provided funds to meet the Dec. 1 sinking fund installment on its external loan 7 per cent 1924 dollar bonds, it was announced yesterday by J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., sinking fund administrator for these bonds.

A wage increase of $2.50 a week, totaling $2,210,000 annually, was awarded yesterday to 17,000 workers employed by 124 milk companies in the metropolitan area by David A. Morse, impartial chairman of the milk industry.

VICHY, France, Oct. 14 -- Concrete proposals for dealing with the cases of General Maurice Gustave Gamelin, former Premiers Leon Blum and Edouard Daladier and the others accused of responsibility for France's defeat were submitted tonight to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain by the new Council of Political Justice.

Final bids amounting to $63,950 were made at the auction sale of the William Fahnestock estate at Katonah and Bedford, N.Y., held on Monday by Joseph P. Day. Several hundred persons attended the auction and bidding was reported to be lively on several of the parcels offered.
The foreign policy of the United States Government with respect to

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night gave the first presentation of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House to that perennial bill of ballets by Michel Fokine which consists of "Les Sylphides," "Petrushka" and "Prince Igor."

The first division of interest within the Democratic organization ranks since the start of the Mayoralty campaign was reported to exist yesterday as a result of the necessity of naming a candidate for State Controller to succeed the late Morris S. Tremaine.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Defense officials were reported ready tonight to advise automobile manufacturers tomorrow that January production must be cut more than 50 per cent.

Short-Term Treasury Issues The market for short-term Treasury obligations, particularly the outstanding notes and short-term bonds, experienced a sinking spell yesterday as traders and investors pondered the suggestion made by an out-of-town bulletin service that the Treasury, after its experience last week with a three-point premium on its new $1,200,000,000 cash offering, may do away with the so-called "rights" customarily given to holders of maturing obligations to purchase or exchange into the new issues.

Mayor La Guardia stressed the current material aid to Great Britain under the lease-lend law and also praised the leadership of President Roosevelt in initiating yesterday the "Thumbs Up" campaign for the British War Relief Society.

The order dissolving the Sokol recalls as if it were yesterday a Sunday several years ago in a farmhouse in a Czech village about fifty miles from Prague. There was a prodigious dinner composed of the native specialties and served with ceremony by the daughters of the house in a low, whitewashed room, half kitchen and half living room.

Volunteer workers in the recent campaign of the Greater New York Fund were guests of James A. Farley, chairman of the drive, yesterday at a reception in the Hotel Biltmore to thank them for their efforts. In turn they presented to Mr. Farley a gift as a tribute to his leadership in making the campaign the most successful in the fund's history.

A dividend of $5 a share was declared yesterday by the board of directors of the new International Paper Company on the cumulative convertible 5 per cent preferred stock of the company, payable on Nov. 15 to stock of record on Nov. 7.

"Married Bachelor, which opens at Loew's Criterion, is this mornings' lone film arrival. The romantic adventure features Ruth Hussey and Robert Young and includes Lee Bowman, Felix Bressart, Sheldon Leonard and Sam Levene.... "Hold Back the Dawn" enters its third and final week today at the Paramount....

The appointment of S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, as general chairman of the New York Red Cross Chapter's twenty-fifth annual Roll Call, was announced yesterday. The minimum objectives of this year's campaign in Manhattan and the Bronx, which will begin on Nov. 11 and continue until Dec. 1, will be to double the present enrollment of 150,000 and raise at least $700,000.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer's charge that Mayor La Guardia schemed to get Communist support was denounced yesterday by Representative Vito Marcantonio, a leader of the left wing faction of the American Labor party; by Samuel Null, candidate for Supreme Court Justice, and by George Marlin, State executive director of the Labor party.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Prices of hogs dropped today below $11 a hundredweight for the first time since July 3. The decline was 10 to 15 cents. The top quotation was $10.90. The best price hogs brought today compared with $12.35 on Sept. 10, a loss of $1.45 in a little more than a month. Average price, however, was down only about 75 cents from the year's high.

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 15 -- Following Sunday night's heavy attacks on Western Germany, British aircraft of the Bomber Command visited Duesseldorf, Cologne and other objectives in Western Germany Monday night. While a small force was bombing Boulogne, Coastal Command planes were attacking enemy shipping off the Netherland coast.

THOMAS WOLFE has been gone since 1938, but still another volume -- the last, or, at any rate, the last for the time being -- from his fabulously fertile pen comes out this morning. This consists of ten short stories, essays and sketches plus a series of ten chapters from an unfinished novel. The title is "The Hills Beyond."*

ALBANY, Oct. 14 -- Governor Lehman started today to put into immediate operation a State-wide mutual aid plan for water service in the event of emergencies, to be a part of the civilian defense program. It will be carried on by cooperation with water officials and coordinated with the work of local defense councils.

Nicholas M. Schenck, president of Loew's, Inc., which operates the Loew'a theatres and makes Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer motion pictures, kept a secret for five years because he was afraid of what might happen to the film business if it were disclosed, he testified yesterday.

The New Opera Company's gala premiere last night at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre, where it opened its initial season with a performance of Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte," was the occasion for much entertaining by members of society and others who have been closely identified with the company since its organization several months ago under the direction of Mrs. Lytle Hull.

VICHY, France, Oct. 14 -- "Economic Aryanization" is proceeding in the unoccupied zone. The Journal Officiel today prints the names of some twenty firms for which "provisional managers" have been appointed because they are owned by Jews wholly or in part.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during September totaled 875,682 bales of lint and 129,731 bales of linters, compared with 874,113 of lint and 131,314 of linters during August this year and 638,235 of lint and 94,794 of linters during September last year.

The merger of the Western Electric Company with its wholly owned subsidiary, Electrical Research Products, Inc., effective Nov. 1, was announced yesterday by Clarence G. Stoll, president of Western Electric.
The demands of the national defense program are retarding the public-housing program in New York, according to Gerard Swope, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Seriousness of the shortage of copper supplies for civilian uses was emphasized in several developments at the Office of Production Management today. Admitting that October requirements of the metal for defense, communications and other critical uses will reach 145,000 tons, officials said the visible supply falls at least 6,000 tons short of the needed total.

Efforts to settle the strike of newsdealers against eight morning and afternoon papers were under way yesterday with conferences at City Hall, participated in by Mayor La Guardia, and at the office of the State Mediation Board.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Sheriff Denton J. Quick of Sussex County, who, with thirteen other defendants, was convicted on Aug. 18 by a jury in Federal District Court here of conspiring to operate liquor stills, was sentenced today by Federal Judge Herbert Goodrich to a year and a day in a Federal penitentiary and to pay a $500 fine.
Manhattan's offensive weapons were sharpened yesterday as Coach Herb Kopf increased the tempo of preparations for the Boston College game on Saturday.
"What's so wonderful about your new soups?" we somewhat tactlessly inquired of the man who sells them.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 15 -- The Soviet High Command announced today the abandonment of Mariupol, Sea of Azov port [claimed by the Germans last week], and reported fierce fighting in the Kalinin and Bryansk directions.

Mrs. Ida M. Pickings, who said she was a member of the bar in Illinois, Maryland and Florida, and her husband, Guy W. Pickings, a middle-aged salesman, were convicted yesterday in Special Sessions of desecrating the American flag by displaying it with advertising for their itinerant tourist camp agency business on the side of their car.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A long-sought repicrocal trade agreement between this country and Argentina was signed in Buenos Aires tonight and was hailed by President Roosevelt as an "outstanding contribution" to the reconstruction of peaceful trade not only in the Americas but throughout the world.

Trimming four strokes from par on the back nine, Monroe Stein and Jimmy Turnesa of Elmsford won a one-day invitation amateur-pro golf tournament for Westchegter and Long Island players, sponsored by the Long Island P.G.A., with 34, 31 -- 65 on the Fresh Meadow Country Club course in Flushing yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- President Roosevelt told his press conference today that transfers of lease-lend supplies to actual and potential enemies of the Nazis and their allies amounted to $155,000,000 in September, or more than double the amount sent in the three months after the start of the program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A clash between Republican and Democratic members as the House Foreign Affairs Committee heard opponents of revision of the Neutrality Act and a meeting at which eleven isolationist Senators laid plans to oppose the arming of merchant ships were today's chief developments in the battle over the Administration's current efforts to render more aid to Great Britain.

BERLIN, Oct. 14 (U.P.) -- The Nazi onslaught toward Moscow was said here today to have enabled the advance of Big Bertha artillery to positions from which it could unlimber a mighty barrage on the "extreme outer defense ring" of the imperlled Soviet capital.

With trade buying orders absorbing most of the contracts offered, the cotton market recovered yesterday from early losses sand showed net gains for the day. Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 4 to 7 points above Saturday.

Instead of attempting to rush a bill through Congress embodying ill-digested changes in the Social Security Act, it would seem far wiser to emulate the sort of procedure that Great Britain, which has long been in advance of us in social security matters, has once again adopted.

Advertising for 1942 will show little change from this year, if national advertisers hold to budgets now being made up. A recent survey showed that 72 per cent would make no change in budgets; 13 per cent would reduce them; another 13 per cent would increase them and the remaining 2 per cent was undecided as yet.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 14 -- Carole Lombard, who has been absent from, the screen for nearly a year, was engaged today by Ernst Lubitsch and Alexander Korda to play the feminine lead opposite Jack Benny in their United Artists production, "To Be or Not to Be."

Plans for a Latin-American Fair to be opened at Macy's during January for the promotion of Latin-American products were announced yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president of Macy's, at a luncheon attended by nearly 100 diplomatic representatives of the Latin-American countries and newspaper, radio, magazine and transportation representtives at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As one who has for several years made detective novels "bedtime stories," I can subscribe to everything your correspondent "Old Pedant" said in your issue of Oct. 12. In most such stories the lifting of cocktails seems the most important order of business, especially to the women involved.

The thirteen and seventeen story office structure known as the Woodbridge Building, at 96-106 William Street, occupying the blockfront between Platt and John Streets, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street sales-rooms.
Two sales of properties in the Greenwich Village sector were among the Manhattan deals reported by brokers yesterday.

Preparing for Saturday's game at the Yankee Stadium, the N.Y. U. varsity went on defense against Syracuse's Y formation, as interpreted by the freshmen and reserves, yesterday at Ohio Field. The sham engagement consumed ninety minutes and the regulars functioned with such success that Coach Mal Stevens is confident he'll soon have Ossie Solem's new creation figured to a T.
CAIRO, Oct. 14 (U.P.) -- The R.A. F. Middle East Command issued the following today:

Ery Kehaya, president of Standard Commercial Tobacco Company, ended his trial in Federal court yesterday by pleading guilty to the fraud charges on which a jury had been hearing evidence since Sept. 28. He and his co-defendants, who also pleaded guilty, received fines totaling $8,400, but no prison sentences were imposed.

LAWRENCEVILE, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Apparently Larry Tiihonen and his football coaching aides at Lawrenceville School have an abundance of those valuable virtues called patience and persistence. They are still making every effort to develop a winning combination, even though adversity has hounded the team to date.

A collection that was distinguished for its refinement of color and line held the center of the stage during the luncheon hour yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton. It was composed of ready-to-wear selections and original creations from Jonai, specialty house at 78 East Fifty-sixth Street.

Actors Equity gleanings: The Equity council yesterday granted Donald Blackwell permission to engage Barbara Everest, alien actress, for "Little Dark Horse," whicn Mr. Blackwell and Raymond Curtis are producing. Miss Everest, who was co-starred in the short-lived "Anne of England," which closed on Saturday, otherwise would have had to wait six months between engagements, as stipulated in the Equity regulations applying to foreign performers.

TOKYO, Oct. 14 -- Following a two-hour audience given the Premier, Prince Fumimaro Konoye, yesterday Emperor Hirohito today received the War Minister, Lieut. Gen. Eiki Tojo, for an audience lasting more than an hour.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- A second Eagle squadron of American fighter pilots in the Royal Air Force has already begun to give a good account of itself and has been performing the important duty of convoy patrols off the British coasts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The announcement by Secretary Hull that he has established a Board of Economic Operations in the State Department and integrated it with divisions of related activity in other departments of the defense establishment means that the economic front of the war against Hitler has been both manned and consolidated.

The part played by William O'Dwyer in stemming intolerance in the 1938 gubernatorial campaign was made public last night by Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, one of the beneficiaries of Mr. O'Dwyer's efforts three years ago.

Council President Newbold Morris stalked off the rostrum at yesterday's Council meeting in City Hall after a heated row with Councilman Louis Cohen, Bronx Democrat, over the latter's charges of anti-Semitism in the administrative policies of Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx.

The vulnerability of the stock market to the news from the Russian front was emphasized again yesterday as prices retreated further in the afternoon when the tenor of the dispatches turned more pessimistic. While the losses did not assume major proportions except in special cases, the downward trend was fairly general throughout the list with final quotations again back to the low levels of June.
Sidney Walker, Augusta, Ga., Negro, better known as Beau Jack, outpointed Tommy Spiegel, Uniontown, Pa., in the feature eight-round bout before a capacity crowd last night at the Broadway Arena.

Judge Flouts Law A rather unusual type of conscientious objector came forward day before yesterday in the person of an up-State judge. He refused to adjourn court on Columbus Day because he denies that Christopher Columbus discovered America.

BOSTON, Oct. 14 -- The baking industry was advised today to cut its operating and distributive costs, but was told bluntly by Harold Rowe of the Office of Price Administration that any attempt to effect such reductions at the expense of the consumer by decreasing the weight of any of its standard products would result in governmental action.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Charge that the California Supreme Court, in the contempt conviction of The Los Angeles Times, supported a doctrine constituting censorship by oblique methods," was made before the Supreme Court today by T.B. Cosgrove, counsel for the newspaper.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Despite differences of opinion concerning details, which can be ironed our pacifists would heartily endorse the air of W.N. Findley's letter -- a lastin peace through international cooperation and world government. Pacifists have been and are striving toward this positive goal.

The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York will celebrate today completion of nine years of service as the central organization for building and loan associations in the States of New York and New Jersey, Nugent Fallen, president of the bank, announced yesterday.

A new unit of the Concord Cafeterias will be opened at 895 Flat-bush Avenue, Brooklyn, in a three-story building, leased in its entirety by Morris Himmelstein and Benjamin Bergman, officers of the restaurant chain, for thirty-one years at an aggregate rental of about $350,000.
SEATTLE, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Detroit on total offense; Tulane in total defense.

The elusive John Steinbeck, whose whereabouts are often a secret even to his publisher, has been in New York since the beginning of the week, it was learned yesterday. The author of "The Grapes of Wrath" has little to say about his plans except that he will be in New York this week and around the East for an indefinite period.

As the President said in his message last week, no law ever prohibited the arming of American merchant ships until Congress suddenly wrote such a provision into the Neutrality Act of 1937. It is clear enough now that the prohibition then adopted was based upon a gross miscalculation as to what would happen in another war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Representative Steagall, chairman of the Banking Committee, expressed the opinion today that the pending price control bill should "control rents everywhere" and not merely in defense areas as proposed by the Administration.
The British War Relief Society, Inc., launched its "ship," Happiness, which will carry Christmas gifts from the United States to British children, at 1265 Sixth Avenue, yesterday afternoon.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 15 -- To four British seamen who collectively have had seven ships shot from under them the Duke of Windsor said today:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We have no means of knowing what is the purport of the negotiations between, the State Department and Japan. We do know, however, that they are causing anxiety to the Chinese.

With quiet conditions ruling in the fur market since the excise tax went into effect on Oct. 1, both retailers and manufacturers are seeking a stimulant to spur volume. Some of the fur merchandise now being offered by retailers has been reduced in price by the equivalent of the 10 per cent excise levy and the results of this move are being carefully scanned in the trade.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 15 -- Numan Menemencioglu, the Turkish Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, disclosed that the new Turkish-German trade agreement went into effect the day it was signed in Ankara six days ago.
NEW YORK Elizabeth, Lady Cheylesmore, who had been at the Savoy-Plaza, returned yesterday to Newport.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 15 (AP) -- The big puzzle surrounding Michigan's battle with Northwestern at Dyche Stadium Saturday is the strength of the Northwestern line -- and it's as much of an enigma to Burt Ingwersen as it is to any Wildcat fan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Representative Boland of Pennsylvania, Democratic whip, said today that House passage of the legislation to permit the arming of merchant ships was so certain that it was "absolutely unnecessary" for him to make an advance poll of the membership.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15 -- They've changed the Bulldog's die up here at Yale and the old fellow seems to be perking up. They're feeding him corn now instead of meat.

Rain wasn't the only thing that fell along Seventh Avenue, between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets yesterday afternoon. A foot-high cake, tremulous with whipped crealn, pineapples and cherries and carefully shielded with an umbrella, was dashed into the muck when a squad of policemen bore down on three pickets carrying the cake outside the Brass Rail Restaurant.
BERLIN, Oct. 15 (AP) -- A special communique of the German High Command said today:

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 15 -- From the defense and economic points of view conditions in Syria have greatly improved since the British and Free French took the country from the Vichy French, according to authoritative information reaching Cairo.

VICHY, France, Oct. 15 -- The continued German advance in Russia is again bringing Franco-German relations to the forefront, and there is every likelihood that it will be discussed in detail in Vichy during the week-end, when the Vice Premier Admiral Francois Darlan and Minister of the Interior Pierre Pucheu return from Paris, and General Maxime Weygand, proconsul in Africa, arrives from Algiers.

Jo Davidson, the sculptor, who returned yesterday from South America, where he executed busts of Presidents of nine republics, declared that the United States was on the verge of a renaissance in art. He said that WPA art projects had done much to make such a renaissance possible.

News of the increasing seriousness of the plight of the Russians depressed prices of stocks yesterday. However, since actual evidence, as gauged by the news dispatches, was not forthcoming of any rout of the Soviet defenders, there was no marked increase in the selling, which about matched that of Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- While the grain markets on the Board of Trade showed fair strength early today, general liquidation developed late and, with many stop-loss orders uncovered, wheat, oats and soy beans dropped to the lowest levels since late August Closing trades were near the ottom.

Incumbent officers of the American Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., conceded yesterday their defeat by an opposition slate that had campaigned on the issue that the old administration had followed the Communist party line to the detriment of the Guild.

ROME, Oct. 15 -- Any one with enough money can buy as much as he wants of rationed foods from bootleggers, writes Giovanni Preziosi, editor of the Vita Italiana, in the October issue of that magazine, which will appear tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The value of a legislative check on the Executive in time of war as well as in peace has again been demonstrated by the publication of Admiral Stark's report to the Senate Naval Affairs Committee concerning the brush off Iceland, Sept. 4, between the U.S.S. Greer, a destroyer, and a submarine, presumably German.

Two Americans who lived many years in France and a French Army officer who escaped from a German prison camp described yesterday the misery of more than 1,000,000 French war prisoners still behind barbed wire at a luncheon of Miss Anne Morgan's committee, which is raising a fund to send Christmas boxes containing food and tobacco to the prison camps in France and Germany.

Not only will the Army's new air defense information center be kept on the job indefinitely, regardless of an emergency or the lack of it, but an alternate center equipped to take over its every function in case of a direct bomb hit will be built in Newark, it was revealed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP.) -- Prices of hogs continued to decline today as liberal supplies and another cut in dressed pork quotations discouraged buyers. Declines ranged from 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight. Salable arrivals, at 13,000 head, were 2,000 more than expected.

Lewis H. Brown, president of the Johns-Manville Corporation, reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $4,488,984 after all charges. This is equivalent to $4.97 a share on the 850,000 shares of common stock after allowing for preferred dividend payments.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 16 -- A powerful German force of tanks and motorized infantry has broken through the defenses west of Moscow, forcing the Russian central armies into retreat, it was acknowledged officially early today, with the hour of supreme crisis for the capital at hand.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Oct. 15 -- Trading on the Bourse today was light and the close was irregular. Royal Dutch lost 1 1/4 points to 311 1/2, after touching 308 1/2; Unilever was 1 lower at 157 7/8, but A.K.U. advanced 3 points to 146 1/4, Amsterdam Trading 2 1/2 to 482 1/2 and Amsterdam Rubber 1 to 310 1/2.

THIS morning Pierre van Paassen has a new book explaining, among other things, why Rudolf Hess climbed into an airplane and flew off to Scotland last May. Where Mr. van Paassen got his information remains a mystery, but there are many mysteries in "That Day Alone."*

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline along the Atlantic seaboard at the close of last week were 18,387,000 barrels, a decline of 192,000 from the 18,579,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Light fuel oil stocks increased 615,000 barrels to 19,418,000, but heavy fuel oil stocks were down 156,000 barrels to 1,226,000.

Former Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church, Democratic nominee for Controller, charged last night in a radio speech from station WMCA that Controller McGoldrick had denied mechanics and laborers a chance to be heard on applications for higher pay and had ignored a decision by the Court of Appeals directing him to do so until just before election.

The ten-room house for two families at 148-02 to 148-04 Thirty-fifth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by the Monoboro Corporation through the Halleran Agency, broker, to James and Joseph Sette for occupancy. The plot is 50 by 100 feet.

The friendly frankfurters that happy picnickers broil over fragrant wood fires and hungrily munch in hot toasted rolls have made their appearance in a big, bright blue tin. These are aristocratic wieners especially designed by a celebrated city company to take the place of the famous frankfurters that once were imported from Holland.

The complete breakdown of gasoline rationing in the New York City area charged by filling station groups was discounted by some of the oil company executives yesterday. While their own surveys have convinced some oil company heads and retailers that there is no shortage of gasoline or oil along the Eastern seaboard, the companies insist that they are complying with the rationing order.

Proposals and counter-proposals for settlement of the strike of newsdealers against eight morning and afternoon newspapers were submitted yesterday to Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the state Mediation Board, but the day ended with the strike still in effect.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The National Defense "Mediation Board went over the head of F. Leroy Hill, president of Air Associates, Inc., at Bendix (N.J.) in an effort today to convince the company's directors that its recommendation should be accepted in order to end the dispute between the company and a local of the United Automobile Workers of America (C.I.O.).

A "dime store" type of parking garage to charge 5 and 10 cents an hour was proposed for congested sections of New York City yesterday before the Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association by Paul Archibald, garage consultant.
Several deals involving loft buildings in Manhattan were reported yesterday by brokers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Navy Department announced tonight that pay increases had been authorized for thousands of civilian workers in Navy shipbuilding yards on the Atlantic dbast, effective as of last Monday.
SEATTLE, Oct. 15 -- The American Federation of Labor dealt two telling blows at racketeering today.

Trading was improved yesterday on some classes of dressed meats, but only fair to slow on others. Lamb prices were slightly easier and some steer and fresh pork cuts were lower. Otherwise prices were about in line with Tuesday's markets. Kosher slaughter was heavy and, except veal and calf, which opened barely steady to weak, prices were about steady with the previous kosher markets of last Friday.

The Dodgers yesterday managed to sneak into Ebbets Field for a workout, but they had to wear sneakers instead of cleats. Larry MacPhail is reported to be away on a vacation, so Owner Dan Topping and Coach Jock Sutherland were unable to iron out matters.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Rain today failed to halt Princeton's preparations for the coming Penn encounter, Coach Tad Wieman calling on the hard-working Princeton football forces for their third straight day of scrimmage.

A precedent-making agreement to end jurisdictional disputes between A.F. of L. and C.I.O. unions engaged in the manufacture and distribution of electrical supplies, lamps and fixtures in this city has been negotiated through the efforts of Mrs. Ethel S. Epstein, labor secretary to Mayor La Guardia, it became known, yesterday.

Calling upon the government and labor to "adjourn politics," former Governor Alfred E. Smith made an urgent plea yesterday for national unity behind President Roosevelt's foreign policy. He declared that all Americans must stand back of the President in the present crisis.

With injuries cutting deep into the personnel of Manhattan's small corps of ends. Herb Kopf yesterday drafted Bob Amo, 184-pound utility back, for action against Boston College Saturday in Fenway Park. The Massena, N.Y., junior worked under the tutelage of Milt Gantenbein, end coach, who was impressed with the aptness of his pupil in picking up the offensive and defensive assignments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Within twenty-four hours after the return to the United States of William Phillips, United States Ambassador to Italy, President Roosevelt held a long conference with the envoy at the White House today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Oct. 16 -- The Russian radio reported early today the withdrawal of Soviet forces from the city of Kalinin, about 100 miles northwest of Moscow, and there were indications that the outermost defenses of the capital were in danger of collapse.

Donning a freshly starched chef's hat, Mayor La Guardia yesterday gave students at the Food Trades Vocational High School, 208 West Thirteenth Street, a demonstration in slicing sweet potatoes and in carving a generous portion of top round steak.

Margo and Sam Jaffe will divide the acting honors in Ferenc Molnar's play "The King's Maid," which will have its Broadway premiere "around Thanksgiving," following an out-of-town tryout. Other roles will be interpreted by Karl Malden, Byron McGrath and Barna Ostertag.

A large dinner dance to raise funds for United China Relief was given last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador to mark the formal opening of that rezuiezvous for the Autumn and Winter season. The room, and its adjoining Circular Lounge were filled to capacity for the occasion.

Musicians on sustaining programs on Station WABC, key station of the Columbia Broadcasting System, were ordered off the air at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, as the result of a controversy between the union and Station WJAS, Columbia's Pittsburgh outlet.

More than 90 per cent of the Catholic clergymen responding to a nation-wide poll conducted by the Catholic Laymen's Committee for Peace voted against the United States engaging in a shooting war outside the Western Hemisphere and against the United States extending aid to Soviet Russia, the committee announced yesterday.

No longer free to accept or reject, American industry must take any defense order whether or not it bears a preference rating if the established price and terms of sale are met, Manly Fleischmann, chief attorney for the division of priorities of the Office of Production Management, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Charging that one leading maker of acetate yarn had raised prices beyond levels which the Office of Price Administration had previously determined to be reasonable, Leon Henderson, OPA administrator, announced today that maximum prices are to be established for all types of rayon yarn.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Working rules and the demand for vacations with pay were two subjects that today were brought by the railroads to the attention of President Roosevelt's Fact-finding Commission, which is investigating the differences between the railroad managements and the rail Brotherhoods in their quest for pay rises.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Whenever Congress authorizes such action the Navy Department is ready and equipped to put guns and gun crews on all American merchant ships as rapidly as they can be put into port for the installations Secretary Knox told his press conference today.

With Market Wise, Fenelon and Shot Put among the nine named, the $17,225 Gallant Fox Handicap will be run at Jamaica today, when the Metropolitan Jockey Club will end its most successful Fall meeting.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Playing spectacular golf to bring home a new record for thirty-six holes, Herman Barron of Fenway won the annual Westchester P. G. A. championship with 68, 64 -- 132 over the hilly, rain-drenched Elmsford Country Club course today.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Ben F.
