Lister's Bell Tower rushed through on the rail today to win by a head from Mrs. Emil Denemark's Kentown in the Lowell Purse, Rockingham Park's feature, a six-furlong dash. Frank J. Kearns's Marion Collins was third in this race, which was run in 1:12 over a fast track.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A short message from London in your issue of Oct. 11, reporting the arrest in Tokyo of two old British residents, J.D. Mason and Graham Martyr, lifts a corner of the veil that conceals events in Japan. The military police are again on the warpath against foreigners.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Get 15 -- The government was warnen suddenly today that it would have to pay part of the increased wages granted to A.F.L. machinists in the bomber plant of the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation.

PAWLING, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- We met only one woodcock hunter in Connecticut covers, from Westport to Bethel, today, but there was a fair turnout of hunters in Dutchess County, and not one of them had a woodcock to show for his efforts.

Stockholders of the Lehman Corporation elected yesterday Wendell L. Willkie and live other new directors not previously associated with the company or the banking firm of Lehman Brothers at their annual meeting in Wilmington, Del.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Hearings were ended today by the Senate Appropriations Committee on the second lease-lend bill carrying $5,985,000,000 and the measure will be speeded to the floor early next week.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 15 -- The synthetic production of a water-soluble form of Vitamin E, recently found helpful in the treatment of some diseases of the muscles, was reported today before the closing sessions of the Autumn meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the jewelry industry in Massachusetts and Rhode Island appealed today to Federal officials in charge of priorities for release of enough metals to prevent a shutdown of their plants employing 33,500 workers.

Helping the city's commercial interests cooperate effectively with the national defense program was among the major activities of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., during the past year, according to the organization's annual report, issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Foreign Affairs Committee sent to the floor of the House today with a favorable majority report the Administration's bill for a revision of the Neutrality Act to permit the arming of American ships, and passage of the measure by Friday was predicted by Administration leaders.

In a sweeping change of policy, the United Artiste Corporation announced last night that it was entering the field of motion-picture production and at the same time disclosed that it had purchased Walter Wanger's interest in Walter Wanger Productions, Inc., and now owns 100 per cent of the Iatter stock.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Alsab, the 2-year-old champion that has a chance to become the first horse of his age to race in the Pimlico Special, staged an impressive trial today for the Spalding Lowe Jenkins Stakes at Laurel on Saturday.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 15 -- "Yeah, Notre Dame has a good team, but we're not dying of fright."
DETROIT, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Due to the defense effort, the Detroit Symphony will play 22 concerts this season instead of 21.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Lieut. Gen. Ben Lear became the center of a new controversy today when Senator Clark of Missouri declared in a telegram that the general was blaming tactical errors of his Second Army on other officers, among them Major Gen. Truman, a cousin of Senator Truman of Missouri.

The First National Bank of Memphis and associates have received the award of an issue of $250,000 of refunding bonds of the Yazoo Delta Levee District, Miss., taking $200,000 as 1 1/2 and $50,000 as 1 3/4 s. The bonds, dated Nov. 1, 1941, will mature in 1952 and 1955.
There being no psychopathic ward at the animal hospital in the Central Park Zoo, Chang, the two-and-a-half-ton female elephant, has been placed under observation in her own quarters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Plans for Navy censorship of outgoing communications from the United States are well under way in an effort to prevent the leakage of military, naval or economic information to enemy or unfriendly powers, Secretary Knox stated today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 15 -- "Misuse of knowledge" which compels thousands of young men "to sacrifice their careers in a blundering program of war or nations defense" was condemned today by President Alexander G. Ruthven of the University of Michigan, presiding at the opening session of the centennial celebration of the College of Literature, Science and the Arts.

Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, disclosed yesterday that the company intends to raise about $12,000,000 of additional new capital for expansion through the sale on leading security exchanges of the unsubscribed portion of A.T. T.'s recent offering of $233,584,900 of fifteen-year 3 per cent convertible debentures.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 16 -- While the highest government quarters continued their day and night conferences, which included another two-hour audience given by Emperor Hirohito to the Premier, Prince Fumimaro Konoye, Captain Hideo Hiraide, director of the naval intelligence section of Imperial Headquarters, declared in a public speech that relations between Japan and the United States "are now approaching the final parting of the ways."

Treasury Allotments Veteran dealers in government bonds again accurately diagnosed the probable demand for the recent issue of $1,200,000,000 of Treasury 2 1/2 per cent bonds issued for cash, and the announcement yesterday by the Treasury Department that allotments will be made at the rate of 12 1/2 per cent of subscriptions coincides almost exactly with what had been forecast at the time of the offering.
HAVANA, Oct. 13 -- The Cane Planters Association of Cuba is working on a plan to establish an agricultural financing bank as a means of protecting and assisting its 40,000 members.

As the Germans close in on the outer defenses of Moscow, it looks as if one of the great sieges of history is beginning. Although the Russians admit that their position on the Western Front has deteriorated, and their forces have had to fall back, reports from the imperiled city give a picture of a population girding itself with stoic calm for a defense to the death.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 15 -- under the stress of war, England is developing a national hospital system in which county, city and voluntary hospitals are being coordinated, Sir Wilson Jameson, chief medical officer of the British Ministry of Health, told 1,200 American doctors, nurses and health officers here tonight at the convention of the American Public Health Association.

BERLIN, Oct. 15 (U.P.) -- German motorized columns were streaming four abreast over feebly defended highways toward Moscow, at places only fifty or sixty miles distant, white the steel arms of a huge nutcracker closing on the capital had smashed through Kalinin and Tula, Nazi informants said tonight.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Aerial warfare will be waged relentlessly upon Peddie School's future football foes if the rugged squad directed by Larry Kelley, former Yale pass-snatching ace, fulfills expectations and becomes proficient in the overhead style of offensive.

The port of New York and all other ports in the country are free of traffic congestion despite war conditions', George C. Kandall, manager of port traffic of the Association of American Railroads, reported last night at a dinner of the Foreign Commerce Club of New York in the Hotel Astor.

Why Their "Crimes"? It is said that Marshal Petain will take into his own hands the case of Edouard Daladier, Leon Blum and General Maurice Gamelin. Their responsibility for the French military disasters that brought about the fall of the republic has been before a high court for more than a year.

With Dr. Hu Shih, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, as the guest of honor, 500 women of the Catholic, Jewish and Protestant faiths joined in an appeal for support of the United China Relief yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The new trade agreement with Argentina, giving canned meat, hides, wool and certain dairy products a more free entry to this country, was denounced by several Republican Representatives from the farm States today as a blow to American agriculture.

Of seventeen companies investigated, including virtually all the better known private carriers of workmen's compensation insurance in this State, fifteen have been found guilty of violating the law against rebates, State Insurance Superintendent Louis H. Pink disclosed yesterday.

A fashionable drawing room of colonial New York was opened last night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art at a reception given by the museum to its members. The guests had a preview also of the new Junior Museum which the Metropolitan will open to the public today.

ATLANTA, Oct. 15 -- Nearly one thousand University of Georgia students invaded the State capitol today in a demonstration of protest against "political interference" with the State's educational system and the ouster of the university by the Southern University Conference.
MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 15 -- Greenwich Time's homestretch spurt enabled him to capture the two-mile Fox-catcher Plate Steeplechase at Rose Tree today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 15 -- Japan has long called Guam an American dagger pointed at the Empire's heart. Today Australia has suddenly and unpleasantly awakened to the fact that the extension by the Japanese of their airlines from Palau Island to Timor, an island only 452 miles from Darwin, Australia, may con statute a dagger pointed at the heart of this great continent.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 15 -- When details of the United States commercial treaty with Argentina became known today, as excellent impression resulted in all financial and economic circles as well as among the general public. The general belief is that the pact will cause a considerable expansion in Argentine exports to the United States, thus helping to relieve the economic stringency resulting front the European War.

Although unwilling to comment on the specific terms of the new trade treaty between the United States and Argentina until after they have had an opportunity to study them, foreign traders here yesterday hailed the new pact as further evidence of the success of the Hull reciprocal trade policy.

The selection of a Democratic nominee for State Controller reached a temporary impasse yesterday. Two conferences with Governor Lehman, one attended by Democratic party leaders, and the other by representatives of the American Labor party, failed to produce agreement on a candidate who might be nominated by both groups.
CAIRO, Egypt Oct. 15 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued this communique today:
BERLIN, Oct. 15 (AP) -- A new wave of anti-Semitism in Berlin these days is characterized by the following developments:

The Citizens Committee for the Re-Election of La Guardia, McGoldrick and Morris has joined with the Affiliated Young Democrats to hold the closing rally of the campaign in Madison Square Garden on Nov. 1, the Saturday night before election, Harold R. Moskovit, State president of the Young Democrats, disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Clement R. Attlee, Lord Privy Seal, declared today that when the war is over the Nazis "responsible for atrocities must not escape punishment." In a speech before the National Defense Committee the Deputy Prime Minister dealt with the efforts of the Germans to hold down the people of the occupied countries.

Dr. Maximilian A. Ramirez, president-elect of the New York County Medical Society, characterized yesterday the charges recently made by Dr. Emanuel M. Josephson against the City's Health Department as "a false and dangerous piece of political propaganda."

DETROIT, Oct. 15 -- R.J. Thomas, president of the C.I.O.'s United Automobile Workers, agreed today to abandon the union's strike at the Hillsdale Steel Products Company plant in Hillsdale, thus clearing the way today for resumption of full production on Army tanks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The War Department today announced the award of contracts totaling $102,925,221. Contracts let to concerns in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey follow:

The problem of priorities unemployment, about which a good deal of concern has been expressed both in Washington and in business circles, appeared yesterday to be affecting some materials. In the chemical field individual traders, who were worried over inability to buy needed quantities of certain materials, said demand for other materials had begun to slacken somewhat because normal consumers were unable to get one or more of the solvents with which to handle them.

In its demand for the removal of Thurman Arnold, the American Federation of Labor is doing itself a grave disservice. The Federation might be justified in the purely legal contention that Mr. Arnold's interpretation of existing anti-trust laws as applied to unions is unwarranted.

Mrs. Henry Epstein, labor adviser to Mayor La Guardia, whose amiable political differences with her husband, the New York State Solicitor General, were emphasized recently in a letter that he wrote to the Mayor in criticism of his stand on the sales tax, disclosed yesterday that she was learning to fly an airplane.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- After his introductory work with the New York Americans yesterday, Jarrin' John Kimbrough, erstwhile Texas A. and M. star, settled down to the task of fitting himself into the scheme of things today.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 16 (U.P.) -- There are increasing indications that Japanese-American relations are approaching a new crisis. A Navy Ministry spokesman warned the nation that the "final crossroads" may be at hand.

Charles B. Murphy, campaign manager for District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, announced yesterday that Mr. O'Dwyer's address to members of the New York County Democratic Committee at Tammany Hall tonight would begone of the "outstanding political speeches in the history of the city."

LONDON, Oct. 15 (U.P.) -- Great Britain claimed today that her air offensive in the west had pinned down half of Germany's fighter planes and aided Russia "on a scale few imagine," but a War Cabinet member inferentially rejected demands for a British invasion of Europe.

In a democracy the party of opposition has responsibilities almost as great as those of the party in power. The minority party, alert to rebuke abuses of power or errors of judgment by the majority, is an essential part of our system of checks and balances. In times like these there is special need for the kind of intelligent "loyal opposition" which Wendell Willkie called for after the last election.

Here today and gone tomorrow. Sic transit gloria mundi, and all of that. A year ago Stanford, Boston College, Cornell, Tennessee and Texas A. M. were riding high and mighty. In the first Associated Press ranking poll for 1941 not a single one of them is to be found to the top ten, and only Texas A. M. makes the second ten.

The advertising field is seriously concerned over the possibility that eventually some government ruling might be forthcoming on the inclusion of advertising costs in the price of goods placed under ceilings, but such fears are based only on a few stray remarks by government officials.

BERLIN, Oct. 15 -- Accusing Washington of drawing Latin America into the "blockade front," not only against Germany and Italy, but also against Japan, the Berlin Institute for Economic Research devotes the greater part of its latest bulletin to analysis of the methods by which this policy is being carried out.

LONDON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Soviet sources said today that well-trained Red Army reinforcements from Siberia were being thrown into the battle for Moscow, raging through a critical phase with the Germans apparently in position for a grant assault on the capital from three sides.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Details of the German fire bomb, described as "one of the most, if not the most, efficient bomb ever devised," have just been disclosed by the Army's Chemical Warfare Service.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 14:

Two silver loving cups, a paid-up insurance policy, a thirteenth century stained glass window and a grant of $700 by an anonymous donor for "a special study" were among the gifts to Columbia University during the last four months. In all, 119 cash donations aggregating $288,718 were received.

N.Y.U.'s football squad held indoor and outdoor workouts yesterday, but while the routine in the gymnasium differed from that on Ohio Field, the oral background, as supplied by Scout Buffer Collins, was the same in both places.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Leon Henderson, OPM Civilian Supply Director, gave orders today that automobile production in January should be reduced by "at least 51 per cent," and warned the automotive industry that sufficient materials for the 204,848 passenger cars permitted under the OPM program, might not be available.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 15 -- "One Hour of Glory," Mary Roberts Rinehart's character study of a retired small-town business man who visits Washington, D.C., was purchased today by RKO from Warner Brothers as a vehicle for Thomas Mitchell.

From going-away suit to bridal gown a comprehensive bridal trousseau in wool was presented to members of the New York Junior League at a luncheon held in the league's clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street yesterday. The presentation was made by the Bureau of Fashion Trends.

A year ago today more than 16,000,000 young Americans registered under the first compulsory military service law ever passed in this country in time of peace. About one out of every twenty who registered is now in the Army. Last August the increasingly critical situation made it necessary to give the President authority to retain drafted men for a maximum period of thirty months.

News more startling than "popinjay" hair-dos and topaz tints electrified the hundreds of hairdressers from all over the nation at their Official Show and Hairdressers Convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. A telegram from Wilmington, Del., informed them that a long-pending suit, involving a beauty patent that cost the hairdressers tremendous sums in license fees, has been thrown out of court.

Acting in sympathy with the weak trend in other commodity markets, the cotton market yesterday lost ground sharply under liquidation operations that were prompted by the uncertainty of the domestic and international situation.

Last Summer Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia reorganized the State Board of Regents in order to get rid of Dean Walter D. Cocking of the University of Georgia's College of Education. Dean Cocking is a distinguished educator who seems to have offended the Governor, first by being born in Iowa, second by being somewhat less than antediluvian in his theories of education.

A reflection on the continued usefulness of the State Transit Commission, made by Council President Newbold Morris, brought a retort that the agency had saved the city millions of dollars in transit unification from Mr. Morris's opponent for the Council Presidency, Transit Commissioner M. Maldwtn Perttg, in an unscheduled debate yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15-Donald M. Nelson told the Senate committee today that the government was preparing to move speedily to take over large stocks of critical defense metals, some of them "undoubtedly" owned by Axis citizens, in this country.

BERLIN, Oct. 15 -- Masses of German infantry were deploying before Moscow today in preparation for the storming of the Soviet capital's outermost defenses in a frontal attack, it was indicated tonight in authorized German quarters here.

Lou Little, Columbia's football coach, has become known as a pre-game pessimist, so a visitor to the Lion's den who attempts to sound out the Professor on the prospects of an approaching Saturday cannot expect to receive a response tinged with overconfidence.

LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 16 -- Seven British bombers and one fighter failed to return home yesterday from daylight sweeps over German-occupied territory, during which the raiders destroyed live Messerschmitts, bombed the waterfront at Havre, France, and strafed shipping off the Netherland coast.

A comprehensive survey of a city-wide abortion racket in which nearly 250,000 illegal operations are performed yearly and their practitioners amass earnings averaging $25,000 annually was handed up in presentment form in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's extraordinary grand jury.

PASCAGOULA, Miss., Oct. 15 (U.P.) -- Bryce P. Holcombe, Federal labor conciliator, announced tonight that an agreement had been reached for resumption of work at the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation's yards here, where 3,000 workers have been idle three days because of a strike of 400 welders

Stringent curtailment of nondefense expenditures and support of a pay-as-you-go policy in New York State, so that residents may more easily meet increasing Federal taxes, were urged yesterday by Abbot Low Moffat, chairman of the State Assembly Ways and Means Committee in an address to members of the Women's Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

A long workout held by Fordham yesterday in the rain was featured by light contact work, the first this week, between the first eleven and reserves, Coach Jim Crowley having decided to avoid hard scrimmaging for the present. Except for Al Santilli, who has a dislocated elbow, the squad is in fine shape and Crowley is fearful lest injuries in practice cost him key men.

Two new films will open in local houses this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall "All That Money Can Buy," a picturization of the Stephen Vincent Benet story "The Devil and Daniel Webster," will be the new attraction. Produced and directed by William Dieterle, the drama, which is being released through RKO, features Walter Huston, Edward Arnold, Simone Simon, Anne Shirley, James Craig, Jane Darwell, Gene Lockhart and John Qualen.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Although the needs of the British people for American milk, eggs, cheese and pork products are as vital as munitions for defense purposes, there is no danger of rationing these products in this country, Dr. M.L. Wilson, director of nutrition for the Department of Agriculture, told members of the National Association of Food Chains at their annual convention here today.

Harry E. Ward, president of the Irving Trust Company, will celebrate today the fortieth anniversary of his association with the bank and its predecessor institution, the New York National Exchange Bank. In the four decades Mr. Ward has risen from the post of clerk in an obscure bank serving the wholesale produce district to head of the ninth largest bank in Wall Street.
Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, made public a seven-page reply yesterday to the Council committee Investigating Mm, calling its report a "fraud and a farce."

Gloves are now presenting the most acute delivery problem in the men's furnishings field, and many lots scheduled for shipment for the Fall and Winter selling season will not be made, buyers reported here yesterday. Many shipments originally scheduled to start on Sept. 1 have not yet been made and all delivery schedules have been correspondingly moved ahead by six weeks to two to three months.
The Russians continued to sell their lives dearly yesterday, but the German tanks still rumbled on.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- A broad program for improving administration of materials distribution, preserving small business and avoiding injustices and discrimination in priorities was outlined today to a special Senate committee investigating national defense by Donald M. Nelson, OPM Priorities Director and Executive Director of the Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Hand-picked for their ability to handle weapons and equipment and for their military bearing fifty-nine enlisted men of the Twenty-ninth Infantry Regiment of Fort Benning arrived here today to become the infantry detachment of the military academy.

An increase of one-half cent a quart in the delivered price of milk was forecast by distributors last night as an aftermath of a decision by David A. Morse, impartial chairman of the milk industry, awarding wage increases of $2.50 a week to 17,000 workers in the metropolitan area.

Copper Items Start to Disappear In advance of the expected SPAB order curtailing the production on numerous non-essential items of copper and brass, manufacturers have begun to tell dealers that they are out of certain items. One buyer sought a small quantity of copper lighters yesterday and was told that the last shipment had been made from the factory and that in the future none would be available.

The Republican campaign for the November general election was begun officially in New Jersey yesterday and the starting gun for the Democrats of Hudson County also was fired. In former years, before Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City gave up the titular leadership of the State Democratic organization because of his quarrel with Governor Edison over the railroad tax compromise, Hudson County was the scene of the opening rally for the Democrats.

To stimulate interest among the city's pupils in the political campaign, the Board of Education will be sponsor for a series of meetings within the schools, where representatives of Mayor La Guardia and District Attorney O'Dwyer will debate issues involved in the Mayoralty election.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after oil charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most coses are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

Two members of Local 856 of the International Longshoremen's Union were arraigned in Special Sessions yesterday as loan sharks in a racket in which Assistant District Attorneys Thomas F. Moore Jr. and Alexander Dreiband said union workers "along the riverfronts in the last few years paid $200,000 usurious interest charges on loans.

ALEXIS THOMPSON is hobbling about on crutches these days, as unsteady on his pins as his Philadelphia Eagles are on the football field. His only consolation is that time will weld together both his broken ankle and the youthful Eagle squad.

The joint executive committee of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, voted last night to endorse Mayor La Guardia for reelection, despite the union's still unsatisfied demands on his administration. The committee's action was taken at a meeting of about 600 officers, section heads and stewards at Transport Hall, 153 West Sixty-fourth Street.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 15 -- The Serbian Chetnik armies are distributing huge arsenals of rifles, machine guns and ammunition to the peasantry throughout Serbia, Bosnia and Montenegro, and, with the withdrawal of all German armored equipment from Yugoslavia to the Eastern Front, today's reports to foreign military intelligence sources here say that open warfare is now under way against the Germans and Italians in three-fourths of the country.

The Continental Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended Sept. 30 a net profit of $294,592. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.31 each on 200,561 shares of no-par common stock.

The United States and Foreign Securities Corporation had net assets on Sept. 30 of $29,242,359, according to a pamphlet report issued yesterday. This figure was equivalent to $169 for each share of first preferred stock, against $163 on June 30 last and $159 a share at the end of last year.
BRAZZAVILLE, Middle Congo, French Equatorial Africa, Oct. 13 (Delayed) -- An American flag is being flown here. It was fashioned by well-intentioned if untutored native labor.
Food enterprises were prominent in the business leasing yesterday. Two of the rentals covered ground-floor space for restaurants in the East Forties.
Sales of tenements and residential properties by banking institutions featured the Bronx realty trading yesterday.

VICHY, France, Oct. 15 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain proposes to frame a new constitution for France in which universal suffrage will give place to a form of hierarchical group representation. This plan, however, is to proceed slowly in preparing the new framework of the State, which would be made operative only after mature study and reflection.
A number of large states, several penthouses and a duplex, were taken by lessees listed in the rental activity reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 - In spite of recent recommendation made by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, to the effect that conventions In Washington be discontinued until the end of the emergency, many national women's organizations are planning to descend on the crowded capital during the Winter and Spring.

Replying to the speech of Lleutenant Governor Charles Polettl in support of District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic Mayoralty candidate, in which he referred to Mr. La Guardia as a part-time Mayor, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, declared yesterday that Mr. Poletti was using his spare time to build up his private law practice and should be called "Part-Time Charlie."

Retailers have been meeting their October payments to manufacturers and wholesalers in a "good to satisfactory" fashion, but a more decisive test of credit developments will come between now and Nov. 15, when larger seasonal maturities fall due, credit authorities here said yesterday.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 17 (U.P.) -- foreign diplomats and part of the Soviet Government apparently have evacuated Moscow, leaving Premier Joseph Stalin and other leaders behind to direct the defense of the seat of world communism, it was reported today.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Between airplane trips Tommy Harmon, Tormer Michigan star back, worked out today for his debut with the New York Americans at the Yankee Stadium on Sunday against the Columbus Bulls.

The reorganization managers of the Wabash Railway issued yesterday a call for deposits of securities affected by the recapitalization. They urged that deposits be made by Nov. 15 so that the company could be sold at foreclosure on Dec. 1.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Herbert H. Cox Jr., 16, of Alexandria, Va., was held here tonight as "a fugitive from justice" after an alleged confession that he had shot and Killed a middle-aged man early Monday morning in an automobile parked on a Maryland roadside and had hidden the body in a thicket.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday Oct. 17 -- "Fighting continued along the entire front but particularly heavily in the sectors west of the capital; during the fight in this direction very heavy losses have been suffered on both sides." In these words the Russian communique of last midnight summed up the situation on the Eastern Front as the battle of Moscow entered the fifth day of its "decisive stage."

The first joint conference looking toward settlement of the strike of newsdealers against eight morning and afternoon newspapers will be held at 11 o'clock this morning in the offices of the State Mediation Board, 250 West Fifty-seventh Street, Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the board, announced last night.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 16 -- After a day of involved legal proceedings, Mayor Joseph Stilz, Town Attorney Irwin Rubenstein and Police Chief John Rooney, all officials of West New York, were free in their own custody tonight following their arrest on charges of false swearing.

Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley, Bronx Democrat, sent a stiff demand yesterday to Dr. Harold Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, for the immediate discontinuance of "political propaganda now being so actively conducted in our public high and elementary schools on behalf of the Fusion mayoralty ticket."

In the sharpest break in several years, the cotton market yesterday declined as much as $6.10 a bale under the impact of international developments. Exceptionally heavy trade buying, however, brought about a recovery during which prices regained about one-half of their losses.

The investigation of war propaganda in motion pictures being conducted by a committee of United States Senators was denounced yesterday as "bigoted," "one-sided" and" a "sad spectacle" by Mayor La Guardia in a talk to the Association of Motion Picture Advertisers at the Hotel Edison.

Marking the founding or the first birth-control center in the United States, twenty-six meetings were held throughout the country last night under the auspices of the Birth Control Federation of America, the National Committee for Planned Parenthood and other civic groups.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 17 -- Cologne was attacked by the Royal Air Force through bad weather in the hours before dawn yesterday while the docks at Boulogne were hammered at the same time by other British bombers. The R.A.F. reported the loss of three machines in these operations.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 16 -- The War Council of the Australian Cabinet conferred today with Air Marshal Sir Robert Brooke-Popham, British Commander in Chief for the Far East, who has arrived here from Singapore. He outlined plans to strengthen the already vastly improved defenses stretching from India to New Zealand.

With the production of "Hotel Splendide," Richard Rodgers, the composer, will branch out as co-producer of the musical with Dwight Deere Wiman. Before arriving on Broadway, the show will spend Christmas and New Year's weeks in Boston.
Two apartment houses were among the residential properties taken by new owners in yesterday's reports of activity in the Bronx.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Brawny, soldily built football warriors who would gladden the heart of many a college coach are numerous on the Blair Academy campus again and they already have attained two impressive victories to give the Blue a fine start toward another banner campaign.

Harassed homemakers, who have grown dizzy watching the foods they buy at the dairy counters climb upward, are promised a respite this week-end by the Consumer's Service Bureau of the Department of Markets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- In one of the most comprehensive orders it ever has issued, the Supply, Priorities and Allocation Board today assured the production and wholsale branches of industry sufficient maintenance and repair materials to keep their plants in good running order.

Security and commodity markets dramatically mirrored yesterday the feeling in financial circles that a "zero hour" was fast approaching in the whole international situation. Prices of commodities suffered a wide-open break, with grains off as far as trading rules would permit, while stocks widened their recent declines as much as 3 points.
Dr. J. Ivimey Dowling has sold his estate in Bridgehampton, L.I., to George Nebolsine of New York City, a former tenant there, according to Previews, Inc.

To the gratification of the audience assembled, the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, performing last night under the baton of Leopold Stokowski in Carnegie Hall, again played like a first-class orchestra. This had not been the case the preceding Thursday night, when the Philharmonic-Symphony opened its 100th season.

LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Major Gen. George H. Brett, chief of the United States Army Air Corps, said today the Near East war front was being "completely refurnished with American aircraft as rapidly as possible." He described British pilots as "tremendously pleased."

The football Giants were pretty slow to adopt it, but yesterday they followed an old radio trend by installing a quiz program in their practice session. Stout Steve Owen took over the role of master of ceremonies, but he never had a chance to ask a $64 question.

Charles E. Murphy, campaign manager for the three Democratic city-wide candidates, announced last night that Dr. Emanuel M. Josephson, who had made charges against the Health Department, was no longer associated with the O'Dwyer-Church-Fertig campaign in "any way whatsoever."

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct 16 -- Students of political trends, particularly as related to foreign policy, will give major attention this Fall to two elections -- the New York mayoralty and the Congressional campaign in the Fifteenth Pennsylvania district.

Two pictures opening today in Broadway houses will complete the week's roster of new film arrivals. At the Globe, the newcomer will be "Target for Tonight," a factual pictorial account of a British bomber plane in action over Germany, made with the cooperation of the R.A.F.

While the strike front of the American Federation of Musicians against the National and Columbia broadcasting systems spread yesterday to include San Francisco, Los Angeles and Hollywood, the union's "out" order to NBC musicians on sustaining programs at Radio City did not materialize.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- A plea by Senator Wheeler for a seven-man committee to plan for cushioning the national economy against possible dislocations after the war emergency touched off a Senate debate today over international affairs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The war Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 15:

Mrs. William Gage Brady Jr. gave a luncheon yesterday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for her debutante daughter, Miss Barbara Brady. The other guests were Mrs. John L. Homer and the Misses Louise Hutchinson, Florence Bigelow, Joan Thorne, Helen Louise McChristie, Clara Jane Thomas, Peggy Keasley, Elizabeth Tomes, Mildred C. Harrison, Patricia L. Lehmann, Sallie Cronkhite, Nancy Pike and Catherine Carlisle.

A twenty-year-old girl from Minneapolis, anxious to learn first aid, Spanish, and how to combat fifth column techniques, was the first to enroll yesterday morning in a nation-wide mobilization for civilian defense of young persons not in military service.

PANAMA, Oct. 16 -- Negotiations between Panama and the United States relating to defense of the Panama Canal, reported to have broken down at the time of the recent visit of the then Foreign Minister Raul de Roux to Washington, are to be renewed soon by Panama's new government, it is learned.

BOOTH TARKINGTON'S "The Fighting Littles" is light Indian Summer reading -- a collection of sometimes hilarious sketches about a rather rambunctious household by an indefatigable historian of adolescence.

Living costs throughout the nation have gone up 8.1 per cent since August, 1939, the month before the outbreak of the European war, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday. The biggest rise, 18.7 per cent, was recorded in food.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Somewhere in the United States today an artist is on the threshold of fame and possibly fortune -- but he doesn't know it yet. The only thing which the public knows about him now is that he is an American citizen, an artist who has never hung a canvas in the Carnegie International Exhibition here, and that $1,000 awaits him.

Charles Walzer, operator, has purchased from the Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Association, through L.V. Hoffman Co., Inc., brokers, the, four-story and basement walkup tenement at 45-9 Mitchell Place, White Plains, Westchester.

Two primary considerations ought to guide American policy in the new crisis which seems plainly to be indicated by the sudden resignation of the Japanese Cabinet and the fact that Prince Konoye apparently has been succeeded by a fire-eater. In the first place, it is clear that we cannot afford, no matter what new hazards face us, to abandon the position we have taken against Japanese aggression in the East.
BERLIN, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The German High Command communique, from the Fuehrer's headquarters said today:

Being in a hospitable mood, the American Foundation of the Blind invited the drama critics in yesterday afternoon to hear a "talking book" record of Maxwell Anderson's "Elizabeth the Queen." From almost every point of view, this turned out to be an excellent idea.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The nation's ten largest steel producers did a $2,930,000,000 business last year and paid out $7,240,000 to their officers and directors the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. The volume of business compared with sales aggregating $2,254,000,000 in 1939, when salaries and other remuneration for top men totaled $6,117,000.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Russia's Far Eastern Army remains virtually intact and stands ready to face any eventuality arising from the Cabinet crisis in Japan, a Soviet source in London said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The War Department announced today the award of supply contracts amounting to $5,335,458. Among those were the following, not previously published, which went to companies in the New York area:

LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- For the seventh consecutive week the Bank of England reported an increase in note circulation and in each instance established a new high record. Today's figures stood at L686,063,000, an increase of L2,744,000.

ALBANY, Oct. 16 -- Governor Lehman told women from local defense councils of the State today that their work must coordinate all community activities in a unifying plan which would present an undivided front against nazism.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- The attitude of the Westchester County and the New Rochelle Leagues of Women Voters toward league officers who become active isolationists as members of the America First Committee received endorsement inferentially today from Miss Marguerite M. Wells of Minneapolis, president of the National League of Women Voters.

The youth of America must win two victories: first the total defeat of Hitler, and then the victory of peace, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, said last night in an address at the National Youth Day rally at the Hotel Commodore.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The besieged Russian port of Odessa is being destroyed by flames within defense lines manned by every man, woman or child able to bear arms, Rumanian military dispatches declared tonight. They said flames hundreds of feet high could be seen for miles, lighting scenes of confusion and ruin.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Oct. 16 -- Weakness developed on the Bourse today with small offerings meeting practically no demand. The close was at the levels with losses running to 11 points. Royal Dutch was 10 1/2 points lower at 301; Amsterdam Trading was 11 down at 471 1/2 ; Amsterdam Rubber 8 off at 302 1/2 ; Philips 8 at 255; Unilever 3 1/2 at 154 3/8, and A.K.U. 1 1/4 at 145.

Market Wise, the thoroughbred who was practically "thrown in" with the sale of other horses about a year ago, captured the $16,925 Gallant Fox Handicap as Jamaica closed yesterday, bringing his winnings to $77,965 on the year. Louis Tufano, the owner, and Trainer G. W. Carroll proudly watched the 3-year-old son of Brokers Tip stride through the stretch to win very easily by eight lengths.

Your correspondent covering the aviation manoeuvres went yesterday to the Information Center of the First Interceptor Command "somewhere in New York" -- the address may not be printed, as it is a military secret -- to find out who won the air battle over Manhattan.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- Wide breaks in the grain and soy bean markets carried prices off the permissible limits for one day's trading, and while there was a moderate rally from the low point on corn, other grains closed weak with wheat and rye off 10 centa a bushel, the limit, and soy beans were 7 3/4 to 8 cents lower.

Despite the fanfare and warfare surrounding Ossie Solem's Y formation, the Syracuse team he will send against N.Y.U. tomorrow at the Yankee Stadium remains an exponent of conservative Eastern football. This sits well with N.Y.U., which will not soon forget its unhappy attempt to match Texas A. and M. at the helter-skelter Southwestern brand last week.

The government moved toward completion of its case yesterday in the Brooklyn espionage trial with the presentation of evidence designed to link Leo Waalen, one of the defendants, with a Nazi spy ring that operated in this country for more than sixteen months.

United States Senator Robert F. Wagner has accepted the honorary chairmanship of the Labor and Progressive Committee for the election of William O'Dwyer, Democratic Mayoralty nominee, and his running mates, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct 16 -- Latin-American countries will get about $150,000,000 in aid for the construction of defense bases and other military purposes if Congress approves the pending Lease-Lend Bill, authoritative quarters said today.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Anybody want to buy a bridge ?
NEW YORK Mrs. Heyward Cutting will give a tea dance on Dec. 6 at the Colony Club to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Constance Cleveland Cutting.
Declaring that there was but one issue in the campaign, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said yesterday that the voters of the city had only this question to answer:

LONDON, Oct. 16 (U.P.) -- The first impression in London following news of the fall of the Japanese Government was that the new Cabinet being formed in Tokyo would pursue a policy of more active cooperation with the Axis than its predecessors.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 (AP) -- After a siege in which the defenders at times and at certain open points of their line fought from behind barricades of their own dead, the Black Sea port of Odessa fell today to the Axis, according to official German and Rumanian announcements.

Plans for the 110th anniversary fund campaign for $110,000 of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society were announced yesterday at the home of James W. Gerard, general chairman of the campaign, at 1014 Fifth Avenue.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Charles T. (Tommy) Davis, former head of a surgical supply firm, is seeking $307,625 from E.F. Hutton Co., brokers, contending that his transactions with the firm in 1933 and 1934 were invalid because he had been adjudged insane in New York.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 16 -- An embargo on "politics, personalities, ancient grudges and economic revolutions," in order to realize the "tremendous potential power of the American machine" in defense, was suggested tonight in an address by Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks for New York City, at the annual dinner of the American Institute of Steel Construction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Department store sales for the week ended Oct. 11 were 13 per cent higher than for the corresponding period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Sales in the week ended Oct. 4 were up 35 per cent (revised).

The College of Literature, Science and the Arts was established at Ann Arbor in 1841. Thence has grown the assemblage of thirteen or so colleges and schools that compose the University of Michigan, first of those remarkable American State institutions to become in the full sense a university.
SEATTLE, Oct. 16 -- The American Federation of Labor endorsed at its convention today the supplying of "all material and assistance possible" to Soviet Russia, "a peopl brutally attacked."

ALBANY, Oct. 16 -- Declaring that the democracies must oppose "the slavery of a Pax Germanica," Dr. Leland Rex Robinson, as principal speaker today at the opening session of the convocation of the University of the State of New York, called upon business and government, aided by science, to point the way to a new international order.

An industry-wide health insurance program covering 140,000 workers engaged in the manufacture of men's clothing has been agreed upon by representatives of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C.I.O., and the United States Clothing Manufacturers Association, the union announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Red armies, admittedly breached and bleeding on the approaches to imperiled Moscow, fought on today with undiminished ferocity. The Russians claimed a heavy toll of the assaulting Germans even while acknowledging great losses of their own.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The importance of radio in the dissemination of news was further attested at today's Federal Communications Commission hearing of press-radio relationships by Herbert Moore, president of the Trans-radio News Service, and Joseph V. Connolly, president of King Features, Inc., of which the International News Service is a subsidiary.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed gold holdings and Reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- The railroads ended today the presentation of their case in the dispute with 1,200,000 employes over wages and working rules.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 16 -- Republic has signed James Ellison for the lead in "Mr. District Attorney and the Carter Case" and has borrowed Marjorie Weaver from Twentieth Century-Fox to play opposite him. The picture will start on Tuesday, with Bernard Vorhaus directing.

The editorial board of the Book-of-the-Month Club has chosen for January distribution a novel of seventeenth century France by Arthur Meeker Jr. entitled "The Ivory Mischief." It is a Houghton Mifflin publication that was to have come out Oct. 28.

NELLS ISLAND, Conn., Oct. 16 -- There may be those who will say Kipling was using poetic license when he said "the dawn comes up like thunder," but no gunner who was present today on the marsh that is Nells Island, at the mouth of the Housatonic in Connecticut, will contest the poet's statement.

Speaking in Tammany Hall to an audience composed almost entirely of precinct workers in the Tammany organization, District Attorney William O'Dwyer declared last night his complete independence of political machines and political bosses.

The split between the Democratic State organization and the State organization of the American Labor party over the nominations for State Controller grew more serious yesterday as the Labor party stood by its determination to nominate no one but an A.L.P. member, and the Democrats, up to late last night at least remained committed to the nomination of Assemblyman Robert F. Wagner Jr.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- About 2,000 or virtually all of the National Guard officers of captain or lower grades who are being removed from active troop commands will be transferred to the Army air forces for ground duties so as to release many officer-pilots for flight duties, Secretary Stimson said today.

VICHY, France, Oct. 16 -- General Maxime Weygand, Vichy's pro-consul in Africa, arrived here today by air for Saturday's Cabinet meeting. It is doubtful whether the customary communique will mention French-German relations; but the fact remains that, as bulletins from the Russian front stress German successes, French-German relations take on added importance.

A baby-faced youth of 220 pounds displacement walked with a slight limp across the Fordham practice field yesterday and came within the ken of Jim Crowley, parked in a parka in a huddle of chilled newspaper men.

In one of the speediest verdicts ever reached in General Sessions Irving Sherman, 48 years old, a confidence man with a "knowledge" of the law acquired in Sing Sing, was found guilty in three minutes yesterday of a check forgery by which he bad tried to use the State Insurance Fund to perpetuate a fraud.

Asserting that rayon weavers have so consistently confined their output to large converters that goods are piling up in warehouses while many medium and small converters are unable to obtain any yardage, Irving Alexander of I. Alexander Co., Inc., converters, said yesterday that he has drafted a plan for government allocation of rayon greige goods and that he was arranging for a conference with the Office of Price Administration to discuss the plan.

The gasoline rationing order for October, issued by Donald M. Nel- son, Director of Priorities for OPM, does not revoke the "curfew" recommendation of Secretary Ickes, Defense Petroleum Coordinator, it was announced, here yesterday by Liouis H. Spiner, Director of Marketing in the new district No. 1 office in the Chanin Building, Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Letters, in one of which former President Hoover criticized Secretary Hull for opposing the shipment of food to the German-occupied countries, and asserted that the United States was adopting "the British policy of starvation and death to these democratic peoples," were made public by Senator Capper today.
Bank clearings in the weekended on Wednesday continued to exceed the total of the corresponding week the year before, although the turnover fell $608,480,000 below that for the preceding week.
Figures for July and August released yesterday by the Port of New York Authority show that the number of ships clearing New York Harbor continue to exceed those listed for 1940.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- History is not in the least likely to repeat itself in the consideration of the armed ship bill by the present Congress. Even if opposing Senators should attempt the filibuster they have abjured in advance, the present bill cannot be ''killed by the Constitution" as its ancestor was in 1917.

As the week's air manoeuvres of the First Interceptor Command came to an end yesterday, high Army officials looked out over a theoretically bombed part of Lower Manhattan, studied reports of damage to other cities of the Eastern seaboard, and then pronounced the fledgling Aircraft Warning Service, manned by thousands of civilian volunteers, a success.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- An allotment of $55,777,000 for an expansion of the production of pig iron, coke, open-hearth steel ingots and plates by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation was announced today by Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator.

Commodity Prices Break The commodity futures market had yesterday the worst day in several years. Most of the grains declined the limits permitted for any one session and sharp declines were registered in cotton, cottonseed oil and lard.

Hopeful of victory, a Manhattan football squad of thirty-two players will leave by train this morning for Boston, where it will engage Boston College tomorrow afternoon at Fenway Park. Coach Herb Kopf named the players who will make the trip after a spirited two-hour drill in game uniform yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Army's football players tonight ended the real work for their first major engagement, the game with Yale in the Bowl on Saturday. Working on the old parade grounds above the windswept reaches of the Hudson, the cadets spent a long afternoon under the eyes and voices of their new staff of coaches.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Backed into odds-on-favoritism, E. R. Bradley's Better Hurry had to do a lot of hurrying and a lot of driving to win by a neck in the Corsica Purse today.

Newspapers in twice as many metropolitan areas as last year will be used by Webster-Eisenlohr, Inc., for Webster cigars in its Fall campaign starting this week, Everett Meyer, president, announced yesterday. The newspaper list will be the largest ever used by the company.

Mayor La Guardia contended yesterday that his Democratic opponents were conducting the Mayoralty campaign "without regard to facts," and that orders had gone out from Democratic leaders to all candidates and supporters of the Democratic municipal ticket to "say anything, charge anything and call any names," in an attempt to discredit his administration.
"They sure have gone up!" was the sober analysis of food prices made yesterday by ten energetic 10-year-olds gathered to work out solutions for this problem.

The first appreciable break in the determination of cotton mills to refuse to sell at current ceiling prices occurred yesterday when, faced with a sharp break in the raw cotton market, a few mills sold several small lots of print cloths and sheetings which probably aggregated something more than 2,500,000 yards.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A broad denial was issued by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today of charges that the United States Government engineered the coup d'etat that unseated Dr. Arnulfo Arias as President of Panama.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 16 -- A vivid and in some ways surprising picture of Greece under Axis occupation is provided by detailed accounts given by refugees and travelers, including neutral officials, reaching Egypt recently by devious routes.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- A national civilian protection bureau, administered independently of the War Department, was recommended here today by Harry Prince of New York City, in an address before the fourth annual convention of the New York State Association of Architects.

ROME, Oct. 16 (U.P.) -- Benito Mussolini's newspaper said today that the fall of Moscow -- which it predicted as imminent -- would not end either Russian resistance or Anglo-American hostility, and that the war probably would develop into an endurance contest.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 -- Odessa, the Soviet Union's largest Black Sea port and the first of the four big Western Soviet cities to be enveloped in the war in the East, fell to Rumanian troops this afternoon after a two months' siege, a special German High Command communique from Adolf Hitler's headquarters announced tonight.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 17 -- The third Cabinet of Prince Fumimaro Konoye has resigned because of a division of opinion among the Ministers regarding policies to be pursued in meeting what is termed here the greatest crisis Japan has faced in all her long history.

Though Dr. John L. Rice has replied effectively to the reckless attack which has been made on his administration of the city's Health Department, any lingering doubts about the work that he has done should be dispelled by a record which speaks for itself. The city's health is the best in its history.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Mrs. Richard Hellmann of Scaradale won low gross honors in the last weekly one-day tournament on the schedule of the Women's Weatchester and Fairfield Golf Association by playing the south course of the Westchester Country Club in 41, 43 -- 84 today.

Food and exercise British food resources are strained, of course, but it is not really a correct picture of things when our own Under-Secretary of Agriculture loses more than thirteen pounds in the course of a few weeks in Great Britain.

In an effort to obtain more nearly adequate appropriations for the support of the city's public libraries, the Readers Association of the New York Public Library has sent a questionnaire to all candidates for the offices of Mayor, Controller, President of the Council and presidents of the boroughs of the Bronx, Manhattan and Richmond, asking their policy and attitude toward libraries.

MOSCOW, Oct. 13 (Delayed) -- Fully aware that this will in all probability be a long war -- as the press has constantly been careful to remind the Soviet people -- the government has completed initial plans and is making new ones for the industrial and economic reorganization of the vast central and eastern provinces to afford food and industrial production to substitute for that of regions lost to the first impetus of German invasion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- While the House in a nine-hour session today debated revision of the Neutrality Act to permit the arming of American, merchant vessels, the Navy Department announced that the United States would turn over to Great Britain under the lease-lend act two over-age, recommissioned submarines, both of which are now operating in the Atlantic.

Seven indignant would-be Atlantic air passengers gathered in the rotunda of the Pan American Airways marine terminal at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon and tried almost in one voice to learn why the Atlantic Clipper was leaving without them.

Passing, punting and dummy scrimmage drills featured Columbia's practice yesterday at Baker Field as the Lions tapered off for the Georgia game here tomorrow. Judging by the length of time paid by Coach Lou Little to aerials, the uptown gridiron will be the scene of a wide-open contest.

Shields Co. received yesterday the award of an issue of $325,060 of capital improvement, relief and emergency bonds of the town of Stamford, Conn., on an interest-cost basis of 1.11 per cent. The successful bid was 100.173 for $150,000 as is and $175,000 as 1 1/4 s.

Elizabeth Lee Wheaton, who knows all about the life of Texas City, Texas (population 5,748), and whose study of one side of it has resulted in a prize-winning novel, met one side of New York for the first time yesterday.

VICHY, Oct. 16 (U.P.) -- Four men, believed to be terrorists, have seized 100 pounds of dynamite from a quarry near Chantilly, twenty miles north of Paris, it was announced here today. The dynamite was taken by four young men who escaped from the quarry before the police could intervene.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, yesterday afternoon received a plaque and scroll for his work in behalf of "Americanism" and law and order at a luncheon in the American Legion headquarters, 160 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- United States troops in Iceland are under their own commander and any attack on that island would be defended by the United States and British troops "by cooperation" rather than through a joint military command, Secretary Stimson informed Senator Vandenberg today in response to the latter's request to clear up the status of our soldiers there.

The Citizens Union urged voters yesterday to vote "yes" on Proposition 1 for county reorganization and "no" on Propositions 2 and 3, the alternative county reform proposals put forward by the Democratic organizations.

A collection of eighty wartime editorials from THE NEW YORK TIMES appears in book form today under the title, "Days of Decision." Edited and with an introduction by Charles Merz, editor of THE TIMES, the collection is published by Doubleday, Doran Co., Inc.

In the widest increase since the final week in May, the earning assets of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City rose $121,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a new record high at $12,309,000,000.

Tax-Exempt Gifts to Benefit Some merchandisers here believe that gift items not subject to the new retail excise taxes will meet with added consumer favor during the Christmas selling period. A trend of this nature is expected particularly to benefit lingerie, which is free from such taxes and which normally ranks as one of the major gift merchandise classifications.

WINNIPEG, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Frank Calder, president of the National Hockey League, conferred today, with the Manitoba Divisional War Services Board in an effort to gain permission for hockey players to get passports to the United States, but afterward said he did not believe the board would change its position.

Sidney R. Kent, motion picture executive who has been described as a heavy contributor toward the $550,000 alleged to have been extorted from the movie industry by George E. Browne and William Bioff, is dangerously ill and will be unable to testify at the trial of the two men in Federal Court, it was disclosed yesterday.

VICHY, France, Oct. 16 -- Charged with having failed in their official duties and engaged France in the war unprepared, General Maurice Gamelin, ex-Premiers Edouard Daladier, Leon Blum and Paul Reynaud, and former Minister of Interior Georges Mandel, have been ordered confined in the Pyrenees fortress of Pourtalet by the verdict of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, announced here tonight in a broadcast to the nation.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 16 -- An explosion, believed due to natural causes, brought death to two men and critically injured two others at 12:45 P.M. today at the plant of the National Magnesium Corporation here, one of this country's main producers of magnesium powder used in manufacturing flares, tracer bullets and incendiary bombs.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 16 -- Independent investigation, following recent announcement that Dr. Alexander Dorner would not return as director of the Rhode Island School of Design Museum, has established that Dr. Dorner is an outspoken opponent of nazism and as such is a refugee in this country from the Hitler regime.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The British tonight had to adjust themselves to the fact that the Russian Government seems to have left Moscow and that the Soviet capital must be defended street by street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 11 totaled 903,877 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 13,639 cars or 1.5 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, but 91,971 cars or 11.3 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 63,925 cars, or 7.6 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

At this crucial hour of the Battle for Russia the stand of Moscow is less important than the stand of Joseph Stalin. He is the key figure of the drama; on the decisions he is taking now hang the immediate fate of Russia and the future course of the war.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 -- Reports that Fritz Thyssen, the former Ruhr industrialist and coal magnate, was confined in a German concentration camp were authoritatively denied today. The man who financed the National Socialist party in the days of its early struggles and then went into exile abroad when the war broke out, allegedly as a protest against the Reich's foreign policy, is now being held in "private custody" in Southern Germany.

The Jooss Ballet, in its final fortnight at Maxine Elliott's Theatre, presented still another new work last night. It is "Chronica," which Kurt Jooss created two years ago after reading in a sixteenth century manuscript the story of a "dictator" who repented of his cruelty and did away with himself.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 -- German infantry and engineers, moving under a veil of intense artillery and air bombardments, today began storming the outermost defenses of Moscow, sixty miles west of the Kremlin walls on a direct line, according to information available in Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- A new financing plan, under which the Treasury Department will do all the borrowing for the government and lend funds as needed to such other Federal bodies as the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Commodity Credit and the United States Housing agencies, is under study by his department, Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. said at his press conference today.

Business and professional circles were represented in the listings of new apartment tenancies yesterday, with executives of utility, transportation and advertising concerns as well as figures of the stage signing for new quarters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The United States Government was calm but determined today in the face of a possibility that ultranationalists, eager for further conquests, might take over direction of affairs in Japan, where the government of Prince Fumimaro Konoye resigned after having been under fire of extremists.

Contending that the city should prepare a program of large-scale construction to take up the slack in employment after the present defense emergency ends, the City Planning Commission made public a tentative capital outlay budget for 1942 yesterday calling for a $500,000,000 reservoir of projects to be laid out next year.

The flow of money into mortgage investments in Manhattan rose sharply last month, when the dollar volume advanced on realty in the borough amounted to $3,608,301. The total was made on 107 new loans, compared with 127-new loans in August when the dollar volume invested was $3,176,009.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Persistent reports that the Russian Government, with the possible exception of Premier Joseph Stalin and his immediate retinue, had evacuated Moscow lacked official confirmation here today. If any such word had been received it was cloaked in the official statement that there was nothing to report and that anything of that nature would have to come from the Soviet Government for obvious military reasons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Persistent reports that the Russian Government, with the possible exception of Premier Joseph Stalin and his immediate retinue, had evacuated Moscow lacked official confirmation here today. If any such word had been received it was cloaked in the official statement that there was nothing to report and that anything of that nature would have to come from the Soviet Government for obvious military reasons.

Frederick P. Keppel, president of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, who since 1922 has directed the $135,000,000 trust created by Andrew Carnegie, will retire on Nov. 18, the corporation announced yesterday. Although relinquishing his administrative duties, he will remain as educational adviser to the corporation.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 16 (U.P.) -- A tentative agreement for settlement of the strike at the Midland Steel Products Company which has made at least 14,000 men idle in two automobile plants was announced tonight by James F. Dewey, Federal labor conciliator.

"I have only been doing my day's work." With that typically modest statement did Dr. Charles Armstrong accept the American Public Health Association's significant award, the Sedgwick Memorial Medal. For his fundamental work at the National Institute of Health on the transmission of sleeping sickness, psittacosis and infantile paralysis this Government scientist abundantly merited an honor that automatically classed him with such medical giants as Hans Zinsser and Theobald Smith.
A West Side property that had been in the estate of William J.T. Getty for forty years was sold yesterday to Harry Shure for investment.

The fact that the Treasury received $10,446,000,000 of subscriptions to its offering of 2 1/2 per cent bonds last week should deceive no one into supposing that it could have raised that amount as easily as the $1,200,000,000 actually offered for cash subscription. Subscribers to the new issue knew that they would receive only a fraction of what they asked, so they asked for many times what they wanted.

The steady decline of bankers acceptances outstanding in the United States continued during September, it was disclosed yesterday in the monthly report on the bill market by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. As of Sept. 30, the total of dollar acceptances outstanding was $176,801,000, a decline of $20,671,000 on the month.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 16 -- New steps toward the control of rabies were outlined before the American Public Health Association here today.

MEXICO CITY, Oct 16 -- It was learned here today that the Mexican Government is trying to make a barter agreement for American oil machinery that, if it should win the support of the United States Government, might alter the whole oil situation to the disadvantage of the expropriated American oil companies.

Despite provisions for Federal income and excess profits taxes, which were more than three times those of the similar period last year, earnings of the General Electric Company for the first nine months of this year equaled those of the 1940 period.

One of the nightmares of a college football coach is overconfidence. It's football's fifth column; creeping in like a thief in the night and being particularly virile among teams that have had long winning streaks, teams that are bowl-conscious, teams that have been lauded in pre-season evaluations.

MANILA, Oct. 16 -- Breaking a protracted silence on international affairs, United States High Commissioner Francis B. Sayre told a group of Manila business men today that "gradually the United States is moving closer toward the brink of war."

Major deficiencies in equipment, inadequate air power and the lack of proper coordination between British, French and Belgian armies were contributory factors in the epic tragedy of the Flanders campaign, General Viscount Gort, Commander in Chief of the British Expeditionary Force in France and Belgium in 1939-40, states in his dispatches, made public today.

Despite provisions for Federal income and excess profits taxes, which were more than three times those of the similar period last year, earnings of the General Electric Company for the first nine months of this year equaled those of the 1940 period.

One of the nightmares of a college football coach is overconfidence. It's football's fifth column; creeping in like a thief in the night and being particularly virile among teams that have had long winning streaks, teams that are bowl-conscious, teams that have been lauded in pre-season evaluations.

MANILA, Oct. 16 -- Breaking a protracted silence on international affairs, United States High Commissioner Francis B. Sayre told a group of Manila business men today that "gradually the United States is moving closer toward the brink of war."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Joseph W. Prazer, president of Willys-Overland Motors, has submitted to the Supply, Priorities and Allocation Board and other defense officials a program for restricting automobile production to each company's "lightest weight" model.

With all the difficulty that each of the leading parties is now having to select its politically most eligible candidate for State Controller, this seems as good a time as any to raise the underlying question whether there is any convincing reason why this should be an elective office at all.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Oct. 18 -- As the titanic battle for Moscow entered its seventh day this morning meager reports from a still depleted battery of Moscow radio transmitters indicated some signs of growing optimism among the city's defenders.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct 17 -- Yale will send an eleven against Army here tomorrow which is determined to disprove the growing theory that it is a second-half scoring unit. The regulars have been worked all week on the plan to play at top speed from the opening kick-off against the West Pointers, who have three of the most brilliant backs of the East in Hank Mazur, Jere Maupin and John Hatch.
BERLIN, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A German Sigh Command communique today said:

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The Royal Air Force has something new in store for the German Air Force's much vaunted Messerschmitt 109-F plane, it was learned today. It is the American-built Airacobra fighter machine, one of the most advanced airplanes of its kind anywhere in the world at present.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following today:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 -- Standing off the explosive speed and hitting power of a big, tough Baylor team from Waco, Texas, Villanova remained in the ranks of the unbeaten, with a 14-6 victory before 30,000 at Shibe Park tonight.

A resident of San Salvador, Central America, has bought two four-story apartment houses at 832-34 Washingston Street, Hoboken, N.J., from the McKinley Square Realty Corporation for cash over a mortgage of $51,500 held by the Hoboken Bank for Savings.

The Appellate Division denied unanimously yesterday an application by a stockholder of the American Tobacco Company for a stay of State court proceedings in another stockholders' suit in which Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins granted judgment for $2,168,023 against George W. Hill, president, and four vice presidents of the company.

Prevailing champions were given top places in the national fencing rankings for 1941 announced yesterday by the Amateur Fencers League of America. Dr. Norman C. Armitage, saber ruler, who successfully defended his crown, is the ony repeater from 1940.

Characterizing District Attorney Villiam O'Dwyer's injection of communism into the city campaign as "the bankrupt shouting of a politician who wants to be elected by stirring up prejudice," Eugene P. Connolly last night lamed Paul O'Dwyer, brother of the Democratic Mayoralty candidate, and his law partner, Oscar Bernstien, as those who had approached him to get American Labor party support for the District Attorney.

The arrest yesterday of four union dock workers, two of them ex-convicts, on coercion and assault charges growing out of a recent two-week strike that held up the sailing of a British freighter from West Tenth Street, brought later from District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey the warning: "I shall not tolerate gangster interefrence with the loading of ships on our waterfronts."

Mayor La Guardia contended last night that Governor Lehman's appointment of Joseph V. O'Leary as Controller and the expected nomination of Mr. O'Leary today as the nominee for that position by the American Labor and Democratic parties represented a "complete and abject surrender" on the part of the Flynn-Kelly-Sullivan "machine."
BATES VS. NORTHEASTERN -- Maybe chemical analysis will help. Probably this will give an acid reaction. One light vote for North-eastern.

"This Woman Is Mine" has entered its second week at the Rivoli, and the Russian film, "Musical Story," has started its second week at the Stanley. . . . "Agnoula," a Greek picture, will open a week's engagement tomorrow at the Miami Playhouse. . . . Revivals of the French films, "The Baker's Wife" and "Under the Roofs of Paris," will start a week's run on Monday at the Fifth Avenue Play-house.
NEW YORK Wollmar Bostrom, the Swedish Minister, and Mme. Bostrom are at the Ritz-Carlton.

No Tax on Men's Wear Stressed In order to eliminate confusion in the minds of consumers about retail excise taxes, the Retail Men's Wear Council of New York yesterday suggested that stores represented in the council add a line to advertiseing copy to the effect that "there is no Federal tax on men's suits and overcoats."

An investor purchased yesterday from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company the twelve-story loft building on a plot 87 by 98 feet at 127-33 West Twenty-sixth Street. The property is assessed at $260,000 and was sold through Butler Baldwin, brokers.

Sign-Posts Needed It evens things up when the newspaper book reviewers are compelled to say that you can't believe what you read in the books; and there is no offense taken. Authors now tell you frankly in the preface that part of the time they tell the truth and part of the time they are making things up.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The Whiteface Area Ski Council has issued a pamphlet containing the written endorsements of Governor Herbert H. Lehman, Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne and the Citizens Union of New York for Constitutional Amendment No. 4, the Whiteface Mountain ski amendment.
