What Senator Bankhead of Alabama, in his interview, chiefly objects to in Secretary Morgenthau's recent speech on cotton is the plan to place a "ceiling" on the price. Mr. Morgenthau had pointed out that the price of cotton had risen "not far from 100 per cent" since the war began, although the Government now holds 7,000,000 bales of cotton.

BERLIN, Oct. 17 -- Franco-German conversations have now progressed to the point that it has been agreed in principle to exchange official representatives between Berlin and Vichy, THE NEW YORK TIMES learned tonight on good authority.

MAHANOY CITY, Pa., Oct. 17 -- The campaign of the Pennsylvania Anthracite Committee to shut bootleg coal holes by dynamiting them started a riot here today as State Motor Police and company guards drove back 1,000 protesting miners before dynamiting a make-shift anthracite mine.

The congregation of St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church, East 140th Street and St. Ann's Avenue, the Bronx, will begin a week's celebration of its 100th anniversary at the 11 A.M. service tomorrow. The sermon will be by the Rev. Frank R. Wilson, rector of St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church, Hyde Park, of which President Roosevelt is senior warden.

We were introduced to peanut butter In the nursery and cherish it as one of the first foods we encountered that had very much taste -- in fascinating contrast to our previous wholesome but somewhat mushy fare of pureed vegetables, milk and gruel.

On the eve of his departure for California Adrian, the Hollywood designer who has been in New York on a two-week visit, said yesterday that he felt there should be no rivalry between the East and the West when it comes to creating styles for the American woman.

Investment Market The current lag in the volume of new bonds offered for public subscription promises to continue at least another week. Bond flotations this week in which the public had an opportunity to participate fell to $3,580,000, and there is scant possibility that this figure will be exceeded in the coming week unless an unexpected railroad issue is placed on the market.

To the many portraits in Walter Hampden's gallery as an actor soon will be added that of Sir Anthony Absolute when he appears under the Theatre Guild's banner in a reproduction of "The Rivals." For a while Mr. Hampden had been pondering an appearance in a road duplication of Patrick Hamilton's thriller, "Five Chelsea Lane."

Army and Navy officers and men and civilian employes of Army posts and Navy stations, who have been getting unlimited supplies of gasoline for their private cars at service-operated filling stations while the rest of the Eastern Seaboard was on rations, are going to have to tighten the belts around their cars' fuel tanks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Contracts for miscellaneous supplies amounting to $7,440,400 were awarded today by the War Department. Among them were the following, not previously published, to companies in the New York area:

While newspapers and magazines this year have just about maintained the rate of gain they showed in 1940, network broadcasting volume has not registered increases similar to last year, nine-month Eigures show. So far this year the networks have been running about 10 per cent ahead of 1940, compared with a 17 per cent rise last year over 1939.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Oct. 17 -- Resignation of the Prince Konoye Cabinet is causing renewed tension in this part of the Pacific, where it is well realized that even if the new Cabinet masquerades as liberal it could not have been formed without the concurrence of war and navy leaders who would have refused to appoint Ministers for their departments unless the Cabinet as a whole and its policies met with their approval.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Oct. 17 -- Following is the text of an address made by Alfred M. Landon before the Second District Women's Republican Club here and broadcast over the Blue network of the National Broadcasting Company:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Georgetown's Hoyas uncorked a smart aerial attack behind a stonewall line to roll over George Washington, 25 to 0, tonight, before 16,000 spectators who turned out for the fourteenth renewal of this gridiron rivalry.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Oct. 17 -- Major Gen. Oscar Griswold, who had commanded the Fourth Motor Division since August, left Fort Benning this week to assume command of the Fourth Army Corps, succeeding Major Gen. Jay L. Benedict. Brig. Gen. Fred C. Wallace, commanding general of division artillery, will replace General Griswold.
Efforts by Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the State Mediation Board, to settle the strike of news-dealers against eight morning and afternoon newspapers collapsed yesterday.

The new procedure of security distribution in which underwriters wholesale most or all of their issues to large institutional investors -- an outgrowth of the competitive bidding principle -- resulted this week in a sharp drop in the amount of bonds actually offered for public subscription.

VICHY, France, Oct. 17 (U.P.) -- The committee charged with writing a new French Constitution will recommend that France remain a republic, it was revealed today amid political manoeuvring that was said to include an unsuccessful attempt to restore Pierre Laval to the Petain Cabinet.

DOODLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- This little village of seventy-eight persons, situated on a plateau near Bear Mountain Park, today awoke from a pleasant Rip Van Winkle-like reverie to discover that the Bear Mountain Bridge had been sold -- not the sale that is threatened by Rockland County for unpaid taxes but the sale to the State of New York a year ago.

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 18 -- The appointment of General Tojo to direct this country's affairs at a time of grave crisis was made by the Emperor yesterday on the advice of a conference of senior statesmen, mostly former Premiers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: During the mock air raid on the city last week-end, air-raid wardens were stationed on every block in all five boroughs, and the public in general wanted to know who were the people walking around with white bands on their left arms.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The State Department announced officially today, presumably with the permission of the Russian Government, that Ambassador Laurence A. Steinhardt and members of his staff, with other members of the foreign diplomatic corps and newspaper correspondents, "have left Moscow for a point eastward from the capital at the request of the Soviet Government."

The question whether Len Eshmont or Francis Reagan will start at left half for the Football Giants tomorrow afternoon in their National League battle with Pittsburgh at the Polo Grounds is expected to be answered today.

CAMP GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., Oct. 17 -- At McFarlan, N.C., this week, Major Gen. Milton A. Reckord announced age-in-grade reassignments of seven officers in his Maryland-Virginia Twenty-ninth Division, which has its head-quarters here.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 17 -- The successful use of a double-barreled vaccine which simultaneously protects children against diphtheria and whooping cough was reported today to the American Public Health Association at the final session of its annual convention here.

The Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra, a professional organization intended to serve the Borough of Brooklyn, has been formed by the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, it was announced yesterday. John Barnett, Gerald Warburg and Carl Bamberger have been engaged as conductors.

THE most astonishing new book about the grisly world of the Nazis is "Munich Playground,"* by Ernest R. Pope, a bouillabaisse of strange tales and straight reporting, halfway between the classic foreign correspondent's memoirs and one of the heartier merry-go-round volumes of yesterday.

BENDIX, N.J., Oct. 17 -- An expected C.I.O. mass picketing demonstration in front of the Air Associates, Inc., plant here this morning failed to materialize and the more than 100 helmeted and armed county police, special deputies and court officers called out for duty had no trouble during the day.

BABSON PARK, Mass., Oct 17 -- If American finance and industry are to stand up against post-war dislocations, Ganson Purcell, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, declared today at the twenty-eighth annual business conference here, preparations must be made now.

A tentative proposal by the Republic Steel Corporation, third largest steel company in the United States, to purchase for $7,349,062 in cash all assets of the Wickwire Spencer Steel Company, with plants in Massachusetts and at Buffalo, N.Y., was disclosed yesterday by George W. Treat, chairman of the board of directors of Wickwire Spencer.

Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson announced his support of Mayor La Guardia in a statement issued here yesterday through William M. Chadbourne, director of the Citizens Committee for the Re-election of La Guardia-McGoldrick-Morris.

The most efficient and newes methods of making a hen lay more eggs and a cow give more milk were explained yesterday by experts from the New York State College of Agriculture of Corned University to county agents and farm group representatives from nine adjoining agricultural counties meeting at the Hotel Barbizo Plaza, Sixth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street.

THE HAGUE, German-occupied Netherlands, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A decree by Reich Commissioner Arthur Seysz-Inquart today fixed a maximum, penalty of death for endangering or limiting the Netherland food supply.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Oct. 17 -- After a weak opening due to the change in the Japanese Cabinet prices on the Bourse rallied with a heavier turnover. Royal Dutch lost 1 1/2 points at 299 1/2 after touching 294; Amsterdam Trading was 4 1/2 lower at 467, and Amsterdam Rubber 5 at 297 3/4.
Upton swelled the number of New York trainees at this Army replacement center to more than 4,000, the largest number of men from any one State in training here.

George Balanchine's "Baiser de la Fee" and Leonide Massine's "Three-Cornered Hat" had their first performances of the season last night by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House, along with a repetition of the Massine-Dali-Schubert "Labyrinth."

Lieut. Comdr. Anthony L. Danis was assigned command of the Kearny September, 1940, and prior to that had taught meteorology at the Naval Academy following a year's study of the subject at Bergen, Norway, according to his wife, who discussed the attack on the Kearny yesterday at her home, 8701 Shore Road, Brooklyn.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Small colleges and universities of this country, struggling to uphold their educational standards in the face of declining funds, face grave danger of extinction unless immediate financial support is forthcoming, prominent educators warned today at the closing sessions of the seventy-seventh convocation of the University of the State of New York.

Believing that few subjects are mor interesting to general readers than the experiences of men in aviation, Alfred A. Knopf has set up a prize of $2,500 for an autobiographical book-length manuscript by an American aviator now engaged in Army, Navy or commercial flying.
FORT DIX, N.J., Oct. 17 -- Selectees and National Guardsmen awaiting release here from active duty will have aid beginning Monday in obtaining civilian employment.

To Sports Editor of The New Fork Times: When the Brooklyn Dodgers won the National League pennant I was not at all convinced that they were the best team in their league. Since the world series I have been even more sure that they were not the best opponent for the Yankees.

Three of the newly opened exhibitions in the New York galleries present unusual points of interest. Yesterday Alfred Stieglitz opened An American Place for the new season with a group of paintings by Marin, Dove and Georgia O'Keeffe in the central gallery, supplemented by three works by Picasso and a group of Mr. Stieglitz's own too rarely seen camera studies.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Raymond S. (Skeeter) Baxter, 27, a golf club greens tender, was arrested on a murder charge today as a third suspect in the robbery-slaying of the golfer, Marion Miley, and her mother. Police also reported finding the two guns used to kill the women.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 17 -- Rita Hayworth's plans for the coming month were outlined today when three studios disclosed a schedule for the actress involving "My Sister Eileen" at Columbia, the Bing Crosby-Fred Astaire "Holiday Inn" at Paramount, and "Tales of Manhattan" and "My Gal Sal" at Twentieth Century-Fox.

It is too early to attempt to forecast the probable policy of General Tojo, the new Premier of Japan, but on the record of his expressed views it is difficult to find any basis for optimism regarding the future of the Far East. General Tojo is one of the militarists who is impatient with the restrictions of such obligations as the Nine-Power Treaty.

So far as broadbill and black ducks are concerned, the opening of the waterfowl season in the intermediate zone seems to have been a success, for the reports received yesterday indicate that the flights are early and large.

Americans of Irish descent should remember that if they play Hitler's game by obstructing either America's defense or American aid to Britain they are, however, unconsciously hurting the interests of the people living in Ireland," Frank MacDermot, Senator of Eire, said last night in a radio address over Station WEVD.

About 4,000,000 yards of print cloths and perhaps half as many narrow sheetings were released by gray goods mills yesterday, despite the fact that raw cotton recovered nearly half of its drastic loss of Thursday. So far as print cloths were concerned, it was said that not more than half a dozen mills were participating in the freer of fering of goods, and buyers sale the goods were allotted to then "by the thimbleful."

Although speculative initiative was still handicapped by the continued adverse war news, the stock market managed yesterday to present a bold front as the situation in the Pacific appeared less critical than it had been judged on Thursday to be.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Petroleum Coordinator Ickes said today that measures taken by his office had resulted in definite improvement in supplies of light fuel oil in the East.
Retailers and manufacturers of apparel and concerns in allied lines figured prominently in business leasing yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct 17 -- Contracts have been given by the Navy Department for fourteen experimental gilders, including four large troop-carrying ships built of a newly developed, wood-impregnated plastic.

VICHY, France, Oct. 17 -- Many members of Rotary Clubs are unware that they are in any way connected with Masonry, but documents found in the French Masonic headquarters have established that a definite influence exists, according to a statement made to the press in Vichy today by Bernard Fay, librarian of the French National Library.
TOKYO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Eiki Tojo, the new Premier of Japan, wears horn-rimmed glasses, puffs cigars rapidly, speaks incisively and is known by the Japanese public for his quick intellect.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Like some of your correspondents, I have been puzzled by the negotiations which it is reported are now being carried on between Japan and the United States. It is to be hoped that these negotiations look, not toward a temporary modus vivendi, but toward a definite settlement of the conflict in the Far East.

The aid given by Bundles for Britain and other war relief organizations has brought a new bond of good-will and friendship between England and this country, Mrs. Edward R. Murrow, London representative of Bundles for Britain, reported yesterday at a luncheon in her honor at the Hotel Astor.

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 18 -- Lieut. Gen. Eiki Tojo formed and swore in a new Japanese Cabinet today, with himself as Premier, War Minister and Home Minister and Shigenori Togo, former Ambassador to both Berlin and Moscow, as Foreign Minister of a government reported pledged to pursue a strong foreign policy.

Religion will be discussed in sermons in the city's churches tomorrow in relation to the world's current problems, including those of individuals as well as of nations. Roman Catholics will conduct an appeal for funds to help missionaries.

MOSCOW, Saturday. Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Red Armies before Moscow beat off one fierce attack after another by German forces battering at the western defenses of the capital, the Russians announced officially early today.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 17 -- The second round of the four-ball best-ball tournament of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association, twice postponed because of bad weather, was played today over the Rock Spring course, Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont and Mrs. F.A. Neuberg of Hackensack coming through to victory by adding a 77 to their first-round 75 for a thirty-six-hole total of 152.

Replying to charges that the city's schools are being used to spread political propaganda in favor of Fusion candidates, Board of Education officials declared yesterday that it has always been the practice of social studies classes in the high schools to discuss both sides of current issues.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 18 -- British newspapers predicted today that the torpedoing of the American destroyer Kearny, coupled with the worsening of United States-Japanese relations, may be the first of a series of events that soon will plunge the United States into the war.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 17 -- Bermuda, already surfeited by war and defense activities arising from the establishment of the Imperial Censorship Department and the building of United States bases, is having another plum thrust into its palm.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Two national leaders of women criticized United States citizens today for their "habit of spectatorship" and their selfish thinking in relation to defense.

With the general liquidation which marked the break In the cotton market on Thursday having pent its force, prices of cotton futures rose yesterday as much as $2.15 a bale. Offerings grew scarce soon after the opening on the New York Cotton Exchange and with trade buying continuing active, prices of active futures closed with net gains of 31 to 41 points, or $1.55 to $2.05 a bale.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 -- City officials answered the order by President Roosevelt for a survey of the city's water and sewer systems to determine whether they were a menace to the defense program and said they would welcome any assistance which the Federal Government could give in solving a problem which has plagued the municipality for eighty-five years.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 18 -- British bombing raids through Thursday night on Duisberg and other places in Germany's Ruhr industrial area, attacks on Nazi shipping off the Norwegian coast and near the Frisian Islands and sorties over the docks of Ostend, Dunkerque and Calais were reported yesterday by the Air Ministry.

BERLIN, Oct. 17 -- Powerful German infantry forces, supported by tank formations, have taken the outermost bunkers before Moscow and are continuing their drive against the Soviet capital, it was reported in messages arriving here tonight.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- In three columns dividing 1,600 vehicles, the Fourth Armored Division took to the field this week for its first mass march and bivouac, assembling 9,000 men for three days' training in road movement and camp making.

The government rested its case shortly after noon yesterday against fifteen persons, accused of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government, as the Brooklyn spy trial rounded out its sixth week before Judge Mortimer W. Byers and a jury in United States District Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Within a little more than two weeks contracts totaling $3,307,226 for the erection of fifty-one United Service Organization recreational buildings for the nation's defense personnel have been awarded by the War Department's Construction Division.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- While a radio played frequency-modulated music to her Mrs. Pauline Siegal was delivered of a five-pound son, by Caesarian operation in Henrotin Hospital today. Only a local anesthetic was used and the mother, evidently free from pain, hummed the airs of Tchaikovsky's Concerto in B flat minor while the physicians performed the operation.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 17 -- Any army that tries to invade the Australian sector of the Malay Peninsula will find itself up against a tough proposition. The Australians, who make up a large proportion of the Malayan defense forces, recently were assigned to a definite part of the peninsula guard and have incorporated the latest ideas in warfare in constructing positions that will be a death trap for any force that dares attack.

BERLIN, Saturday, Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- It was claimed in Berlin early today that German forces had unleashed "important new operations" against Moscow -- possibly a smashing drive to encircle it -- and estimated Russian material losses since start of the war at 16,183 armored units and 24,308 guns.
A large duplex apartment in the building at 829 Park Avenue has been leased by Miriam Smyth of the interior decorating firm of Smyth, Urquhart Marckwald, Inc., through N.A. Berwin Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A rayon yarn schedule fixing ceiling prices for all types of yarn is expected to issue from the Office of Price Administration within two weeks. This was the unofficial word here tonight following an all-day session in which representatives of a dozen leading yarn manufacturers were closeted with OPA officials.

LONDON, Oct. 17 (U.P.) -- Russian cavalry and motor-cycle reserves were reported by the Moscow radio tonight to be surging out of the beleaguered capital in three directions, routing and slaughtering "worn out" Germans in their path. Westward of the city one Soviet cavalry unit commanded by Major Dovator was said to have slain 10,000 Germans in the past five days.
The following books of a religious or inspirational nature have recently been published:
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 17 -- Three hundred and fifty students in two high schools at Cambridge, Mass., have sent a petition to the school committee asking that courses be given in military training.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Brig. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Administrator of the Wage and Hour Division of the Labor Department, was reported today to be a likely choice to administer the Property Requisitioning Bill, which President Roosevelt signed before he left for Hyde Park last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The House voted 259 to 138 today to amend the Neutrality Act to permit the arming of American merchant ships, after a sharp debate set off by the announcement of the attack on the destroyer Kearny.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Prior to the torpedoing of the United States destroyer Kearny -- which did not sink -- eight American-owned merchant vessels were sent to the bottom in the more than two years of the European war.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The favored Duquesne Dukes tonight scored their ninth straight victory and their fourth this season, but managed only a single touchdown against a hard-fighting St. Vincent eleven which grudgingly yielded, 7 -- 0, before 8,500 fans at Forbes Field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Results of experiments on clothing for cold climate made by Dr. Paul Siple during the Byrd Antartic expeditions have been used in the design of three new pieces of soldiers' headgear which have been standardized by the Army Quartermaster Corps.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Another attack on an American war vessel engaged in patrolling the North Atlantic was revealed today by the Navy Department in an announcement of the torpedoing of the U.S.S. Kearny, one of the Navy's newest and fastest destroyers.

VICHY, France. Oct. 17 -- Within the next few days, in view of observers here, it should become clear whether the latest German offensive that began Oct. 2 will end in a decision or in another lull. Whichever it is, the carnage will have been great.

For the first time this season a full-course football feast will be spread on the metropolitan board today. The local gridiron menu offers Columbia-Georgia at Baker Field as piece de resistance and substantial side dishes in N.Y.U.-Syracuse at the Yankee Stadium and Fordham-West Virginia at the Polo Grounds.

The steamships Black Eagle and Black Hawk, the last of a fleet of eight vessels that traded before the war in the North Atlantic service to Europe, have been sold by the Black Diamond Line to the States Marine Corporation of 80 Broad Street, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- The 51 per cent reduction in passenger automobile production schedules by the OPM for January was about in line with the expectations of finance companies here, whose officers have been resigned for several months to a shrinking demand for their services.

Talk of feeding 200 men in the Army on one can of soup in standard rations Group D awakened fears of "starving the boys" among 200 members of the Women's Home Bureau of Orange County, N.Y., who gathered yesterday at the Civilian and National Defense Exposition to study current food problems.

ALBANY, Oct. 17 -- Twice today the fundamental value of community welfare work in the national defense program was brought home to the 215 women members of New York State's local defense councils who have been meeting here for two days to learn how to organize their communities for defense.

Great Britain is running into labor shortages that are preventing her from attaining maximum war production, despite the employment of many thousands of women in factories, John D. Biggers, Special Minister to England in charge of synchronizing British and American war production, said yesterday on his return from Europe aboard the Dixie Clipper.

ATLANTA, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A pooling of the power resources of the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Commercial and Southern Corporation was decided on by a group of utility men. It would avert, at least until Nov. 10, a threatened power shortage in Tennessee, Alabama and Georgia.

Hitler fired a shot in the North Atlantic yesterday and heard an immediate echo. A few hours after the United States destroyer Kearny was struck by a German torpedo in American defensive waters the House of Representatives voted by a majority of nearly two to one to arm American merchant ships.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Oct. 11 totaled 243,571,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented a drop of 2,573,000 barrels in the week, comprising decreases of 2,528,000 and 45,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude, respectively.

Renewing his attack on real estate valuations for tax purposes, Lloyd Church, Democratic candidate for city Controller, charged last night that Mayor La Guardia was seeking to evade the issue by "vituperation, personal abuse and childish name-calling."

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Further weakness in dressed pork quotations and arrival of twice as many salable bead as expected combined to came a sharp break in the price of hogs today. Most prices were down 25 to 40 cents a hundred pounds, but in some cases loses ran to 50 cents. While $10.30 was paid for one choice load, the practical top was $10.25.

To Sports Editor of The New YorK Times: I am not a New York University alumnus, but my immediate circle of acquaintances includes many old Violets, so I feel impelled to introduce this subject, which I know to be a cause of grave concern among them.

It is strange to think of Moscow under siege. It is a bulging monster of a city, never in all the years since the revolution able to catch up with its own incessant growth. Of all the governments in the world the Soviet government is at once the widest in scope and the most centralized.

The world situation rapidly approached a climax yesterday as the Nazi tide of conquest swirled in confused fighting around the outer defenses of the Russian capital; as an American destroyer was torpedoed in the icy waters off Greenland, and "a very few" American merchantmen plying the Pacific were ordered to the safety of friendly ports as the result of the fall of the Japanese Cabinet and the crisis that that implied.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 17 (AP) -- A dispute that threatened to cancel racing here tomorrow was settled tonight and the Saturday program will be offered as scheduled, including a teat for Alsab, the 2-year-old champion.

Construction of the first concentration camp for aliens since the last World War is nearing completion at Camp Upton on Long Island, it was admitted last night by Brig. Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, commanding general of the Second Corps Area.

Trading in veal and calf was slow yesterday and lamb moved only fair to slow. Other classes were fairly active. Steer hinds and ribs were weak and some steer cuts were lower. The lamb market was steady. Veal and calf hindsaddles were weak and other classes steady. The kosher markets opened steady.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 17 (U.P.) -- The selection of Lieut. Gen. Eiki Tojo to head Japan's new "total war" Government means that Japan intends immediately to attack Russia and risk war with Britain and the United States, the Chinese Foreign Minister, Dr. Quo Tai-chi, said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- American merchant ships in Asiatic waters have been ordered by the Navy Department to put into friendly ports because of the Japanese crisis.

BERLIN, Oct. 17 -- German military commentators took issue today with what they said was British and American opinion that the Soviet Supreme Command should have followed the traditional Russian strategy of withdrawing its armies into "the vast Russian spaces."

HYDE PARK, Oct. 17 -- President Roosevelt stated today that the United States destroyer Kearny was within the American defense zone when it was torpedoed. He made it clear that his orders to the Navy to shoot on sight at German and Italian raiders operating in waters considered vital to American defense had not been changed.

The new medical and hospital insurance plan, providing both hospital and medical care for employee men and women of limited means and their families at yearly premiums ranging from $12 to $27, will begin operating Nov. 1, it was announced here yesterday by Dr. S.S. Goldwater, former Commissioner of Hospitals, who is president of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, which administers the 3-cents-a-day hospital plan.

Assets of the Tri-Continental Corporation before deducting bank loans and funded debt were $27,656,234 on Sept. 30, against $26,740,478 on June 30 and $27,586,283 at the end of 1940. Thus they covered debt by $2,669, $2,581 and $2,662 for each $1,000 of principal amount on the three dates.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 17 -- Alfred M. Landon cautioned the Republican party tonight against running interference for a "small group who are using the national defense emergency as a smoke screen for their attempts to build a collective State."

WITH BRITISH FORCES IN EGYPT, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The most powerful army Britain has ever assembled in Africa lies spread over the western desert for defense of Egypt and for whatever offensive action against Italian-German forces in Libya may be decided on by the British.

After a conference with leaders of the Democratic and American Labor parties, Governor Lehman last night appointed Joseph V. O'Leary, State Commissioner of Standards and Purchase and a member of the Labor party, Controller to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Morris S. Tremaine.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 17 -- With a view to saving time of busy executives of the gas industry the twenty-third annual meeting of the American Gas Association has been condensed to two and a half days instead of the usual four-day conclave.
ROME, Oct. 17 (AP) -- An Italian High Command communique said today:

In a strong plea for labor support, District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic Mayoralty candidate, last night told members of Plasterers Union 60, A.F. of L., that as a city magistrate he had never demanded bail in a labor dispute and had never been on the bench when a picket was convicted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- While the full impact of the defense program upon nonessential industries may cause unemployment to as many as 2,000,000 persons, the period of idleness will be only temporary in the opinion of officials here.
John T. Flynn, chairman of the New York Chapter of the America First Committee, in connection with the reported torpedoing of the Kearny, issued the following statement:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A grim hunt was Believed in progress tonight in the North Atlantic for the raider Which torpedoed the Kearny but failed to sink her some 350 miles southwest of Iceland this morning.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- President Roosevelt said at his press conference today that the sanitation situation in Philadelphia constituted literally and figuratively a stench in the nostrils.

CAMP UPTON, Oct. 17 -- Having temporarily hung up his diver's equipment, Captain L.J. Hagglund of Port Washington, L.I., reported for active duty here today to Lieut. Col. H.C. Brenizsr, commanding officer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Defense chieftains are preparing a tremendous new military "victory program," contemplating the expenditure of more than $100,000,000,000 by the end of 1943 or early 1944 to provide the United States and the rest of the anti-Axis world with about 125,000 airplanes, including 25,000 to 30,000 four-engined long-range bombers, and tens of thousands of tanks.

The Countess of Limerick, president of the London County branch of the British Red Cross, arrived from Europe on the Dixie Clipper yesterday for a visit to American Red Cross chapters in the United States, bringing the thanks of the British people to Americans who have helped them through the Red Cross, particularly the gratitude of women who are sharing the dangers of war with men.

The American Federation of Musicians' strike against sustaining musical programs of the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company here and in several other cities ended shortly after 8 o'clock last night.

Sixteen, including Haltal and Dit, have been named for the $10,000 Scarsdale Handicap, to be run this afternoon at Empire City, where the racing began yesterday before a crowd of 10,936. Perhaps double that number will turn out today to see the feature as well as the Autumn Day Stakes, for which a dozen youngsters have been entered.

William R. White, New York Superintendent of Banks, notified yesterday all commercial banks and trust companies that are not members of the Federal Reserve System and all private bankers and industrial banks in this State that the reserve requirements will be increased to conform with the recently announced increase in such requirements of the Federal Reserve Board.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The torpedo that crashed into the U.S.S. Kearny this morning struck one of the sturdiest and most powerful destroyers of the American fleet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- President Roosevelt was reported today to be hopeful that the Office of Production Management would work out a solution of the problem of jurisdictional disputes which are hampering the defense program.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 17 -- Princeton will meet the powerful Pennsylvania football forces tomorrow in an effort to halt the Quaker drive for supremacy over the Big Three on successive Saturdays. A crowd of 40,000 is expected to witness the encounter, which will start at 2 P.M. in the Palmer Stadium.

An all too sadly familiar story is that told in the dispatches of Viscount Gort from Flanders, now revealed to the home public and to the world as explanation of the defeat in part redeemed by the miracle of Dunkerque, and summarized yesterday in our news columns by Hanson Baldwin.

The rapidly diminishing list of unbeaten teams will shrink even more today and the nation's leaders will become a bit more firmly established as football undergoes another big Saturday of major games and major upsets.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Sparkling putting by Frank Strazza enabled the Round Hill pro and Mike Izzo of Engineers to win the fourth annual Metropolitan P.G.A. 36-hole Scotch foursomes championship today at the Gedney Country Club.

After five full weeks devoted to twenty-two court sessions, several of which ran far into the night, a jury of twelve men and two alternate jurors was completed yesterday in Kings County Court for the first-degree murder trial of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, industrial racketeer, and two underworld associates, Louis Capone and Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 17 -- A nation-wide railroad strike that has been threatened for several days was today apparently being averted as a result of drastic measures adopted by the government. A Presidential decree called to the colors all railroad workers, and troops were ordered to occupy railway stations and take over the service if necessary.

SEATTLE, Oct. 17 -- Delegates to the annual convention of the American Federation of Labor started for home today after taking action which President Green declared would "strengthen and develop the national defense program and result in carrying out the no-strike policy of the A.F. of L. in a more universal way."
WASHINGTON. Oct. 17 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 16:

FORT DEVENS, Mass., Oct. 17 -- Despite the fact that the First Division is away from the cantonment on war games, a private war still goes on between the War Department and the Selectmen of the neighboring town of Ayer.

Mayor La Guardia in his second Installment of "Lessons on Good Municipal Government," said yesterday that 50,000 persons of low income had received new model housing at an average rental of $24.60 a month for four and two-tenth rooms.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 18 -- The German's petty looting in Greece has extended from stealing fire wagons to snatching the babies' milk -- literally.

TWO new operas will be presented by the New Opera Company at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre in the second week of its season. They are Tchaikovsky's "Pique Dame," in an English version, conducted by Herman Adler, and Verdi's "Macbeth," sung in Italian, under the direction of Dr. Fritz Busch.
LONDON. A FEW years after the last war Mrs. C.A. Dawson Scott, a well-known novelist and poet, founded an association which took the name of the P.E.N. Club. John Galsworthy was its first president.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Tennessee's Johnny Butler couldn't get going today, so Alabama's Red Elephants handed the Volunteers a 9-to-2 setback, although the score falls to disclose the superiority the winners held over the retiring champions of the Southeastern Conference.

BOSTON, Oct. 18 -- Out-manned, out-weighed, out-scored, but not out-gamed. That tells part of the story of the Boston College's 26-13 defeat of the injury-ridden, undermanned Manhattan College football team in Fenway Park today under gray skies before a crowd of 12,000.

THANKS to the title, you already know that a corpse is to be concealed in a snow man, but you do not know whose corpse it is nor who placed it there, nor will you know until Nigel Strangeways has completed his investigation.

Officials of the National Council of Women and leaders in its affiliated organizations will be in session this week at the Park Central Hotel for their biennial meeting, when, in addition to their own reports, they will hear from women leaders in the national defense program.

LEXINGTON, Va., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Captain Bounding Bill Dudley, stamping himself as a great player on defense,' as well as one of the nation's leading ground-gainers, whipped three touchdown passes through the air today to lead the University of Virginia to a 27-7 victory over Virginia Military Institute before 14,000 spectators.
BERLIN, Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- Reports abroad that Russian troops had recaptured Kalinin, north of Moscow, were denied officially in Berlin. Kalinin remains in German hands, official quarters said.

ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 18 -- Several hundred alumni of Phillips Academy who returned today for the annual luncheon and other ceremonies of alumni day heard the headmaster, Dr. Claude M. Fuess, praise Secretary Stimson, Bishop Henry W. Hobson of Cincinnati and President Hopkins of Dartmouth, all trustees, for their contributions in these trying times.

THE title of J.B. Priestley's stirring call to new social thought and action is taken from Walt Whitman -- "Everything comes out of the people." But the first three words of the American Constitution supplement the title's definition: it is "We, the people," as lively minded men and women, never as "masses," from whom must come, as Mr. Priestley says, victory in war and in peace.

OTTAWA, Oct. 18 -- Declaring that Canada must now choose between guns and butter, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King announced tonight in a broadcast that "the government has decided to halt the rise in prices, to undertake the control of all prices, and, where necessary, to take any other steps to control civilian consumption in fair and equitable ways."

ARTHUR MAYER and Joseph Burstyn, who specialize in horror pieces at the Rialto Theatre, are about to duck into another doorway -- legitimate theatre production. They have taken over H.S. Kraft's "The Crown Cafe" and expect to start rehearsals about the first of next month with Elia Kazan directing.

In addition to the $52,700,000,000 of direct national debt which will be outstanding after giving effect to the latest Treasury issue, the United States Government has an indirect obligation of $7,000,000,000, consisting of securities issued by various Federal agencies, such as the RFC, the HOLC and the CCC, which have been guaranteed by the Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Net gold imports into the United States in September totaled $65,702,000, compared with $36,973,000 in August, the Department of Commerce reported today. Exports for the two months were $5,000 and $6,000, respectively.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18 -- Harvard finally managed to break the spell that Dartmouth has woven over it of late, beating the Indians by the score of 7-0 in today's football game in the Stadium, the forty-ninth of a series that started in 1882.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 18 -- Recent weeks have seen a shift in sentiment in this area away from isolationism and toward a showdown with Hitler, whether or not that means a shooting war. But this trend is something one feels in the air.

PANAMA -- The Galapagos Islands, a strange and desolate archipelago lying right on the Equator 800 miles west of Ecuador, and uncomfortably close to the important sea lanes fanning out from the Panama Canal, have emerged in recent months from what amounted almost to an "orphan" status to a delicate and vexatious problem in hemisphere defense.

WITH no more invidious purpose than to make a million or more at the box office, Paramount has produced a picture that threatens the solidarity of the South. A near-feud has arisen between two cities which long have existed in amiable disregard of each other, separated by another State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The prospect of a Senate battle over major revision of the Neutrality Law developed today as Senator Glass called the existing act "a craven piece of poltroonery" and announced that he would work for its complete repeal.

A spirited and alert James Monroe High School football team, outweighed but never outfought, downed Evander Childs by 2 to 0 in the second game of a schoolboy double-header yesterday at Randalls Island before 5,000 spectators.

BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- While German forces were reported to be widening the gap cut yesterday in Moscow's outermost defenses, a special German communique tonight proclaimed the double battle of envelopment at Vyazma and Bryansk, west of the capital, at an end.

If the 1941 shipbuilding schedule under the Maritime Commission's expansion program is carried out in the remaining two and a half months of the year the production volume of the first three years of the war will be almost three times that of the same period in the first World War.

William M. Chadbourne, director of the Citizens Committee for the Re-election of the La Guardia-McGoldrick-Morris ticket, announced yesterday at his campaign headquarters at the Hotel Astor the appointment of a physicians and surgeons campaign committee, composed of 168 doctors.

THE Swedish postal authorities have announced that two large-size stamps, 15-ore brown and 1.20 kroner red-violet, will be issued with likeness of "Sancta Birgitta" (Saint Bridget), who, "Prophetess from the North," is called the first person of Swedish birth to have exerted an important influence on the Christian world.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Yonkers Central this afternoon beat A.B. Davis High of Mount Vernon. 7 to 6, in a W.I. A.A. game at Howard Field. It was the first league victory for Yonkers and Davis first defeat in three games.

It was true what they said about Sinkwich. The boy with the wired jaw can play extraordinarily good football, but there were others in the flaming red jerseys of Georgia who played with him yesterday, and Columbia's dream of gridiron empire faded on the end of a 7-to-3 defeat.

Bergen County continues to be one of the most active home building and home selling localities in New Jersey. Despite the recent restrictions against many essential construction materials, developers in many communities report a steady demand for houses exceeding $6,000 in price and many builders are making preparations for active home building operations next Spring.

Although domestic oil companies have turned down the proposal submitted through Secretary of state Cordell Hull for the settlement of their claims against Mexico, negotiations for loans and credits to Mexico from the United States Government are continuing in Washington.

In the Central Argentine lie the level treeless plains called the pampas. Average temperatures in the region range from 74 degrees in January to 49 degrees in the Winter months of June and July. Temperate climate and deep rich soil make the pampas the best agricultural land in South America.

TO THE EDITOR: In the article "Devotees of the Desert," by Martha Tucker, I notice the omission of a name which I think ought to have been included [among the Englishmen who turned their backs on the West to live in the deserts of Arabia].

The records of the Departments of Buildings and Docks during his two administrations were cited by Mayor La Guardia yesterday as examples of what could be achieved by city agencies unfettered by "politics and hidden graft." The achievements of the two departments were summarized by the Mayor in the third of his current series of "Lessons on Good Municipal Government."

RADIO'S annual tussle of cadenzas for operatic honors opens this afternoon at 5 with the seventh edition of WEAF's "Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air." From the quiet that comes in the Spring will emerge at least two erstwhile hopefuls holding contracts with the company as their prize.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala. BUT I can't play this longhaired stuff," said the despairing youth with the bass fiddle. "I have had music for only one year."

A SUMMARY of market conditions is an innovation in each of the two standard reference volumes which Scott Publications, Inc., will release tomorrow -- the United States Stamp Catalogue (Specialized) and the Catalogue of Air Post Stamps.

FREQUENTLY we have wondered why the storehouse of American folklore -- that growing accumulation of rich and robust legends sprung from fertile American minds -- has not been more often and more successfully raided by Hollywood.

Change Since 1812 Parallels between Napoleon in Russia in 1812 and Hitler in 1941 rarely mention one difference which is not to the advantage of Hitler in the final outcome. In 1812 the United States was a country of approximately eight million people and today we are close to 135,000,000.

RESTRICTIONS proscribing communication with foreign countries by amateur radio operators have been waived by the Federal Communications Commission in the case of Earl F. Lucas of Midland Park, N.J., at the request of Nelson A. Rockefeller, coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.

IN the mid-eighteenth century in France the concept of the Prince was something very different from Machiavelli's. The chief tenet of monarchy had ceased some time since to be military and had become largely a matter of divine right; but the fallacies of this apotheosis were quickly apparent, and with the ideas of the philosophes came a new visualization of the rights and duties of sovereignty.

TRAVEL LINES: Curly Horse Ranch at Sonoita, Ariz., while not one of the big riding ranges of the West, adjoins several, and offers similar activities to a limited clientele. Its owner-manageress understands good food and comfortable surroundings and furnishes them along with horses, guides and excursions around Tucson, Tombstone and Nogales, Mexico (the latter only thirty-five miles disstant).

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 18 -- Unheralded Ray Terrell stole the spotlight today from Mississippi's talented touchdown twins, Merle Hapes and Junie Hovious, as the Rebels swamped Holy Cross, 21 -- 0, before 22,000 at Fitton Field.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Bluntly telling a crowd of munitions workers at a Midlands town today that "things are really desperate," Ernest Bevin, Minister of Labor, called upon Britain for greater output of weapons and ammunition to stop a possible Nazi invasion attempt next year.

Since the public health aspect of the war emergency first became emphasized, officials looking for women to fill essential tasks have found a reservoir of trained personnel in the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service. A number of its staff have consequently been called to posts far from the administration offices at 262 Madison Avenue.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Collegiate-service athletic relations were renewed here today as undefeated Rutgers beat Fort Monmouth, 26 to 0, before 8,000 fans in the Rutgers Stadium. Scoring twice in each half, the Scarlet was never threatened in recording its fourth triumph of the campaign.
Fifteen thousand gifts totaling $700,000 have been received to date in New York by the United China Relief, it was announced yesterday by Raymond Rubicam, chairman of the Greater New York Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Senate Defense Investigating Committee disclosed today that it would seek a showdown on the government's labor policies in the construction field by calling Sidney Hillman, John L. Lewis and William Green for joint testimony on Wednesday concerning a Wayne County (Mich.) housing project.

Moral rearmament and reaffirmation of religious principles by nations and individuals are required to end the present social chaos and to establish order and justice in our world, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday.

STIFFER this year than last is the meting out of license suspension and revocation penalties against erring drivers. More driving, more cars, increased pressure of living and greater vigilance by States under these conditions cause the penalty rise.

An interest in community work which has received the accolade of officials both high and low as the first duty of women at this time has been reflected in rising memberships in those organizations which have had long experience in directing such activities.

THE literature of flight (not of escape, however) is, of course, in its infancy. It would be prophecy of the rashest kind to venture a prediction regarding its eventual scope and character, but that it begins with certain obvious advantages over the literature which has grown up about every form of human transportation must be apparent to any one who has given the matter a moment's thought.

ALFRED, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Alfred University routed a plucky Brooklyn College eleven tonight, triumphing, 29 to 2, in notching its second victory of the season. Frank Trigilio paced Alfred in a game that saw every man on the victor's bench in action.

Queens College students of education are going out into the field for practical experience in leading youngsters of the same age groups as they are preparing to teach, under a new program adopted by the college Department of Education, Professor Harry N. Rivlin, chairman, announced yesterday.
RUMSON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- A race meet dinner dance was held tonight at the Rumson Country Club after the Monmouth County Hunt Races at the Woodland Farm race course this afternoon.

The American agave or aloe -- a member of the amaryllidaceae -- is commonly known as Century-plant, because of the superstition that it blooms only once in a hundred years. While it requires many years to mature, there is no reason for the belief that it takes a hundred.

TOKYO, Oct. 18 -- After being promoted to the rank of full general and formally taking office this afternoon, Premier Eiki Tojo issued a statement declaring in effect that Japan's policy remained unchanged.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- It is not without significance that the Ministry which was known in the last war as the Ministry of Blockade in this war is known as the Ministry of Economic Warfare. It can be said perhaps that it took the World War to teach the world the lesson that war of the present is total war and that nation faces nation.

ROME, Oct. 18 -- Catholic Church missions had stronger reason than ever for support, said Mgr. Celso Costantini, Titular Archbishop of Teodosia, in the annual appeal made today over a world-wide broadcast on behalf of Missionary Day.

THE publication of Part XIII of "A Dictionary of American English, on Historical Principles" needs, of course, only the barest announcement as a news item for all those scholars and laymen who await the appearance of the book, volume by volume as it comes from the press.

YOU step into the little stationery shop -- or maybe it's the corner drug store, the restaurant, the saloon, the roadside inn or the penny arcade. Instantly, the glittering device -- its name may be Red Hot, Lineup, Landslide, Brite Spot, Mascot, Three Score, Sporty or Scoop -- catches your eye.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 18 -- A scrappy, though outweighed, Ursinus eleven fought Lehigh's Engineers to a scoreless stalemate before a house party crowd of 6,000 today.

DETROIT -- Curtailed car production is just beginning to be felt, but already noticeable is shrinkage in the number of dealers throughout the country, reports here indicate. Dealer mortality, while small as yet, is taken as an indication that several thousand more outlets will close under the full effect of 50 per cent curtailment.

Three passes tossed to a surefingered Clarkson Tech back named Harry Przybylowski spelled defeat for City College at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, for Przybylowski ran all three tosses over the Beaver goal line and Tech won, 20 -- 0.

THE making of what may be called "dolls" goes back many thousands of years into prehistory. But those first little figures were "cult objects"; and as Janet Pagter Johl says in the second chapter of her interesting and impressively comprehensive volume, it is difficult to ascertain the point at which "the doll stops being a fetish and becomes a doll."

Mrs. Ethel S. Epstein, labor secretary to Mayor La Guardia, intervened yesterday in the inter-union dispute that has resulted in the posting of pickets outside twenty major department stores and specialty shops in Manhattan and the Bronx.

In the city political campaign District Attorney O'Dwyer, attacking the Mayor's claims of nonpartisan government, charged in a speech that, in fact, the La Guardia regime had been "superpolitical" and that the Sanitation Department had been turned into a "personal political club."

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- A call to 250,000 C.I.O. workers in New Jersey to picket the plant of Air Associates, Inc., will be issued by executives of the union unless the eighteen-day strike at the plant in Bendix is settled by tomorrow night.

PITTSBURGH. Oct. 18 -- Notre Dame slipped and slid today to a 16-0 victory over underdog Carnegie Tech before a rain-soaked crowd of 27,719 that came expecting an Irish field day, but left cheering the Tartans' amazing goal-line stands.
THE VENTURESOME VOYAGES OF CAPTAIN VOSS," with an introduction by Weston Martyr (Dodd, Mead Co., $2.75), is a book of strange tales by a world-encircling small-boat skipper.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Oct. 18 -- Vermont Junior College made a desperate fourth-quarter drive to tie the New York Aggies on the gridiron today, but a blocked kick for the point after touchdown left the score 9 to 8 in favor of the visitors.

MELINDA was a tomboy back in the early Nineteen Hundreds when custom and costume made life much more difficult than it is today for little girls who happen to prefer penknives and baseball to hair-ribbons and Sunday school.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Services designed to guide the consumer through the economic whirlpools now spinning with the forces and demands of the current trend of production are soon to be offered in information centers throughout the country.

THE Czech nation's Sokol Athletic Societies, which have been called "the expression of the national soul," have been suppressed by the Nazi occupation authorities. A dispatch from Berlin last week said that Reinhard Heydrich, Acting Reich Protector of Bohemia and Moravia, had ordered the societies and their affiliated group dissolved on the ground that the Sokols were aiding opposition to German rule and were maintaining "illicit relations" with the Czech emigre circles in London.

PAINTINGS by Max Weber have been acquired by three American museums recently, according to announcement by the Associated American Artists Galleries. "Winter Twilight" goes to the Santa Barbara Museum.

Park, director, made public yesterday.

Jones, chief of the housing priorities branch of the Office of Production Management.

Now the great question is whether the Russians will keep on fighting. In other words, even if he loses Moscow and the Kremlin, can and will Stalin keep an army of 2,000,000 or more men, with reasonable equipment, fighting the German invaders through the Winter and into next Spring? ARTUR RODZINSKI, conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra, has decided on a new way to select the American works that will appear on his programs. He is forming a committee of a dozen musicians and persons active in the cultural life of the city.

Decreases of 5 to 20 per cent or more as compared with a year ago mark the enrollment this Fall of fun-time students in a large majority of American colleges and universities, as shown in official statements just received from 573 approved institutions in all parts of the United States.

FOR those who believe in fate and cycles there is something definitely impressive in the announcement that the famous studio at 110 East Fifty-ninth Street which was once Isadora Duncan's has now been taken over by that other great figure in the shaping of the American dance, Ruth St. Denis, and will be opened next Sunday as a center for her activities.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 18 (AP) -- An injury-riddled Illinois football team, repulsed by Minnesota's Conference champion last Saturday, bounded back through the air and on the ground today for six touchdowns and an easy 40-to-0 victory over Drake before 12,193 spectators in Memorial Stadium.

TUCSON, Ariz. -- As Tucson's Santa Catalina Mountains turn to purple silhouettes against the gold blaze of the Arizona sunset, dudes swing off their perches on the ranch corral and mount their pinto ponies. To the creaking of saddles and the jingle of ornamental Mexican silver spurs, they lope across the mesa toward the hills.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- President Roosevelt has asked Congress to appropriate $50,000,000 for foreign war relief in a move interpreted in some quarters as an answer to Herbert Hoover's demand that this country feed the starving peoples of Nazi-conquered nations.

Following the liberation of almost 100,000 game birds and animals during the present year, the New Jersey State Fish and Game Commission predicts that 1941 will be a record season for the hunters of that State.
AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Univeraity of Texas' surging Orange Wava rolled on today, inundating a valiant Arkansas football team, 48 to 14, for its fourth consecutive triumph this season.

SAMUEL GOLDWYN is experiencing the big casting headache of his career in trying to decide who should play Lou Gehrig in his forthcoming film biography of the great ball player -- or so says the producer's not entirely uninterested press representative.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Indiana of the Big Ten did everything better than Nebraska, football champion of the Big Six, before 33,000 homecoming day far today and went away with a 21-to-13 victory, the first time the Hoosiers have beaten the Co Huskers in six starts.

THREE books dealing with Germany and the Nazi ideology are announced for early publication by the Alliance Book Corporation. The first of these, to be published on Oct. 22, is "Hitler's Counterfeit Reich," by Dr. Karl Robert.

The annual report for 1940 of the Banque de Paris et des PaysBas, one of the principal French banks, which has just been received in this country, makes only sober or veiled , allusions to the events of that year. It does, however, show for the bank a net profit of 15,306,673 francs for the year (about $306,130), against 21,325,570 francs the year before.

GREETER: Two hundred thousand Baltimoreans lined their city's streets last week to welcome a visiting hometown girl, the Duchess of Windsor, and her husband, the Duke. The official greeting was tendered by Mayor Howard W. Jackson at his flower-banked office in City Hall.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The third Open House of the Westcheater County Recreation Commission will be held Monday night at the County Center here. Point is given the event this year by President Roosevelt's appeal to recreation workers to strengthen their program for the sake of civilian morale.

BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- Following in the wake of the Kearny incident, a special German High Command communique issued today announced that U-boats in the Atlantic had sunk ten merchantmen and two protecting destroyers from a convoy en route to Britain from North America in a conflict lasting several days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Rising prices were reported today by both the Labor Department and the C.I.O. Living costs for moderate-income families are 9.6 per cent higher than in August, 1939, the month before the outbreak of the European war the department said.
MADISON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Wisconsin, led by two fleet sophomore backs, slapped a surprising 23-to-0 defeat on a favored Iowa eleven in a Western Conference football game before 20,000 today.

While activity in some sections of the wholesale market was stimulated by cooler weather, orders generally were fewer than usual at this time of the year, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

European and American antiques collected by 175 dealers in all parts of the country will be shown at the Fourteenth Annual Antiques Exposition to open tomorrow at 1 P.M. at the Hotel Commodore. It will continue through Friday.

THE recent announcement that previous attendance records of our national parks have been increased this season by some 4,000,000 more visitors indicates the rapidly mounting interest in the American scene. According to the National Park Service of the Department of the Interior, 21,050,426 persons visited the country's national parks, historic and national recreation areas, during the travel year just closed.

MR. MENCKEN became a reporter on The Baltimore Herald at the age of 19 and he is still writing pieces for The Baltimore Sun at the age of 61, so far as this reviewer has heard. Out of a very distinguished journalistic career extending over more than forty years Mr. Mencken has taken the first seven years and called them "Newspaper Days."

The latest in the series of events arranged this season in behalf of Bundles for Britain is a Navy Ball, which will be given by that war relief organization, in cooperation with the Navy League of the United States, on the night of Nov. 26 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

A picturesque event now being planned for the early Winter is a Renoir Centennial Costume Ball, to be held Dec. 17 at the Ritz-Carlton under the auspices of the Free French Relief Committee. MOTORISTS who have struggled through congested Eastern Boulevard in the Bronx between the Whitestone Bridge and the Hutchinson River Parkway were able last week to use a new three-and-one-half-mile six-lane parkway between the old parkway in Pelham Bay Park and the Whitestone Bridge approach.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Superficially, the United States relations with Latin America are good. The recent comprehensive trade agreement with Argentina and the sudden collapse of the pro-German regime in Panama support this view.
Shade trees prepared now for the Winter will have new health and beauty with the coming of Spring. Fall watering, feeding and repairing are essential to their well-being.

OF the thirteen new works to be presented this season by by the National Symphony Orchestra, under Hans Kindler, in Washington, D.C., seven are by American composers. Four of the novelties will receive their world premieres; one will be performed for the first time in this country, and four will be heard for the first time in Washington.

HOLLYWOOD. WILL JAMES and Metro are eying each other with that caution which marks the relationship between strangers in the West. MGM has agreed to purchase "The Saga of the American Cowboy" for $10,000, but the cattle-punching novelist and artist is skeptical, and while he has been waiting for the conclusion of the deal, he has prepared the illustrations for the volume which Scribners will publish in the Spring.

TUNIS may not be the seventh son of a seventh son but the prophecy of "The Kid Prom Tompkinsville" came true this year when the Dodgers won their way into the World Series, and if the climax of this sequel doesn't quite jibe with the outcome of the most exciting baseball season in years, the reader can scarcely help feeling that Mr. Tunis is right and destiny wrong.

GRIDIRON OUTPOST: Icelanders have been startled in past months by the landing of British troops, the appearance of Nazi scout planes, the arrival of United States forces. Last week came another surprise. American infantrymen, in blue-and-gold jerseys, padded pants and leather helmets, played football on a field at Reykjavik.

TO the people in aviation who believe the next important development in air transport is cargo planes the figures of the Air Express Division of the Railway Express Agency must be a regular monthly pleasure.

BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- General Eiki Tojo's Cabinet is greeted with satisfaction here in so far as it promises a more active Japanese policy, but official circles seemed to prefer to wait with more than general comment until they have seen the official results of the Cabinet.

FOOTBALL Georgia ousted Columbia from the rapidly dwindling ranks of the unbeaten college elevens, winning at Baker Field on a first-period touchdown. Fordham was the only big New York team to triumph, the Rams having little difficulty, in downing West Virginia. Syracuse routed New York University, Boston College beat Manhattan and Clarkson blanked City College. There was one big surprise in Ivy League play.

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity declined during the week ended Oct. 11 to the lowest level since May 10. It stood at 126.5, compared with 127.4 (revised) the week previous and 112.1 for the week ended Oct. 12, 1940.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- National defense accomplishments of WPA, particularly in construction of airports and buildings for military posts before 1939, were cited today by Commissioner Howard C. Hunter in a report on WPA defense construction projects for the six-year period ended June 30.

PACIFIC GROVE, Calif -- The annual migration of monarch, butterflies on the Pacific Coast this year is forecasting an early Winter. The advance guard, heralding the arrival of the main flight later on, was seen on Sept. 8 -- extremely early.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 18 -- Bottled up in its own territory and limited to a single first down in the opening half, in which it stood with its back to the wall on the 5-yard line, Navy's heavily favored football team finally found its offensive punch in the brilliant outside running of Barnacle Bill Busik today and defeated Cornell, 14 -- 0, in the Municipal Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The advent of a new board known as the State Regents for Higher Education in Oklahoma is an event of significance in the American higher-educational scene. All institutions of higher education supported wholly or partly by direct legislative appropriations now form the Oklahoma State System of Higher Education, headed by the regents.

IN recent years Swiss letters have been much enriched by the work of a young man in his middle thirties: Denis de Rougemont. An unusually heavy demand for furnished apartments has been one of the outstanding features of recent leasing activity in New York, according to William B. Hall, manager of the Parc Vendome apartments in West Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets, who bases his statement on the renting records at that building.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 18 -- In an exciting finish to the three-mile steeplechase over timber, Mrs. Frank M. Gould's 4-year-old chest-nut gelding Hold Forth scored by a neck over Christopher M. Greer Jr.'s Houseman in the sixteenth running of the Montmouth County Hunt Cup.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Leon Henderson, Federal price administrator, revised upward today the prices of zinc scrap and secondary slab zinc and changed the pricing system from a "delivered" to a "shipping point" basis to afford an equal opportunity for all manufacturers to compete for supplies.

Egon Werdelman, co-captain of the Bryant squad, romped off with the Queens title in the P.S.A.L. cross-country borough championship tests for individuals and teams at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. The husky blond lad, who has been in the forefront all season, made the best time of the campaign.

A Presidential train pulled out of Washington's Union Station last Thursday night and rolled northward. Mr. Roosevelt was bound for a "long weekend" at his ancestral home overlooking the Hudson. A small party of guests traveled along -- Harry Hopkins; the President's son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. John Boettiger, and Crown Princess Martha of Norway.

After 129 years the name of Borodino has come back once more into the war news. The Russian town marks the battlefield from which Napoleon, after fearful loss, marched victoriously into Moscow. But the famous name seems hardly more than an echo of the past. The fighting there was fierce enough, but Borodino is only one of a hundred towns swallowed up in the vast Nazi engulfment surging around the Soviet capital.

A $380,000 mortgage held for more than fifty years by the late Andrew Carnegie and his heirs on the premises of the Lotos Club at 110 West Fifty-seventh Street was burned there last night before a gathering of the members by the club's president, Harry Woodburn Chase.

The decline in commodity prices last week was a sharp reminder that even in a period of inflationary influences prices can fall as swiftly as they rise. Grains tumbled 6 to 10 cents a bushel, the latter figure representing the maximum drop permitted in one day.
