Recent interchange of correspondence between the defense agencies and the Department of Justice goes a long way toward clearing up the confusion that has developed with respect to the legality of standardization and simplification, according to P.G. Agnew, secretary of the American Standards Association.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- As the fight in Congress over changing the Neutrality Act heads toward a climax, American public opinion is favorable to two basic revisions in the act.

Interest is growing in Chinese flower arrangements. Despite the general assumption that Japan was the first country to develop this art, the fact is that it originated in China, and the fundamental principles were there first worked out.

FORT WORTH, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Texas Aggies didn't need even the ghost of John Kimbrough today to stay undefeated and untied. They beat Texas Christian University at football, 14-to-0, in a Southwest Conference game.

As the time approaches for selecting shrubs or trees for late Summer and Autumn planting, the gardener may well give particular attention to the their effect in the landscape during late Fall and Winter, when their forms are most conspicuous.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Deterioration of the military situation in Russia and renewal of the tension in the Pacific area, although overshadowing all trade transactions, failed this week to influence the British commodity markets. This is proof of the completeness of government control over those markets.

A new Russian radio technique of addressing personal messages to women in Germany telling them of the death on the Eastern front of their husbands or sons is having a terrific effect on German morale, according to reports from inside Germany, Lieut. Col. George A. Drew of Toronto said yesterday on his return from a two and a half-month visit in England and Lisbon.

ACCIDENTS will happen. Until some one made the fearful mistake of reminding George Cukor that he once had been labeled a "woman's director," he seemed almost as relaxed as a whirling dervish -- a degree of passivity one might add, rarely achieved by Hollywood directors unless bitten by a tsetse fly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The decision to halt all but essential building in the United States, made by the Supply Priorities and Allocation Board, probably illustrates more clearly than any other event the fact that the expanding arms program finally has reached a point where private interests and industries must feel its full effects and the public make tremendous sacrifices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Willys-Overland "Jeep" has been made the Army's standard light reconnaissance car and the Willys Company and the Ford Motor Company, in the first agreement of its kind since the first World War, has made an arrangement under which each will produce identical models of the vehicle.

Carrying out the agreement previously reached by party leaders with Governor Lehman, the State Committees of the Democratic and American Labor parties yesterday nominated Joseph V. O'Leary, State Commissioner of Standards and Purchase, who is a Labor party member, for State Controller to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Morris S. Tremaine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Govrenment press agents were ordered tonight to conserve their words. The corps of public relations men working for the United States were told to stop triple and double-spacing and to write their publicity on a single-space basis to conserve paper.

RELATED by the scene of their activities and the subjects with which they dealt, work by two artists of the third quarter of the last century is being exhibited simultaneously in two local galleries this week. At the Durand-Ruel Galleries a group of characteristic paintings by Eugene Boudin may be seen.

Fruit trees have taken a new lease on popularity with the development of dwarf ones suitable for the suburban garden or limited acreage. Still another practical offering in this line is the multi-kind fruit tree, with three to five varieties grafted on a single small, well-developed tree.

After a study of the suburban market and the possibility of fitting their activity into the defense housing program, many builders in the New York area are taking a somewhat more optimistic view of the situation than they did when the first impact of the SPAB's restrictions on purchase of essential materials reached them.

A NEW 50,000-watt radio "voice" for WHN, a station almost as old as broadcasting, will soon be heard on the air. WHN is the first station prepared for high-power operation in this area as a result of the re-shuffling of Western Hemisphere waves last Spring.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 18 (AP) -- J.G. Leiper's stable scored a double as the eighty-second Fall meeting of the Rose Tree Hunt Club ended today, winning the Sycamore Mills Plate and the Ormead Cup, both steeplechases, before a capacity crowd.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 18 -- Alsab, the bargain-basement colt that experienced horsemen call the best 2-year-old to come down the pike in years, won his ninth straight race today and became the thirteenth juvenile in racing history to earn more than $100,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A new high-speed camera which can take pictures at the rate of 7,200,000 per minute is the subject of a patent (No. 2,259,228) awarded to Wiliam K. Rankin of Lansdowne, Pa. The patent is assigned to the Genral Electric Company of New York.

FAVORED: Pressure Groups The present will be known in the future as an era of special privileges freely granted by the government to pressure groups in Washington. Chief of these are the labor unions, which maintain a powerful lobby. The favors already obtained are largely responsible for the present widespread strikes at a time when strikes are particularly unfortunate for the public.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The fact that three steamers have left Japan to evacuate Japanese citizens, in what is loosely termed an exchange of nationals, has left an erroneous impression that Americans in Japan have been under strong pressure that hinders their departure.

ONE of the heartrending moments in the professional football campaign of 1941 came when Bert Bell, now half-owner of the Pittsburgh Steelers, who haven't won a game so far this season, felt compelled to fire the Pittsburgh coach. This distant observer wasn't on hand at that touching scene, but it must have been dramatic when Magnate Bert Bell, looking himself in the eye, said to Coach Bert Bell:
Land uses in American cities must be "replanned on a realistic basis," because the urban land pattern has become outmoded and unsuited to the complexities of modern living.

Dark Legend A few years ago a lad who shall here be known as "Gino" walked up to a New York policeman and said quite simply: "I just killed my mother." The next day the newspapers carried headlines: "Stabs Mother to Death When She Rebuked Him for Getting Home Late," "Killed Mother to Avenge Father," and "Jealous Son Kills Widow."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The OPM labor division, listing strikes in progress, reported today that twenty-nine labor disputes were current in plants working on Army and Navy defense contracts, but contended that "only seven cases, involving approximately 11,000 workers, have any significant effect on the defense effort."

What is said to be a new method in keeping homes cooler in Summer and warmer in Winter, is explained by scientists of the Armour Research Foundation. They state that it represents the result of studying the effects of window shades in excluding heat from the sun during the Summer time and in retaining indoor heat during the Winter time.

With a salute by two Mayors, music, talks and comedy from London, Hollywood and New York, and a bit of engineering comment as electric switches were thrown, the new WABC, key station of the Columbia Broadcasting System, on "Columbia Island" in Long Island Sound off New Rochelle, went into action last night shortly after 10 o'clock.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Prospect Club, the first cooperative eating establishment at Princeton University, marked its first month of existence today with an announcement that costs were running 10 per cent below preliminary estimates.

The basic cause of slums is the lack of proper advance planning and of proper supervision in the growth of communities and not the so-called industrialization of society, according to George A. Boehm of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday a letter received from Bernard M. Baruch declaring that his re-election would be in the city's interest. Mr. Baruch enclosed a campaign contribution of an unspecified amount.

BEGINNING next Sunday the New Friends of Music will offer in its sixth season the ten last string quartets of Mozart, his two piano quartets and the quartet for oboe and strings. In presenting these quartets in cycle forms we hope to open up to our audience, the vitality and joy in Mozart's works, and let them have the experience to be drawn from the depth, power and the compassion "manifest in his later writing.

Mayor La Guardia is sending to Prime Minister Churchill this morning a "Thumbs Up" message and five "Thumbs Up" pins of the British War Relief Society of America arranged in a V shape in a small jewel box. The Mayor's letter to Mr. Churchill, dated Oct. 14, follows:

What the passing of Prince Konoye signifies is that Japan is resolved never again to miss the boat because those who presumably direct its course stand on the shore and argue about which way to go or whether it is not safer to stay at home.

Clearly demonstrating its superiority during two substantial scoring sprees, Syracuse engineered a 31-to-0 triumph at the Yankee Stadium yesterday and thus capably continued its football mastery over N.Y.U., routing a squad that defied superstition in a futile effort to re-enter the victory column.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 18 -- Official circles here believe that the more acute the international situation grows the more necessary it becomes for the United States to settle the oil expropriations issue. American observers agree that the negotiations between Mexico and the United States are closely linked with defense.

ANTI-FREEZE liquids, essential for automobile in cold weather, face some supply restriction this year in the nonevaporating types. For defense purposes Canada curbed these chemical compounds last month. In the United States, the methanol, ethanol and ethylane glycol types are affected by explosives manufacture and demand for aircraft coolants.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 18 -- There's the next thing to a Mardi Gras celebration in New Orleans tonight, because Tulane's Green Wave is rolling -- rolling merrily toward a bowl Invitation, and the wreckage of a flattened North Carolina eleven was here to prove it.

ON the jacket of Margaret Flint's new book the publishers tell us that after her fifth novel she "no longer fears that her material will run out." But it's plain to be seen that something has run out, and if it's not material then it is a certain substance of style and approach without which mere material has no significance.

DANDELION RUBBER -- While touring the Tien-Shan Mountains in 1931, a young Soviet student, named Bukhanovich, and a farmer, Spivachenko, found at an altitude of over 6,000 feet above sea level a variety of dandelion, now known as the kok-sagyz, which proved to be a rubber-bearing plant.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 18 -- The best hunter in the second annual Greenwich hunter fixture, held today at Yale Farms for the benefit of the American Red Cross, was the towering brown gelding Heman II, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Hale of Greenwich.

Because Brooklyn and Queens are within a designated "defense area," residential construction within a stipulated quota may be undertaken for or by persons in defense industries or other employment considered essential to the national defense, the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce pointed out yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Bureau of the Budget today, in response to a request from the Senate Finance Committee, pointed out how $1,000,000,000 to $2,000,000,000 could be saved in non-defense expenditures during this fiscal year.

The United Service Organizations for National Defense, Inc., announced at its headquarters in the Empire State Building yesterday that the Army Quartermaster Corps had advised that 100 new USO club buildings would be completed and in operation by the first of the year.

The fascinating pursuit of antiques is usually a hobby for those who have plenty of leisure. Welcome to many, therefore, as a time saver, will be the fourteenth annual Antiques Exposition, where under one roof may be seen the most prized antiques of more than 150 exhibitors.

The evening performance on Nov. 13 of "Macbeth" at the National Theatre will be a benefit for the Art Workshop of the Rivington Neighborhood Association. Mrs. Seymour L. Cromwell Jr. is chairman and Mrs. Frederick R. King associate chairman of the committee arranging the event.

The performance of the Cesar Franck symphony by the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, under Leopold Stokowski, last night in Carnegie Hall, succeeded in re-creating the music of that masterpiece and imbuing its three movements with a new fascination for listeners overly familiar with the work.

The methods of Sheriff Jess Roden remind one somewhat of those of Sherlock Holmes, although the personalities and the environments of the two are quite dissimilar. Jess is a backwoods Kentuckian who has developed his powers of observation and deduction to an extraordinary degree, as those who read "Murder at Deer Lick" and "Murder at the Schoolhouse" will remember.

Plans for a secondary highway system through New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, to be used in the event main arteries are taken over by the Army during an emergency, have been drawn up, it was revealed last night by members of the Metropolitan Defense Transport Committee, who participated in a round-table discussion over WOR of the Mutual Broadcasting System.

Asserting that the people of New York City had "entrusted their affairs too long to an amateur fireman with a Napoleonic-Caesar complex on a part-time basis," Solicitor General Henry Epstein last night urged believers in racial and religious tolerance to vote for District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor.

Although a public official who assumes duties over and above those of his office is called a "part-time" official, the people understand him, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday, as he accepted from Howard Chandler Christy, the artist, a poster publicizing the campaign against false fire alarms.

The former Danish freighter Helga, now operating in the Chilean Line service between South America and New York under the Chilean flag, sailed on Thursday for Valparaiso after a delay caused by difficulty with Danish seamen among the crew.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Waiting for developments in the Far East, Russia and on the Atlantic to take more definite form, President Roosevelt today subordinated his interest in world affairs to the affairs of a Hudson Valley squire entertaining royalty.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Reports of a material improvement in the domestic demand for flour and persistent buying by mills kept wheat prices on the upgrade from the opening today. At no time did the market show indications of weakness, and every small dip disclosed good support.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 18 -- By the narrow margin of a first-period safety, Ohio State defeated Purdue, 16 to 14, today before 66,074 fans in the opening Western Conference contest for each squad.

OMAHA, Oct. 18 -- There have been recent suggestions that isolation is wearing thin in the Middle West and speculation over how real that trend is and how far it has gone. For six or eight months there have been witnesses trying to say that it was very real indeed, but they haven't been taken very seriously until now.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The British War Relief Society will benefit from the gala concert which will take place here in the Westchester County Center on Saturday evening. Proceeds of the concert, featuring songs by Miss Gracie Fields and a program by the United States Marine Band, will increase the beneficiary's fund for aid to bomb-shocked children in Great Britain.

Almost one-third of America's homes are substandard, according to official real property surveys conducted in 419 different localities during the past seven years of about 10,000,000 dwellings, Nathan Straus, Administrator of the USHA, reported yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 18 -- Beautifully handled through all sorts of tests by Clifford H. Wallace, Bryngarw ireside, James Simpson's thorough-hunting spaniel, won the open all-age springer stake which concluded the Bath County Field Trial Association meeting high in the mountains today.

As the Securities and Exchange Commission approaches the final stage in its application of the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, the question is being raised in utility and investment circles how it can carry out this program successfully with due respect to the investor, under present admittedly unfavorable market conditions for utility equities.

PANAMA, Oct. 18 -- It was learned here today from the most reliable sources that the Cabinet this afternoon resolved to allow ships under Panaman registry to be armed and that public announcement of this decision was due soon.

JEROME KERN'S "Scenario for Orchestra" on themes from his music for "Show Boat" will receive its world premiere by the Cleveland Orchestra, under Artur Rodzinski, this Thursday and Saturday nights, in Cleveland.

Combination of socially motivated thinking and a knowledge of concrete reality may escape the "puttering of the strict vocationalist" and the "futility of the closet philosopher" in formulating a wise business policy, Dean Roswell C. McCrea, retiring dean of the Columbia University School of Business, declared in a report made public today.

Moscow, city of white stone, city of forty-times-forty churches, to recall two of its pre-revolutionary characterizations, is fighting once more, as so many times in its history, against invaders at its gates. The city is one of the most picturesque and one of the dingiest capitals in the world.

The present shortage of tulips, hyacinths and many other bulbs formerly imported has given gardeners a new interest in the Bulbous Irises, one of the least known of the so-called Dutch bulbs, but destined, as their merits get to be more widely known, to become a leading flower in late Spring gardens throughot America.

DETROIT, Oct. 18 -- Nine ring-leaders of a wildcat strike at the Great Lakes Steel Corporation in Ecorse were suspended from union office and membership today by Orval Kincaid, district director for the Steel Workers Organizing Committee. He said he was convinced that there were not more than seventy-five workers who were followers of the suspended strike leaders.

The Federal food stamp program has added more than $10,000,000 to the purchasing power of needy families in this city since it became operative on a city-wide basis last May 1, Louis L. Horch, district supervisor of the Surplus Marketing Administration, reported yesterday.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Minnesota mauled Pittsburgh's Panthers, 39 to 0, today, but the Golden Gophers' captain, Bruce Smith, was knocked out of the ball game.
THIS novel can make you think of a folk ballad if you stare at it long enough; of a kind of Frankie and Johnny in prose.

Ordinarily we do not think of cool days and frosty nights as seed-planting time. But after all the bulbs are in the ground and most of the garden made tidy for the Winter there is still time to plant many varieties of seed which actually prefer to spend their Winter in cold and frozen earth rather than spiffy paper envelopes.

VICHY, France, Oct. 18 -- Once again, at a time when. French-German relations absorb general interest, the communique issued after a Saturday Cabinet Council is devoted entirely to internal questions. That fact causes no surprise, however, since it is realized that conversations upon "collaboration" may be prolonged before any concrete decisions are made public.

HERE is a concise factful survey of primitive cultures which can almost be described as a picture book. Of 230 pages in the main text of "By Their Works," 107 are given over to extremely impressive photographs which show in their rich variety just what those "works" were and are.

Under the auspices of the Central Council of Associations, an organization comprising women's groups cooperating in behalf of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York in its work for seamen, a nautical card party will be held on the afternoon of Oct. 29 in the Apprentices Room at the headquarters of the institute, 25 South Street.

IT happens at the oddest times and places. My wife and I have felt it most acutely when we have been to a "movie."

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Abnormal psychology at Colgate University this year will become largely the study of problems related to war, primarily to encourage greater tolerance toward peoples and nations suffering in the present conflict, Dr. George H. Estabrooks, head of the psychology department, announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Forty-three of the country's leading financiers and railroad and car manufacturing executives, including J. Pierpont Morgan, were subpoenaed today by a special three-judge Federal court to appear as witnesses in the government's anti-trust suit against the Pullman companies.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Oct. 19 -- Russian forces continued throughout yesterday to hang on to the outer defenses of Moscow at all points, despite increasingly heavy German thrusts, and military commentators on the Russian radio early today professed to see some indications of a change in the Russians' favor.

WASHINGTON. FROM a sprawling, whitewashed building erected during the World War and more nearly resembling a factory than the monumental structures that house most government departments, the vast and expanding establishment of the United States Navy is operated.
A powerful St. Francis Prep eleven outclassed the Brooklyn College junior varsity yesterday, scoring six touchdowns and a safety for a 41-0 victory, at the Bedford Avenue field.

It satisfies a spiritual need because it bestows a spiritual power. But what it has to give must be placed at the disposal of the great masses of men and women of America.

Reviewing the recent apartment house renting reason in an optimistic manner, Clement E. Merowit, head of the realty firm bearing his name, states that the occupancy record for the buildings under the firm's management stands at 94.3 per cent for the coming year.

The referendum for a smaller county board in Westchester is being supported vigorously by clubwomen of the county, and an educational campaign is being promoted for the weeks remaining before the election.

A mid-Autumn season replete with benefit theatre parties currently is providing members of society with opportunities to aid various philanthropic enterprises and at the same time to seek diversion by attending special performances of outstanding plays.

Against a background formed by government and industry feverishly moving heaven, earth and dollars to expand aluminum production for defense and by civilians giving up their old aluminum in a nation-wide scrap collection, there is believed to be rising an accumulated pile of low-grade "orphan" aluminum which may run into millions of pounds.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 18 (AP) -- For two years, Jack Jenkins, 200-pound blocking back from Texarkana, Texas, had been clearing the paths for his Vanderbilt team-mates, but they let him carry the ball today and he personally conducted the Commodores to a l4-to-7 victory over Georgia Tech.
AMES, Iowa, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Missouri roared a challenge for Big Six Conference honors by routing Iowa State, 39 to 13, today before 15,000 homecoming day fans.

A little less than 118 years ago President Monroe laid down the doctrine that we should consider any attempt on the part of European Powers to "extend their system to any portion of this hemisphere as dangerous to our peace and safety." THE long annals of English letters have been starred by a number of unique and brusque individualities who, for want of a better word, we call dynamic. Ben Jonson (by legend, mostly), Doctor Johnson, Doctor Parr, Sir Richard Burton, Cunningham Grahame and others, the majority of them better remembered for their personalities than their literary accomplishments, form a galaxy that is England's peculiar contribution to literature.

Supreme Court Justice William R. Wilson sustained yesterday the nomination of Robert H. Haskell, right wing member of the American Labor party, for the nomination for Surrogate of Kings County by the King's County Executive Committee, and invalidated a meeting of the left wing members of the County Committee that nominated William Stanley Miller, Republican candidate for Surrogate.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 18 -- The division of opinion in the States of this section on the war issue is still necessarily in the realm of individual judgment. Perhaps the most competent political judgment in Minnesota is that of Governor Harold E. Stassen, who identifies isolationism in this State with "the Lindbergh influence" and thinks that it is on the decline.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- In a surprise move, Wayne L. Morse, chairman of President Roosevelt's fact finding board, offered today the board's services to arbitrate or mediate the demands of about 1,250,000 railroad employes for wage increases.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Southern California's Trojans crept slowly but successfully out of the football doldrums today, defeating a stubborn Washington State eleven, 7 -- 6, in a game that kept 40,000 fans on uneasy street.

News that Japan had decided to continue peace discussions with the United States bolstered the cotton market yesterday and lifted prices to maximum gains of 15 to 18 points. Closing prices on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 9 to 12 points.

The most important Red Cross meeting here since the first World War will be held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow to plan "all-out service in national defense" and to map the greatest membership roll-call in history.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Oct. 18 -- The tiny country that was Belgium is still marked upon the map of Europe, wedged between Germany and what was France. On the map of Africa, athwart the Equator, is limned almost garishly the Belgian Congo, a colony some fifty times the size of the mother country.

MOSCOW (By Wireless). NOT a few travelers who returned to Britain or the United States from Berlin in the years immediately following the last World War reported conversations which they had had in the bar of the Adlon Hotel or in shabby night clubs with seedy and disgruntled German ex-officers who were not so humiliated by defeat that they were incapable of contemplating revenge.

EXETER, N.H., Oct. 18 -- Hugh Knowlton, former Groton school halfback, contributed mainly to the Yale freshmen eleven's 19-to-0 victory over Exeter today in a game which broke wide open for the Elis in the third period.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 18 -- Tufts ran into the Brown powerhouse today and was chased home with a 28-6 spanking, the first defeat for the Jumbos in four starts. Close to 10,000 saw Brown take a 28-0 lead in the first half and then use a flock of substitutes thereafter.
HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 18 -- With Frank Bradley's touchdown and extra point in the last quarter, Peddle today defeated St. John's Prep of Brooklyn, 14 to 10.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Southern California's Trojans crept slowly but successfully out of the football doldrums today, defeating a stubborn Washington State eleven, 7 -- 6, in a game that kept 40,000 fans on uneasy street.

News that Japan had decided to continue peace discussions with the United States bolstered the cotton market yesterday and lifted prices to maximum gains of 15 to 18 points. Closing prices on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 9 to 12 points.

The most important Red Cross meeting here since the first World War will be held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow to plan "all-out service in national defense" and to map the greatest membership roll-call in history.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Federal Government is not infrequently charged with failure to practice what it preaches, but in the matter of conserving paper, at least, some Federal departments and agencies have turned over a new leaf -- or rather, started making one leaf do the work of two.

There are many reasons to believe that there will soon be heavy fighting in North Africa. One of the best is that the Poles have been sent into Tobruk. They were ordered to the beleaguered city only a fortnight ago and already Cairo reports them in action beyond the outer trenches.

BATON ROUGE, La., Oct 1 (AP) -- With a burst of cleverly-executed scoring power, Louisian State University's Bengals spran an upset tonight by conquering the powerful Rice Owls, Southwest Conference kingpins, 27 to 0, before 25,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- An Axis squeeze play, requiring American military defensive operations in both oceans at the same time, has always been recognized by this government as a possible outcome of the alliance between Germany and Japan. Therefore, when a Japanese Cabinet crisis on one day was followed the next by the torpedoing of an American destroyer off Iceland, officials naturally asked themselves, "Has it come?"

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18 -- The Army mule has a kick that he has not had in a half dozen years. A beautifully drilled, hard-hitting cadet eleven toppled Yale before a gathering of 56,000 in the Bowl today, 20 to 7, performing with such fire and fury as to bring back memories of the days of Jack Buckler and Co.

Since its formation five years ago last Summer, the American Labor party has occupied a strategic position in the politics of New York State and City. The close to half a million members enrolled in its ranks helped re-elect President Roosevelt in 1936 and 1940, twice aided Governor Lehman and provided Mayor La Guardia with his margin of victory in 1937.

Editor The New York Times Book Reviev: THOMAS KERNAN'S book "France on Berlin Time," recently reviewed in your columns, contains a reference on the number and behavior of the German emigrants in France which cannot remain unanswered.

Considerable progress has been achieved under the auspices of the Bronx Board of Trade during the first half of its six-year program adopted in October, 1938, for improvements held essential to the future prosperity of the Bronx, Maskell E. Fox, president of the board, announced yesterday.

HATTIE is 7, gay as a lark, and getting on fine in Grade 2B. "A different girl entirely," says her father. "A wicked, stubborn girl" was an earlier family dictum on Hattie when, at 5 1/2, she was letting the baby carriage roll down hill. She's the same child differently handled.

Some tribute is due to the steel industry for the addition of 6,000,000 net tons of annual productive capacity since the outbreak of war in Europe and particularly during the early stages of our own national defense program. Including steel facilities now in process of completion, it will bring annual capacity to 88,000,000 net tons by the close of this year.

HERE is a gay and gossipy batch of letters from a lady -- for ten years a confirmed stayer-away from movies -- who suddenly went to Hollywood. The reason she went was because the book, "Country Lawyer," just finished by her husband, Bellamy Partridge, soared at once into the best-seller list.

MANILA, P.I. -- The growing Pacific crisis has upset the old argument that any Japanese expansion southward would strike directly at the Philippines and thus force the United States into war. Japan today is playing for bigger stakes.

IT is a simple trick of sophistry to dispose of what one does not like by calling it names. Thus one could label Arnold Schoenberg's Pierrot Lunaire (Columbia, four twelve-inch records, $4.50) as a decadent work and feel that the score had been put in its place.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- The Mustangs of Southern Methodist romped to a 20-to-7 intersectional victory over Auburn today largely because of a stellar performance by Fullback Preston Johnston.

Retail trade in the New York area continued active during most of last week. Aided by gains of 30 per cent or more over a year ago on Columbus Day, department-store sales indicated increases of 10 to 15 per cent for the week. Chain drug, shoe and variety store sales showed larger gains.

ABOUT this time of year many women are getting last year's Winter clothes out of storage and trying to decide which of them can go through another season. Most of the garments will look pretty sad; the skirts are apt to be a bit too long and genarally saggy, hats tired and slightly funny like the ones you see at costume rental companies.

Politics still is supposed to be a man's game, but in the impending city election enough women are waging earnest battle on the political front to form a petticoat parade. Not only are soft voices being raised in pleas for election to the City Council, but several efficient women are invading a post usually reserved for men -- that of the cigar-dispensing campaign manager.

Closer cooperation between the Board of Education's child guidance bureau and the various city welfare and social agencies was urged yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at the tenth anniversary conference of the bureau, held at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Martha Lipton, mezzo - soprano and winner of a National Federation of Music Clubs award for 1939, yesterday afternoon assumed the role of Dorabella, the weaker of the two fickle sisters, in the New Opera Company's production of Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte" at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- President Roosevelt's statement of labor policy to the convention of the American Federation of Labor is to be followed by a pronouncement to American Labor designating the procedure which should be followed in cooperating with the President's plea for maximum defense production without strikes.

Abraham Lincoln High's football team downed DeWitt Clinton High, 19 to 0, at Lincoln Field in Brooklyn yesterday. While the Honest Abes scored their third straight decision and remained unscored upon, Clinton found itself rudely knocked from the ranks of the unbeaten.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Oct. 20 -- The Red Army defenders of Moscow threw German forces back from Maloyaroslavets, about sixty-five miles southwest of the capital, in heavy fighting yesterday, according to Russian reports received here today.

BANGUI, Ubangi, Shari Territory, French Equatorial Africa, Oct. 19 -- The white population of this garrison town and small administrative and trading center has increased sixfold while other similar places have recorded rises that are even greater.

BERLIN, Oct. 19 -- German troops have broken through the "especially strong" Soviet defense system on the front before Moscow, and have captured the important port of Taganrog, on the southern front, the Germans reported tonight.

Here and in Washington preparations are being rushed for the opening of the hearings on revision of the securities acts, scheduled to start before the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce on Oct. 28. On Friday representatives of the financial industry and of the Securities and Exchange Commission conferred with Clarence Lea, chairman of the Congressional committee, but reached no conclusions on the order of business.

Twelve hundred persons attended a dinner celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of Beth Israel Hospital last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and heard messages of congratulations from President Roosevelt, Viscount Halifax, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman and Bishop William T. Manning.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Since the dark days immediately following the collapse of France there has been a remarkable rise in virtually all high-grade securities on the London market. This has oecurred despite the frequent military setbacks to the Allies and reflects, generally speaking, confidence in the ultimate result of the war that has been growing in the past year.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 19 -- When the Germans first rolled into Greece they were fully equipped and amply provided with food. Quickly, however, it became evident this self-sustaining policy was for the period of the active campaign only.

Two citations for bravery In the performance of duty are laurels which would suffice most men, but Charles A. Duffy, 37-year-old patrolman, is not content to bask in the reflection of past glories. Having served with distinction on the police force fourteen years, Patrolman Duffy is combining his work with a quest for academic honors at City College, where he is enrolled as the school's oldest freshman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The prospect loomed tonight that the Federal Government might withdraw contracts from or possibly go so far as to seize and operate the plant of Air Associates, Inc., at Bendix, N.J., because the position taken by the company toward the strike that has been in progress since July 12 is considered unsatisfactory by the National Defense Mediation Board.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Following friendly representations by the British and Russian Governments, news has been received here from Afghanistan that the government in Kabul has decided to expel all Germans and Italians in residence in the country.

Adoption by the city of a unified plan for all future neighborhood rehabilitation, coordinating needed housing with park and playground construction, the laying out of streets and provision for essential facilities is recommended by Park Commissioner Robert Moses in a report that he will submit to Mayor La Guardia today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Those of us who work in public health, social welfare and other fields related to the health of our people feel a need at this time to express ourselves against the accusations made by Dr. Emanuel Josephson regarding this administration's endeavor to make New York one of the healthiest cities in our country.

HOUSTON, Texas, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Postmaster General Frank C. Walker, addressing the National Conference of Catholic Charities, said today that "We of America cannot -- we shall not -- seek a peace purchased at the sacrifice of the hopes, the ambitions, the freedom of others."

The American Republics liner Brazil is due today from Buenos Aires via Montevideo, Rio de Janeiro, Santos and Trinidad. Her passengers include a large party of Deputies from the Argentine National Congress, headed by Dr. Jose Luis Cantilo, President of the Chamber, invited here by the Department of State of the United States.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Oct. 19 -- The markets of the small Continental countries showed mostly increasing easiness last week, profit-taking, dividend-limiting measures and other factors overriding the intrinsic monetary abundance.

A Bishop from the South Seas gave the pontifical benediction at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon at the close of the celebration there for the Archdiocese of Catholic Mission Sunday, which was observed throughout the world yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The rampant Chicago Bears uncorked another savage offensive to crush the Detroit Lions, 49 to 0, today before 29,980 spectators.

Pleading for a new church consciousness, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared in his sermon yesterday in Riverside Church, that the very existence of Christianity and the most precious spiritual values of mankind depend upon the creation of a Christian morale to combat Nazism, fascism and communism.

ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- The Republican State organization is circulating independent nominating petitions, in the name of the City Fusion party, in order to be able to have its candidate for State controller appear on the ballot in two places, it became known tonight as the leaders assembled here in advance of the Republican State committee meeting tomorrow.
LONDON, Monday, Oct. 20 -- Moscov and adjoining districts were placed under a state of siege today as a citizens' army surged westward to fight the German invaders.

The New York City Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild, of which Osmond Fraenkel is president and Robert J. Silberstein secretary, announced yesterday its disapproval of the candidacy of Paul P. Rao, Democratic nominee for Supreme Court Justice in the First Judicial District, on the report of its judiciary committee that Mr. Rao was associated with profascist groups and that he was not qualified by professional attainments for the office.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 19 -- The cotton futures market here went last week through one of the heaviest periods of liquidation and stop-loss selling in a long period and active positions lost $6.50 to $7.50 a bale before there was any semblance of a technical rebound.

The Greater New York Industrial Union Council, C.I.O., announced yesterday the endorsement of candidates for whom it will make an active campaign through the Trade Union Committee for the Election of Labor's Candidates, of which Austin Hogan, president of the Transport Workers Union of Greater New York, is head.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The stock market has resisted the depressing news from Russia and Japan as stubbornly as the Russians have been resisting the attack on their capital. It is indeed Russia's fight which largely has supported the markets in this highly critical period.

After almost a year and a half of unprecedented appropriations for national defense, the Federal Government is entering a period of wholesale borrowing to finance this huge effort. True, a considerable amount of borrowing has been done and devices have been set in motion to tap the savings of individuals, but until recently the rate of expenditure had not reached the point where really large-scale borrowing by the Treasury was necessary.

A revival of "As You Like It" will open tonight at the Mansfield Theatre. It will be the first Shakespearean offering of the season. In the company are Helen Craig (Rosalind), Alfred Drake (Orlando), Carol Stone (Celia), Leonard Elliott (Touchstone) and, among others, Philip Bourneuf, Paula Trueman, John Call, Arthur L. Sachs and David Leonard, Eugene S. Bryden and Ben Boyar are the producers.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19 -- A well-known liberal, Dr. Israel resigned in 1940 from the advisory committee of the American Youth Congress, and about four years ago resigned from the national executive board of the American League for Peace and Democracy.

A REALLY astounding day, this past Saturday. There were no major upsets on the intercollegiate gridirons. That came close to making it a record-breaking afternoon in football annals. Practically everything turned out about as expected, give or take a few points here and there.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- A new price schedule was announced today by Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, bringing virtually all major types of cotton goods made of carded yarn, from coarse bagging and tough work-clothing denims to fine-count broadcloths, under ceiling prices automatically adjustable to the price of spot raw cotton.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 19 -- Claims amounting to more than $155,000 have been filed against the estate of Dr. Glenn Frank, former president of the University of Wisconsin, it was learned today.

Norman Vincent Peale declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twentyninth Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19 -- "Up in Mabel's Room," bedroom farce of two decades ago by Wilson Collison and Otto Harbach, has been acquired by Edward Small for filming with Hona Massey and Lotus Hayward this Winter. Production will follow Small's "Twin Beds," which is also a revival from the same period.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 20 -- General Eiki Tojo, the new Premier, reported his assumption of the offices of Premier and War and Home Minister to the Sun Goddess at the Ise shrine yesterday and then returned to Tokyo by airplane where he made a similar report at the shrine to Emperor Meiji and at the Yasakuni shrine for the war dead.
PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- The Paterson Panthers defeated the Newark Bears at Hinchcliffe Stadium today, 28-12, to wrest the American Football Association lead from Jersey City.

Communists, Nazis and Fascists will be barred from membership in the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, A.F. of L., when the organization's new constitution becomes operative Jan. 1, it was learned last night.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said tonight that a news story she read recently, which said that German girls were told it was their duty to have children by German soldiers regardless of whether they were married, "took my breath away."

The Washington-New York overnight express of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad will bring the Duke and Duchess of Windsor to Jersey City at 6:30 A.M. today. By arriving at a terminal remote not only from this city proper but from the business section of Jersey City, the former King Edward VIII of England and his American-born wife hope to avoid crowds.

Charles E. Murphy, campaign manager for District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic Mayoralty candidate, and his running mates, declared yesterday that political opponents were spending $1,000,000 "in a desperate attempt to remain in power at City Hall."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Chairman Connally of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee accused Senator Wheeler today of conducting "guerrilla warfare" against the national defense and foreign policy programs. His statement was in reply to Mr. Wheeler's assertion that any attempt to repeal the Neutrality Act outright would be countered with a war resolution designed to test Congressional sentiment on the question of war or peace.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The British Board of Trade's index of commodity prices for September, based on 1930 as 100, was 154.3, compared with 153.2 for August and 141.0 for September, 1940.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Foot Service Equipment Industry, Inc.; the American Vitrified China Manufacturers Association, their officers and directors, member corporations and a number of manufacturers of such equipment have been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease "certain agreements and combinations" to restrict competition, it was announced today.
ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Oct. 19 -- The United States Government may go out of the rum business, or at least cut down on production.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Oct. 19 -- When Captain Walter Budd called us on Friday to report that the broadbill were plentiful on Great South Bay on either side of the mouth of Great River he was not exaggerating, for we have just completed two days of the best broadbill shooting we have ever had.

Apartment renting, active on the West Side over the week-end, was featured by leases with three brothers, all members of the firm of Penchassoff Bros., Parisian fur merchants. The rentals were arranged by the Apartment Renting Company, brokers, to Alexander Penchassoff in 175 West Seventy-ninth Street, to George in 945 West End Avenue, and to Albert in 898 West End Avenue.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Dr. Max Mailhouse, eminent neurologist and Professor Emeritus of Neurology in the Yale Medical School, died tonight of a heart ailment at his home here at the age of 84.

Two hundred persons attended yesterday a special service at the Central Church of the Disciples of Christ, 142 West Eighty-first Street, during which the Rev. Ira W. Langston was inducted as pastor and the 131st anniversary of the founding of the church was celebrated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Over the next, five years the nation's defense program, as now planned will cost $77,000,000,000, including the pending $6,000,000,000 supplemental lease-lend appropriation, the National Economy League estimated today in its monthly bulletin.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Johnny Borican of the Asbury Park A.C., won the National A.A.U. pentathlon championship today at Warinanco Park. Borican, who last July took the decathlon event, became the first athlete ever to win these two crowns in the same year.

A blanket of snow now covers the bloody battlefields of Russia from the Arctic to Rostov-on-the-Don. Rostov is almost 800 miles south of Leningrad, where the cold is already bitter. The air around Moscow is sharp and frosty. The roads have hardened, but are choked with snow.

Dog Onto Bed On cold nights many dogs of tolerable sensibility beg to be taken up on the bed. This is a situation we must all face squarely at this time of year. Some dogs are frank about it; they file their request openly at bedtime.

Low and other members of the organizing group of the Associated Leagues for a Declared War, urging the United States to again meddle in European affairs, may I remind them that the people of the United States are more concerned with the maintenance of this country than they are in the maintenance of any foreign power.

MOSCOW, Oct. 19 -- With the residents of Moscow rallying tonight to defend the city, a "thorough transformation" of the suburbs within the last few days was reported by Tass, official news agency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The United States destroyer Kearny, torpedoed last Friday morning 350 miles southwest of Iceland, has reached port, and eleven members of her crew are missing and ten others injured as a result of the attack, the Navy Department announced tonight.

KENSICO, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- In the presence of 500 playwrights, authors, actors and friends, a tall granite shaft that suggests the Obelisk at Karnak, sculptured in relief to symbolize comedy, music, tragedy and authorship, was unveiled in Kensico Cemetery this afternoon as a memorial to the members of the Actors Fund of America.

John P. Connolly, an unattached entrant from the Bronx, today is the new national A.A.U. 15,000-meter walking champion, having led home a field of star performers in the annual event at Clove Lakes Park in Staten Island yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- A list of 1,124 names of Federal employes alleged to be Communists or affiliates of subversive organizations was sent tonight to Attorney General Biddle by Representative Dies, chairman of the Committee on Un-American Activities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said today that industrial output advanced seasonally during September, holding the adjusted index of activity at 160 per cent of the 1935-39 average, the third month that level has been maintained.

The third and last of the season's novelties on the schedule of the Ballet Basse de "Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House took place last night in the form of the world premiere of "Saratoga," with choreography by Leonide Massine and libretto and music by Jaromir Weinberger.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- General liquidation developed in the grain and soy bean markets last week, with wheat falling to the lowest prices since July, and dropping the permissible limit of 10 cents a bushel on Thursday. It was the first wide-open break in the general market since May, 1940, when Germany started to invade Holland and Belgium.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 19 -- The increased threat of a Japanese attack on British territories in the Far East as a result of the fall of the Konoye Cabinet finds defense preparations in these territories at an advanced stage.

The international marine terminal at La Guardia Field saw one of its busiest days yesterday as one of Pan American Airways' giant flying boats, the Dixie Clipper, departed in the morning carrying forty-eight passengers for Bermuda and Lisbon and another, the Atlantic Clipper, arrived a few hours later with fifty-two passengers.

PASSAIC, N.J., Oct. 19 -- Louis Knecht an expert in synthetic fibers and president of the Walser Manufacturing Company in Clifton, N.J., died yesterday at his home here, 97 Aycrigg Avenue, after a long illness. His age was 72.

ROME, Oct. 19 -- Conversations began here today between Dr. Wilhelm Funk, Germany's Minister of Economics, and Raffaelo Riccardi, the Italian Minister of Foreign Exchange, to reach what was believed to be a preliminary understanding on the form and extent of Italy's share in the exploitation of the resources of the Russian territory conquered by the German Army.

The Eighth Regiment, New York Guard, the colorful Washington Greys, consisting of 500 men and fifty-five officers, attended its annual solemn high military mass at 11 A.M. yesterday in the Fordham University Church. Six hundred relatives and friends of the guardsmen also attended.

ALBANY, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Registration figures from, major cities indicated today fewer persons will vote on Nov. 4 than in recent comparable "off years" despite hopes for a last-minute upsurge because of the unexpected contest for State Controller.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday that a whispering campaign that he is an anti-Semite and a member of the Christian Front was being directed against him. He made the charge in speaking to a gathering of the Bochnia-Wishnitz and Birgler Benevolent Association at the National Palace, East Houston Street and Second Avenue.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices declined from 98.4 to 98.3. As was the case in the previous week, rises in semi-manufactured goods prices were slightly outweighed by declines in raw material and finished product items.

PESHAWAR, Northwest Frontier Province, India, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Afghanistan radio at Kabul, the capital, announced today the expulsion of German and Italian nationals from that primitive country, a natural gateway between German-invaded Russia and India and the only gap in the 2,000-mile political and military front the British are building across central and southwestern Asia.
ROME, Oct. 19 (UP) -- Humor magazines started a campaign of Jokes, cartoons and wisecracks about the food and clothing rations this week-end in an attempt to lighten the Italians' troubles.

Brooklyn football fans, after watching the Dodgers bow to the Chicago Cardinals yesterday at Ebbets Field, became convinced that they should adopt the "Wait Till Next Year" chant voiced so often in the past by the borough's baseball rooters.

OTTAWA, Oct. 19 -- The plan for fixing a ceiling for prices and wages in practically all Canadian industry, which Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King announced last night in a radio speech to the country, will be drafted this coming week, it is expected, in an order-in-council and will become effective on Nov. 15.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- The imported brown gelding Dalchoolin, owned by Mrs. Elizabeth Correll of New York City and shown by Gordon Wright, today added another title to his collection when he captured the hunter championship of the seventh annual Fall Hutchinson horse show, held at the Hutchinson Farms.

HYDE PARK, Oct. 19 -- President Roosevelt decided to remain at his estate here until tomorrow to enjoy the clear October weather. As a result he will not arrive in Washington until Tuesday morning, then and there to deal directly with developments growing out of the torpedoing of the United States destroyer Kearny off Iceland, the Far Eastern tension and the armaments needs of Russia.

The New York City Symphony Orchestra opened its third season of concerts sponsored by Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project last night in Carnegie Hall. Reginald Stewart, conductor of the Toronto Philharmonic Orchestra, directed, and Joseph Szigeti, violinist, was the soloist.

While some popular gift items will be absent from store shelves during the Christmas selling season as a result of shortages, most advertisers are making plans for extensive campaigns in anticipation of a good volume of business. Stocks in the cosmetic, jewelry, toilet goods, luggage, men's furnishings and women's accessory fields, with few exceptions, will be ample to take care of all needs because stores have bought heavily in advance.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Soon after dawn tomorrow 200 "hostile" bombing planes will simulate a raid on cities in the Carolinas and Georgia and the Third Air Force will try to drive them back to theoretical bases in the West Indies.

The Brooklyn Bureau of Charities spent $674,368 for relief, services and management in assisting 21,546 men, women and children during the fiscal year ended April 30, 1941, It was announced yesterday in the bureau's sixty-third annual report issued by Mrs. Mary Childs Draper, president.
The eight-story fireproof garage building at 247-59 West Fifty-fourth Street has been sold by the Bank for Savings to an investment syndicate in a transaction negotiated by Arthur L. Dryfoos, broker.
CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 19 -- The War Cabinet and the full Cabinet held emergency meetings yesterday to consider the Pacific situation. All Cabinet members will remain near Canberra.

Opening's of the new cruise lines attracted considerable attention in the wholesale market last week. Many large prints were shown in the collection. Tapered bottom slacks were included in several lines and a good number of sports dresses had matching rabbit's hair jackets.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 19 -- Ending fifteen years of continuous effort by Nassau County, the Long Island State Park Commission and the town of Hempstead, the War Department has agreed to the improvement of Jones Inlet, between the east end of Point Lookout and the west end of Jones Beach.

Mrs. Don Smith of Rumford, R.I., found herself the owner of a dog that came through as tough a best-in-breed class as could well be assembled when her Ch. H.M.S. Kiddie Boot's Son took the top award in the eleventh annual specialty show of the Brooklyn Boston Terrier Club at the Lost Battalion Building in Elmhurst last night.

The twentieth annual parade and ceremony of the Massing of the Colors brought yesterday a display of 350 flags and banners as 2,000 service men and civilians marched down Fifth Avenue from Seventy-eighth Street to St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church at Fifty-third Street, where the observance culminated in the traditional vesper service.

NEW YORK Mrs. Frederick J. McEvoy of the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria will give a dinner dance on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 29 for her debutante niece, Miss Anne Rogers Benjamin, daughter of Mrs. George Hyde Clark of Aiken, S.C., and Henry Rogers Benjamin of 2 East Eighty-seventh Street.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The New York Tuberculosis and Health Association is convinced that it should speak out in view of the current controversy over the record of the Department of Health of this city.

The 1,000,000 school children of New York City are urgently in need of a coordinated program of social services, according to a report issued yesterday by the local chapter of the American Association of Social Workers, 289 Fourth Avenue.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- A demand for military action on the Western Front, coupled with a plea for a thorough overhaul of British methods of production -- each designed to bring relief in its own way to Russia -- was made today by the National Council of the Engineering and Allied Trades Shop Stewards.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 -- Covering 56 yards on three forward passes by Slingin' Sammy Baugh in the closing minutes, the Washington Redskins came from behind to beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 21 to 17, today in a National Football League game before 19,071 at Shibe Park.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- At their low point last week soy bean futures on the Board of Trade were 47 1/2 cents a bushel below the high point reached about a month ago. The rapid approach of the harvesting of a crop that will be the largest ever known had considerable influence on sentiment, and when stop-loss orders were uncovered in profusion the market dropped rapidly.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- A fawn-colored Afghan hound, Champion Rana of Chaman of Royal Irish, was best in the National Capital Kennel Club dog show today for Mrs. H.A. Florsheim of West Norwalk, Conn.

BUFFALO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The C.I.O. United Automobile Workers Union voted today in favor of a strike at the Bell Aircraft Corporation's two warplane plants in Buffalo and Niagara Falls, but decided to withhold action "until all possible means of arbitration have been exhausted."

Ethel Elfenbein, who gave her first Town Hall piano recital two seasons ago, was heard again yesterday afternoon in the same auditorium. In the interim Miss Elfenbein's playing has grown far more mature and gained considerably in dynamic range and application of color.

BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- Stagnant business at irregular prices was the reaction of German stock markets to fresh reports of spectacular German successes on the Eastern Front during the past week. This paradoxical situation confirms once more the statement that the tone of the German boerses is governed primarily by domestic and technical factors and not by military or political developments.

PANAMA, Oct. 19 -- Germany's attempt to use the ousting of Arnulfo Arias from the Presidency of Panama as anti-American propaganda in Latin America, by charging United States complicity, has been an almost complete failure. The Latin-American press, with few exceptions, has taken a clearer view of the change in government here than many newspapers in the United States, particularly the noninterventionist press.

No. 9 along the lane that winds through a bustling New England town is an old-fashioned bakery, warm and welcoming and filled with the odor of baking bread. When a rich, delicious, chocolaty fragrance fills the lane it means that brownies are coming out of the big brick ovens, being tipped from their warm pans and neatly wrapped for market.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Oct. 19 -- The Long Island Indians crushed the New York Yankees, 47 -- 0, for their fourth victory in the American Association football race at Memorial Field before a crowd of 3,000 today.

Industrial plants continue to figure largely in the realty activity in New Jersey, with many firms participating in the defense effort taking additional facilities for expansion of their production programs.

BERLIN, Oct. 19 -- The charge that the incident of the torpedoing of the United States destroyer Kearny was invented by President Roosevelt "to bamboozle Congress, with genuine Jewish unscrupulousness," into modifying the Neutrality Act characterized comments that appeared suddenly in this morning's Berlin press, after the incident had not been so much as mentioned to the German public for two days.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19 -- The steel industry continued last week to face the double threat of loss in production due to shortages of raw material and the possibility that the captive coal mines might go out on strike, although a thirty-day truce has been extended on a day-to-day basis.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 UP) -- The Transportation Association of America reported today that railroads were undercapitalized and that while the wages of rail labor have been increasing' during the last decade the investor's return has been steadily declining.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 -- Before serving in Congress he had been his brother's secretary. After his election he worked for passage of the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill, of which his brother was coauthor, and for better working conditions and "living hours and wages" for New England's thousands of workers in the textile industries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- An informal poll indicated tonight that Administration leaders in the Senate have enough support to secure passage of the ship-arming resolution within ten days but cannot get enough votes in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for outright repeal of the Neutrality Act.
H.L. MENCKEN of Baltimore began his personal memoirs last year in a book called "Happy Days, 1880-1892." He carries them forward this morning in a sequel called "Newspaper Days, 1899-1906."*

Louis Waldman, chairman of the Labor and Progressive Committee for the Election of O'DwyerChurch-Fertig, charged yesterday that the list of the 168-man Physicians and Surgeons Committee made public Saturday by William M. Chadbourne, director of the Citizens Committee for the Reelection of Mayor La Guardia, "reeks with deception and constitutes a fraud on the public."

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 19 -- The golfers representing the Nassau Country Club, registering a total of 41 points, turned back the Meadow Brook, Rockaway Hunting and Piping Rock combinations in the semi-annual interclub matches at the Meadow Brook Club today.

As the football parade passes the reviewing stand, the order of march is Fordham, Navy and Pennsylvania in the East, with Villanova and Temple next in line and Army coming on in a cavalry charge as the team to watch. It's look out, Columbia on the Plains of West Point this week, and Navy may need the dreadnought Gene Flathmann, hors de combat last Saturday, when it trains its guns on Harvard at Soldiers Field.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Appeals to the President, to the clergy of America, and to religious laymeri of the nation to help save the United States from war were voiced today by a high Roman Catholic churchman and a distinguished layman in nation-wide radio broadcasts.

Introduced by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Edgar J. Nathan Jr., Fusion candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, last night pictured John F. Plunkett, whom he described as the former right-hand man of James J. Bines, convicted Tammany district leader, as the type of politician, that would be back in public office if Tammany regained control of the Borough President's office.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 19 -- About 110 German divisions, supported by some 7,000 tanks, are participating in the attack upon Moscow, it is learned here from a usually reliable neutral source in close contact with the German capital.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 19 (AP) -- With only a minute to play, Don Hutson calmly place-kicked a field goal from the 15-yard line to give the Green Bay Packers a 17-to-14 National Football League triumph over the unexpectedly tough Cleveland Rams before 13,086 spectators today.

KEARNY, N.J., Oct. 19 -- Although they were leading by 4 -- 0 at half-time, the Scots-Americans, champions of the American Soccer League, had to be content to draw with the Irish-Americans in their championship fixture at Scots Field today.

Removal from union membership of William Michelson, leader of the recent strike of employes at Gimbel Brothers Department Store, has been demanded by five members of the international executive board of the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes of America, C.I.O., it was learned last night.

History did a bit of repeating for the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday. A fortnight ago the pupils of Stout Steve Owen staggered off the field at the halfway mark, tied by the Pittsburgh Steelers. Yesterday the same thing happened, and again the Giants had too much dynamite stored in the powder room to be held back for long.

America's way of living will be the keynote of the 1941 Christmas toys, according to the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A., Inc., who will place on display at 200 Fifth Avenue today a preview of their newest wares.

Supported by active trade buying, the cotton market late last week recovered more than half the losses brought about on Thursday by the avalanche of liquidation operations following the adverse turn of the international situation.

BERLIN, Oct. 19 (U.P.) -- Competent but unofficial Nazi sources predicted today an imminent resurgence of the Moscow offensive with the early arrival of four Panzer and three other German armies, moving eastward under forced march after cleaning up the Vyazma and Bryansk pockets.

Defense officials are reported to be preparing a tremendous new military "victory program" contemplating the expenditure of more than $100,000,000,000 by the end of 1943 or early 1944. This would almost double even the present enormous plan calling for the expenditure of nearly $60,000,000,000, which extends into 1943 and 1944.

The American Institute of Graphic Arts issued a few days ago an invitation to the nation's publishers, printers and designers to cooperate in assembling an exhibition for Latin America that will reflect methods of book production in this country during the last decade.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Oct. 11 to 17 are given in the appended tabulation:
The Brookhattans, American Soccer League stars, suffered their first defeat of the season yesterday, losing to the New York Americans at Starlight Park, the Bronx, by 2-1, before a crowd of 4,000.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command today issued the following communique:
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- St. Mary's Gaels ran themselves ragged today in defeating a scrappy but outclassed University of Portland football team, 31 to 0, before a crowd of 5,000.

Arturo Toscanini will return to the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and conduct it in a special two-week post-season centennial festival, it was announced yesterday by Marshall Field, president of the board of directors of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society.

BENDIX, N.J., Oct. 19 -- F. Leroy Hill, president of Air Associates, Inc., described the company's offer as a "complete capitulation" to the National Defense Mediation Board, but Loren Houser, acting regional director of the Aviation Division of the United Automobile Workers, said it was nothing of the sort.

VICHY, Oct. 19 -- In all the belligerent countries, as well as in others, there is concern over the situation arising from the enormous State expenditures which cannot be covered by taxes and the surplus of which results in the creation of new capital. which is flooding the market.

With multicolored safety posters and brightly clad bands blaring, a thousand men, women and children marched up Seventh Avenue in uneven ranks yesterday in an effort to save lives by spreading a message of caution on the street to Harlem's thousands of inhabitants.

As Mayor La Guardia prepared to start today an intensive personal campaign in all boroughs [Page 1, Column 1], District Attorney O'Dwyer charged yesterday that he was the victim of a "whispering campaign," calling him an anti-Semite [Page 20] and his campaign manager asserted that his opponents were spending $1,000,000 on the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson, director of the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board, said today that the board's recent order restricting private building construction was not a blanket stop order and that structures which did not call for using such critical materials as steel, copper and brass might be built as freely as a year ago.

Brokers yesterday reported a series of transactions involving business properties, including several lofts, in various sections of Manhattan. A parcel in Yorkville comprising a number of structures of six to ten stories was acquired by a pharmaceutical concern now a tenant in one of the buildings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- In a sudden move, highly disconcerting to the leadership of both major parties in Congress, three Republican Senators -- Bridges of New Hampshire, Austin of Vermont and Gurney of South Dakota -- today introduced an amendment to the House-approved armed ship resolution calling for outright repeal of the entire Neutrality Act of 1939 amending the law of 1937.

All that N.Y.U. has to show for two weeks of almost constant attention to defense is 80 points on the wrong side of the scoreboard -- 31 by Syracuse Saturday and 49 by Texas A. and M. last week. This week, as the team pre- pares for its game with Holy Cross on Saturday at Worcester, Mass., Coach Mal Stevens will be inspecting the offense to see what doesn't make it click.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 20 (AP) -- At the request of the Commonwealth Judge Samuel Shull dismissed today all remaining charges against former State Senator John J. McClure and six others, including two Chicago brokers, in connection with the sale of the Chester Water Company in 1939.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was interested to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the "Thumbs Up" program of the British War Relief and wish to call attention to the significance of "Thumbs Up" to some four hundred million people fighting for their very lives.

The National Defense Mediation Board has recommended that Air Associates, Inc., reinstate men on strike. The company has agreed to do so, but has asked for a period of thirty days within which to complete reinstatements. The NDMB insists that a "very few days at the most" would be necessary.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 20 -- Police provided protection for public services today to a transport strike growing out of labor opposition to the government's mobilizing of Bolivia railway employes last week after the railway men had voted a walk-out to enforce payincrease demands.

William Blake's set of twenty-eight water-colors designed for Bunyan's "Pilgrim's Progress" will be placed on view today at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street. These water-colors, not previously seen in America, have been lent by the Marquess of Crewe and are to be exhibited through the courtesy also of George Macy, director of the Limited Editions Club.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 20 -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, Commander of the British forces in India, has intensified his vast preparations for a joint Anglo-Russian Caucasian command, coincident with the collapse of Odessa and the beginning of a new German drive upon Rostov and the Caucasus, according to information circulating in foreign military circles here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Army supply contracts awarded today amounted to $19,716,241, among which were the following, not previously published, which were granted to firms in the New York area:

Encouraged by the last-period flare against Boston College last Saturday, the men of Manhattan College started building yesterday for the game with Villanova at the Polo Grounds on Friday night. Harassed by injuries, the Jaspers did not seem too discouraged by the defeat in Boston and the energetic Herb Kopf started revamping the team.

Columbia's battered football varsity reported to Baker Field late yesterday afternoon, having been excused from contact work by Head Coach Lou Little because of a host of minor injuries suffered in last Saturday's 7-3 defeat by Georgia.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Anne O'Hare McCormick wrote a few days ago an account of the reaction against nazism on the European Continent. As one of the symptoms she quoted a Free Hungary movement by Dr. Eckhardt in the United States and Count Karolyi in London, "notable because it is the first such movement on the part of the so-called allies of Germany."

Two members of the Brooklyn College staff, one a former chair- man of the Chemistry Department, and an assistant professor of the City College Chemistry Department were suspended yesterday following charges by the conduct committee of the Board of Higher Education of "conduct unbecoming a member of the staff and neglect of duty."

The disbarment of former Municipal Court Justice C. Ernest Smith, long a political power in Staten Island and twice president of the Richmond County Bar Association, was requested yesterday by a grand jury that has been investigating with Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen the Staten Island aspect of a $1,000,000 citywide paving racket.

CARMEL, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- More than 200 ardent opening-day gun- ners accompanied by almost every breed and cross-breed of hunting dog contributed to the color, interest and excitement coincidental with the starting of the Landowner-Sportsman Project today, and although some of them failed to get birds or rabbits, every one saw game and every one seemed enthusiastic.

ANNANDALE - ON - HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- "It is an error of the first magnitude to look upon this war as Europe's; it is worldwide," Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said in an address this morning to faculty members and students of Bard College, the residential unit of Columbia.

Five brilliantly dressed Indians, descendants of the warriors who made a treaty with the young United States Government in 1784, journeyed here yesterday from upper New York State to watch a white man fight for their rights, according to white men's rules, in the Federal court.

Assailing the element of racial hatred that has been injected into the municipal campaign, District Attorney William O'Dwyer, candidate for Mayor, charged last night that "it must berths fault of the City Administration."
PANAMA, Oct. 20 (U.P.) -- The Panamanian Government decree canceling the ban against arming of ships sailing under Panamanian registry follows:

CLEVELAND, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Lem Franklin, 201, of Cleveland, scored a fifth-round technical knockout over 255-pound Abe Simon of New York in their scheduled ten-round match at the Arena tonight, to strengthen his claims for a chance at Joe Louis's crown.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 20 -- Developments in Japan have served to underline the military importance of the United States in the Malayan situation, it was stated here today.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Three men out of twelve who took to a tiny raft when their ship was sunk by a raider in the Atlantic have survived with a new tale of horror. For five and a half days they drifted under a fierce sun, sharks devouring those who failed to regain their slender margin of safety whenever the raft capsized, which it did hundreds of times.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 18:

A study of last year's Presidential campaign, made for the American Council on Public Affairs, leads Professor Hugh A. Bone of the University of Maryland to the conclusion that something has to be done to clean up campaign literature. As a dispatch to this newspaper summarizes his findings, prejudiced appeals made on behalf of both major parties touched such subjects as "the personalities and families of the candidates" and "questions of religion, race and nationality."

The Petroleum Marketing Committee for District 1, which serves as an advisory group for Petroleum Coordinator Harold L. Ickes, will meet in Washington tomorrow to frame its recommendations for rationing of gasoline to filling stations during November.

The dash, the glitter and the fierce determination of youth are poured into the piano playing of Hilde Somer, who appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night. These are not unexpected qualities in a musician of 19, but Miss Somer has them in overflowing abundance.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Maurry O'Connor and Ray Peeney of Branch Brook teamed today to post a best-ball total of 32, 31 -- 63. seven under par, and win the proamateur competition of the New Jersey P.G.A., at the Essex Fells Country Club.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Wheat showed a heavy undertone from the start today and while there were numerous small rallies they were largely the result of professional short covering, and the close of the Board of Trade was only slightly above the low point with losses of 1 5/8 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel.
