WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The speeding-up of United States aid to Russia in the present critical phase of the war was signalized by an announcement today that the government had advanced the Soviet Union $30,000,000 out of the Stabilization Fund against gold that Russia would send to this country.

Caution continued the rule in additional retailer commitments on seasonal merchandise, although a slight improvement in mail orders reaching resident buyers was reported here yesterday. For the most part, however, reorder activity lacked snap on furs, coats and suits, and dresses.

Dr. Raul Damonte Taborda, president of the Committee Investigating Anti-Argentine Activities, who arrived here yesterday from that country with eleven members of its Chamber of Deputies, said he would exchange information with Representative Martin Dies.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Middle East Headquarters of the R.A. F. issued this communique today:

Fordham began preparations for the game with Texas Christian on Saturday in the Polo Grounds with a light workout yesterday after- noon on Fordham Field. Head Coach Jim Crowley excused most of the players who had seen action against West Virginia and after an hour of signal drill, punting and passing for the remainder of the squad, he called a halt.

Bobby Ruffin, 134 1/2, Astoria, stopped Frankie Conn, 140, Brook- lyn, in the third round of the fea- ture eight-round test at the Ridge- wood Grove last night before 2,000 fans. Referee Jack O'Sullivan halt- ed the contest after 1:26 of the third in order to save the loser from further punishment.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor arrived here early yesterday with a minimum of ceremony and what would have been a complete lack of public acclaim, except for one emphatic hooray.

For the second time within three weeks a giant Nazi bomber roared over an American Export liner carrying United States citizens and war refugees from Lisbon to this country, and after examining the ship from a low altitude, disappeared, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- A series of industrial and regional priorities "clinics" at which business men can obtain information on the principles of priorities and the manner in which they are applied, was announced today by the Priorities Division of the Office of Production Management.

Fear of personal violence was admitted for the first time yesterday as a reason for acquiescence to the alleged demands of William Bioff, movie union leader who is on trial with George B. Browne, his nominal superior, on charges of extortion.

A re-check of City Fusion nominating petitions for Kings County was ordered yesterday by the Board of Elections after a report from the board's Brooklyn office said they lacked sufficient valid signatures. The board, at its meeting yesterday, also rejected nominating petitions of twenty-three candidates for places on the City Council on the ground they lacked sufficient signatures.

Juan Pradenas, Chilean Minister of Labor, was among 160 passengers who arrived here yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Clara from South America. Senor Pradenas beaded a delegation to the International Labor Congress to be held here next week, when he will discuss problems of the working man in the post-war era.

MITCHEL, FIELD, L.I., Oct. 20 -- The First Air Support Command, a new unit designed to provide greater air support for the Army's ground units, has been established here, Major Gen. Herbert A. Dargue, commanding the First Air Force, announced today.

Another unit in the city's expanding plant for the improvement of public health was dedicated yesterday with the laying of the cornerstone by Mayor La Guardia of the new 150-bed tuberculosis pavilion at Riverside Hospital on North Brother Island.

The two-story bank building, formerly owned by the Lincoln Trust Company, at 70-72 Montgomery Street, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by the First National Bank of Jersey City to Joseph F. Kearney of Palisade Park. The building is assessed for $130,000 and was sold for a consideration shown as $13,500, according to stamps on the deed.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 21 -- Embarking on the task of executing Japan's "immutable" policies, General Hideki Tojo, the new Premier, has issued two more declarations about his program, and in both he significantly emphasized the necessity for settling the war in China.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 20 -- Radio Ankara, one of the most powerful short-wave stations in this part of the world, sells air time to THE NEW YORK TIMES for the transmission of dispatches direct to New York, to the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company correspondents, to the British Broadcasting Corporation's special broadcasters and to occasional magazine writers for American publication.

The names of the wounded and missing of the Kearny's crew have the pathos of all such lists. But for another reason they set one to thinking. Dobnikar, Stoltz, Lafleur -- these were Americans, too. So were Larriviere, Kurtz and Frontakowski, no more and no less than Calvert, Camp, Curtis, Wade and Young.

BERLIN, Oct. 20 -- Promoting President Roosevelt to "warmonger No. 1" to the detriment of Prime Minister Winston Churchill, who has hitherto occupied that position in the German press, the Strassburger Neueste Nachrichten warned its readers today not to overestimate the importance of America's non-interventionists even though they include such people as [Charles A.] "Lindberg, who merits the esteem of all decent people."

THAT odd and interesting novel by Robert Graves. (author of "I, Claudius," "Count Belisarius," etc.) about a British soldier in the American Revolution is now complete. The first part, reviewed in this column last Fall, was "Sergeant Lamb's America." "Proceed, Sergeant Lamb,"* is the sequel, and may be read as such or quite by itself.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 20 -- Vigorous patrolling of Egypt's frontier area resulted yesterday in several skirmishes that probably indicate a growing tension on both sides. For some time the Germans have been trying hard to find out what the British are doing, even essaying reconnaissance in force last month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- For the third time the right of a New York bakery wagon drivers' union to combat the use of bakery "peddlers" through peaceful picketing will be before the Supreme Court for decision under an order issued today.

Paul P. Rao, Democratic candidate for the Supreme Court in the First District, has been declared not qualified by the board of directors of the New York County Lawyers Association, Terence J. McManus, its secretary, announced yesterday.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Secretary Knox, speaking today at the commissioning of the aircraft carrier Hornet, said that every man who lost his life on the destroyer Kearny lost it as a volunteer in an "ultimate sacrifice" so that men everywhere may "keep the hope of human freedom."

A one-day Red Cross regional conference in the Hotel WaldorfAstoria heard yesterday a message from Queen Elizabeth of England and a declaration that expanded services required by the national defense program had forced up the national budget of the American Red Cross to almost three times last year's figure.

Cotton mills, which had been un- willing until last week to sell more than scattered minor lots at the old ceiling price of 43 cents a pound for printcloths, sold large quan- tities yesterday at that level as they prepared to operate beginning today under a "sliding scale" system by which cloth prices are tied to raw cotton fluctuations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The House Banking and Currency Committee agreed unanimously today to terminate hearings on price control legislation next Friday and to begin drafting a bill on Oct. 28.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended Oct. 4 was 2,450,090 shares, compared with 3,485,950 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Many salad - loving Americans find themselves neatly impaled on the horns of a particularly perplexing dilemma in these days of blockade and embargo. A future devoid of their favorite food turns them pale with anguish, but so do the prices now charged for dwindling stocks of the olive oil that used to figure so prominently in their salad bowls.

The cotton market lost ground yesterday in quiet trading, as publication of the new price ceilings on cotton goods failed to bring in any important buying orders. Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 31 to 40 points.

James A. Farley, Democratic State chairman and former Democratic national chairman, will make five speeches appealing for the election of District Attorney William O'Dwyer as Mayor, it was announced yesterday by Mitchell May, chairman of the O'Dwyer, Church, Fertig campaign committee.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- In preparation for defense work as nautical assistants to the Coast Guard, seventeen members of the Bronx and Manhattan units of the American Women's Voluntary Services went aboard power boats at the Larchmont Yacht Club today and received first instruction in seamanship.

Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and all subsidiaries report today, in United States currency, net profits of $8,110,012 for the fiscal year ended on July 31, after a $4,043,315 provision for income and profits taxes, including Canadian and United States excess profits taxes of approximately $649,000 and provision of $1,000,000 for contingencies.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

The national defense program has increased the burden of the nursing profession threefold because of additional problems in caring for the men in service, workers in industrial production and civilians, Miss Sophie Nelson, director of the visiting nurse, service of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston, declared last night.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 20 -- It takes longer to make a good doctor out of a youth than it does to build a battleship, Dr. Marion A Blankenhorn, Professor of Medicine of the University of Cincinnati, told the annual meeting of the Association of Urban Universities today in discussing professional education for national defense.
Touchdown outbursts by a pair of Eastern halfbacks brought them a tie for the lead in the national collegiate football scoring race.

Mayor La Guardia accused the "Kelly - Flynn - Sullivan machine" yesterday of using city hospitals for political purposes prior to 1934, and declared that his administration had removed politics from the Hospitals Department.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- American newspaper correspondents in Russia sent word today that they had arrived at Kuibyshev on the special train of the Soviet Foreign Office, with members of that office, Laurence A. Steinhardt, the United States Ambassador, members of his staff and other foreign diplomats.

David Arnott, vice president and chief surveyor of the American Bureau of Shipping, received the Miller Memorial Medal for "conspicuous contributions to the art and science of welding" at the annual meeting of the American Welding Society at Philadelphia yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia condemned Democratic members of the City Council yesterday as he signed local laws reducing the sales and compensating use taxes from varying rates of 3 and 2 per cent to a flat 1 per cent, effective next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- For many months before the President's message of July 30 to Congress, the administration deferred coming to grips with inflation, disregarding every warning and sign that delay made the problem much more difficult of solution. But ever since the President asked for legislation, responsibility for postponing action belongs entirely to Congress.

Mayor La Guardia swung into his active campaign yesterday with a series of speeches in which he said the only "issue" of his opponents was a desire to return to the spoils system. [Page 1, Column 1.] Business men from twenty-seven industries formed a committee to work for his re-election.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- In one of a number of orders, the Supreme Court today denied a petition of the Ford Motor Company for review of lower court decisions upholding a Federal Trade Commission order to cease using the term "6 per cent" in advertising automobile financing.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Form was conspicuous by its ab- sence today. Through the first six races not one public choice had connected, much to the disgust of some 9,000 fans.

The dramatic struggle raging before Moscow should not obscure developments in the southern sector of the long battle line from Leningrad to the Black Sea. There the German spearhead of invasion, curing along the Sea of Azov, has reached Taganrog, where in the seventeenth century Peter the Great established a fortress.

Because of its increasing industrialization and dependence, upon American goods, there is every reason to assume that the extension of relations between the Netherlands East Indies and the United States will be of a "lasting nature," Dr. Slotemaker De Bruine, general director of the Netherlands Information Bureau here, declared yesterday.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 20 -- An airplane crash here this morning caused the death of the pilot and injuries to a motorist whose car was one of two struck by the airplane on Route 3. The accident also disrupted service of two radio stations for forty-five minutes by ripping transmission wires.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 20 -- Negotiating the back nine in 31, 5 under par, Dick Moskin and Leon Pettigrew, Fresh Meadow, tied Percy J. Fynan, Rockville, and Charles Mayo Jr., North Conway, at 66 for the honors in the Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro tour- ney over the Lakeville Club course today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The five operating brotherhoods rejected today last week's offer by President Roosevelt's five-man fact-finding board to arbitrate the railroad wage controversy, in which the board has been hearing evidence since Sept. 16.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Andrew R. Jones, 21-year-old senior at Princeton University, was killed accidentally this morning while hunting alone on his father's farm in Hopewell Township, five miles from here. The youth was struck in the left side by a 22caliber rifle bullet, his rifle apparently having been discharged while he was climbing a barbed-wire fence.
The preliminary report of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for the

Opposition to legislation to per- mit trustees to invest funds in insurance stocks was expressed by Surrogates James A. Foley and James A. Delehanty before a joint legislative committee yesterday in the State Office Building, 80 Center Street.

BERLIN, Oct. 20 -- Apart from the assertion that the German advance continued to be "fluid" everywhere except at Leningrad, Berlin sources tonight would not relent in their reticence concerning their forces' operations in the east.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 20 -- The Province of Buenos Aires underwent its second political crisis in little more than a month and a half when its "interventor," or Provisional Governor, Dimas Gonzales Gowland, resigned today together with all three Ministers who compose his Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (U.P.) -- Mrs. John L. Whitehurst, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, told a press conference today that a just completed tour of the "isolation belt" in the Midwest convinced her that there was a too general feeling of complacency about the nation's future and a feeling that the defense program was unnecessary.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Zino Francescatti, concert violinist, who leased a furinshed penthouse apartment in 327 Central Park West through the Apartment Locating Bureau, broker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Louis K. Comstock, electrical engineer and contractor of New York and Montclair, N.J., was named today as chairman of the board of review set up under the building trades defense stabilization agreement. His appointment was announced by the Office of Productipn Management.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Declaring "that the man has not yet been found who can with assurance answer the question: 'Have you stopped beating your wife,'" State Senator Oscar Wilensky, Passaic County Republican, refused today to take the witness stand at Governor Charles Edison's investigation of the State Highway Department.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Here, along the banks of the old Raritan, the cradle of intercollegiate football, all is outwardly calm, a calmness that a job well done brings on. Thus far the Rutgers football team has accomplished everything asked and expected of it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Use of copper as a component in more than 100 types of civilian articles will be restricted by 40 per cent for the rest of the year and prohibited after Jan. 1, according to terms of an order issued today by the Di- vision of Priorities of the Office of Production Management.

Add to the list of films opening in local houses this week, Columbia's "You'll Never Get Rich," a musical starring Fred Astaire and Rita Hayworth, which will arrive at the Radio City Music Hall on Thursday. Also in the comedy are Robert Benchley, Osa Massen, John Hubbard and Frieda Inescort. . . .

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 20 -- Heavy fighting continues in Western Serbia between the German Army and the Serbian Chetnik armies and armed peasantry, according to reports in neutral foreign military circles and Yugoslav sources at Ankara and admissions by German authorities in the zone of the hostilities.
Antiques awaiting collectors and collectors seeking antiques crowded the ballrooms of the Hotel Commodore yesterday afternoon as the fourteenth National Antiques Exposition opened for a five-day run.

Mayor La Guardia has introduced "sound, ethical and economical government" to the city, representatives of twenty-seven industries in New York declared last night at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue, as they met to form a businessmen's committee to work for the re-election of the Mayor.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20 -- Fourteen Yale regulars were excused from scrimmage today, but the remainder of the squad had a spirited practice at which Coach Spike Nelson tried some promising reserves in palace of regulars. He said that Yale must improve its offense, particularly its blocking.

LONDON, Oct. 20 (U.P.) -- A revolt has broken out in the Macedonian section of Greece, where the "victims of Bulgarian savagery" were "conservatively estimated" at 15,000, the Greek Government-in-Exile announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Officials of leading unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations meeting here today agreed with the contention of Philip Murray, President of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, that employment dislocation has been caused by "ineffective and inadequate planning of the national defense program and of the resulting failure to use our industrial resources fully."

The mechanism of the New York Stock Exchange was utilized successfully yesterday in a new securities flotation when $5,164,000 of 3 per cent debentures of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company were sold on the Exchange floor through brokers who received only the regular brokerage commission of 25 cents for each $100 bond handled.

Probably it is something to see the melancholy Jacques played bril- liantly. That is the chief virtue of the "As You Like It," which was put on at the Mansfield last eve- ning. Eugene S. Bryden, a refugee from Europe, has staged Shakespeare's pastoral with several ideas and some imaginative intentions, and Helen Craig, who was mumming the mute in "Johnny Belinda" last season, is appearing as Rosalind.

The German advances of the last two weeks around Moscow, the fall of Odessa after a historic siege, and particularly the continuing German push to the east along the Black Sea littoral, have re-emphasized the importance of the Mediterranean and the Middle East in the scope of the war.

ALBANY, Oct. 20 -- Frank C. Moore of Erie County, head of the influential Association of Towns, was nominated today for State Controller by the Republican party to oppose Joseph V. O'Leary, Democratic and American Labor party candidate, for the post which was held by the late Morris S. Tremaine.

ROME, Oct. 20 -- In the "new order" in Europe Italy will have economic and political dominion over the Mediterranean, Dr. Walther Funk, German Minister of Economics and president of the Reichsbank, told a distinguished audience of Italians this morning at the University of Rome, where he was made a doctor honoris causa in economics and commerce.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The State's highway program for 1942-1943 announced today by Arthur W. Brandt, Superintendent of Highways, named improvement projects to be undertaken if the State obtains $30,000,000 from the grade-crossing elimination fund, provided in constitutional amendment No. 1 to be voted on next month.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Completion of negotiations for a united front in the Pacific area, composed of Britain, the United States, China, the Netherlands Indies, Australia and New Zealand, was reported today in Canberra.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Advocating repeal of the Neutrality Act and asserting that "the best assurance of a just peace lies in the defeat of Hitler in battle," Secretary Ickes declared here tonight that the United States must make a decision now.
An explosion in the midst of a chemical demonstration at Columbia University injured eleven persons, two seriously, yesterday when apparatus containing concentrated sulphuric acid blew up.

Having cleared the first five hurdles in their path, the football Giants will begin working today to get by their next opponents, the Dodgers. This is going to be one of the busiest weeks for the Giants as they prepare for the interborough clash on Sunday at Ebbets Field.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The significance of organized recreation as a builder of good citizenship and community happiness, as well as of rugged health for national defense, was demonstrated tonight in a series of "living exhibits" at the third annual open house of the Westchester County Recreation Commission.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Gas service has been maintained throughout England despite mass air raids that devastated such towns as Coventry, Davis M. Debard, vice president of Stone Webster Service Corporation, New York, said here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The torpedoing of the American destroyer Kearny by a submarine presumed to be German was denounced by Secretary Hull today in scathing terms. He referred to Hitler as an international highwayman.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- New steps to aid small business by spreading defense orders as widely as possible were announced today by the Army Quartermaster Corps.
The architectural gem of a stadium that Hurry-Up-Yost reared at Ann Arbor, Mich., in the late Twenties will be the venue this week of one of the red-letter football games of the year.

A.J. Cronin, who hag come to the Waldorf-Astoria with Mrs. Cronin from his home at Blue Hill, Me., plans to go to California in a few days to be "within call" when work starts on the movie scenario of his best seller, "The Keys of the Kingdom."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The two Neutrality Act repeal bills offered by Democrats and Republicans in the Senate today were im- mediately referred to the Foreign Relations Committee -- concerned officially as yet with only the House-approved measure for arming ships.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (U.P.) -- Senator Burton K. Wheeler charged tonight that some of the "juke box movies" being produced in Hollywood are "lewd and lascivious" and announced that the Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittees investigating the industry would continue its hearings.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 20 -- Reports filtering through from Belgrade to Serb circles in Turkey throw some light on the new Serb puppet government.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 21 (From official Russian sources; distributed by The Associated Press) -- Repeated attacks by large formations of German tanks have been repulsed by the Russian armies on the central front before Moscow, it was announced early today.

Under the auspices of the Associated Hospitals, originators of the threecents-a-day plan for hospital care in this country, Dr. S.S. Goldwater's Community Ward Service Plan has been organized to render both medical and hospital care at a rate of $12 a year for single persons with incomes of not more than $1,200 a year and $27 a year for families with incomes of not more than $1,680 a year.

Th Police Department property clerk has no right under existing law to retain lost articles for any period of time, and must return a ten-carat diamond valued at $4,000 to $8,000 to its finder. Mrs. Theresa Garramone of 597 East 136th Street, Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder ruled yesterday.

Store Sales Here Up 3% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 3 per cent for the week ended Oct. 18, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 20 -- Extending the activities of Girl Scouts in lines that will aid national defense will be a primary topic at the twenty-eighth annual convention of the National Council of Girl Scouts which opened tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Police officials in fifty-five cities will receive instruction in civilian defense work from the Federal Bureau of Investigation under a program undertaken in cooperation with the Office of Civilian Defense.

Among the newest of the supper clubs to attract members of society this season, La Maisonette of the St. Regis will be formally opened Wednesday night with a benefit party for the Navy Relief Society. Mrs. Vincent Astor is chairman of the arrangements committee.

LONDON, Tuesday, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- Moscow's defenders, barricaded behind a long siege line, weathered a storm of German airplanes, tanks and parachutists yesterday and held their ground at all points, the Russian radio reported today.

It was Minnesota and Texas still running one-two yesterday as 127 of the nation's football experts scanned performances of the top college teams and, in the second of the weekly Associated Press ranking polls, kept these two teams at the head of the parade.

Younger members of society headed by Miss Margot Elizabeth Johnston are aiding in the plans for the dinner dance and entertainment in behalf of the Children's Village Thrift Shop which will be held tonight at the formal opening for this season of the Casino-onthe-Park of Essex House.

VICHY, France, Oct. 20 -- The occupied seaport of Nantes, near the mouth of the Loire River, was under stricter curfew regulations tonight after one of the most daring acts of terrorism since the campaign of shootings and sabotage began against the German occupying forces nearly two months ago.
BERLIN, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Oct. 15 shows the following changes from that of Sept. 30 as follows, in thousands of reichsmarks:

A thousand Protestant churchmen throughout the United States, including Bishops and college presidents, have signed a petition to President Roosevelt urging "immediate action to the end that freedom may march on its enemy and that it may march from Washington," according to an announcement yesterday.

ABOARD THE PRESIDENT'S TRAIN, Oct. 20 -- President Roosevelt will arrive in Washington early tomorrow to face a momentous decision as to whether the loss of eleven American sailors from the torpedoed destroyer Kearny is to lead to far-reaching action, such as a request for complete repeal of the Neutrality Act, or merely to mark another tragic incident in the Battle of the Atlantic.

The Football Writers Association had an entertaining and informative luncheon at Toots Shor's Restaurant yesterday with Wallace Butts of Georgia, Ossie Solem of Syracuse, Jim Crowley of Fordham, Lou Little of Columbia, Mal Stevens of N.Y.U., Herb Kopf of Manhattan and Steve Owen of the Giants providing the battery of speakers.
ROME, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Italian High Command today issued this communique:

Judge Mortimer W. Byers denied yesterday motions of defense counsel to dismiss an indictment against all fifteen defendants accused of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government as the espionage trial in Brooklyn entered its seventh week.

ABOARD THE PRESIDENT'S TRAIN, Oct. 20 -- President Roosevelt will arrive in Washington early tomorrow to face a momentous decision as to whether the loss of eleven American sailors from the torpedoed destroyer Kearny is to lead to far-reaching action, such as a request for complete repeal of the Neutrality Act, or merely to mark another tragic incident in the Battle of the Atlantic.

The Football Writers Association had an entertaining and informative luncheon at Toots Shor's Restaurant yesterday with Wallace Butts of Georgia, Ossie Solem of Syracuse, Jim Crowley of Fordham, Lou Little of Columbia, Mal Stevens of N.Y.U., Herb Kopf of Manhattan and Steve Owen of the Giants providing the battery of speakers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 20 -- Threatened suspension of Joan Fontaine by David O. Selznick over salary differences resulted today in a truce and cancellation of the actress's strike of a few hours' duration. Miss Fontaine has accepted the role of Prudence opposite Tyrone Power in "This Above All" at Twentieth Century-Fox, and the Eric Knight yarn will get away on schedule on Nov. 3 with Anatole Litvak directing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a dairy farmer I was not amused to read in THE TIMES that David A. Morse, impartial chairman of the milk industry, had awarded wage increases to 17,000 workers of $2.50 a week in the metropolitan area. A.F. of L. unions had previously demanded an increase of $7.50 a week, raising the retail price of milk 1 cent.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 20 -- Observers recently in Greece believe that the orgy of looting by individual German officers and soldiers is one of several indications that all is not well in the German Army. It is so revolting to all standards of decency and military honor that one would suppose it would not be countenanced by any army, not even the German.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Fred Annunziato and Henry L. Shuldener of Metropolis won the weekly pro-amateur best-ball tournament of the Westchester P.G.A. today when they smashed par by eight strokes to score 32, 31 -- 63 over the rolling fairways of the Siwanoy course.

HAVANA, Oct. 20 -- Some seven hundred employees of wholesale food and liquor companies in Havana walked out today on an unauthorized strike demanding a wage increase. Four persons were detained, accused of attempting to picket the wholesalers.

Canada is developing a "women's air force," whose personnel will be able to assume responsibility for a part of the men's war tasks should the need arise, Air Vice Marshal Harold Edwards said when he arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon.

Lieut. Col. Arturo Arevalo, lead- er of the Peruvian Army team which will compete in the international military jumping at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden Nov. 5-12, arrived yesterday on the S.S. Santa Clara of the Grace Line.

There was increasing evidence yesterday that the approach of a zero hour in the international scene, of which the stock market gave advance warning last week, was narrowing, although the share list failed to move much in either direction.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. William H. Davis of 130 East Seventy-fourth Street will be at the Wardman Park Hotel in Washington for the Winter. They expect to spend the week-ends at their home here. Mr. Davis is chairman of the National Defense Mediation Board.

Heretofore represented on Broadway only as a collaborating playwright ("Jayhawker" and "It Can't Happen Here"), Sinclair Lewis will step forth tonight as the director of "Good Neighbor," opening at the Windsor. To prepare himself for this task Mr. Lewis has done some acting off Broadway and during the past Summer became acquainted with the intricacies of directing by staging various offerings at Stony Creek, Conn., where "Good Neighbor" first saw the light of a stage.

While Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, industrial gangster who formerly headed a $1,000,000 rackets empire in the city, sat scribbling notes on the prosecution's disclosure that his old friend and collection man, Max Rubin, would "finger" him in a Brooklyn murder case, the victim's widow rose from the witness stand yesterday and dramatically pointed out Lepke's chief aide as the man who entered her store a few hours before her husband was slain.

Thirty-eight newspaper rotogravure sections and sixteen national magazines will be included in the Christmas advertising schedule of Shulton, Inc., on its Early American toiletries, in what has been announced as the most extensive campaign ever conducted by this company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- J. Ed- ward Jones of New York lost today his appeal to the Supreme Court for review of a lower court deci- sion rejecting his $1,000,000 damage suit against three former members and one present member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull informed the Peruvian Ambassador, Manuel de Freyre y Santander, in a note today that the United States "is taking steps to give the government of Peru full and immediate compensation" for eighteen airplanes that had been purchased by Peru and were requisitioned by the United States on Sept. 23 from a freighter in New York Harbor.

Homeward Bound, owned by Mrs. A. Crouch, took the Exodus Purse at one mile and a sixteenth at Em- pire City yesterday. The judges announced the result following an examination of the photograph of the finish.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 21 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 -- Major Gen. Jacob L. Devers, commander of the armored force of the United States Army, declared here today that "there appears to be no defense against armored formations except by more numerous and stronger formations."

Ralph Kirkpatrick, young American harpsichordist, who for the last two seasons, with the assistance of six or seven other young artists, has conducted concerts of early music for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Dalcroze School of Music, last night embarked on a solo series for the fund at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall.

Ossie Solem of Syracuse is pretty well sold on his reverse center manoeuvre and even thinks he may have given something actually new to football, which rarely has a new wrinkle but merely adaptations of old ones.

When Britain Changes Mrs. Roosevelt on the subject of changes in English life after the war is much more cautious than most forecasters. She said yesterday, "People who have become accustomed to living on the same rations, to working side by side and facing constant danger together, are apt, in the future, to forget minor distinctions permanently."

Several debutantes of this season are active in the sale of tickets for the premiere showing of Walt Disney's new film, "Dumbo," on Thursday night at the Broadway Theatre for the benefit of the Vocational Service for Juniors. Miss Eugenie M. Tuck heads the debutante committee working in behalf of the event, for which a large advance subscription already has been reported.

The publication today by Doubleday, Doran of the official British Air Ministry report, "Bomber Command," comes fifteen days after the book was released in London by the Ministry of Information. The 128-page report, which is a sequel to "The Battle of Britain," published several months ago, was flown from England by a bomber carrying ferry pilots and was at the printers three days after it left England.

Frederick Joubert Duquesne, a dark, beetle-browed native of South Africa, whom the government has described as a veteran espionage agent of more than forty years and an inveterate Anglophobe, took the witness stand yesterday in his own behalf at the Brooklyn espionage trial and outlined in dramatic detail a career of adventure, intrigue and mystery.

Senator Robert F. Wagner announced last night his wholehearted support of the Democratic city ticket, headed by District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brookly, as Democratic campaign orators blasted away at Mayor La Guardia's assertions on slum clearance and transit unification.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Don Hutson's last-minute field goal Sunday not only gave Green Bay victory over Cleveland, but enabled the great Packer end to hang on to first place in the National Football League's individual scoring race.

Anatole Kitain, Russian pianist, who last year returned to New York after an absence of six years and gave a recital at Town Hall, was heard last night at Carnegie Hall. The major works on his program were Beethoven's Sonata in C minor, Op. 111, and Schumann's Carnaval.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The government and people of Russia are determined to fight on against Germany at all costs, but the Russian armies "need substantial quantities of munitions and raw materials."

BERLIN, Oct. 21 -- While closely guarded official silence continued to hide the progress of the battle for Moscow, the German High Command in a special communique today claimed new successes at the northern and southern ends of the eastern front -- the occupation of the Island of Dagoe and thus the "liquidation of the enemy in the entire Baltic area," and the occupation of the town of Stalino in the Donets Basin.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Oct. 21 -- Twenty-eight persons were injured, fourteen of them so seriously that they were admitted to Rahway Hospital, when the crack Embassy Limited of the Pennsylvania Railroad, bound from New York to Washington, sidewiped a New York-to-Philadelphia local here at 3:58 o'clock this afternoon.

The ten-day strike of newsdealers against eight morning and evening papers arising from a trade dispute with the publishers was settled yesterday through the intervention of Mayor La Guardia. The dealers thereupon resumed the sale of newspapers.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 21 -- In some football quarters there may be a tendency to shed a few tears for Lafayette, where Edward Everett (Hook) Mylin is in his fifth year as head coach. After all, the Leopards did go through an unbeaten season in 1940 and what ostensibly appears to be a definite reversal of form has been the order thus far.
The battle for Moscow ended its twentieth day yesterday, with great armies locked in a welter of bloody fighting from the northern reaches of the icy Volga to the warm waters of the Southern Don.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21 -- Princeton's power broke out in a ten-touchdown display today as Coach Tad Wieman sent the regulars through nearly an hour of scrimmage against the junior varsity. The Tigers face Vanderbilt at Nashville, Tenn., Saturday.

Governor Lehman endorsed District Attorney O'Dwyer's candidacy for Mayor yesterday in a statement issued in Albany, as the city election was complicated by developments in the Moore-O'Leary race for State Controller.

"Trouble stay 'way from my door," is the tune Lou Little is singing up at Columbia these day and especially yesterday, when it became known that Don Snavely, the Lions' great center, had been lost for the rest of the season.

Male nurses attending the five-day biennial convention of the New York State Nursing Association in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, yesterday heard their tasks compared to those of a District Attorney's office.

Installation of a set of defensive alignments calculated to stop the razzle-dazzle attack of undefeated Villanova kept Herb Kopf and his Manhattan squad busy for most of yesterday afternoon's two-and-one-half-hour drill.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 21 -- The New York State Banking Board will not add to the State's list of legal investments for savings banks and trust funds any new issues of securities marketed in a manner to favor a few large institutions, William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks, told the forty-eighth annual convention of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York here today.

Harry M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., testified yesterday that it was "good business" to keep on friendly terms with William Bioff, leader of the powerful International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, but the film executive admitted that there was a time when he had two bodyguards to protect him from the union leader.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines forecast today the November demand for domestic crude oil at 122,100,000 barrels, or 4,070,000 barrels daily. This was 57,100 barrels higher than the estimated daily demand for October and 13 per cent above the actual demand for November, 1940.

In lands across the seas where rations are the order of the day and where hunger is too often a commonplace, Christmas this year will not be a matter for merriment. Here in New York, however, are organizations that owe their being to an impelling desire on the part of their members to help those whose lives have been ravaged by the war.
ROME, Oct. 21 -- Dr. Karl Clodius, German trade expert, was stated to be arriving late tonight or some time tomorrow in Rome to conclude an important Italo-German trade agreement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Nearly 43,000 miners will be idle Saturday night in the "captive" mines of the largest steel companies unless the United Mine Workers of America wins a union shop for the men in these mines.

The Germans are fighting two wars on the Eastern Front, one against Russia itself, the other against Britain and the Western world. The siege of Moscow is a climactic movement in the battle for Russia. By a solar plexus blow it aims to crush Soviet power at its center and to knock the Soviet Union out of the conflict and out of Europe.

The 5-year-old mare Inscoelda, who one day will take her place on the broad acres of the King Ranch in Texas, ran her first race and scored her first victory in the Lone Star colors in the Hannibal Handicap at Empire City yesterday.

The Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland filed yesterday plans for its new home, a seven-story office and penthouse building at 138-40 William Street, to cost $500,000. The proposed building, from plans by W.C. Ely, architest, will occupy a site 54.9 by 100.5 feet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The House adopted by a voice vote and returned to the Senate with an amendment today a bill providing $170,000,000 in authorizations for the improvement of strategic defense highways and access roads to defense plants.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Local and commission house trader vied with each other today in buying wheat futures, the market being snapped out of a small decline early to advance as much as 5 cents a bushel before profit-taking checked the upturn.

BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- To finance on a permanent basis the largest telephone construction program in recent years, directors of the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company voted today to authorize the raising of more than $22,000,000 through an offer of stock to present stockholders.

The establishment of a temporary Soviet capital at Kuibyshev, or Samara, to give the city its ancient Czarist name, marks the second, but probably not the final, phase of the Russo-German war. The battleline now extends from Leningrad to the Sea of Azov, with a great bulge threatening Moscow in the center and an arm reaching out in the south toward the Caucasus.

One of the season's auspicious events takes place tonight at the Shubert, where Helen Hayes will be seen in Maxwell Anderson's play, written in prose this time, and called "Candle in the Wind." Alfred Lunt directed the production. The joint sponsors -- the Theatre Guild and the Playwrights Company -- have been in no rush to unveil the offering here, preferring to keep it on the road for five weeks.

Some 250 executives of New York companies doing an annual business well in excess of $1,000,000,000 were warned by an OPM official yesterday that priorities are cutting across every line of business and that business men must acquaint themselves with the details of the priorities system if they are to stay in business at all.

By a unanimous vote the Board of Elections ruled invalid yesterday the independent petitions nominating William J. Goodwin of Queens for Mayor as the candidate of the American Rock Committee. It held that the petitions lacked sufficient valid signatures.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 22 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The following Russian communique was broadcast early today:

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 22 (From official Russian sources; distributed by The Associated Press) -- The repulse of several strong German attacks in combats of undiminished ferocity on salients before Moscow was announced early today by the Soviet Information Bureau.
NEW YORK Robert M. Scotten, United States Minister to the Dominican Republic, and Mrs. Scotten are at the Beekman.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 21 -- Oscar Straus, Viennese composer of "The Chocolate Soldier," the operatic treatment of Bernard Shaw's "Arms and the Man," will write a new score for the screen version of the Shaw comedy, with Cary Grant and Ginger Rogers, RKO announced today.

Many parties were given during, the luncheon hour yesterday at the formal opening for this season of the Caprice Room of the "Weylin, which was the setting for an entertainment, known as "Fashion Portraits," presented in behalf of the Masters School Day Nursery.

Handy Andy Marefos apparently is the nominee for the No. 1 spot on the hurling staff of the Football Giants. For more than an hour Coach Steve Owen had the rookie fullback from St. Mary's pitching footballs at the, Polo Grounds yesterday as the team settled down in earnest to get ready for the battle with the Dodgers at Ebbets Field on Sunday.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 21 -- Industry, education and the Federal Government exchanged ideas today at the annual meeting of the Association of Urban Universities.

Paul P. Rao, Democratic candidate for the Supreme Court in the First District, was declared not qualified for that office and his election was opposed in a report of the Committee on the Judiciary adopted last night without a dissenting vote by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command today issued this communique:

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that any endorsement of his third-term candidacy by President Roosevelt would "speak for itself" and that the announcement of Governor Lehman's support of William O'Dwyer, his Democratic opponent, was "a matter of complete indifference to me."

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Prices of hogs advanced 5 to 10 cents 100 pounds in moderately active trading today despite fairly sizable receipts and further weakness in dressed pork quotations. All interests were in the market, livestock men said, as buyers saw the possibility of heavy government purchases in the pork and lard market reducing available supplies for general consumption.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Oct. 21 -- The Bourse was steady to firm today, with, a minimum turnover and small fluctuations. Royal Dutch was 1 3/8 points higher at 305 1/8; Amsterdam trading rose 3 1/2 to 473, and Phillips 3 1/2 to 261 1/2. A. K. U. was depressed and bonds were lower, especially the Dutch Indians.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Supervisor Bert C. McCulloch of Mamaroneck, chairman of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors committee that four years ago drafted the present county charter declared today that the charter drafters never intended that the Board of Supervisors necessarily be abolished and a small legislative board be created.

BERLIN, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- The severest anti-Jewish, drive in almost three years appeared to be in progress in Germany and the Bohemia-Moravia Protectorate today, with thousands being dispatched to Poland on short notice or evicted from their Berlin homes into wooden hutments on the city's outskirts.

The United States should endeavor to insure continuance of those exports necessary to the expanding industries of Brazil as a matter of hemispheric defense, Richard P. Momsen of Momsen Freeman, export attorneys, declared yesterday.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 21 -- Twenty-five amateur and professional jockeys and approximately seventy-five horses will gather tomorrow and Saturday for the Essex Fox Hounds meeting inaugurating pari-mutuel betting on flat and steeplechase races in New Jersey.

Mrs. Juan T. Trippe gave a buffet luncheon yesterday at her home, 10 Gracie Square, for a group of women serving with the Homeless Children's Committee of the Children's Aid Society in its campaign to raise $298,700 to extend its foster care for neglected children.

The schedules of possible cuts in nondefense spending to save from $1,000,000,000 to $2,000,000,000, which have been prepared by the Bureau of the Budget in response to requirements of the new revenue act, provide another demonstration that there is no easy road to economies.

Prophets in Rompers All these years before the ghastly storm broke on us in September, 1939, who was it that best knew what the future held in store, who was it that best understood the world in which we live?

"You can't win football games any longer on spirit alone." The speaker was a veteran coach, who as player and teacher has been connected with the gridiron game for almost twenty-five years. The remark was made during a discussion of the Army victory over Yale.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Confronted with an immediate shortage of merchant shipping, pending delivery of mass tonnage of Liberty ships and other cargo vessels now on the ways, the United States Maritime Commission announced today that it plans to build 127 smaller special-type vessels which can be constructed without interfering with the larger shipbuilding program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Disclosure of the sinking of two more American-owned merchant ships combined today with the urgent appeals of Secretary Hull and Admiral Stark, Chief of Naval Operations, to give added impetus to quick Senate action on revision of the Neutrality Act to permit the arming of this country's merchantmen.

VICHY, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Summary execution of fifty French, hostages was ordered today by General Heinrich von Stuelpnagel, German occupation commander in France, as a "preliminary measure" of reprisal for the killing yesterday of Lieut. Col. Friedrich Karl Holtz, the Nazi commandant at Nantes.

LONDON, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- Albert V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, contended by inference tonight that British, Allied and neutral shipping losses "from all causes" in the last twelve months had totaled less than 5,639,000 tons.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- William Fox, bankrupt former motion picture producer, was sentenced today to a year and a day in a Federal penitentiary and fined $3,000 on a charge of conspiracy to obstruct justice and defraud the government.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 21 (AP) A revolution in American food habits and farm production will result from the training in nutrition which more than 1,600,000 soldiers are receiving in Army training, it was predicted by Colonel R.A. Osmun of the Army Quartermaster Corps in an address before the annual meeting of the American Dietetic Association.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Those who saw the movie "Ben-Hur" will recall the half-witted galley slave aboard the Roman flagship who, seeing the overseer whip a man already fallen ove his oar, exclaims, "They lash, and they lash, and the man is dead."

For the fifth time in six weeks, the general death rate in New York City dropped below the "expected" rate last week, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner. The rate last week was 8.8 per 1,000 population. For the year to date it is 9.9, contrasted with 10.2 at this time last year, and also in 1939.

Contributions totaling $31,920 toward the campaign goal of $225,000 needed to balance the budget of the Young Women's Christian Association in this city were announced yesterday at a luncheon in the headquarters building at 600 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Fifteen of the oil tankers diverted to British use have been released subject to recall and are being restored to their owners for their normal services. It is understood here that all of them will have been returned by the end of the month.

The Duchess of Windsor, interested more in social problems than in clothes, she said, spent half an hour yesterday afternoon investigating Inwood House, 228 West Fifteenth Street, where unmarried mothers and their babies receive shelter and treatment.

Fordham began earnest preparation, after Monday's light workout, for Saturday's battle with Texas Christian at the Polo Grounds by holding a long drill on Fordham Field yesterday, the practice continuing until darkness forced Coach Jim Crowley to call a halt.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Strikers voted tonight to return to work at the Sloss-Sheffield Steel and Iron Company, thus indicating an early end to the industrial gas shortage which closed more than forty plants, employing 15,000, today.
VICHY, France, Oct. 21 -- In the near future all French citizens above the age of 15 will be compelled to carry a uniform identity card that is intended, to serve many ends.
Despite increased taxes, earnings for the first nine months of 1941 reported yesterday by three manufacturers of chewing gum equaled those of the similar period last year.

Governor Lehman's announced decision to "support and vote for William O'Dwyer for Mayor" must necessarily bring up the subject of the advantages and disadvantages of party regularity in local elections. The public knows the Governor too well to doubt his sincerity when he states his belief that as Mayor Mr. O'Dwyer "will give the people of New York City an efficient, honest, independent and progressive administration."

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Another surface symptom of the undercurrent of feeling that Britain is not doing all she should to aid Russia was shown today when a deputation of workers went to Downing Street and left a resolution for Prime Minister Churchill calling for greater aid for Russia.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick produced last night figures on patronage awards made, he said, by Lloyd Church, his Democratic opponent, while Mr. Church was on the Supreme Court bench. Mr. McGoldrick contended that the figures and names showed that Mr. Church had always been "regular" and that "it is the same old Tammany doing business in the same old way."

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 21 -- A 22-year-old German, who obtained positions as a draftsman and designer in six defense plants by allegedly representing himself as a United States citizen, was arraigned here today before Federal Judge William F. Smith and remanded to the Hudson County Jail in default of $25,000 bail to await action of the Federal grand jury.

LONDON; Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- British press reports from Stockholm today said that Premier Joseph Stalin had donned gray breeches, a blue blouse and top boots, like those he wore when he fought the White Russians, and had set up headquarters in an armored train so that he could serve as commander in chief.

Oct. 21. . . 112.9 114.4 111.9 118.9 106.5 117.7 The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Cancellation in advance of the season's social program of official entertainments at the White House was announced today by Mrs. Roosevelt.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 21 -- With the field in the Tred Avon Purse reduced to three, chief interest on today's program centered in the Top Flight Purse, a test of a mile and 70 yards involving seven 2-year-old fillies, six of them eligible for the rich Selima Stakes here Saturday.

Excess Reserves Drop Reflecting the payments on Monday for the new issue of the Treasury's 2 1/2 per cent bonds, it was estimated in banking circles yesterday that the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City dropped $170,000,000 to a total of $1,525,000,000 as of Monday.

PITTSBURGH, Qct. 21 -- Hundreds of cheering students at Carnegie Tech gathered on the campus at noon today and contributed $537.35 -- a good part of it taken from their lunch money -- as the nucleus of a fund to get bigger and better football players for the school.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Oct. 22 -- The Red Army has successfully stemmed all but one of the German thrusts against Moscow's outer defenses, according to late reports. The Russian High Command announced early today that fighting was particularly fierce around Kalinin, ninety-five miles northwest of Moscow; Mozhaisk, sixty miles west, and Maloyaroslavets, sixty-five miles southwest.

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 22 -- The Royal Air Force has carried out an almost continuous twentyfour-hour bomber and fighter attack upon targets in Germany and Northern France. It was still going on early today. [A London dispatch of The United Press said that a British attack of last night and early today upon the French coast opened in the Calais area and was extended later southward to Boulogne.]

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- Recent rapid advances in the perfecting of spot welding of aluminum alloys have presented "almost limitless possibilities" to American aircraft manufacturers, Paul H. Merriman, who has charge of electrical engineering for the Glenn L. Martin Company, told the American Welding Society today.

Fourteen local housing authorities sold yesterday a total of $22,895,000 of short-term notes, maturing variously in three months to one year. Of the total, the Girard Trust Company of Philadelphia purchased $13,706,000; the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and associates bought $7,189,000 and the Industrial Trust Company of Providence took $2,000,000.

Democratic members of the City Council will move today to investigate the Health Department and Correction Department on alleged violations of the Sanitary Code that were brought before the Council Committee on General Welfare at City Hall yesterday by, Councilman Walter R. Hart, Brooklyn Democrat.

The cotton futures market felt yesterday the first effects of the new schedule of ceiling prices for cotton goods. Spurred by a steady flow of price-fixing orders by mills, apparently a result of the heavy volume of gray goods sold on the previous day, prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose steadily to close near the high marks of the day and at net gains of 28 to 31 points.

Mayor La Guardia summarized yesterday the accomplishments of his administration in parks and playgrounds as he made public his fifth "Lesson on Good Municipal Government," with the customary slaps at the triumvirate of Kelly, Sullivan and Flynn.

CRANBURY, N.J., Oct. 21 -- Virginia R. Boy, the white and liver pointer owned and handled by Dr. B.F. Driggers of New Brunswick, N.J., excelled once more in the birdfield today in the ninth annual national amateur pheasant championship.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Paramount the newcomer will be "Nothing But the Truth," a comedy starring Bob Hope and Paulette Goddard. Included in the picture's cast are Edward Arnold, Leif Erikson, Glenn Anders, Willie Best and Helen Vinson. ...
BERLIN, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The following communique was issued today:

Cooperative advertising by manufacturers with dealers appears to be the chief casualty of the current emergency, if announced plans of manufacturers for 1942 are not changed. Following the abandonment of such advertising by several companies in the men's wear field, Stewart-Warner, first important refrigerator manufacturer to introduce 1942 models, has told distributors that there will be no cooperative budget for either distributors or dealers, as a result of curtailed production.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Total internal revenue collections in September amounted to $1,053,458,231, compared with $654,622,519 in the same month last year, the Treasury Department announced today. The increases were registered, although the increased income and excise levies contained in the recent defense tax bill had not yet gone into effect.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Office of Price Administration today side-stepped a controversy in New York over liquidation of outstanding raw silk futures contracts. The OPA maintained that since the contracts involve only payment of cash, and not transfers of actual raw silk, it would take no position.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, last night assured recipients of home relief and those deserving of relief that if he were elected Mayor they would not have to fear for their treatment "at my hands or the hands of my administration."

THERE ought to be some excited buzzing in and around the Chevy Chase Country Club and from one end to the other of Pennsylvania Avenue, now that a little history called "Washington Waltz"* has appeared.

VICHY, France, Oct. 21 -- Reprisals, swift and terrible, were visited today on the city of Nantes in occupied France, where yesterday the German military commander was assassinated. An order was issued by General Heinrich von Stuelpnagel, in charge of the German occupying forces in France, for the immediate execution of fifty hostages.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Former champions advanced true to form today in the world pocket billiards championship, with Andrew Ponzi, New York; Erwin Rudolph, Cleveland, and Jimmy Caras, Wilmington, Del., winning their first-round matches.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- Members of the Senate Foreign' Relations Committee said today that Admiral Harold R. Stark, chief of naval operations, told them that the U.S. Destroyer Kearny was on convoy duty last Friday when it was torpedoed in Icelandic waters by a German submarine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President Roosevelt announced at his press conference the sinking of the American flag vessel Lehigh in the South Atlantic. In the morning he conferred with party leaders from the Capitol. His callers included William H. Davis, W. Averell Harriman, William J. Donovan, Sidney Hillman and a group from the Argentine Chamber of Deputies headed by Senor Don Jones Luis Cantilo, speaker.

Carlos Alexander, young American bass-baritone, gave a first New York recital of uncommon quality at the Town Hall last night. It does not happen often that first recitals convey the happy blend of assurance and style that Mr. Alexander managed.

The professional pessimists who greeted the football rules changes with gloomy predictions of four and five-hour games can stop worrying right now. Although substitutes are being employed more often than a bottle opener at an alumni reunion, they haven't slowed up the action -- at least not enough to matter.

The Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago received yesterday the award of an issue of $405,000 of water, street and public improvement bonds of Concord, N.C., on a bid of 100.04 for $79,000 as 4$ and $326,000 as 1 1/2s, or at a net interest cost of 1.694 per cent.

MANILA, Oct. 21 -- President Manuel Quezon assembled the heads of his civilian emergency administration with representatives of Far Eastern armed forces in the United States High Commissioner's office for a report on the progress of civilian protection measures.

It seems a far cry indeed back to Les Fauves, to whose salutary revolution the Marie Harriman Gallery, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street, pays tribute in its current show. So much has happened in art since 1905.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Two more American owned merchant ships, one flying the Stars and Stripes and the other the flag of Panama, have been sent to the bottom of the ocean in the spreading battle of the Atlantic, President Roosevelt and the State Department announced today.
The woodcock shooting in the Catskills has been fair in several areas since the opening day, but the majority of the guides believe that the birds found were natives and not flight birds.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Herbert Hoover, in his appeal of Oct. 19 for the feeding of children in the conquered democracies, repeated the assertion frequently made last year to the effect that the Germans had responded favorably to the suggestions of his committee, whereas he had met an outright refusal from the British.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 21 -- The national emergency is a test of a democratic form of government, T.J. Strickler of Kansas City, retiring president of the American Gas Association, said here today as he called for solidarity among all industries and business.

TRENTON, Oct. 21 -- John Franssen, chief of the State Highway Department's right-of-way division, testifying today as a witness for the examiners conducting Governor Charles Edison's investigation of the department, declared that $1,500 had been paid for use of rights of land in Perth Anaboy that New Jersey did not need and never would need.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 21 -- The national Girl Scout organization pledged its cooperation in working with, other agencies striving to preserve democracy in a credo on defense adopted by the board of directors today.
LONDON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

There being no shortage of midnight oil, the N.Y.U. football squad burned some of that variety last night for an after-dinner blackboard session devoted to reviewing offensive and defensive strategy and ending well past the usual bedtime hour prescribed for football players.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Counsel for labor and management in the railroad wage dispute began final arguments today before President Roosevelt's fact-finding board. Arguments will be ended tomorrow and the board will start deliberations on a recommendation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 21 -- Yale's longest and hardest scrimmage before the Dartmouth game in the Bowl Saturday was held on Anthony Thompson Field today and was marked by the most lineup changes made since the Elis suffered a series of reverses a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Three of Leon Henderson's key aides in the Office of Price Administration were disclosed today to have flown to Canada on Sunday morning to prepare a confidential report on the causes and effects of Prime Minister MacKenzie King's surprising radio announcement Saturday night that Canada would abandon selective price-fixing of commodities in favor of an overall ceiling and would extend the wage control in war industries to cover all industrial labor.

LONDON, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- Montenegrin guerrillas have killed 1,000 Italian soldiers the past few weeks, chased Italian administrators out of the interior of the country and assassinated seven members of the puppet Parliament set up by Italy on July 18, a spokesman for the Yugoslav Government in Exile said today.

TOKYO, Oct. 21 -- Japan's new "wartime" Cabinet today held its first regular session, at which Foreign. Minister Shigenori Togo reported the repercussions that the Cabinet change had produced in Britain, the United States, Germany and other countries.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your correspondent Mr. A.J. Bourrienne's answer to my letter reveals a concept of possible world peace predicated on the horse and buggy days.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

The New York City public school system was described as a "great American institution" meriting defense and protection "against fifth columnists, dictators and bombers" by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, last night in an address to members of the United Parents Association, at Washington Irving High School.

If a bird could read (and how do we know that birds can't read, especially city birds, who are continually looking at signs?) he would preen himself at the statement made this week by Roger Tory Peterson before the National Audubon Society that the bird population of the United States is about 5,750,000,000.

The stock market made yesterday its boldest bid for support yet evidenced in the recovery movement which set in late last week, and buyers responded in fairly substantial numbers when the recent weak spots of the share list did an about-face.

A tentative program, formulated by the National Consumer-Retailer Council to stimulate closer cooperation among consumers, retailers and manufacturers in the present emergency was announced yesterday by Harold W. Brightman, vice president of L. Bamberger Co., Newark, and chairman of the council, in an address before the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Operations of McKesson Robbins, Inc., in the three months ended with September resulted in earnings of $1,352,825 after provision for debenture interest of $119,875 and Federal taxes of $992,000, after giving effect to certain non-recurring tax savings arising from the company's recent reorganization, according to a report for publication today by W.J. Murray Jr., president.

PANAMA, Oct. 21 -- Dr. Arnulfo Arias, deposed President of Panama, left Albrook Field in the Canal Zone at 5:07 this morning in a chartered plane on a non-stop flight to Managua, Nicaragua. It is reported he will remain there for the present.

In a final step designed to "streamline" the service organization of the $1,000,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric Company system, directors of the Atlantic Utility Service Corporation, mutual service unit of the system, elected yesterday L.D. Staver as president and reorganized the unit's administrative staff.

There is no question that Sybil Shearer, who made her local solo debut last night at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, is a talented dancer. In advance her performance was perhaps of more interest than the average debut recital, for she was for several seasons a prominent member of the Humphrey-Weidman company and for the last two seasons has been appearing with Agnes de Mille.

THERE is a feeling of relief in this corner that the silver-thatched Jack Coffey, who supervises the athletic program at Fordham, hasn't filed any written complaint about the mean trick that the football fates have been playing on the old Maroon. When Mr. Coffey sets himself down to write, the output may be in any one of three or four modern languages.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 20:

Trading was only fair to slow in the wholesale dressed meat markets yesterday. Fresh pork cuts sold unevenly. Steer hinds and ribs and veal and calf hindsaddles were lower. Bull beef sold weak to lower. Other classes were about steady. All kosher meats opened about steady.

Savings banks and other lending institutions were advised last night by Dr. Anton F. Mannel, treasurer of the Prudential Savings Bank in Brooklyn, to take the leadership in providing new housing to fit modern needs in New York.

Top executives of leading life insurance companies, several securities analysts and the State insurance supervisors of New York and Massachusetts warned the Joint Legislative Committee on Revision of the Insurance Law yesterday against permitting life insurance companies to invest in common stocks.

Current retail slowness on soft goods, while occasioning some uneasiness, has not weakened confidence in prospects for the Christmas selling period, according to views in merchandising circles here yesterday. Many well-posted executives look for a record season in point of dollar sales increase and possibly in units.

The strong statement in support of a clear-cut and outright repeal of the Neutrality Act, published this morning over the signatures of six Republican Governors and other prominent Republicans in forty States, gives further assurance, that the days of partisan debate are drawing to a close and that the country is finding its way toward unity on the great questions of the hour.

Declaring that millions of Republicans are determined to wipe the "ugly smudge of isolationism" from the face of the party, Wendell L. Willkie called on Republican members of Congress yesterday, in a message signed by leading Republicans of the nation, to repeal the Neutrality Act as a "hypocritical and degrading" law that now serves Axis interests by hampering United States aid to Britain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The first industry-wide pooling of productive facilities for defense resulted today in a $12,000,000 War Department order to three washing machine manufacturing companies for 90-caliber anti-aircraft gun mounts under terms of an industry-government program in which the thirty-one other companies in the washing machine industry will share in the work to prevent dislocation of employes due to curtailed production of consumers' durable goods.

Lois Lockner, who spent many a happy hour with Department of Justice agents at the Beaux Arts Hotel bar, went on trial in Federal court yesterday for impersonations that she says were all in fun. She impersonated Federal attorneys and evaded payment of a hospital bill, and persuaded a garage man to let her use a G-man's automobile, and all this is a violation of the law, according to the government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Contracts awarded today by the War Department totaled $17,120,615.52. Included among these were the following, not previously published, to concerns in the New York area:

Declaring that millions of Republicans are determined to wipe the "ugly smudge of isolationism" from the face of the party, Wendell L. Willkie called on Republican members of Congress yesterday, in a message signed by leading Republicans of the nation, to repeal the Neutrality Act as a "hypocritical and degrading" law that now serves Axis interests by hampering United States aid to Britain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The first industry-wide pooling of productive facilities for defense resulted today in a $12,000,000 War Department order to three washing machine manufacturing companies for 90-caliber anti-aircraft gun mounts under terms of an industry-government program in which the thirty-one other companies in the washing machine industry will share in the work to prevent dislocation of employes due to curtailed production of consumers' durable goods.

Lois Lockner, who spent many a happy hour with Department of Justice agents at the Beaux Arts Hotel bar, went on trial in Federal court yesterday for impersonations that she says were all in fun. She impersonated Federal attorneys and evaded payment of a hospital bill, and persuaded a garage man to let her use a G-man's automobile, and all this is a violation of the law, according to the government.
ALBANY, Oct. 21 -- The adjutant general released the following orders today:

Pete Scalzo, 131, of the West Side, former N.B.A. featherweight titleholder, scored a technical knockout over Morris (Curley) Nichols, 128, of Brownsville at 2:10 of the fifth round of the scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena last night before a capacity crowd.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, reported to President Roosevelt today that the United States had not reached the stage in its defense program "where we need or could wisely adopt" the drastic price and wage controls which are being set up in Canada.

Dr. Hermann Rauschning, who resigned as president of the Danzig Senate in 1934 after an unsuccessful attempt to work with the Nazi party element in the Free City, asserted in an interview here yesterday that the German leadership was already looking forward to a "third World War" in which, after a breathing spell following the present conflict, it hoped to establish conquest of the world.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday its recommendations in election contests for membership on the Board of Estimate. It endorsed Mayor La Guardia, Controller McGoldrick, Council President Newbold Morris and four of the five fusion candidates for Borough President.

The active buying by mills which had brought gains to the cotton market on Tuesday carried over into the first hour of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and lifted futures 14 to 18 points. This buying, however, was not sustained, and final prices showed net declines of 2 to 5 points.

In the enslaved territories of Europe at this moment it is Nazi mathematics that prevails. For Lieut. Col. Paul Friedrich Hotz, removed from this earth by unknown persons at Nantes last Monday morning, General Heinrich von Stuelpnagel, commander of the army of occupation in France, butchers fifty guiltless hostages and orders the murder of fifty more if those who killed Hotz are not delivered.

DETROIT, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Picket lines were maintained today in the week-old strike at the Great Lakes Steel Corporation's plant in suburban Ecorse by C.I.O. unionists openly rebelling against orders of their union officials.

BUFFALO, Oct. 22 -- The thoroughgoing British preparedness for civilian and national defense was impressed upon members of the New York State Conference on Social Work today by Dr. Winnifred Clara Cullis, Professor of Physiology at the University of London and past president of the International Federation of University Women.

Maxwell Anderson and Helen Hayes have joined hands in a portrait of Nazi malevolence. "Candle in the Wind" is what Mr. Anderson has called it. As directed by Alfred Lunt, it was put on at the Shubert last evening by the Theatre Guild and the Playwrights Company.

THE great Pierre Laval is violently denounced this morning in a biography* by a one-time friend and associate now living in America -- Henry Torres, attorney, author, editor and former vice chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the French Parliament.
BERLIN, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- Nazis said today they doubted German submarines sank the American-owned freighters Lehigh and Bold Venture.

The New York City Cancer Committee opened last night its fifteenth annual campaign for funds "to fight cancer with knowledge" at a dinner held in the Advertising Club, at which the Clement Cleveland Medal, given annually for conspicuous service to cancer education, was presented to Abbott Kimball, president of the advertising concern bearing his name.

La Maisonette, new supper club of the St. Regis, was formally opened for the season last night with a dinner dance for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society. The rendezvous was taxed to capacity for the opening celebration. Mrs. Vincent Astor was chairman of the sponsoring committee for the benefit.

In a speech before the Kiwanis Club, which three weeks ago heard Senator Frederic R. Coudert rebuke the American Committee for Democracy and Intellectual Freedom for criticizing the Rapp-Coudert investigation, Dr. Ned H. Dearborn, national chairman of the committee, accused the Coudert committee yesterday of employing unfair, though legal, tactics.
The Duchess of Windsor smiled publicly yesterday at a couple of thousand persons, waved at hundreds and personally addressed more than fifty. But she kissed only one.
