Federal Agencies Refunding The program outlined by the Treasury Department whereby it will gradually absorb the approximately 57,000,000 of government-agency guaranteed debt will get underway today, when the Treasury will offer to holders of maturing obligations of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Commodity Credit Corporation a new issue of Treasury direct notes.

Increases on virtually the entire schedule of war-risk insurance rates, covering shipments on United States flag vessels to and from overseas ports, were announced yesterday by marine underwriters here and will become effective today.

With more intersectional contests arranged than ever before, the eighth season of college basketball at Madison Square Garden will open on Saturday, Dec. 13. Director Ned Irish yesterday announced a list of eighteen doubleheaders, one more than last season, for the 1941-42 campaign.
The U.S.S. Bristol, newest unit of the Navy's rapidly growing destroyer flotillas, was commissioned yesterday at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- West Coast canners of fruits and vegetables, who estimate they will need at least 25 per cent of the available steamship cargo space to move their 1941 packs to the East Coast markets, pressed the Maritime Commission here today for word as to when the space allocations for their goods will be made.

Lashing out against the abuse of civil liberties by those who seek to destroy all liberties, Dorothy Thompson, columnist and president of the Ring of Freedom, decried yesterday as "a counsel of impotence" the words of those libertarians who imply that the Bill of Rights grants complete public license.

On one page of this newspaper yesterday two disconnected pieces of news belonged to the public breadbasket. The estate of one of the founders and most successful conductors of the Automat was estimated at $2,500,000. In another column an officer of the Quartermaster Corps of the Army spoke of the introduction of so many of the soldiers now in training to a balanced diet.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22 -- "Directions in American Painting." arranged as this year's big annual here, is now fully installed in the galleries of Carnegie Institute, where it is to be opened officially tomorrow evening, after the founders Day exercises in the music hall -- at which time the prize-winning pictures will be announced.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Oct. 23 -- The Russian forces on the front before Moscow are holding their ground or attacking, but a Soviet communique issued today acknowledged a Red Army withdrawal from Taganrog [already claimed by the Germans], on the southern front.
LONDON, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- Government sources asserted tonight that the Russian campaign had taken a heavy toll of German transportation, health and production.
NEW YORK Edward D. Dunn and his daughters, the Misses Anton and June Dunn, have returned from Old Westbury, and are at 1060 Fifth Avenue for the season.

The Federal Government should issue an announcement that wage ceilings will not be fixed for the present, it was declared yesterday by Dr. Robert P. Brecht, Associate Professor of Industry at the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce, in a talk before nearly 800 office executives attending the opening of the two-day conference of the American Management Association, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ROME, Oct. 22 -- The conversations of Dr. Walther Funk, German Minister of Economics; Dr. Karl Clodius, German trade negotiator, and their dozens of experts with Raffaelo Riccardi, Italian Minister of Exchange, and Italian financial and industrial leaders were, virtually completed today.

Nearly 43,000 miners will be idle Saturday night in the "captive" mines of the largest steel companies unless the United Mine Workers of America wins a union shop for the men in these mines. The kind of union shop on which John L. Lewis insists is one in which the company may hire non-union employes, but they must join the union after they are hired.

LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 23 -- Widespread air raids by the Royal Air Force on a number of ports of Germany and German-occupied territories that are constant danger points in connection with the Battle of the Atlantic and the Nazis' threat to invade Britain were announced by the Air Ministry last night.

The problem posed to organization Republicans because of the fact that Mayor La Guardia is a running-mate of both Republican and Democratic candidates for State Controller was solved yesterday by an apparently definite decision on the part of the La Guardia managers that neither controllerahip candidate would appear at the Madison Square Garden rally on Nov. 1.
The New Opera Company and a certain composer, one Peter Illytich Tchaikovsky, had an astonishing success, despite obvious inequalities in the situation, last night in the Forty-fourth Street Theatre.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22 (AP) -- District leaders of the United Mine Workers issued a formal call tonight for a strike in the "captive" soft coal mines operated by seven large steel companies, effective at midnight Oct. 27.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Office of Production Management accused defense strikers today of aiding Hitler.

The new Nurse Practice Act, which goes into effect in January, was criticized yesterday by Miss Stella M. Hawkins of the State Board of Nurse Examiners on the ground that it does not assure safe nursing care.

SEATTLE, Oct. 22 -- Welders left their jobs in six shipbuilding plants in a jurisdictional labor dispute in the Seattle area today, threatening a stoppage of many millions of dollars' worth of defense construction.

Hemphill, Noyes Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane offered yesterday after the close of the Stock Exchange a block of 150,000 shares of new "when-issued" common stock of the Erie Railroad. The stock was priced at $7 a share until the opening of business on the Stock Exchange today and thereafter at the same price, plus the usual commission.

Surprise and encouragement over the degree to which the American defense and lease-lend programs are progressing was expressed here last night by a group of British industrialists who have completed a month of touring some sixty-seven defense plants in fourteen cities at the invitation of William S. Knudsen, Director General, and Sidney Hillman, associate director general, of the Office of Production Management.

Charles Butterworth's starring vehicle, "Western Union, Please," which began a Chicago engagement on Sunday night, will not continue beyond Saturday night's performance at which time the tour will end there. The announcement was made here yesterday by Richard Aldrich of the firm of Aldrich Myers, the sponsors.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Secretary Ickes, in his Chicago speech, criticized both industry and labor for retarding the effort to aid the nations resisting Axis aggression. Is that fair?

District Attorney William O'Dwyer repeated last night the charge of his campaign manager that more than a million dollars was being spent to defeat him. He called for a City Council investigation of campaign expenditures.
VICHY, France, Oct. 22 -- Another German officer has been shot dead in France and 100 more French hostages have been seized in retaliation by the German occupying forces.

At the fourth of nine stops on a hectic six-and-one-half-hour motor tour between Eighty-ninth Street and the Battery yesterday, the Duchess of Windsor remarked to a group of those accompanying the party, "We're going to run you around a lot today."

The Schools, Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Mayor La Guardia turned with full force last night upon William O'Dwyer, his Democratic Mayoralty opponent, charging that despite Mr. O'Dwyer's proclamation of political independence, the latter had appointed to his staff of thirty-three aides in the Kings County District Attorney's office, twenty-nine persons who owed political allegiance to the Kelly Democratic machine.

Democratic members of the City Council adopted a local law yesterday reducing water rates by 50 per cent to save taxpayers more than $900,000 a year, despite Councilman Genevieve B. Earle's contention that the Council has no jurisdiction over water rates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Sidney Hillman assumed full responsibility today before the Senate Committee investigating defense contracts for the action of the Federal Works Agency in withholding from the Currier Lumber Company of Detroit, the low bidder, a contract for a defense housing project involving 300 dwellings.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Oct. 22 -- An increase in the demand on the Bourse against a small supply was responsible for a rise in shares that in some cases reached 7 points. Royal Dutch rose 4 5/8 points to 309 3/4; Amsterdam Trading 7 to 480; Amsterdam Rubber 3 3/4 to 304 3/4; Philips 7 3/4 to 269 1/4, and Unilever 2 5/8 to 158 5/8.
ROME, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

The thirty-six N.Y.U. players who will journey to Worcester, Mass., for Saturday's game with Holy Cross were named by Coach Mal Stevens yesterday after a two-hour contact scrimmage, the third of the week.

ROME, Oct. 22 -- A diplomatic incident between Italy and the United States was intimated by Virginio Gayda today, who discussed the possibility that William Phillips, United States Ambassador to Italy, had something to do with Breckenridge Long's speech at Detroit on Oct. 19.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- General Robert E. Wood, acting national chairman of the America First Committee, appealed today to President Roosevelt to submit to a vote of Congress the question of war or peace.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 22 -- An exploratory proposal for college and university participation in the work of building civilian morale met sharp criticism as well as support today at the closing session of the annual conference of the Association of Urban Universities when Dr. Frederick J. Kelly of the Federal Office of Education discussed with a luncheon group a program he presented yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 22 -- Five waves of British planes bombed Naples for five hours during last night, dropping hundreds of incendiary and explosive bombs that caused "huge" damage, killed fourteen persons and wounded twenty-seven, the war communique announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 22 -- Irene Dunne and W.C. Fields were signed today for Doris Morros's "Tales of Manhattan," bringing the budget for principal players to an estimated $300,000. The picture went before the cameras at Twentieth-Century-Fox today with Julien Duvivier directing and a cast which includes Charles Boyer, Rita Hayworth, Edward G. Robinson, Joel McCrea, Charles Laughton, Elsa Lanchester, Paul Robeson, Ethel Waters and Eddie Anderson.

Under auspices of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War, women of nearly twenty nations gathered yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt to exchange experiences and to discuss common problems related to the international situation.

Denying that their action was politically motivated, fourteen majority members of the City Council put through a local law yesterday giving policemen forty-eight hours off at the end of their six-day week instead of the existing thirty-two hours off.

A "reasonable supply" of zippers will be available for Spring corset lines in view of the OPM order allotting the slide-fastener industry 70 per cent of its 1940 copper quota, it was reported yesterday at a special meeting of the joint priorities committee of the Corset and Brassiere Manufacturers of America and the Associated Corset and Brassiere Manufacturers at the Hotel Vanderbilt.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 22 -- John Hay Whitney's The McClain, a winner on the flat at the Mon-mouth County meet last Saturday, captured the Froh-Heim Chase, a two-mile test over twelve brush obstacles, as the twenty-sixth annual two-day meeting of the Essex Fox Hounds opened on the estate of Evander B. Schley today.

After two years of apprenticeship with Manhattan's reserves, Roosevelt Hedemark, 185-pound senior guard, yesterday clinched the right guard berth for the set-to with unbeaten Villanova tomorrow night at the Polo Grounds. In moving into the first-string line, Hede-mark replaces a classmate, Art Rogers, on the strength of his fine defensive performances in recent contests.

In a move expected to double the number of sabbatical leaves granted to teachers the Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday adopted sweeping liberalizations governing leaves of absence in the city school system. The changes will help particularly the older members of the teaching staff.
Some fellows seem to get all the breaks.

Columbia's backfield corps, hampered by injuries since the beginning of the season, is likely to be at full strength for the first time this Saturday when the Lions meet Army at West Point. The two casualties, Adam Spiegel, wingback, and Ken Germann, alternate tailback, took part in full workouts yesterday at Baker Field and it is likely that both will see action at the Point.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- The Westchester County Republican Committee organized today a bi-partisan citizens' committee to study the four-year-old county charter and draft proposed revisions, including a change that might give to towns and cities more equitable representation on the Board of Supervisors.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- A bill changing the method of prosecuting impeachments against Federal district and Circuit judges was passed by the House today, 124 to 123, and was sent to the Senate.

The New York chapter of the American Red Cross was geared to keep pace during the past year, while "history was being made at a speed the world has never before known," its chairman, General James G. Harbord, who presided yesterday at the annual meeting in the organization's headquarters, 315 Lexington Avenue, declared.

The hunters who have discarded their deer rifles in favor of the long bow and the traditional "cloth-yard shaft" are increasing in numbers as well as in support, for the Southern New York Fish and Game Association has gone on record as favoring an open deer season in Westchester County for archers only.

Vintage Port, the one-eyed gelding that has his good eye on the port side, ran one of his gamest races when he captured the Gun Hill Handicap before 15,147 persons at Empire City yesterday. Yet it is true that Carroll Bierman, aboard Sheriff Culkin, did much to present the victory to the Sanford Stud Farms' English-bred.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Watson gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Park Benjamin, Mr. and Mrs. W. Whitewright Watson and Mr. and Mrs. Witherbee Black. In the luncheon party given by Mrs. Henry Coster Emmet in the Persian Room were Mrs. Sidney D. Ripley, Mrs. Philip Rhinelander, Mrs. William Baylis, Mrs. George S. Mahana and Mrs. William A. Fairburn.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- A national program to require young men and young women to serve the government for one year in civil annd military capacities, both in peace and war, was advocated this afternoon by Mrs. Eugene Meyer of Mount Kisco and Washington, chairman of the Westchester County Recreation Commission, in an address before the Westchester League of Women Voters.

WASHINGTON, Oct 22 -- The Maritime Commission tonight announced that after next Tuesday all shipments of war materiel to Russia would go through the port of Boston, immediately reviving earlier rumors that the new Japanese Government of General Hideki Tojo had informed the United States that shipments to Vladivostok would be intercepted.

Furs Await Cold Weather Spur Little appreciable change has developed in the fur situation, with both retailers and manufacturers awaiting the turn in the weather that is expected to inpart a stimulus to demand that has been lacking since the last week of September.

The Thomson Equipment Corporation, manufacturer of aircraft parts and accessories, has leased from Interboro Industrials, Inc., through the Roman-Caswell Company, brokers, the one-story industrial building on the southeast corner of Thirty-seventh Avenue and Twenty-second Street, Long Island City.
Another American-owned ship has been sunk in the North, Atlantic, bringing this country's tonnage losses in the war to eleven vessels of more than 60,000 gross tons in less than a year.

Those who have experienced the snowstorms that blow from the steppes to herald the Moscow Winter will not dismiss lightly the Russian reports, supported by admissions in Berlin, that the Nazi drive on the capital has been slowed up by bad weather. The first Russian snows have the violence of a Nazi, "blitz" and the cruel persistence of tropic rains.

Testimony before the Joint Legislative Committee on Revision of the Insurance Law has been preponderantly against the proposal to permit life insurance companies in this State to put their money into common stocks. Chairman Wright of the committee has wisely concluded that exhaustive study should be undertaken before a decision to alter the existing law is reached.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Japanese press charged with growing wrath today that the United States was seeking Siberian bases for use against Japan, and warned that "Siberia belongs to Asia."

Quickening the already speedy pace of the prosecution of George E. Browne and William Bioff, United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa yesterday wound up his case against the leaders of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Amid the same scenes of good humor and courtesy which marked its inauguration on Sept. 16, the hearing on the railroad labor dispute by President Roosevelt's five-man Fact-Finding Board ended today. Opposing counsel expressed mutual esteem and spoke cordially of the interests each represented.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 22 (AP) -- A report condemning war as "a manifestation of sin" and pledging support to "victims of aggression" was adopted today by the Presbyterian Synod of New York at its annual session.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

WITH BRITISH WARSHIPS, east of Tobruk, Libya, Oct. 22 -- A long line of British warships stood off the bleak Libyan coast early today and pumped tons of high explosives into German artillery positions east of besieged Tobruk in a spectacular reminder that a major British land offensive might begin soon in the desert.
BERLIN, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A communique from Adolf Hitler's Headquarters said today:

Frederick Joubert Duquesne testified yesterday at the Brooklyn espionage trial that he had informed the Federal Bureau of Investigation that William G. Sebold, counter-espionage agent for the FBI and principal government witness, was a "dangerous lunatic" because he had urged Duquesne to "put dynamite in President Roosevelt's church in Hyde Park."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Administration fiscal leaders have been told that Congress will look askance on added tax burdens, soon to be sought to help finance the defense load, unless the administration shows signs of cooperation in cutting non-defense expenditures.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A stock argument of the isolationists is to point to what they call the futility of the last war. Was it futile when it gave us some twenty years of comparative freedom from the German menace? For let no one suppose that if Britain had been defeated we would not have been menaced by Germany just as we will be if Britain should be defeated now.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 22 -- With the resumption of relations between Great Britain and Mexico, official and other Mexican circles are revealed to be discussing a new approach to the oil problem.

Three of the remaining Harlem River rowing clubs, hardy survivors of an age when greater interest was shown by New Yorkers in the sport, have been spared from eviction by Dock Commissioner John McKenzie, he disclosed yesterday.

The Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce reports that production by the aircraft industry for the first six months of this year reached $617,435,000 worth of planes, engines and propellers. This compares with a value of $544,440,000 for the entire year of 1940. Deliveries for the first six months of 1941 were up 182 per cent as compared with the same period of last year.

LONDON, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- Lord Moyne, Colonial Secretary, speaking for the government, sought to squelch demands for a British invasion of Europe today with an assertion that Britain still has too few tanks and big guns to risk another "Dunkerque."

One of the most famous 'families in international banking was represented yesterday in the reports of residential leasing with the announcement that the Baroness Alphonse de Rothschild took the furnished apartment of Conde Nast, president of the publishing firm bearing his name, in 1040 Park Avenue in a transaction negotiated by Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc.

Unanimous support of outright repeal of the Neutrality, Act was voted yesterday by 100 members of the New York City League for a Declared War during the first of a series of luncheon meetings held at Town Hall. This declaration was substantiated by a telegram sent to Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, leader of this move in the upper house, at the suggestion of Maurice Davidson.

At a meeting of directors yesterday Langbourne M. Williams Jr., president of the Freeport Sulphur Company, reported for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 net income of $706,608 after all charges, including depreciation, depletion and reserve for taxes, or 89 cents a share on 796,380 shares of common stock.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- A delegation of 300 women from Brooklyn and Northern New Jersey, representing the America First Committee, delivered a letter today to the office of Senator Connally, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, protesting against the pending bill to legalize the arming of American merchantmen.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Directors of the Maine Central Railroad voted today a dividend of $9 a snare of prior preference stock of record of Oct. 25. Payment will cover arrearage on the stock, dividends on which are cumulative, up to July 1, 1937.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The death of Hector Cowan, reported in THE TIMES today, takes me back more than fifty years to the time when I saw him in action and became one of his intimate friends. He was a truly great football player, one of Princeton's immortal heroes, and remembered by all.

WASHINGTON, Oct .22 -- President Roosevelt issued a proclamation today designating a six-day period, beginning Armistice Day, Nov. 11, as a period during which all Americans should give thought to the part each could play in the home defense program of the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "Read German history and you will find no instance where the Reich ever stabbed a friend in the back," boasted a German spokesman in Berlin, trying to counteract the impression that Breckinridge Long's speech in Detroit on Oct. 19 cannot have failed to make in Italy.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, largest single operating utility system holding membership in the American Gas Association, fact-finding, statistical and service organization for the gas industry, has withdrawn from active participation in the association's affairs, it was learned yesterday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 22 -- Brig. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, Chief of the Construction Division, Office of the Quartermaster General, War Department, told delegates to the forty-eighth annual convention of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York at the concluding session here today that despite the late start made by the United States in arming for defense, progress had been substantial and beyond all reasonable expectations.

Loomis J. Grossman, operator, who recently bought the eight-story loft building at 336-40 Canal Street, resold it yesterday to the Fonta Realty Corporation for cash over a mortgage of 528,350 held by the Bowery Savings Bank. The property, which is assessed at $45,000, fronts fifty-seven feet, near Church Street, and was sold through the Algra Realty Corporation.

The International Longshoremen's Association and a ship owner's committee representing the coastwise services will begin discussions today for a new wage and working agreement covering longshoremen employes of the lines.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Wheat lacked the aggressive buying which gave impetus to the market yesterday, and moreover felt the effect of profit-taking. Shorts covered freely on Tuesday, and lacking any new incentive to spur buying, prices sold off sharply today from the early high spots.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Prices of hogs were higher today for the first time in several weeks, recording gains to 15 to 25 cents a hundred pounds, as producers curtailed shipments and buyers were encouraged to mark up bids on expectations of heavy government purchases of pork and lard this week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- A diplomatic source indicated tonight that resignation of Premier Jonasson's government was precitated by sharp rises in living costs and "unsettled difficulties" in connection with the joint occupation of Iceland.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 22 -- Changes in Girl Scout uniforms and equipment are being made voluntarily to release vital defense materials, Mrs. Robert T. Swaine of New York City, chairman of the national equipment service committee, told the National Girl Scout convention today.

Expressing pride in the "perfect engineering and clean financing" of the project, Mayor La Guardia officially opened yesterday the new link of the East River Drive, from Twenty - third to Thirty - fourth Streets, and indicated his confidence of being re-elected when he said he hoped to officiate at the completion of the drive next April.

Lamb isn't lamb, in the opinion of this column, if there isn't a bit of mint about it somewhere. So we feel a peculiar fondness for the jolly new jars of fresh mint chutney which are making their debut today.

As a result of a new rubber component definition by the Bureau of Internal Revenue, many products containing rubber, which were previously exempt from manufacturers excise taxes, are now subject to such levies, it was learned yesterday.

New York's football Giants, hopefully headed toward their sixth straight triumph of the season when they meet Dr. Jock Sutherland's Dodgers at Ebbets Field next Sunday, started yesterday's workout at the Polo Grounds in the dark.

Harold Rosen, a round-faced and bespectacled former night school teacher, whose father was slain by members of the notorious Brooklyn murder syndicate because he knew too much, testified yesterday in Kings County Court that he saw his father emerge white-faced and shaken from a conversation with Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, industrial rackets czar, just six months before the collapse of the Rosen family's garment trucking business.

As the City Council moved for an investigation of the Health and Correction Departments, officials of both agencies denied yesterday that inmates of Rikers Island Penitentiary had been used as "guinea pigs," for research into trichinosis at the prison piggery in 1938 and 1939 as charged on Tuesday by Councilman Walter R. Hart, Brooklyn Democrat.

In addition to individual brand advertising, Schenley Distillers Corporation is planning a heavy over-all campaign for its complete line of twenty-two straight whiskies in order to inform consumers of the range of ages, proofs and types available, it was announced yesterday.

MERCERSBURG, Pa., Oct. 22 -- Probably none of the comments made today by Coach Fido Kempton better summarizes the prevailing football situation at Mercersburg Academy than the assertion, "We could have a good team if we had sufficient time to work."

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Princeton completed preparations for the Vanderbilt tilt Saturday with twenty minutes of stationary scrimmage against the Southerners' plays as staged by the Tigers' junior varsity on University Field today.
MANILA, Oct. 22 -- Francis B. Sayre, High. Commissioner in the Philippines told a group of Americans and Filipinos tonight:

CRANBURY, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Beau Essig's Don, English setter owned by Virgil Hawse of Staunton, Va., held the spotlight on the third day of the ninth annual national amateur pheasant championship today.

BERLIN, Oct. 22 -- Concrete military news from the east today gave little indication of further German progress toward Moscow. Such reports as were available, in fact, indicated that the burden of Germany's part in the battle for the Soviet capital was being borne not by the ground troops, but by the Air Force.

The latest sinkings or American-owned ships, which yesterday spurred Senatorial moves to repeal the Neutrality Act, show that the war at sea is not bounded by any latitude or longitude and that socalled "zones" have no meaning in a shooting war.

The stock market stumbled around yesterday in an effort to find a balance after the decline of last week and the subsequent recovery. The dullness of the session argued, however, against any definite movement, and final quotations were irregularly lower on the day.

The seven-story industrial building at 170 Tillary Street, Brooklyn, tenanted in its entirety by Howard Clothes, operators of the men's clothing chain, has been sold by the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America to the 170 Tillary Street Corporation, L.F. Camardella, president, subject to a purchase money mortgage of $114,000.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 22 -- A modern Sherlock Holmes or Hawkshaw the detective is wanted at Lehigh. There is a mystery here that so far has defied solution. Clues are non-existent and if there is a motive that, too, will have to bit unearthed.

Modern school children, given their choice of "educational" moving pictures, prefer "lifelike Indian raids" in films showing the life of early Kentucky pioneers, "more action" on the part of Joan of Arc and "no silk stockings" on modern Indians.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 21:

Robert B. Condon, campaign manager for Paul P. Rao, Democratic nominee for the Supreme Court, charged yesterday that the judiciary committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York was "not familiar with the facts" when it found Mr. Rao "not qualified" for the Supreme Court bench.

BERLIN, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- Nazi military commentators said tonight that driving snowstorms and freezing nights were impeding armored operations on the Moscow front and that Axis troops occupying the Donets Basin had slowed down for a breathing spell after two weeks of forced marches.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, announced today that Defense Plant Corporation would build a $35,000,000 pig iron plant at Provo, Utah, to be operated by the Columbia Steel Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Treasury notes to be issued tomorrrow to refinance something over $500,000,000 in outstanding notes of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Commodity Credit Corporation will bear interest at the rate of 1 per cent a year and will mature in 1946, according to an announcement tonight by the Treasury Department.

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, was accused yesterday of having forfeited the right to continue in office because of political activity in violation of the State Civil Service Law and the New York City Charter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, announced today that Defense Plant Corporation would build a $35,000,000 pig iron plant at Provo, Utah, to be operated by the Columbia Steel Company.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 22 -- The National Defense Mediation Board recommended today that members of the United Mine Workers in nearly forty commercial mines in Alabama, and their owners, accept findings which would increase wages about $1,700,000 a year for about 22,000 miners, but which fall short of the demands made by the Alabama miners.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The White House gave at least indirect endorsement today to the movement in Congress to repeal all remaining restrictions of the Neutrality Act of 1939, so that American merchant ships may go anywhere on the seven seas under their own flag and the protection of their own guns.
Trading was mostly fair in the wholesale meat markets yesterday. Cow beef was weak to lower and some fresh pork cuts were slightly lower. Other classes were mostly steady.

The Flintkote Company and subsidiaries report, in a statement covering the forty weeks ended on Oct. 4, to be made public today, a net income of $1,390,035 after $1,302,177 provision for Federal, State and foreign taxes, including $645,142 for accrued Federal excess-profits tax.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Maritime Commission received word today that all thirty-nine of the American crew aboard the freighter Lehigh, which was torpedoed on a trading voyage off the African coast Sunday, had been rescued and brought to African ports.
Receipt of gifts totaling more than $100,000 was announced yesterday by Roy E. Larsen, general chairman of the campaign committee of the United Hospital Compaign.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 22 -- Reports circulating in foreign air circles in Ankara today indicated that there has been a sharp drop in German aerial activity on all fronts -- in Russia, the Middle East and over Britain -- during the last several days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today a request by the Louisville Gas and Electric Company (Kentucky) for permission to sell direct to the public 150,000 shares of common stock at $23.50 a share.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 22 -- A wave of rioting, sabotage and bitter resistance to further Rumanian participation in a costly south Russian campaign is sweeping Rumania's north and eastern provinces, according to well-documented reports to foreign military intelligence sources here this evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Ralph Greenleaf, seventeen times a champion, staged a sensational rally tonight to keep pace with Willie Mosconi, the defending titleholder, and other former rulers in the $10,000 world pocket-billiard tournament.

Reporting to stockholders on operations in the third quarter of this year R.G.A. van der Woude, president of the Shell Union Oil Corporation, announced yesterday that earnings were double those the year before despite increased taxes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Rumania has denounced the Vienna pact with Hungary in an effort to regain the part of Transylvania she surrendered after the outbreak of the present war under Axis pressure.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A Royal Air force Middle East communique today said:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- William S. Knudsen has told a Senate appropriations subcommittee that the program for the monthly production of medium tanks has been doubled.

Vicinity of the Volga Soviet Russia's temporary capital, Kuibysheff, used to be called Samara. It was the name of a province as well as of its provincial capital on the Volga. Exactly fifty years ago Samara was a not unfamiliar name for a while in American ears.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The award of contracts totaling $12, 497,427 was announced by the War Department today. Awards in the New York area were listed as follows:

Operations of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation in the first nine months of this year resulted in a consolidated net profit of $3,989,236 after providing $6,890,198 for Federal income and excess profits taxes, according to a report issued yesterday.

TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- As part of elaborate air defense manoeuvres a complete blackout went into effect in Tokyo tonight. Although ordered some time ago it served to bring to some persons the possible implications of what government officials and the press have so often proclaimed to be the greatest crisis in Japan's history, for which the "wartime Cabinet" is mobilizing the entire nation.

Following is the identification, politically, of twenty-nine of the thirty-three assistants appointed by William O'Dwyer in the District Attorney's office in Kings County, as outlined by Mayor La Guardia, in an official statement to the press, issued at City Hall yesterday:
LONDON, Oct. 22 (AP) --The Air Ministry issued this communique, today:

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The prospect of having control of Reuter, foremost news distributing agency of the British Empire, fall into the hands of a few powerful London publishers caused a wave of concern in the House of Commons this afternoon.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 22 -- Germany was declared today to be committing suicide by slow starvation in her conquest of Europe.

TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- As part of elaborate air defense manoeuvres a complete blackout went into effect in Tokyo tonight. Although ordered some time ago it served to bring to some persons the possible implications of what government officials and the press have so often proclaimed to be the greatest crisis in Japan's history, for which the "wartime Cabinet" is mobilizing the entire nation.

Following is the identification, politically, of twenty-nine of the thirty-three assistants appointed by William O'Dwyer in the District Attorney's office in Kings County, as outlined by Mayor La Guardia, in an official statement to the press, issued at City Hall yesterday:
LONDON, Oct. 22 (AP) --The Air Ministry issued this communique, today:

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The prospect of having control of Reuter, foremost news distributing agency of the British Empire, fall into the hands of a few powerful London publishers caused a wave of concern in the House of Commons this afternoon.

Delegates representing 5,000,000 women in organizations affiliated with the National Council of Women were urged yesterday to direct their national defense efforts toward the home and their local communities.

SEATTLE, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The King County (Seattle) Sheriff's office has received a writ from the British Government for service upon Sir Thomas Beecham, erstwhile conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra, alleging that u1,298 (about $5,215) is due from him in income taxes.

Unless otherwise stated, the remits of operations of following companies are after all charges, federal income and excess profits axes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, speaking last night at rallies in the Bronx, attacked his Democratic opponent, M. Maldwin Fertig, on the basis of Mr. Fertig's past record in public office. Mr. Morris spoke at Public School 55, St. Paul's Place and Washington Avenue, and Theodore Roosevelt High School, East Fordham Road and Washington Avenue.

The moody filly, Devil's Gir who has to be brought to the post with a lead pony 30 that she will remain calm, was a courageous winner yesterday at Empire City of the featured Laura Dianti purse. Jimmy Stout, who has had his troubles with this daughter of Diavolo and White Favor, was in the pilot house and was all agrin when his mount was led into the winner's circle.

VICHY, Friday, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The second batch of fifty French hostages will be shot at dawn for the slaying of the Nazi commander of gendarmerie at Nantes. Fifty more hostages will be summarily shot at Bordeaux, probably this morning.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo returned to the Metropolitan Opera House last night after a brief series of appearances in nearby cities, and presented as the chief novelty of its program a shortened version of "Bogatyri."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Jess Jones, head of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and his other superiors in that government agency where he was employed as a loan examiner, raised no objections to his accepting employment with the International Utilities Corporation, W. B. Yeager, president of the corporation, testified today before Richard Townsend, trial examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 23 -- Talk of international team, matches with the United States, goal of the Argentine Golf Association for nearly a decade, has revived since the arrival of Uncle Sam's newest links ambassadors, Sam Snead and Jimmy Demaret.

DALLAS, Oct. 23 -- Sir Gerald Campbell, director general of British information services, speaking at the national Girl Scout convention banquet tonight, characterized the European war as a struggle between the ideals inspiring the youth of Germany and those inspiring the youth of Britain and America.

Governor Lehman formally dedicated the new Miller Memorial Factory of the Industrial Home for the Blind at 1000 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday and played father to children in the pediatric division of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn at 555 Prospect Place.

The "pro-labor" declarations of the Democratic candidates for city-wide office were criticized last night by Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler as attempts on the part of the Democrats to "fabricate a fake labor record for themselves."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Miss Mary Isabel Lloyd Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Lloyd Jones of Bronxville, has organized a junior committee to sell programs at the gala concert to be given at the County Center here Saturday night as a benefit for the British War Relief Society.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In recent editorials you have referred to the "alliance" between Russia and Germany. Surely it is time we stopper spreading the myth that an "alliance existed between the U.S.S.R. and Germany prior to June 22, 1941. This "alliance" theory, constantly reiterated, has done a great deal of harm to good relations and understanding between the United States and the Soviet Union, and indirectly has served Hitler's purpose.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 23 -- Ten speakers warned fifteen hundred members of the Associated Industries of Massachusetts at their annual meeting today of heavier taxes, the necessity for greater sacrifices and, above all, of speed in production, if Hitler is to be defeated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Secretary Ickes, who reported last Summer the existence of a petroleum shortage on the East Coast and restricted sale and use of petroleum, declared today that the shortage was being rapidly eliminated and that closing of gasoline stations between 7 P.M. and 7 A.M. would no longer be necessary.

Supporters of District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic nominee for Mayor, yesterday awaited with interest final efforts by Democratic leaders to get President Roosevelt at least to avoid a complete endorsement of Mayor La Guardia in his statement on the New York City Mayoralty contest which he has indicated he will make at his press conference today.

Respite for wives with the budget blues lies in this week-end's report of the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets. Dairy product prices are happily unchanged, and all meats show a steady or downhill trend -- with each cut of beef selling for 1 to 4 cents less a pound than at this time last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- A.D. Lewis, chairman of the United Construction Workers Organizing Committee (C.I.O.) and a brother of John L. Lewis, charged today that Sidney Hillman's Labor Division of the Office of Production Management had acted, in effect as "a recruiting agency for the American Federation of Labor in connection with defense projects."
The store in the building at 425 Madison Avenue has been leased by Douglas L. Elliman, Inc., brokers, to Ruth, Milliners.

Word from Washington yesterday that Secretary Ickes had recommended the suspension of OPM's limitation order on the use of gasoline in the seaboard States and had rescinded his request that filling stations close from 7 P.M. to 7 A.M. had a mixed reception among oil men and filling station spokesmen.

Thomas E. Dewey, calling himself "one of the leading authorities on Mayor La Guardia's shortcomings," praised the latter yesterday as a "great Mayor," against whose re-election neither logical nor factual argument could successfully be advanced.

Unit Sales Watched Closely Unit sales of merchandise will come in for much more scrutiny than heretofore as a measure of retail volume, it was indicated in merchandising circles here yesterday. Dollar volume, it was pointed out, is becoming increasingly affected by price rises, which already are estimated as running about 13 per cent above a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Right Rev. Francis J. Spellman, Archbishop of New York and long in service at the Vatican, had an unannounced luncheon conference with President Roosevelt today. Myron C. Taylor, the President's personal envoy to the Vatican, was in the White House at the time of the meeting.

The spectacle of a long line of British warships raining tons of high explosive upon the German heavy artillery positions east of Tobruk inevitably leads to speculation as to whether this is not a portent of something more serious than relieving pressure upon the besieged garrison.
ROME, Oct. 23 -- The efforts of President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull to get the Neutrality Act revised resulted today in some truly vicious personal attacks in the Italian press.

A favorable home environment is much more important than biological heredity in promoting the length of life, Dr. Louis I. Dublin, vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, in charge of its statistical research, declared yesterday before the annual meeting of the Association of Life Insurance Medical Directors of America at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

One week from tonight when the sun goes down and the spirits of Haloween emerge from dusty corners and bent Yew trees a bewildered witch will hover momentarily amid the buildings at Rockefeller Center and wonder if she has missed her course, for between the British Empire Building and La Maison Francaise she will see tall shocks of corn bound and ready for the harvest.

BENDIX, N.J., Oct. 23 -- Mass picketing by between 2,000 and 3,000 C.I.O. adherents temporarily shut down the plant of Air Associates, Inc., here this morning, but this afternoon the company succeeded in resuming production on $5,000,000 defense orders by rushing 500 nonstriking employes into the plant by a back road.

One of the most interesting things brought to our attention during this season is the increase in the number of hunters with dogs, and it is apparent that the average hunter is beginning to realize that a good dog is almost as essential as a gun if he is to get the full enjoyment of his sport.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 -- Professor Sidney Allan Gunn of Boston University, one of the leading authorities on Gaelic and Irish cultures, died tonight as he was preparing to leave for a class at the College of Business Administration, where he had been a member of the faculty for seven years.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23 -- Prize-winning pictures in the exhibition called "Directions in American Painting" -- which was commented upon in a general way yesterday -- were announced tonight at the Founders Day exercises held in the Music Hall of Carnegie Institute.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works and subsidiaries, including the Midvale Company, of whose capital stock Baldwin owns about 61.5 per cent, reported yesterday for the twelve months ended with September a consolidated net profit of $3,910,222 after all charges, provision for Federal and Pennsylvania income taxes including $3,594,000 for excess profits tax, and deduction of minority interest of the Midvale Company.

The defense by Sidney Hillman and other Government officials of their failure to accept the Currier bid does not put the case in any better light. On the contrary, it confirms the worst suspicions that arose when the case originally came to public notice.

LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Predictions that Moscow would hold out through the long Russian Winter and that the main force of the German drive would be switched southeast toward the Caucasus came tonight from informed British sources.

The ebb and flow of the tide of war sweeping in its daily fluctuations back and forth past the outer bastions of Moscow and roaring around the periphery of Europe brought hope to the Russians Wednesday, to the Germans yesterday, and a measure of sober but impatient confidence to the British.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- William C. Bullitt, former Ambassador to France, said today that the United States should declare war upon Germany at once, that war is inevitable.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- W. H. Harrison, OPM production director, revealed today plans to double tank production and speed up the output of new and more modern long-range bombers so that the British would be able, and the United States prepared, to fight the enemy wherever he is.

Trailing a last-minute rally in the commodities inspired by a Congressional committee's approval of legislation requiring the Commodity Credit Corporation to make loans on five basic farm commodities at 100 per cent of parity in 1942 and 1943, the stock market came to life yesterday in the final hour.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- Major Kilbourne Johnston, who is on duty at the War Department here, remarked tonight that he guessed he would have to pay $3,355 back to the government out of his major's salary since his Commander in Chief thought he should.

Charging Mayor La Guardia with demagoguery and boastfulness in claiming that he saved the city from bankruptcy, Lloyd Church, Democratic nominee for Controller, quoted Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick last night as having said that it was the so-called bankers' agreement that saved the city from bankruptcy and added that it was George McAneny, then Controller, and Governor Lehman who put through the bankers' agreement in 1933 before the Mayor took office.

Reporting yesterday on operations in the first nine months of the current year, A.W. Robertson, chairman, of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, informed stockholders that orders booked during the period reached a high record of $450,242,292, an increase of 72 per cent over the similar period of 1940.

Replying to a letter of greeting sent to Soviet scientists by ninety-three American mathematicians expressing sympathy with the cause of Soviet Russia in her resistance to Nazi invasion, sixty-three Soviet mathematicians have acknowledged gratefully the receipt of the communication as proof of "the unity of Soviet and American scientists and their determination to fight the twentieth century vandals till the end."

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- German mechanized units, reported to be within thirty-seven miles of Moscow on the Central Front and inside the city limits of Kharkov in the Donets basin, were being hindered in their further progress by "extremely bad weather conditions," an authorized military spokesman said here tonight.

Although a fairly close relationship has been found to exist between critics' opinions of new books and the books' reception by the public, a novel that has made a comparatively slight showing on best-seller lists has been named by a panel of prominent literary critics the "best" fiction work published in the last three months.

Reflecting subscription payments on Monday for the Treasury's largest single piece of new financing since the World War, the new 2 1/2 per cent bond issue, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $570,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $4,660,000,000, lowest since Aug. 16, 1939, or just before the outbreak of war in Europe.
BERLIN, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The German High Command communique from Adolf Hitler's headquarters said today:

The return of John Barbirolli, accompanied by the presence of Josef Hoffman as soloist, and a new work, "Plain-Chant for America," by William Grant Still, poem by Katherine Garrison Chapin, with Wilbur Evans as officiating baritone, packed Carnegic Hall last night for the third Philharmonic-Symphony concert of the season.

So many are the unknown factors in the Nazi campaign in Russia that no analysis of that titanic conflict can be made with confidence. But one factor that seems to have received considerably less attention than it deserves is the transportation of oil supplies. As an army in Frederick the Great's day traveled on its belly, the modern panzer division travels on its gas tank.

William Bioff and George E. Browne, movie union leaders who have been on trial in Federal court since Oct. 8, will have to let a jury decide whether they are guilty of the extortions attributed to them, by the government, Judge John C. Knox ruled yesterday.

On the main question now before the Senate -- the question whether to change the Neutrality Act a little or to change it very much -- the Gallup survey has something of interest to say this morning. It reports the results of a checkup of opinion on the proposal to amend the law to permit American merchant ships with American crews to carry war supplies direct to Britain.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Oct. 23 -- Increased buying was in evidence on the Bourse today and gains up to 14 points were made. Royal Dutch was 4 1/2 points up at 314 1/4; Amsterdam Trading, 4 at 484; Amsterdam Rubber, 3 5/3 at 308 3/8; Philips, 2 at 271 1/4, and Unilever, 1 3/8 at 160, but A.K.U. was depressed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Increasing its fifty-four combat groups to eighty-four provided by Congressional appropriation, the Army Air Force is to be expanded by June 30 to 400,000 men, with a subsequent expansion to 500,000 in view.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Office of Production Management ordered a 29 per cent cut today in December production of light trucks for civilian use, to conserve materials for heavier trucks needed for defense and essential civilian transport. There is no restriction on the number of heavy trucks which may be manufactured.

In a meeting marked by an air of cool politeness, Mayor La Guardia and Governor Lehman came face to face with each other yesterday for the first time since the Governor announced on Tuesday his support of William O'Dwyer, Democratic Mayoralty candidate.
The report of the Gillette Safety Razor Company, announced yesterday, disclosed a net profit for the nine months ended with September of $2,333,337 after all charges including Federal taxes.
MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:
Sophie Tucker, the musical comedy star, has leased an apartment in the Hotel St. Moritz, 50 Central Park South.

Color glowed vividly yesterday at Oppenheim Collins "half-pint" fashion show. Contrary to the belief that petite women should not wear vivid contrasts of color, big plaids, dazzling sequins or a wide variety of trimming, Oppenheim Collins showed that a "half-pint" can wear any costume, provided that it is properly proportioned.

SOUTH KENT, Conn., Oct. 23 -- Mrs. Florence Maybrick, member of an old Southern family who served sixteen years in prison in England as the poisoner of her husband, a Liverpool cotton broker, and escaped the death penalty only because of the public clamor aroused in England and the United States back in 1889, was found dead today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- If members of Congress had not been bombarding the Maritime Commission with demands for greater use of port facilities south and north of New York City and San Francisco, and if the commission's publicity department had been careful in phrasing a statement issued yesterday, the German Navy would not today have the useful information that war materiel for Russia is soon to be shipped from Boston to Archangel.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, attacking the policies of Commissioner of Markets William Fellowes Morgan, told 500 merchants and workers at Washington Market yesterday that when he becomes Mayor "the door will be open both ways at City Hall."

THE excellent new "Treasury of Gilbert Sullivan,"* informingly edited by Deems Taylor and published this morning by those inveterate treasury builders, Mr. Simon and Mr. Schuster, will cause fresh bursts of song among those who like to think that every man is his own Savoy company -- and probably send those who do not think so at all into hastily devised refuges in the hills.

Apparently foreseeing a clash between Germany and Russia, General Gregory K. Zhukoff, the new Soviet commander in the center, warned the Communist party conference in Moscow last December that the Red Army in the western zone should remain constantly mobilized so that it might not be caught unprepared by foreign "tricks."

Another Dilemma Wall Street underwriters have been watching, quietly but with much interest, the situation that has developed in Louisville, Ky., in respect to the distribution, or rather offering, of a block of 150,000 shares of new common stock of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company.

LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Note circulation at the Bank of England continued, in the week ended on Oct. 22, its record-breaking pace, reaching a total of u688,528,000. The increase was u2,465,000, and the eighth consecutive week that a new record was established.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Maritime Commission was publicly rebuked at the White House today for having announced that hence-forth all shipments of war supplies from the United States to Soviet Russia would depart from the port of Boston.

Columbia's football forces turned their attention to aerial manoeuvres yesterday at Baker Field, fashioning a two-man overhead attack for tomorrows game with Army at West Point. Ken Germann, alternate wingback and tailback, combined with Paul Governali to put on a two-hour display of passing.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 23 -- An increase in public sentiment for changing the Neutrality Act to permit American ships to carry war supplies to Britain has taken place in the last ten days -- a period during which Congress has been hotly debating the issue of revising the neutrality law.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 24 -- British Bomber Command planes attacked objectives in the Rhineland over Wednesday night, the main weight of the offensive being thrown on the southern industrial center of Mannheim.

Bank clearings for twenty-three leading cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $8,153,832,000, the highest level since Oct. 8, 1931, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This was an increase of 31.3 per cent, or $1,944,103,000, over the preceding week and a rise of 38.1 per cent over the $5,902,504,000 reported in the corresponding period of 1940.

A total of $12,584,856 has been allotted to the Board of Education in the proposed capital budget for 1942 to complete buildings now under construction and to purchase new sites for future use, James Marshall, president of the board, disclosed yesterday.
ST. LOUIS. Oct. 23 (AP) -- A superliving race of Americans in the year 1961 was forecast today if parents of 1941 took advantage of present knowledge of nutrition.

A brilliant spotlight was trained on the models as they stepped upon a raised platform at noon yesterday in the center of the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. In its bright circle were set off the fashions which B. Altman Co. considers the correct ones for women to wear from twilight to midnight.

After three days spent in earnest consideration of its scoring potentialities, the N.Y.U. football team drew a sharp reminder from Coach Mal Stevens yesterday that Holy Cross probably entertained some touchdown notions of its own for the meeting with the Violets tomorrow at Worcester, Mass.

VICHY, France, Oct. 23 -- The office of Francois Lehideux, Secretary of State for Industrial Production, issued today a communnication to stress the activities of the department, and it made clear that M. Lehideux, by virtue of his office, may impose a fine of 1,500,000 francs as well as suspend manufacturers and business men for a term as long as one year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The general level of wholesale prices continued to remain fairly steady for the fifth consecutive week, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 91.7 for the week ended on Oct. 18, compared with 91.6 on Oct. 11 and on Oct. 4, and with 78.4 on Oct. 19, 1940.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 23 -- The Rev. George C. Groves, retired minister who was rector of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church here from 1913 to 1919, died last night in St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn, where he had been taken on Monday suffering with a cardiac ailment.

Small-scale bootleg trading in ethyl alcohol, which was placed under ceilings on Sept. 15, was reported in the market here yesterday, but traders said that there was little prospect that any policing activities would be undertaken to halt the ceiling violations.

Many a person less enthusiastic than Coach Lou Oshins might have paled at the problems of developing a football team at Brooklyn College the last few years, but Oshins is still on the job and football is still a sport there.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday endorsement of three candidates for the City Council in Manhattan. They are George S. Counts, right wing Labor party candidate, and Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, and Robert K. Straus, candidates of the City Fusion party.

The American Republics liner Brazil is due to sail tonight for Buenos Aires via Rio de Janeiro and Santos. Among her passengers will be Dr. Raul Pena, surgeon general of Paraguay, and Mrs. Pena, Lieutenant Hal B. Armstrong, Air Attache of the United States Embassy in Brazil, and Mrs. Armstrong.

JUST the other day there came swinging along a tall, stalwart gent with a sprinkling of gray in his hair. At a little distance he looked like Harry Heilmann, the former big hitter of the Detroit Tigers. But on closer inspection it turned out to be another old acquaintance, Jack Kelly of Philadelphia, former national and Olympic champion sculler.

OCEANSIDE, L. I., Oct. 23 -- Jimmy Hines of Lakeville, Ernie Catropa of Idlewild and Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills each shot 36-hole totals of 147 on the galeswept Oceanside course today to tie for first place in the annual Long Island P. G. A. championship.

Describing the Neutrality Act as a product of "the same childish mentality as the Prohibition law," Dr. William Agar of Columbia University predicted yesterday the repeal of the act and the eventual entry of this country into the World War.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Department store sales for the week ended Oct. 18 were 7 per cent higher than for the corresponding period of 1940, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Sales in the week ended Oct. 11 were up 13 per cent.

With the finest defensive record of any unbeaten team the country over and the highest scorer among the winning entries of the East, Navy heads into troubled waters in which it will need to fire its heaviest salvos for three successive engagements.

A negotiating committee representing coastwise steamship lines under contract to the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F. of L., has rejected the union's proposal that longshoremen's wages be Increased 15 cents an hour during regular working time and 23 cents for overtime.

VICHY, France, Friday, Oct. 24 -- In addition to the fifty French hostages killed by the Germans Wednesday in reprisal for the shooting of the German military commander of Nantes, fifty more Frenchmen were ordered executed today for the slaying of the German officer in Bordeaux.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Parliamentary spokesmen for British Labor voiced today in fervent and caustic debate their demands for military action to aid Russia, somewhere or anywhere. They demanded that Prime Minister Winston Churchill get rid of certain Ministers, lest they "drag him down with them."

PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 23 -- A dispute between Herbert Hoover and a faculty committee over the attitude of the Stanford University faculty toward American foreign policy continued today with the announcement of the result of a new poll, showing a ratio of about six to one as favoring "stronger measures" by this government "if they should be needed to defeat the Axis powers."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 23 -- At the end of the second Cabinet council dedicated to considering Argentina's rearmament program, Acting President Ramon S. Castillo today confirmed reports that a military mission would leave soon for the United States to make necessary purchases.

The Anglophobia that Frederick Joubert Duquesne has been credited with cherishing during most of his adult life flared into the open yesterday at the Brooklyn espionage trial, as the 63-year-old native of South Africa spent his third day on the witness stand, mainly under the cross-examination of United States Attorney Harold M. Kennedy.

Mayor La Guardia's disclosure that twenty-nine of the thirty-three assistants appointed by District Attorney O'Dwyer have been active in Democratic party affairs is important for two reasons: first, because the Brooklyn political machine is conducted along traditional Tammany lines, and second, because Mr. O'Dwyer, before his election to the District Attorneyship, had given the voters of Brooklyn to undertand that he would not make that kind of appointment.

American Woolen Directors of the American Woolen Company have decided to postpone consideration of a year-end dividend on the 7 per cent preferred stock until the next regular meeting of the board, scheduled for Nov. 19.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed gold holdings and Reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 18 totaled 922,884 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 19,007 cars or 2.1 per cent more than for the preceding week, 108,975 cars or 13.4 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 66,595 cars, or 7.8 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

DETROIT, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Six members of the crew of the tug America were drowned when the vessel capsized at 2 o'clock this morning during an attempt to free the grounded freighter B.F. Jones in the Detroit River.

Six hundred college students yesterday put on a rally for Mayor La Guardia at Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South, where, under the auspices of the youth division of the City Fusion party, representatives of several colleges in the city presented to the Mayor a scroll in appreciation of his interest in public education.

NEW YORK Frank P. Corrigan, United States Ambassador to Venezuela, and Mrs. Corrigan have come to Essex House from Washington to join their son, Robert F. Corrigan, newly appointed vice consul at the American Embassy in Rio de Janeiro, who sails for Brazil today.
LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- General Charles de Gaulle, the Free French leader, in a broadcast tonight asked the men of occupied France, "in the present circumstances, not to kill Germans."

On the eve of her return to London, Lady Louis Mountbatten told yesterday of the "wonderful courtesy and help" she had received as official representative of the British Red Cross during the eight weeks she has spent visiting American Red Cross Chapters throughout the country in behalf of the British society.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 23 -- The American Bankers Association is opposed to any further tightening by the Federal Reserve Board at this time of its regulations governing consumer credit, Walter B. French, deputy manager of the association, told a State-wide consumer credit conference sponsored by Ohio banks here today.

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- The latest assassination of German officers in Nantes and Bordeaux were looked upon in authoritative political circles here today as dictated more by the "general French dislike of Vichy" than by any feelings of hatred for Germany.

CRANBURY, N. J., Oct. 23 -- Lawless Boy, the white and orange pointer, owned by Dr. H. E. Longsdorf of Mount Holly, N. J., today became new national amateur pheasant champion, winning his laurels in a record field of thirty-eight dogs from fourteen States, the largest list of starters in the history of the competition.
Mayor La Guardia, acting quickly on District Attorney William O'Dwyer's attack on his campaign expenses, arranged for an impartial inquiry into the actual costs involved. [Page 1, Column 1.]

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A New York Democrat told the House today that if President Roosevelt endorsed the third term candidacy of Mayor La Guardia "he will break faith with the party that made him what he is today."

Stockholders of the General Foods Corporation will receive today the report of the corporation and its subsidiaries covering the first nine months of this year, in which C.M. Chester, chairman, announces that sales exceeded any previous corresponding period in the company's history.

Robert Brennan, Eire's Minister to Washington, says in the current issue of America, national Catholic weekly, that 99 per cent of the Irish people are against any involvement in the war and that no government could last overnight that attempted to depart from a policy of neutrality.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- With producers curtailing shipments to most leading markets, prices of hogs moved up again today. Early gains ranged from 15 to 20 cents a hundred pounds, but were shaved 5 to 10 cents in later trading. In the first four days of this week 83,000 fewer hogs have been offered for sale at twelve leading markets than in the same period last week.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Decision was handed down today in a stockholder's suit against William Randolph Hearst and several of his corporations filed by Samuel Mann, a stockholder.

"The Blonde From Singapore," which opens at the Central, is this morning's sole film newcomer. Starring Florence Rice and Leif Erikson, the picture features Gordon Jones, Don Beddoe, Alexander D'Arcy, Adele Rowland and Lumsder Hare among the supporting players. . . .

Undefeated Villanova will unfold its razzle-dazzle attack tonight at the Polo Grounds against a twice-beaten but ever hopeful Manhattan eleven. It is expected that 14,000 will witness the renewal of a series begun in 1897. The kick-off will be at 8:30 o'clock.

MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 24 (From official Russian sources; distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Red Army announced today that it had repulsed repeated German attacks in the Mozhaisk and Maloyaroslavets sectors before Moscow, where fighting has raged for five days.

Mrs. Fenton B. Turck of the Savoy-Plaza gave a luncheon yesterday in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Among her guests were Mrs. M. Harris Hamersley, Mrs. Walter J. Berbecker, Mrs. John Vaughn and Mrs. Alice Stewart.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 22 (Delayed) -- The nineteen missing members of the Bold Venture were in their mess quarters drinking tea or coffee when a torpedo struck the ship, according to Donald McLeod of Boston, one of the seventeen survivors.

BUFFALO, Oct. 23 -- Charles P. Taft, assistant coordinator of health, welfare and related defense activities of the Federal Security Office, answered tonight the criticism of delays in the construction of recreation centers to be operated by the United Service Organizations, asserting that the delays were "considerably exaggerated."

As a result of increased circulation and higher publishing costs, the Curtis Publishing Company yesterday announced rate increases for the Saturday Evening Post and the Ladies Home Journal. The increases, which raise the Post black and white page rate from $8,000 to $8,500 and the Journal rate from $8,500 to $9,200, become effective with the July 4, 1942, issue for the former and the July issue for the latter.

If the restrictions placed or Brooklyn's Football Dodgers during the week were to be carried over every Sunday, they would not come close to winning a game all year. They had to keep off Larry MacPhail's treasured grass again yesterday.

The expected post-war slump can be cushioned or averted by intelligent planning on the part of industry in product research and development, according to results of a survey among forty-two leading companies conducted by the Market Research Corporation of America and released yesterday.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Perhaps "Old Pedant" and Dr. Henry Wallace, who calls himself an old pedant also, in your columns, have described themselves accurately. True, in Shakespeare's time "pedant" was used occasionally to mean a pedagog; but the more general use at that time and solely since the beginning of the eighteenth | century is somewhat unflattering, a meaning that a person is chary of applying to himself.

Organization of the natural gas industry for defense under the Office of the Petroleum Coordinator was begun yesterday at a conference in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel among representatives of the American Gas Association and Dr. Robert E. Alien, director of production of the OPC.
A variety of buildings in Manhattan figured yesterday in sales and leases for loft, garage and storage purposes.

Joseph E. McWilliams, leader of the American Destiny party, was rearrested by members of the Criminal Alien Squad at Eighty-seventh Street and Lexington Avenue at 11:30 P.M. last night on charges of violating the terms of a parole imposed last Sept. 9 on his second conviction of disorderly conduct in publicly assailing the Jews.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Subscription books for the offering of 1 per cent Treasury Notes, Series A-1946 will close at the end of business tomorrow, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, announced today.

If there is to be a better balance between nursing intelligence and nursing skill, schools of nursing must obtain financial support similar to that now enjoyed by schools of medicine, Dr. Bancroft Beatley, president of Simmons College, Boston, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- A proposal that the United States Government offer itself as a mediator to negotiate peace between Hitler and the non-Axis Allies was made to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today by John Cudahy, former Ambassador to Belgium.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Prices of wheat moved up sharply in the final trading on the Board of Trade today when the House Agricultural Committee voted to make the loan rate on the five basic farm commodities 100 per cent of parity for 1942 and 1943.

ROME, Oct. 23 -- Dr. Walther Funk, Reich Minister of Economics, left Rome this evening after a three-day visit, during which he held conversations with Italian economic leaders that resulted In "full agreement on all the most important economic questions connected with the war," according to his farewell speech to Raffaelo Riccardi, Italian Minister of Exchange.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 22 (Delayed) -- The seventeen Known survivors of the American-owned merchantman Bold Venture reported today that their nineteen missing shipmates were probably killed or fatally injured when a submarine torpedo sank their ship Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Senate approved today by a vote of 59 to 13 the Supplemental Lease-Lend Bill for aid to nations fighting aggression and returned it to the House with a request that it be sent to conference to iron out a few changes.
LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

For two weeks detectives have been seeking two men who severely injured Mrs. James A. McCabe, 59 years old, West Side undertaker, who, the police said, had disregarded several warnings to buy only union-made coffins.

Wendell L. Willkie, whose candidacy for President last year was bitterly opposed by the American Labor party, will speak at the rally arranged by it in Madison Square Garden next Tuesday for Mayor La Guardia's re-election.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Seattle, with a gain of 48 per cent, and Phoenix, Ariz., with 45 per cent, showed the largest September increases in department store sales as compared with September, 1940, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board.

Stimulated by news from Washington that the House Agricultural Committee had voted favorably on a recommendation for loans of 100 per cent of parity on the 1942 and 1943 cotton crops and four other basic farm commodities, the cotton market rose sharply in the late trading yesterday and closed near, the high marks for the day.

LONDON, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- Every Russian soldier, every man, woman and child of the civil population, and all military and industrial equipment were slipped out of the Black Sea port of Odessa under the noses of besieging Rumanian and German armies in one of history's greatest evacuations, an official Soviet dispatch claimed today.

Four officers, Major Henri A. Luebbermann, Captains Frank S. Henry, Martin W. Frame and Franklin S. Wing, have been selected for the United States Army horse show team to compete in the National Horse Show's nightly international military jumping tests at Madison Square Garden, Nov. 5-12, it was announced by Secretary John S. Wise yesterday.

The week of Nov. 10 will bring Cornelia Otis Skinner to Broadway n the Somerset Maugham-Guy Bolton dramatization of Mr. Maugham's novel, "Theatre." Although it could not be confirmed locally because of John Golden's absence in Chicago, it was learned that Mr. Golden had Expressed a wish to install "Theatre" into the Hudson if it is available.

S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, has been elected treasurer of the Metropolitan Opera Association, Inc., by the board of directors of which he is a member. Frank Garlichs, who was the treasurer, has retired after completing forty-three years "of faithful and distinguished service to the Metropolitan as assistant and treasurer."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 23 -- Howard Hawks has been signed to direct the screen biography of the late Lou Gehrig, Samuel Goldwyn, the producer, announced today. The picture is scheduled to get under way in January, and will continue the acting-directing combination of Gary Cooper and Hawks who worked together in "Sergeant York" at Warners and the recently completed "Ball of Fire" at Goldwyn's.

City employes who are in debt may refinance their obligations advantageously under a new plan announced jointly yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick and Patrick W. Harnedy, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- F.E. Gimlett, 76-year-old "sour-dough," known as "the hermit" of Arbor Villa, Colo., because he was the last of 3,000 citizens of the little ghost town 250 miles south-west of Denver, appeared today before the House Banking Committee as the last witness on the price control bill.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- After receiving a letter from Secretary Jones calling for a "comprehensive" but flexible price control law, the House Banking Committee ended today its public hearings on price legislation.

The large public demand for invitations to the NEC Symphony Orchestra radio concerts Leopold Stokowski will conduct next month has caused the adoption of a paid-admission policy, temporarily suspending the custom of a guest audience for the broadcasts, it was announced yesterday by Niles Trammell, president of the National Broadcasting Company.
