POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 23 -- One of the Hill School's most promising football elevens in recent years is primed to down Lawrenceville on Saturday and become a historymaking squad in the bargain. The Blue and Gray has never taken three straight games during this ivy-tinged gridiron series, but indications are that this objective will be attained within forty-eight hours.

Today's events Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Verdi's "Macbeth," premiere of the New Opera Company's third production, Forty-fourth Street Theatre, 8 P. M.; Marisa Regules, piano, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Adele Vosari, soprano, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30 P. M.;

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 24 -- The Cabinet has decided to convoke the Diet in a five-day extraordinary session Nov. 15 to approve additional expenditures, increased taxation and stimulation of rice production.

FREETOWN. Sierra Leone, Oct. 23 -- A submarine, attacking without warning on Sunday morning, sank the United States Line's Lehigh, which was flying the American flag at the time, seventy-five miles west of this West African port, Captain Vincent P. Arkins of Montrose, N.Y., said tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Oct. 24 -- Russian forces, after twenty-four hours of fierce fighting and despite heavy losses, are still holding off the worst of the German onslaughts on a line sixty to sixty-five miles west and south-west of Moscow.

Application of "assembly-line" technique to office operations because of the special demands of tha defense situation tends to impair efficiency and reduce output, Henry E. Niles, superintendent of agencies for the Baltimore Life Insurance Company, declared yesterday at the final session of the two-day conference of the office management division, American Management Association, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A traveling scholarship to "further the good neighbor policy existing between the United States and the Dominican Republic" has been established at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism by Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo, former President of the Dominican Republic, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon by Dean Carl W. Ackerman.

The Duke of Windsor, who spent a brief moment yesterday "running the universe" at the Hayden Planetarium, will leave La Guardia Field at 9 o'clock this morning for Hartford, Conn., where he will inspect the Hamilton Standard Propeller and Pratt Whitney Engine divisions of the United Aircraft Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 22:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Representatives of more than forty youth organizations were told by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt at a conference today that the largest contribution they could make to civilian defense activities would be insistence on increased recreational facilities in the average community, particularly in the larger defense centers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Responsibility for administering the new Federal restrictions on nonessential private and public building was turned over to Leon Henderson and his Division of Civilian Supply today by the Office of Production Management.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 -- American industry, especially the shipping industry, was warned today by Captain Howard L. Vickery of the Maritime Commission that it could not afford "the luxury of daydreaming," for, he said, "ships are soldiers, and if we cannot win with the ships we may possibly have to send the soldiers themselves."

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 23 -- Princeton's football squad, thirty-one strong, boarded an eleven-car special train tonight for the Tigers' first gridiron excursion into the deep South. The destination is Nashville, Tenn., where Princeton will meet Vanderbilt on Saturday.

While solemn-faced school children followed in his wake, a beaming Mayor La Guardia dropped three pennies into a huge flask yesterday to start the collection of the defense tax in the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 23 -- A determined, hard-hitting football team from the University of South Carolina swarmed ll over the heavily favored Clemson Tigers for almost three quarters today, then fought off a desperate final-period drive to score a sensational upset before 22,000 spectators.

The vital function of voluntary hospitals in peace and in war was stressed yesterday by Dr. Phillip D. Wilson, chief surgeon at the Hospital for the Ruptured and Crippled here, and who also organized the American Hospital in England last year, in addressing the first report meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of the Manhattan women's division of the United Hospital Campaign.

The National Maritime Union, headed by Joseph Curran, national vice president of the C.I.O. and president of the New York C.I.O. council, found itself under C.I.O. fire yesterday for using A.F. of L. labor in renovating its new headquarters at 346 West Seventeenth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A three-way tie for the lead in the 1941 world pocket billiard championship tournament still existed tonight after completion of the fourth day of play and seventeen matches in the round-robin at Town Hall.

The report that Rumania has denounced the Vienna award which ceded part of Transylvania to Hungary sounds authentic because it is a perfect example of Hitler's methods in dealing with his satellites. First he bludgeons Rumania into complete subjection by carving up her territory and giving a choice slice to Hungary, thus by one stroke putting both countries under his power.
The clash with Texas Christian University on the Polo Grounds gridiron tomorrow not only marks the mid-point in Fordham's eight-game campaign but shapes up as the Rams' crucial test of the year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Miscellaneous supply contracts totaling $45,723,946.60 were awarded today by the War Department. Awards, not previously published, to companies in the New York area were as follows:

SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- A welders' strike spread from the Seattle shipyards to Tacoma today, with five others from Alabama to California threatened by union leaders sponsoring the weldera' side of a jurisdictional dispute within the American Federation of Labor.

Ninety high school students from nine Bronx secondary schools held a forum yesterday in the Howard Taft High School of the Bronx in which the issues of the present Mayoralty campaign were discussed. An informal tabulation showed Mayor La Guardia the choice of the students.

DETROIT, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Members of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee (C.I.O.) voted at a mass meeting tonight to end a strike at the Great Lakes Steel Corporation and return to work immediately.

Punic Time-Table Herr Rauschning's views of the Nazi plans of world dominion are on the whole reassuring for the democracies. He says that the Nazi ideologists think of the job of world conquest as requiring three wars, by analogy with the three Punic Wars in which Rome disposed of Carthage.

Trading in fresh pork cuts was fairly active yesterday. Demand for lamb was fair and for veal and calf slow. The lamb market was steady to slightly higher, veal and calf lower, steer cuts steady to lower, other classes mostly unchanged. Thursday being an off-kosher day there was not enough early business to test the markets.

EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 24 -- Flame gushed from electric furnaces, 2,000-horsepower motors roared in test cells and laden tractors rumbled right by the Duke of Windsor here today as the former King of England for the first time saw the American defense program in action.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- Willie Mosconi, the defending champion from Philadelphia, won nil fourth straight match in the work pocket billiard tourney tonight beating Arthur Cranfield of Syracuse, 125 to 93, in 12 innings.

For the first time in its twentythree-year history the Yiddish Art Theatre has suspended its activities, it became known yesterday. The reason for its decision was not disclosed at the offices of the organization, although it was admitted by a spokesman that "war conditions" might have been one of the contributing causes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 24 -- "The Oxbow Incident," a novel by Walter Van Tilburg Clark published last year, will be brought to the screen by Harold Hurley as the first of eight pictures he has contracted to deliver to United Artists at the rate of two a year for four years.

Trade reports this week were again rather mixed, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The unevenness has become somewhat more pronounced, as the persistent lull in seasonal goods lines affects sentiment in primary markets.

HAMILTON FIELD, Calif., Oct. 24 -- A twin-motored Army bomber headed for its home base at Fort Douglas, Utah, by way of Sacramento, crashed in flames during a heavy fog today on the higher of the twin sisters peaks in Suisun Valley, killing the five occupants.

All conjectures and wishful thinking to the contrary, the American Government can harbor few illusions that at this stage of the conflict Italy can either be knocked out militarily or induced to seek a separate peace. Whatever the sentiments of the people, getting out by either route entails consequences too grim to be faced so long as the Germans command force enough to hold the Continent.

BUFFALO, Oct. 24 -- Britain's fight to maintain freedom in the world should inspire a double effort in this country where democcracy came into being, David C. Adie, commissioner of the State Department of Social Welfare, told the closing session today of the State Conference on Sociay Work.

The muddled gasoline situation, thought to have been clarified by the lifting of all rationing restrictions and curfews, ran into a new snag yesterday as filling station operators moved to retain the curfew and their union employes threatened to strike if they did.

Secretary of State Michael F. Walsh rejected yesterday in Albany the City Fusion party designating petitions offered in behalf of Frank C. Moore by the Republican State Committee. Mr. Moore is the Republican candidate for State Controller, and the State committee immediately took the matter into the courts, arguing the case before Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan yesterday afternoon.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct. 24 -- The new interdenominational chapel at Camp Upton, built at a cost of $20,000 and designed to seat 400 persons, will be opened and dedicated on Nov. 2, Lieut. Col. H.C. Brenizer, commanding officer, said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- A structure of price control covering Harris tweed cloth from the time it left the mills abroad until its ultimate sale in garment form to consumers here has been erected by five producers in Scotland and their agents in the United States, the Federal Trade Commission charged in a complaint issued here today.

An offering on Wednesday of $10,230,000 of refunding bonds by Asbury Park, N.J., will make up about two-thirds of the new State and municipal issues scheduled for sale next week. In all, forty-seven municipalities will be in the field with issues amounting to $15,174,422.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Irked at being called "amiable amateurs" by Westchested County Supervisors, 200 members of the Westchester Federation of Women adopted today at their Autumn meeting a report from their government committee that reaffirmed the federation's demand for abolition of the Board of Supervisors and asked for a reformation of the County Republican Committee through federation-member infiltration.

Trading yesterday in locally dressed meats was somewhat uneven; veal and calf was slow; pork cuts active and other classes fair to good. Prices on steer hinds and ribs were mostly 50 cents lower; veal and calf hind-saddles weak; fresh pork cuts were steady to $1 higher; and other classes steady. The kosher beef market opened weak; veal and calf foresaddles barely steady to weak; and lamb foresaddles stronger on better grades.

Many persons probably still believe that the way to make a man ferocious is to feed him on raw meat. They would accordingly recommend, if asked, that if we want a ferocious army its diet should rest on a solid basis of slightly warmed beefsteak. They would be wrong on both counts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Some concern is being expressed privately in Congressional circles over the apparently dimming prospects of realizing President Roosevelt's aim for adequate price-control legislation to halt inflationary trends.

An explosion of "pyroforic powder yesterday at Columbia University, the scene of a chemical blast last Monday that injured eleven persons, sent Dr. Walter Zinn, 34 years old, of 14 Linden Terrace, Leonia, N.J., to St. Luke's Hospital with second-degree burns of both hands and forearms.

The National City Bank has sold its banking offices in the Dominican Republic, consisting of the head office and five branches there, to the Government of the Dominican Republic, it was announced here yesterday. The main office is in Ciudad Trujillo, and the branches are at Barahona, La Vega, Puerto Plata, San Pedro de Macoris and Santiago de Los Caballeros.

CAMP WHEELER, Ga., Oct. 24 -- Reorganization of this Army replacement center from a two-group command into four training regiments, involving the assignment of many officers and the increase of non-commissioned officer personnel by nearly 100 men, has been announced by Colonel A.R. Emery, camp commander.

Protection of the family from possible domination by the State and equal rights for women were stressed yesterday in principles formulated by the National Council of Women for a "post-war world in which women want to live." Points embodied in a resolution adopted during closing sessions of the twenty-seventh biennial meeting of the Council at the Hotel Park Central, were urged for consideration by peace-making bodies after the war.

BENDIX, N.J., Oct. 24 -- A thousand pickets of the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers of America continued today to patrol all entrances to the plant of Air Associates, Inc., and to overflow into neighboring Hasbrouck Heights to such an extent that town authorities warned of legal action to stop "trespassing."

The Borden Company and Sheffield Farms, the two major milk distributing agencies in the city, yesterday announced an increase in the price of milk of one-half cent a quart. It brought the price for delivered quarts to 17 cents, the highest in twenty years and exceeded only by the 18-cent-a-quart price reached at two different periods in 1919 and 1920.

However their parents may vote in the current municipal election, groups of students of Manhattan and Staten Island left little doubt yesterday as to their own preference for the re-election of Mayor La Guardia. They voiced their approval of the present city administration, and indicated that four more years of the same brand would be highly desirable.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, charged last night that hundreds of property owners were losing their homes in the five boroughs because of the "over-assessment evil" practiced by the city administration.

A fine fruit compote -- such as appears in a crystal bowl on the top shelf of the pastry wagon that inevitably is trundled up at the end of the meal in your favorite French restaurant -- may be bought for 25c in a certain city store.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis announced today approval of the Dodgers' division of their world series shares, in which only twenty players received full cuts of $4,829.40.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 (AP) -- After spending a night in a cell, George Butcher Jr., a 21-year-old Yale junior, registered "under protest" for the draft today, asserting that he was convinced that he would be "of more use both to myself and others by being outside of jail for a while."

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- A 26-year-old flight lieutenant of the Fleet Air Arm who is serving aboard one of the British Navy's new catapult ships had just told of the first time he had to bail out over the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced that the Illinois Commercial Telephone Company of Madison, Wis., had filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933, covering $5,750,000 of 3% per cent firstmortgage bonds, due Oct. 1, 1971; 24,000 shares of $5 cumulative preferred stock, no par value, and subscription receipts for the preferred stock.

Labor disturbances in this country probably have received "exaggerated emphasis" as a hindrance to the war effort, Sir Frederick Leggett, Chief Industrial Commissioner of the Ministry of Labor and National Service of Great Britain, told a press conference here yesterday afternoon.

Citrus County, Fla. Welsh, Davis Co. of Chicago yesterday received the award of an issue of $464,000 of refunding bonds, bearing a fixed rate of interest of 4 per cent, of Citrus County, Fla., on a bid of 107.266. The bonds, dated Nov. 1, 1940, will mature serially on Nov. 1, 1942 to 1957.

Sixty debutantes of the new season, each with two escorts, revivified the fashionable dance steps of yesteryear for one hour last night at a Diamond Ball and Debutante Cotillion given in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as the annual ball in aid of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.

In case of war, 20,200 registered nurses in New York State would be ready to serve in the armed forces of this country, it was announced yesterday. The figure was included in a report delivered by Miss Caroline Falls, director of the defense program of the New York State Nurses Association, to a general session of the association's five-day biennial convention, which closed last night in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 24 -- With the return of the 122d Coast Artillery from Fort Totten on Monday, Fort Du Pont is returning to its normal appearance before the general exodus preceding the air defense manoeuvres.

Invincible during a major portion of the fray, Manhattan College's football forces upset previously unbeaten Villanova, 9 to 6, before 15,000 fans at the Polo Grounds last night for their first victory over the Wildcats in forty years.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 24 -- The next to the last one-day tournament on the schedule of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association brought out a large field of 70 players today and Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches took low gross honors with her card of 40, 38 -- 78 over the Morris County course.

An expansion move has been made by the Western Electric Company in the leasing of the Margon plant on Avenue A, between West Thirty-first and Thirty-second Streets, Bayonne, N.J., for a branch. The property comprises 235,000 square feet of land, part of which fronts on Newark Bay, and is improved principally with onestory buildings.

Continuing its report on candidates for the City Council, the Citizens Union endorsed yesterday four candidates in the Bronx -- Lowell H. Brown, Republican and City Fusion, and Gertrude W. Klein, Councilman Salvatore Ninfo and Charles Rubinstein, American Labor -- and one in Queens, Charles Belous, City Fusion.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- Yale and Dartmouth, bitter football rivals, will meet tomorrow before a crowd that is expected to nearly fill the Bowl. The teams will celebrate a quarter of a century of competition on the gridiron. In the series Yale has won sixteen, Dartmouth four, and four games were tied.

Commenting on Mr. Willkie's proposal for a clear-cut and complete repeal of the Neutrality Act, the chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations expresses the opinion that there are certain provisions of that legislation which ought to be preserved. He mentions, among other things, that part of the law which establishes a Munitions Control Board to license the export of war materials.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Charles A. Lindbergh raised an issue which has provoked wide discussion when he named recently the groups which, in his opinion, are most active in trying to get the country into war. He declared that they were the Roosevelt Administration, the Jews and the British.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Roosevelt asked John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, C.I.O., today to prevent the strike of 53,000 workers in the captive coal mines threatened for tomorrow midnight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- William S. Knudsen, OPM Director General, asked the Defense Plant Corporation today to provide funds for the construction of a 500,000-ton steel plate mill and a plant capable of turning out 30,000 tons of steel casting at Pittsburgh, Calif.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Governor Walter W. Bacon of Delaware expressed pride in the achievements of the 198th C.A.C. Anti-Aircraft Regiment, "first regiment in the first State," on a visit to Fort Ontario, present station of the former Delaware National Guard command.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Following a high-class exhibition of spaniel work both on land and in the water, the brown cocker spaniel Field Trial Champion dinar's Ring, owned and handled by Harry I. Caesar of New York City, today was awarded first place in the open all-age stake for that breed.

Vegetable seeds for the use of the Queen of England and residents of her estate at Sandringham were prepared for shipment yesterday with the endorsement of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as a sponsor for the organization known as American Seeds for British Soil.

A revised program of design protection has been prepared by the Fashion Originators Guild of America to be put into effect after receiving the approval of the interested Federal agencies and of representative retailers, it was announced yesterday by Albert M. Post, executive director of the organization.

The first widespread, and apparently organized, price-cutting on popular brands of liquor since September of last year was reported yesterday by retailers. Generally, the reductions were confined to two products of the so-called Seagram's group, Carstairs and Calvert rye whiskey.

Word was received yesterday by Senorita Graciela Mandujano, Chilean Department of Agriculture official, that she had been appointed technical adviser to the Chilean delegation to the International Labor Office conference, scheduled to open here next Monday.

FORT JACKSON, S.C., Oct. 24 -- At Fort Jackson, the nation's sixth largest Army post, more than 3,000 permanent buildings are spread out over the Carolina hills, providing housing and facilities for the 42,000 soldiers stationed here.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Evidence of the increasing production of trained airmen in the far-flung schools of the Empire Air Training Scheme, which includes elementary and advanced schools in the United States, was offered here today when King George and Queen Elizabeth inspected many hundreds of the latest arrivals, including detachments of Americans.

There once was a fat, middle-aged colonel who was trying to lose weight. And 300 housewives from the metropolitan area were willing to help him to the extent that they prepared an emergency dinner menu for seven unexpected guests and took into account the officer's obesity.

The second four volumes of the monumental Public Papers and Addresses of President Roosevelt, the first five of which were published in 1938 by Random House, wall be published Nov. 25 by the Macmillan Company, it was learned yesterday.

John C. Cudahy, former Ambassador to Belgium, did not have his tongue In his cheek when he told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the United States should offer to serve as mediator between the Axis and the Allied Powers. But for any one still to believe that a negotiated peace is possible in the present stage of the war implies a degree of naivete surprising in a former diplomat.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- In the brief space of 116 seconds, Arthur H. Starnes, 43 years old, veteran Calumet City parachutist, today made the longest free fall ever survived by man. He stepped from an airliner at a height of 30,800 feet above the ground and dropped for 29,300 feet, or five and a half miles, before ripping open two parachutes and floating safely to earth.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 24 -- The quiet, orderly tenor of this bucolic university community, known in its original state as Ann's Arbor, will give way tomorrow to the rhapsodic excitement of 85,753 ticket holders converging here by plane, railroad and automobile for the football game of the season to date.

Sholem Bernstein, a shifty-eyed underling in the notorious Brooklyn murder syndicate, who fled West when his death was ordered for balking at a killing assignment, testified yesterday in dramatic detail and with obvious enjoyment against his former underworld bosses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A Miami, Fla., lawyer declared today that the Florida East Coast Railway had become unpopular with residents of the peninsula because in recent years it had been under inefficient New York management.
LONDON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 24 -- New York University and Holy Cross, whose respective elevens suffered a pushing-around the last two week-ends, went through final tune-ups today, each hopeful of doing some pushing on its own account when the two clash on Fitton Field tomorrow.

The report of apartment leasing yesterday reflected a diminution in the volume which has been current for some weeks past. The rentals listed covered quarters in buildings on both East and West sides of the city, with the distribution about equal between the two.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Molding the Fourth Armored Division into a combat unit is being carried on daily under direction of Maj. Gen. Henry W. Baird.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 23:

BATHURST, Gambia, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- The remaining twenty-two survivors of the United States freighter Lehigh, torpedoed Sunday seventy-five miles off Freetown, have been landed here and some said today that "when we have guns it will be better for us and not so good for Jerry."
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued the following today:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Exporters, importers and insurance companies today won an extension until Nov. 29 for the filing of forms TFR-300 listing foreign trade transactions or operations, in an order issued by the Treasury Department.

VICHY, France, Oct. 24 -- After appeals by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, and Admiral Francois Darlan, Vice Premier, and pressing representations made to the German authorities, a respite of a few days was granted today for 100 hostages held for execution in reprisal for the deaths of two German officers in Nantes and Bordeaux.

Relegation of any new tax legislation to a later date on the Congressional program, coupled with some encouraging domestic industrial news, brought out fresh buying yesterday in the stock market. Best additions to values were registered in the initial hour, and as activity diminished during the remainder of the session some weak spots appeared, with a resultant shading of gains.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 24 -- The Buenos Aires-Rio de Janeiro link of the Italian Lati line, the Axis air connection between this continent and Europe, appeared today destined to early extinction, in view of a notice served on Lati by Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales, the Argentine Government Oilfields concern, that in the future it would be unable to deliver aviation gasoline to the line.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I went to the Yankee Stadium last Sunday to see Harmon and Kimbrough play for the New York Americans. I don't intend to visit the stadium again until next April, when the Yankees open the baseball season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson and William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management, announced tonight acceptance by Air Associates, Inc., at Bendix, N.J., of recommendations by the National Defense Mediation Board.

Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Wintrab gave a dinner last night in the Casino-on-the-Park of Essex House for Archduke Otto of Austria and his sister, the Archduchess Adelaide. Among the other guests were Dr. Frank P. Corrigan, United States Ambassador to Venezuela, and Mrs. Corrigan; Dr. Robert S. Chamberlain and Mrs. Herman Chamberlain of Washington, Miss Georgia Stamm, Count Henry Degenfeld and Robert, Edward and Kerwin Corrigan.

The Ardsley and the Dainger field Handicaps, the latter having its first running as a memorial to Algernon Daingerfield, the Jockey Club's secretary for a generation will be the features today at Empire City, where a crowd of 25,000 Is expected to see the seven-race program.

MONTREAL, Oct. 24 -- The City of Montreal debenture holders committee has drawn up a refunding plan for submission to the City Council which it says will bring "restoration of a sound current position through speedy liquidation of floating indebtedness."

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The British destroyer Broadwater, formerly the U.S.S. Mason, was torpedoed and sunk in the North Atlantic twenty-four hours after attacking and "probably destroying" a German U-boat, the Admiralty announced today.

"At last it was done, and he was free of his lifelong bondage to the sea." This is the opening sentence of William McFee's new novel, due from Random House Nov. 5, and the character referred to is Chief Engineer Spenlove who has appeared in many of the author's novels as the narrator of other people's adventures.

The enthusiasm brought about in cotton circles on Thursday by the House Agricultural Committee's recommendation for 100 per cent parity loans for basic farm commodities carried over into the first hour of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday to lift prices of active futures to gains of 20 to 23 points.

VICHY, France, Oct. 24 -- French Somaliland is being attacked by British and Free French forces, according to an announcement here this evening. The action began yesterday when two light columns aggregating about 300 men occupied Daszneito, some twenty miles northwest of Tajura.

Thomas Wilfred opened his ninth Clavilux season with a recital of Lumia (color organ) compositions last evening in the Arts Institute of Light, Grand Central Palace. Recitals are given there each Friday night at 8:30.
FORT DIX, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Major Daniel Debrier, Forty-fourth Division rear detachment commander, began making preparations today for the arrival of replacements for men released from the division.

ONCE upon a time a Mr. Smithers, who had just been testifying as an eyewitness to a terrific railroad accident, was asked by a covey of reporters to say precisely what had passed through his mind at the time of the catastrophe.

Two films, arriving in Broadway houses today, will round out the week's new offerings. The newcomer at the Rialto will be "Never Give a Sucker an Even Break," a Universal comedy starring W.C. Fields. The supporting cast includes Leon Errol, Gloria Jean, Franklin Pangborn, Butch and Buddy and Mona Barrie. . . .

In 152 years the Senate has sat twelve times as a court of impeachment on charges brought by the House. In nine of these cases the charges were brought against a Federal judge. Four Federal judges have been removed by this method. Several have escaped trial by resignation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Growing shortages of paper and waste paper brought two governmental agencies into action today to insure equitable distribution of domestic supplies. By an order from Milo Perkins, head of Export Control, that Division of the Economic Defense Board clamped a rigid control over exports of many different paper products.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Oct. 24 -- With the present drive toward Moscow apparently checkmated along a fluctuating front varying in distance between sixty and 100 miles from the capital, the Germans staged a heavy air raid on the city last night, presumably in an effort to disrupt its communications and batter down-popular morale.

Giuseppe Verdi's opera, Macbeth," was produced fay the New Opera Company in the Fortyfourth Street Theatre last night, ninety-one years after this Shakespearean music-drama, which Verdi himself called a "melodramma," was first seen on an American stage at Niblo's Garden, this city.

Brilliance, life and vigor marked the playing of Marisa Regules, youthful pianist from Buenos Aires, who made her New York debut last night in Town Hall under the patronage of the Argentine Ambassador to the United States. In an extremely exacting program Miss Regules aroused the enthusiasm of her large audience by the virtuosity of her performances, which exhibited an inborn gift for the keyboard.

The Soviet freighter Petrovski, the first ship flying that flag that will carry American aid to Russia from this port, was loading yesterday at Pier 8, foot of Pineapple Street, Brooklyn, and will depart next week. Captain Fedot Vlasov, master of the ship, in a talk on board his vessel yesterday, said that the Russian people were united and would do everything to achieve victory over the invading Nazis.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 24 -- Bulgarian courts-martial are working overtime, foreign circles learned today, and evidence of several recent executions has been uncovered. The former police chief of Varna, Anton Prudkin, and an accomplice have been put to death for "sabotage and conspiracy."

Dr. Vannevar Bush, president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington and director of the Office of Scientific Research and Development, created to mobilize America's scientific brain-power in the national defense, cold a large gathering of scientists yesterday that a United States scientific team of 2,000 trained minds working as one was transforming "ideas into copper and iron" three times faster than is the case under peace-time conditions.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Buying of wheat was of fairly broad proportions in the early trading on the Board of Trade today. The markets reflected the bullish sentiment placed on developments in Congress, especially the move to establish loan levels at 108 per cent of parity for the next two years -- 1942-43.

ROME, Oct. 24 -- A summary of a speech made by Cardinal Suhard, Archbishop of Paris, was printed on the front page of today's Osservatore Romano. Cardinal Suhard, according to the official Vatican City newspaper, spoke at a meeting of the French clergy, to whom he gave "some directives."

Investment Market After the dullest period in more than two years in the field of offerings of new securities, interest in investment circles will center on Monday on the scheduled sale by competitive bidding of $38,000,000 of Central Illinois Public Service Company bonds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The situation in the Far East is "extremely strained" because Japan shows no intention of abandoning her expansion policy and because a "clash" would eliminate Vladivostok as a port of entry for military aid to Russia, Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, told a group of naval ordnance manufacturers here today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 -- A powerful Navy eleven, rated one of the three top teams of the country, meets Harvard in the Stadium tomorrow afternoon at 2 o'clock before a crowd estimated at 40,000.

SAPULPA, Okla., Oct. 24 -- An oil fortune which flowed from the rocky, 160-acre land allotment of an illiterate Creek Indian woman was awarded today to an elderly Claremore widow and two Negro packing plant workers of Kansas City.

Tomorrow will be celebrated as Girl Scout Sunday in city houses of worship by Christians and Jews. Special services will be held and there will be three major services, one each for Roman Catholics, Protestants and Jews, during the day. Girl Scouts and their leaders will attend from all boroughs.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Oct. 24 -- An amateur short-wave radio station, to reach parents or friends back home has been set up by one of the selectees in the Field Artillery Replacement Center at Fort Bragg.

There was a six-year period, a movie executive testified yesterday, when. George E. Browne held such power that he might have destroyed the motion picture industry. The witness, called by defense counsel at the Federal court trial of Browne, president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, and William Bioff, his agent, was Patrick J. Casey, chairman of the film producers' committee on Hollywood's basic labor agreement.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 24 -- When two days ago Swedish newspaper men asked a Berlin Foreign Office spokesman about the attitude of Germany toward the expulsion of Germans from Afghanistan, he retorted:

A two-year wage and working agreement between the strong National Maritime Union and the American Merchant Marine Institute, headed by Frank J. Taylor, was accepted at the institute's offices late Thursday night and made public yesterday.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., Oct. 24 -- "The Pride of Devens" is the name of a march written by Malcolm F. Willoughby of Watertown, Mass., especially for the 366th Infantry, Negro, which will be played for the first time tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Oct. 18 totaled 243,605,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented an increase of 34,000 barrels in the week, comprising an increase of 551,000 barrels in stocks of domestic oil and a decrease of 517,000 barrels in stocks of foreign oil.

CAMP DAVIS, N.C., Oct. 24 -- The entire Fifty-fourth Coast Artillery Regiment, about 1,800 men, is now at Fort Fisher, having completed its movement from Camp Davis to the firing center this week. Preparations are being made for one of the most important target workouts along the coast line of the Carolinas this year.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Oct. 23 (Delayed) -- The main German thrust toward Moscow through the Mozhaisk salient, west of the city, has been stopped dead, it was officially announced this afternoon as the Red Army continued to hold firm in all other salients about the capital from south to north.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- An augmented program at the Fort Slocum Y.M.C.A. will include camera, radio and dramatic clubs, dances every other Saturday afternoon, a basketball team of former college players now in the Army and a musical comedy written and acted by soldiers.

AMSTERDAM, (Via Berlin), Oct. 24 -- Prices on the Bourse opened strong today but the close was at net losses of 5 points. Royal Dutch was 2 3/4 points lower at 311 1/2 after touching 319. Amsterdam Trading lost 5 at 479; Amsterdam Rubber 4 3/8 at 304 and Philips 3 3/4 at 267 1/2.

Increased La Guardia strength in Queens was reported yesterday by Queens Republican leaders, who, because of the antipathy to the Mayor among organization members in that county, have refrained so far from taking a definite stand on the Mayor's candidacy.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Ira Clifton Copley will give a dinner this evening in the Persian Room of the Plaza.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Oct. 23 (Delayed) -- Several sections of the Soviet Government and some of the national commissariats have been transferred from Moscow to Kuibyshev, it was officially announced this afternoon, although spokesmen emphasized that this city can not be considered even a temporary capital and that Moscow's status should not be thought of as changed.

To THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES : Tour financial section of Oct. 5 contained a highly interesting discussion, by D. Stewart Iglehart and others of the W.R. Grace organization, of the trade relations of Latin America with the United States and the necessity of providing Latin America with gold backing for its currencies.

Mayor La Guardia's alleged relations with Communists again came under fire last night. Louis Waldman, chairman of the Labor and Progressive Committee for the Democratic candidates, dared the Mayor to make public the report on an investigation of "Red" influence in the Welfare Department.
COMMERCE, Okla., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Dr. James Porter Fiske of Los Angeles, orthopedic surgeon, was killed today in a three-car collision four miles east of here.

Representing a cost of almost $100,000, "Viva O'Brien!" will end a storm-tossed career tonight at the Majestic Theatre. The announcement was made yesterday by Glendon Allvine, spokesman for the management. The expensive production will have had only twenty New York performances from Oct. 9; a Boston tryout of a week and a half preceded its debut here.

WEST POINT, N.T., Oct. 24 -- Army and Columbia are all set for their football battle in Michie Stadium tomorrow. The cadets held a light workout on the Plains gridiron today and is in the pink of condition for the game.
Announcement of honors conferred on Roman Catholic clergymen of the Archdiocese of New York by Pope Pius XII was made yesterday by Archbishop Francis J.Spellman, as follows:

The new investment market came the closer this week to a complete standstill than at any time since the crisis leading up to the outbreak of the European war in September, 1939. At that time no new bond issues were placed on the market for three consecutive weeks.

TOKYO, Oct. 24 -- The decision of the Tojo Cabinet to petition Emperor Hirohito for the convocation of an extraordinary session of the Diet beginning Nov. 15 took the country by surprise and caused many to speculate regarding its significance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Roosevelt stated today that Congress would be requested soon to provide funds to double the tank-building program. Experience in Europe and Africa, he said, demonstrated that this country needs more of these weapons.
President Roosevelt gave his unqualified support to Mayor La Guardia on the basis of good government. Tammany leaders were bitter at the action, but Edward J. Flynn said he would keep his party post.

Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius W. Dresselhuys gave a dinner last evening at the Plaza, later taking their guests to the premiere of Verdi's opera "Macbeth," presented by the New Opera Company at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre. Guests at the dinner included Lady Louis Mountbatten, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hoving, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Keresey, Mr. and Mrs. James I. Bush, Mrs. Ormond Lawson-Johnston, Baron Von Zuylen and Conde Nast.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 (AP) -- German troops hammered closer to Moscow tonight across a maze of snow-covered land mines and village street barricades and drove into the rich industrial Donets basin in the south as Russian losses spiraled into "numerous millions," German dispatches said.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 24 -- The assertion that the eleven-year-old regime of President Getulio Vargas had doubled Brazil's economic wealth and unified the nation was made tonight in reply to critics of the government by Dr. Arthur de Souza Costa, Minister of Finance, on the anniversary of the Vargas revolution of 1930.

Football and Mr. Alumnus Football has its natural season. In soggy In soggy Spring or torrid Summer or icy Winter it would be mistimed. It is proper and seemly and best in Autumn. And does it not have a season likewise in the life of man? John Q. Alumnus, who is getting along in years, wonders about that as cheers from the distant stadium reach his ears these October Saturdays.

A MHERST vs. Wesleyan -- A is for Amherst and also for Aardvark, an odd-looking animal found in Africa and cross-word puzzles. The Aardvark eats termites without cooking them first. A vague vote for Amherst.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The movement for outright repeal of all important restrictive provisions of the Neutrality Act, as precipitated by a combination of "Willkie Republicans" and New Deal Democrats, will receive its first test tomorrow when the Senate Foreign Relations Committee passes on the House-approved resolution to remove the ban against arming American merchant ships.

The importance of weather conditions to good hunting was never more clearly emphasized for us than it was this week at Nickerson's' Pheasant Preserve, in Redding, Conn., for it was one of those days when pheasants simply refused to stop running and dogs simply couldn't trail them.

Taking the full glare of the local spotlight for the first time this season, Fordham's football team moves into action at the Polo Grounds this afternoon against Texas Christian University. The kick-off is scheduled for 2 o'clock. With all other major New York teams out of town, one of the biggest crowds of the local season is likely to be on hand.

The Acoustical Society of America, a national organization of scientists engaged in the study of sound, heard a new synthetic streamlined barber shop quartet last night, in which one man, by merely moving his lips in utter silence, produced a combination of voices, ranging octaves above and below any human voice, all singing in a harmony that only years of training could produce.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- George Hill, secretary of Representative Fish of New York, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of giving perjured testimony in connection with the inquiry into the activities of Nazi agents in the United States, including George Sylvester Viereck.

Mayor La Guardia charged yesterday that the Democratic organization in the city was conducting 'the most disgusting and repulsive campaign" on racial issues in a 'desperate' last-minute attempt to gain votes.

The pamphlet report of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and wholly owned subsidiaries, issued for publication today, reveals that net sales and other operating revenues amounted to $130,633,618 for the three months ended on Sept. 30, compared with $91,797,317 for the September quarter of 1940, while the total for the first nine months was $365,694,774 against $254,815,899 for the corresponding period last year.

Eighty-four students in the evening division of the New York University College of Engineering will mark the completion of their bachelor degree requirements with class day exercises at 8:30 P.M. tonight in the auditorium of Gould Memorial Library on the University Heights campus, 181st Street and University Avenue, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- The Coast Guard has received complete control over American harbors as a safeguard against marine sabotage.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times : It seems to me that colleges are going to ridiculous extremes in drawing up their football schedules so far in advance. A college never knows how good a team it will have a couple of years in the future and certainly it knows less about its opponents.

The unqualified endorsement of Mayor La Guardia by President Roosevelt is an event reflecting great credit upon both men. For the Mayor it is the most striking tribute yet paid to the high character of his administration. For the President it was an act of political courage and independence.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Oct. 24 -- Following a three-day training manoeuvre which covered 350 miles of Georgia terrain the Fourth Motorized Division combined activities with the Second Armored Division in a tactical exercise on the reservation.
Corporation profits have unquestionably passed their peak for the duration of the war, according to the quarterly industrial review of Spencer Trask Co., a New York Stock Exchange firm.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- Little concrete information was available here tonight on the progress of the German forces in Russia to supplement yesterday's claims that they were within thirty-seven miles of Moscow and were inside the city limits of Kharkov in the Donets Basin.

Removal of restrictions on the sale of gasoline in the East will probably not have much effect on advertising campaigns of the leading refiners who sell in this area, reports yesterday indicated. All of them had planned "change-over" and tune-up campaigns with the approach of cold weather, anyway, and the only possibility now is that these schedules may be a little heavier than originally planned.

This promises to be the red-letter day of the 1941 football season. A magnificent card topped by the Michigan-Minnesota game should shake down the nation's leaders into something like permanency and leave the top-ranking teams relatively undisturbed for the rest of the campaign.

Germany has brought strong pessure -- so far unsuccessful -- upon the Vichy government for the ouster of General Maxime Weygand as French Pro-Consul for Africa and his replacement by General Henri Dentz, who directed the French defense of Syria.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- German bombers raided the west coast of Britain last night and early today, bombing at least two towns, while British raiders lashed the Calais coastal area of Northwest France.

Tax Cut Retail Trade Factor Retail trade was fairly active here this week, although some merchants expressed the belief that considerable consumer buying of higher-unit items was delayed because of the forthcoming reduction on Monday of the city sales tax from 2 to 1 per cent.

The so-called California type of fair sales law was dealt a blow which may well have the practical effect of invalidating efforts to set uniform "selling costs" for retailers, by a decision by the King County Superior Court at Seattle on Thursday, according to comment yesterday among lawyers specializing in such legislation.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Mrs. Rachel M. Richardson Ominsky of 203 West Eighteenth Street, New York City, an artist best known for her ecclesiastical murals, was killed and her husband, Frank K. Ominsky, an artist, was slightly injured yesterday when their automobile skidded on Route 6 and overturned.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Richard J. Gray, president of the building construction department of the American Federation of Labor, declared today before the Senate Committee investigating defense contracts that A.F.L. members in Detroit would revolt against their leader if the P.J. Currier Company received the award of a government contract for 300 defense houses in Michigan.

The inquiry requested by Mayor La Guardia into Democratic charges that his campaign was costing $1,000,000 will get under way this morning when Frederick E. Crane, former Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, and James W. Gerard, honorary chairman of the Democratic finance committee, have their first meeting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Secretary Ickes urged today intensive activity on the part of the oil industry to increase the country's production of high octane gasoline for airplanes to at least 100,000 barrels daily by Jan. 1, 1943. The government, he said, stands ready "with definite plans to assist in the financing" of new refining plants for aviation fuel.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Oct. 25 -- All reports from the Moscow front up to an early hour today gave increasing indications that the tremendous battle for the capital had "turned the corner" -- in favor of the defenders.

The twentieth annual observance of Navy Day, the birth anniversary of Theodore Roosevelt, will begin today -- two days early -- and reach its climax Monday with parades in many cities and a broadcast address by President Roosevelt from Washington that night.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The Admiralty announced tonight that a British submarine had torpedoed an Italian armed merchant cruiser of the Citta di Genova class in the Central Mediterranean. The torpedo blew a big hole in the side of the Italian vessel, forcing her to halt, and British officials said it was "probable" the ship sank.

VICHY, France, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- Brief dispatches from Jibuti, French Somaliland, today said that British troops, believed to have been Hindus, attacked in one light column and Free French troops, chiefly Senegalese, attacked in another.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Temple's undefeated and untied football Owls smashed Bucknell, 41 to 14, for their fifth straight victory before 18,000 spectators here tonight. Fullback George Sutch ran seventy-nine yards for the first score in the opening minutes and the Owls ran up a 41-0 lead before the Bisons got their two touchdowns in the closing minutes.

Hushing across a touchdown three minutes from the end to snap a 13-all tie, Adelphi Academy downed Brooklyn Prep's football team, 19 to 13, in the sixteenth meeting between the Brooklyn rivals, at Boys High Field yesterday. Adelphi capitalized on a Blue and White fumble, recovered by Right End Harry Miller, and went forty-five yards for its winning marker.

In addition to releasing the earnings figures for the nine months period, W.S.S. Rodgers, president of the Texas Corporation, announced yesterday that the board of directors have voted to merge into the Texas Corporation its principal operating subsidiary, the Texas Company, and to change the name of the Texas Corporation to the Texas Company.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : May I call your attention to two mistakes in today's statements on the part of those representing the present administration of the city. One with the caption "Mayor Tells of Increase in Parks Since 1933," and the other, "Controller McGoldrick Calls Attention to the Three Million Dollars Saved in the Attempted Bergen Beach Steal."

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Five Army pursuit planes, their gasoline supply long exhausted, were missing tonight from a nineteen-plane formation on a flight from March Field, Calif., to McClellan Field here.

From his lexicographer's easy chair Dr. Charles Earle Funk from time to time sends to this newspaper comment upon contemporary uses and abuses of words. In a world where ruin may almost be said to be characteristic of the landscape it is no wonder that reporters seek a little variety of description.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 24 -- Thanks badges, awards made by the Girl Scout organization to persons outside the organization who have been outstanding friends of Girl Scouting, were given today to Bertram Cutler, the Rev. Edward Roberts Moore, Edgar Rickard and Lewis Gawtry, all of New York City, and Frank Phillips of Bartlesville, Okla.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- A hint that an international control program is in the making for leather and finished shoes was given the Tanners' Council of America by Major Joseph W. Byron, chief of the hides, skin and leather section of the OPM.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman will preside at the annual rally of the West Side Manhattan Holy Name Societies at 3:30 P.M. tomorrow. A parade will start at 2:30 P.M. from 116th Street and Morningside Avenue and march to Convent Avenue and to the campus of the College of the Sacred Heart, at 133d Street.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Felix V. Ferdinand Schumann, 62 years old, a house-to-house lingerie salesman and a grandson of Robert Alexander Schumann, German composer and pianist, was found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning at 8 A.M. today in his automobile, parked in a garage behind his home at 168 Delhi Road in the Greenville section of the town of Greenburgh near here.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Big John Petty trotted out on Rossade Field in the late minutes of the Iowa-Purdue football game today and booted an after-touchdown place-kick to relieve the tension of a home-coming crowd of 22,000 and give the Boilermakers a 7-to-6 decision over a fighting Iowa eleven.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 25 -- Penn State's football team drove to a 40-6 victory over Lehigh before a Dad's Day crowd of 12,000 today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Roosevelt officially set up today the new Office of Facts and Figures "for the purpose of facilitating the dissemination of factual information to the citizens of the country on the defense effort and on the defense policies and activities of the government."
MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 25 -- A smart Williams College football team, paced by slippery Gunnar Hayes, spoiled home-coming day for Tufts by sinking the Jumbos. 34 to 7, today, at Tufts Oval.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25 -- The football teams of Dartmouth and Yale both were on the comeback trail today, but only one of them arrived at the destination. That was the big Green eleven from the hills of Hanover, which, after numerous failures, pushed over a touchdown in the final period and won, 7 -- 0.

The stock market acted yesterday in the familiar pattern for a short session. It shuttled about without reaching any definite point and closed irregularly easier than on Friday. Trading was at about the usual rate for a Saturday, with transfers on the Stock Exchange reading 269,140 shares, against 296,130 in the previous week-end session.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 25 -- With Kharkov captured by the Germans and the intensity of their assault toward Rostov undiminished, foreign military quarters here tonight anticipated a new determined German offensive on all the Southern Russian front from the Sea of Azov north along the Don and Donets Rivers.

What started out to be a debate on neutrality has become a debate on whether we shall do all we can to defend the Atlantic or only a part; and whether we shall do what we do soon enough or too late. Those who propose that we do only a part, or that we put off doing it, are not arguing for peace.

Betting, attendance and speed records fell yesterday at Empire City, where 26,745 persons who wagered $1,361,090 saw Fair Call capture the $12,225 Ardsley Handicap and Piping Rock take the $5,090 Daingerfield, which had its inaugural running.

ABOARD THE FLAGSHIP OF THE MEDITERRANEAN FLEET, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Britain is destroying or damaging up to 50 per cent of all enemy convoys attempting to carry fresh supplies to the Axis armies in Libya, the Commander-in-Chief of the British Mediterranean Fleet, Admiral Sir Andrew Cunningham, declared today.

ALBANY -- The coming election day will mean much to skiers, particularly those living in New York State. The public then will be asked to vote on Amendment No. 4, the Whiteface Amendment, by which the Conservation Department receives authority "to construct and maintain not more than twenty miles of ski trails thirty to eighty feet wide on the north, east and northwest slopes of Whiteface Mountain in Essex County."

President Roosevelt declared yesterday that "the destruction of the Hitler menace" was "the real end, the inescapable end," of United States foreign policy. He asserted that the American people "are constantly becoming more determined" to bring about that purpose.

Some people have a weakness for fancy fixings in the bathroom. Even though they never take a foam bath, they like to think their bathrooms are good enough for a fancy ritual if they had a mind to go through with one. And as for the rest of us, we like to have everything neat and shiny and in its place, doing its job well.

IT was just about this time last year, when Walt Disney's "Fantasia" was popping hereabouts, that Mr. Disney quite casually let drop a most revealing remark. "Don't get the idea," said he, "that we are completely satisfied.

THE publisher was not able to refrain from comparing, only in an indirect way, to be sure. Mr. Parker's lawyers with Mr. Charles Dickens's legal lights. Readers familiar with Messrs. Dodson Fogg and "Bleak House" may feel that this book is dilute Dickens, but they should feel rewarded just the same.

WHEN he was lecturing in the West, in an old mining town called Conquista, John Erskine -- who tells this curious story as if in his own person -- was startled by the laughter of a woman in the audience at a remark which he had thought serious, even profound.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct 26 -- Flying through showers and heavy clouds over the Strait of Dover yesterday, British fighter plane squadrons punished Nazi troops and shot up airfields, trains and factories in Northern France.

The tenth anniversary of the opening of George Washington Bridge was marked yesterday with a broadcast at 7:45 A.M. from radio station WOR, in which three automobiles were stopped at random on the bridge and the drivers were informally interviewed through a microphone connected near the Manhattan towers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- From the Capitol developments of the last few days there is much to argue that Democratic leaders greatly misjudged the mood of Congress in laying the strategy for revision of the Neutrality Act of 1939.

IN view of the avowed fact that man is an animal, it is not difficult to understand his periodic lapses into barbarism: a condition unconsciously developed by the organized machinery of a national culture founded on materialism, selfishness, tribal consciousness, wealth and power, rather than on righteousness and the human need of fellowship and loyalty.

The first major market to operate under a sliding scale of ceiling prices, tied to raw material, moved cautiously last week when cotton mill executives attempted to appraise the possibilities for maximum profits. Volume probably exceeded a week's production for the first time in many months, but the offerings were still too small to test the question of whether buyers would cover heavily if offerings were plentiful.

In a dramatic setting recognizing the part women in England, China and Russia are taking in the defense of their countries, the Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries will open tomorrow for one week at Grand Central Palace.
Twenty thousand A. F. of L and C.I.O. unionists forgot their factional differences yesterday afternoon and attended a "Stop Hitler" rally in Madison Square Park.

Major Clement R. Attlee, Lord Privy Seal, Deputy Prime Minister and leader of the Labor party in Great Britain, declared yesterday that the major lesson concerning labor learned in England during the war was the "extraordinary extent to which the emergency called out the cooperation between the government, employers and employes."

Developments in Washington were the major influences in the cotton market again yesterday. Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, after opening at net losses of 8 to 17 points, near the high marks of the day, fell as much as 37 points in the short session.
NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Santa Clara, last unbeaten giant of the Pacific Coast, toppled today before Oklahoma and the sling-shot passing of Indian Jack Jacobs, 16 to 6, in a resounding upset.

NEW MILFORD, Conn., Oct. 25 -- In the presence of a handful of mourners, who knew her only as a lonesome old lady, Mrs. Florence Elizabeth Maybrick was laid to rest today in a grave lying within the shadow of the brick chapel of South Kent School.

In many homes one of the most difficult problems in the growing of plants is that of controlling the heat from radiators in close proximity to the locations otherwise best fitted for plants. In our own home a large steam radiator preempted the big south window in the dining room which would have been the best place in the house for our indoor garden.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 25 -- Northwestern's Wildcats clawed their way back into the Western Conference football picture today, defeating Ohio State's Buckeyes, 14 to 7, before 71,896 fans.

Addressing 600 high school administrators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut at a special meeting called by the New York University School of Education to discuss secondary school problems, Dr. H. Claude Hardy, Superintendent of Schools in White Plains, N.Y., yesterday urged the discontinuance of the Carnegie system of credits and fixed schedules of "time spent" in the high school curriculum.

In the current Atlantic Robert S. Binkerd estimates that labor dues,fines, assessments, initiation fees and other income will this year total the huge sum of $500,000.000. This, he declares, is the prize which leads so many racketeers to try to seize control of unions. He declares that two-thirds to three-quarters of these receipts will never know an independent audit.

THIS is largely a book of music rather than about music. Mr. Ford, who has traveled all over the land, has set down a healthy fragment of America's folk music. Here one may discover the vigorous roots of our folk music, which is as varied in its style and content as the very topography of the nation.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 25 -- After spotting Wesleyan seven points in the first quarter, Amherst came back today to register a 16-7 victory, its first in the series since 1938.

TO some people the extensive use of unusual buttons on feminine toggery this Fall may seem to be just a chance idea of the stylists, but there are those who, with a knowing look in their eyes, say that it is the direct result of a new hobby, that of collecting buttons, which has recently spread like butter on hot cakes, all over the country.

KEARNY, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Described by Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, Commandant of the Third Naval District, as "another nail in Hitler's coffin," the 6,000ton cruiser Juneau was launched today at the yard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company here.

The Council of the Acoustical Society of America, composed of several hundred leading authorities on the science of sound in the United States and Canada, took measures at the final sessions of its annual meeting here yesterday to mobilize the scientific knowledge of its members in aid of efforts throughout the country to abate unnecessary noises that are regarded as a menace to the collective nervous system and morale of the nation.

QUESTIONS -- said to be vital -- currently pertinent to American and world freedom are to be taken up in a definitive series entitled "What Freedom Means," to begin a weekly run Tuesday at 3:45 P.M. on WABC's chain.

Massacres of thousands of Jews deported from Hungary to Galicia and the machine-gunning of more thousands of Galician Jews by German soldiers and Ukrainian bandits are reported in letters reaching Hungary from Galicia and eye-witness accounts of Hungarian officers who have returned since the deportations ended on Aug. 10, according to information received by reliable sources here.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Joining President Roosevelt in condemnation of the Nazi executions of French hostages in reprisal for assassinations of German officers at Nantes and Bordeaux, Prime Minister Churchill declared in a statement issued tonight that one of the major purposes of this war would henceforth be to avenge these crimes against innocent Frenchmen.

In a special report soon to be submitted to the Board of Higher Education, Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, calls upon the board to take a "long view" in educational planning, and points to the need for careful study of changing relations between public and private educational institutions, according to a summary issued yesterday.

St. Lawrence University's football team, which had been playing against heftier squads all season, finally found one with an even more acute manpower shortage than its own and responded with two quick touchdowns in the first quarter for a 13-7 victory over Brooklyn College yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- The University of Rochester football team today knocked Hamilton College from the ranks of the undefeated with a smashing 19-to-7 victory. The Yellow Jackets, held scoreless in the first quarter, notched touchdowns in the last three periods.

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity declined further during the week ended Oct. 18 and now stands at 126.2. It was 126.5 for the week ended Oct. 11 and 112.1 for the week ended Oct. 19, 1940.

FORT DIX, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Cozy interiors for company day rooms at Camp Dix is the latest project New Jersey clubwomen are sponsoring for the comfort of the boys in olive drab. Under the leadership of Mrs. Thomas W. Streeter of Morristown, chairman of the Citizens Committee for Fort Dix, the women are striving to furnish as many of the 189 enlisted men's clubrooms as possible by Christmas.

A forthcoming benefit theatre party with unusual international significance is that arranged for the performance of England's wartime play, "The Wookey," on the night of Nov. 6 at the Plymouth Theatre. The New York branch of the English-Speaking Union has taken over the performance to raise funds for the extensive war relief projects of the organization now being carried on in this country as well as in England.
"ISN'T this dumb? I made it." Age Seven is speaking about a drawing. "Mine's dopey as anything," says another child brightly, and a third chimes in, "So's mine."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 25 -- New evidence of the lack of manpower in Germany was revealed here when several Swedish seamen received a German circular letter offering all kinds of advantages to Swedish workers consenting to go and work in Germany.

NEXT Thursday the oldest church edifice in New York City -- built of the stone which is the rocky foundation of Manhattan -- celebrates the completion of 175 years of service to the community. It is St. Paul's Chapel, standing very little changed -- except for the portico which faces Broadway -- since it was opened for worship in 1766 just south of the Common, which has become City Hall Park.

Land of Suomi At least one person who is in the habit of listening to good music on the radio is Suomi strongly under the impression that very little Sibelius has been played of late. Is this really the case? And if so, can there be any possible connection between a decline in the Finnish master's popularity and Finland's new international friendships?

The wartime attitude of the 2,000 students at Columbia College is characterized by a dogged recognition of the seriousness of the national emergency and a zeal for training which will make their technical and scholarly knowledge most useful to the nation, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes declares in his annual report to President Nicholas Murray Butler, made public today.

FROM time to time this department has used its space for the purpose of redirecting attention, if possible, to books not on the current lists which for one reason or another have seemed worth turning to again.

SWITZERLAND'S Christmas-time "Pro Juventute" (For Youth) anti-tuberculosis semi-postals have since 1927 been used to introduce newcomers to philately's gallery, and this year a 5-centimes plus 5c green will present Johann Kaspar Lavater, poet, theologian, mystic and physiognomist, while a 30c plus 10c blue and light blue will honor Daniel Jean Richard, "father" of the Swiss watch industry.

Surpassing by one second the season record he set last week for the two-and-one-quarter-mile Van Cortlandt Park course, Egon Werdelman, Bryant High School senior, ran an 11:40 race over the same winding trail yesterday and won the fifth interscholastic cross-country meet sponsored by New York University's Alumni Spiked Shoe Club.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The survey of the Selective Service System shows that 50 per cent of the men examined were rejected for physical defects. Of these, 20.9 per cent were disqualified for defective teeth, 13.7 per cent for faulty vision, 10.6 per cent for heart and circulatory troubles, and 6.3 per cent suffered from venereal diseases.

At a time When the works of American composers are being accented in radio concert fare, it seems only natural that WABC should chip in with "Milestones in American Music" Tuesday at 4 P.M., when the new weekly will open.

The Automobile Club of New York through William J. Gottlieb, president, announced yesterday its support of Amendment 1 to the State Constitution, providing for transfer of $60,000,000 in bonds authorized to be issued for grade-crossing elimination to highway and parkway construction.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 25 -- Notre Dame's football machine, sputtering for three periods before Illinois' inspired play, came to life today with a terrific explosion of fourth-period power which produced four touchdowns and a 49to-14 victory before 45,000 roaring spectators.

Health programs conducted by Hadassah in Palestine and its educational work here -- both expanding as a result of the emergency -- will be reviewed at the annual convention of the organization which will be in session this week in Pittsburgh, Pa.

THE late Sir Wilfred Thomason Grenfell -- "Grenfell of Labrador" -- is to receive philatelic recognition. R.H. Tait, managing editor of The Newfoundland Times, published in New York, announced last week that he had received word from St. John's that Newfoundland will release about Dec. 1 a 5-cents violet-brown stamp in commemoration of the humanitarian work which Sir Wilfred carried on among the natives of Labrador and Northern Newfoundland across nearly fifty years.

Chrysanthemums are in their glory this week, both in the New York Botanical Garden and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, as the flowering season reaches its height. Featuring a wide range of types and colors, and being labeled, they provide visitors with a rare opportunity to compare varieties.

LUNCHING exhibitions in quick succession this season, the Museum of Modern Art opened two more last week, both consisting of examples from its own collections. One of these is of the museum's "primitives," with ten recent acquisitions.

ENGLISH radio talks from Tokyo to America are being heard on a new schedule these days beginning at 6 P.M., Eastern standard time. Coming from the west this beam holds up longer on the 19-meter evening band than the Europeans, because the Oriental wave has the advantage of daylight to urge it on through Fall skies.

Plans have been perfected for the development as soon as building conditions resume their normal status of a tract of twenty acres forming part of the former Milburn Country Club in Freeport, Nassau County, L.I., by the Harben Homes Corporation of which Benjamin Levin is president.

COLLEGE STATION, Texas, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Texas Aggies welded their claim of greatness today with a 48-0 victory over Baylor University. Not since the Southwest Conference was organized has Baylor been so humiliated at the hands of A. and M.

WEATHER conditions turned more favorable to seasonal trade in the week and some pick-up was reported from centers where the post-tax lag was more pronounced. In less than a month the holiday shopping season will be launched and retailers view the possibilities with optimism.

After a fortnight in which the Russian defenders of their capital appeared to have held the German drive to take it, it now seems that the Nazis, having undoubtsdly brought up fresh troops and materiel, have launched a new drive for Moscow which is making progress. There is now no doubt that Stalin has ordered all efforts to hold Moscow, but the evidence points to an inching-in process by the attackers.

THE scene is the famous Imperial Hotel in Tokyo. It is 9 in the evening. The lobby is almost deserted. To save electricity nearly all the lights have been turned out. The main dining room is in darkness. A hat-check girl and a clerk wait forlornly behind the desk.

In a radio speech from Station WINS, Lloyd Church, Democratic nominee for City Controller, charged yesterday that Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, his Fusion opponent, had favored certain financial firms in the sale of more than $129,000,000 of city securities, which he said should not be confused with serial bonds or corporate stock sold by the Controller at public auction.

BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- School teachers who came under a cloud when the Nazis took power in 1933 and were subsequently retired or pensioned off, have now been told that they may apply for temporary reinstatement. The official notice, published yesterday, emphasized that this was only an emergency step to relieve the shortage of teachers.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 25 (AP) -- California's thrice-beaten Bears sprang a 14-to-0 upset of the University of Southern California today. Short-enders as they lined up before 40,000 fans, the Bears scored touchdowns in the second and final periods.

Of the 5,348 mortgage loans representing $28,000,000 in values placed on a premium-paying basis in the New York City area during the first nine months of this year and insured by the FHA, 50 per cent were for properties in subdivisions analyzed and set up as new neighborhoods by the administration's land planning division, according to Thomas G. Grace, State director.

THE thirteenth century in town and country, in England and France and the Low Countries, was a period of prosperity and confidence. It was the period, moreover, when the social and economic order of the Middle Ages was least challenged, most solidly and successfully based.

TOKYO, Oct. 25 -- The statement of United States Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox regarding the danger of an American collision with Japan and the shifting of war materiel shipments from Vladivostok to Archangel should this occur has attracted considerable attention here without causing any undue misgivings.

To permit artists more time in which to submit their work for display in Art Week exhibition here, the New York City Council for Art Week, Inc., has decided to extend the time originally set for receiving painting's, sculpture, photographs and other examples of art.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 -- The Duke University Blue Devils continued their scoring rampage today, defeating the Pitt Panthers, 27 to 7, before 28,000 fans in sunbathed Pitt Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- As Representative Martin of Massachusetts, Republican national chairman, called Republican State chairmen and vice chairmen today to meet here Jan. 12 to make plans for the 1942 Congressional campaign, Secretary Knox, Republican member of a Democratic Cabinet, was reported to have pledged active support in next year's elections to consistent Republican supporters of the Administration's foreign policy.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Forty seconds after the teams went into action, Cornell had a touchdown advantage over the Colgate team in their clash on Schoellkopf Field today. This stunning, sudden blow was just a little too much for the erstwhile Red Raiders to absorb with indifference, and before they were able to recover their aplomb they yielded the local athletes two more touchdowns.

PITTSBURGH, Sunday, Oct. 26 -- In conformity with the order of John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, a strike of 53,000 workers in "captive" coal mines demanding a union shop became effective at midnight in western Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Kentucky, Illinois and Alabama.

THERE'S a gala mood at formal parties even at this early date. The desire to appear glamorous is evident. The glitter of sequins and jeweled embroidery has been wholeheartedly accepted. Rainbow hues have outstripped black.

WHEN a picture has been completed and sent out into distribution by a film studio, the salvagers go to work. The sets are taken apart and stored for future attractions, the excess film is filed or reclaimed.

ECONOMIZER: On the second floor of a wooden barnlike "temporary" government building on Washington's Maryland Avenue is a huge room, 160 x 45 feet. It is the office of Maury Maverick and his staff of eighty who form an OPM division handling priority applications of State and local gov- ernments.

SELINSGROVE, Pa., Oct. 25 -- Accurate passing and clever ballhandling in their double-wingback formation behind a sturdy line gave Coach Benny Friedman's City College of New York Beavers a hard-earned 7-6 triumph in the closing minutes of their game with Susquehanna University today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- With its Y-formation operating in smooth fashion and taking advantage of every break, Syracuse marched to a 49-to-7 triumph over Rutgers today, jamming all its scoring in the first three periods when the first two teams were in action.
