Hunter College's first Book Fair, with auctions of books and talks and readings by men and women prominent in the world of books, will take place next Thursday and Friday at the Park Avenue building of the college, Miss Babette Levy, staff member in charge of the fair, announced yesterday.

The electrical manufacturing industry has thus far accepted more than $2,000,000,000 worth of direct defense orders and has assumed responsibility for at least a like amount of indirect business, Earl O. Shreve, vice president of the General Electric Company and president of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, reported here yesterday.

"HE piped higher, the music climbed the mountainside, echoing into the kranses till it died. He stopped playing and shook the water from his pipe. * * * It was as though he had emptied some of the sadness from his heart into the hills.

Reducing Reflections Reflection from the glass of showcases, pictures and meters is a nuisance. And it is particularly a nuisance in television in which images are first "painted" by light on the glass surface of a cathoderay tube, then passed through a thick protector plate to a glass mirror in which it is seen.

Individual and family savings in the United States during the year 1940 represented more than $3,500,000,000, reports the current issue of the Federal Home Loan Bank Review, stating that this sum is the highest recorded for any single year since the big financial years of 1925-1926.

IT is considerate of Herr Hitler that as he pushes us from thought to action he simultaneously supplies our novelists with exciting new material for melodrama. Much melodrama is being written, and better written than ever before.

MEXICO CITY -- Already in the market places of Mexico are appearing sugar skulls, death's-head masks, wooden skeletons which jiggle when a string is pulled, and a lot of other cheerful ware which foreshadow The Day of the Dead.

James Monroe High School's football team remained in the undefeated and untied ranks by subduing DeWitt Clinton, 12 to 6, for its fourth victory in the second game of a scholastic twin bill yesterday at Randalls Island. In the curtain-raiser Evander Childs upset a favored Stuyvesant eleven, 13 to 7.

LONDON. MY forecast of Fall publications, made eight weeks ago, may now be supplemented by later information. Royalty will figure prominently in the biographical field, for we are to have studies of Richard II by Anthony Steel, of Elizabeth by Hilaire Belloc, and of Edward VII, to celebrate the centenary of his birth, by Dr. Catherine Gavin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The following Foreign Service changes since Oct. 17 were announced by the State Department today: Coert du Bois of San Francisco, consul general at Havana, assigned Department of State.

EACH of the recent succession of books in which air fighters are recording their experiences, physical and mental, contributes one or more new lineaments to the composite portrait of the battling Icarus.

Mrs. Henry J. Heinz, first chairman of aviation ever appointed by the General Federation of Women's Clubs, outlined her plans for that major group's participation in the air phases of the national emergency during an interview yesterday at Hampshire House.

WASHINGTON. WILLIAM HAMMATT DAVIS holds one of the most difficult of the New Deal's many and varied fronts, the defense labor mediation sector. A patent attorney by profession. Mr. Davis is a labor catalyst by avocation.

Classed among unofficial promoters of the good-neighbor policy, the Pan-American Women's Association is, however, giving a good account of itself in strengthening feminine relations in this hemisphere, and is now active in each of the twenty republics south of our border.

Peru's representatives in the National Horse Show, four officers and eight horses, arrived in New York yesterday aboard the Grace liner Santa Rita after a 6,000-mile journey from Callao. The South Americans are slated to compete in the nightly international military jumping events at Madison Square Garden from Nov. 5 to 12.

Perry landed his 300 bluejackets on Kurihama beach on July 14, 1853, in the midst of 10,000 hostile but intensely curious Japanese, and with oriental pomp and ceremony delivered President Fillmore's letter to two "princes" supposedly deputed by the Emperor (actually they were minor local officials), the sailor-diplomat displayed, according to Mr. Price, not only audacity but a

BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- The fall of Kharkov, industrial center of the Ukraine, was announced today. Most of the Donets Basin is now believed to be in German hands and the rest appears to be in danger of being enveloped by German spearheads driving north and south of Kharkov.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Oct. 25 -- Marking their tenth anniversary, the Mount Holyoke Friends of Art are bringing to the campus this month an exhibition of classical art honoring the late Caroline M. Galt, founder of the organization and for many years a member of the Department of Art and Archaeology.

Kharkov, whose capture the Germans claimed yesterday, was the chief hub of the economic life of the Ukraine, occupying an extremely strategic position on the main routes between Moscow on the north and Crimea and the rich Caucasus oil lands to the south.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Field Trial Champion Wakes Wager of Green Fair tonight was awarded the first prize in the open all-age stake of the eighteenth annual meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association after a full day of running in the difficult and testing cover at the eastern end of the island.

ROME, Oct. 25 -- Italy expects to have an equal partnership in the new European order and will not abandon her industrial structure for agriculture, according to Virginio Gayda in an editorial in the Giornale d'Italia discussing the visit of the German Economic Minister, Dr. Walther Funk, to Rome.

TRAVEL Lines: The liner Kungsholm is scheduled for seven Winter cruises, the longest being nineteen days, the shortest eleven. The Christmas-New Year's gala (sixteen days) leaves New York on Dec. 19, for Haiti, Panama and other spots where manana rules . . . The "Big Zoo," by William Bridges, with photographs by Desider Holisher, is an intimate close-up of the world's captive wild animals as seen by their keepers and visitors.

THE library that has been a star performer in the literary annals of American book collecting will make its positively last public appearance this week. What is left of the troupe belonging to the late A. Edward Newton, the books and manuscripts he never tired of fondling and writing about, will be found on display at the Parke-Bernet Galleries in New York.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Governor Lehman of New York, declaring that the war peril confronting the United States was a matter of days, demanded here today repeal or drastic revision of the Neutrality Law "without loss of time."

THIS is a youthful novel of prep-school life in one of those legended academies found only in New England. The intention is a dramatic study of youth in a confusing background of parlous times and mossy traditions.
Variegated-foliaged plants as a general rule are not very popular. But an exception is the Variegated Yucca -- Yucca filamentosa variegata.

MEDICAL LECTURES -- To keep the public informed of the progress of medicine, the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street, New York, has arranged for a series of six evening lectures to the laity on Nov. 13 and Dec. 11, 1941, and Jan. 22, Feb. 26, March 26 and April 23, 1942.
As a result of the national defense effort and shipment of war materials from this port traffic on city-owned ferryboats has shown a marked increase in recent months, it was learned here last week.

Where are the weather prophets? Here it is practically November, and we don't know yet what to expect of the Winter. We know it will be reasonably warm indoors, for Mr. Ickes has called off his oil shortage; but what about the outdoor weather? It's high time we had some light on the subject from the goose-bone seers.
EASTMAN is now making a new Kodak Precision Enlarger, equipped with a power-cooled lamp-holder and a control box for operating the cooling mechanism and the enlarger lamp independently of each other.

BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- Newspapers owned or controlled by the Nazi party account now for two-thirds of the total circulation of the Reich's daily press, which is estimated at about 25,000,000 copies, it was stated yesterday in an article on the "Economics of the German Press" by Max Amann, the head of the party's press and publishing section.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 25 -- Nebraska battered itself to pieces on Missouri's rock-ribbed forward wall today to see its Big Six football dynasty seriously threatened as the Tigers plugged over a touchdown in the last quarter for a 6-0 triumph.

THE Oxford University Press is bringing out a series of pamphlets under the general title "America in a World at War." Twelve of these are now available and may be had for 10 cents each or $1 for the twelve.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Oct. 26 -- An official Soviet news bulletin broadcast from Moscow this morning stated that what appeared to be a major German offensive was under way along an almost continuous line from Kharkov to the Sea of Azov.

The New York Mayoralty campaign, as never before in City history, is cutting completely across party lines. It hardly needed President Roosevelt's announcement of his preference for the re-election of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, great as was the impetus it gave to the Mayor's candidacy, to make this evident, for it had been apparent since the beginning of the campaign.

THE world of backstage is always interesting to people who sit out front and accounts for the popularity of books dealing with the theatre, the circus, the movies and night clubs. In his new novel, "Radio City," Hartzell Spence devotes himself to the backstage story about the most popular form of modern entertainment.

Real estate sales in Great Neck, L.I., during the first eight months of 1941 were better than double those for the same period of 1940, an analysis recently completed by Myers E. Baker, broker, reveals.
ALBANY, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Republicans lost today their first court action to give Frank C. Moore, the party's candidate for State Controller, two ballot listings in the Nov. 4 election.

American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation and Subsidiaries in United States -- Nine months to Sept. 30: Net profit, $5,171,849, after provision of $5,400,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes, equal, after dividend requirements on 7 per cent preferred stock, to 49 cents a share on 10,043,471 common shares, compared with $3,720,806 or 35 cents a common share last year; profit before Federal income and excess profits taxes, $10,571,849, compared with $4,948,806.

BERLIN, Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- A German propaganda company reporter said that Kharkov was captured after a campaign of almost unimaginable difficulty. A month ago a German spearhead reached Poltava, eighty miles to the west. It took four weeks for German forces to push forward those eighty miles and into the city.
There are several essential, relatively inexpensive tasks for the gardener who wishes to give his evergreens maximum protection against the ravages of Winter.

GUATEMALA CITY -- Guatemala is one of the best travel bargains in the world today. The rainy season has just ended. From now until next September it's a sunny land to which the wise traveler takes nothing heavier than a topcoat.

Irving S. Olds, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, has been appointed chairman of the special gifts committee for the annual roll-call of the American Red Cross in Manhattan and the Bronx, it was announced yesterday by S. Sloan Colt, general chairman.

Production of steel for defense will be materially affected within ten days unless there is an earlier settlement of the strike in the "captive" coal mines of the seven largest steel companies, called last night by the United Mine Workers of America.
BEAVER FALLS, Pa., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Geneva College came from behind with two touchdowns in the final period to defeat once-powerful Carnegie Tech, 13 to 6, before 5,000 spectators today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 25 -- Across 3,000 miles of mountains, deserts and plateaus from the dizzy Pamir massif of Afghanistan to the Libyan frontier, the British forces of the Near and Middle East are stiffening a defensive bastion against the Axis armies of the Western Desert and the mighty German war machine that is slowly crushing its way toward the Caucasus and the threshold of India.

COMPREHENSIVENESS as well as earnestness and searching study marks this symposium on American youth. Under the editorial supervision of Thacher Winslow, administrative assistant in the National Youth Administration, and Frank P. Davidson, graduate associate, The Harvard Guardian, ten vital aspects of youth's needs and hopes are presented by as many experts.

Through the widespread use of subcontracting, the Sperry Corporation has achieved a rate of operation which would have required an expenditure of $40,000,000 for expansion if the company had undertaken the work itself, Thomas A. Morgan, president of the company, declared yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25 -- Navy's football craft steamed out of Harvard Stadium tonight with its flag still nailed to the mast, but with gaping shell holes in its side.

Commander Gatti's "Saranga, the Pygmy," which appeared two years ago, was an unforgettable account of the most primitive life in the African jungle. Now, in this true story of one of the youngest members of his expedition, we see what the coming of the white man meant to one small native.

In many key defense cities standard defense housing warranting forty-year amortization can be developed out of existing structures at a cost far below that of comparable new housing, according to Fred W. Catlett, member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

OF use to motorists estimating automobile repair prices for themselves is a new handbook of parts and labor costs recently published by the National Used Car Market Report, Chicago, and prepared as an aid to used-car appraisers and insurance adjusters.

IN spite of the fact that warfare was contrary to his "habits and education and repugnant to all his tastes," John M. Palmer was one of the small group of civilian soldiers in the War Between the States who rose to high rank on merit and performance.

To acquaint the faculty and students of Queens College with the wealth and diversity of French culture in the Americas, an immense collection of French-Canadian newspapers, periodicals, books and works published by French men of letters has been placed on exhibit in the college library it was announced yesterday.

From opposite sides of the Pacific Ocean come the only two women, aside from Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins, with official status in the International Labor Office convention which opens tomorrow at Columbia University.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 25 -- An influential group within the inner circle of Nazi affairs is preparing to introduce a plan to reorganize religion in Germany by substituting Hitler's "Mein Kampf" for the Holy Bible, according to Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, who spoke tonight before the annual convention of the National Council of the Y.M.C.A.

THAT perennial stepchild of the film industry, that cinematic stray, the "movie shorts," has reached, in the course of its wanderings, a turning point of which few theatregoers are aware. For, ever since Sept. 1, when there went into effect a new plan for peddling pictures from producers to distributors, a bitter behind-the-scenes battle has been raging between "shorts" and "second features" for playing time on theatre programs.

FORT BENNING, Ga. YOU shout ''Geronimo!" and leap like a broad jumper into 1,200 feet of space. You wear greenish, rubberized-silk coveralls and a green plastic, dish-shaped helmet that is strapped tightly to your chin with chamois cloth, with a bib of chamois hanging down over your throat and upper chest.

L. Seth Schnitman of the Office of Price Administration will meet with operative home builders in Detroit Nov. 7 to discuss what has been done to hold prices in the building material field at an equitable level and what administrative or cooperative action to this end is proposed for the future.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Roosevelt denounced in scathing terms today the German executions of "innocent hostages" in France. He declared that these killings were revolting and that it was impossible to break men's spirit by terrorism.

OTTAWA, Oct. 25 -- Canada, which has a population of about a million less than the State of New York and a geographic economy of something like a hundred-mile-wide strip of the United States between Massachusetts and Washington, has voluntarily raised 338,000 soldiers, airmen and seamen to fight wherever they may be called on to fight, and has a reserve of 170,000 partly trained men for home defense.

London has not been utterly demolished by bombs, yet some of its most beautiful buildings have been destroyed and some of its uglier areas are heaps of rubble. Not since the great fire of 1666 has the metropolis been presented with such an opportunity to correct the mistakes of the past.

The German juggernaut rolls relentlessly toward the East. Under its crushing pressure the Russian military machine has given way though defending each foot of native land. These two military machines are destroying all over which they pass -- medieval towns and cathedrals, great Industries and plants, vast reserves of oil and pipe lines, stores of grain and clothing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- President Roosevelt shunted aside the usual routine of callers and conferences today and devoted his time to preparing a Navy Day speech expected to contain important statements on foreign policy.

IN case any party or parties were wondering what Paul Green, the Pulitzer Prize playwright from North Carolina, has been doing in preparation for the current season, let them be hereby advised that he has had his hands full turning out various items about (a) an Uncle Remuslike character named "Mr. Mac"; (b) Mr. Green's old friend, Sir Walter Raleigh, and (c) the "quaint but dangerous primitive folk-philosophy" of the presentday dictator boys.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The latest overall defense chart published here shows that under the President thirty-four separate agencies, divisions or offices are concerned with one or more defense problems, and an unofficial enumeration shows that a total of more than 800,000 employes are at work in these offices, either in Washington or in the field.

WITH the opening of a new five-mile link on the Wilbur Cross Parkway, in Connecticut, last week, the planned extension of the dual roadway system to the Massachusetts State line was brought closer to reality. When this is complete, motorists bound for Boston and other New England points along the coast will be able, not only to avoid congestion on the Boston Post Road, but to reduce the driving distance by nearly thirty miles.

A SHIP with the most colorful career in this country's naval history bobbed up in the news again recently when the old Coast Guard cutter Bear steamed into Boston harbor escorting the tiny Norwegian freighter Busko.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area continued active last week, but volume was affected by the action of many customers in deferring purchases of higher-priced items in order to profit by the reduction tomorrow in the city sales tax from 2 to 1 per cent.

FOR the principal character of his first novel, "Phoenix in East Hadley," Maurice B Cramer has chosen an elderly woman, Mrs. Luella Pickering, the dominating influence in whose life is her belief in the resurrection of the body.

A new testing program for New York State schools, designed to modify the Board of Regents examinations and place greater emphasis upon improvement of skills and not on final marks, is now under way in the State Education Department, it was disclosed yesterday.

VICHY, France, Oct. 25 -- With publication of the names of the fifty hostages executed at Bordeaux, the government here was bending every energy to avert what a communique today termed "the tragic reprisals of which the victims are Frenchmen who had no part in the attacks" fatal to two German officers in Nantes and Bordeaux.

The November sky picture is interesting because it contains some stars of both the Summer and Winter seasons. Early in the evening many conspicuous Summer constellations may be seen descending in the west, while the Winter star groups are climbing out from beyond the eastern horizon.
GOBLINS. monsters and good old-fashioned ghosts will walk Friday night, when the small fry of the land indulge in the traditional mumbo-jumbo of All-hallows Eve.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 25 -- Bruce Smith did it again today, and for the eighth successive year Minnesota defeated Michigan in the most searching challenge the burly Gophers have overcome in their quest for Western Conference and national championship football honors. The score was 7 to 0.

The serious situation confronting the investment banking industry in respect to the flotation of new securities to the public was emphasized last week by the absence of a single formal offering of bonds for any of the major classifications of borrowers.

It would be hard to find more beautiful flowers than the South African nerines, which may be grown as house plants if provisions are made for their not-too-compli- cated needs. They belong to the Amaryllis family. The flowers grow as a rule in a circular cluster at the top of a bare stalk.
Racial and religious appeals for votes in a political campaign were deplored by rabbis in sermons here yesterday. Morality as a prerequisite of world peace and liberty were other sermon topics.

DETROIT -- After two or three years of national emergency, what will the automotive picture be? A prominent car sales executive has very definite ideas on the subject. He expects many changes and revival of practices that have proved successful.
A warning that the entire defense program would collapse if a strike in the "captive mines" forced a halt in steel production was issued yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

Shipping activity in the Port of New York continued at a high level during September, although it was slightly under August and the year's peak in July. Total entrances and clearances for the month, compiled by the Customs Service, amounted to 1,141 vessels of 3,663,940 net tons. In July there were 1,170 ships of 3,925,432 tons, and in August 1,143 or 3,722,000 tons.

THE Metropolitan tournament, which began last Sunday at A the Park Central Hotel, will come to a close today with a two-session mixed-pair contest. The two sessions will begin at 2 and 8:30 P.M. The mixed-pair event is usually the best attended of the five contests on the Metropolitan schedule.

New York builders who were in a position, to proceed with the construction of small homes under the restrictions laid down by the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board have lost no time in applying for preferential ratings which would enable them to purchase the necessary building materials.

With the exception of the consumers' durable goods lines, American industry expects to market in 1942 a volume of civilian goods close to the totals of this year and is now scheduling advertising expenditures on a scale comparable to the 1941 figure, according to a canvass made last week among advertising managers of important companies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Oct. 24:

Nobody is much surprised when murder is done in the premises of Business Journals, Inc., an organization devoted to the publication of trade journals. The business has been conducted along such crazy lines that anything might be expected to happen.

LONDON, Oct. 25 (Reuter) -- The difficulties encountered by British soccer clubs in wartime were illustrated today, when Arsenal, leader in the London League, had trouble in fielding a team against Watford. As a result the team's winning streak was ended, 3 -- 1.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Oct. 25 -- General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock launched a new offensive against Moscow yesterday and after a heavy barrage of artillery and mortar fire, forced the Red Army to withdraw at two points south of the town of "N."

NEW YORK'S adolescents, the generation now growing up, have just begun another year of high school. To most of these boys and girls getting through school is the preface to a job; to some it is a hurdle to take in order to get to college, and to still fewer it is the last lap of a good time.

THE Great Bears of pro football appear to be on a climbing spree. They opened their season by beating the Green Bay Monsters to the tune of 25 -- 17, an 8-point margin for the Halas hirelings. Next they tackled the Cleveland Rams and, needless to say, threw them for a long loss. The score was 48 -- 21, a margin of 27 points in favor of the Great Bears and the T-formation.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 25 -- Operating for the first time under the new plan, classes in the college of science, literature and the arts at the University of Minnesota this year are now departmentalized into three divisions -- humanities, natural sciences and social sciences.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- When the Maritime Commission this week told more than it intended to about the rerouting of war materiels to Soviet Russia, and in so doing made an incorrect statement as well, Washington's attack on the problem of delivering supplies to Stalin's military machine was exposed to public view.

As the outdoor flower season draws to a close, home gardeners again are facing the season that means dependence on flower shops as the major source of supply for cut flowers for the house -- for only the minority are fortunate possessors of a frame house or greenhouse in which to grow plants that bloom all Winter.

The executive committee of the New York chapter of the America First Committee yesterday sent telegrams to the National Broadcasting Company, the Columbia Broadcasting System and the Mutual Broadcasting System accusing the networks of having "refused, proper and adequate coast-to-coast radio time" for Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Charles A. Lindbergh and former Ambassador John R. Cudahy, who will address the anti-war meeting at Madison Square Garden on Thursday.

THREE years have passed since Thomas Wolfe's death, and this is the third book which has been culled from the mountain of manuscript he left behind him. It is also, we are told, to be the last, although material remains for as many more.
TOPPER LAKE, N. Y., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Three Royal Canadian Air Force fliers were killed today when their twin-engined bomber crashed in a bog at the foot of Big Tupper Lake.

Decision on 'Neutrality' A quiet -- a surface quiet -- pervaded the White House last week. There was little noticeable tension, no hasty parleys of military and Cabinet advisers. Even the hardest-worked member of the secretarial staff found opportunity to go home at a decent hour. At times the deceptive calm was broken.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 25 -- Bob Margarita, Brown's star halfback, personally accounted for Lafay- ette's fourth defeat of the season today when he raced 90 and 58 yards for touchdowns to give the Bruins a well-deserved 13-0 triumph.

As a means of winding up the affairs of a number of title, mortgage, casualty and surety companies in liquidation, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday that his department had compiled a list of 200 offerings of real property, mortgages and certificates for quick disposal by mail auction and private offers.

As its contribution to the Bethlehem bicentennial celebration, the Bethlehem Bach Choir, under Ifor Jones, will present Haydn's "The Creation," Feb. 22, in Packer Memorial Chapel, Lehigh University, Bethlehem, Pa.

Children in a democracy should get an opportunity to have healthy bodies, receive adequate recreational centers and have "freedom from fear," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday in speaking to 500 men and women attending the twenty-fifth anniversary luncheon of the Summer Play Schools Association at the Hotel Astor.

Committees aiding in the sale of boxes and patron memberships, as well as in plans for various entertainment features, are now being organized for the National Horse Show to be held at Madison Square Garden from Nov. 5 to 12. The show this year will benefit the United Service Organizations.

A NUMBER of people were asked what was their idea of complete comfort; and furthermore what were the little discomforts of their home life that they'd like to get fixed up. On the general picture most of them just wanted to lie down somewhere and be let alone.

TO THE EDITOR: In the interview with Burton K. Wheeler, all the questions asked and answered are obviously arranged by Mr. Wheeler with a view to excusing himself. The most obvious follow-up questions -- questions the entire public of this country has a right to see Wheeler forced to answer yes or no -- were unasked.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- Pennsylvania gained its fourth straight victory of the football season by overpowering Maryland at Franklin Field today, 55-6, before 40,000 persons.

THIS freshly original novel of life among a certain element of the colored population of a Texas seaport has been given the first prize of $2,500 and a gold medal in a contest sponsored jointly by the Virginia Quarterly Review and its New York publishers.

Sea View Terrace, the palatial residence of the late Edson Bradley at Newport, R.I., will be offered at auction at a sale to be conducted on the premises on Nov. 29, Joseph P. Day, the auctioneer announced yesterday. The property, which consists of the mansion and fourteen acres, will be placed on the auction block in five seperate parcels.
Twenty-five scholarships for Latin-American students arranged through the city in cooperation with its leading business establishments, were announced Friday by Mayor La Guardia.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Debutantes from this community and all sections of the metropolitan area were honored tonight at the fifty-fourth annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball held in the Tuxedo Club. More than 400 attended the event, which made one of the gayest week-ends the park has had in recent years.

Mahler: Symphony No. 1, in D. Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Dimitri Mitropoulos. (Columbia, six twelve-inch records, $6.50.) Columbia deserves a special citation for putting out a score like this, which is seldom performed in the concert hall and which is likely to have a limited public appeal.

THE gray falcon is an enigmatic figure in a Slav folksong about a military defeat in the year 1389; and it offered the Serbian king a choice which expresses the sad dilemma of modern pacifism and points to its tragic results.

AT least two new types of fighter planes have been put into service by the Red Air Force since Hitler launched his drive against Russia last June. It is very likely that several other new types of fighter and bomber craft have been used by the Russians since the first assault, but definite information about them is meager.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday afternoon that while he might differ with New York City Republicans on national and economic issues, no member of the Republican organization in the city ever would have occasion to "be ashamed of my city administration."

A report "to the members, subscribers and friends of the Greek War Relief Association" telling of the work of the association since Greece was overrun by the Germans and Italians last Spring and of the progress of plans to ship food there for distribution by the International Red Cross was made public yesterday by the association's executive committee.
ATLANTA, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Johnny Bosch climbed back in the saddle today and Georgia Tech roped and branded Auburn, 28 -- 14.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Princeton University's part in the national defense effort was summarized today by President Harold W. Dodds in his annual report to the board of trustees, which declared that "a substantial beginning of important university contributions" had been made to the defense program during the academic year 1940-41.

MANHATTAN'S streamlined East River Drive came a step nearer completion last week with the opening of the link between Twenty-third and Thirty-fourth Streets. One other important gap in the new speedway -- from Thirty-fourth Street to Forty-eighth Street -- remains to be closed.

HOLLYWOOD. THERE is unhappiness in paradise -- at least, in the quarters occupied by Deanna Durbin, Joan Fontaine, Victor Mature and their respective employers. The reason for Miss Durbin's revolt against Universal has not been explained officially, but the disputes between Miss Fontaine and David O. Selznick and Mature and Hal Roach admittedly spring from that orthodox and sordid root of evil, money.

A new educational journal, "The University Administration Quarterly," which will acquaint the public with the best thinking and findings of scholars on problems of educational program, will make its first appearance this week, it was announced by Acting President Harry N. Wright.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- What are high school seniors thinking about politics and political activity?

Meeting in conjunction with the Association of Urban Universities in Cleveland last week, the Association of Deans and Directors of University Evening Schools had a good deal to say on the subject of adult education. It is a subject of such consequence that James Creese of Stevens Institute of Technology, has predicted for it an influence on higher education in this country that may change the character of the school system.
ROME, Oct. 25 -- The British Air Force raided Naples for the third time in four days during last night, and also bombed Licata and Ragusa, in Sicily, the High Command announced today.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia will speak on civilian defense before delegates to the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs meeting for their Fall convention on Friday at the Hotel Astor. The Mayor's talk will be given at the morning session, which opens at 10 o'clock with the pledge of allegiance led by Mrs. William Foster Rowland, chairman of the Department of American Patriotism, which is directing the convention program.

"INTOXICATION MADE EASY." by Elliot Paul and Luis Quintanilla, is a difficult book to catalogue. Should it be classed under the heading humor, cookery, erotica, or popularized natural history, who can say, for it has elements of all these subjects?

AFTER more than a quarter of a century on Broadway, George Abbott, producer and man-of-all-work, is still enjoying the theatre. He does not grow stale. He produces a musical comedy like "Best Foot Forward" with the enthusiasm of a first work.

The home decorator who, with comfort and order already achieved, is now seeking atmosphere and individuality, does well to turn to accessories that are made by hand. Whether the work of one's own hands or those of another craftsman, it is reassuring to feel that a one-of-a-kind possession is being acquired.
NEW YORK Major Gen. William Crozier, U.S.A., and Mrs. Crozier have arrived at the St. Regis from Washington.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Iong Prep triumphed over Isaac Young High by 21 -- 0 today. Billy Nisbet scored twice.

IN between-war days, the American radio listener was probably only faintly annoyed when, on twisting his dial, he tuned to a broadcast in a foreign language. Doubtless these days, warned of propaganda, he wonders considerably what the stuff of these programs in German, Italian, Polish and other tongues is, anyway.

DISTANCE makes mountains blue and mortals great, say the Icelanders. Though they themselves have now been drawn closer to the Western Hemisphere by the exigencies of war, they still remain a part of the far-off North and the Scandinavia that a thousand years ago began to make its early contribution to world literature.

The Old World atmosphere of Piccadilly Arcade, Mayfair, London, has been created in a picturesque setting at the Piccadilly Arcade, which will be opened by the British War Relief Society, Inc., on Tuesday, where family treasures from American homes will be sold for the benefit of homeless British families.

New York's new "safety responsibility" law, effective Jan. 1, is expected to increase insurance coverage on 2,400,000 passenger cars in the State from 30 per cent at present to more than half in 1942, it was learned yesterday.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: The length and vehemence of Mr. Hindus's letter of protest are somewhat surprising to me, in view of what I consider the very temperate and balanced character of my review of his book. All I did was to put a few question marks after some of its more exclamatory affirmations.

THIS is a small but important book. Count Sforza, was at one time Italy's Foreign Minister. He is an implacable foe of fascism and nazism and all that savors thereof, and he is wise in the ways of underground European politics.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Oct. 25 -- An alert and aggressive Hill School football squad bagged a 21-to-7 victory today, sending its traditional foe, Lawrenceville, down to defeat for the third straight year.

THE publishers assure us that "the principles of magic as set forth in 'The Incomplete Enchanter' are not simply invented for the purposes of the book but solidly founded on research." They warn us of the formidable intellectual arsenal of the authors -- Scandinavian mythology, Arthurian legend, Norse and Anglo-Saxon linguistics, eight-dimensional mathematics, paraphysics and a good deal else.

"THUS the face of things in life changes, the center of empires, the register of fortunes, the chart of positions, all that seemed final, are perpetually remolded, and during his lifetime a man can witness the completest changes just where those seamed to him the least possible."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is astonishing how crudely designed the machinery of democracy often is to achieve its basic purposes. The orthodox system of election presumably exists to choose candidates that most nearly represent the sentiments of the voters, or have the approval of most of them.

A new venture by prominent New Yorkers in the field of British war relief work will be started Tuesday morning with the formal opening of the Piccadilly Arcade at 6 East Fifty-seventh Street Here, in surrounding's reminiscent of Mayfair's shopping center of the same name, a sale of donated "treasures" from American homes will be held daily from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. for the benefit of homeless families of Britain.

LONDON, Oct 25 -- Spurred by the continuing clamor for an invasion of the Continent, members of the government, led by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, today took to the rostrums to declare in varying terms that the decision on opening up a second front in Western Europe necessarily rests with the War Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Extension of domestic price ceilings to the export market is under serious consideration by officials here who recently have been upset by the operations of a number of "fly-by-night" exporters who are selling steel and other materials in Latin America and elsewhere at exorbitant prices.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Tennessee had to rely on sophomores today to dispose of a stubborn University of Cincinnati football team, 21 to 6, before a crowd of about 7,000.

Marking a significant move to guard against the effects of potential inflation and subsequent deflationary influences upon retail inventories, leading retail executives for the first time are giving consideration to the use of the "last-in, first out" method of inventory valuation, which has already met with widespread adoption in industrial lines, it was learned here yesterday.

VICHY, France, Oct. 25 -- A communique issued after a Cabinet meeting this morning said that Yves Bouthillier, Minister of National Economy and Finance, gave details of the present cost of occupation and of the situation with regard to the prices of commodities.

Fearing that budget slashes might be in store for such non-defense government agencies as the Civilian Conservation Corps or the National Youth Administration, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt appealed yesterday to women workers to study the needs of their communities and advise Congress about them.

FOOTBALL Fordham, bagging two touchdowns after Texas Christian had tied the score in the last quarter, gained a thrilling victory before 39,500 at the Polo Grounds in the city's only big game of the day. Army's team, led by Ralph Hill, earned a two-touchdown decision over Columbia at West Point. Holy Cross beat New York University by the same margin at Worcester, Mass. City College topped Susquehanna by 1 point.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Before 10,000 spectators, the largest crowd to attend a hunts meet in this vicinity, R.V.N. Gambrill's Parma won the Fowler Memorial Cup three-mile steeplechase over the estate of Evander B. Schley today.
LONDON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

OIL APLENTY: Last Summer Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes forecast an oil shortage along the Eastern seaboard. Allegedly arising from diversion of tankers to Britain, the shortage led to a curfew on gas station sales. Public criticism was followed by a Congressional inquiry and report that supplies were adequate.
FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 25 -- The meeting today of the Essex Fox Hounds, which ended in a colorful ball at the clubhouse, will go down in history as the most outstanding in the long career of the hunt.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Babe Cranfield of Syracuse tonight chalked up the second major upset in the world pocket billiard championship when he outlasted Erwin Rudolph, former world champion from Cleveland, to win, 125 to 73. The match was completed with Cranfield's unfinished run of 27 in the twenty-first inning.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 25 -- The destruction of the legend of absolute invincibility of the German Army, brought about by the unexpectedly successful resistance of the Russians in the East, has brought a renaissance of hope in all the occupied countries in Europe at present suffering plague of "reprisal" executions such as has rarely been seen in history since the time of Attila.

BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- A manifest crescendo in the vituperations of the German press propaganda against American statesmen is coupled with assiduous efforts of official Germany to avoid any incidents that might offer the United States a formal "pretext" for declaring war upon Germany.

WALT DISNEY was in a jovial mood the other afternoon. And small wonder, for with the plaudits of South America still echoing from below, the critics hereabout were cutting some of their fanciest literary capers over "Dumbo," his latest feature-length cartoon.
DURHAM, N.H., Oct. 25 -- The University of New Hampshire routed a traditional rival, Vermont, 40 to 18, today before a huge Dad's Day crowd.

The writer of the following letter is a well-known military historian and analyst. He was attached to General Headquarters in France during the World War and, after the Armistice, was assigned to duty at the Peace Conference. He has conducted courses in military history at Columbia University and has contributed numerous articles on military subjects to periodicals.

WE are invited by this book to attend a symposium wherein one of America's foremost critics, two distinguished scholars and an English poet present their views, after an Introduction by Princeton's associate professor of English.

BOSTON, Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- The Boston College Eagles took to the air today and defeated George-town, 14 -- 6, with a brilliant attack before 20,000 fans at Fenway Park. A 27-yard pass achieved the Eagles' first touchdown in the second period and a long heave featured the fourth-period touchdown march.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Wisconsin marked up its second Western Conference football victory today by edging out Indiana, 27 to 25, in a thrill-packed seesaw game which kept 33,000 homecoming fans on edge until the final gun.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Democratic Leader Barkley set Monday for the start of Senate debate on amending the Neutrality Act.

This column has consistently opposed every form of taxation which has sought directly or by the process of coercion to compel corporate business enterprise to distribute earnings required for its reasonable needs and development.

A record crowd of delegates was on hand as the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's twentieth annual convention got under way yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker. More than 100 delegates, representing eighty-five clubs scattered throughout New England, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania and Maryland, participated in the opening day's activities.

While manufacturing operations have been steadily rising to capacity in nearly all lines and sections, the limitations on the production of various consumers' durable goods may soon become a drag on further expansion of over-all output, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Dr. George Washington Hall died today of a heart attack in the Hotel Statler, Detroit. He was 72 years old. The noted neurologist, for many years head of the department of, nervous and mental disease at Rush Medical College and senior neuropsychiatrist at St. Luke's Hospital, was attending the annual conventien of the Central Neuropsychiatric Association, of which he was a past president.

RARELY, if ever, in the literature of photography does one come across references to the filter as an aid in portraiture. In fact, this omission can be laid to the fact that hitherto most writing on the subject has been done with an eye to the professional reader.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 25 -- The Pennsylvania State College will use a "laboratory on wheels" this Fall to meet unusual teaching problems encountered in its engineering defense training program, under which more than 15,000 men and women in industry are enrolled in off-campus, non-credit courses of college level.

THE author of this book is the managing editor of The Emporia Gazette -- or would be if The Gazette were as big as it is important. Anyhow, Mr. Clough sees to it that the news is gathered, edited and put into the paper.

ORGANIZED for independent action, the road-transport arm of the United States Army is the largest truck operator in the world, with possible exception of Europe's combatant armies. Its 250,000-vehicle fleet, enameled in lusterless olive drab, is fourteen times the size of the largest civilian fleet of 18,000 in America.

ALTHOUGH Pittsburgh is a good sleepable night's run from New York, the annual at Carnegie Institute can always be depended upon to cast its shadow over Fifty-seventh Street, so far as space allotment for comment is concerned.

To the Music Editor: IN reviewing Aaron Copland's "Our New Music," Mr. Downes takes exception to Copland's evaluation of Mahler above Richard Strauss and Sibelius. Mr. Downes evidently does not like Mahler.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 25 -- Princeton's first football venture in the Southland ended disastrously today, as Vanderbilt's star collection of backs romped up and down Dudley Field to a 46-to-7 victory before 16,000 persons, including 1,500 Tiger alumni.
ANN HARBOR, Mich., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Minnesota, winner on the scoreboard in today's battering gridiron contest with Michigan, was the loser from the standpoint of injuries.
The Fusion campaign managers took yesterday two steps to combat a charge of overassessment of real estate in the city, made on Friday night by William O'Dwyer, the Democratic Mayoralty nominee.

The automobile has brought a new landscaping interest to that part of the home ground which formerly was thought of as "the back door." Nowadays the garage, particularly of a new house, is either attached to the residence or set quite close to it.

This thriller follows the Erle Stanley Gardner formula -- investigator embroiled with police, business man embroiled with mysterious lady, swift and not always scrupulous action in the interests of ultimate justice, everything high-geared, streamlined, and don't spare the horsepower.

Aleksandr Helmann, Russian pianist, was heard yesterday afternoon in Town Hall in his first local recital since his return from a seven-year sojourn abroad. Mr. Helmann possessed an exceedingly polished technique and evoked exquisite, most subtly shaded tone from the keyboard, but turned these assets to small account because of excessive vagaries and eccentricity as interpreter.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 25 -- Northeastern University defeated a stubborn Upsala eleven, 14 to 7, before 2,000 fans today on Huntington Field.

Funds to provide emergency aid for needy naval service men and their dependents will be raised from the benefit premiere of the motion picture, "How Green Was My Valley" on Tuesday night at the Rivoli Theatre. The performance is under the auspices of the Navy Relief Society.

FACED with slashing curtailment of its consumer goods production for the "duration," the automotive industry is forging ahead with defense assignments which by this time next year will make it a dominant force in the aeronautical manufacturing industry.

JOHN GUNTHER said that sometimes he wakes in the night and thinks: "My God, suppose I hadn't written it!" He was talking about "Inside Europe." Since writing that book he has been well paid, with no boss, can make his own assignments.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25 -- Informed quarters here express the opinion today that soundings between Mexico officials and the United States oil companies would be resumed before long and that the State Department at Washington would look with favor upon direct negotiations toward a settlement of the expropriation issue that diplomacy has been unable to achieve.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 25 -- Pictor and Ficklebush, a son and a daughter of two great sires, lived up to their illustrious bloodlines today by scoring smashing victories in Laurel's two richest stakes before a crowd of 22,000.

TIME, this author sums up his book's theme, is not lethal. It is a good, crisp phrase which occurs in the last chapter of an earnest but wordy volume on the subject of geriatrics -- old-age therapy. Mr. Newman begins with what he believes to be the enormously cheering assurance that "greater than ever in world history are the odds in favor of our reaching advanced age."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The White House issued today's statement by President Roosevelt in mid-morning for use at 12 noon. Broadcasting companies, translating it into French, Italian and German, sent the text across the Atlantic by short-wave radio.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: In all my years of writing I have never taken issue with a reviewer. If I make an exception this time it is because the subject of my book ("Hitler Cannot Conquer Russia") transcends in importance the feelings and the prestige of Mr. Chamberlin and myself.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- John L. Lewis today rejected President Roosevelt's request that he arrange for continuation of production at the "captive" mines owned by steel corporations, and the 53,000 employes of these mines will strike on the expiration of a truce at midnight.

CHICAGO. CORNELIA OTIS SKINNER, who used to go it alone in drama, is apparently lost to that narrow field for some time to come. In "Theatre," a comedy by Somerset Maugham and Guy Bolton, she is demonstrating that she was justified in abandoning solo flights for the squadron formation John Golden has sent out over the midlands.

THE zoo is planning an insect house which will eventually contain a great collection of world-wide scope. As far as I know, it will be the first insect house at any American zoo. We shall have to develop the idea as it progresses, for while living animals have been collected from very early times, the annals of insect houses are short and simple.

Professor Alonzo F. Myers of the New York University School of Education, who made a personal survey of more than 100 educational institutions in a countrywide tour during the last year, declared in a report made public yesterday that there was a greater need for proper training of college teachers, and cited the examples of institutions of higher education on the West Coast which had already begun a trend toward satisfying that need.

THOSE who are old enough to remember the Nineteen Twenties will recall one curious fallacy of that decade, a belief more extraordinary than the prosperity that accompanied it. The victory over Germany and the efflorescence of invention that went with and followed the war staggered men's minds.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- unfavorable Russian war news and reports from Washington that the farm bloc's leaders might compromise on loans for basic farm products for the next two years at 90 per cent of parity if assured of price ceilings of 110 per cent of parity in the price-control bill, depressed prices of wheat and other grains today an the Board of Trade.

BREAD, milk, gasoline, furniture, flowers, new cars, building materials, ice boxes, beer, newspapers, ice cream and beef -- there are few items of American living that do not travel by truck in one or many stages of their manufacture and transportation to the consumer's hands.

A parade of 4,300 members of the services and veterans' and patriotic organizations down Fifth Avenue, and the launching of a small, fast submarine chaser of new design in the Harlem River at 177th Street, the Bronx, marked yesterday the opening of the twentieth annual observance of Navy Day here.

Campaign Homestretch William Learned Marcy, Troy lawyer and politician, was one of the "Albany Regency," a group of powerful Democrats so-called because they dominated New York politics in the Eighteen Twenties. As Controller under Governor Martin Van Buren, Marcy had a share in perfecting a system of rewards and punishments through dis- tribution of public offices and favors.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Oct. 25 -- One of the five P-40 Army pursuit planes missing since yesterday from a flight of nineteen from March Field, in Southern California, was found today on the slopes of Gray's Peak, sixty-five miles east of Fresno, with its pilot in the burned wreckage.

INCENTIVE and measure of performance are little used in the perpetual American battle for traffic safety. As the "forces of evil" retreat or gain by years, they register progress by decades with only the rate of increase being slowed.

Building managers in the financial district are accepting rentals which do not meet their expenses simply to get the cash to meet tax bills, according to the current issue of The Exchange, organ of the New York Stock Exchange. Rental levels, it adds, are the lowest in twenty years and about 2,000,000 square feet of downtown space lie unused.

A collection of incunabula or "cradle books," the earliest volumes printed from moveable type, will be placed on public sale tomorrow by Gimbel Brothers, according to an announcement by Frederick A. Gimbel, managing director.

A steadily rising demand for old-type houses in many parts of Westchester County and Connecticut is noted by Arthur F. Parrott, president of the Fish Marvin realty firm operating in Westchester County and adjacent areas of Connecticut.

Tomorrow will be the fourth anniversary of the Federal Reserve Board's slash in initial margin requirements, hailed at the time a a cooperative gesture by Washington to stabilize markets and stimulate price recovery. Since that move was made, conditions in the stock market have grown progressively worse.

THE phrase "education in a democracy" connotes not only high intention and earnest responsibility but complexity as well. In this slender but intellectually capacious volume eight members of the Department of Education of the University of Chicago examine the factors that go to make education a force in American life: its functions, responsibilities and problems.

A decline was noted in September open-market sales of Manhattan properties in number, dollar volume and percentage of assessed valuation realized, as compared with the figures for August, but the market last month was more active than in the same period last year, according to the monthly sales report of the Real Estate Board of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- A hot flame moving at a uniform rate of speed is the basis of a simplified and new method for detecting subsurface or concealed, flaws, such as cracks, gas bubbles and weaknesses, in metal castings, plates and other bodies.

President of Bennett College The dedication, next Sunday, of Annie Merner Pfeiffer Chapel and Little Theatre is of signal significance to the Bennett College community at Greensboro, N.C., and the friends of Bennett believe, to the cause of higher education for Negro women and what that cause means to a nation flexing its sinews of democracy for its greatest testing time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today, and reported to the Senate by a vote of 13 to 10, a measure to repeal all remaining important provisions of the Neutrality Act and thus untie the hands of the Administration in carrying out fundamental foreign policies.

Of all the fantastic activities into which an industry may be forced through Federal regulation those of the widely heralded, but now exploded, oil crisis along the Atlantic seaboard probably set a new high record, even exceeding those of the old blue-eagle days of tha National Recovery Administration, in which Secretary Harold Ickes of the Department of the Interior also played a colorful role as oil administrator.

LAWRENCE EDWARD WATKIN is still having good fun trying out various forms of literary prose expression. In "Gentleman from England" he also provides good fun, with assured American background, for American readers.

With the avowed purpose of helping to forestall inflation, the Federal Reserve Board's reserve requirements against deposits of its member banks will be lifted this week to the maximum permitted by law. The immediate result will be to cut approximately $1,000,000,000 from the existing $4,660,000,000 of excess reserves of these banks, with an estimated one-half of this cut affecting member banks in New York City.

The mounting demand last week for repeal of the Neutrality Act, resulting from the increased sinking of American shipping, again turned the spotlight of public interest on the war at sea, now entering its third Winter.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Staving off a touchdown bid late in the fourth quarter. New Rochell High School battled White Plains High, defending Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association champion, to a scoreless tie today. The deadlock enabled New Rochelle to remain unbeaten in four league games, three of which were victories, and hold its lead.

MELBOURNE, Australia. AUSTRALIA'S wartime theatre boom reached a climax a few weeks ago when the Minerva Theatre Company's production of "Susan and God" recorded its 100th performance at the Melbourne Comedy. Only two other plays have recorded 100 performances in Melbourne theatre history -- "Peg o' My Heart," in 1916, and "The Patsy," in 1927.

MEASURED by almost any standard, this is a great book. It is akin to the spirit of the indomitable Greeks in the most perilous days of the Persian invasions. We have been familiar for a long time with the nature of Mr. Dixon's writing, but in this he has outdone himself.
GLADSTONE, N.J., Oct. 25 -- The Duke and Duchess of Windsor arrived at the home of Mr. and Mrs. C. Suydam Cutting here tonight to spend a quiet week-end within the confines of the 5,000-acre estate.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 25 -- God's relation to man and to human history is to be the general theme of a series of twelve theology lectures to be given at the University of Virginia beginning tomorrow night and continuing until March 1.
Frank Tuma reports that the striped bass are really plentiful in the Montauk surf, with anglers taking as many as five a day and best results being had during the early morning and evening fishing.

Russia Holds Out From the frontier dividing East Prussia and Soviet Baltic territory before Hitler sent his legions into the east eighteen Sundays ago, it is about 535 miles by winding road to Leningrad. From the former boundary between German and Russian-held Poland, a main highway stretches 660 miles to Moscow.

COLLEGE girls drink beer now in preference to the cokes which their elder sisters consumed in quantity a decade or so ago; Scotch is easier to get, and so also are week-end leaves off campus; so the endless dormitory conversations have a slicker patina of knowingness, are less speculative; otherwise both girls and conversations are much the same.

WOULD you know the traditional cottage recipe for haggis -- and then learn "haggis royal" as well? Would you understand the precise intricacies of that barley broth which so surprised and delighted Dr. Johnson in Aberdeen?

TELEPATHY is a subject of which little is known and a word which is used with more frequency than sound acquaintance. In a clear, unsensational and, in some chapters, charming book, one of the foremost of present-day "sensitives" has set down the results of personal study and experience in telepathy, and has given the public an authoritative introduction to an interesting quest.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 25 -- Cutting loose with two decisive touchdown thrusts, one in the first period, the other in the last, the Purple Crusaders of Holy Cross conquered a valiantly fighting New York University eleven today by a score of 13 to 0.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick continued last night, over the radio, his attacks on Lloyd Church, his Democratic opponent, for the conduct of real estate reorganization cases under Mr. Church when he was a Supreme Court Justice.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 25 -- Texas's mighty scoring machine rolled on today over a Rice Institute team that never had a chance. 40 -- 0. Smarting from a 13-0 upset at the hands of the Owls last year, the unbeaten Texas team, aided by reserves chalked up its second Southwest Conference victory and fifth consecutive triumph.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 25 -- The University of Mississippi's fast little Rebel football team ran the socks off Tulane's big and supposedly fast team today, knocking the Green Wave out of any posaible bowl consideration with a 20-13 upset before 45,000 spectators.

The Brooklyn Dodgers will attempt to check the rush of the New York Giants to the Eastern championship of the National Football League today when the interborough rivals clash at Ebbets Field. The kick-off is scheduled for 2:15 o'clock.

Arguments against the defense of America were described last night by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, as "futile gestures of protest." Dr. Chase spoke at class-day exercises of the Evening Division of the College of Engineering on the Heights campus in the Bronx.

ALEXANDRE TANSMAN, after some nightmarish years in Paris and in unoccupied France, has returned to America, where he had not been since the happier days before Hitler of 1933. Mr. Tansman did not wish to talk very much concerning his personal experiences.

The development of suitable substitutes for materials now included in the OPM's defense housing critical list is the most urgent task now confronting American architects, builders and manufacturers of building materials, says Joseph J. Ott of Ott Handren, architects.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25 -- While the Republicans in Congress have focused their attacks on New Deal foreign policy, actually one of the greatest criticisms which the American people have against the Roosevelt Administration today is not its handling of foreign policy but its handling of strikes and the labor situation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Defense officials predicted today that adoption of the new "victory" military program would mean the virtual cessation next year of the manufacture of durable goods for consumers. Outstanding lines thus to suffer will include automobiles, refrigerators, stoves, washing machines and similar items.

BERLIN, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Reichfuehrer Hitler conferred with Count Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, for two hours today at the German front headquarters in a meeting officially described as occurring "in the spirit of their two countries' proven comradeship in arms."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The National Defense Mediation Board has approved recommendations by Mgr. Francis A. Haas, suggesting that the board reprimand a shop committee of a C.I.O. local which called an unauthorized strike in February in the Vanadium Steel Company's plant at Bridgeville, Pa.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25 -- Harvard's first comprehensive survey of the National Scholarship Plan, established by President Conant in 1934, was issued by the lean's office today, revealing the "remarkable record" made by the 161 scholars during the first six years of the plan.
SEATTLE, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Stanford defeated the University of Washington at football today, 13 to 7, to emerge as Pacific Coast Conference leader.

There is nothing dull about that Fordham football team. The Rams struck Texas Christian with cyclone force for 14 easy points in the first quarter of their Polo Grounds battle yesterday, petered out to a mild zephyr while the Horned Frogs made 14 of their own, and then drove the Texans to the storm-cellars again with a 14point outburst in the final session.

THE present season is obviously going out for a record. Not only has it already scheduled more performances before Nov. 1 than whole seasons used to contain fifteen years ago, presented two ballet companies concurrently for the first time, and introduced a distinguished debutante in the recital field (Sybil Shearer) first crack out of the box, but now it announces quite the most impressive educational event that it has yet sponsored.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra begins its nineteenth season of Young People's Concerts Saturday morning at Carnegie Hall. There will be six concerts in Carnegie Hall and three Monday afternoons at Town Hall under the direction of Rudolph Ganz.

With the free labor movement of most of Continental Europe driven underground or crushed under Hitler's heel, delegates from thirty-three nations will assemble here tomorrow for the first world labor conference since the Nazi invasion of Poland in September 1939.

AMONG the dozens of books that tell the inexperienced listener how to become experienced in hearing music there are an honorable few that refuse to sugar-coat the subject. Add to this group of adult and forthright writers the name of Theodore M. Finney, who does not sell "appreciation" as if it were a new gadget for your motor car, nor does he indulge in long and wordy panegyrics about "culture."

BENDIX, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Five hundred non-striking employes of Air Associates, Inc., returned to work on $5,000,000 worth of defense contracts today, following the settlement in Washington last night of the twenty-five-day strike involving fifty to seventy-five memmembers of the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers Union, Aircraft Division.

Visitors to Princeton University admire the handsome Gothic-style buildings on the campus -- so fitting to an atmospnere of learning -- but are likely to be mystified by the "vines" which decorate them. Seeing plants in an unusual situation is like meeting a movie star in old clothes; recognition doesn't always click on first glance.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 25 -- One cheerful sentence in an otherwise pessimistic speech made today by Senator Hughes of Delaware caused rejoicing among members of the National Woman's Party, gathered here for its joint national biennial conference and Eastern regional conference.

YORK, Pa. -- Coasting down the grade from Red Lion, the York Mail out of Baltimore on the Maryland Pennsylvania rolled into this onetime capital of the nation, now booming with defense work, at 11:35 A.M., exactly on time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- John L. Lewis's refusal today to accede to President Roosevelt's request that captive mines keep operating while contract difficulties are ironed out appears to point to a showdown between the President of the United States and the head of the United Mine Workers.
