WASHINGTON. THERE were two reasons for doing an interview with John Ford. First of all, he is Commander Ford, presently in Washington as head of a newly formed photographic unit which has brought many of Hollywood's ace camera men to active service under the Navy Department; Mr. Ford probably will make no more films for some time to come.

TORONTO -- Wendell L. Willkie, Admiral Richard E. Byrd, James A. Farley, Mayor La Guardia, Edward G. Barrow of the Yankee baseball club, Adolphe Menjou and Ginger Rogers of the movies are among United States citizens who have donated philatelic material for the National Patriotic Auction for Britain's Air Raid Victims which is to be held here on Nov. 21 and 22 by the Canadian Philatelic Society.

"SEASON'S GREETINGS" is a story that pulses with feeling for the complex and comprehensive personality of New York. Like many other people, Mr. Lewis finds the city grimly, grotesquely and grandly fascinating, with much to admire and despise, to love and to hate.
THIS month's complement of American works on records brings albums of music by Deems Taylor, Ferde Grofe and Harl McDonald.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 25 -- The next few months will see a sizable increase in Turkey's force of British Hurricanes and American-made Curtiss Tomahawks. Two consignments of American Tomahawks, released from British quarters in the Middle East, have already reached Turkey, it was learned today.

Three major committees supporting Mayor La Guardia will spend not more than $185,000, of which $70,327 will go for printing and distributing literature, it was testified yesterday at the investigation of District Attorney O'Dwyer's charges that $1,000,000 was being spent by the La Guardia forces.
ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 25 -- Coach Steve Sorota's undefeated Andover eleven crushed the Bowdoin freshmen, 25 -- 0, today.

Believing that a post-war depression can only be avoided by careful study and preparation, the General Electric Company has set up a special planning committee to study the entire post-war situation and to make recommendations as to how it should be met, David C. Prince, manager of the company's commercial engineering department and chairman of the new committee, stated in an interview last week.

WITH its clear, bright colors, its simplicity that eliminates confusing details and the zestful activity of its hero. "Curious George" is an ideal picture book for the 3-to-5-year-old. This is the tale of a monkey whose irresistible curiosity brings him down from his palm tree to inspect and try on the yellow hat deposited on the ground by the hat's owner with that very result in view.

To the Radio Editor: GUESTS who are invited to take part in the broadcasts of the People's Platform are always urgently instructed not to speak when others are speaking, not to quarrel or make points for the sake of putting some one else in the wrong and to remember always that quiet discussions are the most dramatic.

In a game marked by long runs including a 69-yard dash by Bill Wiley of the winners and a 98-yard run by Navio Ottavi of the losers. Wagner College defeated the New Britain (Conn.) Teachers eleven yesterday, 20 to 18, at Grymes Hill S.I.A Homecoming Day crowd of 1,500 saw the encounter.

THIS second novel by the author of "She Married a Doctor" continues the high promise shown in the first novel: it has the same fullness, freshness, suffused with a novelist's true sentience. Through deft writing the Boston of 1721 comes alive the vigor and excitement of this lusty but benighted period is given its full value.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: WHEN you wrote your Oct. 12 editorial deploring the lack of good, old-fashioned, full-bodied humor in present-day American novels you came into my own back yard. For years that has been my own opinion and I have tried by many means to make up in part for the deficiency.
THE news that Louis Armstrong has been celebrating his silver Jubilee as a professional musician these days is in many ways significant of the passing of an era in jazz.

The Citizens Union yesterday summarized its advice to voters on the seven questions, four State constitutional amendments and three local county reorganization propositions, that will appear on the top line of the voting machines on election day, recommending a negative vote on the first and last two and an affirmative vote on the middle three.

ARTURO TOSCANINI has not yet told the Philharmonic-Symphony Society what he intends to play at the special two-week post-season centennial festival he will conduct with the orchestra. But this much seems fairly certain.

BRITISH bombing-plane crews reported on their return from a recent foray into Germany that at one point they encountered a storm which, without any display of lightning, cloaked their aircraft in a bright, blue, wavering glow.
"Grease monkey" ensembles were displayed yesterday in a preview of smart fashions for wartime in a benefit show for the British American Ambulance Corps at the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center.
LONDON -- British philately plans to raise a minimum of $50,000 for the national Red Cross organization on Dec. 30 through Jan. 1 by auctioning rare pieces donated by British collectors.

FREEDOM: War Aim A recent letter in THE TIMES signed by A.J. Bourrienne says: "All Europe is not worth the life of one American soldier." This is an evil statement. No one is asking any American soldier to die for Europe; the battle is for the freedom of man -- including the American people.
Jesus was characterized as a master psychologist in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. George Caleb Moor, pastor of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church at Thirty-first Street.

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 27 -- Royal Air Force raiders harried the the Germans from the Netherlands to the Breton Peninsula yesterday. They damaged three ships in a convoy off the Netherlands coast and shot up freight trains, oil trucks and barges, a radio station and airfields in and around Dieppe, Cherbourg and Brest.

A "bill of particulars" was submitted yesterday by Robert Daru, attorney for the Democratic campaign committee, in an attempt to sustain the charge of District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic Mayoralty candidate, that more than $1,000,000 was being spent by his opponents in the city campaign.

A strike of the 6,000 employes of the Robins Drydock and Repair Company, which has shipbuilding yards at the foot of Dwight Street, Brooklyn, and holds defense ship repair contracts as well as contracts for the repair of British merchantmen, was called last night for 7 o'clock this morning.

TOBRUK, Libya, Oct. 26 -- I am writing this story in a concrete strong post in Tobruk's front line where I spent a night with a company of the Australian infantry battalion that helped the garrison to smash every enemy attempt to retake this stronghold during the last six months.

Characterizing the Mayor as "a political mountebank and charlatan," Edward J. Flynn, Democratic National Chairman and Bronx leader, declared last night that Mr. La Guardia was the political boss of the strongest municipal machine the country had ever known.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Prices of corn on the Board of Trade made little gain early last week when other grains and commodities were booming, but later they staged a rather independent rally on a spurt in cash corn buying and on increasing fear that the rainy Fall, which has left fields in the soggiest condition ever known, might cause some deterioration in the quality of the actual grain.

Sumner Welles, Mrs. Cordell Hull and five Ambassadors, three Ministers and nineteen consul generals from Latin-American countries are sponsoring the Inter-American. Music Fiesta, which will be given in Carnegie Hall tomorrow night under the auspices of Inter-America House to raise money for Pan-American music scholarships.
The State Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board ruled yesterday that insurance agents were not entitled to benefits under the State Unemployment Insurance Law.

America is paralyzed by indecision today because for the past quarter of a century we have been too busy discussing something else to heed Christ's message for this generation, the Rev. Jesse William Stitt, pastor of the Greenwich Presbyterian Church, 135 West Thirteenth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

The government of the City of New York, with its $667,000,000 budget, is a very large financial enterprise. As chief fiscal officer and adviser of the city the Controller occupies an important and responsible position in that government. He keeps the accounts and publishes the financial statements.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 -- Failure of Dr. A. Maude Royden, best known of Britain's women preachers, to appear in a church here today for a scheduled address brought disclosure that no word had been received from her since she sailed for this country in a convoy nearly one month ago.

ABOUT a year ago the publishing house of E.P. Dutton Co., in conjunction with the editors of The Virginia Quarterly Review, established the Thomas Jefferson Southern Award, by which a gold medal and $2,500 in cash is to be given annually for the best book manuscript submitted by a Southern author. The first winner is Elizabeth Lee Wheaton of Texas City, Texas, with a first novel called "Mr. George's Joint."*

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Repeal of the neutrality act's preamble reciting that this country desires to "preserve neutrality in wars between foreign States" was demanded today by Republican Senators supporting an Administration move to arm American merchant ships and permit them to enter belligerent ports.

BERLIN, Oct. 26 (AP) -- German armored and infantry divisions have broken Russian resistance "on a broad front" on the sector before Moscow, D.N.B., the official German news agency, stated tonight, after fierce fighting that included a number of German surprise attacks.
As Germany struggles deeper into Russia, today -- Navy Day, 1941 -- emphasizes more fully than any other has done the real meaning of sea power.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Captain Alexander J.M. Tuck gave a luncheon today at the Tuxedo Club for his debutante daughter, Miss Eugenie M. Tuck, and his debutante niece, Miss Emily Tuck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Hallam Tuck.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 26 -- Charles Davila, for nine years Rumanian Minister to the United States and once a leading figure in the Rumanian National Peasant party of Juliu Maniu, announced today his intention to form a Rumanian National Committee to work for a free Rumania.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Supply contracts totaling $8,311,951.87 were awarded yesterday by the War Department. Among the awards were the following, not previously published, which went to concerns in the New York area:

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Dangerous though the threat to Moscow has become, the City continues to express the greatest confidence in the outcome of the struggle. It noted without apprehension the first changes in the Russian Army command made since the Russian campaign started.

As the city campaign entered its final week, with heavy speaking schedules listed on both sides [Page 11, Column 2], Mayor La Guardia brought the issue of county reform into the forefront, demanding that the Democratic leaders put themselves on record.

In line with the victory program of greatly expanded arms production hints came from Washington last week that defense officials may eventually suggest that creation of desire in the minds of the public through advertising at a time when civilian goods are scarce, is not advisable.

Orders fell off in the apparel market last week as retail business turned sluggish. A temporary lull in store activity throughout the country was reflected in the coat and dress markets. Buyers in the market felt that the new print lines would stimulate the dress business.

Through the welter of Sunday evening traffic, the Duke and Duchess of Windsor were driven back last night without escort to the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria from the home of Kenneth B. Schley in Lamington, N.J., where they concluded a brief "holiday."

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 26 -- Governor Charles Edison today discussed the Nazi threat to organized labor and to American women at a conference for women members sponsored by the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, District 4, C.I.O., at the Hotel Douglas here.
CAMDEN, S.C., Oct. 26 -- The first Army, in the midst of final manoeuvres of its training year, will lose about 20 per cent of its personnel between December and March, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Butter and fresh pork have been added to the list of foods that are available for purchase with the official blue stamps by families participating in the government's "food stamp" program, according to an announcement today by the Department of Agriculture.
ROME, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

Convening for the first time since the outbreak of the war, the International Labor Organization, an arm of the League of Nations, will meet here this morning with thirty-three nations represented, including some overrun by Nazi armies, to buttress the resistance of the democracies in their struggle against totalitarianism.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 26 -- Miss Barbara Kent, a 22-year-old British war nurse, and Helen Peek, 24, of Fairfield, Conn., both licensed pilots, took off today in a twoplace Piper Cub Cruiser monoplane on a three-week good-will visit to twelve cities in behalf of Bundles for Britain, Inc.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 26 -- "Uncle Clem's Boy," the biography of Will Rogers written by his widow, Mrs. Betty Rogers, has been purchased by Warner Brothers for an estimated $140,000. The sale, regarded as one of the most important of the year, was concluded following spirited bidding by all major studios.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Census Bureau has reported that 6,855,808 running bales of cotton of this year's growth, counting round as half bales and excluding lintners, had been ginned to Oct. 18, compared with 7,027,189 bales a year ago, and 8,874,291 bales two years ago.

Jarrin John Kimbrough played fifty-six minutes of football at the Yankee Stadium yesterday and the verdict of a crowd of 11,866 completely forgave the former Texas Aggie for his lukewarm showing of a week ago. Apparently in excellent shape after six days of practice, Kimbrough carried the ball nineteen times, pained 84 yards and paced the New York Americans to a 31-14 victory over Buffalo in their American League encounter.
Clark, Kohl Eyman have prepared an analysis of the effect on the Boston Maine Railroad preferred stocks of the opening of Boston Harbor for shipments to Great Britain, Iceland and Russia.

ROME, Oct. 26 -- In a battle between Italian torpedo planes and a British convoy said to be rushing supplies, including some from the United States, to Libya in preparation for a Winter offensive, the Italian High Command claimed tonight that the planes hit a British cruiser on Saturday in the "central part" of the Eastern Mediterranean.

Eddie O'Toole, sophomore star at Manhattan College, won his first championship in Van Cortlandt Park yesterday when he led a starting field of fifty in the Metropolitan A.A.U. junior crosscountry title event.

A bronze tablet honoring the inventive genius of Colonel Richard March Hoe, designer and builder of the rotary printing press, was unveiled yesterday morning in St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church of Morrisania, St. Ann's Avenue and East 140th Street, the Bronx, where Mr. Hoe served as a vestryman for twenty years.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Jews living in Bessarabia and Bukovina are being banished by Rumanian authorities into ghettos established in the neighborhood of the Bug River in the Russian Ukraine, the official news agency Rador announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles gained their second National Football League victory today, piling up a 21-0 lead and then withstanding a savage second-half assault by the Chicago Cardinals. The final score was 21 to 14, with the Cardinals' bid for the tying touchdown ending on the Eagles' 5-yard line.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 26 -- The strike that has kept this city without traffic or newspapers for more than a week was finally settled last night following a conference between President Enrique Penaranda de Castillo and labor delegates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Senate debate on its Foreign Relations Committee's recommendation for repeal of all remaining substantial provisions of the Neutrality Act will occupy the spotlight on Capitol Hill this week to the practical exclusion of everything else.
KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Oct. 26 -- With Moscow under martial law, infringements against military discipline there are being summarily punished.

CLANTON, Ala., Oct. 26 (AP) -- At least fourteen persons were burned to death tonight in a flame enveloped Montgomery-to-Birmingham bus which struck a concrete bridge railing and caught fire four miles south of here.

TOKYO, Oct. 26 -- Speaking today in Osaka to 200 higher officials the new Premier, General Hideki Tojo reiterated that Japan's policies were "immutable and irrevocable," and there would be "no going back."

NEW YORK Miss Faith Griswold Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Griswold Hall of 1120 Fifth Avenue, will be introduced to society at a dinner dance to be given by her parents Dec. 26 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- While Friday's stock market displayed a slight reactionary tendency, the week's course of prices again was slightly upward. The bond index reached a new wartime record and the industrial index also moved up a trifle.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- "A better-than-normal" buyer attendance at the American Furniture Mart and a 20 per cent increase in registrations at the Merchandise Mart will probably greet the one-week Fall furniture market here when it opens Nov. 3, a check-up of sentiment at the two exhibit centers indicated.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Oct. 26 -- There recently has been a similarity of movements in the stock markets in continental European countries which has become noticeable. It may be attributed perhaps to the fact that their economic and financial developments are running more nearly parallel.

Girl Scout Sunday was observed throughout the city yesterday with group attendance of girls in uniform at special services held in their honor at St. Patrick's Cathedral, the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East Ninetieth Street, and at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixtyfifth Street.
"Minnesota isn't as good a team as its record."

PROMISED LAND, L.I., Oct. 26 -- Coot or sea duck shooting as practiced along that stretch of tide-troubled water from Maine to Carolina is usually a casual form of sport, pursued with a minimum of ritual and practically no preparation, but the annual coot shoot of the Associated Perspicillata Poppers of Promised Land is an affair excelled in pomp and circumstance only by a royal coronation.

A vacant plot 60 by 100 feet on the east side of Bay Twenty-eighth Street, 160 feet south of Eighty-sixth Street, in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, has been sold by the estate of Gustave Wolburg to Samuel Glushein for improvement with three two-family dwellings.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- The Chicago Bears, only undefeated team in the National Football League, walloped the Pittsburgh Steelers today, 34 to 7, for their fifth straight victory in the title race.

Effective resistance to unwarranted demands of pressure groups will remain a major necessity in Federal finance, according to the current issue of The Guaranty Survey, published by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

VICHY, France, Oct. 26 -- The execution of 100 more Frenchmen in Nantes and Bordeaux in reprisal for the killing of two German officers may yet be stayed. Such were the indications tonight in dispatches from Paris through German censorship that said information furnished by various French sources had narrowed the scope of the inquiries into the killing of officers at Nantes and Bordeaux.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Advancing farm prices and improving demand growing out of the defense program are enabling the Government to reduce its huge stocks of surplus agricultural products.

Although "all the subversive forces in the world today have as their common and diabolical objective the exclusion of the King of Peace from the affairs of State," the struggle, "as old as creation," is doomed to failure, according to the Rev. Robert E. Woods, who preached yesterday, the Feast of Christ the King, at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

In connection with a major change in the organization of the General Electric Company, five new vice presidents have been elected by the board of directors, Charles E. Wilson, president, announced yesterday. They are Walter R.G. Baker, Chester H. Lang, David C. Prince, Elmer D. Spicer and Harry A. Winne.

Familiar British Names When a sharp war debate in the House of Commons finds a Wedgwood arrayed against an Eden it suggests that not only will there always be an England but that very likely some of the old English names will also be there.

Edgar J. Nathan, fusion candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, declared last night in a radio address that Tammany would like the people of the city to change the "real theme" of the municipal campaign, "lest we forget," to "let us forget."

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Three stakes were completed today, the third day of the eighteenth annual meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association. Two of these events are among the most important in American spaniel competition and the trophies the most desired by all amateur trainers and handlers.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 26 -- Less disturbing news from the Russian front and the passage by the House Agricultural Committee of the proposal to increase the parity loan basis on leading commodities from 85 to 100 per cent gave cotton futures enough boost after the middle of last week to turn earlier losses of $1.75 a bale into net gains exceeding $1 by late Friday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Arrangements have been made for a portrait of Rachel Donelson Jackson, who died just before her husband, "Old Hickory," was inaugurated as President, to be placed in the "Gallery of First Ladies" at the White House.

The Mayoralty campaign enters its final week today, with Mayor La Guardia and William O'Dwyer, opposing candidates, scheduled for a crowded period of vigorous campaigning. The Mayor's efforts will be designed to hold the favorable position he is now considered to enjoy, while Mr. O'Dwyer and his associates on the Democratic ticket planned to attempt to prove the Mayor vulnerable on city government issues.

Strange things happen at Ebbets Field, and another gem in a startling collection was supplied yesterday as the thrice-beaten Brooklyn Dodgers burst the bubble of Giant invincibility by vanquishing the New Yorkers, 16 to 13, and handing them their first setback after five straight triumphs.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Oct. 26 -- John Fucci, 61 years old, of 167 Devoe Street, Brooklyn, was killed last night in the back yard of his small Summer home on Railroad Street by a blast from a shotgun fired from the adjoining yard. His neighbor, John Messano, 51, of 565 Hendrix Street, Brooklyn, was arrested today and charged with the shooting.

Irish pipers led the parade in the upper West Side yesterday afternoon that began the annual rally of West Side Manhattan Holy Name Society. Many bands were in line with members of the society, and uniformed Knights of St. John, Catholic War Veterans and Spanish-speaking Catholics took part.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 26 -- The British forces in Malaya tested their defense against air-borne attack in large-scale war games yesterday and early today.

The fear is frequently expressed that in waging total war the democracies may lose the very thing for which they are fighting. Even though political democracy survives the war, it is feared that the strains of post-war reconstruction may prove too much for it; that a disillusioned and pessimistic people will turn despairingly to the totalitarian principle for the sake of stronger leadership and greater security.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- President Roosevelt called on all Americans today to sacrifice "personal, sectional and group interests in order that we may remain united and unconquerable."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board revised today its installment-credit regulations, effective Dec. 1, in order, it said, to close some loopholes and ease some restrictions.

New York City served as host for the first time in twenty years to the annual convention of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association the past week-end. Judging by the comment from the record representation that left last night for points north and south--eleven States had delegates-the two-day meeting was the best since six clubs founded the association back in 1922 at Saranac Lake.

The clamor in England for an offensive in the west grows louder as the Germans inch closer to Moscow and threaten to occupy Rostov, bridgehead of the Caucasus. It is serious enough to worry the British Government and compel members of the Cabinet to go about the country explaining why an immediate invasion of the Continent is not militarily feasible.

Ed Wynn's ambitious road version of "Boys and Girls Together," which opened a tour in Newark last Sept. 5, with hopes of appearing in all of the forty-eight States, will close prematurely in St. Louis on Nov. 8, Mr. Wynn announced in Cincinnati yesterday.

BERLIN, Oct. 26 (AP) -- German bankers are rapidly spreading their influence over Europe behind German forces of occupation. The German financial publication Bank-Archive drew attention today to the expansion of German banks into France and into Eastern and Southeastern Europe.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Oct. 27 -- Russian radio spokesmen acknowledged this morning that the German stranglehold on the Donets Basin had been tightened, and the Red Army communique announced the evacuation of the important city of Stalino [already claimed by the Germans] after several days of hard fighting in which more than 50,000 Germans were killed or wounded.

Farrar Rinehart, sponsors of the Latin-American Prize Novel contest won by Ciro Alegria, has announced a new Latin-American literary competition. This contest, like the novel competition, will be undertaken with the Division of Intellectual Cooperation of the Pan-American Union and will offer $5,000 for three books -- $2,000 for the best novel, $2,000 for the best nonfiction work, $1,000 for a juvenile.

With several "significant matters" pending before two extraordinary grand juries, including an inquiry into charges of police graft for protecting organized gambling in Brooklyn, John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor declared yesterday that actions resulting from his investigation had been 9C per cent successful in the lower courts and entirely successful in the appellate courts and that the inquiry had been virtually self-supporting through restitutions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- In an eleventh hour appeal to John L. Lewis and his associate officers of the United Mine Workers, "as loyal citizens, to come now to the aid of your country," President Roosevelt tonight called for reconsideration of the decision which ended the truce in the captive coal mines of big steel corporations and resulted in the calling out of 53,000 workers on strike.

The bright young lads of New York's East Side may not believe, as did the heathen Celts of ancient Britain, that Oct. 31 brings the night when ghosts are most likely to walk abroad and witches ride forth on errands of mischief. But they have plenty of superstitions of their own, it was disclosed yesterday in the returns of a pre-Halloween census taken at the Madison Square Boys' Club.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 26 -- A resolution demanding that the International Labor Office Convention, which opens tomorrow in New York, take active recognition of the equality of men and women in industry was adopted here today by the National Woman's Party, holding a week-end biennial conference in the Hotel du Pont.

IT gets complicated now. A couple of weeks ago everybody was talking about Navy and feeling a little bit sorry for Army in a football way. But the way they were going the other day, nobody need feel sorry for Army any more. Those Kaydets might do all right for themselves when they meet the Midshipmen from the banks of the sedgy Severe.

DETROIT, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The opportunist Green Bay Packers achieved their season's sixth National Football League victory in seven tries today by turning the Detroit Lions' mistakes into touchdowns to win, 24 to 7, before 30,269 spectators.

A denial that radio station WOR or the Mutual network had refused radio time to the America First rally next Thursday night at Madison Square Garden was made yesterday by a WOR spokesman, who quoted from a letter in which an America First official admitted the committee's own dilatory tactics had been to blame.

A feature of the Navy Ball to be given Nov. 26 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria by the Navy League of the United States and Bundles for Britain, will be the auctioning of the Queen's Birthday Book, a volume of portraits and autographs of royalty published in 1887 in London for the Golden Jubilee of Queen Victoria.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The United States Government has developed in the past fifteen months a vast uncoordinated defense information service which will cost more than $10,000,000 in the current fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- "I have no comment of any character."

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices declined from 98.3 to 97.7, thus marking a downtrend for the third consecutive week. The sharpest price decreases again occurred in agricultural raw materials and foodstuffs, especially cotton, hogs, cattle, cottonseed oil, meats and flour.

The resignation of Gradwell L. Sears as general sales manager of Warner Brothers and the appointment of Ben Kalmenson as his successor were announced over the week-end by Major Albert Warner, vice president and treasurer. Mr. Sears, who had been with the company twenty-one years, also resigned as president of Vitagraph, Inc., the Warners' distributing agency.

Cotton prices moved over a fairly wide range last week, but the market closed the period with moderate net losses. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts closed on Saturday at net losses for the week of 6 to 15 points.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, in the Western Desert, Oct. 26 -- The terrific bombings now being administered to the Naples waterfront by heavy Royal Air Force aircraft are being watched with special enthusiasm by the army and air force commanders on the Libyan front.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Oct. 26 -- Fort Monmouth's football team, composed of former college and high school stars, overwhelmed the Perth Amboy Greyhounds. 25 to 0, on the Army post gridiron today before a crowd of more than 5,000.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Lord Beaverbrook's review of aid for Russia in the House of Lords on Thursday, while mainly confirming known facts, revealed some new facts about commodities. British supplies to Russia include wheat from the British Government's Canadian reserve and sugar from the United Kingdom's stocks.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Little Loyola University's gallant football team played the role of giant killer for half a football game today, but had to yield to the seasoned St. Mary's Gaels in a bruising clash before a capacity crowd of 18,500.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll calls in Congress during the period Oct. 18 to 24 are given in the appended tabulation:

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Ten thousand supporters of various labor groups in this country, gathered in Trafalgar Square this afternoon for an "aid to Russia" rally, shout- ed down speakers who suggested that any offensive on the western front now would be premature.

The greatest fleet in American history will celebrate Navy Day today guarding the ramparts of our defense -- the oceans. There will be no "open house" at navy yards or aboard the fighting ships. The men of the fleet will spend this day as they have spent many in the months past -- standing by their guns ready for action.

Professor George W. Hartmann, Socialist candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that Mayor La Guardia had permitted a situation to exist in the Department of Sanitation as corrupt as existed in the heyday of Tammany.

Lower rentals to be paid by tenants and a saving to the city of more than $1,500,000 over a period of fifty years will result from an important departure in the method of applying State aid to a local housing project, it was learned yesterday, when Edward Weinfeld, State Commissioner of Housing, announced that the State had lent the New York City Housing Authority $7,100,000.

The series of card parties held annually in various communities throughout Westchester County by members of the Westchester Smith College Club for the benefit of their scholarship fund is now in progress and will continue throughout the first week in November.

Asserting that it was unquestionably on the program of President Roosevelt and Mayor La Guardia to break up the two-party system, John R. Davies declared yesterday that Republicans in New York City now faced the question whether they should vote for the Mayor, who was supported by New Dealers, Communists and other left-wing elements in the electorate opposed to everything for which the Republican party stands.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., Oct. 26 -- Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills and Jimmy Hines of Lakeville finished all even at 73 strokes in the three-way play-off for the Long Island P.G.A. championship over the Oceanside Golf Club course today. Ernie Catropa of Idlewild, third member of the match, trailed with a card of 79.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A brilliant first-half aerial attack, featuring Slingin' Sammy Baugh and Frank Filchock, gave the Washington Redskins a 17-13 victory over the stubborn Cleveland Rams in a National Football League game before 32,820 spectators today.

In making public its recommendations on candidates for judicial office in Manhattan and the Bronx, the Citizens Union announced yesterday its endorsement of Supreme Court Justice Alfred H. Townley, General Sessions Judge George L. Donnellan and Bronx County Judge James M. Barrett in recognition of a full term of satisfactory service by each of these candidates for reelection.

Assets of the National Bond and Investment Company are to be acquired for cash at their approximate book value by the Commercial Credit Company, according to a joint announcement made yesterday by the chairmen of the boards of the two companies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- The Treasury Department is preparing the most elaborate plan of tax collection in American history for use when the higher income taxes come due in March.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

Seven new films will have local premieres during the week. The first arrival is "The King," French satirical farce starring Raimu with Victor Francen, Gaby Morlay and Elvire Popesco, which opens today at the Fifth Avenue Playhouse. This evening the film will be shown as a benefit for the American-French War Relief, Inc.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Such of Park Commissioner Moses' report on slum clearance as was quoted in THE TIMES of Oct. 20 vitalizes, as the Commissioner's reports always do, striking emergency and post-emergency problems.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 -- Last midnight the threat of a captive mine strike materialized when John L. Lewis ignored President Roosevelt's request that the mines operated by steel companies and furnishing important material for steel production continue operations pending further negotiations.

Four leading members of the New York tea trade met over the week-end at the tea laboratories of the United States Food and Drug Administration in Varick Street and sipped their tea expertly decided on the standard for judging the 2,100,000 pounds of black tea the Army will buy during the next year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The execution of hostages is being obviously and deliberately developed into a basic technique of Nazi government in conquered Europe. Over and above the horror of the deeds themselves, this practice raises three alarming dangers for the future.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 -- Last midnight the threat of a captive mine strike materialized when John L. Lewis ignored President Roosevelt's request that the mines operated by steel companies and furnishing important material for steel production continue operations pending further negotiations.

Appointment of forty-one students representing eight colleges in the metropolitan area as research associates in the Department of Investigation was announced yesterday by Commissioner William B. Herlands. The appointments were made in pursuance of Mayor La Guardia's policy of "interneship for public service" established in 1938.

Citing the drop in juvenile delinquency that has followed the vast expansion of parks and playgrounds in New York City in the last eight years, Robert Moses Commissioner of Parks, condemned the Board of Education yesterday for failure to cooperate by opening hundreds of gymnasiums after school hours.

It's pretty and it's practical, the brand-new beverage that looks like a milk shake of peaches and cream, and packs enough vitamins to invigorate an army. The lovely, pastel-pink mixture is a combination of tomato juice and -- amazing -- acidophilous milk!

Settlement of the twenty-four-day strike at the Bendix, N.J., plant of Air Associates, Inc., arranged in Washington last Friday, hit a snag yesterday when union and company spokesmen disagreed in their interpretations of the agreement.

The premiere of "The Land Is Bright," one of the most important openings of the current season to date, in which George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber are reunited as collaborators for the first time in five years, is set for tonight at the Music Box.

An effort to restrain the New York Dress Institute by injunction from collecting its "tyrannical advertising tax" was decided upon last night at a mass meeting of dress manufacturers sponsored by the Dress Manufacturers Forum in the Hotel Astor.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday its recommendations for judicial and county offices in Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond. For the Supreme Court, which takes in the three areas, the group endorsed Philip M. Kleinfeld, Democrat, now on the bench by appointment, and Jonn B. Johnston, ending a fourteen-year term and unopposed by a major party candidate.

The United States is "flying planes to Europe every day and the distance from there to here is no greater than the distance from here to there," Mayor La Guardia warned 15,000 persons yesterday at the Brooklyn Defense Day rally sponsored by Brooklyn College and affiliated organizations and held on the college's campus.

A confectionary as dainty as a doll's house decorates a sedate city street and enchants the passerby. The candy store with its fuschia woodwork and pale blue-and-silver wallpaper is the captivating little sister of an elder shop that bears a distinguished name.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27 -- The navies of the United States and Great Britain will keep the sea lanes open, "wherever they may lead," Rear Admiral John W. Greenslade, commandant of the Twelfth Naval District, said at a Navy Day luncheon today.

An alleged German espionage agent took the witness stand in his own behalf yesterday at the espionage trial in Brooklyn and testified that his devotion to the country of his adoption, the United States, had cost him his $30,000-a-year position as managing director of the Ford Motor Company In Germany.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 27 -- A cursory glance at the record of the Williams College football team may give one the impression that the undergraduates are walking on air, setting nightly bonfires atop "grand old Greylock" and generally singing the praises that accompany victory.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Consolidation of the National Youth Administration with the Civilian Conservation Corps, under the Federal Security Agency, was suggested today by President Roosevelt.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's Navy Day address as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES from a radio broadcast:
DETROIT, Oct. 27 -- Complete repeal of the Neutrality Act was urged today by Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, in a speech made at a "Navy and Total Defense Day luncheon" here today.

Trading was none too active in yesterday's wholesale markets. There was a moderate interest, however, in lamb and fresh pork cuts, and values were mostly strong. The demand, for beef was only fair; veal and calf slow; veal and calf were weak to lower and other classes mostly unchanged in price.

Stocky, bland Willie Bioff, the movie union leader, opened a surprise attack on his accusers in Federal court yesterday by taking the witness chair and testifying that he had done it all for "Joe" and "Nick" Schenck. That is, he liked to fly, and so he flew back and forth between California and New York gathering up "over a million dollars" and delivering it to Joseph M. Schenck, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation executive, he said.
BERLIN, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A communique issued today by Adolf Hitler's Headquarters:

Conrad Thibault, who appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night, ought to be one of America's best baritones. He has had a wealth of experience on the radio, in opera and other fields. His voice has the makings for a big singer, and his musical sensibilities are of no mean order.

E.C. Buchignani, an American Who has lived in France for the last six years, said yesterday on his arrival here aboard the Excambion that reprisal executions of French hostages by the German authorities would fail to put an end to attacks on German soldiers in the army of occupation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Supreme Court undertook today to rule on the question of how overtime pay must be computed under the wages and hours law. It agreed to review lower court decisions said to present the most far-reaching issue since the yalidity of the law was established.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Secretary Hull takes the position that the foreign policy of the United States is now based upon the primary consideration of self-defense, and that whatever steps are necessary must be taken to assure national safety against a move ment for world conquest led by Adolf Hitler.
Two hospital cases resulted from Sunday's gridiron struggle between the Giants and Dodgers, each team being hit equally, a check of casualties revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The old-fashioned ice box was dealt another blow today when Donald M. Nelson, director of priorities, ordered the nonmechanical refrigerator industry to cut its consumption of steel by 35 per cent in the period between Sept. 1, 1941, and Dec. 31, 1941.
Football heads into the second half of the campaign this week with a royal spread of succulent offerings.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Lord Halifax disclosed no secret in making the comment that the British were not in a position to open up a new Western Front. During the past few months the British and American press, as well as military officials of both countries, have repeatedly stressed the strenuous efforts we have been making to make up the shortage of arms and equipment in the Middle East.

Four proposed amendments to the State Constitution and three proposed changes in the City Charter will be offered for the consideration of New York City's voters next Tuesday. Taking them in their official order, this newspaper presents its interpretations and recommendations regarding each of these proposals.

The quarterly report of stock holdings in the United States Steel Corporation, issued yesterday, showed a small net decline in total number of shares held in other countries in the third quarter, but minor increases in net holdings in some of the countries.

The controversy about who first put holes in doughnuts was settled for the moment yesterday by a vote of delegates to the first annual convention of the National Dunking Association at the Hotel Astor. Seventy-five persons were present.

On the eve of hearings before the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce on proposed amendments to the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 the Commerce and Industry Association of New York issued yesterday a report in which it held that the proposals "would do little to relieve the needlessly burdensome restrictions now imposed by these laws and their administration on the financing of private business by private capital."

Mayor La Guardia and Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, were the principal speakers at groundbreaking ceremonies yesterday at the site of the proposed new Nightingale Hospital, an institution for the treatment of cancer, at 163d Street and Fort Washington Avenue.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, asked yesterday for reform of the Selective Service Act as it applies to college students. At the same tune he warned that demands upon institutions of higher education in the name of national defense carried with them the threat of jeopardy to the institutions' role as defenders of democracy.

PHILADELPHIA. Oct. 27 -- James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, told a Navy Day dinner audience tonight that the destroyer Kearny, torpedoed on Oct. 17, suffered an amount of damage which no other destroyer had ever received and remained afloat.

Department Store Sales Off 6% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 6 per cent for the week ended Oct. 25, in comparison with the same week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27 -- Rosalind Russell, who terminated a seven-year association with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer three weeks ago after finishing "Design for Scandal," has signed with Columbia to make two pictures a year for five years.

In 1841 Brooklyn had ceased to be a village seven years; hadn't yet married Williamsburg. A pretty good little village-city to live in. At its Lyceum you might hear Before the Mast Dana, Professor Woolsey of Yale, Dr. Holmes, Rufus Choate. And The Brooklyn Eagle had just begun to be.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., Oct. 27 -- Walter Ravold and Joe Turnesa, Rockville, and Jerry Adler and Frank Sarro, Inwood, finished even at 66 strokes, five under par, in the weekly amateur-pro golf tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. over the Oceanside links today.
Ben Collins, West Texas State halfback, tops the nation's football scorers with 87 points in six contests.

Joseph, Not Josef Who is this "Josef" Stalin that so many people and publications insist on? In his own Russian tongue he is Iosif. This form we encounter in a good many of our American library catalogues where they make it a point to preserve the original form of a foreign name as far as it can be done.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- In a Navy Day address here tonight Rear Admiral Harold R. Stark, Chief of Naval Operations, stressed the right of the naval and merchant vessels of the United States "to use the high seas for their legitimate ends, no man making them afraid."

We believe that the American people were fully prepared for the President's statement in his radio address last night that the shooting war has started. In point of fact, it started many months ago. The date of its beginning was not the September day when Mr. Roosevelt ordered the Navy to shoot at sight on any German warship entering our defensive waters.

Containing reductions of more than 10 per cent, a new schedule of liquor prices to be maintained under its fair-trade contracts with dealers was issued to retailers yesterday by National Distillers Products Corporation, in what was described by a spokesman for the organization as an effort "to establish some kind of order in price maintenance."

Continued expansion of national defense production by the General Motors Corporation and subsidiaries in the United States and Canada was announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, in a report for the third quarter of 1941.

For the first nine since March, 1940, the index of manufacturers' unfilled orders compiled by the National Industrial Conference Board declined in September. The dip was caused by the fact that new orders were off while shipments remained at about the same level as in August.
NEW YORK Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, who arrived last night from Washington, is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

ROME, Oct. 27 -- Haj Amin el Husseini, exiled Mufti of Jerusalem and chief foe of Britain in the Arab world, is in Rome today after what is described as an adventurous flight by plane from the Middle East.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- If war should come to the United States the people will look to the schools to take care of their children, James Marshall, president of the Board of Education of New York City, told members of the State School Boards Association at their annual meeting here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Many thousands of small manufacturing firms in the United States would be forced out of existence under the stepped-up national defense production program unless some special Federal help is granted to them.

Determined not to allow brutality to erase all beauty the women of a war-torn world have collaborated in arranging the eighteenth annual Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries that opened yesterday at Grand Central Palace, sponsored by the Women's National Institute.

A benefit supper dance was given last night at Fefe's Monte Carlo under the auspices of the American Friends of Britain, of which Mrs. George Seymour Repton is founder and national chairman. The proceeds will be donated to the Lord Mayor of London Fund to purchase warm, clothing for war-afflicted children of London.

Constructive, if True The major life insurance companies, commonly referred to as "the big five," refrained yesterday from participating directly in the bidding for an issue of $38,000,000 of Central Illinois Public Service Company 3 3/8 per cent bonds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- John L. Lewis's refusal to continue operations at the "captive" mines of the major steel corporations when requested to do so by President Roosevelt for the second time within forty-eight hours evoked a storm of criticism in both houses of Congress today with demands for immediate action by the Congress and the Chief Executive.

Eleven Canadian newspaper writers and editors, including a Bishop of the Church of England and a canon of the Roman Catholic Church, declared yesterday after arriving here from England that "total warfare," including an invasion of Germany, must be waged by "all the great nations of the world which are opposed to aggression" if Hitlerism is to be crushed.

Huge quantities of water cascading into the IRT subway just north of the Longwood Avenue station of the Pelham division from a break in a thirty-six inch main in the East Bronx disrupted service yesterday on the Pelham line for nine hours and twenty-four minutes and deprived 250,000 East Bronx residents of their normal means of transportation during the morning rush hour.
VICHY, France, Oct. 27 -- Nantes will not hear tomorrow of another execution of fifty hostages, nor will Bordeaux on Thursday morning it became known here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Nazi submarine warfare against United States naval and merchant vessels is an attack on America and "the shooting has started," President Roosevelt told the nation and the world tonight.

Coach Lou Little directed a rough-and-tumble scrimmage between the Columbia second-stringers and a combination of freshmen and scrubs yesterday while the varsity enjoyed a day of rest after Saturday's defeat at West Point.
LONDON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:
VICHY, France, Oct. 27 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's Labor Charter, heralded for months as the cornerstone of his National Revolution was published in the Journal Officiel today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- An Administration demand that America free itself from the shackles of her neutrality law and meet Adolf Hitler's challenge to the freedom of the seas was countered in the Senate today by a proposal that instead this government offer the Axis the alternative of "reasonable negotiations" or our all-out entry into the war.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 27 (AP) -- The billion-dollar tobacco industry's three largest companies, one subsidiary concern and thirteen executives were convicted today on charges of monopoly and price fixing in criminal violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.
When one coach praises another, it's news. When one coach nominates another as the greatest mentor in the game, it's almost a stop-press bulletin.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Britain's determination to renew strong protests against the continued Japanese detention of Graham Martyr and J.D. Mason, British subjects arrested early in September, was affirmed here today. The essential purpose Is to let Premier Hideki Tojo know -- If he had any doubt -- that whatever the outcome of the talks between Japan and the United States, the position taken by the United States will be fully backed by this country.

The State Court of Appeals dropped a bombshell into the city campaign yesterday by ruling out the election of a State Controller this year, thereby automatically continuing Joseph V. O'Leary, Lehman appointee, in office until Dec. 31, 1942.

A strike over a wage Issue by 5,800 C.I.O. workers at the huge Robins Drydock and Repair Company yards in Brooklyn tied up repairs on at least fourteen merchant ships yesterday morning and led the National Defense Mediation Board to urge utmost caution on both union and company "in the interest of national defense," pending mediation "at the earliest possible moment" by the board.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Now that the City Council has passed the measure to reinstate the water tax rates that existed prior to 1934, property owners are to be subjected to the wellknown squeeze play -- as the Mayor has already declared that the Council is without power to reduce the water rates which affect the rentals of a million families in this city.
Thirty-one colleges, large and small but all great on the football field, have elevens without a defeat or a tie as the gridiron season makes the turn into November.

A syndicate headed by Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., has received the award of an issue of $2,100,000 of bridge revenue bonds of Natchez, Miss., on a bid of 100.30 for 3s. The bonds, dated Nov. 1, 1941, will mature serially on Dec. 1, 1943 to 1956, and Dec. 1, 1958.
City realty transactions reported yesterday by brokers largely involved residential properties in Brooklyn and Manhattan. In the former borough a large apartment house went into new ownership.
Victories by Feathery and Pumpgun in the fourth and fifth races, respectively, enabled Owner C.U. Yaeger, Trainer H.T. Bray and Jockey Robert Robinson to score doubles at Empire City yesterday.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 27 -- The German Gestapo is facing a new crisis in Rumania, with popular resistance rapidly growing against further participation in the campaign east of the Dneister River, reports to foreign military sources at Istanbul said today.

A detailed program of social and economic reconstruction after the war was outlined yesterday by Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins at the opening session of the conference of the International Labor Organization of the League of Nations at Columbia University.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 28 -- Pursuing the line of thought recently expressed in an authoritative editorial in the Japan Times Advertiser, the newspaper Miyako urges the Japanese Government to mediate between Russia and Germany in the name of humanity and the "new order."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Senator Pepper of Florida expressed, the belief tonight that President Roosevelt's Navy Day speech would hasten revision of the Neutrality Act.

Among the official representatives of other nations the American people perhaps know best the Statue of Liberty. Presented on Oct. 28, 1886, by the people of France in commemoration of her participation in the American Revolution, the Statue has fulfilled the duty of a diplomat.

In a radio address over Station WOR last night Alfred A. Cook, chairman of the committee on the judiciary of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, reiterated the opposition of the association to the candidacy of Paul P. Rao, assistant United States Attorney General, named by the Democrats for the Supreme Court in the First District.

The first national training school for teachers of air-raid precaution was started yesterday at the Museum of Science and Industry, RCA Building, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, by the American Women's Voluntary Services, Inc.

An 80-year-old American woman who had lived in Germany ever since she left the United States seventy-two years ago, two members of the Rothschild banking family and three delegates to the International Labor Organization's conference were among the twenty-five passengers from Lisbon aboard Pan American Airways' Atlantic Clipper, which docked at La Guardia Field at 12:40 P.M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Roosevelt rejected tonight John L. Lewis's attempt to make the "captive" mine issue an issue between labor and the United States Steel Corporation, and for the third time requested him to authorize, the immediate resumption of operations.

Hoping to get back some of the business they lost during the last year, when draftees dropped "civvies" for khaki, men's wear manufacturers and retailers are beginning to plan special campaigns aimed at soldiers to be released within coming months.

NORTONVILLE, Ky., Oct. 27 (U.P.) -- Fifteen men trapped by an explosion in the Daniel Boone coal mine, about four miles south of this town, were found dead tonight by an emergency crew. The dead were among a shift of forty-eight workmen which had entered the shaft just before an unexplained explosion at 7:30 A.M.

THERE are two remarkable short stories, four good ones, three odd ones and no bad ones in Martha Gellhorn's "The Heart of Another,"* her first collection of short stories as such and her first book of any kind since she became Mrs. Ernest Hemingway in November of last year.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force issued the following communique today:

BERLIN, Oct. 27 (U.P.) -- Even the German High Command took cognizance today of the descending Russian Winter. Despite unfavorable weather, its communique said, the German offensive continued and was "making further progress."

The cut in the city sales tax to 1 per cent from 2 per cent went into effect smoothly in retail establishments yesterday. Store executives reported little or no confusion in the application of the new tax brackets. Some consumer buying of higher price items that was delayed last week in anticipation of the reduction made its appearance, and more was expected this week.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Ralph Greenleaf stayed unbeaten in the world pocket billiard championship tourney tonight. Earlier in the day the defending champion, Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia, was defeated for the first time.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F. of L., announced yesterday that he had appealed to President Roosevelt and several government agencies for aid in enabling coastwise ship lines to charge higher freight rates, so that union demands for increased wages might be met before the present contract expires on Friday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Navy Day was celebrated throughout the United States today against a grim background of international events.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Confidence that religious peace would return to Mexico during President Manuel Avila Camacho's administration was expressed today by Archbishop Luis M. Martinez, head of the Catholic Church in Mexico.

Prince Serge Obolensky gave a dinner last night in La Maisonette of the St. Regis. His guests included the Misses Mary Munn, Rosemary Warburton and Fernanda Munn; Count Vasilli Adlerberg and Frank Montgomery. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Ridder entertained with a dinner in the Iridium Room of the same hotel for Mr. and Mrs. Edgar W. Garbisch and Mr. and Mrs. James I. Bush.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Oct. 22 aggregated $12,884,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Roosevelt directed his third appeal to John L. Lewis a fewhours after he had indicated to Congressional leaders that his patience is about exhausted and that he is on the verge of requesting legislation to correct the defense labor situation.

Tonight will witness one of the more important openings of the screen season with the world premiere at the Rivoli of the John Ford-Twentieth Century-Fox screen version of the Richard Llewellyn novel, "How Green Was My Valley."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 25:

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday by Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $34,743,604.

The time for action Has come, Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, commandant of the Third Naval District, declared last nigght in a Navy and Total Defense Day address, in which he called upon the nation to give President Roosevelt power to extend to all waters his "shoot on sight" order to our Navy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You published, on Oct. 23, a letter from Count Sforza recalling some incidents in which Italy has suffered. In the third paragraph he states: "In 1914 Austria - Hungary decided to invade Serbia without the previous consent of Italy, formally required by Article VII of the Triple Alliance.

The uneasiness created by the strike in the coal mines of the steel companies could not be erased yesterday by a long list of the favorable industrial development, and, coupled with a sharp break in the tobacco issues which jolted the structure of the share list, the stock market sold off.

The cotton market drifted to lower prices yesterday on liquidation and hedging operations. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, after touching their high marks for the day in the second hour, at levels unchanged to 4 points lower, eased off to close with net losses of 21 to 27 points.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 27 -- The Baltusrol team of Johnny Farrell and Harold Brown, with a card of 34, 33 -- 67, won the weekly proamateur tourney of the New Jersey P.G.A. at the Montclair Golf Club today. A field of thirty-four teams started and fourteen failed to return scores.

Mayor La Guardia, reviewing over the radio last night the high calibre of the men he has appointed to serve the city government, declared that "when the President of the United States wants expert help and wants experience and loyalty to the country, he calls upon my administration and not upon Ed Flynn."
LOOKING up, Coach Lou Little of Columbia saw Lieutenant Harvey Jablonsky of the Army football staff and said briskly:

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- With the running of the amateur gunner-handler stake, the eighteenth annual meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association was brought to a close today. The contest was open to any amateur running any cocker or English springer and drew a field of eighteen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Fourteen local unions of the American Federation of Labor have charged the Ford Motor Company with violating the National Labor Relations Act by favoring the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
Atlantic Refining A special dividend of $1 on the common stock in addition to the regular quarterly of 25 cents were announced yesterday by the Atlantic Refining Company.
BERLIN, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Complete elimination of Jews from European life now appears to be fixed German policy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The effort of the government to collect $9,675,000 from the estate of Zachary Smith Reynolds, who married Anne Cannon and later Libby Holman and who was mysteriously shot to death in July, 1932, when he was 20 years old, will be reviewed by the Supreme Court.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Oct. 27 -- In a generally depressed market on the Bourse today stocks were up to 6 points lower on small trading. Royal Dutch lost 1 3/8 at 312 1/2; Amsterdam Trading 6 at 474; Amsterdam Rubber 1 at 303 1/8.

Dr. Marvin Allen Stevens changed from street clothes into football coaching togs and went out on Ohio Field yesterday to start preparing New York University's football team for the first appearance it has ever made under arc lights. Friday night at the Polo Grounds the New Yorkers and Penn State come together in a game which also will be the first under lights that State has ever played.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Rival air lines, joined by a government lawyer, demanded today that the Civil Aeronautics Board deny the application of Seaboard Airways, Inc., for authority to operate from New York to Miami and New Orleans.

CLANTON, Ala., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Death claimed its fifteenth victim today in the Montgomery-Birmingham passenger bus clash and fire last night. The coach struck the concrete guard rail of a bridge four miles south of this community.

The essence of John L. Lewis's letter to the President (a masterly piece of demagoguery) is, as always, that work can be resumed immediately if the other fellow will give him precisely what he wants. As Mr. Lewis correctly notes, it would not take ten minutes for the seven steel companies involved to give Mr. Lewis the completely unionized shop or anything else that he chooses to ask for.

LONDON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- There were increasing indications tonight that British armies in the Middle East, ready for possible action against the Germans in the Caucasus, might be forced at the same time to oppose a German thrust at the Suez Canal.

Actual or prospective expenditures of about $99,000 for Mayor La Guardia and his running mates were listed yesterday at the unofficial inquiry being made, at the Mayor's request, into Democratic charges that $1,000,000 was being spent for his re-election.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Oct. 28 -- German forces exerting pressure against the western and southwestern defenses of Moscow have made some progress, a military commentator on the Russian radio conceded this morning. The Russian communique mentioned particularly heavy fighting in the Mozhaisk and Maloyaroslavets regions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Roosevelt will give a luncheon tomorrow at the White House for the Duke and Duchess of Windsor. Mrs. Roosevelt said today that she "deeply regretted" that she could not possibly be present.

As a result of lower temperatures in the northern areas, the waterfowl are more active in the coastal waters of Connecticut, New York and New Jersey, and the bluebird weather that has been cutting down the bag limits in several areas is rapidly giving way to real duck-shooting conditions.

Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, was greeted with cries of "Open up a Western front!" last night when he spoke at a Russian war relief rally at Madison Square Garden. With other speakers, Lord Halifax pleaded for all-out help to the Soviet armies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Following is the text of the letter by which John L. Lewis rejected for a second time President Roosevelt's request that the coal strike by called off, and the text of the President's third appeal to the mine union leader in reply:

SHANGHAI, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A raid by twenty Japanese soldiers across the tensely patrolled Soviet-Japanese Far Eastern frontier, precipitating a clash in which both sides suffered casualties, was reported today by Tass, the official Soviet news agency.

Charging that Mayor La Guardia was overestimating his own strength and ability in attempting to fill two important and demanding positions on a part-time basis, Governor Lehman appealed last night to the people of New York City to elect William O'Dwyer, Democratic nominee for the Mayoralty, whose character and background he praised highly.

Sholom Bernstein, a minor member of the Brooklyn murder ring, spent six hours in Kings County Court yesterday describing the life and duties of a gambler, money lender, bookmaker, thug, automobile thief, death-car driver and holder of the ghoulish job of lookout man for underworld gravediggers burying a victim by moonlight in lonely woodland.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, repeated last night the charge that Mayor La Guardia had done nothing regarding overassessments of property in his eight years in office. The candidate quoted Park Commissioner Robert Moses, one of the Mayor's appointees, to support the accusation.
Major league baseball attracted ten and a quarter million fans through the turnstiles during the 1941 season, but it was a year of mixed success.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Lieut. Comdr. William K. Vanderbilt, retired, presented to the Navy today the yacht Alva, reputed to be one of the finest afloat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Black Hills Power and Light Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment disclosing the terms of a bond deal and public offering of the concern's preferred and common stock as registered with the commission on Sept. 6.

BERLIN, Oct. 27 -- Continued downpours of rain on the central front before Moscow were cited by an official German spokesman today as grounds for the slowing down of German operations there, as well as for the failure of the German Army finally to "liquidate the last remnants of the Red Army."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27 -- Defense shipbuilding all along the Pacific Coast, except for navy yard construction, was threatened today with a shutdown as a strike resulting from the American Federation of Labor's refusal to grant autonomy to welders crippled defense work in the Seattle-Tacoma area, spread to Los Angeles shipyards and won the moral support of independent welders in the East Bay district here.

LONDON, Oct. 27 (U.P.) -- British fighter planes, paced by an American Eagle pilot who shot down two Messerschmitts, punished the occupied coasts of France and the Low Countries today and battled German aircraft high over the Channel.

Supreme Court Referee James A. O'Gorman brought to an abrupt end yesterday the hearings before him on two actions against Serge Rubinstein and other defendants in the case of the Chosen Corporation. The referee summoned counsel for the litigants and announced that he had disqualified himself.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Oct. 27 -- Although advices from the central front today reported that the Germans were seeking to accelerate their offensive against Moscow, it was learned that picked Russian infantrymen had made a slashing counter-attack south of the capital and had succeeded in recrossing the Nara River.

J.F. Hartlieb, president of the Continental Can Company, Inc., announced yesterday that net earnings of the company and its wholly-owned subsidiaries were $7,381,502 for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, last, after deducting $9,482,191 for depreciation, depletion and estimated income and excess profits taxes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Large contracts for guns and ammunition brought the total of the day's Army awards for miscellaneous supplies to $167,403,208. In the New York area the War Department awarded the following contracts, not previously published:

In an ardent appeal for support of Miss Anne Morgan's campaign to send Christmas boxes to 1,300,000 French war prisoners, Charles Boyer declared yesterday that both the Free French and Vichy sympathizers desired above all "to save the French race from annihilation."

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs here and at most other major markets today were moderate and buyers, noting additional firmness in wholesale pork raised prices 10 to 20 cents a hundred pounds in active dealings. Light loins sold at 21 1/2 to 23 cents a pound, a gain of 1/2 to 1 cent over last Friday.

Dehydrated and pasturized bananas made their New York appearance in the grand ballroom of the Capitol Hotel, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, yesterday when the New York Health Food Exposition, scheduled to continue through tomorrow, was opened to the public.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- The Elmsford Country Club team of Jim Turnesa and Nat Shein, first of fifteen pairs to finish, topped the field by three shots and won the last scheduled one-day pro-amateur competition of the Westchester P.G.A. season with a best-ball card of 33, 31 -- 64 on the east course at the Old Oaks Country Club today.

The seventh annual exhibition of printing sponsored by the New York Employing Printers Association opened yesterday in the Hotel Commodore. A dinner in the hotel was attended by 400 users, buyers and producers of printing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Inasmuch as those pacifists who -- win or lose -- fear the social consequences of our entry into war and want peace are plainly either outnumbered or outmanoeuvred, the practical question remaining seems to be to ask how best to fight.

With well over 500 manufacturers showing their lines, the Spring shoe market got under way here yesterday and the only unanimous opinion among both makers and buyers was that prices were definitely higher. The degree of the advance varied with each manufacturer and the degree of resistance by buyers differed with the type of retailer involved.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 28 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Moscow radio broadcast the following communique of the Soviet Information Bureau early today:

Publishing firms and manufacturers of upholstery, radios and clothing were among the concerns reported yesterday as having rented new commercial quarters through brokers operating in various sections of the city.

The present strike in the coal mines operated by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation will make necessary an immediate and substantial reduction in the steel-making operations of the corporation, Benjamin F. Fairless, its president, stated last night.
BOSTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Senator Walsh asserted today that the Navy was not in a position to wage a foreign war.

An "underground railroad" system enables R.A.F. fliers stranded in France to return to England and French youths to reach the forces of General Charles de Gaulle in London, two women passengers on the American Export liner Excambion declared yesterday when the ship docked at Pier F, Jersey City, from Lisbon.

Niles Trammel, president of the National Broadcasting Company, made public yesterday a telegram to the New York Chapter of the America First Committee, denying the charge by the chapter that the major radio networks have "barred" America First spokesmen from the air.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The special committee on personnel, procurement and materiel of the House Military Affairs Investigating Committee today praised the results but not the method of the campaign for scrap aluminum and recommended that any future drives to salvage waste materials for defense purposes be directed through "the regular channels of the existing waste materials industry."

A tremendous task and a great opportunity face the trucking industry of the United States as a result of the national defense emergency, Ted V. Rodgers, president of the American Trucking Associations, Inc., asserted yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania in sounding the keynote of the association's eighth annual convention.
BERLIN, Oct, 27 -- The impression in authorized circles in Berlin tonight is that the 100 French hostages held for execution this week will not have to face the firing squad.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 27 (U.P.) -- With a Siberian border clash between Japanese and Russian troops reported today, foreign military quarters, showing increasing anxiety over Japanese Fleet activities, speculated on the possibility that Japan might try to seize Russia's half of Sakhalin Island, off the Siberian coast, or make big-scale raids on China's Burma Road from French Indo-China.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 28 -- President Roosevelt has been recognized so long not only as leader of the United States but also as spokesman for all the democracies of this continent that his speeches always awaken the deepest echoes throughout South America. Seldom if ever, however, have his words had such resonance as those he uttered yesterday.

Loew's, Inc., is conducting negotiations with, insurance companies for a private refunding of $11,581,000 of its 3 1/2 per cent debentures and $13,672,200 of its $6.50 preferred stock, under a plan which will include a utilization of a substantial portion of the company's large cash reserve in retiring the foregoing securities.
It is Vinton Freedley's pleasure to introduce this evening at the Imperial a new musical comedy, "Let's Face It!" embellished with songs by Cole Porter.

Buyer Registrations Lower The number of out-of-town buyers reported in the market last week numbered 620, as against 782 in the previous week and 892 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to THE NEW YORK TIMES listings. Registrations yesterday totaled 438 which compared with 382 for a week ago.

PARIS, Oct. 28 (AP) -- A "last chance" offer to spare the lives of 100 French, hostages and release war prisoners whose families turn informer on the assassins of two Germans was announced tonight by General Otto von Stuelpnagel, commander of the German occupation forces.

Instead of promoting a reserve to Len Bates's vacant fullback post, Coach Mal Stevens Intends to give Jack Barmak, N.Y.U.'s regular quarterback, a thorough test for the job, It was announced yesterday. The effect will be somewhat the same, for Barmak has had no college fullback experience, although he played there occasionally at Boys Sigh School.

Following the award at competitive bidding last Monday of $38,000,000 first mortgage 3 3/8 per cent bonds of the Central Illinois Public Service Company, they will be offered to the public today by a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including forty-six other members.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Alex Taub, technical consultant in the OEM's labor division, asserted today before a House committee investigating defense migration that the automobile industry had put the manufacture of automobiles ahead of defense and had delayed the conversion of tools and productive facilities which might now be speeding defense output and providing jobs for displaced workers.

In the presence of 300 leaders in religious, civic and business life, including Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, the honorary degree of Doctor of Hebrew Letters was conferred yesterday upon Paul Baerwald, honorary chairman of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, at the Fall Convocation of the Hebrew Union College, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.
