LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The Reuter news agency, a world-wide newsgathering organization, will henceforth be owned jointly by the Press Association, a company financed and controlled by the provincial newspapers of Great Britain, and by the Newspaper Proprietors Association, a representative corporation of the London press, under arrangements announced today.

The cotton market moved irregularly yesterday in quiet trading on the New York Cotton Exchange. A momentarily active demand that found a scarcity of contracts in the ring lifted prices of active futures in the first hour as much as 22 points.

In reply to Mayor La Guardia's assertion that when President Roosevelt wanted anything done he called on him and not on "Ed" Flynn, Edward J. Flynn, Democratic National Chairman, declared last night that Mr. La Guardia had been a failure as Director of Civilian Defense and that "Mrs. Roosevelt had to be called in to straighten out the mess that La Guardia had created."

The Board or Estimate is an executive rather than a legislative body. Its main function is "to direct the business affairs of the city" and it is given general control over financial policies. It has the power to fix all salaries paid from the city treasury except those of day laborers and those set by statute or the charter.
Apartment renting in good volume was reported yesterday by brokers and agents, who listed leases for a number of large suites on both East and West Sides.

Joseph E. McWillliams, head of the American Destiny party, amid murmurs of approval and disapproval from a packed courtroom yesterday in the Felony Court was ordered by Magistrate William W. Hoppin to serve the remainder of a sixty-day workhouse term he had imposed on McWilliams last Sept. 9 and suspended when he found McWilliams guilty of disorderly conduct in a Yorkville speech assailing Jews.

Orders were issued yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine calling 18,000 members of the department, virtually the entire force, to a thirty-six-hour period of duty in guarding the polls and carrying out other election day tasks next Tuesday.

BERLIN, Oct. 28 -- Drawing on what should be their last reserves of invective, Berlin circles -- both official and semi-official -- including press and radio, today discharged a verbal blast of such magnitude against the President of the United States over his Navy Day speech that earlier efforts to disparage Mr. Roosevelt, even in the gutter-strength vocabulary of the Stuermer, pale into insignificance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Further details of the submarine attack on the Destroyer Kearny were made public in an analysis prepared by the Bureau of Ships of the Navy Department today. This showed that a torpedo virtually cut the vessel in two and that her survival was due to factors in her design.

Two anonymous gifts from Brooklyn, one of $10,500 and other of 56,750, headed the latest United Hospital Campaign contribution list made public yesterday by Roy E. Larsen, general chairman. Thus far $365,120 has been raised in the drive.

A flicker of life was shown yesterday by the stock market under the impetus of signs of a firmer hand by Washington in dealing with the coal strike and President Roosevelt's Navy Day address. Although values in the tobacco group continued to retreat-the fresh weakness being traced directly to the court findings involving the Anti-Trust Act against the three big companies -- the remainder of the list, in general, followed an improved course.

The limited price cutting of certain standard brands of liquor, which began on Friday and continued sporadically over the weekend, was extended to other brands yesterday in what appeared to be the beginning of a city-wide price war.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- The grain markets fluctuated in a most erratic manner today. The President's address on Monday was construed as belligerent and had some effect early, as did strength in cotton, but houses with North-western connections sold December wheat on a fairly liberal scale on the advance, and when professional traders started to sell they found support lacking.

"These are my new soups, says the proprietor of a Manhattan shop, shop, and his matter-of-fact words do little to disguise his pride in his wares. Green tins, standing primly on his shelves, conceal savory soups for frosty weather.

At the annual meeting of the International Agricultural Corporation held yesterday, stockholders voted to change the name of the company to the International Minerals and Chemicals Corporation. Louis Ware, president, explained that the change was made because the old name no longer properly described the company's operations.

Any one who wants to stir up an argument as to whether they play better football in the Big Ten or the Southwest Conference can find plenty of material for both sides in this week's rankings of the nation's leading teams by 127 experts participating in the third Associated Press poll of the season.

Shoe buyers yesterday responded variously to the rising price trend developed at showings of Spring lines at four hotels here. While some were covering in anticipation of possible delivery delays and were paying the higher prices with little protest, others were holding off.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 -- The flying wedge formation, famous in the annals of football, was employed today by the Boiler-makers' Union, A.F.L., to smash Seattle picket lines of the Welders Union, on strike because the Federation has refused their demand for autonomy.

In a telegram sent yesterday to President Roosevelt, Richard T. Frankensteen, national director of aviation for the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., threatened to use his union's "large-scale economic strength" to force settlement of the labor conflict at Air Associates, Inc., at Bendix, N.J.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued this communique today:

A new policy regarding the educational care of physically handicapped children that will in effect abolish the principle of segregation has been adopted by the Board of Superintendents, Dr. Frank J. O'Brien, associate superintendent in charge of the handicapped, disclosed yesterday.
BERLIN, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Reichbank's statement as of Oct. 23 shows the following changes for the week, in thousands of reichsmarks:

The new Palace of the League of Nations stands forlorn and empty on the shaded shores of Lake Leman. All that made the sober city of Geneva an international capital during the rainbow period of the late armistice has departed. Gone are the days when the hotels along the Rhone were crowded with Foreign Ministers and their buzzing entourages.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Roosevelt formally proclaimed Nov. 11 as Armistice Day today, saying, that the American people on that occasion should rededicate the nation to the fundamentals of human liberty. His proclamation read:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The National Defense Mediation Board made public tonight telegrams from three steel companies involved in the captive mine strike, accepting the board's suggestions for settling the dispute between the companies and the United Mine Workers (C.I.O.).

Mayor La Guardia's claims of a city housing program were attacked yesterday by Professor George W. Hartmann, Mayoralty candidate of the Socialist party, who declared that more people are living in substandard houses today than before the Mayor took office, and that the present rate of building would require a century to replace the old law tenements alone.
Dr. Jock Sutherland's Football Dodgers may go ahead and ravage the terrain of Ebbets Field by wearing their cleats in practice from now on until Nov. 8 of this year, "but never again."

Sholom Bernstein, self-styled eccentric assigned to carry out bizarre jobs for the Brooklyn murder ring, spent his third day on the witness stand in Kings County Court yesterday, this time describing the life of a pampered informer sleeping at night with two detectives at his bedside and on balmy days playing baseball as a "ringer" on a police team.

Bradford B. Locke, executive vice president of the Church Pension Fund and Church Life Insurance Corporation, has been elected president of the Church Properties Fire Insurance Corporation, succeeding William Fellowes Morgan, who resigned after eleven years as president, it was announced yesterday by J.P. Morgan, chairman of the board.

Miss May Birkhead, for many years society and fashion authority for The New York Herald's Paris edition and later correspondent for The Chicago Tribune and THE NEW YORK TIMES, died Monday night at the Hospital for Special Surgery after a long illness.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Roosevelt established today an entirely new and more independent organization for administering the leasing program as he signed the new $5,985,000,000 appropriation measure and gave to Edward R. Stettinius Jr. blanket powers to dispense the new fund for aiding the enemies of Hitler.

Two young princesses stole a march on celebrity-conscious New York yesterday. Unrecognized, they toured the eighteenth annual Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries at Grand Central Palace, where they were guests of honor in the afternoon at an international children's party.

ROME, Oct. 28 -- A circular containing confidential instructions for British officers in the Middle East and Egypt "to insure the greatest cooperation of the men under their command," was published in the Italian press yesterday. The circular was said to have been found on a "high British officer recently captured."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt welcomed back to Washington today the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, whose visit here last month was clouded by the death, on the morning of their arrival, of G. Hall Roosevelt, brother of the First Lady.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Oct. 22 THE TIMES printed a letter from Professor H.C.F. Bell, who wrote: "Many months ago, being deeply interested in this question, I made attempts to get some specific information about the negotiations of the Hoover, committee with, the German Government from Mr. Hoover's supporters particularly requesting an exact statement as to what the Nazis had agreed to do in furtherance of Mr. Hoover's project.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- An increase in the social security tax rate, in addition to the broadening of its base recently foreshadowed by President Roosevelt, has been recommended by the Treasury for White House approval and is expected to be announced soon as an anti-inflationary measure.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Edward L. Ryerson, chairman of the board of the Inland Steel Company, has resigned from the America First Committee.

Greeted by cries of "Hi-ya Butch" from an enthusiastic audience of 5,000 men, women and children, Mayor La Guardia, grinning happily, yesterday laid the cornerstone of the new $200,000 extension of the 135th Street branch of the New York Public Library.

A proposal to deepen the channel leading from Kill van Kull to Port Newark was supported yesterday by speakers who appeared at a hearing before Lieut. Col. L.S. Dillon, district engineer of the War Department, at 39 Whitehall Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 27:

The Downtown Athletic Club, last season's champion, dropped from a first-place tie to a four-way deadlock for third place in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B competition last night, losing to the Union League, 4 to 1, on the latter's courts.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Onofrio Lauri, Brooklyn, N.Y., veteran, defeated Ralph Greenleaf, 125 to 54, in seventeen innings tonight to knock the seventeen-time former champion out of exclusive leadership in the world pocket billiards championship tournament.

A little "jump-the-grn" spooking kept a group of 4-to-6-year-olds prancing yesterday in the Children's Aid Society's James Center, 154 Hester Street. And when a round of clucking for apples had been followed by rooting for doughnuts in pans filled with powdered sugar, many of these "jumping-bean" pranksters would have held their own in any ghostly competition.

As the Germans pushed deeper into the Donets Basin yesterday and Axis supply ships -- despite heavy losses -- continued to ferry troops and supplies from Italy to North Africa, the Middle Bast, cornerstone of the British Empire, assumed a growing importance in the strategy of world struggle.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 28 -- With November just around the corner, the Lord Jeffs of Amherst are preparing for a new football season. Since the Sabrinas already have played five games, such a statement would seem to require an explanation. But it's true, and you have Coach Lloyd Jordan's word for it.

Mayor La Guardia, while inspecting the new Arthur Avenue Market, between 184th and 186th Street, the Bronx, which he officially opened yesterday, was asked to select some foodstuff and pose for the photographers. Picking up a head of cabbage, the Mayor exclaimed, "My opponent's head."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Looking fit despite his 26 years, Exterminator came back today to Pimlico, where he will be honored on Thursday at the opening of the Maryland Jockey Club's Fall race meeting.

There are two versions of the strike at the Air Associates, Inc., plant in Bendix, N.J., which has led to a threat of a general stoppage by the C.I.O. in the Eastern industrial area. Those versions are set forth below.

It was a refreshing show full of sunshine and romance that delighted yesterday's luncheon guests at the Ritz-Carlton at the weekly Tuesday fashion show in the Oval Room. The exhibitor was Mary Lewis, whose shop, at 647 Fifth Avenue, specializes in youthful styles.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that the nine Bronx Democrats appointed to various posts in his administration had denied having made any promises of political support as a condition of obtaining' their jobs.

The four-story apartment for eight families on a plot 30 by 100 feet at 509 Second Street, Brooklyn, was sold by Mrs. Florence Jackson to a client of the Charles Partridge Real Estate Company, Inc., brokers.

Governor Lehman's restrained speech on behalf of Mr. O'Dwyer on Monday evening, put beside his indignant comment of yesterday on the Mayor's political oratory, suggests that he is a good deal more annoyed with Mr. La Guardia than he is pleased with Mr. O'Dwyer.

Demand for locally dressed meats was fair yesterday to very slow. Supplies of veal and calf hindsaddles as well as all kosher meats were more than ample for trade requirements. The cow market was weak, veal and calf hindsaddles weak, fresh pork cuts steady to higher and other classes steady.

MONTCLAIR. N.J., Wednesday, Oct. 29 -- At least twelve Negroes, including one child, were burned to death last night in a fire that swept through a flimsy two-and-a-hlaf-story dwelling house at 4 Walnut Place, here. Five persons were Injured seriously.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Roosevelt, concerned over the "captive" mine and other strikes affecting defense industries, has given up his long opposition to further legislation dealing with industrial disputes and is considering a new legal approach to the problem of minimizing defense industry controversies.

Mrs. Lytle Hull gave a luncheon yesterday in her apartment at Hampshire House for a group of women serving with her in organizing the "Monday Musical Mornings" to be held on successive Mondays from Nov. 10 through Dec. 8 in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Musicians' Emergency Fund.

JOHN GUNTHER'S "Inside Latin America,"* published this morning, lives up to expectations and Mr. Gunther's reputation. It is a highly informative, patient and good-natured report on the twenty republics to the south, written by one of our most indefatigable journalists after a five months' grand tour.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 28 (AP) -- L. Phillips's Circus Wings swept through, a sloppy track at Rocking ham Park today to take the feature from Water Cracker. The time for the six furlongs was 1:15 2-5 and the favored Adolf ran third, a nose ahead of Five O Five.

High-ranking naval officers and leaders in society and artistic circles attended the gala premiere last night of the new motion picture, "How Green Was My Valley," at the Rivoli Theatre. The performance was presented under the auspices of the Navy Relief Society of the Third Naval District to raise funds for needy dependents of naval service men.

To THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the editorial "Mr. Cudahy's Peace Plan" you say that this war is different from others, that others were for markets and such things, but this is "a battle to the death between two philosophies."

Hollywood could hardly have reproduced more faithfully the atmosphere of London's Mayfair that has been provided by the British War Relief Society for its Piccadilly Arcade sale of donated American family treasures that opened yesterday in a little redcobbled street that can be entered at 6 East Fifty-seventh Street, in the heart of the upper Fifth Avenue shopping district.

It hardly takes a new report from Commissioner Moses to make New Yorkers conscious that the city's park system has blossomed out in eight years from an obsolete, local system, with many neighborhoods neglected, to an orderly, comprehensive and adequate pattern of playgrounds, swimming pools and all the other modern facilities needed for a great metropolitan center like ours.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 28 -- Charles Stern's Coercion, claimed in New York, raced to his second straight victory here today in the Worthington Purse, a sprint of six furlong's involving a field of six.

Lou Schwartz, promising Brownsville middleweight, 163 3/4, easily outpointed Saverio Turiello of Italy, 154 1/2, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena last night before a crowd of 4,000. Turiello substituted for Augie Arellano.

Wendell L. Willkie appealed last night for the re-election of Mayor La Guardia on the grounds that "we need as our Mayor not alone a believer in our country's foreign policy, but we need a champion who is known and proclaimed as such both here and abroad."

The Association of National Advertisers and the American Association of Advertising Agencies are making determined efforts to interest every important business faction in their campaign to combat anti-advertising sentiment. Top management executives of leading media and officers of associations in industries which are heavy users of advertising have been invited to attend the association's joint meeting at Hot Springs, Va., on Nov. 13 to 15.

The cooperation that the people of the United States will give to an established peace at the end of the present war is uppermost in the minds of church leaders abroad in the midst of the current conflict, according to views expressed yesterday at a conference of leaders of Protestant denominations in this area.

New Town Planners Of all professions it seems to us that the architects should be thinking harder than anybody else about the post-war world. What as matter of fact will the cities of the future look like? What is the answer to war in the air? People usually say it is a choice between the world organized against war and the collapse of civilization under a rain of fire from the air.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A survey of the Federal Government's information services shows that while the defense agencies are gaining the headlines, the non-defense agencies are spending twice as much money to tell the world about their activities.

The Inter-American Music Fiesta drew 2,800 persons to Carnegie Hall last night, and artists from Argentina, Chile, Cuba, Mexico, Brazil and other Latin-American countries entertained the capacity audience for more than two and a half hours.

Announcing yesterday declaration of a dividend of $1 a common, share, the same as in the first two quarters of this year, Irving S. Olds, chairman of United States Steel Corporation, reported also for the third quarter a net profit of $34,313,345, equal to $3.21 a common share after preferred dividends.

VICHY, France, Oct. 28 -- The City Council of Bordeaux has voted a resolution supporting the appeals made by Marshal Henri Philippi Petain as Chief of State and Admiral Francois Darlan as Vice Premier, exhorting the people of the city to aid in seeking out the guilty in the slaying of a German officer, it was revealed here today.

While the current lull in furs is serving as a brake upon the advance, raw skin prices at the start of the new trapping season in December are expected to show increases of 20 to 50 per cent over the opening levels a year ago, according to estimates in the trade yesterday.

In the latest of the Canadian reports on the St. Lawrence project, a report prepared for the Canadian Electrical Association, Professor John L. McDougall of Queen's University raises points which have hitherto received little attention in a consideration of our national defense needs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- House Interstate Commerce Committee hearings on proposed amendments to the Securities Acts of 1933 and 1934 opened today with Ganson Purcell, SEC commissioner, recalling the history of stock dealing evils in the 1920's and later which led to the passage of the two acts.

Mayor La Guardia charged yesterday that despite the "recklessness" and bitterness that his opponents had injected into the municipal campaign they had been unable to make "even the remotest charge that a penny has been wasted or a penny has been grafted" in the public improvements program of his administration.

After taking a fascinating glance back into American history, George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber declare themselves for today in "The Land Is Bright," which was brilliantly acted at the Music Box last evening. Some of it is comedy; some of it is melodrama and a little of it is related as a solemn lesson for our times in the last act.

A subpoena issued yesterday in United States District Court in Brooklyn called for the appearance of Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson there on Monday morning as a witness for the defense in the espionage trial in Brooklyn.

TOKYO, Oct. 28 -- President Roosevelt's Navy Day speech was received by headlines in the Japanese press as "the declaration of a shooting war against Germany." But the press also notes that while the President again pledged continued aid to China and Russia he omitted any mention of American-Japanese relations and gave no hint identifying him with Navy Secretary Frank Knox's "strong, surprising statement about the inevitability of a clash in the Pacific."

Fordham's football players had a short workout yesterday on Rose Hill, but it was thorough and rigorous after Monday's lay-off. Both the linemen and backs were lectured on their shortcomings in the Texas Christian game and immediate steps were taken to see that they did not repeat them in this Saturday's tussle with Purdue.
Two large East Side residences of the type which continues to dwindle in Manhattan were reported yesterday to have changed ownerships.

BERLIN, Oct. 28 -- For the first time in this war the weather -- hitherto one of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's most faithful allies -- has turned against him with a vengeance and saved Moscow from what is described as certain Nazi conquest, according to reliable information arriving here from the Eastern Front.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- President Roosevelt's speech produced mixed reactions here today, most of them not unfavorable but expectant. There was no official reaction for the very good reason that all officials were told not to comment.

The Mill River Stable of Mrs. Barclay Douglas, which brought off such a surprise when Fair Call took the Ardsley Handicap last Saturday, accounted for another upset yesterday at Empire City, where Azimuth scored at $27.40 for $2.

LONDON, Oct. 28-- A 20-year-old merchant seaman, Gerard Riley, who has just returned to his home in this country, told Liver-pool dock workers yesterday how his ship had been shelled and sunk by the Nazi pocket battleship Admiral Scheer last year.
Restaurants, chemical concerns, a bank and a Federal agency figured as lessees in commercial rentals reported yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 28 -- The increasing tempo with which the people of the Americas are facing the threat of nazism was vividly reflected by President Roosevelt in his speech last night, according to the consensus of Brazilian opinion as surveyed by this correspondent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The duties and rights of American women under the law are discussed in a bulletin issued today fry the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor. The bulletin, "The Legal Status of Women in the United States of America," regarded as being of significant interest in these days when women are assuming many roles in the national defense program.

Abe (The Killer) Beitler lived up to his nickname to the last early yesterday morning in the Hotel Abbey in Fifty-first Street, east of Seventh Avenue. He killed himself with his own revolver in an unlighted banquet room on the twenty-second floor of the hotel.

ROME, Oct. 28 (U.P) -- When Premier Mussolini told 50,000 persons, cheering wildly beneath his palace balcony tonight, that the United States and all other anti-Axis forces would be crushed by Italy and her allies thousands booed and hissed lustily.

A syndicate composed of the First National Bank of Portland, Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Kaiser Co. received yesterday the award of $600,000 of assessment collection bonds of Portland, Ore., on a net interest cost basis to the city of 1.0975 per cent.
Joseph B. (Smoky Joe) Martin, retired assistant chief of the Fire Department, who died last Saturday, will be accorded funeral honors of a chief of department at a service to be held this morning.

Alaska Packers The Alaska Packers Association, 84 per cent owned subsidiary of the California Packing Corporation, declared yesterday a dividend of $5 a share, payable on Nov. 10. The current declaration is the first since 1938, when $5 was paid In that year.

A Clean-Cut Competitive Sale The competitive sale on Monday of the $38,000,000 of Central Illinois Public Service 31/8s, and formal offering of the bonds to the public today by the winning syndicate, marks the first clean-cut operation of the SEC's compulsory competitive bidding rule as applied to a major bond issue.

It is not overstating the matter to say that today a labor crisis exists in this country. The defiant strike called by John L. Lewis, which threatens to cripple our entire defense program by closing down the coal mines on which the manufacture of steel depends, is not the only problem of the sort that confronts us.

CHICAGO. Oct. 28 (AP) -- Overnight loadings increased receipts of hogs here to 3,000 more salable head than expected and the market reacted under the liberal supply. Opening about 15 cents lower, the market grew weaker, with the late trade 10 to 15 cents down on lighter weights and off as much as 15 to 25 cents on butchers.

VICHY, France, Oct 28 -- On the 128th day of the war in Russia news reached here from Berlin that the "desperate resistance of the Reds calls for maximum efforts on the part of the German armies." Superlatives are more than ever the rule in this campaign.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- A sharp warning that the next few years for us and for the country would be an "all-out" fight, not to save England, but "to preserve for tomorrow's children the blessings of liberty," was sounded today by Captain James R. Newman of the Coast Artillery Corps in an address to 1,000 school trustees at a closing session of the annual meeting of the State School Board Association.
The address of James A. Farley, on behalf of William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, delivered over Station WOR last night, follows:
ROME, Oct. 28 -- On entering the twentieth year of fascism today, Premier Mussolini promised the shattering of "the coalition of bolshevism and its European and American Allies."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- A large new Winter program of shows for Army camps and naval stations will start Friday when an Army transport plane leaves Mitchel Field, filled with motion-picture, stage and radio performers, and flies to Puerto Rico, going from, there to other Caribbean bases.

Coach Lou Little opened his well-known bag of tricks a little wider yesterday at Baker Field and pulled out several new offensive formations fashioned expressly for Columbia's contest with Cornell here Saturday. Based on Big Red operations, as reported by Scout Gerry Seidel, the Columbia plays feature a combination of deception and speed.

Offering to make public disclosure of his private bank account for the last twenty years, Mayor La Guardia challenged yesterday Edward J. Flynn and Frank V. Kelly, Democratic leaders of the Bronx and Brooklyn, respectively, to do likewise. He also dared "Tammany Hall, Flynn and Kelly" to make public the contributions "cash and otherwise" received for their campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Four words in the President's Navy Day speech last night are being accepted here today as his own evidence in rebuttal of the charge that his present foreign policy violates the Democratic platform of 1940 and his anti-war campaign pledges in that same year.

The Trade Book Clinic of the American Institute of Graphic Arts found that the unusual number of twelve books among those published this month fitted its definitions of "purposeful and imaginative" design combined with sound execution.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Chesapeake Ohio Railway showed its intention of divorcing itself from its one-time subsidiary, the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad, by inviting bids today on its entire holding of 67,484 shares of C. E.I. no-par common stock.

Royal Typewriter Net profit of the Royal Typewriter Company, Inc., for the first two months of its current fiscal year showed an increase of 39 per cent over the similar period of the previous year, E.C. Faustmann, president, told stockholders attending the annual meeting yesterday.

Despite the fact that retail stocks in men's wear are heavy as a result of the combination of extensive advance buying and unseasonable weather in the last two months, the wholesale market is still firm and many individual items are becoming tighter from a. supply viewpoint, buyers reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Charges that President Roosevelt in his Navy Day speech admitted publicly that he "tricked" the American people onto the road to war were made in the Senate today by Senator Taft of Ohio as foreign policy critics regained a modicum of hope that they might narrow the measure repealing all substantial provisions of the Neutrality Act of 1939.

A barter system for exchange of paint and varnish materials, in which more than 100 members of the Paint and Varnish Exchange Club of Brooklyn and other producers in the metropolitan area are participating, was disclosed yesterday by Benjamin Joachim, president of the club and president of Joachim Research Laboratories, 263 Norman Avenue, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- An order providing priority ratings for maintenance and repair materials for retail stores of all types, covering the smallest neighborhood shop as well as the largest department store, is in process of preparation at Office of Production Management and should be ready for issuance early next month, according to reports circulating here yesterday.

The piano recital given by Bernhard Weiser last night in Town Hall, his first in this city, revealed a young artist with an inborn talent for his instrument, a singing tone which he never forced, a neat and fluent technique, seriousness, a native sensibility and enthusiasm which carried him far.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The House Banking and Currency Committee promised today a price control bill by the end of this week, with indications pointing to a swing in sentiment toward inclusion of some form of wage ceilings.

Asserting that Mayor La Guardia had stepped beyond bounds of decency in political debate in his comments on the Court of Appeals decision voiding the election of a State Controller next week, Governor Lehman and James A. Farley, Democratic State chairman, assailed the Mayor yesterday as grossly abusive and vituperative and completely misrepresenting the facts.

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline on the Atlantic seaboard at the close of last week amounted to 19,547,000 barrels, a decrease of 12,000 from the 19,559,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Stocks of light fuel oil increased 559,000 barrels to 20,771,000 and stocks of heavy fuel oil were up 32,000 to 10,907,000.

The New York City Council for Art Week now estimates that by the time the newly set deadline for receiving material is reached, at 5 P.M. next Friday, some 5,000 items will be assembled, awaiting the attention of the various juries. These juries, which will judge work in various departmentspainting, sculpture, graphic art, architecture, crafts, etc. -- have a combined membership of more than one hundred.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- After having spent a large portion of the current season attending wakes over departed football hopes it is indeed a pleasure to be in a camp where mirth still prevails.
The lengthy Long Island upland game season opens on Sunday and will continue until Dec. 31, with grouse, pheasants, rabbits and squirrels included in the list.

Allowances totaling $803,357 to lawyers, accountants and others involved in the reorganization of McKesson Robbing, Inc., were awarded yesterday by Judge Alfred C. Coxe of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.
A touch of Winter came to Manhattan College's practice field yesterday, but, so far as the football squad was concerned, the "heat was on." Head Coach Herb Kopf was generating it.
BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Oct. 29 -- Rain and Red Army strategy have turned the tide of battle west of Moscow, it was announced this morning by an authoritative commentator on the Moscow radio.

HONOLULU, Oct. 28 -- One of the main reasons that apparently delays a Japanese attack upon Vladivostok and the Russian maritime and Amur River areas is not hesitance or doubt regarding whether the United States would thereupon participate in the war, but the fact that such an attack upon the Soviet Union would immediately and automatically involve Japan in war with the whole British Empire.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 -- "The Black Swan," Rafael Sabatini's novel of seventeenth' century piracy which Twentieth Century-Fox bought a year ago for $50,000, has been revived and scheduled for Winter production, with Tyrone Power and Maureen O'Hara.

Declaring that the people of democracies should put no hope in the sporadic uprisings that have flared in Europe recently because, lacking organization and leadership, they cannot succeed, Jan Valtin, author of "Out of the Night" and one-time Communist water-front terrorist in Germany, proposed yesterday that democracies train a corps of underground workers to "beat totalitarianism at its own game."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28 -- A group of bruised Yale football players returned to the line-up this afternoon, including Chuck Willoughby, Jack Magee, Ted Turner and Jim Potts, and all except Magee were in action against the third eleven, which was kept largely on the defensive in a drill that lasted two hours.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The War Department announced today that it had awarded miscellaneous supply contracts totaling $23,704,666.59. Among these were the following, not previously published, which went to concerns in the New York area:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Roosevelt characterized as a scream today the Nazi denunciations of his statement in his Navy Day speech yesterday that this government had an official German map showing plans for dividing most of Latin America into five vassal States and a "document" outlining Nazi plans for the elimination of religion in the world.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The privileged classes of Great Britain and the other countries of Europe will try to retain their position when the war is over, leaders of the National Conference of Christians and Jews said today. They predicted the world's worst troubles if the rights of the poor were ignored.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Preparations for defense of the Caucasus by Russian and British troops against the eventual advance of the German Army already are under way.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Albert A. Volk's communication in THE TIMES of Oct. 23, in which he takes THE TIMES to task for its editorial "Russia Is Not a Democracy," seems to be part of a campaign to obscure issues which, in the interests of political and logical hygiene, should be kept clear.
Mayor La Guardia cited a 50 per cent cut in fire losses and a substantial saving in the cost of cleaning streets yesterday as achievements of his administration.

Close tripartite cooperation between government, industry and labor to meet the perils confronting democracy in its death struggle with the Axis powers was characterized as essential to the survival and victory of the democratic countries by speakers at yesterday's session of the International Labor Organization's conference at Columbia University.

NEW YORK Mrs. Elonzo Tyner of Washington, D.C., now at the St. Regis, will give a tea dance Friday at the Savoy-Plaza for Miss Betty Burnham, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Beverly Burnham of Montclair, N.J.
DETROIT, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Workers in the Navy's ordnance plants are as vital to national defense as the men on its battleships, Secretary Knox asserted here today.
Loft buildings figured prominently in the reports of real estate sales in Manhattan yesterday. Two apartment houses on the West Side also changed hands.

The committee on judiciary of the Bronx County Bar Association in an "amended and supplemental report" on the qualifications of Paul P. Rao, Democratic candidate for Supreme Court Justice in the First Judicial District, has rescinded its original endorsement of Mr. Rao, contained in a report dated Oct. 17, which endorsed all Bronx County candidates.

Among the proposals to be discussed at the fifty-third annual convention of the A.A.U. at Philadelphia Nov. 15-17 is the suggestion that registration, residence rules and entry fees for national championships be waived for service men.

Avowing his belief that "the trade union la an indispensable part of democracy," District Attorney William O'Dwyer appealed last night for the votes of labor at a rally in Manhattan Center arranged by his Labor and Nonpartisan Committee.

Voluntary continuation in New York of the recently abandoned gasoline curfew from 7 P.M. to 7 A.M., appeared a possibility yesterday after union and filling station representatives found that they were not far apart on the terms of an agreement that would take care of most of the 500 men thrown out of work.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- On the heels of John L. Lewis's refusal to heed President Roosevelt's three requests to keep the "captive" coal mines working on fuel for national defense steel, the storm aroused in Congress beat higher today with suggestions and plans for drastic anti-strike legislation for the defense industries.

There cannot be one consistent enemy of Adolf Hitler who does not rejoice when news comes that the Russians are holding the Nazi advance. If the Russian armies were broken up next week, Britain, the United States, the Governments-in-exile and the peoples of the conquered countries would still owe Russia a debt of gratitude.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, in the Egyptian Desert, Oct. 28 -- Three British soldiers captured last May have reached British positions after a long trek across the desert from Bengazi with a unique story of their five months life as prisoners and their ingenious, plucky escape.
Mrs. Constantine Fotitch, wife of the Yugoslav Minister, has arrived from Washington, and is at the St. Regis.

In spite of several Injuries and other incapacitations, the Brooklyn Football Dodgers were generally in high spirits yesterday morning as they scampered briskly through a three-and-a-half hour workout in the bright sunshine at Ebbets Field.

The report of the Crown Cork and Seal Company, issued yesterday for the third quarter and first nine months of this year, disclosed a 25 per cent gain in earnings for the nine months, a tax liability more than four times as large as in the same period last year and a rise of 32 per cent in net sales for the period.

The possibility of a general coastwise tie-up affecting 15,000 longshoremen and a considerable portion of the coastal shipping fleet appeared yesterday to have been dissipated by the decision of the longshoremen to continue at work during attempts of the Department of Labor to arbitrate a wage dispute.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- Providing Pennsylvania can stop "Navy Bill" Busik's punt returns and slow down his open-field running, the Red and Blue considers it has a good chance to snap the middies' unbeaten streak Saturday before a capacity crowd of more than 73.00O.
An onlooker who sat through an exhibition of some forty or fifty Braagaard hats remarked yesterday morning: "They look as though they should be taken with a goodly portion of whipped cream.

Resentment over the prevailing policy under the Lease-Lend Act, by which purchases are made and forwarded directly by foreign government agencies instead of through American foreign traders, was brought into the open yesterday when John A. Zellers, chairman of the international trade committee of the Advertising Club of New York, announced that the committee had unanimously passed and sent a resolution of protest to Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Lease-Lend Administrator.

A wide variety of concerns have taken space in business buildings, according to lists of latest rentals reported yesterday by brokers and managing agents. The activity was most intensive in the midtown section of Manhattan and also was marked by contracts for quarters in outlying areas.

The Bronx County Bar Association, by a vote of 55 to 14, accepted last night the supplemental report of its Judiciary Committee rescinding the committee's original endorsement, on Oct. 17, of Paul P. Rao as a Democratic candidate for Supreme Court Justice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Striking a double blow for Wester Hemisphere solidarity, the Export-Import Bank of Washington today invited Latin-American banks to take advantage of a plan under which this government will advance funds to finance something over $70,000,000 worth of Latin-American purchases here a month and require payment only after the goods have actually been delivered in South American ports.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 26 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The young Shah of Iran, Mohammed Reza Pahlevi, said tonight in a private audience with a United Press correspondent that "dictatorships and autocracies are short-lived." He added that dictatorships were "likely to be disastrous to any country because no one man always can make the proper decision," while "democracy permits the pooling of ideas for checks and balances."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Roosevelt at a White House conference today effected a compromise in the captive mine strike. John L. Lewis was prevailed upon to pave the way for resuming production at the mines Friday, or Monday at the latest, and the National Defense Mediation Board was induced to abandon its decision to refuse to make recommendations in the dispute.

The directors of the Inland Steel Company declared yesterday in Chicago an extra dividend of $1 a share in addition to the quarterly dividend of $1 on the capital stock, bringing distributions for the current year to $5, the same as in 1940.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29 -- The Harvard varsity drove into a forty-minute scrimmage against the freshmen today with more than general smoothness of play. What inspired Dick Harlow's pupils to extra effort was that the doctor shave pronounced the left end and kicker, Loren Mackinney, ready to play against Princeton on Saturday, and the condition of Don Forte, end, so satisfactory that he may be expected to be available without any physical handicap.

BERLIN, Oct. 29 -- While weather and Russian counter-attacks continued to hold up the Germans before Moscow, Nazi divisions in the south were said by German quarters here today to be driving deeper into the Crimean peninsula.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Mackenzie King of Canada are expected to discuss at a meeting next week-end at Hyde Park the possibility of coordinating Canadian and American price controls to some extent.

Len Bates will be lost to N.Y.U. for its game with Penn State tomorrow night at the Polo Grounds. The fullback's arm ailment was diagnosed yesterday as a temporary paralysis of the front portion of the deltoid muscle in his right shoulder.

The war is lost for the moment behind a curtain of rain and snow. The armies writhe in the mire that surrounds Moscow like a bridgeless moat. The demoted General Mud is at last in command of the troops on large sectors of the Russian front. But we know the death struggle goes on;

Holders of securities of the Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation will receive today the annual report for the year ended on July 31, 1941, in which Frank H. Woods, chairman, and Joseph E. Rogers, president, say that the backlog of orders is nearly three times the highest level ever reached in the company's history.

Trading in the local wholesale markets yesterday opened only fair to slow. Steer hind and rib supplies were moderate and storage exceptionally heavy. Other classes were in fairly light to moderate supply. The market on hinds and ribs was weak, fresh pork cuts steady to higher, bull steady to strong, cow weak, other classes were weak to lower.

Improved methods of protecting the Port of New York in the present emergency were urged yesterday at a meeting of Federal and municipal agencies, shipping men and representatives of organizations interested in waterfront activities.

If the "last-in first-out" method of inventory accounting is to be of any help to retailers in preventing inventory losses when price start to decline, it will have to be adopted as of the end of this year to cover the heavy advances already in effect, Kenneth C. Richmond, vice president and controller of Abraham Straus, Inc., told members of the Metropolitan Controllers Association last night at a meeting in the Hotel Martinique.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The largest flying boat in naval service will be launched by the Glenn Martin plant at Middle River, Md., on Nov. 8, Rear Admiral John H. Towers, Chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics, said today as a report was isssued showing rapid progress in the development of the Navy's air arm.

The Cinderella game of the year is coming up. Army, the ugly duckling of football in 1939 and 1940, will join the issue with Notre Dame at the Yankee Stadium Saturday and no one has wired Frank Leahy's Fighting Irish to pull their punches.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29 -- For a man of his huge stature, Elton (Tad) Wieman was pretty low today when we contacted him in Osborn Field house.

The City Councilman whose terms expire with the end of this year comprise fourteen Democrats, two Republicans, two members of the American Labor party, two members of the City Fusion party and one Independent. As the local legislative body with power to make the local laws, the Council is an important branch of the city's government.
"Why all the worry about your team?" says the message attached to the ornament on the desk of Jim Crowley, Fordham coach.

ROME, Oct. 29 -- The Italians learned the sad news tonight when the point system for the clothing cards was issued that they can have a suit or a pair of shoes during the coming year, but not both. Moreover, their suit or shoes will have to last more than a year since so many points are taken off that not enough are left for other necessaries.

Katharine Cornell has chosen Philip Merivale as her leading man in the Henri Bernstein play, tentatively called "Rose Burke." It will open here in February. San Francisco, where Miss Cornell's tour in "The Doctor's Dilemma" ends on Dec. 13, will be the first city to assay the new work on Jan. 5.

ALBANY, Oct. 29 -- Pre-election expenses and disbursements of the La Guardia - McGoldrick - Morris Committee, of which Walter S. Mack is treasurer, were reported today to Secretary of State Walsh. The receipts were $21,766 and disbursements $20,958.
Shrimp, of late, have been following a perverse course that leaves the managers of the numerous small stalls in the Fulton Market shaking: their heads in bewilderment.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland, four-time champion, and Irving Crane of Livonia, N.Y., climbed into a four-way tie with Ralph Greenleaf of Chicago and defending champion Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia for the lead in the world pocket billiard championship today.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Mounting evidence that the Germans may be in for a long Winter campaign has caused something akin to panic in the generally will-oiled Nazi commissariat, according to the British Ministry of Economic Warfare.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic nominee for Mayor; James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, and Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, who presided, all attacked Mayor La Guardia last night at the main rally of Tammany Hall at Manhattan Center for using abusive language and making false statements.

BERLIN, Oct. 29 -- In six days of alternating pursuit and attack on the sea between Gibraltar and Southern England, a pack of German U-boats sank fourteen merchantmen from a single British convoy and torpedoed a British destroyer, a German message states.

Mayor La Guardia charged yesterday that the "big guns" of the Democratic party, faced with a losing municipal campaign and lacking a "single, solitary real issue," had resorted to abuse and name calling similar to the language employed by Nazi spokesmen, in Berlin in assailing President Roosevelt's Navy Day address.

A firm tone prevailed yesterday in the cotton market and closing quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 9 to 11 points. Trading was quiet, and about the only feature to the market was a spurt in the early afternoon on reports from Washington that Republicans in the House would oppose ceilings on wages and farm products.

HONOLULU, Oct. 29 -- President Roosevelt's Navy Day speech in the opinion of most responsible quarters here, not only makes American participation in a shooting war inevitable, but puts the date of such participation earlier than had been anticipated.

Hunting conditions on the land-owner-sportsman public shooting area in Putnam County have improved considerably since the rainfall of the past weekend, according to the report from wardens at the area's permit station.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 29 -- At the annual meeting of the Women's Long Island Golf Association today, Mrs. James McMillen of Nassau was elected President for 1942. The session was held at the Cedar Creek Club, with thirty-five members present.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 29 -- The Turkish Republic celebrated its eighteenth anniversary today with in impressive display of military might in huge parades and marches-past in the Turkish capital and in Istanbul.

BERRYVILLE, Va., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Miss Marie Pierce, 26, a farmer, testified in the Circuit Court today that she shot Louis T. Moreland, a neighbor-farmer, the night of March 18, only after he had refused to leave her home and had threatened her.
WHOLESALE COMMODITY PRICES U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (August, 1939=100)

Electric power output last week recovered nearly two-thirds of the previous week's loss and reached a level exceeded only by that of two weeks before. The gain was more than the usual seasonal rise and the adjusted index rose to 120.4 from 120.1 for the week ended Oct. 18. It stood at 107.2 for the week ended Oct. 26, 1940.

Very Grim Past In the space of something like forty years, between the second election of Grover Cleveland and the first election of Franklin Roosevelt, there were added to the population of the United States approximately fifty million robber barons, gangsters, boot-leggers, speakeasy wastrels, fake mining stock salesmen, crooked real estate promoters, fraudulent patent medicine vendors and the like.

Mayor La Guardia endorsed yesterday the work of Young America Wants to Help when Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt, national chairman of the organization, reported on its first year of aid to refugee children in Great Britain at City Hall.

Two loft buildings in Manhattan passed yesterday into the hands of realty operators, a Greenwich Village apartment house was purchased by an investor and a building in the Grand Central zone changed hands in a cash deal.

After a morning visit to the navy yard in Brooklyn, where a band greeted him from an American warship with "God Save the King," the Duke of Windsor left Grand Central Station at 7 o'clock last night for Detroit, where he will inspect defense plants today.

ONCE upon a time a certain Miss Nelly Russell of Boston confided to her diary, "Oh, ye scorpions, tarantulas, centipedes and cock-roaches! I feel so tingly all over!" This most un-Bostonian sentiment was inscribed one day in 1874. Ulysses S. Grant was then President of the United States and Miss Nelly Russell was 16.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Oct. 29 -- The Red Army, which held firm and counter-attacked yesterday in the face of one of the heaviest artillery barrages of the war thus far, continued today to strike at the Germans on the Mozhaisk and Maloyaroslavets salients before Moscow.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 29 -- Michael William Etzel, 22, a painter in the Glenn E. Martin airplane plant, admitted that he had cut vital wires on Martin B-26 bombers, but refused today to plead to a warrant charging him with damaging the wires specifically July 12.

Directors of the American Tobacco Company authorized yesterday the declaration of 75-cent dividend on the company's outstanding common and common B shares, payable on Dec.1 to stockholders of record Nov. 10. This will make a total of $4.50 in dividends paid this year.

ROME, Oct. 29 -- Count Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, was back in Rome today after several days of conferences with Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Foreign Minister, on the Eastern Front. His trip was believed in diplomatic circles to be connected with the politico-diplomatic situation in the Mediterranean, and Turkey was mentioned as the power on which the attention of the Axis diplomatists was focused.

The late Louis D. Brandeia favored the re-election of Mayor La Guardia, it was revealed yesterday by Charles C. Burlingham, former president of the Bar Association, who has been active in the Fusion cause for many years.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- A device for recording wild life sounds, which members of the staff of the American Museum of Natural History believe may have considerable scientific and educational potentialities, will be tried out in a beaver house under construction in the Palisades Interstate Park here on Friday evening.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Your editorial "A Labor Program -- Now" is a magnificent piece of public work. It would seem, however, that it does not go as far as it well might.

Voicing his belief that Americans are now generally determined to "get on the move," Lord Barnby, British industrialist and member of the House of Lords, declared yesterday before departing for Europe on the Atlantic Clipper that his observations here convinced him that war production in the United States would soon, climb at an astonishing rate.
BERLIN, Oct. 29 (U.P.) -- Authorized Nazi sources said today that the Germans were "ready to prove to Roosevelt that we are superior to him in every respect -- even in using gutter language."

Major Clement R. Attlee, Lord Privy Seal, leader of the Labor party in the House of Commons and deputy of Prime Minister Winston Churchill, told the conference of the International Labor Organization at Columbia University yesterday that while it was essential to plan now for world economic reconstruction after the was all such planning is "just lost labor unless Hitlerism is destroyed."

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 29 -- Motions attacking convictions of seventeen defendants in the tobacco anti-trust trial, asserting that the verdict was not supported by sufficient evidence and enumerating points on which rulings of the court allegedly were in error, were filed today in Federal District Court here.
WITH RUMANIAN ARMY OF OCCUPATION, at Ochakov, on Black Sea, Oct. 20 (delayed) (AP) -- Rumanian troops stationed in this area believe the Russian war is over as far as they are concerned.

John McCormick, 67 years old, president of the DeVinne-Brown Printing Corporation, at 52 Duane Street, and the corporation itself, yesterday, through their lawyer, Neilson Olcott, entered guilty pleas in Special Sessions to an information that they conspired with fifteen other printing concerns and seventeen of their officers to bid collusively on city printing contracts.

The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers catalogue of 1,250,000 songs became available to the networks of the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System at midnight last night for the first time since Jan. 1. Contracts ending the long and bitter disagreement were signed by network and ASCAP officials late yesterday afternoon in the society's office at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

The strong will and self-control which have brought Willie Bioff, one-tune Chicago urchin, to a position of eminence in the film union field stood by him in Federal court yesterday when he tried to convince a jury that he was really Morris Bioff and that a leading film executive secretly had commissioned Bioff to collect hundreds of thousands of dollars after they had eaten six or eight apples together.

A loan exhibition of Chinese iron pictures opened yesterday in the small special exhibition gallery, E-15, at the Metropolitan Museum and will continue through December. The gallery has been redecorated in Chinese red and orange to form a complementary background for the dark metal pictures.

There is nearly $100 in hard cash lying down at the property clerk's office at police headquarters, and any one who lives or works in the neighborhood of East Thirtieth Street has a pretty good chance of claiming it, especially if he can prove he is in the habit of leaving such sums around in sealed blank envelopes.

Sholom Bernstein, the garrulous informer who has spent four days in Kings County Court testifying against his former underworld bosses, disclosed yesterday that he was assigned to kill another gangster on the West Coast but that instead of killing him he got him a job.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 29 (AP) -- The scarlet and white stripes of Joseph E. Widener, New York sportsman, flashed to their first victory of the Fall meeting at Churchill Downs as Misty Isle scored decisively in the Falls City Handicap, today's featured dash at one mile.

Walter P. Chrysler Jr. gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Edith Helen Backus, daughter of Mrs. Helen C. Backus of this city and the late Frederick Charles Backus, and his brother, Jack Forker Chrysler, whose engagement was announced recently.

One hundred and eighty of the 500 monuments, public ornaments and historic buildings in the city have been built or restored by the Park Department since the La Guardia Administration came into office in 1934, Park commissioner Robert Moses reported to the Mayor yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 -- The steel industry was hopeful tonight that the captive coal mines would reopen within twenty-four hours, thereby halting curtailment of mill operations.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 29 -- Plans for a world-wide workers' revolution, as contained in the Socialist Workers party declaration of principles, were offered in evidence today at the sedition trial of twenty-eight defendants in Federal District Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Brig. Gen. R. L. Maxwell, former Administrator of Export Control, will leave soon with a military mission for the Middle East to study British proposals for broad extension of railway facilities there as a means of implementing resistance to Germany by the Soviet Union.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Hogs moved slightly higher today as the wholesale pork market continued to give encouragement to packing interests. Light weights of around 200 pounds were in good demand at steady to 5 cents higher quotations. For the third consecutive day gains were recorded in dressed pork.
Death Announced Enrollee Frank J. Devine. Fire Department Emergency Auxiliary Corps, H. and L. 23, residing at 520 West 145th St., Manhattan, died Oct. 28.

EDENTON, N.C., Oct. 29 -- Twelve little pigs and their mother, carried off into the blue by the dangling steel cable of a runaway barrage balloon, were found dead today, and here is the story of their aerial voyage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Non-essential Expenditures elected Senator Byrd as its chairman today and prepared to meet next week for a preliminary study of ways and means to effect economies of from $1,000,000,000 to $2,000,000,000 in non-defense expenditures.

William Jefferson Field, president of the Commercial Trust Company of New Jersey of Jersey City, has been nominated as a Class A director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and Frederick E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, has been nominated as a Class B director, it was announced yesterday by Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the board of the Reserve Bank.

The Appellate Division sustained yesterday the right of Dr. George S. Counts, Professor of Education at Teachers College and president of the American Federation of Teachers, to go on the ballot for City Council in Manhattanas candidate of the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee.

Donald Dickson, baritone, who appeared with the Metropolitan Opera Association during its Spring season of 1937 and since has sung principally on radio broadcasts, gave his first New York recital last night in Town Hall.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer blamed Mayor La. Guardia yesterday afternoon as being largely responsible for the spread of the Brooklyn murder ring before it was exposed by Mr. O'Dwyer as Kings County District Attorney. The Democratic candidate for Mayor addressed the members of the Kiwanis Club of New York at their weekly luncheon in the Hotel McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- To those who heard or have read the analysis of price-fixing made yesterday before the House Banking and Currency Committee by Representative Albert Gore the thought might easily occur that there is something unusual in the soil and breed of the Congressional district he represents.

A colorful presentation was, made yesterday at the tea hour in the Metropolitan Museum. In one of the Oriental galleries. Under the auspices of the United China Relief a rainbow-hued collection of thirty colors was exhibited by the Forstmann Woolen Company.

Approving the Board of Education's six-year activity program experiment, the New York State Department of Education after an extensive survey recommended that the program be extended throughout the school system as rapidly as possible, it was disclosed yesterday.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

Tribute to the women of Great Britain and her allies was paid last night by William V. C. Ruxton, president of the British American Ambulance Corpa, who spoke at the Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries at Grand Central Palace.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

A preview of the first exhibition devoted exclusively to children's books, sponsored by the American Institute of Graphic Arts, was held last night in the newly opened Junior Museum of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and Eighty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Six new lease agreements, increases in three previously granted by the Defense Plant Corporation, and three loans for defense purposes by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation were announced today by the Federal Loan Agency.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Contracts of a total value of $3,955,895 were awarded today by the War Department. Those to concerns in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut follow:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Republican members of the House Banking Committee lined up in opposition today to inclusion of wages in the Administration's Price Control Bill, it was learned, and it was indicated they also would try to exclude control of farm prices.
Out of the hairdresser's world comes the news that common sense actually can be applied to the creation of what are generally known as "hair-doss"; common sense, mathematics and an Einstein theory.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Soviet Russia has suffered a heavy defeat thus far in the war, but is not finished and desperately needs new planes to challenge Germany's crushing air superiority, expert foreign observers said tonight upon reaching here by Russian passenger plane from Kuibyshev, auxiliary Soviet capital.

An exhibition of contemporary British paintings, purchased with $5,000 donated by the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute, of Arts and Letters, was opened yesterday afternoon at the American British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street.

With Felix Bonadio, sixty-minute center, confined to bed with a severe cold, Manhattan's bruised and tired football team went through its defensive paces yesterday with Alex Cerulli, guard, in the pivot spot. Coming as final preparations are being made to meet the University of Detroit Saturday, the illness of the 188-pound senior was a blow to the Jaspers' hopes for a victory.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The United States and Japan must at least arrange a truce in their economic war if "a very dangerous situation is to be avoided," a high Japanese spokesman said today.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 29 -- The influential Swedish newspaper Dagens Nyheter yesterday published an analysis of the oil situation in Germany after four months of war in the East. The conclusion of the article was that the Axis oil reserves were strained to the utmost.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Federal defense and labor spokesmen decided tonight to give officials of Air Associates, Inc., at Bendix, N.J., one last opportunity to comply with the letter and spirit of the National Defense Mediation Board's recommendations for ending its month-old strike, and the plain indications were that the plant would be commandeered if the company did not cooperate fully.

The two-story building on the northwest corner of Broad and Market Streets in Newark, N.J., one of the busiest intersections in the United States, has been sold by the Prudential Insurance Company of America to the F.W. Woolworth Company in a deal arranged by Harry Thoens Company, brokers.

Democratic majority members of the City Council ordered an investigation of the Health Department and Correction Department yesterday by a committee of five Councilmen, on the basis of a list of specifications against the Health Department submitted by Councilman Walter R. Hart, Brooklyn Democrat, Mr. Hart will head the committee.

The spokesmen for the Axis Powers have never gone farther to justify Winston Churchill's description of them as guttersnipes than in their comments on President Roosevelt's Navy Day speech. The aging athlete who uttered a few words from his familiar perch on the balcony of the Palazzo Venezia on Tuesday was the most restrained.
LONDON, Oct. 29 (U.P.) -- British fighter planes, following up night raids upon Germany, attacked enemy positions in occupied France and Belgium today, according to an Air Ministry communique.

One of the finest existing copies of one of the greatest books in English literature -- the first folio edition of Shakespeare's plays -- was sold for $22,000 when Part 3 of the library of the late A. Edward Newton of Philadelphia came up at auction last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc.

Work by two artists, one French and the other American, constitutes the present attraction at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. These artists are, respectively, Maurice de Vlaminck and Waldo Peirce. To each of them has been accorded one of the large exhibition rooms on the fifth floor.

American Tobacco Dividend Stockholders of the American Tobacco Company are among the first of a large company who will feel the impact of the higher Federal taxes contained in the Revenue Act of 1941. The company had been paying dividends of $1.25 a share quarterly on both the common and common B stocks.

Following are the scheduled public appearances today, announced by the candidates' headquarters and subject to change, of Mayor La Guardia and District Attorney William O'Dwyer, opposing candidates for the Mayoralty:

Barring injury in the last full-length practice session for the Columbia football squad this afternoon, Coach Lou Little will start the same eleven which opened the Lions' last three games, against Cornell at Baker Field Saturday. This means that Adam Spiegel, wingback, will be used in a reserve role, spelling Phil Bayer.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 -- Because of casting conflicts, RKO today opened negotiations to borrow Betty Grable from Twentieth Century-Fox for the lead in "Shore Leave," and to sign Barbara Stan-wyck for the title role in "There Goes Lona Henry."
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- The will of Harold F. McCormick, chairman of the board of the International Harvester Company, who died Oct. 16, at the age of 69, was filed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Charles Fahy, acting solicitor general since the elevation of Francis Biddle to Attorney General, was nominated by President Roosevelt today as Solicitor General. The nomination, sent to the Senate, was referred to the Judiciary Committee, and thence to a subcommittee which will conduct a hearing on Monday.

The National Association of Manufacturers declared yesterday in a report on a special study covering the electric power demands of the defense program that, taking into consideration power construction scheduled for completion by the end of 1943, the electric power supply of the United States should prove sufficient to meet "probable demands of the defense program."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 -- In the midst of renewed threats from the Los Angeles and San Francisco Bay areas of a further extension of the welders' strike which has hampered defense shipbuilding in Seattle and Tacoma, strike leaders prepared tonight to fly to Washington for a conference.

The first formal Interview granted by the Duchess of Windsor since her arrival in this country found her willing yesterday to discuss topics ranging from her much maligned clothes-buying "spree" to the welfare clinics in the Bahamas that she sponsors.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, in the Egyptian desert, Oct. 29 -- The exploits of British patrols, although small change against the vast background of this war, are often thrilling in detail. Day after day and night after night the British holding out at Tobruk, now in the seventh month, perform on a small scale feats that are gems of courage and skilful tactics.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 29 -- Wesleyan's gridiron forces have not set the football world on fire, nor have they started any flames in the hearts of their followers. Three defeats in five games are hardly conducive to any burning demonstrations, but there can be no criticism of the Wesmen's enthusiasm and determination.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 29 -- The War Department released the following order today, dated Oct. 28:

The midtown film scene remains unchanged today as "You'll Never Get Rich" enters its second and final week at the Radio City Music Hall. A new Mickey Mouse cartoon, "A Gentleman's Gentleman," will be added to the program. . . . "Honky Tonk" starts its fifth and final week today at the Capitol.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Efforts of the Securities and Exchange Commission to prevent stock manipulations are so effective that in many cases manipulative plans to unload securities on the public at inflated prices have been exposed and halted practically before they began, Ganson Purcell, a member of the commission, told the House Interstate Commerce Committee today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : As reported in your newspaper recently, the sale of United States defense bonds throughout the country reached $1,504,411,000 as of Sept. 30. September sales of these bonds were $232,327,000. Defense stamp sales as of the same date totaled $18,998,000 for the initial five months of the effort.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Administration resolution repealing the vital portions of the Neutrality Act of 1939 was declared a "war measure" time and again in the Senate this afternoon, as critics of President Roosevelt's foreign policy attempted to win new votes against it.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Business on the stock markets today was quiet, with the exception of a boomlet in Cunard Steamship issues. The ordinary rose 1 1/2 to 13 7/8 s., the second preference 1 1/2 at u105 and the first preference 1 at u107. The activity spread to other shipping shares which were firmer.

Hard on the hoofs of the bucking horses, cows and steers of the annual rodeo, Madison Square Garden last night witnessed for the first time a machine-age "Roadeo," staged by the American Trucking Associations, in which the performers were well disciplined behemoths of the highway.

Let's face the facts of Let's Face It!" which was staged at the Imperial last evening. It is a wonderfully joyous musical show. Taking an old remainder, once known as "Cradle Snatchers," Herbert and Dorothy Fields have run it up into an impudent knockabout book that keeps all the performers congenially at work.

Philco's full-page ads In newspapers yesterday on its frequency modulation radio receivers intensify the competitive battle between the company and manufacturers licensed under the Armstrong FM system, according to comment in the radio trade.

TRENTON, Oct. 29 -- With the time of decision drawing near, the Democratic and Republican organizations of New Jersey were speeding up today campaigns for election of their candidates to the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- A curtailment order slashing production of domestic washers and ironers 17.3 per cent below average monthly output in the twelve months ended June 30, last, was issued today by Donald M. Nelson, Director of Priorities of the Office of Production Management.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (U.P.) -- The war blackout is on in the capital, but so far it applies only to formal entertainment. From the White House down official Washington is abandoning those glittering, formal social functions so popular in normal times.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 -- Support of President Roosevelt and the forces of democracy throughout the world and a plea for resettlement of homeless Jewish masses in Palestine were enthusiastically approved by 1,500 delegates of Hadassah, women's Zionist organization of America, in adopting a six-point "declaration of principles" tonight when they opened their annual convention with a mass meeting in Carnegie Music Hall.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, was declared a "traitor to our American ideals, and a menace to the peace and prosperity of our nation," by Senator Ellender in a statement today in the Senate, where Administration leaders were using every precaution to prevent drastic anti-strike legislation being appended to the resolution repealing part of the Neutrality Act.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The destroyer Kearny was actively engaged in combat with a submarine, after responding to distress signals from a convoy under attack by a pack of submarines, when a torpedo exploded in her side and killed eleven men on the night of Oct. 16-17, Secretary Knox said today in a formal report on the first engagement by the Atlantic patrol to result in the death of naval personnel.

BERLIN, Oct. 29 -- Exemption from taxes was offered tonight to Germans with, "iron savings accounts" in a nationwide radio address by Fritz Reinhardt, Assistant Minister of Finance. He admonished his listeners to intensify their savings efforts in helping to finance the war.

A syndicate headed by B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., and including about fifty-four members received yesterday the award of $10,230,000 of city of Asbury Park, N.J., refunding and revenue bonds bearing a fixed interest rate of 3 1/2 percent.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- A "courage diet" for the nation, to be placed, if possible, in every American kitchen to guide housewives in helping to improve the health of the populace, has been devised and will be submitted to the Department of Agriculture for approval Friday, John B. Kelly, National Director of Physical Training for Civilian Defense, said today.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 29 -- A non-wagering match between Market Wise, and Haltal in the Pimlico Special and the second running of the Exterminator Handicap, featuring the appearance of "Old Bones" himself, will mark the opening of the Maryland Jockey Club's thirteen-day Fall meeting at Pimlico tomorrow.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Oct. 29 (U.P.) -- German artillery has unleashed a savage barrage on the approaches to Moscow and the city's defenders expect an onslaught, but without waiting for it they have started attacks that have driven the Germans from several towns, war dispatches said today.
SEATTLE, Oct. 29 (AP) --The Texas Longhorns and the Texas Aggies, both undefeated, looked as large on the nation's gridiron yardstick today as their home State does on the map.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Roosevelt will make a ten-minute talk to representatives of the International Labor Organization, a branch of the League of Nations, at the White House next Wednesday, it was announced today.

THE visitor was the amiable Bob Woodworth, the "public relations counsel" for Purdue, and his official mission was to beat the drum for the Boiler-makers who will meet Foalham at the Polo Grounds this Saturday. But somehow the conversation got off the ground and away up in the air.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 29 -- The defense program Has brought a record volume of business to the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, but its net earnings for the first nine months of this year, owing to increased taxes and operating expenses, were $550,459 less than for the same period in 1940, G.W. McRae, vice president and general manager, reported here today.
