STOCKHOLM, Oct. 29 -- Sweden is solidly with Finland, but is firmly determined to continue the policy of neutrality, Swedish Foreign Minister Christian E. Guenther said today before the open session of the Riksdag, which followed yesterday's secret debate on foreign affairs.

The problem of labor relations is delicate and complicated. It cannot be solved overnight. But if Congress cannot instantly frame a well-rounded program of labor legislation, it can promptly take one essential first step. This is to provide for an obligatory "cooling-off" period of at least thirty days during which labor difficulties may be adjusted by direct negotiation, fact-finding and compulsory mediation procedure.

CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 29 -- Labor's budget was introduced today in the House of Representatives by Treasurer Joseph B. Chifley. It imposes additional taxation of u22,000,000, Australian, compared with the u32,000,000 that former Prime Minister A. W. Faddenhad proposed to raise by a, combination of taxation and compulsory loans in the budget submitted Sept. 24.

In one of the largest realty transactions in White Plains in many months, the Altschul Foundation of Mount Vernon has purchased for a cash consideration of $700,000 from Sam Minskoff Sons, New York builders and operators, the two store buildings erected by them on Mamaroneck Avenue, Martine Avenue and Court Street in 1939.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Austin J. App asks us to mention "one single war we Americans ever got into that the interventionists did not call a war for ideas and an ideal." We cannot do it. America does not fight and never has fought for imperial interests.

Edmund Carl Heine, former $30,000-a-year executive of the Ford Motor Company in Germany, passed an uncomfortable three hours on the witness stand yesterday at the Brooklyn espionage trial as the government sought to break down his testimony that he had gathered and forwarded to Germany information about the United States aviation industry purely for commercial purposes.

The stock market was unable yesterday to retain much of its buoyancy of the previous session, and although isolated issues managed to hold, their heads above water, the list in general sagged irregularly. Trading was at the approximate pace of Tuesday, but it had a lopsided appearance, due to the continued heavy business in low-priced utilities.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- While trading in wheat was slow most of the day there was no material pressure on the market and late in the session buying by commission houses and shorts based on reports that there was a possibility that no ceiling would be imposed on farm products in the Price Control bill now being discussed by Congress caused a sharp advance.

LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- The Exchange Telegraph news agency quoted today a Moscow radio report that Russian bombers had raided Berlin last night, causing fires and explosions among military and industrial targets.

A new series of orders, to be known as "S" (for suspension) orders, will shortly be issued by the Priorities Division of the Office of Production Management as a detailed compliance program gets under way, according to William P. Homans, coordinator of the priorities field service for the north-eastern area.

The French-bred Obash, who had been knocking at the door in recent races, drove home first in yesterday's $5,850 Tarrytown Claiming Stakes, which helped to attract 13,325 persons to Empire City. This was more than double the crowd on the equivalent day a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has called upon the three major networks for a "statement of facts" in regard to their reported refusal of broadcast time for the America First rally in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 29 -- Striving for more smoothness, Yale's coaches declared the varsity attack still ragged tonight after a scrimmage in which a fighting freshman eleven balked the running game except for a few sizable gains with which Chuck Willoughby signalized his return to the line-up.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 30 -- Repudiating the idea that an American Japanese clash is inevitable, Chugai Shogyo organ of the business world, declared yesterday that there was still room for negotiations and endorsed a plan for round-table discussion by American and Japanese delegates.

DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Two C.I.O. strikes in Michigan defense Industries today halted production of eight subchasers and mine sweepers in a Bay City shipyard and closed a Detroit suburban plant producing machine guns for aircraft.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Erie Railroad Company applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to purchase eight of its subsidiaries prior to their dissolution.

VICHY, France, Oct. 29 -- To some extent France today may be compared to the United States in Prohibition times, except that bootleggers here deal in food, not liquor. Each day brings its list of internments, fines and prosecutions, not to speak of establishments closed by administrative order -- bakeries, oil refineries and eating houses.

Bigelow-Sanford Carpet A year-end dividend of $1 a share on the common stock was voted yesterday by the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, bringing dividends for 1941 to $4 a share, or $1 more than in 1940.
The building at 30 Sutton Place will soon number among its tenants a member of the Habsburg family as the result of a lease just arranged by Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton. Inc.

Henrietta Schumann, young American pianist, who has appeared extensively on the radio and in concert, appeared in recital at Carnegie Hall last night. Choosing for her program several works that are not played in season and out by piano recitalists, she elicited approving tributes from a large audience.

The writer of the following article, who has just arrived in New York from London, was for several years a special adviser to the German Foreign Office and was high in the Nazi party's inner councils until 1935, when he broke with Adolf Hitler and left Germany. He is the author of "The Voice of Destruction" and other books exposing Nazi plans for world conquest.

WASHINGTON, Oct 29 -- Nathan Straus, administrator of the United States Housing Authority, complained today to the Senate committee investigating defense expenditures that his organization had secured only "dribbles" of funds to continue defense housing, and declared that other Federal agencies which had received most of the funds had failed to deliver.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Denouncing John L. Lewis as a traitor for calling the captive coal mine strike during the national defense emergency, Representative Russell of Texas introduced a bill today to make the fomenting of defense strikes a treasonable offense.

FRESNO, Calif., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Two Army pilots, lost during a storm from a formation of nineteen planes last Friday, were found alive beside a camp fire in the Mount Whitney region of the high Sierras, the Army reported tonight.

The deer season will open tomorrow in the Adirondacks, and for those who will be on their initial hunt, this is scheduled to be an event that will be remembered with considerable pleasure, disappointment or sorrow. The equipment, preparation and mental attitude of the hunter will determine which of these three are to be attained.
AGAIN the time has come for one of the three annual reviews of reviews. These are some of the books that we have discussed since Independence Day:

Assurance that members of the National Defense Mediation Board would be "as fair as fearless Americans can be" in deciding the issue of the union shop in captive coal mines was given yesterday by William H. Davis, chairman of the board.

As stubborn Soviet resistance and a sticky morass of Russian mud halted or slowed the German "push to the East" yesterday, the stage was being set in the Middle Eastern theatre of war for another act in the great drama of the Levant.

The cotton market was listless and thin again yesterday. After touching both their high and low marks of the day in the first hour of trading, prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange drifted within a narrow range and closed at net gains of 8 to 11 points.

Trading was only fair to slow yesterday in the locally dressed wholesale meat markets. Supplies were uneven. Fresh pork cuts were moderate to light. Steer hind and rib supplies were moderate. Cow beef liberal, other classes about normal. Lamb and fresh pork cuts sold steady to higher, other classes were mostly unchanged.

An appeal to the citizens of New York to support Mayor La Guardia because he has made the city "the foremost living example of democracy in action" was made public yesterday by a committee of leading citizens.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Large Air Corps contracts increased the total value of the Army's awards to $154,440,241 today. Among these were the following, not previously published, which went to companies in the New York area:
LONDON, Oct. 3O (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

Bishop William T. Manning, head of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of New York, urged yesterday the re-election of Mayor La Guardia and the continuance "of the honest, efficient, non-political administration" of the city government already given by him.

Advance Rebuttal Without once mentioning the over-the-counter markets, Emil Schram yesterday devoted a good half of his address before the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce to rebuttal of the arguments which they are certain to present when their turn comes to testify on Security Act revision.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Mrs. Carolyn Packard, who was killed in the airliner crash at Moorhead, Minn., was a former dramatic actress who, with her husband, operated a guest house at 112 South California Avenue here.

BERRYVILLE, Va., Oct. 30 (AP) Miss Marie Pierce, 26, farmerette and divorcee, won acquittal in Clarke County Circuit Court today on a charge of slaying Louis Townsend Moreland, 51, a married farmer-neighbor.

Wendell L. Willkie has been retained as counsel by the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board to defend it against charges of restraint of trade filed recently by the Federal Trade Commission, it was announced last night by Alexander Printz, chairman of the organization, and David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, who heads representatives of labor on the board.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A moderate number of salable hogs, 1,000 below estimates, and continued firmness in dressed pork gave support to the live hog market today Gains of 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight were recorded, with lightweight swine attracting the most interest. Light pork loins remained unchanged wholesale at 22 1/2 to 23 1/2 cents a pound.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 -- A recordshattering performance by an unsung, Argentine-bred horse, Market Wise's narrow victory over Haltal in the Pimlico Special and Exterminator's appearance in the role of guest star provided a series of spine-tingling thrills today for 15,000 racing fans at Pimlico.

New York City's mounted police will be represented at the National Horse Show, which opens in Madison Square Garden next Wednesday, by Sergeant James Gannon, Sergeant Edward Burke and Patrolman Andrew McKnight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A partial "black-out," which 'will extinguish the lights on theatre marquees, store show windows, athletic fields and signs, in seven Southern States where a serious shortage of water menaces the supply of power needed for defense industries, was ordered today by Donald M. Nelson, director of priorities of the Office of Production Management.
Large loft buildings on Broadway and on University Place were among the Manhattan properties reported yesterday as having changed hands.

The stock market demonstrated forcefully yesterday that neither the coal-mine strike nor its conclusion was a factor in the "paralysis" that has beset "our exchange markets." Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, used just such a phrase in describing conditions in Wall Street when he appeared yesterday before the House committee considering changes in the securities laws.

The three taxpayer buildings at 2339 Sixty-fifth Street, 806 Avenue S and 435 Kings Highway, Brooklyn, all of which are occupied by self-service food markets, have been purchased by the Heller Realty Corporation, represented by Abraham Beier, through the Taub Realty Company.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Shortly before last midnight a Montclair telephone operator heard a man's voice gasp the word "Fire" into the transmitter of his telephone. She traced the source of the call and notified local fire headquarters, but firemen arrived too late to save the lives of the man who made the call and of his wife.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The current diplomatic conversations between Japan and the United States looking to an adjustment of differences will offer no prospect of an easing of the situation before the Japanese Diet meets on Nov. 15 if Japan waits for this government to take the lead by making economic concessions, according to all indications today.

Although shortages of raw materials will lead to a considerable revision of the habits of the American people so long as the defense emergency lasts, they will be "pervasive shortages," cutting horizontally across all the people and much of the slack can be taken up by overcoming waste and eliminating frills, according to Sumner H. Slichter, Professor of Business Economics at Harvard University.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- Germany is tightening her belt another notch for the Winter. Civilian passenger train services, already curtailed to a third of peacetime schedules, will be further cut. As of Nov. 1 official permits will be required to buy tickets for any but local trains.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 29:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Department-store sales for the week ended Oct 25 were 8 per cent higher than for the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Sales in the week ended Oct. 18 were up 6 per cent (revised).

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Fastmoving events in Russia have prompted, within the last few days, the adoption of an Administration policy whereby combat planes and related war materials are to be supplied to the Soviet armies even at the expense of the United States Army, subject only to limitations on transportation.

The big news at the Broadhurst Theatre tonight is the local premiere of George Jessel's musical comedy, "High Kickers," in which Sophie Tucker is absolutely guaranteed to do a strip-tease. Or at least her version of one.

Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, announced yesterday that net billings of the company for the third quarter of 1941, at $260,052,000, were the highest for any quarter on record, and that billings, of $663,334,000 for the first nine months of 1941 also were a high record.

Asbury Park, N.J. Formal offerings to the public will be made today by a syndicate headed by B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., of a new issue of $10,230,000 city of Asbury Park, N.J., 3 1/2 per cent refunding general and revenue bonds, dated Nov. 1, 1941.

Immediate passage of the Administration's Emergency Price Control Bill to forestall rapid increases in the cost of living was demanded last night by Price Control Administrator Leon Henderson, addressing "America's Town Meeting of the Air" in a foursided debate at Town Hall.

One hundred and seventy-five police chiefs and their executive aides from the city, Long Island and Westchester County began a course in wartime emergency duties yesterday in the Federal Building at 641 Washington Street, under supervision of the FBI in cooperation with the Office of Civilian Defense.

Despite a decrease of about 13 per cent from, the twelve-year high, record made In the preceding week, bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday continued to show wide gains over those of a year ago.

MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 31 (From official Russian sources; distributed by The Associated Press) -- Soviet troops defending Moscow's approaches beat off German attacks yesterday in another bitterly contested area -- around Tula, munitions center 110 miles to the south -- the Soviet Information Bureau reported today.

Exporters here yesterday welcomed the new plan to permit the Export-Import Bank to finance Latin-American purchases, seeing great benefit in it for Latin-American buyers who have had to pay cash terms. The program was announced in Washington Wednesday. Most business, they pointed out, is on a draft basis and this cash business represents only a part of the total.

A New York-to-Chicagro plane of the American Airlines with seventeen passengers and a crew of three plunged into a farmland patch on the Ontario side of Lake Erie last night and burst into flames. All on board were killed.

Even though, production of civilian goods will be curtailed "it is imperative that we maintain our advertising and our sales efforts in order that there may not be too serious a lag in the reconstruction period following the cessation of hostilities," Arthur W. Ramsdell, vice president and director of sales of the Borden Company, declared yesterday at the monthly luncheon meeting of the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Commodore.

Stout Steve Owen showed little mercy to his Giants yesterday on the Polo Grounds gridiron and in the projection room. He drove them in practice as his reorganized elevens labored long over their own attack and then flayed them verbally while he ran off pictures of last Sunday's game with the Dodgers.

While girls outside in vivid scarlet costumes proclaimed loudly that every one who crossed their picket line must have Fascist and anti-Semitic sympathies fifty members of the motion picture division of Friends of Democracy lunching at Shor's restaurant, 51 West Fifty-first Street, were asked by this organization's national director, Dr. L. M. Birkhead, to contribute $10,000 for a publicity campaign branding Charles A. Lindbergh as a Nazi.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- United States exports in August rose to the highest level of the war period, reaching a total of $455,000000, an increase of 27 per cent compared with July and of 30 per cent compared with August a year ago, the Department of Commerce reported today in revised statistics based on geographical areas.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Rising taxes, defense priorities reactions, and the higher cost of materials generally have made themselves felt in the Christmas flyer catalogues sent out by Sears, Roebuck Co., and Montgomery Ward Co. to their mail-order customers.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, promised last night that when he took over the post at City Hall he would be the Mayor of the whole City of New York. He said he would not be the Mayor for the Democratic party nor the Mayor of Brooklyn, and added that he would not be beholden to any group, organization, race or creed.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Dr. Edith Summerskill, a Laborite member of Parliament, says that Great Britain should raise an army of women to defend their homes if invasion comes.

SAYBROOK, Conn., Oct. 30 -- Indian Hill's Red Pat, victor at Fishers Island last week, repeated in the English springer spaniel puppy stake at the eighth annual trials of the Connecticut Spaniel Field Trial Association, which started today at the Ingham Hill Game Farm.

Twenty judicial positions in Greater New York will be filled as a result of next Tuesday's election. We present as a trustworthy guide for voters the recommendations of the leading Bar Associations and of the Citizens Union with respect to all these vacancies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 25 were 913,605 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 9,275 cars ,or 1 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 75,948 cars, or 9.1 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 84,247 cars, or 10.2 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

An accused Nazi espionage agent testified yesterday at the Brooklyn espionage trial that he had successfully resisted attempts by his German wife to involve him in what he believed to be a spy ring in this country.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 30 -- Brains rather than brawn have boosted Choate School's football prestige considerably this Fall. Long on cunning and aggressiveness, although short on experience and physical massiveness, the current squad has made the Blue and Gold's rooters forget the dismal victoryless 1940 campaign.
Buildings along Park and Fifth Avenues drew many of the new apartment tenancies listed yesterday, when a good share of the volume went into East Side houses.

Westchester County will vote next Tuesday on a proposal to amend the county charter by abolishing the present governing board of forty-four Supervisors and replacing it with a County Board of eleven members. Town Supervisors would continue to be elected, but their jurisdiction would be confined to town affairs.

President Roosevelt ordered seizure of the Bendix, N.J., plant of Air Associates, Inc., last night after riotous demonstrations by non-striking employes inside the plant had twice forced the removal of reinstated C.I.O. strikers under police guard.
The following is the text of the audress last night of Charles A. Lindbergh before an America First rally at Madison Square Garden:

The visor of his coaching cap pulled low over his spectacles, Lou Little stood in the gloom of an overcast afternoon, at Baker Field yesterday, supervising Columbia's final hard workout for the renewal tomorrow of the series with Cornell.

Sholom Bernstein, who has spent five busy days recounting droll stories about life with the Brooklyn murder ring, offered yesterday to disclose the identity of several killers, engendered an etymological discussion of underworld jargon and admitted that he had written letters while in police custody allegedly demanding money under threat.

The strike in the "captive" coal mines is temporarily ended and the issue of the closed shop is now in the hands of the National Defense Mediation Board. In making its decision the temptation, will be strong for the board to take the path of least resistance. That path will doubtless seem, at least for the immediate present, to be the one that awards Mr. Lewis his closed shop.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Dissatisfaction with the manner in which the Administration has been dealing with labor strikes in defense industries was said today to be narrowing the chances of the Senate's passage of "all-out" repeal of vital sections of the Neutrality Act of 1939, as sought by the White House.

Lily Djanel, Belgian lyric soprano, has been engaged for the orthcoming season of the Metropolitan Opera Association, Edward ohnson, general manager, announced yesterday. Although the arts in which Miss Djanel will appear here have not as yet been diulged, it is understood that among them is likely to be the title role in sizet's "Carmen" in the restudied ersion which Sir Thomas Beecham will conduct.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Greek submarines operating in the Mediterranean have sunk 50,000 tons of Italian shipping, A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, said today at the meeting of the Anglo-Hellenic League to commemorate the first anniversary of Italy's invasion of Greece.

To counteract the lull in consumer demand for furs during the last few weeks and to offset the competition of tax-free cloth coats, a new promotional campaign having a patriotic appeal and sponsored by the Associated Fur Coat and Trimmings Manufacturers was launched yesterday at a special meeting of more than 100 retail merchandisers and representatives of the industry at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 30 -- Japanese military strength in Indo-China has not reached offensive proportions either in the north or in the south, well-informed sources here believe today.

The twenty-eighth annual exhibition of the Allied Artists of America will be seen at a preview tonight and will be open to the public tomorrow morning in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.
TIME out from football! With all this chatter of triple reverses, T-formations, short-side spinners, split ends and turned-around centers, a fellow has to spar for breath now and then.

So far $58,234 has been raised in the campaign of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York for $225,000, it was reported yesterday at a luncheon for campaign workers at 600 Lexington Avenue, national headquarters.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Note circulation continued to increase in the week ended yesterday the Bank of England statement today revealed. Circulation figures showed a gain of approximately u4,800,000 for the week, the eighth consecutive week this figure has advanced.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 30 -- Metro signed Ronald Colman today for the male lead in James Hilton's "Random Harvest" and named Greer Garson to play opposite him. The Hilton novel, which Metro bought last year for a reported $65,000, originally was scheduled for British production with Robert Donat as star and with Clarence Brown directing, but Brown withdrew because of the dual income tax to which he would have been subject.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Irving Crane of Livonia, N.Y., took an undisputed lead in the world pocket billiard championship tonight by upsetting the defending champion, Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia, 125 to 75, in eight innings. It was Mosconi's second straight defeat.

With most of his regulars absent for the greater part of practice because of late classes, Coach Jim Crowley sent the rest of the Fordham football squad through an intensive drill yesterday on Rose Hill, their final hard workout for the Purdue game tomorrow at the Polo Grounds.

ROME, Oct. 30 -- The Germans "will not betray" Italy after the war, Roberto Farinacci told 40,000 persons in Trieste in a speech he made to them on Tuesday, it was learned today when the Regime Fascista of Cremona arrived here. Italy's traditional enemy, he said, was not Germany but Habsburg Austria.

MOORHEAD, Minn., Oct. 30 -- Fourteen persons perished at about 2 A.M. today when a North-west Airlines plane crashed and burned on a prairie within sight of its destination, the airport at Fargo, N.D., across the Red River from here.

NEW YORK Princess Elisabeth and Princess Marie-Adelaide, daughters of the Grand Duchess Charlotte of Luxembourg, who were at the Waldorf-Astoria with Mrs. Joseph Beck, wife of the Luxembourg Foreign Minister in London, have left to visit their grandmother, the Grand Duchess Marianne, in Washington, before returning to their home in Quebec.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 -- Formation of an armed Jewish corps in the Near East to serve on a basis of equality with Britain's other allies, and denunciation of England's "crystallization policy" which curtailed Jewish immigration to the Holy Land, were stressed in resolutions adopted at the closed political session of the annual convention of Hadassah, women's Zionist Organization of America, at its session tonight.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Archbishop John T. McNicholas, writing to priests and laity of his archdiocese, said today that the late Pope Pius XI's denunciation of communism "was not given as a moral direction to governments regarding aid or refusal of aid to Russia in case of a war of defense" and "the same must be said regarding diplomatic relations with Russia."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- John L. Lewis called off the captive mine strike at 11:30 A.M. today. At 2 P.M. he announced that he had set a new strike deadline for Nov. 15.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : If the author of a letter which appeared in THE TIMES today in defense of Austro-Hungarian action against Serbia in 1914 is a former Austrian subject, I respect his feelings. They are natural, given the great past of the Vienna monarchy.

Democracy, like communism and nazism, must "give hope of a new order" if the United States is to develop good national morale, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared last night at a dinner meeting of the tenth educational conference held at the Hotel Biltmore.

Willie Bioff, the movie union leader who is on trial in Federal court for the alleged extortion of $550,000 from four film companies, volunteered testimony yesterday that Joseph M. Schenck had bought $200,000 worth of stock for Murray W. Garsson when Garsson was chief investigator for a Congressional committee.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 30 -- W. T. Ashcroft has been appointed assistant production manager by the Remington Arms Company, effective Dec. 1, it was announced here today. Mr. Ashcroft, who is now works manager, will report to C. M. Green, production manager.

A warning to women of the United States to be on guard against "the dangers lurking at their doors" and to strengthen home defense was issued yesterday by women from ten countries that have been the victims of aggression.

The Nypano Railroad Company, successor to the New York, Pennsylvania Ohio Railroad Company, and the trustees of the Nypano Railroad property have called for redemption on Dec. 1 all outstanding prior lien bonds of the New York, Pennsylvania Ohio (extended under the agreement of March 1, 1935), at 103 .nd interest.

VICHY, France, Oct. 30 -- "At Escoire, in the Dordogne Department, funeral services have been held for Mile. Amelie Girard, M. Georges Girard, assistant curator of archives at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and Mme. Louise Soudieux. They were, held very quietly on Oct. 29, 1941."

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 30 -- Although, silk stockings and other luxury goods are still on sale in Egyptian stores wartime conditions have unsettled the local economy in a way that forecasts a certain amount of inconvenience for the average citizen.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- President Roosevelt signed today the new Tax Amortization Bill and issued a statement explaining its provisions and purposes. The statement read:

Mayor La Guardia received yesterday an American flag and a small model of the Caproni plane he flew in the World War when 200 members of veterans' organizations, including many city employes, held a rally in City Hall Park.

TRENTON, Oct. 30 -- Governor Edison's investigation of the State Highway Department turned today to the part politics may have played in the hiring, promoting and disciplining of the employes of the maintenance division, with the opening testimony and other evidence indicating that it was the dominant factor in the hiring of workers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- At the request of the Office of Production Management, the Defense Plant Corporation has authorized a lease agreement with the Granite City Steel Company for the construction and equipment of a plant at Granite City, Ill., for the production of steel ingots and plates.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES. Former President Hoover has again come forward as self-designated spokesman for the subjugated nations of Europe to plead that food be sent to their children.

Republic Steel Net profit of the Republic Steel Corporation for the third quarter of 1941 amounted to 54,378,379 after all deductions, equal after prior preference and preferred dividend requirements to 68 cents a share on 5,670,628 common shares.

The map of an entirely imaginary parcel of real estate was sold at auction here yesterday for $3,200. The land described in this map lies in a distant sea, bounded only by the fancy of a romantic author, and safe, even, from the scheming of Nazi cartographers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- By a vote of 16 to 5, the House Banking and Currency Committee rejected today the bill by Representative Gore of Tennessee for a universal plan of price control, but it adopted one of Mr. Gore's proposals that all price-fixing legislation terminate on June 30, 1943.

Convinced that gasoline will be diverted ultimately from its usual channels for use in national defense, the executive committee of the Eastern States Gasoline Dealers Conference voted yesterday to recommend that all retailers continue the voluntary observance of the gasoline curfew.

On the eve of the effective date of the Federal Reserve Board's new reserve requirements for member banks which will cut the excess' reserves of the New York City banks by at least $500,000,000, the weekly figures, as of Wednesday, released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, reveal that excess reserves of the city's member institutions fell $190,000,000 in the period.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- American-built British bombers, smashing at one of Germany's main supply ports for the northern Russian front, left seven German ships -- six supply vessels and a small warship -- sinking or afire in the flame-wreathed western Norwegian harbor of Aalesund and hit another ship outside that port last night, the Air Ministry reported tonight.

The Department of Justice, the United States Treasury and the Securities and Exchange Commission, are conducting an exhaustive investigation into the corporate activities and financial affairs of Sofina, a sprawling European utility holding company and investment trust, which, indirectly through subsidiaries, is operating now in the United States, it was learned yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 30 -- Waves of British medium bombers swooped over Southern Italy in resumption yesterday of the drive against Axis supplies for Libya. Siderno, Soverato and Locri were the chief objectives of the raid.
The first information service to be set up in any of the thirty Department of Health Districts was officially opened yesterday afternoon at the Lower West Side Health Center, 303 Ninth Avenue.

Replying by John T. Flynn, chairman of the New York chapter of the American First Committee, who accused CBS and the other major radio networks of prejudice in favor of the interventionist cause at a rally in Madison Square Garden last night, the Columbia Broadcasting System issued the following statement:

Mayor La Guardia, deviating in most of his speeches yesterday from his attacks on the politicians in both parties, stressed instead the substantial accomplishments of his administration, and included, for the first time, a budget analysis to prove that he actually had saved the city $100,000,000 a year during his administration.

I WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Liberalizing amendments to the Securities Acts of 1933 and 1934 are necessary to preserve the American system of free private enterprise, the House Interstate Commerce Committee was told today by several spokesmen for securities dealers' organizations.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Noel Coward, actor and playwright, appearing in Bow Street Court today, was fined u200. with u20 costs, for failing to register $57,847 in American assets with the British Government.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 30 -- The campaign for the election of candidates for the Legislature moved into North Jersey tonight as Representative Charles A. Eaton of the Fifth Congressional District addressed a Republican rally at Morristown and Governor Charles Edison spoke at a Democratic rally in South Orange.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- President Roosevelt granted a leave of absence from government service today to John D. Biggers, Special Minister to London and Lease-Lend Expediter.
MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 31 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The official agency Toss today broadcast the following Soviet communique:
Three new pictures will open in Broadway theatres this morning.

VICHY, France, Oct. 30 -- Under the title of "Plans and Prospects of the New French State," the weekly newspaper Gringoire today publishes under the signature of the former rightist Deputy Philippe Henriot an interview with Pierre Pucheu, Minister of the Interior, that implies the State will be totalitarian and supported by a single party growing out of the War Veterans Legion.
Arthur W. Page of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club was elected president of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound yesterday at the annual meeting of delegates at the New York Yacht Club.

Attorneys representing owners of the forty-eight licensed junk boats in New York Harbor conferred yesterday at the Barge Office with Captain John S. Baylis of the United States Coast Guard, Captain of the Port, in an attempt to obtain a fifteen-day extension on the permits, which expire today.

Declaring that "there is no danger to this nation from without" but that "our only danger lies from within," Charles A. Lindbergh charged last night that the American people were being led into war by subterfuge. He appealed to them to unite behind a demand for "a leadership of integrity" in Washington.

DETROIT, Oct. 30 -- The Duke of Windsor visited this city for the first time in seventeen years today, and in a stay of less than twelve hours rode in a tank, plowed through a ditch in the first cousin to an Army "jeep," and renewed acquaintance with Henry Ford.

VICHY, France, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- French Somaliland authorities have agreed to discuss a British request for the use of the port of Jibuti and the railroad to Addis Ababa, the Vichy government announced today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Professional buying was responsible for an upturn of about 1 cent a bushel in the wheat market on the Board of Trade here early today, but the strength came largely from sympathy with other grains rather than to any other influence.

Operations of Marshall Field Co., textile manufacturers and operators of department stores and other businesses in Chicago and other cities, yielded a net profit of $1,098,167 in the three months ended with September, according to the report of F.D. Corley, president, issued for publication today.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- Information reaching London from several trustworthy sources strongly Indicated today that Japan was preparing to launch a new and powerful campaign against Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in a final effort to end the long Chinese-Japanese conflict.

In the belief that the best if not the only chance of the election of District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic nominee for Mayor, lies is a shift of voters because of Mayor La Guardia's allegedly slurring references to Governor Lehman, Democratic speakers concentrated last nignt on further attacks on the Mayor for use of vituperative language and on assertions that the Mayor has a dictator complex.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Italy has the largest number of subjects among a total population of nearly 5,000,000 aliens resident in the United States, according to final figures on the registration of aliens given out by the Department of Justice.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 30 -- The presence of so many men without a country who continue to serve the Allied cause offers a striking feature in the Middle East.
BERLIN, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique from the Fuehrer's Headquarters today:

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Oct. 30 -- Trading on the Bourse today was small but the tone was cheerful. Dutch Indians showed gains up to 10 points. Royal Dutch rose 5 1/8 points to 317 1/8; Amsterdam Rubber 7 1/4 to 309 3/4; Amsterdam Trading 10 to 457; Philips 4 to 276 1/2 and Unilever 2 to 161 7/8.

Cold Wave to Test Trade Theory Reports that a cold wave is due in this city at the week-end will enable retailers to test their theory that recent slowness in retail trade has been largely due to abnormally warm weather. A number of stores here have planned important promotions for the week-end, and the response to these events will be watched with keen interest, particularly in fur and cloth coat lines.

Ray Robinson's big moment is at hand. In the climax of a year of sensational campaigning, the 21-year-old Harlem fighter will climb through the ropes at Madison Square Garden tonight for his ten-round battle with Fritzie Zivic, certain that a triumph over the former welterweight champion would place him right in front for a crack at the welterweight crown now held by Freddie (Red) Cochrane.
TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 31 -- Addressing the Japan-East Asia Development League yesterday as its ex officio president, Premier Hi-deki Tojo said:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The United States Government has been forced to take precautions against a new crop of Axis agents who have been attempting to evade the restriction of our official Latin-American "blacklist."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A registration statement covering an issue of $15,000,000 of serial debentures due at the rate of $1,000,000 annually from Nov. 1, 1942, to Nov. 1, 1956, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Hiram Walker-Gooder-ham and Worts, Ltd., a Canadian company, and Hiram Walker Sons, Inc., an American company.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- Lunch-hour crowds in the Mamaroneck Avenue shopping area here were surprised today when two clubwomen stepped from a chauffeur-driven automobile and started picketing the headquarters of the Citizens Home Rule Committee of Westchester County, carrying a sign that said "unfair to taxpayers."

The report of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company announced yesterday disclosed a net profit of $1,781,216 for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 after depreciation, interest and provision of $3,000,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes.

There was immense enthusiasm last night in Carnegie Hall at the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's concert when Robert Casadesus finished the Ravel piano concerto for the left hand alone, and, with Mr. Barbirolli, who had conducted, was called back by an audience that would not have enough of him, to acknowledge the crashing applause.

United States Leather A dividend of $3.75 a share against arrears on the prior preference stock was announced by the United States Leather Company. This will bring payments for 1940 to $14 a share. Dividends this year were the first since January, 1938.

The two-story colonial-type dwelling at 551 Wolf's Lane, Pelham Manor, Westchester, has been sold by the East River Savings Bank to William G. and Madelon Gabel in a deal arranged by Sylvester E. Powers, broker.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed Reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

One of the best played favorites of the meeting, the Barrington Stable's Olympus, got home first yesterday at Empire City as 12,911 persons watched on a bleak afternoon when $807,884 was wagered on seven races and the daily double.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 30 (AP) -- In warlike surrounding's at Mexico City's mountain-locked Chapultepec Country Club, sixteen topnotch United States golfers and an equal number of Mexican stars today played the eighteen-hole qualifying round for the 1941 Mexican amateur championship.

Homemakers eagerly scanning the price tags in their butcher's showcases will see much to console them this week-end. Meat prices have in most cases held or bettered the reductions reported eight days ago by the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A plan of the Treasury to absorb surplus purchasing power by increasing social security taxes will be ready for presentation to Congress before the end of the year, Secretary Morgenthau said today.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- Except before Moscow, where heavy rainfall continued, German troops were advancing on the whole Eastern Front from Leningrad to the Donets River and Crimea, German reports claimed today.

Denying that epidemics of dysentery and cholera infantum had been traced to milk sold in city depots, Health Commissioner John L. Rice said yesterday that the City Council had made a "malicious and unwarranted attack" on his department in ordering an official investigation of it.

Harvard's investments in foreign bonds in the last two years have been "negligible," according to an article in the Nov.1 issue of the Harvard Alumni Bulletin. With the article are three charts which for the first time reveal the university's distribution of its investment of its $143,000,000 endowment, the oldest and largest for any university in the country.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Oct. 30 -- This dispatch may throw some light upon one of the principal questions in America today: Can Russia maintain sufficient industrial production by successful transfer of factories to keep a large army equipped with mechanical supplies?
Industrial and business properties in Long Island City and Maspeth figured In several Long Island transactions reported yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- The lonely note of a bugle through the frosty night air, sounding taps on the reservation, touched off a pyramid of fire as the climax of a night of unbridled enthusiasm on the eve of Army's departure to meet Notre Dame at the Yankee Stadium.

VICHY, France, Oct. 30 -- According to officials here, slight response is expected in the unoccupied zone of France tomorrow to General de Gaulle's appeal for a five - minute silence in memory of the recently executed French hostages.

An investing client of the Herman A. Acker Corporation bought from the Peoples National Bank Trust Company the six story apartment house at 340 East 207th Street, the Bronx, paying cash above a first mortgage of $45,000.
The Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A interclub series opened last night with the Downtown A.C., last year's champion, scoring a decisive triumph as six teams swung into action.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 3O (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued this communique today:

Mayor La Guardia dared District Attorney William O'Dwyer yesterday to follow through with his statements that the "paymaster" of the Brooklyn murder ring was still at large, and known to the Mayor. He issued his challenge after Police Commissioner Valentine, during the day, had denied the O'Dwyer charges and put the responsibility for any unsolved crimes back on the Kings County prosecutor.

Never, Never, Never! Winston Churchill told the boys at Harrow School that the big lesson for them from today's events is never to give in to force, never, never, never! Mr. Churchill is not the first British Prime Minister to employ the emphatic triple never.

N.Y.U.'s hopes for victory over Penn State tonight at the Polo Grounds are founded not so much on the Violet's estimate of its own abilities as on Penn State's demonstrated shortcomings. In four games this season the Nittany Lions have proved vulnerable defensively, inconsistent offensively and generally weaker than the 1940 eleven which scored a 25-0 victory over N.Y.U.

Final contracts are all but ready to sign for the merger of Whitehouse Co., one of the oldest firms on the New York Stock Exchange, with the "Winthrop end" of Winthrop, Mitchell Co. Leeds Mitchell and his Chicago associates in the firm recently arranged to join Shearson, Hammill Co.
Mayor La Guardia, in a brief ceremony yesterday afternoon, dedicated the new $1,000,000 outpatient dispensary building of the Kings County Hospital, at Clarkson and New York Avenues, Brooklyn.

Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran, whose memoranda to the judges of his court have been frequently marked by philosophic phrases, sent letters yesterday to the magistrate court clerks urging simplification in the procedure of opening the sessions of these tribunals.

Earnings for the quarter year ended Oct. 4 are estimated by Paramount Pictures, Inc., at $3,071,000 after interest and all charges including provision for all Federal taxes, normal Federal income taxes being computed at 31 per cent, the company's report revealed yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Oct. 31 -- A serious threat to the Moscow defenses from the south-west has developed in the last twenty-four hours, it was acknowledged by an authoritative Soviet broadcaster early today.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., Oct. 30 -- As workmen were putting the finishing touches on the stockade for aliens here, it was learned unofficially that the next project at the concentration camp would be the erection, of a barbed-wire fence around one of the post's hospital buildings designated for the treatment of aliens who became ill while interned.

With the starting status of several regulars in doubt, Manhattan's twenty-nine man football squad entrained last night for Detroit to tangle with the powerful University of Detroit eleven tomorrow in the only intersectional clash for Kelly-Green this campaign.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -- Captain Gene Davis's Pennsylvania team, undefeated and untied, meets Navy, unbeaten but tied by Harvard a week ago, on Franklin Field tomorrow before a capacity crowd of 74,000.
BERLIN, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler's Headquarters issued the following communique today:

Mr. Paul P. Rao is a Democratic candidate for judge of the Supreme Court in the First District. All the bar associations of Manhattan and the Bronx have examined through committees his record and professional standards as a lawyer, his intellectual capacity and his knowledge of law.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 31 -- Mastermind behind the Minneapolis Union Defense Guard, which the government argues was really a private army, was Leon Trotsky, who was slain in Mexico, jurors were told this afternoon in the sedition trial of Socialist Workers party members in Federal District Court.

Q, Has H.R. Knickerbocker just published a new book? A., Yes. Q. What is it called? --- It is called "Is Tomorrow Hitler's?"* Q. What is it about? A. It is about the war. Mr. Knickerbocker, as you know, has served as a correspondent in most of the wars of the last two decades. Q. In what form is it written ? A. I'm glad you asked me that.

ST. THOMAS, Ont., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Three inspectors of the United States Civil Aeronautics Board took over tonight the investigation into the unexplained crash of an American Airlines transport plane which plunged seventeen passengers and three crew members to death in an oat field Thursday night in a drizzling rain.

The City Planning Commission in adopting the city's capital outlay budget yesterday said Federal aid had made possible the large improvements in the city in the last eight years and expressed the hope that Federal funds would be provided to meet a two-billion dollar program of municipal improvements during the next six years.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Yale will meet Brown tomorrow in the Bowl with a line-up which will not be decided upon till game time. Coach Spike Nelson said that he had decided to start Jack Ferguson, 1940 freshman captain, in his first intercollegiate game. He replaces Ed Taylor at tailback.

The new Cotillion Room of the Pierre was opened formally last night with a special dinner and supper dance featured by an entertainment program. Many members of society were hosts at dinners and supper parties. The rendezvous will be opened to the public today at the luncheon period.

Acting swiftly on President Roosevelt's Executive, order to seize and operate the airplane parts plant of Air Associates, Inc., at Bendix, N.J., the Army Air Corps, backed by 2,100 fully armed troops from near-by New York and New Jersey stations, moved in early yesterday to take over the small but vital defense plant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A representative of the Investment Bankers Association asked Congress today to relax regulations relating to the sale of securities in order that "we may still do business" and yet give prospective purchasers full information.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31 -- Harvard's cross-country team upset Yale and Princeton on the grueling five-mile Lake Carnegie course today in the annual Big Three hill and dale varsity meet. The Crimson outpointed Princeton, 27 -- 32, and won from Yale, 26 -- 37.

The five-day strike of 5,800 C.I.O. members at the Brooklyn yard of the Robins Dry Dock and Repair Company was settled yesterday, clearing the way for resumption of repair work Monday morning on fourteen British and American merchant ships.

Despite the political and economic differences between the United States and the Latin American countries, the spirit of hemispheric solidarity is steadily improving, Dr. Stephen Duggan, director, Institute of International Education, declared yesterday at the tenth educational conference at the Hotel Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Administration leaders said today that the sinking of the destroyer Reuben James had solidified a "safe majority" in a grim determination to remove all restraints from America's full exercise of the right of freedom of the seas.

Eugene C. Donovan, president of the New York State Bankers Association, announced yesterday that he had notified Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau that all the 706 banks in New York State eligible to qualify as issuing agents for defense savings bonds, Series E, were so qualified.

An overwhelming majority of the city's trade union voters will cast their ballots for Mayor LaGuardia next Tuesday, on the basis of his eight years of service to labor at City Hall and his twentyfive years of pro-labor activities during his public career, Thomas J. Lyons, president of the New York State Federation of Labor, predicted last night.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Another Yale football team has exploded in the face of its public. Yale's showing against Army was unbelievable in view of the ability of its coach, certainly one of the ten best in the country. What is the trouble?

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Austin J. App's letter in your issue of Oct. 29 is not really an argument for a negotiated peace but an argument for a German victory. He denies idealistic motives to the British but he affirms a high and lofty idealism on the part of Germany.
New York's football spectacle of the year comes into the Yankee Stadium today in the twenty-eighth meeting between Army and Notre Dame.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A bill providing pay increases for all the armed services, from the lowest Army buck private to the top-ranking Navy admiral, was introduced in the Senate today by a Military Affairs subcommittee.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: As a firm believer in the necessity and fairness of compulsory service in some branch of national defense at this time, I cannot avoid resentment when eligible young men seek to avoid that service.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Growing governmental concern over the problem of speeding up steel production to the expanding rate required for defense was evident today in orders and statements from Federal agencies charged with pushing the defense effort

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The sinking of the destroyer, Reuben James, in the view of informed British naval circles, highlights the current phase of the Battle of the Atlantic. The belief here is that Germany is "all out" now to make her submarines operating in the North Atlantic as much of a danger and a nuisance to the United States convoy escorts as can be accomplished.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Starting the opening phases of advanced training, first units of Maj. Gen. Henry W. Baird's Fourth Armored Division this week engaged in field exercises in which companies and platoons were pitted against each other in a miniature of the Red and Blue opposition characterizing all army manoeuvres.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: John Kieran's Saturday football forecasts follow a policy that has puzzled a number of TIMES readers for a long time.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 1 -- German, troops have crashed through the outer defenses of Tula, a city of 200,000 only 110 miles south of Moscow, and Nazi forces also are driving through Crimea, headed for a showdown with the Soviet BlacK Sea Bleet, Russian reports said today.

The United States Destroyer Reuben James, first American warship to be sunk in this war, was one of scores of World War destroyers which were completed too late to be used in the 1917-18 hostilities but the war careers of which were eventually realized when they were "resurrected from the graveyard" two years ago to enforce the Neutrality law.

Announcing the declaration of a dividend of $1.50 a share, the fourth of the year, K.T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation, said yesterday that net profit of the company and subsidiaries for the first nine months of 1941 was $29,460,848, after all deductions, equivalent to $6.77 a share on the capital stock.

Three annual exhibitions open tomorrow in Philadelphia at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. The thirty-ninth annual Philadelphia Water-Color and Print Exhibition will be held with the cooperation of the Philadelphia Water-Color Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Continued expansion of defense production and an employment rise of approximately 218,000 workers between Aug. 15 and Sept. 15 were reported today by Secretary of Labor Perkins.

A case believed to be the first involving a fraud based on the Federal procedure for reorganizing corporations, as distinguished from ordinary bankruptcy procedure, resulted yesterday in the conviction of five men. The racket, according to Jay Slonim, assistant Federal prosecutor, was designed to take advantage of the fact that a trustee in reorganization is not required to scrutinize thoroughly the listed assets of the corporation involved.

The word seems to have hung over the world so long, like a bar sinister, that it is difficult to believe that it is only five years ago today that we heard the first mention of the "Axis" as applied to a line of policy connecting Rome and Berlin.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Japan is ready to undertake mediation of the Russo-German war if an opportunity can be found, the English language newspaper Japan Times Advertiser, which usually reflects the views of the Foreign Office, said today in an editorial.

NORDEGG, Alberta, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- Twenty-seven miners working on the fourth level of the big Brazeau Collieries here were killed in an explosion which buried many of the victims under tons of coal and rock, rescue operations revealed tonight.

As a result of recommendations by the Office of Price, Administration, prices on the 1942 lines of electric refrigerators will be practically unchanged from the last prevailing lists on current models, it was learned here yesterday.

Despite the Federal income and excess profits taxes which were more than double those of the previous year, earnings of the Reynolds Metals Company in the nine months ended with September increased substantially over the 1940 period.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Last July I invited the members of the Track Writers Association to enter the City Hall to Coney Island walking contest, held on Thanks giving Day. I promised to pay their entry fees and now take liberty to repeat the offer.

LONDON, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- A Yugoslav spokesman asserted tonight that Yugoslavia's "second war" against the Axis was raging between 80,000 guerrillas and German and Italian occupation troops along a 125-mile battle front in the Serbian hills.
Riding on the crest of four straight victories, Fordham meets its third intersectional opponent of the season when it plays Purdue University this afternoon at the Polo Grounds.

A jurisdictional strike growing jut of a dispute between two A.F. of L. unions has halted painting work in the new $5,300,000 storehouse and office building at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, commandant of the yard, disclosed yesterday.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 31 -- The plant of Becton, Dickinson Co., one of the largest manufacturers of surgical instruments in the nation, was shut down today by a strike of 750 production employes. The plant has about 250 other employes.

Trade Here Up 10% or More Cooler weather stimulated retail trade here this week. Apparel was a more direct beneficiary than home wares departments. Department store sales were estimated as likely to show an increase of 10 per cent or more over the like week of last year.

VICHY, France, Oct. 31-- In Vichy at 4 o'clock this afternoon it was impossible to detect that any one was aware that General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Free French forces, had asked for a five-minute demonstration of silence for that hour.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Manufacturers' shipments climbed to the highest volume on record in September and as a result the expansion in backlogs was the smallest for any month this year, according to the Commerce Department. New orders placed with manufacturers also turned upward during the month despite growing restrictions imposed by defense needs.

An ex-King climbed the stairs of an old-fashioned East Side tenement yesterday, chatted with housewives over the simmer of cabbage, and literally was mobbed by the youngsters of Gouverneur and Madison Streets as ha crossed to inspect an example of a newer type of housing.

Blush-pink biscuits that owed their hue to the application of tomato juice and honey-flavored carrots were among the menu novelties employed by the first prize winner of an emergency cooking contest arranged by the Women's National Exposition of Arts and Crafts, which is occupying Grand Central Palace this week.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday the "national patience is being tried" and that the sinking of the United States destroyer Reuben James had brought the country to the brink of a declared war with Nazi Germany.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 31 -- Assailing "the wave of disastrous defense strikes," Senator Clyde L. Herring, Democrat of Iowa, said today that he would sponsor legislation providing that union membership not be required "as a condition of employment on defense work."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 -- "Merrily We Roll Along," the George S. Kaufman-Moss Hart play produced on Broadway in 1934 and then purchased by Metro, but never filmed, has been revived by the studio as a vehicle for Robert Young.

American and British delegates to the conference of the International Labor Organization in session at Columbia University united yesterday in espousing the least possible measure of government interference in employer-employe relations as the means most likely to promote collaboration in industry.

AMSTERDAM (via. Berlin) Oct. 31 -- The Bourse was very quiet and mostly reactionary today. Royal Dutch lost 1 1/2 points to 315 1/2 ; Amsterdam Trading 2 to 485; Amsterdam Rubber 2 to 307 5/8 ; Philips 1 to 275 1/5 and Uniliver 1/2 to 161 3/8. A.K.U. was firmer.

SAYBROOK, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Cinar's Chuck, owned by Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Milbank of New York and handled by Dr. Milbank, won top honors today in the open all-age stake for cocker spaniels, feature event of the eighth annual trials of the Connecticut Spaniel Field Trial Association at the Ingham Hill game farm.

Since George Jessel's "High Kickers" takes a sentimental view of old-fashioned show business, we may as well use an old-fashioned word to describe it -- "melange." It is a musical melange with Sophie Tucker shouting some grimey lyrics, and it was acted with considerable aplomb at the Broadhurst last evening.

Thomas L. Thomas, young baritone from Scranton, Pa., who gave his first New York recital last night in Town Hall, not only possessed a well-schooled voice but used it with intelligence, taste and sensibility in a program which, in addition to songs in German, French, Welsh and English, also contained operatic selections.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The first reaction in the capital to the sinking of the Reuben James was that it would hasten revision of the Neutrality Act.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for saving's banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Memorial Services Members of the Fire Department Anchor Club off duty and other members off duty, who care to participate, are Invited to attend the annual memorial services of the Police Department Anchor Club on Sunday, Nov. 2.
BERLIN, Oct. 31 (AP) -- D.N.B. reported tonight that four more Czechs were executed in Prague today as members of a group active in sabotage and incendiarism.

Mayor La Guardia formally dedicated the new offices of the Legal Aid Society's Criminal Courts Branch in the new Criminal Courts Building, 100 Centre Street, yesterday afternoon. In presenting the keys of the new quarters to William Dean Imbrie, first volunteer lawyer for the society, and to its president, Harrison Tweed, the Mayor said:

Max Rubin, the former school teacher turned labor racketeer, whose stories of the inner workings of organized crime have been principal factors in obtaining forty years in prison for his old friend arid boss, Louit, (Lepke) Buchalter, industrial rackets czar, spent five hours in Kings County Court yesterday offering testimony designed to place Lepke in the electric chair.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 31 -- Accusing him of trying to make himself a political martyr rather than a conscientious objector, Judge John Boyd Avis in Federal District Court here today sentenced the Rev. James E. Bristol of this city to eighteen months in prison for his refusal to fill out a draft questionnaire.

Acting on the invitation of Lease-Lend Administrator Edward R. Stettinius Jr., foreign trade forwarders, members of export commission houses and similar organizations who feel they have been adversely affected by the manner in which goods for Britain have been cleared, will begin formation on Monday of a special committee to meet with the administrator, it was reported yesterday by a spokesman for the New York Foreign Freight Forwarders' and Brokers' Association.

The City Club announced yesterday its recommendations to voters on amendments and propositions appearing on the voting machines next Tuesday. It suggested an affirmative vote on amendments 1, 2 and 3, took no action on the fourth, and urged an affirmative vote on proposition 1, dealing with county reform, and a negative vote on the two other propositions.

When Commissioner Moses finds the surface of the earth too congested for one of his parkways, he lifts the road into the air and continues it on its way. That is what he has done with the new Gowanus Parkway, the first section of which opens with appropriate ceremonies today in Brooklyn.

BERLIN, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Russian troops were reported retreating tonight in Crimea and the Donets basin, hotly pursued by Axis infantry and German dive bombers, but official quarters acknowledge stubborn Red Army resistance on the Moscow and Leningrad fronts.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct. 31 -- Camp Upton's new interdenominational chapel will be dedicated Sunday, Lieut. Col. H.C. Brenizer, post commanding officer, said today. The chapel has a seating capacity of 400.

Inauguration of monthly "emergency allowance" payments of 5 per cent of basic weekly salaries up to $40 to employes of the John Wanamaker stores in New York and Philadelphia, to enable them to meet higher living costs, was announced yesterday by Charles R. Shipley, president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The United States lost its first warship in the Battle of the Atlantic when the destroyer Reuben James was torpedoed and sunk last night west of Iceland while on convoy duty, the Navy Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that he did not expect the sinking of the destroyer Reuben James to affect American foreign policy or diplomatic relations with Germany. He appeared to regard the torpedoing as an inevitable incident in the Battle of the Atlantic.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 31-- Returning again to the scene of the air battles of Crete that went against the British last Spring, strong forces of British bombers blasted Candia and the Suda Bay area Wednesday night through stormy weather, the Middle East Command reported today.

A Geman-born mechanic wept on the witness stand yesterday at the Brooklyn espionage trial as he described the treatment accorded him and his wife by Nazi customs officials and secret police agents when the couple returned to Germany for a visit in 1938.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Oct. 31 -- Five New Yorkers were honored here this afternoon, two posthumously, by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission. Two lived in Long Island and the others come from Rochester, Buffalo and Lancaster, N.Y. In all, the commission gave twenty-four awards, to persons risking life to save the life of some one else.
NEW YORK Mrs. Donald M. Ryerson of Lake Forest, Ill., is at the Ritz-Carlton.
CANTERBURY, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Christian Kerr, Tax Collector, will be available in one of his numerous henhouses if any delinquent in this currently taxless town wants to pay up his back taxes.

VICHY, France, Oct. 31 -- General Maurice Gustave Gamelin and former Premiers Leon Blum and Edouard Daladier will be called to trial before the Supreme Court at Riom on Jan. 15, 1942. Minister of Justice Joseph Barthelemy announced that date to the Council of Ministers here today for the opening of the trial for responsibility for the French defeat.

As a result of a widespread rumor that the Pennsylvania deer herds had been seriously reduced by disease, the State Game Commission has made a thorough survey of the deer situation of that State, and reports that this rumor is without any basis of fact.

Standard Brands, Inc., has transferred its Chase Sanoorn coffee account from J. Walter Thompson Company, Inc., to Kenyon Eckhardt, the company announced yesterday. Plans for 1942 are now being prepared.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 31 -- Effective immediately the Palestine Government announces today the discontinuance of individual import licenses for a number of commodities imported from the United States but that limited supplies will be made available by the government provided they are necessary to insure the maximum war effort or to maintain the civilian community on a wartime basis.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 30:

The Film Library of the Museum of Modern Art today will begin the showing of Part II, "The Talkies," of its cycle of 300 films highlighting the history and development of motion pictures from 1895 to 1940. The second half of the cycle will include forty-five programs and will continue through January.

Extreme nervousness prevailed yesterday in the stock market as a result of the first sinking of an American warship since the Navy extended its patrol, and prices cracked as much as 3 points. Assurance by President Roosevelt, however, that this incident does not change the relations of Washington with the Reich enabled the share list to close slightly above the low marks of the day in trading which was the heaviest of the week.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 1 -- Some London newspapers today stressed the United States, nearness to open war as result of the sinking of the Reuben James, which, according to British sources, probably was the victim of one of the "wolf packs" of German submarines preying on Atlantic convoys.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 -- While shipbuilding operations continued on a somewhat curtailed basis in Seattle and Los Angeles today as a result of the welders' revolt against A.F. of L. metal trades unions, a strike vote at two aircraft plants was ordered by the executive board of the United Aircraft Welders.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 31 -- Acquisition by the Ordnance Department of the United States Army of the 330-acre waterfront site at Caven Point and New York Bay, here, for use as a lease-lend depot was formally completed in the City Hall this morning, ending months of negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Two weeks ago today, Oct. 17, the destroyer Kearny, engaged in a night battle against a German submarine wolfpack which had attacked a convoy southwest of Iceland, was hit amidship by a torpedo and eleven American seamen were killed and ten wounded.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 31 -- During the absence from Fort Ethan Alien of the 186th and 187th Field Artillery Regiments from Brooklyn on manoeuvres in the Carolinas, the few troops of the headquarters contingent left to garrison, the post are having a quiet time for the most part.

TRENTON, Oct. 31 -- Getting his long-sought "day in court" to defend his administration of the State Highway Department in the Gubernatorial investigation of the department, Commissioner E. Donald Sterner, a Republican, pictured today the plight of the "poor, starving Republican" seeking a job outside the patronage pastures of the New Deal.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31 -- For the thirty-seventh time since 1877, Harvard and Princeton meet each other tomorrow on the football field. Very little depends on the outcome of this game that starts in Palmer Stadium at 2 o'clock, but in the rain tonight around the cannon that is embedded in the campus back of Nassau Hall, Princeton undergraduates, band men and cheer leaders seemed unaware of this.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Comment by members of Congress on the sinking of the Reuben James included the following:

FORT DEVENS, Oct. 31 -- When the First Division, returns from the Carolinas it will find three USO houses ready for it. Federal and community agencies are hard at work malting the buildings ready for use. There will be reading rooms, pool and billiard rooms, cotequipped dormitories and showers.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- The first concert of the twelfth season of the Mrs. Julian Olney series was given tonight at the County Center here, with Richard Crooks, American tenor, as the guest artist. About 3,000 persons attended.

The National Pocket Testament League will observe its silver jubilee next Friday at 8 P.M. in Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street. Its headquarters are at 156 Fifth Avenue. Alfred A. Kunz, executive secretary, will preside at the service.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Strength in soy beans and continued wet weather, combined with reports indicating that price control measures would provide generous treatment for agricultural products resulted today in a better demand for wheat.

BERLIN, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- German dispatcches released here tonight said the Russians were counter-at-tacking through the mud outside Moscow, but that the armies of Field Marshal Fedor von Bock were hurling them back with heavy casualties and were shelling fresh Soviet troops concentrated behind the lines.

In a surprise move yesterday the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, meeting in convention at the Hotel Astor, approved almost unanimously a motion urging the repeal of the Neutrality Art as an "outdated, farcical piece of legislation."

Park Commissioner Robert Moses, appealing over the radio last night for the re-election of Mayor La Guardia, criticized Goverrior Lehman for taking part in the local campaign "as a respectable front for the worst kind of municipal skulduggery."

Tonight, traditional closing tune for campaign rallies, finds Mayor La Guardia and his Fusion colleagues holding the spotlight with a major rally at Madison Square Garden, while William O'Dwyer and his Democratic associates will travel through Manhattan without a major meeting scheduled.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Federal Communications Commission was served today with papers in the suits filed yesterday in New York by the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System to prevent enforcement on and after Nov. 15 of the new rules and regulations that otherwise would become effective on that date.
The thriftily minded carefully plan and save for financial security when silver threads outnumber the gold. But few of us give very much thought to providing "health security" for the mellow years.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command today issued this communique:

The Appellate Division lashed out yesterday at Russell Forbes, city Commissioner of Purchase, accusing him of seeking to "harass and annoy a willing worker." charging him with desiring to circumvent the purpose of previous orders of the court, and questioning his good faith in preferring charges against an employe.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions, figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

Between the fictitious and misleading issues raised by District Attorney O'Dwyer and the language too frequently employed by Mayor La Guardia the present city campaign has been disappointing and disillusioning.
FORT BENNING, Ga., Oct. 31 -- Only skeleton forces remained at this army center today as virtually all units streamed eastward to the Carolina war games.

After three quarters had been completed without a score, Ted Raffetto, left halfback, gave Poly Prep a 6 -- 0 football triumph over its traditional Brooklyn opponent, Brooklyn Prep, at Brooklyn College Field yesterday. Raffetto turned the tide in favor of the Dyker Heights school when he ran sixty-five yards with a punt in the fourth quarter.

Ceremonies at noon today will mark the opening of the first and principal section of the new Gowanus elevated parkway in Brooklyn, from Owl's Head Park, northward to Prospect Avenue. By Jan. 1 the entire parkway will be finished to Hicks Street and Hamilton Avenue, the plaza of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, now under construction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- A total of $932,673,000 worth of securities was registered under the Securities Act during the third quarter of 1941, more than for any threemonth period since the first quarter of 1937, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. This compared with $761,625,000 during the first three months of 1941 and $623,101,000 during the second quarter.
LONDON, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- The British Board of Trade, stepping lightly and with caution, declared war today on the cosmetic industry's gigantic "black market."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- John L. Lewis will win a decision from the National Defense Mediation Board recommending that steel companies owning captive mines grant to the United Mine Workers the union or closed shop, it was reported authoritatively today as the board held its first meeting to consider the situation as the result of President Roosevelt's intervention several days ago.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 31 -- The New Jersey Congress of Parents and Teachers, in its 1941-42 platform, adopted today, declared that food may win the war and urged housewives to follow nutrition recommendations to maintain family health and conserve "foods necessary to the survival of the other world democracies."

Tonight's business in the Broadway playhouses will be reminiscent of New Year's Eve, ticket brokers observed yesterday, because of the throngs attending a number of major football games in this vicinity today. Many of the shows already are sold out; the others are not far behind, it was reported.

President Roosevelt's Navy Day address will be commented on by clergymen of the various Christian faiths tomorrow, and by rabbis this morning, particularly that part of the speech in which the Chief Executive said the avowed intention of the Nazis was to strangle all accepted religions.

Ray Robinson is still the proud possessor of a ring record that contains nothing but victory. The speedy young welterweight from Harlem scored the most important triumph of his short career last night when he decisively defeated the former 147-pound champion, Fritzie Zivic, in a ten-round clash at Madison Square Garden.
