A sweeping reorganization, both corporate and physical, of the $1,000,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric Corporation system was proposed yesterday by Willard L. Thorp and Denis J. Driscoll, trustees in reorganization of the former Hopson utilities empire.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 -- Problems incidental to the care and safeguarding of 108,000 Jewish, children for whom Hadaasah, women's Zionist organization, is acting as foster mother were surveyed tonight at the organization's convention.

New bond financing here this week jumped to $62,473,000, compared with $1,832,000 last week. Resumption of corporate borrowing on a sizable scale and the appearance of several fair-sized tax-exempt loans accounted for the increased activity.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Colonel Edwin Gunner, commander of Fort Slocum, approved plans today for modernizing the equipment used in serving 9,000 meals daily to the 3,000 soldiers who frequently are stationed here while awaiting transfer to overseas possessions.

"Parity" for farm products is a mirage which can never be translated into actuality, Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institute, told the annual meeting of the Cotton Textile Institute at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- A schedule establishing ceiling prices on used steel drums at levels substantially below those now prevailing is being prepared in the Office of Price Administration and will be issued in the very near future, Leon Henderson, Administrator, announced today.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 31 -- Fort Monmouth was preparing a welcome today for the new chief signal officer of the Army, Major Gen. Dawson Olmstead, who was formerly commandant of this post. General Omstead will review 11,000 troops.

Hence Those Purges Joseph E. Davies, our former Ambassador in Moscow, has his own explanation for Soviet Russia's unexpectedly good showing against the Nazi invaders. The reason is the famous succession of Moscow purges after 1935, and Stalin's remarkable foresight displayed therein.

Columbia's freshman football team defeated Cheshire Academy, 14 to 6, yesterday at Baker Field to record its second triumph in four games. The Lion cubs scored In the second and third periods. Johnny Norton, reserve back, tallied for the losers on a 75-yard return of a punt in the final quarter.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Colonel Myron C. Cramer was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be judge advocate general of the Army for a terra of four years, with the rank of major general.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 1 (From official Russian sources; distributed by The Associated Press) -- Fighting along the entire front from Leningrad to the Sea of Azov was reported by the Soviet Information Bureau early today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The government's contract with the Aluminum Company of America tobuild and operate four aluminum plants for national defense was criticized today by Senator Truman, chairman of the special Senate Committee Investigating National Defense, during a hearing of two Alcoa witnesses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Roosevelt today announced the resignation of Josephus Daniels as United States Ambassador to Mexico. In a voice filled with emotion the President told his press conference that it was with the deepest regret that he was allowing Mr. Daniels to leave his post because of Mrs. Daniels's ill health.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The House Banking and Currency Committee prepared to vote finally tomorrow on the terms of the Administration-requested price control bill, the chief issue being whether to set up specified controls by statute or to delegate authority to the President.

With only two sizable issues scheduled for sale, new State and municipal offerings will drop next week to $5,258,539 from $17,380,773 this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date is $31,841,707.

An underdog Columbia football team, scorning the odds that make Cornell a top-heavy favorite, will meet the 1941 edition of Carl Snavely's Big Red squad today at Baker Field in high hopes of defeating its traditional opponent for the tenth time in the twenty-ninth game of the series.
BOSTON COLLEGE VS. TEMPLE -- Up a tree right at the start. And Omar sang: "When all the Temple is prepared within" -- Leaving the Temple and going out on a limb, one wondering vote for B.C.

Buying by the trade brought enough support to the cotton market in the late trading yesterday to stop a decline in prices that had been persistent. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 22 to 24 points lower at midday, but the close was at net losses of 9 to 23 points.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 31 -- The granting of discharges to men who have reached the age of 28 started this week at Fort Du Pont and there were a number of informal farewell parties as the men departed for their homes.

LONDON, Oct. 31 - Standing | with his head bowed in silence at the Free French headquarters in Carlton Gardens here this afternoon, General Charles de Gaulle took the lead in a world-wide demonstration against the reprisal shooting's of German military authorities in France.

The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company sold the residence at 296 Innes Road, Woodridge, N.J., to Harry A. Clark through J.I. Kislak, broker, who also sold for the same seller to Thomas Bissig the house at 262 Windsor Road, Woodridge.

Trading was only fair in the local wholesale meat market yesterday. Fresh pork cuts were moderate to light: steer hinds and ribs moderate: cow "beef liberal; other classes about normal. Lamb sold barely steady: fresh pork cuts steady to higher; other classes mostly unchanged. All kosher markets opened steady and demand was fair to slow.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Oct. 31 -- One of the largest holiday parties on. the North Shore took place tonight at the Cold Spring Harbor Golf Club, where more than 100 of the younger couples gave a Halloween costume supper dance, which followed several dinners in near-by homes of the Oyster Bay, Syosset, Woodbury and East Norwich colonies.

Organization of a "pre-audition board" for children's radio programs was proposed by the Radio Council on Children's Programs at a luncheon yesterday at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street. The proposed board, which would be similar to motion picture preview groups, was outlined in an address by the new president, Mrs. Nathaniel Singer.

TOKYO, Oct. 31 -- In conformity with a previous announcement, the Cabinet today formally decided to submit to the extraordinary Diet session a war-time program of sweeping increases in indirect consumption and luxury taxes, to be followed by corresponding price increases.

Eleven have been named for the $25,000 Westchester Handicap, and seven for the $5,000 New Rochelle Handicap, to be run today at Empire City on the closing day of the metropolitan racing season, which has set so many new records of various kinds.

CAMP WHEELER, Ga., Oct. 31 -- Orders affecting the transfer of three full battalions, comprising more than 2,000 trainees, to nineteen different Army posts throughout the United States and Newfoundland, were issued yesterday by Colonel A.R. Emery, camp commander.

Six touchdowns and as many successful conversions provided barrels of happiness for Penn State rooters last evening as the Nittany Lions blanked N.Y.U., 42 to 0, on the rain-soaked Polo Grounds turf in the night football Inaugural for both teams.

The modest item chronicling the arrival in Britain of the largest contingent of Canadian-trained airmen that has yet reached the war zone marks a new milestone. The great empire airtraining scheme which initially was Canada's outstanding contribution to the fight against Hitler is now producing flyers, observers and air gunners in constantly increasing numbers.

Democratic speakers continued yesterday to hammer away at Mayor La Guardia for his "insults" to Governor Lehman, who at the party's climax rally in Brooklyn called him "unworthy" of his office. [Page 1, Column 1.]

Fifteen years ago the Information Bureau of the New York City Cancer Committee opened its now famous "little red door" to the public -- the first step in a fine effort to "fight cancer with knowledge." Since then tens of thousands have either telephoned to the committee for advice or passed through the little door to receive comfort and aid.

Wendell L. Willkie urged the immediate repeal of the Neutrality Act and advocated steady production to speed up the national defense program in commenting yesterday upon the sinking of the United States destroyer Reuben James.

Directors of the General Aniline and Film Corporation met here yesterday and elected John E. Mack of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., as president and a director of the company. He will succeed D.A. Schmitz, who resigned as president on Sept. 23, although the resignation was not announced until Oct. 3.

Cash From England The American motion picture industry received yesterday pro rata shares of the sum of $8,000,000 remitted from London to New York on account of blocked balances held in Great Britain, or 25 per cent of the profits which accrued to them from their British operations in the last year or two.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Oct. 25 totaled 242,261,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. This represented a decrease of 1,344,000 barrels in the week, comprising decreases of 1,189,000 and 155,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude, respectively.

BERLIN, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- German sources said tonight that sinking of the United States destroyer Reuben James was "justifiable under international law if it was escorting a British convoy," and that it might have been the same destroyer reported sunk in today's High Command communique'.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland climbed into a tie with Irving Crane of Livonia, N.Y., for first place in the world pocket billiards championship tourney by trouncing Ralph Greenleaf of Chicago, 125 to 54, in twelve innings tonight.

THIS sober-suited essay, with its academic title and dedi- cation to collegiate seminars, suggests a laboratory where a physicist of gentle demeanor and impressive knowledge of his science prepares an innocuous-looking powder which differs from common salt in just one important respect.

Recent gifts have swelled the total of contributions to the United Hospital campaign to more than $500,000, Roy E. Larsen, general chairman of the campaign announced yesterday, while reiterating his plea for widespread public support to bring the sum to the $1,784,292 needed by the seventyfive hospitals participating in the drive.
QUANTICO, Va., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Secretary Knox said today that the sinking of American ships was "worse than piracy" and that "we are in this fight to the finish."

AS the title, theme and thesis of its new show on national defense, WOR sends along "Keep 'Em Rolling." The program, to be presented jointly with the Office for Emergency Management, takes off next Sunday at 10:30 P.M.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1 -- A total of $170,895 in scholarship grants, the largest sum in the history of Princeton University, was made to students during the academic year just completed, according to the annual report of Richard W. Warfield, director of the Bureau of Appointments and Student Employment.

WALK around the reservoir any morning -- any reservoir, for that matter -- and it's an even bet that you will run into Edna Ferber. Miss Ferber is a walker. That daily walk, she says, is essential to her physical and mental well-being. Me, I'm different.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

The electric range field may turn out to be an industrial guinea pig for the government's experimentation in the development of a program for streamlined low-cost products through the elimination of de luxe features during the emergency, it was learned here last week.

In common with colleges throughout the country Yale has felt the immense upsurge of interest in the affairs of Latin America. The dangers and possibilities which lie in the vast continent to the south of us become clearer every day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The official statement from Berlin charging that the United States had begun a shooting war against the Reich raised the question here at once whether Hitler had decided to force the issue and bring on all-out war between America and Germany.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The University of Mississippi football players proved to be better mudders and cashed in on scoring opportunities in the first and final periods to defeat Marquette by 12 to 6 today before a homecoming crowd of 10,000.

TWENTIETH Century Man sometimes is discouragingly blase. He has become so accustomed to dropping coins into slots and having anything from peanuts to boogywoogy jump out at him that he doesn't get particularly excited about anything new in the way of coin-grabbing "automatic salesmen."

Announcement of the engagement of Mass Janet Barclay Walling, daughter of Mrs. Robert Guthrie Page and William Henry Walling of this city, to John Townsend Lawrence, of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Bailey Fish Lawrence, has been made by her mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Guthrie Page.

ALEXANDER MOSSOLOFF, who is known mostly for his "Iron Foundry" and an earlier string quartet, was for a time considered among the most promising of the younger Soviet composers. In the turbulent years of the reign of the R.A.P.P. (Association of Proletarian WritersComposers) Mossoloff was aligned with the elder and conservative group, and, as it turned out, on the wrong side of the fence.

From the outset of trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday stocks displayed a steadier tone than on Friday, and, although gains were limited to small fractions, the improvement of the list after Friday's sell-off was considered encouraging.

City College took advantage of a blocked kick to score a touchdown in the first two minutes of play in the rain and mud at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, then nursed that lead to register an upset, 6-0 victory over favored Hobart College.

SPEAKING of extraordinarily good dancing, as it is always a pleasure to be able to do, there is Fred Astaire now on the screen at the Radio City Music Hall. He has been in Hollywood so long that it is easy to drift into the habit of letting him go by default, but that would be a serious mistake.

HARTFORD, CONN. THIS New England center of today's clanging defense program is the traditional home of the Yankee mechanic, a wise, ingenious fellow with deft hands and inventive brains. Meeting him on his home ground, one recalls the most apt words ever written about him:

Glen Rounds, as readers of his "Ol Paul," "Lumbercamp" and "Pay Dirt" well know, writes of outdoor life and real people with zest and a contagious enjoyment. "The Blind Colt," Mr. Rounds's finest piece of writing, is an unforgettable animal portrait, drawn witn understanding and a moving simplicity.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King of Canada began an intimate conference here today and, according to reports, they are discussing plans for a coordinated American-Canadian program in production and shipping in an attempt to make certain that a large volume of armaments reaches Russia.

BOSTON, Nov. 1 -- Mrs. Mina S. Crandon, widow of Dr. Le Roi G. Crandon and famous Boston medium known as "Margery," whose seances provoked wide controversy over the validity of pyshic phenomena, died today at her home, 10 Lime Street, Beacon Hill, after a long illness.

The sword-rattling heard from Tokyo when it probably seemed to the Japanese that Hitler was about to take Moscow has died down noticeably as the Russian capital still holds out. It is apparent that the new Tokyo government is considering the complicated situation in which Japan finds herself as an Axis partner with the purpose of making moves when the moment seems opportune.
MONTREAL, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Red Wing's captured their opening game of the National Hockey League season when they defeated the Canadiens, 3 to 2 tonight.

IN these columns last Sunday Maxwell Anderson set down in trenchant prose some conclusions drawn from his experience in the theatre. "The theatre is a religious, institution devoted entirely to the exaltation of the spirit of man," he said.

Women who suffer agonies of self-consciousness, women who feel as if they had two left feet, or who, once in a room, have trouble getting out gracefully, are enrolling in the Self-Appraisal Laboratory of the Brooklyn Y.W.C.A.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Advocacy before the New York joint legislative committee on revision of the insurance law of common stock buying by institutions, closely following the Administration's new philosophy favor- ing greater equity financing, harbors the broadest financial and economic implications.

IF there happen to be such Americans who are inclined to grumble about their country, they are advised promptly to read Martin Gumpert's "First Papers," a charmingly persuasive book by a distinguished German emigre who considers it a great privilege to be allowed to become a citizen of this Republic.

IF the journalist is the historian of the passing moment then Mr. Gunther is by this time one of the foremost world chroniclers. The present volume conies practically to round up the political history of the three major continents, which he began so brilliantly with "Inside Europe" and continued with equal perspicacity if not with the same assurance in "Inside Asia."
CANTON, N.Y., Nov. 1 (AP) -- A 77-yard drive with big Jim Hefti carrying the ball on every play enabled St. Lawrence to top a favored Alfred University eleven today, 7-6.

MUCH has been written about the great convoys which carry troops from one part of the world to another and even the slow convoys of cargo vessels, but what of the solitary ships that ply homeward with their precious life-line of food and equipment for Great Britain?

The Securities and Exchange Commission in its recent decision to exempt the sale of 150,000 shares of common stock of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company of Kentucky from its competitive bidding rule and permit the company to sell directly to the public without underwriting has set a precedent that may have farreaching effects upon the methods of distribution of equity securities.

Requirements for typists', steno- graphers' and clerical workers' jobs are rising, but the rewards are also higher than formerly, according to a compilation made recently by a group of women supervisors of transcription departments in city offices.

VICHY, France, Nov. 1 -- At Perigueux today, Henri Girard, the young man who is charged with the killing of his father, his aunt and a servant, continued to proclaim his innocence, while the inquiry turned to questions of a motive in the killings.

In the Nineteen Thirties, when women first wore fresh flowers in their hair, they felt dashing, a little daring, and as alluring as a senorita with a rose over her ear. That first single, demure gardenia or the brace of fringed African daisies have grown up during the years until now they have become a definite and accepted part of an evening coiffeur, and could be dignified by the name of flower headdresses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- A system has been set up under which prior approval by United States lease-lend authorities is necessary before an English manufacturer can get a license to export to this country any product in which materials are used of a type given England under lease-lend, it was learned here today.

India is gradually coming under the ever-lengthening shadows of actual aggression. Every sign points to a southward swing of the Nazi thunderhead with the Caucasus as its immediate objective, for that way lie the rich oil fields of both Russia and Iran.

The United States Office of Education, the American Council on Education, and the National Education Association are among the organizations working together on the problems that arise out of national defense and that will accompany post - war reorganizations.

Four amendments to the State Constitution and three propositions relating to reorganization of the county government system within New York City are being submitted to voters Tuesday for approval or rejection. The constitutional amendments are being voted on throughout the State, but the propositions are appearing only on New York City voting machines.

The annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States adopted a wide range of resolutions affecting shipping, including one suggesting a joint committee representing the shipping industry and the Maritime Commission to study and confer on shipping legislation and legislative policies.
MEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 1 -- A fourth-quarter place-kick by Elwood Richardson, 195-pound junior center from Lynn, for the point after touchdown, gave Tufts a triumph over Northeastern today, 7 to 6.

"AS children," wrote John Buchan in his autobiography "Pilgrim's Way," "we lived much in the past * * * and permitted bygone ages to color our every-day lives." Every child, the most active and matter-of-fact, as well as the quiet and thoughtful, escapes from the adult world at times to live a part of his life elsewhere.

HOLLYWOOD. "TALES OF MANHATTAN" is before the camera and Boris Morros, its producer, is being looked upon by Hollywood with awe. The venture is so prodigious that practical minds declared it would never start.

The "Luck" of the Comstocks was an ancient schooner which a century ago had seen duty as a smuggler's vessel off the Isle of Wight and which could still weather the Atlantic as plucky 18-year-old Heather Comstock sailed her across the ocean almost to the front door of her uncle's lighthouse on Block Island and right into a double mystery.

OTTAWA, Nov. 1 -- On the eve of the reassembly of Parliament, which adjourned in June and will reassume its sitting on Monday, there has been this week an outburst of complaint that Canada's war effort is not total enough, that the government seems to wish to exclude Parliament and the people from its confidence and from as full participation as, it is claimed, they are willing to give.

The Seamen's Church Institute of New York, largest shore home in the world for merchant seamen of all races and creeds, will benefit from the evening performance on Nov. 17 of "Macbeth," starring Maurice Evans and Judith Anderson, at the National Theatre.

Features commemorating two decades of sponsorship by seventeen religious, patriotic and theatrical organizations cooperating with the work of the New York State Commission for the Blind are being inculcated in plans for the twentieth anniversary sale of articles made by blind workers, which will be conducted from Dec. 1-23.

Freedom for teachers to participate actively in the political life of the schools and the community was called an "indispensable condition of democratic education" by Dr. George S. Counts, president of the American Federation of Teachers and candidate for the City Council, at a luncheon in his honor yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 1 -- With Johnny Spasyk, 150-pound left halfback, pacing a first-half attack, the University of Vermont today defeated R.P.I., 16 -- 0.

ATLANTA, Nov. 1 -- Duke shoved aside a hard-fighting Georgia Tech football team, 14-0, today and rolled on undefeated and untied.

The Humbert Moruzzi Youth Center, 256 Mott Street, named after a policeman who lost his life in the line of duty on April 12, 1938, was dedicated yesterday afternoon in exercises attended by 200 children and numerous adults of the neighborhood.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- The candymakers of the country are making every effort to meet the OPM requests for a 25 per cent reduction in paper and board consumption, it was learned today following an industry committee conference in which Philip P. Gott. president of the National Confectioners Association, took part as its representative.

"Liberty on the March," a ten-foot statue weighing 1,000 pounds, dominated the entrance to Grand Central Palace yesterday. Completed in two days by members of the Clay Club of New York, the statue appeared before visitors on the final day of the Women's National Exposition.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: YOU have published in your issue of Oct. 19 a letter from Mr. Heinz Pol, in which he disputes a passage of my book, "France on Berlin Time." In this passage I speak of the deception of the people of occupied France at the failure of more than a few hundred German and Austrian refugees to enlist in the Foreign Legion.
BRUNSWICK, Me., Nov. 1 -- Sparked by Card, Johnson and Walker, Bates drove nearer the State football championship today with a 19-6 victory over Bowdoin.

CRANBERRIES, with their scarlet tartness, are as fondly associated with Autumn as are blazing open fires and brown leaves hurrying before the wind. It is hard to realize that so familiar a friend might have been almost unknown to most of us if Cape Codders had not been forced to look about for a new enterprise when the sailing-ship era ended.

Moderate price dresses, budget furs and home furnishings departments accounted for the bulk of consumer activity last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

TRAVEL LINES: Tucson's Temple of Music and Art inaugurated its Winter schedule recently with an exhibit of paintings of Western scenes and the twenty-fifth anniversary program of the Arizona Archaeological and Historical Society.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Royal Air Force pilots, raging up and down Britain's blockade front from Norway to the Bay of Biscay Friday night and yesterday, rained bombs and torpedoes into eleven or twelve Axis ships and left fire and wreckage in France and Germany, the Air Ministry reported. Many British bombers hammered Bremen and Hamburg in the night.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Bill Green and Bernard (Bus) Mertes, two fast, slashing backs, touched off a rip-roaring thirdquarter rally to pace Iowa's Hawkeyes to a 13-to-7 Western Conference football victory over Indiana's Hoosiers before 28,000 homecoming fans today.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Nazi spokesmen said tonight that German armies were storming anew through Moscow's outer defenses and nearing decisive victories in Crimea and the Donets industrial basin. Reichsfuehrer Hitler's field headquarters communique said that German and Rumanian troops were in pursuit of the "defeated" enemy in Crimea.

For the third time New York on Tuesday will elect a City Council by the proportional representation system. Because of the experience gained in the past the vote for members of the Council may be higher this year than it has been and the results known earlier.

The Office of Production Management's priorities division will shortly publish a series of booklets presenting in readable form the orders already issued and the pattern of the priorities system as the first step in a program to get business men to learn the details of the system, it was learned here yesterday.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Nov. 1 -- The Bryn Mawr archeological dig in Arizona this Summer proved extraordinarily successful, Dr. Frederica deLaguna, assistant professor of anthropology, has just reported to the Alumnae Association whose gift made the expedition possible.

MIDDLETOWN, Nov. 1 -- Wesleyan nosed out the Coast Guard Academy eleven, 21 to 20, on a rain soaked field today. It was a heart breaking defeat for the plucky Coast Guard squad, with a point after touchdown spelling defeat.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Large areas of the West and Northwest were blanketed today by snow which fell last night in one of the most severe pre-Winter storms in years.

ONE of the effects of the war on American philately is a serious curtailment of the importing of bulk "mixtures" of stamps gathered at many sources in all parts of the world. Probably the leading dealer in this type of business is E.A. Pade, "the mixture man," of Denver.
SHREWSBURY, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Malcolm C. Cleveland, former chief engineer of the New York Public Service Commission, died at his home here last night at the age of 64.

A program of post-war world reconstruction was presented yesterday by the American delegation to the conference of the International Labor Organization at its session at Columbia University.

CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Nov. 1 -- President Paul Swain Havens, reviewing the five years of his presidency of Wilson College in his just-published report to the Board of Trustees, singles out three processes which have marked this last half-decade of Wilson's 72-year history.

Many members of society and patrons of racing will attend the Autumn meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association on Tuesday, Election Day, at Belmont Park. The last day of racing of the Autumn season in the metropolitan area, it will be held under the license of the New York State Racing Commission and with the sanction of the Hunts Committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association and the Jockey Club.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1 -- Convinced that post-war or post-emergency unemployment and depressions can be averted by mass production of low-cost houses, Professor Walter C. Voss of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology nevertheless foresees a bottleneck in this vital program unless the nation's secondary-school educators direct more students to the field of building engineering and construction.

Polite children filled Carnegie Hall yesterday for the opening of the nineteenth season of the Young People's Concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York. Rudolph Ganz came to the podium and, after conducting the national anthem, turned to welcome his youthful audience.

The Art Workers Club for Women has taken over the evening performance on Nov. 17 of "Spring Again," starring Grace George and C. Aubrey Smith, to be presented at the Henry Miller Theatre. Mrs. Laurence Eyre is president of the beneficiary, which aids women artists and models, and provides for the members club rooms, a library, a free costume bureau and a free placement bureau.

The cotton market in the short session drifted lower yesterday in quiet trading. On the New York Cotton Exchange, prices of active futures closed near their worst levels for the day and at net losses of 8 to 16 points.

In a comparatively unnoticed moment last week President Roosevelt signed an appropriation measure adding $5,985,000,000 to the gigantic leaselend reservoir of funds for the fight against aggression. The Chief Executive had asked for the new money in September after reporting that the original $7,000,000,000 lease-lend appropriation of last March was almost exhausted.

A.F. pilot restored to the arms of his bride before the end of the story.

Mrs. Stephen C. Clark and members of the board of directors of Grosvenor Neighborhood House will give a reception Thursday afternoon in Mrs. Clark's home at 46 East Seventieth Street for the debutanje committee of the annual December Ball to be held Dec. 4 at the Ritz-Carlton.
VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Nov. 1 -- Coq Noir swept like Black Lightning through a driving rain to take the Pickering Challenge Cup race today on the Pickering Hunt Club program.

The Bayside Power Squadron, with an enrollment well over 300 skippers, ten times the size of the nucleus that started this unit in 1936, will observe the fifth anniversary of its charter on Nov. 14.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Missouri's once-beaten Tigers exploded an annihilating offense on a soggy, gale-swept field to crush Michigan State College, 19 -- 0, today before a Spartan homecoming crowd of 15,000.

WACO, Texas, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Texas Christian threw too many long bullseye passes for Baylor to cope with today, and the Christians retained a slim-mathematical chance at the Southwest Conference football title with a 23-to-12 victory.
Fordham went Michigan strategy two better in beating Purdue by 17 to 0 in the rain and the mud at the Polo Grounds yesterday before 20,500 spectators.

RUMSON, N.J., Nov. 1 -- The hunter trials, which will be held tomorrow at Mr. and Mrs. Morton L. Newhall's estate, Stonehill Farm, under the auspices of a junior committee of the Monmouth County Hunt, will be followed by a tea at the Lincroft Inn.

Appreciation is differently handled at the Museum of Modern Art, where, in setting up services for the young, thought has been given not to what children ought to like but to what they do like.

Whatever the outcome of the dispute of the United Mine Workers of America over the captive coal mines with their owners, the country's largest steel producers, there was drama to spare last week in the situation involving Myron C. Taylor, formerly chairman and now a director of the United States Steel Corporation, and John L. Lewis, president of the labor union.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 1 -- Williams fraternities -- almost as old and well-established as the college itself -- have been under close and critical scrutiny here during recent weeks.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Far out and high up over the Niagara River, the Union Jack and the Stars and Stripes were unfurled today from staffs erected three feet from the border line between the Dominion of Canada and the United States to mark the opening of Niagara's giant new steel Rainbow Bridge to traffic.

An offer to arbitrate the jurisdictional dispute that has delayed completion of painting work on the new $5,300,000 storehouse and office building at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn was made yesterday by Sam Freeman, secretary-treasurer of District Council 18 of the Broth- erhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, A.F. of L.
ONCE more Don Salvador de Madariaga has given us a book which will inevitably find its place in the library of every student of American history and in every collection of Americana.

The problem of attractive flower arrangements for the dinner table is sometimes a troublesome one. Women who find it easy to create an attractive one-sided composition for a console table, mantle or niche are often stumped when it comes to making an arrangement which is interesting and attractive from every angle, as it must be when used as a dining-table decoration.

On Monday the growers and reitail florists of the New Jersey Florists' Association will act as hosts to those interested in flowers and their use. A display of cut flowers, pot plants and flower arrangements will be held at the Elks Club, 44 South Munn Avenue, East Orange.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 -- Heavily favored Ohio State today defeated victory-less Pitt, 21 -- 14, before 50,000 spectators, but all during the sizzling offensive struggle Edgar Jones, fleet Panther back, haunted the Buckeyes like a Halloween spook working overtime.

Unity between accessories and the rest of a room's decoration is one of the things which makes for the effectiveness of an interior. Since pottery is one of the most versatile types of accessories, it is quite worth while for any one interested in home decoration as well as in art expression to view the exhibition of the New York Society of Ceramic Arts at the BarbizonPlaza Hotel.

Although the New Jersey woodcock season officially opens today, Sunday hunting is forbidden in that State, so the men who are willing to take out a special woodcock license will have to wait until tomorrow.
MANILA, P.I., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Amid intense defense preparations, several million Filipinos will decide on Tuesday who is to lead this Commonwealth in the crucial years ahead.

What may be the first joint effort by American industry to protect a vital phase of its operation in the post-war period will be taken soon by the Industrial Research Institute, which will seek a way to insure the jobs of industrial research workers after the current emphasis on defense is eliminated, Maurice Holland, secretary of the organization, announced yesterday.

With the Eastern divisional race tightened up and the headlong clash of the New York Giants toward the title checked, National Football League teams will engage in another brisk Sunday of activity today.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 1 -- The nineenth running of the rich Pimlico futurity was all Contradiction today.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Britain disclosed tonight that she was manufacturing a "new and highly secret" ammunition for the battle of the Atlantic, the formula for which presumably has been passed on to the United States, as are other British military secrets.

New Microscopic World An ordinary microscope with glass lenses has limitations imposed by light itself. Light is a wave motion in the ether, if you still believe in that hypothetical medium. The waves measure a thousandth of a millimeter from crest to crest.

The President Garfield of the American President Lines docked early yesterday at Eighth Street, Hoboken, N.J., with eighty passengers from the Far East, India and South Africa. The vessel left San Francisco on Aug. 13 and made stops at Honolulu, Shanghai, Hongkong, Singapore, Bombay, Cape Town and Trinidad.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 -- A United States ministry of information to spread propaganda for democracy was urged tonight by Dr. L.M. Birkhead of Kansas City, who asserted that the America First Committee is the "Nazi party of the United States" in an address to the delegates at the annual convention of Hadassah, women's Zionist organization.

Maintaining the traditions of its fifty-eight years of existence, but with a spirit of preparedness and national defense predominating, the National Horse Show will open Wednesday in Madison Square Garden and continue through Nov. 12.

The Irvington Children's Museum, headquarters of educational and recreational facilities for children of Westchester County, moved yesterday from a store on Main Street to Glencoe, a modern, twenty-room residence on the grounds of the Columbia University Aboretum at Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y.

ON the basis of three of the four productions of its first season it can be said that the New Opera Compary has been conspicuously successful in its early approaches to its ultimate objectives. This is shown by the vitality of the performances and by the interest of the public.

Fifty years ago a gay, young, but earnest group of New Yorkers met at the Bible House on Astor Place to found the Needlework Guild of the City of New York. The idea was adapted from a plan that originated ten years earlier with Lady Wolverton in Dorsetshire, England.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Scoring three touchdowns in the second quarter, California's football team routed the University of California at Los Angeles eleven today, 27 -- 7, to wreck a homecoming day celebration.

DURING the World War, when the aviation industry was a problem child no na- tion fully understood, Harold Wills, the chief metallurgist on the Liberty engine, tried putting molybdenum in the crankshafts of that famous aircraft power plant.

Public Improvements recently carried out in various parts of Manhattan have helped to preserve real estate values and have served to point the way for future changes to make the borough a more desirable place in which to live, according to Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President.

THERE were 91,442 certificated pilots in the United States on Oct. 1, a 107 per cent increase over the 44,000 licensed pilots on record as of the same period last year, Donald H. Connolly, administrator of the Civil Aeronautics Administration revealed recently.
BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- The German Government formally declared today that the United States "attacked Germany" in incidents involving the American destroyers Greer and Kearny.

LONDON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Lord Beaverbrook's Evening Standard declared editorially today that the torpedo-sinking of the destroyer Reuben James west of Iceland Thursday night was a declaration of war by Adolf Hitler.

Clarence Francis, president of the company, said in an interview last week.

DETROIT, Nov. 1 -- Playing in a steady twenty-mile wind under gray skies and in a 47-degree temperature was tough enough for Manhattan College's football team, but the University of Detroit made matters even tougher for Herb Kopf's Jaspers today.

It is fitting that one of the last books written by Johu Buchan, who never forgot his own boyish love for high adventure and the romantic past, should be a book for boys dealing with the deeds of those brave men who made and lived the early history of Canada.
AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 1 -- Scoring in the last three periods, Amherst took the mythical town football championship by halting Massachusetts State today, 20 to 0.
COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 1 (AP) -- If you thought Halloween came last night, you should have been here today to watch the finish of the Georgia-Auburn football game.

TOOTH DECAY -- Dr. W.W. Wainwright declared before the American Dental Association last Wednesday that dentists would have to abandon the belief that tooth decay had anything to do with the amount of calcium and phosphorus in saliva.

Lesson Not Learned The first installment of Herbert Hoover's recollections of the Paris Peace Conference in The Saturday Evening Post has an introductory note stating that the chapters were written more than six years ago.

IT will be recorded in contemporary radio history that tomorrow marks the beginning of the tenth year on the air of the program generally conceded to be responsible for starting the cycle of quiz broadcasts. Vox Pop, it is called.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Toppling four heavy favorites into the discard, Spec Stewart of Roswell, N.M., and Wilford Wehrle of Racine, Wis., today gained the final round in Mexico's amateur golf championship.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 1 -- Displaying a dazzling lateral pass attack and a brilliant running game, Syracuse defeated a favored Wisconsin football team, 27 to 20, be- fore 19,000 chilled and dampened spectators today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Albert W. Hawkes, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said today that any government official who used his power to urge the owners of a private business to remove any one in the management of their business because of inability to settle a difference with labor was "violating a fundamental principle which underlies the free enterprise system and our American way of life."

Plans for expanding the industrial output under the national defense program in Nassau and Suffolk counties will be accompanied by a drive to obtain increased living quarters for workers in plants there. One of the first steps in this direction will be taken next Wednesday when a meeting will be held at the Farmingdale High School to stimulate interest in the remodeling of houses to accommodate employes in arms factories.

As the result or a successful six-year experiment in offering courses in city and regional planning as a field of undergraduate study, the Graduate School at Cornell University announces that, beginning this Fall, graduate students may elect to major in this field leading to a degree of master of regional planning.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 1 -- Red-eyed and listless, after hours of vigil with little sleep, about forty wives of members of the crew of the destroyer Reuben James, now living in Portland, were anxiously awaiting tonight official word from the Navy Department.
The New York Americans will play the Milwaukee Chiefs in an American Football League game at the Yankee Stadium today. The kick-off will be at 2:30 P.M.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Andrew Ponzi of New York threw the 1941 world pocket billiard championship into a four-way tie for first place tonight by beating Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland, 125 to 88, in thirteen innings.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 1 -- Connecticut College students will study English as a language for the first time this year, seeking among other things, a cure for the weakness which afflicts student writers -- a vague rather than sure feeling for the meanings of words.

ARENTINA, having postally marked the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of its Bank of the Nation with a 5-centavos stamp (illustrated in these columns last Sunday), now plans to pay similar tribute to its "Caja Nacional de Ahorro Postal" (National Postal Savings Bank).

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The House Banking Committee approved tonight a commodity pricecontrol bill after refusing to include wages and voting to prohibit ceilings on farm commodities lower than some of the highest agricultural prices in history.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- By all accounts the bill to repeal the three most restrictive sections of the so-called Neutrality Act will pass the Senate and be accepted by the House. But as the week ended it seemed certain that the Senate majority would be narrow, even possible that several Senators who have opposed the neutrality legislation from the start will vote against repealing it.

Asserting that Mayor La Guardia's repudiation of Communist support could not be trusted because he had proved himself unworthy of belief, James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, declared yesterday that the Mayor had shown such favor to Communists and Communist-dominated organizations that it was no wonder that many persons were calling him "Red" La Guardia.

It is reassuring to learn from the correspondent of The Times of London that Gibraltar has been strengthened greatly. For fifteen months pneumatic drills have been boring new galleries in the heart of the Rock. The correspondent describes the scene underground as still presenting a Dantesque picture of toil, although the work is close to completion.
ROME, Nov. 1 -- Today's newspapers content themselves with publishing the news of the sinking of the Reuben James without comment.

"BETWEEN wars, and home from wars," Martha Gellhorn has written these short stories about troubled Europe. It is a rather uneven collection, not so satisfactory as a whole, but with two very fine pieces in it.

Brooklyn College is rapidly approaching a standard for its athletic recreation program which, if it does not already exceed that offered by any other college in the country, soon will, according to Dr. Frederick W. Maroney, chairman of the hygiene department.

TORONTO, Nov. 1 -- A thirdperiod drive that produced three goals gave the New York Rangers a 4-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the opening game of the National Hockey League season tonight. A crowd of 12,661 saw the Leafs fold in the final session under a Ranger attack that refused to ease off at any time.

GEORGIANA GODDARD KING, distinguished Hispanic scholar, poet and teacher, was working on a book on the little-known architecture of Portugal at the time of her death in 1939; but among her papers was found also the finished manuscript now published as "Heart of Spain."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The boat-sailing lad -- the boy you can spot anywhere by the cut of his jib and the roll of his gait -- is the young man Uncle Sam is looking for today to meet an urgent national defense need. The United States will build 1,200 ships during the next two years.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Professional operations dominated the wheat market on the Board of Trade today, and the failure of outside trade to broaden discouraged the pit element. Opening prices showed little change from yesterday's finish, but scattered selling later disclosed a lack of support and at one time prices were down 1 cent a bushel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 -- Welders of the Pacific Coast, whose strike for union autonomy has slowed defense production in shipyards of the Seattle and Los Angeles areas, indicated today that they would "mark time" with present gains pending word from their leaders, who are now in Washington seeking government guarantees.

VICHY, France, Nov. 1 -- No demonstrations or incidents of importance were reported in either zone of France yesterday as a consequence of General Charles de Gaulle's orders for a brief sit-down in memory of the executed hostages.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Lehigh and the University of Buffalo battled to a scoreless tie today on a rain-soaked gridiron. It was the third draw recorded this season by the Bethlehem, Pa., eleven.

It's at Wrigley Field that the Green Bay Monsters will make a second attempt to prove that the Great Big Bears are not too, too divine, but only human, after all, and subject to defeat.

Realty and construction problems growing out of the defense program and the priorities regulations will be the chief topics for discussion at the annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, being held in Detroit this week.

Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, addressing a mass meeting of Zionist organizations in Carnegie Hall last night, urged formation of a Jewish Army in Palestine as "part of the world front that the forces of freedom are maintaining against the aggressor" and called for the full establishment of a Jewish homeland in Palestine "when the time comes for the building up of a new world."

In "Leif the Lucky" Mr. and Mrs. D'Aulaire are at their enchanting best. This magnificent picture book tells how Leif, son of Erik the Red, sailed as a boy with his father to a new home in Greenland and later sailed still farther west and found there the continent of North America.

After one of the hardest fought campaigns in recent times voters of New York City will go to the polls Tuesday to select a municipal administration for the next four years. About 2,300,000 persons are expected to vote in the election. Polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 7 P.M. to accommodate them.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Partisan control of county government through a majority on the Board of Supervisors is the issue in Rockland County at the elections on Tuesday. There will be many split tickets, the usual custom in off-year elections, when no county offices are at stake and in the town elections petty, localized party disputes come to the fore.

The Grace Line announced yesterday the appointment of Captain Albin A. Andersen to the post of terminal manager of the company and the promotion of Captain Walter N. Prengel to succeed him as port captain. Captain Andersen has been with Grace for more than twenty-five years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The controversy over demand for the closed shop in the steel industry, the possible early return of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company's yards at Kearny, N.J., to the United States Steel Corporation and the "union security" issue before the Bethlehem Steel Corporation appeared to be today linked together by industry members of the National Defense Mediation Board who are also considering the captive mine controversy.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Prices of live- stock were steady here today after a week of irregular trends with reflected increased receipts in some departments and the strong tone of the dressed meat trade. Not enough animals were put on sale to test prices accurately today. Receipts of hogs were increased here and at outside markets during the week but the runs were well below those of a year ago.
HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Rice opened up with an offensive which netted almost a point a minute tonight to defeat Centenary, 54 to 0, before 12,000.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Upsala scored its first victory of the season today by defeating an Arkansas Aggies eleven that hasn't won a game in three years. The score was 19 -- 6, with the losers' gaining their first touchdown in three seasons.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Having spent too much of my earlier life in reading, I have in the last few years cut that practice sharply, much of the time thus saved is being spent in rereading.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- At times the final score in a football game can be deceiving. Any one who did not witness today's rainsoaked struggle between Penn and Navy at Franklin Field, where the middies recorded a 13-6 victory to remain unbeaten, might be prompted to remark, "What a game."

DALLAS, Nov. 1 -- Texas broke an eight-year football jinx and gave Jack Crain a chance to avenge two bitter years today by flattening Southern Methodist, 34 to 0.

Left Hal: back Howie Extract made the touchdown that gave Lincoln it fifth straight triumph of the campaign and the tenth in a row since it lost its opening contest last season to Brooklyn Tech.

With a final spurt of effort, the New York League of Women Voters and the Women's City Club are winding up this week-end their campaign to win county reform through proposition No. 1 on the ballots next Tuesday. Although both groups admitted that the issue had been definitely confused by the appearance of propositions 2 and 3 on the same subject, they believed that chances were favorable for success of the first measure.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 1 -- The tragic spectacle of Bruce Smith, one of Minnesota's all-time backfield greats, trying to help stop Northwestern's challenging Wildcats with a crippled knee, took some of the edge from the Golden Gophers' 8-to-7 homecoming triumph today.

"Plants -- The Struggle to Survive" will be the subject of the free lecture to be given by Dr. H. Beaman Douglass at the New York Botanical Garden at 3 P.M. on Saturday. Dr. Douglass will tell how plants developed their present forms and distinctive structures.

Superior and more modern construction saved the Kearny two weeks ago, but she was badly damaged and eleven of her crew were killed.

About 32,000 homes for the families of workers in defense industries and enlisted and civilian personnel of the Army, Navy and Marine Corps were completed under the Federal Works Agency's defense housing construction program by the end of last month, reports Federal Works Administrator John M. Carmody.

Leaders of finance, business and government saw themselves lampooned last night in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, where the New York Financial Writers Association gave its fourth annual Financial Follies, a satirical revue.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- For his daily ration of information the man in the street in Germany is primarily dependent on the press and radio. The Reich's daily press now has a total circulation of 25,000,000, twothirds of which belong to newspapers owned or controlled by the Nazi party.

ANNISTON, Ala., Nov. 1 -- Major Gen. William N. Haskell relinquished command today of the Twenty-seventh Division after fifteen years of service with this unit and is on his way to his home in New York for a brief visit, before starting on a three-month inspection tour of military establishments for the War Department.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Union College has instituted a new form of educational government by unanimous vote of its faculty, and ratified by the trustees, as announced this week. The college retains its divisional system, which has operated since 1933 and which groups the teaching staff and their courses largely under four divisions -- literature, social studies, science and engineer- ing.

In the rain and mud of the Yankee Stadium another Army football team rose with a valor that confounded odds heavily in favor of Notre Dame yesterday as the ancient intersectional rivals fought to their first scoreless draw since 1922.

Marking the seventh successive month to show such a comparison, dividends declared in October were, in the aggregate, the largest for any corresponding period since 1937 despite smaller declarations by several large corporations.

WHEN William O'Dwyer drives around town policemen stick their heads in the windows of his car and say, "Hello, Bill," and Bill yells back, "Hello," and the cops go away smiling. For O'Dwyer was once a cop in Brooklyn, and little guessed when he was pounding a beat that some day he would be running for Mayor of New York on the Democratic ticket.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor will leave for Nassau via Miami at 10:30 tomorrow morning, it was announced yesterday, after what will have been a visit of exactly two weeks.

DETROIT -- Amid widely cirulated reports that automobile production may be halted completely in January, April or June, it is to be remembered that at least six months' time is necessary, from the date of a stoppage order, before car output can be halted entirely without great economic losses.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Oklahoma, a gathering football storm in the Big Six Conference, blew down Kansas, 38 to 0, before 11,000 fans today in its first impressive display of power aground and by air.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Tennessee used tricky reverses today to score its fourth victory in a row, 13 to 6, by beating Louisiana State University at football before a homecoming crowd of 30,000.

SEEKING comfort and strengthening in this day of dismay and disillusionment, Bonaro W. Overstreet finds the good where we also find the bad: in human beings. She is the kind of person, she explains in this book's first chapter, who must go to human contacts for "warmth and nourishment."

IN its activities to provide serious music for members of the armed forces the New York City Defense Recreation Committee is receiving the cooperation of a number of organizations which are contributing free tickets to enlisted men for various concerts and other musical events slated in New York for this season.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1 -- One 88-yard run that flared against the murky, rain-laden air in Palmer Stadium like a sudden burst of August lightning gave Harvard victory over Princeton, 6 to 4, today in the opener of the Big Three round robin.

The teaching of arithmetic has resulted in hardly more than meager mastery of the ability to use numbers in problems and other practical situations by college and high school students, according to the results of two recent surveys by three members of the faculty of the City College School of Business and Civic Administration.

PRODUCTIONS of Cosi Fan Tutte are bedeviled by the superficiality and incredibility of the plot. Nevertheless, the opera does not want for revivals; witness the most recent by the New Opera Company. The plain fact is that Mozart's radiant score triumphs over improbabilities of story and weakness of character portrayal, and those who value the composer and his music are quite willing to overlook and forgive deficiencies in the tale.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- An explosion-proof electric motor for driving mine locomotives which reduces danger of igniting mine gases is the subject of a patent (No. 2,260,360) awarded to Robert L. Barry of Downers Grove, Ill.

A corps of volunteer workers will shortly start training for posts as assistants to the regular staffs of the Bureau of Nursing of the Department of Health and the Department of Welfare -- an innovation for both departments which has developed from the public interest shown in the civilian defense movement.

Coral Island, somewhere off the coast of the United States, has only one policeman, Ray Coburn, and his job is a sinecure up to the moment when Harold Banks, manager of the Alhambra Hotel, is murdered. After that Coburn is both busy and worried, as is also his friend Denny King, who plays in the hotel orchestra.

THE most cautious reviewer can predict skyrocket success for "Saratoga Trunk" -- and not feel that he is getting out on a limb, either Few of Edna Ferber's vastly popular novels of the past decade have arrived on the book counters with more fanfare.

RUMANIA'S postal authorities have announced the design of five Red Cross semipostals to be released about Dec. 15 -- 1.50-lei plus 38.50L, 2L plus 28L, 5L plus 35L, 7L plus 33L, 10L plus 30L. A girl stands with right arm extended, and in lower corner is a crimson cross.

IN brief, I have found my religion in the theatre where I least expected to find it and where few will credit that it exists. But it is there, and any man among you who tries to write plays will find himself serving it, if only because he can succeed in no other way.

OF the many books that E.L. Grant Watson has had published either here or in his native country, England, several have had Australia and its bush, with which he is said to be well acquainted, as background. "The Nun and the Bandit," however, as before we began.

Many an enthusiastic gardener possesses an ailing flower bed -- one which does not respond as it should to watering or fertilizing; the plants of which dry up in mid-July, the blooms of which are never as gorgeous as in neighboring beds. In nine cases out of ten the reason is probably tree roots.
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Repeating his victory of a week ago, John R. Macomber's Side Arm scored a handy triumph in the featured Wakefield Handicap today at Rockingham Park.

The disappearance of Collier Brent brings Christopher Gibson to Seattle and then to the home of Collier's aunt, Jacqueline Brent, on an island in Puget Sound. With Gibson is his secretary, Miss Hull, familiarly known as Scraps.

THERE was a reunion at the Philharmonic Symphony offices last week. Arturo Toscanini, who had not been there for more than five years, signalized the restoration of happy relations with the society by paying a call.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Issues pertaining to county management and fiscal policy will be decided in Westchester on Tuesday, when residents elect an exceptionally large number of public officials and vote on a county charter amendment that would substitute a small legislative board for the Board of Supervisors.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Charles B. Norris of Irvington-on-Hudson, attorney and utility corporation executive, died of a stroke in his hotel room during a visit here.

The fall of Eden must have come at about this time of year, for where is the mortal who can turn his back on such orchard bounty as now invites his choice? Baldwin and Rome Beauty and McIntosh, Delicious, Winesap and Black Twig. Jonathan for the lucky, Greening for the patiently persistent.

PENROD and Willie Baxter and little Orvie may have grown up by this time, but not Booth Tarkington -- at least never to the point of losing his deep and humorous understanding of adolescent and subadolescent boys and girls.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Between December, 1940, and June, 1941, additional workers to the number of 238,509 joined the service of the executive branch of the government, raising the total from 1,119,641 to 1,358,150. Of the total 1,091,897 were men and 266,253 women.

THE 1941 New York Salon of Photography, presented by the Camera Club, opens today with a showing of 204 prints by 116 photographers chosen from more than 1,000 prints submitted. Prints were received from various parts of the United States, North and South America and from Asia.

Mayor La Guardia and his running-mates on the Fusion ticket, supported by Thomas E. Dewey, Samuel Scoury and Charles H. Tuttle, brought the Fusion campaign to a climax in Madison Square Garden last night with declarations that the Democratic opposition had failed, in the month-long campaign, to produce an issue that would stand the light of day, and that all the Democrats had was a desire to get back into power.

Its Strikes A War Department report lists a total of twenty-two strikes involving 8,500 workers in defense industries. The numbers are small in comparison with the vastiness of the production effort (4,000,000 workers are handling defense orders), but they do not tell the whole story.

HAMILTON, N.Y., NOV. 1 -- A Colgate alumni homecoming day gathering braved the rain today and saw the Red Raiders' short-lived lead erased as Holy Cross tallied on a 45-yard aerial in the second period to bring about a 6-6 deadlock.

Inability of defense agencies to forecast what their needs will be six to twelve months ahead and complicated procedure required in the placing and filling of lease-lend orders are two of the most serious handicaps to the key de- fense industry of machine tools at the present time, according to comment last week by leaders in the field.

FLOATING PALACE: A motion picture called "Over the Seven Seas" ran at New York's Plaza Theatre during the Spring of 1933. The film was a pictorial record of a world cruise made by William Kissam Vanderbilt aboard his gleaming white yacht Alva.

Absolute outsider in the $29,450 Westchester Handicap, John Hay Whitneys Gramps yesterday drove through mud and half a gale at Empire City to win at 27 to 1 before 17,308 rain-swept persons who turned out for the last day of the Jockey Club racing season.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Nov. 1 -- A curly headed sophomore named Mike Zeleznak streaked 66 yards through the mud to one touchdown, then plunged to another today as Kansas State made football history by defeating Nebraska, 12 to 6.

IN this unusual story of girls in a penal institution there is laid bare all the emotional relationships, the crushes, hates, comedies, and even horrors, which are all the inmates have to compensate for the everyday life of the world on the other side of the high picket fence.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Sixteen months to the day after her keel was laid down, the 10,000-ton cruiser Cleveland, first of her class, was launched today at the yards of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the review columns of THE TIMES mention was made recently of the parachutist who landed atop Devil's Tower in Wyoming and subsequently found extreme difficulty in getting down. Several interesting legends, as the reviewer pointed out, are connected with the volcanic formation, but the one accepted by the Federal guardians of the tower is presented in the little museum at Devil's Tower Monument.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 1 -- Lafayette's Leopards outplayed Gettysburg's Bullets to win by a score of 17 to 6 on the gridiron totody. The battle, played in steady rain, was waged in Gettysburg territory for the greater part.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 1 -- Stanford's T formation proved efficient in the mud today as the Indians scored a 27-7 victory over anta Clara before 60,000 fans.

With the German Army striking deep into Southern Russia, attention is being focused on the highly productive Caucasian oil fields, the output of which is essential to the military, industrial and agricultural activities of the Soviet Union. As that area yields more than 90 per cent of the oil output of Russia, a German drive to any point on the Caspian Sea would cut off that supply from the rest of the Soviet Union.

With emphasis being placed upon the production of more food, the growing of vegetables is bound to find increased importance in gar- den planning. There is much to commend in the practice of raising vegetables in the home garden. They can be picked fresh and at a stage that will insure the full use being made of all their valuable food elements.

IN the month just closed retail trade for the most part returned to more normal proportions and showed, in fact, some reaction from the feverish buying of earlier months. The stocking up movement by the public and the "beat-the-tax" spurt led to slackened sales in all except war boom areas.

By 1921 it had been generally recognized that what good telephone service required was not competition but monopoly. At the end of 1940 the Bell System employed about 322,000 people and its assets totaled more than $5,500,000,000.

S. Sloan Colt, general chairman of the twenty-fifth roll-call of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, which will be held in Manhattan and the Bronx Nov. 11 to 30, made public yesterday the names of nearly 200 chairmen of groups that will represent busi- ness, industry, the professions and government in the annual drive.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Naval sources said tonight that there was still a good chance that at least some of the sixty-nine or seventy men and seven officers missing from the torpedoed United States destroyer Reuben James were safe or would be rescued.

In a distinguished little volume this young author once again shows himself past master of authentic nonsense. Gravely, as a child carries on a game of makebelieve, he sets forth what can happen when a locomotive made for the National Swiss Railways and capable of becoming a "Swiss flyer" is made to draw a cheese train instead.

NEW YORK Lars Christensen, financial counselor of the Norwegian Legation in Washington, and Mrs. Christensen have come to the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria from their country home in Lloyd Neck, Huntington, L.I.

THE roads of New York State are expected to become safer and pleasanter places as a result of a new insurance law which goes into effect on Jan. 1, 1942. A similar law in New Hamp- shire is reported to have cut by one-half fatalities resulting from automobile accidents in the first year of its operation.

SINCE genius or even talent is not a matter of dollars and cents, not all the wealth, of the radio industry can evoke successful works at will, an artistic failing not unknown to the legitimate theatre, the cinema and the book publishing businesses.

The Very Rev. Mgr. John J. O'Donnell, pastor of the Guardian Angel Church and Port Chaplain of New York, began last week his eighth year as the official spiritual adviser to the thousands of seamen, longshoremen and other wa- terfront workers of the port.

HOLLYWOOD. MY mythology is bad. If, as Dr. Kildare once told me, "Our memory is contained in the curved coruscations, convolutions and curlicues of the brain," then there is a department marked Greek Mythology in my own cerebral area which is as flat as a Harrow hat.
EARLY in the year 1937 the University of Texas announced that it had contracted for the services of Dana X. Bible as football coach for a period of ten years. His salary was reported to he $15,000.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Rutgers' football team snapped back from its overwhelming defeat of last week to rout Maryland today by 20 to 0 before 20,000 spectators, thereby avenging its setback by the Terrapins last Thanksgiving Day.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, identifying himself as the "ole redhead," imitated Red Barber and a Brooklyn Dodger broadcast in his speech last night at Madison Square Garden, to give to the dying campaign one of its first sparks of genuine humor.

One is hard put to it to analyze the special charm which characterizes Elizabeth Enright's books, but it seems to be chiefly derived from her quick eye for the unexpected, the amusing and the beautiful in what might be just ordinary experiences, and from her own joyous sense of living.

HONOLULU, Nov. 1 -- The Japanese Navy lately has been guilty of activities in American waters that are said here to verge closely upon the beginning of hostilities, and while the American naval au- thorities have patiently withheld retaliative action, much has been learned of the tactics and aims of the Japanese through simulated ignorance of what their ships were doing.

"There's a job to be done, and we're going to do it." That sentence made the rounds in Albany two weeks ago when more than 200 women members of New York State's 118 local defense councils met in a training institute to learn about their work.

MOLASSES SOFTIES, New Orleans style, may be ordered freshly baked for an office lunch or an impromptu supper. The fat soft cookies cost 40 cents a dozen, and if you ask for $1 worth they will promptly appear by special messenger.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1 -- Defying all the rules of strategy that would be regarded sound on this rainy, muddy afternoon, the Brown football team released a forward pass midway in the fourth quarter of its clash with Yale, saw the play click for a-touchdown, and walked off triumphant over the Blue aggregation by 7 to 0.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Michigan threw its might and power against outclassed Illinois today and emerged with a 20-to-0 victory before 30,000 half-frozen homecomers. It was Illinois' second Conference disaster of the year.

Research aimed at the development of a series of all-inclusive retail price indexes covering merchandise carried in department stores is now under way, it was learned here yesterday. The project, regarded as one of the most important in the field of distribution in recent years is being under -taken by the National Retail Dry Goods Association in conjunction with an outside statistical agency.

TOKYO, Nov. 1 -- Japan is completing her war structure for an armed clash in the Pacific "that now seems inevitable" and can be averted only if the United States alleviates its economic pressure on this country.

THE second part of the collection of stamps, covers and related historical material assembled by the late Edward S. Knapp, New York broker, will be publicly auctioned this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, with afternoon and evening sessions from tomorrow through Friday and an afternoon session on Saturday.

Unusual interest has been shown in the newly created sports section of the Office of Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs and many athletic activities between representatives of North and South America are being planned, Asa Bushnell, director of the sports section, said yesterday, The United Press reported.

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity broke its five- week decline by rallying 0.5 point. It stood at 126.7 for the week ended Oct. 25, compared with 126.2 for the week previous and 113.8 for the week ended Oct. 26, 1940.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- It took the modulated tones of an enemy radio kibitzer to bring home to the British public the fact that a ceaseless battle is being waged over the air waves. The uninvited voice from the Continent turned men's minds to questions on radio propaganda: Is there a Briton "ghosting" over German wave lengths?
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Duquesne University's undefeated and untied football team kept its record clean tonight with a 7-to-0 defeat over a scrappy Villanova eleven.

ON the opening program of its first pair of ten concerts this week in Indianapolis, the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, under Fabien Sevitzky, will include Frederick Converse's "Flivver Ten Million" and Mr. Sevitzky's arrangement of Kreisler's "Preludium and Allegro."

WRITTEN with a gravity, dignity and authority which are wholly characteristic, "Green Centuries," Caroline Gordon's new novel, is an epic of life on the Southern frontier round the time of the American Revolution.

ALFRED A. KNOPF is offering a prize of $2,500 for an autobiographical booklength manuscript by an American aviator. Only American citizens who are now employed as fliers, military, naval or commercial, are eligible to compete.
BERLIN, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A picture of swift destruction and snail-like reconstruction lingers in the mind after a visit to the southern sector of the German-Russian front.

Like all the best books written for boys and girls, it will appeal also to their elders, for even those who are familiar with what archaeology has accomplished will enjoy again the story of how men have sought and found the records of four great civilizations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Coordination of nation-wide demands on medical, dental and veterinary personnel and assurance of the most efficient utilization of these professional specialists in the defense program of the United States will be undertaken by the establishment of a Procurement and Assignment Service, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, stated today.

Reorder action was only fair during the past week, as retailers continued their efforts to bring stocks into line, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Retail business was better on mediumpriced goods than in the lower and upper-priced brackets. Opportunities for "good buys" at "offprices" appeared in a number of wholesale lines, the report added.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1 -- In the present labor crisis, one thing is certain: the public is against strikes in the defense industries and is ready to take drastic action to prevent them.

Drastic changes in American labor policy must be undertaken if our defense and lease-lend program is to be fully effective, in the view of British experts, who believe that we must make labor unions more responsible and management more cooperative.
