BERLIN, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A picture of swift destruction and snail-like reconstruction lingers in the mind after a visit to the southern sector of the German-Russian front.
BOSTON, Nov. 1 -- Boston college, a latent power-house, returned with a bang to its 1940 championship form today to tumble Temple from the ranks of the unbeaten, 31 -- 0.
LONDON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

ONE Fall day in 1928 a young New Jersey automobile mechanic heard of a part-time job that was open for some one who knows a little about radio." The young New Jerseyite promptly applied for the job and was accepted -- on trial.

More than sixty schoolboy football games carded for gridirons in New York City, Long Island, WestChester and New Jersey were postponed yesterday because of the heavy rain. Many of the contests have been rescheduled for election day, Tuesday, while others have been canceled or deferred until later this season.

FOOTBALL Army and Notre Dame, meeting in the rain and mud at the Yankee Stadium as 76,000 looked on, battled to a scoreless tie in one of the features of a big day on the nation's gridirons. Another huge crowd of 73,391 in Philadelphia saw Navy thoroughly outplay Penn to win by the margin of a touchdown. Captain Franny Lee made an 88-yard touchdown dash to give Harvard a close decision over Princeton.
(AP) -- North Carolina State College's dream of 14 years -- to whip the North Carolina Tar Heels -- came true today before 18,000 amazed spectators. The score was 13 to 7.

The correlation of world events at a given period in history is a feat to stump the average adult, let alone a schoolchild, yet as the world shrinks through transportation and communication this visualization of historical events as a whole becomes increasingly important to an understanding of past and present.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- All eyes are now concentrated on Russia. As the tides of battle surge on that front, there is another front in the Middle East that may prove to be one of the war's most important.

FOR his initial performance with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra Thursday night, Bruno Walter will conduct the Handel Concerto Grosso in B minor for strings, and the Mozart "Requiem." Mr. Walter, the third conductor of the orchestra's, centennial season, will direct the Handel work from the piano.

IN the life of every young actress already or about to be crowned with stardom there comes a time when for the purposes of her education and particularly the public's she is handed over lock, stock and barrel to the studio's publicity gnomes.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 1 -- The educated toe of Harley Johnson, which has not missed a point after touchdown all season, was not to be denied today. A little band of William, and Mary rooters groaned in the second period when his tremendous field goal attempt hit the right upright, but there was no doubt about his third-period try.

In this city and countless other American communities next Tuesday citizens who take their elections seriously will spend a minute or two marking ballots or operating voting machines. If recent elections are a guide, half or more of those who might have qualified and voted will be derelict.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters, which usually holds its annual meeting, with election of officers and new members, in November, will break tradition this year by postponing this meeting until next May. The literary exercises, usually held in the Acad- emy's auditorium, in conjunction with the annual meeting, also will be postponed, as will the opening of a new art exhibition.

Now that plants, as well as humans, are moving indoors for the duration of the offensive by Old Man Winter, problems pertaining to window-plant culture attract more attention. Decorative plant stands, adjustable trays for window sills, and inexpensive but attractive glazed pots are augmented with absorbent mats and various other devices for the successful culture of house plants.

James Tippett, whose books of verse, "I Live in a City," "I Spend the Summer," "I Go A-Travelling" and "Counting the Days," have a warm place in the hearts of boys and girls, shows once again that he understands children and can share their interests and enjoy their pleasures with them in wholehearted fashion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Control of non-Axis world shipping will be centered in an international committee operating here if Congress repeals shipping restrictions in the Neutrality Act, informed diplomatic sources predicted today.

SAYBROCK, Conn., Nov. 1 -- Performing in a style that even the terrific rain which prevailed most of the day could not mar, Hollybrook Wink, 4-year-old bitch owned and handled by Harry I. Caesar of Fishers Island, N.Y., won the open all-age stake for English springer spaniels, concluding feature of the Connecticut Spaniel Field Trials Association meeting today.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1 -- General Maximino Avila Camacho, brother and chief adviser of the President of Mexico, who was mentioned in these dispatches last Wednesday as under consideration for future negotiator with the expropriated American and British oil companies, told your correspondent yesterday that he would be glad to assist in this capacity or any other in improving relations between Mexico and the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: What is happening to children in this time of national emergency? What now becomes of children whose families are broken by death, desertion, divorce, mental and physical sickness, prison sentence or unemployment? Who are the children affected?

In the November issue of The American Mercury Prince Hubertus zu Loewenstein argues for the establishment of a German Free State beyond the confines of Adolf Hitler's conquest- bloated Reich. There are sufficient po- litical emigres whose names carry weight with the German people, he contends, to form a Government which would be a link between the allied democracies and Hitler's enemies at home.

This is the first long story for boys to be written by Cicely Fox Smith whose ballads of ships and sailors have delighted the readers of Punch for many years. It is a briskly moving tale in the Treasure Island tradition. The 14-yearold hero, Barty Dale, is brought up by his uncle, once a sailor but now landlord of "The Ship Aground," an inn on the bank of London River.

FROM his recent performances it appears that the pigeon of New York City is among our more avid space grabbers, headline hounds and lens hogs. Cats up in trees and dogs down in the subway and horses that fall off docks are pretty good at it, but the pigeon wins the gift-wrapped box of cracked corn.

PHOTOGRAPHERS are often subject to attacks of boredom. Every picture, so it seems, has been taken. Snaps of baby are a glut in the album. Aunt Emily has smiled for the camera until her cheeks ache. "The landscape has lost its photogenic charm.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 1 -- Tulane's mighty Green Wave roared over Dudley Field today, swamping Vanderbilt's hopes, 34 -- 14, and sweeping the Commodores from the ranks of unbeaten, untied teams.

A great clashing of steel that is in no way connected with national defense can be heard any evening in November and for several months thereafter from the various fencing halls in New York as girls thrust and parry in an endeavor to achieve promotion to the top ranks of swordswomen.

Up in the Nipegon country north of the Great Lakes, an Indian boy carved a little figure in a canoe a foot long and started his "Paddle Person" on a journey through the different waterways across the Great Lakes and down the St. Lawrence to the ocean.

BY an odd quirk of geographical nomenclature, the Mississippi Delta and the Delta of the Mississippi are entirely different areas, and wholly unalike. The Mississippi Delta is the rich cotton-growing district between the Mississippi and Yazoo Rivers which begins, according to David Cohn, one of its students as well as one of its sons, at Beale Street in Memphis and ends at Catfish

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The British people were told today they must expect sweeping changes in the Government. This prediction was made in conjunction with the criticism of the government for lack of offensive action to aid Russia.

New York's time-honored insti- tution, the National Horse Show, will open in Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, to continue through Wednesday, Nov. 12. It will be the fifty-sixth annual exhibition, and the proceeds will be donated to the United Service Organizations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Neutrality Act was called "an act of appeasement" toward Hitler today by Senator Green of Rhode Island, who urged its repeal. Continuing the debate today in the Senate over revision of the law, he declared the United States had said in effect that if we gave up some neutral rights, our remaining rights would De respected.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 1 -- An explosion this afternoon demolished the three-story brick and frame house at 411 Berkeley Avenue, the residence of William Schlegle, manager of the fur department of the New York store of Jay Thorpe, Inc., and many hours later the body of his wife, Mrs. Marion L. Schlegle, 53 years old, was discovered buried in the wreckage.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Nov. 1 (AP) -- A star-studded Alabama team exhibited a wide margin over Kentucky today to gain a 30-0 victory in its Southeastern Conference contest before a homecoming day crowd of 10,000.

WITH three new miles of pavement now under construction at its eastern end, Southern State Parkway, pioneer artery of the model Long Island Parkway system, is gradually stretching out along the course plotted for it years ago by engineers of the Long Island State Park Commission.

Elihu Root Jr. was announced yesterday as the city-wide chairman of the Lawyers Committee for the Re-Election of La Guardia, with Allen W. Dulles as chairman for New York County, Louis Susman for the Bronx, Lawson H. Stone for Kings, Howard O. Wood for Queens and Lester J. Callan for Richmond.

The safety of the Port of New York in the national emergency depends on the awareness of the ship operator and the waterfront property owner, and they are not yet sufficiently alert, in the opinion of Captain G.C. Pegram, U.S.N., Supervisor of the Harbor.

ARHUR MENKEN, the Richard Harding Davis of the newsreels, came hack last week after an eight months' survey of trouble spots and potentially fulminous areas in the Pacific. Much of the material he photographed has already been released by Paramount News, but there is enough left over out of the 50,000 feet of negative he exposed from Singapore to Sydney, Australia, to form a fresh pictorial account of the Far Eastern situation.

With more men at work than before the Army marched in, the Bendix, N.J., plant of Air Associates, Inc., will remain open day and night over the week-end turning out plane parts vital to the national defense program, Colonel Roy M. Jones, military commander of the plant by designation of President Roosevelt, announced yesterday.

The Speech Education Clinic of Hunter College, conducted by speech majors and attended by prospective teachers, is unique be- cause the assistants are volunteers and those who attend are volun- tary "patients," according to Dr. Egbert J. Spadino of the speech department, who directs the clinic.

In a simple prose Arensa Sondergaard has put this country's story into a form that can be read and enjoyed by the younger boys and girls. When she tells of the explorers and the early settlements, with a sure knowledge of children's interests, she adds the vivid detail, the bit of description, that catches and holds the attention.

There are some profound explanations and some perfectly simple ones of the immense success of the recitals that Serge Rachmaninoff gives each season in this city, recitals which, as that of yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, are always packed with as many listeners as the law allows.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Nov. 1 -- A twin-engined Army bombing plane, its motors roaring, fell out of mist-filled clouds and exploded in a cornfield today. Five men testing automatic flight equipment were killed.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer charged last night that the Sanitation Department, with the knowledge and approval of Mayor La Guardia, had operated for months without a Commissioner, with the result that "neglect and indifference had permitted intolerable conditions" to exist.

By its clearly written text, well-printed page and suitable design this book deals comprehen- sively with mechanical power. An arresting cover will catch boys' eyes and lead them to the many excellent illustrations, consisting of old prints, modern photographs, diagrams and interpretive sketches.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 1 -- Dr. John S. Millis, who has been dean of administration at Lawrence College, Appleton, Wis., for two years, was elected today to be president of the University of Vermont. He will begin his new duties immediately.

In a simple prose Arensa Sondergaard has put this country's story into a form that can be read and enjoyed by the younger boys and girls. When she tells of the explorers and the early settlements, with a sure knowledge of children's interests, she adds the vivid detail, the bit of description, that catches and holds the attention.

There are some profound explanations and some perfectly simple ones of the immense success of the recitals that Serge Rachmaninoff gives each season in this city, recitals which, as that of yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, are always packed with as many listeners as the law allows.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Nov. 1 -- A twin-engined Army bombing plane, its motors roaring, fell out of mist-filled clouds and exploded in a cornfield today. Five men testing automatic flight equipment were killed.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer charged last night that the Sanitation Department, with the knowledge and approval of Mayor La Guardia, had operated for months without a Commissioner, with the result that "neglect and indifference had permitted intolerable conditions" to exist.

For the second successive year real estate purchasers able to pay cash enjoyed the advantage in buying negotiations during 1940, according to an analysis of all 1940 open-market Manhattan realty transactions by the Real Estate Board of New York.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- President Ismet Inonu said today that Turkey -- "an oasis of peace amid the flames of war" -- would be happy if she could become "a source of the peace for which the entire universe longs."

FROM the earliest days of collecting, books and pamphlets published during the fifteenth century have occupied a place apart, being coveted by bibliophiles and scholars and looked upon with awe and wonder by the laity.

MOO: Britain's Minister of Health, Ernest Brown, last week received an essay written by a 10-year-old London East End boy who had been evacuated to the country. It read, in part: "The cow is a mamal. * * * The head is for the purpose of growing horns and so his mouth can be somewhere.

THE depression has made deeper marks on their faces, they are perhaps a little older, there are four or five women among them, and they don't wear formal evening clothes when they give concerts, but otherwise the ninety men of the New York City Symphony Orchestra look like the members of any of the country's major symphony orchestras when they are assembled on the stage.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 1 -- Minnesota's mighty mite, 147-pound Bud Higgins, took the controls for one quick scoring drive today to send the Golden Gopher Express rolling along the Western Conference and national championship roadways with a well-earned 8-to-7 victory over Northwestern's Wildcats.
District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, declared last night that Mayor La Guardia had evaded every charge he had made against him in the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- In spite of the "almost astronomical increase" in the miles flown by Army pilots and students since 1939 and the use of new planes of much higher speed and complexity of operation, the accident rate in military flying remained "substantially unchanged" in the year ended June 30, the War Department reported today.

Adolf Hitler's charge that the United States has attacked Germany is a piece of routine mendacity. Germany, according to the Nazi propagandists, has been "attacked" by every nation that dared to defend itself. The ab- surdity of this latest sample of the "big lie" is obvious.

Visions of a $19,000,000 Harlem River Drive rivaling the East River Drive and similarly combining parks and playgrounds and other recreational facilities were presented yesterday to residents of Harlem by Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Borough President, in a campaign speech at Mount Olivet Baptist Church, 201 Lenox Avenue.

THIS morning the customary July 1-Nov. 1 round-up. Of the books to come my way in the four-month period the following stand out, in retrospect, above the rest. Charles Poore, who presides here on Fridays and Saturdays, has already made a report of his own.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Immediate speeding up of supplies of rubber for the United States to increase this country's supplies is planned. It has been confirmed that at the recent meeting of the International Rubber Committee this development was considered with others.

Walter S. Mack Jr., president of the Phoenix Securities Corporation, has issued his report for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31. It shows that the net asset value of the corporation on that date was $16,083,289, after deducting accrued dividends on the preferred stock.

In honor of the 150th anniversary of the death of Mozart and of the centenary of the birth of Dvorak, the program presented by the New Friends of Music at its second concert of the season, yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, was devoted to works by those composers.

MEXICO CITY. Nov. 2 (AP) -- Wilford Wehrle, 28-year old Racine, Wis. golfer, won Mexico's sixteenth amateur golf championship today, beating Spec Stewart of Roswell, New Mexico, 2 and 1, in the 36-hole final.

Out of the rain, fog and mud that enveloped so many gridirons and largely grounded the air arm on a day that set a record for the scarcity of first downs, Fordham, Navy and Army emerged as the triumvirate of Eastern football.

A preview of the new John Golden production, "Theatre," starring Cornelia Otis Skinner, will be given, at the Hudson Theatre on the evening of Nov. 11 as a benefit for the Outdoor Cleanliness Association. Mrs. William F. Carey is chairman of the committee arranging the event and is being assisted by Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, Mrs. James Breckenridge Curtis and Mrs. C. Frank Reavis.

Two young men, both, of whom are learning to fly for the Navy at Floyd Bennett Field, were arrested yesterday morning after they had returned from a party at the Rockaway Hunt Club and were charged with having assaulted a policeman outside a police booth about 6 A.M.

Financial attention was divided last week between the coal strike incident and apprehension of what might follow if more American war vessels were attacked by submarines. The week began with a stock market decline, resulting from the calling of a strike in the mines controlled by the steel companies.

Special festival services were held yesterday at St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square. Speakers were the Rev. Dr. Elmore M. McKee, rector, and Charles C. Burlingham, attorney and senior warden of the church.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was slightly smaller than in the preceding month and the dullest for a corresponding month in twenty years, or since 1921. Sales in October, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 13,136,756 shares, compared with 13,544,841 shares in September and 14,484,485 shares in October, last year.

The Birds Go South The birds are going south on time this Fall, Go as usual, according to South people who, in the love of nature, carry opera glasses in the parks. The orchard oriole and the nighthawk departed in August, ahead of the rush.

VICHY, France, Nov. 2 -- Three Frenchmen, acting as guards on the railroads near Paris, have received a money reward for preventing sabotage on the lines, it was announced tonight. They stopped an attempt to set bombs on the tracKs and they were rewarded accordingly by the German military commandant, the announcement said.

The Communist party staged the biggest rally of the current campaign at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. An audience that included 16,000 who paid for their tickets, and probably 18,000 over-all, heard leading Communist orators demand all-out aid to Russia and England, formal declaration of war by the United States, defeat of William O'Dwyer for Mayor, and election of Communist candidates to the City Council.

ALBANY, Nov. 2 -- Despite the demands of the defense program, a recent analysis of jobs obtained by women in the metal-working occupations showed little or no Indication of an Increased use of women in jobs customarily filled by men, Milton O. Loysen, executive director of the Division of Placement, and Unemployment Insurance, reported today.

ROME, Nov. 2 -- The United States destroyer Reuben James got what she deserved, The Corriere della Sera writes today. The newspaper asserted that in spite of "Roosevelt's criminal policy" the Axis would continue to sink American merchantmen and warships that entered what Germany regarded as a war zone.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The stock markets here continued last week to base their course upon Russia's dauntless resistance to the German invasion. Despite the further bites that the Germans have taken in Russian territory, the City remains convinced that Chancellor Hitler never will win a complete victory.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES The Home Rule Association for WestChester County has taken no part in the present movement to create a County Board of Legislators in the place of the present County Board of Supervisors, because it feels that a great majority of Westchester voters have learned to think for themselves upon governmental questions.
The plan of the Roosevelt Administration to concentrate control of the unemployment insurance program in the Federal Government was opposed yesterday by the American Association for Social Security.

The Giants took the Cardinals too lightly in their Polo Grounds battle yesterday and so the Cardinals took the Giants, handing them an even ruder shock than the upset by Brooklyn last week. The Chicagoans, playing definitely better football all the way, triumphed, 10 to 7, and thus drove the New Yorkers out of first place in the Eastern Division of the National League to the runner-up post behind the Washington Redskins.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- As the election campaign in Westchester County was drawing to a close today friends of Schuyler Patterson, Democratic candidate for Comity Executive, expressed confidence that he would win by a small margin over Herbert C. Gerlach, the Republican incumbent, while Gerlach supporters predicted a plurality of 30,000 for their candidate.

The midseason furniture market which starts in Chicago today will open under a cloud of recommendations that a part of outstanding orders be canceled, or at least deferred. Arthur Fertig of Arthur Fertig Co., retail advisory service, said that he had recommended these steps in the last few days to many stores whose inventories were too heavy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The vital sections of the Neutrality Act will be repealed by the Senate this week and American merchant vessels will be carrying munitions into British ports within a month, Administration leaders in Congress predicted tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- An Administration campaign was reported in the making today for reversal of the House Banking Committee's decision to permit farm prices to rise considerably higher before ceiling could be imposed.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday the results of a questionnaire on county reform sent to candidates for county offices. Eight of the thirteen Republican, Labor and Fusion candidates said they favored Proposition 1. Two Democrats said they were supporting the alternative measures and others did not answer.

With the municipal campaign coming to an end today, the chances seemed to favor the reelection of Mayor La Guardia, despite a shift of voters to District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic Mayoralty candidate, last week.

On the eve of the formal opening of a new $756,000 road system to and from La Guardia Field, Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, recommended yesterday to Mayor La Guardia a 355-acre expansion of the airport. Mr. Moses pointed out that the additional area would provide for four new runways and extension of existing runways by 4,000 feet.

Erskine Caldwell, novelist, and his wife, Margaret Bourke-White, photographer, returned to New York yesterday aboard the Pan American Airways' Atlantic Clipper after five months in Russia. They expressed the opinion that "we will all be helling' Hitler within the next eighteen months" unless all-out aid is given the Soviet Union.

The State executive committee of the Disabled American Veterans of the World War, at a meeting in the Hotel New Yorker, adopted yesterday a resolution calling, in effect, for immediate severance of diplomatic relations with Nazi Germany, "to be followed, if our leadera see fit, by a declaration of war."

The Coast Guard, which was transferred by President Roosevelt yesterday to the control of, the Navy, was formed in 1915 by amalgamation of the Revenue Cutter Service and the Life Saving Service. Predecessor services were placed under Naval control in the Spanish American War and the Coast Guard was under Navy orders in the World War.
LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Oct. 31 (Delayed) -- The new demarcations of the frontier between the Mongolian Peoples Republic and Japanese-dominated Manchukuo along a 250-kilometer [a kilometer is .621 of a mile] stretch in the Bor Nor region has been settled in conference at Harbin between Mongolian and Manchukuoan delegations, supported by Soviet and Japanese advisers, it was announced this afternoon.

Formation of a bloc of nations to function as an economic unit after the war, embracing Poland, Czecho-Slovakia, Yugoslavia and Greece, has been determined upon by the delegations of those countries to the conference of the International Labor Organization, it was learned yesterday.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Field goals by Al Lee and Sandy Sanford in the second period gave the Long Island Indians a 13-7 victory over the Wilmington Clippers at Memorial Field today before 7,209 fans in an American Association game.

New securities offered to the public here in October continued on a small scale. Bond flotations, although larger than in September, were less than one-third the total marketed in the same month last year. Stock emissions were smaller than in September and less than in October, last year.

At one of the most enthusiastic meetings of the campaign, Mayor La Guardia and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey declared last night that the only issue the voters will have to decide at the polls tomorrow is whether they want to continue a clean, honest non-partisan administration or return the city to the control of "the boys in the back room."
NEW YORK Mrs. Arthur Bliss Lane, wife of the newly appointed United States Minister to Costa Rica, has arrived at the Ambassador from Washington.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Germany's charge that the United States had attacked her was viewed by informed observers today as a statement for the record to counter accusations by President Roosevelt, and it was not believed the Germans would ask Japan to invoke the Three-power pact.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., Nov. 2 -- Jimmy Hines of the Lakeville Club beat par by two strokes with a 33, 36-69 in the second play-off for the Long Island P.G.A. championship to defeat the Wheatley Hills veteran, Willie Klein; who scored a 71, at the Oceanslde Golf Club today.

The New York Americans beat the Baltimore Americans by 4 -- 2 yesterday in the first American Soccer League game staged at Triborough Stadrum, Randalls Island. The contest featured an American Loyalty Day program, which drew a crowd of 5,000.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The TlMES's article "Rise Is Sought in Security Taxes" announged a probable increase of social security taxes to 5 per cent or more. This is the third article on this subject that has come to my attention within the last week or so and clearly indicates that the Treasury really means business.

Throughout the four seasons he has served as usher at the Metropolitan Joseph Clifford has been preparing himself for appearances some day on the stage of that opera house. Last night in Town Hall the young tenor from Denver gave his first local recital, at which he manifested the results of his earnest striving to perfect himself as a vocalist capable of reaching this desired operatic goal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Stocks of canned peaches in distributors' hands Oct. 1 were up 42 per cent above the levels of a year ago, the Commerce Department reports in its quarterly survey of canned food stocks. As recently as July 1, inventories of this item were at 1940 levels, according to the department.

The St. Aloysius Gonzaga High School football team of Washington, D.C. invaded the Bronx yesteaday and turned back the Mount St. Michael High eleven, 13-12. In the last minute of play a forward pass apparently had scored the winning touchdown for the home forces, but it was disallowed because the receiver was out of bounds.

"Taps" sounded by trumpeters in the chancel and choir loft of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon was the climax of the annual vesper memorial service for the New York City Police Anchor Club, 2,400 members of which had marched from Eigrhth Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street with 600 other members of the Knights of Columbus and other societies.

A novel method of educating adult refugees in American folkways and the English language, in which the "textbooks" are such media as the labels on canned food and the captions under newspaper photographs, is entering its third year on an expanded scale under the auspices of New York's Committee for Refugee Education.

Mayor La Guardia is "retreating in disorder," deserting supporters like Park Commissioner Robert Moses, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and Wendell Willkie, James A. Parley, Democratic State chairman, charged last night in a radio speech on behalf of William, O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for liayor, and his running mates in which the Mayor again was accused of using vituperative language.

ITS getting easier ail the time to count the teams that are still standing up. Penn went down before Navy. Vanderbilt was run over by that hot-and-cold Tulane team. But Fordham is standing up in the East, Duke's record remains unsullied, mighty Minnesota went its winning way with a one-point decision over Northwestern and the twin terrors of the Southwest, Texas and Texas A. and M., still have things their own way in that territory.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- Russian morale is "exceedingly good" and the gravest danger the Soviet faces is the serious loss of materials and industrial plants, according to travelers who left Kuibyshev, Russian secondary capital, five days ago.

VICHY, Nov. 2 -- The labor charter published this week is a work of considerable magnitude. It aims to put an end to the class struggle and set up a new organization under which relations of workers, employers and technicians can be brought into harmony.

The executive committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York will urge elimination of the St. Lawrence Waterway project and certain other features of the omnibus Rivers and Harbors Bill in a report to be submitted to the chamber on Thursday, it was announced yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Scotty Isdale made a clean sweep with Queen Mary in Class X Arthur Knapp was consistent to win in Class B with Four Deuces and Bob Bavier Jr. took the honors among the Lawley 110s with Fun in the second weekly dinghy regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club today.
BERLIN, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The German High Command issued the following special communique today:

The Germans claim to have taken Simferopol, capital of the Crimea, which brings them within forty miles of Sevastopol, the great naval base the Russians call the Gibraltar of the Black Sea. Near by is the plain of Balaclava, scene of one of the most heroic and useless engagements in British military history.
SINGAPORE, Nov. 2 -- Strengthened many times over within the last year, the R.A.F. in British Malaya is certain to play a leading role in event of a Japanese attack.

STOCKHOLM. Sweden, Nov. 2 -- A step toward the prevention and cure of infantile paralysis has possibly been made in Sweden, it was revealed today with the announcement that quite recently three Swedish scientists -- Dr. Sven Card, Professor The Svedberg and Professor Arne Tiselius -- working at the research institute at Upsala, had succeeded in isolating the virus of a mouse paralysis.

A warning to young girls not to leave comfortable small-town aomes to seek careers in New York was broadcast yesterday by the missing persons bureau of the Police Department when it appealed for public aid in locating six attractive runaways who came here to embark on professional careers.
PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Paterson Panthers strengthened their lead in the American Football Association today by trouncing the New York Yankees, 31 to 7.

BERLIN, Nov. 2 -- A new offensive against excess purchasing power was launched last week by the Reich's financial leaders. While the Russian campaign is still dragging on, with a prospect of definitely crushing the enemy before the year ends still remote, am while the peoples of German-occupied countries grimly look for ward to a third war Winter, Berlin considers it imperative to take pre cautionary measures for financing a long war.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Two powerful German columns are striking below Moscow, while the battle in the south has surged through a large part of the Crimean Peninsula, war dispatches said today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Liquidation by holders of grain futures on the Board of Trade here apparently ran its course early last week, and a sharp break then was followed by a rally that more than wiped out the decline, especially in corn, oats and soy beans.

DETROIT, Nov. 2 -- The Detroit Red Wings twice came from behind tonight as they played the New York Americans to a 3-to-3 overtime tie in the National Hockey League opener here before 111,452 spectators. It was the Wings' second game and the New Yorkers' first.

Early in this municipal campaign Mayor La Guardia declared that there was only one issue. That issue was whether the people of the city want to continue efficient, intelligent city government or to go back to machine government. In the course of the campaign nothing has been said to indicate that there is any other issue.
FORT SMITH, Ark, Nov. 2 -- The flooding Arkansas River reached a crest of 37.3 feet here late today and stopped rising, indicating that a fall would start during the night.

In the present tragic world situation, humanity is realizing more keenly than ever the help and strength afforded in religion and is looking toward a righteous peace for all mankind, Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday morning in a confirmation address at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street.

Norman Thomas, head of the Socialist party, and Dr. George Hartmann, Socialist candidate for Mayor, closed the party's campaign yesterday with charges that Mayor La Guardia had failed to justify the name of "liberal and progressive" and had given only lip service to the most vital city reforms.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The people of Europe are coming to believe that the war will end in a stalemate -- neither Germany nor Britain winning the conflict and both being invincible, Sir Samuel Hoare, British Amuassador to Madrid, said today at Reading University.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 -- Democracy and Hitlerism cannot exist together, Senator Claude Pepper of Florida told Hadassah delegates today at their closing session when the women's Zionist organization memorialized Justice Louis D. Brandeis and observed the twentyfourth anniversary of the Balfour Declaration.

Approximately two minutes of offensive fireworks, sparked by electrifying lateral passes, netted the Milwaukee Chiefs a 7-to-6 verdict over the New York Americans in their American Football League clash yesterday at the Yankee Staaium.

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, preaching yesterday morning at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, declared that although "the times are evil, they may be redeemed by Christian influences."

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 -- Although the captive coal mine strike was lifted last week in time to prevent practically any actual loss in steel production, an "outlaw" strike of SWOC cranemen at the Homestead plant of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation resulted in a loss of several thousand tons of urgently needed steel ingots.

Evidence tending to show a direct link between the leaders of the Brooklyn murder syndicate and a Brooklyn Democratic club was made public yesterday by Commissioner of Investigation William B. Herlands in connection with a radio address in which he charged that District Attorney William O'Dwyer, the'Democratic Mayoralty candidate, was prevented by his political connections from prosecuting the politicians behind the Brooklyn killers.

BERLIN, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The German High Command published its balance sheet for October in the war on "British supply shipping" today and declared that a total of 441,300 gross tons had been sunk during the month.

KEARNY, N.J., Nov. 2 -- The Irish-Americans and Brookhattan F.C. played to a 1-1 tie in their league fixture at Scots Field today. After a scoreless first half, Jennette tallied for Brookhattan, Owen equalizing.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 2 -- With Finland's troops standing tonight before Leningrad, Risto Ryti, President of Finland, gave me the first direct answers to specific questions since the beginning of hostilities.
LONDON, Monday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force continued its grand offensive with hundreds of planes against Germany, her shipping and continental outposts over Saturday night and yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Washington Redskins pushed Pittsburgh's football machine all over the field to score a 23-3 victory over the Steelers in a National League game before 30,755 spectators today.

CEDAR SPRINGS, Mich., Nov. 2 -- A plaintive note in a New York newspaper columnist's comment several years ago that red flannel underwear was "a thing of the past," adding that he could not buy a pair to take the chill off his commuting to Connecticut, led directly to this town taking its place as a leader in the red flannel industry.

BERLIN, Nov. 2 -- Following: up the penetration of the Perekop Isthmus, the German High Command today announced that its forces, in cooperation with Rumanian units, had swept across the Crimean plains to the foothills of the Yaila Mountains, capturing Simferopol, the capital of Crimea and an important rail and highway junction.

Already the hopeful men of Broadway have turned their eyes to New Tear's Eve. Announcements were made yesterday that tickets have gone on sale for New Year's Eve performances of two of the firmly entrenched hold-overs from last season -- "My Sister Eileen" and "Arsenic and Old Lace."
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- The mighty Chicago Bears, shackled completely for three periods, bowed to inspired Green Bay today, 16 to 14, in the most stunning upset of the National Football League season.

Alfred Ortiz, 17 years old, an errand boy who came here in 1930 from Puerto Rico, and George Johnson, 18, a Negro, were arrested yesterday on charges of raping, assaulting' and robbing a woman whose name the police withheld. The crimes occurred at 6:15 P.M. on Oct. 23 in Central Park at Ninety-seventh Street.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 2 -- A majority of the 128 members of the Llewellyn Park Association, the governing organization for Llewellyn Park here, have agreed to a subdivision of some estates in the park so that homes on plots of one-half acre or more will be permissible in the park,, it was learned today.

Greg Rice, former Notre Dame athlete, making his first appearance in the colors of the New York A.C., won the senior metropolitan cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Competing in a field of fifty starters, Rice ran the six miles in 31 minutes 30 seconds and led his teammate, Jim Rafferty, runner-up, across the finish line by about 300 yards.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- About 100 Coast Guard cutters and patrol boats, some of them of considerable size and fire power, will be transferred to supervision of the Navy by the Executive Order issued by President Roosevelt tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Japanese liner Tatuta Maru sailed from San Francisco today under dripping skies which were in keeping with the moody farewells among nearly 1,000 passengers heading for their homeland and a future obscured by war clouds.

We have just returned from a check-up of the waterfowl situation along the Connecticut shore of Long Island Sound, and so far as ducks are concerned there should be little excuse for any complaint on the part of the gunners.
The first luncheon of the 1941-42 season of the Women's Bond Club of New York will be held at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, at 12:45 P.M. Thursday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Excessive rains, which in some areas were the heaviest on record for an October, have brought field work to a complete standstill in parts of the big surplus corn and soy-bean producing sections of the Central West.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 -- The Detroit Lions alertly converted two pass interceptions into eventual touchdowns today for a 14-to-0 triumph which sent the Cleveland Rams plunging into the cellar of the National Football Leaguels Western division.

OTTAWA, Nov. 2 -- Following last week's announcement that basic wages in Canada would be stabilized and providing for a compulsory "cost of living bonus" according to the rate at which prices might rise, the government today issued a second order-in-council putting a ceiling on prices.

Activity in the apparel market was fair last week with a slight pick-up in some lines. Requests for formal wear increased as retailers started to round out their stocks. High-shade crepes and wools sold steadily. Mail was light on coats and suits.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- St. Mary's Gaels slid through deep mud today to roll up a 26-to-0 victory over the Gonzaga football eleven. Rain poured throughout the contest. About 300 fans braved the dismal weather.

There will be no peace until all of Poland is restored to its former status, Mayor La Guardia told several thousand persons yesterday afternoon in Tompkins Square Park as the State-wide planting of trees in memory of Ignace Jan faderewsM was begun.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 2 -- Mayor Frank Hague promised 1,500 of his constituents here today that his Democratic machine, which he said "always represents the side of the people and good government," ultimately would win its battle to collect $17,000,000 owed to Jersey City by the railroads.

The advantage of nationally advertised food brands over private brands in periods of rising prices are pointed out by the American Institute of Food Distribution. The institute cited both Campbell Soup Company and General Foods Corporation as examples.

The Rev. William Van H. Davies, associate pastor of the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central "Park, West and Sixty-fifth Street, declared yesterday morning in his sermon that "our unfortunate condition today must be attributed to a failure of nerve."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 -- Bobert Benchley, Susan Hayward, Martha O'Driscoll, Barbara Britton and Jim Brown were named by Paramount to complete the screen cast of last season's Broadway comedy, "Out of the Frying Pan," which will go before the cameras on Thursday with Edward H. Griffith directing.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Nov. 3 -- Fighting stubborn rearguard actions all the way, Red Army troops in Crimea fell back to a point just north of Simferopol, the capital, after German forces, strongly supported by mechanized materiel and dive-bomber formations, had broken the Russian center, a Soviet spokesman acknowledged this morning.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- Queen Elizabeth no longer rivals the Duchess of Kent as Britain's bestdressed woman, partly because of the Queen's wartime economy in restocking' her wardrobe, but chiefly because of Scottish stubbornness over what she thinks looks best on her.

Prices of cotton moved within a narrow range last week. They declined early, turned firmer later and softened near the close of the week as trade support lessened. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses for the week of 15 to 36 points.

Far from a set-up were the Philadelphia Eagles yesterday when they dropped into Ebbets Field to do battle with the Brooklyn Football Dodgers. The Brooks won but by the time the final gun barked every man in a red and white uniform knew he had been in a struggle.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The Economist's index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, stood on Oct. 14 at 107.4, compared with 107.1 at the end of September, 106.9 on Sept. 16 and 98.9 on Oct. 22, 1940.
Loft buildings comprised the bulk of realty traded in Manhattan over the week-end.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 2 -- A B-17 Army flying fortress on the way from Reno to Sacramento broke up in a snowstorm and crashed today on a peak of the Sierra Nevadas, the Army announced tonight.

A Brazilian editor and his wife -- who is the first woman to receive such a distinction -- are among the four winners of Maria Moors Cabot Prizes in Journalism, it was announced yesterday by Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- Confronted with an unexpected coal shortage, the government appealed today to housewives to stop washing dishes and clothes under open faucets, discontinue day-long playing of the radio and dispense with heating in their bedrooms.

In his conversations with President Roosevelt at Hyde Park the Canadian Prime Minister could very appropriately, and doubtless did, lay before the President impressive details of his country's all-out war effort. It has been no mean accomplishment In fact, looked at against the background of the Dominion's limited population, peacetime preoccupation with anything but armament, and previous scant development of vast natural resources, the achievement is one of the little appreciated miracles of this war.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- President Roosevelt today placed the entire Coast Guard under the orders of the Secretary of the Navy as an emergency measure.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin) Nov. 2 -- Although the tendency of the small Continental markets, taken as a whole last week, became slightly more uncertain, the general impression persists that they more and more are drawing into one line, which is based principally on the great liquidity and money abundance laying a bottom below the market despite taxation and price-control measures.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The National Economy League, offering the report of a survey which, it declared, showed that only 59 cents of each WPA dollar went to relief workers, repeated today a demand that the government abandon work relief and return to cooperative direct relief during the armament period.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The Russian request that Britain declare war on Finland, Rumania and Hungary, learned of definitely here today, is still under consideration and no decision has yet been reached.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Scoring in every quarter, the Fort Momnouth eleven easily defeated Fort Hancock today, 36 -- 0, before 4,500 spectators at the Asbury Park High School Stadium. Proceeds went to United China Relief.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The War Department announced yesterday the award of miscellaneous supply contracts totaling 5105,110,724. Included among these were the following, not previously published, which were granted to companies in the New York area:

The Speyer family have been bankers since the fourteenth century. It was only natural that James Speyer should have followed the family tradition. Something of the old school flavor of that mellow tradition clung about him even in the brisk atmosphere of Wall Street.
Governor Lehman, in a radio speech yesterday afternoon, asked approval of all four proposed amendments to the State Constitution to be voted upon tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations anommced today an organizing drive among government workers with, the goal of enrolling 1,000,000 members in the United Federal Workers of America.

Adjustment to war conditions has gone so far that business in the United States has become immune to shock, either of renewed tension in the Far East or of torpedoings of United States ships in the Atlantic, the National City Bank asserts in its monthly summary of general business and financial condition.

A new record was established yesterday at the international seaplane base, La Guardia Field, when 135 passengers, using all of Pan American Airways' three giant flying boats, passed through the marine terminal. The Atlantic and Yankee Clippers arrived from Lisbon and the Dixie Clipper departed within a period of five and a half hours.

BERLIN, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Informed spokesmen said tonight that they did not believe the question of invoking the Three-power pact "arises at all at this time" in connection with Germany's formal declaration that the United States attacked her.
World chaos always follows when man's first duty to God is forgotten, the Rev. Thomas Lester Graham declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, where he is a member of the staff.

The United States Sugar Corporation will offer to registered holders of its common and preferred stock as of next Monday rights to subscribe to 200,000 shares of new Series A preferred stock, it was announced yesterday by the company.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- Answering charges from the Purchase Property Owners Association that a "veil of secrecy" covers the methods used in choosing the estate area of Purchase as a county airport site, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors adopted today a fourteen-page report explaining why the Army and supervisors believe that the airport should be built in Purchase.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Erwin Rudolph, Cleveland, four-times winner of the title, entered a two-way tie for leadership in the 1941 world pocket billiards championship tournament tonight when he defeated Defending Champion Willie Mosconi, Philadelphia, 125 to 70, in twelve innings.

Jerry Adler of Inwood and Ernie Catropa of Idlewild tied with Max Habrich and Tony Longo of Inwood at 66 for the honors in the weekly one-day amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Pomonok Club in Flushing yesterday.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, finished up the municipal campaign last night with a broadcast accusing Mayor La Guardia of leading to the polls the disciples of Lincoln with one hand and the apostles of Stalin with the other.

Strong opposition to the contribution of one-third of 1 per cent on sales to the $1,000,000 annual promotion and advertising fund of the New York Dress Institute was voiced yesterday by members of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group at a special meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.
Newbold Morris, candidate for re-election as President of the City Council, issued yesterday a statement appealing to voters to support him on his record.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 2 (Delayed) -- The city of Moscow, which represents an architectural bridge between Europe and Asia has now been transformed into a fortified citadel -- probably the largest defended city in the history of modern warfare.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- Striking welders of the Seattle area rejected today by unanimous vote a "back to work" appeal from Sidney Hillman, associate director of the Office of Production Management.

BOSTON, Nov. 3 -- The American College of Surgeons issued today a list of 2,873 hospitals in the United States, Canada and other countries approved by its 1941 survey. Those in New York City, Westchester County, Long Island, New Jersey and Connecticut are as follows:

Two years ago an intrepid grocery concern started forth on a determined search. They had set their hearts on adding a vegetable cocktail to their stock in trade and their idea of just what that cocktail must be was, as the French put it, "fixe."
Mrs. Oswald B. Lord sees people for fifteen-minute appointments only these days.
Opponents combined with last week-end's rain and mud to cut the list of the nation's unbeaten and untied football teams.

Coach Bob Higgins, whose Penn State Nittany Lions overwhelmed N.T.U. last Friday night, didn't care particularly to talk about his varsity as he addressed the football writers at Shor's yesterday. "We got all the bounces and were very fortunate," he declared, which probably is as modest a manner as any to dismiss a 42-0 victory over a major opponent.

The Columbia football team reported to Baker Field yesterday to begin light work for Saturday's final road game with Pennsylvania at Philadelphia. Only one injury was brought to light, when Stew (Snuffy) McIlvennan showed up with a bruised leg.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Arguments on the petitions of persons seeking to intervene in the case of certain preferred stockholders against the York Ice Machinery Corporation are being-heard by United States District Judge Albert J. Watson of Scranton, Pa., today in the United States District Court here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 --The Nazi government has declined to consider a demand by the United States for compensation for the torpedoing of the American freighter Robin Moor, sunk in the South Atlantic May 21.

The aim of the American Legion is the same as the national objective of the United States, "the defeat of Hitler and all he stands for," and the Legion believes that all other issues should be subordinated and unity achieved on national defense, Ray Murphy, former national commander of the organization and chairman of its foreign relations committee at the recent convention in Milwaukee, declared yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden (via Berlin), Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- Six Norwegians were executed in Norway today for "assisting enemies" and the entire Norwegian fishing fleet of 70,000 vessels was placed under State control, presumably to prevent further escapes to Britain, press dispatches said tonight.

ROME, Nov. 3 -- Premier Mussolini in a brief address at the dedication of the new Garibaldine Shrine on the Janiculum this morning proclaimed to his people and the world that Italy has not forgotten her grievances against France.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- Charles H. Griffiths, Republican chairman of Westchester County, predicted today that Herbert G. Gerlach, Republican, would be elected county executive tomorrow by a plurality of 35,000 to 40,000 votes.
MARTINSVILLE, Va., Nov. 3 -- A million miles more of nylon yarn a day by the Summer of 1942 is the promise given by du Pont's new nylon plant here, which began operation today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- Three American missionaries have been held in custody by Japanese authorities in Manchukuo since Oct. 22, it was disclosed today by the Independent Board for Presbyterian Foreign Missions on the basis of information received by the Department of State.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- The ruthless campaign of Acting Protector Reinhard Heydrich to liquidate Czecho-Slovak resistance to German authority can now after five weeks be looked on as successfully completed, according to a German announcement today, but coupled with it is the conditional information that "investigations still tin progress may occupy the authorities with one or two more special cases."

President Roosevelt was warned last night by the Federation of Long Lines Telephone Workers, an Independent union, that telephone communication vital to national defense would be halted by a strike an Nov. 14 unless the federation's dispute with the A.T. T. were certified to the National Defense Mediation Board.

OTTAWA. Nov. 3 -- Until the "ghastly potentialities" of Nazi military might were squarely faced in all quarters of the globe, humanity must go on suffering "violence and bloodshed on an evergrowing scale," Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King told the Canadian House of Commons today when it resumed its sessions.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The railroads of the United States are facing a critical situation. The decision of the Fact-Finding Board is due within a few days. It will involve railroad wage policy -- not merely the present increase but whether wages shall be rigid or flexible.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 3 -- If Leroy Mclntyre, a fireman, fights a thousand conflagrations and saves a life in every one, he is unlikely to make another rescue like his of today.
The Coca-Cola Company announced yesterday that its volume of operations in the third quarter and first nine months of this year exceeded that of any previous period in its history.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- The Japanese public is keenly interested in Germany's charge that she has been "attacked" by the United States, but it is doubted that the Tokyo government will go to the extent of "unreserved approval" of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's stand, well-informed quarters said today.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 2 (Delayed) -- Moscow has become a regular target for vicious German aerial bombardment and four or five times a day the screams of sirens warn the people that raiders are approaching. The Germans, flying at great heights, bomb the city by day and night, according to Russian accounts.

LONDON, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- Military experts believed today that the Germans planned to drive across Crimea to the Caucasus and turn north to come upon the oil port of Rostov from behind and outflank the whole Russian Don River defense line.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Lynn Waldorf, reviewing Northwestern's 8-to-7 loss to Minnesota Saturday, revealed today that "our observers in the press box thought Bud Higgins's 41-yard touchdown run on the 'sleeper' play was illegal."

Switches in materials away from such metals as copper and copper alloys, together with continued emphasis on intermediate price ranges will feature Spring lines of handbags, initial showings of which will occur this month, reports in the industry indicated yesterday.

After a tour of the United States and Canada that began in Miami on Sept. 23 and included two weeks in New York, the Duke and Duchess of Windsor left Pennsylvania Station for Florida at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

Governor Lehman and Lieut. Gov. Poletti issued yesterday a joint statement urging an affirmative vote on all three local propositions on the ballot today. These provide alternative methods of consolidating the five county offices of Sheriff and Register.

Mayor La Guardia gave yesterday an accounting of the successful operation of the municipal airport that bears his name, citing large increases in air traffic, payrolls and revenue at the field and thus replying to critics who had called it a "white elephant."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 1:
Charles F. Noyes has purchased for investment another business property in the downtown area adjacent to a group of buildings which he has been acquiring over a period of twenty years.
PANAMA, Nov. 3 -- The people of Panama, joined by their Good Neighbors in the Canal Zone, celebrated the thirty-eighth anniversary of the republic's independence today.

CAMDEN, S.C., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Toughened by four weeks of field work, Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum's First Army began today the most elaborate battle practice of its eight-week manoeuvre program in the Carolinas.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 3 -- Labor activities of the Socialist Workers Party extended throughout the Middle West, and even included sending a special representative to edit a strikers newspaper during the Omaha trucking tie-up in 1938, it was testified today in the sedition trial of twenty-eight persons in Federal District Court.

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 3 -- With every minute of every hour packed with some new problem, the Canadian Wartimes Prices and Trade Board was busy today trying to draft schedules of price ceilings in almost every industry and trade in which they are necessary under the new order which was issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Wheat farmers, asked to cut their 1942 acreage, will receive higher rates of conservation payments next year, while those for other crops are reduced.

A total Of 43,000 square feet of space in the buildings at 265 West Thirty-seventh and 270 West Thirty-eighth Streets, has been leased by the Olive Coat Company for the manufacture and sale of women's coats and suits. Spear Co., Inc., was the broker.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- Samuel Murray, well-known sculptor and a student of Thomas Eakins, died today after a long illness at his home here at the age of 71. Mr. Murray, who was born here, studied under Mr. Eakins at the Art Students League and later became assistant to the famous painter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- As President Roosevelt announced in Hyde Park today that he will confer this week with Congressional leaders on House committee modifications of the Administration's price control bill, indications here were that Leon Henderson's Office of Price Administration would recommend adoption of any measure which can be passed quickly rather than risk further delay.
NEW YORK Major Gen. and Mrs. William Crozier of Washington have come to the St. Regis.

Democratic charges that Mayor La Guardia was friendly to communism and Communists were amply proved on Sunday at the Communist rally in Madison Square Garden, James A. Farley, Democratic State chairman, declared last night in a radio speech in behalf of District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor.

ROME, Nov. 3 -- Copies of a document that appears to be the same as the one President Roosevelt mentioned in his Navy Day speech about religion are circulating in Vatican circles today. That gave rise to the report that Harold H. Tittmann Jr., United States Counselor of Embassy in Rome, had presented the document on behalf of Mr. Roosevelt to Pope Pius.

Trading in the local dressed meat markets yesterday showed little or no improvement over last Friday's close. Supplies of practically all classes with the exception of fresh pork cuts were fully ample for trade requirements.

FOOTBALL coaches and scouts are still chuckling over the way Minnesota tripped Northwestern with a trick play lifted from an old trunk in the cellar, It was the "sneak play," started when nobody was looking. But Bernie Bierman's boys must have been good actors to put it over in such a dramatic way. They couldn't have done better if John Barrymore had been coaphing them.
BERLIN Nov. 3 (AP) -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler's headquarters issued the following communique today:

Direct payments to George E. Browne were described for the first time yesterday in Federal court as the trial of Browne and Willie Bioff on charges of extorting many hundreds of thousands of dollars from the movie industry neared its final stages.

Of the many benefit theatre parties of late Autumn contributing to Anglo-American interests and war-relief activities, one of the most largely subscribed is that of the English-Speaking Union for Thursday night's performance of "The Wookey," at the Plymouth Theatre, which deals with England in wartime.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Navy, in starting' today to forge a new weapon for the Battle of the Atlantic, stated that the fifty high-speed escort vessels for Great Britain would be turned out at the rate of about two a month when construction reaches full stride next year.

TONICA, Ill., Nov. 3 -- Deep in the muddy rows of eight-foot corn, twenty-two farmyard athletes competed today for the 1941 national cornhusking championship which was won by Floyd Wise of LaSalle County, who husked more than 60 ears a minute during the 80-minute grind.

Tonight's event at the Belasco will be the premiere of "The Man With Blond Hair," a melodrama by Norman Krasna, once a newspaper man and now a prominent figure in Hollywood. The author and his film partner, Frank Ross, have backed the production, with Mr. Ross credited as the producer and Mr. Krasna also as the director.

ON Election Day in 1940 some 45 of every 100 citizens who went to the polls voted for Mr. Willkie. Some 55 of every 100 voted for Mr. Roosevelt. The majority were satisfied when their candidate won and are doubtless satisfied now. But what about the minority?

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 3 -- Nearly 25 per cent of 5,548 students in seven Eastern colleges polled by the Wesleyan undergraduate newspaper are in favor of immediate declaration of war against Germany.

VICHY, France, Nov. 3 -- By the addition of twenty names and the elimination of seventeen, membership in the National Council of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's advisory body, which is filling the place of the somnolent Parliament, was altered today to give it a character more representative of the new regime.

Stories of Nazi penetration in South and Central America were related by three delegates to the International Youth Conference, who returned yesterday from Mexico City. They met for discussion at the Hotel Piccadilly.

Well pleased with the performance of the squad in last Saturday's 17-0 trouncing of Purdue, Coach Jim Crowley gave the Fordham football team a rest yesterday and will begin practice this morning for Saturday's battle with Pittsburgh in the Smoky City.

HYDE PARK, Nov. 3 -- President Roosevelt declared that the United States would never accept the "new order" of dictatorship in a speech today citing the effective manner in which democracy works in the long run.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 3 -- Mrs. Ira Walton Henry of Old Greenwich will return the "great seal" of Fairfax County, Va., to representatives from that State at a luncheon in the Pickwick Arms Hotel here Saturday, Nov. 8, at 1 P.M.

MOORHEAD, Minn., Nov. 3 (AP) -- The dramatic story of how his 12-ton Northwest transport plane "started to flutter and shake" with the controls dead and speed indicators "out" was related today by Pilot Clarence Bates, only survivor of the Northwest Airlines crash last Thursday in which fourteen persons lost their lives.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Administration leaders in the Senate indicated tonight that they would have enough votes to pass the measure to arm merchant vessels and permit them to go to belligerent ports despite the announcement today by two Senators that they would vote against it.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- An "unsatisfactory" result was reported today by U Saw, Premier of Burma, just before he left London after an attempt to obtain a promise of self-government for Burma within the Empire after the end of the war.

Standing under a sidewalk awning in mid-Manhattan with a heavy rain splashing about his feet and Christmas shoppers hurrying by in the early December twilight, Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, ruler of the city's $1,000,000 industrial rackets empire, listened stonily while a witness in a murder case pleaded for a chance to come out of hiding and visit his wife and child.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System experienced yesterday their first full day with diminished excess reserves, after reserve requirements had been raised by the Federal Reserve Board on Saturday, to the limit now permitted by law.

The Committee for the Election of O'Dwyer, Church and Fertig made public yesterday a list of Republican politicians who it alleges have been appointed by Mayor La Guardia to high paying posts "because of their political efforts" on his behalf or because of "their relationship" to Republican politicians who have been so essential to his "non-political" administration.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 3 -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, British commander of the Indian Army, who arrived here yesterday on a visit to Malaya, was busy today with a series of conferences and visits to military establishments.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 -- Ronald Colman was signed today by Columbia to star with Cary Grant and Jean Arthur in "Mr. Twilight," which Sidney Buchman is writing from the story by Sidney Harmon. The yarn originally dealt with the Supreme Court justice who became involved in the practical, rather than the theoretical, application of the law.

The Fordham University freshman football team will seek its seventh successive victory over the N.Y.U. cubs when they meet today in their annual Election Day game at Ohio Field. This is the only game of the season for the Ram yearlings.

Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer yesterday dismissed a writ of habeas corpus on behalf of Joseph E. McWilliams, street orator and head of the American Destiny party, and remanded McWilliams to the Hikers Island Penitentiary to serve the remainder of his sixty-day sentence for disorderly conduct.

The delegations of Poland, Czecho-Slovakia, Yugoslavia and Greece to the conference of the International Labor Organization at Columbia University made public yesterday a joint declaration announcing formation of a bloc of the Tour nations to serve as the basis, after the war, for a larger confederation of peoples from the Baltic to the Aegean.

Professor Algernon de Vivier Tassin, who originated the course "The Analysis of the Written Word" at Columbia University, died yesterday at the home of a friend in Montclair, N.J., after an illness of several months. He was 72 years old.

The University of Missouri football team, which meets N.Y.U. Saturday at the Yankee Stadium, is reported to be the best Tiger eleven in recent years, but it wouldn't have to be to defeat an N.Y.U. team which plumbed new depths against Penn State in the rain Friday night.
LONDON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique tonight:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Apparent secrecy by the Navy Department concerning details of the loss of a bomber in the "Atlantic Ocean area" and the fact that the announcement was made directly from the Navy Department aroused speculation tonight whether the bomber was operating in the Atlantic patrol and whether it was brought down in action or crashed accidentally.

When the conscientious voter steps into the booth today he will be called upon to decide more problems than it is reasonable to ask him to decide. He must begin by deciding on four different State constitutional amendments and three propositions, several of them rather technical.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Finnish Government today received a strong hint from the United States Government that it would like to see affirmative action on an offer by the Soviet Union to make peace. That offer was transmitted to Helsinki from Washington last Aug. 18.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 3 -- Although he was out of ammunition and only one of his patrol's three Tommy guns was capable of firing, a young British officer from Tobruk almost captured a large German patrol by walking up and ordering the men to surrender, according to a story officially related here today.
Several sections of the city and near-by centers shared in the apartment renting activity reported yesterday by brokers.

There was no evidence yesterday at Manhattan Field, either among the coaches or players, that Saturday's defeat at Detroit had shaken morale. On the contrary, the impression was distinct that both players and coaches felt the Jaspers had done as well as they could and they began practice yesterday for their final three games with high hopes for a season's record to compare favorably with any the Kelly Greens have had.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Marmon-Herrington Company, Inc., of Indianapolis has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 150,000 shares of common stock of $1 par value. These shares are already issued and outstanding, and are to be offered to the public for the account of three stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Representative Leland M. Ford, Republican of California, charged in the House today that Professor William L. Nunn, chairman of the New Jersey Mediation Board, and Dr. Frank P. Graham, chairman of the National Defense Mediation Board panel, which considered the recent Air Associates, Inc., strike, "have long records -- very long records -- of affiliation with subversive organizations.''

When Finland entered the war against Russia on Germany's side her cause was viewed with much sympathy in this country. That was natural, not only because of the traditional friendship between the United States and Finland, but because Finland herself had been the victim of unprovoked Russian aggression, and was regarded as merely taking advantage of an opportunity to recover territory which had been wrested from her by force.

A song recital can be an adventure in a green and pleasant land, provided the singer has the intelligence, curiosity and determination to be an unconventional guide. Doris Doe, Metropolitan Opera contralto, is such an artist, and her program at the Town Hall last night was a musical experience.
American Seating The American Seating Company declared a 50-cent dividend, increasing the year's dividends to $1 from 50 cents paid in 1940.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 3 -- "The American home is going to pieces because we government experts are driving it there," State Budget Commissioner Audley H.F. Stephan asserted today when Dr. Charles H. Elliott, State Commissioner of Education, requested an appropriation of $839,537 for manual training and home economics courses in the 1942-43 school year.

Having swung the lever all the way over and closed the curtain behind him, the voter in today's election will face the following decisions, working from top to bottom and from left to right on the voting machine:

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 -- The fourth running of the Battleship Steeplechase Handicap, named after the only American owned, trained and ridden horse ever to win England's Grand National, saw the improved 3-year-old Caddie an impressive victor at Pimlico today.

BOSTON, Nov. 3 -- Professor Evarts A. Graham of St. Louis, in his address as retiring president of the American College of Surgeons, which opened its annual clinical congress here today, said that "not in a thousand years has civilization been faced with a threat of extinction equal to that which exists now in the appalling possibility of a victory of Hitler and his Nazi barbarians."

Reflecting the trend of developments in Washington with respect to the price-control bill, cotton prices yesterday fluctuated erratically in quiet trading. On the New York Cotton Exchange the prices of active futures closed 2 points up to 3 points down from Saturday's closing levels.

At Philadelphia on June 26, 1940, a member of the House of Representatives was recognized to nominate an aspirant for the Republican candidacy for President. He had many traditions to oppose, including party regularity as a prerequisite for such a nomination. Among other things, he said of his nominee:

An increase of 19.1 per cent in national lineage was the most encouraging feature of the advertising of eight New York newspapers last month. Total volume was down 4.3 per cent, according to a compilation based on Media Records figures.
Although held to a single point In his team's first defeat of the year, Ben Collins of West Texas State retained his lead as the nation's best collegiate point-maker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The United States Lines ship Capulin has been leased from the Maritime Commission by the Red Cross to carry a cargo of milk, infants' layettes and medicines to unoccupied France, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- James Mulloy, a one-time political associate and friend of Senator William. Langer, North. Dakota Republican, told the Senate Elections Committee today that Mr. Longer attempted to buy influence with a Federal judge before whom he was thrice brought to trial in 1935.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Russian defenders of Crimea have been split and are being pushed into the sea, the German High Command announced today, and military commentators declared the Germans soon would have control of the Black Sea to wage the fight for Caucasian oil.

With interesting battles studding the list, plenty of action is promised on the metropolitan schoolboy football front today, when more than sixty contests will be staged on fields in New York City, Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey.

ZACHARY, La., Nov. 3 (AP) -- A white-haired telephone operator, who had a hand in the births, cyclones and train wrecks hereabouts for more than thirty years, felt lost today without her old service-worn switchboard.

Declaring that Japan would never be "strong enough to face us all," Sir Keith Murdoch, Australian newspaper publisher and former Director General of Information in Australia, expressed the belief yesterday that Japan would not try to press its policy or expansion in the face of a united front of the democracies.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- Authorized Nazi spokesmen said today that official statements accusing the United States of having attacked Germany undoubtedly had the "unreserved approval" of Japan and Italy, the other members of the three-power pact.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- Lynn U. Stambaugh, national commander of the American Legion, urged capital and labor today to subordinate their differences to achieve a common unity. He reaffirmed the Legion's determination that "the immediate national objective" was the defeat of Adolf Hitler.

A new note of distinction was added to Fifty-seventh Street over the week-end. After weeks of preparation and a continued uncertainty as to the exact opening date, which kept one segment at least of the local art world in a mood of suspense, Paul Rosenberg's gallery has at length unlatched its front door.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- As the total war of the Germans continues to struggle with the total defense of the Russians, the High Command today reports two successes. It claims, first, to have captured Kursk, a rail junction in the center of the Black Earth area, and, second, to have split the defenders of Crimea into two groups, "one of which is trying to escape by way of Kerch and the other through Sevastopol."

Virtually the entire police force of 18,083 men began last night a thirty-six hour tour of duty to insure New York an orderly and honest election. At least one patrolman in uniform will be on duty at each of the 4,059 polling places when they open at 6 A.M. today.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 3 -- The Rev. Dr. Hugh Wirshing Sublett, rector of historic St. John's Episcopal Church, died today in Stuart Circle Hospital, where he had been a patient for six weeks.
