He was 61 years old, and had served for twenty-seven years as rector of St. John's, famous as the scene of Patrick Henry's "Give me liberty or give me death" speech.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Nov. 4 -- The Navy Department announced early this morning that "it holds little hope for rescue of the seven officers and eighty-eight men who have not been accounted for" from the crew of the United States destroyer Reuben James, which was torpedoed in the North Atlantic Thursday night.

Despite the usual apprehension which accompanies a session squeezed in between a week-end and a holiday, the stock market was bolstered yesterday by a long list of favorable dividend declarations although the news from the other fronts was not too good.

MONTREAL, Nov. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Great Lakes vessels that prove suitable will be diverted to the Eastern United States coast during the Winter, F.T. Cuttle, new technical adviser on inland navigation problems to the Canadian Navigation Board, said in an interview today.

The reorganized Ballet Theatre, with a number of dancers from the various Russian ballet companies added to its personnel, will begin an engagement at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre on Nov. 12, the first two weeks of which will be under the auspices of the New Opera Company.
Several dinner parties will be given before the pre-opening performance of Noel Coward's new play, "Blithe Spirit," tonight at the Morosco Theatre for the benefit of the British War Relief Society.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Before a group of leaders of the steel industry John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, today argued his case in favor of the closed shop in the captive coal mines owned by this country's major steel corporations.

Market Holiday All securities and commodity markets in Wall Street will be closed today for the Mayoralty election. All banks in the States of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Virginia will remain closed, including the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- A hole-in-one by Nat Shein, amateur of the Elmsford Country Club, carried him and Jim Turnesa, playing pro of the same club, to a triumph by one stroke in the Westchester P.G.A. one-day best-ball golf tourney at the Fenway Club today.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 3 -- The Finnish Government has fixed the strategic and defendable fine at which the Finns can and will safely stop their advance into Russia, Premier J.W. Rangell told me today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- Seth W. Richardson, counsel for the Pullman interests in the anti-trust trial that opened today in Federal District Court, charged that the government had brought about the prosecution only because a Pullman competitor had complained.
The four-story flat at 208 Sherman Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by the North Realty Company to the Tavor Realty Corporation.

LONDON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- British airmen flying American-built Hudson bombers "knocked out" four German ships last night off the Norwegian and Netherland coasts to make a total of twenty-four vessels sunk or damaged in less than a week, and also attacked a fish-oil factory on the Norwegian coast, the Air Ministry announced tonight.

GEORGETOWN, Calif., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Eight death-cheating fliers told their dramatic story today of being spilled out of an Army bomber split open in a mountain storm yesterday. It was the eleventh crackup of a military plane in Northern California within ten days.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 3 (AB) -- Chinese military intelligence reports recently have told of large Japanese troop movements in French Indo-China toward the borders of China's Yunnan Province, British Burma and Thailand, a Chinese Army spokesman declared tonight.

As part of their training to become home economics teachers, forty girls, all freshmen at New York University's School of Education, began yesterday a "scientific program" of visits to beauty parlors and dressmaking shops calculated to give them that "New York look."

In the final appeals to the electorate last night a series of Democratic speakers charged that Mayor La Guardia's supporters had made a shameful appeal to religious bigotry and the Mayor himself had attempted to replace the American two-party system with the European multiparty system that preceded the rise of dictatorships.

The budding leaders of Uncle Sam's armed forces are getting their biggest play in years as the current football campaign marches toward a climax. For the second successive week Army and Navy will hold the spotlight in the two top games of the East.

HAVANA, Nov. 3 -- The general labor movement to force increases in wage scales throughout the island is seriously handicapping crop preparations and sugar mills and threatens to cause walkouts when the grinding season opens, it was stated today.

HYDE PARK, Nov. 3 -- President Roosevelt said today in his press conference, which was held in the President's room in the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library, that he had no additional details on the sinking of the American destroyer Reuben James by a German torpedo.

A hundred-mile trip is a mere hop, skip and jump to an ardent surfcaster, and those who have been making the trip to Montauk during the past week have found it produced, dividends, according to the late reports.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Sir Arthur William Hill, director of the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew since 1922 and honorary member of the New York Academy of Arts and Science, was killed today while horseback riding near the Mid-Surrey Golf Club course.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 19 (By Mail) -- The climax of one of the most heroic episodes in the history of the United States Navy was reached today when the United States destroyer Kearny, battered, bloodstained but still proudly afloat, crept into port escorted by the United States destroyer Greer.

Department Store Sales Up 5% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 5 per cent for the week ended Nov. 1, in comparison with the same week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
OTTAWA, Nov. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian aid to Russia included war supplies, food, medical supplies and transport equipment. Prime Minister King told the House of Commons today.

Huge rallies in Harlem and the upper East Side brought to a close last night Mayor La Guardia's fourth campaign for the Mayoralty. He turned in at midnight, after an evening in which he repeatedly proclaimed his certainty of victory.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- The furniture industry through its series of conferences here this week with Dr. James F. Bogardus of the OPA hopes to obtain by allocation its necessary supplies of brass, copper and other incidentals, it was learned today as the one-week Fall furniture market got under way with a sharp increase in attendance by comparison with last year.

The last racing of 1941 in New York State will be staged at Belmont Park today when the United Hunts Racing Association conducts its seven-event program featured by the $3,000 added Temple Gwathmey Memorial Steelplechase Handicap. Post time is 1:30 P.M. for the one-day meeting which for years has closed the season in this area.

Harlem and the Upper East Side ut on a show for Mayor La Guardia last night as he brought to a lose his campaign for re-election, and the Mayor responded by staging a show of his own for his suporters. It was open to question which was the better performance.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Failure of outside interest to broaden in the wheat market, despite the fact that the House Committee reported out the price control bill giving farm products preferential treatment resulted in prices reacting quickly on the Board of Trade today after an early bulge had carried the market up around 1 cent a bushel from Saturday's finish.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Britain's drive to increase the number of Women directly engaged in war work -- in factories or in full-time services -- led today to the announcement that those women between the ages of 20 and 30 and doing voluntary work would be reclassified.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Oct. 29 aggregated $11,012,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has approved modified regulations governing the shipping of freight in corrugated and solid fibel shipping containers which will save 10 per cent of the paper board used for this purpose, the Office of Production Management announced today.

Herman Lang, one of the defendants in the Brooklyn espionage trial, testified yesterday that at the time he is charged with delivering vital secrets of the famous Norden bombsight to Nazi aviation officials in Berlin, he was working on a farm in Northern Bavaria, "collecting mushrooms and chopping wood."

Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller appointed yesterday Samuel Seabury as referee to conduct an inquiry into the adequacy and reasonableness of an offer made by the Omnibus Corporation to minority stockholders of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company in settlement of claims made in two court actions.

ALBANY, Nov. 3 -- Elizabeth Cady Stanton Day will be observed in the State on Nov. 12, the 126th anniversary of her birth. Governor Lehman asked citizens and civic bodies today to celebrate the event with suitable ceremonies.

The thirtieth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America, to be held for the Second consecutive year in the Hollywood Beach Hotel, Hollywood, Fla., from Nov. 30 through Dec. 5, wiil be the most important meeting in the organization's history, Emmett F. Connely, president, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 29: Decreases of $143,000,000 in reserve Balances with Federal Reserve Banks; $55,000,000 in balances with domestic banks; $124,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $101,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and an increase of $55,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

Mrs. Kenneth H. Sheldon heads the executive committee for the performance of "Spring Again" on the night of Nov. 12 at the Henry Miller Theatre, which has been, taken over by the managers of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery to raise funds for that organization.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Dwight Heald Perkins, nationally known architect and designer of more than 200 public buildings in the Chicago area, died yesterday in Lordsburg, N.M., after a brief illness. He was 74 years old.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 3 -- It seemed probable today that the President of Mexico might soon be called upon to make a decision that may well determine the immediate future of his country.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 3 -- In their annual match, native American pros regained the Gaffney Bucket when they defeated their foreign - born professional rivals, 10 to 4, over the Crestmont Golf Club course today.

In Our Town What is the area of this New York whose Mayor we are electing today? Three thousand square miles? Three hundred square miles? Thirty square miles? -- as they say in those fascinating information quizzes where all you have to do is to check-mark the right answer.

ATLANTA, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Southern Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools was implored today to keep Georgia's State colleges on the accredited list even though the Board of Regents had no full defense for charges of political interference in the State university system.

Howard C. Hopson, former president of the Associated Gas and Electric system, reappeared in Federal court yesterday to plead guilty to evasion of income taxes on part of the $20,000,000 he had stolen from the big utilities group. He has lost seventy-eight pounds since entering prison last Janaury to serve a five-year sentence for mail fraud.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Federal Judge Guy L. Fake, acting on a motion of stockholders of the New Jersey and New York Railroad, today granted a rule to show cause why a separate trustee should not be appointed for the company.

A funeral service for James Speyer, financier and philanthropist, who died Friday night, was held yesterday morning in his home at 1058 Fifth Avenue. Nationally prominent figures in the fields of finance, philanthropy, education and society were among the 200 persons present.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Eleven officers and men of the Navy and an Army officer were killed in the crash of a Navy bomber in the "Atlantic Ocean area," the Navy Department announced tonight.

With speechmaking continuing until after midnight, the 1941 city campaign came to an end last night, and between 2,200,000 and 2,300,000 voters will go to the polls today to determine whether Mayor La Guardia is to be re-elected or District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate, will be the next Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today consented to an indefinite postponement of its proceedings against the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company until it has received a large cash contribution from its parent, the National Power and Light Company, as a result of National's dissolution.

The University of Texas football team, which got into nigh gear for the opening game of its season and hasn't been throttled since, yesterday rolled into first place alone in The Associated Press football ranking poll.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Nov. 4 -- Reports from Moscow this morning indicated that an all-out German drive in the center had started at two points -- against Kalinin, northwest of Moscow, and against Serpukhov, below the capital.

Driven to drastic measures by his team's two successive defeats, Coach Steve Owen held practice for the football Giants yesterday, the first Monday drill in recent memory for the Polo Grounds eleven. It was a hard, comprehensive drill.

The trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art have accepted the gift of an extensive broadcasting system that is to be installed throughout its building in Fifth Avenue at Eighty-second Street. This new plant is the gift of Thomas J. Watson, trustee of the Metropolitan and president of the International Business Machines Corporation.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 16 -- In evaluating Colombia's position today vis-a-vis the United States and the question of hemisphere defense one may say that perhaps as high as 80 per cent of Colombia's 9,000,000 adult population are firm believers in the democratic method of government.

Tammany Hall, headquarters of the Democratic party in Manhattan, was virtually blacked out last night as a few officials of the organization listened to returns in their private offices without any of the crowds or excitement of the years when Tammany was in power.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Featured by a contract for airplanes and parts amounting to $107,434,037, granted to the Curtiss-Wright Corporation plant at Buffalo, the War Department's miscellaneous supply awards reached a total value of $270,717,040 today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The 39-year-old son of a Federal judge who presided at three trials of Senator Longer, Republican, of North Dakota, in 1935 told today of accepting $525 from associates of Mr. Langer in advance of the trials.

After five years in which men unfailingly had taken all honors in the annual awarding of the O. Henry Memorial short-story prizes, women writers this year have upset completely the pattern and have "swept the field" by taking all four prizes in the forthcoming twenty-third annual volume.

Paramount Issues Overlooked A thorough scrutiny of all the candidates, amendments and propositions in the voting booth yesterday failed to disclose any of the issues which the Communists had placed before the people.

In the closest city election since the McClellan-Hearst contest in 1905, Mayor La Guardia yesterday defeated District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Kings, his Democratic opponent, by a plurality of 133,841. The total vote was 1,187,978 for Mayor La Guardia and 1,050,397 for Mr. O'Dwyer.

BERLIN, Nov. 4 -- The battle for Crimea has increased in fury in the last twenty-four hours as the Germans throw in all their might in tanks, artillery and aviation to force the issue, according to re- ports available in Berlin today.

Sooner or later it was bound to happen, still it came as a surprise that the N.Y.U. freshmen conquered the Fordham yearlings, 14-0, in the annual election day gridiron battle at Ohio Field yesterday. With a crowd of 5,500 persons looking on, the first-year Violets snapped a string of six consecutive setbacks in the series, which began in 1935.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 4 -- A majority of competent foreign observers in Stockholm believes there is not one chance in a hundred that the Finnish Government will give a satisfactory reply to Secretary of State Cordell Hull's warning, which has been a sensation not only in Finland but also in Sweden.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Robert Robinson's Water Cracker defeated Joe Bruno's Fritz by a nose in the best race on today's card at Rockingham Park. M.R. Fish's Stage Beauty was third in the field of ten with Argella the fourth horse.
NEW YORK Henrik de Kauffmann, the Danish Minister, and Mme. de Kauffmann have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 4 -- The Democrats gained one member on the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors in an upset of expectations in this traditionally Republican county on the basis of incomplete, but sufficiently indicative, returns tonight.

Fiorello H. La Guardia's record during the last eight years at City Hall is studded with major municipal improvements, many of which have drawn criticism because of the methods by which they were accomplished.

Mayor La Guardia comes out of yesterday's election with his eight years of constructive administration endorsed and his few days of reckless name-calling condemned. No other interpretation can be put upon the fact that the Mayor ran behind his own Controller. It is evident that Mr. La Guardia turned some of his friends into enemies by his attack upon Governor Lehman.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- The Japanese press is continuing its campaign to bring the United States to "self-reflection" about its Far Eastern policy. There is a growing crescendo, though with some confusion and contradiction in arguments.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Nov. 4 -- An irregular but mostly better market developed today on the Bourse with a keen demand for A.K.U., which, rose 2 3/4 points to 149 7/8. Royal Dutch was 2 points up at 316 1/8, and Phillips 1 1/2 at 276.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Security dealers who described themselves as "little fellows" doing business "in the sticks" asked today for legislation to permit their customers to obtain new, blue-chip issues as readily as the institutional buyers who are closer to Wall Street.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- Finnish troops have occupied the strategic Koivisto Islands in the Gulf of Finland, driving Russian forces from all former Finnish soil except the Hangoe naval base near Helsinki, it was announced officially today.
Nazi propaganda is turning into a boomerang in South America, according to Dr. Raul Damonte Taborda, head of the committee investigating Nazi activities in Argentina.

New tax laws have made imperative the defeat of the reorganization plan for the Missouri Pacific Railroad now pending in the Federal courts, J.S. Pyeatt, chairman of the board, declared yesterday in announcing a campaign against the plan to be waged among the company's security holders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- "Work, save -- and fight if necessary," are the three precepts for victory which Americans must keep before them in the national effort to down Hitler, William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management, said today.

War contracts placed in Canada since the beginning of the war now exceed $2,500,000,000, and about one-half of the industrial workers in the Dominion are engaged in production associated with wartime needs, the Royal Bank of Canada states in the current issue of its business publication released today.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 5 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast the following communique tonight:

The boys from Peter Stuyvesant High School romped merrily out of the Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday with a victory chant they haven't been able to use since 1935 -- "We beat Clinton!"

OTTAWA, Nov. 4 -- In the course of a detailed statement on Canada's arms and munitions production, which he gave to the House of Commons this evening, Munitions Minister C.D. Howe said contracts had been awarded for $2,600,000,000.

The thirteen-year reign of George U. Harvey as Borough President of Queens was ended last night when complete returns from the borough revealed that he had been routed by James A. Burke, Democratic candidate, in his campaign for re-election.

MELBOURNE, Nov. 4 -- Mrs. J.J. Kitson's great 3-year-old chestnut colt Skipton, an 8-to-1 shot, today won the Melbourne Cup, Australia's outstanding horse race, before a crowd of 90,000. Son of Aurous was second, two and a half lengths behind the leader and three quarters of a length in front of the favored Beauvite.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- A pledge that the British Government after the war will help Burma attain dominion status was given by Dominions Secretary Leopold S. Amery at a luncheon today for Burma's Premier, U Saw.

VICHY, France, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Vichy Government today extended summary trials and the death penalty for "communistic and anarchistic activity" to its American colonies and the rest of its empire in sweeping measures against oppositionists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- What will be Helsinki's answer to Secretary of State Cordell Hull's statement that the continued association of Finland with Germany in pursuit of the war against Russia might force the "abandonment of the friendly attitude, on the part of the United States, toward the little republic?

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The Admiralty disclosed tonight that the British Navy, aided by vessels of the allied fleets and Coastal Command planes of the Royal Air Force, had been scoring remarkable successes in the ceaseless war against enemy U-boats and that since the hostilities had begun the Navy had captured 1,276 officers and men, of whom 467 were Italians from submarines that had been sunk while preying upon allied shipping.

Backed by civic organizations as the realization of the county reorganization that had been blocked by politicians since the county home-rule amendment was adopted in 1935, the county reform amendment to the City Charter, which appeared on the ballot as Proposition 1, was overwhelmingly approved by the voters of New York City yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Fines aggregating $32,500 for violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Law through abuse of the State Unfair Sales Practices Law have been imposed upon the Connecticut Food Council, its officers and various members, the Department of Justice announced today.

Notes of a Cheery hunting song from the ringmaster's coaching horn will resound through Madison Square Garden at 8 o'clock tonight, proclaiming the formal opening of the fifty-sixth National Horse Show. The colorful exhibition for the benefit of the United Service Organizations will continue through next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Nazi propaganda in Latin America is less of a menace than is the indifference of the people generally to the danger it represents, according to Senora Ana Rosa S. de Martinez Guerrero, of Argentina, chairman of the Inter-American Commission of Women.
An increasing number of union leaders are no longer content merely to bring pressure on the employer. They are attempting by the threat of strikes to coerce the Government itself.

ON account of the frenzy over football, probably few citizens noted that, to the northward, the ice jam started some days ago. Five of the big league hockey teams already have had a chance to fire at the nets in championship games. The Boston Bruins have held back. As world champions and holders of the Stanley Cup, possibly it's their duty to let the other teams get a headstart.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Opponents of President Roosevelt's foreign policy severely criticized the Administration today for warning Finland to make peace with Russia or forfeit the friendship of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The fourth known attack on a United States naval vessel reported by the Navy Department was the torpedoing of the tanker Salinas southwest of Iceland last Wednesday night, approximately twenty-four hours before a German submarine sent the destroyer Reuben James to the bottom with a loss of ninety-seven lives.

James A. Burke, the new Borough President of Queens, entered politics as a result of his interest in local and civic affairs. Moving to Queens in 1914 from Brooklyn, where he was born, he became president of the Allied Civic Association of Hollis and Bellaire and vice president of the Central Queens Allied Civic Council, representing forty-five local organizations.

Edgar J. Nathan Jr., member of the law firm of Cardozo Nathan, which was once headed by his cousin, the late Benjamin N. Cardozo, former Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, has been active for many years in Republican politics and in Jewish philanthropic and religious groups.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 4 -- The Republicans emerged from today's election in Nassau County strengthened and virtually completely dominant, with their position as good as, if not better, than at any time during their quarter of a century of control.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Commander Harley Cope, captain of the torpedoed naval tanker Salinas, is an expert in submarine operations.

Voters in municipalities of eight counties in Northern New Jersey and in scores of other communities throughout the State cast ballots in Mayoralty elections yesterday. Final tabulations gave sizable pluralities for incumbent officials of both major parties, but contests were close in several towns and cities.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 -- Pictor, a game little bay colt whose unbroken march, through Autumn stakes has made him the latest pride of Maryland, the State in which he was foaled, added the $10,000-added Riggs Handicap to his string of conquests at Pimlico today.
Despise his unimpressive performance in the world series, Dolf Camilli was the most valuable player in the National League last season, The United Press reported yesterday.

A decree issued by Premier General Ion Antonescu yesterday announced that a national referendum would be held next Sunday to enable the Rumanian people to state whether they approved or disapproved the present regime, according to a German Transocean broadcast transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.

After all the name-calling and exhibitions of hot temper in the election campaign, New Yorkers went forth and voted quietly yesterday. Nowhere in town was there a serious squabble at the polls. The Bureau of Operations at Police Headquarters reported but three arrests at polling places, a new low record for an election day.

The traditional stag-dinner given by the National Horse Show Association for the officers of the international military jumping teams, who will compete in the fifty-sixth national horse show, opening this evening in Madison Square Garden, took place at the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

Parma was a surprise winner of the $3,320 Temple Gwathmey Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday as all Hunts records in this country for betting and attendance went by the board at the United Hunts meeting. A crowd of 16,972, including many or the best-known-figures in the sport, saw New York's 1941 farewell to the thoroughbred horse with wagering of $699,976.

Emergency fare, on a morning when tempers are short and time is more so, is porridge that comes already prepared in a one-pound tin. Lazy ladies, addicted to oversleeping, may heat the contents in a whisk and proudly set forth four bowls of steaming cereal.

Merchants were frankly disappointed yesterday with the results of Election Day promotions of women's coats and suits, and men's overcoats and topcoats, and blamed the lack of interest on the continued warm weather. Department stores had hoped that yesterday would be the turning point in the current retail down trend, since this holiday is normally one of the biggest of the year for apparel.

Mayor La Guardia ended an eighty-one mile tour of the city at 7 o'clock last night with the declaration that he invited comparison between the orderly quality of this election with the disorder which he said had marred the 1933 campaign.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- The Navy has released the following sketches of the officers of the U.S. Destroyer Reuben James:

Delegates from Czecho-Slovakia, Yugoslavia, Poland and Greece attending the conference of the International Labor Organization announced to the conference yesterday their conclusion of an agreement for the establishment of a bloc of these four nations after the war.

William C. Hecht Jr., and Samuel Null, Fusion candidates for the two contested vacancies for Supreme Court Justices in the First Judicial District, defeated their Democratic opponents, Justice Cornelius J. Smyth and Paul P. Rao, complete returns revealed early this morning.

"Mr. Bunting in Peace and War," published today, is in reality two novels. The first part was published in England as "Mr. Bunting," and, setting forth as it did the trials of an "ordinary" Englishman, it met with some success. Mr. Greenwood then wrote the new book "that makes up the latter half of the American edition.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A decision on domestic policy, described by some on Capitol Hill as the most momentous President Roosevelt has been called upon to make, awaits the Chief Executive tomorrow on his return from a week-end at Hyde Park.

VICHY, France, Nov. 4 -- "Enforced residence" for fourteen British subjects, including the son of L.S. Amery, Secretary of State for India, and the capture of a French convoy by the British Navy in South African waters were announced here today.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The Admiralty declared today that "the Vichy government have recently been trying to run contraband for the Germans from the East to France," and announced that one French convoy, consisting of five vessels escorted by a sloop, had been in- tercepted off South Africa and that attempts to scuttle three of the vessels had been frustrated.
BERLIN, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- The United States request that Finland make peace with Russia would receive a "fitting" reply from the Finnish Government, an authorized German spokesman said today.

Even before the House Banking and Currency Committee began its consideration of the Price Control Bill the Administration had made a large concession to the farm bloc. It had consented to a ceiling for farm prices, not at "parity" (the level calculated to give farm products the same relative purchasing power that they had in the years 1909 to 1913), but at 110 per cent of "parity."

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Nov. 4 -- The first move in a plan designed to put the whole British Empire on the production line was announced here today by Munitions Minister D.G. Sullivan. Mr. Sullivan revealed that the government had accepted a "huge" contract for shell fuses that would possibly affeet every engineering shop in the country and elevate New Zealand to a key point in empire munitions making.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The report of the British labor experts to the OPM, summarized in THE TIMES of Nov. 2, is extremely important and should receive careful consideration, coming as it does in the wake of the "captive" coal mine dispute and similar defense strikes which are fraught with such serious implications for the defense effort.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 -- The country's trucking and bus industries were advised today to formulate a plan for supporting other transportation facilities in wartime emergencies.
BERLIN, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The following communiqu was issued today from Reichsfuehrer Hitler's headquarters:

WASHINGTON, NOV. 4 -- The National Defense Mediation Board completed its hearings in the captive mine dispute today, found that employers and employes held to their basic positions and decided to start executive sessions tomorrow to determine whether the government shall request employers to compel non-union employes to join the United Mine Workers of America.

Details of a conversation with the German commander of a submarine that torpedoed and sank the Netherlands freighter Marken off Brazil on Sept. 10 were supplied by the ship's master, Captain Anthonie Kokke, when he arrived here yesterday on the Moore-McCormack liner Uruguay.

Invitations to prospective subscribers have just been sent out for the bi-annual Yorkville Dinner Dances which have been features of the Winter season for many years. The-first of the two dances for this season will take place on Dec. 2 at the Plaza.

Fordham began preparations for its sixth game of the current season, the meeting with Pitt at Pittsburgh Saturday, with a light workout yesterday on Fordham Field. The session started at 10 o'clock and lasted until shortly before noon.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- Studies at the National Cancer Institute at Bethesda, Md., and at Memorial Hospital of New York City, revealing significant differences in the mechanism of respiration between cancer cells and normal cells, were reported today before the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Unshaken by a barrage of eggs and tomatoes hurled at him by women pickets opposing this nation's entry into war, Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, rounded out tonight a two-day tour of Detroit's arms production centers.

The Broadway, film scene will remain unchanged today as "Nothing but the Truth" enters its third and final week at the Paramount and "My Life With Caroline" starts its second and last week at Loew's Criterion.

Acting on behalf of "300,000 Italians living in this hemisphere," Count Carlo Sforza, former Italian Foreign Minister, now in this country, sent messages to President Roosevelt and the heads of the other Pan-American republics on Monday expressing the horror of Italians in North and South America at the executions carried out by the Fascists in Greece and Yugoslavia, the Mazzini Society announced yesterday.

Dedicating the Garibaldian Shrine on the Janiculum in Rome, Signor Mussolini proclaimed Fascists as the inheritors and successors of the liberators of Italy. It was a bold stroke to identify those who won the independence of Italy with those who have thrown it away.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Senator Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, charged tonight that the Administration proposal for what he called "a raid" on social security payroll taxes "for the benefit of the general Treasury" is unsound, unwise and, he added, "a potential breach of trust."
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- Reports from traditional strongholds sent Republican candidates ahead by narrow leads in Philadelphia late tonight over their Democratic opponents for State and local offices.

Leslie MacMitchell cast his first vote yesterday and the 21-year-old N.Y.U. wonder worker soon after celebrated his formal arrival at man's estate by winning the annual Metropolitan intercollegiate cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park for the third year in succession.

Jean Dansereau, French-Canadian pianist, who gave his first Town Hall recital last night, bears a relationship to a famous musician of another generation. He is the adopted son of Jean be Reszke, the Metropolitan Opera tenor of days gone by, and after the singer's death in 1925, Mr. Dansereau took his first name.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- With pluralities exceeding 42,000, Republicans retained today their forty-year grip on West- chester County government by electing their candidates for County Executive, Sheriff and Children's Court judge and by defeating...

MANILA, Nov. 4 -- Heading the Army's first extra-continental air force, Major Gen. Lewis H. Brereton arrived today via clipper to take command of the Far East aerial defenses, which in recent months have grown from a token unit to the status of an army division.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 4 -- Michael Tenerelli, 32 years old, who fought in the professional prize ring under the name of Mickey Blair ten years ago, was fatally wounded just before 2 o'clock this morning in Missouri Avenue at the door of Pleasure Bay, a resort he owned.

ABOARD THE PRESIDENT'S TRAIN, Nov. 4 -- President Roose- velt tonight called for longer hours of work to produce munitions to defeat Hitler, and appealed to the public to halt waste and unneces- sary use of materials required for the armaments program.

Full support by the government of the United States to a program of immediate action for post-war reconstruction of devastated and occupied countries and of international economic rehabilitation was pledged yesterday by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, in an address before the conference of the International Labor Organization after unanimous adoption by the conference of a resolution dealing with the subject offered by the American delegation.
COLD SPRING, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Putnam County had a candidate who conducted a successful campaign to lose.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- All the Navy's new bases in the Western Hemisphere will be in operation early next year. While they will not necessarily be completed in detail within the next few months, they will be prepared to handle a program involving 15,000 planes and provide operations and maintenance stations from Arctic to tropic regions, it was added.

ROME, Nov. 4 -- Taking a cue from Premier Mussolini's speech yesterday, all Italy celebrated today the twenty-third anniversary of the Italo-Austrian World War armistice by recalling the historic grievances against France.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- Mayor Maurice J. Tobin won a second term today in a close election. He again defeated former Mayor James M. Curley but by fewer than 10,000 votes, compared with the 25,000 by which he won four years ago. Republican votes produced his reelection.

Members of the United Hunts Racing Association and society from many parts of the East, South and the Long Island colonies attended the Autumn meeting yesterday afternoon at Belmont Park, which brought to a close the racing season in New York. No larger crowd, it was said at the gates, had attended an Election Day race meeting and besides the public stands, the Turf and Field Club's enclosure and boxes were well filled.

IT may seem a little late in the day to be reviewing unsympathetic books about the 1917 Russian Revolution, but the annual $5,000 Atlantic Prize has gone this year to an autobiography of that general tendency: "Tomorrow Will Come,"* by Edith Martha Almedingen.
Leases calling for store space figured prominently in the contracts for commercial quarters reported yesterday by brokers and agents operating in various sec- tions of the city.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The defense boom was credited today with cutting bank failures to about the lowest level on record.

Eight years ago the biochemists of the International Health Division of the Rockefeller Foundation discovered among their thousands of stock mice one with paralyzed hind legs. Since then some four strains of what is called mouse encephalomyelitis have been discovered.
Apartment and loft buildings found buyers in many of the Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday, when the activity went into many sections of the borough.
LONDON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command today issued this communique:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The names of seven officers and eighty-eight men lost with the destroyer Reuben James, for whom the Navy today announced it has abandoned hope, follow:

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- The Pacific Coast welders' strike closed one shipyard and curtailed operations at three others today and at midnight tonight was scheduled to spread into three of the nation's principal aircraft factories.

If, after all those grade school graduation exercises, any one still doubts that nothing succeeds like success, let him visit Columbia these days. That run of Paul Governali's against Cornell last Saturday has done wonders.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Russian troops between Mozhaisk and Volokolamsk continue to hold the initiative in what appears to be an all-out offensive to reduce the German threat west of Moscow, it was reported today by a commentator on the Moscow radio.

Count Enrico P. Galeazzi, an architect formerly known as the head of the technical department of the Vatican, said yesterday that he had become its economic adviser. He departed for Europe aboard the Atlantic Clipper and disclosed that during a eleven-day visit to the United States he had arranged for the shipment of supplies, including food, to Vatican City.

A special gallery just has been set aside at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, where a collection of Christmas and New Year cards are now on view. The cards shown are designed by Grant Wood, Thomas Benton, Peter Hurd, Ernest Fiene and other American artists.

VICHY, France, Nov. 4 -- There is reason to believe that in the near future the French Government will enact laws giving financial aid to church schools and thus settle a question that has threatened to become critical. Emanuel Celestin Cardinal Suhard, Archbishop of Paris, came to Vichy last week to discuss the matter with Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, and it is understood that the forthcoming legislation is an outcome of this visit.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- President Roosevelt grave his occupation as "farmer" in casting ballot No. 234 in the local elections of this Hudson Valley village today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Hogs were steady to 10 cents lower in fairly active trading today, with most of the supply moving in an exceptionally narrow price range. Arrivals at twelve leading markets were lower than last Tuesday, but unloading of 16,000 salable head here amounted to 2,000 above expectations.
Re-election of Philip Murray as president of the C.I.O. will be sought by all New York representatives at the C.I.O. national convention opening in Detroit on Nov. 17.
Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee and leader in the Bronx, issued the following statement last night:

VAN HORNESVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Facing a labor shortage "becoming progressively more acute each week" and government demands for greater production, dairymen of the New York milkshed today asked $3.75 per hundredweight (forty-seven quarts) for Class 1 fluid milk.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- At least five of the seamen, listed by the Navy as lost in the sinking of the destroyer Reuben James were reported safe tonight by relatives.

Donald Nelson, director of priorities of the OPM, will be the speaker Friday evening at the annual dinner of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, whose annual convention opens today at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria. At a luncheon tomorrow Paul V. McNutt, director of Federal Security, will present the association's 1941 award to the scientist who has contributed most to the knowledge of nutrition in the last year.

Herbert Hoover expressed strong opposition yesterday to the use of pressure on Finland by the United States Government to stop the Russo-Finnish war. The former President asked: "Has America lost all sense of human and moral proportions?"

Facing an assortment of moonshine charges, nine men were arrested yesterday by agents of the United States Treasury Alcohol Tax Unit who raided an isolated farmhouse in Westbury, L.I., shortly after midnight and seized a 400-gallon still.

Egon Werdelman of Bryant took the Individual championship and De Witt Clinton was the surprise team victor in the P.S.A.L. cross-country title tests at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Shortly afterward the C.H.S.A.A. harrier competition was held over the same course, with Larry Schmidt of Loughlin winning the individual crown and Loughlin annexing the team laurels for the eighth successive year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "Abuse of power." This expression is frequent in our days. It fits so well the revolting tyranny of dictators over their subjects, of conquerors over conquered nations and people. It casts blame upon acts of authority of which we do not approve.
The crowd in Times Square, like the weather last night, was mild. Mounting returns brought no apparent reaction. There were no cowbells, no horns, as on former election nights.

The new offering on Broadway tonight will be "Blithe Spirit," the latest work by Noel Coward, which makes it pretty certain that the opening will be somewhat of a gala occasion. It is the John C. Wilson production of the Coward farce, currently running in London, about a novelist, his second wife and the ghost of his first wife, and Mr. Coward himself officially describes it as an "improbable farce."

Daily average gross crude oil production for the week which ended Nov. 1 was 4,071,200 barrels for the entire country, according to an estimate of the American Petroleum Institute. The figure for the corresponding 1940 week, which ended on Nov. 2, was 3,479,950 barrels, so that there was an advance of 527,250 barrels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Lammot du Pont of Wilmington, Del., gave away 1,300 shares of E. L. du Pont de Nemours common stock on Sept. 5, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today in its monthly summary of transactions by so-called "insiders."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Congressional sources forecast today that recent naval casualties in the Atlantic would create a demand for special bonuses and death benefits.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Administration spokesmen in the Sen- ate attacked the isolationist bloc today for following "a policy of inaction which leads to blood and bondage."
LONDON, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- British fighter planes strafed points in occupied France from dawn to dusk today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 4 -- "Song of the Stampede," a story of the Canadian Northwest to be produced in color by Arthur Hornblow Jr., has been scheduled for Spring filming at Paramount, with Ray Milland and Mary Martin in the starring roles.

Adolf Hitler has promised to unify Europe, and he will -- but not in accordance with his own plans. Even if he won the war he could not rule the peoples he now holds in smoldering subjection. No one who knows the Continent can have the slightest doubt on this point.

The six-story apartment house on a plot 125 by 100 feet at 1715 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the Macray Realty Corporation, represented by Arthur Leepson, to Long Beach Equities. The property contains suites of two, three and four rooms and has an annual rent roll of $30,000.

Frank Smithwick Hogan, son of a New Haven watchcase polisher, was elected yesterday as District Attorney of New York County. Since last August, when he became the candidate of every recognized party and received the endorsement of almost every civic group interested in the election, the result had been a foregone conclusion.

FORT DIX, N.J., Nov. 4 -- Reviewing his first year as Fort Dix finance officer, Lieut. Col. Hilton E. Heineke disclosed today that the huge sum of $21,671,513 had been disbursed by his office since his arrival Nov. 1 of last year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Trading in soy bean futures on the Board of Trade today was extremely slow, due in part to the holiday in New York. Wheat prices held within a range of 3/4 cent a bushel, and at no time did the market get above the close of the previous day.

BERLIN, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The German Army in Crimea was declared tonight to be beating rapidly forward in two columns, one having stormed and taken the city of Theodosia, some sixty miles short of Kerch, and the other driving down upon the great Soviet naval base of Sevastopol.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that cash customers of bankrupt brokerage houses are entitled to repossession of their securities even when they were purchased in the name of the broker.

American merchant vessels steaming into the Suez area and the Persian Gulf are steadily building up British war potential in the Middle East, while the British and Imperial armies are being reinforced from the increasingly powerful reservoir of men and materiel in India.

One of the interesting things about duck shooting is the variety and number of the alibis put forward fay the man who has just missed, with both barrels, on a double that had all the aspects of a set-up.

The first of the four concerts with the NBC Symphony Orchestra, which Leopold Stokowski is conducting in what was formerly Mecca Temple and is now entitled the Cosmopolitan Opera House, last night presented two works little or not at all known to New York audiences.
Brushing aside another obstacle in its path to an undefeated season, the Erasmus Hall High eleven handed its time-honored Brooklyn foe, Manual Training, a 26-to-0 drubbing at Ebbets Field yesterday.

DENVER, Nov. 4 -- Colonel Early E.W. Duncan, commanding officer of Lowry Field, Army camp here, announced today that he had instructed his entire command of 11,000 men to stay away from America First Committee meetings and headquarters.

DETROIT, Nov. 4 -- Real estate men and builders from all parts of the country gathered today to face the realization that the impact of the nation's war effort will bring far-flung changes in their business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, acted today to scotch reports that his office would soon approve an advance in lead prices. Prevailing prices of 5.85 cents a pound, New York, and 5.70 cents, St. Louis, are adequate to support a substantial increase in domestic output, he said.

The Curtis High School football team continued its unbeaten streak by halting New Dorp, 6 to 0, at Thompson Stadium, Stapleton, S.I., before 9,000 spectators yesterday. This was the thirteenth straight triumph for the team since 1939 and the fifth of the current season.

An hour and a half before he conceded his defeat last night District Attorney William O'Dwyer submitted to an interview at his headquarters in the Chanin Building and joked about his experiences during the campaign.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Andrew Ponzi of New York came from behind with a spectacular run of 104 tonight to defeat Ralph Greenleaf of Chicago, 125 to 112, in ten inning's and go into a fiveway tie for the lead in the world pocket billiards championship.

Having faith in the goodness of human nature, Norman Krasna has succeeded in reforming a Nazi in "The Man With Blond Hair," which was acted at the Belasco last evening. He has written a melodrama that contains several interesting individual scenes, offers two excellent tenement settings by Howard Bay and bits of engaging acting, especially by Eleanor Lynn and Dora Weissman.

Among the contracts for residential space reported yesterday by brokers was one for nine rooms and four baths in the cooperative building at 1040 Park Avenue which was taken by Mrs. Martha P. Gibb through Pease Elliman, Inc., brokers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 3:

Republican victory in Essex County and hence continued Republican control of the Legislature was certain last night in late returns from the election in New Jersey, where there were no State-wide contests but one State-wide issue -- the effort of Governor Edison to make Democratic gains in the Legislature.
LONDON, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- British newspapers demanded today that the government conscript as many of the nation's able-bodied women as it needed to step up war production to the highest possible peak.

With a strike of 15,000 workers in the long-distance division of the American Telephone Telegraph Company set for Nov. 14, the United States Conciliation Service announced yesterday its intention of making a new effort to settle the wage dispute between the company and the Federation of Long Lines Telephone Workers, an independent union.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 4 -- "The Allied policy of favoring maximum aid to Russia will, it follows, be a costly one to others who them- selves are in pressing need of war materials from the United States and Britain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 - The Defense Plant Corporation today announced execution of a lease agreement with the Fisher Body Division of General Motors Corporation for construction of a military tank factory at Flint, Mich., to cost about $25,782,244.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 4 -- The battle for Moscow has entered a climactic phase and the fighting has been greatly intensified. On the northern and southern Russian flanks General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock, the German commander, again is trying to develop an enveloping movement.

Use of plastics is rapidly shifting from novelties to more important uses, and at present is playing an important part in defense, not only directly as in the case of airplanes and transparent hatches for gun turrets, but indirectly in substitutions in civilian goods made necessary by defense.

HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 5 -- "The Spoilers," Rex Beach's violent tale of Alaskan frontier days, will reach the screen for a third time with Marlene Dietrich, Randolf Scott and John Wayne, Universal Studios announced today. The picture will be made by the Frank Lloyd-Jack Skirball unit.

The following is the text of the address of Arthur Krock, chief of the Washington Bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES, at the luncheon yesterday of the Association of the Alumni of Columbia College in the Bankers Club:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- The Republican party succeeded in winning the only Congressional seat at stake in the State, captured two State judgeships, won thirty-three of forty county bench seats and all but one of the municipal and county offices in Philadelphia at yesterday's polls.

A verbal clash, between court and a defense attorney over the latter's conception of his duties as an "American citizen" was the climax in the trial yesterday of fifteen persons accused of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government.

William O'Dwyer, who was defeated for the Mayoralty on Tuesday, went about his duties yesterday as Kings County District Attorney as though election day had been just another day in his life. His friends called the outcome "a moral victory," but the Democratic candidate only smiled at the expression.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 -- Welders seeking independent bargaining rights struck today at three major aircraft plants building $1,283,000,000 worth of airplanes for the United States and Great Britain, while striking welders in West Coast shipyards, complying with a request of their representatives in Washington, began returning to work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- British redcoats appeared in Congress today for the first time since 1814. They were worn this time by toy soldiers, but Senator Wheeler of Montana said that they were here with diabolical purpose and demanded to know why.

And now, after the production of Offenbach's "Vie Parisienne" by the New Opera Company, one wonders about the value of opera in English. The performance was given last night at the Fortyfourth Street Theatre.

VICHY, France, Nov. 5 -- While the Vice Premier, Admiral Francois Parian, is again in Paris renewing contacts with the German Authority -- a perfectly normal occurrence, it is insisted here -- public opinion is taking due cognizance of many official manifestations.
KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 5-- At a press conference today the official spokesman, S.A. Lozovsky, said there had not been any incidents along the Manchukuo border since the frontier affray of Oct. 23.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The government's charges that George E. Browne and Willie Bioff had used their dominant positions in the movie employes' union to extort $550,000 from four large producing and exhibiting companies were slated yesterday to be placed in the hands of the jury in Federal Court this afternoon.

An anonymous gift of $10,000 launched the drive started yesterday by the Homeless Children's Committee of the Children's Aid Society to raise $300,000 for the extension of their work during the coming year.

It is natural for those who venture to give advice to voters to feel that the voters show their good sense by taking it. Making allowances for that mild bias, we believe that the voters of New York City really did show a high degree of intelligent discrimination in Tuesday's elections.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Harry L. Hopkins, President Roosevelt's confidant and constant companion, was taken directly to Naval Hospital today from the special Presidential train and is there tonight.

Presenting facts and figures on the extent of the reading of comic magazines by the nation's youth, George J. Hecht, president and publisher of Parents Magazine, yesterday attacked this form of children's reading, terming it a threat to character development, and called on the publishers of books for children to counteract the comics' effects.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Nov. 8 -- After days of bitter fighting, Russian forces have broken the Germans' newest major offensive against Moscow, it was announced this morning by the Russian radio. An authoritative commentator added that stubborn resistance by Red Army troops in newly consolidated positions in Crimea was getting the situation in hand there.
CHESTER, Pa., Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Chester Times announced today that it had suspended publication "to avoid picket violence" in a twoday-old strike called by the American Newspaper Guild, C.I.O.

Marking the first time the Federal Trade Commission has held a formal hearing" to determine if a cease and desist order has been violated, the commission began taking testimony yesterday at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, on adherence to the consent order issued in 1936 against the National Electrical Manufacturers Association and sixteen of respondent companies.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Official spokesmen for the British Government said today that the recent seizure of five Vichy merchantmen off the South African coast was entirely legal, that all protests were nonsense and that the same sort of thing had happened often before and would happen again.
"I think I'll make a better Borough president than George U. Harvey was," said James A. Burke yesterday- "George is all right,, and I have no quarrel with him. Personally, I think he's swell."
Sales of properties by lending institutions were among the realty transactions in Manhattan reported yesterday.

Because many American manufacturers are turning down small orders which would upset their production schedules, South Africa is considering a pooling of all such orders to be handled through the South African Purchasing Commission here, J.A. Reid, director of the commission, revealed yesterday at the monthly luncheon of the Export Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- Secretary Ickes warned members of the American Petroleum Institute today that "some measure" of Federal control of the oil industry was "surely and inevitably" coming unless the industry exerted enough self-control to prevent waste and "intemperate exploitation."

Now that the oil shortage appears to have evaporated, the oilburner industry will break a campaign today in a half-dozen cities in the East, promoting the sale of oil burners. The ads are signed by the Oil Burner Industry Emergency Committee on National Defense, which sponsored earlier ads urging home owners to conserve oil.

LONDON, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- A matinee performance of the play "Distant Point," at the Westminster Theatre, was interrupted by Manager Reginald Knight to announce that the author, Alexander Afinogenoff had been killed in an air raid on Moscow.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Nov. 5 -- Stocks on the Bourse showed today a generally firm tendency under the lead of A.K.U., which rose 4 1/4 points to 154 1/8, while Royal Dutch was active and 4 points higher at 320. Amsterdam Rubber rose 2 1/4 to 310 3/4, but Amsterdam Trading lost 2 points to 483 1/2 on the passing of the dividend.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- An M.P. on patrol is not disturbed these nights by the lights that burn long after taps in a top-floor office of the gymnasium building.

A black bag, twelve inches long and six inches in width and height, was the main prop yesterday morning in a sketch presented at headquarters of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service, 262 Madison Avenue. From it a trim uniformed nurse produced dozens of implements she uses daily to help bring relief and health to sick persons in their homes.

Strength in the outside markets aided cotton futures yesterday to recover from early losses to gains of as much as 20 points above Monday's close. Selling operations by Southern interests, however, near the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange wiped out most of these advances and prices of active futures closed with gains of 2 to 6 points.

Infant mortality in New York City which has been running this year well under the averages of 1940 and 1939 jumped radically last week, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday. The rate reached 30.6 per 1,000 live births, contrasted with only 26 the previous week.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- A chemical manufactured to order by a "trained" soil bacillus fed a mixed diet of disease-producing bacteria has proved itself in tests on animals and human beings to be 1,000 to 100,000 times more potent in the healing of local infections In humans than the drugs of the "sulfa" family, it was reported before the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons today.

Reporting yesterday to stockholders on results for the three and nine months ended with September, Eugene E. Wilson, president of the United Aircraft Corporation, said that while sales for the period this year had increased 157 per cent over those in the corresponding nine months last year, net profit had been only 3 per cent better.
BERLIN, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Elimination of wastefulness In every phase of living from home management to the world-wide distribution of raw materials, was set yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as one of the goals for which the American people should strive both at present and in the post-war reconstruction period.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 (AP)Defending Champion Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia assured himself of a tie for first place in the 1941 world pocket billiard championship tourney tonight by beating Ralph Greenleaf of Chicago, 125 to minus 11, in eight innings.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Lewis G. Hines, 'Pennsylvania Secretary of Labor arid Industry, ruled today that 15,000 anthracite miners who left their jobs for four weeks to protest union assessments and increases were entitled to unemployment compensation benefits.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The urgent mission of Saburo Kurusu, former Japanese Ambassador to Germany, to the United States to conduct clarifying conversations was regarded here today as indicating how anxious Japan is to reach an agreement on outstanding questions with this country.

A peaceful pleasure accorded to the lady-of-the-house is the occasional privilege of lunching alone. With her husband away at work and her children safely in school, the harassed housewife relaxes at her lonely table, and quiet flows about her comfortingly.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Bold Chance, a long-striding son of Chance Sun and Grey Watch, who races for J.A. Kinard, established himself as one of the ranking 2-year-olds of the current Churchill Downs meeting as he raced to a narrow victory today in the Shawnee Park handicap, last of the season's 2-year-old stakes.
BERLIN, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Oct. 31 shows the following changes for the week, in thousands of reichsmarks:

Tito Schipa, 52-year-old Italian tenor, has left South America to return to Italy and will not sing in the United States this season. By his action he has canceled about forty engagements in this country, including appearances with the Metropolitan Opera Company.

In a session devoted principally to railway securities, inspired first by anticipation of the recommendations on the wage demands of, the railway employes and then fortified by the actual report the business on the New York Stock Exchange made moderate headway in trading which approached the million-share mark.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 4.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 6 -- Hopes of maintaining peace in the Pacific rose with a bound yesterday when the Japanese Government announced that it had dispatched Saburo Kurusu, one of Japan's most experienced, diplomats, to Washington to assist Ambassador Kichisaburo Noure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- President Roosevelt's emergency board recommended today that the nation's railroads grant to 1,150,000 employes temporary wage Increases aggregating about $270,000,000 on the basis of 1941 payrolls.

Trading was generally fair to slow in locally dressed meats yesterday. Steer hinds and ribs were active at lower prices however. Lamb prices continued downward. Pork loins showed weakness and other fresh pork cuts were steady. Other classes were little changed in price.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Prices of hogs advanced today as much as 25 cents a hundred pounds with heavy sows leading the way, in active dealings on the livestock market. Small killers were aggressive buyers as salable receipts fell below expectations.

BENDIX, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Colonel Roy M. Jones of the procurement division of the Army Air Corps, who has been in charge of operations at the Air Associates plant here since it was taken over by the Army last Thursday, said tonight that the War Department's action in taking over the seven branch plants of the company was based on the necessity of integrating production in all units of the airplane parts manufacturing concern.

Election returns trickling in from up-State failed last night to change the indications on Tuesday night that three of the four proposed amendments to the State Constitution had been adopted. The one amendment defeated was the proposal for a four-year term for State Senators.

Control of the Maryland Drydock Company of Baltimore, one of the principal ship-repair concerns on the Atlantic seaboard, has been acquired by the investment banking firm of Shields Co. of this city, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Eleven members of the National Defense Mediation Board began discussions today in an effort to reach an answer to the demand by the United Mine Workers of America for the union shop in the captive mines owned by a group of major steel corporations.

Miss Dorothy Riddell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Riddell Jr. of Garden City, L.I., whose marriage to John Milton Perkins Thatcher Jr. will take place on Saturday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, entertained with a luncheon yesterday at Hampshire House, where she is now staying, for the Misses Helene Peters and Alice Truesdale.

The problem of American policy toward Finland is a peculiarly delicate and difficult one. We are likely to see its solution more clearly, however, if we separate as far as possible its military and its moral aspects. Finland's war against Russia helps Hitler. It enables him to economize German troops and equipment; it forces Russia to divert more of its own troops and equipment that could be used against Hitler.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Executives of the "Big Five" operating railroad brotherhoods denounced tonight recommendations made by the President's fact-finding board for wage increases made in Washington today. At the same time the railroads said that they were "disappointed" with, the board's findings.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 6 -- An illustration of the close interest taken by Britain in Mayor La Guardia's re-eleption was provided this morning by the unprecedented action of The Times, which devotes a laudatory editorial to the outcome of the New York balloting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Seventeen American and two Canadian civilians bound for Great Britain for service in the technical corps of the Royal Air Force, are missing from a ship presumably sunk in the battle of the Atlantic, the British Press Service announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Navy's official list of dead and missing as a result of torpedoing of the destroyer Reuben James rose to a total of ninety-eight today with the addition of the name of Lewis Aubrey Turner, a seaman, of Rio Hondo, Texas, to the roster of those missing and presumed dead.

DETROIT, Nov. 5 -- Higher taxes and increased living costs probably will reduce the purchasing power of the 40,000,000 persons in the $3,000-$10,000 income brackets by about 25 per cent during the coming year, according to Dr. Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- Pennsylvania's junior varsity and freshman squads, using Columbia plays, continued to give the Red and Blue varsity trouble today as Captain Gene Davis's team, prepared for the Lions.

The Homicide Court in the new Criminal Courts Building was thrown into an uproar yesterday when the mother of one of three Negro youths, accused before Magistrate Solomon of having stabbed a white boy fatally last Saturday at Fifth Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street, became hysterical.

The North American Company and its subsidiaries had in the twelve months to Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $20,266,425, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, according to the report made public yesterday by Edward L. Shea, president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- At a conference today with government officials a committee of the wastematerials dealers gave unanimous approval to plans of OPM's Bureau of Industrial Conservation for a nation-wide year-round drive to collect waste materials of all types necessary to defense.

Columbia's twice-beaten football team gave its aerial defenses a severe test yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for Saturday's game with Pennsylvania at Franklin Field. Running the risk of injury to the varsity squad, which reported at full strength for the first time against Cornell last week, Coach Lou Little ordered a two-hour scrimmage between the first-stringers and the freshman A team.

The complicated job of counting the ballots cast Tuesday for candidates for the City Council got under way yesterday in all the boroughs. Because the tally is being made under the system of proportional representation, final results will not be known for about a week, except in Staten Island, where a complete count is expected today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The War Department today announced contracts totaling $11,917,767. Awards to compaines in the New York area follow:
New styles for the season continued to be ssert yesterday, with exhibitions by Florence Reichtnan, Jane Engel, B. Altman and Sally Victor.

The President declares that "We must work longer hours to produce the munitions required to defeat Hitler." We can no longer doubt the necessity for this. But at the same time as the President calls for longer hours there remains on the books unrevised the Federal Wage-Hour Act of 1938, which limits the normal working week to forty hours and imposes a penalty of 50 per cent on any work beyond forty hours.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 5 -- The Finnish Prime Minister, J. W. Rangell, with great secrecy, spent today in Stockholm, where he had prolonged consultations with Swedish statesmen, evidently on the problems created by the United States' demand that Finland stop fighting Russia.
WASHINGTON, NOV. 5 -- The Army has rejected and returned to the manufacturer 5,000 heavy machine guns built in one of the emergency plants created to manufacture ordnance, it was learned today.
NEW YORK Dr. Aurelio Fernandez Concheso, Cuban Ambassador, and Mrs. Concheso have arrived from Washington, and are at Essex House.

A large apartment property in Orange figured in one of several all-cash transactions just reported in New Jersey. The broker in the sale also reported selling five Jersey City residential parcels in separate deals.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 5 (AP) -- B. Lewin's Alhalon, carrying top weight in its first trip over the Rockingham Park racing strip, headed a field of six across the wire today in the Hilltop Handicap for 3-year-olds and up.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Administration leaders in Congress told President Roosevelt today that they thought both houses would authorize him within the next few days to arm American merchant ships and send them anywhere in the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today the application of American Participations, Inc.; the Arkansas Fund, Inc.; the Founders Mutual Depositors Corporation, the Hamilton Depositors Corporation, Insured Investors, Inc.; the Investors Independence Corporation and the Texas Fund, Inc., for exemption from the restrictions of the Investment Company Act regarding the amount of sales cost which may be charged against periodic payment plan certificates.
MOSCOW, Nov. 5 (Distributed by the Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today over the Moscow radio:

The party system was one of this country's most important contributions to political science. Strong rival parties, acting as a check upon each other, have constituted an effective guarantee of our democracy. For the experience of other countries has shown that when there is only one party, as in Russia, Germany and Italy today, democracy perishes; and when there are too many parties, as was the case in France, democracy ceases to be effective.

Probably Noel Coward ought to be feeling grave amid the anxieties of beleaguered London. But it is to be feared that the war has made him frivolous. For "Blithe Spirit," which was acted at the Morosco last evening, is a completely insane farce that is also uproarious.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Navy announced tonight that President Roosevelt had approved the recommendations of a selection board for the promotion of 463 officers from lieutenant to lieutenant commander.
Manhattan's first and second elevens spent most of a two-and-a-tialf-hour session yesterday polishing defenses for the Boston University game Saturday at the Polo Grounds.

The Japanese outline of what the United States must do or "face the alternatives" should not be dismissed summarily as merely one more phase of an anti-American press campaign. Its publication by the Japan Times Advertiser indicates that it has the sanction, if not the inspiration, of Tokyo's Foreign Office.

TRENTON, Nov. 5 -- Governor Charles Edison's comment today that he wants to look into "certain facts concerning the election which have come to my attention" was taken by political observers as possibly meaning he suspects he was "stabbed in the back" by fellow Democrats at the polls yesterday.

Two new films will arrive in local theatres this morning. Universal's "Appointment for Love" will be the new attraction at the Radio City Music Hall. Charles Boyer and Margaret Sullavan are starred in the comedy romance, the featured cast of which includes Rita Johnson, Eugene Pallette, Ruth Terry and Reginald Denny.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Losses sustained thus far by the Navy in the Battle of the Atlantic will make no change in orders to "shoot on sight," Secretary Knox stated today at his first press conference since disclosure of the sinking of the destroyer Reuben James and the torpedoing of the tanker Salinas.

LONDON, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- Foreign Minister Vaino A. Tanner of Finland asserted, in a radio speech tonight that Finland wants to see peace restored to Europe and "our immediate task is to secure peace for our own national life," The Daily Mail reported.
Characterized by all the glamor and glitter of other years, the fifty-sixth National Horse Show formally opened in Madison Square Garden last night, to continue through next Wednesday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5 -- Night Glow, a 3-year-old daughter of Pharamond II and Red Sunset, owned by Gustave Ring of-Washington, came up with an unexpectedly fine performance to defeat seven other fillies and mares in the Lady Baltimore Handicap at Pimlico today.

The Roosevelt Administration showed a "lack of candor" in its preliminary steps to action against the Nazis, and has continued to do so now that the stage of action has been reached, Arthur Krock, chief of the Washington Bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 5 -- Exactly a year to the day after the Presidential election in which he was the Republican candidate, Wendell L. Willkie, on a surprise tour of the fifty-acre plant of the United Aircraft Corporation in East Hartford this afternoon, heard the old campaign cry "We Want Willkie" echo through the shops as thousands of workers greeted him.

LONDON, Nov. 5 (UP) -- Pilots of British fighter planes, accompanied by an American Eagle pilot who did a "good day's work," hammered at points in occupied France again today after a night In which British bombers attacked industrial districts in the Ruhr and the Rhiheland, and docks at Ostend and Dunkerque, and damaged a vessel in raids upon shipping off the Netherland and Norwegian coasts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister MacKenzie King of Canada agreed during their week-end conference at Hyde Park to the establishment of a Joint Defense Production Committee to coordinate the industrial facilities of Canada and the United States in order to accelerate armaments aid to embattled Russia and to other belligerent enemies of Hitlerism.

Coach Jim Crowley has been lavish in his praise of the current Fordham football team since its 17-0 victory over Purdue last Saturday in the Polo Grounds, but that doesn't mean that he thinks they can't be improved as evidenced by yesterday's workout on Fordham Field.
LONDON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said early today:

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

A special arbitration committee whose members would represent both longshoremen and coastwise steamship operators has been proposed to settle the wage disagreement between shipping lines and the International Longshoremen's Association.

An exhibition of oils, watercolors and photographs, organized by the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies for the benefit of the campaign to aid French children, has been current at the headquarters of the organization, 4 West Fifty-eighth Street, and will continue through Nov. 30.

Joseph.
