Szigeti, who gave the first program of the eight in the twelfth Town Hall Endowment series last night, has a total of six appearances in New York this season, not to mention a host of dates out of town. The reason is plain. He is a violinist of character, and his performances have a distinction and maturity that are constantly rewarding.

Max Rubin, former union official and collection man for Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, industrial racketeer, denied yesterday under cross-examination in Kings County Court that he ever had told a friend in the city's garment center that "if it's the last thing I do I'll burn Lepke, and when he goes to the chair I'll feel that I have lived my life."

A plea that industry use its initiative and ingenuity to solve its present problems instead of rushing to Washington for priorities was made yesterday by Clarence Francis, president, General Foods Corporation, who spoke before 1,000 manufacturers of nationally advertised foods meeting at the opening, session of the thirty-third annual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Secretary of the Navy Knox, in a letter made public today, closed the door on one proposed post-sea-son football game for the United States Naval Academy, but whether the decision might be reconsidered if a Rose Bowl invitation were extended remains to be seen.

DETROIT, Nov. 5 -- Realty inteirests of the nation, who have been supporting a program of voluntary control of rents under the emergency conditions prevailing in some parts of the country, face the prospect of early government control of prices of homes and apartments, at least in some congested defense centers, to prevent undue increases.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Ganson Purcell, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, sharply disagreed today with statements that issuers of new securities were turning to private sales to save time and money spent by adherence to the registration process under the Securities Act of 1933.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- As the headlines say Moscow again is threatened and the campaign for the Caucasus is about to begin, British hopes and fears are fixed on Russia as never before.

Stardust smacked down out of the sky last night to gleam on the swirling skirts of women attending the opening of the National Horse Show. Silver-spangled leaves glistened the length of a gray crepe dress. Gold paillettes gleamed under a red tulle dress while the bodice of many bright-colored gowns were trimmed with even brighter metalic gleam.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- A registration statement covering issue and sale of $15,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent debentures due on Nov. 1, 1956, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Superior Oil Company of Los Angeles.

Adoption by the voters of Proposition 1 on the ballot on Tuesday means the end of the five county Sheriffs and Registers in the city, but probably only after a lawsuit to determine whether those elected to the various posts on the same day have valid claims to the jobs.

BERLIN, Nov. 5 (AP) -- German spokesmen, commenting on the attack on the United States naval tanker Salinas near Iceland, declared today that "now, as always we can only say whoever starts for England heads for certain death."

MONTAUK POINT, L.I., Nov. 5 -- Although, the Montauk skippers had a rather disappointing Summer season, due to the absence of marlin and tuna in real numbers, they have been making up for lost time during the past few weeks by putting out almost every day with striped bass fishing parties.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 5 (AP) -- A secret material developed here recently makes an entirely new kind of photograph, which is formed partly of light rays themselves. Two photos can be developed on the same piece of film, one on top of the other.

Basil Vlavianos, editor and owner of the Greek Daily National Herald, has leased an apartment of nine rooms in the Langham, 135 Central Park West. The Madison Realty Company as broker arranged the rental for the J.H. Taylor Management Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A mild-mannered, bespectacled attorney who described six-figure profits on North Dakota bond transactions told a Senate committee today that he felt so strongly that Senator Longer of North Dakota was a victim of persecution that he paid Mr. Langer $56,800 in 1937 and 1938 for land he had never seen.
The Index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

The press photographers who insist that political adversaries, after battle, pose with hands clasped and smiles on their faces may not have an instinct for a certain historic fact. They demand the pose because they think it makes a better shot than any except the one they can't get very often: the adversaries glaring and shaking their fists at each other.
An early indication of the public's concern over the increased Federal income taxes is revealed in the response to a new edition of an annual tax guide.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- President Roosevelt, after a conference today with his advisers on antiinflationary control, was reported on Capitol Hill to be leaning toward the so-called Baruch plan to put an over-all price limit on all commodities and wages.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 5 -- Four new players were picked tonight by Head Coach Emerson Nelson to start for Yale against Cornell at Ithaca on Saturday. They are Sophomores Jack Ferguson and George Ruebel and Juniors Bert Martin and George Greene, all developed by the new coaching staff.

N.Y.U. has a football data with Missouri come Saturday at the Yankee Stadium and the Violets would like to make it a winning one. They'd like also to beat Tulane the following week. They'd like lots of nice things -- who doesn't? -- but victories over Missouri and Tulane would not make the season a glittering one.

Ignoring the conflict in opening dates with the Theatre Guild's "Hope for a Harvest," starring Fredric March and his wife, Florence Eldridge, the Shubert office announced yesterday that Olsen and Johnson's "Sons o' Fun" definitely will open at the Winter Garden on Nov. 26.

WITH THE ARMY IN THE CAROLINAS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- For the want of a few more bridges, destroyed by their own forces in a policy of extreme caution, the harassed First Army Corps lost a chance today to surprise the advancing First Army with a daring, ripping tank attack.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Representatives of striking welders and cutters agreed with, the Office of Production Management today to ask them and workers on sympathy strikes to return at once to important shipbuilding and other defense work.

For twenty minutes yesterday afternoon and again last night, folks at the fifty-sixth National Horse Show forgot about horses. Taking the spotlight from the oat eaters were the gas eaters -- mechanized units of the United States Army's Fourth Armored Division from Pine Camp, N.Y. -- as the tanbark of Madison Square Garden became an exhibition battleground for a phase of modern warfare.

The blitzkrieg appears to have had little Influence in the choice of subject matter by Britain's child artists, to judge by an exhibition of their work that will open today in the Young People's Gallery of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Criticism of the Administration for allegedly preventing the construction of residential units costing more than $6,000 as a means of conserving critical defense materials was voiced in the Senate today by Senator Taft.
Those Detroit Lions had better have their teeth filed and their claws sharpened if they expect to enjoy a victory meal off Tim O'Mara's football Giants at the Polo Grounds Sunday.

The New York Athletic Club, without raising a racquet, took the lead in the Class A Metropolitan Squash Tennis Association interclub matches, which opened last night, by receiving a default from the Columbia University Club. The N.Y.A.C., which has won the Class A title for the last three years, received five points as a result of the inability of Columbia to get its team together.

The American Trust Company of San Francisco and associates have won the award of $1,500,000 of City of San Francisco tax-anticipation notes at 0.375 per cent. The obligations will become payable on Dec. 19.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 5 -- The Union County grand jury declined today to indict an aged man who discharged a shotgun in the yard of his home in Hillside last June and wounded eight boy pupils of the Coe Avenue Junior High School after some pupils had reportedly goaded him to distraction from the school playyard adjoining his property.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Treasury is seeking a new tax bill for the calendar year of 1942 which would add billions to the record $3,500,000,000 of new levies enacted this Summer, it became known today when legislative leaders were asked if such a bill would be considered by the Congress.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- The new Westchester County Board of Supervisors, to be organized Jan. 1, will comprise thirty-five Republicans and ten Democrats, tabulations of yesterday's election returns showed today. The present board comprises thirty-six Republicans and eight Democrats.

As the Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board moves into allocation of scarce materials through, its Priorities Division, a detailed program aimed at keeping a large number of small concerns alive during the defense emergency will emerge, it was learned here yesterday.

Municipal Power Proposals to put two of the nation's major cities in the public power business were defeated roundly at the polls on Tuesday. In Cincinnati voters rejected by a 3-to-1 margin the proposition to increase the city's indebtedness by some $100,000,000 for the purpose of taking over the Cincinnati Gas and Electric system, either by direct purchase, if possible, or through construction of a municipal plant.
Atlas Powder The Atlas Powder Company declared yesterday a dividend of $2 a share on the common stock, bringing payments for 1941 to $4.50, or 25 cents more than in 1940.

The Import-Export Bank's plan for extension of credit to finance Latin-American purchases in this country will be helpful chiefly in special cases, but will not solve the current shortages of goods and cargo space, according to opinions expressed yesterday at the monthly round-table conference of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Soaring prices for soy beans which advanced the permissible limit of 8 cents a bushel for one day's trading with the close at the top had a decided effect on the grain markets today. There was more confidence displayed by buyers and the market broadened considerably.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Treasury's procurement division announced today that it had signed contracts for the purchase of the entire copper output of the Copper Range Company, Quincy Mining Company and the Isle Royale Copper Company, three "high-cost" Michigan producers of the metal.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Finland has not yet announced a reply to Secretary of State Cordell Hull's warning that she risks loss of the United States' friendship if she keeps on fighting Russia, but the newspaper Sanomat implied today the tenor of the official reaction.

From the paucity of teams that have managed to remain unscathed to date, one might jump to the conclusion that the current football campaign has been topsy-turvy from top to bottom and coast to coast. In reality, the pre-season evaluations have been vindicated to a degree to mark up a handsome score for the prescience of the form appraisers.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Two Japanese have been arrested by the British, it was announced today. The British gave no details and refused to say why the two had been arrested, but two Britons were arrested several weeks ago by the Japanese.

William Fulton Kurtz, president of the Pennsylvania Company for Insurances on Lives and Granting Annuities of Philadelphia, announced yesterday that negotiations were in progress with an investment banking group headed by Smith, Barney Co. for the underwriting of his company's offering of 160,000 additional shares of stock to its stockholders and that a public offering might be made tomorrow, simultaneously with the offering of rights to stockholders.

Pianism that was thrillingly alive and facile was put forth by Sidney Foster, 23-year-old pianist, at his first New York recital, last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Foster won the Leventritt Foundation award for 1940, which entitled him to an appearance last March as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, but otherwise he had not been heard here previously in a downtown auditorium.

MOSCOW, Nov. 5 (From official Russian sources; distributed by The Associated Press) -- The German drive on Moscow has been stopped dead everywhere and in at least one area of the Donets Basin the Germans are in retreat, "leaving behind them heaps of dead and many guns," the Russians announced officially tonight in a broadcast.

Reorganization of the New York City Teachers Council, to be more representative of the 40,000 employes in the local school system, was urged yesterday at an open hearing, held by the Board of Education at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 5 -- Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador, came to Cleveland today, saw some more anti-war picketing, and said to a reporter who asked him about yesterday's throwing of eggs and tomatoes at him in Detroit:

Harry Uviller, impartial chairman for the dress industry, yesterday handed down a decision sustaining the dress union in its complaint that failure by a manufacturer to purchase the promotional labels of the New York Dress Institute constituted a violation of the collective labor agreement signed last February.
THE best movie preview I have ever read is that new American historical novel by Edna Ferber called "Saratoga Trunk."

A plea for official United States recognition of the Free French and establishment of regular diplomatic relations between this government and the Free French organization was made yesterday by Count Jacques de Sieyes, representative in the United States of General de Gaulle, leader of the Free French.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Ruling that the proposed National Defense Pipe Line to carry oil from the East Texas fields to the Eastern seaboard was not sufficiently vital to justify diverting the 660,000 tons of steel ingots which would be needed for the 1,589 miles of pipe, the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board refused today to grant the priority ratings necessary for the project.

The conference of the International Labor Organization ended its ten-day session at Columbia University yesterday after adopting resolutions calling for support of the democracies in the war, implementation of the Atlantic Charter proclaimed by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill, facilitation of trade between the Americas, and wider participation of employers and workers in public agencies charged with the planning and application of public policies.

Higher Gridiron Mathematics Pictures of football drill, as distinguished from pictures of football games, are not what they used to be. Once upon a time they showed action. It was an ardent young man hurling himself through the atmosphere at the flying dummy.

Profit of the Electrolux Corporation in the three months ended with September, before providing for Federal income and excess profits taxes, rose to $928,096 from $373,415 for the corresponding quarter the year before, the company reported yesterday.

The outcome of the movement to replace the present priorities system with something better is likely to result in a slow revision in the next few months in the method of distributing materials, according to Iron Age. The publication bases this conclusion largely on the result of its poll of approximately 2,000 companies on the effects of priorities on the metal industries.

DETROIT, Nov. 5 (AP) -- AllAmerica Tom Harmon today enlisted as a cadet in the United States Army Air Corps, easily got by his physical examination, and a few hours later boarded a plane for Hollywood to see "my girl."
Party lines in New York City were obliterated largely in Tuesday's election, at which the voters re-elected Mayor La Guardia to a third term by a plurality of 133,841.

OTTAWA, Nov. 5 -- Following up a statement he made in the House of Commons last night that Canadian naval forces had sunk "more than one German submarine," Navy Minister Angus L. Macdonald today revealed in a speech at Oakville, Ont., that two U-boats were attacked and one possibly sunk off the northern tip of Newfoundland last month and that German submarines were operating within sight of Newfoundland shores.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 6 -- The possibility that the threatening Japanese moves in Indo-China against Yunnan and the Burma route into China might conceal preparations for a sudden invasion of Borneo was raised here today by some competent observers.

Axel Wheeler-Hill, Russian-born naturalized American citizen, took the witness stand in his own behalf yesterday at the Brooklyn espionage trial and admitted that he had transmitted information to Germany regarding the sailings of British Freighters from New York harbor.

BALBOA, C.Z., Nov. 7 -- That the Conte Biancamano, 23-000-ton Italian luxury liner, may eventually fly the United States flag was indicated by the action taken yesterday, apparently as a preliminary step to forfeiture to the United States.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 6 -- Addressing the Moscow Soviet on the twenty-fourth anniversary of the October Revolution in an atmosphere electric with suspense, Premier Joseph Stalin of the Soviet Union this evening for fifty-two minutes told his audience in a speech broadcast to the world that since Germany wanted a war of extermination "she will get that war."
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Headquarters tonight issued the following communique:

The performance of Mozart's Requiem, instituted in connection with the 150th anniversary of the composer's death, was the outstanding and impressive feature of Bruno Walter's first appearance with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- Senate isolationists demanded today the court-martial of Colonel Early E.W. Duncan, commandant of the Army Air Corps Technical School, Lowry Field, when they learned that he had declared America First headquarters in Denver "out of bounds" for his men.

KEARNY, N.J., Nov. 6 -- Local 16 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C.I.O., revealed today that it had invoked the "maintenance of membership" clause against eight of its members at the government-operated Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company yard.

Two hundred officials of the city's various criminal law enforcement agencies, as guests of Philip F. Amoroso, Commissioner of Correction, yesterday attended the formal "housewarming" of the new Tombs Prison, the thirteen-story limestone and steel structure that faces White, Center and Baxter Streets and adjoins on the north the new Criminal Courts Building at 100 Center Street.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 6 Following is an English translation of the speech made by Premier Joseph Stalin in Moscow as broadcast today:

BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- A new surgical operation on the brain, in which a small rubber tube is inserted permanently inside the gray matter to act as an artificial drainage system for accumulating fluids, in the condition known as hydrocephalus (water on the brain), was described here today before the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Sidney Hillman, associate director general of the Office of Production Management, denounced today the strike of independent unions of welders in three California aircraft plants as "an outlaw, wildcat proposition and a definite interference with national defense."

Nine hundred and forty high school students, representing twenty-six high schools of this city, attended a special matinee of "Arsenic and Old Lace" yesterday at the Fulton Theatre for the admission price of 10 cents. The afternoon performance was sponsored by the Central Control Board of the New York City School Program formed to arrange showings of Broadway theatrical presentations at a cost enabling students to attend.

Fritz Kreisler will not make his concert tour arranged for this season, which was to have consisted of twenty-six appearances, beginning in January, it was announced yesterday by Marks Levine, managing director of the NBC Concert Service.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will open next Friday the Market of the Americas at 484 Park Avenue, where a comprehensive assortment of art objects, antiques and curios will be sold for the benefit of Bundles for Britain.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin),Nov. 6 -- After a firm opening today there was a slight reaction on the Bourse, with the close about 4 points net higher. There was a larger volume of trade. Royal Dutch rose 3 3/8 points to 323 3/8; Amsterdam Trading 3 1/2 to 487; Philips 2 1/2 to 279 1/4, and Unilever 1 3/8 to 162 1/2.

"Unless American women recognize the need for wise food planning and conservation in the home, there will soon be rationing of basic foods," Mrs. Bartlett F. Johnston, chairman of the conservation for defense in the women's division of the Office of Civilian Defense, declared yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is said that the United States is girding itself to defend democracy. But, are we today really a democracy in the literal sense of that word, which implies a government by the people?

Trading was fair to slow yesterday. Lamb business was only fair to slow, veal and poorer grades of calf slow. Demand for other classes was mostly fair. Steer cuts sold unevenly, cow beef was weak to a shade lower, good to choice calf hindsaddles were firm, lower grades and veal hindsaddles weak.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a new apartment at the northwest corner of Eighth Avenue and Fifty-second Street to cost $200,000.

The more important selling facts about merchandise are included in an ad, the better it will pull in direct ratio to the number of facts. William H. Howard, executive vice president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., declared last night at a meeting of the Association of Advertising Men at the Phi Gamma Delta Club.
If any Fordham fans still fear that disaster will befall the mighty Rams in tomorrow's battle with Pitt, which has yet to win a game, they should dismiss those fears immediately.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Aldo (Buff) Donelli, who quit today as football coach of the professional Pittsburgh Steelers to "keep a promise" to his former college squad at Duquesne University, disclosed tonight he may return to the pro job within forty-eight hours "due to the weather."
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 6 -- "Military operations are drawing to a close, as far as our country is concerned," the Finnish radio announced tonight.

The Horticultural Society of New York gave a preview last night at the American Museum of Natural History of its thirty-fourth annual Autumn Flower Show, which will open to the public at 10 A.M. today. Filling Education Hall and the adjoining corridors with vivid masses of color and beauty, the exhibitions contained more than a million blooms.

The problem of "class distinction," supposedly alien to Communist ideology, arose at one time within the ranks of the City College unit of the Communist party, it was testified yesterday at the trial before a faculty committee of Murray Smolar, clerk in the Registrar's office who was suspended as a result of the Rapp-Coudert inquiry into subversive activities in the city's schools.

BERLIN, Nov. 6 -- The city of Tula, to which the southern end of the Moscow defenses has been anchored for almost a month, is in German hands, according to what are considered reliable reports from the front received in private quarters here today.

Scoring a 5-0 sweep, the Harvard Club's Class A team assumed the lead in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association interclub series last night. Playing on its home court, Harvard shut out the Cornell club, Donald Frame, erstwhile metropolitan champion, capturing the No. 1 match from C.V. Schuchard by 15 -- 11, 15 -- 10 and 15 -- 12.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The President today addressed the Washington conference of the International Labor Office in an atmosphere of industrial disputes made more heavily foreboding by renewed strike talk among the representatives of railroad workers at Chicago.
BERLIN, Nov. 6 -- The German people must resign itself to a "hard and relentless" war, and if this war is lost it will face an "inferno beside which all past hardships will pale."

Rain may make the flowers beautiful, but it did not help the Dodgers yesterday. The Brooks had less than an hour's practice at Ebbets Field before the steady downpour set Jock Sutherland to worrying. It was not concern over Larry MacPhail's grass as much as an alarm that the unsteady underfooting might pull muscles, twist ankles or otherwise injure his players.

Warning that it will have sole authority in matters regarding employment of actors by Camp Shows, Inc., the new organization financed by the United Service Organizations to produce professional entertainment at Army and Navy bases, Actors Equity Association yesterday issued a formal statement outlining general rules of procedure for the project.

Discussions of war bonus payments for unlicensed seamen employed by most of the deep-sea shipping companies engaged in foreign trades began yesterday between the American Merchant Marine Institute and a negotiating committee of the National Maritime Union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- Major Gen. Charles M. Wesson, chief of ordnance, said today that the rate of delivery of critical armament and ammunition to the Army by June, 1942, would be about 360 times that delivered during May, 1940.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 6 -- "A singing team is a winning team," said John McGraw in other days of another sport. As early dark, aided by a chilling drizzle, settled down over Harvard Stadium, and the locker rooms of the Field House tonight, Coach Dick Harlow hoped the great baseball manager was right.

Max Rubin, the former school teacher who turned labor racketeer and poured from $400 to $700 a week into the vast extortion-supported rackets' empire of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, ranged yesterday under cross-examination from an eloquent description of Lepke's "magic powers" to a snarling declaration that his association with Lepke had left him "rolling in the gutter with a bullet in the head."

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Bullish enthusiasm in the grain markets evaporated overnight on reports that the price-control measure as drafted by a House committee faced rough sledding before it could become a law. This led to fairly general selling by some of the buyers of yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 3:

After listening to testimony for five hours yesterday, Magistrate Charles Solomon in the Manhattan Traffic Court dismissed hit-and-run and third-degree assault charges that had been made by Mme. Renee Maeterlinck, wife of the Belgian poet, last Oct. 28 against Mrs. Margaret Colt of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., whose husband, S. Sloan Colt, is president of the Bankers Trust Company.

TRENTON, Nov. 6 -- New Jersey's first unconditional license for operation of a race track with pari-mutuel betting was granted today by the State Racing Commission to the Garden State Racing Association of Vineland, with May 1 set tentatively as the opening date.

Another step in the distribution to the public of the $136,330,557 State of Arkansas highway refunding bonds was taken yesterday when arrangements were consummated whereby the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, original purchasers of the entire issue, sold to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., $30,000,000 of the bonds at 106.

Jones Again Heads Corset Group Daniel L. Jones of the Strouse, Adler Company was re-elected president of the Corset and Brassiere Association of America at the annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Vanderbilt. Max Kops Jr. of Kops Brothers, Inc., was chosen vice president and Clarence N. Merritt of Crown Corset Company was named honorary vice president.

Striking A.F. of L. painters were instructed yesterday by the head of their international union to return to work on the new $5,300,000 storehouse and office building at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn while their jurisdictional dispute with another A.F. of L. union over painting of the building's outside walls was being settled through the regular machinery of the A.F. of L.

Preparing for all eventualities in tomorrow's meeting with once-beaten Boston University at the Polo Grounds, Herb Kopf yesterday sent the Manhattan first and second teams through a review of formations in the ankle-deep mud that blanketed Manhattan Field.

After holding generally firm most of the session, the cotton market fell yesterday in the final hour under pressure of hedge sales and local realizing. As a result, prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed at their lows of the day and at net losses of 3 to 6 points.

MAYBE this should be run through a strainer. It's a bit involved. It has to do with two Dartmouth alumni, one graduate of Michigan State, a former Graduate Manager of Athletics at Princeton, a big league baseball magnate and a man from Caracas, Venezuela.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A violent attack on Wendell L. Willkie for his attitude on foreign affairs was made in the House today by Representative Short, Republican, of Missouri. It was applauded for a minute by the Republican side and even some Democrats joined in, urging that Mr. Short receive more time.

Praising the efforts of the women in Great Britain, Miss Caroline Haslett, adviser to the British Ministry of Labor on women's training in engineering and industry, declared yesterday that 90 per cent of the English women, regardless of social status, are engaged in some phase of defense work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Lease-lend aid in the amount of $1,000,000,000 was pledged to Soviet Russia by President Roosevelt through an exchange of letters with Premier Joseph Stalin that was made public by the State Department without comment late today.

Under the weight of two important developments, the stock market bogged down yesterday. Railroad issues about-faced after their rise of Wednesday, and suffered reverses of as much as 3 points. The set-back in prices was a reflection of the action of the heads of the railway brotherhoods in rejecting the wage recommendations of President Roosevelt's fact-finding board, and also of the super-tax bill being prepared by the Treasury for Congressional consideration.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The State Department announcement of the correspondence between President Roosevelt and Premier Stalin follows:

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 6 -- A "job clearance exchange" set up here tonight at the Newark office of the State Unemployment Compensation Commission's employment service division found itself swamped with job seekers from the moment it was scheduled to open.
The proposal to extend the New York racing season of 1942 to Nov. 14 is not likely to meet with any serious opposition if it is earnestly taken up, as now seems indicated, a survey showed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- The Black Hawks' 1941 debut in the National Hockey League tonight was a huge success, the home team beating the New York Americans in a fast and furious contest, 1 to 0, before 12,639 spectators.

If Joseph Stalin had established a better reputation for truth telling and straight dealing before Hitler invaded Russia, it would be possible to take considerably more satisfaction in his radio speech of yesterday than one can take now. We cannot interpret a speech by Mr. Stalin as we would a speech by Mr. Churchill.

Early conferences, aimed at immediate revision of the trade treaties between the United States and Great Britain to implement the commercial declaration of the Roosevelt-Churchill Atlantic charter, were advocated yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- In telegrams to manufacturers of radios and of domestic cooking and heating stoves, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, today asked them not to advance prices beyond levels prevailing recently. For radios the governing date is Oct. 15 and for stoves Oct. 24.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The toll of dead and missing in the sinking of the destroyer Reuben James by a submarine off Iceland on the night of Oct. 30-31 rose today to 100 with the addition of three more names to the roster.

Although the volume was smaller than in the preceding week, due to observance of the Election Day holiday, bank clearings in the first week of November were at a record rate. Wide gains over a year ago continued at all reporting cities.

SOUTH CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 6 (AP) -- An explosion today at the biggest chemical plant in the Kanawha Valley killed at least two men, injured five others and started a fire which was still burning long after nightfall.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 6 -- Vice President Rafael Larco Herrera of Peru, on arriving here today, stressed the necessity of calling a Pan-American conference immediately to organize the defense of the Americas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- Congressional reaction tonight to President Roosevelt's pledge of maximum aid to Russia followed the usual pattern with Administration supporters praising it and isolationists denouncing it.

The large centennial exhibition of paintings by Renoir will open with a preview this afternoon at 4 o'clock at the Duveen Galleries, 720 Fifth Avenue. Composed entirely of loans, it is being held for the benefit of the Free French Relief Committee.

The re-election of most of the members of the City Council who are seeking another term was indicated yesterday at the close of the second day of the counting of ballots cast on Tuesday. It was also indicated that the membership of the Council would be increased from twenty-one to twenty-five, with each borough except Richmond gaining an additional seat.

Retailers are wholly justified in basing final payment for merchandise on the original contract price, regardless of any subsequent agreed-upon higher figure, Irving C. Fox, general counsel for the National Retail Dry Goods Association, has advised that organization, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Four industry members of the National Defense Mediation Board opposed today the granting of the union shop in the captive mines to the United Mine Workers, taking the ground that the board had no right to make such a recommendation in the absence of Congressional action.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 1 totaled 894,739 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 18,866 cars or 2.1 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, but 99,942 cars, or 12.6 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 93,631 cars, or 11.7 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Following the fatal stabbing of a 15-year-old white boy by three Negro children last Saturday within ten blocks of Mayor La Guardia's home and the discovery of the body of a murdered man in Morningside Park yesterday morning, the Mayor said recent crimes in lower Harlem represented "a bad situation" but promised that the additional police assigned to the area would soon clear up the condition.

A Federal court jury in Brooklyn convicted last night seven of thirteen defendants tried on charges of conspiracy to defraud the Federal Government through fraudulently obtaining FHA loans, disagreed on four others and acquitted the remaining two.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6 -- Despite growing public sentiment in favor of changing the Neutrality Act, as revealed in institute polls reported this, week, the American public still draws the line at sending draftees outside the Western Hemisphere.

Gold Stock Reduction For the first time since 1937 the weekly figures of the Federal Reserve System as of Wednesday, released yesterday, show a decline in the nation's monetary gold stock. The reduction was $8,000,000, lowering the total to $22,788,000,000.

ROME, Nov. 6 -- Italian newspapers today publish an official communique calling attention to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's denial regarding the division of South America and the destruction of the world religions by the Nazis, to which President Roosevelt referred in his Navy Day speech on Oct. 28.

After last Friday's rout by Penn State in the Polo Grounds mud the N.Y.U. football squad now knows enough to come in out of the rain. It was impossible to hold yesterday's scheduled scrimmage under prevailing weather conditions, so Coach Mal Stevens herded the boys into the gymnasium for a blackboard drill and an informal chat on the strength of Missouri, the Violet's opponent tomorrow at the Yankee Stadium.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 6 -- Five young actresses were named today for leading roles in major pictures at Warners, Paramount, RKO and Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A vast plan for developing the Amazon Basin of Brazil agriculturally and industrially with United States Government financial aid has taken shape to the extent that informal talks have been held with Brazil about sending United States experts to make a comprehensive survey.

The artistic personnel of the Metropolitan Opera Association will consist of 101 leading Singers during the coming season, according to the prospectus made public yesterday. There will be thirty-six sopranos, thirteen mezzo-sopranos and contraltos, twenty-two tenors, eighteen baritones and twelve bassos.

Nine properties on the East Side of Manhattan, with a total assessed valuation of $235,500, have been purchased by the Schulte Real Estate Company from the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company. They changed hands in an all-cash transaction negotiated by George R. Read Co., brokers.

HAVANA, Nov. 6 -- Cuban cane planters view the project to sell Cuba's entire 1942 sugar crop to the United States and Great Britain in one operation with considerable opposition. Dr. Thomas F. Puyans, legal adviser and former president of the Cane Planters Association, said this afternoon:

Sales of the American Viscose Corporation in the nine months ended with September increased 29 per cent, compared with the corresponding period of 1940, rising from $45,166,000 to $58,378,000, while income from the manufacture and sale of rayon yarn and rayon staple fibre rose to $9,359,299 from $7,073,200, according to the report issued yesterday.

Stockholders and creditors of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation, operated under Federal court trusteeship since Nov. 2, 1940, will vote on Nov. 18 on a plan to lease 400,000 square feet of the corporation's factory space in Detroit to the United States Rubber Company for three years and 215,500 square feet to the Chrysler Corporation for two years at a combined gross rental of $570,850.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 6 -- Walklng off flood-lit Farragut Field tonight after the last stiff drill in preparation for Notre Dame, Major Emery E. (Swede) Larson, Navy's fighting Marine football coach, remarked:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today that a reconvened hearing be held in San Francisco on Jan. 12 to determine whether the Transamerica Corporation failed to comply with the Securities Exchange Act in registering its $2 capital stock and whether it should therefore be suspended or withdrawn for the protection of investors.

The importance of the past to the present in costume art is emphasized in an exhibition, "Sources of Fashion Inspiration," which will be open to the public tomorrow at the Museum of Costume Art. Displayed around the exhibition halls are about 300 articles dating back three centuries.
A ceiling on commodities must be established, as there is no other way to keep prices on a reasonable level, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday.

A suite of nine rooms and three baths in the building at 375 Park Avenue has been leased by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., to Mrs. Joseph Gans. The same broker reports leasing to Robert F. Franco, of the staff of the Colombian Consul General, quarters in 25 East Eighty-sixth Street, and apartments to John Hawkes in 242 East Thirty-eighth Street and Alice Moser in 1201 Lexington Avenue.

TOKYO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Japan's patience has "reached the point of exhaustion" and her army may strike next at the Burma Road to cut off American supplies to China unless the United States comes to terms with her special envoy, Saburo Kurusu, the Japan Times Advertiser, Foreign Office organ, declared tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Railroad labor leaders were marking time tonight on the action they will take over the recommendations made yesterday by the Presidential fact-finding board for the settlement of the railroad wage dispute.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Ganson Purcell, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, vigorously defended that agency today before the House Interstate Committee after Representative Holmes of Massachusetts had said that legislation proposed by the SEC made it appear that "the commission is seeking more power to regulate."

ATLANTA, Nov. 6 -- Upon the death of the seventh elephant in twenty-four hours on the Ringling Brothers, Barnum Bailey Circus lot today, Reynolds Clark, State chemist, reported that arsenic was found in an examination of one and said this type of poison probably had caused all the deaths.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Nov. 7 -- With the Germans' fifth major drive against Moscow's defenses hammered to a standstill, the Russians reported today that their developing counter-operations were pushing the Nazis back northwest and southwest of the capital.
NEW YORK Mrs. Lloyd Bowen Sanderson will give a tea dance on Thanksgiving Day at the Colony Club to introduce to society her granddaughter, Miss Mary Duncan Sanderson.

Until official details are available, judgment on the new Treasury tax proposal must be tentative. But, on the basis of the general outlines agreed upon in all reports, it is apparent that the suggestions laid before the House Ways and Means Committee by Secretary Morgenthau are drastic.
Peru captured the international military jumping competition, highlight of the second night of the fifty-sixth National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, with a total of 24 faults, last night.

A property forming an "L" around a corner in the Chelsea section passed to new control yesterday when the Bank of New York sold the three five-story buildings at 168-70 Eighth Avenue and 278 West Nineteenth Street to a client of Harry J. Sokolow, attorney.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. Nov. 6 -- The will of James Joseph Speyer, New York banker, philanthropist and international financier, filed for probate today in the Westcheater County Surrogate's office, disposes of property valued at more than $2,000,000.

"Week-End in Havana," a Twentieth Century-Fox musical romance in Technicolor, with Alice Faye, Carmen Miranda, Cesar Romero and John Payne, will be this morning's film newcomer at the Roxy. Cobina Wrignt Jr., George Barbier, Sheldon Leonard, Leonid Kinskey and Billy Gilbert appear in supporting roles....

VICHY, France, Nov. 6 -- "The last great battle of the year," announced by Reichsfuehrer Hitler at the beginning of October, is still being fought in Russia, or, more correctly, it is developing into a succession of great battles, none of which yet appears to be the last.
A million housewives here who send out the weekly wash won't have to do their own laundry.

VICHY, France, Nov. 6 -- By taking the lead in "the crusade against bolshevism" Germany has "acquired rightful title to the gratitude of the world," writes Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of the French State, in a letter he has sent to Colonel Jean Labonne, commanding the Legion of French Volunteers Against Bolshevism.
COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 6 -- A three-day forum, "The American Woman and Her Responsibilities," was opened at Stephens College tonight with an inquiry into women's future in the post-war world.
LONDON, Friday, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- London newspapers, commenting on Premier Joseph Stalin's radio speech, appealed today for Britons to exert themselves to a greater war effort.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 6 -- Skin Deep, a 4-year-old son of Balko who was bred by Alfred Vanderbilt and formerly raced for that sportsman, carried the silks of Donald MacVean to a surprise triumph in the Heiser Handicap, a six-furlong dash for horses of all ages, foaled in Maryland, at Pimlico today.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- The British corvette Gladiolus, which had a ship's company of heroes, has been sunk, the Admiralty announced today. Her crew included holders of one D.S.O., two D.S.C.'s, four D.S.M.'s and six officers and men who had been mentioned in dispatches.
Not Wholly Private Loud talk on the Fifth Avenue bus is not as common as once upon a time. The reason is perhaps that most conversation used to be accounted for by the open-top buses in warm weather.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Department-store sales declined in October from September following an unusually large volume of sales in the preceding three months, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. The board's seasonally adjusted index is estimated at 104 for October, as compared with 116 for September and 94 for October last year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Most hogs moved into slightly lower ground today, although sows remained steady, as salable receipts amounted to 2,000 more head than expected. Losses averaged about 10 cents a hundredweight. Traders said the comparative strength of sows, which has been noticeable in several recent sessions, probably was based on the large lard content of heavier offerings in this group.
The New Jersey upland game season opens Monday morning at 9 o'clock and the pheasants, grouse, rabbits and squirrels will be legal game for the hunter.

The British Royal Air Force has been ineffective as an all-around military tool and in many instances actually has attacked British units it was supposed to support, according to Rear Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, U.S.N., retired, who in an article in Collier's Weekly, just out, said he based his statements on "authentic and hitherto secret reports from our observers abroad."

With the announcement of a slate of governors for the reconstituted Association of Stock Exchange Firms, to be elected on Nov. 17, discussion yesterday in association circles pointed to the election of James F. Burns Jr. of Harris, Upham Co. as the next president.

TOKYO, Nov. 6 -- The Japanese Government today lodged a "most solemn" protest with the Soviet Government against the sinking of the Kehi Maru and demanded that the Soviets "reply with sincerity." The protest was presented by Vice Foreign Minister Haruhiki Nishi to Soviet Ambassador Constantin Smetanin, who had been summoned to the Foreign Office and remained there an hour.

The second night of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden attracted a capacity audience of socially prominent persons in the boxes and arena seats, with many dinners preceding the colorful performance in the ring.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Administration leaders in Congress, confident they have enough support to win, called on the opposition today to stop talking and vote tomorrow to arm American merchant ships and send them all over the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The House Ways and Means Committee decided today to defer "temporarily" consideration of Secretary Morgenthau's "suggestion" for a new tax bill, and thus apparently shelved for this session of Congress any probability of enactment of legislation for new levies for revenue or anti-inflationary purposes.

Dr. Harrison I. Cook gave a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Miss Mildred L. Martens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Martens of Mount Pocono, Pa., and Lieutenant George De Metropolis, U.S.N., former aide to Rear Admiral Woodward, whose marriage will take place here on Sunday in the Hellenic Eastern Orthodox Cathedral.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav quarters charged today that Axis forces had slain more than 300,000 Serbian men, women and children, including virtually the entire populations of some towns, in a campaign to exterminate the Serbian race.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Preparation of plans for the transition from a wartime to a peace-time economy was recommended in addresses tonight at the annual Construction Industry Conference, held under the auspices of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, in welcoming to the city the delegates to the thirty-first annual convention of the American Hotel Association at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday afternoon, forecast post-war prosperity due to "deferred buying."

A comprehensive plan of reorganization designed to simplify its corporate structure was filed late last night with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington by the Virginia Public Service Company. It involved the dissolution of two of Virginia's subsidiaries, the Hampton Towing Corporation and the Middle Virginia Power Company, and a merger of the Virginia Public Service Generating Company with Virginia Public Service itself.

So far as Coach Lou Little and the Columbia football squad were concerned, the sun might have been shining at Baker Field yesterday. In a two-hour drill on the muddy gridiron, Little rehearsed the entire repertoire of offensive manoeuvres which the Lions plan to use against Pennsylvania at Franklin Field tomorrow.

When Alfred E. Smith was Sheriff of New York County twenty-five years ago the office carried a salary of $12,000 a year plus half the fees collected. During Sheriff Smith's two years in this position, as he tells in his autobiography, the fees amounted to about $105,000.

A banking syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co. and including twenty-six other investment banking firms will offer today to the public 160,000 shares of $10 par value capital stock of the Pennsylvania Company for Insurances on Lives and Granting Annuities, Philadelphia's largest trust company and second largest commercial bank.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A registration statement covering the issue and sale of $20,000,000 of debentures due on Nov. 1, 1951, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company of Pittsburgh.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 6 -- "The almost slavish reliance" which the American college student now puts upon his instructor should be thrown off and greater responsibility for learning should be put on the student himself, said President Seymour of Yale today in his annual report.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Nazis have withdrawn most of their planes from the Moscow and Leningrad fronts for the Winter, thus substantially confessing their failure to take those major objectives, informed sources declared today.

There may not be enough "surplus foods" in another few months to permit continuance of food stamp plans or hot school lunches, Dr. Thomas Parran Jr., surgeon general of the United States Public Health Service, warned yesterday at the nutrition session of the thirty-third annual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was cold and drizzly that Saturday morning, Nov. 1. I looked out of the window. Something had moved behind that tree or had the tree moved? I looked again in the forest and suddenly remembered. This morning was the beginning of the hunting season.

DETROIT, Nov. 6 -- Residential builders and realty men completed today the organization and financing of a program designed to help them achieve liberalization of building material priority rules which they contend might result in virtual death of the civilian home construction industry.

ALBANY, Nov. 6 -- Ways and means to reduce industrial accidents were discussed today at the Executive Chamber by a group of safety experts and industrialists after Governor Lehman said in an address which was broadcast that the meeting "marked an important step forward in our national defense efforts."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The designation of Maxim Litvinoff as Soviet Ambassador to the United States is accepted here as meaning that Premier Joseph Stalin has de-
Following is the transcribed text of President Roosevelt address to the International Labor Organization's delegates, as taken by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

The emergency board appointed by the President, after careful study, has recommended a settlement of the railway wage dispute which, in view of all the known facts, seems more than fair to the unions; but the leaders of the five railway brotherhoods announce that they cannot accept it.

A comprehensive program for direct allocation of all types of steel, rather than control of distribution through priorities, is now being worked out and will be ordered shortly by the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board, it was learned here yesterday.

The full effect of the lifting of reserve requirements of member banks of the Federal Reserve System on Nov. 1 is shown in the weekly Federal Reserve figures as of Wednesday, released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed Reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Irving Crane of Livonia, N.Y., Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland and Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia were tied for the 1941 world pocket billiards championship when the once-around round-robin tournament reached its scheduled end tonight.
BERLIN, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique from the Fuehrer's Headquarters today:

"Hotel Splendide," which Dwight Deere Wiman and Richard Rodgers had planned to produce as a tentious musical comedy this season, was dropped from their program yesterday. Boston was to have inspected the show on Dec. 22.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution in Washington, said today that failure to check increases of prices would aggravate post-war financial problems. He spoke at the eighth annual convention of the American Finance Corporation.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Smashing at German shipping last night on a broad sea front, the Royal Air Force was reported officially to have bombed several ships in a well-defended convoy off the Frisian Islands. One was seen ablaze.

George E. Browne and Willie Bioff, Chicago hoodlums who won control of the 125,000 members of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, were found guilty in Federal Court yesterday of violating the anti-racketeering statute on three counts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Inter-American Commission of Women, at the opening today of its annual meeting in the Pan American Union, accepted a summons to keep alive faith in democracy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6 -- Ralph K. Davies, deputy petroleum coordinator, told the American Petroleum Institute today that known oil fields in this country for more than three years had been depleted faster than new production had been discovered, with the result that the "margin of safety" in the American oil industry was "fast narrowing."

Mrs. George R. Kent entertained with a cocktail party yesterday afternoon in the Pent House of the St. Regis for those serving with her on the executive committee for the music festival, entitled the "Name Band Jubilee," to be held on Monday night at the Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, for the benefit of the British-American Ambulance Corps.

Although the facilities and services of the New York Red Cross Chapter have been greatly expanded for community and war relief, the added demands of national defense have accelerated the work to the point where the chapter is obliged to double its annual roll-call this year.

"Utter discouragement" to growing small businesses and to the flow of capital into new business is continued in the proposed amendments to the securities acts now being considered in Washington, Edward B. Twombly told a meeting of the New York Security Dealers Association held yesterday it the Bankers Club.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Organization of the police establishment of the new Army, including provision for the custody of prisoners of war, has been completed by the War Department.

VICHY, France, Nov. 7 -- Francisco Largo Caballero, Socialist Premier of Spain during the Spanish civil war, and Federica Montseny, a woman member of his Cabinet, have been arrested in France and taken to Limoges for a hearing on an application by the Franco government in Madrid for their extradition, it was learned tonight.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 -- Sidney S. Zell's Incoming, a son of Ladysman, pounded over six furlongs of heavy going to a two-length success in the Sagamore Handicap, for juveniles, at Pimlico today. Recently a bad seventh in the Pimlico Futurity and a winner at Laurel before that the $14.20-for-$2 shot led home Mrs. E.H. Augustus's Trelawny for the $3,095 first prize.

The Connecticut Light and Power Company announced yesterday plans for a large-scale financing program the proceeds of which will be used for expansion purposes and to retire the outstanding preferred stock. A special meeting to vote on the program has been called for Dec. 8 in Hartford, Conn.

BERLIN, Nov. 7 -- Beyond a claim in today's communique' that infantry divisions had pierced strong Russian positions in the central sector, the German High Command persisted in its silence regarding operations on the vital Moscow front.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 7 -- Tuesday's election results in two areas -- the Fifteenth Pennsylvania Congressional District and New York City -- have started a train of speculation among political observers as to the light which these elections shed on the popularity of the foreign policy of the Roosevelt Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- On the eleventh day of an acrimonious debate before crowded galleries, the Senate voted, 50 to 37, tonight to amend the Neutrality Act so as to permit the arming of American merchant vessels and their passage through combat zones into belligerent ports.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- George A. Selke, chairman of the committee on boys' and girls' work of Kiwanis International, declared today the dislocations of industry and other economic problems during and immediately following the national crisis undoubtedly would bring about the gravest problems young Americans ever have faced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- President Roosevelt announced today the appointment of Secretary Ickes as "Solid Fuels Coordinator for National Defense" and charged him with assuring an adequate supply of coal and coke for armaments, industrial and civilian purposes.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 7 -- Twice-beaten Dartmouth will rule as a slight favorite when the Big Green squad enters Palmer Stadium at 2 P.M. today to engage the embattled Princeton eleven before an expected crowd of 25,000.

CAMP CROFT, Nov. 6 -- Stepped-up recreation for soldiers at this infantry replacement training center is expected by Dec. 15, and two United Service Organization service clubs, listed as among the best in the Southeast, are rapidly being erected by the Army in nearby Spartanburg, one for white soldiers at the cost of $93,000 and the other for Negroes, for $34,000.

Elmer Rice, Pulitzer Prize playwright, again will head the Dramatists Guild as president, having been re-elected for two years on the regular ticket at the annual meeting held yesterday afternoon at the Lyceum Theatre. Other incumbents elected to serve two-year terms were George S. Kaufman, vice president, and Richard Rodgers, secretary.

Because of the complete recovery of Dean McAdams, former University of Washington halfback, from a sprained ankle, Coach Jock Sutherland now feels that he will have two top-notch backfields ready for action when his Dodgers oppose the Washington Redskins in a National League battle tomorrow at Ebbets Field.

The Germans have admitted that weather "miserable beyond description," with ground transformed into deep, gummy mud, has checked their advance on Moscow. Now that the snow has begun to fly, comparisons between Napoleon's and Hitler's campaigns are drawn.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 7 -- The Navy announced tonight that it would take over construction of $10,500,000 in defense projects at three military establishments here if striking A.F.L. building tradesmen did not return to their jobs by Monday.

An agreement on war bonus payments reached late Thursday night by negotiating committees of the American Merchant Marine Institute and the National Maritime Union provides for emergency pay of $80 a month for each seaman and extra bonuses ranging from $45 to $100 a port for entering war zone ports, it was announced yesterday at the institute's offices at 11 Broadway.

BOSTON, Nov. 7 -- A new technique which has made it possible to trace the major cause of hyperacidity in the stomach to an oversecretion of histamine, a natural substance in the body which stimulates the normal secretion of gastric juice, was described today before the closing sessions of the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 -- Two wildcat strikes by small groups of men made 20,000 Ford automobile workers idle today, and at the same time a C.I.O. embargo on the shipment of axles from the Rouge plant here to the Canadian Ford Company threatened the production of war equipment there.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Germany now finds herself faced with enemies in Britain, Russia, Asia and Africa who are sufficiently strong and, by geographical conditions that are sufficiently difficult to make it impossible for her to obtain decisive results in any part of the world by her methods of warfare, General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Free French forces, said here today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- Premier Joseph Stalin told his countrymen today that although their situation was difficult now, they "can and must win victory over the German invaders," who, he said, "are facing disaster" perhaps within a few months, perhaps a year.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 8 -- The American $1,000,000,000 loan to Russia, announced at the moment when Saburo Kurusu is en route to Washington as a special Japanese envoy in a final effort to obtain an easement of the economic blockade against Japan, made a rather painful impression in Japan.

Marcus Gordon, who appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night, manages the technical problems of playing the piano smoothly enough. His tone has an ingratiating quality; he articulates the notes accurately and clearly; he tries to make the piano sing.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Erwin Rudolph, veteran Cleveland cue expert, won the world's pocket billiards championship for the fifth time tonight by defeating Irving Crane, Livonia, N.Y., youth, 125 to 65, in nineteen innings.

Steel production in October surpassed all previous monthly records by a wide margin, bringing output for ten months of 1941 to a figure well in excess of production in the whole of 1940, the best previous year, and setting an operating rate of 99 per cent, the first time since May, 1929, that the industry has maintained operations at such a pace.

Priority consideration will be granted on building materials for housing projects within commuting distance of defense industries located in Manhattan, the Bronx, and Westchester County, according to instructions received here yesterday by Thomas G. Grace, State director of the Federal Housing Administration, from Charles F. Palmer, Defense Housing Coordinator in Washington, D.C.

The recital given by E. Robert Schmitz last night in Carnegie Hall reached its climax of accomplishment in the six Etudes of Debussy which opened the second half of the program. It was small wonder that these examples of expert pianism required several added numbers by the same composer before the audience would permit the artist to continue with his list.

Many dinners preceded the performance last night of "Blithe Spirit" at the Morosco Theatre, which was taken over as a benefit fo rthe Turtle Bay Music School. Mrs. James J. Lee, chairman of the event, had as guests Mr. and Mrs. Alexander M. White Jr. and Mr. and Mrs. William E. Hutton.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Investment Bankers Association asked the House Interstate Commerce Committee today to advise Congress to plug the loopholes which it said permitted private financing, which amounted to 43 per cent of the total of all offerings the first eight months this year, to escape registration requirements under the securities laws.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Inter-American Commission took under advisement today a resolution calling for preparation and training of women for participation in the defense program of each of the Pan-American republics. It was offered by Senora Amalia Ledon of Mexico.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- The Helsinki radio political speaker today rejected, "at least temporarily," British and American demands that Finland get out of the war, saying it would be "suicide" for Finland to "drop our grip on the monster" and give back Soviet air bases.

New bonds offered to the public this week were all tax-exempt loans. The appearance yesterday of $30,000,000 of State of Arkansas highway refunding bonds lifted flotations for the period to $31,095,000, compared with offerings of $62,473,000 last week and with $9,181,000 marketed a year ago this week.

Local friends of the Oxford Group and Moral Re-Armament were unable to tell yesterday where their group would find new headquarters since they have been asked to vacate quarters provided for them for several years at 81 Gramercy Park, North, by Calvary Episcopal Church, which now has "increasing misgivings" concerning "certain policies and points of view" of the group.
BERLIN, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

Those who like to shoot but have an aversion to tramping the woods and fields or sitting in a duck blind in cold weather can prove their skill with a rifle and still have some meat for the pot, for the Cypress Hills Rifle Club of Brooklyn has worked out a system that should appeal to this fraternity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- President Roosevelt appointed an emergency fact-finding board today to investigate and report in thirty days on the dispute between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers of America and the Railway Express Agency, Inc., which threatens to tie up express freight in twenty-eight cities.

American Chicle An extra dividend of $1 in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of $1 was announced to common shareholders of the American Chicle Company. These dividends will bring the total for this year to $6, or 50 cents less than paid in 1940.

Store Sales Up About 6% While apparel volume showed substantial gains on Election Day, retail trade here during the remainder of the week was only fair. Department store sales were estimated as showing an average gain of about 6 per cent.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Last Saturday you printed a letter on Yale football from an extremely uninformed gent named L.H. St. Clair. Half the Yale campus is indignant, righteously enough, and the other half has treated Mr. St. Clair with the tolerance of psychiatrists.

The recent outbreak of crime in the Harlem area is "not entirely a police situation, but more of a social and economic problem," said Magistrate Anthony F. Burke of the Felony Court yesterday in holding two 18-year-old Negro girls and two Negro youths in $5,000 bail each for the grand jury on charges of robbery.

The 1,542-ton Iceland steamship Godafoss arrived here yesterday after safely passing through the newly formed submarine zone in the same convoy with the United States destroyer Reuben James, sunk on the night of Oct. 30-31, and the naval tanker Selinas, damaged on the previous night by submarine action.

Council President Newbold Morris predicted yesterday that the city eventually would have an airport in every borough, as the Board of Estimate approved a $750,000 addition to the capital outlay budget for purchase of an airport site at Idlewild, Jamaica Bay, Queens.

Professor George Monroe Brett, head of the Department of Accountancy and curator of City College, was found dead of stab wounds, apparently self-inflicted, in a bathroom in his home, 136-36 Maple Avenue, Flushing, Queens, yesterday morning. He was 66 years old.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Rye and soy beans featured the trading today on the Board of Trade here. The former moved up 2 3/8 cents a bushel and closed at the top on the announcement that Russia had been given a credit of $1,000,000,000 in this country.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The United States Government charged the Pullman Company today with restricting the development of light weight cars in the last eleven years by requiring railroads to use only Pullman equipment.
AMHERST VS. TRINITY -- This one went to Trinity last year and history might repeat itself. But turn about is fair play. One amiable vote for Amherst.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Mayor La Guardia of New York City predicted before a Senate labor subcommittee today that the European war would end in the defeat of Hitler by November, 1942.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Two witnesses from North Dakota told the Senate Elections Committee today that most of the charges brought by petitioners against the fitness of Senator Langer had been aired repeatedly before voters of his State.

Finland seems to be trying to extricate herself from a cruel dilemma. While the Helsinki government has made no official statement, it is clear that the Finnish people desire to stop fighting and return to the sidelines. They do not wish to forfeit the friendship of Britain and the United States.

FORT BENNING, Nov. 7 -- Civilian Conservation Corps activities at this Army center during the last twelve months have resulted in the completion of eighteen separate Army construction projects and have effected savings to the government of over $100,000 in timber salvage, according to a report issued yesterday by Major C. J. Hutson, C.C.C. commander.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Nov. 7 -- The share market was steady to firm today. Royal Dutch was 1 1/4 points higher at 324 5/8; Amsterdam Trading 3 3/4 up at 490 3/4, and Unilever 1 1/8 up at 163 5/8. Otherwise the changes were small. Tins were strong.
CAMP UPTON, L.I., Nov. 7 -- Several changes in the officers' staff of Camp Upton and a number of promotions in the 1222d Reception Center became effective today.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It seems to me that the public members of the NDMB asked themselves some questions. For instance:

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Nov. 7 -- Staff Sergeant Matthew L. Pelikan of the Fifty-ninth Pursuit Squadron will receive the Soldier's Medal, awarded by the War Department for exceptional deeds of heroism beyond the call of duty, at a formal review here tomorrow.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I note that there is some agitation among sports fans for the erection of a mammoth stadium in this city, the idea being that such an edifice could serve as an arena for big championship fights, important football games, world series baseball games, track meets, international potsy tournaments and so forth.

Warning against the "delusion" that American industry is going to have a profitable war boom, Donald M. Nelson, executive director of the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board, asserted here last night that "just ahead of us, I truly believe, are the toughest, hardest years we have been through since Valley Forge."
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 7 (AP) --The Middle East Command issued this communique today:

Plans to compensate employes for the increased cost of living were disclosed yesterday by three Wall Street banks, the Guaranty Trust Company, the First National Bank of New York and the Marine Midland Trust Company. The extra payments will be in the nature of supplementary compensation, and, therefore, are not listed as salary or wage increases.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 7 -- King George VI's message of congratulations to Syria on the attainment of independence was described yesterday by the Syrian President, Sheikh Taj Eddin Hassani, as bearing great diplomatic significance.

CAMP WHEELER, Ga., Nov. 7 -- Underscored by an eleven-gun salute, the post band played "He's a Jolly Good Fellow," as this Army replacement center reverted to the command of its founding officer, Brig. Gen, A.R. Emery, returning from a four-day leave to a surprise welcome by more than twenty officers of his general and special staffs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The House Rivers and Harbors Committee approved a $1,000,000,000 authorization bill today for a score of projects, including the St. Lawrence seaway and power development.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 7 -- The football teams of Harvard and Army brought back the old-fashioned big-game atmosphere to this town and to Boston today as they went through dress rehearsals inside the steep sides of Harvard Stadium.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 -- Navy and Notre Dame will meet here tomorrow in the only football game the country over between two unbeaten elevens of major status.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- The Tale football squad arrived here today, practiced on Schoellkopf Field and went to Watkins Glen to spend the night. Cornell's squad drilled later in the afternoon in preparation for tomorrow's game, the sixth between the two universities.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 7 -- Moravian College closed its football season tonight by defeating City College of New York, 26 -- 0, before a crowd of 4,000.

With an unexpected last-minute gift of rare Hawaiian orchids to add to its million blooms, the Horticultural Society of New York opened its thirty-fourth annual Autumn floorer show to the public yesterday. One of the largest first-day attendances in the history of the exhibition, estimated at 15,000 thronged the American Museum of Natural History to see the massed chrysanthemums, orchids, perennially popular roses and the more plebeian fruits and vegetables.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 -- After pledging their cooperation in the national defense effort and giving recognition to the theory that "all personal interests must be subordinated" to this program, the members of the National Association of Real Estate Boards adopted several resolutions decrying government "encroachment" on their business.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The easiest thing in this wide world to do is to tell the other chap how to run his job. All one needs is a complete ignorance of the trials and tribulations that confront an athletic director or a graduate manager of athletics.
Trading in lamb was slow yesterday. Demand for other classes was fair to good. Early demand was good for kosher meats and prices were strong.

READING the line of this week's new anthologies, Gathering wits for the children of light, Best of its kind to the best of my knowledge is This one from E.B. and Katharine White. All the good books that the Whites have read recently, All the old masters they didn't find silly,

Paul Berger, a rasp-voiced witness who said he had been a professional "finger man" for killings ordered by Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, former ruler of the city's $1,000,000 industrial rackets empire, spent three hours yesterday depicting an underworld in which union officials and gangsters joined forces while witnesses were shot down in the street, murders were planned behind police backs and fugitives haunted side streets wearing false mustaches.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- For the first time since 1938, Columbia and Pennsylvania will renew their traditional football series on Franklin Field tomorrow before a crowd that will probably be in excess of 40,000.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 7 (AP) -- The help-wanted signs are out in full force, with Christmas shopping days getting near.

The Readers Club announced yesterday that its book for December distribution would be Walter de la Mare's "Memoirs of a Midget." Carl Van Doren, who fifteen years ago first wrote an introduction to the book, and who thinks, upon rereading it, "that it seems hardly to have changed at all with the changing times," will write a new introduction to the edition that will go out to the 75,000 members of the club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- All ranks of official, diplomatic and resident society were represented in unprecedented numbers at the reception held today at the old Russian Embassy in Sixteenth Street in celebration of the October Revolution, which gave birth to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

The chilling process in the stock market was more rapid yesterday than on Thursday, and, with the Treasury's super-tax proposals still fresh in the minds of stockholders, values suffered another impairment under the weight of the opening of the annual selling period to establish losses for the purpose of income-tax returns.

George E. Browne and Willie Bioff, Chicago hoodlums who won control of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, have been found guilty in Federal court of violating the anti-racketeering laws. They used their positions as leaders of this big A.F. of L. union to extort the sum of $1,200,000 from the movie industry.

The first minority report in five decisions of Board of Higher Education trial committees considering charges of communistic activities against members of the City College staff was submitted yesterday by S.J. Woolf in the case of Philip S. Foner, suspended history instructor.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Nov. 7 -- Swimming has been added to the long list of sporting activities here and a team representing the post is being organized to take part in several college meets during the Winter season. Practice sessions will be held three times each week in the Asbury Park Y.M.C.A. pool, under Corporal Albert Peschell, who has been appointed as coach.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Official records were given out by the State Department today to prove that through its agency Finland was informed as far back as Aug. 18 of Russian willingness to discuss peace with her on the basis of territorial compensation to Finland.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: For any one knowing as little about Yale football as L.H. St. Clair to write a letter to THE TIMES concerning it takes nerve. Until very recently I was a member of the Yale freshman football squad.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 6:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- The Westchester County Planning Commission filed today with the County Executive and the Board of Supervisors a proposed budget of $390,000 for capital improvements in 1942 but did not include in it an appropriation for an airport site.
