VICHY, France, Nov. 7 -- Police raids conducted in Paris during the visit of Admiral Francois Darlan, the Vice Premier, and Minister of the Interior Pierre Pucheu are said here to have uncovered a terrorist organization that will be charged with the assassinations of German officers at Nantes and Bordeaux.

The entire eleventh floor in the building at 9-11 East Forty-first Street has been leased by Pringle Johnson Imports, Ltd., importers of English and Scottish textiles. The transaction completes the rental of the structure, which is known as the Wellcome Building, and of the adjoining six-story American Institute of Accountants Building at 13-15 West Forty-first Street, according to Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., agents.

ROME, Nov. 7 -- The Italian press today sees in Premier Joseph Stalin's speech an admission that Russia is fighting a hopeless fight because of the insurmountable physical difficulties that render Anglo-Saxon aid impossible. It also, of course, emphasizes what it terms "the monstrous pluto-demo-Soviet partnership."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I noticed in THE TIMES this morning an article from London stating, among other things, that Russia has demanded the British declare war on Finland; that the British attitude toward Finland in this respect has been and will be determined or directed from the United States.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Surplus Marketing Administration announced today the purchase of 9,812,000 pounds of lard, 10,240,292 pounds of canned pork products. 2,634,000 pounds of cured pork and 74,200 bundles of casings.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In answer to the letter of L.H. St. Clair appearing in THE TIMES of Nov. 1, let me present this rebuttal.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- A.F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, said tonight that his organization and the four other big operating unions would call 350,000 men out on strike Dec. 5 to enforce demands for a 30 per cent wage increase.

The P.R. count of ballots cast for candidates for the new City Council produced its first winner yesterday. He was Councilman Frederick Schick of Staten Island, who was elected for his third successive term, receiving 36,878 first-choice ballots as against 18,171 cast for Harold B. Olsen, his Republican opponent and the only other candidate from that borough.

The antics and problems of a madcap family, which is about to be augmented by a blessed event, are depicted by Aubrey Noel Langley in his comedy, "The Walrus and the Carpenter," which will have its premiere this evening at the Cort. Its sponsor is Alfred Gustave Etienne de Liagre Jr., who also attended to the staging.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Eleventh-hour efforts by Administration leaders to have the pending price control bill altered before it reaches the House floor apparently failed late today despite authoritative word that the measure faces a Presidential veto in its present form.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The average value of daily retail sales in Great Britain in September was 4.2 per cent lower than in September, 1940, according to the monthly statistics issued here today by the Bank of England and the Retail Distributors Association.

Prayers for world peace will be offered on Tuesday, Armistice Day in Protestant Episcopal Churches throughout the United States it response to a call to the entire communion issued by the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, the presiding bishop.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7 -- Undefeated Fordham will undertake to hurdle what is generally considered an easy obstacle tomorrow, when it opposes Pittsburgh.

After the market had held within narrow ranges most of the session, trade buying and local demand in the early afternoon lifted prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday as much as 20 points above Thursday's close.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The text of the memorandum by Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles on his conversation with Finnish Minister Hjalmar Procope on Aug. 18 follows:
Another outpouring of social notables marked last night's performance of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, with the boxes resplendent in shimmering gowns and luxurious furs.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Major Gen. Henry W. Baird's Fourth Armored Division, from which was budded the cadre for the new Fifth Armored Division, soon will undertake intensive field training of full units in battalion and regimental combat exercises with newly assigned equipment.

Two arrivals in Broadway houses this morning will complete the week's list of new film offerings. At the Rialto the new attraction will be Universal's comedy adventure, "South of Tahiti." Brian Donlevy, Broderick Crawford, Maria Montez, H.B. Warner, Andy Devine, Henry Wilcoxon and Armida head the picture's cast. . . .

Nobody seriously expects N.Y. U. to beat the University of Missouri today at the Yankee Stadium. However, the fact that N.Y.U. has nothing to lose except another football game may move the enterprising Mal Stevens to direct the Violet along the daring lines that characterized his strategy in other years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The War Department today instructed the Chrysler Tank Corporation to double the production of the Detroit tank arsenal, which it operates under contract. This arsenal, which was constructed last Spring and recently began regular production, is said to be the largest single-unit factory in the world devoted exclusively to tank production.

The State of California awarded yesterday to Kaiser Co. an issue of $2,922,528 of general fund registered warrants at 0.30 per cent, plus a premium of $33. The warrants will become payable on or about Feb. 25, 1942.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Finnish press contended today that Finland sorely needs to repossess the Hangoe naval base and the islands in the Gulf of Finland that Russia obtained by the treaty of March, 1940, and that to yield to British-American demands for immediate cessation of the war with Russia would be "military and national suicide."
LINDEN, N.J., Nov. 7 -- Forty-four hundred workers were made idle as a C.I.O. strike halted all work at the General Motors assembly plant here today. No defense work was involved in the tie-up.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- Officials said here today they believed the arrival of the new United States military missions at their posts in the Middle East was imminent. The initial missions are understood to consist of about twenty officers each.

Proving that mail truck drivers are not traffic "cowboys," the New York City Postoffice presented Federal safe-driving awards yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania to 493 gray-uniformed drivers operating from postal stations in Manhattan and the Bronx.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Trade rejoicing over the heavy attendance and good volume of orders placed at the one week furniture market here was tempered somewhat at the close by rumors of new government controls of some sort over the industry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today its decision to permit the continuance of the existing practice of designation by the issuer of securities offered for competitive bidding of independent counsel to represent the bidders.

Current student opinion on the war, as represented by the attitude of Dartmouth College students, is "way ahead of public opinion" as the result of a rapid shift from isolationism in the last two years, Dr. Ernest Martin Hopkins, president of Dartmouth, declared yesterday.

Harry Schulman, 35 years old, of 142 Sichel Street, New Rochelle, the pseudo newspaper reporter and magazine editor who had used the names of numerous persons to defraud would-be actresses and dancers, as well as midtown restaurants, was sentenced to a ninety-day workhouse term, yesterday by Magistrate Burke in Probation Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The National Defense Mediation Board may give a decision in the captive mine dispute on Monday, according to Chairman William H. Davis, who summed up the situation at a press conference today following a meeting of the board.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- President Roosevelt today instructed Edward R. Stettinius Jr., the Lease-Lend Administrator, to arrange "as quickly as possible" with Soviet officials the transfer of war supplies to Russia under the Lease-Lend Act.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- The Fort Slocum Post Hospital has established a new record of Army medical service by "processing" in a period of thirty-six hours 2,600 Infantrymen for service at the new American bases in the Atlantic.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- A strike of 350,000 operating employes of the railroads will be called soon to enforce a demand for a 30 per cent wage increase, executives of the Big Five brotherhoods announced tonight. No official date has been set, but it is expected the strike will be ordered for Dec. 5.

Most of the persons shot, stabbed or otherwise injured in hold-ups in the Harlem area are treated at the Harlem Hospital, a city institution, at 136th Street and Lenox Avenue, a survey of the records of five hospitals revealed yesterday. Four of the hospitals are private or voluntary institutions.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Nov. 8 -- Reporting on yesterday's fighting, the authoritative Russian military commentator declared in a broadcast early today that Soviet forces continued to hold the initiative in the Volokolamsk sector.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 7 -- Alfred Hitchcock was engaged today by Frank Lloyd and Jack Skirball to direct "The Saboteur," a photoplay by Peter Viertl and June Harrison, for Universal. Robert Cummings and Priscilla Lane will play the leads.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- The executive committee of the National Association of Retail Druggists will meet here Nov. 25 to 27 to formulate the association's 1942 objectives and to consider a wide variety of problems connected with defense, ranging from drug shortages to the plan of the District of Columbia Pharmaceutical Association for bringing drug stores into the defense program as emergency stations.

The four-story Sandford Court Apartments at 445-7 South Fourth Avenue, Mount Vernon, Westchester, have been sold by the Prudence Bonds Corporation through Harry D. Cole and Porter Waterman, co-brokers, to Dr. Alfred Beyer of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Donald H. Nelson, Director of Priorities, Office of Production Management, predicted today the end in the near future of the priorities system as it now operates. Plans have heretofore been revealed to replace priorities by an allocation system, which Mr. Nelson said he hoped would put industry "on an even keel."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- An "all-out" allocations program affecting every pound of critical materials used by American industry is being prepared by the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board in cooperation with all other defense agencies.

Gus Lesnevich, Cliffside, N.J., boxer who holds the world lightheavyweight championship, and Tami Mauriello, Bronx challenger, yesterday passed a physical examination by the State Athletic Commission and formally signed official contracts for the fifteen-round title struggle in which they are to engage Friday night in Madison Square Garden.

Secretary Ickes's New Job With his appointment yesterday by President Roosevelt as coordinator of solid fuel for the duration of the defense emergency Secretary of Interior Harold L. Ickes now becomes virtually a "fuel czar."

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 7 -- The principal topic of conversation this week at Fort Du Pont has been the football game between the undefeated Post team and the Wilmington Clippers of the American Football Association to be held in Wilmington Park Sunday afternoon.
FORT DIX, Nov. 7 -- Reconstruction of five streets at Fort Dix and the widening of another has caused a maze of detours confusing to Army personnel stationed here as well as to visiting civilians.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 1 -- American women would bear the brunt of a Nazi triumph over democracy, Mrs. Nellie Tayloe Ross, Director of the United States Mint, warned tonight in a speech before the Stephens College Forum on "The American Woman and Her Responsibilities."

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- The Royal Air Force continued its offensive last night with new attacks on the occupied French coast. Considerable anti-aircraft fire near Boulogne indicated the British planes were attacking Nazi airdromes there.

Two hundred and fifty additional patrolmen, detectives and mounted and motor cycle men were assigned to lower Harlem and the upper Central Park section yesterday in an effort to stamp out the outbreaks of crime that have come to a climax in two murders within the past week.

An investing client of Emil Leepson has purchased from Harry Glick through J.J. Boneparth, Inc., broker, the six-story elevator apartment house at 2556 Rochambeau Avenue, on the corner of 212th Street, the Bronx, paying cash above a first mortgage of $242,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- An Army officer accused of embezzling $375 from Theodore J. Mazur, soldier, of Passaic, N.J., who was shot and killed in an escape from the Fort Dix guardhouse, will be taken before a general courtmartial for trial.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Famous trotter Dean Hanover's first crop of yearlings, hailed as one of the best ever, brought a high average of $1,239 at concluding sales of the third annual Harrisburg harness auction today.

A committee representing the coastwise steampship lines has asked the International Longshoremen's Association to extend a wage agreement that expired on Oct. 31, pending clarification of the railroad wage scales under discussion in Washington.
HULL, England, Nov. 7 -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's address here today:

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Harry Wilson Warley will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at their some, 1040 Fifth Avenue, for Mrs. Warley's sister, Mrs. Flynn Stewart, who is leaving next Thursday for Dalja, her Winter home in Palm Beach.

Armistice Sunday will be observed tomorrow in virtually every church of New Tork and vicinity. Today will be Red Cross Sabbath in the synagogues and tomorrow will be Red Cross Sunday in the churches. Red Cross roll-call appeals will be heard this morning in thirty-one Jewish houses of worship and tomorrow in 392 Christian Churches, it was announced yesterday by the churches and synagogues division of the New York Red Cross Chapter.

While Federal conciliators sought to avert a strike of 15,000 long-distance telephone workers, a labor controversy affecting 11,000 employes in the plant department of the New York Telephone Company was settled amicably yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- President Roosevelt announced today that the United States Government was considering the withdrawal of American Marines from China, where they have been stationed at Shanghai, Tientsin and Peiping.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 7 -- Fumes seeping from naphtha cleaning fluid stored in a washing machine were blamed here today for the explosion last Saturday that demolished the twelve-room home of Mr. and Mrs. William Schlegel at 411 Berkley Avenue, Orange, N.J., and took the life of Mrs. Schlegel.

Manufacturers attending the annual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America here this week reported that with few exceptions they were increasing advertising budgets for 1942. Chief change in their programs will be less emphasis on premiums, 1-cent sales and free deals, they said.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 8 -- Asserting that here and there the old imperialistic grip had been loosened in the world and seemed to be giving way slowly to the higher moral purposes inherent in the terms union, federation and commonwealth of nations, Dr. Judah L. Magnes, president of the Hebrew University, yesterday pointed to the changes that already have taken place in the social and political structure.

Marching 56 yards to a touchdown in the fourth quarter, the Hopkins School football team of New Haven battled the Horace Mann School for Boys to a 12-12 tie on the Horace Mann gridiron yesterday. The scoring was divided between two players, Tony Contini going over for both the Horace Mann tallies and Frank Robinson making both of the invaders' 6-pointers.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 7 -- While the 186th and 187th Field Artillery Regiments, made up largely of men from Brooklyn, are on manoeuvres in the Carolinas, their permanent base at Fort Ethan Allen is being prepared to house additional men.

In "tip-top" condition after two scrimmages held last week in the snow in Omaha, an exuberant football squad from Father Flanagan's Boys Town, on its first trip East as a unit, arrived at the Pennsylvania Station yesterday ready for a three-game tour.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, In the Western Desert, Nov. 7 -- A unique story of how a young Polish lieutenant posing as a wounded German penetrated more than three miles within Axis lines outside Tobruk, watched enemy activities a whole day and then returned safely to his own unit, reached British advanced headquarters here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Supervisor George Turner of Somers Township, dean of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors in point of service, was indicted this afternoon by a WestChester County grand jury on charges of misappropriating town funds.

With respect for the upsetting powers of the under dog, having been cast in that role frequently, Manhattan's eleven will oppose Boston University at the Polo Grounds today. The meeting with the once-beaten Terriers is expected to draw 10,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Office of Production Management tonight placed a ban, effective immediately, on manufacture of cellophane and other transparent materials for wrapping many nondefense items, including cosmetics, razor blades and soaps.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Some 24,284,981 man-days of defense effort were lost because of strikes during the first fifteen months of the rearmament program, official Labor Department reports showed today.

BERLIN, Nov. 7 -- German official estimates of the Stalin-Roosevelt speeches were inclined today to assume that their tenor and contents complemented each other perfectly. It was even suggested that both utterances were prearranged. That of the Soviet leader, it was stressed, was plainly addressed to British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and left no doubt that it demanded a British offensive in the West.
Sales of loft buildings in the Thirties were a feature of the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday.

The inevitable has happened at the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company in Kearny. When officials of that company declined to accept the National Defense Mediation Board's recommendation for a union maintenance shop on the ground that it was against their principles to fire workers for failure to pay union dues, they were accused of distorting the issue.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- The discovery of the oldest known story of the creation of the universe, inscribed by Sumerian poets upon slabs of stone some 4,000 years ago as the introduction to a poem written in honor of one of their heroes, was announced today by Dr. Samuel N. Kramer, research associate of the Museum of the University of Pennsylvania, at the Oriental Seminar of the university.

Shipments of United States currency to foreign countries during October aggregated $2,612,000, compared with $566,000 in September, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly survey of foreign shipments and receipts.
Sales of loft buildings in the Thirties were a feature of the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- The discovery of the oldest known story of the creation of the universe, inscribed by Sumerian poets upon slabs of stone some 4,000 years ago as the introduction to a poem written in honor of one of their heroes, was announced today by Dr. Samuel N. Kramer, research associate of the Museum of the University of Pennsylvania, at the Oriental Seminar of the university.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 7 -- An eyewitness report by a competent foreign military observer who has just arrived in Turkey by air direct from, the Soviet's auxiliary capital at Kuibyshev gives fresh documented evidence of increasing Soviet resistance and plans to continue the war indefinitely at all costs.

Robert Nathan, novelist and president of the American Center of the international writers' organization, the P.E.N., revealed last night that he had requested Jules Remains, president of The European P.E.N. in America, to organize the unit of exiled writers he heads in this country "in the proper way or else go out of existence."

After a spectacular jump-off which held the spectators enthralled, the United States Army team was declared winner of the International Low Score Competition Challenge Trophy at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

Now that the National Theatre Conference has released William Saroyan's "Jim Dandy" for use on non-professional stages, productions are beginning to pop off everywhere. At the moment the nearest to Broadway is at the Theatre Intime of Princeton, where the students have been giving the play surprisingly good staging all this week.

A "code of ethics" to govern city school children in and out of the classroom, and to help develop character, is to be prepared by the junior high school students under the guidance of the faculty, Dr. Elias Lieberman, associate superintendent in charge of the junior high school division, announced yesterday.

Three men in an automobile that fell thirty feet off the Highland Boulevard viaduct in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon escaped serious injury when the car landed right side up, bounced and came down again upside down.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Clement R. Attlee, Lord Privy Seal and Deputy Prime Minister of Great Britain, said at a press conference at the British Embassy today that he was "quite certain" the joint action of Britain and the United States in the industrial field would "enable us to defeat Hitlerism."

Gangs of boys between the ages of 8 and 16 or 18, beginning a career of lawbreaking by petty thefts from storekeepers, going from that to holding up other youngsters for a few pennies, and graduating into murder: such is the situation in and around Harlem as light has been thrown upon it following the brutal killing of 15-year-old James O'Connell.

Scarcely a day passes without a fresh warning from official Government sources of the dangers of inflation. Yet, apart from the recent revenue act, the merits of which were largely due to the pressure of public opinion and the initiative of the Senate, nothing effective has yet been done to provide for the control of inflation.

HAVANA, Nov. 7 -- President Fulgencio Batista tonight signed decrees increasing the wages of workers in the island from 10 to 25 per cent as a means of settling the widespread labor difficulties. The Chief Executive pointed out that the sharp rise in living costs made a general wage increase imperative, and he said that investigations by the government showed labor was justified in the present island-wide movement to force wages upward.

Mrs. Gussie Cohen, 68 years old, a tiny grandmother with a police record of twenty-five arrests in the confidence racket, including several convictions, and Morris Pletman, 48, an ex-convict, were held without bail for grand jury action yesterday by Magistrate Burke in, the Felony Court for allegedly defrauding an elderly widower last September in a fake marriage troth.

Plain, Not Little It is not quite clear from the text whether the new Democratic Borough President of Queens himself used the word or whether it was put into his mouth by the interviewer. In the printed story Mr. Burke is represented as saying that his impressive victory was the work of tHe little people of Queens.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Tammany leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District, former Supreme Court justice and Democratic nominee for Mayor in 1937, sent a letter yesterday to Christopher D. Sullivan, demanding the latter's resignation as leader of Tammany, a meeting of its executive committee to elect his successor and abandonment of the historic name of Tammany which, he said, had become too heavy a load for any Democratic candidate to carry.

PENN YAN, N.Y., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Keuka College inaugurated formally today Dr. Henry Elisha Allen as its third president. More than 100 representatives of higher education and learned societies were present.

KEARNY, N.J., Nov. 7 -- The discharge of ten more workers at the government-operated Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company was asked today by Local 16 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C.I.O., under the "maintenance of membership" clause that had been accepted by the Navy during its "temporary" operation of the ship assembly yard.

When you've run through your regular culinary repertoire so often that your, menus seem "stale, flat and unprofitable," it's time to look about for a new trick to add to your bag of monotony-breakers.

The sale of the luxurious new Swedish-American liner Stockholm to the Italian Government for 2,000,000 pounds, reported last week from Sweden, marked the end for the present at least of efforts of the company to add new tonnage to its transatlantic fleet.

IN the year 1787, the year our own Constitutional Convention finally foregathered, the first colonists for Australia sailed from Britain bound for Botany Bay. They were all convicts save, in a few instances, for members of a convict's family, voluntarily accompanying him.
PINEHURST, N.C. -- Golf and polo will continue to headline the calender for the remainder of the month at this Midsouth resort.

AERICANS in general and reticent Vermonters in particular should be grateful to Charles E. Crane, late of Illinois. It is true that the author of "Winter in Vermont" has spent most of his post-natal days in the Green Mountains.

While the repeal or drastic amendment of the Neutrality Act has been under debate the Nazis have settled the issue for us. They have made war upon us in the Atlantic. They sank the Robin Moor, an unarmed merchantman, first. Since then they have fired upon the Greer, wounded the Kearny, sunk the Reuben James with the loss of nearly a hundred lives, seriously damaged the naval tanker Salinas.

The Columbia University College of Pharmacy has devised three tests to measure the general capacity, specialized ability and manipulative dexterity of pharmacy students, Dean Charles W. Ballard disclosed in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, which was made public yesterday.

Perhaps the fact that it was scored upon for the first time this year rankled the powerful Abraham Lincoln High football team. At any rate, the unbeaten Honest Abes came back to cross James Madison High's goal line six times and rout their Brooklyn foe, 38 to 2, before 6,000 fans at Abraham Lincoln High Field yesterday.

Bruno Walter led the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in a monumental performance of Beethoven's "Eroica" symphony last night in Carnegie Hall. The truly heroic interpretation of the masterpiece made such a profound impression on the capacity audience present, that there was a ten-minute ovation for the leader at the work's conclusion.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 -- As part of its contribution to national defense, Simmons College during the next semester will offer two evening courses designed to make available to college graduates engaged in professional work the best and most recent information relating to their fields, President Bancroft Beatley announced today.

APPARENTLY one is either fully a Gilbert and Sullivan devotee, or wholly not. There seems to be no middle course. The present book is likely to produce more votaries, possibly even from the ranks of those who, because they consider G. and S. "old hat," or for some other reason, look upon the British team with kindly superciliousness.

One of the vice presidents of the Consolidated Van Ness Corporation in San Diego is James Flagg, formerly a detective with the United States Narcotics Bureau. He describes himself as a vice president without a portfolio because he has no duties that he has been able to discover, and he doesn't like it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Iceland post was raised to one of the Navy's important operations centers today when Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox announced that a Naval Operations Base had been established there under the Commander in Chief of the United States Atlantic Fleet "both for ad- ministrative and task purposes."

Relief work being conducted for children of unoccupied France, French war prisoners and repatriated prisoners by the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, 4 West Fifty-eighth Street, will be materially advanced through proceeds from Thursday night's performance of "Candle in the Wind."

FICTIONIZED history is something to which there can be and often have been numerous objections, but, when done by a really able writer, a little fictionizing may send fresh blood running through the veins of an episode dried and even mummified by time.

DESPITE reports to the contrary, there is plenty of room for tourists in Hawaii and will be for the coming Winter season, according to Earl Thacker, vice president of Hawaiian Hotels, Ltd., who was in New York last week to attend a meeting of the American Hotels Association.

THIS is two books in one. As soon as the earlier of the two, a first novel, was published Mr. Greenwood began intensive work on the second to the accompaniment of "bombing with machine-gun attacks" in an "invasion town" where he was sanitary inspector and evacuation officer.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The British Ministry of Agriculture's index for farm production touched an all-time high this Fall as efforts to increase the land yield by improved methods and extensive reclamation of derelict or badly managed farms were intensified.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

TAKE a canvass of the nation's top radio gag-writers, asking them the question they hear most often. They'll all come up with the same answer: "Where do you get all your jokes?" Strange to say, a humorist, when meeting another humorist, usually asks the same question.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 8 -- Harvard's football team drew up a chair to the banquet board this afternoon. By a score of 20 to 6, three touchdowns to one, the Crimson moved into the company of the elect, toppling Army's game outfit from the list of the undefeated.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Opinion was prevalent among railroad labor leaders tonight that President Roosevelt could and probably would avert the threatened nationwide rail strike.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 8 (AP) -- A pair of flashy backs, Frank Dornfeld and Benny Bulvin, struck through the air and on the ground behind a stone-wall line, as Georgetown whipped Maryland, 26 to 0, before 7,500 shivering spectators today.

CURIOUS by-products of a review of Mr. Aaron Copland's book, "Our New Music," printed recently in this column, consisted in one correspondent's reference to a "quarrel" which he seemed to perceive between the reviewer and the author of the book, and another letter which concerns itself principally with a minor part of the discussion, regarding the respective merits of Sibelius and Gustave Mahler.

WHEN George S. Kaufman's and Edna Ferber's "The Land Is Bright" opened several days ago, this column applied several approving but generalized adjectives to it "Vibrant" would have been more exact than any of those used.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 8 -- Limiting each other to two touchdowns for the second straight season, the well-drilled, hard-driving football teams of Hotchkiss and the Hill School added another sparkling chapter to their ivy-clad intersectional rivalry today by playing a thrilling 13 -- all deadlock.

Not in several years have so many benefit theatrical performances been offered for the diversion of members of society as those currently on the late Autumn calendar. From the beginning of the new drama season specially organized committees have taken over previews and regular performances of outstanding plays to raise funds for various philanthropic projects, many in the field of war relief.

EXETER, N.H., Nov. 8 -- After driving for a touchdown in the first five minutes of play, Exeter was stopped cold by a fighting Bowdoin freshman eleven, today and was forced to stop several drives deep in its own territory in order to eke out a 7-6 victory.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Colgate University will participate in the nation-wide observance of American Education Week by bringing leading social science seniors and their teachers to the campus from about 100 high schools in fifteen Central New York counties on Armistice Day.

THE recent flight of the Russian technicians across the top of the earth's surface to Alaska was a streamlined fulfillment of one of the dreams of Peter the Great. It was his desire to learn whether Asia and America were connected by land or divided by a waterway that led to the discovery of Alaska and the northern portions of the western coast.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Marine Corps, which will observe its 166th anniversary Monday, was lauded today in messages to Major Gen. Thomas Holcomb, the commandant, from Secretary Knox, Admiral Stark, Chief of Naval Operations, and General Marshall, Army Chief of Staff.

OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- A new program for the intensive five-day treatment of the advanced stages of syphilis, which has been found to affect 15 per cent of the inmates in New York State penal institutions, was presented at the Sing Sing Prison Hospital today before a gathering of forty doctors from all of the State's prisons, reformatories and institutions for feeble-minded criminals.
LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 9 -- The Royal Air Force carried out its heaviest raids of the war against Germany and Italy through Friday night and yesterday.

Shortages in many important lines of industry will be temporarily relieved in the early part of next year as a result of a planned intensification of the inventory-control program of the Office of Production Management, but will be followed by more stringent scarcities as the greatly augmented Victory program gets under way, industrial purchasing agents predicted last week.

IN a time like the present, when the expanding monomania of a fiendishly able tyrant is shaking the civilization of three continents, it is perhaps pertinent to wonder how Mr. Bueno de Mesquita, writing in England in the dangerous year of 1940, could have found the heart and interest to put all this meticulous care upon a dictator of no more than Northern Italy who lived nearly six centuries ago.

Former Judge Harry V. Osborne of Newar: and South Orange, N.J., president of the Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys at Millington, N.J., and Mrs. Charles Edison of Liewellyn Park, West Orange, are Serving as co-chairmen of a sponsoring committee for a benefit party at the Ice Follies of 1942 on the night of Dec. 8 at Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Top-ranking executives from the major meat packing companies will be called next week to testify before the special Federal grand jury investigating alleged monopolies and price fixing in the meat industry. Subpoenas for their appearance beginning Wednesday are being served by Marshal William H. McDonnell.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Bishop Wilson Reiff Stearly, former Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark, died here tonight at his home, 53 Melrose Place, after a long illness. His age was 72. In poor health since 1932, he resigned as Bishop in 1935, his condition having shown no improvement.

The draped and ruffled dressing tables so dear to feminine fancy are now receiving serious attention from designers and decorators, so that new and unusually effective arrangements are appearing. Since they are closely related to the feminine wardrobe, it seems clever to give them decoration derived from elaborate costumes of the past and present.

NOTHING of great consequence has happened to William G. Morse since he graduated from Harvard College in 1899. But he is an affable person who seems to have had a good time in a steel foundry, in two factories, in the Navy during the last war, in the grain business and, since 1920, as purchasing agent for Harvard University.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8 -- It was learned today that in spite of strong pressure from the United States State Department, the American oil companies had again refused the Mexican proposal and were preparing a reply to it, while the British company, backed by its government, took an identical position.

VICHY, France, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- The American Committee at Marseille for the Aid of Political Exiles and Refugees said today that Berthold Jakob-Salomon, German refugee journalist, had been deported from Portugal to Spain and was being held there on a German demand for his extradition.

Founded three years ago on an experimental basis to help raise the teaching standards of this country, the National Committee on Teacher Examinations is now receiving the cooperation of 300 school systems throughout the United States, Dr. David G. Ryans, executive secretary, disclosed yesterday.

Declaring that processes of education are impeded by malnutrition among school children, George H. Chatfield, director of the Bureau of Attendance of the New York City Board of Education, called yesterday for a government program to furnish supplies for the feeding of children at home as well as one for feeding England.
COLLEGE STATION, Texas, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Derace Moser threw scoring passes today to pull the Texas Aggies from the brink of defeat and give them a 21-10 victory over gallant Southern Methodist.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 -- Thoroughbreds from foreign lands captured principal honors in the Grayson Stakes at Pimlico as Trois Pistoles and Filisteo finished noses apart in the order named before a crowd exceeding 20,000. It was any one's guess as to the outcome until the judges made use of the camera to fix on Mrs. Ella K. Bryson's French-bred son of Vatout

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Announcement of elevation of the Iceland post of the Navy followed by a day the Senate's vote to permit American flag vessels to go into belligerent, meaning especialy British, ports. While the House has yet to act, authorities forecast that if cargo vessels were permitted to make the whole trip to England they would travel routes protected by American warships.

IT is a heavy loss to American literature that Scott Fitzgerald died in his forties. Of that fact this volume which Edmund Wilson has edited is convincing proof. When "Tender Is the Night" was published a few years ago there was reason to doubt whether the fine talent which had first fully realized itself in "The Great Gatsby" eight years before would develop sufficiently to arrive at the greater achievements of which it was capable.

OTTAWA, Nov. 8 -- Out of this week of debate in the House of Commons there has emerged a clear indication that Canada is moving steadily toward what is now called "compulsory selective service," although it may eventually be given another name, such, for instance, as "emergency manpower organization."

The final session of a three-day sale of art objects, jewelry and household goods of the estate of Katherine Sanford Nielson of New London, Conn., brougnt $18,557 yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 Bast Fifty-seventh Street.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov 8 (AP) -- Striking for three touchdowns in the opening quarter, and holding the upper hand from there on in, the Saxons of Alfred University downed Hofstra, 32 to 21, today.

THE charm with which Marion Nicholl Rawson invests her researches into her country's craftsman past is not so much nostalgic as robust. To date she has written and illustrated seven books of the works -- and thus of the lives -- of what she happily dubs our "handwrought ancestors."

TWO young Londoners, Michael, 15, and Meredith, 14, left wartime England with their uncle when they were persuaded that in accepting American safety they could still serve their country. They visited Quebec and the Ile de Orleans, enjoying the French people whose loyalty was the same as theirs.

BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- Brain and spine wounds that would have been fatal in the World War days are now healable, thanks to the rapid transportation to rear hospitals made possible by the airplane and to discoveries made in the last two decades by American and Swedish surgeons.

ON the eve of World War II Philip Hazen enjoyed all the bounties Providence could bestow on a Wall Street broker. Still rich, he was also young, handsome, admired by men and romantically attractive to women. He had shown ability and imagination in protecting his father's Stock Exchange firm from the blasts of the 1929 hurricane which wrecked so many other wire-houses.

A letter from Mayor La Guardia, in his capacity as chief of the Office of Civilian Defense, to various leading clergymen, was denounced yesterday as an "unspeakable insult to the clergy of the United States" by the Rev. Dr. Charles Clayton Morrison, editor of The Christian Century, nondenominational weekly, because it included a "sermon outline" suggested for use next Sunday.

The Grace Line announced yesterday the appointment of four captains to new commands and the promotion of Captain A.E. Uldall, chief officer of the freighter Santa Ana, to command the steamship Falcon.

IN simple style at once poetic and pawky. Robert Nathan does another of his satirical fantasies. Tapiola, the little Yorkshire terrier "no bigger than a small spring chicken." is the protagonist. He will be remembered for his "Journey of Tapiola," a bold and symbolic loop round Manhattan which he made two or three years ago when he was a younger dog.

THE American Contract Bridge League has announced the schedule for the annual national championship tournament, which will begin in Richmond, Va., on Monday, Dec. 1. This tournament is always attended by most of the top-ranking New York players, no matter how far from New York it is held.

WHAT is a girl to do when upon her unexpected return from a week-end in the country she finds a strange man in her apartment, and when that man claims that it is his apartment and that he has been there two weeks?

THERE is an old theatrical saying which is bravely trotted out from time to time that a good title can't help a bad show any more than a bad title can hurt a good one. Of course, it is usually just a refuge for an author who is stuck for a tag, and a fellow who lightly flies to it is invariably suspect of being licked.

A demand for recognition of Palestine as a factor of major importance for the rescue of victims of Nazi persecution has been issued by the Emergency Committee for Zionist Affairs in a statement signed by a group of leading American educators, including forty-six presidents, deans and chancellors of colleges and universities.

According to an announcement by the United States Maritime Commission, names of thirty-nine more famous Americans, including patriots, statesmen and military and naval heroes, have been assigned to ships of the Liberty Fleet, now being constructed rapidly at shipyards throughout the country.

In recognition of his "adoption" of ten war-orphaned children under the Foster Parents' Plan and his interest in their welfare, the Foster Parents' Plan for Children, Inc., 55 West Forty-second Street, announced yesterday the appointment of Russell Maguire, Industrialist, of this city, as honorary chairman of the organization.

IN the infant days of broadcasting -- the early Nineteen Twenties -- radio pioneers seldom gave much thought to the selection of efficient transmitting sites for new stations, then springing up throughout the country. Actually, they knew very little about the matter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- President Roosevelt received today from Daniel J. Tobin, general president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers of America, a refusal to accede to the President's request that Mr. Tobin order striking teamsters at the Railway Express Agency in Detroit to go back by Monday.

A $10,000 gift and a $5,000 gift, both anonymous, head the list of new contributions to the $1,784,293 United Hospital Campaign, Roy E. Larsen, general chairman, announced yesterday at campaign committee headquarters, 370 Lexington Avenue.

QUIZZED about his plans for "The Middle Ages," a play he has written in collaboration with Norman Krasna, Groucho Marx, who has washed off his mustache, volunteered the surprising information that he has been "approached by some one interested" in having him play, the Lord Chancellor in "Iolanthe."

ARTURO TOSCANINI will direct the first pair of his concerts as guest conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra Friday and Saturday in Philadelphia. The program will contain Schubert's C major symphony, Debussy's "Iberia" and Respighi's "Roman Festivals."
Cornell's stranglehold on the Heptagonal Games Association cross-country championship was broken yesterday.

A good deal of progress toward halting the accumulation of unbalanced inventories has been made by credit men for major industrial companies who have been getting into the field and checking over the actual position of their accounts for several weeks, it was reported yesterday.

Women scholars throughout the world are working, not only to combat totalitarian aggression, but to prepare themselves and others for the task of rebuilding when the fighting is done, 600 members of the New York City Branch of the American Association of University Women were told at their annual luncheon at the Hotel Pierre yesterday.

READING, Pa., Nov. 8 -- Edward Brechlin, 36 years old, identified by the Pennsylvania motor police as the head of the accounting division of the Chappel Music Corporation of New York, shot and critically wounded his former fiancee today and then took his own life with the same pistol.

YEARNING for Europe in June? Then go to Buenos Aires in November. The tables and chairs are back on the sunny sidewalks outside the Cabildo and Moglyana Cafes on the Corrientes, Buenos Aires' Champs-Elysees.

Elizabeth Schumann gave her annual recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Like previous ones, it was devoted to German lieder, but this time she also sang three songs in English, Purcell's "If Music Be the Food of Love," Eccles's "The Jolly, Jolly Breeze," and, as her fifth encore after her final group, another early English song, "So Well Corinna Knows Her Heart."

THIS coolly intelligent novel shows people changing during the ten-year swing from brandy at lunch to an apple a day, from 1927 when the big money was an intoxicant to 1937 when people thought about money not happily, but only when they had to.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 8 -- Shanghai is buzzing with conjectures on Washington's announcement that United States Marines may be withdrawn from Shanghai, Tientsin and Peiping. Some believe America is backing down, others declare the proposed step is another move to convince Japan that America is ready to follow her announced policy regarding Japanese policies in the Far East.

As tre neutrality repeal bill progressed in the Senate chamber go-ahead signals were flashed out last week to several women's organizations to make their opinions on the question felt in legislative circles.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 8 -- Chilean armed forces turned out today in one of the most brilliant religious demonstrations ever staged in this country as the eighth Eucharistic Congress, which has brought close to 200,000 visitors to Santiago, devoted attention to the military units.

IN a way it might be said that the Actors Fund of America, which since 1882 has dispensed blessed charity to those of the theatrical profes- sion who are down on their luck, is at the crossroads. Not that the venerable institution is in any trouble.

HERE are four boys, aged 11: Ed, Dave, Frank, Eugene. Ed's teacher says he is "very obedient and conscientious." In a club group he likes to be told what to do; says "I'd rather have some one for a leader who keeps smart guys in their place." Dave feels just the other way; doesn't want to be bossed; can work without oversight; likes a club leader who discusses things; gets on with other boys.

BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- Adolf Hitler declared tonight in reply to President Roosevelt's Navy Day challenge that he had ordered the German Navy to fire on American ships only after being attacked, but that any officer who then failed to fire would be courtmartialed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The proposed law to permit life insurance companies to own common stocks does indeed involve broad financial and economic complications, as pointed out by your correspondent A. Wilfred May. But so does the current trend of the companies toward holding Federal Government bonds.
NEW YORK Mrs. P. Hanson Hiss of Cedarcrest, New Canaan, Conn., has arrived at the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria for the season.

TWO albums of the spoken word are at hand. A new volume in Columbia's Masterpieces of Literature is devoted to Our American Heritage (six ten-inch records, $3.75). The other album looks to the Christmas season; it is an adaptation and dramatization of Charles Dickens's standby, A Christmas Carol.

"FOG: any hazy condition of the atmosphere or the conditions causing it." That's a dictionary definition of fog, and it's also Hollywood's. But whereas "conditions causing it" are, in a state of nature, a matter of condensation of atmospheric moisture, in the state of extreme artificiality which is a motion-picture set, said conditions may be almost anything, from dry ice to bee-smoke.

THIS beautiful book of the American scene is both described and localized in its subtitle. For the covered bridge is there introduced as "an old American landmark whose romance, stability and craftsmanship are typified by the structures remaining in Vermont."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Plans for more effective participation in the national defense effort were discussed today by 200 representatives of sixty-seven national organizations of women at a conference on women's activities.

Mayor La Guardia, who is director of the Office of Civilian Defense, called yesterday upon the citizens of New York to observe the period from Tuesday, Armistice Day, through next Sunday as Civilian Defense Week, in accordance with President Roosevelt's proclamation of Oct. 22.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 -- Pittsburgh did all in its power today to carry out its policy of de-emphasis, and succeeded so admirably as to carry the Fordham football team along in the role of unwilling apostles. For the lightly regarded Panthers, losers of all five of their previous games, contributed an unbelievable upset to the current campaign's annals by decisively trouncing the erstwhile battering Rams from the Bronx, 13 to 0.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- On the eve of the opening of American Education Week, President Roosevelt has addressed the following letter to "the patrons, students and teachers of American schools:

ONE of the big American annuals is current, until the fifteenth of the month, at the Fine Arts Building in Fifty-seventh Street. In two years the Allied Artists of America, Inc., will be celebrating its thirtieth anniversary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A new use for grapefruit as the source of lactic acid which is used widely in medicine and industry has been developed by two Department of Agriculture research workers, according to a patent (No. 2,261,926) awarded to Arthur J. Nolte and Harry W. von Loesecke of Winter Haven, Fla.

New York's clubwomen will be urged to put modern knowledge of nutrition into daily practice for the sake of their families' welfare, as well as for national defense, at the convention of the State Federation of Women's Clubs which opens tomorrow at the Lake Placid Club.

TODAY the traveler to Caracas proceeds from the seaport of La Guayra by way of a fine macadamized road that winds steeply across the mountains; or he can go by rail. When Judge Russell and his family arrived in 1874 the single approach to the Venezuelan capital was an old Spanish mule-track.

Urban home financing in the United States exceeded three and one-half billion dollars during the first nine months of the present year, according to a report by economists of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

Two battles that will have a vital bearing on the Eastern championship race in the National Football League will be staged today. The leading Washington Redskins clash with the Brooklyn Dodgers at Ebbets Field while the New York Giants, a half game behind the capital braves, face the Detroit Lions at the Polo Grounds.

Things being as they are, women may be hesitant about buying dusty-pink towels just because they match the tiles in the new bathroom, or yellow glass curtains which would brighten that room which, now that the furniture is in place, seems a "little darker than it did when they first looked at the new apartment.

LINDEN, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Negotiations for settlement of the strike that has halted production at the sixty-acre assembly plant of the Linden division of the General Motors Corporation since Thursday will begin at the company's offices here Monday between the management and Linden Local 595, United Automobile Workers of America, a C.I.O. affiliate, James Reed, president of the Linden local, announced today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Canada is scheduled to put into effect next Saturday a price and wage fixing program of the most far-reaching character. It is a policy which the majority of voters in the United States believe should be adopted in this country.

TORONTO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Two quick-scoring thrusts in the second period produced the goals which enabled Toronto's Maple Leafs to beat the Boston Bruins, 2 -- 0, tonight. It was the Leafs' first victory in two starts in the current National Hockey League race and it was scored before a crowd of 12,566.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Turkey, 750 tons of it, and all the fixin's will wait upon the appetites of 1,500,000 soldiers on Thanksgiving Day as the Army follows its custom of supplying a royal feast on this holiday. A menu specially prepared by the Quartermaster Corps includes breakfast and supper as well as the sumptuous mid-day meal.

While the situation with respect to obtaining brass supplies after Jan. 1 continues critical, development of new sources of production of ethyl alcohol is tending to ease at least one of the major problems facing the toilet goods industry, it was reported here yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 8 -- The United States Warplane Mars, a sixty-seven-ton Martin patrol bomber, was launched today in the Middle River, the first airplane the Navy ever formally launched. Ranking Army, Navy, Congressional, State and local officials were present to see Mrs. Artemus L. Gates smash a bottle of champagne across the silver bow of the flying warship.

JUDGING from the figures, La Guardia Field, already a "hit" with the sightseeing crowds, is also staging a boom as an airport. Approximately 20 per cent more passengers have been flown in and out of the field during the first nine months of this year than during the same period last year.

Construction is about to start, it was announced yesterday, on a large apartment-house project in Passaic, N.J., to be known as the General Spencer Gardens. It will be erected on a portion of the estate of the late General Bird W. Spencer recently purchased by the building syndicate, comprising a group of Passaic, Jersey City and Newark investors, from the Spencer estate.

A mild spurt in the volume of new bond financing is indicated definitely for the remaining weeks of this year. While the program, as now mapped by issuing companies and underwriters, is not particularly ambitious or of a nature to flood the market with new issues, it does mean increased activity on the part of the investment banking community and a fair supply of new material for investors.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 8 -- Sponsored by the Smith College Emergency Council, three new defense courses being given at the college this semester have received such a response that it has been necessary to limit the enrollment and make selections on the basis of academic standing and college class.

Restraints which the government may put on consumer purchasing power during the first half of 1942 make the problem of framing sales budgets and merchandising plans for next Spring the most difficult which has been experienced since the 1920-21 period, retail authorities here said yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8 Yale graduates who in 1906 started the organization now termed Yale-in-China are making to the present Chinese Government important contributions primarily in education and, through its medical school, in medicine and public health.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Fifty-two years ago, lacking a day, A Yale football team, one of whose members was the immortal Pudge Heffelfinger, romped to a 70-0 victory over Cornell on Ithaca's soil.

An industry-wide settlement of war bonuses for seamen, which the Maritime Commission set as its goal early in the Summer and which, for a while, appeared to be impossible of achievement is actually being brought about, although not in the form originally planned.

ALREADY the "frost line" has swept south from Can- ada to cover all States except South Carolina, Georgia, Florida and the southern halves of the Gulf and Mexican border Stated from Alabama to California.
