Although this country has been through financial and political crises before, none has approached the magnitude of the one faced now, according to Jules S. Bache, internationally known banker and head of J. S. Bache Co. since its organization in 1892, who today is to celebrate his eightieth birthday.

IDA TREAT, American-born archaeologist, has made her home in France since 1919, and for fourteen years -- to December. 1940 -- she lived on an island off the coast of Brittany. Her husband, now fighting in the Gaullist forces, was a captain in the French merchant marine, and in the Summer of 1939 he had just started on a Far Eastern voyage.

DR. RAUSCHNING, as he talked, continually stressed the "complicated" processes of German thought and emotion. One strength of Hitler, he said, is that "in Hitler's presence a man feels the complications being cut out of his mind, and we are such complicated people, there is relief in that."

THE third exhibition of the Fall and Winter season at the Cincinnati Modern Art Society has opened in the Lending Gallery of Local Art. Work by Myer Abel, Paul Chidlaw, Reginald L. Grooms and Bezalel Schatz, among others, is included.
1001 Garden Questions Answered. By Alfred Carl Hottes. Illustrated. 386 pages. New York: A. T. De La Mare Company.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 8 -- Thursday was parade day for a majority of the garrison at the Axis post and airdrome of Mallaha, which is south of Tripoli, Libya. Rows of soldiers stood at attention as rain whipped across barrack buildings.

Denouncing the Nazi system of education which trains its youth for war rather than peace, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey declared yesterday that a wholly new emphasis in education was imperative if the young people of this country were to learn how to produce and be useful citizens in the society of tomorrow.

The Grenfell Association of America made available last week a photograph of the design of the 5-cent stamp which Newfoundland will issue on Dec. 1 to commemorate the late Sir Wilfred Thomason Grenfell (1865-1940), medical missionary among the people of Labrador for nearly half a century.

New opportunities are presented for the home owner burdened with an old-style mortgage to convert it to a modernized "direct reduction" loan, according to Fred W. Catlett, member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
TO THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES: Two letters published in THE TIMES recently attracted my attention.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- Britain has launched a longpromised Winter aerial offensive against the Axis war machine with devastating but costly day and night onslaughts by the greatest Royal Air Force armada of the war on targets ranging from the North Sea to the Mediterranean.

The board of managers of the New York Cotton Exchange voted yesterday to prohibit futures trading in cotton at prices varying more than 1 cent a pound from the closing values of the preceding day. The limit on the Exchange had been 2 cents a pound.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 8 -- The campaign being pushed by the organized women of New Jersey for a new State Constitution elicited high praise here today from Governor Charles Edison.

ONCE more the tide of missionary effort and missionary personnel is fast ebbing away from the Far East. Missions and missionary schools and hospitals are being closed, missionaries are returning to the United States, Canada and England.

STOCKHOLM. MORE than half of the films shown in Sweden these days are "made in Hollywood." In proportion to its population Stockholm probably has more motion picture theatres than any other city in the world -- 106 cinemas to 590,000 inhabitants.

ROME, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- The heaviest casualties in any British air raid on the Italian peninsula since Italy declared war were acknowledged officially today in a communique reporting at least 120 dead or wounded in a bombing of Brindisi on Friday night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- President Roosevelt by proclamation tonight set aside Thursday, Nov. 20, as Thanksgiving Day and asked the Divine Blessing "on our decision and determination to protect our way of life against the forces of evil and slavery which seek in these days to encompass us."
BRISTOL, R.I., Nov. 8 (AP) -- William B. MacColl, textile manufacturer and horse fancier, died unexpectedly in his home here late last night at the age of 55.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- It was learned on excellent authority today that plans are well advanced for concerted action soon by Brit

THE very much reorganized Ballet Theatre opens its New York season on Wednesday at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre, where it will play the first two weeks of its engagement under the auspices of the New Opera Company.

Applications for mortgage insurance on homes in the New York City area received by the FHA during the first ten months of this year showed a decline of 1,800 over the same period of 1940, according to Thomas G. Grace, State director of the FHA.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Rival coaches failed to agree with sports writers today that Wisconsin benefited from a fifth down as it scored a touchdown with three seconds to go in the first half of the Ohio State game.

SOME quickening in trade was reported for the week and attributed to more favorable weather conditions. Election Day business in centers where that was a feature, proved somewhat disappointing. There were good increases but they failed to come up to retail expectations.

THE "sharp, dry sound of hoofs hammering against the hard-beaten snow" came through the windows and died away to an ominous quietness. The street lamps had gone out. The middle-aged teacher's old servant rushed in with terror-stricken rumors: "It is the revolution!

TO THE EDITOR: Anita Brenner, in the superb article, "High School Youth," in the Oct. 26 issue, has written a sincere and worth-while report on American youth, but I would like to take exception to some of her statements.
HOLLYWOOD. THE lethal content of films provoked a crisis on the Republic lot this week and brought mutterings of persecution and class discrimination from that last citadel of the elemental cinema.

AUTO tags will be worn smaller by New York automobiles in 1943, in order to conserve metal and paint -- but metal in particular -- for defense needs. These license plates will be of steel as heretofore, only there will not be as much of it.

Thus President Roosevelt in his Navy Day address last Oct. 27 called upon Congress to pass a proposed bill which would knock out the vital sections of the Neutrality Law prohibiting American cargo carriers from mounting guns on their decks and sailing into the ports of the fighting nations.

PERHAPS the most notorious of all great murder cases in fiction or recorded history is that of Duncan, King of Scotland. Since the taking-off of this uninteresting monarch was followed by that of General Banquo, Lady Macduff and her children, as well as countless other unknown murderees, the case has come to be famous in the name of the principal criminal, Macbeth.

A novel music festival by orchestras which have attained fame through the theatre, radio and ballrooms will be presented as a Name Band Jubilee tomorrow night at the Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street. A benefit for the British-American Ambulance Corps, the event will launch a nationwide series of "dances for ambulances," in cooperation with the American Federation of Musicians, in several hundred cities and towns.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Savage Soviet counter-attacks led by strong tank teams have definitely halted the German drive toward Moscow and have thrown the invaders onto the defensive on many salients, the Russians reported today.

At this season of the year, when most gardens are bare of blooms -- except for the last of the hardy 'mums and a late stray rose or two -- foliage and fruit, used either by themselves or to supplement flowers, serve as excellent decorative material.

Assailing the Democratic leadership in New York City as stupid and even worse, former Representative John J. O'Connor called yesterday for a reorganization of the party in a letter to former State Senator John J. McNaboe.

DURING the next twelve months, ships plowing across the Atlantic with cargoes of American munitions for Great Britain and her allies will carry in their holds some 41,000,000 corrugated paper boxes. The boxes will contain not only materiel for the armed forces but also everyday commodities needed by the civilian populations.

New York representatives at the national convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, to open in Detroit on Nov. 17, will fight against any effort by supporters of John L. Lewis to have the convention go on record as opposed to American participation in the European war, leaders of the C.I.O. said yesterday.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Mgr. Timothy M. Donovan, rector of the Church of the Sacred Heart here for twenty-six years and its second pastor, died at noon today in the rectory after a six-week illness. His age was 73.

LOVERS of the dance will find Cubans enthusiastic devotees of dancing. Young and old seem to have rhythm and musical harmony as their sixth sense. Fiesta day or not, every city and hamlet must have its "baile" or dance.

Mr. Jeremiah T. Mahoney, a member of Tammany Hall and once an unsuccessful candidate for Mayor, has written a letter to the leader of that organization asking him to resign. Other New York Democrats have made the same polite request. Some agree with Mr. Mahoney in proposing that the Democrats of Manhattan cut loose from the name and fame of Tammany Hall and begin business under new management.

UNADULTERATED fantasy-must be treated with a deft hand if it is not to become pure tosh. That the warp and woof of Mr. MacArther's weaving is very far from tosh is due in part to the originality of this story and in part to the excellent prose used in the telling of it.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The usual throng of Fall vacationists in this resort has been increased by the many thousands who are here for Armistice Day. Many of them will participate in patriotic programs planned by the city, while others are following the regular seaside program of sports, rest and relaxation.

QUETZALCOATL was a prince. Indeed, he was so princely a prince that the Aztec gods sent him, as a gift, a small seed from the Gardens of Paradise to plant in his royal park. This seed in due course became a small but beautiful tree with dark green leaves and pale pink blossoms clustered along the slender trunk.

The Christmas Fern (Polystichum acrostichoides) is the most valuable of all native ferns for general garden purposes. Not only is it hardy even in very cold sections but the fresh evergreen appearance of the fronds lasts all Winter. Christmas ferns, once planted, make a quick and generous increase.

NO sooner had the presses delivered the first copy of Ciro Alegria's prize-winning novel, "Broad and Alien Is the World," than Farrar Rinehart announced a second Latin-American Literary Prize Competition, this time with three prizes: $2,000 for the best novel, $2,000 for the best work of nonfiction and $1,000 for the best children's book.

FORT DIX, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Major Aage Woldike, post public relations officer, said tonight that Lieutenant William C. Moody, 25 years old, had been convicted by a Forty-fourth Division court-martial of charges of embezzling $375 from Theodore J. Mazur, Passaic soldier shot fatally on Aug. 22 aft- er escaping from the guardhouse.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 -- The Navy board of strategy's carefully laid plans for the frustration of Angelo Bortolo Bertelli went completely awry today and for the fifth successive year Notre Dame defeated the midshipmen on the football field, 20 -- 13, as 64,795 looked on in the Municipal Stadium.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Iowa's steadily improving Hawkeyes put another hole today in Illinois's waning hopes for a Big Ten victory this season by routing the Bob Zuppke eleven, 21 to 0, before 14,339 shivering fans in Memorial Stadium.

THE revival of "L'Elisir d'Amore" was cheerfully fixed for the first Friday evening of the Metropolitan season. With Tito Schipa's sudden return to Italy, the plans may have to be altered, for he was to sing Nemorino.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- High defense officials were reported tonight to have given tacit backing to a proposal that defense strikes be forbidden unless approved in a secret ballot election by a majority of workers in a plant.

An experimental course in study technique, designed to aid freshmen in forming adequate study habits, has been introduced at City College by Dr. Daniel F. Brophy, director of the college's Personnel Bureau. The course will be limited to 400 students who will be divided equally into experimental and control groups.

VICHY, France, Nov. 8 -- "Collaboration" between defeated France and victorious Germany came into being on Oct. 24, 1940, when Marshal Petain, Chief of the French State, met at Montoire Adolf Hitler, Fuehrer of the German Reich, and was received with "deference and courtesy."

VAN HORNESVILLE, N.Y. HE was sitting on the steps of the postoffice -- really the village store -- opening his mail. He was long and lanky, and held in his mouth a curved pipe of extraordinary length. There was about him an air of infinite repose.

CHINA'S promised stamps in commemoration of the thirtieth anniversary of the establishment of the republic reached New York last week from Chungking -- by truck over the Burma Road, by ship from Rangoon through the Malay Straits and on through the Netherlands Indies to San Francisco and thence by rail.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 8 -- Viewing the Navy's back-to-work ultimatum to striking building trades craftsmen on three defense projects here as a "definite threat to organized labor," American Federation of Labor officials here tonight announced a general building trades strike in San Diego County for Monday unless $1-a-day wage increase demands were met.

ROCHESTER. FROM Oct. 27 to 30 the Eastman School of Music conducted its sixth annual symposium of American orchestral music. Conceived in 1936 to present new music through a series of informal, open reading rehearsals, the project has provided opportunity for the hearing of some fifteen to twenty or more scores each year, many in first readings.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Germany's offensive against Moscow has "failed completely," the Soviet radio said tonight in a broadcast asserting that the Red Army had absorbed the impact of a big onslaught and was counter-attacking on many salients.

The National Youth Administration and the Board of Education offer training opportunities for Negro men in a variety of occupations, and accept Negroes in all categories of training, while Negro women find their greatest opportunity for getting jobs in the garment trades.

ATLANTA, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Georgia Tech, rolling along at reduced steam in chilly weather, generated barely enough power today to subdue an ever-threatening band of Kentucky Wildcats, 20 to 13, before 12,000 spectators.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- Because it is believed that the prime objective of the Cultural Olympics, which is to encourage participation in the arts by amateurs of all ages, has a special signifance in the present period of national emergency and in the years to follow, the program, now in its sixth season, has been broadened by the inauguration of several new features and the revival of others.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today that this year's cotton crop was 11,020,00 bales of 500 pounds gross weight, compared with 11,061,000 bales forecast a month ago, 12,566,000 bales produced last year and an average of 13,246,000 bales in the ten years 1930-39.

CHILE recently completed its first season of governmentsubsidized opera, Claudio Arrau, Chilean pianist, reported when he arrived for his second United States tour. The season lasted six weeks and the principals, as well as members of the chorus, were all young native singers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- It is no coincidence that three engagements between three German submarines and American destroyers and the torpedoing of an American tanker all occurred in that section of the Atlantic Ocean lying southwest of Iceland.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, headed by David Dubinsky, has refused to make contributions through Russian War Relief, Inc., because of a belief that some of the organization's top administrative officials are followers of the Communist party line, it became known yesterday.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 8 -- Holy Cross, scoring touchdowns in the first and third periods, conquered Brown, 13 to 0, before a near-capacity crowd of 22,000 at Brown Field today.

Foreclosures on Manhattan realty during October showed substantial increases both in number and dollar volume compared with the same month of 1940, according to the monthly survey of forced transfers of Manhattan properties by the Real Estate Board of New York.

NOT merely as "antiques" are American crafts studied in this lavishly illustrated quarto volume of our handworkers' lore. Looking at fine old furniture, historic glass and pottery, hand-weaving and metalwork. Scott Graham Williamson sets little store by scarcity value.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8 -- Yale University, threatened with a strike Monday by C.I.O. members of its service staff, defied tonight the demand for a union shop and declared that "every effort will be made to operate the university despite strike action."

Aralac, a new fiber made from casein, which is in turn a by-product of skim milk, will shortly find its way into dress fabrics, upholstery, draperies, blankets and numerous other textile products now made from rayon or wool or both, it was indicated yesterday.

PIERRE-AUGUSTE RENOIR was born in Limoges on Feb. 25, 1841. Thus, although his birthday itself is now months past, we are still in the centennial year. And the event is being celebrated most handsomely at Duveen's, where a loan exhibition opened to the public yesterday, to continue until Dec. 6.
BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Washington clung to its slender Rose Bowl hopes today with a 13 to 6 football victory over California before 40,000 fans.

Word has reached New York that after he was arraigned publicly by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain as one of those responsible for the defeat of French arms and ordered to be interned in a "fortified precinct," Paul Reynaud, the wartime Premier, sent several letters to the Chief of State, one of which was particularly bitter.
A large and enthusiastic audience, with the boxes glamorous with brilliant and varied costumes and the sparkle of jewels, attended the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

THE reviewer of "The Great Lady" has two women to talk about -- Barbara Villiers and Margaret Gilmour. And Margaret Gilmour may well be the more interesting of the two. For unless I am much mistaken, this book marks the debut of an important American biographer.

ANEW kind of river packet has invaded the old, romantic region of the lower Mississippi. She's known as the New Majestic. While her run extends only 125 miles between New Orleans and Burwood, where Ole Man Ribber's lifeblood turns salty as it mixes with the sea, her trips reveal many historic spots along the lower reaches of the Father of Waters.

A patriotic display of bunting and naval ship deck appurtenances will be created for the Navy Ball to be given Nov. 26 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of Bundles for Britain and the Navy League of the United States.

VICHY, France, Nov. 8 -- Police inquiries continued in Paris today and in Vichy the government revised its judicial system for the prosecution of de Gaullist agitators and violators of the food restrictions.
LONDON, Nov. 8 (Reuter) -- Results of football matches played in the British Isles today follow:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The current of history flows swiftly and one cannot be sure that what one writes on Monday will not be out of date on Sunday or that one's morning table-talk will not be out of date at dinner. We must think, if we think at all, as we go.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Albert, the groundhog, escaped from the Trailside Museum here today and has entrenched himself for the Winter under the ancient walls of Fort Clinton. This is his second escape in two weeks.

GREAT BRITAIN'S Crown Agents for the Colonies have sent the Cameroons and French Equatorial Africa each a series of stamps which, printed in London, carry the "Libre France" inscription to indicate that these French colonies in Africa are affiliated with the Free France movement headed by General Charles de Gaulle.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- To a group of workers in a northern production town today Lord Beaverbrook, Supply Minister, hammered out what is probably the most vigorous speech yet been made on the necessity for increased production and Russian cooperation.

A meeting of stockholders of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., has been called in Baltimore for Dec. 3 to vote on a plan to reclassify the company's Class A stock, including all rights to dividend accruals, into common stock, at the rate of three and one-half common shares for each Class A share.

Passage by the City Council of the Hart bill, prohibiting itinerant peddlers on New York City streets except in certain limited areas is hailed by Walter LaM. Sparry, chairman of the Broadway committee of the West of Central Park Association, who states that the association hopes that the Mayor will sign the measure immediately.

ESSEX, Conn., Nov. 8 -- Twenty Class X sailing dinghies from all along the coast, with crews from as far as Maine, competed on the Connecticut River today to qualify for the racing tomorrow for the new Roosevelt Trophy.

THE romance that hedges the railroad will be a long time dying. The song and story have dwindled, but verses like "Casey Jones" and "The Hell-Bound Train" bid fair to become part of our folk literature, and the railroad stories of Frank H. Spearman continue to thrill their readers.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 8 -- Northwestern, bounding back after its heartbreaking defeat by Minnesota a week ago, plunged across a fourth-period touchdown today to defeat a stubborn Indiana eleven, 20 to 14, before 32,000 chilled spectators.

VICHY, France, Nov. 8 -- Stamp collecting has come to have such a vogue in France since the armistice that "responsible stamp dealers" have just formed an association "to defend the profession against racketeers." The allegation is made that speculators are taking unfair advantage of a situation that has developed from the fact that persons with funds "are seeking investment in refuge-values," postage stamps apparently being considered one.

Fordham Prep's football team preserved its unbeaten and untied record by topping Brooklyn Prep, 13 -- 6, yesterday at Fordham Field. The visitors had the satisfaction, however, of being the first team to score in the winners' four-game victory string.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Boilermakers of old Purdue came close to victory today, but couldn't quite make the grade and had to settle for a scoreless tie with Michigan State on a snowsogged gridiron before 17,000 shivering spectators.

HERE is one of those clever, streamlined ultra-modern novels that sweep the reader along with such rocket speed as precludes emotions of slow growth like pity and sympathy; even fear and hate are stunted by the atmospheric pressure.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 8 -- Minnesota's Golden Gophers won their fifteenth straight football game today, defeating Nebraska, 3 to 0, in a stubbornly fought contest before a crowd of 43,000.

WHY is it that soups are not more often made in the kitchens of American homes? Can it be that people don't think it worth the trouble to make their own soups when so many kinds come ready-made in cans?

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 8 -- Mrs. Ed Median's consistent Wise Moss led a field of six today in the New Hampshire Handicap at Rockingham Park. Her time for the six furlongs over a slow track was 1:12 4/5 as she beat Alvin Untermyer's Cockerel by a length.

Mail orders fell off in several of the wholesale market lines last week, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. Some manufacturers welcomed the lull to catch up on back orders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Overall iron and steel requirements of the petroleum industry for 1942 were estimated at 5,846,000 tons yesterday in a request submitted to the Office of Production Management by Harold Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator for National Defense.

Although a price ceiling is to become effective in Canada on Nov. 17 and Canadian wages and rents are also to be stabilized, while the United States has not yet taken such action, the price advance in Canada since the outbreak of the war does not greatly exceed that of this country.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 7 (Delayed) -- In bitter, freezing weather the Soviet Union celebrated the twenty-fourth anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution with a series of patriotic speeches and an enormous military parade in the central place of Kuibyshev today, demonstrating to the Russian people considerable in reserves in man power and material that still exist in this vast country despite the admittedly heavy losses in four and a half months.

DOWNTOWN New York more than a place of business. It is the background of a pleasant Saturday afternoon walk past historical land- marks, through foreign settle- ments, to the vantage point of the Battery for a superb view of New York Harbor.

If you are bent on giving monogrammed Christmas presents, this is a good time to consider the field. We've assumed that you know you can go to almost any store, big or little, and get shirts and handkerchiefs and the usual things monogrammed.
HAVERFORD, Pa., Nov. 8 -- Haverford's hard-charging line stopped Milt Jannone, Hamilton's ace scorer, and broke loose a few of its own backs in a 20-0 upset victory over the Continentals today.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 8 -- The undefeated University of Delaware football team routed Swarthmore College, 47 -- 7, today before a crowd of 3,500.

By increasing, as of Nov. 1. the reserve required of member banks, the Reserve Board has reduced excess reserves from $4,600,000,000 to $3,410,000,000. The action was taken, the board announced beforehand, "as a further step in the Government's program for combating inflation."

COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 8 -- A drastic overhauling of women's education is needed now to prepare them to cope with "three tremendous pressures" which may be exerted upon them during the next twenty years, Dr. Malcolm MacLean, president of Hampton Institute, Said tonight in a speech before the Stephens College forum.

BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- Place names were again today conspicuously absent in German Army reports covering operations against Russia in the vital Moscow sector and continuous bad weather was the official reason for an apparent standstill there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The controversial price control bill, which has for its avowed purpose the curbing of inflation during the emergency, was formally presented to the House today by the Banking and Currency Committee, but under circumstances which indicated that a battle royal would greet it when it comes up for consideration probably during the week of Nov. 16.

Missouri's Tigers were a trifle too ferocious for New York University's Violets at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. The husky, speedy boys from the Show-Me-State romped to a 26-0 victory, scoring once each in the second and third periods and twice in the final quarter.
WACO, Texas, Nov. 8 -- Baylor hurled baffling ground play and aerial magic at the University of Texas today to gain a 7-7 tie with the nation's top-ranked football team.

The re-election of Mayor La Guardia last Tuesday not only assured the continuance of good government at New York's City Hall but it also strengrthened Mr. La Guardia's position in the nation and as Director of Civilian Defense.

Urging more effective cooperation in the defense program through the use of substitutes for building materials on the critical list, the Home Owners Loan Corporation has suggested to its reconditioning supervisors throughout the country the use of twenty-one types of substitutes held as suitable for repair, modernization and remodeling jobs.

Stalin Pledges Finish Fight Moscow's historic Red Square for more than a decade has been the focus of Russia's celebration of the revolution. On each 7th of November -- the day in 1917 when armed workers and soldiers of Petrograd launched the uprising that established the first Communist State -- the leaders of the U.S. S.R. have gathered atop Lenin's tomb, reviewed a mighty procession of workers, peasants, students and armed forces.

ANNIVERSARY: On Nov. 3, 1791, the Green Mountain State became the tenth to ratify the Bill of Rights, the Constitution's first ten amendments guaranteeing the country's civil liberties. Seventy-six days later the news reached Congress, assembled in New York City.

LUIS ARAGON is more philosopher than novelist, a probing mind impatient of sound architecture. There are many who can tell a story better, but few who leave so much to ponder on. His novels, often seemingly dull, keep growing in one's mind long after one has finished them.

WASHINGTON. BY rights Claude Wickard should be an individualist, an isolationist, an opponent of deficit spending, a foe of bureaucracy, a hater of high taxes and an adversary of most of the things the Roosevelt Administration advocates.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Nov. 8 -- Philip James Roosevelt, investment banker and noted yachtsman, was drowned today when his sailing dinghy capsized in Oyster Bay off his home Dolonor at Cove Neck.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Federal Communications Commission denied today a petition by the Georgia School of Technology, operator of station WGST, for the taking of the depositions of twelve witnesses in Atlanta in relation to a hearing scheduled to be held in Washington on Dec. 1 on the school's application for renewal of its license.
A spiritual armistice is needed by the world, Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein declared in West Side Institutional Synagogue, 120 West Seventy-sixth Street, yesterday.
LONDON. DESPITE the steady closing in of the blackout, the theatres that continue open are reasonably prosperous. The number of shows remains about twenty, three new ones having appeared last week.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 8 -- Scoring once in each of the first two periods and twice in the final quarter, a powerful Williams team defeated Wesleyan, 25 -- 0, today in the fiftieth renewal of their Little Three competition.

THE Rev. Joseph Fort Newton's syndicated newspaper column offers a few trenchant paragraphs of "courage, common sense and compassion (to quote the subtitle of this collection) for every day in the year. The 365 little essays here gathered into a handy little volume have many of them been written in answer to specific requests for advice; but all have a broad -- as well as a brisk -- pertinence.

The identification of the body found in the cellar of the untenanted Weber mansion proves to be far easier than Tommy Rankin has anticipated, and a little research into the antecedents of the dead man brings to light a motive for the murder and a promising suspect.

MANILA, Nov. 8 -- Admittedly without much hope of reaching a settlement with the United States, Japan's special envoy, Saburo Kurusu, flew eastward tonight while the Far East debated President Roosevelt's contemplated withdrawal of United States Marines from China.

COPENHAGEN, German-Occupied Denmark, Nov. 8 -- When Reichsfuehrer Hitler on June 22 launched his gigantic attack on Russia he declared that the greatest offensive in history had now started and that in this "crusade against bolshevism" Finland in the North and Rumania in the South had decided to join the German forces, "in defense of Western civilization."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 8 -- A contemporary oil painting of Abraham Lincoln, valued at "several thousands of dollars," is the most important single item acquired by the John Hay Library of Brown University during the last year, Dr. Henry B. Van Hoesen, university librarian, disclosed today in his annual report.
DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 8 -- Problems growing out of the emergency and the Government's defense program are absorbing the attention of builders and realty men.

THIS was a fine year in which to publish "A Subtreasury of American Humor." To the already notable list of new anthologies which have been tumbling from the presses this season, E.B. White and his wife have added another for which we gladly make room on the shelf.

With provisions for Federal taxes on income and excess profits nearly five and one-half times the amounts set aside for the purpose in the corresponding period of last year, the combined net profit of twelve steel companies in the first nine months of 1941 none the less was 29 per cent greater than a year before.

IN every spy trial there is testimony about codes, usually stolen codes. In the most recent spy trial here, however, the customary code detail cropped up in the form of a well-known novel -- the German agents were to send back information in a code system based on key words on key pages of that book.

THE Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Award, bestowed annually for distinguished services to chamber music, was received by the composers Benjamin Britten, Alexander Tansman and Randall Thompson at the recent sixteenth Founder's Day concert of the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation, held in the Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Shanghai acted today to prevent trouble coincident with the possible withdrawal of United States Marines from China and a renewed exodus of American nationals and took steps to avert rice riots.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Tennessee played only well enough to win today, entrusting to four sophomore backs the job of belaboring little Howard College, 28 to 6.

GREAT YARMOUTH, one of England's ancient seaports, situated on the dividing line between Norfolk and Suffolk where the rivers Yare, Bure and Waveney debouch in the North Sea, is the setting for a medieval romance in which love often retires to the wings while war, politics or business holds the spotlight.

THE Germans call them Schnellboote, the Italians Mas boats, the British "hornets," the Americans mosquito boats. The sailors prefer to call them suicide boats. But whatever name they go by, these daredevil little ships have already taken over many of the duties of the destroyer, a doughty warship fifty times their size.

A marked decrease in available domestic workers, discussed in various programs of women's organizations for some months past, cannot yet be directly traced to the defense industries draining off the available supply.

A SELECTED exhibition of Australian painting designed to give a comprehensive view of the progress of art in Australia from the earliest times will open to the public at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Nov. 18.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- An unusual incident highlighted a bitterly fought gridiron encounter between Columbia and Pennsylvania on sun-drenched Franklin Field today. Penn was the winner toy a 19-16 count, but they'll be talking and arguing about this one for many a day.

Next Saturday will find the deer and bear season open in the Catskills and the advance reports indicate that, while bear are not exactly abundant, except in a few small sections, the deer are plentiful and in good condition.

THE living college graduates in this country number approximately 2,700,000. This book is a statistical report, based on research conducted by Time magazine, of what its title page sums up as the "status" of these alumni and alumnae -- that is, "who they are, how and where they live, what they earn and at what work."

American Education Week comes in with emphasis on the relation of the schools to defense. On this page Dr. John W. Studebaker explains the program of the United States Office of Education with regard to the schools and colleges and civilian morale.

STRINGENT conversation has rescued the "vanishing" buffalo of the Western plains, and now protection must be extended to the bighorn sheep of the mountain ranges of the West if this animal is to be saved from extinction.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The policy of opposition to Hitler expressed in THE NEW YORK TIMES is one with which we, who fought Hitler in Spain, are in complete agreement.

BERLIN, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Germany tonight claimed a twenty-fourhour toll of fifty-one Royal Air Force planes, including twentyseven bombers destroyed last night during widespread "nuisance raids over German territory" and two separate attacks on Berlin.

Many a gardener who longs to possess a little greenhouse of his own gets along year after year doing nothing about it except some ineffective wishful thinking. Until recently the writer remained in this category. Then he decided to take action and the results have been highly satisfactory.

LONDON. THE Autumn season has begun with a spate of week-end concerts. The Albert, the Wigmore and the Central halls provide entertainment of a varied kind on Saturdays and Sundays, and even the little theatre at Cambridge Circus is now requisitioned by the music maker.

IRONY: "Distant Point," a play written six years ago by the Soviet author, Alexander Afinogenoff, has been enjoying a popular run in London's Westminster Theatre. One matinee was interrupted last week by an announcement. The 41-year-old dramatist who had written the play as a warning of military aggression had been killed in an air raid while on government duty in Moscow.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A 42-yard pass from Substitute Al Ditomo to Cliff Seaver and Tackle Hank Zajkowski's accurate placekicking enabled Temple University to come from behind to nose out Villanova, 14 to 13, in the fourteenth renewal of their football series before a crowd of 30,000 in Temple Stadium today.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Boston College continued on the comeback trail today by whipping a hardfighting but outclassed Wake Forest eleven, 26 to 6, in an intersectional game before a crowd of 15,000.
No one will deny that well-kept hands are as important to good grooming as well-kept hair and straight stocking seams, and the first step, of course, is the manicure.

FOOTBALL Navy, Army and Fordham were ousted from the ranks of the unbeaten teams and mighty Texas, leader in the national rankings, was held to a tie in a day of thrills on the gridirons. Notre Dame, led by its passing ace, Angelo Bertelli, downed Navy before a crowd of 64,795 in Baltimore. Harvard, bagging two second-half touchdowns, subdued Army before 53,000 at Cambridge. Pitt, paced by Edgar Jones, crushed Fordham.

IN a nation the popular attitude of men toward women is a revealing index of its psychological climate and probable potentialities. In those countries where the relationship between the sexes is held in respect and cherished as the basis of the home, there is a certain sanity of life and capability of individualistic achievement; where it has fallen to the mere status of an amusement, there disintegration and ultimate debacle follow.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Lawrenceville's football team was conquered decisively by the Peddie School eleven, 19 -- 0, in their annual clash today. The polished aerial attack of the Blue and Gold was the deciding factor.

The British Government's war policy is not imposed on the people but has its source in the "fierce indignation" of the great mass of the people against the threat of barbarism and slavery, Ralph Assheton, M.P., Secretary Ministry of Labor and National Defense, declared in an address here yesterday.

Police records yesterday showed that the clean-up of crime conditions in Lower Harlem, the north end of Central Park and near-by parks and streets, which was started with the assignment of 250 additional police to those districts Friday afternoon, resulted overnight in a series of arrests and a sharp decrease in the number of petty thefts and holdups, pursesnatchings, "muggings" and attacks on women and children.

Outclassing all opposition, the United States Army team last night won the Intra-American Trophy at the Fifty-sixth National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden. An excited audience or 12,000 cheered the individual performances in the international military jumping event.

LONDON. A DICTIONARY of quotations is a species of anthology. and like other anthologies, it is liable to err both by excess and by defect. Critics will always complain that it includes some things that might well have been left out and that it lacks others that should have found a place in it.
"PETAIN, allez-vous vite!" Thus the voice of "Radio Inconnu" speaks to the Vichy regime. "Get out!" they shout. "Let Frenchmen stand up for France!"

The development of some branches of income-tax law has been a slow process. After an experience of nearly three decades, the application of the principles of law governing the taxation of stock dividends is still unsettled. While the basic interpretation of a stock dividend by the United States Supreme Court remains unchanged, its adaptation to varying situations has resulted in more or less confusion.

TOKYO (By Wireless). OF the two billion people and fifty-five million square miles of this earth more than four-fifths are now directly or indirectly involved in war. In the vastness of the battlefronts, in the numbers of men and machines engaged, and in the totality of its impact on both combatants and noncombatants the present conflict already has surpassed anything the world has seen before.

WHEN the average driver learns the pocketbook-hitting provisions of the new State law on motor vehicle financial responsibility he will be stunned, then angry. The law will hurt. It is "drastic" by admission of officials.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and other members of the government, was severely criticized by T.L. Horabin M.P., speaking at Cornwall today.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Sophomore Earl Williams's foot felt like a leaden weight -- that's how numb it was from the cold -- but he lifted it as light as a ballet dancer would to boot a 35-yard field goal today.

After six hours of heated debate, punctuated by some ear-splitting blasts of the clarinet, a round-table discussion of the place of jazz in American music ended early Friday morning in a draw. Cases for each side were presented argumentatively and rhythmically, the exponents of the classic muse offering most of the forensics and the jazz men a musical rebuttal.

As the outdoor season draws to a close and the gardener, in retrospect, surveys the performance of his beds and borders during the past Summer, planning for their possible improvement, the problem of having to achieve more continuous bloom is almost sure to arise.

TO THE EDITOR: In The New York Times Magazine of Oct. 5 there was a most charming and interesting account by Catherine Mackenzie of a new experiment with gifted children of preschool age carried out at Hunter College.

Living up to their nickname of Terriers, Boston University's football team finally bowed to Manhattan at the Polo Grounds yesterday, 13 to 7, holding their rivals scoreless in the first half. B.U. rallied near the end to gain its touchdown.

PROPER lighting and spontaneity of expression are the clues to fine child portraiture, in the opinion of Maurice Games La Claire, whose exhibit of more than fifty portraits is now on view in the galleries of Carl Zeiss, Inc., 485 Fifth Avenue.

HEAT-TAPESTRY -- Electric filaments of sub-glow temperature are now interwoven with spun glass and other insulating materials on great looms. The result is a veritable "tapestry of heat," a fabric which defies destruction, which has reduced fire hazards practically to the vanishing point, which is immune to short circuits by foreign objects and moisture, and which generates more usable heat.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: IN the advertisements of Mr. Carl van Doren's important work, "The Secret History of the American Revolution," it is stated that the author is "the only writer to have" had "access to the Secret Papers of the British Headquarters."
Workers and Values Mrs. Roosevelt told a Town Hall audience that we may soon be compelled to put a ceiling over wages, "although I hate to see labor considered a commodity."

Third Term Mayor One of the brightest spots in New York on Mayoralty election night used to be the red brick building at the upper end of Union Square. Headquarters of Tammany, the structure's front fluttered with bunting, shone in the reflected brilliance of spotlights.

Lieutenant Pete Mills's Coast Guard Auxiliary has swung into action on its Winter period of instruction. What with the power squadrons and the C.G. auxiliary, the average skipper from the average yacht club on near-by waterways may have laid up his boat for the cold weather but he still can't call this "the off-season."

THE League of Composers will open its nineteenth season Dec. 7, with a concert and reception in honor of Juan Jose Castro, Argentine composer, at the Museum of Modern Art. At this event, which will carry forward the league's promotion of inter-musical relations with Latin America, Mr. Castro will appear as pianist in a program of his own works.

"Floral Adventures in the Pine Barrens" will be the subject of the free lecture Saturday at 3 P.M. at the New York Botanical Garden. John Gill, lecturer, of Haddonfield, N.J., will be introduced by Mrs. Allan Marquand. Mr. Gill has for many years made a study of the New Jersey Pine Barrens.

PRESSURE of world politics has apparently sidetracked a move by the Japanese Government to tender belated honor to Lafcadio Hearn. This tribute is to be a literary shrine in New Orleans, where the eccentric writer spent many years before making Japan his adopted country.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 -- Exploding twice in the first period, Stanford University's vaunted touchdown machine swept over Southern California and on along the road to the Rose Bowl today.

THE idea of home-made and handmade Christmas presents appeals to a lot of people, but when it comes actually to doing the work there is likely to be a slight block, because most of us can remember with horror the battered, lopsided things we use to make as children to foist on grimly appreciative adults.

LINKLATER'S autobiography is much his best book, as it has a right to be. He has led a lively, roving and adventurous life, often wild, always merry, in the rather serious way that Scotsmen take their merriment.

ROBERT GESSNER'S new novel begins with the Eighties, when the Statue of Liberty had just been erected, when women wore bustles, and in the Middle West fortunes were made and lost as the virgin timber that had stood so thick it counted a million feet to forty acres receded like "a shore submerging under the persistent attacks of the tide."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -- Anti-labor prejudices, carelessness and "tortured reasoning" were attributed today to Judge Charles B. Sears in a brief supporting the appeal of Harry R. Bridges, West Coast longshoremen's leader, from Judge Sears's recommendation that he be deported.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Administration leaders decided today to press for a direct final House vote on the Senate's amendments to the Neutrality Bill not later than Thursday.

KUIBISHEV, Nov. 8 -- Russia's traditional ally, General Winter, is slowly moving into action. The Russian Winter is one of the favorite subjects of this country's songs, poetry and painting -- and well it might be. For at least five months every year the major part of the country is blanketed in snow and the peasant's activity is limited to feeding the livestock, talking, singing, drinking, hunting and protecting their cattle from foraging wolves.

NOW for the big fellows, the Great Big Bears, the Detroit Lions, Johnny Mara's Giants, the dashing Dodgers, the Washing-Done Redskins and other ponderous patrols of the paid postgraduate gridiron. There came a letter from Billy Evans of baseball fame the other day. The ex-arbiter is now connected with the Cleveland Rams of the National Football League and his letter was not overflowing with joy.

When 14-year-old Johnnie Tanner's father came home from six years of fortune hunting he brought with him one of those new Colt revolvers just coming on the market. He explained its mechanism very carefully to the boy, and the next day when Johnnie was playing with it in the back yard it was snatched from his hand by Pawnee Harry.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 8 (AP) -- An unbeaten Mississippi State football team reasserted its challenge for the Southeastern Conference championship today, defeating Auburn, 14 to 7, before 11,000 chilled spectators.

How business confidence expressed in trade credit has developed through the instrumentality of a variety of institutions from the founding of this country to the present day so that today the amount of actual cash used in daily commercial transactions is probably smaller than it was a hundred years ago is told in "The Sinews of American Commerce," a book published last week by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., to mark its 100th anniversary.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 8 -- A. Platt Valley farmer watched a golden ribbon of corn flow upward on the mechanical elevator from the wagon box to the top of the corn crib. Evidently the elevator suggested something to him, for he blurted out with some vehemence:

MEXICO CITY -- "Tell her that I love her." The young Mexican leans closer to the typist and watches the keys fill half a page of what is to him unintelligible print. "What else?" the typist asks. "Tell her how I miss her."

Not only increase of the police force in Harlem but more teachers, recreation facilities and social service workers to "check crime at its source" were advocated yesterday by the New York Teachers Guild, Local 2, American Federation of Teachers.

A RADIO assignment of twenty concerts has been booked for the Cleveland Orchestra. Beginning Dec. 6 the musical organization will be heard Saturday afternoons from 5 to 6 through April 18 over WABC and affiliated stations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Edward C. Eicher, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that the commission was speeding the geographic integration of public utility holding companies to facilitate the interconnection of "islands" of power for defense purposes.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 8 -- Civilian defense in Cleveland has taken a great step forward this week with the formation of a centralized employment service for all hospitals in the city under the auspices of Western Reserve University.

MIAMI, Ma. -- A Berlin dispatch on Page One of THE NEW YOKK TIMES last week stated that "for the first time in this war the German public was informed tonight that American fliers were participating in the air war against Germany."
MOSCOW, Nov. 8 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today after a week of irregular declines which reflected increased receipts in all departments and weakening structure of wholesale dressed-meat quotations. A big run of cattle, hogs and sheep was the principal depressing factor, although government purchases of lard and pork helped to steady hogs in some cases.

LENOX, Mass., Nov. 8 -- Giraud Foster celebrated his ninety-first birthday tonight with a dinner party for fifty-two guests at Bellefontaine, Lenox, where he has observed his birthday annually for forty-three years. The tables set in the oak-paneled dining and breakfast rooms were decorated with bronze chrysanthemums, Mr. Foster's favorite variety.

Tchaikovsky: Concerto No. 1, in B flat minor. Vladimir Horowitz, Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra. (Victor, four twelve-inch records, $4.50.) Here is the album that many people have been waiting for. Or has the ubiquitous jazz version of excerpts from this concerto filled every one to satiety?

MONTREAL, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Chicago's Black Hawks battled from behind a 2-0 deficit tonight to gain a 2-2 deadlock with Montreal. Goals by Joe Cooper and Mush March in the third period put the Hawks back on even terms, after Rod Lorrain and Bunny Dame had scored for the Canadiens.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force issued the following communique today:

CHARLES MORGAN has never written for the running reader. Always before now his novels have been longer than the average work of serious fiction, and have made certain inescapable demands upon his audience.

WHEN Tony and Ruth, chance-met companions on a train and both of them winners of a trip to New York in the Fruity Cereal Company contest, arrived in Grand Central Station a day ahead of schedule they were not in the least dismayed until the sinister gleam in the one eye of a mysterious old man who seemed bent on following them filled them with a delicious terror of kidnappers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The capital is thinking more about war this week-end than at any time since the start of the conflict. In the past seven days the sinking of the Reuben James has brought home to the country one consequence of an "undeclared sea war" such as the "shoot on sight" order inaugurated.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 8 -- Lehigh dropped a thriller to Muhlenberg today in the thirty-first renewal of the second oldest football series on the Engineers' schedule, losing to the neighboring' rivals by 7-2.

PRIZE winners in the first annual Bronx Zoo and Aqua- rium newspaper photographers' contest are announced by the Bronx Zoo, as follows: Published pictures: Henry W. McAllister, New York Journal and American, first prize, $150; Arthur Sasse, International News Photos, second prize, $100, and third, $50.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: Your correspondent, Manet Fowler, voiced too much distress in the letter you published Oct. 19 last. He used more than 600 words to take exception to the use of one little word, "decent," by Professor Montenegro.

Money in circulation may reach the unprecendented level of $11,000,000,000 in this year's holiday buying season. Huge payrolls of defense industries and the higher levels of prices are important factors now, whereas in recent years the factor of hoarding, foreign and domestic, figured importantly.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 7:

AUDUBON, N.J., Nov. 8 -- A new mutual method of home buying, whereby the tenant purchases not his own dwelling but an equity in a whole town, was nearly ready today for its first test at Audubon Park under the sponsorship of the Federal government.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The time is now coming again when the Atlantic Ocean will do battle itself against craft of all kinds that are today striving for the mastery of its traffic lanes. With the advent of heavy weather, men and ships will be forced to combat the adverse elements as well as one another in the long haul to survival.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 8 -- In the wildest scoring contest ever witnessed in the big Buckeye Stadium, Ohio State defeated Wisconsin, 46 to 34, today before 58,519 shivering fans to take third place in the Western Conference championship.

EDINBURGH. NEIL GUNN has been mentioned more than once in these letters from Scotland. His first novel, "Morning Tide," was an extremely moving impressionist picture of the herring fishing of the Northeast of Scotland, as seen through the eyes of a boy.

Threats of a strike by the operating trainmen weakened the stock market yesterday and speculative railway shares eased a trifle, setting the tone for the remainder of the list on the Stock Exchange. The close, however, was firm. Trading held about the same pace as that of the previous Saturday, somewhat higher because of the turnover of low-priced shares for tax purposes.

U.S. Commissioner of Education Basic to sound civilian morale in a democracy is public understanding. America's schools, colleges and libraries, therefore, have a vital part to play in developing civilian morale soundly based on an understanding of the nature of the present struggle against totalitarianism and of the problems which face us as a people in our resolve to defend democracy against all threats, foreign or domestic.

THIS is a story of contemporary life in the upper income brackets of a Southern city, which the author calls Seminole, but which closely resembles Birmingham, Ala. The "Whitney" of the title is an iron and steel magnate who, as the novel begins, is returning to his family after four years in New York spent with an attractive and adoring mistress.

MR. MALONEYS "odyssey" over the battlefields of Europe prompts one thought that might be worth mentioning after twenty-six months of war: As a relatively untroubled and secure people we have failed in this country even to visualize, much less to feel deeply, the human misery we have not had to witness.

Many people say that flowers do not behave. As a matter of fact, it is not they but those who attempt to arrange them who do not behave. Just as there are all kinds of people, so are there all kinds of flowers. Like human beings they want care and attention, and respond to kind treatment.

A drive to collect scrap metals for defense, which is being conducted by women of Greenville in Westchester County, took on added speed last week as a plan to make such collections popular nationally was announced by the OPM. Heading the local drive is Mrs. Adam K. Geiger, who, as chairman of the Materials Conservation Committee, has distributed circulars on the campaign this Fall to more than 800 families in the town of Greenburg.

TOKYO, Nov. 8 -- The Foreign Office announced today that it had lodged a strong protest with the Government of Panama against allegedly discriminatory and "in- human" acts designed to drive Japanese residents from areas close to the Panama Canal by depriving them of their livelihood.

At least one corner of the veil thrown over the Allied counter-offensive against German submarines has been lifted by the British Admiralty. It announces that the British Navy up to date has captured 1,276 officers and men from Axis U-boats. Of these, 809 are Germans and 476 Italians.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The following foreign service changes since Nov. 1 were released by the State Department today:
Scoring in every period but the second, Massachusetts State defeated the Brooklyn College eleven, 33 -- 19, yesterday before 1,500 fans at the Bedford Avenue Field.

EAST NORWICH, L.I., Nov. 8 -- Hare hunting, a sport popular for several years in the society colonies of the North Shore, has become a major activity with the opening of this season, and the field of the Buckram Beagles, one of the best known foot-beagling organizations in the East, has grown to a point that makes seventyfive to one hundred members the usual number to be counted at the start.
AMHERST, Nov. 8 -- Undefeated Trinity proved too strong for the Lord Jeffs of Amherst today, stemming three last-quarter scoring drives to win, 13 -- 8.

Had Germany's invasion of Russia been postponed only a few years, its success might have been impossible from the outset. By that time the Soviet might have had enormously powerful centers of military supply production in full operation behind the Ural Mountains, set safely amid the resources of Siberia.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 8 -- Alabama's Crimson Tide came charging from behind with offensive power at the crucial time today to score twice in the final half and beat Tulane's slightly-favored Green Wave, 19-14. It left 'Bama in the Bowl picture.

MR. WILLIAM McFEE is a distinguished novelist who may be always expected to gratify any reader who loves a good story, well told. In this new novel he does not disappoint us. On the contrary, never has his competent craftsmanship been employed to better effect.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 8 -- Lafayette surprised a favored Rutgers eleven today, handing the Scarlet a stunning 16-to-0 setback. After a first-period ground-devouring drive that gained seventy-eight yards without a break, the Rutgers attack lost its power and was completely bottled up for the remainder of the game.

WAR of manoeuvre, the current darling of the military mind, has been aptly described by Charles F. Kettering of General Motors as "plain, old ordinary horsepower." Call it Blitzkrieg, call it anything, it's still a war depending upon horsepower.

TORONTO -- First uniformed military organisation for women in this hemisphere is the Canadian Women's Auxiliary Air Force, whose 2,000 women will release men for "operational activities" with the Royal Canadian Air Force.

The establishment of the Illinois Institute of Technology through the consolidation of two of Chicago's oldest educational institutions provides an opportunity to evolve an efficiently functional type of modern architecture in planning a campus for the great technological center which is to serve the vast industrial region of the Midwest.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The University of Cincinnati Bearcats pounded and passed their way to an easy 20-to-0 victory over Carnegie Tech's Tartans today before a home-coming crowd of 6,000.

Citing instances of disorderliness among public school pupils in Harlem and other "decaying neighborhoods," several teachers attending the third annual educational conference of the Teachers Alliance at the Hotel Astor yesterday called for sterner disciplinary measures, including the power to impose corporal punishment.

Supplementing reading and lectures for engineers taking courses in the arts and social sciences, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has established a changing exhibition of the tools and materials of artistic expression in the Humanities Reading Room at Cooper Union.

Fight for Freedom, Inc., announced yesterday that Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt and seven other prominent Americans who were identified with the Finnish War Relief Fund Campaign in 1939-40 had said in answer to telegraphed queries that they disagreed with Herbert Hoover's present stand and backed Secretary of State Hull's demand for an end to the Finnish-Russian war.

A SHOW of sculpture by Jose de Creeft is an event in the New York art world. The current show at Georgette Passedoit's is small -- only ten pieces with an additional group of little terra cotta figures. But the large head in lead -- a me- dium de Creeft has made peculiar- ly and expressively his own -- and a figure in green serpentine are certainly in the sculptor's best manner.

IN 1925 the author, a 14-year-old Hungarian boy, matriculated at an upper East Side Manhattan high school. Born and brought up in Budapest, Edward Newhouse had entered the United States only two years before, but with the adaptability of adolescence he soon found himself at home in his adopted country.

SERVICE of mail from the United States to Occupied France has been suspended, except to prisoners of war and interned civilians. Mail for Unoccupied France is accepted; delivery is made possible by steamers of the American Export Line or clippers of Pan American Airways.

BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- The first account of the damage done to the great Soviet dam at Dniepropetrovsk by the retreating Red Army three months ago reports that a cavity 600 feet wide and sixty feet deep was blown in the dam when several tons of explosive were buried in it and set off by the Russians.

VERBANK, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Superlative work in the first series and a workmanlike job in the second were needed to take first place in the open all-age stake for cocker spaniels at the annual trials of the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America today.
WHEN young Mrs. Average Housewife sets out to weigh herself it's a comparatively simple matter -- a step onto the scale platform, a penny in the slot -- and there's a neat 116 or 120 pounds.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Dartmouth and Princeton handled their game today as gingerly as if it were a time bomb about to explode. But as soon as they discovered how harmless it was, both wanted it, and wanted it badly.

Department store sales in the New York area last week were estimated at 6 per cent above a year ago. Men's wear sales were slow, due to the warm weather. Topcoat stocks were reported as heavy. The first week of overcoat promotions was poor.
LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

Envoy from Tokyo A mustached, bespectacled, 55-yearold Japanese set out from Tokyo last week on a long journey. By plane and steamer he traveled to Hong Kong. There he changed to a Clipper for a flight over the Pacific. He was bound for Washington, D.C.
A new departure in department store merchandising will be introduced this week by Gimbel Brothers in the form of a public auction gallery for the sale of works of art.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: Not long ago, in your columns, Mr. DeCasseres complained that Elbert Hubbard bought from him sundry gems of thought, one of which is: "Throw your medals away -- only your scars count." This Hubbard garbled into: "God will not look you over for medals, degrees or diplomas, but for scars."

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity recovered further last week with a gain of 0.7 point. It stood at 127.6 for the week ended Nov. 1, compared with 126.9 (revised) for the week ended Sept. 25 and 113.6 for the week ended Nov. 2, 1940.

DAVIDSON, N.C., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Duke's Blue Devils, defending a perfect record for the 1941 football season, overpowered Davidson, 56 -- 0, today in a Southern Conference football game before 10,000 spectators.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Mrs. Edith P. Welty, incumbent endorsed by the City Manager League, and two other City Manager League candidates were among the live elected to the Yonkers Common Council with the completion tonight of the tallying of ballots under the Proportional Representation system.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Attorney General Biddle asked the House Judiciary Committee today to impeach J. Warren Davis, retired judge of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

TOKYO, Nov. 8 -- At the moment when war clouds over the Pacific began to look darkest, when even the stoutest optimists began to throw up their hands, the Tojo Government, which was greeted with such apprehension throughout the world, dispatched Saburo Kurusu to Washington to facilitate an amicable settlement between the United States and Japan.

IF it is true that the average Hollywood script writer resembles a slightly dissipated polo player, wears sports jackets of a design and hue to stun the eye at twenty blocks, and talks like a high-powered vacuum sweeper salesman, then save a separate niche for Casey Robinson.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Samuel Camarota, 46 years old, object of a search since last May as a key witness in the Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson case, was released in $10,000 bail today after being arrested a few hours earlier by a Federal agent at Fort Lee.

When the outlaw Dev Hewett was killed by a rancher, he tried to bushwhack, he left a 3-year-old motherless boy, Everett. That same night the prospector. Warren Alien and his wife, were murdered in their covered wagon, and they, too, left a small boy, called Hap.

A Masonic funeral service, attended by close friends, was held yesterday afternoon for William Sulzer, who held public office for many years, culminating in his impeachment and his removal as Governor of the State in 1913, in his home at 118 Washington Place.

FOR many years military aircraft have been more or less roughly divided into bombardment and pursuit categories. Now there is a tendency to subdivide those general groups, aiming always for greater specialization.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Officials of the Board of Trade at a special meeting early this morning adopted a resolution ordering that the permissible limit on fluctuations on grain and soy bean futures be reduced immediately to comply with an over-night request from Secretary of Agriculture Wickard.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 8 -- An underdog Penn State team throttled the vaunted Syracuse Y formation and unleashed surprising offensive strength to score a 34-19 upset triumph before a fraternity house party crowd of 16,000 today.

PITTSBURGH -- Old Economy, the religious Utopia which flourished near Pittsburgh a century ago, is to be restored by the Pennsylvania Historical Commission and preserved as a memorial to the ascetic pioneers "who fixed their eyes on heaven and built paradise on earth."

Leslie MacMitchell, New York University's ace runner, who has never been beaten in cross-country, led the Violet to a runaway 15-40 victory over Rutgers' harriers yesterday in a dual meet over the five-mile course in Van Cortlandt Park.

COOKERY lately has become such a popular avocation, and has secured such a large army of enthusiastic amateur practitioners, that a publisher may devote an entire book now to a single dish, or to the various ways of preparing a single viand, and still make a profit.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 -- Charles Frederick (Doc) Seeley, Professor Emeritus of Physical Education at Williams College, died today at the Wellesley Farms home of his daughter, Mrs. Lewis F. Pike, at the age of 77. For forty-one years he was director of athletics at Williams College, retiring in 1934.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Five hundred and nineteen additions to and fifty-nine deletions from this country's blacklist of Latin-American firms and individuals believed to be acting in the interest of Germany and Italy were announced today by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, in the third supplement to the list originally proclaimed by President Roosevelt on July 17.
VICHY, France, Nov. 9 -- Three laws printed today in the Journal Officiel give satisfaction to the Catholic hierarchy in the matter of financial grants to church schools of the primary grade.
