As the fifth volume in its series of books dealing with the careers of outstanding contemporary American artists, the American Artists Group will issue on Dec. 1 "Thus Far," the autobiography of Harry Wickey, the sculptor and etcher.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Defense of the nation will be the chief subject under consideration when the board of directors of the League of Women Voters meets here tomorrow for a week-long session looking to formulation of the organization's program for next year.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- More than a dozen titled English women, representing England's oldest and most aristocratic families, are working eleven hours a day in tank, aircraft and amunitions factories alongside shop girls, stenographers and milliners.

Universal sacrifice and an aggressive determination to preserve our rights and liberties is a debt we owe this country, the Rev. Ignatius Smith, dean of the School of Philosophy of the Catholic University, Washington, declared in an address yesterday morning.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 -- With several steel units last week having reported some curtailment due to lack of scrap supplies, the outlook for the immediate future continues to be clouded with uncertainty, especially in view of the advent of colder weather, accompanied by snow in some sections of the country.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Jack Sutphen, sailing an unnamed boat formerly owned by Chick Rollins, won Class B honors as an abbreviated racing program in the Fall dinghy series was held off the Larchmont Yacht Club today. Class X boats did not participate, since they were competing at Essex, Conn., and only two races were held in the other classes because of rain.

Christians and the church are judged according to their works of faith, not merely their profession of it, the Rev. Dr. Wilbert W. White of Silver Bay, Lake George, N.Y., founder and president emeritus of the Biblical Seminary, declared yesterday in his morning sermon at the West Forty-fourth Street United Presbyterian Church, 432 West Forty-fourth Street.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Nov. 9 -- The security markets in the small Continental European countries displayed again last week a rather uniform trend, largely guided by the factors that jointly rule Continental economy and finances under war conditions.

WINDINGSTAIR GAP, Ga., Nov. 9 -- Forty hunters bent on bagging deer with bow and arrow will set out from here at the crack of dawn Tuesday. If they can get within range of a few of the thousand head of deer roaming the Chattahoochee National Forest, there will be some new hatracks decorating walls hereabouts, they say.

Members of the Tammany executive committee are being canvassed in attempts to learn how they stand on the proposed ousting of Christopher D. Sullivan as leader and on abandonment of the name of Tammany for the New York County Democratic organization.

An amendment filed on Saturday with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Hiram Walker-Gooderman and Worts, Ltd., and Hiram Walker Sons, Inc., `in connection with their proposed issuance of $15,000,000 of serial debentures as joint and several obligations of the two companies, listed twenty-eight underwriters of the securities.

CHESTER, S.C., Nov. 9 (AP) -- A three-day mock battle beginning tomorrow in the Fourth Army Corps manoeuvre area is designed to determine how well an entire armored corps will function with the "rolling" Fourth Division, recently motorized.

If the United States and world democracy are to emerge victorious from the struggle with totalitarianism, the American people will have to stop thinking in terms of "business as usual" and labor will have to abandon the policy of "strikes as usual," Sidney Hillman, Associate Director General of the Office of Production Management, declared last night at a dinner in honor of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevent in the Hotel Commodore.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 (AP) -- A 12,500-ton ocean-going tanker, said to be the first of its size in the nation to be partly constructed while afloat, will cruise down the Hudson River Tuesday headed for sea trials before going to Buenos Aires.

Cotton prices moved within a narrow range last week in quiet trading. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the week net gains of 14 to 19 points, while in the previous week they had losses of 15 to 36 points.

Although Pauline Lord is a great actress, she does not have much luck with plays. "The Walrus and the Carpenter," which was acted at the Cort on Saturday evening, is no exception. It is a harum-scarum comedy by A.N. Langley, author of the macabre "Farm of Three Echoes," in which Ethel Barrymore pretended to be as old as the hills two seasons ago.

The Investment Bankers Association has questioned the legality of the purchase by three insurance companies of $90,000,000 of bonds of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company at competitive bidding on Sept. 29, it was disclosed yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, to whom the brokers' complaint was addressed.

The duck-hunting picture, from the Connecticut, Long Island and New Jersey perspectives, is showing an improvement, but until the temperatures drop below the 30-degree line on the thermometer the average gunner is going to find the shooting more comfortable than productive.

A civilian defense council has been formed at Columbia University to devise measures for protection of its huge educational plant on Morningside Heights from sabotage and enemy air raids, it was announced yesterday by Provost Frank D. Fackenthal, chairman of the university committee on national defense.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The steady rise in the circulation of the Bank of England continues to excite comment among economists and others who are showing growing concern over the problem, which appears to defy solution. Last week's increase of L6,622,000 brings the total to a new peak of L699,949,000.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- The liquidation of industrial plants in invaded Russian territory by selling them to German and other private interests might offset a sizable part of the Reich's war expenditure. This remarkable suggestion was made last week in the German financial press, which disclosed that negotiations with German business groups concerning the sale of Soviet mines and factories were already in progress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The sixteen States which, own and operate alcoholic beverage monopolies take in an annual gross revenue of more than $264,500,000 and a profit of more than $58,000,000, the Census Bureau announced today.

Armistice Day services will be held in many churches of the city tomorrow and most of the others will be open all day for silent prayer. Prayers will be offered that "a just and righteous peace may come" and for all our men in service.

Arturo Toscanini will conduct Beethoven's "Missa Solemnis" and all of the nine symphonies during his two week post-season engagement with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, it was announced yesterday. He will give six concerts altogether and all will be devoted to Beethoven.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Nov. 5, "Coercing the Government," contains statements regarding the Federation of Long Lines Telephone Workers which, as counsel to the federation, I am sure would not have been made had you been familiar with all the facts.

VICHY, Nov. 9 -- Restrictions imposed on dealings on the Lyons Bourse are preventing a rise in prices and business is virtually paralyzed. The number of securities which cannot be listed under the rules is increasing constantly. This does not so much result from the excessive number of demands, but rather from the paucity of offers.

Reconstruction of the Isaac L. Rice Memorial Park section of Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx, has been completed, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks. The sixty-acre area, according to the department's announcement, has the many advantages of waterfront location as well as proximity to residential areas and accessibility by rapid transit, bus and automobile.

VICHY, Nov. 9 -- The new French Labor Charter has been the subject of numerous comments in the press. It has formed also the topic of official declarations by three different Ministers. All insist on the social character of the law.

The current letdown in retail sales may bring about an increase in retail advertising, as stores strive to keep their figures above those of last year. Since the start of the year, the increase in retail and department store copy has been far below that of sales.
WASHINGTTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Court may rule tomorrow on long-pending litigation involving the right to publish comment on court cases prior to a final settlement.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The stock markets last week continued to display a resiliency which, however, was unmatched by volume of business except in a few speculative groups, among which South American securities have taken a vigorous lead.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Nov. 10 -- The Russians reported in a communique this morning that the Germans had made their major effort yesterday against Red Army positions in Crimea, but other late reports from Moscow indicated that the importance of operations on the capital's defense line could not be overlooked.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 9 -- The dog that had been named best in the Golden Jubilee Show at Boston a week ago did it again today, this time on a lesser scale, when he came through in the seventh Specialty Show of the Newark Boston Terrier Club at the Robert Treat Hotel.

Eleanor Fine, 15-year-old pianist of this city, made her debut yesterday afternoon in a recital given at Town Hall before a capacity audience. Miss Fine's progress in her art will be watched with keen interest, for she divulged a highly developed, carefully schooled technique.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 9 -- With profiteering and hoarding forcing up the prices of necessary commodities to a greater extent than at any time in past history, despite the Shanghai Municipal Council's efforts at control, fuel and food riots are widely expected here.

GOSPORT, England, Nov. 9 -- A woman sat in the parlor of her home here tonight knitting a jumper. At 9 P.M. she turned on the radio for the news and heard that the British had wiped out an Italian convoy in the Mediterranean.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Duquesne battered the St. Mary's football team today to score a 9-to-0 victory and remain one of the four major unbeaten and untied college teams of the country.

Gregory Rice, America's long-distance running champion for the last two years, and Joseph Smith, a comparative unknown to marathon running, yesterday won the National A.A.U. championships held under the auspices of the Chippewa Club and the New York A.C. at the Empire City Race Track in Yonkers.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 9 -- Maxim M. Litvinoff will leave here for Washington tomorrow to assume his new post as Soviet Ambassador, accompanied by Ambassador Laurence A. Steinhardt, who is returning to the United States on leave and for consultation with President Roosevelt and the State Department.

Activity in the apparel market continued fair last week. More interest was shown in formal wear. Reorders continued to be placed on high shade wools and dressy black crepes. Casual dresses were purchased for resort wear. Orders for coats stressed sports types.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 9 -- Axis merchantmen in the Central Mediterranean were bombed twice by British planes yesterday, a communique of Royal Air Force Middle Blast Headquarters said today. In the first attack one ship was struck and left settling, with smoke pouring from her stern.
Dedication services were held yesterday at the new interdenominational chapels at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn and at Camp Upton, near Patchogue, L.I.

Last week's stock market, after a brief recovery, declined and, at the week-end, touched the lowest average since May, when air raids on London were at their worst. It was not unfavorable war news which depressed the market; on the whole, developments at the Russian front were favorable.

Three thousand Catholic War Veterans of America and members of its Ladies Auxiliary, who marched in Fifth Avenue to St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday for their seventh annual armistice memorial mass, heard the Rev. Edmund A. Walsh, vice president of Georgetown University and regent of the School of Foreign Service, denounce a "whispering campaign of innuendoes" that the Catholic Church is the "secret friend" of nazism and fascism because she condemns communism.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- The High Command today reported the capture of Yalta on the Crimean coast and other Nazi sources said German troops barely thirty miles from Moscow had penetrated and rolled up a Russian defense sector, capturing eighty stoutly defended bunkers.

Seven new films will arrive this week on Broadway, starting with the premiere tonight at Loew's Criterion of "International Lady," starring Ilona Massey with George Brent and Basil Rathbone under the direction of Tim Whelan. Miss Massey will attend the opening, accompanied by her husband, Alan Curtis, the actor.

The National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers has invited all New York hosiery executives and selling agents to a luncheon-conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Friday. Industry problems will be discussed.

In a letter from Mr. Maurice P. Davidson of the State Power Authority, which we publish on this page, the case for St. Lawrence power is presented as convincingly as it can be. We agree with Mr. Davidson that we need power at this juncture. But is the St. Lawrence the only source on which we can draw, particularly at a time when months are precious?

The official count of first-choice ballots for candidates for the City Council from Manhattan and Queens will be finished this morning, and a start will be made on a second count and the appropriate transfer of second-choice votes under the proportional representation system, it was indicated last night.

We give allegiance to the hearty-breakfast school-of-thought. Breakfast, in fact, is our favorite meal. There are those who, morning in and morning out, confine themselves to sipping orange juice and black coffee and nibbling on brittle toast. We can only shake our head in bewilderment -- we demand sturdier fare.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- That part of Reichfuehrer Hitler's latest speech which referred to President Roosevelt and the United States is seen by neutral observers here as a "last word" to the House of Representatives before it sits down to consider the further abrogations in the text of the American Neutrality Law approved by the Senate.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 9 -- The "crash-conditioning" of Britain's shell-shocked Blitzkrieg victims by subjecting them to additional noise was described today to members of the Southern Medical Association.

Why "Indian" Summer? Indian Summer is apt to be associated with the end of October or early November; but, as a matter of fact, it may occur at any time in the early or late Autumn, after the first frost and the brief cold spell which immediately follows the end of Summer.

Twenty-five hundred persons were present in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon as the drive for $110,000, for the Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society to mark its 110th year was started at a special service in connection with the regular evening prayer.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -- Lewis Milestone, film director, and Joris Ivens, producer of such documentaries as "Rain" and "Power and the Land," have began work on a new documentary dealing with the Russo-German war and Russian activities behind the lines.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- While speculative interest in the grain markets remains well below normal, prices were on the upgrade last week, with buying stimulated by prospects that Russia might purchase both wheat and rye from North America, and also a steadfast belief that if Congress places a ceiling on agricultural products by a price-control bill it will be sufficiently high to permit a further upturn in the markets.

In recognition of "heroic acts committed at great personal risk not in the line of duty," five members of the Department of Sanitation will receive the department's medals of valor from Mayor La Guardia on the steps of City Hall at 12:15 P.M. on Wednesday.

KENTON, Ohio, Nov. 9 -- Roaring through the night, the Pennsylvania Railroad's fast "Pennsylvanian" passenger train was wrecked near Dunkirk tonight. Nine persons were known dead. About sixty-five were injured.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- The execution of twenty members of an alleged Czech arson gang for setting fires endangering food stores in the Vienna area was reported today. D. N. B., the official news agency, said Heinrich Himmler, chief of the Gestapo, announced that the Czechs were shot Thursday after having been seized by the Vienna secret police.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Continued wet weather over the main surplus corn-producing areas is delaying the movement of the new crop and has become an important market influence. Not only has an excellent demand developed from the East, but the cash grain has been advancing rapidly.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices advanced from 98.3 to 98.6. There were no price changes in individual commodities of more than minor proportions during the week. In the farm products group, rises in grains, cottonseed oil, lard, potatoes, apples and wool slightly outweighed declines in livestock and oranges.

ROME, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Pope Pius in a broadcast today to Chile's National Eucharistic Congress at Santiago expressed hopes for world peace and preservation of Chile's religious faith against "false doctrines, immorality, disbelief and reborn paganism."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Strategic materials valued at many millions have been made available to the nation's defense program through seizure by the Treasury's Division of Foreign Funds Control of supplies held for "blocked" foreign interests in this country, the Treasury Department announced today.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Ignoring heavy plane losses in the preceding twenty-four hours, the Royal Air Force bombed Germany heavily again last night in a stepped-up air offensive regarded in some quarters as Britain's answer to persistent demands for a second front.

The annual Hope Farm Christmas sale and tea, of which Miss Beatrice L. Renwick is chairman of the junior committee, will take place on Wednesday and Thursday at the Pierre. This widely known philanthropic project supports the Greer School in Dutchess County, a community of 200 children whose parents are unable to provide for them.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- Following is the text of the article in the magazine Reich by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels, in which he warns the German people that they face an "inferno" if they lose the "hard" war ahead. [A dispatch, summarizing the article appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Friday.]

Despite the intensive police drive against crime in Harlem, the northern section of Central Park, and its adjacent areas, a burglar succeeded in breaking into an apartment directly across the hall from that of Mayor La Guardia on the sixth floor of 1274 Fifth Avenue, between 108th and 109th Streets, about 4 o'clock yesterday morning.

LINDEN, N.J., Nov. 9 -- Striking employes of the Linden Automobile Assembly Division of the General Motors Corporation continued to picket the sixty-acre plant here today as George Cranmore, international representative of the United Automobile Workers of America, C.I.O., announced that steps toward a conference with the management are expected to be taken this week.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Middle East Command of the Royal Air Force issued this communique today:
A flawless performance by Captain Marshall W. Frame on Dakota accounted for the $1,000 international military jumping stake at the fifty-sixth National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden last night.

The national referendum on Rumanian foreign and home policies decreed by Premier General Ion Antonescu was held yesterday, according to a German Transocean broadcast recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, but any one who wanted to express disapproval of his collaboration with the Nazis had to declare his intention to the authorities.

It is of immense importance to British and American interests that Russia stay in the war. As long as the Red Army remains an active fighting force the Nazi Wehrmacht will be too busy to undertake decisive action against the British Isles, and so long as that bastion of freedom remains intact Adolf Hitler can neither end nor win the war he started.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 9 -- In the face of a new warning that the Navy could "tolerate no delay in its vital San Diego construction program," the A. F. L. Building Trades Council went ahead today with its plan for a general strike tomorrow on defense construction projects in this county to enforce a demand for higher wages.

FORT LAWN, S. C., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Four soldiers were burned to death and twelve others injured seriously in a collision of two Army trucks near here early today. One of the injured was not expected to survive.

A growing spirit of internationalism in the United States that recognizes the brotherhood of man and the interdependability of nations was noted with satisfaction by the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, in his sermon yesterday morning at Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 9 -- In a fifteen-minute ceremony today Mme. Chiang Kai-shek and Mme. H.H. Kung presented two pandas, the thirteenth and fourteenth ever reported captured, one each to the United China Relief Organization in the United States and the Bronx Zoo of New York City.

SUVA, Fiji Islands, Monday, Nov. 10 -- This strategic island outpost, a British headquarters in the South Pacific, was tied into the expanding network of airlines linking the United States and the Orient by the arrival here today of Pan American Airways' Pacific Clipper, with Captain J.H. Tilton in command.
Representatives of the United States Free France and Great Britain will speak at an Armistice Day rally sponsored by France Forever at 8:30 P.M. tomorrow at Manhattan Center.
The League of Women Voters of New York City made public yesterday correspondence requesting the Rapp-Coudert committee to extend its inquiry by investigating administrative costs in the city schools.

WHAT a lovely Saturday that was! Mourners are still going over the field picking up parts of the wreckage. Well, it had to come. The season had been going along too smoothly. That couldn't last. It might be cricket, but it wouldn't be football if it did.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Two Italian convoys comprising ten merchant ships were wiped out at the same time in the Central Mediterranean early today when a British naval force routed a superior enemy squadron "in brilliant and determined action," the Admiralty announced tonight.

An airway swung between three continents and across an ocean will be placed in operation today to establish a link of transport and communications with the continent of Africa, which the President of the United States, scarcely two months ago, described as being of "inestimable importance."

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 1 -- A contract for the purchase of 60,000 barrels monthly of crude oil produced in the newly discovered Ganso Azul concession east of the Andes Mountains, in Peru, has been entered into with a representative of the Sociedad Nacional de Commercio y Transportes of Rio de Janeiro.

VERBANK, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Flight of Falcon Hill, owned and handled by Robert McLean of Fort Washington, Pa., was declared the winner today of the open all-age stake for English springer spaniels, concluding event of the annual three-day meeting of the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Nov. 9 -- Port Monmouth's well-drilled Signal Corps eleven moved a step nearer the Second Corps Area football championship today by defeating the team from Carlisle Barracks, the Army Medical School at Carlisle, Pa., 27 to 0.
Society was well represented in the boxes at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night, a gala performance with the vast audience applauding the military thrills in the ring.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- As battle lines took shape today for the House debate Wednesday and Thursday on approval of the Senate measure to arm merchant vessels and permit their sailing to beligerent ports through combat zones, Representative Fish, Republican, of New York, said that if the opposition won sixty-five Democratic votes, "this war measure will be defeated, and I think we will get them."
"I have commanded German ships, whenever they see Americans, not to shoot thereupon but to defend themselves as soon as they are attacked."
Vanity of vanities... all is vanity and vexation of spirit.
CAMDEN, S.C., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Overcoat weather hit the Army in the Carolinas today, with temperatures dropping near freezing at sundown of a raw windy day.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Moderately higher prices were established last week in the lard market in sympathy with strength in grains and soy beans and on buying attributed to packers, which in part represented removal of hedges against sales of about 11,000,000 pounds to the government.

The Giants flashed through murk, mud and rain at the Polo Grounds yesterday to a 20-13 victory over the Detroit Lions, thus regaining first place in the Eastern Division of the National Football League from the beaten Redskins. The New Yorkers now are half a length ahead of second-place Washington and one game in front of the third-place Brooklyn Dodgers.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 9 -- Democracy was founded on spiritual things and its downfall is money worship, the eighty-seventh annual convention of the New Jersey Education Association was told here tonight.

TOKYO, Nov. 9 -- With the special envoy, Saburo Kurusu, scheduled to arrive in Washington this week, the long-drawn-out "conversations" between Japan and the United States may be expected to enter their concluding stage.

LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Reuter reported from Baghdad today that Fakhri Bey Nashashibi, a leading Palestine Arab, had been assassinated as he was leaving his hotel in the Iraq city. He was among the leading Arab supporters of the British cause in the war.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 -- James J. Hoey, collector of internal revenue in the second district, lower Manhattan, New York, suffered a cerebral hemorrhage early today. He was reported in critical condition at Union Memorial Hospital tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- This week will be the test period for the British price policy. The Agricultural Wages Board, meeting two-thirds of the workers' demand, has recommended a weekly increase in national agricultural minimum wages by 8s to 56s.

PANAMA, Nov. 9 -- The suggestion of the Japanese newspaper Kokumin that the closing of Japanese stores and numerous barber shops by the Government of Panama was due to pressure by the United States caused considerable amusement here today, while the threat to blockade the canal gave not the least concern.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since the outbreak of war the visa division of the Department of State has had to handle many new problems, but that would seem a poor excuse for its failure to keep abreast of them.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- Twenty Czechs, alleged to have Been members of a secret organization of saboteurs engaged in subversive activities in the vicinity of Vienna, were executed on orders of the German Gestapo [secret police], it was announced today.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt addressed her weekly radio audience yesterday in her capacity as Assistant Director of Civilian Defense, warning that "to achieve total defense every individual must feel responsible for defense."

Despite a few additional attacks upon Mayor La Guardia yesterday for his letter to clergymen containing a "canned sermon" suggested for use next Sunday, on the whole ministers praised the Mayor for his proposal.
AMERICAN ARMY ICELAND BASE HEADQUARTERS, Nov. 7 (delayed) (U.P.) -- Letters mailed in the United States last July have recently arrived here -- by way of Bermuda and London.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Nov. 9 (U.P) -- Bulgarian troops and police killed 482 "armed persons" of a mob of 1,800 to 2,000 "Bolshevik-inspired upstarts" in quelling an uprising at Drama, in Eastern Greece, a government spokesman said today.
LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique tonight:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Once more I find THE NEW YORK TIMES editorially raising the long-dead issue of steam power as against water power for generation of electric energy. Once more this ghost-argument is used against the St. Lawrence development project, now before Congress.

As a prelude to the general Red Cross Roll Call that begins tomorrow, Armistice Day, and continues through Nov. 30, members of the Red Cross churches division began yesterday the enrollment of members of 392 churches in Manhattan and the Bronx.

UNION CITY, N.J., Nov. 9 -- The Boys Town, Neb., High School football team made its Eastern debut today by eking out a 7-to-6 decision over St. Michael's before 10,500 spectators, including Mayor Harry Thourot and other city and county officials.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Effects of the war abroad on the life of Cornell University are described by President Edmund E. Day in his annual report for 1940-41, just published.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. H. Thurston W. Huntting are at the Carlyle for the Winter.

SOME time ago a $2,500 prize was offered jointly by Farrar Rinehart and Redbook Magazine for the best novel submitted by a Latin-American author. The winner is published this morning in a translation by Harriet de Onis: "Broad and Alien Is the World"* ("El Mundo es Ancho y Ajeno"), by 32-year-old Ciro Alegria of Peru.

The driving public of New York State should begin to prepare itself for the operation of the new Motor Vehicle Safety-Responsibility Law which becomes effective on Jan. 1. Throughout the State, Commissioner Mealey is disseminating information about this law which directly affects every person who operates an automobile.

Penitence and tolerance are prerequisites for the building of a new world order, Bishop Herbert Welch asserted yesterday morning in a sermon at the Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. The Bishop was guest speaker for Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, who was preaching at the University of Chicago.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 9 -- German parachute troops are dropping over mountainous Central and Western Serbia in the latest stages of the German campaign to stamp out the resistance of Chetnik armies, according to reliable information from foreign military sources here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: While the defense program is being fashioned to meet any eventualities growing out of the European situation, we are likely to overlook the unpublicized efforts to capitalize the crisis in behalf of national prohibition. We are properly awake to the great danger to our liberties from abroad, but should not allow ourselves to be blinded by those who would curtail our liberties at home.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 9 -- Reports last week in the spot markets of the South of a growing holding movement among growers of cotton, particularly east of the Mississippi River, caused a tightening of the basis for spot cotton here and at most leading centers for trading in the actual staple.

The question of private placements of new security issues -- the direct sale by the issuer to a few large institutional investors -- a prpblem of increasing importance to the investment banking industry in recent years, assumed the spotlight last week in the hearings before the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee on proposed amendments to the securities acts.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. H. Thurston W. Huntting are at the Carlyle for the Winter.

SOME time ago a $2,500 prize was offered jointly by Farrar Rinehart and Redbook Magazine for the best novel submitted by a Latin-American author. The winner is published this morning in a translation by Harriet de Onis: "Broad and Alien Is the World"* ("El Mundo es Ancho y Ajeno"), by 32-year-old Ciro Alegria of Peru.

For the third straight year, Mrs. James M. Austin's noted imported red and white Pekingese Champion Che Le of Matson's Catawba captured premier honors in the Progressive Dog Club's ninth annual toy dog show at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

UNION CITY, N.J., Nov. 9 -- The Boys Town, Neb., High School football team made its Eastern debut today by eking out a 7-to-6 decision over St. Michael's before 10,500 spectators, including Mayor Harry Thourot and other city and county officials.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Effects of the war abroad on the life of Cornell University are described by President Edmund E. Day in his annual report for 1940-41, just published.
ESSEX, Conn., Nov. 9 -- So close was the struggle today for the new Roosevelt Trophy that a tie score resulted in the dinghy racing.

Guthrie McClintic tonight opens the busiest week of the current theatrical season with his presentation of the Isabel Leighton-Bertram Bloch comedy, "Spring Again," starring the notable stage veterans, Grace George and C. Aubrey Smith.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Foreign Policy Association said today that because of a concentration of newer type British and American warplanes in British Malaya, the Netherlands Indies and the Philippines, "the balance of power in Southeast Asia had shifted against Japan."

Speaking before the dinner of the alumni of the Catholic University of America at the Hotel Pennsylvania here last night, the Rev. Ignatius Smith, dean of the School of Philosophy of the University, scored "those who enjoy the hospitality of this country and use it for only one purpose -- to destroy the liberty they find here."

LONDON, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- German troops are being slaughtered by the thousands in battles around Moscow, Soviet dispatches said tonight. Tass, the official Soviet news agency, mentioned fighting on the Naro Fominsk salient, only forty miles southwest of the capital.
LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Germans have opened a new drive on Leningrad, and are massing a host of fresh troops before Moscow for a final blow at the capital, war reports said tonight.

Warning that this city faces large-scale unemployment during 1942 as a result of the application of priorities, Percy H. Jonnston, president of the State Chamber of Commerce, called yesterday for a joint effort by employer, labor and civic organizations to attract new defense industries and to increase the volume of defense contracts held by local manufacturers.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Professional and amateur artists and craftsmen were busy today directing the placing of their works in the exhibit hall of the County Center here as final preparations were being made for Westchester County's largest art show, opening tomorrow and continuing for two weeks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Administration supporters, confident that next week-end will find American ships free to sail any seas, urged today that speedy steps be taken to "deliver the goods" to Great Britain and Russia.

In a wide sweep of week-end air raids from the North Sea to the Mediterranean the British admit losing fifty-two planes in twenty-four hours. While such a loss does not match the plane destruction reported almost daily from the 2,000-mile Russian front, it is heavier than anything the British have hitherto been willing to sustain.

MONTREAL, Nov. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Discussions on economic collaboration between the United States and Canada formed a major part of the three-day session of the joint economic committees of the two countries here during the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- American business men are due for a closer insight into the workings of the defense program and the part which their particular industries are expected to play, if Tuesday's gathering of steel men here proves a success.
It was two days before the Fordham-Pitt game and Dr. John Bain Sutherland was talking.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Oct. 25 was 3,447,230 shares, compared with 2,895,630 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10 -- After eleven and a quarter hours, during which Yale students made their own beds and two law professors called off classes rather than cross a picket line, the first strike in the university's 241 years ended here at 8:15 tonight.
MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Gardiner C. Tucker, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church in Mobile since 1885, died here today.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique issued today:

ROME, Nov. 10 -- Two Italian destroyers and an unspecified number of merchant ships that formed part of a convoy were sunk in the Central Mediterranean yesterday morning during an engagement with British warships, the High Command acknowledged today.
A large and brilliant attendance of society made a glamorous spectacle at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A plea from President Roosevelt that the House Ways and Means Committee initiate action for further anti-inflationary tax legislation which would become effective "within two or three months" brought today from Representative Doughton, chairman of this committee, a statement that the committee already has voted that consideration of such a proposal should be "deferred temporarily."

TOKYO, Nov. 10 -- The project of a Central Asiatic railway connecting Tokyo and Berlin, discussed here recently, was supplemented today with a re-examination of the project of a canal through the Isthmus of Kra to short-circuit Singapore and open a more direct trade route between Japan, the "Greater East Asia Coprosperity Sphere" and India.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 -- A three-day celebration marking the 150th anniversary of the founding of St. Mary's Seminary by members of the Society of St. Sulpice began today with a pontifical mass celebrated at the seminary by the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, apostolic delegate to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture raised its 1941 corn crop forecast today to 2,675,373,000 bushels, the largest since 1932. Based on Nov. 1 conditions, this was 2 per cent higher than the estimate of a month ago.

There was but little change of prices in the local wholesale meat markets yesterday. Supplies of all classes were fully ample for trade requirements. The early kosher markets opened steady with Friday's quotations and trading fair.

GROTON, Mass., Nov. 10 -- Indications may point strongly to a victory for Groton School in its traditional football encounter with St. Mark's on Wednesday, but Head Coach Larry Noble and his squad do not relish the role of favorite.
Prince and Princess Windisch-Graetz have returned from Southampton, where they spent the Summer, and are at 30 Button Place for the season.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 10 (AP) -- May 2 was selected tentatively today as the date for the 1942 Kentucky Derby.

The N.Y.U. freshman football team, which last week scored its first victory over the Fordham University first-year men, will go after its first triumph over the Manhattan College cubs today at Ohio Field. The kick-off is scheduled for 2 P.M.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- A further advance toward the establishment of a post-war Polish-Czecho-Slovak confederation affecting the political and economic organization of Central Europe was achieved today when the coordination committee made up of representatives of both countries, began detailed studies of their problems.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- If war should break out between Japan and the United States, Britain will declare war on Japan "within the hour," Prime Minister Winston Churchill said today.

H.M.S. Cossack was only a destroyer, but no ship of the great fleet was closer to the heart of the British public. None accepted battle more eagerly and none earned victory more gallantly. The Admiralty's laconic announcement gives no hint of how she was lost, though it is possible that she was the victim of a Nazi bomber over Scottish waters.

The new blacklist of Latin-American companies and individuals believed to be acting in the interest of Germany and Italy just issued by the State Department is one of the most important to be released since the listings were begun in July, foreign traders said yesterday, because it includes large purchasers in the American market.

While a Maria Moors Cabot Prize in Journalism for furthering Pan-American relationships was being presented yesterday at Columbia University to Dr. Jose I. Rivero, editor and publisher of Diario de la Marina in Havana, Cuba, a group of pickets representing the United American Spanish Aid Committee, 425 Fourth Avenue, protested the award, claiming on placards that Dr. Rivero was "Hitler's stooge" and an "enemy of America."

One hundred and sixty-five stations where New York motorists may have the gasoline consumption efficiency of their cars tested without charge will be opened tomorrow in all five boroughs, Albert H. Morgan, deputy commissioner of the Department of Public Works, announced yesterday.

Winners of the race for City Council in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx were still officially lacking last night as the fifth day of the P.R. tally ended in the four boroughs. It was definitely settled, however, that the new Council will consist of twenty-six members, instead of the present twenty-one, with Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx gaining an additional seat and Brooklyn two extra places.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today purchased the screen rights to "Men of the Valley," a sequel novel by Richard Llewellyn to his previous "How Green Was My Valley," which Fox recently filmed with Walter Pidgeon, Maureen O'Hara and Donald Crisp.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10--By a vote of 9 to 2 the National Defense Mediation Board today rejected the demand of the United Mine Workers for a closed shop in the "captive" mines and thereby brought on what is believed in the Capitol will be a definite showdown between President Roosevelt and John L. Lewis.

Without passers-by having the slightest hint of it, 723 prisoners were shifted last Sunday forenoon from the old Tombs Prison, on the block of Centre, Leonard, Lafayette and Franklin Streets, to the new Tombs, bounded by Centre, White and Baxter Streets, diagonally across from the old structure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Supreme Court today unanimously sustained the right of Alabama to impose its 2 per cent sales and use taxes on materials bought for government defense projects by contractors holding "cost-plus-a-fixed-fee" agreements.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Tomorrow, Armistice Day, the American Red Cross will open a drive to equal its greatest membership during the World War. The campaign will end on Nov. 30.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 11 (U.P.) -- A third member of the First American Eagle Squadron, Pilot Officer Carroll Warren McColpin, 27, of Buffalo, N.Y., has won the Distinguished Flying Cross, the Air Ministry announced early today.

Declaring that there is no other private agency comparable to the Red Cross when the time conies to meet dangers that threaten "not only the principles of democracy but the life and limbs of Americans as well," S. Sloan Colt, chairman of the New York Chapter's twenty-fifth annual Roll Call, appealed yesterday for a hearty response to the enrollment drive that opens today and will continue until Dec. 1.

Five thousand persons packed the main ballroom at the Manhattan Center last night, where more than a dozen well-known jazz bands participated in a jubilee arranged by the British American Ambulance Corps, with the cooperation of the American Federation of Musicians.

DETROIT, Nov. 10 -- Anti-Semitism has been proved "the spearhead of Nazi aggression everywhere," Dr. Herman Abramowitz, rabbi of Congregation Shaar Hasahonayin of Montreal, declared in a dinner address before the Women's League of the United Synagogue of America here this evening.

PORT MERCER, N.J., Nov. 10 -- With an occasional popping that was far removed from the rattle of musketry that usually signals the opening of the upland game season in this State, hunters took to the field this morning, but in smaller numbers than at any other opening in our memory.

Leon Barzin has made the National Orchestral Association, which gave its first concert of the season at Carnegie Hall last night, one of the liveliest musical institutions in town. He has been eminently successful in the main objective of the association, which is to train young instrumentalists in orchestral routine and literature.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Roosevelt was advised by his Congressional leaders today that the House would authorize him Thursday afternoon to send American ships into belligerent ports and through combat zones.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Champion Paper and Fibre Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to a registration statement covering $8,500,000 of first mortgage bonds due on Nov. 1, 1956, and 40,000 shares of $5 cumulative convertible preferred stock of no par value, disclosing that the bonds are to bear interest at the rate of 3 1/2 per cent.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 10 -- Activity in the frontier area, which increases periodically when one side or the other takes the offensive, now appears to toe definitely on the upgrade after a brief lull since late in October. For the last three days the Germans, who recently had even avoided British patrols, have been sending out an increasing number of armored cars for reconnaissance and raiding.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Prices of hogs dropped 15 to 20 cents a hundred pounds today as producers shipped the largest number of salable head into the local market since March 19. Sows again showed comparative strength with losses confined to 10 cents.
LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Bad weather abruptly Interrupted the heavy offensive by the Royal Air Force against Germany and German-occupied lands today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A complete allocations system covering phenols is provided for in an order issued today by the director of priorities as an amendment to General Preference Order M-27, which originally imposed a milder form of control on Aug. 30.

Paul Berger, dress manufacturer and self-styled "finger man" for beatings and killings ordered by Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, one-time ruler of the city industrial rackets, said yesterday that he was now the victim of union discrimination and unable to get a job because he "told the truth" about union officials and gangsters joining rorces in the garment center.

PANAMA, Nov. 10 -- Spanish Minister Carlos y Cuadra, Count de Bailen, was declared persona non grata in an executive resolution signed by President Rieardo Adolfo de la Guardia and Foreign Minister Octavio Fabrega today. The action was based on a remark made by the Minister in the Union Club Nov. 3, Panama's Independence Day, when he is reported to have said:

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The Westchester golfing season came to a close at the Mount Kisco Country Club today with Herman Barren, Fenway pro, and Milton Jones of the same club carding 32, 35 -- 67 to win pro-amateur honors.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 10 -- More than 2,000 members of A.F. L. building trades unions answered a general striKe call today, to place at about 3,500 the number on strike at $23,000,000 worth of Navy and Marine Corps projects in San Diego County.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, today rated the Army's air forces "the finest in the world," adding that they combined the most successful features of Britain's R.A.F. and the Nazi Luftwaffe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A strike of building trades workers on naval construction projects in the San Diego area was outlawed by American Federation of Labor leaders here tonight within a few hours after the Navy Department had ordered the commandant there to proceed with the work despite the strike, which he characterized "open revolt against the United States Government."

Three rosy-cheeked girls and one small boy returned to their school desks yesterday afternoon proudly displaying gilded medals awarded to them by Miss Margaret Speaks, radio singer, at the first annual Greenwich Village Cat Day celebration held at the Greenwich Village Humane League headquarters, 100 Greenwich Avenue.

QUANTICO, Va., Nov. 10 -- The United States Marine Corps is ready to get "well in hand" any situations that may be pending, Major Gen. Louis McCarthy Little, commanding officer of the Marine Barracks here, asserted today during brief ceremonies marking the 166th anniversary of the Marine Corps.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 10 -- The war in Serbia is raging more fiercely than ever according to eyewitnesses arriving direct from the fighting zone, following a complete breakdown in attempted and hitherto undisclosed peace negotiations between the puppet Premier, General Milan Neditch, and the new leader of Serbian Army regulars fighting with the Chetniks against the Germans and Italians and General Neditch's forces.
WESTFIELD, N.J., Nov. 10 -- The Galloping Hill duo of Francis Coakley and George Goger carded 33, 35-68 to win the final one-day pro-amateur event of the New Jersey P.G. A. at Echo Lake today.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 10 -- The United States Maritime Commission is planning an experiment in the use of concrete oil barges, it was revealed here today.

Consciousness of the increasing tension in the international situation has led to the resignation of Mrs. Harold V. Milligan of New York as defense chairman of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, and the appointment of Mrs. Gustav Ketterer of Rhiladelphia.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The British destroyer Cossack, famous for her exploit in releasing British prisoners from the prison ship Altmark in a Norwegian fjord in February, 1940, has been sunk, the Admiralty announced today. Captain E.L. Berthon was in command when the warship was lost.

BAYSHORE, L.I., Nov. 10 -- Three married women began their preliminary training in the State Aviation Trade School here today as they were assigned to the draft oom, where they are studying blue-print reading. After two weeks they will be assigned to the sheet metal and riveting classes, provided they prove their capability.

Josef Klein, 38-year-old former photo-lithographer, testified yesterday as the Brooklyn espionage trial entered its tenth week that he had received $25 for constructing a short-wave radio transmitter which, the government charges, was used to send Allied shipping information to Germany.

Liquidation and hedging operations near the close of trading carried cotton futures lower yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The close was at the low for the day at net losses of 2 to 8 points.

A protest against the order of the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board of Oct. 9, forbidding the starting of any construction projects using critical materials except under certain conditions, is being prepared by the Building Congress of New York, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A demand that Secretary of State Cordell Hull, cease his reported threats to Finland that she will lose this country's friendship unless she ceases fighting Soviet Russia was offered in the Senate today by Senator Henrik Shipstead, Republican, of Minnesota.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Authority to acquire control of the New York, Lake Erie Western Coal and Railroad Company and the West Clarion Railroad Company was asked of the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the trustees of the Erie Railroad Company.
Once more the United States Army accounted for the chief honors In the jumping competition at the Fifty-sixth National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- Mrs. Edith P. Welty, the crusading grandmother who turned the tables on the entrenched political machines here two years ago by winning election to the City Council, said today she would be receptive to appointment as Mayor of the city in view of the record vote she received last Tuesday when re-elected to the Council.

In the face of repeated warnings that the Navy could "tolerate no delay in its vital San Diego construction program," the A.F. of L. Building Trades Council went ahead with its plan for a general strike in San Diego on defense construction projects to enforce a demand for higher wages.
BERLIN, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Today's German communique, issued at Adolf Hitler's headquarters:

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 10 -- Dr. Geronimo Mendez, a Senator and leader of the Radical party, the country's major political group, took over the Presidency of Chile tonight when President Pedro Aguirre Cerda announced that he was temporarily retiring from the office because of illness.
Because of national defense, novel experiences yesterday befell a group of women prominent in society, and two work horses, one black, one white.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Rhode Island State's Harriers, paced by Bob Nichols's second record-smashing victory in a row, won impressive team and individual honors today in the twenty-ninth annual New England intercollegiate cross-country championship at Fenway Park.

Holiday All securities and commodity Exchanges and all banks in the United States will be closed today in observance of Armistice Day. The same will hold true for Canada, where the day is known as Remembrance Day.

Because of the serious shortage of food in France, infants weigh only four or five pounds at birth and adults are consuming even household pets, Dr. Bessie Strongman, a pediatrician of Pittsfield, Mass., reported on returning yesterday aboard the American Export liner Exeter.

The latest addition to Pan American Airways flying fleet, the Capetown Clipper, took off at 7:02 o'clock yesterday morning on the first leg of an 18,290-mile route-proving flight over a newly chartered tri-continental aerial trade route that extends from here to the Belgian Congo, Africa, via the West Indies and South America.

A new kind of Armistice Day dawned this morning. Twenty-three years ago the mood was one of wild rejoicing. Later our commemoration of the valiant dead was mingled with a spirit of disillusionment. Between our latter-day view and the cause for which they gave up their lives there appeared the tottering edifice of the Treaty of Versailles.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 10 -- Brazil is ready to fight to preserve her independence and ready to carry out her obligations to defend the American hemisphere from outside aggression, President Getulio Vargas asserted today, addressing army leaders at a luncheon in his honor on the fourth anniversary of his regime.

Gross operating revenues of the Western Union Telegraph Company in the first nine months of this year amounted to $83,751,101, an increase of $10,408,454, or 14.2 per cent, over the same 1940 period, Albert N. Williams, president, announced yesterday.

The first in a series of Monday Morning Musicales, sponsored under the chairmanship of Mrs. Lytle Hull and patterned after the famous Musical Mornings inaugurated by the late Albert Morris Bagby, which were features of the social season here for more than fifty years, took place yesterday in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Trustees of the Henry R. Towne Endowment Fund have petitioned Surrogate James A. Foley for approval of their decision to discontinue payments of income to the Museum of Science and Industry and to distribute the remaining principal of $1,630,010 in equal shares between the Museum of Natural History and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (Canadian Press) -- British aircraft have sighted and attacked U-boats on more than 300 occasions and have captured one since the war started, according to an authoritative statement tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- With an exceptionally large number of landscape and genre paintings, the eleventh annual exhibition of the Westchester County Arts and Crafts Guild opened tonight at the County Center here. Five hundred artists and friends attended a reception that marked the opening.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 -- C.K. Bassett's Corrigan, winner of the Foxcatcher National Cup, came out of recent retirement to win the Manly Steeplechase Handicap of two miles and a half at Pimlico today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- With a holiday ahead traders took to the sidelines in the wheat market today. This resulted in limited operations within a range of about 1/2 cent a bushel. Final sales were 1/8 to 1/4 cent higher. A large part of the business was of a professional character with little attention paid to the news.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10--United States foreign trade declined 8 per cent in September, compared with the high level of August, but exports were 40 per cent larger than in September a year ago and imports were 35 per cent higher. The export total was $417,000,000 and imports were valued at $263,000,000.

BERLIN, Nov. 10 -- German reports tonight admit bitter Soviet resistance and a series of counter-attacks by the Red Army near Sevastopol, in contrast with previous German claims that Soviet resistance in Crimea had been crushed and the operations converted into a pursuit.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies in October allowed the smallest increase over a year ago since June and, except for that month, since March, according to a compilation by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The October gain amounted to 21.5 per cent, compared with 26.7 for September and 29.8 -- the year's high -- for August.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 10 -- A plan for improvement of education in this State was adopted today by the New Jersey Education Association at its eighty-seventh annual convention here.

Police Commissioner Valentine, in response to a question from reporters yesterday on whether he felt crime conditions in Harlem and near-by parks had been improved since his assignment of additional police to the area last week, replied "Yes," but he did not elaborate on the situation.

A thirty-year plan for rebuilding urban centers in England after hostilities cease has been prepared and is now going the rounds of various British governmental bodies, Dr. Luther Gulick, director of the Institute of Public Administration, revealed yesterday.
Among the contracts for residential space reported yesterday by brokers was one for six rooms at 1112 Park Avenue signed by John B. Barry through Walter Samuels, Inc., brokers.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The British issued this communique today:

Aside from the various house-to-house collection campaigns now being instituted, the flow of waste paper from large collectors through dealers has not improved materially in recent weeks and the paper industry's high rate of operations will definitely be affected by shortages by the first of the year, according to reports from dealers and paper manufacturers yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Contracts awarded today by the War Department totaled $6,344,715.58. Among those were the following, not previously published, which were granted to companies in the New York area:

In setting up a system of allocations, calculated ultimately to displace priorities, for the distribution of essential raw materials, the Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board is taking us another long step toward complete war-time industrial planning. Such a step was needed, for the priorities system has not been adequate to meet the problem.

An abbreviated but attractive scholastic football program is on tap in the metropolitan area today, when more than twenty contests are slated on four fronts. The New York City list of five games, two of which will be played at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, finds two teams, Curtis and Monroe, risking their undefeated records.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The French Ambassador, Gaston Henry-Haye, accompanied by Secretary of State Cordell Hull, called on President Roosevelt at the White House today to discuss the possibility of obtaining this country's aid in getting shipments of food and clothing through the blockade to 1,350,000 French prisoners in Germany and to French children.

Slowness has persisted in the dress industry considerably beyond the point at which a sharp pickup was expected, reports in the trade yesterday indicated. October business was poor, particularly in the volume low-end field, and there has been little improvement thus far this month.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The text of a Royal Air Force communique:

Richard F. Walsh, president of the Brooklyn local of the stagehands' union, has been elected president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and Motion Picture Operators of the United States and Canada, succeeding George E. Browne.

Asking his Polish listeners to be neither "discouraged" nor "afraid," Wendell L. Willkie predicted in a short-wave mesage to Poland yesterday that "within a relatively brief period the democracies of the world will command both the oceans and the air."

Add to the list of openings this week Warners" "One Foot in Heaven," the film version of the Hartzell Spence book, which will arrive at the Radio City Music Hall on Thursday. Fredric March and Martha Scott are starred in the drama.

In an editorial commending Mayor La Guardia's outline to clergymen for a suggested sermon on American democracy, The Churchman, independent journal of the Protestant Episcopal Church, declared yesterday that Dr. Charles Clayton Morrison, out-spoken critic of the Mayor's "canned sermon" was himself the publisher of a booklet used as a "pony" by clergymen in preparing their sermons.

Improved Pan-American relations through the medium of a free, democratic press were seen by the four Latin-American journalists who received Maria Moors Cabot Prizes in Journalism yesterday at a special convocation in the Low Memorial Library of Columbia University.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 10 -- Prime Minister John Curtin, in an Armistice Day message today, said Australia pledged that no effort would be too great to make it so that "we once again shall have an armistice marking a new peace in which a new world can be built."

Department Store Sales Up 4% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 4 per cent for the week ended Nov. 8, in comparison with the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Without waiting for all of the large banks in Wall Street to put into effect plans for extra pay for employes to compensate for the increase in the cost of living, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday a "Supplemental Compensation Plan" under which extra payment of 6 per cent, subject to certain restrictions, will be paid on the first $1,800 of annual salary.

Three ambulance-loads of bundles were collected yesterday morning at a concert in Carnegie Hall to which no one was admitted unless he or she first left some contribution for the British people at one of the receiving stations in the lobby.

Henry W. Nevinson was one of those brilliant English, irregulars, full of non-conformity, suspicious of authority, patters of the underdog. An aristocrat, he was on the side of the deprived, unfortunate, oppressed. He was an enthusiast of freedom and president of the Council for the Defense of Civil Liberties when he died.
The New York Giants will stress pass defense when they start preparations today for their National Football League clash with the Cleveland Rams next Sunday at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's assertion today that Britain would immediately join the hostilities if the United States became involved in war with Japan was taken here as another indication that the situation in the Pacific had reached a particularly tense stage.

ROME, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Vatican radio broadcast without comment today a religious creed of Nazi "believers in God," including a declaration of faith in Reichsfuehrer Hitler which the announcer said was published in a German paper.
Except for their modern dress and greater beauty, the women who took their places yesterday beneath as many paintings looked almost like "portraits come to life."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The House instructed Representative Hamilton Fish, Republican, of New York, today to "refrain from responding" to a summons to appear Wednesday before the grand jury of a United States court investigating Nazi propaganda.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The constitutionality of a New York State law suspending automobile drivers' licenses on failure to pay damages resulting from accidents was sustained in the Supreme Court by a 5-to-4 division, as the first decisions of tne term were handed down today.

Armistice Day, marking the twenty-third anniversary of the end of the first World War, will be celebrated throughout New York City and the rest of the nation today with solemn ceremonies and in some instances with festivities.
There was a surprise in store for visitors to New York University's beleaguered football camp yesterday.

Mrs. Arthur M. Grenfell of London, president of the British Y.W. C.A., arrived here yesterday aboard the Exeter and expressed amazement that Americans had heard of the bombing of Bristol and Coventry, and were so acutely aware of the suffering in England.

KENTON, Ohio, Nov. 10 -- A half-ton cylinder head blown from a passing freight locomotive into the path of a speeding Pennsylvania Railroad luxury train was blamed tonight for a wreck that killed twelve persons and injured at least forty others.

Mrs. Anthony Bassler of the Westchester Country Club was elected president of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association for the coming year at the annual meeting yesterday in the New York Junior League clubhouse. Mrs. Bassler succeeds Mrs. Charles P. Luckey of Mount Kisco, president for three years.
ROME, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

VICHY, France, Nov. 10 -- Although details are still unobtainable as to the "luxury tax" adopted in principle by the government last week there are indications today that one at its forms may be "solidarity bonds" to be purchased compulsorily in high-priced restaurants with every meal or order, tailor shops, fur stores and the like.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Nov. 11 -- Savage fighting on the Tula salient of the Moscow front and in Crimea was reported in a Russian communique this morning. Other Soviet sources said that the Germans had failed to break Red Army resistance in those areas and had made little headway.
Tenders will be considered on Nov. 19 by officials of Torrington, Conn., on $400,000 of tax certificates to mature in installments on April 29, May 4 and Nov. 19, 1942.

As a means of encouraging higher education in architecture, the American Institute of Architects will award Edward Langley scholarships in 1942 for advanced study, research, and travel, announces Richmond H. Shreve, president of the institute.
The Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday by brokers was marked by a wide variety in the types of buildings passing into new ownership. The sales were well scattered throughout the city.

SINGAPORE, Tuesday, Nov. 11 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's announcement at London yesterday that strong British naval units had been spared from the Atlantic and Mediterranean for service in the Indian and Pacific Oceans caused great satisfaction here today.
The twenty-ninth annual National Hotel Exposition opened for a five-day stand at Grand Central Palace yesterday and 15,000 representatives of the hotel and allied industries viewed its 300 exhibits.

Hearings will start tomorrow before the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries on legislation to require purchases made in this country under the Lease-Lend Act to be handled by American freight forwarders, according to T.E. Reeve of the New York Foreign Freight Forwarders and Brokers Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- Hugh D. Scott Jr., the only Republican Representative from Philadelphia, asked President Roosevelt today to give the nation seven pledges, including one denouncing all aspirations for a fourth term, to win complete unity for the foreign policy now being pursued.
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Mahdi, from the stable of Harold O. Simmons, beat the Merry Ho Stable's High Martin by a nose today to win the six-furlong feature event at Rockingham Park.

HAVANA, Nov. 10 -- Minister of Labor Oscar Gans this afternoon denied a report that the Cuban Government "will take over and operate" any company that fails to comply with the blanket wage increase decreed last week by President Fulgencio Batista.
Firms in the apparel and textile industries and allied lines figured largely in the business leasing yesterday, when a number of full-floor units were taken.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- Proceeding on the theory that there's nothing: like a rousing controversy, an inquisitive fellow today wandered out to River Field, where the University of Pennsylvania football team was drilling for Saturday's meeting with Army.

Despite the present deadlock in the railroad wage dispute, the Twentieth Century Fund, after a survey of collective bargaining in leading American industries, has reached the conclusion that the railroads as a whole have one of the best records for labor peace of any of the major industries in the United States.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- Clubwomen who hitherto have been community leaders should now be only cooperators in the national civilian defense effort, 250 women delegates to the convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs were told today.

Coach Lou Little gave the Columbia football varsity a day of rest yesterday and concentrated his attention on the reserves in a spirited three-hour contact session at Baker Field. Limited to players who did not get into Saturday's game with Pennsylvania at Philadelphia, the scrimmage was between the second and third elevens.

An expected decline of 30 to 40 per cent in straight product selling copy for major electrical appliances next year will be partialy offset by increased institutional advertising by manufacturers, according to agency men yesterday. Full-line manufacturers will attempt in their institutional campaigns to promote the idea of completely electrical kitchens as a springboard for campaigns when shortages are over.

Any device for getting Grace George and C. Aubrey Smith on the stage together has this column's full permission. "Spring Again," which was put on at Henry Miller's last evening, is the device offered by Isabel Leighton and Bertram Bloch, and it will serve.

The International Mercantile Marine Company has notified the New York Stock Exchange that a special meeting of stockholders of record of Nov. 15 will be held Dec. 9 to approve the borrowing by the company of $11,469,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and for other purposes.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- The United States, Britain, China and the Netherlands have reached an agreement in regard to "Japan's next move in the Pacific," T.T. Tsiang, government spokesman, said today. He added that the Japanese move was expected to be a Japanese drive on the Burma Road munitions route, over which American lease-lend supplies are being delivered to China.

Mr. and Mrs. William V.C. Ruxton gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis in advance of the Name Band Jubilee held at the Manhattan Center for the benefit of the British American Ambulance Corps, of which Mr. Ruxton is president.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As we celebrate the armistice terminating a war which was to end all wars and make the world safe for democracy there come to us from across the waters the muffled tread of armed millions and the crash of battle on unprecedented scale. Most of the democracies are dead or enslaved, the rest are at bay and civilization itself is imperiled as never before.

Mrs. Donald S. Stralem gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 941 Park Avenue, for members of the ticket, junior and debutante committee aiding in the plans for the Ice Follies premiere on the night of Dec. 1 at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

Attacking the isolationists. Mrs. Henry R. Caraway, former president of the Women's National Republican Club, broke away yesterday from her criticism of the present administration to defend President Roosevelt against charges that he had ignored his campaign pledges.

Eighty-three men and women have been Indicted here in a $1,250,000 lottery fraud, and all because a typographical error made an Indianapolis barber lose his temper, it was revealed here yesterday. The group, whose agents operated in many parts of the country, dealt in counterfeit tickets for the Irish Hospital Sweep-stakes, at $2.50 each; the Jamaica (British West Indies) Sweepstakes, at $1 each, and the Cuban National Lottery, at 50 cents each, it was charged.

IF you smoke too much, sleep too little, have hemophilia, swell up-after eating lobsters or are merely a normally morbid and normally curious human being, George W. Gray's latest book ought to prove interesting reading. The title is "The Advancing Front of Medicine."*

The International Mercantile Marine Company has notified the New York Stock Exchange that a special meeting of stockholders of record of Nov. 15 will be held Dec. 9 to approve the borrowing by the company of $11,469,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and for other purposes.

Mr. and Mrs. William V.C. Ruxton gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis in advance of the Name Band Jubilee held at the Manhattan Center for the benefit of the British American Ambulance Corps, of which Mr. Ruxton is president.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As we celebrate the armistice terminating a war which was to end all wars and make the world safe for democracy there come to us from across the waters the muffled tread of armed millions and the crash of battle on unprecedented scale. Most of the democracies are dead or enslaved, the rest are at bay and civilization itself is imperiled as never before.

Mrs. Donald S. Stralem gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 941 Park Avenue, for members of the ticket, junior and debutante committee aiding in the plans for the Ice Follies premiere on the night of Dec. 1 at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

IF you smoke too much, sleep too little, have hemophilia, swell up-after eating lobsters or are merely a normally morbid and normally curious human being, George W. Gray's latest book ought to prove interesting reading. The title is "The Advancing Front of Medicine."*

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- On the surface, and on the basis of facts available at this writing, it appears that at San Diego, and through the Navy, the administration has moved more forcibly to prevent unwarranted defense work stoppages than at any time since the war situation became critical.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov., 10 -- Continuing its investigation of relief costs in Westchester County, the Welfare Committee of the County Board of Supervisors said today in an interim report that the cost last year of maintaining 1,636 children in county institutions and foster homes was $473,255.

Rapidly accelerating labor costs a man-hour compared with output a man-hour, said to be the consequence of defense production since October, 1940, may lead to a difficult post-war adjustment period, with wage rates far out of relation to the purchasing power of consumers of manufactured goods, according to a survey just completed by the National Association of Manufacturers.

In trying to be friends with a foreign nation it certainly helps to remember that the people of England speak English and the people of China speak Chinese. That is why it is only reasonable for the people of Brazil to prefer being addressed in the Portuguese tongue.

Rallying strongly from the furious first-round assault of his rival, Tommy Tucker, Rockaway light heavyweight, now in the United States Navy, last night scored a technical knockout in nine rounds over Johnny Colan, West Side, in their scheduled ten-round battle before a crowd of about 5,000 at the St. Nicholas Palace.

Standing amid the ruins of the ancient City of London yesterday, Winston Churchill warned Japan that Great Britain is not so engrossed in war in Europe that she will close her eyes to acts of aggression in the Pacific. For the second time he declared that if American efforts to preserve peace in the Far East should fail, Great Britain would be at war with Japan within an hour after hostilities began.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 10 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 8:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Nov. 5 aggregated $11,722,000,000.

The worst effect of the assault of the Nazis upon the Jews is that many of the victims are beginning to believe the charges made against them, Dr. A. Leon Sachar, national director of the Hillel Foundation of B'nai B'rith and member of the faculty of the University of Illinois, declared yesterday.

Christopher D. Sullivan, Tammany leader, declined yesterday to quit his post under pressure. In a letter to Jeremiah T. Mahoney, leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District, who had requested Mr. Sullivan's resignation in a letter last week, Mr. Sullivan declared that Mr. Mahoney represented only a small fraction of sentiment within the Tammany executive committee.

"Liquid apple" is the description given to a creamy fluid that is in reality the captured essence of the apple. The flesh of the crisp, snowy fruit lends its color and its flavor to a fresh and natural tasting beverage. All this is done by an intricate machine so newly patented the official ink has hardly dried on the papers.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- An attempt to have the Selective Service Act of 1940 declared unconstitutional because it had not followed a declaration of war was rejected today by the Third Circuit Court of Appeals, which held that the nation was "not precluded from preparing for battle, if battle must come, until such time as our preparation would be too late."

The fire blitz over London in 1940 cast a flaming pictorial reflection here last night when the Museum of the City of New York opened an exhibition of paintings depicting the conflagrations caused by German bombs.
Dr. Roy Chapman Andrews resigned as director of the American Museum of Natural History at the annual Fall meeting of the museum's board of trustees last night.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 11 -- Going beyond cautious and flexible formulas employed by both Premier Hideki Tojo and Foreign Minister Shigenori Togo, to the effect that Japan's policies aim at a successful conclusion of the "China incident" and the establishment of "a greater East Asia co-prosperity sphere," Finance Minister Okinori Kaya declared yesterday it was also Japan's aim to "force Britain and the United States to retreat from East Asia."
