Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation in October were 1,851,279 net tons, a record monthly figure and a gain of 187,052 tons over September. The increase over October, 1940, was 278,871 tons.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 10 (AP) -- An A-24 dive bomber, one of the Army's latest types, crashed into an Army encampment and burned tonight near the Raleigh airport, and the pilot, Second Lieutenant H.P. Taylor, was killed.

Jimmy Crowley greeted the Football Writers Association yesterday with a cheery smile but a heavy heart. The Fordham coach was as flippant as ever at the weekly luncheon at Toots Shor's, but there was a serious undertone to his remarks.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Following is the text of the speech Prime Minister Winston Churchill delivered today at the Mansion House in London:

City and Federal officials and stage and radio stars joined with representatives of the fur industry yesterday in a parade and ceremony in Seventh Avenue, at Twenty-ninth Street, to further the sale of defense bonds and stamps.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and Hiram Walker Sons, Inc., have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment disclosing that $15,000,000 of serial debentures due $1,000,000 on Nov. 1, 1942 to 1956, to be issued jointly by the two liquor concerns, will be offered to the public at a price of 100.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10 -- Ogden D. Miller, Yale's athletic director, speaking before the Connecticut Sportwriters Alliance at its weekly football luncheon today, said that "regardless of the outcome of he Eli's last two games the head coachship would remain the same for next year."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Roosevelt nominated Robert P. Butler as United States Attorney for Connecticut; his callers included Democratic leaders from the Capitol, Secretary Hull and the French Ambassador, Henry-Haye; the Chinese Ambassador, Dr. Hu Shih; Representatives Baldwin, Cole, Gale, Hill and Maas, and Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 10 -- Roscoe P. McClave, Speaker of the Assembly, who is a Bergen County Republican and ex-officio member of a legislative committee appointed a year ago to study the State's water problem, made public today a report prepared by the committee but never signed or forwarded to the Legislature.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The remodeling of the Hutchinson River Parkway, long the worst death trap and bottleneck in the Westchester County parkway system, is proceeding ahead of schedule and should be completed by January, the County Park Commission said today.
Heavily studded with intersectional games, the intercollegiate football schedule this week will offer any number of engagements bearing on national and sectional standing and the race for bowl bids.

Artloom Corporation The Artloom Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents on the common stock. The company paid 15 cents in September, 12 1/2 cents in May and 25 cents in January, the first payments on the issue since 1930.

A thirteen-point statement by Professor Philip O. Badger, chairman of the New York University board of athletic control, explaining schedule difficulties which might be blamed for the poor showing of the varsity football team this season and last, was mailed to 60,000 graduates yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Mrs. Abraham Shapiro of Brooklyn was unanimously re-elected president of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America, religious women's Zionist movement, as 500 delegates wound up business today at the conclusion of their three-day annual convention.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Santa Clara's Broncos bowed to the University of Oregon football team today, but it was the accurate place-kicking of utility fullback Jim Newquist that turned the trick, 21 to 19, before a crowd of 16,000 fans.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 11 (AP) -- A crowd of more than 30,000, the biggest in the track's history, bet the record total of $641,675 in the Rockingham Park pari-mutuel machines today as B.A. Dario's colt Blue Warrior ran away with the Armistice Day Handicap.

Enormous shadows of French poilus strode across the high wall of the Manhattan Center auditorium last night as more than 2,000 French men and women and their friends marked the anniversary of the only armistice with Germany recognized by them.

Ted Williams, lanky outfielder of the Boston Red Sox, whose blazing 406 average won the batting crown last Summer, became the first major leaguer to crash, baseball's magic group of "four hundred" clouters since Bill Terry achieved the feat in 1930, but the most valuable player in the American League in 1941 was a fellow named Joe DiMaggio.

None of the assorted "Macbeths" this courier has seen rank with the performance led by Maurice Evans and Judith Anderson at the National last evening. As directed by the energetic Margaret Webster, it is brimming over with the horrors and monstrosities of Shakespeare's text, and Mr. Evans and Miss Anderson play with consuming passion.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Britain did not pause for a moment today in the grim task of pushing ahead with her war effort, yet thousands of men and women managed to remember that it was the twenty-third anniversary of Armistice Day.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- British Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement regarding alleged German peace feelers provoked a vigorous denial from the Foreign Office spokesman, who told the foreign press in Berlin, "There have not been and will never be any German peace feelers in this war."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Philip Murray and Thomas Kennedy resigned today as members of the National Defense Mediation Board. Mr. Murray is president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and both are officers of the United Mine Workers, Mr. Murray being vice president and Mr. Kennedy secretary-treasurer.

Boy Scout buglers, stationed at more than 100 points throughout Queens, sounded Taps at 11 A.M. yesterday in Armistice Day ceremonies. Two of the most colorful of the Scout ceremonies took place at Parsons Boulevard and Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, where the old Town Hall stood until a few weeks ago, and on the steps of the Queens General Courthouse, Sutphin Boulevard and Eighty-ninth Avenue, Jamaica.

On the basis of a sample survey covering twelve industries, 20 per cent of New York's 500,000 wage earners are threatened with loss of their jobs unless priorities regulations are changed in such a way as to provide materials now either unobtainable or difficult to get, according to data issued yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

Vladimir Drozdoff and his son and daughter, Paul and Nathalie, pianists, last night gave another of their joint recitals at Town Hall. It followed the lines of previous ones, with each member of the family playing a solo group of classical selections and the father closing the program by playing a group of his "tone versions" of different poems.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The likelihood of any direct conferences in Washington between President Roosevelt and Japan's special envoy, Saburo Kurusu, receded tonight as the Chief Executive maintained tentative plans to leave Washington for Warm Springs, Ga., before Sunday and the envoy was held up for a second day at Midway Island, in the Pacific.

Stricter control over issuance of display material to dealers, less elaborate sales presentations to distributors and stores and a cutting down of the use of paper in packaging will be some of the results of the current paper stringency, according to agency men yesterday.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 11 -- No official Singapore comment was forthcoming today on Prime Minister Winston Churchill's revelation that strong British naval units are available for service in the Indian and Pacific oceans. It is strongly believed here that still more warships will reach the Orient soon.

A chill wind swept across the plaza in front of Borough Hall in Brooklyn yesterday morning as the old clock in the building's tower struck the hour of eleven, but the crowd of several thousand persons massed throughout the plaza and in the surrounding streets facing the Borough Hall steps stood motionless and quiet during the annual two minutes of Armistice Day silence in tribute to World War dead.

Asserting that we are facing a world revolution that threatens to bring about the end of western civilization, Herbert Agar, editor of The Louisville Courier-Journal, called upon American youth for resolute action in an address last night at a rally of American Youth for Freedom, in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- A nation-wide organization of the distilled spirits industry was formed here today when wholesalers, distillers, rectifiers, importers and brokers joined in setting up the Allied Liquor Industries, Inc., and unanimously elected Thomas McCarthy of Austin, Nichols Co., New York, as president.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 11 -- There's one nice thing about the Prineeton football situation as the Tigers prepare for their invasion of Yale on Saturday. They don't have to fear an upset.

Sweeping the first three places and finishing five men in the first nine, the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School first team romped off with the twentieth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

In rejecting the demand of John L. Lewis for a closed shop in the "captive" coal mines the National Defense Mediation Board has at last courageously taken the only possible stand. No matter how disguised, acceptance of Mr. Lewis's demand on this point would have meant that in the face of his threatened strike the United State Government had surrendered.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 11 -- Nassau County's proposed 1942 budget, announced today, shows an increase over the 1941 budget of $1,094,270 to $25,021,961. It also discloses a county tax rate increase of 11 cents to $1.02 for each $100 of assessed valuation, a 1/2-cent reduction in the armory and Supreme Court levy to 1 1/2 cents and an unchanged police district tax rate of 19 cents.

The art and literary treasures of The Pierpont Morgan Library have been increased substantially during the last few years, according to a review of the activities and acquisitions of the institution from 1936 through 1940 just published.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII sent his felicitations today to a gathering of Catholic hierarchy commemorating the 300th anniversary of the founding of the Society of St. Sulpice and the sesquicentennial of its establishment in the United States.

The sixth day of the P.R. count of ballots for candidates for the City Council ended late last night with the election of six members from Manhattan, five from the Bronx and two from Brooklyn, making a total of fourteen, in view of the re-election of Councilman Frederick Schick, Staten Island Democrat, last Friday.

A reversal of the national policy of the United States in reference to the remainder of the earth will have to be effected if world peace is to be achieved, the Rev. Dr. Elmore McNeill McKee. rector of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church in East Sixteenth Street, declared yesterday.

Asserting that the United States was on Hitler's list of intended victims, Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, New York State Director of Civilian Defense, called for "forthright offensive and united action" to suppress Nazi aggression, in an Armistice Day address yesterday.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities Included in each group is given.

A revised course of study in modern history designed to emphasize the democratic principles of this country and point to the threat of totalitarian regimes has been proposed for the New York City school system by the Board of Superintendents.

DETROIT, Nov. 11 -- Neither strikes nor freedom of speech should be curtailed at the present time, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said in an address tonight before the Women's League of the United Synagogue of America, which is holding, its annual convention here.

LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Vichy Chief of State, has received an annuity of u600 regularly from England despite wartime exchange regulations and breaking of diplomatic relations between London and Vichy, Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today.

Leland Shaffer, quarterback for the New York football Giants, returned to action yesterday as his squad practiced at the Polo Grounds. Shaffer, who suffered a wrenched knee two weeks ago worked out with the B team in preparation for the Giants' clash with the Cleveland Rams here on Sunday.

The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, opened with a preview yesterday afternoon its annual exhibition of paintings. The preview was held for exhibiting artists and invited guests. The exhibition opens to the public today.

UNION CITY, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Union High School's football team turned back a late challenge by Memorial of West New York today to score an 18-12 victory in the eighteenth annual game between the North Hudson County rivals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A "consumers' pledge for total defense," through which 30,000,000 homes are invited to enlist in the national defense program, was made public here today by Miss Harriett Elliott, Associate Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, in charge of the Consumer Division.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Nov. 12 -- Having battered the Germans to a standstill on Moscow's western defense line, Russian troops concentrated yesterday on consolidation of their positions west of the Nara River, an authoritative commentator announced this morning on the Russian radio.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 11 -- Secretary Knox declared in an Armistice Day speech here today that America has striven by every means to maintain peace in the Pacific, but further forbearance would be misunderstood and the time had come when this country could no longer ignore its rights.

Hailing the Western Hemisphere as guardian of "the wave of the future," Dr. Carlos Davila, one-time President of Chile and Chilean Ambassador to the United States, declared last night that democracy and the free press had regained "their crusading spirit and their stoic fiber" after complacently having let it appear that "other worlds" had snatched "the torch of revolution from our hands."

MONTREAL, Nov. 11 (Canadian Press) -- The high-powered Detroit Red Wings line of Syd Abel, Don Grosso and Eddie Wares monopolize the first three spots in the National Hockey League's individual scoring race, statistics for the league's first week showed today.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 11 -- In authoritative quarters here great confidence was expressed today that the oil question would be settled approximately on Mexico's terms for these reasons:

Coach Lou Little interrupted the Columbia football practice yesterday at Baker Field to take his squad indoors for a chalk talk on Michigan manoeuvres. The players returned to the gridiron to practice the formations he had outlined and finished the drill under lights.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 11 -- At a meeting of Congress this afternoon the Rightest party voiced its criticism over the manner in which President Pedro Aguirre Cerda had withdrawn temporarily because of illness and Vice President Geronimo Mendez had been placed in supreme Executive power.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- The need for immediate mobilization of all American citizens to fight nazism and strengthen its own democracy was brought to the attention of the New York State Federation of Women's Club today. Speakers discussed international affairs, nutrition and preventive medicine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- As the United States celebrated today the signing of the World War armistice, President Roosevelt declared in his address that this country may be forced by Germany into another war. Other speakers emphasized the same theme of the Nazi peril.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a teacher in the Harlem area for ten years I am horrified by the wide-spread labeling of Harlem as a crime center. I am equally horrified at the detailing of hundreds of additional policemen to "solve" the problems of Harlem.
Iva Kitchell gave a program of "dance pantomines and parodies" last night before an audience that completely filled the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall and obviously loved every minute of it.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11 -- Running six furlongs in 1:11 1-5 to equal the stake record, George D. Widener's Overdrawn drove to a head triumph in the fifth Ritchie Handicap before more than 20,000 fans at Pimlico today. Mrs. Walter M. Jefford's Dawn Attack, favorite in the field of seven which contested the race named after Maryland's late Governor, lost the photo duel.

By a special two-way radio system set up just before he fled his country at the time of the German occupation, Dr. Jan Masaryk, Foreign Minister of the Czecho-Slovak Government-in-exile and son of that country's first President, keeps in constant touch with Czechoslovak patriot leaders in his homeland.

LONDON, Nov. 11 (U.P.) -- Maxim Litvinoff, new Soviet Ambassador to the United States, has been appointed Deputy Commissar for Foreign Affairs, in addition to his diplomatic assignment, it was announced today by Tass, official Soviet news agency, coincident with reports that Mr. Litvinoff would visit London briefly en route to Washington.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Underground garages from, which Russian tanks and armored cars can speed to the attack form a part of the intricate fortification system protecting Moscow, German dispatches from the front said tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 11 -- Dr. Ralph A. Burns, Professor of Education at Dartmouth University, told the New Jersey Education Association at the closing session of its annual convention here today, that American histories "were provincialized by a dominant Harvard School of Historians."

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Less than one-third of British voters feel that Britain has taken full advantage of the opportunities offered by the German attack on Russia, and the number who are satisfied with their government's conduct of the war has declined sharply since early Summer.

SOUTHBORO, Mass., Nov. 11 -- Dark clouds in the form of injuries have constantly enveloped the current St. Mark's School football team, so a strong hope exists here that the overdue silver lining will appear en masse during the classic Groton game tomorrow.

"New York Town," a comedy drama which opens at the Paramount, will be this morning's sole film newcomer. Mary Martin, Fred MacMurray, Lynne Overman, Akim Tamiroff and Robert Preston are featured in the film, which has been scheduled for a one-week showing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- General George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, called the nation tonight to be on guard against "a sudden and widespread attempt" by the Axis powers to sabotage the United States munitions, utility and transportation industries.

Boss, but Elected A discontented Tammany district leader has suggested to Christopher D. Sullivan that this would be a good time to resign as leader of the organization. Thereupon Mr. Sullivan reminds his critic that the latter represents only one-seventieth of the votes on the Tammany executive committee.

The average daily production of crude oil in the United States in the week ended Nov. 8 was 4,096,100 barrels, an increase of 24,900 barrels over the previous week and comparing with the 3,584,200-barrel daily average production in the same week of 1940, it was announced yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

Curtis High's powerful eleven ran its victory string to fourteen yesterday by downing Seward Park High, 21 to 7, at Thompson Stadium, Stapleton, S.I. Curtis, victor in six games this year and seven last year, is undefeated in fifteen games in a streak started with the final game of 1939.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 (U.P) -- Military spokesmen intimated tonight that German and Finnish troops had undertaken a far northern drive from the Salla area, ninety miles from the northwest corner of the White Sea, in an attempt to cut Russia's communications with the port of Murmansk and the whole Kola Peninsula.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- The Germans have been fought to at least a temporary standstill on the Russo-German front proper. This much it is permitted to deduce from the lack of important news from these areas.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- Bob Odell, 185-pound junior halfback from Sioux City, Iowa, was promoted to Pennsylvania's first team today as a replacement for Paxson Gifford and will start against Army at Franklin Field on Saturday.

The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, acting under Section 195a of the Penal Code, which makes the exhibition of a horse upon whose tail an operation has been performed a misdemeanor, served summonses yesterday on two managers of stables that are competing in the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- It costs the Army Quartermaster Corps only 48 cents a day to feed the average enlisted man, but on the diet the average new soldier grows out of his shoes and sometimes out of his clothes in a few months.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 12 -- Although Japanese Spokesman Koh Ishii declared yesterday that Prime Minister Winston Churchill's speech lining up Britain with the United States in case of a conflict in the Pacific was no surprise to Japan, which would "wait and see," the Japanese press denounced it as "an outrageous but crafty British plot to involve the United States in a war in the Pacific for the protection of British interests."

Sinclair Lewis, Clifton Fadiman and Sterling North have been selecting recently the book that will receive the third gold medal of the Limited Editions Club. The judges, working from a long list of books recommended by literary critics throughout the country, have been trying to find, and may have found by now, the book published in the last thtee years that is "most likely to attain the stature of a classic."

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- October sales of the members of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers ran ahead of last year, while the increased sales of clothing generally are forcing forward buying to be sure of delivery, the monthly report of the association showed today.

Men's and women's All-America swimming teams were nominated by committees of the Amateur Athletic Union yesterday, subject to approval at the fifty-third annual A.A.U. convention in Philadelphia on Saturday, Sunday and Monday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A check to see if rubber vital to defense output is being equitably distributed among plants through the country, was ordered today by Donald N. Nelson, director of priorities at the Office of Production Management.

Three fires that occurred within a short time of each other in the Bronx last night destroyed enormous quantities of wood, necessitated seven alarms and kept thirty-one pieces of fire and emergency apparatus on the go for about two hours.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- When the House Judiciary Committee tomorrow begins to examine the laws and the precedents concerning the legal immunities of members of Congress, before determining whether Representative Fish of New York shall respond to a grand jury subpoena, it will review the history of the greatest struggles in the history of democracy.
CAIRO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The R.A. F. Middle East Command issued this communique today:

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The threat of a second welders' walkout in Los Angeles County shipyards disappeared tonight with a statement from Karl V. Morris, president of the United Welders, Cutters and Helpers Union, independent, that A.F.L. and C.I.O. union officials had agreed to end any discrimination agrainst members of the Independent group.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The national income as shown by payments of money to individuals rose in September to a point representing an annual total of $92,000,000,000, the highest figure on record, the Department of Commerce announced today.

An Armistice Day throng of 35,000 persons at the Eternal Light monument in Madison Square yesterday heard Mayor La Guardia declare that America would "stand by until nazism, Hitler and the dictators are crushed and destroyed and the world is free again."
A number of sidelights on the American "front" of the last two weeks -- all of them of direct or indirect, great or minor importance to the fighting fronts:

Ironic though an Armistice Day peace conference might appear on the surface, the one conducted yesterday by Sir Norman Angell at Town Hall provided an example of how men representing widely divergent viewpoints can agree on the fundamental principles of a permanent world peace.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11 -- Plans for two productions at RKO took shape today with the announcement that Randolph Scott and James Craig will play the leads in "Bombardier" and the disclosure that Joseph Cotten and Ruth Warrick will be seen in the major supporting roles in "There Goes Lona Henry."

Another Resumption Act by the United States Government, making currency and gold coin mutually convertible was urged as the best control against Inflation by Walter E. Trent, director of the Rocky Mountains Metals Foundation, Washington, yesterday at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

ROME, Nov. 11 -- Italy yesterday seized 150 hostages as a consequence of bombing and shooting incidents in Spalato on the occupied Dalmatian coast of Yugoslavia. It is not stated what will happen to the hostages if those guilty of the attacks are not apprehended.

In an effort to find a constructive program to remove conditions that breed crime in Harlem, the Social Service Bureau of the Magistrates Courts called yesterday an emergency conference of magistrates, social welfare workers and church leaders for 3 o'clock this afternoon in Harlem Court, 121st Street near Lexington Avenue.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 11 -- Brazilian Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha arrived by plane from Rio de Janeiro late this afternoon on his way to Chile for an official visit.

Commissioner Rudolph Reimer of the Port of New York Authority has been designated by Mayor La Guardia to represent the city at the National Rivers and Harbors Congress in Miami tomorrow and Friday, it was announced yesterday.

A registration statement covering the proposed public offering of 230,000 common shares of Marshall Field Co. is being filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The offering will not constitute new financing by the company.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- A panting youth, bearing an aluminum baton encasing a pledge of Pennsylvania schoolboys that they would keep themselves physically fit for national defense, dashed up to Independence Hall at 10:59 A.M. today to end a 567-mile cross-State relay run in which 1,600 students took part.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Four troop or supply ships, plus two sailing vessels and an Italian destroyer, have been sunk in the Mediterranean since the brilliant convoy action of last Sunday, the Admiralty announced today. This time it was British submarines that attacked.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Nov. 11 -- America is in real danger today, because it is smug and self-satisfied and susceptible to overconfidence, Sergeant Alvin C. York, World War hero, said here today in an Armistice Day address. He blamed the activities of Charles A. Lindbergh and other leaders of the America First Committee for this condition.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Defense officials acted today to assure Soviet Russia of the machine-tool equipment she needs. In an order issued by the Office of Production Management at the request of Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Lease-Lend Administrator, machine-tool builders were directed to accept specific purchase orders placed by the Amtorg Trading Corporation, buying and selling agency in this country for Russia, on behalf of the Soviet Government.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Led by Raymond Dooney, fleet-footed back, Admiral Farragut Naval Academy of Pine Beach, N.J., turned back the New York Military Academy eleven of Cornwallon-Hudson today in their "Little Army-Navy" battle before more than 7,00 spectators in Hinchliffe Stadium.

VALLEY COTTAGE, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- On a country estate here in the hills of Rockland County a Russian harvest grown with hopes for the best in American soil has been carefully stored for the Winter under the watchful eye of Countess Alexandra Tolstoy, youngest daughter of the late Russian novelist.

Troops from Army posts throughout the State enlivened parades and exercises held yesterday in New Jersey in observance of Armistice Day. Displays of mobile military equipment featured many of the processions, which were climaxed by the laying of wreaths on graves and monuments.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's Armistice Day address:

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bradley Murray will give an old-fashioned reception on Thanksgiving Day at their home, 11 East Ninetieth Street, to introduce their daughters, the Misses Joan and Marcia Murray.

The phrase "What did it get you?" which President Roosevelt yesterday borrowed from Sergeant York, is a pungent Americanism. The man who asks it wants to be shown. You can't kid him. His answer to a burst of eloquence is likely to be, "And so what?" or "Yeah?" with a rising inflection that goes right through the roof.

An immense audience listened last night in Carnegie Hall to a program consisting of two major-compositions by Sergei Rachmaninoff, played by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conductor, and received both compositions with rapturous applause.
Unusual experiences came to Benny Friedman, head coach of C.C.N.Y.'s football team, and one member of his squad yesterday.

SAN DIEGO, Nov. 11 -- The strike of A.F.L. building craftsmen, which has tied up $23,000,000 of Navy and marine construction in San Diego's defense program, will end at noon tomorrow, union leaders announced tonight following a long meeting.
Mayor La Guardia backed up his proclamation urging support of the annual roll-call of the American Red Cross by being enrolled himself early yesterday in his office in City Hall.

N.Y.U.'s freshman football team, victor over the Fordham yearlings on election day, sought an Armistice Day success over the Manhattan College cubs yesterday, but was lucky to come off with a 6-6 tie at Ohio Field.

Armistice Day retail trade was active hare yesterday, with colder weather proving a stimulating factor. Merchants estimated that the combined sales of yesterday and Monday showed an increase of 10 to 15 per cent over the corresponding days last year.

A sales campaign to enable the hotel industry to take its place in the forefront of American business was initiated yesterday for the benefit of members of the New York State Hotel Association and others in the field at a session held in conjunction with the National Hotel Exposition, which opened Monday in Grand Central Palace.

VICHY, France, Nov. 11 -- Returning from a round-trip air flight to French Somaliland, Vice Admiral Rene Platon, French Minister of Colonies, today declared to reporters at the air field here that In view of the British attitude the colony would hold out to the end.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Power plays carried the St. Bonaventure football team to two fourth period touchdowns today and a 13-to-6 victory over the St. Anselm Hawks in a game marred by frequent fumbles, pass interceptions and penalties.

MANILA, Wednesday, Nov. 12 -- Returns in yesterday's elections indicated early today that President Manuel Quezon was leading his nearest opponent by about 7 to 1, assuring him of re-election to the Presidency for another four years. He had previously announced, however, his intention to serve only two years and then relinquish the Presidency to Sergio Osmena, who is apparently winning re-election as Vice President by an even bigger margin than Quezon.
MOSCOW, Nov. 11 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The following Soviet communique was broadcast today:
BERLIN, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The German High Command communique issued said today:
I will buy carefully. I will take good care of the things I have. I will waste nothing. This is the pledge that we are all asked to sign on this "War Against Waste Day."

LONDON, Nov. 11 (UP) -- A spokesman for the Polish. Government in Exile charged today that the Germans had converted the tiny settlement of Palmiry, fifteen, miles from Warsaw, into a "village of death" and had executed and buried there 10,000 Polish political, educational and religious leaders.

WATERVILLE, Me., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Colby won the Maine College Football Conference championship today by scoring two touchdowns in the last period to down Bates, 14 to 7. Colby shared the title with Bowdoin the past three years, and this was the first time that the Mules had won outright in eighteen years.

Approximately $400,000,000 will be distributed to more than 8,000,000 Christmas Club members by about 5,000 banking and savings institutions in National Prosperity Week, which begins on Dec. 1, it was announced yesterday by Herbert F. Rawll, founder and president of the Christmas Club system.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- President Roosevelt and other officials and citizens joined tonight in appealing for the support of all American citizens in the annual membership roll-call of the American Red Cross in a program carried by the major broadcasting companies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A story of how adventure carried him through bitter political battles, troublesome lawsuits and even physical danger to the highest office of his State, leaving a trail of enmities, was told to the Elections Committee today by Senator Langer of North Dakota.

PARDON the inadequate presentation. There should be sound effects with this. And dynamic gestures. It was Al Schacht, the Clown Prince of Baseball, who delivered the monologue. Mr. Schacht has a good loud voice -- anyway, a loud voice -- and he throws a lot of dramatic acting into his telling of tales. He really weaves a tale forward, backward and then crisscross just to confuse the issue.

James Monroe High's hopes for an unbeaten season were shattered yesterday when the Eagles fell before the heavier Stuyvesant High team, 7 to 0, in the opener of the scholastic football double-header at Triborough Stadium. In the finale, DeWitt Clinton turned back a rugged Evander Childs eleven, 14 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Speaking at the tomb of Woodrow Wilson in the Washington Cathedral today, Sumner Welles, Undersecretary of State, drew a contrast between the situation of the United States as it is, and as it might have been if it had followed Wilson's leadership.

Net profit of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., for the first nine months of 1941 amounted to $883,169 or $1.54 a share, it was announced yesterday by Captain E.V. Rickenbacker, president and general manager of the corporation.This profit compared with $792,221, or $1.38 a share, earned in the same period of 1940.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Nov. 11 -- The capacity of Christ Episcopal Church here was taxed this morning at the funeral service for Philip James Roosevelt, prominent yachtsman and investment broker, who was drowned on Saturday afternoon off his estate, Dolonor, in Cove Neck.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A pledge to supply the defense industries with all the steel required was given by steel representatives today in the first industry-wide conference ever held with the government on defense needs. For its part, the government, through high officials of the defense organization, promised to define more precisely the types and quantities of steel which were needed and the dates upon which it should be delivered.

ROME, Nov. 11 -- The sudden announcement that regular transportation by bus and street car in all Italian cities will cease after 10 in the evening was made today. This means a sort of practical curfew, for the official communique ordered that, in consequence, all public places -- meaning restaurants, cafes, theatres or opera and concert halls -- must close by 10 o'clock, starting tonight.
HELSINKI, Finland, Wednesday, Nov. 12 -- The Finnish Government rejected today the United States' warning to stop fighting Russia or risk loss of American friendship.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The texts of the majority and minority opinions of the National Defense Mediation Board in the captive coal mines case are as follows:

Street-length evening dresses of simply cut gold and silver metal cloth or rayon crepe, with glittering sequin trim, featured yesterday by Abraham Straus at a benefit fashion showing at the Waldorf-Astorla Hotel, suggested a further step for those of the younger set who have adopted the trend toward casual evening wear.

Fifteen persons were injured and dozens of others were shaken severely at about 6 o'clock last night when a northbound local-express of the Third Avenue elevated line failed to stop despite application of the brakes and rammed another train standing in the 143d Street station in the Bronx.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Jeremiah T. Mahoney's call for the reorganization of the Democratic party in New York County raises an issue much deeper than would appear from the open letter which he addressed to Christopher D. Sullivan. His objective is not to be achieved by the simple device of obliterating the label "Tammany" and substituting new leaders who will be more restrained in parceling out choice jobs among their kinfolk.
Armistice Day was observed with three-fold significance yesterday throughout the United States and Great Britain as well as in many parts of Europe.

LONDON", Nov. 11 -- A "mad killer," reportedly an artilleryman on leave, roared through West London in a black sedan for five hours today, blazing away at bystanders with a submachine gun and shotgun, killing two and wounding seven before he was captured in a wild police chase.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Hog arrivals here and at leading outside markets were reduced substantially today and prices held steady. Best offerings brought $10.35 a hundred pounds. Packing plants and dressed meat markets were closed because of the holiday. Salable receipts at twelve leading livestock centers amounted to 47.100 head against 68.800 last Tuesday.

The Harlem "crime wave," shocking though it is, has at least called attention to the deplorable situation, of thousands of good citizens who are doing their level best to improve their own lot and to bring up their children in the right way. The Harlem situation is not a race problem.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio said today in an interview that a story was current in Washington that the President had rejected a Japanese peace plan that involved the maintenance of Japanese garrisons in five principal Chinese cities.
Fordham's defeat by Pittsburgh and the 7-7 tie to which Texas was held by Baylor had their aftermaths in the fifth of the weekly football ranking polls conducted by The Associated Press.

Mrs. Frederick J. McEvoy gave a luncheon yesterday in her apartment in the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria. Among the guests were Prince and Princess de Bourbon, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Newton, Mrs. Jan Boissevain, Mrs. Chester Davis, Mrs. Richard T. Wilson, Mrs. Caresse Crosby, Mrs. Henry Downe, T. Chesley Richardson, John Cyrus Distler, Thomas Haskins, Roger Stern, S. Van Houten, Said-Reute Werner, Riccardo Magni, Neil McIntyre Pearce and Frederick O. Beach.

Any one passing through rural New Jersey yesterday would have had no doubts as to the popularity of hunting in that State, for it seemed that every man with a shotgun and enough money for a box of shells was out to get a rabbit or pheasant for supper.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The acting chairman of Argentina's "Dies Committee," declared tonight that he had evidence substantiating President Roosevelt's charges of German designs on South America.

It was probably no coincidence that Leopold Stokowski scheduled Beethoven's Ninth Symphony for Armistice Day. In presenting the tremendous work at his second concert with the NBC Symphony Orchestra at the Cosmopolitan Opera House last night, he chose a solemn day in a momentous time to set forth once more Beethoven's affirmation of the brotherhood of man.
A vast audience, with fashion in all its glamour radiating in the boxes and arena seats, viewed the performance of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

DETROIT, Nov. 11 -- J. Pierrepont Moffat, United States Minister to Canada, told an audience at the dedication of an international peace monument at Belle Isle today that 126 years of peace and understanding between Canada and the United States had resulted in a strong defense tie-up between the two countries.

VICHY, France, Nov. 11 (U.P) -- Admiral Rene Platon said today that British planes had dropped warnings that the British would execute any persons found guilty of destroying the railroad or port works at Jibuti.

"We must remember," said Mr. Roosevelt in his letter to Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee, "that taxation is a necessary complement of price control legislation, because the continuing effectiveness of price control is largely dependent upon the restriction of the demand for goods."

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- Maxim Litvinoff's appointment as Russian Ambassador to Washington has annoyed the Reich sufficiently for its propaganda service to unloose a flood of abuse against "Moscow's traveling salesman in bolshevism."

The Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income of 51,795,051 for the three months ended on Sept. 30, equal to 96 cents a share on 1,857,912 capital shares, compared with $438,475, or 23 cents a share, in the 1940 period.

Under the banner of John Golden, Cornelia Otis Skinner, heretofore seen on Broadway mainly in monologue dramas, will make her bow at the Hudson tonight as star of the comedy, "Theatre," by Guy Bolton and Somerset Maugham.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The number of unemployed in the United States declined 600,000 to 3,900,000 from Sept. 15 to mid-October, Howard O. Hunter, WPA Administrator, said today.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 11 -- The National Government has neither the information nor the capacity to take care of communities and their working people in the small businesses all over the United States, Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney of New York, told the New York State Council of Retail Merchants here tonight.
LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Admiralty today issued this comminique:

Unless President Roosevelt's "attempts to draw the United States" into "actual war" are checked, the American people who are opposed to war may be forced to form a movement of "Free Americans" similar to the Free French Government of General Charles de Gaulle, John F. Finerty, national chairman of the Keep America Out of War Congress, declared last night.

Lieutenant Carios Alfaro of the Peruvian Army team covered him self with glory at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night by winning the International Individual Military Championship Challenge Trophy, the only triumph gained thus far by the Peruvians in seven nights of competition.
PROFESSOR ARTHUR HOBSON QUINN of the University of Pennsylvania has produced, after years of painstaking research, a massive and major critical biography of Edgar Allan Poe.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Nov. 11 -- Trading was rather active on the Bourse today. The undertone was firm and there was a good investment demand. Royal Dutch rose 1 5/3 points to 328; Amsterdam Rubber 1 3/4 to 317 1/4 and Philips 1 1/4 to 281 1/4.

ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- Little net change in factory employment and payrolls was noticeable in October, Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, announced today in her report showing that employment rose 0.3 per cent, while payrolls dropped 0.3 per cent.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 12 -- The German position about Tula, 110 miles south of Moscow, was described tonight in Soviet military dispatches as seriously endangered by Russian counter-attacks that already had driven two German divisions back five miles.

It is more than a decade since Ernest Hutcheson, who played last night in Carnegie Hall, has given a piano recital in this city. The dean of the Juilliard School of Music has played much more recently 'with orchestra and in performances of chamber music; this was the occasion he chose to reappear as recitalist before his New York public.

LAKE PLACID CLUB, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Reaffirmation of the fundamentals of American democracy was urged upon the club women of New York State by three speakers at the convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs at the Lake Placid Club.

SOUTHBORO, Mass., Nov. 12 -- Deft, timely passing and potent line smashing earned favored Groton a 26-to-0 gridiron success this chilly afternoon and sent the happy victors home with numerous St. Mark's jerseys as prized souvenirs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- An order for about $240,000 worth of airplanes, let today by the War Department, marked the introduction into military operations of light aircraft of the types heretofore used exclusively by private fliers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- An undetermined number of Southern Democrats, estimated to be sufficient to turn the scales either way on the pending amendments to the Neutrality Act, was reported tonight to have won from the Administration a promise of antistrike legislation to curb walkouts during the emergency period.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts will enter the market on Nov. 24 with an issue of $1,500,000 of Boston airport bonds, for which bidders are requested to specify the rate of interest. The bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1941, will mature serially on Oct. 1, 1943 to 1947.

Mrs. Alfred W. King Jr. of Apawamis won in straight games in leading her team to a 4-to-1 victory over Ardsley as Class B competition began yesterday in the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association. Playing on her home court, Mrs. King defeated Mrs. Ruliff Davidson, 15-6, 15-7 and 15-6.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Habit being hard to break, it's difficult to restrain yourself from seeking Route 7, which, is one way to get to Dartmouth, when you set out to pay a call on Earl (Red) Blaik, Army's football coach.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- A tie-up of freight transportation by motor truck in eleven Midwestern States after midnight Saturday was threatened today by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, after negotiations over wages between the drivers and operators reached a deadlock.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 12 -- Gestapo agents have made mass arrests of leading Belgrade families, who are being held as hostages and will be shot without trial in reprisal for Chetnik warfare in Serbia and all forms of violent resistance to the German occupation of the capital, this correspondent learned today from foreign military intelligence sources at Ankara.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 12 -- A strike halted production today at the Mack Manufacturing Corporation, which holds $10,000,000 defense contracts, notably for tank transmissions. The strike became effective at 8 A.M., when the day shift was to go on.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The memory of Elizabeth Cady Stanton was honored today on the 126th anniversary of her birth, by the opening in the headquarters of the National Woman's Party on Capitol Hill of the first feminist library in the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Calling the defense housing set-up "a confused multiplication of defense housing agencies, with ill defined functions competing avidly with one another," Nathan Straus, Administrator or the United States Housing Authority, urged today before the House Public Buildings Committee investigating the possibilities of moving some Federal agencies out of Washington the abolition of "wasteful, inefficient or unnecessary" agencies and the centralization of authority under the USHA.

BERLIN, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Pursuing German and Rumanian troops have partly blocked the narrow Kerch Straits and are "slowly strangling" Soviet forces trying to flee from Crimea into the Caucasus, a military spokesman claimed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Complete cooperation with the Civilian Defense program was pledged at the annual meeting today of the Women's Supreme Council of B'nai B'rith. On behalf of the forty-eight senior and junior auxiliaries, having 50,000 members, the council voted unanimously for all-out participation in the nation's defense effort.

The newly reorganized Ballet Theatre last night opened a twoweek season under the auspices of the New Opera Company at the Forty-fourth Street theatre. Its reorganization, besides a change of management, includes the addition of Irina Baronova, Alicia Markova and a dozen other dancers from the various Russian ballets (replacing favorites of other seasons) as well as a director, a musical director and a regisseur from the same source.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 12 -- If transport difficulties can be solved, Free Poland soon will have an army of 150,000 in action on the Eastern Front, equipped with material from the United States and Britain, General Wladyslaw Sikorski, the Polish commander, said here today.

George W. Treat, chairman of the Wickwire Spencer Steel Company, yesterday notified holders of voting trust certificates for its stock that the directors had declined an offer of the Republic Steel Corporation to buy the assets of the company for $16 a share.

Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra Day came to a climax last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with the first concert of the newly formed Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra, the first professional symphony orchestra with a regular subscription season that the borough has had since the demise of the old Brooklyn Philharmonic in 1891.

Equality in sacrifice must be accepted by the American people for the duration of the national emergency regardless of the constitutional rights of the individual, Vice President Henry A. Wallace said last night in an address at the annual dinner of the Academy of Political Science.

Willie Bloff and George E. Browne, Chicago hoodlums turned labor leaders, were sentenced yesterday to ten and eight years in prison respectively and then held up as bad examples of union chiefs who used their positions only to benefit themselves.

Marking a radical departure from the accepted pacifist attitude that the government keep "hands off" camps set up for conscientious objectors, the Rev. Eric M. Tasman, representing the National Service Board for Religious Objectors, disclosed yesterday that the board would consider proposals for the establishment of a government-sponsored camp.

The cumulative effect of the steady wearing away of values in the last two months became boldly evident yesterday when pent-up unrest among holders of securities over the holiday resolved itself into liquidation which dropped stocks to the lowest levels in almost a year and a half.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Japanese situation in the Pacific area is "very serious," and Administration officials are "very much concerned over it," said Attorney General Francis Biddle today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Directors of the Eastman Kodak Company declared today an extra dividend of $1 a share on the common stock and the quarterly dividend of $1.50. At the same time it voted a wage dividend to employes, which consequently was increased by about $1,200,000.
HELSINKI, Nov. 12 -- Following is a partial text of the Finnish Note to the United States:

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 12 -- The Connecticut Manufacturers Association was told here today by a Treasury official that higher taxes are required to avert inflation, and by a Yale professor that luxury taxes must be spread to the 90 per cent of the population which is not now touched by such levies.

Tammany Hall has recommended to Governor Lehman the appointment of Lloyd Church as a Justice of the State Supreme Court to fill the vacancy caused by Mr. Church's resignation on Sept. 15, it was learned yesterday.

Allie Tannenbaum, obviously shocked by the sudden death of his room-mate and close personal friend, Abe Reles, a former leader of the Brooklyn murder syndicate, spent yesterday afternoon in Kings County Court, pale-faced and weak of voice, testifying against the underworld bosses who gave the murder assignments by which Tannenbaum and Reles lived.

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 12 -- Notice of an intent to strike at the Chrysler tank arsenal in Macomb County has been filed with the State Labor Mediation Board by the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., Local 833, the board announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- President Roosevelt intervened in the captive-mine situation today and called leaders of the United Mine Workers and of the steel companies which own the mines to a conference Friday morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Trade between the United States and China, as far as the Chinese end is concerned, was placed under the complete control of the Chinese Stabilization Board by amendments to the Freezing Fund Control, General License No. 58, announced today by the Treasury.
LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A lone daylight raider dropped high explosive bombs at a point on then northeast coast of England today.

Efforts to provide "a maximum of educational opportunity for 50,000 young men and women" in the four municipal colleges, while over-shadowed somewhat in the last year by the revelations of the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the schools, have resulted in the adoption of a number of "new or newly emphasized services and policies," according to the second annual public report of the Board of Higher Education.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Superior Oil Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment disclosing the names of the underwriters for the offering of its $15,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent debentures due on Nov. 1, 1956.

The anti-gray-hair vitamin, a member of the all-important vitamin B complex, recently identified as the chemical para-amino-benzoic acid, has restored color to the hair of more than 300 human beings of all ages, who had become gray prematurely or otherwise, it was reported here last night before the Fall meeting of the Society for Experimental Biology and Medicine at the Cornell University Medical College.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, which is now at loggerheads with coastwise steamship operators over the question of higher pay, announced yesterday that he would join with the operators in appearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission to argue for higher freight rates.

Two of the largest companies printing cotton goods announced shutdowns yesterday because they were unable to buy enough gray goods to keep their plants running, and several other companies admitted that they were running only from week to week with no reserve of goods either in their possession or on order.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, Nov. 13 -- From Congressional sources it was learned early today that President Roosevelt is considering a three-point plan to end strikes in defense industries.

Following successful training of 25,000 volunteers for the Fire Department auxiliary in the last fifteen weeks, Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh said yesterday that he was trying to enlist 25,000 longshoremen in a special marine division to guard the waterfront during the national emergency.

To turn Bacon's saying around, some people count the misses and not the hits, and make more of a black mark or two than of long rows of white. Most of our old endowed colleges have been denounced unfairly from time to time. The State or citysupported institutions are subject to similar misjudgments.

TRENTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Philip L. Coffin Jr., a former assistant Attorney General of New Jersey, and Morris Frank Whealton, one-time Philadelphia and Camden investment broker, were sentenced today by United States District Judge Phillip Forman after pleading guilty to a five-year-old indictment charging conspiracy to use the mails in a fraudulent scheme.

A new City Council of twenty-six members, whose roster includes the first Communist to be elected to public office in New York City, was officially elected yesterday after just one week of counting of the Proportional Representation paper ballots cast on Nov. 4.

The National Defense Mediation Board at its formation was ostensibly balanced. It consisted of four members to represent labor, four to represent management and three to represent the public. (In addition, a list of alternates was named.) But the paper balance did not, unfortunately, also represent a real balance.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 12 -- Hedy Lamarr and John Garfield will play Dolores and Danny in the screen version of John Steinbeck's 'Tortilla Flat," with Spencer Tracy as Pilon if Metro-GoldwynMayer adheres to present plans, it was learned today.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Following is the text of King George's address opening a new session of Parliament today:
LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Allied military experts interpret a series of optimistic Russian claims as meaning that Adolf Hitler's war machine has Jolted to a dead halt in Russia.

A strike of 15,000 long-distance telephone workers was called for midnight tomorrow after efforts by the United States Conciliation Service to settle the wage dispute between the American Telephone Telegraph Company and an independent union had broken down for the third time yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Administration's proposal to permit American merchant ships to enter combat zones and ports of belligerents was vigorously opposed in the House today by a recalcitrant Democratic minority, which rebelled against the Administration's failure to solve defense strikes and insisted that drastic revision of the Neutrality Act meant war.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Nov. 12 -- The demand for stocks continued today on the Bourse and prices showed gains up to 5 points. Royal Dutch was active and 3 1/8 points higher at 331 1/8; Amsterdam Trading rose 5 to 500 1/2; Amsterdam Rubber 2 1/4 to 319 1/2; Unilever 1 to 164 7/8 and A.K.U. 1 to 154 3/4.

Working on the theory that crime in Harlem is due almost entirely to economic conditions, the Rev. Adam Clayton Powell, newly elected Negro Councilman, announced yesterday formation of a People's Committee which will attempt to bring together the Negroes and Puerto Ricans in the area and use their organized strength to get jobs for them.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 12 -- Six occupants of a truck were killed and another injured critically this evening as a Long Island Railroad express train, thundering down the westbound track at fifty miles an hour, crashed into the vehicle at the Old Country Road grade crossing here.

The National Horse Show closed last night in Madison Square Garden with many social and military notables in the boxes and fashion in its full sweep of glory. The attendance at the week's sessions set a record.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 11 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- A survey of opinion here today showed that Thai leaders generally believe a Japanese invasion of this country, as part of a drive to cut China's Burma Road munitions route, will be undertaken during the next few weeks, when the dry season makes military operations easiest.

An entire floor in the building at 41-3 West Twenty-fifth Street has been leased by August Rupp Jr., manufacturer of bedspreads, draperies and allied lines, through Adams Co., Inc. The latter concern also rented to the Newspaper Guild of New York about 5,000 square feet in 90-8 Park Avenue through the Cross Brown Company.

VICHY, France, Nov. 12 -- Some passive resistance to the Vichy Government continues, according to an article in the Royalist newspaper, Action Francaise, which predicts that the movement will be stamped out.

An outpouring of five times as many persons as had been expected jammed Harlem Court yesterday afternoon to discuss with intense interest the conditions that prevail in Harlem and possible remedies for them. More than 200 persons answered the call of the Social Service Bureau of the Magistrate's Courts, which had summoned the emergency meeting.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 12 -- On legs a bit shaky but with plenty of timbre in her moo a 1,300-pound Holstein cow was led back to the farm today after a bolt for freedom that took her on a fourteen-hour ramble through a storm sewer.

With twenty-three new diphtheria cases in New York City last week, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, warned parents thata the "diphtheria season" was beginning. The total was the greatest for any week since early last March.
NEW YORK Baron Robert Silvercruys, Belgian Minister to Canada, is at the Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull, discussing at his press conference today Finland's "polite" refusal to heed his plea to cease offensive military operations and negotiate peace with the Soviet Union, expressed the hope that the Finnish people were still not irrevocably committed to the war and a collaboration with Germany that would mean the loss of their liberties and institutions.
NAIROBI, Kenya Colony, Nov. 12 (AP) -- British East African Headquarters issued the following today:
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A British R.A.F. Middle East communique today said:

The Helsinki Government took many hundreds of words yesterday to say no to Secretary Hull's proposal that she withdraw her troops to the 1939 frontier and cease hostilities against Russia. Much can be said for some of the arguments advanced. The Finns have had a taste of one unprovoked Russian attack, of compulsory cessions of Finnish territory to Russia, of unwarranted interference by Russia in Finland's domestic affairs.

Brooklyn's revivified Dodgers, apparently out of the running three weeks ago but now a definite threat for Eastern honors in the National Football League, will leave for Pittsburgh at 10:30 tomorrow night. On Sunday, at Forbes Field, Dr. John Bain (Jock) Sutherland's men will attempt to add the Pittsburgh Steelers to their list of recent victims, who, in succession, include the Giants, Eagles and Redskins.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A suggestion that a committee of six foreign traders, three representing exporters and an equal number freight forwarders, be named to confer with his office on the prob- lem of handling lease-lend shipments through normal channels, was made to a foreign trade committee which met with Edward R. Stettiniua Jr., Lease-Lend Administrator, in his office today.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 -- Leading operators and plain miners Joined today in predicting that any stoppage of coal digging in the captive mines owned by the steel companies because of the unionshop controversy would be shortlived if it even developed.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The Soviet Union is performing the miracle of long-term planning coupled with improvisation in re-establishing all its key war industries in provinces east of the Volga, the British Ministry of Economic Warfare disclosed today.

Time after time there were outbursts of applause to greet the gowns that made up the midseason collection, presented by Stein Blaine at yesterday's Salon d'Elegance luncheon in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton.
LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued this communique today:

WHEN this innocent bystander was handed what looked like a frayed playbill advertising the dramatic appearance of "The Champion of the World, the Actor-Athlete, with a Carload of Scenery," the natural conclusion was that it had to do with Madcap Max Baer. The part about the "Carload of Scenery" was responsible for that glaring error.
Trading in the local wholesale markets yesterday was fair to good and supplies were normal to moderate. Prices on steer hinds and ribs were weak to lower. Kosher beef was steady to 50 cents higher.

An audience representative of society and artistic circles attended the opening performance of the Ballet Theatre last night at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre. The ballet is being presented under the auspices of the New Opera Company.

There will be an adequate supply of steel next year both for defense and restricted civilian needs, according to a fifty-five page survey issued yesterday by the statistical department of the National Association of Manufacturers.

Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, will make his next defense of the title on Jan. 9 in Madison Square Garden in a return bout against Buddy Baer California giant. The fight will be in the interests of the New York Auxiliary of the Navy Relief Society, of which Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, Commandant o the Third Naval District and Commander of the North Atlantic Naval Coastal Frontier, is president.

Sometime after daylight yesterday Abe Reles, squat, bulgy-jawed informer against the Brooklyn murder ring, climbed out on a window ledge on the sixth floor of the Half Moon Hotel on Coney Island boardwalk, fully dressed but hatless.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- A strike on the country's railroads beginning at 6 A. M., Dec. 7, was ordered today by the executives of the "Big Five" operating brotherhoods. The 350,000 workers in the brotherhoods -- engineers, firemen, conductors, brakemen and switchmen -- were instructed to leave their jobs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 10:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The preoccupation of defense agencies with steel supply problems was evident here today in orders issued by the Office of Production Management and the Office of Price Administration applying to that industry and its products.
The Aussies were in town yesterday -- the dinkum Aussies. That is, to the uninitiated, the honest-to-goodness Australians.

Many dinners were given last night at Sherry's before the performance of "Spring Again" at the Henry Miller Theatre for the benefit of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery. Mrs. Roger Wisner, president of the beneficiary, and Captain Wisner entertained for Mr. and Mrs. A. Wallace Chauncey, Miss Elisabeth Remsen, Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. O'Brien, Dr. and Mrs. Eugene S. Coler and Dr. Clinton Barker.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Nov. 13 -- German troops are engaged in an all-out effort to break Red Army resistance in one area of the salient around Serpukhov, which is about sixty miles below Moscow, and the Russians have been forced to yield some ground, it was acknowledged this morning by a Soviet radio commentator.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Such hope as exists here that work will not stop in the captive coal mines, and thus depress the essential output of steel for the defense program, arises from the presence of a set of alternatives. These may all die by Saturday, but they were breathing today.

Directors of Merck Co., Inc., proposed yesterday in a letter sent to stockholders the issuance and sale of $5,369,000 of 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock. Sale of the stock would provide additional working capital for continued expansion in operations and would enable the company to pay off existing bank loans.
BERLIN, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Nov. 7 shows the following changes for the week, in thousands of reichsmarks:

Mal Stevens, N.Y.U. coach, who by now is accustomed to being on the short end of things, would like very much to start a triple-threat left halfback against Tulane Saturday at the Yankee Stadium. As it is, however, Mal will have to settle for a double-threat man if he chooses between Joe Frank and Wyatt Teubert, as now seems probable.

They have been doing it all their lives. Walking miles to buy a cut of meat for a few cents less or a remnant from a pushcart. Not only taking care of their meager supply of clothes but passing them on to their children and their friends' children.

Officers and instructors of the United States Army Quartermasters School for Bakers and Cooks at Governors Island visited the National Hotel Exposition in Grand Central Palace yesterday to compare methods and sample the work of French chefs and others engaged in the preparation of food.

Sales of the Schenley Distillers Corporation for the fiscal year which ended Aug. 31 were the highest in the company's history and were almost 50 per cent greater than in the 1940 year, according to the annual report signed by Lewis S. Rosenstiel, chairman, and Lester E. Jacobi, president. They rose from $81,473,632 to $121,992,349.
SINGAPORE, Nov. 12 -- The most extensive manoeuvres yet held in Northern Malaya began today in the jungles and rice lands of Selangor, Kedah and neighboring Malay States.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday unless otherwise specified.
It was bleak and cold yesterday on the field where the Manhattan College football squad was drilling for its penultimate battle of the season with Holy Cross at Worcester on Saturday.

Nicaragua has ten thousand soldiers ready to assist the United States in twenty-four hours if this nation should become involved in war, Colonel Irving A. Lindberg, Honorary Commissioner of Customs and High Commissioner of Nicaragua, revealed here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A heavy run of hogs forced prices 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight lower on the livestock market today. Dressed pork was steady to 1/2 cent a pound lower, light loins showing the loss at 21 1/2 to 22 cents a pound.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income equivalent to $25,695,938 in United States currency after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal after preferred dividend payments to $1.66 a share on 14,584,025 common shares.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Senator Langer of North Dakota, concluding three days of testimony, told the Elections Committee today that he paid a total of $60,455 for land and improvements which Gregory Brunk of Des Moines testified that he bought from Mr. Langer for $56,800 on a "sight unseen" basis in 1937 and 1938.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill gave the House of Commons, opening its new session today, late figures showing that the Battle of the Atlantic was proceeding steadily in Great Britain's favor. He foresaw that "the freedom-loving powers will be possessed of large quantities of ships in 1943 which will enable overseas operations to take place utterly beyond British resources at the present time."

Once upon a time there was a maid of all work whose name was Missouri. And when she traveled north to Connecticut to ply her trade, she brought with her the pride and prejudice of the South. Deepest of all was her disdain for the yellow cornmeal of the North, unfit, she thought, to be dignified by the name of meal and unworthy to appear in her crisp co'n pone.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Eric Thomson, Pinehurst amateur, and Gene Sarazen, veteran professional, teamed so well today in the final round of the Mid-South amateur-professional golf tournament that they returned a net score of 29, 28-57.

The major Pall exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, "America South of the United States," opened with an invitation preview last evening, will open to the public today and will remain current through Jan. 4. It consists of colonial and folk art from all the Central and South American countries.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 12 -- China now has 6,000,000 men under arms and 4,000,000 at the front, with plenty of food, small arms and ammunition, General Ho Yingchin, War Minister and Chief of Staff, told me today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The War Department awarded contracts totaling $4,112,167 today. Awards to concerns in the New York area included the following:
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 12 (AP) -- The projects committee of the National Rivers and Harbors Congress refused today to recommend opposition to construction of the multimillion dollar St. Lawrence seaway.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Ed Dudley, a transplanted Philadelphian now in a professional post at Colorado Springs, was elected president of the Professional Golfers Association today, succeeding the popular Tom Walsh of Chicago, who declined to be a candidate.

The United States Army team last night won the International Military Perpetual Challenge Trophy, most important of all the jumping competitions at the fiftysixth National Horse Show before 8,000 spectators in Madison Square Garden. It was the third straight triumph for the United States in this event.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The text of Prime Minister Churchill's statenent before the House of Comnons today, except for the introluctiot outlining proposed legislaion, follows:

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Six more elephants were stricken ill today in the circus herd which already has lost ten by poisoning. A private detective said it was "a clear case of mass murder" of animals.

BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- To increase the flow of youthful workers into the neglected industrial and white-collar jobs, German students in what corresponds to American high schools and preparatory schools will no longer have to pass the customary "maturity examinations" on graduating.

OTTAWA, Nov. 13 -- In reply to the open and undercover demands for outright conscription for overseas service that have come from the Opposition benches in the House of Commons during the past ten days, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King this evening stated his position clear, as follows:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The War Department is asking National Guardsmen and selectees to re-enlist for three-year terms in the Regular Army and to serve overseas if necessary.

Under a new name, with many new faces and In circumstances they have never faced in the history of the National Hockey League, the Americans tonight will open the 1941-42 hockey season in Madison Square Garden. The opposition will be supplied by the Chicago Black Hawks.

While waste paper collections are improving, they are still falling about 15 per cent short of current requirements of the greatly expanded paper manufacturing rate, according to a report issued yesterday by the conservation committee of the Waste Paper Consuming Industries of America, which is sponsoring the National Waste Paper Conservation Drive, following a meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Because waste material badly needed in one part of the country may be worthless elsewhere, with transportation costs barring the shipment of the bulky materials over long distances, the OPM is planning to set up local salvage committees in cities throughout the country to decide what household waste materials shall be saved and collected.
ROME, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

Praise for the "unconquerable" spirit of the Greeks and predictions that their country would be restored to them as early as next year marked addresses yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Pierre to honor representatives of the Near East Foundation, recently returned from Greece.

By unanimous vote, the Board of Education restored at its regular meeting yesterday seventy-six swimming teachers who had been discharged for economy at the start of the term. They were taken back at salaries ranging from $1,400 to $2,000.

ROME, Nov. 12 -- Virginio Gayda again accuses the United States of operating submarines against Italian shipping in the Mediterranean and seizes on British Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement that a large part of the American fleet is already at war against the Axis to point out to Japan that there is nothing left of American neutrality.

Acting in sympathy with breaks in the stock and grain markets, cotton futures closed yesterday with net losses of 11 to 28 points. Trade support near the close brought about a momentary recovery, but final values of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were within 1 to 5 points of their lows for the day.

Sophomore backs have been conspicuous in the football headlines this year and nowhere more so than in the Middle West. The East has come up with Andrejco of Fordham, Hill of Army, Martin of Cornell and Margarita of Brown, but out in the Corn Belt there is hardly a team without its brilliant fledgling operative.

By eleventh-hour decision of Theresa Helburn, tonight's scheduled premiere of "Little Dark Horse," Miss Helburn's adaptation of Andre Birabeau's French play, was called off. The management insisted that the opening now will be on Sunday evening.

Finished Rayon Ceilings Due The method for computing ceilings for finished rayon lingerie cloths will be greige goods plus converting charge plus 8 to 12 per cent for overhead and profit, according to information obtained by the National Women's Undergarment Manufacturers Association.

Government agencies are engaged in intensive studies of methods which may be followed in conserving use of metals for erection of private homes, and Federal experts in the building material, equipment and construction fields will hold a conference shortly in Washington to compare notes on their findings.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- King George VI, accompanied by Queen Elizabeth, drove to Westminster today to open the new session of Parliament. It was the third time he had taken part in this ceremony under wartime conditions that deprived it of most of its color while endowing the ritual with special significance.

In one of six Manhattan realty sales at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street rooms, the sixteen-story Hotel Gramercy Park at 2 Lexington Avenue, on the north-west corner of Twenty-first Street, was bid in for $560,000 by the New York Life Insurance Company, plaintiff in foreclosure proceedings against the Gramercy Park Hotel Corporation.

A rapidly solidifying challenge by the Congress of Industrial Organizations to the government's defense-labor policy presented a major crisis on the nation's production front last night as a showdown approached in the captive coal mine dispute.

The daily steamship service between New York and Boston, which has been maintained by the Eastern Steamship Lines for many years, is to be discontinued through the Winter because of a shortage of tonnage, it was announced here yesterday.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 11 (Delayed) -- Greek insurgent activity is spreading, according to direct reports received here today. The German economic administration has now ordered not only the commandeering of the tobacco crop, which was the first measure to incite trouble, but the seizure of all food crops, including corn, wheat and potatoes and such small stores as had been accumulated in reserve, it is learned.

While the plastics industry is one of the most rapidly expanding fields in the country, the nature of the product has prevented it from becoming a large national advertiser in consumer media. Some institutional campaigns have occasionally appeared and since the defense program started there has been more of a trend to these drives, but as yet advertising by makers of branded plastics material is a very minor part of consumer copy.
