WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 12 (AP) -- A "short-of-war" policy of maximum defense production, aid to those fighting Hitler, and preservation of the Monroe Doctrine was advocated today by Louis J. Taber, master of the National Grange, until the nation is "more nearly united" on another course.

The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C.I.O., which acclaimed the government's decision to enforce a National Defense Mediation Board recommendation by commandeering the Kearny yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, withdrew yesterday from further participation in NDMB proceedings intended to iron out a dispute affecting 5,800 workers at the Brooklyn plant of the Robins Drydock and Repair Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The United States will probably have to devote 40 per cent of its national income to manufacture of the materials of war in order to defeat Hitler, Donald M. Nelson, OPM Director of Priorities, told a conference on labor legislation and the problems of its administration today.

Because of a second default by the Columbia University Class A squash tennis team, the Bayside Tennis Club five remained in a first-place tie with the New York A.C. in the Metropolitan Association competition last night.

As part of the civilian defense program, every public school in New York City will participate today in emergency fire and bombing drills, James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, announced at the close of yesterday's board meeting.

Two-minute engine check-ups won favor with 2,000 drivers yesterday as the city opened a ten-day campaign to give free tests of fuel economy to motorists in the interests of conservation of gasoline for the national emergency.

A new issue of $15,000,000 of serial debentures, issued jointly by Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., a Canadian company, and its United States subsidiary, Hiram Walker Sons, Inc., distillers, will be offered to the public today by a banking group headed by Smith, Barney Co., and including twenty-seven other under-writers.

ROME, Nov. 12 -- The merciless pounding of Naples and points in Sicily continued last night. Nothing comparable with the continuous and prolonged raids on Naples has yet been seen in Italy, for this was the fourth night in succession that the British rained explosive and incendiary bombs on the great port.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 12 -- Finland's negative reply to Washington was the only one that could have saved this country from renewed threats against her two vulnerable frontiers and therefore the only possible one under the circumstances -- this is the consensus of the press here today.

At no time since he became Prime Minister has Winston Churchill seemed in as good spirits as he was in his address at the opening of the new session of Parliament yesterday. Never has the contrast between democratic sanity and the ravings of Berlin been greater.

BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- The bombardment of the harbor of Anapa on the Caucasian mainland, mentioned in today's High Command communique, has given the Germans the basis for claiming that the Russians are using this harbor for debarking troops evacuated from Crimea.

VICHY, France, Nov. 12 -- General Charles Leon Clement Huntziger, 61-year-old Minister of War in the Petain Cabinet and Commander in Chief of the French land forces, was killed today in an airplane accident as he was returning from a tour of inspection of the defenses of France's African colonies.
BERLIN, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A communique from Adolf Hitler's headquarters said today:

Extending commingled "benediction and commiseration" to his successor, Elmer Davis, author and radio commentator, ended yesterday his two-year term as president of the Authors League of America and reported that for the first time in many years the writers' organization in 1940-41 had operated "out of the red."

STRATFORD, Conn., Nov. 12 -- Less than a month from completion, a sleek thirty-ton flying boat capable of carrying forty passengers 3,000 miles non-stop at a speed of 200 miles an hour was exhibited here today at the Vought-Sikorsky plant by American Export Airlines.

Ten American women, each outstanding in her own field, will be invited to visit England in the near future under the auspices of the British Government, to see at first hand the conditions under which women are living and working in Great Britain, it was announced yesterday.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 12 -- Dr. Coelho de Souza, Secretary of Education of the State of Rio Grande do Sul, charged in an address here today that Adolf Bitler's "Mein Kampf" was read from pulpits by preachers of German churches in his State and that Nazis there were plotting to annex the State to Germany.

SAN DIEGO, Nov. 12 -- Some 2,000 members of A.F.L. building and construction trades unions reported for work today at eight vital defense projects at which they had gone on strike Monday morning for higher wages.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Rarely, in my opinion, has a more unfortunate and harmful plan been hatched than that proposed by Prince Hubertus zu Loewenstein and commented on in your editorial of Nov. 2. I refer to the plan of creating a "Free State Germany" which would be granted a "token" sovereignty over a strip of Tanganyika or some other former German territory, under the jurisdiction of some prominent German emigres.

Although the Ruppert fishing contest, with its $6,000 in prizes, is now on the last leg of its journey, anglers still have an excellent chance of topping, the fields in some of the classes, for the derby will not close until jnidnight of Jan. 15.

Earnings of the Celanese Corporation of America and its wholly owned subsidiaries in the first nine months of this year established a new high record of $10,441,361 before provision for taxes, according to the report of Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president, issued for publication today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Syracuse University revealed today that Ossie Solem, head football coach since 1937, would remain in his present post, the announcement coming only a few days before the traditional game with Colgate here Saturday.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 12 -- Dr. Coelho de Souza, Secretary of Education of the State of Rio Grande do Sul, charged in an address here today that Adolf Bitler's "Mein Kampf" was read from pulpits by preachers of German churches in his State and that Nazis there were plotting to annex the State to Germany.
How to Build Peace The late Henry W. Nevinson, pacifist by conviction and war correspondent by trade, is best remembered in this country for his work at the Washington disarmament conference in 1921.

Two new Warner productions will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. "One Foot in Heaven," a picturization of the Hartzell Spence book with Fredric March and Martha Scott in the starring roles, will be the new attraction at the Radio City Music Hall.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 13 -- The Armistice Day speeches of President Roosevelt, United States Navy Secretary Frank Knox and Under-secretary of State Sumner Welles, coming right on top of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's speech, produced a profound impression on Japan as a final demonstration of Anglo-American solidarity.

VICHY, France, Nov. 13 -- No successor will be appointed to General Charles Huntziger as Minister of War and Commander of the French Land Forces until after the national funeral that will be held in Vichy on Saturday for him and the six other victims of the accident to the airplane on which he was returning from North Africa.

DETROIT, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- Sidney Hillman, associate director of the Office of Production Management, capped a day-long tour of automobile industry defense plants tonight with a plea that labor settle its disagreements with management and its "family quarrels" without work stoppages.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of the comedy "Junior Miss," on the night of Nov. 25 at the Lyceum Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Berkshire Industrial Farm, the private school for problem boys in Canaan, N.Y.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- City Manager Raymond J. Whitney announced today the abolition of tweny-three city jobs and reduction of salaries of several top city officials, including his own, as another step in the city's economic campaign.

BERLIN, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels charged today that the Jews had brought on the war in hope of destroying Germany and declared that "they are suffering no injustice by the treatment we bestow on them -- they more than earned it."
A legion of deer hunters will take to the woods tomorrow morning in the Catskill area, which will be opened to the taking of male deer for the following two weeks.

Gloria Swanson, film star, presided last night at the nineteenth annual drawing at the Grand Central Art Galleries, Inc. Dressed in a simple black costume, with a large black hat, Miss Swanson read out, as they were drawn, the eighty-two names of the lay members of the galleries participating in the drawing, which was for choice in the allotment of eightytwo paintings and sculptures by eighty-two artist members.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A British Middle East communique today said:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's letter to Speaker Rayburn and Representative McCormack, majority leader, which was read in the House today:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Resentment over secret consideration of a reciprocal tax waiver treaty with Great Britain led four Senators to walk out of a meeting of the Foreign Relations Committee today.

A mock air raid with sound effects of the real thing was held last night in the Bronx, while in Manhattan air raid wardens and Red Cross workers demonstrated the effectiveness of their training in putting out incendiary bombs and caring for casualties.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Army is seeking 10,000 recruits to fill out the military establishment in Iceland, and thus relieve United States Marines and British soldiers now there, General George C. MarShall, Chief of Staff, said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Department store sales during the week ended Nov. 8 were 14 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. A gain of 18 per cent was reported for the week previous.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 8 totaled 873,585 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 21,154 cars, or 2.4 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, but 95,267 cars, or 12.2 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 91,997 cars, or 11.8 per cent more than during the corresponding week, two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Toward the end of the President's appeal to the House today to concur in the Senate amendments to the so-called Neutrality Act came the pledge which an increasing group of his labor policy critics have been demanding. It came on the eve of the vote, but it was sufficient to stem the standstill movement against proceeding further with foreign policy until all domestic policy is integrated with it.

A graphic warning to America in the form of a blurred photograph of five Nazi soldiers, guns on shoulders, aiming at two figures slumped against a stone wall, was displayed yesterday at the headquarters of the Committee to Defend America, 8 West Fortieth Street, as men from occupied countries, representing three religious faiths, met to protest the persecution by Nazis of their countrymen.

Asserting that only a few manufacturers, representing a small fraction of nylon hosiery production, have advanced prices to levels which can be questioned, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers yesterday termed the raising of an issue over rising nylon hosiery prices overhasty action taken without sufficient projection of vision into the future.

The most urgent need in assuring mental fitness in both the armed forces and the civilian population under the stress of emergency is the training of doctors in the fundamentals of psychiatry, Dr. Harry Stack Sullivan, Consultant in Psychiatry to the Selective Service System, declared yesterday.

Exchanges of cablegrams yesterday between London and Washington relative to the list of American women who will be invited to England to inspect the work of women there under wartime conditions left the situation last night in a state of uncertainty as to the probable members of the group.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Hjalmar J. Procope, the Finnish Minister, assured Stunner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, at a conference today that he had reported fully and accurately to his government their conversation of last Aug. 18 when Mr. Welles transmitted the Russian suggestion of peace negotiations with Finland.
RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 13 -- Secretary Knox, In a letter to a Raleigh newspaper publisher, stood fast on his assertion that the Navy would not give out the news if a German submarine were sunk.

In a letter addressed to President Roosevelt and Congress, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., called yesterday for legislation to prevent stoppage of work in defense industries by limiting the right to strike during the present emergency.
Investors were active yesterday in purchases of properties in Manhattan from lending institutions.
ROME, Nov. 13 -- Willingness to die once victory is achieved is avowed by Premier Benito Mussolini in his revealing book "I Speak With Bruno," the first copies of which reached Rome today from Milan.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Spencer P. Hazard and their daughter, Miss Georgiana H. Hazard, have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from their home in Philadelphia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A majority of women members of the House went on record in favor of letting ships flying Old Glory sail where they please on the seven seas with cannon on their prows.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company yesterday bought an issue of $1,500,000 of tax-anticipa- tion certificates of indebtedness of Onondaga County, N.Y., at 0.22 per cent, plus a premium of $2. The certificates, dated Nov. 18, 1941, will become payable on April 15, 1942.

An investing client of Louis Reibel, attorney, has purchased from the Home Life Insurance Company for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $285,000 taken back by the seller the six-story elevator apartment house at 271-285 Hawthorne Street, Brooklyn.

TRENTON, Nov. 13 -- A Rockaway Borough ordinance requiring permits for moving of household goods and other personal property was set aside today by Supreme Court Justice Joseph L. Bodine, as an unconstitutional restriction on freedom of action.

The plight of children in defense industry areas getting their earliest impressions of family life while "packed like sardines in trailers or in a rooming house with several families sharing one room," is creating a serious need for more day nurseries, it was said yesterday by Miss Elizabeth Woodruff Clark, executive director of the National Association of Day Nurseries.

A plan to provide the 4,400 tenants of the East River Housing Project, 446 East 104th Street, with the services of physicians at low cost has been adopted and approved by the comitia minora of the New York County Medical Society, it was made known yesterday.

With automotive, financial and classified showing declines, advertising linage in newspapers of fiftytwo cities measured by Media Records registered an over-all increase of 4.2 per cent for October. This brought the gain for the first ten months of the year to 3.3 per cent.

The four-story fireproof industrial building at 43-20 Thirtyfourth Street, Long Island City, has been sold by Loomis J. Grossman, operator, to the Stuard Realty Company, an investing client of Jerome Malino, attorney. The structure is on a plot 200 by 100 feet and brought a cash consideration above the first mortgage of $118,000.

A.F. of L. motion picture operators in Newark renominated yesterday a slate made up of supporters of Louis Kaufman, union business agent who is under indictment in this city on charges of conspiring with George E. Browne and William Bioff to extort more than $1,000,000 from four movie companies.

Gus Lesnevich, Cliffside (N.J.) boxer who holds the light-heavyweight championship of the world, will risk his title tonight when he engages Tami Mauriello, youthful Bronx contender, in the star bout of fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden.

American Maize Products A 25-cent dividend and an extra of 50 cents were declared on the common stock by the American Maize Products Company. These dividends will bring 1941 payments to $1.50, or 25 cents more than last year.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Resolutions calling for passage of the Neutrality Act amendments by the House of Representatives and for inclusion of women at post-war peace conferences were adopted by the State Federation of Women's Clubs in the closing session of their annual convention here.

TRENTON, Nov. 13 -- The New Jersey Legislature adjourned tonight until Dec. 8 after the Senate had adopted two measures depriving the municipal police courts of Hudson County of virtually all jurisdiction in criminal cases and another bill lifting the restrictions on night work for women under certain circumstances.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Contracts awarded today by the War Department were valued at $22,680,542.61. Among the contracts were the following, not previously published, which were granted to concerns in the New York area.

A portrait by George Romney was sold for $12,500 last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at the first session of the auction sale of the art collection of the late Arthur Curtiss James, financier, railroad builder and yachtsman.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- President Roosevelt, in a message to the National Catechetical Congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine, which will open on Saturday, said yesterday that the nation must fight "with every resource at our command" to preserve the heritage of liberty of conscience.

The appearance of a mild form of smallpox among the crew of the American-South African liner City of New York held the vessel and all on board in quarantine waters last night after a voyage from Cape Town and other African ports.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Senator Clark, Democrat of Missouri, charged tonight that opponents of the Administration's neutrality revision bill had a twenty-vote majority "at midnight last night," and that the measure was approved by the House only after a series of secret White House messages to Representatives.

Jacques Poberejsky of Paris, French inventor, has leased through Reba E. Minford, broker, a twelve-room maisonette apartment at 855 Fifth Avenue for his own occupancy and a private garage with servants' quarters above at 168 East Sixty-eighth Street.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 13 -- The Yale Dramatic Association tonight borrowed a swimming pool from one of the neighbors, and plunged into it in search of the classics. This event was the first performance of a "new version" of Aristophanes's "The Frogs," which took place in and around the pool of the Payne Whitney gymnasium.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Nov. 13 -- Considerable mystery tonight surrounded the late Mrs. Ada Loveland Torrance, who was a wealthy Kalamazoo widow. She was 70 years old. She died while on a honeymoon with a man who identified himself as Arthur Torrance, 55, of New York.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Nov. 14 -- Counter-attacking fiercely since dawn yesterday, Russian troops in the Tula region, 110 miles south of Moscow, were reported by the authoritative Soviet military commentator in his regular broadcast this morning to have driven the German back at four points.

Electric power production declined slightly last week from the record figure of teh week previous. Since the decrease was less than seasonal, the adjusted index advanced to 123.1 from 121.6 for the week ended Nov. 1. It stood at 108.1 for the week ended Nov. 9, 1940.

Weakness in the distant October contract was a feature yesterday of an erratic and thin cotton market. Excluding October, which closed 8 points lower than on Wednesday, final prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 3 to 6 points.

Treasury Bill Financing To assure a steady supply of new funds to maintain the desired cash balance and to delay any major financing in the open market at least until next month, the Treasury Department announced yesterday that it will seek $100,000,000 of new money each week through the bill market instead of the $50,000,000 that it has been obtaining for four weeks.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 13 -- Tommy Armour, Chicago and Boca Raton, Fla., three-putted the eighteenth green on the championship course of the Pinehurst Country Club today and lost an opportunity to top the field in the first round of the thirty-six-hole Mid-South golf tournament.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Nov. 13 -- The Bourse ran into selling today and on a heavy turnover losses ran to 5 points. Royal Dutch was 2 5/8 points lower at 328 1/2; Amsterdam Trading 4 1/2 at 496; Amsterdam Rubber 3 1/2 at 316; Unilever 1 7/8 at 163, and A.K.U. 1 at 153 3/4.

Approaching closer to the ultimate performances in every field, America's amateur athletes during the last year posted 193 accomplishments that will be submitted for record certification by Chairman Paul R. Jordan at the fifty-third annual convention of the Amateur Athletic Union opening in Philadelphia tomorrow.

BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- The full purchasing power of the Reichsmark will be restored after the war, when it will be bolstered by a flow of cheap goods from newly conquered territories producing raw materials. This striking announcement was made by Walther Funk, president of the Reichsbank, at a rally of 5,000 employes of the Reichsbank in one of Berlin's largest sport arenas.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- Taking advantage of warmer weather today, Coach George Munger put his Pennsylvania players through one of the longest offensive drills of the season in preparation for the game with the Army, but no tackling was allowed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- President Rdosevelt, in a letter to Speaker Rayburn and Majority Leader McCormack, urged that the House approve the Senate amendments revising the Neutrality Act. His callers included Senator Kilgore and the West Virginia Congressional delegation and Senator Murray.

The editorial board of the Book-of-the-Month Club, meeting yesterday, selected a new novel by Pearl Buck entitled "Dragon Seed," which is now running serially in Asia Magazine, as its February book. The book had originally been planned for early January publication by John Day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Two prominent members of the House Rules Committee said tonight that they would block future Administration legislation unless the leaders permitted anti-strike legislation to be brought to the floor. This aim was stated by Representatives Cox of Georgia and Smith of Virginia, the first and second ranking members of the committee, after an outburst in the House which followed announcement of the result of the vote on the neutrality resolution.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov 13 -- The Board of Estimate and Taxation will meet within the next few days to set the tax rate for 1942 following the adoption of a $3,908,631 budget by the Representative Town Meeting last night. A rate of 18.9 mills, the same as this year's, or 19 mills is anticipated.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 14 -- Passage by the House of Representatives at Washington of the Neutrality Act amendments was welcomed here late last night with considerable pleasure on all sides. The action was viewed as another important step by the United States involving great practical advantages to Britain and her Russian ally.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Scattered liquidation and some hedging pressure carried soy bean prices off as much as 4 1/8 cents a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, making a recession of 10 1/8 cents in two days. However, the selling movement ran its course and a fair commission-house demand plus covering by shorts caused a fair rally.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 13 -- The writer was privileged to take a look at an unbeaten and untied football team today, which comes under the head of unusual experiences at this stage of the nation's gridiron wars.

A YOUNG friend, a great rooter for Tami Mauriello, dropped around to give warning that Tami would lift the light heavyweight crown from the brow of Gus Lesnevich at Madison Square Garden this evening.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- With a strike on the country's railroad transportation system set for Dec. 7 by the big five operating brotherhoods, officials of the fourteen non-operating unions, meeting here to consider action on the Presidential fact-finding board's recom- mendations, deferred announcement of a decision, but expressed their determination "to press their demands for equitable consideration and relief against present intolerable wage standards and to gain reasonable vacations."

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The King has approved the recommendations of the Royal Society's Council awarding two royal medals for the current year to Professor Edward Arthur Milne for his researches on the atmospheres of the earth and sun, on the internal constitution of the stars and on the theory of relativity, and to Professor Ernest Laurence Kennaway for his investigations on the production of cancer by synthetic substances.

Last September, before those twin bolts from the Light Blue knocked Don Snavely and Len Will out of the Columbia football picture and cured the professor of any optimism for weeks, Lou Little made the statement: "If Paul absorbs coaching and works as hard as Luckman did he'll be as good a passer by next year as Sid was."

The threatened strike of 15,000 long-distance telephone workers was postponed yesterday for at least a week after Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the United States Conciliation Service, had appealed to the independent union involved to resume negotiations "in the public interest."

Debutantes aiding the Musicians Emergency Fund appeared yesterday in a Bonwit Teller fashion show of Winter sports clothes that formed part of a preview of the benefit "Ice Follies" to be held Dec. 1. Also on view during the day were a display of teen-age clothes at Gimbels and Gladys Belle's midseason hat collection.
ROME, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

Many dinner parties were given in advance of the performance of Macbeth" last night at the National Theatre for the benefit of the Art Workshop of the Rivington Neighborhood Association. Mrs. Seymour L. Cromwell Jr., who headed the benefit committee, and Mr. Cromwell entertained with a dinner at their home, 150 East Eighty-first Street.

Conditions are comfortable, says the Consumers Division of the Department of Markets, reporting on prices that will prevail on this all-important week-end in the food world. Except for the prodigal pork, meat prices are fractionally lower than last week-end and compare favorably with last year's quotations.

BERLIN, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- Nazi spokesmen tonight predicted the early fall of Kerch, Russia's besieged bastion of eastern Crimea, and said the Germans already had loosed across the adjacent narrow water gap "the first blows in the great battle for Caucasian oil."

Editorial comments on passage of the Neutrality Amendment by the House were generally in accord in acclaiming the result. In interpretation of it the closeness of the division was variously construed as a warning to labor and as an indication of a need to bolster the national morale.
SEATTLE, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The rise of Arizona and Duke and the fall of Texas and Texas A M., featured last week's yardstick battles for total offensive and defensive football statistical supremacy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Following is the roll-call by which the House accepted the Senate amendments to the Neutrality Act:

The Harvard Club remained in first place and the Princeton Club hurdled into second in the weekly Class A team matches of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday when both registered 5 -- 0 sweeps. The Crimson players were victorious over the Yale Club on Harvard's courts and Princeton drove the Cornell Club deeper into the cellar on the Tiger courts.

Carl Reuper, a defendant in the Brooklyn espionage trial, testified yesterday that he had rejected the suggestion of a counter-espionage agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation that he report details of the United States defense program to Germany in revenge for "what England did to Germany after the World War."

A curb on strikes in defense industries and a curb on nonessential governmental expenditures were demanded last night by Percy H. Johnston in his Presidential address at the 173d anniversary banquet of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

Sentiment within Tammany Hall's executive committee has rejected, thus far, the suggestion made by leading outsiders that a general city Democratic committee be set up to replace the present five county organizations that Tammany once dominated.

Negotiations for the purchase of the Great Lakes Pipe Line Company, owned by eight oil companies, are being carried on by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc. If the deal is consummated, it is understood that an underwriting group will be formed and the securities of the company will be offered to the public.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 12 (Delayed) -- Despite huge losses in men and equipment, the Nazi forces of Field Marshal Fedor von Bock continue their assaults to take Tula, but the Russians are still holding stubbornly, despite heavy losses of their own.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- During the week ended Nov. 12 member bank reserve balances increased $113,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves rose from decreases of $126,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $32,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, and increases of $16,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $5,000,000 in gold stock, offset in part by increases of $51,000,000 in money in circulation and $18,000,000 in Treasury cash.
N.Y.U.s motto yesterday at Ohio Field was "Divided We Practice, United We Play."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The general level of wholesale prices showed a moderate gain during the week ended Nov. 8, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, rose to 91.7 last week, compared with 91.6 on Nov. 1, 91.2 on Oct. 25, 91.6 on Oct. 11 and 78.8 on Nov. 9, 1940.

The recent round-up of Harlem criminals ordered by Mayor La Guardia began to snow results yesterday when two youths were indicted by the grand jury on counts of rape and robbery in connection with an attack on a young woman in Central Park on Nov. 2 and two of four others arraigned in the Felony Court were held for the grand jury as Sullivan law violators.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- Donald M. Nelson, national director of priorities, told the six New England Governors and 800 of the region's leaders in business and industry today that Washington had reached the conclusion that this country's economy could not survive unless the small manufacturer survived.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday the demotion of three detectives and two patrolmen pending departmental trial on charges of laxity in guarding Abe Reles, the blustery Brooklyn gang leader who once blurted in open court: "All cops are yellow and I'll fight any single one with guns, knives or broken glass."

Perhaps it has been quite a while since some of us thought about those five little girls who live in Callander, Ontario, and have a friend and physician named Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe. Well, this week's news from Callander is that they are all right, and that by next Summer they will move into a new house, across the road from where they were born, with their seven brothers and sisters and their parents.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Hogs closed steady to weak in a slow market today after showing strength during early rounds. Top price remained at $10.30 a hundredweight. Further weakness in dressed pork was a depressing influence. Light pork lions sold at 21 to 21 1/2 cents a pound, down 1/2 cent.

Postponements of the Broadway openings of two of the biggest shows of the current season -- "Banjo Eyes," the Eddie Cantor musical comedy, and "Sons o' Fun," the new Olsen and Johnson revue -- were announced yesterday.

People Under Guard You find yourself comparing the standard of living enjoyed by the late Abe Reles with the way some other people live under protective custody. With two friends in the same line of general thuggery and murder the late Reles was the occupant of a five-room suite at a fine Boardwalk hotel.

Trading in locally dressed meats yesterday was fair to good. Lamb prices were strong to higher, veal steady to strong and calf steady. The cow market was lower and bull about steady. Pork loins were weak to S1 lower. Steer hinds and ribs were weak to lower. All kosher markets were steady, with the exception of steer Plates, which were weak to slightly lower.

VICHY, France, Nov. 13 -- On the central and northern Russian fronts the expected lull seems now to have begun, in the view of competent neutral observers here. In modern warfare, of course, there can be no question of actually taking up Winter quarters, and fighting is not likely to cease.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 13 -- On the eve of President Roosevelt's conference with John L. Lewis in an effort to solve the threatened strike in captive coal mines, Governor James sent a telegram to Mr. Roosevelt pledging support of "any course you may determine upon to break the deadlock."

BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- With cold weather an added factor in holding up large scale operations against Moscow, according to the German military spokesmen, the war in Crimea benefits by the warmer climate there, permitting the Germans to continue efforts now well in their second week to capture Sevastopol and Kerch, the latter port considered an easier gateway to the Caucasus than the road by the "Rostov corner" has so far proved to be.

Although bank clearings for the current week maintained a lead over the corresponding period last year, the gain was the smallest reported since the week of May 21. The volume for the week ended on Wednesday was considerably below the preceding week, the decline amounting to $1,218,438,000, or 17.3 per cent.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 13 -- Flatly denying that he or members of his staff intend to curb advertising as a method of inflation control or to eliminate it as a necessary expense in price ceiling calculations, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, today promised an audience of 700 advertising and publishing executives to maintain as far as possible the maximum of civilian activity, in which he classified advertising.

Dr. Alexander Loudon, Netherlands Minister to the United States, brought to 250 members of the Holland Society of New York, all descendants of early Dutch settlers, last night a "message from across the seas" that "Holland will fight."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On our economic front, the three most urgent problems of the moment are the questions of price ceilings and the threatening inflation, wage increases and strikes, and what new taxes are most feasible to raise additional revenues.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 13 -- After weeks of nightly goading by Australian and Polish patrols from Tobruk, Axis forces again launched a drive with tanks last night in an attempt to regain control of the No Man's Land.

Many officials, present and past, in the city, State and Federal Governments and political leaders were among the 4,000 persons who attended the funeral yesterday morning of James J. Hoey, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second New York district.

In the presence of Godfrey Hag gard, British Consul General at New York, and a representative of the British Press Service, U Maung Saw, Prime Minister of Burma, yesterday expressed disappointment at his failure to achieve dominion status in the British Commonwealth for his country.

Simon Guggenheim, president of the American Smelting and Refining Company and former United States Senator from Colorado, who died of pneumonia on Nov. 2, left nearly all of his estate to "The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation" established by him and his wife as a memorial to their 18-year-old son, who died in April, 1922.

Miss Margot Elizabeth Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Bayne Johnston of 122 East Seventy-sixth Street, gave a luncheon yesterday at the New York Junior League clubhouse for Miss Joan Irene Hoffman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gouverneur Hoffman of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., whose engagement to Douglas S. Dodge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Dodge of Scarsdale, N.Y., has been announced.

LONDON, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- British tipplers faced the fearful prospect of "going on the wagon" today, not by inclination but because of the thirst for Scotch and other British whiskies in the United States.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 13 -- "My Friend Flicka," Mary O'Hara's new novel about a boy and his horse published last August, was purchased today by Twentieth Century-Fox as a vehicle for Roddy MacDowall, the studio's child actor who appeared recently in "How Green Was My Valley." The purchase price, according to the studio, was "close to $50,000." Ralph Dietrich will produce the film.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Pope Pius XII cabled an expression of his gratitude today for the generosity of Catholics of the United States in aiding the people of war-torn Europe.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 13 -- It indications at today's practice of the Yale football squad mean anything, Princeton's backfield will spend most of Saturday afternoon manning the anti-aircraft guns.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 13 (AP) -- The first bills under New Jersey's new railroad tax laws showed today that 1941 levies dropped $3,117,462 under last year's total, slumping from $18,296,688 to $15,179,226.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- One of the largest crowds ever to seek admittance to the House chamber to hear a debate was on hand today when the resolution to revise the Neutrality Act was considered. With the galleries packed, Capitol police in force were necessary to handle throngs in the corridors.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed Reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Navy is ready to proceed immediately with the arming of American merchant ships, a state of preparedness stressed tonight alike by Secretary Knox and spokesmen for naval operating executives immediately after the House approved Senate amendments further revising the Neutrality Act.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Following is the text of the letter sent by Secretary Hull to Speaker Rayburn and Representative McCormack:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 12:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The nation's coal-supply situation was characterized today as "generally comfortable" by Secretary Ickes, who said that stocks on hand at steel mills are sufficient to last about thirty-one days.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 13 -- Undefeated and untied, but not over confident. That is the way Andover's current football squad, the most successful in Steve Sorota's three-year reign as head coach, will enter its classic clash with Exeter on Saturday.

Five prominent alumni of City College will receive Townsend Harris medals for "notable postgraduate achievement" at the sixty-first annual dinner of the college's Associate Alumni tomorrow evening at the Hotel Roose- velt, it was announced yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 13 -- Market Wise, the bargain horse who humbled Whirlaway, won again today at Pimlico, adding $9,750 to his previous 1941 earnings of $87,965 to become the most lucrative purchase Louis Tufano has made in his comparatively brief turf career.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- Richard Loveland, son of the late Mrs. Ada Loveland, told the press tonight that he would remain here "as long as necessary." He said he had last heard from his mother less than two weeks ago when he received a letter from her from New Orleans announcing her marriage to Arthur Torrance and saying she was en route to Mexico.

The Shelton Club defeated the City A.C. by 5 -- 0, and Midston House won from the New York A.C., 4 -- 1, in Eastern Squash Racquets Association matches last night. As a result, Shelton and Midston tied for the lead at 9 -- 1.

BERLIN, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- Tobacco will be rationed on Dec. 1, with men probably restricted to six cigarettes or one cigar a day and women over 21 to three cigarettes every other day, it was reported tonight.

Beethoven and Bruckner made the program of the concert at which Bruno Walter conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, with Artur Schnabel as soloist in the performance of the Beethoven C major concerto, in Carnegie Hall last night.

Declaring yesterday that the adoption of the amendments to the Neutrality Act by the House was "gratifying," Wendell L. Willkie attributed the close vote in part to "the Administration's negligence and muddling in the solution of our industrial labor relations problem" and "its utter disregard of the needs and rights of large elements of our population in the handling of our domestic and defense program."

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- Commerce Minister V.A. Tanner said today that the "greater part" of the Finnish Army would be sent home and the remainder placed on patrol duty as soon as "a situation is created in which we can regard ourselves as safe."

TORONTO, Nov. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Dave (Sweeney) Schriner came back to the National Hockey League wars tonight with a broken toe in a cast and paced the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 4-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiena. It was the Leafs' second victory in three starts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and the Ohio Fuel Gas Company have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a combined application for approval of several transactions designed to solve the corporate simplification and integration problems arising from the relationships of the Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company, the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation and the Michigan Gas Transmission Corporation to Columbia Gas and Electric.
A bit of everything important to the success of their busy lives was offered to 200 executive housekeepers yesterday afternoon at the National Hotel Exposition in Grand Central Palace.

Three separate conspiracies to restrain interstate commerce in American-made watches were charged in Federal indictments yesterday to the Hamilton Watch Company, the Elgin National Watch Company and the Waltham Watch Company.

John Paul Dickson, Berlin correspondent for the WOR-Mutual Broadcasting System, voluntarily requested his office yesterday to discontinue his news reports because "censorship has made them useless at the present time."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Close to 100 items in the builders' hardware field will go under price ceilings Nov. 19 as a result of an order issued today by Leon Henderson, head of the Office of Price Administration. Manufacturers were asked to stabilize quotations at Oct. 21 levels.

The steel and other industries now being developed in Brazil make it important for American exporters and manufacturers to consider "what that South American market may mean in the next ten or twenty years," Francisco J. Silva Jr., director, Brazilian Information Bureau, asserted yesterday at a meeting of the Overseas Automotive Club, at the Hotel Lincoln.

Members of the Manhattan Women's Division of the United Hospital Campaign were guests at a tea at the home of Mrs. William Woodward, 9 East Eighty-sixth Street, yesterday. Virginia Cowles, the author, pleaded for support of voluntary hospitals to insure the future health and security of the country.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A Chinese Army spokesman said today that intelligence service reports told of large-scale Japanese troop movements at sea and indicated that great numbers of warships and troop transports were being massed off the coast of Northern Indo-China.

Stocks of refined copper in the United States, exclusive of consumers' stocks at their plants or warehouses on Oct. 31, amounted to 67,260 tons, an increase of 3,590 over the 63,670 on Sept. 30, according to the Copper Institute. Blister stocks last month decreased 1,071 tons, making the net increase 2,519 tons.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 14 -- The speeches to be delivered by Premier Hideki Tojo, Foreign Minister Shigenori Togo and Finance Minister Okinori Kaya at the extraordinary session of the Diet opening tomorrow, were approved at a special Cabinet session yesterday and the three Ministers will now proceed to the imperial villa at Hayama to obtain Emperor Hirohito's sanction for them.

Retail Furniture Sales Spotty Retail furniture sales here this week were spotty and showed movements in both directions, store executives reported yesterday. Several stores that ran promotions during the week increased their gain over last year to points as high as 25 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- In response to a last-minute message from President Roosevelt, who pledged his government to take effective action in quelling labor disputes, the House voted today, 212 to 194, to amend the Neutrality Act to permit arming of American merchant vessels and their sailing into any combat zone or belligerent port in the world.

New common stock financing in the amount of $3,200,000 for the San Diego Gas and Electric Company reached the investment market yesterday when an underwriting syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., offered to the public 246,750 shares of the company's $10 par value common stock.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Nov. 13 (AP) -- United States Consul Henry Waterman said today that a man identifying himself as Arthur Torrance, 55 years old, of 47 Fifth Avenue, New York, was being held by Monterrey police pending investigation of the death of his wife, the former Mrs. Ada Loveland, with whom he was honeymooning in Mexico.

"THANK you, Mr. Floss. Whatever it was you said, you said in far less than an hour, however long it may have seemed to our impetuous audience. Weather clear, track fast. Enunciation positively mellifluous, with overtones of unction.

The apartment house for thirtythree families at 86-8 Convent Avenue, Yonkers, Westchester, has been sold by the Nore Realty Co., Inc. through H.T. Wood, broker, to the K A Realty Corporation, Ansel J. Merritt, president, for cash above a first mortgage of $49,500 held by the United States Life Insurance Company, and a purchase money mortgage of $3,750.

The offering to the public of $20,000,000 Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company 2 1/8 per cent debentures, due 1951, made early yesterday afternoon by a banking group headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co., attracted such widespread attention in investment circles that subscriptions exceeded the supply.

The stock market was subjected yesterday to a moderate test, and under the early leadership of the steels it managed to reclaim a portion of the severe setback suffered on Wednesday. It was not, however, any too reassuring, for the moderate demand slackened in the afternoon so that closing prices were mixed and below the best levels of the session.

In the election of the new City Council proportional representation did not achieve a brilliant success. Tammany and its allied organizations in this city have several times paid "P.R." the compliment of trying to get rid of it; but they have nevertheless learned to use it for their purposes far better than have their opponents.

TRENTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A blanket denial of assertions that he ordered or condoned alterations of appraisals on which right-of-way purchases were based was made today by State Highway Engineer James Logan as the Road Bureau opened its defense of its land acquisition operations.

Two seeded players, H. Robert Reeve, Class A team captain of the Bayside Tennis Club, and Willard K. Rice, who holds a similar position at the Harvard Club, came through to start the Twentysecond annual invitation squash tennis tournament at the Princeton Club yesterday.

Acting swiftly and without any trace of panic, 1,100,000 children in the New York City school system left their classrooms yesterday at the sound of fire alarm bells, and poured into the streets in a quiet, orderly manner. Some carried books, others musical instruments, while still others were struggling with overcoats -- but all got out of their buildings in record time.

DETROIT, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- Emil Rieve, general president of the Textile Workers Union of America (C.I.O.), and Herbert W. Payne, a vice president of the union, submitted to President Roosevelt tonight their resignations as alternate members of the National Defense Mediation Board.

BERLIN, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- Press reports of German military reprisals against dissidents said today that nine Greeks were sentenced to death for stealing a barge loaded with oil, that two Greek villages were "severely punished" for attacks on German soldiers and that Athens University dining halls had been closed as a measure against striking students.
Eight men and a dog were rescued from the chill waters about two miles off Sandy Hook last night when a Gloucester fishing boat was in collision with a collier shortly after dark.

William LaVarre, chief of the American Republics Unit of the Department of Commerce, outlined last night before the Foreign Commerce Club of New York an Administration program for cooperation with the Latin-American republics, including assistance from the United States in stabilizing economic conditions, stimulating new industries and the purchase in this hemisphere of the largest possible quantity of strategic war materials.

Appeals are being filed with OPM by a number of manufacturers of copper and brass iters, including cosmetic compacts, for permission to complete the manufacture of articles after Jan. 1 which are in substantially completed form on that date, it was learned here yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- "Some anxiety was voiced in official quarters in London tonight for the safety of Maxim M. Litvinoff, Soviet Deputy Foreign Commissar and new Ambassador to Washington; Laurence A. Steinhardt, United States Ambassador to Russia, and Sir Walter Monckton, director of | British information services in the Middle East, who were overdue on an airplane flight from Kuibyshev, Russia, to Teheran, Iran.

Actively engaged in production of national defense materials, the copper and brass producers show a gain of 60 per cent profits as compared with the first nine months of 1940, despite Federal income and excess profits tax provisions at virtually five-and-onehalf times the amount set aside for the purpose last year.

Just as the Giants began to emerge from their midseason slump for the home-stretch drive, a new blow hit then yesterday when it was discovered that Len Eshmont would not be able to play Sunday against the Cleveland Rams.

Rosa Bok, coloratura soprano, has been engaged as a member of the Metropolitan Opera Association, General Manager Edward Johnson announced yesterday. Although no definite report has been made of the roles in which she will appear, it is likely that Miss Bok will be heard as the Queen of the Night in the forthcoming revival of Mozart's "The Magic Flute" and as Sophie in "Der Rosenkavalier."

Commercial loans of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City, including loans to defense industries, increased $29,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, U.S.N., retired, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission and president of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, in his president's address yesterday before the annual meeting of the society at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, outlined the progress made by the Maritime Commission and the Navy in building up a fleet of naval and merchant vessels, second to none other in the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Twenty-five paintings from the Chester Dale Collection have been hung in the National Gallery of Art here. Sent from New York to Washington on indefinite loan, they will be exhibited privately at an invitation preview scheduled for 9 o'clock tomorrow evening, and will be placed on public view Saturday.

Work on $10,000,000 in orders for tank transmissions and other vital defense equipment was resumed last midnight at the New Brunswick plant of the Mack Manufacturing Corporation after a forty-hour shutdown caused by a strike.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- President Roosevelt is expected to appeal tomorrow to officers of the United Mine Workers of America and officials of the steel companies owning the captive mines to cast aside all other considerations but national defense in this grave hour, and to work out an amicable solution to the dispute over the miners' demand for the union shop, which threatens a strike Saturday night.

"Wings of Victory," a Russian film biography of the late Valeri Chkalov, the Soviet aviator, who headed the first non-stop flight from Moscow to the United States over the North Pole, will have its American premiere at the Stanley Theatre tonight.

Treasury and other Administration officials have lately shown increased concern over the need for additional measures to combat inflation. This is a wise and proper concern, but it may be asked whether the Treasury in its anxiety for new taxes has yet made full and effective use of an important safeguard already at hand -- the Defense Savings program.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The wheels of democracy grind slowly. It has taken fifty years, from James Bryce through Alfred E. Smith down to Mayor La Guardia, to demonstrate that the elected candidate and not the party or its leader is chosen to the public service.

ROME, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Axis bombers in a continuous forty-eight-hour pounding of British-held Tobruk have "scored hits on barracks, fuel depots, munition dumps, motor vehicles, bunkers and gun emplacements," the official news agency, Stefani, reported tonight.
Earnings of the United Air Lines Transport Corporation in the third quarter this year nearly doubled those of the corresponding three months a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Laborite Emanuel Shinwell, a most persistent critic of the government, made a full-dress attack against the government in the House of Commons today, declaring its policy was incapable of winning the war.

In spite of the discrimination against Negroes in America they feel that the fight against fascism is their fight, too, Mrs. Mary McLeod Bethune, president of the National Council of Negro Women, declared yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- As Winter settles on the Eastern Front, Germany is preparing to launch a fresh offensive on the sea with the aim of forcing a decision in the Battle of the Atlantic. Germany will employ more and larger "packs" of U-boats than hitherto and these will be supported by new weapons and methods of attack.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- "In Austria all former political parties have now united to fight the German oppressor and I strongly believe they will soon play an important part in the Allied war effort," Archduke Robert of Habsburg, second son of the late Emperor Charles of Austria told the writer today.

The majority of film producers in Hollywood are completely apathetic toward the present world crisis, Garson Kanin, motion picture director now on leave to work in the Division of Information of the Office of Emergency Management, declared yesterday.

A second intermediate accounting in the estate of Frederick W. Vanderbilt, railroad director, who died June 29, 1938, leaving a gross estate of $76,838,063, showed that all but $8,808,064 of it had been distributed or paid out.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- Two sons of Ch. My Own Brucie gained honors today at Horticultural Hall during the first day of the twentieth annual specialty show of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England. The event drew 175 entries and the largest list of exhibitors in years.

City College will close its 1941 football season at the Lewisohn Stadium this afternoon by opposing Brooklyn College in the ninth renewal of their football rivalry. The kick-off, set for 2 P.M., is expected to be made before a capacity crowd of 8,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The House judiciary committee decided today that a grand jury subpoena served on Representative Fish violated the rights and privileges of the House, but added that the House could waive those privileges under such conditions as it might determine.

In 1934 Lloyd Church was elected a Justice of the State Supreme Court for fourteen years. He served for seven with distinction, winning the confidence of the public and of his colleagues. This year, much entreated by the sages of Tammany, he consented to be the Democratic candidate for City Controller.

The report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sep. 30, issued yesterday by Edward Reynolds, president, shows a net income of $11,043,778 after all expenses, taxes and other charges.

The delayed American liner City of New York, which lay in the quarantine anchorage off Staten Island for thirty-two hours after a modified form of smallpox was discovered among the crew, docked just before 8 o'clock last night at the foot of Thirty-first Street, Brooklyn, with thirty-six of her complement of fifty-two passengers and fifty-one of her crew of eighty-two.

Radical changes in marketing procedure will be required as defense preparations expand into the gigantic Victory program requiring the expenditure of $33,000,000,000 annually to defeat Hitler in three years, Leo M. Cherne, secretary-treasurer of the Research Institute of America, said yesterday in an address at a luncheon meeting of the Market Research Council at the Yale Club.

A strike of 2,500 A.F. of L. workers in three major sugar refineries in Brooklyn and Yonkers went into effect at the close of the night shift at 11 P.M. yesterday. The strike was called by the Refinery Workers Union, Local 1,476, of the International Longshoremen's Association to enforce a demand for a 10-cent increase in the old basic hourly wage of 70 cents.

Although foreign traders have urged merging of the British blacklist and the United States proclaimed list, the same names appear in the supplementary listings of the governments in the case of only two Latin-American countries -- Panama and Paraguay -- it was revealed in an analysis issued by the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau to its members yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Little immediate change will be made in the American-British shipping situation when President Roosevelt signs the bill amending the Neutrality Act.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Sharp price advances on nylon hosiery by some manufacturers and jobbers drew the Office of Price Administration into that market today with an announcement that it will investigate the advisability of establishing ceiling prices for the products.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 14 -- Holy Cross tapered off a week of strenuous preparation for Manhattan with a light signal and kicking drill today. The Crusaders will be at top strength for their tenth clash with the Jaspers here tomorrow.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "The President on Taxes" you say: "The President is completely right" when he draws our attention to the fact "that taxation is a necessary complement of price-control legislation, because the continuing effectiveness of price control is largely dependent upon the restriction of the demand for goods."
It is not for Tami Mauriello further to question the reign of Gus Lesnevich, Cliffside, N.J., fighter, as world light-heavyweight champion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Frayser Jones, as spokesman for the National Association of Manufacturers, vigorously opposed today proposed amendments to the securities laws which would require registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission of so-called "private placement" issues, which are sold largely to insurance companies, and do not have to go through the process of registration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Roosevelt conferred with, steel company officials and officials of the United Mine Workers of America on labor dispute in the "captive" coal mines. At his press conference he reported orders for the withdrawal from China of United States Marines.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 -- Damage estimated at upward of $1,000,000 resulted today from an earthquake centering in suburban Torrance and Gardena. Although it was the heaviest since the disastrous shock of 1933, which cost 130 lives, no deaths or injuries were reported.

In the Bronx the five candidates for the City Council who had the largest number of votes on the first count, when first choices alone were considered, were precisely the five candidates elected after eleven sets of meticulous transfers to second, third, fourth choices, and so on, and after twelve separate counts of the ballots.

Arthur Murray, head of the dance studio which bears his name, has leased a large apartment in the building at 820 Park Avenue through Pease Elliman, Inc., brokers, and Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., agents.

A project to extend the neighborhood social service work done on the lower East Side of Manhattan for more than half a century by Riis House, founded by the late Jacob A. Riis, to the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, which is roughly analogous to the Harlem district in Manhattan, was revealed yesterday by Roger William Riis, head of the institution and son of the founder.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Mechanized forces as represented by the Fourth Armored Division here are less prone to accidents on manoeuvres than the Army is as a whole, according to figures compiled by post personnel.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Two hundred Army engineers from Fort Belvoir, Va., and 100 quartermasters from Camp Lee, Va., arrived today at Fort Slocum to await transfer to Panama and Puerto Rico. The quartermasters, largely trainees drawn from New York City rolls, have completed a thirteen-week basic training course.

Full vent was given yesterday in Wall Street to the belief that Washington would successfully override the threat to the defense effort contained in the labor situation, and as a result the stock market turned in the best recovery of the month.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- Britain's Commandos, the black-uniformed men of the night, raided Bardia, Libya, so realistically one night last Spring that German and Italian occupying forces, thinking a full-scale invasion was underway, brought out tanks and armored units to protect themselves, it was disclosed tonight.
The college football season draws toward its climax today with most of the teams of the East and Middie West making their penultimate appearances.

Groups from all the enslaved countries of Europe where churches have been destroyed and freedom of religion curtailed will participate in the special services opening the full length of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine during the week of Nov. 30, according to an announcement of the program yesterday.

Willie Bioff and George E. Browne, former movie union leaders who have been in jail since their conviction of extortion last Thursday in Federal court, will have to stay there, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals decided yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- An Admiralty communique today:

BERLIN, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Berlin representatives of the NBC, CBS and MBS broadcasting systems were banned from the air today by the Reich's Broadcasting Company on charges that they submitted to their companies "unjustified complaints" without previously negotiating with the German, company about their grievances.
CAIRO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

The President's statement after his conference with the coal mine union and steel company officials is the strongest he has ever made on defense strikes and on national labor policy during the present emergency. In the main points on which he insists he will have the overwhelming support of the country.

Russia will continue to "fight hard and well" regardless of the tide of immediate battles between the Red armies and the Nazi invaders, Captain Harold H. Balf our, British Parliamentary Under-Secretary for Air, asserted yesterday morning1 before boarding the Lisbon-bound Dixie Clipper at the marine terminal of La Guardia Field.

BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- Unofficial German reports from the Moscow front indicate increased activity in that sector despite the present zero weather, and the High Command reports that the Germans are now close enough to Kerch to keep both its harbor and the city itself under constant artillery fire.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. "Swamp Water," Twentieth Century-Fox's screen version of the Vereen Bell novel, will be the newcomer at the Globe. It is the first American film to be directed by Jean Renoir, and features Walter Brennan, Anne Baxter, Walter Huston, Dana Andrews, Virginia Gilmore, John Carradine and Mary Howard.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- The 198th C.A.C. Regiment, Anti-Aircraft stationed at Fort Ontario take pride in the appellation, "a perfect organization" bestowed by Governor Walter W. Bacon, of Delaware, home State of the regiment, following a recent visit to the post.

"The Forgotten Village," John Steinbeck's documentary film of the conquest of primitive Indian superstition by a modern social order in Mexico, was finally approved for showing by the State Board of Regents yesterday.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 14 -- Labor won an easy victory today in mediation proceedings between Paterson silk workers and Paterson silk manufacturers. Everything was neatly cleaned up within two hours after the session got under way.

HAVANA, Nov. 14 -- The second conference of the National Committees on Intellectual Cooperation of the Americas will open here tomorrow with delegates from at least twenty countries of the Western Hemisphere attending the eight days of meetings.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Roosevelt told organized labor in general and the United Mine Workers in particular today that "the Government of the United States will not order nor will Congress pass legislation ordering a so-called closed shop."

Advertisers who continue to use selling copy in their campaigns when their goods are scarce are courting consumer antagonism, according to opinions of agency men. In recent weeks, several examples have cropped up where consumers, reading national advertising, have attempted to buy goods at both local stores and direct from the manufacturers without success, with the result that they have become angry with the manufacturer.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The discussion now holding forth in your columns over Yale football is interesting. It is doubly interesting to me as a Yale alumnus and, no doubt, it is highly interesting to many other people, also, both ill and well-wishers of Old Elihu Yale.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. John Bassett Moore of 960 Park Avenue will give an afternoon reception on Dec. 3 at their home for their debutante granddaughter, Miss Angela Toland Place, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hermann G. Place.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A plan of recapitalization of the Empire Gas and Fuel Company, a subsidiary of the Cities Service Company, which proposes to issue new 4 1/2 per cent prior preference stock of $10 par value for the $12,775,100 of publicly held preference stock, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

One hundred seventy-five women will become members of the Ladies of Catholic Charity at the annual mass of that organization at 9 A.M. today in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Bishop Stephen J. Donahue will be the celebrant and the Rev. Vincent J. Brosnan, moderator of the group, the headquarters of which are at 415 Lexington Avenue, will assist him.

The Ambassador Theatre, 215 West Forty-ninth Street, has been taken for a period of six months by a syndicate headed by Irving Maidman, described as a Times Square real estate man and night club operator, it was announced yesterday.

The consolidated net income of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation for the first nine months of this year rose to $16,457,071 and nearly doubled the $8,305,639 net cleared in the corresponding period of last year, according to the report of Guy W. Vaughan, president, issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- By ordering United States marines to withdraw from China and through remarks made at a press conference, President Roosevelt today made clear his belief that the situation in the Far East contains elements of danger that might lead to war between the United States and Japan. He expressed hope, however, that peace would be maintained.

BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- The House of Representatives vote on the revision of the Neutrality Law provokes no surpirse in German official quarters. Curiosity as to its outcome for the last few days had converged solely on speculation over the size of the majority to be accorded to the Administration.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Reports that the House banking committee was to reconsider the price-control bill and the more warlike character of the news following the amending of the Neutrality Act resulted in fairly general short covering in the grain and soy bean markets in the early trading today on the Board of Trade.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Dartmouth will present a revamped line-up in its twenty-fifth game with Cornell on Schoellkopf Field tomorrow. Stub Pearson, a tackle, is slated to start at blocking back, and Nick Daukas, brother of Cornell's Lou Daukas, has been named to open at left tackle in place of the injured Charles Camp.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Nov. 14 (AP) -- "A large number of Axis troops still are getting across from Italy to Libya," Admiral Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham, Commander in Chief of the British Mediterranean Fleet, acknowledged today, but he added that most of these are reaching North Africa "with wet shirts."

BOSTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Fifteen survivors of the torpedoed freighter Bold Venture, arriving at Boston today, reported that thirteen vessels in their convoy of fifty-three ships were sunk in the North Atlantic on the same night -- Oct. 16 -- and that two others had been lost a day or two previously.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Playing with a brand-new set of clubs, Horton Smith, Pinehurst's new club professional, fired another 2-under-par 70 today for a 36-hole 140 to win the $500 first prize of the Midsouth open golf tournament.

Paulina Ruvinska, New Jersey pianist, who gave a recital last night at Town Hall, had impressed at her previous appearances here by the sanity and the technical cleanness of her performances. Yesterday evening Miss Ruvinsko adopted a different approach, whether consciously or not, and in attempting to "interpret" Bach, Scarlatti and Weber, subjected the offerings by these composers to rhythmic distortions and misconceptions of style and content, quite at variance with her former wholesome readings.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A dozen times Dr. Arthur Torrance threw himself full length, into a muddy roadside ditch near here late today as he re-enacted, in a shaking voice, his version of how his wealthy, elderly bride of less than a month met her death.
Started in 1856 with a one-room office lighted by an oil lamp and a total capital of $700, H. Hentz Co, today will celebrate its eighty-fifth birthday.

Three hundred and fifty members and guests of the American Friends of German Freedom heard several speakers at their dinner last night at the Biltmore Hotel urge that Germany as a nation must not be destroyed at the end of the war, in line with the declarations by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill in the Atlantic Charter to that effect.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Following is the text of the White House statement on the President's conference with mine union and steel company leaders:
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14 -- Harvard, because of its powerful line, is rated a favorite over Brown in tomorrow's forty-second contest of a football rivalry dating back to 1893.

To Sports Editor of The New york Times: Much has been published about the athletic situation in general and the football situation in particular at New York University. I agree with the majority of the comments, which are to the effect that N.Y.U. either ought to obtain teams equal to those it plays or else revise the schedule and play smaller schools.
Aluminum Company of America The Aluminum Company of America declared yesterday a dividend of $3 a share on the common stock, which will make payments in 1941 equal the $6 distributed last year.
New Yorkers walking their dogs in Central Park were startled at 9 o'clock last night when martial music shattered the quiet and park roadways resounded to the purposeful tread of marching feet.

EXETER. N.H., Nov. 14 -- No trace of a, defeatist attitude exists on tile Phillips Exeter Academy campus, even though the Red and Gray's major rival, Andover, rules favorite for the annual renewal of their classic football series here tomorrow.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I wish to report that a great void in my life has now been filled. For years I had languished in the Wintertime with no accursed Brooklyn team at which to sneer. In the Summer, I could put the hex on the baseball Dodgers;

Forty thousand Boy Scouts will set doorbells ringing throughout the city today as they canvass their neighborhoods in quest of waste paper. Their drive to collect old paper to be reprocessed into cartons for shells and munitions was officially launched yesterday when three speechless young representatives trudged up the steps of 49 East Sixty-fifth Street to receive an eight-inch pile of newspapers from Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

American merchant seamen declared yesterday their readiness to take vessels under the United States flag into any ports in any war zones, and joined with shipping men to welcome the Congressional action that cleared merchant marine decks of restrictions.

Claudio Arrau, a consummate artist, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. He is a pianist of most exceptional equipment, imagination and unfailing taste. He is also a magnificent musician. His technique is not merely one of force and speed;

Industrial bond financing featured the new-issue market this week, two major loans in that classification lifting bond offerings to $37,180,000. This compares with new bond emissions of $31,095,000 last week and with flotations of $30,978,000 a year ago this week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -- Smilingly expressing the hope of "making a touchdown" in his negotiations with President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull, Saburo Kurusu, special Japanese envoy, arrived here today after a flight from Tokyo.

Good Second Thoughts Boys and girls in the American history classes beginning in 1943 will have three famous repeals to remember. There is the repeal of Prohibition in 1933 and the repeal of the Neutrality Act in November, 1941, and for next year President Roosevelt has pledged himself to the repeal of his own Thanksgiving Day repealer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A second-period ground drive sparked by Halfback Melvin Knupp and aided by a George Washington fumble gave Bucknell a 6-to-0 victory over the Colonials before 6,000 football fans tonight.

BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- The basic food rations of the civilian population of Germany, which with few exceptions have remained stable during the last twenty-six months of the war, are likely to be maintained at the present levels during the coming Winter, according to informed local opinion.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 15 -- Japan's answer to international developments will be revealed at an extraordinary session of the Diet that began at 10 A.M. today with a meeting of both houses for organization. The formal opening ceremony will be held tomorrow morning in the presence of Emperor Hirohito, who will read an imperial message calling on the Diet to cooperate with the government in meeting the critical situation.

Katharin Dewey, America's only woman champion bobsledder, whose achievements were followed by the barring of all women from this highly dangerous competition, has found an outlet for her energies in her new job as head nurse of the urology department at St. Luke's Hospital, it was revealed yesterday.

FORT DIX, N.J., Nov. 14 -- A church parade by the reception center of the First Battalion will precede acceptance ceremonies of a third new chapel at Fort Dix on Sunday morning. The building, lolated in the reception center, will be presented by Lieut. Col. Frederick H. Richardson, construction quartermaster, to Colonel Cassius M. Dowell, post commander.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 14 (AP) -- A Rutgers University eleven with a record slightly spotted by last week's 16-to-0 beating by Lafayette, will close its home season tomorrow against the University of Connecticut at Rutgers Stadium.

In his statement yesterday before the Joint Committee on Reduction of Nondefense Expenditures, Secretary Morgenthau urged the re-examination of three types of Government expenditures. These were: Construction projects that divert man power and materials needed for defense;

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 14 -- Changes in the technique of war have made modern conflicts great industrial contests with victory favoring the group of nations able to produce more and continue to produce more of the weapons of destruction, Mayor La Guardia, Federal director of Civilian Defense, told a conference of State and local civilian defense councils today.

Trading in the local dressed meat markets yesterday was fairly active on most classes. Steer hinds and ribs were somewhat uneven. Cow beef prices were steady to weak. Lamb about steady. Fresh pork cuts sold steady to lower. Other classes were mostly steady. Kosher veal and calf foresaddles were strong to higher.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- The crew of the aircraft carrier Ark Royal behaved as calmly with their great warship sinking under their feet as if she had been safely tied at a dock, survivors of the torpedoing said today.
