PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14 -- One of the many morale problems in the United States Army today is the resentment of the trainees against strikes in the defense industries, particularly in those cases where the workers on strike include young men deferred from the draft because they are needed in industry.

Cabbage is a much maligned martyr, according to the State Department of Agriculture. Cabbage is delicious, nutritious and economical -- and its bad reputation is the direct result of the bad habits of bad cooks, it is said. Cabbage, may, become tender, flavorful and elegant of aroma if properly chosen, properly stored and properly prepared.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., NOV. 14 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court in Trenton sustained today the right of Mayor Frank Hague and the city commissioners to spend an estimated $75,000 for newspaper, billboard and radio advertising in their unsuccessful campaign to defeat the railroad tax compromise bills.

Very simple is the issue which John L. Lewis has put up to the government of the United States. And very simple is the President's answer. "I tell you frankly," he said to a contingent of mine union officials, "that the government of the United States will not order, nor will Congress pass legislation ordering, a so-called closed shop."

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 14 -- "The shape of the future world order is being hammered out in the fiery crucible of the present war," stated Benjamin Gerig, Professor of Government at Haverford College, in an address today to 180 student delegates and faculty guests from forty-three colleges and universities attending the tenth, annual New England International Relations Club conference at Smith this week-end.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 14 -- Approval of President Roosevelt's program for creation of a reservoir of public works for the post-war period was voted today at the close of the special session of the National Rivers and Harbors Congress.

CAMP WHEELER, Ga., Nov. 14 -- Following the arrival of 2,600 Selective Service men from Midwestern reception centers during the last weeks of this month and the first few days of December, all shipments of trainees to and from this infantry replacement center will be suspended for one month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The plan defense officials have devised for getting complete information on supplies of any critical material needed for defense was indicated to business men today in an order from the Office of Production Management calling for the complete allocation of existing stocks of magnesium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Roosevelt in a proclamation today tightened procedure governing the departure of aliens from the United States. The provisions govern the movements of both citizens and aliens entering or leaving the country.

During the opening week of the Metropolitan opera season, which begins Monday night, Nov. 24, with a performance of Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro," four new singers will make their debuts. They are Jan Peerce, American lyric tenor, who will appear as Alfredo in "La Traviata";

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: If the situation were not so tragically sad, then the statements made by Professor Badger concerning N.Y.Y. football would be downright funny. As things stand, however, they appear to be a gross misrepresentation of the true facts.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- Striving for its sixth victory of the season in seven starts, Pennsylvania meets Array's hard-blocking team on Franklin Field' tomorrow in the third game of the series that started in 1901. The crowd will probably reach 65,000.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Nov. 15 -- Russian forces were advancing in the Leningrad sector early today after they had loosed a heavy attack against German concentrations along the entire line southeast of the city to Tikhvin, 125 miles to the east, it was reported by Soviet sources.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 14 -- Virtually every member of the Twenty-first Coast Artillery attended the military funeral yesterday for Lieutenant Henry S. Brady Jr., of Battery B who died Monday after a two-day illness.

The Appellate Division upheld unanimously yesterday a ruling that the courts of the State must recognize and enforce the decree of the Netherlands Government-in-exile, which vested in that government title to all assets here belonging to persons or corporations still in occupied Netherlands territory.

Sparked by Fullback Dan Comerford, the St. Paul's School football team of Garden City, L.I. turned back its traditional foe Poly Prep, 10 to 7, in the thirty' fourth meeting between the schools on Poly's field in Brooklyn yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Colgate and Syracuse will meet tomorrow in the forty-third game of a gridiron series that dates from 1891. Good weather is expected and Archbold Stadium, probably will hold a capacity crowd of 34,000.

DETROIT, Nov. 14 -- Sidney Hillman, associate director of the Office of Production Management, told regional leaders of the American Federation of Labor today that "no grievance is big enough to warrant loss of production at this time."

HOLLYWOOD Calif., Nov. 14 -- Desertion by a conscript who finds life in an Army camp Intolerable will be the subject of William Holden's next starring vehicle at Paramount, "Absent Without Leave," the studio announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A moratorium on the debts of the "priorities unemployed" and provisions for voluntary arbitration in all labor contracts were suggested today at the final session of the National Conference on Labor Legislation, sponsored by Secretary Perkins and attended by employers, employes and State Labor Department officials.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 14 -- Yawl, carrying the blue, with gold stars, of M.M. Jackson, captured the featured Cherrystone Purse as Bowie opened its Fall meeting today before 7,000 persons, who wagered approximately $300,000 on the first eight-race program to be run in the Fall at this track.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The scrapping by Congress of all shipping restrictions of the Neutrality Act left these provisions of the law:

FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 14 -- A long list of citations for units of the Twenty-ninth Division and for individual officers and men were handed out today at McFarlan, N.C., according to word received here. Announcement of the honors was made by Major Gen. Milton A. Reckord, commander of the division.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 14 -- Two exciting matches featured the opening round of the Northeast field hockey tournament on the fields of Adelphi College today.

It will be the new Tom Harmon against the new Sid Luckman today when Tommy Kuzma of Michigan matches his skill with Paul Governali of Columbia in a Wolverine-Lion battle that shoud attract a capacity gathering of 31,000 to Baker Field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A remarkable decrease in the foreign-born in nine States for which census data is available is shown in studies made public by the Census Bureau today. This shows that the United States is ceasing to be the world's population melting pot, the bureau said.

For the first time since its founding on Oct. 7, 1889, Barnard College opened yesterday the sacrosanct portals of its gymnasium, inviting the "Columbia boys" to cross the Broadway trolley tracks and engage in a "Co-ed Sports Afternoon."

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 14 -- With negotiations between Mexico and the United States in suspense after having apparently approached the point of the signing of an economic agreement, bewilderment prevails here regarding what has happened, and in official circles sharp indignation was expressed today at the delay, which is attributed to the United States.

The last of the shooting dog field trials held by the Field Trial Club of the Southern New Tork Fish and Game Association will be held tomorrow and next Sunday at the grounds of the Goldens Bridge Hounds, Goldens Bridge, N.Y.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by thirty-eight municipalities aggregates $5,969,517, compared with $3,320,937 this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $30,665,535.

New York City's 109,000 volunteer air-raid wardens and 60,000 Fire Department auxiliaries will mobilize today at seven assembly points in the five boroughs to receive their identification cards and take part in a practice air-raid drill under simulated raid conditions.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 14 -- Colonel Frank L. Whittaker, post executive officer at Fort Jackson, S.C., today was named commanding officer of Camp Gordon, Augusta, new station of the fourth motorized division.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

BABYLON, L. I., Nov. 14 -- A smoothly working black Labrador dog, fast, dependable and at times flashy in his retrieving, today was the winner of the opening stake of the annual Autumn meeting of the Women's Field Trial Club held in this town.

As it awaits the 2 o'clock kickoff for its game with New York University today at the Yankee Stadium, Tulane may be compared to the fighter who goes into battle with one hand tied behind his back but knows he has nothing to fear because both his opponent's hands are tied.

BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- Revision of the Neutrality Law will plunge the United States into a "sea of incidents" because German warships "obviously will be obliged" to fire on American ships carrying munitions to Britain or Russia, an authorized spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- On the basis of yesterday's vote in the House of 212 to 194 to permit American merchant ships to enter War zones, President Roosevelt's foreign policy was endorsed by members from twenty-eight of the forty-eight States, with the South leading.

Leon Henderson has long been regarded as one of the more radical New Dealers. He was the chief stage manager of the long and disappointing TNEC hearings which seemed to be designed chiefly to demonstrate that private enterprise in this country had lost the power to sustain itself.

After the cotton market had gained 15 to 17 points at about noon, an increase of selling operations near the close yesterday carried prices to final losses of 2 to 7 points in all active contracts except-October, which showed a gain of 10 points over Thursday.

Swatnped with, orders from department stores and specialty shops for extra clerks to handle the Christmas sales rush, the State Employment Service is trying to lure housewives with recent sales experience out of the kitchen to take temporary jobs.

In a letter congratulating the National Broadcasting Company on its fifteenth birthday, which it celebrates today. President Roosevelt yesterday expressed his confidence that members of the broadcasting industry would rededicate "their vast resources to the maintenance of our democratic traditions, while at the same time they work with redoubled zeal to make our American system of broadcasting the best in the world."

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Nov. 14 -- The Bourse was quiet and irregular today after a slightly better opening. Royal Dutch rose 1 1/2 points to 340 and Amsterdam Rubber was 1 7/8 down at 314 1/8. Otherwise the changes were fractional. Bonds were divided, with the Dutch Indians lower.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The airplane carrier Ark Royal -- so often reported sunk by the Germans and Italians that she became a sort of phantom ship ranging the seas from the Arctic Circle to the Equator and in the Mediterranean -- has finally gone to the bottom.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The vote on Neutrality Act revision yesterday marked a new high for defections of Democrats on matters of foreign policy in the last few years.

Begun more than three years ago as the Motion Picture Research Project and carried on through grants from the Carnegie and Rockefeller Foundations, a study of Hollywood done through the "microscopes of social science" has been completed by Leo C. Rosten and a staff and will be published Nov. 28 by Harcourt Brace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumed during October totaled 953,600 bales of lint and 133,006 bales of linters, compared with 875,682 and 129,731 during September this year and 770,832 and 113,837 during October last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Nov. 8 totaled 241,829,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented a decrease of 1,511,000 barrels in the week, comprising a decrease of 1,545,000 barrels in domestic stocks and an increase of 34,000 in foreign stocks.

The secrets of the Kings Country District Attorney's office were available to the underworld during a period that the prosecuting agency was under the direction of William F.X. Geoghan, who twice was superseded because of scandals involving alleged breakdowns in the administration of criminal justice, it was testified yesterday in Kings County Court.

The Ballet Theatre gave the season's first performance of Agnes de Mille's "Three Virgins and a Devil" last night at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre, but without Miss de Mille and Eugene Loring in the two central roles which they created last season when they were members of the company.
The New York Rangers will make their bow before the home folks tonight when they skate against the world champion Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 14 -- Four boys, discovered in a store early this morning after they allegedly, had looted the cash register and a gum-vending machine of 38 cents, were in custody of police tonight after four hours of misadventures which included a plunge through a plate-glass window, a twenty-mile pursuit by police, with cars speeding ninety miles an hour at times, and a crash into a ditch.

The morale of the young men of this country, whether in the Army or in civilian life, is remarkably good; Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday in an address before 700 persons attending the annual institute of the Child Study Association at the Hotel Commodore.
CHARLOTTE, Mich., Nov. 14 -- Three Battle Creek men in a rented plane crashed to death this afternoon as they raced their plane with an eastbound grand trunk passenger train, the Maple Leaf.
Sir Girja Shankar Bajpai, first Agent General from India to the United States, arrived yesterday from Bombay on the President Monroe of the American President Lines, which docked at Pier 8, Hoboken.

Phi Beta Kappa Associates, an organization termed last year to provide a nucleus of leadership within the honorary scholastic fraternity, elected ninety-three new members last night at a dinner in the Metropolitan Club. Among them were Wilbur L. Cross, four times Governor of Connecticut;
LONDON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- Intensified activity by British, and United States naval patrols has resulted in the destruction of "many" German U-boats in the Atlantic, naval quarters said today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 14 -- The football forces of Yale and Princeton retired to prepared positions tonight and rested on their arms, waiting for their game the Bowl tomorrow.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 14 -- While the word from Helsinki tonight is that the Finns hope their reply to the United States will not be considered In Washington as closing the doors to further negotiation, observers in Stockholm agree that untill the Finns have reached what they consider a "strategical" frontier, such negotiations are bound to be fruitless.

Hosiery manufacturers have be come beggars rather than chooser with respect to the commodities they must use, and soon retailers and eventually consumers must also become beggars, Sari Constantine, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, said yesterday.

Production in the Yale swimming pool of "The Frogs" of Aristophanes as "a Grecian aquacade" brought out a lively and original show. Roughly summarized, the farce takes the god Dionysus, disguised as his brother Heracles, down to Hades on Charon's ferryboat.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- Withdrawal of 970 United States marines from China will start late next week on a United States President liner that is being sent here for the purpose, it was understood.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Fifty-one railroads will be shut down at 6 A.M. on Dec. 7 in the first day of a three-part program designed to stop all major carriers to enforce wage demands, the "big five" operating brotherhoods stated today.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 14 -- Finnish officials indicated today they were waiting for the American and British Governments to make the next move, hoping that it would not be a declaration that would place Finland at war ,with the world's democracies.

Unless otherwise stated, tlie results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductiotis. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

Tithonus was granted immortality but not eternal youth, with the result that he shriveled like an orange and chirped like a locust. The Greek tale points the moral that we can never think of everything and that a price must be paid for any advantage that we may acquire over nature.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The National Defense Mediation Board in two cases today rejected the demands of American Federation of Labor unions for union shops or strong union security clauses as the compensation for no-strike agreements.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- New England business and industry were told today by economists that American payrolls this year will be $60,000,000,000 and that retail buying is up 10 per cent. They closed their annual conference with a refusal to attach fear or pessimism to the approach of rising prices or possible inflation.

With an Eye to Taxes It is at this season of the year that "tax-selling" of securities is reported on every side, a market characteristic which has increased as the tax schedules have mounted. With the income-tax schedule for next year at a high record, the Treasury has been pushing its sales of tax-anticipation notes.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 14 -- The Berlin Foreign Office press chief, Paul Schmidt, will arrive in Ankara Monday at the head of a German press mission to begin a Winterlong campaign designed to obtain favorable publicity for the Reich in the Turkish press.

Immediate action by Congress to outlaw strikes and lockouts in defense industries, making it a criminal offense thus to obstruct production, was demanded yesterday by the American Legion through Lynn U. Stambaugh, its national commander.

"Put the lid on" an oil dealer inscribed on one of his oil jars on the island of Cyprus about 1200 B.C., and that was the beginning of Greek writing, according to Dr. John P. Daniel, assistant curator of the Pennsylvania University Museum.

The effect of the "private placement" of new security issues -- the direct sale by issuing corporations to institutional investors -- upon "home securities and home people" was described graphically yesterday before the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee at hearings on amendments to the securities laws by J.C. Folger of Folger, Nolan Co., an investment firm in Washington, D.C.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Nov. 12, "The Other Side of Harlem," denies the basic cause for the situation in our country of which the new manifestation of crime in Harlem is only a symptom slight enough for what it signifies. Nor are the constructive measures proposed sufficient.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- Russian warships loose in the Baltic have sunk four Axis transport ships totaling 36,000 tons, according to a Russian war communique broadcast by the Moscow radio tonight. The Germans reported last week that Russian warships had left the Kronstadt naval base, crashed safely through a mine barricade and reached open sea in the Gulf of Finland.

In the present critical test that Western Hemisphere solidarity is undergoing, Dr. Juan Carlos Blanco, Uruguay's first Ambassador to the United States since the elevation of that country legation in Washington to the rank of embassy, declared yesterday that the Montevideo government adheres faithfully to the good-neighbor policy and its economic principles.

HOT SPRINGS, Nov. 14 -- In an urgent plea to the advertising profession to abandon business as usual, submerge its unfounded antipathy to the government and plunge into an all-out war effort, William L. Batt, director of the Materials Division of OPM, today warned that England and Russia will be beaten unless American supplies are tremendously increased.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Complete elimination of Federal highway expenditures for 1944 and drastic reductions in appropriations for reclamation, rivers and harbors improvements, agricultural aid, the Civilian Conservation Corps and the National Youth Administration were recommended today by Secretary Morgenthau to the Joint Congressional Committee on Non-Essential Expenditures, as a means of reducing Federal outlay by $1,000,000,000 annually.

The "Lindbergh flag," the United States banner carried to Paris by Charles A. Lindbergh on his famous non-stop flight to Europe in 1927, no longer hangs in the restaurant of the Hotel Lafayette, University Place and Ninth Street, whose former owner, the late Raymond Orteig, donated the $25,000 that inspired the transatlantic airplane journey.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- British American Tag Day will be observed in Westchester County tomorrow with a seventy-two-mile parade of motorized hospital units touching twenty cities, towns and villages, according to an announcement from the British American Ambulance Corps.

The story of how a small party of Royal Marines, just back from a similar mission, to Boulogne, crossed the English Channel to Calais by destroyer on the night of May 24-25, 1040, fought a covering action against overwhelming odds for almost forty-eight hours and then, its duty done, returned to Dover, was told officially yesterday for the first time by the British Admiralty.

Uninterrupted flow of diplomatic, commercial and private communications to all parts of the world was assured yesterday when Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the State Mediation Board, announced that two weeks of negotiation in the offices of the board had resulted in an agreement between RCA Communications, Inc., and the American Communications Association, C.I.O., on terms of a new two-year contract.

Meetings of the 1941 nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange have been called for next Tuesday and Tuesday, Nov. 25. Members of the Exchange have been invited to make suggestions as to the make-up of the 1942 nominating committee, which will be elected in January.

VICHY, France, Nov. 14 -- Adrien Marquet, Mayor of Bordeaux, together with the Mayors of many communities in that district, have asked Paul Charbin, Minister of Supplies, for an interview to tell him that in all these localities adults "who are not sick and who pursue their normal activities" have lost on an average from twelve to twenty pounds In weight and that "children between 9 and 14 years old are in danger."

VANDERBURG, N.J., Nov. 14 -- Cinar's Chuck, owned by Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Milbank of New York City, and handled by Dr. Milbank, captured the open all-age stake for cocker spaniels today in the sixth annual meeting of the Monmouth County Spaniel Field Trial Association at the Big Brook Pheasant Farm.

Continuing its policy of presenting both sides of controversial questions in the classroom, the Board of Education has arranged for a discussion of the national crisis and the position this country should take in regard to the current war, it became known yesterday.

BOSTON COLLEGE vs. Tennessee -- A regular stumper right off the reel! This would be a good time to keep quiet and curl up with a good book. And WR observer has a good book practically fresh off the press: Captain William H. Baumer Jr.'s "Not All Warriors," a delightful volume concerning the careers of some former West Point students who became famous for work beyond military lines.

William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management, told a gathering of 1,200 naval architects and marin engineers last night that, "as long as you keep the line open to England, Hitler can't win, and if you can get superiority in the air Hitler is going to lose."

ALIVELY spirit of combat generally animates discussion of the short story. Fighting words are apt to fly. Advocates of the amoebic, or spoonful-of-life school scarcely tolerate those owho speak up for the vast mechanized division. Copies of Story Magazine and The Saturday Evening Post are infrequently found on the same living-room tables.

THIS wise, mellow and altogether charming book grew out of the Survey of American Painting, which, in lieu of the perforce relinquished "International," was held in the galleries of Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh in 1940.

Saburo Kurusu, special Imperial Ambassador, reached Washington yesterday and yesterday the Japanese Diet met in what is called in Tokyo a special "crisis" session. Mr. Kurusu will see Secretary of State Hull tomorrow to begin his talks, which are intended to explore the possibility of an agreement between the United States and Japan on the many issues which have arisen between the two countries because of the Japanese expansionist program in the Far East.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 15 -- Until the United States is actually at war the morale problem among both civilians and Army selectees may best be met by clarification of the ideals toward which defense effort is directed, delegates from Fourteen Eastern colleges were told this afternoon at Vassar College.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 15 -- A powerful and versatile Williams eleven captured its second Little Three championship in as many years today by routing a hard-fighting Amherst team with a last-period scoring barrage, 28 -- 6, on Weston Field.
BERLIN, Nov. 15 -- Gebriele Reuter, widely known novelist, died at Weimar at the age of 82. Frau Reuter was for many years the German correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review.

AUTHOR: In Rome last week Italians were reading "I Speak With Bruno," Premier Benito Mussolini's tribute to his son who died in an airplane accident last August. The book was the Italian dictator's first since his "Life of Arnaldo," written after the death of a brother nine years ago.

TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 16 -- Emperor Hirohito formally opened today the extraordinary session of the Japanese Diet, which was convoked yesterday to cope with the critical international situation. His brief message from the throne exhorted the members to do their utmost to cooperate with the Tojo Government in its grave task.

BERLIN, Nov. 15 -- While igloo experts are reportedly teaching the German soldiers to build Eskimo snow huts in which to pass the Winter on the Eastern Front, attention here today centered on the fighting in Crimea, which German military observers said now offered the best promise of a break in what is seen as a temporary deadlock in the war with Russia.

Ku-ma, largest and strongest of four jaguar cubs, was chosen by Fate to play a royal role in the jungles of British Guiana. For "Ku-ma the Swift," as the Indians came later to call him, was that rare creature, that freak of nature, a white panther; white, except for the soot-black tip of his tail, as the snow he would never see, white as the shining quartz pebbles at the bottom of a stream.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Delivery of warplanes and aeronautical equipment to Britain reached a record high of $330,000,000 in eight months of 1941, the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America reported today.

Completing the Autumn field trial season of the retriever breeds, the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club will hold its annual meeting this week-end on the properties of Ralph Greene and James I. Davis in Bayport, L.I.

Promise that the textile industry will be increasingly affected by government demands for readjustments in production because of defense needs is being met by the National Consumer-Retailer Council with an intensified campaign for informative labeling to be accelerated by a series of dinners, the first of which is to be on textiles early in December.

In a realistic simulation of actual wartime conditions, helped along by heavy Saturday afternoon traffic, magnesium flares and sulphur pots, more than 70,000 volunteer air raid wardens and fire department auxiliaries mobilized at seven posts in the five boroughs of the city yesterday afternoon to receive identification cards and do their stuff for Mayor La Guardia and admiring crowds of friends and neighbors.

MANILA, Nov. 15 -- President Quezon, addressing Filipinos on the sixth anniversary of the commonwealth, today informed them that America had decided upon all-out defense of the Philippines in case a general war breaks out in Asia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Georgetown took to the airways to tame an equally pass-minded North Carolina State team, 20 to 7, today before 10,000 excited spectators.

NORMAL Washington is like a gay cosmopolitan village overshadowing its more or less somber lining of diplomacy. Imposing houses open their doors to receive long lines of pleasure-seekers great and small; even at the more selective official dinners men and women, trained to make a noise like a party, meet in social unity no matter what tussle is taking place between the representatives of their country and the State Department.

DE LAND, Fla. -- As the motorist travels along the East Coast highways from South Carolina to Central Florida he may, by making short trips of only a few miles from the main routes, ferret out some of the oldest remnants of European civlization in the United States.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 15 -- The Blair football team won its nineteenth game in the traditional series with Peddie today, beating the visitors by 26 -- 0. The schools have met on gridiron annually since 1903.

In a session on the Stock Exchange which for a Saturday was the most active since Aug. 2 and the broadest in nine months, the share market yesterday fluctuated irregularly and closed firm and mixed, with practically no change in prices.

There were signs last week that a Winter stalemate was settling over most of the long and bloody battlefront in Russia. In Berlin newsreel theatres the film record from the Leningrad, Moscow and Ukraine sectors showed German troops busily putting up cold-weather quarters -- portable log cabins of Norwegian pine.

Members of the New York Chapter of the American Bridge League will give a games party on Tuesday night in the ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the children's cancer ward of Memorial Hospital. Mrs. Donald B. Tansill heads the committee.

The scarcity of print cloths, major weave type in the cotton gray goods field, which has caused closings of some printing plants and threatened to bring additional stoppages, is due to a number of causes and is only remotely connected with the fact that mills are dissatisfied with some features of the sliding-scale ceiling system now in operation, according to millmen and selling agents.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Concern by police officials over their inability to provide adequate protection to the public in the face of priority restrictions which "have virtually dried up" their source of guns and ammunition, radio equipment and motor vehicles was expressed today at a meeting here of officers of the International Association of Chiefs of Police.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15 -- The chief public relations problem of American labor unions today lies not merely in the hostility of American business men who as representatives of "capital" are considered the traditional foes of labor. There are two other groups, far more potent in numbers, whose attitude makes the labor union problem of dealing with the public doubly serious.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today after a week of declining quotations, reflecting unsettled dressed meat trade, due partly to competition of poultry for holiday season. Some dressed pork cuts lost 1 1/2 to 2 cents a pound.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 15 -- Captain Bill Dudley, in his final appearance in Scott Stadium today, led the Virginia eleven, to a 34-to-0 victory over Lehigh.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas -- The Rio Grande Valley, in which Texas and Mexico meet, will entertain more visitors this year than ever before, it is expected. Residents, occupied largely during the past two decades with making the valley attractive and homelike, have completed their preparations and are awaiting the Winter influx.

WHEN I was asked recently to speak concerning acoustical reflectors, microphone placement and my new seating of the orchestra, my first thought was that music lovers are interested in music itself, but not in the technical methods by which music is conveyed to them.

Because of present war-time conditions and the development of their transportation facilities, Latin-American nations are now trading among themselves "on a scale heretofore unknown," according to Charles H. Roditl, head of the Latin-American purchasing commission of R.H. Macy Co., who has just returned from a four-month buying tour throughout South America.

The advance subscription for the benefit performance of "Don Giovanni" on the afternoon of Dec. 5 at the Metropolitan Opera House indicates that a capacity audience will attend. The Manhattan School of Music will be the beneficiary of the special matinee.

For more than two decades Federal income-tax statutes have consistently permitted a domestic corporation owning a majority of the voting stock of a foreign corporation, from which it receives dividends, to take credit, with certain limitations, for income, war-profits and excess-profits taxes paid by such foreign corporation to any foreign country.

Members of the Catholic Young Women's Club, who have already given volunteer service to a number of projects connected with war relief and the emergency, will hear of the special contributions young business women can make to plans now developing at a defense rally to be held tomorrow evening at their clubhouse, 641 Lexington Avenue.

THE reader who is cognizant of current events will perhaps remember how President Roosevelt disposed of Mr. Lindbergh with a reference to Vallandigham and the Copperheads. "Copperheads" was the name given to the Northern opponents of the war with the South.

Sociologists, community planners and housing experts can cite impressively profound reasons for decentralizing industry and population, but not one of their arguments is as impressive as a clear November evening in what they call "the circumferential area." An evening with stars and a touch of frost in the air, with leaning birches and wind-stripped maples on the skyline, with lighted windows down the road and a dog barking some one welcome.

THE Latin American Prize Novel Contest promises to be one of the most successful ventures launched by an ambitious publisher. Besides the present winner, which John Dos Passos calls one of the most impressive novels he has ever read in Spanish, there are to follow novels from Ecuador, Brazil and Mexico.

AT this time, when thousands of youths are worried about the mathematical requirements that stand between them and an officership, or that may hazard the road to promotion in an industrial defense establishment, the publication of a new guide to self-education in this field assumes extraordinary interest.
HAPPY EXILE: In Madrid a year ago last week an abdicated monarch awaited Spain's decision on his fate. Carol of Rumania had sought temporary asylum there.

A WEEK ago yesterday "Life With Father" wandered into its third year. Persons interested in the matter took occasion to look over the figures; they found that the gross intake for the second year was $859,546, as against $972,734 for the first -- neither figure spelling failure exactly.

The isolationist cycle in American foreign policy, symbolized by the neutrality legislation that has been on the statute books for six years, came last week to its official close. In a dramatic and solemn session, Congress gave final approval to repeal of those important sections of the Neutrality Act which have survived the impact of war abroad.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- Michigan State College today uncorked an aerial and running attack that crushed favored Temple University, 46 to 0, before 10,192 football fans.
LONG is the arm of coincidence -- but is it long enough, asks the Brazilian literary world, to embrace Daphne du Maurier's "Rebecca" and Carolina Nabuco's "A Sucesora"?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- A group of House members is drafting broad, new anti-strike legislation as a preliminary to an attempt to force Congressional action on the question of restricting the stoppages of defense production.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Scoring three touchdowns, one on a 63-yard run by Fred Florsheim, Gettysburg defeated Ursinus College, 20 -- 0, today in their annual Eastern Pennsylvania Collegiate Conference game.

PRITCHARDVILLE, S.C. -- In the Low Country between Charleston, S.C., and Savannah, Ga., one can find the seclusion of a Robinson Crusoe without any of the inconveniences he experienced. Thousands of little islands on this broad stretch of indented coastline are for sale or rent.

Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, said last week that the commission's far-reaching program of ship production was designed not only to meet the exigencies of emergencies and wars, but to re-establish the merchant marine in a dominant peacetime position among the maritime countries of the world.

The film producers could have the five State censorship boards in the United States abolished if they took the matter before the Supreme Court, it was asserted yesterday by Morris Ernst. Mr. Ernst is counsel for the distributors of "The Forgotten Village," the John Steinbeck documentary film that was approved Friday for public showing by the New York State Board of Regents after it had been banned by the Board of Censors.

My wife's father, who has the green thumb, can perform miracles with grass seed. He uses the "burlap method," and he made it work last Fall even on that bare spot near the kitchen, made by members of the family who persisted in taking a short cut, despite the presence of a flagged path only slightly longer, and despite the patient grumblings of the nominal head of the house.

A home-made gun and two rival gangs of Harlem Negro youths, the Mutineers and the Royal Knights, figured in a street fight that sent two Negroes to Harlem Hospital and caused the arrest of five other early yesterday. Ages of the prisoners ranged between 14 and 16 years, and both wounded youths were 17.

The Ballet Theatre restored two works to the repertory yesterday at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre, namely, "Peter and the Wolf" at the matinee, and "La Fille Mal Gardee," newly christened "The Wayward Daughter," in the evening.

Almost 2,000,000,000,000 tons of high-grade bituminous coal are known to lie beneath the earth crust in the United States. Last year some 431,000 men dug out 453,245,000 tons of this fuel for America's factories, railroads and steel furnaces that forge the sinews of war.

Steam heat, puffing and snorting through the radiators these nippy Fall days, mean comfort to the family, but if you cherish your fine furniture, if you love that bit of a tortoise-shell table, the Regency side chair, you may well do a little worrying.

The New fork Committee for the National Cathedral will celebrate its forty-second year with a benefit performance of "Spring Again" at the Henry Miller Theatre on Tuesday. The proceeds will be used to augment New York's quota toward the maintenance of religious services at the Washington cathedral.

AS the months go by, it is becoming harder for the novelist to write in a vacuum, as it were, and to ignore what is happening to our world. Even escape fiction -- with which "Strangers Are Coming" should be classed -- is not always wholly unclouded by the shadow of the war.

The military situation on the Russian front appears to have reached a state of critical balance. German admissions as well as Russian claims confirm this view. A balance of this kind cannot be maintained indefinitely. Some degree of movement must be restored as the initiative passes to one side or the other.

BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 15 -- Hi-Wood Mike, a black Labrador retriever owned by Mrs. J.S. Williams and handled in the field by the veteran trainer David Elliott, today was awarded the chief trophy in the limited all-age stake, the most important event in the annual meeting of the Women's Field Trial Club, which will be completed tomorrow.

LETTERS: Service Men Like Them Here is the final line of a letter just received from one of the boys formerly in our employ and now doing his bit in Uncle Sam's Army: "Write soon; receiving letters is a psychological lift." This is everybody's chance to do a bit of personal USO work for the boys in the service.
