Boys High made too many slips against Erasmus Hall High yesterday, and Erasmus capitalizing on the miscues, finished its schedule unbeaten and untied as it triumphed, 20 to 0, at Boys High Field. It was the thirty-seventh meeting between the Brooklyn Schools.

DOWN West Indies way is the island of blondes -- Saba. It's in that American tropical world where there are only conspicuous and strange summits of submerged tableland, that world of a chain of purple mountain, islands and silvery and blue seas.

GENERALLY any novel combining physical suspense with a spiritual struggle sacrifices one to the other, but here the suspense and the mental struggle of Allen's escape from the circle of stultifying rationalization blend nicely in this vigorous second novel.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I know of good minds who dislike and distrust the very notion of post-war thoughts. At the conference of the International Labor Organization Mr. Gibson, vice chairman of the British Trades Union Congress, declared: "Put first things first.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- How yeast may be utilized to synthesize vitamin B1 from various chemicals and in the process become supercharged with this vitamin is disclosed in a patent (No. 2,262,735) awarded to Alfred S. Schultz and Lawrence Atkin of the Bronx, and Charles N. Frey of Scarsdale, N.Y.

The current debate in Congress on the price control bill and the Administration's insistence that a more effective measure be passed, together with its advocacy of further heavy increases in taxation, reflect the growing concern lest the present rising cycle of prices, wages and costs lead to serious inflation.

IF the producers will promise not to be scared off, which they shouldn't be, they may read herewith of the new deal at Princeton University's McCarter Theatre, home of many a tryout, whereby no play may be presented there unless its script is read and approved in advance by a professor and a lady.

A long-distance telephone call from the office of a physician while it was being robbed resulted yesterday in the arraignment of Ruth Hilton, 40 years old, of 356 West Twenty-seventh street, on charges of suspicion of burglary and violation of the Sullivan law.

WE see by the papers that hit-run highway accidents continue to take life and cause injury. Maybe the number of drivers who cravenly flee is on the increase. In recent weeks, there seem to have been many more such anger-provoking incidents than usual.

One of the most temperate and realistic studies yet made of the relationship of fast driving to traffic accidents has just been issued by the speed regulation committee of the National Safety Council. It covers the experience of many States and of communities with widely varying traffic problems within those States.
THE visiting Boston Symphony will be heard in its first pair of concerts here this season when it appears in Carnegie Hall Thursday night and Saturday afternoon.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Ralph M. Barton, widely-known golf course architect, died at his home here last night at the age of 66. Among the courses he designed were those at Yale and Dartmouth, the Mid-Ocean in Bermuda, and nearly a dozen others in New Hampshire.

HOUSTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Texas A. and M.'s master craftsman cranked up their passing machine today and clinched at least a tie for the Southwest Conference football title with a 19-6 victory over Puce Institute, which realized its defensive powers too late.

A growing tendency on the part of corporations to meet their financial requirements by offering their securities directly to the public without the usual protection of underwriting by investment bankers revives the now moss-covered quesion, "What true economic function does security underwriting fulfill?"

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 15 -- Rutgers closed its home football season today with a 32-to-7 victory over Connecticut. The Scarlet pushed across four touchdowns in the first half in recording its sixth triumph of the campaign before 8,000 spectators in the Rutgers Stadium.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Nov. 15 -- A survey of the city government of Rockford, undertaken by students of public administration at Rockford College, is being published by the city this week. This is believed to be the first time that any college group has been entrusted with a comprehensive project of this kind and that their report, the work of an outside, independent group, has been approved and published with city funds.

To keep a continuity of their organization in spite of the interruption of activities abroad, the International Federation of University Women has called a meeting this week for delegates from associations in countries of the Western Hemisphere.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- In the highest-scoring game that has marked the series since 1927, Cornell rolled to a 33-19 gridiron victory over Dartmouth before a crowd of 20,000 at Schoellkopf Field today.

In celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Protestant Teachers Association, founded to instruct children in religion after school hours, 2,800 city school teachers attended the group's annual luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- A broad program to strengthen the position of Christianity in a war-torn world by increasing participation in the liturgy by the laity and by revising present methods of teaching the young was expounded today at the opening sessions of the seventh National Congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 15 (AP) -- A versatile and hard-hitting Alabama team gained a 20-0 victory today over Georgia Tech to strengthen its chances of participation in one of the bowl games Jan. 1. The triumph, before a capacity crowd of 25,000, was the fifth straight in the Southeastern Conference for the Tide.

APPOMATTOX COURT HOUSE, Va.-- Congress has appropriated $100,000 to be used in restoring "The Surrender House"-- that famous brick-and-wood structure in which General Robert E. Lee surrendered to General Ulysses S. Grant.

IOWA CITY, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Minnesota's Golden Gophers, their bruising power given a tremendous inspirational lift by Captain Bruce Smith, crushed Iowa, 34 to 13, today to stay among the select few of the nation's undefeated and untied football teams.

"IN all things we should consider the result," wrote wise and witty La Fontaine. This admonition should hang upon the walls of every kitchen, and be engraved upon the conscience of every cook, from mere well-meaning novice to the proud Cordon Bleu.

Syracuse THE first exhibition of contemporary ceramics of the Western Hemisphere, closing today at the Syracuse Museum, will come to New York in its entirety to be shown at the W. J. Sloane Galleries, beginning on Dec. 8.

ROME, Nov. 15 -- General Francisco Pricolo, Chief of Staff and Under-Secretary for Air, was replaced today in both those posts by Rino Corso Fougier, commander of an air armada. A communique explained that General Pricolo, who was rated as one of Italy's best air-force officers, would be "assigned to another task."

If the United States will send to China "one month's production" of tanks and planes, China can defeat Japan in 1942, thereby releasing for the battle against Hitlerism the tremendous British, American, Australian, Indian and Russian forces held in the Pacific by the existence of an unconquered Japan, according to Chu Hsueh-fan, president of the Chinese Association of Labor.

Eighteen public schools in the "high juvenile delinquency areas" of Harlem have gymnasiums or indoor playgrounds that are now kept idle at night, but could be used for recreational purposes, Paul Blanshard, executive director of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission issued today a plan of reorganization for the Fonda, Jonnstown Gloversville Railroad Company which reduces capitalization, including loans and bills payable, from $9,734,123 to $2,414,755 and cuts annual interest charges from $137,820 to $26,164.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of fifty-three women to membership in the New York City Defense Council. The selections, the Mayor said, were based on the parts played by these women in the boroughs from which they were named.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Despite mass executions, mounting in official Yugoslav announcements to 350,000, a spokesman for the exiled government said today that 80,000 guerrillas to relentless mountain warfare, had wrested most of Serbia from the Axis.

A timely idea is that of Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Biddle, wife of our Ambassador to the Governments in Exile, to send a group of ten representative American women to England, there to see at first-hand the conditions under which their sisters are living and working to bring this war to a successful conclusion.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force stepped up its offensive across the Channel yesterday. British fighters set fire to a factory and oil tanks on the Nazi-occupied French coast during the day, the Air Ministry reported.

THE National Broadcasting Company yesterday celebrated its fifteenth anniversary and the radio world paused to look back over the technical developments of that period -- developments symbolized by the appointments of two new Radio City studios now ready for service; marvels of acoustical excellence fitted into the atmosphere of the intimate theatre.

IMPORTANT at Thanksgiving are Presidents and Governors. They remind us of our blessings; they appoint the Thursday, or Thursdays, on which we shall give thanks, and through their conduct, wise or otherwise, of public affairs they help to determine the extent of our gratitude.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Mexican police said tonight they were investigating new evidence in the death of the wealthy Kalamazoo, Mich., widow, 65-year-old Mrs. Ada Loveland, whose second husband, Arthur Torrance, maintains she died in a motor car accident near here a week ago.

THE Ballet Theatre duly opened on Wednesday evening at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre under the auspices of the New Opera Company. Though the premiere occurred too late for comment in these columns, be it recorded that the program contained the first New York showing of a ballet by Michel Fokine, which is always an event.

RUSHVILLE, Ind., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Eight passengers and the driver of a Cincinnati-to-Indianapoils Greyhound bus were injured fatally tonight as the vehicle plunged over a twenty-five-foot embankment and caught fire after a collision with an automobile, four miles east of here on Indianapolis Road 44.

BERLIN, Nov. 15 -- In a striking juxtaposition of the sweetness of victory and the bitter consequences of defeat, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Reich Minister of Propaganda, told the German people that the opportunity open today is not only the greatest in its history but also the only one.

Station CURC, approaching its first anniversary as the student-operated broadcasting unit of Columbia University, has added an educational workshop to its other features which niclude broadcasts of world news, interviews with political and literary personalities, periodic broadcasts of the university's intercollegiate and intramural sports program, and musical presentations.

Wall Street is calling attention to the fact that share prices in London are out-performing those in New York. Since the start of the war industrials in London have risen about 2 per cent, against a drop of 15.7 per cent here. Since June of 1940, after Dunkerque, London has recovered 60 per cent, in contrast to a decline of 2 per cent here.

While new home construction on Long Island for several months to come will evidently be limited chiefly to residential building in defense areas, developers in many other localities are preparing to complete the home groups already started.

Reorders and fill-ins comprised the bulk of business placed in the wholesale market last week, reflecting the return of retail activity to a more normal level, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

In reply to the increased demand by government authorities for increased civilian defense activity Brooklyn College has expanded this work so rapidly among its students and faculty that this week Harry D. Gideonse, president of the college, announced the appointment of a faculty civilian defense committee.

AFERMENT is at work in the American art world. Of sufficient vitality and substance to make its impact clearly felt, this takes the form of an upsurge of new talent, some of which may not be remarkable, some of which, having emerged, may be destined to affect the course of future developments.

Mayor La Guardia will address 1,000 voluntary workers of the Manhattan Women's Division of the United Hospital Campaign at the fourth report meeting of the division Tuesday morning at 11:30 o'clock at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Roy E. Larsen, general chairman of the campaign, announced yesterday.
Retail trade in the New York area was stimulated by cooler weather last week. Department store sales were estimated at 10 to 15 per cent ahead of last year, when the weather was unfavorable.

Josef Lhevinne accomplished his greatest feats of pianism in the second half of his recital given yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. It was in the Debussy offerings and the Chopin group, which comprised this part of his list, and the lavish series of encores demanded thereafter, that Mr. Lhevinne employed his stupendous technique to the utmost advantage.

The tax bill of machinery-making industries was multiplied nearly fourfold in the first nine months of 1941, compared with a year before, but the net profits of nineteen manufacturers in this field rose nearly 30 per cent in spite of the higher tax bill.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 15 -- Washington State, giant killer of the Pacific Coast Conference, wrote one of the season's great upsets into the football records today by scoring a 14 to 13 victory over Stanford before 45,000 fans.

Families qualified for aid to dependent children will be included beginning tomorrow under the medical and nursing service which previously has been available to families on home relief, to veterans, the blind and aged.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Presidential intervention is expected next week to avert a national railroad strike scheduled to begin at 6 A.M. Dec. 7, leaders of both sides said today in discussing the wage dispute involving 1,250,000 workers on 180 of the country's roads.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: For two reasons it is painful to note that an editorial writer of The Sun is acquainted with only one Deer Island off the coast of New England, and that one in Boston Harbor which maintains a penitentiary. One reason inspired him to write recently under the title "Metered Error":

Accelerated interest in the Friendship Dinner of sixty women's organizations gathering tomorrow at the Hotel Biltmore will focus on the personnel of the group of American women who will shortly visit Great Britain.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Outplaying West Virginia in the first half and then stopping two Mountaineer threats on the 6 and 8 yard lines in the third and fourth quarters, Penn State's football team triumphed, 7 -- 0, before 11,000 today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- A young man named Leland (Bunky) Morris saved Syracuse from defeat and sent a record crowd of 33,000 into a frenzy of delight today when the Orange was only forty-one seconds from disaster.

A gigantic educational campaign, designed to reach the millions of non-citizens in the United States, is now getting under way, aided by a $14,000,000 grant from the Federal Government. New reading materials are being prepared, advisory councils are being formed in each State and standards for an impressive teaching corps are being developed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The War Department ordered today about $30,000,000 in olive-drab Cloth for uniforms.

CLINTON, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Expansion of Hamilton College's teacher-training program through appointment of five members of the Clinton Central School's high school faculty to serve the college part-time is announced by President W.H. Cowley.
NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- For the first time in fifty years Rockland County opened its vast woodland reaches to deer hunters today. A fifteen-day open season on bucks started at 7 o'clock this morning.

VICHY, France, Nov. 15 -- General Charles Huntziger, Minister of War and Commander of the French Land Forces, and his six companions who met death with him in an airplane accident, were buried here today with rites both ecclesiastical and military.

BERLIN, Nov. 15 -- In a special communique issued by the German High Command this afternoon on the sinking of the British aircraft carrier Ark Royal, the 31,000-ton battleship Malaya is claimed to have been so seriously damaged that the vessel has had to go to Gibraltar for repairs.
"Winter Protection of the Garden" will be the subject of the free lecture given by J.H. Beale of the Boyce Thompson Institute, at 3 P.M. on Saturday at the New York Botanical Garden.

Who killed Lilac Reed, and why? Was it George Reed, who may have discovered that she was completely out of sympathy with the environment to which he had brought her as his bride? Was it her stepdaughter, Tony, who resented having another woman preside over the household where no other woman had held sway since Tony's mother died?

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Ohio State moved into a second-place tie with Michigan in the Western Conference football race today, but only after coming from behind to subdue a valiant and ever-fighting Illinois team, 12 to 7.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 15 -- At the reopening of the Egyptian Parliament today Prime Minister Hussein Sirry Pasha emphasized Egypt's cordial relations with other nations "in matters unaffected by the war," and explained in considerable detail what the government is doing to relieve Egyptians in the matter of such wartime evils as rising prices and food shortages.
ROME, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

ANKARA, Nov. 15 -- Germany's huge armies are poised to smash against the Caucasus -- the 900-mile mountain graveyard of Huns and Mongols and the legions of Peter the Great -- in a desperate Winter campaign to force the gateway to India, capture the oil of Iraq and come to grips with the waiting armies of the British Empire.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- Delaware defeated Drexel today, 7 -- 6, when Jack Castevens blocked Joe Michaels's punt on the Drexel 10 and Harold Thompson, right end, grabbed the ball and ran into the end zone. Bill Hogan converted on a line plunge.

LATEST wrinkle in Amos 'n' Andy's appeal to the public to purchase defense bonds and stamps is the timely suggestion that they would make attractive Christmas gifts. Henry Morgenthau Jr., Treasury chief, has approved the idea and during the coming weeks the Harlem harlequins will work along plans outlined by his department.

Recently a long-time member of the American Rose Society deplored the fact that nurserymen selling roses devoted a great deal of catalogue space to describing the tints, tones, shades and color combinations of their roses but rarely said a word about the, to her, most important characteristic of the rose, its fragrance.
HOLLYWOOD. ORSON WELLES declared openly the other day that his second venture as the cinema's universal genius, "The Magnificent Ambersons," which he adapted in nine days from Booth.

OTTAWA, Nov. 15 -- Out of the debates of these past two weeks in the Canadian Parliament there has emerged a picture of the country's war effort which even those who would like to see more being done have found stimulating and a companion picture of the completeness with which even after two years of war the democratic right of discussion and criticism has been preserved.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Nov. 16 -- Russian forces on the Leningrad front continued throughout yesterday their unrelenting pressure against German positions along a line stretching from a point just south of the city to Tikhvin, about 125 miles away on the Leningrad-Vologda road.

WHAT makes a hit? After years of pacing back and forth in Shubert Alley mumbling strange double-talk and occasionally stopping to count on its fingers, Broadway still hasn't answered that one. Unfortunately the mathematics of the theatre are haphazard and two and two don't necessarily make four.
THE President calls them "armchair strategists." "Indignant subscribers" denounce them. Slings and arrows from outraged readers beat heavily these days upon the door of the "experts."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- OPM technicians have been asked by Army and Navy consultants to estimate stock piles of vital metals on the basis of needs for a three-year period, it was learned today.

A SOMEWHAT indignant subscriber wrote in to ask why, on Autumn Sundays, this space was given over to comment on professional football players and teams. He much preferred reading matter concerned with the college game. At a pinch, or for a change, he could take essays on golf, tennis, the turf, track and field or basketball in stride, but pro football was not his dish and comment on it bored him no little.

Officials of government agencies engaged in home financing and emergency housing were among the speakers at the recent three-day conference of the presidents of the twelve Federal Home Loan Banks. Among the topics discussed were changes in building codes to permit acceptable substitutions for scarce materials, particularly plumbing equipment, and stream-lining the procedure for obtaining priorities for building materials on the critical list of the OPM.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 15 -- American agriculture, after a victory over Germany, will face the task of feeding "hundreds of millions throughout the continents of Europe and Asia" unless the world is allowed to relapse into an "endless barbarism," Secretary Morgenthau told the National Grange today.

Customarily a benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund, as of the last few years, the opening performance of the Ice Follies at Madison Square Garden again will serve to aid that cause. The premiere will be on Dec. 1 and already it has a large advance subscription.

AT a time when there is a tendency on the part of those who are writing books for children to try to explain the theory of democracy, it is refreshing to find an author who is fully aware that action and descriptions of action mean far more to boys and girls than ideas in the abstract.
BERLIN, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The following communique was issued today at Adolf Hitler's headquarters:

FEW contemporary books have ever impressed me quite as deeply as this book of stories by Eudora Welty. It seems to me almost impossible to discuss her work detachedly. Reading it twice has not given me any critical distance, but has only drawn me closer into its rich and magic world.

The serious theme of national defense and tributes to the role being played by radio in the emergency were among the features of a special three-hour broadcast last night in commemoration of the fifteenth anniversary of the founding of the National Broadcasting Company.

MONTREAL, Nov. 15 -- Overtime goals by Fred Thurrier and Buzz Boll gave the Brooklyn Americans their first victory of the National Hockey League season when they defeated the Montreal Canadiens before 9,882 fans at the Forum tonight, 4 -- 2.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Arkansas failed to win a single Southwest Conference game for the first time in ten seasons as Southern Methodist toppled the Razorbacks before 9,000 homecoming fans today, 14 to 7.

American standards of physical fitness for Army induction are now considerably higher than those of the present German Army as well as those used in this country in 1917. Dr. Morris Fishbein of the American Medical Association declares in an editorial in the December issue of Hyglea, released yesterday.

Saburo Kurusu, special Japanese envoy, arrived at La Guardia Field at 11:10 A.M. yesterday after flights totaling 13,000 miles from Tokyo in a little more than a week. Less than an hour later he flew for Washington.

BERLIN, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- German artillery, entrenched on heights overlooking Sevastopol, was reported blasting away continually at the city, but a German radio military spokesman said today the Soviet garrison there, like the one at Leningrad, was charging out to make frequent counter-attacks and that it was not yet possible to determine whether the Russians could hold out there indefinitely.

FIVE years ago I cruised on a tiny coastal liner into the Kerch Straits, outlet of the shallow Azov Sea into the deep waters of the Black. I stood on deck on a clear, star-lighted night and scanned the silhouette of the land on our starboard for lights of the city of Kerch toward which our pilot was cautiously steering.

VALHALLA, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Volunteer chauffeurs of the Westchester unit of the American Red Cross, driving ambulances in a British-American Ambulance Corps county-wide trek, obtained first hand experience early tonight when they were called upon to administer first aid to two men injured in an automobile crash here on Columbus Avenue.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: H.J. Mainwaring's statements in his letter of Nov. 10, in which he maintains that proposed prohibition legislation to establish dry areas adjacent to military training camps "is supported by the expressed opinions of military authorities of the rery highest rank, not only abroad but here," are not, I believe, based on facts.

Free exercise classes and nutrition lectures for women to be given in Y.W.C.A. centers in Manhattan and the Bronx between Nov. 24 and Dec. 16 were announced yesterday by Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Offices, and Mrs. William Hugh Coverdale, president of the Y.W.C.A. of the City of New York.

Lloyd Lewis, whose "Myths After Lincoln" is the November selection of the Readers Club, is a working newspaper man in Chicago, but he has found time to write several books, of which "Sherman, Fighting Prophet" is probably the best known.

IN the great majority of States the earlier Thanksgiving this week ushers in the holiday shopping season. Retailers continue to believe that Christmas volume will top last year's by a good margin and bring the year to an all-time record in dollars as well as units.
BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- Louisiana State and Auburn fought to a 7-7 tie today before a crowd of 30,000.

THE dates 1741 and 1941, the inscription "Vitus Bering in Memoriam" and the picture of an eighteenth-century sailing vessel suggest the significance of a 10-ore stamp to be issued by Denmark in December. It will commemorate the discovery by Vitus Johanssen Bering, in 1741, of the strait which bears his name and separates the continents of America and Asia.
LONDON, Nov. 15 (Reuter) -- Results of football games played in England and Scotland today:

A large subscription has been reported for the Gotham Supper Dance, arranged annually by a group of young Catholic women in behalf of philanthropic enterprises, which will be held on Wednesday at Sherry's. Miss Marie Murray is chairman, and Miss Macy Anne Reilly co-chairman, of the committee in charge of the plans.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, the city's largest union, is considering withdrawing from the American Labor party because it does not wish to provide a "cloak of respectability" for Communist elements in the party, it was learned last night.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force issued the following communique today:

Manufacturing labor costs per unit of output have advanced 10 per cent over the average for the first half of 1940 just before the inauguration of the emergency defense program, according to a comparison of government data.

BOMBER sections for North American B-25 planes are now being shipped to Kansas City, Kan., for assembly by the Memphis aircraft division of the Fisher body division of General Motors Corporation. Twenty-one different types of bomber sections are now being produced at the Memphis plant and this will be increased to sixty-nine in the near future.

THE North Atlantic gets cold suddenly in early Autumn. On the wings of the bridge at 2 A.M., the chilly puffs have a peculiar way of whistling under the lobes of your ears and down your collar so as to make you feel far more uncomfortable than you may allow yourself to appear.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The naval action in the Mediterranean this week, coupled with strong German thrusts in the Crimea, drew the outline of a gigantic pincer which seems here to be the principal plan of the Axis Winter war. One claw of the pincer is dug into the North African mainland, where the pocketed British garrison at Tobruk continues making troublous thrusts and sniping supply lines, while the other is reaching for the Caucasus.

Answering the demand of yachtsmen and would-be skippers in nearby Connecticut who want to learn the rudiments of navigation now instead of in the Spring because of a possibility of national defense service, the Stamford Power Squadron will launch its two sets of free instruction lessons Tuesday night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- Penniless, drought-driven Okies and Arkies, who crossed desert and High Sierra in their overburdened jalopies in the latter Nineteen Thirties to pour into this "promised land" by the tens of thousands, are being followed by relatives and neighbors in even greater numbers in this boom year of 1941.

GERTRUDE BELL'S life was a complete proof of the truth that those who understand the past can better interpret the present and prepare for the future; and everything she did from the time she went to Oxford helped to fit her for the gallant, useful part she played in World War I.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute invited the Mohawk-Hudson section of the American Society of Civil Engineers to its campus this week for another step in its long examination as to how effectively engineering education is meeting the needs of industry and business, the engineer himself, and society.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Still time to spade up soil -- all areas that are vacant. This accomplishes four things: leaves the ground better exposed to helpful frost action; retains rains and snows that might run off a hard surface; exposes insects, grubs, and eggs to the elements; and saves time in Spring. The rougher the surface is left the better.

MULTIPLE -- sometimes known as "tandem"-- flash work, the practice of using two or more flash bulbs in unison, has received such general acceptance that one active photographer recently declared it was sacrilege to use only a single flash.
THE 1942 estate wagon, on a 121-inch series 40 special chassis, was announced recently by the Buick division of General Motors Corporation.

In a Christmas season which comes to a sad and troubled world it is good for us to have such a book as Ruth Sawyer's. The author has a true feeling for festival. These thirteen tales (to last from the first cock-crow on St. Thomas's Day to the blessing of the candles on Candlemas), and the interspersed carols and Christmas rhymes, lay their emphasis on the inner vision of the holiday.

The increasing opportunities for career women during the emergency have given the theme to sessions of the Women's Professional Panhellenic Association, which is holding its tenth biennial convention at the Hotel Pennslyvania from Friday through Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Recognizing the value of research in the defense effort, the Office of Production Management today acted to broaden the assistance already extended such establishments in getting materials necessary for their operation.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute defeated the University of Buffalo at Rotary Field today, 21 -- 6. It was R.P.I.'s fourth victory in seven starts.

Methods adopted in America and in European countries for regulating building construction under a war economy are detailed in the ninth edition of the world economic survey of the League of Nations, now being distributed in this country by the interhnational documents service of the Columbia University Press.

THE consent decree, which introduced compulsory arbitration and a new form of selling in the distribution of motion pictures, will be one year old this Thursday. The arbitration machinery has been in operation in thirty-one key cities for the past ten months, but the selling provisions only became effective with the dawn of the new entertainment season last September.

A full set of X-ray equipment has been presented to the Norwegian Shipping and Trade Mission by a group of United States shipping men who have formed the American-Norwegian Liner Committee to aid the Norwegian cause against nazism, it was learned last week.

HOUSE and headland, Windswept stood solitary and stalwart against the buffeting of gales and ocean, on the bold eastward-pressing coast of Maine. Philip Marston bought the untouched stretch of shore and wilderness in 1880 and planned the house for his son and himself; and young John Marston built the long, low dwelling on the little promontory seventy feet above the sea and lived there as his father had dreamed.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- German troops are stalled in the dismal cold or flinging themselves to destruction at the major siege points of the vast Russian fighting line as the twenty-first week of the war ends, Russian war reports asserted tonight.

THE story of Joseph Pulitzer and The World is one of the most colorful in the annals of daily journalism. The tale has been told before, and Mr. Barrett adds few revelations but brushes in a generous supply of color. He was the last city editor of The World and a moving spirit in the efforts of the employes in the last few days to save the paper from extinction.

Stanley Romero and Harold Aronson, a pair of running and passing halfbacks whose brilliant performance belied the contest's official designation as "the amateur football championship of New York," paced the City College eleven to a stunning 43-to-13 triumph over Brooklyn College before a crowd of 5,000 at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.
THE third and last of the double Thanksgivings is just around the corner, and the folks back home are getting everything in apple-pie order for the return of the natives.

LA GUARDIA Airport at North Beach, Queens, which only a few years ago was a small privately owned field, and now has the heaviest air passenger traffic in the world, is to have its area increased by 355 acres under plans now taking shape in the office of Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

VERY advisedly, the Schola Cantorum will repeat at it first concert of the season, Wednesday fortnight, the Mass in C minor of Mozart which it produced for the first time in New York last Winter. That performance revealed one of Mozart's strongest religious compositions, although the C minor Mass, like the Requiem, to which it has certain other analogies, is incomplete.

Mrs. Bedell Holmes Harned will give a tea tomorrow at her home, 115 East Eighty-second Street, for members of the debutante committee assisting with plans for the benefit performance of "Theatre" on Dec. 11 at the Hudson Theatre in aid of the Youth Consultation Service of the Church Mission of Help.

Significant strides have been made toward eliminating discrimination from defense industries, Edward H. Lawson of the labor division of the Office of Production Management declared yesterday at a conference on vocational education in Public School 194 in 144th Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 15 -- The twentieth consecutive football loss for the Trenton Teachers was a decisive one. The Lions were handed a 58-7 setback today by Montclair Teachers, but the Trenton gridiron brigade was happy, for it was the final contest on the schedule.

Leaders in society, diplomatic, civic and artistic circles have joined to cooperate with the Second Region Council of the Army and Navy Second Corps Area in the presentation of "Stars of the Milky Way," a benefit luncheon and fashion show to be held at the Plaza on Nov. 24.

HOWARD LINDSAY entered the living room of his home in Greenwich Village with the same gusto that has endeared him to his audiences for the past two years as Clarence Day, Senior, in "Life With Father." "Sorry to keep you waiting, young man," he said, "but my tonsils blew up like a couple of barrage balloons last night and I didn't get much sleep.

LONDON. PROBABLY the most important and certainly the most diverting musical entertainment of the last few weeks here has been the production at the Savoy Theatre of Mussorgsky's "Sorotchintzi Fair" in a new scenic version of George Kirsta and Anatole Fistoulari, the present company's producer and conductor respectively.

DETROIT -- To safeguard dealer interests during the national emergency, the National Automobile Dealers Association will move its national headquarters from Detroit to Washington about Dec. 1, the executive board decided here last week.

THIS year's Christmas seal of the National Tuberculosis Association will be released on Nov. 24. Designed by Stevan Dohanos, muralist and illustrator, and printed in yellow, black, red and blue, it pictures a lighthouse casting its gleam on the double-barred cross, the anti-tuberculosis symbol, against a background of wintry sky.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15 -- A thousand invited guests, including many noted scientists and engineers who have helped make this country the communication center of the globe, witnessed here today the cornerstone laying of the new RCA Laboratories, being built by the Radio Corporation of America on a historic 300-acre site three-miles southeast of Princeton University.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 15 -- The Department of Journalism at Rutgers University is faced this year with the prospect of handling a larger enrollment than in any previous year, Dr. Frederic E. Merwin, head of the department, indicated in a statement issued today.

Continuing its policy to make athletics an integral phase of its educational and citizen-building curriculum rather than a stepping-stone for professional athletes, Queens College opened last week the most ambitious intramural sports program in its four-year history.

The cotton market held thin and trendless in the short session yesterday and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly. Except for the December contract, which closed 4 points higher, final values of active futures showed net losses of 2 to 6 points.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of Oct. 28 you published an interview with E.C. Buchignani, described as a correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, recently returned from Nice, France. Among other things, he was quoted as saying:

DR. C.E.K. MEES, Hon. F.R. P.S., Hon. F.P.S.A., scientist and vice president of the Eastman Kodak Company, will address the fifth anniversary reunion and dinner of the Oval Table Society at 7 P.M. on Friday at the New York Athletic Club.

TRAVEL LINES: The new Cuba Mail freighter Agwimonte will enter the New York-Vera Cruz run later this month.... The thirty-eighth anniversary of the first flight by the Wright Brothers will be celebrated on Dec. 17, at Kitty Hawk, N.C....

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- With the arrival today of Saburo Kurusu, the Japanese envoy, to conduct conversations looking to an adjustment in relations between Japan and the United States, events in the Far Pacific may well have reached a turning point, one that can affect materially the whole course of the European war.

FOR almost two decades of American life, beginning with the Spanish-American War and ending with the First World War, Finley Peter Dunne's Mr. Dooley had the last word on all matters relating to what Dooley's sententious friend Hogan would have called "th' body pollytick."
New Yorkers will have an opportunity to see something of Australian art, past and present, in ax exhibition which opens to the public on Tuesday, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Two benefits to advance the work of the Free French Relief Committee, which currently is conducting a national campaign to aid the Free French, are eliciting the cooperation and support of many members of society. One is the Renoir Centennial Loan Exhibition which will be on view at the Duveen Galleries until Dec. 6, and the other is a Renoir Costume Ball to be held at the Ritz-Carlton on Dec. 17.

On Thanksgiving Day Americans should express gratitude for their country's freedom by aiding the national defense program, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday. Other sermon subjects included the revision of the Neutrality Act, Mayor La Guardia's "canned sermon" and race relations and national defense.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 15 -- Steve Lach, 190-pounder from Altoona, Pa., led Duke's football forces to a convincing 20-0 victory over North Carolina today. In so doing he kept the Blue Devils undefeated, untied and presumably to be invited before long to a New Year's Day bowl game.

GUATEMALA. SO much has been written and said lately about cultural solidarity between the American republics that much of the good intended to be achieved is likely to be lost in an avalanche of extraneous verbiage.

PREPARATION of Thanksgiving dinner need hold no terrors for the housewife if she goes about it properly. A schedule that spreads the work over several days instead of letting it pile up on Thursday morning will enable her to sit down to the table not too weary to eat a bite herself.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Saburo Kurusu, Japan's special envoy, arrived at Washington National Airport early this afternoon with the word that as long as the American people remained sympathetic he believed he had a "fighting chance" of succeeding in his mission.

MIDDLEBURG, Va. -- The horse shows and hunt races are mostly over now, and the Virginia Piedmont quivers again with the ague that seizes the horsy gentry every November when the foxhounds begin to run.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 15 -- Lafayette coasted to a 26-to-0 football victory over Western Maryland before 5,000 spectators in Fisher Stadium today in a tune-up for the traditional battle with Lehigh next week.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Nov. 15 -- Discussion of preventive methods to guard against so-called "crime waves" and "race riots" was emphasized today at a meeting of Negro social workers of the metropolitan area, including Long Island and Westchester County, held by the New York State Conference on Negro Welfare.

Roy Conacher's two goals proved just enough to enable the Boston Bruins to ruin the home bow of the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. Winners of both of their previous contests in National Hockey League competition -- both games were played on the road -- the New York Blueshirts found young Conacher's marksmanship, and luck, too much for them, and had to accept a 2-to-1 defeat.

"If we knew as much about mental health as we do about physical health," says Dr. David M. Levy, specialist in child psychiatry, an epidemic of hate would be considered as dangerous as an epidemic of typhoid."
SALEM, N.H., NOV. 15 (AP) -- Blue Warrior made it two handicaps in a row for B.A. Dario today as he beat John R. Macomber's Side Arm by a neck in Rockingham Park's Whirlaway Handicap.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 15 -- Rosetown, the Jamestown filly who has done so well for George D. Widener, led virtually from start to finish of the $6,050 Lynch Memorial Handicap before 12,000 persons today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- A defense program featuring the need of a defense of religion as the foundation of democracy is being started at the College of New Rochelle by the new Defense Council, composed of members of the Advisory Board, organ of student government, working in cooperation with Mgr. Francis W. Walsh, president of the college, and Mother Thomas Aquinas, dean.

THERE'S little doubt -- no doubt at all, in fact -- that the threat of war and then the actuality of war in Europe affected radio in a vast number of ways. For one thing, almost overnight the newscasters and news commentators became just about the most important people in the entire industry.

The ice-skating carnival season at Madison Square Garden will be launched by the 1942 edition of the Ice Follies on Dec. 1, it was announced yesterday. The colorful show will continue through Dec. 6, pause for the hockey game the following day, then resume Dec. 8-10.

The news of the day in education illustrates a statement by Wilford M. Aikin last September that the schools and colleges of this country are finding again the chief reason for their existence and that here and there whole faculties are reconsidering purposes and re-examining practices.

Significant social movements are usually sooner or later reflected in home decoration; today we have the "good neighbor" movement manifesting itself not only in dance music but also in decorated interiors. The designers, cut off from Europe, can turn to Mexico and South America for unusual colors, fabrics and furniture, and even for almost forgotten period motives.

"Save Paper and Save the Forests" is the slogan of a group of women who will start ringing doorbells in West Side apartment houses and shops this week from Columbus Circle to 110th Street. Mrs. Gabriel Hamburger, as chairman of the Housewives Conservation Committee of the newly created West Side Defense Council, will direct the drive.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A Federal security official working out plans to consolidate the Civilian Conservation Corps and the National Youth Administration said today that the two agencies would probably turn back to the Treasury about $100,000,000 of their appropriations for the current year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The personalities of two men in conflict color the current struggle between the United States Government and the United Mine Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations. Few doubt that it would be easier to settle union strife threatening vital defense production if John L. Lewis and Franklin D. Roosevelt were not at loggerheads.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 15 -- Johnny Spasyk's perfect placement, after he had caught a short touchdown pass in the end zone from Al Shaw early in the second period, provided the margin of Vermont's 7-6 victory over Middlebury today before a crowd of 4,500.

We have passed through a week of historic decision. The repeal of neutrality was just, consistent and wise: just because we shall now risk our own ships in waters where we expect other nations, engaged in the same task, to risk their ships; consistent because otherwise the lease-lend policy would become a mockery; wise because it enables us to keep the war at a distance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Congress has long discussed the wisdom of decentralizing the Federal Government personnel as that personnel has grown larger and larger through the years. Adolf Hitler has now made the decision.

MELVILLE, L.I., Nov. 15 -- An Army pilot and a mechanic, both attached to the Sixtieth Pursuit Squadron at Mitchel Field, bailed out of a primary training plane this afternoon after the pilot found himself cut off from Mitchel Field by a heavy ground fog and his gasoline supply near exhaustion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Revision of the United States Neutrality Act as passed by Congress this week will assure the British people of increase in three things essential to their independent existence -- food, weapons and hope.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Traders who had expected heavy rains in the Central West overnight were surprised this morning when no rain was reported, and the forecast indicated generally fair weather for several days.

Once again the New York University football team found itself overmatched yesterday and, after a mighty Tulane aggregation had spent almost the entire fourth quarter kicking on first and second downs -- a magnanimous gesture by the Green Wave -- the clock at the Yankee Stadium came to the Violets' rescue, ending the one-sided conflict at 45 -- 0, with, of course, Tulane the winner.

In a small but particularly attractive garden in the Lawrence Park West section of Bronxville one finds an excellent example of what planning to scale, intelligence in selection and planting, and patience can accomplish in the way of a garden of distinction and charm in a limited area and against decided odds.

HEADING the list of the week's exhibitions in size and scope, "America South of the United States," at the Brooklyn Museum, is an exhibition that embraces the folk and colonial arts of twenty nations over a span of nearly four centuries.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- The unseasonable heat and the Penn football team caught up with Army in the second half of a furious battle before 70,000 in Franklin Field today, but the cadets fought both antagonists to the bitter end.

The red-hot races in the National Football League will continue to sizzle along today with firing on five fronts. Local interest will be focused on the Polo Grounds, where the New York Giants, the Eastern leaders, take on the Cleveland Rams, now at full strength for the first time in many weeks.

Civilian defense efforts come under the spotlight for Westchester clubwomen this week. In a forum of three sessions, opening tomorrow afternoon, a number of national leaders in the movement will discuss developments to date at the auditorium of the Woman's Club of New Rochelle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Increasing pressure upon the Lease-Lend Administration to arrange purchases under that act so that all but actual fighting equipment for Great Britain would be ordered by Lease-Lend through regular trade channels was expected from foreign traders in the coming two weeks.

In its recommendations for reorganization of New York City government, the 1936 Charter Revision Commission leveled much criticism at the old Board of Aldermen. The sixty-five-member municipal legislature, it was charged, was far too large and unrepresentative, was dominated by political bosses and had confusing legislative functions.

If you are one of the lucky ones with a ticket South already in your clutches, along with your new clothes, you will plan changes of make-up. Why not, on this holiday, be as attractive as you can manage to be?

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The conviction that the Royal Air Force is indeed, as Prime Minister Churchill says, equal in power to the vaunted Luftwaffe of Germany is percolating through the mind of the British nation. It seems to many people almost too good to be true, yet there is mounting evidence to support the statement, which is beyond doubt one of the most comforting to come this way since the war began.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I clarify a few points which have come up for discussion in connection with my recent proposal that a democratic German Free State should be established immediately in the territory of Tanga, a province of the British mandate of Tanganyika.

MEXICO CITY -- There is one side of Mexican life which invariably escapes the casual traveler in too big a hurry to stop in smaller towns or villages. It is small-town life, as focused in the Mexican cafe -- the cantina or the pulqueria -- into which women, minors and soldiers in uniform are not allowed.

A NEW play by Lynn Speakman is to have its tryout at a Summer theatre on Long Island. Lucia Dracott is to be the star, and Susan Holland, a society girl, is to make her debut in a minor role. Margot Blair, who is doing public relations work for Susan, attends the rehearsal and is a witness to most of what happens then and later.

WHEN Leopold Stokowski began rehearsing with the NBC Symphony Orchestra he turned the workout over to an assistant at intervals and went into the control room for a huddle with the chief engineer of the company. Mr. Stokowski handled the apparatus, made suggestions and discussed mechanical problems with the engineers.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 -- Duquesne University's big football team closed a perfect season today by running over previously undefeated Mississippi State, 16 to 0, before 31,483 fans at Forbes Field.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- The impact of the government's war program upon health facilities was pictured here today at a medical conference addressed by Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, the director of selective service. All constituent State societies of the American Medical Association sent their secretaries to the meeting, held in association headquarters.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 15 -- Robert L. Peters Jr. of the Kingsport, Tenn., Peterses, came back from the hospital today and Princeton suddenly blossomed into a football team. By the time the Tiger captain had finished an exhibition of running, passing, kicking and tackling, with his teammates rising to the chance with him, the men of Nassau had mastered Yale's eleven and taken the sixty-fifth game of the series, 20 to 6.

IN two of the smaller galleries on the second floor, not occupied by artists participating in the annual exhibition, the Whitney Museum at this time pays deserved tribute to Emil Ganso, who died last Spring. Thirty-one items have been assembled there -- oils, watercolors and gouaches.

More than any other flower, the cheerful chrysanthemum marks the period of transition from outdoor gardens to cut flowers for indoor decoration. Its very name suggests the mellow gold of Autumn sunshine, and lessens that feeling of nostalgia which attacks all gardeners as the outdoor garden season draws to a close.

THE Army is being bothered by snakes in the South. From Camden, S.C., comes a story of a soldier who failed to answer his telephone because he was out killing copperheads. Brownwood, Texas, supplies a story of a soldier who had been a snake-trainer in civilian life and who made himself thoroughly unpopular by keeping rattlers in his tent.

Evidence continues to pile up that the defense housing program, which was directed toward more than 300,000 new homes, has bogged down. The blame has yet to be allocated. United States Housing Director Nathan Straus, testifying before a House committee, listed the following agencies, besides his own, as involved in Federal housing: the Army and Navy, the Public Buildings Administration, the Division of Defense Housing, the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Farm Security Administration.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- With the exception of one seaman the entire crew of approximately 1,600 officers and men aboard the Ark Royal, which sank yesterday in the Mediterranean while being towed to Gibraltar after being torpedoed, have been saved, the Admiralty announced today.

NORTHVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- There may not be the concentration of deer in this section that there is in an old apple orchard in the Sullivan County hills or Rockland County meadows, but this is a country of tall timber and the deer that live here are wary, wild and full of what the local hunters term "zing."

AS this column has no way of knowing how its readers stand on the Thanksgiving date controversy, it is playing safe and getting the whole subject over with before any of them start Christmas shopping.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 15 -- Germany has offered Turkey Grecian Thrace and parts of the Rhodope Mountains northward to the Maritza River in Central Bulgaria to include Bulgarian Thrace, according to a neutral foreign diplomatic quarter here, in a "last bid" to Ankara to throw in her lot immediately with the Axis or "take the consequences."

THE Heritage Club is taking no chances with the illustrations that the eminent English wood engraver, Agnes Miller Parker, is making for its forthcoming new edition of Thomas Hardy's "The Return of the Native."

LONDON. THE STUDIO, one of our leading art magazines, has been running a useful correspondence on the mechanical side of book production. An expert contribution comes from L. Stanley Jast, past president of the Library Association and for many years Manchester's chief librarian.

There was something strange about the death of Caroline Faine, directress of nurses at the City Hospital. She should have responded as usual to the insulin treatment she had been receiving for years, but she did not respond. Dr. Willoughby, who has been attending Miss Faine, confesses himself unable to understand what has gone wrong, but Cyrus Harvey, a young interne, has a theory which he proceeds to test.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 15 -- Wesleyan smashed Trinity's dream of a perfect football record today 1 by burying the Hartford eleven, 27 to 0, in a veritable hurricane of running power and passing skill that brought about the most stunning upset of the season among New England's small college elevens.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Officials of the United Mine Workers of America, defying President Roosevelt, late today ordered 53,000 miners in the "captive" mines feeding the nation's steel mills to cease work at midnight tonight, and served notice that "it may become necessary momentarily" to withdraw their 400,000 members from all bituminous coal mines.

COLOGNE, Germany, Nov. 15 -- In the ''new European order" the Netherland people would receive full equality with their "German comrades" but no single nation would have full independence apart from the "common Germanic State," Dr. Arthur Seyss-Inquart, Reich's Commissioner for the Netherlands, told a gathering here today of Nazi party leaders from the Rhineland.

Mayor La Guardia declared last night that now is the time to think seriously about post-war problems of reconstruction, but almost in the same breath admitted that the hardest thing for a public official to do was to find time to think any problem through.

An invitation preview and formal opening of National Art Week in New York will be held at 9 o'clock this evening in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. WORKS by Americans will be featured on this season's programs of the Elizabeth Philharmonic Orchestra, under August May. Among the native compositions presented will be examples by Clarence Cameron White of Elizabeth, N.J.; Virgil Thomson and Ethel Glefin Hier.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Seven hundred county employes will receive salary increases totaling $80,000 under the proposed 1942 county budget of County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach, submitted today to the Westchester Board of Supervisors.

HAVANA, Nov. 15 -- The Cuban Premier, Carlos Saladrigasy Zayas, told the second conference of National Committees in Intellectual Cooperation here today that the intellectuals of the Americas must defend the spiritual values of our civilization and our traditions of independence and liberty.

WORD came from Buenos Aires last week that Argentina, which has announced its intention of according postal honor to "the greatest and most outstanding figures of our national glories," will issue a 5-centavos stamp in commemoration of the centenary of the birth of Jose Manuel Estrada, distinguished writer, orator, educator and diplomat.

The United States is no longer attempting to aid Great Britain and Russia with one arm tied behind its back, now that the Neutrality Act has been amended, W. Averell Harriman, who described himself as President Roosevelt's special representative in London, said at La Guardia Field yesterday.

Lending institutions selling repossessed realty are urged by Benjamin Winter, realty operator, to continue the practice of offering such holdings on "easy" terms. Showing its usual powerful ground offensive, Abraham Lincoln High School's football team closed its campaign with an unbeaten and united record for seven games by sweeping to a 40-6 decision over New Utrecht in the feature of a double-header at Lincoln Field yesterday.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 15 -- A long program of field hockey was capped by a thrilling victory for Long Island over Boston by 4 to 3 in the second day of the Northeast tournament at Adelphi College today.

To those who have lived in the country the word "sumac" calls to mind a thicket of shrubby growth along the pasture fence, but where this plant stands alone it forms a symmetrical and attractive small tree. It is then that one can see its characteristic mushroom-shaped top, and each furry branchlet bears a pyramidal dark red, velvety fruit cluster.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 15 -- Faculty members at Bucknell University have embarked on an important project of self-education, including the revaluation of their own educational offerings in an effort to insure in the college program comprehensiveness in all fields of study without overlapping in curriculum offering.

One of the biggest realty jobs in history is being carried out by the office of the Quartermaster General in providing land throughout the country to accommodate the defense training program of the War Department.

THE Trenton Opera Associaciation will open its season with a performance of Bizet's "Carmen," Thursday night at the War Memorial Theatre, Trenton, N.J. Other operas to be presented are "The Barber of Seville," Dec. 18; "La Traviata," Jan. 29; "Madama Butterfly," Feb. 26, and "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," April 8.
WORCESTER, Nov. 15 -- Farmers were told by a National Grange leader today that they lacked sufficient representation in Washington to assure them of a fair deal on agricultural prices.

AN exhibition of American paintings by the Peale family, including work by Charles Willson, Rembrandt, Raphaelle, James and Mrs. Rembrandt Peale, is being held at the galleries of James Graham Sons, 514 Madison Avenue, until Dec. 15.

Five graduates of City College received last night Townsend Harris medals for "notable post-graduate achievement" at the sixty-first annual dinner of the Associate Alumni at the Hotel Roosevelt. Jan Masaryk, Foreign Minister of the Czecho-Slovak Government-in-Exile, was the principal speaker.

The performance tomorrow night of "Spring Again" at the Henry Miller Theatre has been taken over for the benefit of the Art Workers Club for Women. Many persons of prominence in society have subscribed to the event. Mrs. Laurence Eyre is president of the beneficiary.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Many of us have postponed judgment on the Japanese situation. We have been genuinely puzzled as to what America's course should be and have, reasonably enough, distrusted our own ability to judge properly. Now, however, it is quite possible that another fortnight will bring a crisis in which we can no longer shirk this responsibility.

AS the English ship carried Elspeth up the river to Tientsin on a September day in 1880 she felt a shiver that was almost fear; there was hatred in those Chinese faces on the sampans and along the shore; in the hearty self-confident laughter of the Scottish merchant she had come out to marry there was negligent contempt.

"INVITATION TO LEARNING" resumes today after a recess of seven weeks. That is to say, three men will meet as before in a quiet room on the twentieth floor of a New York skyscraper and talk about a book. A great book ("Don Quixote" today, as it happens).

Eight of thirty-one conscientious objectors from this city have been released from the civilian-directed camps to which they were assigned by the Selective Service Administration because they were 28 years old before last July 1, it was announced yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott.
BOSTON, Nov. 15 -- Sugartown Tribute took best-in-show at the twentieth annual specialty fixture of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England at Horticultural Hall tonight.

LAKELAND, Fla. -- Visitors to Florida this Winter will find that the peninsula has acquired a military motif, but they will not find residents too preoccupied with their tasks in national defense to provide their traditional hospitality for vacationists from other States.

THERE have been various arrangements of Bach's Art of fugue, and each has been a matter for dispute, since the composer left no indication of what instrument or ensemble this set of fugues based on one theme was meant for.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Washington, society turned out in full force for the private preview today at the British Embassy of the collection of heirloom laces assembled under royal patronage for exhibition and sale in this country for the benefit of the bomb-shocked children of England.

Some trails surely never end, and it looks as if some trials last forever, too. At least the trial of Sandy, in court and out, was a long one. Sandy was a fine young man and deserved better of life than that his business partner and his wife should get together in most intimate circumstances behind his back.

WITH sincerity and deep sympathy Alvah Bessie has told the story of a man to whom life for many years gave not bread but a stone. A brutal stepfather, a home that was no home, then reform school, the penitentiary, odd jobs, the penitentiary again, were all Ed Sloan knew for more than thirty years.

HERE is a story of enterprise of young musicians. Last year about twenty members of the National Music League, a musical cooperative, banded together to prepare a series of nine programs tracing the history of chamber music from 1600 to modern times.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 15 -- A comprehensive campaign to save paper and paperboard has been started by producers and users of window display, direct mail and other advertising media not directly related to the publication field, it was learned here last week.

Although the present volume of sales based on defense work is not likely to be maintained after the existing emergency, the Sperry Corporation anticipates a relatively short period of readjustment in its business when the war is ended, Thomas A. Morgan, president of the company, declared in an interview last week.

MISS WINWAR'S biography, "American Giant: Walt Whitman and His Times," is actually contained within the compass of 321 pages (the extra twenty are devoted to bibliography and index), and, while it may seem a feat of prestidigitation to confine the sprawling, all-enveloping poet of democracy and the seventy-three years of "his times" within such narrow bounds, one must admit that the writer has accomplished it without giving her readers a feeling of cramp.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Improvement in Great Britain's situation in the form of shipping and cargo space, plus the lease-lend help of the United States, will make Nov. 17 a red-letter day for Britain's food control. On Monday rations of fat will be increased 25 per cent and those of sugar will be advanced 50 per cent.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Chicagoans are drawing up their ringside seats for what may be a lively journalistic battle between a projected new Chicago morning newspaper, backed by Marshall Field 3d and his millions and the venerable Chicago Tribune, backed by Colonel Robert R. McCormick and his millions.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- Mrs. Elizabeth Trenchard Leaf, widow of Edward Bowman Leaf, an iron manufacturer, and for more than fifty years active in welfare and civic organizations here, died last night at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Henry Elmer Howell, in suburban Rosemont, after a long illness.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Frederick J. Thielbar, a Chicago architect for the last forty-nine years, died today in Wesley Memorial Hospital, where he had been ill for two and a half months. He was 75 years old.

LONDON -- After an intensive scientific search for a cheap unrationed fuel-substitute for gasoline, British motorists have discovered that, so far as road performance goes, a messy, cumbersome -- looking contraption called the Portable Producer-gas Plant most nearly meets their demands.

Tom Thumb Chemistry In the Westinghouse research laboratories is Dr. E.C. Bruce Ashcroft, a microchemist, whose business it is to make chemical analyses of substances that weigh only millionths of an ounce. Since such small fractions would be lost in ordinary chemical work, he has to use miniature flasks, beakers, crucibles and test tubes.

NATURE has slipped up somewhere. Out in the West and Southwest there have been bountiful rainfalls, but in the Northeast, despite a recent downpour or two, there is a shortage of water. Streams have dried up, springs have disappeared, wells have receded out of sight.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- The University of Rochester's best football team in recent years downed Hobart College, 19 to 7, today before a record crowd of 10,000. It was the fifty-fourth game of Western New York's keenest gridiron series, in which Hobart had won the previous six contests.

As large a crowd as has ever jammed Baker Field -- to the capacity of its standing room -- saw butchery committed yesterday by one of the greatest football teams ever turned loose in the Columbia horseshoe along the Spuyten Duyvil.

THE double-feature plague is like the weather: everybody complains but nobody does anything about it. After nearly a decade the panacea so guilelessly grasped by exhibitors in fear of bankruptcy has now become the albatross about their necks, and so far they have done nothing more constructive than feel sorry for themselves.

The following statement issued yesterday by Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, shows receipts and payments for October, 1941 and 1940, with receipts and payments from July 1 to Oct. 31 and for the similar period of 1940.

Fall bulbs are not the only investment to be made at this time for Spring bloom. Seeds of many of the hardy annuals may be sown in late Fall for early bloom and for more robust plant growth. The Fall sowing of annuals also saves much time in Spring, when every moment counts.

LONDON, Nov. 16 (British Official Wireless) -- An authentic account of how the German Propaganda Ministry "sank" the Ark Royal in September, 1939, was broadcast from here today by the well-known American journalist William Bayles, who has spent the last eight years in Germany and personally knew Lieutenant Franck, the pilot alleged to have been responsible for this exploit.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- The cinema's current cycle of New Orleans pictures will be continued by "Dark of the Moon," a new novel by Margaret Bell Houston, which Paramount has purchased as a vehicle for Dorothy Lamour, MacDonald Carey and Brian Donlevy.
DETROIT, Nov. 16 -- Here are highlights from the report President Murray will make tomorrow to the convention of the Congress of Industrial Organisations:

When present hostilities in Yugoslavia reach a stage at which the Serbian Quislings under German domination find it desirable to take up "peace negotiations" with the rebels, the fighting has passed out of the guerrilla status and takes on the aspect of real civil war.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 15 (Delayed) -- White-clad German infantrymen supported by large formations of tanks newly coated with white paint again have tried desperately to start a new push against Moscow on the Russians' left flank, but in a series of hard battles across the snow they have made no signal gains, according to Russian reports received today.

PHILADELPHIA, Monday, Nov. 17-- The nominating caucus of the Amateur Athletic Union named the incumbent, Lawrence Di Benedetto of New Orleans, as the lone candidate for president of the organization, but it was learned early today that his candidacy will be opposed when the A.A.U.

An offering of $15,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent debentures of the Superior Oil Company, incorporated in California, will be made today by an underwriting group headed by Dillon, Read Co. The debentures, which will mature on Nov. 1, 1956, will be priced at 103 plus accrued interest.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 16 -- A "collaboration" crisis in Franco-German relations of particularly serious proportions has just opened in Vichy, according to information circulating here among foreign neutral diplomats, who are watching the situation very closely tonight.
Throughout the nation today 6,000 volunteer workers for National Art Week will start a campaign to put American art into American homes.

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Wreckage of a missing twin-engined bomber was sighted from the air today in jungle-like Maine woodlands, sixty miles northeast of this city, by service pilots, who said that they saw "no sign of life" in the vicinity.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One of the knottiest and most vital problems to be acted upon by the next session of the New York Legislature will be what judicial machinery New York City should have for handling adolescent criminals. Because the problem has national significance, any solution arrived at will get national attention.

Tableau -- With the clock showing eight seconds left to play, a 19-yard forward pass nestled into the arms of a Texas Christian back behind the goal line of the University of Texas. The eyes of Texas popped again and Dana X. Bible's five-year plan had become one with Nineveh and Tyre.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Santa Clara's inspired Broncos gave their oldest and most bitter football rivals, St. Mary's Gaels, a 35-to-13 walloping today in the twentieth contest of a gridiron feud started in 1886.

The American Council on Soviet Relations honored Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, wife of the former United States Ambassador to Russia, at a tea and reception in the Gold Room of the Ambassador Hotel yesterday.
KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 15 (Delayed) -- Enactment of the changes in the United States Neutrality Act was welcomed here as another and tighter link in the chain being forged around Germany.

Victor M. Rubio, who was assistant commissioner of the Peruvian Pavilion at the New York World's Fair, arrived here from Peru aboard the liner Aconcagua yesterday with the announced purpose of tracing the disappearance of two Chimu Indian gold bracelets, which he said had been spirited from a public display case at the Fair exhibit in the Summer of 1940.

There has been a good deal of speculation about the forthcoming book that bears John Steinbeck's name. Actually, the book is not purely Steinbeck's; he is co-author with Edward F. Ricketts, a scientist. The title is "Sea of Cortez: A Leisurely Journey of Travel and Research," Viking Press, Dec. 5.

War and its consequences -- pain, destruction, agony, distress -- are teaching men new truths today, asserted the Rev. Michael Coleman, rector of All Hallows Church, London, which was destroyed by bombing. Mr. Coleman spoke yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

MANILA, Nov. 16 -- After five months of the heaviest fighting in the history of war, Russia is battered but unbowed, still strong enough to hold the German Army through the Winter and to face a new campaign in the Spring of 1942.

DETROIT, Nov. 16 -- The unqualified, support of 5,000,000 C.I.O. members in the country's basic industries was pledged today to John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers in their strike for a union shop in the captive coal mines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Public and private debt in the United States aggregated $167,300,000,000 on Dec. 31, 1940, or an increase of 3.2 per cent for the year, the Department of Commerce announced today. Net indebtedness per capita for the year was $1,263, compared with a high record of $1,406 in 1930 and a low one of $1,184 for the 1929-40 period, the report said.

BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 16 -- Field Trial Champion Timbertown Clansman lived up to his title and reputation today when he won first place in the special open stake for women handlers, the concluding event of the three-day meeting of the Women's Field Trial Club.

The Giants hit the Cleveland Rams with everything except the goal posts at the Polo Grounds yesterday and, in a breath-taking display of surging power, made good all of the rich promises they have been withholding all season long. Before the fascinated eyes of a gathering of 32,740 they rolled up the second highest score in their history for a smashing 49-to-14 victory.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 16 -- Lafayette Street, a quiet, tree-lined thoroughfare in a residential district of this city, was thrown into a virtual state of siege tonight as scores of policemen, using tear gas and bullets, battled more than an hour to force a puny, 67-year-old Negro, armed with a 45-calibre automatic pistol, to surrender.
BERLIN, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The German High Command communique said today:

Many striking changes among occupants of the famous "Diamond Horseshoe" at the Metropolitan Opera House for the fifty-ninth season, which opens next Monday night with Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro," are revealed in the list of subscribers for parterre boxes made public yesterday.

A 23-year-old gunman, who with two confederates tried to rob a dozen customers in an East Harlem bar and grill, was killed early yesterday morning by a policeman in a pistol battle, during which a customer was also slain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Sales of independent retailers were 11 per cent greater in October than the year before, according to preliminary data based upon reports from 17,064 stores in thirty-four States, it was reported today by the Bureau of the Census.

A New Order of Liars? It was once assumed that nothing remained to be learned about liars. All genera, species and varieties of their large and interesting family were thought to have been discovered and catalogued, their habits had been "studied, the fund of knowledge concerning them was complete.

Spokesmen for the left wing of the American Labor party discounted yesterday the reported threat of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union to withdraw from the party so as not to provide a "cloak of respectability" for the Communist elements in the organization.

Holders of bonds of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company are being urged by John W. Stedman, chairman of the protective committee for holders of the railroad's first and refunding mortgage 5 per cent bonds, to accept the plan of reorganization they are to receive this week from the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Along the sidewalks of an urban avenue on sunny mornings nurses with well-polished perambulators parade their chic, cherubic charges. Slim Manhattan matrons in tweeds and furs stroll by. Many of these people turn in at the door of a tiny shop, which has pyramids of pastries in the window and a wonderful aroma that wafts out into the street as the door opens.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Saburo Kurusu, Japan's special envoy to the United States, spent today in a series of informal conversations with officials at the Japanese Embassy in preparation for his first meeting with Secretary of State Cordell Hull tomorrow morning.

BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- With investors and jobbers still groping in the dark regarding important details of government pressure intended to check future advances of stock prices to enforce liquidation of shares acquired during the war by corporations and private holders, the volume of business transacted during the last week at the Berlin Boerse was small and quotations of some shares had to be canceled owing to the absence of orders.

DETROIT, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Roaring back in the last eight minutes with touchdown pass plays of 69 and 45 yards, the Detroit Lions snatched a 21-to-17 National Football League victory from, the Philadelphia Eagles today before a crowd of 16,306.

BERLIN, Monday, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- Nazi spokesmen said today that German troops were storming through the streets of Kerch in Eastern Crimea, but they admitted full-fledged Russian attacks on the Moscow and Leningrad fronts, where 112 Soviet tanks were reported destroyed in titanic tank battles.
