Spotting their rivals' two goals in the first period, the Americans turned what appeared to be a losing cause into a commendable 3-to-2 triumph over the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night. Pat Egan, sturdy defenseman, rapped home a free shot awarded on a penalty in the final period to break a 2-2 tie.

The cotton market was rather featureless last week, with fluctuations from day to day smaller than usual. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts showed net declines for the week of 13 to 38 points. The largest declines were in the distant July and October deliveries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A strike in the "captive" coal mines of the major steel companies was scheduled to start tomorrow morning. Negotiations between the United Mine Workers of America and three steel executives terminated today without agreement.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 16 -- Germany will make a strong bid for peace with Britain, proposing Turkey as mediator, when the German Armies have concluded the "decisive phase" of the campaign in Russia, the Reich's Ambassador Franz von Papen told the correspondent of the Barcelona newspaper Yanguardia in an exclusive declaration upon German foreign policy last week.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- Because of the opposition of wealthy residents, the Friends Meeting and other property owners at Purchase, in Harrison Township, to a county airport being laid out near Rye Lake or on the Chisholm estate, it was reported today that when the Westchester County Board of Supervisors meets tomorrow a survey to select a new compromise site will be ordered by County Executive Herbert Gerlach.

From the cotton fields of the then unknown Southern United States came the materials for the rich and glittering habiliments for medieval Scotch thanes and ladies -- or so the costumed-in-cotton presentation of "Macbeth" at the National Theatre would seem to indicate.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Nov. 17 -- While Russian forces on the snowbound Leningrad and Moscow fronts continued in brief but fierce engagements to improve their lines at many points and to contain the Germans at all others, fighting in Crimea continued in the Germans' favor, despite the first heavy snowfalls there.

BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- The interest of government and financial circles in Berlin continued last week to be focused on the freezing of excess purchasing power as the outstanding immediate objective of the German financial policy. Addressing a meeting of Reichsbank employes, its president, Dr. Walther Funk, once more emphasized the necessity of maintaining the equilibrium between currency circulation and the quantity of available consumer goods.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 16 -- Under the headline, "An entire people in prison," the important Swedish provincial newspaper Eskilstuna Kuriren gives details about conditions prevailing in Norwegian concentration camps.

In ordering a shutdown of the captive coal mines, John L. Lewis is defying the President. But he is doing something much more dangerous from the point of view of organized labor itself. He is defying a public opinion that has now become thoroughly aroused to the menace to the national defense program involved in such needless strikes.

A 13-year-old boy who was a patient at Willard Parker Hospital, East Sixteenth Street and the East River Drive, where he was isolated as a diphtheria carrier, escaped last night and was captured by the police after escaping a second time by means of a ruse.

The 106-year-old Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Clinton and Kane Streets, Brooklyn, swept by fire nearly three years ago, was rededicated in a special service yesterday afternoon by the Right Rev. Ernest Milmore Stires, Bishop of Long Island.

CHUNKING, China, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Chinese forces in Kwangsi and Yunnan Provinces, bordering on French Indo-China, were reported tonight to be blowing up bridges and destroying roads for a depth of many miles from the frontier to hamper any Japanese offensive from the French colony.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Arthur Torrance, 54, whose self-identification as a celebrated American globe-trotting medical researcher has been substantiated by Mexican police, was taken from his hotel bed at 3 o'clock this morning and formally accused of murdering his 65-year-old bride.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 -- While the steel industry last week was still facing a threat of curtailed operations due to a possible shutdown of captive coal mines and also to accentuation of the shortage of scrap and pig iron, steel observers envisioned progressive tightening of governmental control over shipments of steel by way of the allocation method.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued the following communique today:
ROME, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 16 -- Pickets belonging to the C.I.O. United Mine Workers turned back employes of a Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company captive coal mine late today. It was the first indication that the strike ordered by John L. Lewis was being carried out.
Loft buildings continue as a chief attraction for investors in Manhattan real estate. The demand for properties of this type was indicated in two more sales involving lofts over the week-end.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 16 -- Hedging in the late positions, mainly against lower grades as better-grade cotton moved into loan channels at an increasing pace, kept the cotton futures market here in hot water most of last week.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- In hectic going, with what the weather man has called a slant of warm northwest air that has nothing to do with the so-called Indian Summer, twenty-four dinghies went out today in the fourth cold-weather sailing session at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- The German Foreign Office has turned down as unreceivable the Mexican Government's observation on the French hostages shot by the Germans as a reprisal for the murder of two Reich army officers in France.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Nov. 8 to 14 are giyen in the appended tabulation:
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP0 -- The Chicago Black Hawks regained first place in the National Hockey League tonight by running up a 3-0 lead on the Detroit Red Wings and then staying ahead for a 3-2 victory.

It would seem that for any particular refreshment of the orchestral repertory we have to go to the WPA concerts, such as the one given by the New York City Symphony Orchestra, Paul Morel, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.

The Bank for Savings sold to Arnold Hochstrasser the fourstory rooming house on a lot 18 by 102.2 feet at 28 West Eighty-third Street for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $12,500 for ten years. Frederick Mortati was the broker.

An hour at the Duveen gallery's Renoir centenary exhibition should prove profitable and pleasant to many lovers of art. The 50 cents entrance fee goes to the French Relief Committee for which the show has been organized with the whole-hearted support of private collectors and museums from all over the country.

DUKE, Duquesne, mighty Minnesota and Texas A. and M., there they stand. And how they run! The big snicker came when the single men beat the married men. That happened down in the Lone State State, where Texas Christian beat the great Texas team that had nine married men on its side. That wasn't supposed to happen to Dana Bible's brigade.

NORTHVTLLE, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- Two more bucks went on the deer rack at Tony Farrell's camp at Akwissasne this morning, and both of them were earned, for more uncomfortable weather conditions could not possibly exist.

The Rovers gave 10,763 followers a brand-new team, a new Eastern Amateur Hockey League season, a rousing overtime game and a taste of defeat in the first of the Sunday double-headers at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

The Department of Commerce estimates that the national income, as measured by payments of money to individuals, had risen in September to a yearly rate of $92,000,000,000. This would break all records. For the first nine months of 1941 the estimated actual income payments were $64,332,000,000, or something like 17 per cent above the $54,998,000,000 of the same months in 1940.

Miss N. May Karff of Boston, playing at the Marshall Chess Club, won the first game of her championship match with Mrs. Adele Belcher, who, as Mrs. Rivero, gained the national title in a tournament of the U.S. Chess Federation here early last year.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 16 -- United States Circuit Court Judge William Clark said today he favored compulsory arbitration of labor disputes, "at least for the duration of the national emergency." Judge Clark said that during his recent trip to England he studied the legal machinery that handles employer employe disagreements and was greatly impressed with its effectiveness.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- The Chicago Bears, who scored eleven touchdowns to defeat the Washington Redskins, 73 -- 0, in the 1940 world championship football play-off, could achieve only five today but trounced the Redskins, 35 to 21, before 30,095 spectators at Wrigley Field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A United States cruiser captured in "Atlantic equatorial waters" on Nov. 6 an Axis ship disguised as an American merchant ship, with an American name and the United States flag painted on its hull, the Navy announced tonight.
VICHY, France, Nov. 16 -- Otto Abetz, who had come to Vichy for the funeral yesterday of General Charles Huntzinger, Minister of War, and who had remained overnight, left for Paris this afternoon.

Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, made public yesterday a sharp reply to the recent protest of the New York Civil Liberties Committee against the Department of Parks regulation requiring permits for meetings in Union Square.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Japanese Premier, General Hideki Tojo, stressed today the necessity for preventing spread of the European war to the Pacific and laid down Japan's terms for settlement of the Japanese-American crisis.

The attempt by Leslie MacMitchell, New York University's great distance runner, to duplicate a feat accomplished only by John Paul Jones of Cornell and the traditional keen scramDle for team honors will be the chief points of interest in the annual varsity and freshman cross-country championships of the I.C.A.A.A.A. at Van Cortlandt Park this afternoon.

At least five new films will open in Broadway theatres this week. "This England," a historical film survey of critical periods in English history during the last 1,000 years, will have its American premiere this morning at the World Theatre.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 16 -- Telegrams of protest were sent from Miami tonight by J.Y. Gooch, president of the Chamber of Commerce, and H.H. Nace, president of the Greater Miami Hotel Association, to the New York City Board of Education against a proposal by the board to reopen New York schools Jan. 2, thereby cutting short holiday vacations in Miami of hundreds of New York school teachers.

BARNSLEY, England, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Emanuel Shinwell, Laborite Member of Parliament, said in a speech today that "the repeated suggestions of invasion [of Britain] sound suspiciously like an attempt by the government to justify its failure to take the initiative."

Spring merchandise came to the fore in the apparel market last week. Interest centered on black dresses with lingerie trimming and new prints. The demand for formal wear continued strong. Activity on street dresses spurted. Coat business was fair.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Wilmington Clippers trounced the Newark Bears, 23-7, before a crowd of 6,200 in the City School Stadium today for their third victory in the American Football Association.

Jane Cowl will return to Broadway tonight as the star of the evening's new play, "Ring Around Elizabeth," a comedy by Charl Armstrong, presented by Allen Boretz and William Schorr in association with Alfred Bloomingdale, at the Playhouse Theatre.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 -- The champion Boston Bruins opened their eighteenth National Hockey League home season by turning back the New York Rangers, 2 -- 1, before 15,000 fans at the Boston Garden tonight. It was the victors' second such triumph over the Blueshirts in as many nights.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Corn showed independent weakness last week on the Board of Trade here, selling pressure resulting from a growing belief that recent persistent rains will cause much damp grain. Because of lack of elevator room to handle this damp grain, it is feared that the spot market will become extremely weak if the movement becomes heavy and beyond the ability of industries to absorb the offerings.
NAIROBI, Kenya Colony, Nov. 16 (AP) -- British Headquarters here issued this communique" today:

There will be an enforced "moratorium" on both private and public building in 1942, so that the city will be "lucky" if it is able to maintain its present facilities in reasonably good condition and complete improvements directly related to national defense, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick predicted yesterday in a capital budget message to the Board of Estimate and the City Council.

The completion of a plan to improve traffic conditions at the busy intersection of Cathedral Parkway and Eighth Avenue-Central Park West, as well as to beautfiy the area, was announced yesterday by Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- A prayer that the current enthusiasm of this country for its Latin-American neighbors might be permanent and based upon "mutual esteem and solid justice" was offered today by the Most Rev. John F. O'Hara, military delegate of the armed forces of the United States, in an address delivered in conjunction with the national congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine.

Speaking before 3,000 persons last night at the Nazi "mass murder" protest meeting held at the Metropolitan Opera House under the auspices of the Committee to Defend America and the Free World Association, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, declared that "a desperate nazism finds that it is faced with a growing unrest throughout the occupied lands and a stronger and firmer line of resistance in the free nations of the world."

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The Economist's index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, stood on Oct. 28 at 107.2, compared with 107.4 as a fortnight before, 107.1 a month before, 99.7 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

Though the Ballet Theatre was compelled to cancel the premiere of its new version of "Goyescas" scheduled for last night at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre because of the regrettable illness of Argentinita, who is staging the work, the evening was by no means without novelty.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 16 -- Congress meets tomorrow, with the House, where the only pending legislation is ready for consideration, facing a confused situation.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Jean Decoux, Governor General of French Indo-China, said in a broadcast heard here today that "any one in Indo-China who won't cooperate fully in the new order must not expect from me weakness, indulgence or mercy."

George W. Blossom Jr. of Chicago has been nominated for the presidency of the United States Golf Association for the coming year, it was announced yesterday. His election will take place at the annual meeting to be held in New York early in January.

The New York Americans retained their hold on second place in the American Soccer League standing by downing the Philadelphia Nationals, 3 -- 2, before a crowd of 3,000 at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

Governor Lehman, it was indicated yesterday, has rejected Tammany Hall's plea that Lloyd Church be reappointed to the post on the Supreme Court from which he resigned to make the race for City Controller on the Democratic ticket in the recent election.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- After losing three straight, to Manhattan, Duquesne and Temple, an aroused Villanova College football eleven scored a 7-to-6 upset victory over highly favored Detroit before 23,480 at Shibe Park today. Ed Kasky booted the winning point after the Wildcats had marched 58 yards for their touchdown in the third quarter.
NEW YORK Mrs. Morton McMichael of Wayne, Pa., has joined Mrs. Charles G. Berwind of Paoli, Pa., at Hampshire House.

In urging support yesterday of the annual roll-call of the American Red Cross, S. Sloan Colt, chairman of the New York chapter, pointed out the Importance of the organization in civil defense as exemplified by the number of Red Cross workers taking part in the demonstrations staged Saturday all over the city by civilian defense volunteers.

Andre Birabeau has a mind that might be described as provocative. In "Dame Nature," which was presented here three years ago, he discussed the dilemma of an adolescent boy and girl who, much to their astonishment, had become parents.
Business in the foreign exchange market last week developed contradictory movements in two currencies, a sharp rise in the Uruguayan peso being offset by a decline in the Canadian dollar.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 17 -- Following is the text of Foreign Minister Shigenori Togo's address prepared for delivery to the Diet today:

Six thousand New York business concerns will be asked today to support the thirty-fifth annual Christmas Seal sale of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association. Letters over the signature of Wallace C. Speers, vice president of James McCutcheon Co., and chairman of the business groups sponsoring committee, were mailed to these concerns Saturday.

VICHY, Nov. 16 -- In a message he addressed to the commission appointed to study economic organization, Marshal Petain, Chief of State, explained the task he had set for this commission. He did not attempt to conceal that criticism had been aimed at the organization of committees.

America is faced with the problem of Nazi paganism and must destroy it, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Philosophy at Catholic University, Washington, told 750 persons yesterday afternoon in a lecture at De Gray Hall of St. John's College, Brooklyn.

A graphic portrait of manufacturers as the public sees them will be presented to the 10,000 business men who will assemble in this city Dec. 1 for the Congress of American Industry, held under the auspices of the National Association of Manufacturers.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Nov. 16 -- Michael Lszek, one of the 20,000 captive coal miners in Fayette County technically on strike since last midnight, leaned this afternoon against the green clapboard house for which he pays rent of $11.80 a month and smiled down at the two black and white kids just presented to his household by a pet Nubian goat.

A blockfront in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn passed to new control when Heilbronn Realty, Inc., sold to the Derrall Holding Corporation, Irving Dworman, president, the six-story elevator apartment house at 7040 Colonial Road.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "Vichy Arrests an Exile" was a fine and human piece. Having seen Largo Caballero in Marseilla not so many months ago, I feel it is my duty to confirm the well-established will of Vichy France to serve not only the Nazi invader but also his small vassals, such as Mussolini or Franco, against political exiles or Jews.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The stock markets here continue their upward course. The Financial News's index of industrial shares at 80.1 has reached its highest point since March 6, 1940, and its bond index has made a new war-time record at 132.2.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was delighted to observe by the editorial of Nov. 10 that THE NEW YORK TIMES agrees that the United States needs power "at this juncture."

When Moriz Rosenthal came on stage for the second half of his recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, the audience rose en masse and stood cheering for several minutes. It was a spontaneous tribute not only to a supreme artist but to a great personality.

A SECOND galaxy of the World's Great Letters, so called, is published today in an imposing volume by the firm of Simon Scbuster.* This time it is not Mr. Schuster himself who has done the editing, as was the case with Volume I last year. The responsible parties are Wallace Brockway and Bart Keith Winer.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- With Christmas trade here due to be opened formally Friday by the toy and gift shopping trade, the best information available at Chicago Association of Commerce headquarters is that the city's holiday sales this year will approximate $130,000,000.

Seventeen sections of New York City department stores recorded increases over last year in advertising linage in newspapers during October, according to figures released by Media Records, Inc. Total, department store advertising in the month amounted to 3,345,630 lines compared with 3,468,449 in the 1940 month, a decrease of 3.5 per cent.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- With the Neutrality Bill out of the way, price-control measures are again the major price-making influence in the grain markets. Conflicting views as to what should constitute ceilings on farm products resulted last week in extremely erratic fluctuations on the Board of Trade.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Liberal purchases of lard and pork products by the government last week tended to offset scattered liquidation by holders of December lard contracts. Removal by cash interests of hedges against sale of the actual product to the government was the main influence.

One million children and 30,000 teachers in the city's schools will return to their classes on Friday, Jan. 2, after the Christmas vacation this year, reversing the custom of previous years by which schools were closed on Fridays after holidays that fell on Thursdays, it was learned yesterday.

The Most Rev. J. Francis A. Mclntyre, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, yesterday invested the Rev. Ercole J. Rossi and the Rev. Edward R. Gaffney as monsignori at a solemn pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Old Cathedral, Mott and Prince Streets, where the Right Rev. Mgr. Rossi is paston and the Very Rev. Mgr. Gaffney, who is a vice chancellor of the archdiocese, is a member of the staff.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, declared tonight that those dissidents "who consciously or unconsciously are playing the traitor's part" must stand aside while the nation marches toward the goal approved by an overwhelming majority -- the defeat of Hitler.

A new destroyer, displacing about 1,650 tons and incorporating the same kind of design that enabled the destroyer Kearny to reach, port in spite of a great hole blown in her side by a German submarine, will be launched Wednesday morning from the ways of the Bethlehem Steel Company at 3075 Richmond Terrace, Staten Island, the Navy announced here yesterday.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Nov. 16 -- Although the bourses of the Continental countries may show a temporary reaction which generally is of a technical character, the undertone remains firm in the main, reflecting generally a considerable demand in excess of supply that is noticeable especially in Amsterdam, Brussels and Paris, where monetary liquidity is playing an important part.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices regained its 1936-41 high of 98.8, which had previously been attained in the first week of October. As usual, most of this week's price changes occurred in agricultural raw materials.

Clergymen of many faiths marked "Freedom Day" yesterday by commenting from their pulpits on the outline sermon suggested for the day by Mayor La Guardia in his capacity as United States Director of Civilian Defense.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Declaring that 1,000,000 married women were needed for either full time or part time work in munitions factories and elsewhere, Ernest Bevin, Minister of Labor, hinted today that the government might resort to drastic compulsion shortly and to a much greater extent than hither-to as a means of solving the country's wartime problems of man and woman power.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 16 -- The Reich special six-man press mission to Turkey arrived by special plane at Istanbul from Berlin today, boarding the Anatolia Express tonight for Ankara. The Germans will arrive here tomorrow morning.

ROME, Nov. 16 -- In the light of plans for a Winter campaign and the means to cope with what is regarded here as direct American intervention, manifested by Congressional approval of the revisions to the Neutrality law, the visit of Saburo Kurusu, special Japanese envoy to Washington, is watched with great interest.

In the first full fiscal year of operation ended on June 30 last, the city's unified system of subway, elevated, street car and bus lines produced revenues $27,769,213 in excess of operating expenses, according to official figures of the Board of Transportation, made available yesterday.

Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of Alleghany Corporation, the largest stockholder in the bankrupt Missouri Pacific Railroad, issued yesterday a statement in which he denounced the stand taken by John W. Stedman of the Prudential Life Insurance Company and chairman of the protective committee for holders of the road's first and refunding mortgage 5 per cent bonds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The United States and Great Britain, it was learned today, have made "substantial progress" toward the completion of an important agreement on the broad economic principles that they intend to follow at the end of the war.

The International Longshoremen's Association, A.F. of L., through Joseph P. Ryan, its president, indicated yesterday that a strike called last Friday among 2,500 workers against three sugar refineries in Brooklyn and Yonkers, may spread today to Baltimore.
Several large leases for space in downtown buildings featured the commercial rental reports from brokers and agents yesterday.

AMSTERDAM. (via Berlin), NOV. 17 -- In a hesitant market with small changes Philips declined 4 1/4 points on the Bourse today to 276 1/2. Royal Dutch was slightly better at 333 5/8, Amsterdam Trading 1 point lower at 498 and A.K.U. 1 off at 153 1/4.

HAVANA, Nov. 17 -- The possibility that the committees on intellectual cooperation between American nations may sever their connection with the Paris institute created by the League of Nations as a headquarters for these committees and establish their own institute was seen here today as the second inter-American conference of the committees got down to work.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- C.D. Hertzog, district manager of the United States Civil Service Commission, disclosed today that more than 400 persons employed by that agency in Pennsylvania and Delaware in the last year had been discharged since Oct. 1 because they falsified their job applications.

France's Nazi-controlled press, by featuring news of strikes in United States defense industries, has given the French people the impression that labor dissension will prevent this country from rendering effective aid to Britain and Russia until it is too late, a native of Paris declared when he arrived here yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- A duty rests uppn women to aid civilian and military defense by improving nutrition, developing national unity and strengthening public morale, speakers said today at the opening session of the third annual forum conducted by West-Chester County women's clubs with the cooperation of Arnold Constable Co.
It's the last big round-up this week for college football in the East and Middle West.

The Phillips 66 quintet of Oklahoma, led by sharpshooting Hank Luisetti, arrived yesterday for its game with the Ohrbach A.A. in the Golden Jubilee basketball tournament that will start at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. Twentieth Century-Fox, holder of the National A.A.U. crown, is slated to arrive this morning for its meeting with the Roanoke (Va.) Legionnaires.

Plans filed last month, with the New York State Labor Department for construction in defense industries in the extreme western part of the State brought the total number of industrial plans filed during that month to near the record number of the same period last year, although the total cost was only about four-tenths of the 1940 figure, Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller reported yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- There is a general belief among those who study such subjects here that the reported declaration of Frans von Papen, German Ambassador in Ankara, and other stories about the possibility of peace that emanate from Turkey all are part of a German plan.

Germany's fifth column in Latin America, now stronger than ever before and with its operations better concealed, probably will resort to overt revolutionary activities along the west coast if it appears that the United States will go to war with Japan, a leading Uruguayan foe of Nazi political warfare warned yesterday.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 17 -- A six-man German press mission, headed by Paul Schmidt of the Wilhelmstrasse Press Section, arrived here this morning.

The more non-defense economies are discussed the clearer it becomes that there is only a limited area in which budget cuts can be made. In the recent recommendations of the Budget Bureau it was found that nearly two-thirds of any cut totaling $1,000,000,000 or more would have to come out of aids to agriculture and work relief, the larger part from aids to agriculture.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Finnish High Command issued this communique today:

Although Mr. Lewis has done his best to convince the public that members of the United Mine Workers are all alike, and all very much like John L. Lewis in their ways of thinking, it takes only a little direct inquiry to reveal that they are as diversified as the rest of us.

No serious shortages of fabrics will pinch the consumer at least for the coming Spring, it was reported yesterday at the meeting of the fabrics and ready-to-wear division of the Fashion Group at the Murray Hill Hotel. Simplicity and durability will be style highlights, with continued emphasis on the casual types of garments for day wear, but with a growing trend toward functional and dressier clothes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- "The Rivals," a two-act, nine-scene play by Richard Brinsley Sheridan, presented by the Theatre Guild, opened tonight at the National Theatre.
The four-family flat at 21 Hancock Avenue in the heights section of Jersey City, N.J., was purchased by Joseph J. Koenig from Minnie King through J.I. Kislak, Inc., brokers.

Ben Collins, the West Texas State whirlwind, kept his lead last week as the nation's best collegiate manufacturer of football points, but his title is being jeopardized by Bill Dudley, pride of Virginia University.

Last night the Hispanic Society commemorated the hundreth anniversary of the birth of William Henry Hudson. He was born in August, 1841. He detested dates as impertinent monitors of death. This want of exactness in his centenary was in character. His grandfather was of Marblehead, his mother of Maine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Nazism and communism are "the two greatest evils of today which would destroy all spiritual values," the Catholic Bishops of the United States said today in a pronouncement which was prefaced with the statement that "Christianity faces today its most serious crisis since the church came out of the catacombs."

Flanders Hall, Inc., a small publishing house at Scotch Plains, N.J., named by the government in its indictment of George Sylvester Viereck as a link in a pro-Nazi propaganda chain, has been quietly dissolved, it was learned yesterday. Dissolution papers were filed several days ago in Trenton with the New Jersey Secretary of State.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The names of thirteen American fliers, nine of whom have been killed, three missing and one taken prisoner were announced by the Air Ministry today. Five of those killed were members of the Eagle Squadron and the other four were with the Royal Canadian Air Force.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Arthur Torrance, a graying, careworn man wearing a jaunty brown beret, will be taken out of Monterrey penitentiary tomorrow to witness the reopening of the grave of his wealthy 67-year-old bride, whom he is accused of beating to death with a vacuum bottle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress for a supplemental Army appropriation of $6,687,369,046 and a supplemental Navy appropriation of $380,050,000. His trip to Warm Springs, Ga., Wednesday, was postponed.

The need for prompt American military aid to the Soviet Union was emphasized last night at a meeting called by the Council on Soviet Relations in Manhattan Center to mark the eighth anniversary of the opening of diplomatic relations between the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Ceiling prices for wood furniture of all types are imminent and will probably be announced by the Office of Price Administration in the coming few days, according to reports circulating in the offices of the defense agencies. OPA had said previously that it contemplated establishing a price schedule for wood furniture, but the action was not expected to come for some weeks.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A declaration by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek that Japan is on the point of opening a drive to shut the Burma Road coincided today with, the assertion of his Foreign Minister, Quo Tai-chi, that "all signs seem to point" toward an "A.B.C.D." alliance of America, Britain, China and the Netherland (Dutch) Indies to resist Japan.
NEW YORK The Right Hon. Richard G. Casey, Australian Minister, and Mrs. Casey have arrived from Washington, and are at the Ritz-Carlton.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Detectives investigating the poisoning of eleven circus elephants arrested today a man whom they identified as Elwin Bolgen Michael, 32, of Grettinger, Iowa, a member of the show's train crew.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 17 (AP) -- The National Grange elected Albert S. Goss of Washington, D.C., as its master today to succeed Louis J. Taber, who held the post eighteen years, longer than any of his predecessors in the seventy-five years of the organization.

Trading In locally dressed meats was fair to good yesterday. Steer hinds and ribs were stronger and other steer cuts sold unevenly. Fresh pork cute were steady to slightly higher. Other classes were mostly unchanged. Early trading m kosher meats was slow and the markets somewhat irregular. Kosher beef was about steady, veal and calf steady and kosher iamb weak to lower.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 12. Increases of $60,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $275,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $82,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The House "authorized" Representative Hamilton Fish of New York today to testify before the District of Columbia grand jury at such time as the House was not in session. There was little discussion preceding the vote, in which only a few "noes" were heard.

Narrower spreads between bid and asked quotations on over-the-counter securities were put into effect yesterday by the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc. This applied to most of the 625 issues of securities regularly quoted by the association.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Contracts awarded today by the War Department totaled $7,863,668. Of these, the following, not previously published, went to companies in the New York area:

The cotton market fluctuated irregularly yesterday as traders moved with caution in the face of uncertain Japanese-American relations and the domestic labor situation. Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered moderately from an early weakness to close with net losses of 1 to 9 points.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The sea lanes of the world again became open highways for American ships today, despite war or threats. President Roosevelt signed the law repealing sections of the Neutrality Act which kept American vessels from combat zones and forbade them to carry guns for their own protection.

Apologists for Japan and proponents of a Pacific Munich have frequently protested in the past that it was unfair to judge Japan's aims by the admittedly jingoist newspapers. Such a method of appraising the Japanese objectives is no longer necessary. Japan's "terms" have become official.

Though the National Defense Mediation Board and the Administration finally emerged with the right and only possible decision in the "captive" coal mine case, they have even yet failed to make clear the chief reason which made that decision necessary.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 -- After cheering a call by Philip Murray for whole-hearted support of President Roosevelt's defense policies, the fourth constitutional convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations at its opening session today voted full backing to John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers in the strike for a union shop in the captive coal mines.

Civilian defense in America is the "worst sold proposition ever put before the American people," Colonel Edward B. Towns, assistant liaison officer between the Second Corps Area and the Second Civilian Defense Office, declared here yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 17 -- The appointment of Dr. Alfred Rosenberg to the post of "Reich Minister for the East," or chief civilian administrator of occupied Soviet territory, which has been an open secret for several months, was officially confirmed today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 17 -- Serbia's war against the German troops of occupation, the pro-German armies of General Milan Neditch, the Yugoslav puppet Premier, and the Croat Ustashi continues with unabated fury, according to reports to foreign military intelligence sources in Ankara.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- There was much action behind the scenes, but the threatened election fight on the floor of the Amateur Athletic Union convention didn't come off on schedule today as Lawrence Di Benedetto was reelected national president.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Favorable weather over the week-end and uncertainty in regard to the situation in the Far East and the Price Control Bill resulted in a sharp break in the soy bean and grain markets in the early trading today on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Total round lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Nov. 1 was 3,221,260 shares, compared with 3,447,230 In the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Local College Youth In round numbers the Board of Higher Education calls it 50,000 boys and girls in the four municipal colleges. Last year it was more than 52,000 students. National defense and the lure of well-paid employment probably explain a drop of almost 3,000 students.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey asked a three-judge Federal court today to free it from Securities and Exchange Commission restrictions that the company contends interfere with its plans for increased production of electric current.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Japan has requested the Indo-China Government to provide facilities for 50,000 additional Japanese troops in the French colony, which would establish a Japanese force in that strategic country of more than double the 40,000 agreed upon last July, according to trustworthy reports received here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Split decisions of the Supreme Court on two issues today found the bench as widely divided as on last Monday, when the first opinions of the present term were announced.
BERLIN, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler's Headquarters issued this communique today:

The order of the Board of Education reopening the public schools on Friday, Jan. 2, instead of the following Monday, will be fought by Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, board member, in a resolution to be offered at the next board meeting, it was learned yesterday.

WITH THE BLUB ARMY IN THE CAROLINAS, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- A Blue Army communique said late today that operations were continuing according to plan and that bridgeheads established Sunday night across the Pee Dee River in Red Army territory had been strengthened.

National Art Week is now in full swing. As was also the case last year (when Art Week, proclaimed by President Roosevelt, was inaugurated), activities are spread out over large sections of New York City. These take the form of exhibitions arranged in galleries and in shops.

With reviews from the road practically guaranteeing the high laughter content of "Junior Miss," Max Gordon's production of the Jerome Chodorov-Joseph Fields adaptation of Sally Benson's sketches will have its local premiere at the Lyceum Theatre tonight at 8:30.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Nov. 18 (From official Russian sources; distributed by The Associated Press) -- German troops have been rolled back eight miles by a Russian counter-drive on the Tula salient that sent some surprised invaders "running down frosty streets in their underwear," the official news agency Tass announced in a broadcast today.

LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Royal Air Force fighters carried out "several lightning attacks" on occupied France today and left thick smoke pouring from three targets at one place, Air Ministry sources said.

MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Nov 17 (AP) -- About 5,000 miners in a dozen Monongalia County commercial mines stayed away from the pits today in what a United Mine Workers official termed a "sympathy" walkout in connection with the captive mine strike.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 17 -- G.R. Watkins's Clyde Tolson, ever partial to the Bowie strip, sped to smart triumph in the six-furlong Goodspeed Handicap today. The 4-year-old Carlaris gelding overcame difficulties to register by a length in 1:123 -- 5, paying $10.40 for $2.

Department Store Sales Up 12% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 12 per cent for the week ended Nov. 15, in comparison with the corresponding week of last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Reflecting the substantial Improvement in sales, which rose to 59,074,196 in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 from $5,764,134 the year before, earnings reported yesterday by the Mergenthaler Linotype Company bettered those of any year since 1930.

Wholesale grocers moved yesterday to protect themselves against sudden loss of goods on order through the commandeering of stocks at the source by government agencies. The National American Wholesale Grocers Association rejected as being "entirely too broad" a revision of the present canned foods contract form proposed recently by the Canners League of California.

Praise for George Franck, All-America speedster from Minnesota, was sung by Coach Steve Owen of the Giants yesterday as he started planning for the important battle with the Redskins at the Polo Grounds on Sunday. A triumph over the Washington squad will give the New Yorkers the. National League's Eastern Division crown.

The eighth report of the trustees in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric System, filed yesterday in Federal court, showed a consolidated net profit of $12,969,257 for the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30.

What is Jane Cowl's bad luck is our misfortune. In point of fact, it is "Ring Around Elizabeth," which was acted like a cage of flying squirrels at The Playhouse last evening. It is a misguided comedy that Charl Armstrong, author of "The Happiest Days," has written from the woman's angle -- full of homey touches and roguishness.

The business community of New York and the public in general were asked yesterday to support the extended program of care for homeless children announced by the Children's Aid Society. The appeal was made at a luncheon given at India House, 2 Hanover Square, by the homeless children's committee of the society for a group of prominent business men.

Merchandise inventories of New York and Brooklyn department stores were 35 per cent above a year ago at the end of October, while sales during that month showed no Increase over 1940, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

STAR JUNCTION, Pa., Nov. 17 -- Sparks flew from the glowing slope of the great slate dump at the Red Lion mine here tonight, but the men with coal-smeared faces, who had worked all day despite the strike call, feared that the real "fireworks" might begin tomorrow morning.

Red Dawson of thrice-beaten Tulane probably is ready to agree with Pop Warner that first downs should count toward the winning of football games. The King Canute of the Green Wave mournfully told the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's yesterday that in the three losing battles his team had made fifty first downs to nineteen for the opposition.

CAMDEN, S.C., Nov. 17 --Ten women joined the Army here today, but not to carry guns. That many feminine writers, dispatched to cover the war manoeuvres from their individual perspectives, arrived in "spectator togs" of such, wide and amusing variety that their powder, of the nose-dusting variety, was the one common denominator of their costumes.

Only within the last generation or two have the Latin American and English-speaking peoples come to an understanding of "our community of interest, of faith, of responsibility and of free institutions," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared last night in an address at a celebration of the centenary of William Henry Hudson, novelist and naturalist.

ROME, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- Public auditing of all cooperative organizations to help produce a demand for public audits by labor unions was urged here tonight by Dr. H. E. Babcock, president of the Cooperative Grange League Federation and chairman of the Board of Trustees of Cornell University.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 15:

The Eastern Railroad Presidents Conference, representing all the Eastern railroads, announced yesterday that it would accept the findings of President Roosevelt's fact-finding Committee, which recently adjudicated the demands of the railroad unions for increased wages.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The text of a Royal Air Force communique:
Fordham plays St. Mary's next Saturday at the Polo Grounds and despite the Gaels' poor record the Rams are by no means taking this game lightly, not after the hard lesson they absorbed in Pittsburgh.
PARK CITY, Utah, Nov. 17 (AP) -- An Army bomber plunged to a fiery end in the snow-lashed Wasatch Mountains early today after five of the seven men aboard had parachuted to safety.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A bill to tighten the Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938 and transfer administration from the State Department to the Department of Justice was offered in the Senate today by Senator McKellar of Tennessee. The plan has been approved by the two departments, he indicated.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- An Increase of more than 10,000,000 members in the Catholic Church in the United States, representing a rise of more than 50 per cent in fifteen years, was estimated today by two Bishops in addresses delivered before the National Congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine.
FROM a position on the fringe of the weekly football huddle the following forward and lateral passes, complete and incomplete, were noted:

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 16 (Delayed) -- While few exact details of its extent are generally known and its development has not been widely advertised, Anglo-Russian cooperation in the Middle Bast has greatly improved the Allied position, not only in that wide area but in the broad relations to the danger in the West and the threatened danger in the Far East.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Nov. 12 aggregated $9,070.000,000.

The proud American biros that are scheduled to make their traditional appearance this Thursday on Thanksgiving dinner tables currently cost 7 to 10 cents more a pound than they did last year. Large turkeys, says the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets, average 32 cents a pound, while those under sixteen pounds may be had for about 35 cents.

BALBOA, C.Z., Nov. 17 -- The United States Navy was searching the seas today for an Axis raider reported to have attacked the Yugoslav merchantman Olga Topic in the Pacific off South America last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A United Mine Workers spokesman said today the International union would "neither encourage nor prevent" sympathy strikes in commercial soft coal pits in support of the men who ceased work in "captive" coal mines today.

When the Navy Department announced some days ago that the United States destroyer Kearny had been struck by a German torpedo in the North Atlantic, authoritative voices in Berlin at once burst into an angry chorus of denial. Hitler's own newspaper called the charge "a stinking lie."

Machinery for quickly obtaining financial backing for defense contractors, subcontractors and potential contractors able and willing to participate in defense production but unable to provide the necessary working' capital was set up here yesterday by the contract distribution division of the Office of Production Management.

"Gaucho," "Amazon," "Andes," "Aztec," "Brazilian mocha," were words that echoed over and over again during the hour spent by fashion writers yesterday at the review of Milgrim's Southern and holiday collection. Sally Milgrim turned her eyes to the Latin-American republics for the spirit with which she endowed her collection.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Fensylvania-Central Airlines Corporation of Pittsburgh has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 75,000 shares of $1.25 cumulative convertible preferred stock of no par value and 150,000 shares of common stock of $1 par value, to be reserved for issuance upon the exercise of the conversion privilege of the preferred stock.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was George A. Horton vice president of Pagel, Horton Co., Inc., dealers in crude rubbei and wood pulp, who leased an apartment in the new eighteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 530 Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Navy emphasized today that officers and men were prohibited from reporting even to their own families whether their ships bad sunk any German submarines.

Believe it or not, the names of Dumbo and Renoir were spoken together yesterday in an introduction to what was one of the most brilliantly presented millinery showings ever to take place in New York. Dumbo's ears gave rise to a new side draping on hats to be worn in the North and the South, and Renoir's exquisitely soft colorings and feminine styles were the motivating themes for enchanting chapeaux of many silhouettes.

The first step in the metropolitan area toward a voluntary payroll allotment plan for purchase of United States Defense savings bonds and stamps was taken yesterday. Under the plan an employe may allot part of his salary for purchase of the securities, which are to be delivered after deduction of the price from the payroll.

Gaining its strongest support of the season after its best offensive showing in recent weeks, Minnesota retained the top spot in The Associated Press football ranking poll yesterday by a vote of landslide proportions.

William G. Sebold, counter-espionage agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and principal government witness at the Brooklyn espionage trial, was pictured again yesterday in testimony as a self-confessed Nazi agent who attempted to lure German-Americans into an espionage ring under threats of reprisals by the Gestapo against their relatives still in Germany.

GART, W.Va., Nov. 17 (AP) -- T.J. McParland, general manager of the United States Coal and Coke Company's captive operation in Southern West Virginia, declared today that 60 per cent of the day shift in six mines reported for duty in defiance of the captive mine strike called by the United Mine Workers.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The strike for a union shop threw out of work most of the "captive" miners in Western Pennsylvania today, although a spokesman for the United States Steel Corporation asserted that 25 per cent of its 18,600 miners in the important Fayette County field had defied the strike order and entered the pits.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- The letter written by President Lincoln on Jan. 26, 1863, when he appointed Major Gen. Hooker as head of the Army of the Potomac, was bought at auction tonight for $15,000 by Alfred W. Stern of Chicago, a collector of Lincolnia.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 17 -- Robert C. Zuppke, the "Little Dutchman" of University of Illinois football fame, resigned tonight as head coach after twenty-nine years of service.

A proposal designed to check the deterioration of the downtown area of Brooklyn by increasing the residential zone from 15 per cent to 52 per cent was submitted yesterday to civic officials and other groups by the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement.

VICHY, France, Nov. 17 -- While Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's government is occupied with grave matters of State the Minister of Supplies is busy today fixing maximum, prices -- an endless, thankless and possibly a futile task.
taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

Nominations for the new officers and committeemen of the New York-Yacht Club were posted yesterday In the clubhouse at 37 West Forty-fourth Street. The election will take place at the annual meeting on Dec. 18.

The building industry is threatened with serious curtailment as a result of priorities restrictions, "the necessity of which has not been shown," Richmond H. Shreve of New York, president of the American Institute of Architects, declared yesterday.

National advertising in newspapers, magazines and radio is showing a definite spurt as the year draws to a close and gains for the final quarter over 1940 will be the best of any three-month period this year. This Increase is being made in the face of curtailed promotion for consumers' durable goods, such as automobiles and appliances.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- The State Board of Examiners of Professional Engineers today recommended to the State Education Department the names of those who passed the recent examination and are eligible for licenses as professional engineers.

The State Labor Relations Board announced yesterday that employes of the Prudential Insurance Company had selected Local 30 of the C.I.O. Industrial Insurance Agents Union as their bargaining agent. Of the 2,285 ballots cast, Local 30 received 1,600, the A.F. of L. Industrial and Ordinary Insurance Agents Council, 79, with 559 voting for neither union.

Seeking to speed up the process of getting entertainment to American soldiers and sailors through the medium of Camp Shows, Inc., a delegation representing West Coast motion picture and radio interests, which flew here Sunday, began conferences yesterday with Camp Shows officials.

Despite the refusal of John L.I Lewis to continue operations in the so-called "captive" mines, financial markets held to the belief that Washington would find ways and means to reopen the pits, and, as a result stocks did nothing more than turn irregular yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Seaboard Airways, Inc., told a Civil Aeronautics Board hearing today of its financial set-up following its separation from the Seaboard Airline Railway, whose application for a north-south air route the new company took over.
The tie with Holy Cross and its disappointing ending so far as Manhattan was concerned have made the Jaspers all the more determined to hurdle the final obstacle in their path to a good season.

VICHY, France, Nov. 17 -- A general denial was issued here today of what it called "fantastic, rumors emanating from Switzerland during the last two days regarding the evolution of the political situation in France."

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is difficult for any thinking citizen to understand fully the reason why Congress has permitted the collection and expenditure of millions of dollars by labor unions without supervision. I am confident that the gross irregularities which the Bioff-Brown trial brought out represent but a small part of the unconscionable abuses which must mark the administration of the affairs of a great many unions.

A new and bloody test of the Nazis' ability to carry Blitzkrieg warfare across a formidable water hazard -- as they spanned forty miles of sea to capture Crete -- is brewing at the Kerch Straits gateway to the Caucasus.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A definite assurance was given to the House today by Speaker Rayburn that anti-strike legislation would be considered "at the earliest opportunity," as the defense labor situation flared up in both branches of Congress.

Reports or contributions made to date in the sixty-third annual appeal of the United Hospital Fund of New York will be made today at a meeting to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse, women's chairman of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Senate committee investigating defense today accused the Army and Navy procurement divisions, along with the Office of Production Management, of lack of foresight which had brought unnecessary hardship to many small businesses, delayed defense production and created material shortages, more stringent than necessary.

Scranton, Pa., will be in the market on Dec. 8 with $519,000 of school district bonds for which bidders are to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 per cent. The bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1941, are to mature on Dec. 1, 1943 to 1951.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Should the captive coal mine strike affect defense production to a point where the President deems it necessary to have the government work the mines, he has a precedent half-made for him by his relative and predecessor, Theodore Roosevelt.

The quarter-final round in the twenty-second annual invitation squash tennis tournament of the Princeton Club was completed last night. Among those advancing was Joseph J. Lordi of the New York A.C., national amateur titleholder.

"The Forgotten Village," the John Steinbeck-Herbert Kline feature length documentary film dealing with the fight of modern Mexican science against primitive Indian superstition, will have its premiere today at the Belmont Theatre.

Albert Spalding is a violinist who can be depended upon to play with excellent taste and with high sincerity of purpose. His performances -- witness his appearance at Carnegie Hall last night -- seldom, if ever, fall below this reliable level, and occasionally they soar higher.

Although many or the books written in the last six years by the Federal Writers Project (now the WPA Writers Program) scarcely could be called successes from the standpoint of sales -- and this includes the impressive and highly-praised volumes of the nearly-completed American Guide series -- a survey of the achievements of the New York City Writers Project reveals that among its nineteen published works is one quiet but solid best seller.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, the only woman regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, received the eminent achievement award of the American Women's Association at the fifteenth annual "Friendship Dinner" of New York business ant professional club women in the Hotel Biltmore last night.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Nov. 18 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Two blast furnaces were shut down in Alabama today as a strike of 8,000 captive coal miners in this State cut off production of fuel.

BERLIN, Nov. 17 -- Today's most important entry in the ledger of military events on the Eastern Front, as kept in Berlin, is the capture of Kerch, called here the "springboard for the Caucasus," which was claimed in a special communique from the German High Command.

A composite picture of Russia at war is contained in a 100,000-word manuscript that reached this country last week and is now in the offices of Alliance Books being translated, edited and prepared for January publication. The manuscript was prepared in Russia by the All-Union Society of Cultural Relations.

Two thousand persons swamped the office of the retail section of the State Employment Service at 10 Bast Fortieth Street yesterday in the hope of obtaining jobs in department stores and specialty shops for the Christmas sales rush, but the great majority were disappointed.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 17 -- A New York police official was with Frank Erickson, New York City gambler, when Erickson was held up by thugs in the New York Athletic Club last April 24, it was charged today. Several days later the police official was said to have killed himself.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We are interested in the letter of Hans R.L. Cohrssen, in your issue of Nov. 9, entitled "Transportation a Problem for Service Men on Leave."

BERLIN, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- With the official announcement that German shock troops had captured Kerch, military spokesmen said today that the Axis forces might strike on across the Kerch Straits into the Caucasus on the momentum of

The first annual meeting of the reorganized Association of Stock Exchange Firms was held yesterday in the New York Stock Exchange. Thirty new governors were elected, comprising fifteen from New York and fifteen partners of New York Stock Exchange firms residing in other cities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Supplemental appropriations totaling $7,082,419,046 for the Army, Navy and defense housing were asked of Congress today by President Roosevelt. If granted they would bring to $67,577,000,000 the net total for appropriations and contractual authority for the defense program since its inception in June, 1940.

Complete reorganization of the executive staff of the United Artists Corporation was disclosed yesterday with the announcement of the appointment of a four-man committee to administer the affairs of the company. Edward C. Raftery, general counsel, was named president, a post which has been vacant since the resignation of Dr. A.H. Giannini in June, 1938.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There were no doubt strong reasons for the formal appeal made to the Finnish Government from Washington, but there is no reason to put forward the illusion that an armistice with Finland could substantially alter the Russian military situation on the northern front.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The following is the text of the statement entitled "Crisis of Christianity" which the administrative board of the National Catholic Welfare Conference issued today following the annual meeting of the Catholic Bishops of the United States:

Plans were filed yesterday for a six-story apartment house to be erected on Yellowstone Boulevard in Forest Hills, Queens, at an estimated cost of $540,000. The details of this and other projects follow:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The text of John L. Lewis's speech to the policy committee of the United Mine Workers, explaining the negotiations with heads of the steel companies for settlement of the captive coal mine controversy, follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- The House Rules Committee today delayed floor consideration of the pending price control bill for at least a week when it recessed without granting any rule for the measure.

On a mission of revenge, Toronto's colorful Maple Leafs will come to town tonight for their first appearance of the season at Madison Square Garden. The Canadian stick-wielders will battle the Rangers, renewing a rivalry which started with their opening National Hockey League contest on Nov. 1, when the Blue Shirts administered the only defeat of the campaign to the Leafs in Toronto.

Alabama Great Southern Directors of the Alabama Great Southern Railroad Company authorized yesterday dividends of $6 on the preferred and $6 on the ordinary stock, both payable on Dec. 23. Dividends for the year on both issues will total $9 each, the same as in 1940.
DETROIT, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The executive board of the C.I.O. endorsed unanimously today a pronouncement on "lagging arms production and defense unemployment."

Steel Situation On the surface, the slight gain in the steel production rate this week indicates an amelioration in the general situation, but from various sections of the country it is possible to glean signs that companies which depend heavily on purchased scrap steel are not doing well.
DETROIT, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The executive board of the C.I.O. endorsed unanimously today a pronouncement on "lagging arms production and defense unemployment."

Steel Situation On the surface, the slight gain in the steel production rate this week indicates an amelioration in the general situation, but from various sections of the country it is possible to glean signs that companies which depend heavily on purchased scrap steel are not doing well.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Conferences that may decide whether there will be peace or war in the Far East opened today when President Roosevelt received Saburo Kurusu, special Japanese envoy, for an hour-and-a-quarter conference at the White House. Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Japanese Ambassador Kichisaburo Nomura also were present.
New York City has made its usual elaborate plans, for the celebration of Thanksgiving Day, which this year will include the entertainment of thousands of visiting soldiers, sailors and marines.

THE enormous collection of documentary photographs in the Farm Security Administration files (now numbering 65,000, more or less) has again been drawn upon to illustrate a striking book, this time a report on the plight of the Negro in the United States: "12 Million Black Voices,"* by the author of "Native Son," Richard Wright.

A gate of $257,000 is possible for the fifteen-round battle Jan. 9 in Madison Square Garden in which Joe Louis will defend his world heavyweight title against Buddy Baer, California giant, under the schedule of prices announced yesterday by Promoter Mike Jacobs, who is conducting the match for the New York auxiliary of the, Navy Relief Society.

The steel industry filed yesterday its estimates of the current week's production of steel with the American Iron and Steel Institute, taking into account any effect to be anticipated from the coal strike or other causes. After compilation of these data, the institute said that the rate of output this week would be 97 per cent of theoretical full capacity.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 17 (AP) -- United States Ambassador Laurence A. Steinhardt and Maxim Litvinoff, new Soviet envoy to the United States, en route to Washington, arrived here safely today after a blizzard-plagued five-day plane trip from Kuibyshev, auxiliary Soviet capital.

Mental breakdowns in the United States armed forces could be largely prevented by strict psychiatric tests before induction, Dr. Robert Dick Gillespie, psychiatrist for the Royal Air Force, told a large gathering of physicians at the New York Academy of Medicine last night. Dr. Gillespie delivered the first of two Salmon Memorial Lectures on the general subject "Psychoneurosis in Peace and War and the Future of Human Relationships."

VICHY, France, Nov. 17 -- Five days after being transferred to confinement in the fortress of Portalet, former General Maurice Gustave Gamelin, who is awaiting trial for responsibility of the French defeat by the Supreme Court at Riom, has been moved to a clinic in the neighborhood of Pau.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A work stoppage of 53,000 miners at dawn today in the "captive" coal mines which feed the nation's steel mills put squarely up to President Roosevelt tonight the question of finding a method of carrying out his "indisputable obligation" to bring about a resumption of coal production necessary for national defense.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The texts of the letter of John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, and the report and subsequent letter of Benjamin F. Fairless, Eugene G. Grace and Frank Purnell, representatives of the major steel corporations, to President Roosevelt about negotiations for an agreement in the dispute over a contract for the "captive" coal mines were as follows:

A copy of "The Queen's Birthday Book," issued in 1887 in celebration of Queen Victoria's jubilee and signed by many of her royal relatives, was presented yesterday by Dr. Armand Hammer, president of the Hammer Galleries, to Mrs. Wales Latham, president of Bundles for Britain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The publicly and privately owned lands of the West hold untapped natural resources sufficient to provide a plentiful supply of most critical defense materials now under priorities and also the normal needs of the civilian population, a Senate Public Lands Subcommittee reported today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Nov. 18 -- The German Army's drives toward Moscow from the Kalinin and Tula salients have been "definitely checked" and the invaders are in full retreat in several areas of those salients and fighting on the defensive in other areas, it was announced this morning by a spokesman on the Moscow radio.

If you take the number of hunters who turned out for the opening of the Catskill deer season the week-end was successful, but in most of the popular hunting grounds the number of deer killed was far from the peak prophesied by many wise guides before the season opened.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 -- Walter Wanger will release his partly completed production, "Eagle Squadron," which deals with the American volunteer units in the Royal Air Force, through Universal, the studio announced today.

Establishment of a reserve on a scientific basis to cushion future losses and determination of methods of compensating employes in relation to the cost of living stand out as the No. 1 problems facing retailers in 1942, according to the results of a survey made by the National Retail Dry Goods Association of the views of merchants throughout the country, and announced yesterday.

Materials for city construction, such as subways and schools, are not available because of Federal priorities, the Board of Estimate was told yesterday as it considered the city's capital outlay budget for 1942 at City Hall.

Exiles who are loyal to the Latvian Republic today celebrate its twenty-third anniversary. They have a sad but stirring history to look back upon. In seven or eight recorded centuries they have had less than a generation of complete freedom. Germans, Swedes, Poles, Danes and Russians at various times have been their masters.

Five years ago Leslie MacMitchell, then a, senior at George Washington High School, found himself gaining too much weight. Rather than diet, he figured It would be more fun to go in for cross-country running, and go in for it he did in a great big way.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The mysterious Axis ship reported by the Navy last night as captured on Nov. 6 in "Atlantic Equatorial waters" while proceeding under the United States colors was identified today as the German freighter Odenwald.

Mrs. Bruce Barton gave a cocktail party yesterday afternoon at her home, 117 East Fifty-fifth Street, for members of the committee serving with her in behalf of the performance of "Theatre," with Cornelia Otis Skinner in the leading role, on the night of Nov. 25 at the Hudson Theatre for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the New York Wellesley Club.
AMITYVILLE, L.I., Nov. 18 (Tuesday) -- Three or four patients were believed to have perished early today in a fire that destroyed one of the buildings of the Brunswick Home, a private hospital here.

Actors Equity Association, which for years has been plagued by barges of "ism." -- mainly Red -- control of its governing board, has decided to frame a constitutional' amendment prohibiting members of or sympathizers with such groups from holding office in or being employed by the association, The decision was reached by the membership in a referendum; the council now must draw the amendment and submit it again to the membership for a final vote.

Entering the tenth, week of trial, the prosecution rested its case yesterday in the first-degree murder charge against Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, former ruler of the city's $1,000,000 industrial rackets, and his two henchmen, Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss and Louis Capone, before Judge Franklin Taylor and a blue-ribbon jury in Kings County Court

Members of the Society or Tammany, or the Columbian Order, the fraternal side of the political organization known as Tammany Hall, are beginning to discuss the possible fate of the building at 102 East Seventeenth Street, the principal tenant of which is the New York County Democratic Commitee, it was disclosed yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- Judge M.M. Joyce of the United States District Court directed a verdict of acquittal today for five of twenty-eight persons accused of conspiracy to overthrow the government by revolution. Those acquitted were Walter Hagstrom, Dorothy Schultz, Rose Seller, Nick Wagner and George Frosig.

Employes, officers and trustees of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company who have been with the institution twenty-five years or more were guests of the bank at a dinner last night in the Hotel Roosevelt on the occasion of formation of a Quarter-Century Club.

Housewives were warned yesterday not to turn to women on relief to allay the shortage in domestic help. If they are not ill or broken down physically from undernourishment, they have small children of their own to care for, Dr. Amey Watson, executive secretary of the National Council on Household Employment, declared.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Sows were in good demand today, selling at strong to 10 cents higher prices. Other classes were strong in moderately active trading with $10.35 a hundred weight paid for numerous loads. Dressed pork was weaker, with light loins at 19 to 20 cents a pound, down 1/2 cent from yesterday.

Memorial Service Memorial services, and unveiling of tablet, for the late Hon. Deputy Chief William W. Cohen will be held at Riverside Synagogue, 310 West 103d St.. Manhattan, at 8 P.M., Friday, Nov. 21.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 17 (Delayed) -- It may be said authoritatively that the Soviet Government's confidence and optimism are rising continually. Further diplomatic reports received from Germany by a roundabout route indicate growing anxiety there.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 18 (AP) -- The National Grange called on Congress today to take immediate steps "to prevent and prohibit all strikes which would retard progress of defense industries."

MONTERREY, Mexico, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A two-inch depressed fracture behind the left ear was found today by four physicians performing an autopsy on the body of Mrs. Arthur Torrance. They sought to determine the manner in which the wealthy Michigan woman came to her death on the highway north of here ten days ago.

Six basic reasons lie behind current magazine advertising of manufacturers who are oversold, according to a brochure issued yesterday by the Magazine Marketing Service. They are: To protect the trade name and good-will, to protect the dealer structure, to lay the foundation for after-emergency expansion, to educate the public on how to conserve, to spread the news of war-born products for peace and to tell "how we're doing the job."

Tomorrow's Holiday All securities and commodity exchanges in the United States will be closed tomorrow in observance of Thanksgiving Day. As is customary on holidays, many livestock markets will remain open.

The Undergraduate Newspaper Council of New York University, following Professor Philip O. Badger's statement that he had no authority to institute fundamental changes in the university's athletic policy, addressed a letter to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase yesterday asking for a hearing on the subsidization of football.

On Dec. 1 THE NEW YORK TIMES and Station WMCA (570 on the dial) will begin a daily news bulletin broadcast every hour on the hour from 8 A.M. through 11 P.M. On Sunday the broadcasts will be heard four times -- 9 A.M., 1 P.M., 5 P.M. and 11 P.M.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Contestants of the will of Mrs. Anna H. Paton, wealthy New York widow, charged today in the Westchester County Surrogate's court that the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest on Fifth Avenue at Ninetieth Street, New York, had been immoderately friendly with Mrs. Paton when she drew wills bequeathing part of her $1,300,000 estate to him.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Nov. 19 -- Red Army forces on the Moscow front held firm at all points during yesterday's fighting, a Soviet military spokesman announced in a broadcast this morning. The fighting again was heaviest on the Kalinin and Tula salients.

Two large one-man shows opened with previews last evening at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. They spread before us retrospectively the art of two celebrated modernists, Joan Miro and Salvador Dali. Beginning today these exhibitions will be open to the public and both are to remain current through Jan. 11.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Now seems an appropriate time to set right a rather wide misapprehension as to the manner of appointment of the proportional representation canvassers who count the votes for members of the City Council.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- The House killed late today the Hobbs Alien Detention Bill, which would have empowered the Justice Department to detain aliens who cannot be deported under current war conditions. The vote was reported at 167 to 141.

An effort to outlaw pinball games in this State met what law-enforcement officials described as its first court test yesterday in Queens, and resulted in conviction of a man and a woman defendant in a test case.

As a result of the current industrial boom, hundreds of students fare leaving their classes to take Jobs paying $15 to $25 weekly, Board of Education officials disclosed yesterday. During October, officials estimated, more than 2,000 boys and girls quit their classrooms to go to work.

During the hard times of the Thirties, in which relief and other social benefits here accentuated the higher living standards of Northern cities compared to the deep South, the non-white population of New York City increased by 135,130, according to census figures tabulated by the Department of Welfare.

All-out mobilization of its resources has been completed by New York City to make Thanksgiving Day currently an occasion for thanksgiving for thousands of visiting service men, for unfortunates and for the community generally. At the same time civic, patriotic and religious groups will commemorate the day.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 19 -- Premier Hideki Tojo pledged the Japanese Government yesterday to abide by the following resolution adopted by a unanimous, rising vote of the members of the House of Representatives:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- As the Germans started a new and possibly abortive offensive against Moscow yesterday, the Russian campaign -- and the war kaleidoscope -- completed another phase.
