WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The large expansion in air operations led today to the establishment within the Air Corps of an Air Service Command. This unit will take over operations heretofore handled by the Maintenance Command, a discontinued subsidiary of the Materiel Division.

Special mediation services for this nation, Great Britain, Russia and China, as well as for those killed or otherwise victimized "in the struggle against aggression," have been added to the program for the opening of the full length of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine during the week of Nov. 30, Bishop William T. Manning announced yesterday.
Special dividend declarations were announced yesterday by a number of industrial companies, resulting in substantial increases over the total payments distributed last year.

The anticipated court test on the election of Sheriffs for each of the city's five counties in the recent election at the same time a charter amendment was adopted abolishing the offices and substituting a city-wide Sheriff appointed from civil service lists was instituted yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Frank A. Erickson, New York City gambler, was acquitted in Morris County Court here tonight of the charge that early on the morning of May 25 he assaulted Milton F. Untermeyer, stockbroker, in the Untermeyer home at Kinnelon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There will surely be general appreciation by right-thinking men and women of Mrs. Pearl Buck's noble argument against race prejudice throughout the world. It is a pity that she disfigures it by a mistaken comparison between the alleged treatment of American Negroes and that of Pundit Nehru.

The slogan adopted for National Art Week this year is "A Work of Art for Every American Home." This connotes a popularizing campaign based on sales. Again, as was the case in 1940, a nation-wide effort, courageously directed and generously staffed, is focused on selling.

Franz Joseph Stigler, former chief baker on the United States Lines steamers Manhattan and America, and a defendant in the Brooklyn espionage trial, admitted yesterday on cross-examination that he had lied to FBI agents about his connection with an alleged Nazi spy ring, following his arrest last June.
MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Foreign Affairs Commissariat today issued a communique denying Finnish contentions that Finland was at war with Russia in self-defense against Soviet imperialism.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- A personal message from President Manuel Avila Camacho of Mexico was handed to President Roosevelt today by Josephus Daniels, retiring Ambassador to Mexico, who told reporters subsequently that Mexico was extremely anxious for an early settlement of oil expropriation problems.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "P.R. and the Council " betrays a note of disappointment. Proportional representation apparently has been the least successful of the various reforms adopted to improve the city government. You even seem to wish a return to the majority method of electing the city's legislature.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Some Congressional leaders left a conference with President Roosevelt this morning with the impression that he is ready to crack down hard on John L. Lewis for calling the captive mine walkout in defiance of White House wishes.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 18 -- The cruiser Omaha today was revealed as the warship that seized the German freighter Odenwald, disguised as the steamer Willmoto of Philadelphia, in Atlantic equatorial waters.

Now that "Junior Miss" has arrived at the Lyceum, where it opened last evening, everything is for the best in the best of all possible worlds. For Jerome Chodorov and Joseph Fields, who last season were writing "My Sister Eileen" out of the fecund pages of the New Yorker, have apparently renewed their subscription.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The average wage-earner doubtless will do a lot of headshaking in bewilderment over the Treasury's proposed bill for increased income taxation at the source. He will not understand just where he fits into the bugaboo of inflation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The strike in the captive coal mines and anti-strike legislation were discussed this morning at a conference between President Roosevelt and leaders of Congress, one of whom was Speaker Rayburn.

Many dinner parties will be given in advance of the performance of "Junior Miss" on the night of Nov. 26 at the Lyceum Theatre for the benefit of the Westchester County Childrens Association. The same organization had planned to hold its benefit last night at the performance of "The Walrus and the Carpenter," but because of the play's closing, changed its plans.

Confronted with a general price rise in materials, Budget Director Kenneth Dayton directed all city departments yesterday to stop expenditures for supplies, materials and equipment until each head of a department had devised a program of economies sufficient to offset rising costs between the present and June 30, 1942.
Business leasing transactions with concerns in a variety of commercial lines in many areas of the city were reported yesterday by brokers and agents.

The National Needlecraft Bureau, which conducted a contest for 400,000 crocheters throughout the country for the title of National Crochet Champion, announced last night that the fifth annual award had been divided between two women, Mrs. H.R. Campfield of 47-45 Forty-third Street, Woodside, Queens, and Mrs. Theresa Blum of 6204 Roy Street, Los Angeles.

ALBANY, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Interstate planning to assure continuous civilian production was urged by Governor Lehman today so that the labor supply can be fitted to jobs "with the least possible dislocation of population"

Leopold Stokowski, a man of surprises, sprang a first performance of importance at his concert with the NBC Symphony Orchestra at the Cosmopolitan Opera House last night and called it an "informal reading." The work was the Sixth symphony of Dimitri Shostakovich, Soviet Russia's most gifted composer, who is helping, with more than music, to defend his home city of Leningrad these days.

James F. Burns Jr., partner In Harris, Upham Co., was elected president of the reorganized Association of Stock Exchange Firms yesterday at the first governors' meeting since its expansion into a nation-wide organization. Today he is expected to name his executive and finance committees.

VICHY, France, Nov. 18 -- Several members of a terrorist band accused of responsibility for the killings of German officers in Nantes and Bordeaux have been arrested, according to a notice published today in Paris.

Cotton mills which switch looms from one construction to another in order to earn an extra 1/3 of a cent of profit because of ceiling's were chided yesterday by James P. Davis, in charge of textiles and related products in the Office of Price Administration.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that government loans on this year's corn crop would average 74.8 cents a bushel, or 13.8 cents higher than the 1940 rate.

Major Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, yesterday placed his stamp of approval on Ken Overlin, Washington, D.C., and Al Hostak, Seattle battler, both former holders of the world middleweight championship, who are to fight ten rounds in a light heavyweight encounter Friday night in Madison Square Garden.

The President has asked Congress for another $7,000,000,000 for national defense. If Congress meets this request -- and there is every reason to believe it will -- the total of defense appropriations and authorizations will be increased to more than $67,000,000,000, a sum which exceeds our total national income for six out of the past ten years.

Higher prices than last year must be paid for a number of furs during the coming season, but there is no justification for "an all-round rise in prices," Lampson, Fraser Huth, Inc., declared yesterday in its pre-season analysis of market conditions.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- United States Lease-Lend Administrator W. Averell Harriman arrived today with a cheering message for the British, who, he said, are setting such a rapid pace in production of war supplies that Americans are finding it the hardest sort of job to keep up.

Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., reported yesterday for the three months ended on Oct. 31 a net income of $8,613,885, compared with $6,580,322 the year before. Net income for the nine months ended with October amounted to $15,930,923, against $15,525,776 for the corresponding period of 1940.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 18 (AP) -- The threat of a strike at the Fairfield works of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company by the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee was removed tonight by a plea from the striking C.I.O. United Mine Workers in Alabama's captive coal mines.

Mrs. Ava Willing Ribblesdale, the mother of Vincent Astor, who last year relinquished her British title as Lady Ribblesdale when she regained her American citizenship, was reported yesterday to have taken an apartment in 420 Park Avenue In a transaction arranged by Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc.
VIENNA, Ga., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Senator George called upon President Roosevelt today to put an end to strikes in mines and industrial plants essential to the national defense.
It may take an executive dispensation to get wish-bones released for wishing purposes this year, as the Office of Civilian Defense has plans even for the turkey.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 18 -- New evidence to show that such adverse criticism of labor unionism as exists on the part of the public today arises largely from the conduct of labor union leaders is revealed in a nation-wide poll just completed by the institute.

The American Women's Association showed discrimination, and possibly, also, a sense of timing, in giving its annual reward for distinguished achievement this week to Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director for the National Labor Relations Board. Mrs. Herrick is the innocent bystander's dream of what an industrial adjudicator ought to be.

The traditions of the United States and the recorded progress of the world both reject the idea of isolationism, Guy J. Swope, director of the division of territories and island possessions of the Department of the Interior, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Propeller Club of the Port of New York.

DETROIT, Nov. 18 -- Routing the isolationist forces of John L. Lewis, the fourth constitutional convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations gave its support today to President Roosevelt's foreign policy, with its program of all-out aid to Great Britain, Soviet Russia and China.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Federal Court of Appeals sustained in an opinion today the constitutionality of the Railway Labor Act of 1934, establishing the National Railway Adjustment Board.

Nat Sobler, a small, quick-tempered, baldish man about 60 years old, twice rose indignantly from the witness stand at the first-degree murder trial of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, industrial racketeer, yesterday and asserted that he was walking out of the courtroom because he regarded the questions asked by the prosecution as insulting.
NEW YORK Prince and Princess Alexandre de Caraman-Chimay have left Mayfair House for Beverly Hills, Calif., to stay for several months.

Hesitancy marked a dull session yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as financial circles awaited the next move of Washington in the coal strike crisis. The limited amount of offerings, except in the low-priced public utilities and there sales to establish losses for income tax purpises ruled, again bespoke of the confidence as to the ultimate outcome of the labor troubles besetting defense industries.

BERLIN, Nov. 18 (AP) -- German submarines have sunk four armed merchant ships totaling 21,000 tons and an escort vessel in the North Atlantic and the northern part of the Arctic Ocean, the High Command announced today.
A strong demand for the larger and more expensive type of home in various sections of Long Island is indicated by reports received yesterday from brokers operating there.

The extension by the Vichy government of its anti-Semitic laws to the French possessions means the unfurling of the swastika in the Western Hemisphere, Thomas E. Dewey declared last night. He spoke to the lawyers' division of the Federation for Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies at the Hotel Biltmore.
The Index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities Included in each group is given.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. "Skylark," Paramount's picturization of the Samson Raphaelson book and play, will be the new attraction at the Paramount. The film, which marks the theatre's fifteenth aniversary, is the 575th picture to be shown there since the theatre's opening on Nov. 19, 1926, the management announced.

Commemorating fifty years of basketball, the golden jubilee of the sport originated by the late Dr. James A. Naismith at Spring-field College in 1891 will get off to a flying start tonight at Madison Square Garden, where four of the finest amateur quintets in the country will swing into action.

Officers and members of the board of directors of the Smith College Club of New York gave a reception and tea yesterday afternoon to mark the formal opening of the organization's new headquarters at the Weylin. Mrs. Howard J. Rogers is president of the club.

Assailing selfish labor leaders, Walter D. Fuller, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, yesterday warned members of the Sales Executives Club of New York that "if the government can't lick John L. Lewis, then it better lay off Hitler."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Expectation of government action on the coal strike was whetted by statements from those closely associated with the President today that he was of the opinion that the time had arrived to "crack down" on John L. Lewis and on all interruptions in defense production.

James W. Gerard, general chairman of the 110th anniversary campaign committee of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society, announced yesterday at the first report luncheon in the Hotel Biltmore that $30,684 had been raised thus far toward the goal of $110,000.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 18 -- Sympathy walkouts today closed thirteen additional commercial mines which were not included In the United Mine Workers' strike call. Sympathy strikes, which the U.M.W. here declared were unauthorized, also halted operations at all four captive mines of the Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation and one of two "captive" mines of the Duquesne Light Company.

British praise of the Canadian war effort was brought to New York yesterday by W. Ross Macdonald. Liberal Member of the Canadian Parliament, who arrived at the marine terminal at La Guardia Field aboard the Pan American Airways Dixie Clipper.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- General Sir John G. Dill will retire as Chief of the Imperial General Staff -- the highest post in the British Army -- upon reaching his sixtieth birthday on Christmas Day this year, it was announced today. He will be succeeded by Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan Brooke, Commander in Chief of the Home Forces.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- The renamed Brooklyn Americans afforded the Boston Bruins their customary feeble opposition tonight, with the result that the Stanley Cup champions pulled out a 7-2 victory before a crowd of 8,000 at the Boston Garden.

BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- On the principle that neither total war nor total defense can afford any lengthy breathing spells, the operations on the vast Russian-German front continue regardless of the weather, but thrusts and counterthrusts do not appear to have greatly modified the main features of the front line as it has existed for more than a month and where it shows tendencies of stabilizing itself with the coming of Winter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The long-accepted thesis that, in event of war in the Far Pacific, the United States could not defend the Philippines and therefore would not try has been demolished by recent developments of war-making and foreign policy.

Thanksgiving Day services will be held tomorrow in cathedrals, synagogues, churches of all faiths and in Salvation Army and other halls. Prayers for "a just and righteous peace" will be offered widely. Gratitude for freedom of worship in this country will be expressed.

New York, which has not provided the setting for major league baseball's annual Winter conclaves since 1938, will have to forego the pleasure of playing host to the magnates for at least another year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Wheat prices drifted in a listless manner today, with professional traders doing most of the business. Announcement that Canada had sold 120,000,000 bushels of wheat futures to England, the largest single trade on record, had no effect as a price-making influence here or in Winnipeg.

VICHY, France, Nov. 18 -- The Count of Paris, pretender to the French throne, sent a "most formal denial" to the Paris press today that he is a supporter of General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Free French; an anglophile or a supporter of the Parliamentary regime.

Dr. Juan Carlos Blanco, the first Ambassador appointed by Uruguay to the United States, praised the protection offered by this government to all the Americas in addressing members and guests of the Pan American Society at a luncheon held in his honor yesterday at India House, 1 Hanover Square.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18 -- "Father Malachy's Miracle," a fantasy staged on Broadway in November of 1937, was purchased today by RKO as a vehicle for Thomas Mitchell. Al Shean appeared in the title role in the play, which was dramatized by Brian Doherty from a novel by Bruce Marshall.

Switches from near to distant months in anticipation of the first notice day for the December contract on Tuesday featured yesterday an otherwise dull cotton market. Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, after moving irregularly throughout the session, closed unchanged to 5 points higher, except for the October contract.
DETROIT, Nov. 18 -- Following are the texts of President Roosevelt's message to the C.I.O.'s convention and the organization's resolution on foreign policy:

Post 29 on the floor of the New York Curb Exchange was the center of an unusual ceremony yesterday noon, when it was opened to trading in United States defense bonds and stamps by Linda Darnell, motion picture actress, to the accompaniment of speeches and flashlight bulbs.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- Dr. Robert R. Jones Jr., 39 years old, associate professor of surgery at the Duke Medical School, was shot fatally today, police said, by a patient who emptied a 22 pistol at him and was still firing with a 32 revolver when overpowered.
Estates and executors figured in several sales of residential properties reported in Manhattan yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Secretary Wickard announced today the formation of a nation-wide organiaztion of farmers and Department of Agriculture workers to make plans for a three-point program for agriculture in the postwar period.
UNIONTOWN, Pa., Nov. 18 -- Mass picketing spread through the captive coal area today and virtually stopped the production of more than twenty mines In Fayette, Greene and Washington Counties.
Following is the text of Wendell L. Willkie's address last night at the dinner of the Churchman Associates:

Wendell L. Willkie said last night that the closed shop issue, the cause of the present conflict in the coal industry, "should not be settled during an emergency when Hitler is holding a pistol at our heads."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Roosevelt took personal command today of efforts to avert a threatened nationwide strike of railroad workers on Dec. 7, and it was reported in informed quarters tonight that a compromise wage increase probably will settle the dispute between rail unions and management.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- With an assertion by one Bishop that no good Catholic could hold a brief for dictatorship or totalitarian government and a plea from another for all members of the faith to join in an all-out struggle between modern paganism and Christianity," the national Congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine ended this evening.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Several former Illini gridiron stars were mentioned as possible successors to Bob Zuppke as head Illinois football coach today as the university's board of trustees took cognizance of his surprise resignation and named Doug Mills permanent director of athletics.

The report of the International Paper Company, submitted yesterday by Richard J. Cullen, president, disclosed a consolidated net profit for the September quarter of $4,751,008, including a credit of $429,118 in excess tax provision for the first six months of 1941.

Each season the duck hunters concentrate their complaints on one particular regulation which they agree should be eliminated or amended, and this year the argument is based on the inflexibility of the law prohibiting shooting from a motor boat.

A plea for more adequate hospital and medical service within the means of the middle-income group was made yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at a meeting of the Manhattan women's division of the United Hospital Campaign in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- Col. Gen. Ernst Udet, noted flier in the World War and the leading creator of the present German air force, died yesterday in an accident "while experimenting with a new weapon," it was announced today.

CAMDEN, S.C., Nov. 18 -- The Kirkwood Hotel, the Winter residence of polo-playing vacationists, taken over by the Army during war manoeuvres, today houses numerous generals and members of Congress. These luxurious quarters provided for observers are situated in the oldest inland town in the State, In the center of an area originally roamed by Indians, then by Irish Quakers, later by pre-1929 millionaires and today by 300,000 soldiers engaged in the manoeuvres.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- The prospective public offering of Marshall Field Co. common stock was reduced today to 135,000 shares, from the original block of 230,000 shares, when underwriters announced they would amend their registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

If there's anything at all in the old saying that coining events cast their shadows up front, then Fordham is setting up a brand new backfield for the game with St. Mary's up (or down if you're an uptowner) at the Polo Grounds this coming Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Navy set up a priorities system today for arming merchant ships and provided that vessels which will carry munitions to Britain and Russia through the North Atlantic would be the first to receive guns and gun crews.

An invitation preview showing of the Dali and Miro exhibitions, held last night at the Museum of Modern Art, was preceded by several dinner parties given by museum officials and their friends. One of the largest of these prefatory fetes was that given in the ballroom of the Gotham by Monroe Wheeler, director of exhibitions and publications for the museum.
Saks Fifth Avenue displayed play toys for the South and West at its showing yesterday, while John-Frederics offered hats that were part of the dress.

Savings and loan institutions have continued to hold their business on an even keel despite the introduction of priorities in the construction field and despite the possibility of shortages which may develop later on, Nugent Fallon, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, told the Metropolitan League of Savings and Loan Associations at its Fall forum and dinner meeting last night in the Hotel Astor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Prices of food and farm products will start upward again in the next few months, government economists forecast today as they reported a recent halt in such increases.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Representative Dies of Texas, chairman of the committee to investigate un-American activities, suggested today that there be an investigation of the "influences" which have brought about "an influx of Communists and fellow travelers" into Washington official life.

MONTREAL, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press) -- The Detroit Red Wing line of Don Grosso, Eddie Wares and Syd Abel still is setting the scoring pace in the National Hockey League, statistics released today by the league revealed.

A syndicate composed of Field, Richards Co., Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., and Braun, Bosworth Co. received the award yesterday of a new issue of $900,000 of road improvement bonds of Cuyahoga County, Ohio, on a bid of 100.89 for 2s.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 19 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The midnight Soviet communique, as broadcast by the Moscow radio, follows:

A boycott by newsdealers of seven metropolitan newspapers will go into effect at 11:30 A.M. today unless the publishers grant a lower price on newspapers, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Masiello, president of the Newsdealers Federal Labor Union, an A.F. of L. affiliate, at the union's office, 140 East Fourteenth Street.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 18 -- Australians, who are working feverishly to make their country one of the most important arsenals for the democracies, are greatly disturbed over the labor situation in the United States. Prime Minister John Curtin told this correspondent today:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Mineral resources of Latin America are to be thoroughly surveyed in the near future under an arrangement worked out between this government and the authorities in South and Central American countries, it was learned here today.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Nov. 18 -- Today's market on the Bourse was narrow, dull and irregular. Royal Dutch was 2 points lower at 331 5/8; Amsterdam Rubber was 2 3/4 better at 319 1/8; Amsterdam Trading 1 down at 497 and Philips 2 up at 278 1/2.

The eighteenth annual Thanksgiving Day parade aranged by R. H. Macy Co., starting at 11:45 A.M. tomorrow at 106th Street and Central Park West, will comprise twenty-six sections, the store's management announced yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Resolutions urging labor to avoid all strikes in defense industries and asking President Roosevelt to seek legislation prohibiting such strikes were adopted unanimously today by 1,000 clubwomen attending the third annual forum conducted by Westchester County women's clubs with the cooperation of Arnold Constable Co.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The War Department announced today the award of supply contracts totaling $22,776,076, of which the following, not previously published, went to firms in the New York area:

In the days of our forefathers plum puddings were majestic monuments. They were proudly, pompously and ceremoniously borne to the festal board -- great towering cakes wreathed with holly and bedizened with bright blue plumes of flame.

Columbia's battered football squad prepared to fight off another dose of the same medicine it took from the spin-bucking of Michigan's captain, Bob Westfall, last Saturday, as it worked on formations designed to stop Colgate's Mike Micka yesterday at Baker Field.

Six goals are enough to win any ordinary hockey game, with plenty to spare. But six goals were good only for second money at Madison Square Garden last night, when the Toronto Maple Leafs humbled the New York Rangers in a National League clash.

MONTREAL, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Dealing with Canada's war effort and the competition of non-essentials, Colonel A. A. Magee, in his presidential address to shareholders of Barclays Bank, Canada, said today:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18 -- In the last protracted scrimmage of the season, the Yale first and second varsity elevens battled each other today and then alternated in opposing a team of players skilled in executing the Harvard attack.

Reversing the trend of the previous five months, the volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding in the United States grained $8,005,000 in October, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York revealed yesterday in the monthly survey of the bill market.

ZAGREB, Croatia, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Information reaching here from throughout Axis-dismembered Yugoslavia indicates a situation charged with distrust, unrest, terrorism and even, in some areas, virtual civil war.

The Cosmopolitan Club of New York defeated the Rockaway Hunting Club yesterday, 4 to 0, with the No. 1 players of each team postponing their match in the women's metropolitan interclub Class B squash racquets. This contest, which was played over the courts of the Rockaway Hunting Club, found only the No. 3 player, Miss Marion Raymond of Rockaway, forcing Miss Zelia Peet into four games before losing.

ROME, Nov. 18 -- The Rev. Hiram Gruber Woolf of Elmira, N.Y., rector of St. Paul's American (Episcopal) Church, was arrested thin morning by two police agents and is being held incomunicado in an unnamed prison on suspicion of intelligence activity.

Funeral services for Edward E. Spafford, former national commander of the American Legion, who died last Thursday, were delayed yesterday while his daughter and his second wife took to Supreme Court a dispute over the place of burial.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Governor Lehman cautioned labor and industry today that strikes retarded and "might eventually completely destroy" America's program of defense production.

The fifty members of the C.I.O.'s national executive board committed themselves the other day to the proposition that John L. Lewis's coal strike is more important than the national defense. No other construction can be put upon the wording of the resolution which they adopted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Because of the increasing number of non-deportable aliens, the Justice Department is planning to triple the capacity of detention camps, which hold about 2,000 aliens who have been ordered sent back to their native countries but cannot be deported for various reasons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Roosevelt indicated today his belief that further measures of economy were desirable in the field of Federal-aid highway appropriations. In a statement to his press conference he stressed that present and past legislative and executive actions in approving laws requiring approval of such appropriations by future Congresses were causing him trouble with his 1943 budget recommendations.
Two hundred delegates to the Games Committee for the Pan-American Games to be held at Buenos Aires, Argentina, Nov. 21 to Dec. 6, 1942, met last night at the New York Athletic Club.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 18 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull's statement, published here today, that his department proposed to "intensify" conferences with American oil companies was interpreted here as indicating that the United States would not sign a global agreement with Mexico omitting the oil question.

A marked rise of whooping cough among New York children was noted during the week ended last Saturday, Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, reported yesterday. New cases of the disease totaled 294 and there were three fatalities.

Luther Greene's production of "Walk Into My Parlor," a play by Alexander Greendale, winner of a Dramatists Guild-Rockefeller Foundation award for his dramatic writings, will open at the Forrest Theatre tonight at 8:40, the fourth Broadway premiere of the current Week.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 18 -- The Fourth United States Marines under Colonel Samuel L. Howard are making final preparations for their early departure from Shanghai although nothing official has been said regarding the date of their sailing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Major Gen. John N. Greely, until recently in command at Fort Sam Houston, one of the country's largest Army posts, is scheduled to leave soon for Archangel, Russian White Sea port, as the head of a large United States military mission in process of formation, responsible quarters reported today.

The New York Football Giants recalled Dick Horne, an end, from the Paterson Panthers, their farm team, yesterday to serve as a replacement for Don Vosberg, rookie, after Vosberg, who had not seen much service this season, joined the United States Navy at Norfolk, Va.
Continued activity in loft properties was noted in several reports of sales made by brokers in Manhattan yesterday.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 18 -- That good mud runners have a fondness for the soft Bowie strip even when it is fast was evidenced again today when C.E. Nelson's Rodin made a show of four rivals in the Hambleton Class C Handicap. The Chance Shot gelding had won his last race at Pimlico in mud, and he scored by eight lengths this time.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- Pennsylvania expects to be at full strength for its traditional game with Cornell at Franklin Field on Saturday, when these gridiron foes meet for the forty-eighth time.

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline along the Atlantic seaboard at the close of last week amounted to 19,013,000 barrels, a decline of 321,000 from 19,334,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Light fuel oil stocks increased an additional 333,000 barrels to another record high of 22,375,000 and heavy fuel stocks were up 280,000 to 11,523,000.

High Retail Standards Holiday jobs behind the counter are hard to get, not because they are scarce but because the requirements are so high. To qualify for a place in the department stores and specialty shops, between Thanksgiving and Christmas, the State Employment Service says that one must have an "outgoing" personality.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The diplomatic conversations looking to an adjustment of relations between the United States and Japan proceeded to a point today where the Japanese participants, Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, the Ambassador, and Saburo Kurusu, special Japanese envoy, had to refer questions to their government for instructions.

The securities, commodities and banking section of the New York Board of Trade has released the first issue of its new bulletin, called Team-Work. The first issue points out evidences that inflation is under way and declares that listed securities "representing part-ownership in America's greatest enterprises are at low prices, yielding high returns and may be obtained in a market closely supervised by an agency of the United States Government."
GARY, W.Va., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Two men were shot and wounded today as miners and pickets clashed in the first serious disorder accompanying the widespread strikes at the captive coal mines.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Nov. 18 -- After one charred body was tentatively identified today, more than fifty men began working under floodlights tonight in an effort to find five other bodies in the ruins of the Brunswick Home here, which was destroyed by fire early this morning.

BUFFALO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The New York State Teachers Association, closing its annual convention, directed its legislative committee tonight to seek passage of a bill to extend tenure to the 1,900 teachers not now covered.

Faced with sharply higher taxes and increased operating costs, the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey yesterday reduced the quarterly dividend on its common stock to 30 cents a share. The previous payment was 55 cents.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, warned yesterday that any attempt to divert sugar vessels from New York because of the strike of longshoremen against three refining companies, would spread the strike to other ports.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 19 (From official Russian sources; distributed by The Associated

THE Japanese Army, Lin Yutang says in a new book, has committed acts of almost inconceivable stupidity and bestiality in China. For this reason, if for no other, he thinks, Japan has already lost the war.

WITH THE BLUE ARMY IN THE FIELD, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- Major General H.H. Arnold, chief of the Army Air Corps, said today that the nation's air forces were using the Carolina First Army manoeuvers to test plane-ground communications based on lessons learned from the European war.

MANILA, Nov. 19 -- Joseph Stalin stood at the head of a banquet table around which American and British guests were gathered in the Kremlin one night last month and raised his glass for a toast to President Roosevelt.

Many members of society actively interested in the support of the Hartley House Music School at 413 West Forty-sixth Street attended a dinner dance given in aid of that institution last night at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- India's discontent over Prime Minister Churchill's statement that the Atlantic Charter did not apply to her was recorded today by the Indian Council of State in New Delhi, according to a Reuters message received in London.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Roosevelt today described as not a valid point John L. Lewis's principal ground for insisting upon acceptance of the union shop as a basis for settling the strike of 53,000 coal miners in the captive mines of the major steel companies.

With furniture prices now leveling off, the time has passed when ceilings would do any good, and action by the Office of Price Administration at this time would defeat its announced purpose of encouraging sales of consumer goods that do not interfere with defense production, retailers asserted yesterday.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Sergeant Hank Greenberg of the Second Infantry Anti-tank Company will end a six-month military career next Monday, thus making himself available for the Tigers' anti-Yank forces.

The Inter-Allied Information Committee, representing the Allied governments-in-exile in London charged yesterday that more than 100,000 persons had been executed to enforce Axis domination in the occupied countries of Europe.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 19 -- Cold-shouldered by minor British officials who barred them from passage to Cairo on a British Overseas Airways transport today, Maxim M. Litvinoff, Russian Ambassador to the United States, and his wife prepared to proceed tomorrow in the Russian plane that brought them here.

LONDON, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- German troops, in a new blaze of activity along the whole Russian front, have crashed through the northern flank of the Moscow defenses at Kalinin and are still advancing, Russian dispatches said today.

A world which is apt to judge a scientist by his practical accomplishments will remember Walther Nernst chiefly for the obsolete electric lamp that bears his name, his application of the electron-tube to the piano to control volume of tone, his studies of the storage battery, and his work in diathermy, which has made it possible to treat tissues and joints with electrical heat.

TOKYO, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- Japanese newspapers today reported a Japanese-Soviet armed clash last Sunday on Manchukuo's northwestern border, the second frontier skirish since Japan's Axis partner, Germany, opened war on Russia. One Russian was killed and two were taken prisoner about thirty miles from Manchuli, Domei reported.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 -- Booed on the floor of the convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations for their undisguised hostility to Philip Murray, supporters of John L. Lewis retaliated with their fists here today, beating three pro-Murray delegates and creating what the president of the Detroit C.I.O. Council denounced as a "reign of terror" in the convention headquarters at the Hotel Statler.

Despite the slowness which has marked recent merchandising of women's Fall apparel, and to some extent because of it, the Spring season in suits, better grade dresses and sports coats is getting off to an early start in the wholesale markets here.

Even the vegetarians are preparing to be bold trenchermen this Thanksgiving, although without benefit of turkey, stuffed or otherwise. Proposed holiday menus indicated yesterday that the members of various religious sects and non-affiliated individuals who eschew both fowl and flesh will have as much of a problem with leftovers as their meat-eating brethren because of an abundance of food.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- President Roosevelt called upon leaders of the U.M.W.A. and the steel corporations to leave the union shop issue in status quo for the emergency or submit it to arbitration. He nominated John M. Carmody to be a member of the Maritime Commission and Captain Thomas C. Kinkaid to be a rear admiral in the Navy for temporary service.

Miss Jenny Hunter, petite, 85-year-old daughter of Hunter College's first president, received tribute yesterday from all grades of Hunter students, from "gifted children" aged 3 1/2, to college students, at an assembly dedicated to her in the Park Avenue college building.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Leopold S. Amery, Secretary of State for India, in a speech at Manchester today declared that Great Britain could not undertake any immediate solution of the problem of Dominion status for India. He reiterated there must first be substantial agreement among the various Indian factions on the main principles of a constitution.

WITH A BRITISH ARMORED FORCE, in the Western Desert, Nov. 19 -- The British Army is sweeping forward today in the opening phases of the most heavily mounted offensive it has yet launched on land in this war. In the number of tanks, planes and men available it is the most formidable force the British have been able to throw against the Axis.
Five hundred youngsters registered ear-splitting enthusiasm yesterday for two American "institutions" -- ice cream and their country's flag.

Herbert Newton, 37 years old, a discharged Negro WPA teacher of 1013 Kent Avenue, Brooklyn, who is vice president of the WPA Teachers Union, was found guilty last night in General Sessions of third-degree assault. He was convicted of having punched a plain-clothes patrolman while he was picketing Mayor La Guardia's home at 1274 Fifth Avenue on July 18.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A $22,000,000 contract for the manufacture of aluminum and a $9,000,000 contract for the manufacture of copper were announced today by Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Charging that the Hegeler Zinc Company of Danville, Ill., had violated an agreement concluded last February between OPA officials and primary zinc producers, Leon Henderson today said that the infraction had made possible gross profiteering and inflation of prices and suggested that buyers of the zinc might explore possibilities of recovering for what he termed "over payments."

Declaring that an informed public is our first line of defense, Emmett F. Connely, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, called yesterday for greater frankness on the part of the government in telling the American people about our foreign policy.

A PHENOMENAL novel called "Storm"* comes out this morning. The author is that phenomenal Professor of English, George R. Stewart of the University of California, author also of "Bret Harte," "Ordeal by Hunger," "East of the Giants," etc. Mr. Stewart is said to regard it as his most important book to date. It seems to me one of the most remarkable books of the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, told a press conference here today that a reported statement by Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, to the effect that the government had recognized the union at the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, Kearny, N.J., gave a false impression.

The name Sande, known to racegoers on both sides of the Atlantic, may soon again be on the lips of thousands who cheer a horse through the homestretch. Not that Earl is coming back to the saddle, from which he retired in 1928, following which he was called to ride Gallant Fox throughout his triumphant year of 1930.

Paul J. Kern, president of the unicipal Civil Service Commission, announced a five-man board yesterday to hold the civil service examination for Sheriff under the new law which consolidates the five Sheriffs' offices into one unit.

Slower buying of dresses has found reflection in slackening demand for rayon finished goods, according to market reports yesterday, and several of the top prices which had been paid during the last few weeks were said to have eased off.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Nov. 19 -- Spreading strikes in commercial coal mines, described by union leaders here today as spontaneous gestures of sympathy with the striking captive miners, turned out to be largely inexplicable to many captive miners themselves.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The situation surrounding the diplomatic conversations looking to an adjustment of relations between Japan and the United States remained completely uncertain today as the Japanese diplomats, Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, the Ambassador, and Saburo Kurusu, the special envoy, awaited instructions from their government in response to questions arising out of the first two days of discussion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Consolidated Electric and Gas Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for approval of a plan to simplify the concern's corporate structure and to redistribute voting power more equitably among its security holders.

With traditional contests holding the center of the stage, more than sixty schoolboy football games are scheduled for gridirons in New York City, Westchester, Long Island and New Jersey today. Many of the teams will be closing their seasons, and virtually all of the games are listed for the forenoon.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Giraud van Nest Foster have arrived from Lenox, Mass., and are at the Westbury.

Alpha Portland Cement The Alpha Portland Cement Company announced a dividend declaration of $1.25 a share. This will make a total of $2 distributed to stockholders this year, against $1.50 paid in 1940.

A considerable amount of private construction work can and probably will be carried out despite the recent government controls placed on prices and purchases of materials, in the opinion of Peter A. Stone, price executive of the lumber and building materials section of the Office of Price Administration.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 19 -- In view of recent requests by the Office of Civilian Defense for economy in the use of paper, members of municipal defense councils in Essex County wondered today why they had been virtually snowed under by "America Calling" posters sent them by the OCD.

Total bank clearings for twenty-three leading cities of the United States for the week ended yesterday were $7,895,898,000, or 17 per cent more than the $6,748,673,000 for the similar period last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19 -- In another closed practice session on Thompson Field, adjoining the Bowl, where last Saturday it lost to Princeton, Yale's football squad worked again until darkness today toward the final objective of the season, the sixtieth meeting with Harvard in Cambridge Saturday.
Boys in the lower elementary grades were poorer readers than girls in a three-year project in reading conducted at P.S. 168, Manhattan, and P.S. 47, the Bronx, it was disclosed yesterday.

Four Negro youths were arrested early yesterday and the previous night in connection with the murder of Joseph Keelan, 32-year-old laundry worker, in Morningside Park early on the morning of Nov. 6. This was one of the two killings that centered public attention on crime conditions in lower Harlem, the north part of Central Park and adjacent streets and parks.

Official circles in Washington nave given unqualified support to the first Pan American Games scheduled from Nov. 21 to Dec. 6 of next year in Buenos Aires, Argentina. This was emphasized at a luncheon attended by the nation's amateur sports leaders at the New York A.C. yesterday.

Stout Steve Owen ordinarily confines himself to the basic business of instructing his football Giants in how to block and tackle, throw forward passes and make the proper getaway with the ball, but yesterday he went in for a bit of extracurricular activity in preparing his charges for their highly important game against the Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds next Sunday.
Sales so far at the Art Week exhibition at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street totaled $3,300 yesterday afternoon and include paintings, sculpture, prints and ceramics.

With all the trimmings needed to make the Thanksgiving Day clash one of the East's outstanding gridiron meetings, Manhattan will bring to a close its season by meeting Georgetown this afternoon at the Polo Grounds. The colorful gridiron rivalry, started in 1933 and resumed after a lapse of two seasons, is expected to attract 20,000 spectators.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Prices of hogs closed steady in slow trading today after local packers and out-of-city buyers had raised the top 5 cents to $10.40 a hundred-weight in early dealings. Dressed pork was steady to weak. Light loins remained unchanged. In the cattle section most classes were up 25 cents.

For the third time in the eleven years since tragedy struck down Knute Rockne in the prime of his phenomenally successful career at Notre Dame, the Fighting Irish come down unbeaten to the Southern California game this week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Bernard M. Baruch, who was World War Price Administrator, endorsed the Gore Price Control Bill today ins preference to the House Banking and Currency Committtee measure and called for full and effective legislation which would make each segment of the population, a participant in the national defense program and cause sacrifice to be the rule rather than the advantage.
Nairobi, Kenya, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The British Army and Air Force issued this combined communique today:

FORT WASHINGTON, Pa., Nov. 19 -- The Chancefield Flush of Earlsmoor Trophy was awarded to Robert McLean of Fort Washington today as the owner and handler of Flight of Falcon Hill, who gave the best performance in the amateur gunner-handler stake, next to final event of the three-day meeting of the Valley Forge Field Trial Association on the Pheasant Run Game Farm.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman dedicated yesterday the new wing and entrance of St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Fort Washington Avenue and 190th Street. The improvements recently were completed at a cost of $125,000.

ROME, Nov. 19 -- The American colony of Rome will have its Thanksgiving service tomorrow morning even though the Italian authorities have arrested the only American Protestant clergyman in Italy, the Rev. Hiram Gruber Woolf, who remained incomunicado in the Regina Coeli Prison today.

The Weather Man said he'd like to help, but Thanksgivings nowadays were different. Last night's charts indicated the temperature in town may go to around 68 or 70 degrees by noon today. Even up-State there will be no holiday sleighing.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Regardless of how convinced the coal strike leaders are as to the merits of their case, they have apparently not succeeded in convincing the public that their action in calling the strike was justified.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 19 -- Dr. Paul Schmidt, the Wilhelmstrasse press chief, left Ankara for Berlin this evening. He will fly to the German capital from Istanbul accompanied by the five-man press delegation that arrived in Ankara with him three days ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The first armed American merchant ships will go to sea in a week or ten days and others will follow in rapid succession, as soon as they can go into ports and be fitted with weapons, Secretary Knox stated today.

The Central National Art Week exhibition at the American Fine Arts Building will be open this afternoon from 1 to 6 o'clock. Oils, water-colors, etchings and ceramics are included in this show, one of many being held, but the only one open today, in art galleries, department stores and shops in all five boroughs during Art Week.

The Newsdealers Federal Labor Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, renewed yesterday its boycott against seven morning and evening newspapers in this city, tying up hundreds of newsstands so far as the sale of such papers was concerned.

Mrs. Eleanor Elkins Rice, wife of Dr. Alexander Hamilton Rice, surgeon, geographer and explorer, left an estate valued at $15,462,897 gross and $14,284,276 net, according to the estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday. Mrs. Rice, who was the daughter of William L. Elkins and formerly the wife of George D. Widener, Philadelphia traction man who lost his life on the Titanic, died in Paris on July 13, 1937.

The Argentine Information Bureau in New York disclosed yesterday that Argentina was ready to place in service the sixteen former Italian freighters, requisitioned earlier this year, to expand the country's merchant marine.

HAVANA, Nov. 19 -- The second inter-American conference of Committees on Intellectual Cooperation today resolved to establish an institute for intellectual cooperation in some country of the Americas for the duration of the war to take over the functions of the Paris Institute, which is now in German hands.

A Federal judge looked back of the superficial aspects of the case of "the Candy Kid" in Federal Court yesterday, and what he saw led him to free the culprit. On the surface, the culprit was a fellow who, when in need of money, took it from the vaults of the bank he worked in.

Indictment of Irving Feinberg of Willow Road, Woodmere, L.I., former president and chairman of the American Beverage Corporation, on a charge of defrauding that company of several hundred thousand dollars was announced yesterday by James J. Caffrey, regional administrator of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and United States Attorney Harold M. Kennedy.

Mr. and Mrs. Harvey S. Firestone Jr. of Akron, Ohio, and this city gave a ball last night at the Ritz-Carlton to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Firestone. It was the first large debutante dance of the Autumn here.

The Navy's intensive shipbuilding program dramatically "hit its stride" here yesterday in scenes reminiscent of World War days as one 1,630-ton destroyer went down the ways of the Bethlehem Steel Company yards in Staten Island, the keel of a second man-of-war was laid even before the new ship was fully in the water and preparations were completed for the twin launchings of two more destroyers in near-by Kearny, N.J., on Saturday morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Strong opposition was reported in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today to a proposed treaty with Britain providing for exemption of taxation of all British property or transactions in this country connected with defense, in return for a reciprocal exemption on United States defense properties and transactions in Britain.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 19 -- The Cunningham brothers and a fellow named Coningham have teamed up to make things hot for the Axis in North Africa.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- John M. Carmody, Federal Works Administrator and a veteran of the New Deal, was nominated today by President Roosevelt to be a member of the Maritime Commission.

The experiment by which President-Manager Red Dutton discarded his team's New York identification for a Brooklyn tag gets its first real trial tonight in Madison Square Garden when the Americans engage the Rangers in the opening struggle of the series involving metropolitan supremacy and the William J. Macbeth Memorial Trophy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The United States Government today formally agreed to stabilize the Mexican peso, buy large fixed amounts of Mexican silver and finance an extensive Mexican road-building program. In exchange Mexico agreed to pay $37,000,000 over a period of fourteen years to settle all agrarian and "general" claims of American nationals, to make a trade agreement and to attempt to negotiate a settlement of the petroleum expropriation controversy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a volume "Story Sermons for Juniors" which was in its third printing when I purchased mine, by the Rev. Dr. Alfred Sadler, minister of the First Presbyterian Church of Jersey City, I find something new to me about our national holiday.

Many citizens are disappointed that the President did not act instantly when John L. Lewis and his supporters deliberately defied the Government, denounced the mediation machinery it had set up and in which they had participated, and called a strike that, if prolonged, must cripple the defense program.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- The Westchester County Sheriff's office should be restrained from carrying out its avowed intention of destroying United States money that had been seized in a gambling raid, even though the law does specify that "everything suitable for gambling purposes" must be destroyed in such raids, a county court referee said today in a 5,200-word report to Judge Frank H. Coyne.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Nov. 19 -- On the fringe of the war manoeuvre area, this city, a hot-spot of housing problems, is enjoying a respite from daily invasion by soldiers while the Red and Blue forces are battling in South Carolina fields, but residents suspect that it won't be for long.

Recommendations urging the rezoning of twenty-one Manhattan areas and the retention of present classifications for four others will shortly be made by the Twenty-third Street Association to the City Planning Commission and the Manhattan Borough President's office, it was announced yesterday.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

When Columbia and Colgate haul off for the final game of the year for both teams on Baker Field Saturday ten men in the starting lineup will be vocalizing "Auld Lang Syne," doubtless without tears in their voices.

Paul Henri Spaak, Foreign Minister of the Belgian Government-in-Exile, and Jan van den Tempel, Minister of Social Affairs for the Netherlands Government-in-Exile, who represented their governments at the International Labor Conference here recently, were among the twenty transatlantic passengers aboard the Yankee Clipper when it left for Lisbon yesterday morning.

Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, who rose side by side with Louis (Lepka) Buchalter from strong-arming pushcart peddlers on the East Side to extorting $1,000,000 annually through industrial racketeering, has been secretly brought from the Federal penitentiary at Atlanta as a potential witness in behalf of his old partner now on trial for murder.

The Feather and Hair Export Company, importers, exporters and general dealers in feathers, leased the two-story building at 242 Monitor Street, Brooklyn, from Helen A. Hughes. Its former quarters at 624 Kent Avenue were taken in connection with the expansion program of the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

The Committee for National Morale, the research organization of military and political scientists, sociologists and historians that seeks to utilize and publicize the lessons taught by the fall of France, is working out a book for Farrar Rinehart to be called "The German War Plans:

The city of Montgomery, Ala., will enter the market on next Tuesday with an issue of $1,390,000 of refunding bonds, for which bidders are asked to specify a rate of interest. The bonds will mature on Jan. 1, 1969 to 1972.

Electric power output declined again last week, but was still greater than any week prior to that of Oct. 11. The decline was contrary to the normal seasonal trend and the adjusted index dropped to 121.8 from 123.1 for the week ended Nov. 8.
Apartment buildings on the East Side obtained the bulk of new renters in the latest lists of leases issued yesterday by managing agents and brokers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Investment Bankers Association appealed today to Congress to increase the $100,000 exemption on registration of new securities with the Securities and Exchange Commission in order to remove hardships on small businesses.

Sinclair Lewis and Lewis Browne, the authors, kept a Town Hall audience amused for an hour yesterday, while Mr. Browne spoke for the affirmative and Mr. Lewis the negative on the question: "Has the Modern Woman Made Good?" Women composed about 99 per cent of the gathering.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 20 -- British tank and motorized forces, strongly supported by planes, have begun a big-scale offensive against the German and Italian positions in Libya. They struck on a front extending southward from a point on the Mediterranean coast slightly east of Solum, Egypt, to Jarabub.

In the absence of any official notification from the State Department in Washington, oil executives here refused yesterday to comment on the settlement arranged between the United States and Mexican Governments for their claims growing out of the seizure of their properties in Mexico in March, 1938.

If a man is going to be a professional playwright he has to begin somewhere. Alexander Greendale has begun with a slavish imitation of Clifford Odets's "Awake and Sing!" He calls it "Walk Into My Parlor," and it was put on at the Forrest last evening in a performance directed in imitation of the Group Theatre.

Isaac Stern, youthful violinist from San Francisco, again made a vivid impression at his recital given last night in Town Hall. Mr. Stern possesses more than the usual amount of intelligence, inborn musicianship and a facile technique of finger and bow, which combined with a voluminous, vibrant tone resulted in performances that rated far above the average.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Following are the texts of the letter which President Roosevelt sent today to executives of steel companies owning coal mines and to John L. Lewis, head of the United Mine Workers, and the replies thereto:

BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- Heavy fighting now seems to be in progress on the Moscow and Rostov fronts, judging from the latest German reports available here, and the Germans and Russians are battling day and night for every yard of ground.

Three midtown theatres will present new attractions today. At the Radio City Music Hall the new picture will be "Suspicion," an RKO melodrama directed by Alfred Hitchcock and starring Cary Grant and Joan Fontaine. Based on the Francis Iles novel, "Before the Fact," the film features Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Dame May Whitty, Nigel Bruce, Heather Angel and Isobel Jeans....

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Spain and France are cooperating with the Germans in propaganda in Latin America, United States officials reported today. A memorandum outlining German activity in Latin America noted "a very definite lull in German propaganda activities," and "a corresponding increase of activities by Spanish and to a less extent by French elements."

At weight and in top condition, Ken Overlin and Al Hostak, former world middleweight champions, yesterday concluded training for their ten-round bout tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden, a battle which is to determine which of the two is to merit consideration as a 175-pound championship possibility.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 19 -- On his return to Buenos Aires from Chile this afternoon, Brazilian Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha declared that he considered another conference of Foreign Ministers of all the American republics, similar to those held in Panama and Havana, urgently necessary.

Though ex-President Hoover did not propose peace negotiations in his address last night in Chicago, the only logical conclusion to be drawn from his argument is that the time has come to talk with Hitler. He finds "every indication that the war in Europe is a military stalemate" -- not for the time being but "for the foreseeable future."

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 20 -- Confronted with the delicate task of maintaining an "immutable" fundamental policy, Japanese diplomacy habitually works with abstruse but flexible formulas open to many interpretations. Thus the statements made in the Diet by Premier Hideki Tojo and Foreign Minister Shigenori Togo suggest a certain modification of Japan's "greater East Asia" program that may have an important bearing on the Washington negotiations.

Holiday Although sixteen States of the Union will not observe Thanksgiving Day until next Thursday, all the important securities and commodity markets are in the States that are observing the holiday today, and therefore will be closed.

The long-awaited new offensive by the British in North Africa has apparently begun, and under circumstances which indicate that it possesses those qualities of surprise used so skillfully by Allied forces in that theatre before, and a striking power which may finally challenge the last Axis strongholds in Africa.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 18:

Deaths Announced Retired Fireman Daniel A. Burns, formerly a member of Engine Co. 19. residing at 432 East 80th St., Manhattan, died Nov. 18. Funeral will take place from Oates Funeral Parlor, 209 East 83d St., Manhattan, at 9:30 A.M., Friday, Nov. 21.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Nov. 20 -- Slashing down the Don Valley from Novocherkassk, German forces at dawn yesterday launched a terrific offensive against Russian defenses before Rostov in an "all-out" attempt to break through the "northern gate" to the Caucasus.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The destruction of four divisions of Col. Gen. Paul Ludwig von Kleist's German Army in a flaming trap on the Don, barrier to the North Caucasus, and the recapture of important heights in Crimea were announced tonight in Soviet military dispatches.
The East and the West were divided yesterday on the advisability of mixing marriage and a career.

The stock market threw off yesterday some of its timidness and turned in the best performance so far this week. The bulk of the day's business was in the final hour of trading and the heavy volume during this period raised the day's transfers on the Stock Exchange to 800,960 shares from Tuesday's turnover of 678,800.

Jim Crowley gave his new Fordham backfield combinations the acid test of competition yesterday as the Ram varsity and cubs met in more than an hour of regular scrimmage, the first such contact work in six weeks. Although the varsity pushed over five touchdowns, the coaches were not entirely pleased with the performance, the blocking particularly not being all that they desired.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Two years of blockade has exerted such pressure on Germany's supply of textiles that the effect is at last beginning to show in the German Army and Navy, in the opinion of the Ministry of Economic Warfare.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 19 (AP) -- British General Headquarters here tonight issued the following communique:

A proposal that American Catholics unite in a movement to urge the canonization of John Henry Cardinal Newman, whose lifetime spanned almost the entire nineteenth century, is made in the Nov. 22 issue of America, national Catholic weekly, by Father Charles J. Callan, Dominican friar of this city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The ouster of General Maxime Weygand as commander of the French forces in North Africa is expected to lead to the suspension of American aid to that area, at least until its full implications are understood.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 19 -- Vintage Port, an English-bred gray gelding that flies the Sanford Stud Farm's silks, held on in tenacious fashion to eke out a head triumph over the lightly backed Bala Ormont, from the E.D. Axton Barn, in the St. Inigoes Purse today.

Holiday theatregoers will have their choice this afternoon of twenty-one Broadway offerings. These, of course, do not comprise the entire list of current shows, as five prefer to be idle this afternooon. Here are the matinees (thirteen of them are non-musical and eight are musical):

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Prospects for averting a nation-wide strike of 1,150,000 railroad workers on Dec. 7 were brighter tonight as President Roosevelt arranged at a two-hour conference for a resumption of negotiations on Friday between officials of the workers and the operators.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 19 -- Rich coal fields, vital to the defense effort, were crippled tonight by "outlaw" walkouts. Overshadowing the walkout of 53,000 miners from the captive shafts was the "holiday" taken by about 92,500 miners in four States from commercial and from five captive mines which already have granted the union shop to the United Mine Workers.
The New England hunting season, now drawing to a close in most of its States, seems to have been unusually successful, especially for the grouse and deer hunters.
Sales of loft properties in Manhattan by lending institutions continued yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 19 -- While heavy rain turned the desert dust into a pasty gumbo yesterday, Britain's Eighth Army, under the command of the conqueror of the Italian East Africa, Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan Gordon Cunningham, and led by armored divisions, attacked on a 130-mile front and slogged westward into Libya.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Two groups -- the Typewriter Manufacturers Export Association and the American Pulp Export Corporation -- have filed papers with the Federal Trade Commission under the Export Trade Act, it was announced today.

Trading in fresh meats, though only fair, was somewhat better yesterday than the trade anticipated, considering the interest displayed in poultry for the Thanksgiving holiday trade. Steer hinds and ribs showed another advance, with the market now around $1 higher than last week. Cow beef was higher, lamb and fresh pork cuts steady to lower, other classes steady.

At your request 'for the common good, for the maintenance of defense production' our coal mining subsidiaries will accept either of the two alternatives set forth in your letter of today to Messrs. Fairless, Grace and Purnell, and to the United Mine Workers of America.

In homes all over the nation -- except in those where tradition delays Thanksgiving until next week -- the old and the young, the aunts and the uncles, the nephews and the nieces will gather today to celebrate a holiday whose origin goes back to our earliest days.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 19 -- Brown and Rutgers drilled on Brown field this afternoon in final preparation for tomorrow's Thanksgiving Day game. The home eleven ruled a slight favorite tonight.

Although Clarence (Pug) Manders, the Dodger fullback, continues to lead the ground-gainers in the National Football League, Clarke Hinkle, the Green Bay veteran, is very much in the running for top honors in this department. Official figures, released yesterday, show Manders to be in first place for the seventh consecutive week, but his margin over Hinkle, the runner-up, has been reduced to 44 yards.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- A new contract embodying the recommendations of the emergency fact-finding board appointed by President Roosevelt was signed today by representatives of the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Brotherhood of Railroad Shop Crafts of America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Foreign trade data by countries for September, released today by the Department of Commerce, show that exports totaled $417,000,000, well above the average reported for the first eight months of the year and 40 per cent higher than in September of last year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The State Department's text embodying the agreements between the United States and Mexico signed here today follows:
Magistrate Anna M. Kross in the Homicide Court defended newspapers yesterday against charges that they had given too much publicity to crime in Harlem.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Car manufacturers were instructed today to cut passenger automobile production in February at least 56.1 per cent below the levels for last February. The decision came from the Automotive Defense Advisory Committee who met with Leon Henderson, director of the division of civilian supply of the Office of Production Management.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 19 -- The feeling that war with Japan is inevitable is growing among many leaders in Singapore because of the statements of Japanese leaders in the last few days and the tenor of Japanese public opinion.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 19 -- Mexican officials today expressed themselves as highly pleased by the agreement with the United States. It is generally regarded here as a diplomatic victory for Mexico, since Washington has accepted Mexican terms that the American companies twice rejected.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Steel company executives accepted tonight, and John L. Lewis rejected an appeal by President Roosevelt to submit their differences on the union shop in the captive mines to binding arbitration or postpone the issue until the end of the national emergency.

The Workers Alliance, formed about ten years ago by left wing elements with the purpose of serving the interests of the unemployed and relief recipients, has been dissolved as a national organization, it was announced yesterday. The announcement marked the end of the organization's stormy career, during which it frequently was charged with being Communist-controlled.

VICHY, France, Nov. 19 -- A law promulgated today sets up the French Legion as "the only organization for civic action open to citizens desirous of associating themselves with war veterans in order to serve the principles of National Revolution and of ensuring their application in all fields."

Hence the Delay General Udet, second only to Goering in Nazi aviation, was killed while experimenting with a new type of firearm. It sends the mind back to Hitler's secret weapon. He announced it more than a year ago as the trick that would settle England's business.

The Continental Oil Company announced yesterday that it will issue a call soon for redemption of a minimum of $11,000,000 of its ten-year 2 3/4 per cent debentures due on Dec. 15, 1948, of which $21,071,600 is outstanding. After Dec. 15 next these debentures are callable at 102, plus accrued interest on forty days' notice.

Brokers who use for their own account, even temporarily, funds deposited with them by customers for the purchase of prospective security issues are acting illegally, Attorney General John J. Bennett ruled yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Despite the independent moves in Congress and the pledges of Administration spokesmen at the Capitol, Congress may continue to be deprived of an opportunity to vote for effective legislation to minimize defense industry stoppages. The link between promises and acts often turns up missing.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Corn made a relatively small response today to the announcement that the government loan on the 1941 crop would show a national average of 74.8 cents a bushel, compared with 61 cents last year. Prices advanced around 1 1/4 cents a bushel early, but the market ran into selling and at one time much of the upturn was lost.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 19 -- Robert Young was named today for the starring role in "Journey for Margaret," W.L. White's account of his adoption of a British war orphan, which Metro has purchased for Winter production. The author, son of William Allen White, went to London as a newspaper correspondent and brought back an 8-year-old girl whom he and his wife have adopted.
VAN NUYS, Calif., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Trapped in a 7,000-foot railroad tunnel, five men perished today as a Southern Pacific locomotive burst into flames and turned the bore into an inferno.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A total of 112 new two-engined aircraft has been allotted to commercial airlines for 1942, the Civil Aircraft Committee, the aircraft branch of the Office of Production Management, announced today. Decision regarding the number of four-motored planes to be allocated to the commercial lines will be made at a later date.
ALBANY, Nov. 19 -- The Adjutant General released the following orders today:
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

Strategic manoeuvres in the War on Waste in the kitchen were outlined yesterday before members of the Jewish Federation of Women's Clubs by Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon, director of the Bureau of Consumer Service of the Department of Markets of New York City.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES of Nov. 13 you published a report of the meeting of the Episcopal Pacifist Fellowship entitled "United States Camps Urged to Train Pacifists." You quoted some things I said favoring the establishment of government camps for conscientious objectors.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES of Nov. 13 you published a report of the meeting of the Episcopal Pacifist Fellowship entitled "United States Camps Urged to Train Pacifists." You quoted some things I said favoring the establishment of government camps for conscientious objectors.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Australian Imperial Forces in Malaya were strengthened today by the arrival of a large contingent, which included infantrymen, airmen, technical auxiliaries and a group of nurses.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The American Civil Liberties Union and a score of Los Angeles County religious leaders intervened today in the controversy surrounding the two-year sentence of Henry Welty Kuhns as a draft law violator after classification as a conscientious objector had been refused him.

Hard on Hamilton Taking one consideration with another, Alexander Hamilton's fate at the hands of present-day writers is not a happy one. People do not find it easy to be fair to the man who, when all is said and done, did write a very considerable part of The Federalist.

EDENBORN, Pa., Nov. 20 -- Bitterness between pickets and a Negro coal loader who insisted on getting to work at the H.C. Frick Coke Company Mine led to the first shooting of the five-day-old strike here this morning.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Virginia Military Institute fused its team play with flaming courage to defeat a more powerful Virginia Tech football team today, 15 to 10, before 20,000 in one of the best-played games of their long Thanksgiving Day rivalry.
Blonde and brown-eyed Betty Ortquist has been elected Hunter College's new beauty queen, it has been announced at the college.

Reorganization of faculty government at City College to facilitate administration and provide greater unity among the several schools of the college, was announced yesterday by Harry N. Wright, the acting president.

The boycott of seven newspapers by the Newsdealers Federal Labor Union continued yesterday as the dealers prepared to challenge the complaint filed by the publishers with the State attorney general's office charging that the boycott was in restraint of trade, contrary to the Donnelly State anti-trust law.

Direct transatlantic air service to Ireland, with planes flying through the war zone, previously banned to American traffic by the Neutrality Act, will be resumed in the immediate future, it was announced yesterday by the Pan American Airways System.

ATLANTA, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Chancellor S.V. Sanford said today that L.W. Robert Jr. met at the Atlanta Municipal Airport with seven other members of the Board of Regents last night and concurred in their move to rehire ten University of Georgia educators ousted at the direction of Governor Talmadge.
