BOSTON, Nov. 20 -- Status for Palestine as unequivocally a Jewish commonwealth after the war and authority to form immediately a Jewish military force to fight under its own flag was requested today in a formal declaration to the British Government by Junior Hadassah, the young women's Zionist organization of America, as its annual national convention opened.

TRENTON, Nov. 20 -- Representatives of labor and management joined today in pledging any sacrifice to insure the preservation of democracy at exercises in the War Memorial Building here celebrating the 152d anniversary of the ratification of the Bill of Rights by New Jersey and the 150th anniversary of the completion of ratification by the other States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A simplification of the procedure under which manufacturers will get preference ratings for materials necessary for their defense and essential civilian production is expected to be announced here early next week by the Division of Priorities of the Office of Production Management.

When Brooklyn Prep and St. John's Prep collided in the twenty-fourth game of their old series at Brooklyn College Field yesterday, both were endeavoring to salvage something from disappointing seasons. But at the end of four well-played and bristling periods, neither team had crossed the other's goal line.

More effective organization of the labor market, offering new, efficient hiring channels for New York City employers who are facing labor stringencies for the first time in years, will be in operation after Dec. 1, Milton O. Loysen, director of the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department, announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Nov. 20 -- The text of the resolution adopted by the C.I.O. convention today, calling on President Roosevelt to scrap the no-strike building stabilization agreement with the A.F.L., and denouncing the OPM and its officers, read as follows:

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- United States Ambassador Claude G. Bowers said today that he had called his government's attention to an "outrageous" dispatch referring to President Pedro Aguirre Cerda in the Nov. 17 Latin-American issue of the magazine Time.

The street attacks and hold-ups in Harlem that started a police drive against crime recently flared up again last night when a 51-year-old man was attacked by two Negro youths at 125th Street and Morningside Avenue.
VALLEY COTTAGE, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- Forty modern Pilgrims -- exiles from their Russian homeland -- sat down gratefully today to a Thanksgiving dinner made from their first harvest in a free world.
It was 20 degrees above normal for the date in the city yesterday, and much of the East Coast experienced a similarly mild Thanksgiving. West of the Appalachians it was colder.

Two hundred and fifty boys and girls, costumed as their fancies dicated, paraded through midtown Manhattan, yesterday at noon in the sixteenth annual Thanksgiving Day ceremony of the Madison Square Boys' Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A sharp increase in shipments of food and other agricultural products to England was disclosed today as officials made public the first breakdown of supplies actually sent.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- British warships in the Mediterranean have sunk or damaged four more Axis ships in the Libyan supply service and have destroyed a German submarine that "almost certainly" helped sink the aircraft carrier Ark Royal, the Admiralty announced today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 20 (AP) -- American-armed British tank units smashing as far as eighty miles inside Libya in a great encircling movement were reported officially tonight to be only ten miles short of besieged Tobruk's outer defenses after having smashed an Italian tank force in the first major test of United States war materials.
A veteran of the last war led the parade in the Walkers' Club of America's thirty-first annual handicap race from City Hall to Coney Island yesterday and another one brought up the rear.

VICHY, France, Nov. 20 -- The outstanding feature of the campaign in Russia, in the view of competent observers here, is that, apart from the Crimea, there has been relatively little change since the first of this month. Consequently there is much talk now of a war of position.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Sophia M.R. O'Hara, a whitehaired spinster who reads detective stories for relaxation, tackled without emotion today the grim task of deciding the fate of two men condemned to die.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Defense officials hinted tonight that legislation would be offered for government seizure of the closed captive coal mines.

BOONVILLE, Mo., Nov. 20 -- Ralph Conger, coach of the Wentworth Military Academy football team, collapsed today during a traditional Thanksgiving Day game with Kemper Military Academy and died shortly afterward in a truck on the way to a hospital.

BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- With the first news of the British offensive in North Africa, military interest here was abruptly switched today from the snow-covered plains of Russia to the desert wastes of Libya. The German High Command, in its usual laconic way, stated that "strong British forces" that on Tuesday had launched an offensive south and southwest of Sidi Omar were beaten back with heavy losses by immediate counterattacks of German and Italian units.

DETROIT, Nov. 21 -- The convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations called on President Roosevelt today to scrap the no strike stabilization agreement made by the Office of Production Management with the American Federation of Labor on defense construction projects, but killed a demand by supporters of John L. Lewis for the ouster of Sidney Hillman from his post of Associate Director of OPM.

ABOARD THE FLAGSHIP OF THE MEDITERRANEAN FLEET, off Libya, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The flash of big British naval guns mingled with stabs of lightning during a violent thunderstorm early Tuesday morning as hundreds of high explosives were pumped into German and Italian bases on the Libyan shore to aid a huge British land drive westward across the desert.

BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- Today's communique of the German High Command exercised its usual reserve in regard to the scope of operations and progress in various sectors of the Russian front. But Berlin spokesmen declared that for those familiar with the technique of German military reporting there could be no doubt as to the magnitude of these operations.
VICHY, France, Nov. 20 -- The text of the official summary of the report of Vice Premier Francois Darlan explaining the retirement of General Maxine Weygand follows:

Georgetown pieced together two passes that spanned 45 yards to the goal line, and with that firstperiod touchdown turned bach Manhattan College at football before 12,000 at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 21 -- The British Eighth Army moved yesterday through German and Italian positions toward besieged Tobruk on the third day of the offensive in Libya, and it was announced today that Rezegh, ten miles from Tobruk's outer defenses, had been taken.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, asked today for legislation to control industrial wages and for sharply increased taxes to curb Inflation and finance two-thirds of the national defense cost out of current revenues.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 20 (AP) -- William and Mary employed an offense based on sheer power -- with 200-pound Harvey Johnson as the main battering ram -- to crush a battling University of Richmond football team, 33 -- 3, before 12,000 spectators today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Industrial activity continued to increase in October and the first half of November and there was some further advance in prices of industrial materials and finished products, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The Russian line above Moscow appeared today to be bending back under the shock of one of a series of strong new German offensives all about the capital, but the southern Red Army anchor was reported holding firm at Tula against violent tank and infantry assaults.

It is a sheer feast to the ear when the Boston Symphony Orchestra comes to town. Playing and conducting of the highest order are customarily the rule when Dr. Serge Koussevitzky and his men officiate. The public satisfaction in their accomplishment is shown as it was shown last night by the audience which packed Carnegie Hall and congested the boxes and galleries and acclaimed the performances.

Macy's eighteenth annual flight into fantasy -- its Thanksgiving Day parade -- weaved and bobbed down Central Park West and Broadway before an estimated 1,000,000 amused and excited on-lookers, a large part of them small fry, for a mile or more and half an hour yesterday just after noon on one of the best days it ever has drawn in the weather lottery.

LONDON, NOV. 20 (U.P.) -- Foreign Under-Secretary Richard K. Law expressed the government's regret today for the "unintentional discourtesy" shown Maxim M. Litvinoff, new Russian Ambassador to the United States, by the British Overseas Airways in Iran.

BERLIN, Nov. 20, (U.P.) -- Tropaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels says in an article written for next Saturday's issue of the magazine Reich that the destruction of the British Empire will take more than "a few months."
LONDON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique today said:

LONDON, Nov. 20, (AP) -- For the twelfth consecutive week, note circulation as reported by the Bank of England for the week ending yesterday established a new high record. The sum was u706,697,000, an increase of u2,662,000 in the week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Faced with the spreading "sympathy" stoppages of coal production essential for national defense, President Roosevelt was reported tonight to be nearing the point of cracking down on John L. Lewis to fulfill his "indisputable obligation" to end the walkout of 53,000 men in the captive mines, but he was said to be hopeful that he could avoid use of the Army to break the strike.

Many changes caused by marriage and divorce appear in the listing of prominent families of this city in the New York Social Register for 1942, Which is now being delivered to subscribers. Several notable omissions of names also occur.

ROME, Nov. 20 -- The American colony in Rome celebrated Thanksgiving today without benefit of clergy, bewildered and worried by the arrest of their only Protestant pastor and by the realization that some of their Italian friends were under suspicion.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Scoring all their goals in the second period, the Black Hawks held second place in the National Hockey League tonight with a 3-to-2 victory over Boston before 18,222 spectators at the Stadium.
NEW YORK Mrs. J. Borden Harriman has arrived from Washington and is at the Ritz-Carlton.

Every program for non-defense economies in the Federal budget that has thus far been brought forward has shown that there can be no substantial savings without a cut in the Government's program of aids to agriculture. Secretary Morgenthau, in his recent statement before the joint committee of Congress on non-defense expenditures, gave some strong reasons why such a cut is justifiable at this time.

There should be no hesitation on the part of any American in responding to the Red Cross roll-call. President Roosevelt has appealed for a membership of eighteen million, and in this eleventh hour of our preparation for a vast emergency that figure seems modest, indeed.

KUNMING, China, Nov. 4 -- (By Air Mail) -- The Burma Road is all it is reputed to be -- the world's most spectacular and vital wartime highway -- and more. I have just ridden over great stretches of it and flown over other parts. It is a "boom road" today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Striking four times through the air and twice on the ground with offensives that baffled George Washington, Wake Forest routed the Colonials, 42-0, before 5,000 spectators today.

DETROIT, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Toronto captured its fifth straight victory and maintained its National Hockey League lead by defeating the Red Wings, 4 to 3, in an overtime game tonight before a sell-out crowd of 12,581.
SAYBROOK, Conn., Nov. 20 -- Yesterday was a perfect example of the kind of weather a duck hunter travels several hundred miles to avoid, and the kind that ducks travel even farther to find.

Tonight's new play will be "The Seventh Trumpet" by Charles Rann Kennedy, venerable English-born playwright, who last was represented on Broadway by a revival of his "The Servant in the House" in 1926. Curtain is at 8:40 at the Mansfield.

That part of the world still sane and nominally at peace must experience a thrill of horror over the careful computation by which representatives of the governments-in-exile in London have reached the conclusion that more than 100,000 persons have been executed to enforce Axis domination in the occupied countries of Europe.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 20 -- "The Caucasus, Iran, Iraq and Syria may well prove to be the great battlefield of 1942," said General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, British commander in chief in India, in an interview here today.

ROME, Nov. 20 -- The Italian High Command announced today that Italian motorized forces at the end of the first day of battle in North Africa had beaten back and partly surrounded British formations that had unleashed the longexpected offensive against Axis positions.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- There is joy on the campus of the United States Military Academy today, for a victory -- or at least a tie -- is in the offing for the Army football team when it clashes with Navy in Philadelphia a week from Saturday.
BERLIN, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A communique from Adolf Hitler's Headquarters today said:

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 19 (Delayed) -- Having again regrouped their forces and preceded their attacks by large-scale reconnaissance, the Germans now are trying to advance around General Gregory K. Zhukoff's a flanks in the Kalinin and Volokolamsk salients and considerably south of Tula, where what appears to be an effort to begin an extremely wide enveloping movement was launched by forces commanded by the Nazi tank specialist, Col. Gen. Heinz Guderian.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 20 -- T. D. Buhl's Sweep Swinger, badly outrun at the start, raced through the field in the $7,500-added Endurance Handicap today at Bowie and won by a half length over Jake Freedman's Wood Robin.

Merchants, munching turkey legs at groaning Thanksgiving tables in a million homes yesterday, were building up their vitamins in preparation for the coming five-week pre-Christmas store sales stretch just ahead when clanging cash registers may ring up the biggest sales totals in history.

A band of thirty-three football players from St. Mary's College in the Moraga Valley of California yesterday completed their transcontinental journey here for the game with Fordham at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The American Hospital at Assiut has been watching with growing concern the approach of the dark clouds of war. The difficulties of obtaining medical and surgical supplies have continually increased. We finally obtained a small supply of the literally life-giving drugs, sulphanilamide and sulphapyridine, by parcel post from America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- American cotton spinners attained a record activity during October, the Bureau of the Census reporting today almost 11,250,000,000 active spindle hours for the month. The previous record was slightly more than 10,500,000,000 spindle hours in July this year.

VICHY, France, Nov. 20 -- An item in a country newspaper received here today reveals the scope of the efforts put forth by Vichy's Economic Police with the dual object of ensuring an equitable distribution of food and repressing the black market.

One of the biggest stories an American newspaper could print today would be an accurate account of the dealings our Navy has had with submarines: how many, if any, have been sunk or damaged, where, and under what circumstances. Next in importance would come a complete list of submarines sunk by the British since the beginning of the war.

The Peoples Mandate Committee has advised members of the mediation commission working for negotiation of the dispute between Ecuador and Peru that it would, support the commission "by every means in our power," it was announced yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Wilson (Bud) Schwenk, Washington University's one-man football team, pitched himself into the collegiate hall of fame today by establishing a national record of 103 completed forward passes in one season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 20 -- Henry Fonda will play the lead in Twentieth Century-Fox's "The Golden Touch," a novel by Stephen Long-street dealing with Wall Street financial conflicts, which the studio purchased last year for Spring production, but subsequently shelved.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Placing its entire team among the first twenty-five finishers in two-and-a-half mile race over the Seton Hall College campus course, Seton Hall preparatory school easily won the national invitation interscholastic cross-country run today.

A second-year back on the Giants' squad may become the punting champion of the National Football League if he gets chances enough to kick and continues to propel the pigskin with the same energy in remaining games that he has displayed in contests to date.

Showing entirely too much speed for their New Jersey rivals, the New York Rovers notched their first home triumph yesterday by handing the River Vale Skeeters a 4-to-1 setback in the Eastern Hockey League clash featuring the holiday amateur twin bill at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Japanese envoys, Saburo Kurusu and Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, having received "new advices" from Tokyo, returned today to the State Department, where they continued to discuss with Secretary of State Cordell Hull the possibilities of reaching a general settlement in the Pacific.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The girls of the New Jersey College for Women are versatile, indeed, when it comes to earning extra money during Summer vacation.

HAVANA, Nov. 20 -- Plans for the participation of interested individuals and groups of the American nations in an effort toward the gradual unification of civil and commercial law in the American republics were approved today by the second Inter-American Conference here of Committees for Intellectual Cooperation.
CAIRO, Egypt, Friday, Nov. 21 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued the following communique early today:

DETROIT, Nov. 20 -- The Curtiss-Wright Corporation, after testing the American version of the British Rolls Royce Merlin engine, series 28, in the newest P-40 single-seater fighting planes, reported today that it is the best liquid-cooled motor being built for American military aircraft.

General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, U.S.A., will be one of the principal speakers at the thirty-fifth, annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to be held in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 11 and 12. His topic has not been announced.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Senator Adams of Colorado asserted today that Congress was being asked to appropriate for war supplies "far in excess of the needs for American defense."
"Charge 'em harder and block 'em better," was Coach Steve Owen's order at the Polo Grounds yesterday as he ran his football Giants through another snappy workout for Sunday's game with Washington.

One of the partners of Random House who is concerned with the design and manufacture of the firm's books tells of an English lord who once purchased an especially bound book from the famous English bookbinder, Sangorski. The lord came back to the binder with the book a week after it had been delivered.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 20 -- Dr. Adrian Van Maanen has added twenty-four small stars, some of them 1,000 times as faint as the sun, to the known population of the Pleiades.

Maybe there is something to that Brooklyn influence, after all. Through all the years that they were Manhattan's other representative in the National Hockey League, the Americans were little more than set-ups when they collided with their home town rivals, the Rangers.

THE books we've been reading this week are S.I. Hayakawa's "Language in Action," Harry Scherman's "The Last Best Hope of Earth," Sheldon Cheney's "The Story of Modern Art," Irwin Edman's "Fountainheads of Freedom" and Arthur Train Jr.'s "The Story of Everyday Things." We hope to have a chance to discuss them today and tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Although the last two months have seen a narrowing of the rate of grain in most lines, Chicago wholesale concerns are rounding out one of the best years they have experienced since 1929.

Ben Fidd, the veteran watchman of the Chelsea piers and deep-sea sailor man, went to the Battery yesterday and sat on a seat with his grandson, Ben Fidd Jr., to watch the craft pasisng in and out of the harbor, which is his only recreation since he retired from the waterfront a few months ago.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- To pay off the State's canal debt No. 6, due on Jan. 1 next, amounting to $5,000,000 principal and $100,000 interest, State Controller Joseph V. O'Leary will sell on Tuesday next various blocks of the State's sinking fund holdings amounting to $1,818,000.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 20 -- Success marked the fourth Rutgers football visit to this city on this warm, sunny Thanksgiving Day morning. The Scarlet, sparked by Senior Vinnie Utz and Sophomore Don Jones, outcharged and outfought Brown's warriors for a 13-to-7 decision and its first major surprise victory in three years.

The Broadway film scene remains unchanged today as "Week-End in Havana" enters its third and final week at the Roxy. . . . "Wings of Victory," the Russian film based on the exploits of the late Valeri Chkalov, Soviet air hero, will start its second week today at the Stanley.

A full-page, four color advertisement a week from Sunday in a national magazine distributed with newspapers will open the Winter campaign of the Tea Bureau, according to an announcement by Benjamin Wood, managing director.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- As a result of official reports that "the French Government has acquiesced to the express demand of Hitler to remove General Weygand from his post as Delegate General of France in Africa," the State Department announced today that "American policy toward France is being reviewed, and all plans for economic assistance to French North Africa are suspended."
VICHY, France, Nov. 20 -- "General Maxime Weygand has retired."

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Captain Mearle Duvall of Maryland teamed with Tommy Mont, sparkling sophomore halfback, to give the Terrapins a hard-fought 6-0 victory over a dogged Washington and Lee eleven today before 6,000 fans.
Several sales of Manhattan properties to investors were reported by brokers in this borough yesterday.

ST. LIN, Quebec, Nov. 20 -- That unity of the peoples of Canada in a single nationhood and a single patriotic spirit that was Sir Wilfrid Laurier's life ambition and life work was fittingly marked today in this little Quebec village when the hundredth anniversary of Sir Wilfrid's birth was celebrated by the dedication as a national monument of the little house in which he was born.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The usual fevered atmosphere of Washington subsided for a day while the Capital and thirty-two States celebrated the last "early Thanksgiving." Most officials remained away from their offices and government workers had a holiday.

ALWAYS willing to help, this observer will now try to straighten out the esteemed Washington correspondent, Mr. Arthur Krock, who was flabbergasted by words he heard uttered on the Senate floor a couple of weeks ago during the debate on the Neutrality Act repeal. It was shortly after Mr. Krock, a loyal Princeton alumnus, had sat through a rainy afternoon in the Palmer Stadium gloomily watching Harvard beat Princeton, 6 -- 4.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill told the House of Commons today that the goal of the Libyan offensive was to destroy the Axis armies rather than to capture positions, and that the crucial battle was imminent, if not already under way.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20 -- Yale's football preparations for the Harvard game were confined to a morning session today. Later the football squad enjoyed Turkey Day and all its fixings in bountiful style at the training table in Ray Tompkins House.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The five United States Republican Representatives on a flying visit here -- Joseph Clark Baldwin of New York City, Melrvin J. Maas and Richard P. Gale of Minnesota, Wililiam S. Hill of Colorado and W. Sterling Cole of New York -- faced British reporters today in an interview in the office of Ambassador John G. Winant.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The National Grange asked today that Congress enact legislation to guarantee farmers "the same price protection as industry" in the post-war period.
BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Nov. 15 shows the following changes for the week, in thousands of reichsmarks:

WITH THE RED ARMY IN THE FIELD, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Mechanized forces on an attack-a-day schedule in this week's Carolinas' war games have captured ten times as many prisoners and equipment as the opposing Blue First Army, Major Gen. Charles L. Scott said today.

Stymied for most of the first half, the Wagner College football team rallied after the intermission and blanked Brooklyn College, 27-0, on the Wagner gridiron, Grymes Hill, Staten Island, yesterday in the last game of the season for both schools.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The British R.A.F. headquarters today issued the following communique:

General 10 per cent advances in premiums on ordinary life insurance were forecast yesterday with the announcement by Leroy A. Lincoln, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, that, effective Jan. 1, its reserve basis would be cut to 2 3/4 per cent.

RAPID CITY, S.D., NOV. 20 (AP) -- Fourteen, years after the first granite was blasted from Mount Rushmore's face, superintendent Lincoln Borglum formally announced today the completion of work on the sculptured heads.

Hardly larger than a match cover are the rich brown cookies newly displayed on the counters of city shops. One-hundred-and-thirty sugary pieces, encased in a midnight-blue box, are delicately flavored with almond and nourishingly made from fresh eggs, butter and oatmeal.

HAVANA, Nov. 20 -- The first regional meeting of the International Federation of University Women opened here tonigfht with delegates in attendance from Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Cuba and the United States.
WINNIPEG, Nov. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Cash wheat dealings took the spotlight in a slow trade on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange with an estimated 1,000,000 bushels of top-grade wheat taken by shippers.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Xavier University of Cincinnati showered first downs and touchdowns on Providence today, blanking the Friars on a mud-soaked field, 33 to 0, before a crowd of 7,000. It was the fourth meeting of the schools since 1927 and the Easterners have been victorious only once.

Lady Louis Mountbatten, wife of the former commander of H.M.S. Illustrious, and Captain Arthur Marsden, M.P., member of the executive committee of the British Navy League, presented yesterday five war mementos fashioned by Royal Navy men to Bundles for Britain, 745 Fifth, Avenue, for auctioning at the Navy Ball to be held Wednesday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A decision of the Court of Appeals in Albany on Wednesday prohibiting the sale of beer in kegs on Sunday drew conflicting opinions yesterday as to whether the decision would stop all Sunday sales of beer for off-the-premises consumption, particularly sales in delicatessen stores.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The most severe unemployment problem in the United States is among youths under 20 years of age and workers who are approaching retirement age, according to an analysis by the Bureau of the Census, issued today, and based on a survey made in the week of March 24-30, 1940.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- Tuckahoe repeatedly stopped Eastchester in the first half, and went on to hold its intracity rival to a scoreless tie today. Ben Heinzinger, Eastchester fullback, and Jimmy Scliultz, Tuckahoe end, were outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The "unlimited emergency" was laid off again today, the second holiday this month, not counting Sundays and Saturday afternoons. The defense effort joined the captive coal miners for at least twenty-four hours. And complaints by some who tried vainly to make engagements tomorrow with certain distinguished engineers of armament production suggest that a few of these intend to make it a long week-end.

A pair of former middleweight champions, Ken Overlin and Al Hostak, will meet in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Their middle-weight status having been abolished because of the impossibility of getting down to the class weight, the ex-champions are now training their sights on the light-heavyweight throne, at present occupied by Gus Lesnevich.

Activity continued brisk yesterday in private dwellings in Brooklyn. One buyer will remodel a home on Third Street into four suites. The purchaser of a vacant building on Bushwick Avenue plans to improve the site.

WITH BLUE ARMY IN THE FIELD, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- The Blue First Army troops of Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum appeared today to be developing a huge pincers against the Red Fourth Army Corps of Major Gen. O. W. Griswold.

Prayers of thanks for the blessings of peace and liberty were offered yesterday in churches and synagogues throughout the city with an unusual spiritual fervor born of the knowledge that their maintenance in the days ahead may require many sacrifices and much hardship.

With three governments, two of them at war with each other, cooperating to make his trip possible, Prince Alessandro Torlonia of Italy arrived here yesterday on the Atlantic Clipper to go to the bedside of his mother, Mrs. Elsie Moore Torlonia, who is seriously ill.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- News of the British advance into Libya gave the stock markets a strong opening today. Buyers came in for industrial shares and further improvement was shown in the most popular groups, but later profit-taking caused a set back and many prices ended below their best levels.

The three-centuries-old American custom of giving thanks at this time to the Almighty for His blessings was observed yesterday in thirty-two States of the Union, in the District of Columbia and by the armed forces of the United States at many remote spots on sea and land.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 20 -- While the press today celebrated yesterday's agreements with the United States, observers here studied their economic and political implications. Their consensus was that the agreements revealed Mexico's complete economic dependence upon the United States, which Mexico had turned to diplomatic advantage.

Crucible Steel Company of America, for the first time since Jan. 15, 1931, is to pay a dividend on its common stock. Directors have voted to pay $1 a share on Dec. 22 to holders of record of Dec. 8. The last dividend was $1.25, paid on the company's old no par value stock.

A large oven door in a basement kitchen on West Twenty-second Street was opened yesterday with awe and reverence. With understandable pride, Mrs. Adelaide Andrews pointed to three generous platefuls of Thanksgiving dinner, waiting in warm security for tardy visitors to the Women's Emergency Lodge of the Salvation Army.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 20 -- Wild Bill Dudley, the touchdown tabulator, today gave one of the most amazing performances ever witnessed in Kenan Stadium as he led Virginia to a 28-7 victory over North Carolina in a traditional Turkey Day football game witnessed by 22,000.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said today that his government had implicit faith in President Roosevelt's ability and desire to protect Great Britain in conversations with Japan now going on in Washington.

A seven-point proposal for a labor policy to be adopted by the government as a consequence of the "captive mines" strike was sent yesterday to the 8,000 members of the National Association of Manufacturers in a circular letter by Walter D. Fuller, president of the association.

With theatrical producers gambling on hopes of bad -- or at least cool -- weather, twenty-one of the twenty-six current attractions offered Thanksgiving matinees yesterday. The weather was too balmy, however, and theatre business suffered.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Important factors in the timing of our defense effort are ignored by Maurice Davidson of the State Power Authority in his recent letter to THE TIMES.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 21 -- Having, in the words of Domei, perfectly fulfilled its mission, which was to demonstrate the solidarity and fighting spirit of the whole Japanese nation, the present crisis in the Diet is winding up routine business and is expected to end the session today.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- "The British Imperial armies, throwing out successively widening arcs of steel across the bleak Libyan terrain while the Mediterranean Fleet loosed a running storm of fire upon the Axis coastal positions, were declared tonight to be threatening General Erwin Rommel's North African Corps with disastrous envelopment.
The Clinton Trust Company sold the one-family dwelling on a lot 30 by 100 feet at 111-32 208th Street, Hollis, L.I., to Eugene Girrbach through the Realty Mortgage Corporation, broker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Democratic National Committee is disturbed by the recent appearance here of a monthly publication, called The Democratic National Press, which has no connection with the committee but has a large number of advertisements and business cards inserted by companies which have defense contracts or are equipped to handle them.

Police Commissioner Valentine ordered an investigation yesterday of a complaint by Henry Hennessey, 51-year-old war veteran, that he walked four blocks through the busiest part of Harlem without finding a policeman after being stabbed in an attempted "mugging" hold-up by two young Negroes on West 125th Street shortly after midnight Thursday.

Trade Here Shows Upturn Retail trade here turned sharply for the better yesterday, with some stores estimating gains of 10 to 15 per cent over the corresponding day last year. The day was a school holiday, and customer traffic rose substantially in toy, gift, main floor and a number of apparel departments.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 21 (AP) -- A six-furlong match race between R. W. Collins's Sweet Willow and Mrs. Ed McCuan's Wise Moss will feature the closing program of the most successful season in New Hampshire turf history tomorrow at Rockingham Park.

School vacations, balmy weather and the Macy Thanksgiving Day parade served to boom holiday business at many of the Broadway houses, theatre managements reported yesterday. The Paramount, where "Skylark" opened on Wednesday, played to approximately 70,000 persons and grossed $32,000 for the three-day period, representing' a record holiday figure since the theatre adopted its present stage and screen policy six years ago.
CAMP UPTON, L.I., Nov. 21 -- For the first time since the 1222nd deception Center was set up here more than a year ago, unassigned selectees will take part in a general training program.

Vincent Sheean, who said a few months ago that he might do another book on Europe in the fashion of his "Personal History," is now in the East Indies instead, working out a book on that part of the world.

Practical and in some instances realistic suggestions for a "code of ethics" to help them in their daily conduct, both inside the classroom and in the neighborhood, have been submitted by pupils in the junior high school division, Dr. Elias Lieberman, associate superintendent, revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Under a rule which will give to the House full freedom to express its views and write its own legislation to control prices, the Rules Committee today sent legislation to the floor. The leadership made it the order of business all next week.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -- Pennsylvania and Cornell will meet at Franklin Field tomorrow for the forty-eighth time in one of the classics of Ivy football before an estimated, crowd of more than 73,000. The kick-off is set for 1:30, half an hour earlier than usual.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 21 -- (AP) -- The tail end of a Dakota blizzard will whip across the gridiron tomorrow as Minnesota plays Wisconsin, the Golden Gophers' last obstacle to another perfect season.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 -- There can be no real world freedom, unless the Jewish people are also free to develop their culture in their own homeland of Palestine, said Miss Sulamith Schwartz of New York, former national president of Junior Hadassah, in an address at the second day of the annual convention today.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Nov. 21 -- Hailed by Secretary Knox as a symbol of the nation's will to survive in a world at war, the 35,000-ton battleship Indiana slid into the waters of the James River today from the ways of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, six months ahead of schedule.

OTTAWA, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- Administration of the government's price ceilings will be guarded by six principles, the Wartime Prices and Trade Board said today in a statement of policy. The principles are:

ROME, Nov. 21 -- Today's communique on the British drive into Libya did not give the impression of a decisive British offensive that had an initial success. But informed Axis sources in Rome are warning commentators not to jump to conclusions and to await the outcome of the battle.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 21 -- The War Department released the following orders today. dated Nov. 19:

OTTAWA, Nov. 21 (Canadian Press) -- Blunt notice to Canadians that the government intends to make its new price-ceiling program stick, preferably by cooperation but by order if necessary, was given today by Donald Gordon, new chairman of the Wartime Prices and Trade Board.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A new export-subsidy plan for wheat and flour, expected to stimulate trade with countries to the south, was announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton of this year's growth ginned to Nov. 14 was 8,808,361 running bales, counting round as half bales and excluding linters, compared with 10,069,167 running bales ginned to that date a year ago and 10,682,457 two years ago.

For the second consecutive period industrial bond financing featured this week the new-issue market and accounted for all but $1,444,000 of the total of $16,444,000 in new bonds offered to the public. This compared with $37,180,000 in new bonds offered last week and with $80,720,000 floated in this week last year.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Miami's surprising Hurricanes cashed in on their one offensive showing tonight to topple favored South Carolina, 7 to 6, before 17,210 Orange Bowl Stadium spectators.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Princeton's rejuvenated football forces, buoyed by last week's triumph over Yale, will brave the once-beaten Navy juggernaut in Palmer Stadium tomorrow afternoon, starting at 2 o'clock.

Max Pollikoff, violinist, devoted the first half of the program of his recital at Town Hall last night to two concertos, the familiar example by Glazunoff and the little-known concerto in C major of Haydn discovered in 1909. The other numbers presented included the unaccompanied sonata, Op. 31, No. 1, by Hindemith; the Saint-Saens "Havanaise," and as novelties Norman Dello Joio's "Colloquy" and three excerpts from Prokofieff's ballet, "Romeo et Juliet," transcribed by David Grunes.
The American Export liner Excalibur sailed yesterday with twenty-three passengers for Lisbon and seventy-three for Bermuda, her first port of call.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx and his wife and three children were among fifty-four families that evacuated the apartment house at 2305 University Avenue in six minutes last night during a demonstration of the handling of an air-raid incident by the voluntary services.

Faced with the opportunity of capturing the Eastern division crown in the National Football League without further ado tomorrow afternoon when they meet the Redskins at the Polo Grounds, the Giants will engage in their final workout for the game this morning.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 21 -- The long-anticipated British drive into Libya, which had won initial successes yesterday, parallels a new German drive against Moscow. The circumstance is not entirely fortuitous. For the British offensive in the arid wastes of the Western Desert is a political as well as a military gesture.

WATERTOWN, Nov. 21 -- The entire Fourth. Armored Division set out from Pine Camp at 2:30 P. M. today for a night march and bivouac which will bring Major Gen. Henry W. Baird's command back to the cantonment by midday Saturday.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- The new $60,000,000 Irvin works of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation will be closed within forty-eight hours because of a shortage of fuel, a result of the widespread coal mine strikes, it was announced tonight.

The wholesale market was kept fairly busy during the week with reorders, but as in the previous week there was little additional purchasing for inventory increase, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Manufacturers also were reporting a comparative lull in new orders.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 21 -- Lucille Ball and Henry Fonda will be co-starred in "The Little Pinks," Damon Runyon's first production for RKO, according to the studio's present plans. Miss Ball was named for the role today, and it was learned that negotiations with Fox to borrow Fonda to play opposite her are virtually completed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Spokesmen for the War and Navy Departments endorsed today the Connally Bill, which would author ize the government to take over strike-bound defense mines and factories.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 21 -- Governor Walter W. Bacon of Delaware and his staff were guests of honor at a parade and review of the troops at Fort Du Pont this afternoon. He was greeted with a nineteen-gun salute.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 21 -- Lehigh University and Lafayette will meet at Taylor Stadium tomorrow, with hopes for a Lehigh victory high as thirty-four men on the squad packed up after practice today and left for Stroudsburg, where the team will remain until just before game time.

Winners of three of their last four games, the Americans will seek to add to their successes tonight when they oppose the Red Wings in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Sarden. Red Dutton's athletes will find themselves in the unusual role of favorites, inasmuch as the Wings have been defeated in each, of their three starts.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I call your attention to two dangers into which this city is likely to fall because of its deep concern over crime conditions currently reported in lower Harlem. One danger is that we can become preoccupied with this single section of Manhattan to the exclusion of other sections occupied by both Negroes and whites where problems are just as serious.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 21 (AP) -- With a capacity crowd of 56,000 in prospect Notre Dame battles Southern California tomorrow hopeful of winning to give Frank Leahy an undefeated record in his first season as head coach of the Irish.
ROME, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

An exhibition, entitled "Ten Years of American Opera Design," is being held (until Dec. 10) at the New York Public Library. The material, presented to the Library by the Juilliard School of Music, includes photographs, candid camera shots, original opera scores and original drawings.
Testerday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed Reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A definite indication was given by President Roosevelt at his press conference today that the United States did not intend to sever diplomatic relations with France, at least for the present, as a result of the dismissal of General Maxime Weygand as commander in North Africa.

EDENBORN, Pa., Nov. 21 -- Gunfire wounded eleven men here this morning in the worst outbreak thus far of the captive coal mine strike and led Sheriff Charles T. Frock of Fayette County to ask Governor James for aid from the State motor police.

Joseph J. Lordi, national champion, of the New York A.C., and H. Robert Reeve of the Bayside Tennis Club became the finalists in the twenty-second annual invitation squash tennis tournament at the Princeton Club last night by defeating, respectively, Willard K. Rice of the Harvard Club and Frederick B. Ryan Jr. of the Yale Club.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: After this current football season, I think there will be a wholesale reversion to sound, conservative tactics. The 1940 success of Stanford, the Chicago Bears, Boston College and Georgetown had a regrettable aftermath in an outbreak of unorthodox offensive formations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Department store sales during the week ended Nov. 15 showed a gain, of 14 per cent over the corresponding week of 1940, the same as in the previous week's comparison, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Orleans Levee District, La. Authorities of Orleans Levee District, La., will enter the market on Dec. 29 with $3,944,000 of refunding bonds. Details of the financing will be announced later.

The scientists in the National Bureau of Standards have turned their attention to wool. Warm and serviceable as it is, it has its drawbacks. The larvae of moths devour it. Molds grow on it. Bacteria play havoc with it. Strong soaps corrode it. Sunlight ages it. Taken all in all, it presents as many problems as an automobile or an airplane.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -- A possibility that some of the decisive aerial battles of the war may be fought by long-range bombers high above the white Arctic wilderness by the light of the midday moon and the midnight sun was visioned tonight by Vilhjalmur Stefansson, Arctic explorer, in an address at the annual Autumn meeting of the American Philosophical Society.

TOKYO, Nov. 21 -- The extraordinary Diet session, which unanimously passed all thirteen bills submitted to it by the government -- including the supplementary budget of 4,315,000,000 yen, provided a forum for policy speeches, and adopted resolutions urging the government to enforce the nation's immutable policies, regardless of cost, formally closed today.

Convinced that a world championship of the International Star Class could not be brought back to Long Island Sound with a light sloop, Frank Campbell purchased one of the heavy-weather craft on the Pacific Coast and had it shipped east.

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Enlisted men of Fort Hancock are awaiting word whether Lana Turner, film actress, will visit the fort. Miss Turner was elected "Sweetheart of Sandy Hook" last week in balloting conducted by the post newspaper, Sandy Hook Foghorn.

ALBRIGHT VS. BUCKNELL -- "Once more into the breach, dear friends, once more!" Also, "If it were done when 'tis done, then 'twere well it were done quickly." Without stopping to think, a blind vote for Bucknell.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Federal Government took an unprecedented step today when it discharged the Grand River Authority, a State agency which has had charge of the $25,000,000 Grand River power project in Oklahoma, and put a Federal official in control.
LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued this communique today:

HAVANA, Nov. 21 -- A new Impetus toward intellectual cooperation, which constitutes another step in continental unity, is regarded here as one of the chief accomplishments of the second InterAmerican Conference of Committees on Intellectual Cooperation that closes tomorrow.

Forty-three political subdivisions are scheduled to offer next week new State and municipal issues amounting to $16,898,201. This compares with $6,569,517 this week and with a weekly average of $30,152,853 in new offerings for the year to date.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Nov. 22 -- After successfully delaying the launching of the Germans' sixth "major offensive" against Moscow for more than three weeks, Russian forces on the capital's western defenses, as the war draws to the close of its fifth month, are being subjected to an offensive "the like of which has not yet been seen" on the entire front, according to the Soviet military spokesman this morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Behind a warning today to scrap iron and steel dealers to comply immediately with allocation orders issued by the Office of Production Management lies a determination to "crack down" drastically on a few dealers who the government has reason to believe are trying to profiteer in the defense program.
NEW YORK Ernesto Jaen Guardia, the Panamanian Ambassador, has come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Washington.

VICHY, France, Nov. 21 -- General Maxime Weygand having retired and the Pro-Consulate in French Africa having been abolished, there was a political lull today, permitting consideration of implications, reactions and possibilities.

Reflecting increased earnings, extra and special year-end dividend declarations were announced yesterday by directors of several industrial companies. Payment dates indicated that checks will be available for Christmas spending.

The open deer season for New York's southern tier counties will get under way Monday morning and continue through Saturday. And, with a much larger area thrown open to hunters, the deer kill for the State should be considerably increased this year.

After a long meeting held here yesterday, the oil companies whose properties in Mexico were seized in March, 1938, announced through W.S. Farish, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, that they could not accept the Mexican Government's oil settlement proposal that the State Department in Washington approved Nov. 19.

NEWTOWN, Conn., Nov. 21 -- Four male attendants at the Fairfield State Hospital, an institution for mental cases here, were bound over to the December term of the Fairfield County Superior Court this evening when arraigned on manslaughter charges before Judge Harry F. Bradley of the Town Court in connection, with the death this morning of Herbert Hoyt, 41 years old, of Stamford, who had been a patient at the hospital.

NEW ROCHELLE. N.Y., Nov. 21 -- With thirty soldiers as students, Fort Slocum has opened a radio school for volunteers in the post Y.M.C.A. Officers said that it was one of the first voluntary schools of its kind in the Army.
When Dr. Annie S. Daniel walks down the street these days, she often meets a former patient who stops abruptly and asks:
PORT DIX, N.J., Nov. 21 -- After delay of several weeks for lack E structural steel, construction, reached full peak on the Fort Dix ports arena this week.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Major Gen. George H. Brett of the United States Army Air Corps said in an interview today that there is a large number of American-built planes operating in the Middle East and that "a great deal of pressure is being brought to bear on supply activities" in the United States to insure that the Middle East sectors are being "very well taken care of."

ROME, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A titanic battle, "the duration of which is not to be foreseen," has burst in full fury in the Libyan desert with the British hurling everything in their arsenal by land, air and sea at Axis forces, Italian war correspondents reported from the North African front tonight.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Nov. 21 -- The Bourse adopted today a waiting attitude. Most changes were small, except that of Amsterdam Trading, which was 4 points lower at 493. Royal Dutch was steady at 332 1/2; A.K.U. lost a point at 151 5/8 and Philips gained a point at 279 1/2.

An order requiring the Newsdealers Federal Labor Union, Local 22371, A.F. of L., to show cause on Monday why it should not be restrained from continuing to boycott seven morning and evening newspapers in violaion of Section 340 of the General Business Law -- Donnelly Act -- was signed late yesterday afternoon by Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins.
Columbia will end its football season at Baker Field this afternoon against Colgate before a crowd expected to reach 25,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The diplomatic negotiations looking to a readjustment of relations between the United States and Japan struck a snag today, with the result that no meeting of the conferees was held.

Post-Thanksgiving sermons will be preached tomorrow in many of the churches of the city. Prayers will be offered that all strikes in the nation cease and that the labor issue in national defense be permanently settled. There will be a number of special military and patriotic services by organizations in the afternoon and evening.

WITH THE FIRST ARMY IN THE CAROLINAS, Nov. 21 (AP) -- On ending the first big battle of the Carolinas war games, Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum said today that his newly developed tank-killer units proved themselves invaluable.

As the chill winds begin to whistle about the corners of tall buildings and a thin film of gray ice forms over the puddles on the pavement, a New Yorker's thoughts turn irresistibly Southward. The pungent smell of mothballs still lingers about last Winter's overcoat when visions of sunny orange groves and golden sands appear before the mind's eye.

That old ring axiom that a good boxer will always beat a slugger had another demonstration last night in Madison Square Garden, where, before 7,969 impatient fight fans who paid $18,920, Ken Overlin, Washington jumping-jack, speared a decision over plodding Al Hostak, slugging Seattle warrior, in ten tedious rounds.

VICHY, France, Nov. 21 -- Francisco Largo Caballero, exiled Spanish republican former Premier, has been administratively interned at Vals-les-Bains, it was learned here today following the rejection by the Limoges tribunal of the Spanish Government's request for his extradition.

ALEXANDRIA, La., Nov. 21 -- The dental health, of troops now serving in Camp Livingston will be guarded more closely than ever with the formal opening last week of the new Camp Dental Clinic, in which all dental service for personnel of the camp will be centralized.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 15 totaled 883,839 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced to- day. This was 10,254 cars, or 1.2 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 138,544 cars, or 18.6 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 116,852 cars, or 15.2 per cent, more than during the corresponding' week two years ago.
A miniature forest of a hundred live evergreens, through which a life-size Santa Claus rides in a sleigh, was unveiled last night on the front of Franklin Simon's on Fifth Avenue.

Excess reserves of the thirty-six member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City rose $160,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures revealed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The increase was the largest for any week since that ended on May 21, and carried total excess reserves of these banks to $965,000,000, highest since the end of October when the increased reserve requirements went into effect.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Nov. 21 -- Colonel John T. Kennedy, former commander of the First Army Provisional G.H.Q. Brigade, is expected to arrive at Fort Bragg Nov. 30 to command the post. Brig. Gen. Edwin P. Parker Jr., commanding- general of the Field Artillery Replacement Center, is temporary post commander.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 More than 3,000 C.I.O. members went on strike today at the Columbia Steel Company's mills at nearby Pittsburg, stopping work on $5,000,000 worth, of defense orders for the Army, Navy and Maritime Commission.

Forty-one patriotic societies of New York will participate in the nineteenth annual "Joint Thanks-giving Service" to be held tomorrow at 4 P.M. in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Bishop William T. Manning will preach the sermon.

BUENOS AIKES, Argentina, Nov. 21 -- The first step toward elimination of all customs barriers between Argentina and Brazil, with the ultimate objective of creating a customs union between the two countries, was taken this evening when their Foreign Ministers, Enrique de Ruiz-Guinazu for Argentina and Dr. Oswaldo Aranha for Brazil, signed a treaty whereby each country will grant free entry to the goods of the other produced by new industries.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The more cheerful conditions were maintained in today's stock markets, the busy week ending in good style. The turnover was smaller than for the last two days, but with only a little profit-taking going on.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 22 -- The British reported stiff fighting in North Africa today, with tank battles over widely scattered areas going "extremely well." A large encircling movement by attacking tank and motorized forces has trapped the "largest part" of the German tanks in a wide area between Gambut and Capuzzo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- J. Warren Davis, retired judge of the Third Circuit Court of Appeals, has resigned, and in return impeachment proceedings against him will be dropped, it was stated in Administration circles tonight. The resignation, said to be on President Roosevelt's desk, will be accepted almost immediately, it was added.

What you pay for your life insurance depends chiefly upon two factors: How long you may expect to live, and how much the insurance company can expect to earn on its investments. In spite of the unkind state of the world, life expectancy has improved. But rates of interest have become steadily worse.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I have been following with interest the comments in "Letters to the Sports Editor" concerning N.Y.U. football. It seems to me that most of the disappointed followers of the Violets have failed to recognize the only valid reason for their team's plight.

With One Hand? One can't help admiring this particular C.I.O. organizer at the Detroit convention. He believes a man's job should be something you can get your teeth into. "We want to whip Hitler, yes," he said, "but we want to whip those other Hitlers -- industrial management -- in this country also."

MEXICO CITS', Nov. 19 -- Leading Mexican industrialists said today that the supply of raw materials and machinery from the United States was "difficult and precarious" because of the priorities system, and they urged that it be modified by the allocation of fixed quotas of commodities for each country.

Importers of Chinese merchandise, much of it intended for the Christmas trade, are now facing what they term an absurd situation as a result of a current official ruling which extends the recent Treasury order on Chinese goods to stocks held in bonded warehouses, it was learned yesterday.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 22 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast the following communique over the Moscow radio early today:

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Some light on the problem of Britain's postwar relations with Soviet Russiaa subject for speculation here these days-was cast today by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden when he spoke about a sound and permanent basis for the closest understanding and collaboration between the two countries in the future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- President Roosevelt signed today, but with objections, the $587,000,000 defense roads authorization bill which differed in only minor particulars from a measure which he vetoed Aug. 4.

With their faded but still existing chances of landing a bowl bid in the balance, Fordham's football forces are set to go all out at the Polo Grounds this afternoon when they renew gridiron hostilities with St. Mary's.

Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, mother of Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh and Widow of the former United States Ambassador to Mexico, speaking yesterday afternoon at the Roosevelt Hotel at a meeting of 400 New York women launching the new national's women's organization of the Fight for Freedom Committee, declared that the views of persons who oppose aid to Great Britain Should be respected, even if not accepted.
BERLIN, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The German High Command communique said today:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Negotiations between railway labor leaders and railroad officials for averting the threatened strike reached a deadlock tonight when the carriers declined to consider any proposals other than those recommended by an emergency fact-finding board.

BERLIN, Nov. 21 -- At the close of the fifth month of the war against Russia, German interest, both official and at home, is concentrated on the new offensives on the Moscow and Rostov fronts, which started three days ago and are calculated to carry the Germans both past Moscow and into the Caucasus.

Francisco de S. Laracegui, cor- respondent for Latin-American newspapers, was dropped last night from membership in the Foreign Press Association, semi-official organization of foreign newspaper men in the United States, according to an announcement by the executive committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Vallejo and Napa, Calif., with a rise of 48 per cent, and Long Beach, Calif., with a 41 per cent gain, over a year ago, scored the highest increases in department store sales in October, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 21 -- Reversing the order of their recent duel, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Air Brigade turned the tables on G.R. Watkins's Clyde Tolson in the featured Carvel Hall Handicap, at six furlongs, at Bowie today.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMORED FORCES, in Libya, Nov. 19 (Delayed) -- The crossing of Premier Mussolini's barbed wire barricade along the Libyan-Egyptian boundary yesterday was completely unopposed though the British had expected that it would be contested to some extent.

CAMP CROFT, S.C., Nov. 22 -- The Infantry Replacement Training Center was host to 5,300 men and officers of Fourth Army Corps air organizations over Thanksgiving tables which were bent beneath the weight of 23,800 pounds of turkey and additional thousands of pounds of other edibles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The United States Government agreed today to underwrite Britain's financial obligations with regard to the key North Atlantic base of Iceland. These run to about $20,000,000 annually.

The present labor crisis can be seen in perspective only when we review the longer labor policy of the present Administration. An adequate review of that policy, to show just how heavy is the Administration's responsibility for the present situation, would have to begin at least as far back as the passage of the Wagner act in 1935.

Although there is but one Broadway opening next week -- "Hope for a Harvest," on Wednesday -- the week of Dec. 1 should see the busiest period of the current season. Barring postponements, the list reads:

Erich Strunck, a defendant in the espionage trial in Brooklyn, testified yesterday that William G. Sebold, counter-espionage agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and principal government witness, had urged him on two occasions to join the Communist party, as a means of safeguarding his job and because "communism has a great future in America."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21 -- The passing of Co-Captain Hugh Knowlton, former Groton star, enabled the Yale freshmen to come from behind and defeat the Harvard yearlings, 19-13, in their annual football game on Soldiers Field today.

BERLIN, Nov. 21 -- Calling Americans "cultureless barbarians" and President Roosevelt a "poor fool," Dr. Robert Ley, head of the German Labor Front, told 15,000 laborers from fourteen European countries today that unless Europe "finds herself" she will be crushed by America.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- Yesterday was the first .Thanksgiving meal in the Army for 500 selectees from Brooklyn, Kentucky, West Virginia and Ohio who joined the Delaware outfit last week from Fort Eustis.

Asserting that he visualizes his role as chairman of the board of directors of General Mills, Inc., as being the representative of the many hundreds of scattered owners of shares, rather than as top man in the management, James F. Bell addressed yesterday several hundred stockholders residing in the East at an informal meeting in the Hotel Commodore here.

Trading was fair to active on locally dressed traefer meats yesterday. Steer hinds and ribs were again higher. Other classes showed little price change from Wednesday. Trading in kosher meats opened slow. Kosher veal and calf were higher and other classes opened steady.

Post-holiday influences on the stock market were varied yesterday, but once the sell orders for income-tax purposes were cleared off the books the share list made a good advance, with volume the heaviest in more than a week. The tip for the upturn was given by the railroad issues, and followers of this group persisted in their belief that there would be no tie-up of the nation's carriers.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21 -- The German High Command and radio's Quiz Kids were lampooned here tonight as the Prinoeton University Triangle Club staged its fifty-third annual production with the showing of "Ask Me Another" at the McCarter Theatre.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 21 -- Operating as a provisional armored corps during the Carolina war games, Fort Benning's Fourth Motorized and Second Armored Division are expected to continue as a combat team in GHQ manoeuvres later this month.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The War Department announced the award of contracts amounting to $18,783,888 today. Included were the following, not previously published, to companies in the New York area:
A young man wearing a lumber-jacket and showing obvious signs of several days' involuntary dieting walked up to the information desk at Police Headquarters last night and asKed to be arrested.

A new listening post through which the government will check on European radio propaganda soon will be set up in London, supplementing those which have been operating: here, Lloyd A. Free, director of the foreign broadcast monitoring service of the Federal Communications Commission, disclosed yesterday.

The library of William H. Woodin, former Secretary of the Treasury who died in 1934, will be sold by auction here at the ParkeBernet Galleries, Inc. So extensive is the collection that it will be sold in three or perhaps four parts, with each part comprising several sessions.
A pair of Ivy League classics dominates the program in the East today as the football legions run, not walk, to the nearest exit for the last big Saturday of the campaign.

DETROIT, Nov. 21 -- In an address accepting re-election as leader of the 5,000,000 members of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, Philip Murray charged today that Federal defense agencies were "virtually infested" with corporation executives who were acting on the inside of government to get "fat, juicy, profitable contracts" for their own companies and were thus "sabotaging" the national defense effort.

Instead of stalking an underworld victim at night through deserted Brooklyn streets with a pistol in his hand, Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss, chief aide to Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, industrial racketeer, was following his elderly mother's suggestion and giving a birthday party for his younger brother to patch up a family quarrel.
The sale on Sunday of beer in bottles, cans or containers by retail stores for off-the-premises consumption will be permitted to continue so far as the State Liquor Authority is concerned.

The USO-Camp Shows, Inc., government agency designed to provide "live" entertainment in the Army and Navy camps, announced yesterday the expansion of its board of directors as a means of expediting production plans.

Flanked by lingerie and junior miss dresses, a bit of London's Old Bond Street appeared on Arnold Constable's fourth floor yesterday when the British-American Ambulance Corps opened its Mayfair shop for the Christmas season. Complete even to sandbags in front of glassless windows, the new shop will offer for sale any item carried by the Fifth Avenue store plus a large variety of British goods brought in by the ambulance corps.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Two paintings and a colored print stolen Nov. 11 from the Doris Duke Cromwell estate at Highboro were recovered by State Police in an abandoned church in Blair Road near Carteret last night.

In a leading realty deal in New Jersey reported yesterday, the 24-family tenement at 422-28 Fifth Street, Union City, was sold by the Gilman Realty Company to the Lilyan Realty Company through the C. B. Snyder Realty Company and Louis Shapiro, co-brokers.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21 -- The last-ditch stand of Yale's victory-starved football team against Harvard's highly favored outfit tomorrow in the Harvard Stadium may mean little or nothing to the rest of the football world, but it has brought forth all the blare of a traditional game week-end to this town and Boston.

Fraudulent and unfair advertising practice used by certain shoe dealers who advertise bargains have been substantially reduced as a result of recent action by the Better Business Bureau of New York City, in cooperation with reputable shoe dealers and manufacturers and the District Attorney.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A shift of emphasis by the Treasury to heavier corporation taxes from a 15 per cent income tax on individuals, to be collected at the source, was reported today in connection with the $4,800,000,000 bill which two weeks ago the Treasury asked Congress to enact before Jan. 1.

SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Nov. 21 -- Mrs. Ethel Leta Juanita Spinelli, 52 years old, known to her gang of petty crooks as "The Duchess," died at 10:25 A.M. today in the lethal gas chamber of San Quentin Prison, the first woman to pay the legal death penalty in California.

Reports that the Pirates would trade their star shortstop, Floyd (Arky) Vaughan, have been echoing around the National League without an answer -- probably because Manager Frank Frisch had his tonsils removed a few weeks ago and was in no shape to engage in debate.

Insurance Troubles In Stock Exchange circles the announcement yesterday that the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company will cut its reserve basis to 2 3/4 per cent on Jan. 1 was met with a revival of talk about equity investments for insurance companies.

With switching and liquidation holding the near months under pressure and trade buying giving support to the distant contracts, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were irregular yesterday in generally quiet trading. Closing prices of the active futures were 5 points lower to 9 points higher than Wednesday's close.

CAIRO, Egypt, Saturday, Nov. 22 -- After having repelled three counter-attacks by German Panzer divisions without once losing the initiative, British armored forces in Libya continued today to batter apparently trapped Nazi tanks and armored cars in the biggest battle of this type ever waged on the African continent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- With a final showdown between President Roosevelt and John L. Lewis on the question of reopening the captive coal mines expected this week-end, the Administration sought formal assurance today from all soft-coal operators that they would not demand open shop conditions if Mr. Lewis signs anything less than a union shop contract for the captive mines.

The United States Government will cut off the movement of French vessels between United States ports and Casablanca because of the apparent futility of aiding France as a deterrent to French-Reich collaboration, according to reports here yesterday.

In a scathing denunciation of the democratic theory that admits the rank and file into America's col- I leges, Dr. Alvan E. Duerr, officer of the National Interfraternity Conference, called last night for "an intellectual aristocracy" nurtured in a highly selective fraternity system to provide leadership in the battle to save democracy.

The 6,275-ton freighter Ville de Tamatave, which formerly flew the French flag, arrived at Pier 54, West Fourteenth Street, yesterday from Liverpool with twenty-two passengers, the first French vessel captured by the British to arrive here flying the British flag with an all-British crew on board.

The Ballet Theatre, which has more than exhausted its quota of changes of bill with and without notice, last night finally got a program upon the stage of the Forty-fourth Street Theatre that differed from all three of the programs, that had been announced previously for this date.

Advice and information is offered to skiers and mountaineers who may wish to join the newly formed Eighty-seventh Infantry Mountain Regiment in a bulletin that the National Ski Association of America, with headquarters in the Graybar Building, began circulating throughout the country yesterday.
A special kind of "royalty" came to town yesterday -- red-robed, bewhiskered monarchs of the imagination who, ensconced on department store thrones, greeted thousands of youngsters come to pay court.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Once again this season, only with more regularity, the tie game is appearing in Sunday's football headlines. I believe that in the majority of cases, the tie is not a satisfactory result. Ice hockey, basketball and baseball have found solutions, so why can't football?

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 21 -- A plea for reciprocal understanding between Latin America and the United States and for tolerance in the present crisis is today made by the newspaper Liberal, which reflects the growing resentment at United States press charges of nazism when it is asserted here, "there are no Lindberghs, Wheelers, Nyes or John L. Lewises in these countries."

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The House of Representatives now has before it consideration of penalties for violation of price-fixing legislation. It is proposed to compel every business to operate under a license and to revoke this license if the proposed law should be violated.

WORD has just been received in this country of the death of Captain Wilma Finch, master of a British cargo ship, the Chinese Prince. He died as a result of exposure in an open boat several days after his ship was torpedoed somewhere in the bleak latitudes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Prospect that the conversations between the United States and Japan might achieve a modicum of success loomed for the first time today when Secretary of State Cordell Hull conferred jointly for more than two hours in his office with the representatives of the four other powers that, with the exception of Russia, are the most interested in the Far East.
SPOKANE, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Washington State College took the wraps off a sophomore halfback today and piled up a nine-touch-down, 59-to-0 victory over Gonzaga.

HANNS EISLER is a small man with a passion for musical composition, a great admiration for John Steinbeck, and ears like Bunny Rabbit. The ears haven't much to do with this article; but were it not for Mr. Eisler's heady enthusiasm for the problems of musical mathematics and his eloquent friendship for Mr. Steinbeck, Herbert Kline and Alexander Hackensmid it is doubtful whether he would have planed down to Mexico City last December at all.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- In a ninety-minute conference today with representatives of both sides in the railroad wage dispute, President Roosevelt arranged for a resumption of direct negotiations between unions and carriers. Later, spokesmen for 1,150,000 railroad workers expressed the hope that the dispute would be settled in advance of the Dec. 7 strike deadline.

ROME, Nov. 22 -- The Axis forces still were holding their ground in Libya yesterday after having inflicted heavy losses on the British, according to today's High Command communique and Stefani dispatches from the front.

DETROIT, Nov. 22 -- When word of the agreement for the arbitration of the coal dispute was received by C.I.O. officials in an executive board meeting today, it evoked expressions of approval and relief.

The ever-dramatic Giant-Red-skin rivalry will be renewed before some 50,000 fans at the Polo Grounds today with a victory for the New Yorkers carrying with it the Eastern championship of the National Football League. Defeat for the Giants would muddle the situation completely and leave the eventual divisional winner in doubt.

Throughout the first period of their eleventh meeting with the Gaels of St. Mary's yesterday at the Polo Grounds the Fordham Rams, their bowl aspirations already in jeopardy, were as lethargic a group of football players as Sleepy Jim Crowley would never care to see.

FLIGHT Strips -- narrow emergency landing fields to adjoin highways in level areas -- may one day be the means to lift the American automobile driver's horizon literally to the skies. At present, the strips are a military matter and a $10,000,000 fund for them makes a new bedfellow in the Defense Highway Act of 1941.

IT must have been fun for Miss Baldwin's publishers to read her manuscript -- all about life behind the scenes in their own business. Perhaps they sighed and wished routine could be as romantic as it is in the book or maybe they just nodded wisely and said that it is.

With the tremendously increased need for persons skilled in the administration of first aid that the national emergency has inspired, such training at Fordham University is being intensified this year through an extensive series of classes of wide scope and variety being conducted by the College of Pharmacy on the campus in the Bronx.
Applications for home mortgage insurance continue to show substantial gains over last year, points out Abner H. Ferguson, administrator of the Federal Housing Administration.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 22 -- Notre Dame's mighty football warriors achieved an undefeated season today, their first since the 1930 Knute Rockne team, but they had the scare of their lives before it went into the record book.

THERE is a fine porcelain quality about these three stories which makes them fit neatly into a single volume of delicate but telling wit. All are set in the early years of the nineteenth century when young men made the Grand Tour by chaise and young ladies, carefully chaperoned, were dispatched by sailing boat to prospective husbands in India, solid gentlemen carefully selected by the young women's elders.

IF you want your season's greetings to receive more than a cursory glance this year, you will need to have something different from the run-of-the-mill cards. This may take some pains, but not so much as you might think; besides, the satisfaction of turning out strikingly unusual greeting cards more than makes up for the relatively slight extra effort involved.

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business continued its advance during the week ended Nov. 15. It rose to 130.1 from 128.3 (revised) for the week ended Nov. 8, and a low mark for the current half-year of 126.0 (revised) for the week ended Oct. 18.
