Precautions have been taken by the FHA to guarantee a reasonable amount of open recreational space in most defense housing construction in Long Island and West-Chester towns and villages, Thomas G. Grace, New York State director, reported yesterday.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Dr. Arthur Torrance, accused of beating his elderly bride to death, today flatly denied the killing and asserted that he had no interest in the estate of the former Mrs. Ada Loveland of Kalamazoo, Mich.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 -- A C.I.O. strike at the plant of the Columbia Steel Company in Pittsburg was settled today on a temporary basis after ten hours of conferences arranged by Omar Hoskins, a Federal conciliator. The strike tied up $5,000,000 worth of defense work.

HUGH ROSS will direct the Schola Cantorum and members of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra in a performance of Mozart's C Minor Mass at Carnegie Hall Wednesday night. The assisting soloists are Ina Souez, Anne Roselle, Hardesty Johnson and Robert Nicholson.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Sidney Hillman, Associate Director General of the OPM, said today that nine A.F.L. metal trades unions had agreed to grant welders "one-card" privileges and cease alleged discriminations against welders involved in the recent West Coast shipyard strike.

WHEN parents get to thinking that child talented in art or music is another little Mozart or Raphael -- or Deanna Durbin -- they may push the youngster in one direction at the expense of other aptitudes, says Dr. Irving Lorge. Bright children may have many talents.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The dispute over agricultural wages in Britain was settled this week by the decision of the Central Wages Board to raise the national minimum 25 per cent to 60s a week. The increase, costing the farmers about u17,500,000 annually, lifts the minimums, according to districts, from 60 to 85 per cent above prewar levels.

Steps preliminary to training its 1,000 members in activities useful on the home front were taken last week at the Women's City Club, with the creation of a defense committee headed by Mrs. Winslow Carlton. Expansion of the club's program in line with the general interest among women in national preparedness was approved by the board in the belief that defense is an integral part of civic planning.
GREENVILLE, S.C., Nov. 22 -- Clemson turned loose a highly geared offensive today and smashed out a 34-6 victory over Furman in a Southern Conference game witnessed by 18,000 shivering fans.

Through its nineteenth annual benefit theatre party, for which it has chosen Tuesday night's performance of "Junior Miss" at the Lyceum Theatre, Chapter No. 1 of the Berkshire Industrial Farm hopes to realize sufficient funds to maintain at least six boys at Berkshire Farm for a year.

SINCE democracy is now engaged in a desperate struggle to prove its right to survive before the world, there could hardly be a better time for the retelling of the story of that portion of the American population which came to our shores during another "nightmare interval" of history.

The creation of a three-man impartial grievance committee as a subordinate agency of the Board of Transportation to deal with complaints submitted by the employee of the unified transit system or their representatives was announced yesterday at City Hall by John H. Delaney, chairman, in the presence of Mayor La Guardia and Frank X. Sullivan and George Keegan, Transportation Commissioners.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 22 -- Purdue and Indiana, rivals of old, battled rain, snow and each other to a standstill for more than three quarters today, but finally Sophomorc Billy Hillenbrand the Evansville Express, smashed across the goal line and Indiana captured its onl 1941 Western Conference victory, 7 to 0, before 24,000 chilled and ripping spectators.

A shortage of housing accommodations for workers in areas of defense industry, so serious in some instances that four or five girls are sharing the same room, and where they work alternate shifts even sharing the same bed, is reported by Miss Opal Boynton, liaison officer between the Y.W. C.A. and the USO.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Political progress of the women of the Philippines reached a new height on Nov. 11, when the Commonwealth elected a woman to the lower house of the newly created Philippine Congress.

A response to the title -- as to all good titles -- is wonder that it was still available right up to this publishing season. Cockfighting and surf-casting, horse racing, football, boxing, have recently supplied material for books, but the generalities, the wide scene, have been neglected.

The 3-to-6 year olds who last year took Mr. Hurd's "The Race" to their hearts will find this new picture book equally exciting and even more brilliant. It is the old, old story of what happens when dog meets cat -- and away they go to the discomfiture of whoever happens to be in the way.

ON the first day of October there was published in New York the first volume in Polish to appear in the United States through the efforts of the New Polish Emigration. The book is a slim volume, handsomely illustrated, recounting the history of the Polish soldier and describing his present activities on various fronts.

Then came Edward Stettinius Jr. and other government heads of bureaus charged with solving the problems of defense, with a myriad of disturbing orders.

The National Maritime Union plans to seek higher bonuses for seamen entering war zones around England and in other sections recently opened to the American merchant marine by the repeal of neutrality bans, a spokesman for the union said yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I would not presume to write you these lines if an impression did not seem to be gaming ground which may have serious effects on our thinking and planning as to post-war reconstruction, prosperity and peace, and even on the morale and hopefulness with which we approach our colossal tasks of today.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 22 -- The agreements that Mexico and the United States signed in Washington this week are viewed here as signifying joint recognition of Mexico's almost complete economic dependence upon the United States, at least for the duration of the war, and the determination of the United States Government to see that Mexico does not suffer unduly from this relationship.

VICHY, Nov. 22 -- In political circles here it is insisted tonight that the retirement of General Maxime Weygand from the post of Delegate General of the Government in French Africa merely concerns one person, and that it has always been the privilege of the government to replace any person occupying any official position.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- To speed up the production of metals needed in the defense program, priorities officials of the Office of Production Management today granted an A-l-c preference rating to help manufacturers of furnaces used in the heat treatment of metals get necessary materials.

Slightly Confused Picture Ethelbert Smith said this very interesting Town Hall debate about American youth and its moral code had set him to thinking of other times. It wasn't only moral codes or political views or literary ideas but a general picture of what the world was like when he was one of the youth.

TUXEDO PARK. N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Members of this colony are busy these days, sewing:, knitting, making bandages and other supplies for the Red Cross and the British War Relief. They devote two days each week in the workroom at St. Mary's Episcopal Church here for the Red Cross and another day to relief of the British.

ONE of our fitful readers wrote in the other day and politely requested that this column make critical mention of more films. "Just a line," urged Fitful Reader, "to let us know what to expect." The candor with which she was ready to settle for "just a line" may have piqued our vanity for the moment, but it did not obstruct this response.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Appointment of Nelson A. Rockefeller, coordinator of commercial and cultural relations between the American republics, to membership on the Economic Defense Board was announced today by Vice President Wallace, board chairman.

OLD MAN WINTER still lurks in the Far North. Yet, undaunted by lack of frost and deep snow, intrepid stylists took a photographer, models and sports togs up to Lake Placid to get the last-word styles in their proper setting. Nearly 5,000 feet above sea level they climbed on Whiteface Mountain where the new slide is to be to get the major portion of the photographs shown here.
Here is a truly American fairy tale, fashioned from a legend of a New England family, to cheerily confound our grimmer memories of Salem witches and Puritan taboos.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Maritime Commission announced today the award of $11,000,000 worth of contracts for construction of twelve coastal tankers and four seagoing tugs. This makes a total of 129 vessels for which the commission has awarded contracts under its small-ship program.

Belief that specialty shops and small department stores have allowed large retailers to build up a tremendous advantage over them by accumulating stocks of silk and part-silk hosiery was expressed yesterday by hosiery manufacturers.

READING, Pa., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Bucknell handed Albright one of its worst defeats in a decade, scoring six touchdowns, kicking four extra points and forcing a safety for a 42-to-0 victory over the Lions today.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 22 -- Sparked by the passing of Captain Lou Foveromo, Hofstra College scored a 21-6 victory over Hartwick today on Hofstra Field for its fourth victory in six starts.

The siege of Tobruk will rank with Dunkerque as one of the epic stories of this war. It appears to be ending now, not in surrender of the dogged garrison that held it through more than seven months of almost continual shelling from the air, but as that garrison fights its way toward British rescue forces sweeping westward once more across Libya.

The letter was written two months ago; the writer reported planning to return to Paris the day after writing it.

Closer coordination of the Army, Navy and Civil Aeronautics Administration with American colleges training young fliers to provide military air services with pilot material during the national emergency was urged yesterday by aviation representatives of 115 Eastern universities.

As was generally expected the Ballet Theatre will extend its engagement al the Forty fourth Street Theatre beyond its fortnight of sponsorship by the New Opera Company, which expires with Tuesday's performance.

DAVID O. SELZNICK emerged last week as a dominant figure in the af-affairs of United Artists, of which he became an owner-partner only a few weeks ago, with the reorganization of the company's administrative personnel.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Mississippi's once-beaten Rebels rushed on toward a possible bowl bid today with a sloshing 18-0 victory over Arkansas before about 10,000 rain-soaked fans.

NASHVILLE, Term., Nov. 22 -- A gallant Vanderbilt team wrecked Alabama's post-season bowl hopes today and enhanced its own chances for a New Year's Day invitation by smashing the Crimson Tide into the rain-soaked mire of Dudley Field, 7 to 0.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- New German gains on the Moscow front, where what is termed "probably the greatest battle ever fought" left blood-soaked fields strewn with thousands of German bodies and the wreckage of hundreds of tanks, were acknowledged today in reports from the Soviet capital.

"We Go Forward," a "sacred masque," was presented at Town Hall last night by the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society in its drive for $110,000 as part of its 110th anniversary. The masque, described as a "miniature opera on a religious theme," depicted in a series of dramatic episodes the history of the society.

That the war is already having a serious effect upon education in the United States is brought out by a report made public yesterday by the Commission for the Defense of Democracy Through Education, a body set up last Summer by the National Education Association at its Boston convention.

AMES, Iowa, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Iowa State's Cyclones, beaten four times by other Big Six foes, battled Kansas State's favored Wildcats to a 12-to-12 tie today in their final Conference football game before 6,000 chilled spectators.

THE root idea of this arresting book is to be found in a sentence quoted by Mr. Adamic from one of the thousands of letters he has received from persons of immigrant stock (and who, besides the American Indian, is not of immigrant stock ?) all over the country.

THE adult world as it impinges upon the mind of a child is a difficult thing to portray. Barbara Tunnell Anderson succeeds notably in this field in her novel, her first, "The Days Grow Cold." Through the eyes of 12-year-old Lucinda Darby the pattern of a small Southern town comes vividly to life.

VICHY, France, Nov. 22 -- There has been a fight going on between Jean Borotra, the "Bounding Basque," and former tennis champion, who is now Commissioner General for Sports, and Pierre Caziot, the matter-of-fact Minister of Agriculture.

Although complete figures of sales of paintings, sculpture, prints, photographs and craft work throughout the country during National Art Week, Nov. 17-23 will not be available for some time, a few encouraging statistics from various parts of the nation reached the office of Thomas J. Watson, national chairman of Art Week and president of the International Business Machines Corporation, last week.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- The Jewish people will have a "tremendous reparation bill" to present to the nations when they sit around the peace table and will have the right to ask that the Jewish problem be solved in a fundamental way, Dr. Joshua Loth Liebman, rabbi of Temple Israel, declared tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- How the accumulation of carbon in engines can be reduced to a minimum by a coating of zinc oxide, the same chemical which is the basis of zinc oxide ointments, is disclosed in a patent (No. 2,263,366) awarded to Edward B. Peck of Elizabeth, and Peter J. Gaylor of Union, N.J.

IN his first year as editor of this annual, Herschel Brickell -- ably assisted as was Harry Hansen before him, by Miss Munel Fuller, herself an editor of discriminating taste -- has gathered together stories that are serious in their intention, workmanlike in construction, and very pleasant to read.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- The Cornell University Athletic Association had a net profit of $62,305 during the year 1940-41, according to the report released by James Lynah, director of athletics. This was the fifth successive year that the Department of Physical Education and Athletics of the university showed an operating surplus.

FOLLOWING the recent formal opening of the first exhibition of the Gertrude Whittall Foundation Collection of Musical Autographs its treasures have been placed on display at the Library of Congress for an indefinite period.

DETROIT, Nov. 22 -- Philip Murray emerged this week from the shadow of John L. Lewis, in which he had lived for thirty years. The fourth constitutional convention of the Committee for Industrial Organization, just finished, marked the end of the dominance which Mr. Lewis has exercised over Mr. Murray and over the affairs of the C.I.O. since it was founded six years ago.

MONTREAL, Nov. 22 -- The New York Rangers ended a four-game losing streak tonight when they swamped the Montreal Canadiens, 7 to 2, at the Forum. Phil Watson and Bryan Hextall scored two goals each for the Blue Shirts, with the others going to Lynn Patrick, Grant Warwick and Mac Colville.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- With one scintillating play, Army's eleven turned the tide and went on to defeat West Virginia, 7 -- 6, before a gathering of 25,000 at Michie Stadium today.

Physical education students at Hunter College will present the woman's angle in the "keep fit for defense" drive on Wednesday evening in a program showing various aspects of their work at the college.

Medical re-education of persons with speech defects will be the theme of the twenty-fifth anniversary celebration of the National Hospital for Speech Disorders at which Dr. Edmund Ezra Day, president of Cornell University, will be the principal speaker on Tuesday.

SEATTLE, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The University of Oregon's touchdown twins -- Tommy Roblin and Curt Mecham -- outscored and outlasted the Washington Huskies today to knock the Washingtonians out of further Rose Bowl contention with a stirring 19-to-16 victory.

TOKYO (By Wireless). IN the beginning the parent gods, Izanagi and Izanami at the command of the Council of the Gods, gave birth to the Japanese Islands and also the succession of deities who peopled the heavens, earth and nether world. The most illustrious of these deities was Amaterasu O-Mikami, the Sun Goddess, who was appointed to rule the plain of the High Heavens.

After an absence of three seasons Margaret Matzenauer returned to the local concert platform with a recital given yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The former Metropolitan contralto, who will go down in the history of song as one of the greatest artists of her day, was ardently acclaimed by a large audience eager to honor her and happy to be accorded the privilege of conveying its admiration, high esteem and abiding affection.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- The hope that German Government and business circles are pinning to an eventual conquest of cotton-growing areas in Eastern Europe and Asia is reflected in the reorganization and expansion of the Baumwolle Aktien Gesellschaft of Bremen, details of which have been announced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Passage of the law revising the Neutrality Act has spurred governmental activity on the oceans far beyond the basic legal authorizations in the law.
ROME, Sunday, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Violent new British attacks in the Tobruk sector of the Libyan front were reported early today by the official news agency Stefani.

BRITISH HEADQUARTERS, Western Desert, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- Squadron after squadron of the Imperial Air Fleet, pouring out like an endless stream of great hornets, hurled themselves into the titanic tank battle raging south of Tobruk today.

An assemblage of diplomatic officials, high-ranking military and naval officers, members of the British and Canadian colonies in this city and other men and women prominent in society and official circles will gather in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Wednesday night for the gala Navy Ball under the auspices of Bundles for Britain and the Navy League of the United States.

An increasing share of national defense production is being distributed among the smaller manufacturers of the New York metropolitan area, it was disclosed yesterday by W.O. KEY WEST, Fla. -- Work will begin Dec. 1 on the construction of one of the most unusual water mains in the country, a 145-mile pipeline from Florida City to Key West. To be completed in May at a cost of $3,500,000, the eighteen-inch pipe will carry fresh water from the mainland of Florida to the southernmost point in the United States.

As its contribution to the national emergency the nursing committee of the national defense department of the General Federation of Women's Clubs is urging more women to enroll in one of the various nursing services, for which there is an increasing demand.

Another phase no less important and dramatic takes place in the laboratories where engineers and designers work against time and each other to produce a more efficient plane.

MEXICO'S antiquity, one of the country's chief attractions, will be dramatized with the early conversion of a colonial palace to an information center for tourists. Early arrivals this Winter will find busy typists and hustling clerks and attendants dispensing travel information for 1941 within the rooms of a gracious mansion dating from the eighteenth century, and itself an outstanding point of interest in Mexico City.

HAVING shown us what he can do as a popularizer of science in his "Birth and Death of the Sun" the lively and entertaining Professor Gamow descends from his pedestal as one of the leading theoretical physicists of our time to give us a companion volume on the earth and to converse engagingly with the masses again.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The "retirement" of General Maxime Weygand as leader of the French Empire in Africa has produced about as many vague and conflicting interpretations as a patient public will stand, but everybody seems to be agreed on at least one point: this development bodes no good for the democracies.

RETURNED letters addressed to sections of Poland where Jews have been settled indicate that delivery there is impossible. LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Maxim M. Litvinoff, newly appointed Soviet Ambassador to the United States, abandoned plans to visit London en route to Washington, it was learned tonight, following a "muddle" that barred him from a British transport plane at Teheran.

To "the heart of one of the wildest and richest regions in the whole fabulous span of Spanish glory" -- so Randolph Leigh invites his readers to follow the course of his own journeying along the Gulf of California.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Oregon State College, Pacific Coast Conference football leader, overcame a light University of Montana team today, 27 to 0.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: IN the first edition of John Gunther's "Inside Latin America" (Harper Brothers) appear some paragraphs relating to Bolivia which I feel constrained to rectify. Plans to establish new civilian defense volunteer offices in Northern New Jersey will be furthered at a meeting called for Tuesday at the Essex County Country Club, in West Orange. WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Nearly 1,000,000 persons in the country are enrolled as volunteers under the Civilian Protection Program worked out by the Office of Civilian Defense, Mayor La Guardia, director, announced today. A total of 5,935 defense councils have been set up, it was added.

Upon this country's exporters Mexico depends for her automobiles, typewriters, radios, machinery, watches, perfumes, tooth paste, razors and other consumer and industrial articles.

THE Metropolitan Opera House in season is like a railroad terminal, operating twenty-four hours out of every twenty-four. LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Tennessee used two of its own passes and one of Kentucky's to tally three times and defeat its Southeastern Conference rival, 20 -- 7, today before 13,000 chilled fans.

Stocks yesterday went through the heaviest Saturday session since May and the second broadest session of 1941 and closed steady and mixed. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was large in low-priced shares, reportedly being sold for tax purposes, and amounted to 364,270 shares.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 -- In a hopelessly one-sided game that contrasted with last year's thrilling spectacle, Pennsylvania today concluded its most satisfying season since 1924 with a 16-0 victory over Cornell before 73,000 at Franklin Field.

ONE of the most madcap situations of the current theatrical picture seemed to be developing the past week out of a mixture of Groucho Marx, jazzedup Gilbert and Sullivan and M. Lincoln Schuster. Mr. Marx, who can turn out rapid-fire gags on the telephone just as fast as he can on the stage, was asked just who was going to sponsor that rumored production of "lolanthe" in which he would play the Lord Chancellor.

KEARNY, N.J., Nov. 22 -- The United States was brought two steps nearer its two-ocean Navy today when the twin destroyers Aaron Ward and Buchanan, sister ships of the torpedoed U.S.S. Kearny, were launched within twenty-two minutes of each other at the Navy-operated yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Contending that "we have made a record of military production which has probably never been equaled even in Germany," Senator O'Mahoney asserted tonight that the time was here to relax rigid defense priorities and release materials vital to small industry.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22 -- A complete change in attitude toward libraries and library resources is advocated by Dr. Julian P. Boyd, librarian of Princeton University, in his annual report.

The concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall introduced to the public of this city the Third Symphony of young Mr. William Schumann, a symphony which, for this chronicler, takes the position of the best work by an American of the rising generation that he has heard.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 22 -- Muhlenberg crushed the Upsala eleven by 52 -- 7 today. Scoring in every period and registering nineteen first downs to three, the home forces dominated the play against the Viking's.

Six matches were played yesterday in the seventh annual proamateur squash racquets doubles tournament in the Heights Casino, Brooklyn. Allan Cummings and H.D. Lancaster, defending champions from the Apawamis Club, came through to defeat C. O'Connor and C.K. Cook of the Union League, but it took them four games to score a victory.

LONDON. ONE of the burning questions of the day is that of nationalism versus internationalism, and a widespread sense of our need to cultivate an international outlook has given rise to the proposal of many schemes for establishing some kind of government that will control the mutual relations of individual countries while leaving them free to regulate their own internal affairs.

CAMDEN, S.C., Nov. 22 -- Five months of the greatest campaign in military history ended this week as the Nazis renewed their Moscow offensive and continued to struggle eastward painfully -- and slowly -- through the mud and snow of a Russian Winter.

FHA Administrator Abner H. Ferguson reported yesterday that work was started on more than 100,000 small residences in defense housing areas designated by President Roosevelt since last April, utilizing private capital and the FHA insured-mortgage plan.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The British military and air headquarters here issued the following today:
NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Oklahoma shoved Marquette's golden avalanche back uphill today, 61 to 14, after the invaders had roared down on the Sooners to take a first-quarter lead.

Determined to wrest back from the drug trade the lucrative business in vitamins, food manufacturers were reported yesterday to have set in motion positive steps to increase consumer demand for nutritional foods through greater cooperation wit one another and with government agencies.

I When the cast of the Ice Follies arrives in New York to begin its stand at Madison Square Garden, the Roy Shipstad and Oscar Johnson show will have performed before more than half a million persons in seven cities. The current edition of the Ice Follies opens at the Eighth Avenue arena on Dec. 1.

THE Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra, which made its bow ten days ago, is being sponsored by the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences in the hope that it will become a permanent institution, for the borough has not had a regular symphony orchestra since Theodore Thomas dealt the old Brooklyn Philharmonic a death blow by leaving it to organize the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in 1891.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Traders in wheat remained on the sidelines today on the Board of Trade and prices held within a range of about 5/8 cent a bushel. Reports that the House of Representatives would start debate next week on the price-control bill kept interest at minimum.

Admirals are generally such awesome figures that one seldom thinks of them in anything but a state of finished glory, but the first one of the United States Navy was a midshipman at 9, a captain at 12, and a war veteran at 13, and as such is a figure to capture the young imagination as seen here in his boyhood.

FORT WORTH, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Texas A. M. won the Southwest Conference football championship although idle today as Rice battled Texas Christian to a scoreless tie in a game which saw the Horned Frogs unable to get past the Owl 38.
THE committee which has been working on standard laws for the game of gin rummy has completed its draft of the laws and they will be published on or about Jan. 1, 1942.

The violin, and other string instruments are losing their popularity in this country, while the piano and various non-string orchestral instruments have grown in popularity, George A. Wedge, dean of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music, disclosed yesterday in making public his seven-year report.

A NEW objective for the more than 21,000,000 tourists who visit our national parks, monuments and military areas each year, a vast wilderness of 2,500 square miles has been proposed officially as the Escalante National Monument.

A plan whereby unemployed actors and playwrights in New York would get resident fellowships at community and university theatres throughout the country was proposed yesterday by Elmer Rice and John Gassner at the tenth annual meeting of the National Theatre Conference in the Hotel Piccadilly.

ASSUMING that many people add house guests to their list of holiday projects this column is devoted to housing such characters -- on the theory that if you are going to go to the trouble of having extra people in the home you might as well knock yourself out and do a superior job.

HOLLYWOOD. BECAUSE of its contemporary aspects, "Yankee Doodle Dandy," Warners life of George M. Cohan, is a difficult subject for the screen, but the studio regards the time as peculiarly ripe for a biography of the flag-waving song-and-dance man.

SPARTANBURG, S.C., Nov. 22 -- The largest fleet of transport planes ever assembled In this country for military purposes was used this week in the first phase of the First Army manoeuvres as air power again demonstrated its major importance in modern war.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Andy Tomasic, Temple's magnificent tailback, bade a spinetingling farewell to college football today, lashing his Owls to a 31-13 triumph over injury-riddled Holy Cross before 18,000 at Fitton Field.

THE school teacher's occupational disease -- supporting a husband -- is the broad pattern of this book. The perceptive and thorough analysis of a man's degeneration, and subconscious dependence upon his wife's steady salary, and the sensitive unfolding of a wife's realization that the justification of faith and love imposes new problems and psychic responsibilities definitely prove that this is not a mediocre novel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 -- (AP) -- Marriage, with Charley Corbett up, came through for a surprise victory in the $15,000 added Marchband Handicap at Tanforan today. The time was 1:49 for the mile and an eighth.
ORLANDO, Fla. -- Fish psychology and cottonseed meal today are transforming Florida lakes and streams into veritable paradises for fishermen who seek the big-mouth black bass.

"Peloponnesian Wanderings," a traveler's view of the southwestern peninsula of Greece in the days before the war, will be the subject of the free lecture to be given at the New York Botanical Garden Saturday at 3 P.M. Professor and Mrs. Clarence H. Young, who made their last visits to Greece in 1934 and 1935, will be the speakers.
A "SONG OF FRANCE" can never be a matter of the emotions merely. The "song" that has echoed through a thousand years of triumph and tragedy must speak from, as it pays homage to the mind and spirit.

SANTA CRUZ, Calif -- Of the many New Yorkers who will visit California this Winter, a large number will inevitably miss the most spectacular scenic effect which the State affords -- the big trees. This is probably because most travelers seem to connect these mastodons of the vegetable kingdom only with the high Sierras, when, as a matter of fact, there are thousands of these giants right along the coast.

THOUGH George Preston (the Magnificent) Marshall doesn't like to have it mentioned, last year the Washing-Done Redskins met the Great Big Bears in the play-off for the national professional football championship. Under ordinary circumstances Mr. Marshall, the luxurious laundryman who owns the Washing-Done Red-skins, would still be going about tapping acquaintances on the chest with his malacca cane and telling them how long his warriors held on last year.

MARIA MARKAN, the Icelandic soprano who will make her debut this season at the Metropolitan, is indignant because a mimeographed news-letter known as "The Hour" has bluntly implied that she is a Nazi spy.

Aluminum production in the United States and Canada will be at the rate of 1,120,000,000 pounds a year by the end of next month. At the same time, Germany, Italy and all the conquered countries on the European Continent probably will produce a maximum of 1,100,000,000 pounds, according to an estimate by the United States Bureau of Mines.

Ivy Christmas Wreath I have found that an English Ivy plant, trained around a coat hanger which has been bent to form a circle, will make a delightful Christmas wreath. Carefully wound around the wire, the ivy stems form a perfect wreath.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 22 -- William Carman Roberts of Oswegatchie, Waterford, Conn., managing editor for thirty years of the now defunct Literary Digest, died last night of a heart attack in a State police car which was taking him to the Lawrence Memorial Hospital, after a chauffeur found him lying on a road near his estate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Increased income for farmers and higher food costs for consumers next year were forecast today by the Department of Agriculture.

Open market sales of Manhattan real estate during October showed a substantial increase over the same month of last year both as to the number of deals and the total dollar volume of trading, according to the monthly sales survey of the Real Estate Board of New York.

A comprehensive nine-point plan to guard against espionage in the radio "shacks" of America's merchant fleet and against other enemy activities is receiving serious consideration from authorities in Washington, and some suggestions already have been placed in effect.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Passage of some measure to curb strikes will be pushed, Representative Norton of New Jersey said today after a conference with President Roosevelt.

NEW CURARE -- Fred Hardenbrook, research fellow of the Rochester Museum of Arts and Sciences, recently returned from Dutch Guiana with a type of curare which, as shown by analysis made in the Squibb Institute, belongs to a hitherto unknown variety.

IT is sixteen years since Louis Bromfield published his first novel. In that time, if it were possible to take a census, probably the adjective most often applied to him by reviewers would be "exciting." Mr. Bromfield is remarkably versatile -- novels so disparate as "Night in Bombay" and "The Strange Case of Miss Annie Spragrg" have not seemed incongruous coming from his pen.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 22 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizaions ended its annual convention at noon here today with the adoption of resolutions savagely assailing the National Labor Relations Board and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. George Walbridge Perkins of this city and Cold Spring, N.Y., will give a tea at their home, 6 East Ninety-fourth Street, on Friday to introduce their daughter, Miss Penelope Perkins. On Dec. 26, they will give a supper dance for their daughter and Miss Mildred C. Harrison, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Harrison of this city and Bedford Village, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Representative Norton said today that the Labor Committee would consider several proposals on Monday, including her own, which would give statutory sanction to the Defense Mediation Board, provide for a thirty-day cooling-off period before strikes and permit the chairman of the Mediation Board to fill vacancies caused by resignations from that body.

THE important question to which this book gives a clear reply is that of the influence of a relatively small group, a "gang," on a nation fundamentally sound. It is more than a biography and a simple portrait of a politician.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- John L. Lewis ordered the captive coal mine strike ended today when he unexpectedly accepted the proposal of President Roosevelt for arbitration of the union shop issue.

Returning from a two-day trip to Washington and Philadelphia on national defense matters, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would begin an immediate investigation into the Harlem stabbing in which the victim staggered four blocks, in each of which a policeman was supposed to be on duty every minute of the day and night, without being able to find a single patrolman.

AVOIDANCE of sharp curves in building highways and elimination of those in existence is increasing as a safety factor in American motoring. The movement raises the question "What is a safe road curve?"

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Defense agencies received authority to requisition property required for the defense of the country in an Executive Order signed by President Roosevelt on Wednesday and made public today.

To advance its intensive community health, civic and social work on the lower East Side, the Jacob A. Riis Neighborhood Settlement will give a benefit theatre party on the night of Dec. 11. The play chosen for the occasion is "Junior Miss," at the Lyceum Theatre.

JOHN DOS PASSOS said that he had been particularly interested lately in what happens to American writers when they reach middle age, what it is that confuses them, what checks their careers. He shook a last drop of gin and bitters out of the ounce-and-a-half measure onto the ice in his drinking glass.
The Rev. Bernard Michael Kaplan, author, lecturer and dramatist, died in his home, 644 West 204th Street, yesterday, after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 -- Che Le of Matson's Catawba, Pekingese champion owned by Mrs. James M. Austin of Old Westbury, L.I., triumphed among 1,089 dogs in the forty-seventh fixture of the Kennel Club of Philadelphia tonight. The Peke now has a record of twenty-one best-in-show awards, ninety-nine group victories and 103 breed prizes.

A NATION-WIDE opening of the Metropolitan Opera Company's 1941-42 season is due Saturday afternoon at 2, five days after its formal home-town introduction here. A WJZ hook-up, this time boasting a roster of 145 stations, will line up to carry the presentations afield from the Thirty-ninth Street auditorium for the next sixteen weeks.

HARRY SCHERMAN. who as president of the Book of the Month Club, has unified the reading habits of what is coming to be an amazing number of Americans, has just turned his attention to another kind of unification.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Prices of livestock here were steady today atfer a week of irregular gains which reflected prospects of a let-up in the competition of poultry and sharply reduced receipts, for which the Thanksgiving holiday accounted in part. Fresh pork loins lost 1 to 1 1/2 cents a pound during the week and some cured items also were down.

New York City's gasoline conservation campaign begun on Nov. 12 to cut down waste through free tests of motor vehicle engine efficiency ended yesterday after, it is estimated, 60,000 cars, trucks and taxicabs had been examined. This is about 5 per cent of vehicle registration in the city.
WHAT THE CITIZEN SHOULD KNOW ABOUT THE MERCHANT MARINE. By Carl D. Lane. Illustrated by the author. 201 pp. New York: W.W. Norton Co. $2.

HOLIDAY shopping got off to a fast start in many centers after the earlier holiday. Some signs of spottiness were noted but it was not yet possible to distinguish general trends. Trade volume was boosted by a combination of gift and apparel buying.

VICHY, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Authorized sources acknowledged today that Chief of State Marshal Petain was going to meet "a high German personage" in occupied France, amid indications of imminent developments in the Mediterranean area involving not only Germany, Italy and France but Spain as well.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The new surtax rates as set forth under Form 1040 of the individual income tax return for 1941 upon certain specified amounts of surtax net income are given as follows:

Taking advantage of an opening-period fumble to get its first touchdown and then driving seventy-five yards in the second quarter for its other marker, Boys High downed its time-honored Brooklyn foe, Manual Training, 13 to 6, in the thirty-sixth annual game between the schools at Boys High Field yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 22 -- While the reverberations of the "Weygand crisis" dwindled to official whispers in Vichy circles today, "collaborationists" pushed preparations a step nearer for France's immediate induction into the "New Order" in Europe, according to information reaching diplomatic foreign sources here tonight.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Major Edwin C. Eckel, chief geologist of the Tennessee Valley Authority, died tonight at his farm home near here. Death was attributed to a heart ailment. His age was 67.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sunday, Nov. 23 -- So great Is the ascendency of the Royal Air Force in the Libyan battle that the Imperial troops moving up to the front do not even look up when they hear the drone of motors because they know the planes are friendly.

DURING the first World War Gino Speranza, an American living in Italy, offered his services to the United States Embassy at Rome and was appointed Attache on Political Intelligence. It was his job to keep the Embassy and the State Department informed on Italian events and policies, and, more particularly, on current opinion in Italy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Refusal of the Navy to make public news of Axis submarine sinkings was criticized today by three of the Senate's non-interventionist bloc, who declared all publicity regarding naval activities should be made known unless American lives were endangered.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 22 -- Robert C. Zuppke, the little man no longer there, ended a brilliant twenty-nine-year coaching career today emotionally watching his last "Fighting Illini" go down to a crushing defeat before Northwestern, 27 to 0.

Historians are likely to underline some date in this late Fall of 1941, and write that here a tide carrying all mankind into the future began to flood the lowlands of a distressed world. The date may not fall within the week which ended yesterday, yet over the vast oceans of our destiny there has been a stirring.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 22 -- The expected didn't happen here today, despite the fact that Harvard defeated Yale before the biggest crowd that has sat in the Harvard Stadium, since 1937. The expected, had been a slaughter of the innocents, but there was no such thing.

NEW ROUTE: The British radio last week announced completion of the first full-scale trip over a "great new overland supply route" from India through Iran to Russia. The first shipment, a consignment of jute, rolled past 5,000 laborers still at work preparing the way for lorry caravans that will carry armaments for Russia's war machine.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Referring to the thoughtful and extremely interesting letter of Dr. Herman A. Gray, in THE TIMES of Nov. 12, I quote a historian of the early history of these parts, no less a person than Diedrich Knickerbocker, whose sapient observations first appeared, I believe, in the notable year of 1809. Says our good friend Diedrich:

IN a week when some fifty new exhibitions opened -- to say nothing of the special event connected with National Art Week -- it is possible only to point hastily here and there for the benefit of the conscientious gallery goer.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Nov. 22 -- At the conclusion of the first running in the annual two-day Autumn meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club today, three dogs stood out as having accomplished many of the things that are expected of first-class retrievers.
Colgate and Columbia staged a scoring hurly-burly at Baker Field yesterday and the Red Raiders were on top at the finish, 30 to 21, as the teams closed out their campaigns.

BUFFALO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Direct negotiations between the Bell Aircraft Corporation, producing planes for the United States and Britain, and the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers in an effort to prevent a threatened strike are likely to be resumed within a week or two, a company spokesman said tonight.
HAVANA, Nov. 22 -- Closer cooperation among university women of the Americas was planned by the first regional meeting of the International Federation of University Women which closed here today.

The man who likes to roll cliches off his tongue could have a field day with the recent accomplishment of Herman Haines up in the Province of New Brunswick who, fifty years after his father performed a similar feat, killed two deer with one shot.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass -- This city has lost its last whaler. The town, which in its heyday ninety years ago owned almost half of the American whale fleet of 700 sail, now has parted with the only survivor of its former glory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- President Roosevelt has evidence that Reichsfuehrer Hitler has plans for an all-Europe economic conference designed to obtain the collaboration of Axis belligerents, occupied countries and neutrals for supplies that Germany urgently needs.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- Rostov, the "door to the Caucasus," has been captured, a special German High Command communique announced this morning. The Germans are now seen well on their way to Krasnodar and the first of the Caucasian oil fields at Maikop.

Capital and labor must cooperate for the welfare of democracy in this emergency, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday. Jewish Book Week, Propaganda Minister Goebbels's "Ten Commandments" of anti-Semitism, and peace aims were other sermon subjects.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 22 -- Scoring an upset, Mrs. Ed McCuan's Wise Moss came from behind today to win going away from R.W. Collins's Sweet Willow in a $5,000 match race at Rockingham Park with a side bet of $1,000 -- winner take all -- as the New England turf season ended.
DALLAS, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Striking twice in the second half, once by air and once on the ground. Southern Methodist whipped the in-and-out Baylor Bears, 14 to 0, before a football crowd o 10,000 today.

"INNOCENCE is a gem, a hidden treasure, rarely to be brought to light," writes Mr. Belloc in the last of the forty-eight diminutive essays collected in this volume. The gem may be a little dim at times, with a milky suffusion which is not always opalescent; but on the whole Mr. Belloc's book does convey a pleasing impression of your mild scholar's candor.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 -- The first photographs of the influenza virus, type A, which caused the epidemic in this country last year, and a report describing the isolation, concentration and preparation of a new powerful vaccine against it were presented today at the Autumn meeting of the American Philosophical Society.

Although the gardener will not be driven indoors for some weeks yet, it is none too soon for him to be giving thought to the Winter window garden. And among all bulbs suitable for flowering indoors, none is more satisfactory, all things considered, than the calla.

BOSTON will be the center of philatelic interest on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, when the American Philatelic Congress, comprising collectors, dealers and stamp writers, will hold its seventh annual assembly. The Postoffice Department will set up a convention branch postoffice in the Hotel Statler and a special cachet will be applied to covers.

LONDON, Nov 22 -- The biggest ingle campaign in which the Britsh are meeting the Germans has now opened in Libya. It would be quite impossible to exaggerate the importance of the British offensive, which was planned for six nonths and is designed to destroy, once and for all, Axis power in Libya.

AMERICAN art dominates the galleries and museums this year. More works by Americans are being shown in more places than ever before. The Carnegie International Exhibition, one of the most important annual shows in the country, this season became all-American.

HERE is delightful entertainment for an evening and part. It may be, of a night, for this is a book that cannot well be laid aside till its intricate plot has been untangled to the last thread. It is entertainment that is invariably absorbing or amusing, has moments of explosive excitment and a sufficiently terrible and dramatically suitable climax.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 22 -- Aonbarr, a brown son of Boatswain, making his first start since his arrival from Kentucky, captured the $6,350 Prince George Autumn Handicap before a crowd estimated at 15,000 here this bright afternoon.

As its ninth annual benefit dance, the Kosciuszko Foundation, of which Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken is president and Professor Stephen P. Mizwa, executive director, will present a Polka Ball on the night of Jan. 23 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Here are six detective stories by five different authors, one of whom writes under two different names. The titles are: "Bermuda Grapevine," by Mignon G. Eberhart; "Death on Post No. 7," by Frank Gruber; "Farewell Party," by Leslie Ford; Rx: Death," by Philip Wylie; "The Policeman's Cape," by David Frome, and "Bottom Deal," by Judson Philips.

WILMINGTON, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- The Whiteface Mountain project, approved by the public at the recent election, should give New York State one of the leading downhill skiing centers in the country during the Winter of 1942-43.

THE awakening of the earth in the springtime is the background for the awakening of love in Elizabeth Reeves's new novel, "Then Again June." Gabrielle Adams has been brought up in a gloomy house by a stern maiden aunt and a father with an unsteady mind.

MR. TATE'S essays, which have nothing to do with the war, argue that man is no longer allowed to be moral, intelligent or literate. Finance-capitalist economics has, long before the present conflict, taken from the people any responsible control over the way they make their living.

A open meeting is announced for this afternoon at 2 o'clock at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. This is to be held by what is known popularly and tentatively as the Bombshell Group, now in process of being fully organized, as a direct result of the controversy that ran for so many weeks in these columns, following publication of the challenge sent in to us by Samuel M. Kootz.

OPERA on the grand scale, given, whatever its relative defects or virtues, as it is given nowhere else today in the world, makes its periodical beginning tomorrow night in the Metropolitan Opera House. Opera is presented there, as a prevailing rule, in the language to which it was composed, and with casts accustomed to sing the composer's language.

ONE of the most eloquent albums to come this way in many days is by and with Carl Sandburg, who reads some of the lines from his book The People, Yes. (Decca, three twelve-inch records, $3.50.) The lines themselves, as much as we have of them here, are the true stuff of American life.

ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 22 -- Frankie Sinkwich and the Georgia football team made twin bids today, routing Dartmouth, 35 -- 0, before 17,000 fans to reassert Georgia's hope for an Orange Bowl invitation and Frankie's bid for an All-America rating.

A departure from the usual design and exterior and interior arrangement of a small home is to be found in the story-and-a-half house of the cottage type recently designed by Frank J. Fellowa, Long Island builder, and completed for Frank Thomas in Kenwood Estates, newest community being developed by Mr. Fellows at DeMott and Wales Avenues, Baldwin, L.I.

When the word "talent scout" is mentioned one usually thinks of an agent from Hollywood, wearily dousing cigarettes while giving a bored eye and ear to the younger performers along Broadway. Or perhaps of coaches from the professional leagues in the grandstands of college ball games.

ROMANTIC novels with love-ladies gracefully posing against the background of history crop up regularly. This tale, unpretentious and credible, manages at times to achieve an air of excitement and tenseness, but falls short of doing justice to the original Lona and the hectic period of the great Southwest's development.

ROME, Nov. 22 -- Catholicism is not at a cross-roads with a choice to make, writes the Osservatore Romano today in an editorial that sources close to the Secretariat of State assert represents a fundamental pronouncement of Vatican policy.

A periodic inventory of holdings of textiles by mills, converters and cutters, which may also include holdings of distributors, is planned by the Office of Price Administration, and the first count may be taken of stocks as of the end of this month, it was learned last week.

Several developments yesterday in realty and building trades circles indicated that the industry in New York and elsewhere is preparing promptly to meet the new conditions brought about by Federal orders controlling purchases of some vital construction materials.

TOKYO, Nov. 22 -- The international situation surrounding the Japanese Empire is becoming so tense it is on the point of explosion, Lieut-General Kisaburo Ando, executive vice president of the Imperial Rule Assistance Association, told the conference of the Executive Members Association, and leading businessmen today.

FROM Netherlands Indies philately's Dutch East Indies, has come the promised series of semi-postals issued for the benefit of the Indonesian Association Moehammadijah, which, devotes itself to caring for indigent Mohammedans.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 22 -- The first study ever undertaken at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology about the collective careers of a representative majority of students who were graduated in the last twenty-four years from the Department of Business and Engineering Administration was recently completed.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 22 -- Bail of $25,000 each was set today by United States Commissioner Joseph F. Holland for two brothers described by Federal narcotic agents as operators of an international narcotic smuggling ring.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 22 -- This city's journalist-prophet who counseled "count the Leopard's spots and divide by two" saw his pre-game prediction transformed into an accurate appraisal today as Lafayette laced Lehigh, 47 to 7, in their seventy-fifth football clash.

MR. JOHNSON has made out his case. As the reader might suspect from the order of words in the subtitle, the evidence shows that President Roosevelt is a democrat and not a dictator. The book deserves to have a wide hearing.

Potting up, albeit a simple process, has more to it than filling a pot with a plant and soil. The intention is not to make it sound complicated, but to route the shortcuts and procedure for ease and satisfactory results.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Nov. 22 -- The leaders of District 4 of the United Mine Workers of America, acting on telephoned instructions from William Hynes, district chief, notified each of the seventy-six locals tonight to send three delegates to a meeting here tomorrow afternoon at which John L. Lewis's agreement to submit the captive coal mine strike to arbitration is expected to be ratified.

The main ballroom of the Plaza will be the setting on the night of Dec. 2 for the first of the biannual Yorkville Dinner Dances for this season. These dances have been features among Winter parties here for many years and are given under the auspices of the Yorkville Community Association to support its center at 1639 York Avenue and Camp Yorkville in Harriman State Park.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 22 -- In an unpopularity contest a native son who has become a powerful labor leader would doubtless lead the voting in the Corn Belt. That is because John L. Lewis, product of a little Southern Iowa village, is the present smybol in the mind of the Corn Belt farmer of all that he believes to be wrong with organized labor.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- The German Air Force suffered its second heavy loss within a week when Colonel Werner Moelders was reported killed today in a Junkers-52 transport plane accident near Breslau on returning from yesterday's funeral of General Ernst Udet.

RADIO sets produced and sold this year will establish an all-time high. By New Year's more than 13,000,000 new receivers, it is estimated, will have been set up in American homes. Had radio held to the almost furious pace established in the first half of 1941 the year's set total might well have passed 15,000,000, but defense priorities and scarcity of materials slowed the production.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: After Russia's heroic resistance and the repeal of the Neutrality Act provisions it has become certain that the Allies will win the war. But it still remains very doubtful if they will win the peace or lose it again as in 1919.

Rain fell in the hour before the Egyptian dawn. The sandy desert turned into brown and sticky paste, but in the wet darkness hushed infantrymen were boarding trucks and from camouflaged shelters planes of the R.A.F., waiting for leather helmeted pilots, were being trundled.

New York debutantes of this season and former years are receiving the cooperation of several prominent young women of Pan-American heritage in plans for the Coffee Ball -- Fiesta Pan-Americana, Which will be given Dec. 12 at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Center.

Under the broadened income tax base it is estimated by the Treasury Department that more than 22,000,000 individuals will be required to make returns for the current year. Probably not over half this number, however, will be obligated to pay a tax.
BORDENTOWN, N.J., Nov. 22 -- Coach Robert (Doc) Hoehn's Bordentown Military Institute football team concluded its 1941 campaign today with a 19-0 triumph over the Albright College freshman eleven.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The week-long "captive" mine strike, called by John L. Lewis despite Presidential admonitions that coal production essential for defense must continue, produced such strong reactions in Congress this week that most any type of antistrike legislation would have passed either house of Congress if the Administration leadership had permitted it to be brought to a vote.
ASIDE from all its literary associations, the product of the industrious bee has very practical aspects for the cook determined to do her Christmas cooking early.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Nebraska power-housed the length of the field for one touchdown, then blocked a kick for another, to offset the brilliant passing of Tom Farmer and gained a 14-to-13 victory today over Iowa in an inter-Conference football game.

IT must always be a matter for gratification that humorous writers ever write at all. They live in a world in which objects, animate or inanimate constantly threaten their repose and their sanity. Their modest attempts to behave like ordinary human beings are thwarted at every turn.

THE Winner's Series of the National Orchestral Association, which opens Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Hall under Leon Barzin's direction, will consist of five concerts devoted to representative works by American composers who have won awards in important composition contests.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Missouri, its T-Formation ticking off dazzling long runs with the regularity of the falling snow and rain, capped an undefeated Bix Six football season today with a dynamic 45-6 triumph over Kansas.

IN 1833 Michael Floy Jr. was 25 years old, and took his share of toil in the nursery and greenhouses established by his father as a family enterprise. Their Bowery Village home was on Broadway near what is now Eleventh Street, but the nursery was in the country at Harlem, on land extending from Fourth to Fifth Avenue and from 125th to 127th Street.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 22 -- Speculation that the battleship Prince of Wales may be in Indian or Pacific waters as the nucleus of a new British Asiatic Fleet is current here in consequence of the announcement that the vessel recently visited Cape Town.

OTTAWA, Nov. 22 -- With the courage of pioneers and under the leadership of Donald Gordon, the most dynamic man the government could find for the job, Canada today is getting ready to put a complete control on all prices so as to prevent war-time conditions from dislocating the wage and price structure of the country and producing such inflation as occurred during the last war.

Evening wear was much in demand in the apparel market last week, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. Mail orders picked up on piece goods.

In his third book for boys and girls Robb White explores a new path of adventure, not that there isn't much of the salt and sea wind of "Smuggler's Sloop" in Cherry's handling of a sailboat in Florida sun and squalls, but here the main theme is a little girl's discovery of courage and her brave acceptance of life's emergencies, which were, in her case, strange and hard.
Late Fall rentals are increasing considerably the number of East Side residential buildings under the management of Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., that are 100 per cent rented.

Despite the increase in merchant ship construction during the last year in the United States, the average age of vessels in the American merchant fleet is higher than last year, according to the latest bulletin issued by the American Bureau of Shipping.
Janet Wood, 23-year-old model, and Frederick Babe, 34, a writer, of 23 West Ninetieth Street, were found shot to death early today in her apartment at 410 East Sixtyfifth Street.

CARLISLE, Pa., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Dickinson tired in the fourth quarter after leading Gettysburg for three periods today and the Bullets pushed over three touchdowns, including one on an 86-yard run by Geiter, to come from behind for a 31-to-17 victory before a crowd of 5,000.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 22 -- Pepper Petrella, a slippery little halfback from Downingtown, Pa., slithered through the hands of the Panthers today for three touchdowns to give a young Penn State eleven a 31-to-7 victory over Pittsburgh before 33,000 ans.

UNDER the sea-wind lives a densely peopled world. From the point of view of its own denizens it is a world of varied adventure and strange compulsion. As man may look at it he finds drama and beauty and amazement, astounding survival and the merciless battles of appethe.

Mayor La Guardia will conduct an orchestra composed of band leaders at the eighth annual "Night of Stars" in Madison Square Garden Wednesday night for the benefit of the United Jewish Appeal for the Joint Distribution Committee, United Palestine Appeal and National Refugee Service, it was announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sunday, Nov. 23 -- Fort Capuzzo, the Italian stronghold in Libya that has changed hands so many times since war came to the desert, has been wrested from the Axis army by New Zealand soldiers taking part in the new British offensive, it was reported last night.

A Northwest Passage around the world and back to Europe has always existed. But for three centuries frustrated explorers failed to find it. Cabot, Hudson and Frobisher all thought that there must be some opening from the North Atlantic, but the gods of chance were against them.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 22 -- Without mentioning the political situation, the official radio at noon today emphatically denied rumors concerning serious complications in President Pedro Aguirre Cerdo's condition. It asked Chileans to avoid spreading unfounded reports and to rely on medical bulletins issued periodically for their information.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 -- A slippery, elusive halfback by the name of Roy (Monk) Gafford played the greatest game of his football career today to spark Auburn to an upset 13-to-0 victory over Villanova.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Nov. 21:

More than $5,000,000,000 of home-loan insurance has been written by the FHA and its income now is sufficient to cover its own operating costs for an indefinite period, Administrator Abner H. Ferguson declared yesterday.

THE series of 'Hiving biographies" continues apace with sketches of twenty scientists, and the newest volume is a welcome addition to the existent set. Already Henry Thomas and Dana Lee Thomas have published the brief life stories of eminent painters, poets, philosophers, composers and rulers.

With only two trading sessions left before the first notice day next Tuesday for the December contract, switching of contracts from the near to the distant positions continued yesterday to ease prices of cotton futures. In quiet trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, liquidation of the near months exerted pressure on the distant months and active futures closed at their lows with net losses of 8 to 12 points.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 22 -- Premier John Curtin, in commenting on the Returned Soldiers' League's advocacy of conscription, said that the whole history of such advocacy in Australia had been marked by increasing national disunity, which was most undesirable at any time and would be adverse in the conduct of the war.

RADIO executives, constantly on the alert for an excuse to take the sting off what they've failed to do with television, have just been struck by a brilliant idea. Thanks to national defense a new excuse for their failure has been found: the great god Priority.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The office of production management will start after Jan. 1 an expanded program of sub-contracting clinics into the hinterland of American industry -- a campaign intended to save the little business man.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 22 -- Dr. Kurt Koffka, Professor of Psychology at Smith College and an authority on the Gestalt theory of psychology, died this morning at his home of a heart ailment at the age of 55. He had been ill for many months.

ON a Spring morning in 1887 an 8-year-old American boy stood on a ship's deck and realized suddenly that he was in the Thames. "Against the leaden sky stood a maze of masts, spars and rigging," and the boy said to himself, "It really is a forest of masts' " as he recalled a phrase from a child's book about London.

RUSSO-JAPANESE medleys clash in the evening sky, when at 6 o'clock the Tokyo and Moscow broadcasters appear on one wave length simultaneously Sometimes both cities are serenading the world with music of a rhythmic nature which blends as in counterpoint.

BY now we tend to say no-hum to criticism of the Administration's defense effort by its "loyal opposition," but when high officials of our government accuse other high officials of gross neglect of the health of our soldiers, that's news -- at once sensational and alarming.

WASHINGTON. APERT little stenographer at the Navy Department remarked the other day that the men may have made this war but the women are running it. And judging from the appearance of the capital these days there is something in what she says.

A corps of more than 100,000 well-trained workers for civilian defense is contemplated in the plans for the first aid training project undertaken by the local Works Project Administration with the cooperation of the American Red Cross and the Department of Health, it was disclosed yesterday by Major Irving V.A. Huie, local WPA Administrator and City Commissioner of Public Works.

KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Nov. 22 -- W. Plunkett Stewart, widely known gentleman rider and president of the Masters of Fox Hounds Association of America, was injured critically today when thrown from his favorite mount while approaching a fence in a fox hunt.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 22 -- Business men and bankers today predicted a "new epoch" in Mexico's economic relations and "new life" for her economy as a result of the agreements signed in Washington.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 22 -- Blacklists, whether American or British, embracing Brazilian firms have raised adverse comment and discussion, and the press has taken up the defense of such firms and condemnation of the measure.

THE Photo Arts Committee for War Relief to the Allies has swung into action with two major events -- a benefit cocktail party at the School of Modern Photography and an organization-dinner meeting at the Hotel Edison.

Retail trade in the New York area turned sharply better on Friday, when gains of 10 per cent or more over a year ago were reported by some local stores. Warm weather during the earlier part of the week, however, slowed sales appreciably.

Engineering work in the national defense program will be discussed at the sixty-second annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Dec. 1 through 5, in the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday. About 100 technical papers will be presented.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Nov. 15 totaled 240,399,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented a decrease of 1,430,000 barrels in the week, comprising decreases of 1,381,000 and 49,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Outplayed for three periods today, the University of Delaware Blue Hens roared back with a three-touchdown assault in the final period to defeat Washington College, 18 to 6, and close its season undefeated.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 22 -- Thirty thousand tons of steel, enough steel to build thirty destroyers, were "irrevocably lost" to the national defense effort as a result of curtailment of production caused by the captive-mine strike in the mills of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, principal subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, officials said tonight.

In a season when appeals for relief in war-ridden countries have multiplied, the movement to aid the children of China is gathering support among more than 500 women's organizations in the city, each of which has received a scroll on which individual members may inscribe their names.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Florida 'Gators loosed two aerial thunderbolts for a pair of touchdowns and a 14-7 victory over Georgia Tech's Engineers before a homecoming crowd of 15,000 today.

The Santa Claus season is here again and the stores are all set to entertain droves of inquisitive young ones who want to make up their minds in advance what to ask for. Only a catalogue could describe every toy, but some are especially tempting.

LONDON -- Burma holds a key position in the Far East, vital to both the British and the Chinese. Hitherto Burma was an asset to Britain mainly in that she had valuable economic resources, such as petroleum, tungsten, wolfram, copper, lead, rubber and silver, together with an annual output of 3,000,000 tons of surplus rice.

Scoring four goals in the final period, the New York Rovers handed the Johnstown Bluebirds their first defeat of the season, 6 -- 1, in an Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The game was the feature of a double-header.

Monday morning, a year ago tomorrow, some 18,700 young Americans, first of new Army's 1,750,000, were inducted into the armed forces under the Selective Service Act. Some stumbled into draft boards with farewell hangovers, some with their women folks' tears still damp on their suiting. Glumly they took the soldier's oath and marched, broken step, to the troop trains.

The Great Okefenokee Swamp is a fearsome place, and yet it is there that Peter Ravenel chooses to spend Christmas with a party of his friends, including Andrea Reid (Andy for short), the girl whom he hopes to marry. Another man who wants to marry Andy and has once been engaged to her is David Ramsay, who also is of the party.

THIS latest book about Cuba focuses its interest on history; and it is as well not to allow yourself to be prejudiced by the jacket's description of the history as "most unique." In spite of that discouraging appeal to impossibility in the blurb-writer's assault upon the English language, the book itself is good reading.

DR. THOMPSON'S thoroughgoing and workmanlike presentation of the background for judgments in dealing with present problems in Southeastern Asia is not a book for beginners. It is in no sense a "popular" book, offers nothing to the "glamour and lure" enthusiasts, avoids arguments and eschews anecdote.

TRAVEL LINES: "Short Grass Country," by Stanley Vestal, tells good tales of that region between the Ozarks and Rockies where life was lusty when prairie schooners and the pony express made history while blazing new trails.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22 -- Princeton didn't have enough Peterses to go around today and so Navy won the twenty-ninth game of the series by the score of 23 -- 0 in the presence of 42,000 spectators in Palmer Stadium.

While shortages of vital materials are beginning to be experienced in most industries, wide discrepancies in the extent of such scarcities are developing, with some manufacturers still turning out astonishing quantities and with others forced to curtail sharply, distributors reported last week.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 22 -- Minsota's mighty tide of football empire -- with Captain Bruce Smith brilliantly riding the crest of the wave -- swept over Wisconsin today to carry the Gophers to the Western Conference and national football championships.

LONDON, Nov. 22 (Reuter) -- Discussing the future of gold in an article titled "Junk or Treasure?" The Manchester Guardian observes that most of the world's old lies underground -- nearly 25,000,000,000 sterling in the United States Government's vaults in Kentucky and the bulk of the remainder in unmined ore.

Challenging the fundamental policy of the Securities and Exchange Commission in corporate reorganization proceeding's, particularly where public utility enterprises are involved, the Pennsylvania Public Utilities Commission, it was disclosed yesterday, has rejected the SEC's recommendations in the reorganization of the Pittsburgh Railways System, a unit in the Standard Gas and Electric Company system.

DO not let the title lead you astray: this is a murder mystery, and a grim one. It begins, to be sure, with a marriage, the marriage of Sophronia Brace (Rony for short) to Eric Chatonier. When Eric brings his bride to the Chatonier plantation home in the bayou country near New Orleans she meets his family for the first time.

General Aniline and Film Directors of the General Aniline and Film Corporation declared yesterday dividends of $1 on the common A stock and 10 cents on the common B stock. A year ago the company paid 75 cents on the A and 7 1/2 cents on the B stock.

Those old rivals for national A.A.U. basketball supremacy, Twentieth Century-Fox of Hollywood, the current champion, and Phillips 66 of Tulsa, titleholder in 1940, will renew their hardwood feud at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night in the final of the Golden Jubilee tournament.

HAVANA, Nov. 22 -- Dr. Juan J. Remos, Minister of Education, today called on the governments of the American republics to put into practice immediate plans for the intellectual cooperation agreed upon by the second Inter-American Conference Committees on Intellectual Cooperation, which terminated this afternoon.

VICHY, France, Nov. 22 -- French trial by jury is to be modified, according to a decision of the Cabinet today. The communique issued after the meeting described the forthcoming measure as "very important."

One of the most popular charity subscription parties of the Winter season, the annual Gay Thirties Dinner Dance, will take place Dec. 11 on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astorla, with the Boys' Club of New York as the beneficiary.

The history of Portland, Me., Longfellow's "beautiful town that is seated by the sea," is studded with stories of America's wars. When known as Falmouth, the seaport was blasted by the cannon of British ships in 1775. During the War of 1812 almost twoscore American privateers brought many a rich prize to Portland.

To the Radio Editor: THE season is all but over, and the football announcers will soon be resting their respective larynxes until next Fall, with the exception of the lucky few who work the Bowl games.

The American passenger liner Acadia, which sailed from New York Oct. 9 with 100 Pan American Airways technicians for Lagos, Nigeria, on the west coast of Africa, docked last night at Pier 38, King Street, Brooklyn, with 187 passengers from West African ports.

The virtual offsetting of recent increases in consumer income by higher living costs is noted by retailers and others interested in distribution and general business conditions. They expected that rising prices would begin to cut deeply into the gains in wage scales and pay envelopes, but the rapidity with which recent price advances have been felt has surprised them, they admitted last week.

IF you are a New Yorker well on in years, you may remember having seen in your childhood a small, thin old gentleman, square of forehead and of chin, deep-sunken eyes and a long hooked nose. As he walked slowly up the street, his high silk hat tilted far back, he was a picturesque character.

Two goals in the first period enabled the Detroit Red Wings to turn back the Brooklyn Americans in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The troupe guided by Red Dutton put up a desperate battle in an effort to erase this advantage, but succeeded only in part, and as a result had to bow to the visiting aggregation by 2 to 1.

Of the labor difficulties which have beset the American arsenal the most serious began and ended last week. It was concerned with coal, upon which depends the manufacture of steel, war's basic metal. On Monday, after weeks of negotiation and recrimination, members of the United Mine Workers struck at the bituminous coal mines owned by steel companies and called "captive" in the argot of the trade.
HIDDEN in the rugged range that constitutes the very backbone of Brazil -- the Serra do Espinhaco, which resembles our Appalachian chain -- lies one of the world's greatest treasure-houses.

News which appeals to the coquette lurking (it is to be hoped) in every woman until she is in the neighborhood of 90 is the report that golden hair -- and red and black -- that has gone silvery may at some future date be re-established in its original hue through correct and sufficient vitamin rationing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Government officials, busy putting the finishing touches on their new "production requirements plan" for handling the allocation of materials to producers, had high hopes today that the new system will work as advantageously for business men as it will for the government.

IN composing for the theatre, musician and playwright agree on one thing: "The play's the thing." But the matter is not disposed of that easily. The very acceptance of that adage creates a new set of problems for every play.

Odorless Gasoline C.F. Mason, R.D. Bent and J.H. McCullough of the Atlantic Refining Company's research laboratories have taken the smell out of gasoline and thereby improved its power-producing quality and also did something in the way of coping with priorities and raw-material shortages.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 22 -- Completing a highly successful year, the West Point booters defeated a hard fighting Naval Academy soccer team, 5 to 3, today in the middies football stadium. It was the cadets' second straight triumph over Navy and their third in the four-game series that began in 1939.
