The problem of providing the tools with which to destroy Adolf Hitler and Nazism is a problem of transportation as well as of production. It Is not enough to turn out an ever-increasing number of tanks, airplanes and guns. Stored in warehouses and on docksides here, they would not affect the outcome of a single battle.

Rejection by United States oil companies of the terms of the Mexican Government's oil settlement, which was approved by Secretary of State Cordell Hull on Wednesday, is not expected to interfere with other parts of the general agreement concluded on that date between the two governments.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- German forces were reported tonight to have driven "a new breach" into the defense lines before Moscow. On the Moscow front weather conditions were improved with the freezing of the ground.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 22 -- Undefeated during the United States Field Hockey Association tournament concluded today at Wellesley College, the Middle Atlantic States eleven was rewarded tonight at the annual association dinner in the Wellesley Country Club when six of its players were named to the All-America team and five others were elected to the Reserves.

Twenty thousand packets designed to aid school principals in preparing programs for the observance of Bill of Bights Day, Dec. 15, are to be mailed to secondary schools throughout the country, it was announced yesterday by the Council Against Intolerance in America, Lincoln Building, 60 East Forty-second Street.

Rejection by United States oil companies of the terms of the Mexican Government's oil settlement, which was approved by Secretary of State Cordell Hull on Wednesday, is not expected to interfere with other parts of the general agreement concluded on that date between the two governments.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- German forces were reported tonight to have driven "a new breach" into the defense lines before Moscow. On the Moscow front weather conditions were improved with the freezing of the ground.
TUCSON, Ariz -- The desert is beginning to disappear. In only a few places is the real, the arboreal desert, which once covered most of Southern Arizona, still to be seen.

Economists of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board report that material and labor costs in the construction of a standard six-room house in September, this year, were 13.2 per cent above such costs for the same period of 1940.
CHESTER, Pa., Nov. 22 -- La Salle defeated P.M.C. today, 12 -- 2.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Winding up their 1941 campaign today, Santa Clara's Broncos outscored the University of California at Los Angeles, 31 to 13, in a game that had its moments -- some of them brilliant.

TORONTO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Toronto's Maple Leafs beat back the Chicago Black Hawks' bid for the National Hockey League lead tonight, winning their sixth straight, 3 -- 0. It was the first defeat in six games for the Hawks, who dropped three points off the pace.

In announcing publication of a new statistical series on stocks that have paid dividends continuously for ten years, the New York Stock Exchange discloses, in the current issue of its magazine, The Exchange, that nineteen such issues are selling now to yield better than 12 per cent and that fifty-nine yield better than 9 per cent.

MAINE'S black-on-buff license plates for next year offer "protective coloring" that should provide a camouflage blending well with the State's vast forest background. The new tags are in sharp contrast with the 1941 combination of red-on-aluminum.

Ten times more man-hours were lost last week as a result of strikes than in the preceding week, according to a report covering thirteen strikes in defense plants made public yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

The advancement of Christ's ministry can only be accomplished when the church makes the spiritual aim paramount rather than the material, asserted the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

SPARTANBURG, S.C., Nov. 23 -- The news from North Africa read against the background of both British and Axis communiques, makes it clear that the British have won important initial victories in Libya -- victories that may prove to be decisive, but, from what is known, are not yet so.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- A somewhat firmer undertone prevailed last week In the lard market, but outside trade was not large. Scattered liquidation by holders of December contracts was absorbed by cash interests either in the way of removing hedges against sales of cash product to the government or to transfer the hedges into the distant futures.

Unhappy is the lot of the New York Rangers these days. The blue-jerseyed athletes have yet to win a game on their own ice. They had an idea that they would call a halt to these reverses before the home folks last night when they skated against the Canadiens of Montreal in Madison Square Garden.

One hundred "women in white," wearing the uniform of workers cooperating in the sale of Christmas seals, will be in hotel lobbies, restaurants, theatres, railroad stations and other public places at 9 o'clock this morning to offer the 1941 Christmas seals for sale to the public as the campaign of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association opens.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A cartoon reproduced in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 16 calls to mind the plight of a great number of our citizens with incomes not benefited by the defense program. An individual called "Fixed Income" is therein depicted as lost in a desert and extremely dejected on discovering that a distant oasis, representing Washington's promises to stop price advances, is but a mirage.

The country will breathe a great sigh of relief now that the strike in the "captive" coal mines, which had already slowed down steel production and threatened the entire defense effort, has been called off. Whether such relief is warranted is still a matter of doubt.

DETROIT, Nov. 23 -- The mighty Chicago Bears today crushed the Detroit Lions, 24 to 7, for their eighth victory in nine National Football League games, but the losers provided the top thrill for 28,657 fans when Billy Jefferson ran 101 yards to a touchdown on a kick-off return.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Twelve hundred members of the dock workers' contingent of the Highway Drivers' union, a local of the A.F.L. International Brotherhood of Teamsters, howled down the pleas of their officials and voted today for an immediate strike which may tie up the huge motor transport system in the Midwestern States.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Legislation for control of prices is expected to be brought up for debate in the House of Representatives this week, and brokers predict that developments there will dominate the trend of the markets for wheat and other grains.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The conversations between the United States and Japan, it was learned today, have reached a critical phase. Both sides have indicated a willingness to reach a "truce" in their long-range economic-strategic war; both sides have made suggestions about the terms on which they are prepared to reach a limited agreement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Use of lead and tin foil as a wrapping material for cigarettes, chewing gum, candy and a variety of other products will be prohibited after March 15, the Office of Production Management announced today. The action is expected to result in a monthly saving of 5,500 tons of lead and 250 tons of tin needed for defense purposes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The questions of how to check inflation through price control and how to prevent strikes in defense industries will be practically the only subjects before Congress this week.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices dropped from 98.8 to 98.6. A general moderate decline occurred throughout the indexes. In agricultural commodities, where there has been mainly an upward trend, price declines in livestock, corn and oranges outweighed price increases in eggs, grains, cotton and lard, leading to net losses in the raw materials major group and in the farm products and foodstuffs subgroups.

Prices of cotton moved last week within a narrow trading range The widest spread between the highest and lowest price, at which any one active delivery sold was 29 points. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contract on the New York Cotton Exchange showed changes ranging from a de cline of 21 points to an advance of 2 points.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- The home furnishings industries as a group will maintain 1942 advertising and promotional efforts at a level equal to or better than this year's, replies to questionnaires sent out by Percy Wilson, managing director of the Merchandise Mart, indicate.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Favorable weather for harvesting corn and soy beans prevailed during the greater part of last week and considerable progress was reported in gathering of the crops.

Waiting for Winter A mid-season restlessness prevails in that comparatively new breed of sportsfolk, the skier, although opportunities for testing "Christies" and "Snow Plows" will not be realised on a large scale for several weeks.

Despite the increased police patrols that have been assigned to Harlem recently several minor crimes of violence took place there late Saturday night and early yesterday, the most serious of which was the hold-up of two white men by a gang of youthful Negro robbers who stabbed one of them.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Having read for many years comments on the situation in Harlem, past and present, one capital point I find is ignored with astonishing regularity.

ABOARD A BRITISH BOMBER, Over the Libyan Battlefield, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Germans are rushing fighters, bombers, supplies of gasoline and anti-tank guns to North Africa by transport planes and gliders in a desperate effort to turn the tide of battle in Libya.

Mrs. Donald Belcher, United States women's chess champion, and Miss N. May Karff of Boston adjourned the third game of their match for the title after playing sixty-four moves last night at the home of L. Walter Stephens, 279 East Thirty-fourth Street, Brooklyn.

BERLIN, Nov. 23 (AP) -- German armies appeared today to be gathering strength for a new eastward lunge from Rostov, which Berlin claims to have captured, to isolate the oil-rich Caucasus completely from Central Russia.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Nov. 23--Emphasizing that they were Americans first and mine workers second, 228 delegates representing more than 20,000 captive mine workers in Fayette and Greene Counties voted unanimously here this afternoon to back John L. Lewis in his acceptance of President Roosevelt's proposal for arbitration of the union shop issue.
KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 23 -- Russian troops have been pushed back in the central and southern sectors of the defense arc before Moscow, dispatches from the front acknowledged tonight.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 23 -- Champion Pillicoc Reverie, black poodle from the Pillicoc Kennels of Mrs. Milton Erlanger of Elberon, took the special award for best dog in the tenth annual fixture of the Camden County Kennel Club at Convention Hall today.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin) Nov. 22 -- Although the markets in the small continental countries displayed irregularity in the last week their joint feature was a general resisting power with trade clearly shrinking under a downward hiovement, but expanding strongly as soon as prices rose.
SPARTANBURG, S.C., Nov. 23 -- The Red and Blue "enemies" of the Army's last great mimic war of 1941 rested over the week-end, and tonight were busily preparing for the resumption of field operations.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 24 -- The obvious acceleration of United States-Japanese negotiations in Washington is being followed in Japan with somewhat nervous suspense that, except for continued exhortations to maintain national unity and prepare for the worst, has led to a pause in the hectic publicity barrage with which Japan sought to press her side of the case.

A letter from President Roosevelt, in which he declared that the need for funds to combat infantile paralysis was greater than ever, was made public yesterday as the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis opened its ninth annual campaign.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 23 -- Apparently indifferent to the possible reactions of an as yet uninformed public in France, the runaway collaborationist cabinet in Vichy continued today its final preparations to bring France economically, politically and militarily into the Axis orbit.

"Hail to the Giants!" With a bow to George Preston Marshall's theme song, "Hail to the Redskins," that was the reaction of the turnout of 49,317 persons who streamed out of the Polo Grounds yesterday, satisfied that they had seen just about everything there is to be seen on a gridiron.

The first step toward formation of a commission to define and classify standards for all existing fraternities and honor societies on college campuses was taken yesterday at the final session of the Professional Panhellenic Association's tenth biennial conference in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 21 (Delayed) -- Traveling for sixteen days across European Russia, and going through the Ural industrial belt before looping back to this city, the writer had an opportunity to view the Soviet Union that rarely is given to foreigners in wartime.

More than two-thirds of all exports of the United States now are going to British Empire destinations, compared with somewhat more than one-third before the war, the Guaranty Trust Company asserts in the current issue of The Guaranty Survey.

For the past two months there has been a lull in the upward course of major commodity prices. Possibly that may account in part for the delays on the part of Congress in putting through price-control legislation, a subject which the House will only today begin to consider, despite its urgency.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The Economist's Index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, stood on Nov. 11 at 107.4, compared with 107.2 a fortnight before, 99.8 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.
A thousand members of the Police Department and as many guests attended annual memorial services at Mount Neboh Temple yesterday for members of the department who have died in the last year.

Some institutional or cooperative campaigns by industry and trade associations are being held up or will never see print, because their sponsors fear that "special pleading" might have an adverse effect at this time. Several industries, considered in the luxury or nonessential class, would like to run campaigns justifying their continued existence but are worried that such appeals might boomerang during a period of "all-out" defense work.

Harry R. Amott, chairman of the protective committee for holders of Equitable Office Building Corporation thirty-five-year 5 per cent debentures, has notified the holders that the building is about 85 per cent rented, with a gross rent roll of $2,545,000 and estimated income from electricity and other sources of $285,000 for the fiscal year beginning on May 1, last.

Phillips 66 of Tulsa and Twentieth Century-Fox of Hollywood, the nation's premier amateur basketball teams, will meet tonight at Madison Square Garden in the final of the Golden Jubilee Tournament commemorating the invention of the court game by the late Dr. James Naismith.

In a harum-scarum second half which seemed to have been stolen bodily from a mad Hollywood scenarist, the Giants came roaring from behind to defeat the Redskins at the Polo Grounds yesterday for a thrilling victory that left a gathering of 49,317 limp and exhausted.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Nov. 23 -- Driving 80 yards for a touchdown in the fading minutes of the contest, the Brooklyn Dodgers of the National League defeated the Long Island Indians of the American Association, 6 -- 3, in an exhibition football game at Memorial Field today before a crowd of 7,400.

UPPER JAY, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- The importance of high-altitude ski trails was clearly shown today as members of the Conservation Commission, the Whiteface Area Ski Council and the press completed their two-day exploratory climb of the contemplated site of the "down-hill only" ski area the public endorsed in the past election.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 23 -- Mrs. Mary Anderson, born a slave in Virginia 111 years ago and one of those who did not want to be emancipated, died today in the Englewood Hospital of complications from an injury suffered in a fall two weeks ago.

Looking to protection of American export markets in the postwar period, the New York Board of Trade sent yesterday to Edward R. Stettinius, Lease-Lend Administrator, a communication declaring that the aid being rendered to foreign nations in the form of "strictly commercial merchandise for civilian use" should be "handled as before" and not be classified with the shipment and commerce of defense materials.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- Two Axis convoys, attempting to run supplies through the Mediterranean inferno, were caught in the middle of the sea, one by British submarines, the other by the Royal Air Force, according to an R.A.F. communique here today and one issued by the Admiralty in London.

Several thousand persons In crowded Delancey Street near the Williamsburg Bridge were awed last night at a pistol battle between policemen and a bandit who a few moments before had seriously wounded a customer in holding up a lunch wagon.

The Department of Commerce's weather bureau station at La Guardia Field has restricted distribution of transatlantic weather reports it was learned yesterday. Before the airport was opened in December, 1939, it had been planned to correlate and distribute weather information from all over the world.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 23 (AP) -- The All-America eleven today upheld the judgment of the United States Field Hockey Association's selection committee, which named the teams, by scoring a 5-0 victory in its traditional match with the All-America Reserves.

The Rover boys who represent New York in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League vaulted into second place in the standing by beating the Washington Eagles, 4 -- 2, before 12,412 spectators at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

Mrs. Richard W. Lawrence will give a tea on Thursday at her home, 79 East Seventy-ninth Street, for members of the debutante and junior committees aiding in the plans for the performance of the Ice Follies on Dec. 4 at Madison Square Garden to aid the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins pounded home a pair of goals in each of the first two periods tonight to defeat their Stanley Cup rivals of last year, the Detroit Red Wings, 4 to 2, in a National League Hockey game before 9,739 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- For the "difficulties which Russia has been encountering on the Finnish front she has herself to blame," Hjalmar J. Procope, the Finnish Minister, said today in a statement commenting on the communique issued Tuesday in Moscow denying that Finland's participation in the war was a self-defense measure.

The demand for evening wear was brisk in the apparel market last week. Business picked up somewhat on daytime dresses. Untrimmed coats continued to be emphasized. Action on fur coats improved and satisfactory sales were reported by stores in colder sections of the country.

BERLIN, Nov. 23 -- The announcement of Dr. Alfred Rosenberg's appointment to the new post of Reich Minister for Occupied Russian Territory has offered official circles in the German press a new pretext for directing the interests of business toward the gigantic task of exploiting the vast Russian "hinterland" in the interests of German and European economy.
Half the people of the city are receiving insufficient milk under "very costly" distribution methods, the Mayor's Milk Committee declared in a 96-page report to Mayor La Guardla, released yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The torpedoing of one enemy cruiser and a destroyer as well as two enemy supply ships in the Central Mediterranean was announced by the Admiralty tonight. The cruiser was believed to have been sunk and the three other vessels were claimed as "probables."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 -- A deal for Norma Shearer to play the lead in Warner Brothers' "The Gay Sisters" has been closed, it was reliably reported at the studio, though official announcement of the agreement was withheld. Her appearance in the screen version of the Stephen Longstreet novel would mark Miss Shearer's first film engagement away from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer since 1924, when she joined that company.

The Metropolitan Opera, which began its career in 1883, will open its fifty-ninth season tonight at 8 o'clock, when Ettore Panizza steps to the conductor's podium and gives the signal for the orchestra to strike up the overture to the first Mozart opera ever to be given by the company on an opening night, "Le Nozze di Figaro."

As the shadow of the Nazi legions stretches further southeastward into Asia the 400,000,000 people of India begin to receive attention. More than two months ago Mr. Churchill indicated that the Atlantic Charter did not apply to them. Last week the Indian Council of State declared that this point of view was "likely to prejudice the war efforts of India at this critical juncture."

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 23 -- With the labor crisis, Japanese problem and the price control bill all still hanging fire, the cotton market was able to get up very little steam last week, when fluctuations were the narrowest in many weeks. Switching from the December position into March, May and July about on an equal basis saw a widening once again of premiums on late months over the near options.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- Despite conditions that would have discouraged all but Winter sailors, fourteen craft went out today from the Larchmont Yacht Club in the weekly dinghy competition there.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Advertising appropriations and sales promotion campaigns of leading manufacturers are not being curtailed, a survey indicated today. The national defense program, it was shown, had created a rush of business.
VICHY, France, Nov. 23 -- A notice in the Journal Official today announces the appointment to the presidency of the inter-Professional Group of the Sugar Beet Industry in France of Jean Achard.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Reductions in the Federal budget for next year totaling $1,783,000,000 were recommended by the National Economy League today in a study prepared for submission to the joint Congressional-Executive Committee on Reduction of Non-Essential Federal Expenditures.

ROME, Nov. 23 -- British attacks in Libya were "sharply repulsed" yesterday, with a loss of more than 255 tanks, it is stated in today's war bulletin. At the same time it is to be noted that the communique and authorized accounts from the front no longer talk of Axis counter-attacks, while all commentators make it plain that a battle of the utmost importance is taking place.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23 -- The Columbia Steel Company's plant at Pittsburgh the largest steel works on the West Coast, stood idle again today as 3,200 C.I.O. unionists resumed picketing in a dispute over Wages.

VICHY, France, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Germany was revealed tonight, on the eve of a meeting of French and Nazi leaders, to have cut the occupation cost levied against France by 100,000,000 francs a day, retroactive to last May 10.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, sponsor of the National Industrial Recovery Act and the Wagner Labor Relations Act, and regarded as one of the staunchest friends of labor in public office, warned labor last night that public opinion would not tolerate any strikes In defense Industries and declared that during the emergency all labor disputes should be settled by arbitration.
LONDON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique today said:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Roosevelt was represented tonight as hopeful of following up the settlement of the captive mine strike with an agreement within the next two or three days, which would avert the threatened nationwide railroad strike.

The West Side Savings Bank sold to an investing client of Hirsch Islon, attorneys, the eight-story loft building on a lot 25 by 92 feet at 13 East Sixteenth Street for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $18,500. The property is assessed at $43,000 and was sold through the Kempner Realty Corporation, broker.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., Nov. 23 -- Three soldiers serving guardhouse terms overpowered a guard this afternoon, taking his .45-caliber pistol, and then commandeered an Army truck and forced the driver to drive them west of the camp where they took to the woods, only to be captured three hours later when they sought a lift from a military police squad that was searching for them in a private automobile.

Labor leaders who promote strikes in defense industries are "giving aid to the forces of Hitler," Bishop William T. Manning declared at the nineteenth annual joint Thanksgiving service in which forty patriotic societies, including several British groups, participated yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
THE novelist Lion Feuchtwanger, too, was a prisoner in a French concentration camp during the Summer of 1940.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 23 -- German armored units, assisted by advance patrols of the army of Marshal Milan Neditch, puppet Premier of occupied Yugoslavia, have captured and destroyed two villages in South Serbia, but suffered heavy losses and were repulsed in fighting in Central and Western Serbia, according to reports to foreign military intelligence sources here this week-end.

BEIRUT, Syria, Nov. 22 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- If the Germans attempt a diversion southward through Turkey in an effort to divert Britain's push into Italian Libya they will find themselves up against a powerful, well-equipped army of Englishmen, British Imperials and Free French.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 -- Emanuel Neumann of New York, formerly of the World Zionist Executive and now adviser to the Emergency Committee for Zionist Affairs, asserted today that "conspiring and intriguing British bureaucrats" were "sabotaging" plans for a Jewish military force in Palestine.

Six months have passed since the Germans completed the conquest of Greece. The few persons who have passed through Greek territory in that time agree that in this war no country except Poland has been reduced to such bitter destitution by its conquerors.

Awards fat meritorious services will be made to 101 policemen in special orders to be announced this morning by Police Commissioner Valentine. In addition, two posthumous awards of honorable mention will be made to policemen killed in the line of duty, whose names will be placed on the memorial tablet at Police Headquarters.
The football curtain was lowered on most of the nation's college gridirons Saturday to a crescendo of climactic happenings as kaleidoscopic and overwhelming as a Gershwin rhapsody.

One difference between Americans and Europeans that strikes a traveler in a journey through eight or nine of these United States is that all the people in this country live somewhere near the same moment of historic time. The reporter of Europe travels not only from State to State but from century to century, and his hardest job has always been to translate the ideas and outlook of one epoch into the terms of another.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Acceleration of the shift from gilt-edge stocks to industrial shares was last week's outstanding feature in the stock markets, although in general strength the exhilarating news from Libya played an important part, which was reinforced by the continuing toughness of the Russian resistance.

Inez Lauritano, young New York violinist, who gave her third New York recital last season at Carnegie Hall, last night gave her fourth recital in this city, returning to Town Hall, where she made her debut in 1932 as a winner of a Walter W. Naumburg Foundation award.

LONDON, Nov. 23--The United States Navy "is shooting Germans--German submarines and aircraft at sea," W. Averell Harriman, United States war-aid expediter, declared in a radio broadcast to the British people tonight.

CAIRO, Egypt, Monday, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The British have forced the Germans to rush new air support from Europe and have split the Axis Libyan forces into four battered segments, war reports said today.

The fifteenth annual observance of the National Jewish Book Week opened yesterday in synagogues, community houses and Hebrew schools through the country with exhibitions and discussions stressing the role of American Jews in keeping alive Jewish cultural traditions in the face of the destruction of Jewish communities in Europe.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Scoring four touchdowns in six hectic minutes in the second quarter, the Green Bay Packers routed the Pittsburgh Steelers today, 54 to 7, in a National Football League game.

With 3,000 teachers in New York City on eligible lists and 1,000 substitutes dismissed this Fall because of decreased enrollment, it may come as a surprise to learn that the United States now faces an acute shortage of teachers. Yet that is the warning issued by the National Education Association's newly formed commission for the Defense of Democracy Through Education, following a nation-wide survey.

With Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presiding, the week-long celebration of the golden jubilee of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Elizabeth of Hungary, 211 East Eighty-third Street, closed with a solemn Mass of Thanksgiving yesterday morning.

The annual convention of the National Labor Committee for Palestine, representing labor and civic organizations with a membership of 500,000, ended its sessions at the Hotel Astor last night with a call to American Jews to intensify their aid to Histadrut, the Labor Federation of Palestine.

BERLIN, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The German High Command said today that Axis armies were stemming the great British offensive in Libya in "successful battles" featured by violent tank and air clashes and enormous destruction of war materials.

Phillips R. Turnbull, president of Rogers Peet Company, has been appointed general chairman of the 1942 campaign for the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, 120 West Forty-second Street, it was announced yesterday by J. Stewart Baker, president of the foundation.

VICHY, Nov. 23 -- Franco-German economic collaboration has made a further step forward with the formation of Francolor-Paris, a new dyestuff and chemical concern combining four principal chemical companies with the I.G. Farbenindustrie of Berlin.

Completion of three small marginal playgrounds at Washington Square Park was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks. The areas are fenced and paved, and equipped with kindergarten and play apparatus. They are situated as near as possible to park entrances and offer attractions to children whose former conduct in the park caused much harm to lawns, shrubbery and park facilities.

Founding of a Franco-Belgian institute of advanced study in New York, the Ecole Libre des Hautes Etudes, with financial support from the Free Belgian Government-in-Exile and a faculty composed of more than thirty distinguished French and Belgian scholars, was announced yesterday by Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

There's a woman living in Greenwich Village whose maiden aunt recently died, leaving her an extraordinary Inheritance. Included among the various bequests in the will was a set of old New England recipes and a modest sum of money, which she promptly invested in a tiny restaurant.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 23 -- The discontent of the Finnish population in the face of a war that no longer looks defensive, seems to have spread to the Finnish Army.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- The market for corn on the Board of Trade here had an easy undertone last week, although there was a fair rally from the low point following the announcement that the government's loan price on the 1941 crop would be based on a national average of 74.8 cents a bushel, compared with 61 cents during the preceding crop year.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23 -- Although the captive coal mine strike was ended yesterday when the United Mine Workers agreed to arbitration on the closed-shop question, effects of the week-long shutdown will be felt for some time to come.

Adolf Busch, violinist, and Rudolf Serkin, pianist, who provided the program of the concert of the New Friends of Music given late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, outdid themselves in a superlative performance of Beethoven's "Kreutzer" sonata.
ROME, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

Teddy, a chow dog, returned home at 6 o'clock Saturday night after having been absent without leave for two months. A few minutes later his master, Kenneth Martin, 22 years old, of 316 Sixtyeighth Street, Brooklyn, arrived from Fort Eustis, Va., on his first leave since his induction into the Army on Oct. 10.

The New York City Symphony Orchestra gave a concert last night in Carnegie Hall under the auspices of Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project. Jean Paul Morel conducted and Roland Hayes, tenor, was the soloist.

News of the union's sudden agreement to arbitrate the dispute which for a week had closed the "captive" coal mines, did not reach Wall Street until the market had closed on Saturday. The character of the news was unexpected; it had been hinted that a "show-down" was in store for the week-end, but no one had predicted that the C.I.O. would accept a new proposal.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Nov. 23 -- Hi-Wood Mike, black Labrador retriever owned by Mrs. John S. Williams of Hewlett, L.I., and handled by David Elliot of Islip, today was awarded the Arnold Hanger Challenge Cup, emblematic of victory in the limited all-age stake in the annual Autumn meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club.

A musical comedy version of "The Warrior's Husband," which has been seen as a play and a movie, is in the making and may go into rehearsal within a month if negotiations with the screen company that holds the rights to the work are successful, Richard Rodgers announced yesterday.

Asserting that "the days of denominationalism are over," the Rev. Ralph S. Meadowcroft declared yesterday morning in his sermon at All Angels' Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street, that "the church of "tomorrow" would be universal in character and that within the near future there would be an increasing union in religion.

LONDON, Nov. 23--The main battle between British and Axis tanks in Libya continued today, without a final decision, in an area of forty square miles near Rezegh, nearly twenty miles below Tobruk. While this combat was going on New Zealand troops entered Bardia, which apparently had been evacuated by Axis soldiers.

WITH A BRITISH ARMORED FORCE, in Libya, Nov. 22 (Delayed) -- British troops, fighting in American-built tanks, have won the first round of the greatest tank battle in which the British have ever engaged. The battle is still going on, with German and Italian tanks supported by long-range artillery and ground-strafing aircraft fighting stubbornly.

Stressing the presentation of the Christian message against the "awful background of war-consciousness," the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer urged in his sermon yesterday morning that religious leaders should be preaching more of Christ than bloodshed.

WEEK ENDED NOV. 22, 1941 Higher prices for the Canadian dollar, and the Colombian and Uruguayan pesos was all that was evolved out of the trading in the foreign currency market last week. Otherwise, the free pound sterling, the Far Eastern and other Latin-American units were dull and unchanged in value.

ABOARD THE FLAGSHIP QUEEN ELIZABETH With the British Mediterranean Fleet off Libya, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Not a single Axis surface craft has been sighted by the strong British naval units which, in battle formation, are protecting the British garrison at Tobruk from possible bombardment by the Italian war fleet.
NEW YORK Mrs. Francis P. Garvan will give a dinner with dancing on Dec. 26 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for her debutante daughter, Miss Marcia Anne Garvan.

The threatened nation-wide strike of 15,000 members of the Federation of Long Lines Telephone Workers was averted last night with the announcement of a settlement granting $3,000,000 in wage increases and making other concessions to the workers.

A black siskin, said to be the first bird of its kind to be raised in captivity in the United States and exhibited, was shown yesterday at the annual show of the Empire Cage Bird Association, Inc., at which, prize winners among the 570 canaries and tropical wild birds exhibited for two days were announced.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Black Hawks scored three goals in less than three minutes of the second period tonight to defeat Toronto, 3 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game witnessed by 18,491. The Maple Leafs got their last goal with one second left, just after two Hawks and two Leafs had received major penalties for a two-minute fight.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Frank Ivy's alert Interception of Parker Hall's risky flat pass on the Cleveland 20 gave the Chicago Cardinals a 7-to-O triumph today over the cellar-dwelling Rams, who ended their National Football League season with nine straight setbacks.

CALL'S HOLLOW, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- So far as we were able to learn yesterday, even James A. Farley passed by Call's Hollow, for this tiny hamlet has no distinctive post-office structure to dwarf the few low houses with their smoking chimneys that sprawl along the foot of the mountain, but now that Rockland County has an open deer season the cars of hunters line the valley.

WHEN the report sifted through Cambridge that Ornithologist Harlow went into the Yale dressing room after the game on Saturday and told the Elis they had put up the toughest opposition Harvard had seen all season, the sideline cynics said that the big bird man and fern fancier must have been soft-soaping the Yale boys.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 23 -- Information brought here from Chungking by competent, reliable sources indicates some improvement in relations between the Kuomintang and Communist factions in Free China, although the two parties are said to be still far from full adjustment on points, of conflict.

Rex Battle, English pianist, whose professional career has been confined to Canada, where he has lived for a number of years, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. His program was composed of the Bach-Busoni organ prelude and fugue in D major; Beethoven's sonata in A major, Op. 101; the Chopin "Ballade" in F minor; the Saint-Saens Liszt "Danse Macabre," and offerings by Schumann, Ravel and Debussy.

As most of the features in the first-run theatres held up strongly at the box office over the weekend, only three new films are slated as yet on this week's Broadway calendar. On Tuesday "A Date With Murder" opens at the Rialto with a cast that includes George Sanders, Wendy Barrie, James Gleason and Alien Jenkins.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Contracts have been let for more than 75 per cent of the allocation of $7,000,000,000 for lease-lend aid to Britain and her Allies under the first lease-lend law, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Lease-Lend Administrator, stated today.

BERLIN, Monday, Nov. 24 -- A Berlin conference of ten or more powers to discuss renewal and extension of the first Anti-Comintern pact signed by Germany and Japan in 1936 will begin Tuesday, the day the pact expires, it was announced today.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The British Board of Trade's index of commodity prices for October, based on 1930 as 100, was 154.6, compared with 154.3 for September and 142.7 for October, 1940, and 98.1 for August, 1939.

After an early advance from Saturday's closing levels, the cotton market eased yesterday near the close under a flurry of liquidation orders when trade demand had slackened. Final prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were, consequently, at their lows for the day and showed net losses of 2 to 9 points.
ROME, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- While the wheat market showed a little activity at the opening trading was largely of a professional character, and a small upturn at the opening in sympathy with soy beans and other-commodities was followed by a decline of around 1 cent a bushel from the top when some of the early buyers tried to unload.

The music department of Cornell University had reason to be proud of itself last night, for, drawing only on the faculty and alumni of the department, the Cornell Women's Club of New York was able to present two fine young singers and a distinguished European pianist at Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Electric energy produced for public use in the United States in October totaled 14,991,953,000 kilowatthours, an increase of 17 per cent over production in October, 1940, the Federal Power Commission noted today.

The economic war is causing Germans to scratch their heads "pretty hard," Professor Noel Frederick Hall of the University of London, who is Minister at the British Embassy in Washington in charge of coordination of British and American economic activities, said yesterday morning when he arrived at La Guardia Field aboard the Pan American Airways' Yankee Clipper.
CALI, Colombia, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Anibal Rios claimed tonight that he was the rightful and constitutional President of the Republic, and that "come what may, I am going to serve."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Cancellation of deportation proceedings against Harry Bridges was urged by his attorneys today before the Board of Immigration Appeals in all-day sessions at which issue was taken on factual and legal grounds with every contention advanced by government counsel in support of the return of the labor leader to his native Australia.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 -- Sir James Barrie's "Peter Pan" will reach the screen as a featurelength animated cartoon late next year, Walt Disney announced today. Disney has owned the rights to the Barrie story since 1938, having acquired them from Paramount and the estate of the author, but today's announcement marks the beginning of production activity on the film.

Chicago, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Bill De Correvont, Northwestern University's senior halfback who concluded his college gridiron career Saturday against Illinois, said tonight the would play Sunday with the New York Yankees in a charity football game against a Negro allstar team at the Polo Grounds, but that he understood he would retain his amateur standing.

MONROE, N.C., Nov. 24 -- The United States is commencing to develop anti-tank weapons and anti-tank technique of great promise, Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair, Army GHQ chief of staff and director of the current manoeuvres, indicated today at a press conference.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 24 (AP) -- About 8,500 A.F. of L. machinists of the St. Louis area went on a general strike today in a jurisdictional dispute with A.F. of L. hoisting engineers and millwrights.
PANAMA, Nov. 24 -- The arrest of nine well-known Panamanians has crushed plans for a subversive movement intended to overthrow the government, it was announced officially today.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Gambut, long used as an important supply base by the Axis troops in Libya, was reported today to have been taken by one section of the British forces moving steadily eastward toward the scene of the gigantic tank battle still raging in the vicinity of Rezegh.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Louis Lipsky, chairman of the governing council of the American Jewish Congress, today charged the British Government with "delays, evasive speech and unconvincing excuses" in reply to an offer by Jews "to organize a Jewish military unit under its own name and flag in the English service."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 -- The California Attorney General, Earl Warren, said today he hoped that the Supreme Court's Okie decision would "result in Federal legislation which will solve in a humane and equitable way the entire migrant problem."

Nothing is so charming and gay as an informal supper, when every one pitches in with clumsy enthusiasm and eager appetite. But a little of the enthusiasm disappears and the gaiety wears somewhat threadbare as the steak under the broiler refuses to broil and the enterprising omelette fines herbes falls fatally flat.

Free and Secure The two items were on the same page yesterday. Negro leaders in Philadelphia want to have Feb. 1 designated as a national holiday in commemoration of the Thirteenth Amendment abolishing slavery.
An attractive program of twen- ty-one bob-sled races has been scheduled for the Mount Van Hoevenberg run at Lake Placid during the Winter.

The incorporation of Bundles for Bluejackets as a separate organization to aid sailors of the United States Navy and merchant marine was announced yesterday by Mrs. Wales Latham, president of Bundles for Britain, who also is president of the new organization, which has been functioning as a division of Bundles for Britain since last July.

Mrs. Beatrice Rathbone, 31-yearold American-born member of the House of Commons, who was elected to succeed her husband after his death in action with the R.A.F. last December, arrived here yesterday on the American Export liner Excambion from Lisbon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The House began consideration of price control legislation today, and while divergent opinions were expressed over what means should be adopted to protect the public during the war emergency there was general admission that a broad measure was necessary to prevent runaway inflation.

Mrs. McClure Meredith Howland gave a luncheon yesterday in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Princess Diane R. Eristavi, who is serving as co-chairman with the hostess of the junior committee for the Yorkville Dinner Dance on Dec. 2 at the same hotel.

The funds of foreign central banks and of foreign commercial banks that have been "frozen" here by executive order, along with foreign accounts not "frozen," are now being used in increasing amounts for the purchase of United States Government obligations, mostly short-term, it was learned yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24 -- The names of eleven midshipmen who will receive prizes during the graduation exercises which will begin at the Naval Academy Dec. 13 and end Dec. 19 were made public today by Rear Admiral Russell Willson, superintendent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The California Anti-Migrant Law, used sometimes during dust storm years to check the ever-increasing influx of "Okies" into that State, was held unconstitutional today by the Supreme Court.

TOKYO, Nov. 24 -- The Japanese Foreign Office has sent a new communication to its mission negotiating with the United States Government in Washington, and a new development is expected "very shortly," Domei, Japanese news agency, said tonight.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 24 (AP) -- British middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

BERLIN, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- German bombers continued to blast all along the Moscow front, attacking artillery batteries, anti-aircraft emplacements, railroads, marching troops and trucks in low-level attacks, according to today's German reports.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The White House made public tonight a report from a Presidential factfinding board which 'contended that unions were obligated to settle jurisdictional disputes "peaceably and without embroiling employers or interrupting service with consequent damage to public interest."
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Coach Ray Morrison's fountain pen played as big a role in Temple's 31-13 crushing of Holy Cross on Saturday as did the running of the Owls' triple-threat Andy Tomasic.

"The Corn Is Green," the Emlyn Williams story of a courageous schoolmistress in Wales, acted by Ethel Barrymore, tonight completes its first year on Broadway, having opened Nov. 26, 1940. Last season the play was selected by the local Drama Critics Circle as the best of the foreign crop.
High tribute was paid yesterday to the citizens committee of the Second Corps Area at the "Stars of the Milky Way" luncheon and fashion show given under its auspices in Hotel Plaza.

Among those reporterd yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Herman Feldman, dean of the school of business and civic administration at City College, who leased an apartment in 67 Park Avenue through Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., brokers.

A group of investors, comprised of Samuel Wasserman and several associates, Baker, Evans Co. and Duncan M. Findlay, has purchased from the Bankers Trust Company for cash above a first mortgage of $230,000 the fourteen-story building at 145-51 East Thirtysecond Street.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Winthrop Pennock, director of volunteer defense activities in the State Defense Council, asserted today that "unglamorous, undramatic home defense" is the backbone of our total defense.

Store Sales Here Rise 2% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 2 per cent for the week ended Nov. 22, in comparison with the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Hearing on the application of State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for an order restraining the Newsdealers Federal Labor Union, Local 22,371, A.F. of L., from continuing its boycott against seven New York morning and afternoon newspapers was postponed yesterday until this morning at 10 o'clock by Justice Edward R. Koch in Special Term, Part 3, Supreme Court.

Tony Musto, Chicago heavyweight, who survived until the ninth round against Joe Louis, will make his local ring debut tonight at the New York Coliseum, the Bronx, where he is to face Buddy Knox, Dayton, Ohio, heavyweight, in the feature bout of eight rounds.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson will return today from Dark Harbor, Me., and will be at the Plaza.

Playtime was the subject yesterday afternoon at Fefe's Monte Carlo Beach, where Lord Taylor put on a resort showing. The hour was dedicated to Brigance's 1942 collection. This young American designer left all care behind him when he turned his thoughts to bathing and play suits.

In accordance with the practice established several years ago of naming their own starting line-up for the Fordham game, the New York University football players yesterday voted for the eleven men to face the Maroon on Saturday and then moved into their final week of practice at Ohio Field.

Dick Harlow, inventor of unorthodox gridiron defenses, lashed out yesterday at those who would standardize defense by legislation. He told the final general meeting of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's Restaurant yesterday that such a rule would be as silly as making a pitcher throw a straight one whenever he reached a 3 and 2 count.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Dr. John R. Steelman, chairman of the board named by President Roosevelt to arbitrate the captive coal mine dispute, said tonight that hearings would begin Wednesday morning.

IDENTIFYING himself not only as a reporter ("Well, I am a good reporter") but also as a "philosopher" in search of "keys" to the mysteries of life, Walter Duranty has written a book to explain one of the great political mysteries of Europe. It deals with Soviet Russia and is called "The Kremlin and the People."

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Minnesota's champion Gophers, Northwestern's Wildcats and Michigan's Wolverines dominate the Western Conference all-star football team selected annually for The Associated Press by Big Ten coaches.

BERLIN, Nov. 24 -- The battle for Moscow continues with undi -minished fury, according to German reports released here today, and for the first time in many weeks the High Command communique mentions a place name in the Moscow sector, that of Solnechnogorsk, a village thirty-one miles northwest of the Soviet capital.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 24 -- (AP) -- The Red Army was fighting one of the most critical battles of its history tonight against the onrush of massed Nazi tanks and men, which battered at Moscow's second lines of defense and pierced within fifty miles of the capital.

Artur Rubinstein appeared in a piano recital last night which formed the second event in the current Hurok Carnegie Hall Series. Mr. Rubinstein was in superb fettle, providing his large audience with a congeries of performances ranging from Beethoven to Stravinsky that sustained the interest unremittingly througout an evening of superior artistry.

This week Fifty-seventh Street becomes still more perceptibly the world's art center, with the addition of two galleries. The Valentine, which used to be located at 16 East Fifty-seventh Street, reopened yesterday in new quarters at No. 55 (one flight up) and the Andre Seligmann will open today at No. 15, entrance from the street.

As a result of General Weygand's recent removal from, command by the Vichy government, General Robert Odic, one of General Weygand's high-ranking staff officers now in this country on a mission, has broken with Vichy and joined the de Gaulle "Free French" movement, the Free French delegation in the United States disclosed here yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- Continued operation of Grasslands Hospital, the Westchester County institution at Eastview that cost the taxpayers $1,194,165 to maintain this year, will redound to the benefit of the county from every economic, health and governmental standpoint, the welfare committee of the Board of Supervisors said today in a sixty-eight-page report based on a twenty-month survey.

Jim Crowley apparently has decided not to listen to the persistent talk of the gridiron experts and non-experts that N.Y.U., the last remaining foe on the Fordham 1941 schedule, will be a soft touch for the Rams Saturday in the Yankee Stadium.

Charles West, an early New Dealer who served as a contact man between President Roosevelt and Congress for a while, has brought suit for $700,000 against an ordnance concern which, he alleges, received orders amounting to $70,000,000 since last November, it was learned yesterday.

College football will ring down the curtain in the East this week with four of its big features and the season's largest crowd, while elsewhere in the country six games will hold the spotlight in their bearing on the various bowl pairings.

Although she was living under assumed names and fleeing from town to town across the country while her husband was wanted for questioning as the trigger man in an underworld killing, Mrs. Blanche Weiss said yesterday that her sympathies had caused her to take time out in Kansas City to do some knitting for Bundles for Britain.
Even Army fliers like Brooklyn for their daffier exploits.

It took Mozart almost six decades to be tapped for a Metropolitan Opera opening, but he made it last night. His radiantly humorous and humane opera, "The Marriage of Figaro," started the Opera House on the fifty-ninth year of its existence.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24 -- The Navy football squad is expected to be at full strength for the fortysecond meeting with Army at the Philadelphia Municipal Stadium on Saturday.

December Treasury Financing It has been estimated variously that the Treasury may seek to raise at least $1,000,000,000 of new money next month. There has been speculation whether the Treasury will elect to offer special obligations which would be taken by insurance companies and savings banks, rather than by commercial banks.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Interstate League today became the first circuit in organized baseball to adopt helmets officially as protection for batters against "bean balls." Under a rule passed at the league's annual meeting, all eight clubs in the Class B loop must purchase helmets for their players.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 24 -- E. Donald Sterner, State Highway Commissioner, charged flatly today that salesmen of Thomas A. Edison Industries, of which Governor Charles Edison is president on leave, had been "high pressuring" various State departments and contractors to purchase Edison products for State work.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The International League came to the aid of the Toronto Club today with a revenue-boosting plan after the last-place team's new president, Peter G. Campbell, told league executives he represented a syndicate of Toronto sportsmen determined to continue operation in the circuit.

For the average sheep, fame is only skin deep. The best he can hope for, after parting periodically with his woolly shirt, is a fleeting hereafter in the form of a framed diploma. But Billy Wassermann 2d is different. He is a sheep with a career. For four years he has lived in honored comfort at the Montefiore Hospital for Chronic Diseases.

A quarter of a century ago there was angry debate over alleged German "atrocities," occurring chiefly in Belgium and France. Some of the stories told were exaggerated. Some were invented. Some were true but due to the actions of irresponsible individuals rather than to orders of the high command.

The twelve-family apartment house at the southeast corner of Park Lane South and Eightyeighth Street, Woodhaven, L.I., was purchased by Chris Mack and John Braunreuther from James Riggio, builder. The property is assessed for $40,000. Theobald Dengler was the attorney for the buyers.

If you have a few dollars rattling around in your pocket and can get your family doctor to write a note to the boss explaining that your health demands an immediate journey to a warm climate for at least a week, now is the time to do it, for Ernie Lyons of Stuart, Fla., wired yesterday that the ocean is "alive with sailfish."

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Vincent R. Dunne, a leader of General Drivers Union 544, C.I.O., who, the Government contends, was the "brains" behind the Socialist Workers party here, related his history in the radical movement in Federal Court here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 19: Increases of $66,000,000 in holdings of United States Treasury bills, $60,000,000 in United States Government deposits, $221,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $41,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $97,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 24 -- The battle in Libya has become a brutal slugging match in which no quarter is asked or given. The British command reported today that the tank combat around Rezegh had been in progress continuously for two days.

Taking no chances with the condition of the principals in a bout designed to give boxing its first undisputed world middleweight champion since the reign of Mickey Walker, Major Gen. John J. Phelan today will inspect the public workouts by Tony Zale of Gary, Ind., and Georgie Abrams of Roanoke, Va., who are to battle fifteen rounds in Madison Square Garden Friday night.

The opening night of the Metropolitan Opera season of 1941-42 was, as usual, a public, a social, and a sartorial success. The many facts which bear witness to that achievement are recorded in neighboring columns.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Negotiations between railroad labor and management in an effort to avert a threatened nation-wide strike scheduled to start Dec. 7 collapsed again late today.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 24 -- The arrival early in December of the new British Minister to Mexico is expected to raise -- perhaps in diplomatic form -- the question of the fate of the British oil interests in Mexico which were expropriated at the same time as the American.

Lack of mutual understanding and mutual knowledge still makes a wall between North and South America despite all the inter-American conferences, congresses and floods of literature, Francisco Pardo de Zela, Minister Plenipotentiary and Consul General of Peru in the United States, declared yesterday.

In ordering American troops into Dutch Guiana the President has taken a wise and not unexpected precautionary step in pursuance of our avowed policy to protect the Western Hemisphere. This move compares in gravity with the decision to dispatch American forces to Iceland to guard the North Atlantic sea routes, and it may have even greater strategic and political significance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Nov. 8 was 3,440,230 shares, compared with 3,221,260 shares in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

More play facilities to keep boys and girls off the streets are necessary to check the tendency toward juvenile crime in the Negro section of Brooklyn, as well as in Harlem, Paul Blanshard, executive director of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, said in a statement yesterday.

Reviewing the struggle for power between the A.F. of L. and the C.I.O., Mrs. Henry R. Caraway said yesterday that a labor civil war is raging in the United States. She asserted that the President wants to reconcile both sides and that he does not want the government to fight labor or to excite it.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 24 -- Spencer D. Moseley of Highland Park, III., today was elected captain of the Yale football team for the 1942 season by the unanimous vote of the twenty-three players who took part in the games with Princeton and Harvard.

KUIBISHEV, Russia, Nov. 24 -- At this writing the situation around Moscow is still far from clarified. The Germans initial momentum in their current drive has considerably reduced the area of the horseshoe-shaped front covering Moscow, which now can be said to run from the Klin salient on the north and to average fortythree to fifty miles in the distance of the battle line from the capital.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 24 -- Satisfaction and confidence were expressed in Brazil tonight after it had been announced that at 1:15 o'clock this afternoon United States troops had hoisted their flag in Surinam, Netherland colony to the north, and that simultaneously and by agreement Brazilian troops had reinforced the garrisons on the southern boundary of the colony.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin) Nov. 24 -- There was a cheerful tendency today on the Bourse, with considerable buying. Orders were especially numerous for plantation shares, which rose as much as 8 points and closed at the day's best figures.

Savoie Lottinville, director of The University of Oklahoma Press, has announced the appointment of Mary A. Hansen as associate editor and of John G.H. Scoon as assistant editor. Mrs. Hansen has been with the press for the last three years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull conferred again for two hours today with the diplomatic representatives of Britain, China, the Netherlands and Australia regarding United States negotiations with Japan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 22:

With the occasional intrusion of an Army uniform, the nocturnal fashion pace for the season was set last night by the audience that filled the Metropolitan Opera House for the start of the operatic year.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Nov. 24 -- Dr. Arthur F. Torrance told a Mexican judge trying him for murder today that he was listed in Who's Who in America, had an income of $200 a month plus book royalties, and was sober when his wealthy bride was injured fatally near Monterrey about two weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The War Department today announced awards of contracts totaling $105,323,132, including one for $35,705,287 for anti-tank ammunition, to General Motors Corporation.

The six proud nations of the Iroquois Indian Confederacy may never have been conquered by the United States, but their members are citizens of this country whether they like it or not, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here ruled yesterday.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 24 -- Reports of heavy fighting in Central and Southeastern Serbia and two large battles in which Serbian Loyalist forces and Chetnik guerrillas destroyed a German motorized column and a punitive patrol of the forces of General Milan Neditch, Premier of occupied Yugoslavia, reached foreign military intelligence sources at Istanbul this evening.

PISTOLS are optional in football, but Professor Lou Little of Columbia, a peaceable citizen, thinks that they should be barred altogether. He is for total disarmament in that respect. As the rules read now, the timers are allowed to choose their own weapons. In the college game the field judge is official timer. In the professional game, it's the umpire who handles the watch and flourishes the pistol.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- As a protective move the United States Government is establishing Army forces in Surinam, or Dutch Guiana, which lies on the eastern bulge of South America, next to French Guiana, under an agreement reached with the Netherland Government in London, it was announced at the White House today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (AP) -- This is the time of the year that college football coaches begin thinking about 1942 and '43 prospects and the chances are that a large percentage of them are turning hopefully to Pennsylvania high school gridirons.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Looking beyond the present British offensive in Libya, the easiest way into Germany in 1943 or even 1942 may not be through the Brenner Pass but through the Balkans into Austria.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 24 (Australian Associated Press) -- The Australians who broke out of Tobruk to join the advancing imperial forces in Libya suffered no loss of life in the engagement, but left behind in a cemetery the graves of more than 500 Australians who lost their lives during the long siege, according to word received from Cairo today by Army Minister Francis M. Forde.

Things were quiet along the professional football front yesterday with the dramatic victory of the Giants over the Redskins on Sunday still the dom nant topic of conversation. The new Eastern champions received a three-day holiday and will not report until Thursday.

Although, as any member of the herpetology department of the American Museum or Natural History could tell you without even taking a deep breath, snakes fall easily into eighteen main families, the Boidae, the Typhlopidae, the Dasypeltidae, the Elachistodontidae, etc., such technical information will be kept under wraps during the New York Book Fair at the museum from 10 A.M. tomorrow through Sunday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The American consulate at Saigon, French Indo-China, was wrecked last night by a bomb, but none of the consular staff was injured, the State Department announced today. French Indo-China is occupied by Japanese troops.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, assistant director of the Office of Civilian Defense, said today that the OCD was planning to organize a "women's land army" to help harvest next year's crops.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The White House announced that contingents of the United States Army would protect bauxite deposits in Dutch Guiana. President Roosevelt met with Democratic Congressional leaders in the morning and tonight conferred with a Congressional bipartisan group on anti-strike legislation.

The recently announced policy of the Estado de Sao Paulo, Brazilian Government controlled newspaper, of deciding the justification of advertisers changing agencies without good reason or the consent of the agency was applauded yesterday by J. Russell Kiernan of Frank Kiernan Co.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Trucking operations in Chicago, the hub of the Midwest's vast network, slowed down to a trickle today when 2,500 A.F. of L. freight handlers went on strike for higher wages.

Extension of American lease-lend aid to the armies of General Charles de Gaulle in Africa and Syria was announced here yesterday by the Free French delegation to the United States. Simultaneously, it was made known in Washington that the Economic Defense Board, without explaining its reasons, had revoked all export licenses for French North Africa, together with all permits for exportation of petroleum products to Spain and Tangier.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 24 -- F. Leroy Hill made public today a letter written by him to Robert P. Patterson, Assistant Secretary of War, protesting against seizure by the War Department of the plant of Air Associates, Inc., in Bendix, N.J., following labor disturbances at the plant.

ROME, Nov. 24 -- The British forces in Libya have suffered heavy losses in battles that have been raging without pause in the quadrangle formed By Tobruk, Bir el-Gobi, Sidi Omar and Solum, today's communique said. The bulletin acknowledged that the Italian Savona Division, in the Solum region on the Libyan-Egyptian frontier, was "strongly engaged."

OTTAWA, Nov. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Wartime Prices and Trade Board today laid down four general rules under which the general price ceiling will be applied to new purchases of goods identical with those sold during the basic period Sept. 15 to Oct. 11 and to goods of a kind or quality not sold during that period.

A united effort is the most important need of the church in this time of world stress. Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist area declared yesterday at a service of rededication for the Methodist Building, 150 Fifth Avenue.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 25 -- Although a formal announcement by the Foreign Office that the liner Tatuta Maru would sail for Los Angeles and Balboa, C.Z. before the end of the month, and various 0other indications, both in Washington and Tokyo, served to revive hopes for a successful conclusion of the American-Japanese negotiations, the Japanese Government continued to speed up the creation of a wartime military, economic and financial structure in preparation for the worst.

H. Robert Reeve of the Bayside Tennis Club defeated Joseph J. Lordi of the New York A.C. in five games in the final of the twentysecond annual invitation squash tennis tournament at the Princeton Club last night. The event was held under the auspices of the National Squash Tennis Association, and Reeve, with a steady, driving pace, proved too much for Lordi the national champion.

LEESBURG, Va., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The body of Ward Loveless, 51 years old, a Washington attorney, was found today stuffed into a small closet in his country home. The disordered contents of the house gave evidence of a terrific struggle.
BERLIN, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

Higher prices and shortages of materials, together with increases in labor costs, preclude reductions in prices of toilet goods to offset the repeal of the manufacturers' excise tax and the imposition of the 10 per cent Federal levy on retail cosmetic sales.

BERLIN, Nov. 24 -- Seven more nations will join the Anti-Comin -tern Pact when that "corridor to the Tri-Partite Axis Treaty" is renewed here tomorrow for another five years, German officials announced today.

Commonwealth of Massachusetts A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers received yesterday the award of an issue of $1,500,000 of Boston airport bonds of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts on a bid of 100.34 for the bonds bearing interest at the rate of 3/4 of 1 per cent.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 24 -- The German Economic Ministry has established three huge trusts, consisting of seven great Axis machinery and arms plants with headquarters in the Reich and branch offices at Salonika and Istanbul, to meet the stringent requirements of the heavy industry section of the new Turko-German trade pact, it was learned today from informed Istanbul trade circles and from authoritative foreign commercial sources in the Turkish capital.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was much interested to see in your issue of Nov. 15 an article about a lecture by Dr. John F. Daniel in which he told the students of the Columbia University of his excavations in Cyprus and his discovery of the meaning of four words in the Cypro-Minoan script which an ancient potter contemporary of Homer had inscribed on one of his oil jars.

The missile that ended the career of the destroyer Reuben James and made her the first United States naval vessel to be lost in the present war struck without warning during the early hours of Oct. 31, and cost the lives of all her officers and all her petty officers except one, who led the forty-four enlisted men remaining alive after the blast over the side into three rescue rafts.
LUBEC, Me., Nov. 24 (AP) -- War has brought prosperity to the "Down East" sardine industry.
OTTAWA, Nov. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Navy Minister Angus Macdonald tonight announced that two Canadian corvettes -- the Chambly and Moosejaw -- recently sank a German U-boat in the North Atlantic.
Extra payments and special year-end distributions made up a large proportion of the dividends declared to stockholders yesterday.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Army, entering the stretch today in its drive for the Navy game, had a light workout. There was little more than a limbering-up exercise and a signal drill following the skull practice, in which Coach Earl Blaik went over the mistakes made in the West Virginia game last Saturday.

Contending that the proportional representation method of electing City Councilman is neither "proportional nor representative," Councilman Louis Cohen, Bronx Democrat, will move in the Council today for abolition of this system and its replacement with, election of the Councilmen by Senate districts.

While the team's supporters are busy viewing with alarm, the New York Rangers tonight will skate out on the ice at Madison Square Garden determined to do something about a situation that is rapidly becoming painful. The Blue Shirts will seek to shake off the jinx which finds them unable to win a game on the home rink.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The largest convoy of Canadian troops to cross the Atlantic in this war has safely arrived in Britain, it was announced today.

Add to the list of films opening this week, Twentieth Century-Fox's "Marry the Boss's Daughter," with Brenda Joyce, Bruce Edwards, George Barbier and Hardie Albright, which will arrive at the Palace on Thursday. "Bad Men of Missouri" is the associate picture on the double-feature program.

Preferred stock financing on behalf of the Pennsylvania-Central Airlines Corporation and of the Fisher Brothers Company, together aggregating in excess of $4,000,000 based on the offering prices, will be undertaken today by two underwriting groups.

Appointment of a special committee to meet with Lease-Lend Administrator Edward R. Stettinius Jr., to discuss the problem of foregin freight forwarders who feel they are being adversely affected by present procedure under the act, was announced yesterday by T.E. Reeve, of the New York Foreign Freight Forwarders and Brokers Association.

OTTAWA, Nov. 24 -- The arrival of the final contingent of the Fifth (Armored) Division of the Canadian Army in Britain, escorted part of the way by American warships, marks one more record marking Canadian accomplishment.

Bill Dudley marched to the top of the nation's scorers last week by collecting 22 points in the Virginia victory over North Carolina, while Ben Collins, erstwhile leader from West Texas State, was blanked by Texas A. and I.

VICHY, France, Nov. 24 -- Increases of capital by French companies, which have been carried on steadily since the beginning of this year, had numbered 126 by end of October, according to figures published in the Parisian Zeitung, German-language newspaper in the occupied zone.

While two prosecutors were urging yesterday in General Sessions that leniency be shown George (the Weasel) Stern, a confessed robber-gang leader, because of aid he had given them in breaking up the Brooklyn murder ring and his own in Manhattan, Judge James Garrett Wallace revealed that Stern also was suspected of being involved in a plot two years ago to kill a police inspector.

BERLIN, Nov. 24 -- In her war against the Soviet Union Germany is fighting not only for the obliteration of bolshevism but to destroy the traditional Russian "imperialism" -- a significant change in the Reich's declared war-and-peace aims -- it was announced here tonight on the eve of the AntiComintern Conference.

HAVANA, Nov. 24 -- The need for a pronouncement setting for the ideas and beliefs of the intellectuals of America, in view of their responsibility in the present world situation, was emphasized at a conference here today under the auspices of the Cuban National Commission on Intellectual Cooperation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The record of Dr. John R. Steelman, who is to decide whether or not the United Mine Workers are to have what amounts to the closed shop throughout the captive mines, suggests that he has a special talent for settling industrial disputes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Close on the heels of the conviction of George E. Browne and Willie Bioff, the Supreme Court today upheld prison sentences for two more labor union racketeers in the moving picture industry.

ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- Every bank and financial institution to which had been offered an allotment of short-term notes by State Controller Joseph V. O'Leary accepted the tender and tomorrow will receive its share in the $100,000,000 issue that will bear date of Nov. 25.

The first local hearing by the Federal Trade Commission on its charges alleging price fixing by the Tag Manufacturers Institute was held yesterday at the offices of the institute at 370 Lexington Avenue. Arthur P. Williams of the Dennison Manufacturing Company testified to certain price schedules issued by the organization.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Nov. 19 aggregated $12,653,000,000.

Whether they recognize it or not, labor union leaders by their recent policies have been destroying the machinery for conciliation, mediation and fact-finding that the Administration has set up to secure industrial peace. For they have shown -- and the Administration has permitted them to show -- that that machinery has little use except to make decisions against employers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In such a time as this true Americans, appreciating the dangers confronting the Republic, will range themselves behind the Administration and will do all within their power to uphold and strengthen the hands of the President. They will do this regardless of political affiliation and irrespective of how they may have cast their votes at the last election.

To the national A.A.U. champion Twentieth Century-Fox team of Hollywood, Calif., went the Naismith Plaque last night at Madison Square Garden, by virtue of a stirring 42-39 triumph over Phillips 66 of Bartlesville, Okla., in the final of the two-night tournament that set off basketball's six-month golden jubilee celebration.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 -- Striking C.I.O. employes of the Columbia Steel Company at Pittsburg, participants in a walkout which is holding up $5,000,000 worth of Army, Navy and Maritime Commission contracts, made plans for an extended strike at a mass meeting today.
