Trading in locally dressed meats was only fair yesterday. The lamb market was steady to higher and fresh pork, steady to lower. Otherwise, prices were about in line with Friday's markets.

The Pure Oil Company in the first nine months of this year had consolidated net earnings of $10,045,304 after charges and taxes, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $1.78 each on the 3,982,031 common shares, according to a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in accordance with SEC requirements and in connection with the issuance of the company's 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred shares.

The assessment situation in New York City probably will be the most important topic discussed at the sixth annual general metropolitan realty conference at the Hotel Commodore Dec. 10, according to the Real Estate Board of New York.

Close bidding marked the sale yesterday by the Philadelphia Electric Company of an issue of $20,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent bonds due in 1971, in what turned out to be one of the most clean-cut sales yet conducted under the Securities and Exchange Commission's compulsory bidding rule put in effect last May.

A message from President Roosevelt endorsing the thirty-fifth annual Christmas Seal Campaign of the National Tuberculosis Association was made public here yesterday by the association as it opened its 1941 drive.

To take care of their own morale problem, members and supporters of the theatrical profession opened yesterday at 164 West Forty-eighth Street the first Actors Thrift Shop. Its proceeds will provide new clothes for needy actors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Representative McCormack, Democratic floor leader in the House, announced tonight after a bipartison conference with President Roosevelt that it was the "consensus" that anti-strike legislation providing for a "reasonable" waiting period in advance of walkouts in defense industries should be enacted by Congress.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 -- A proposal that finance capital be brought into defense and post-war planning under an intergovernmental committee resembling those that control the use of all other national assets was made today by Ganson Purcell, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to 1,000 persons attending a luncheon meeting of the Detroit Economic Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Reynolds Metals Company today criticized the order of the Office of Production Management limiting the use of lead and tin foils, saying that it would compel the shutting down of its two factories at Richmond, Va., and Louisville, Ky.

The Chicago Bears, who became the first National Football League team to score 313 points in one season by downing Detroit, 24 -- 7 on Sunday, also became the first outfit to gain 3,000 yards or more this season, it was reported yesterday through The Associated Press.

New money financing on behalf of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company will be carried out today with the public offering by an underwriting group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., of an issue of $25,000,000 of the company's first and refunding mortgage 3 per cent bonds, due on June 1, 1971. The bonds will be priced at 105 and accrued interest.
Families of eighty-six Navy enlisted men moved into the thirteen-story Walabout Houses opposite City Park in Brooklyn yesterday, five months after the project was started.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: For those who remember, last week was a week of mourning for the Czecho-Slovak people. Two years ago more than one hundred young students of the Charles IV University were murdered by the Germans for singing patriotic songs in open defiance of foreign rule.

If Rostov has fallen before a Nazi assault, as the German High Command announces, it is a grave blow to Russia. The Don River, on which the city stands, marks the easternmost limit of Germany's advance in the World War, but its conquest now would seem merely a prelude to a new sweep forward.

Pending a clarification of the labor situation, especially as it concerns national defense and a legislative curb on strikes, financial markets contented themselves yesterday in reaping what consolation they could from the resumption of operations in the captive coal mines.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Frederick L. Wilt, slim Indiana University runner, today capped his first big time harrier season with an easy triumph in the fourth annual National Collegiate A.A. cross-country championships.

Before a brilliant gathering, in which military uniforms vied with feminine charm, a new type off fabric was displayed yesterday. Its basis was milk. Combined with wool yarns and rayon the casein textile fiber produced fabrics of crepe and tweedlike texture and others resembling sheer woolens and linen weaves.

The past and future of medical pioneering for women joined last night to honor one of its leaders, Dr. Annie S. Daniel, for sixty years a member of the staff of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children. Dr. Daniel, who gives her age as 80-plus, was toasted and cheered at a dinner at the Hotel St. Moritz by 100 graduates of the infirmary, several of whom studied under her in the Eighteen Eighties.

A new clinic for the study of the brain wave patterns of stutterers and sufferers from other speech and voice disorders, the first of its kind in the world, will be opened soon at the National Hospital for Speech Disorders, 61 Irving Place, it was announced yesterday by Dr. James Sonnett Greene, founder and director of the hospital, at the celebration of the institution's twenty-fifth anniversary.

The International Committee of Bankers on Mexico, headed by Thomas W. Lamont, will ask Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Koch today to confirm a report by Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, as special referee, denying the claim of the Mexican Government to ownership of any part of the fund of nearly $7,000,000 still held by the committee.

A study of basic disorders and environmental factors that cause excessive drinking, and the problem of alcoholism, as it might affect industrial production will be undertaken by the Research Council on Problems of Alcohol, it decided yesterday at its annual meeting at the Hotel Commodore.

BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- In a ceremony at the Reich Chancellery lasting an hour and a half representatives of twelve European and Asiatic governments this afternoon affixed their signatures to the document known as the Anti-Comintern Pact, technically directed not against Russia but against the activities of the Moscow Communist International.

The Long Island University basketball team scored a 64-35 victory over Mitchel Field at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium yesterday. The regular varsity line-up started and had a 24-14 lead at half-time.
American Export Lines American Export Lines, Inc., voted a year-end dividend of 50 cents, increasing 1941 payments to $1.50 from $1 distributed last year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A heavy run of arrivals broke the market for live hogs today. Opening losses of around 15 cents a hundred weight were extended in later dealings and at the close prices were generally 25 cents down. Top price of $10.15 compared with S10.35 yesterday. Trade sources said the slaughter of hogs in centers under Federal inspection totaled 837,807 head last week, toe largest for any 1941 week.

Buddy Knox, Dayton, Ohio, heavyweight, and Tony Musto, Chicago, battled to a draw in the eight-round feature of the boxing show at the New York Coliseum before a crowd of 4,000 last night. Knox weighed 192 1/4 and Musto 206 1/2.

Collectors' items from near and far, some dating back 200 years, were displayed yesterday by members of Chaminade, one of the largest women's music clubs in Brooklyn. This hobby show was held to raise money for the club's scholarship fund, given in honor of Mme.

HOLLTWOOD, Calif., Nov. 25 -- Charles Chaplin's next picture will be a comedy adaptation of the Bluebeard theme, it was learned today. The chief character was suggested by the career of the French criminal, Henri Landru, according to a Chaplin representative.

Fears that the loss of foreign freight handling resulting from lease-lend transactions with the British would spread to domestic warehousing and shipping of products destined for Britain, were heightened yesterday with the disclosure by foreign freight forwarders here of a memorandum by a government official which outlines a proposed extension of existing practices.

Two stockholders' actions were filed in Supreme Court yesterday, one against present and former directors of Paramount Pictures, Inc., for accounting and recovery of funds paid to George E. Browne, president, and William Bioff, Hollywood representative of the International Alliance of Theatrical and Stage Employes.

At the Guild Theatre this evening the curtain will, rise on the Theatre Guild's second subscription offering of the season, "Hope for a Harvest," a comedy written by Sophie TreadwelL The acting team of Fredric March and his wife, Florence Eldridge, head the cast.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The War Department announced today award of contracts amounting to $56,837,890.83, most of which went for ordnance items. Included were the following, not previously published, to companies in the New York area:

The protracted negotiations between the International Longshoremen's Association and coastwise shipping lines bore fruit yesterday when the dock men agreed to extend their expired working contract at the old wage rate of 95 cents an hour and $1.42 for overtime.

LISBON, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Violent earth shocks rocked the Portuguese coast about 6 P. M. today, and persons in many small towns rushed screaming from their shaking houses and prayed in the streets. There were no reports of damage.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 25 -- A Pan-American fiesta at the Essex House here today, with 500 women present, marked the first step in a fund raising campaign initiated by Contemporary of Newark to provide more country vacations for underprivileged children.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Separate discussions between representatives of the United States, Britain, China and the Netherlands, and a White House conference of top American officials with President Roosevelt suggested tonight that the United States was clearing the way for a major move in the Far Eastern situation.

In a raid on the Musical Knights, so-called social club in Harlem, it 5 o'clock yesterday morning the police seized five pairs of dice, one of which was a set of "tops" on which seven could not be rolled, and twenty-seven Negroes, including 49-year-old James Marshall, alleged operator of the club.

The eighth annual "Night of Stars" for the benefit of the United Jewish Appeal owill be given tonight in Madison Square Garden, with Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mayor La Guardia as guests of honor and with the endorsements of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman.

Seeking to check crime in Harlem and other areas with, high juvenile delinquency rates, the City Council voted unanimously yesterday to ask the Board of Estimate to open school gymnasiums, swimming pools and other indoor recreation facilities in these sections.

Mrs. Molly Perlson, Queens housewife whose fox terrier Sporty has been condemned to death as a third offender for biting children, went to the Supreme Court in Jamaica yesterday with a petition for clemency signed by 120 children and parents, including two of the bitten children.

The board of trustees and corporate members of the Community Service Society were told last night at their annual dinner at the Hotel Plaza that the organization's educational nursing and anti-tuberculosis work, as well as its nutrition service, medical clinics and other activities were "pushing beyond the business-as-usual formula in these times."

DOWNEY, Calif., Nov. 25 -- Vultee Aircraft, Inc., is negotiating for the stock holdings of Major Reuben H. Fleet in the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation as a preliminary to a prospective merger of the two companies, which have a backlog of defense orders totaling about $1,000,000,000.

The most interesting part of Leopold Stokowski's programs with the NBC Symphony Orchestra at the Cosmopolitan Opera House continued to be the "informal rehearsal" that followed the broadcast section last night. It might be argued that music and the large public would be better served if Mr. Stokowski put on the air the compositions that are less frequently heard and if he saved for "informal rehearsal" recurrent symphonies like Tchaikovsky's Fourth.
The Grace Line announced yesterday that the new freighter Santa Teresa had been assigned to the New York-Caribbean service to replace the liner Santa Paula for a period of several weeks.

PITTSBURGH, Calif., Nov. 25 -- Complying with requests from national officers of the C. I. O.'s Steel Workers Organizing Committee, striking employes of the Columbia Company, owner of the largest steel plant in the Far West, voted today to go back to their job of turning out $5,000,000 worth of defense work for the Army, Navy and Maritime Commission.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Captain George W. Cowan, police amusement inspector, notified the management of a theatre here that the new Greta Garbo film, "Two-Faced Woman," may not be shown Thursday as scheduled.

After early weakness under pressure of continued liquidation in the near months and issuance of a ten-year high number of transferable notices of delivery against the December contract, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday to close with net gains of 2 to 10 points.

Successfully completing the longest proving flight ever made in aviation, the Pan American Airways Capetown Clipper glided to a landing off the marine terminal of La Guardia Field at 12:57 A.M. today after covering a distance of 19,961 miles to Leopoldville, Belgian Congo, and back.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 25 -- The Navy football team will put a defense on the field against Army at the Philadelphia Municipal Stadium Saturday that has yielded only four touchdowns during the current campaign.

LEESBURG, Va., Nov. 25 (AP) -- With a greasy felt hat as a major clue, authorities sought today to reconstruct the slaying of 51-year-old Ward Loveless, Washington attorney. The hat bore the initials "A. T." in the band.

ALBANY, Nov. 25 -- Governor Lehman named a committee today to consider the responsibility of government and industry in absorbing the unemployed when the defense emergency has passed. Public works and research on new products are among the measures to be studied.

Formal offering to the public will be made today by an under-writing syndicate headed by the Mellon Securities Corporation of $20,000,000 of Philadelphia Electric Company first and refunding mortgage 2 3/4 per cent bonds, due in 1971.

Despite low money rates and upset world conditions, the total funds of the pension boards of twenty major Protestant denominations and the Y. M. C. A. and Y. W. C. A. brought an average investment income of 3 1/2% per cent last year, the twenty-seventh annual Church Pensions Conference heard yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- General Robert Odic, until recently commander of the French Air Force in North Africa, said today he had resigned to join the Free French forces because the Germans were undermining the French will to resist in North Africa.

KRISHNALAL SHRIDHARANI says that when he walked into an American cafeteria for the first time he had to pull a sandalwood-scented handkerchief from his pocket and hold it to his nose and eyes. For there on the steam table, right before him, lay exposed a large chunk of naked meat, and not only naked meat but meat "with fat hanging on it and bones protruding."

The Supreme Court's unanimous verdict in California v. Edwards, the so-called "Okie" case, upsets the California anti-migrant law, and possibly the anti-migrant laws of New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and twenty-four other States. Yet it merely reaffirms an old and noble principle, embedded in our history, implied in Article IV of the Constitution and explicitly stated in the Fourteenth Amendment.

IT was some years ago that an esteemed professional confrere, Colonel Joe Williams of Memphis, Cleveland, New York and way stations, thought up the scheme of having football coaches vote each season for the "Coach of the Year." It's a vote by secret ballot. As Clerk of the Polls at this annual election Colonel Williams is now up to his ample waist in ballots and secrecy in the campaign of 1941.

More than a thousand years of "The British Tradition" are illustrated in some of the monuments of her literature, her art and her craftsmanship that will be placed on public exhibition today at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East Thirty-sixth Street.

Earnings of the chemical industry in the third quarter of 1941 increased the lead over the 1940 period established in the second quarter, despite the considerable increase in taxation. Twenty-one companies comprising the major part of the industry togethere arned $47,881,913, against $42,784,485 a year ago, an increase of 11.9 per cent.

George Cummings and his amateur partner, David McElroy, representing the University Club, won the seventh annual pro-amateur squash racquets tournament at the Heights Casino last night by beating their club-mates, James McKinney and Edward C. Oelsner, in four games, 15-13, 12-15, 17-16, 15-7.

A program of "quota" teachers smaller classes and individualized remedial instruction is planned by the New York City school official to meet the juvenile delinquency existing in Harlem and other problem areas, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 25 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 24:

ROME, Nov. 25 -- The anti-Comintern meeting in Berlin is hailed today by the Italian press as an important manifestation of European solidarity against Russia, Great Britain and the United States as the nations representing "bolshevism, plutocracy and international Jewry" and bent on asserting their hegemony at the expense of "the new European forces.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Office of Production Management today explained in detail its new production requirements plan, worked out to simplify the priorities procedure for manufactures. The order setting up the new system has not been formally approved by Donald M. Nelson, OPM Priorities Director, now out of the city, and the plan therefore will not be officially announced until his return.

Inspector Michael Murphy, head of Police Commissioner Valentine's confidential squad, led a raid upon the Lincoln League Republican Club, 281 Grand Street, Just before 7 o'clock last night. Later he announced that the police were holding fifty-six men as participants in a "big" dice game.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- "Food will win the war and write the peace," H. B. Little, president of the New York Association of County Agricultural Agents, said at the annual meeting of the State Farm Bureau Federation today.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- Ferry service between Nyack and Tarry-town will end at 9:30 o'clock Sunday night after 101 years of operation, according to announcement today by John E. Englis, president of Ferries Operating Company, proprietors of the line.

Mayor La Guardia held yesterday his first important political conference since the election, when he met Thomas J. Curran, Republican leader of New York County, in City Hall. Mr. Curran arrived about 4 P.M. and waited about two hours.

Stanley Clarke, trustee in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, top unit in the bankrupt Associated Gas and Electric System, took sharp issue yesterday with the trustees in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation over the proposed integration of the system and declared that if properties were disposed of at depressed prices now, "millions of dollars of value will have been sacrificed and the security holders will have suffered irreparable damage."

The awarding of the third Limited Editions Club gold medal to an author whose book published in the last three years Is most likely, in the opinion of a board of judges, "to attain the stature of a classic," will take place this morning at aliterary breakfast at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

With Major Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, and Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. looking on, Georgie Abrams, Roanoke, Va., middleweight, and Tony Zale of Gary, Ind., yesterday concluded training for their fifteen-round bout in Madison Square Garden Friday night to decide possession of the disputed world middle-weight title.

Housing is not looked upon as an obstacle to defense but is actually regarded as a vital part of the defense program, Thomas G. Grace, New York State director of the FHA, told the Brooklyn Real Estate Board yesterday at a luncheon meeting in Michel's Restaurant.

BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- What the Germans stigmatize as "President Roosevelt's first military attack on South America" received publicity In the German press almost equal to that given the ceremony of the promulgation of the Anti-Comintern Pact.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The anti-Comintern meeting in Berlin, attended by representatives of thirteen States, is little more than the harbinger of the far more elaborate and "epoch-making" assembly that Reichsfuehrer Hitler and his men intend to summon whenever they think it possible to trim the military operations in Russia with the colors of victory.

After hearing arguments yesterday on the State Attorney General's application for a temporary injunction restraining the News-dealers Federal Labor Union, Local 22,371, A. F. of L., from continuing its boycott against seven New York City morning and afternoon newspapers, Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Koch, Special Term, Part 3, gave both sides until tomorrow morning to file briefs.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- A renewed fog of war hangs over the British operations in Libya and the way the battle there is proceeding. Some news continues to seep through by communique or otherwise, but meanwhile it is perhaps fitting to record the views of military experts here, so far as they can be obtained.

"Keep 'Em Flying," the latest Universal service comedy, starring Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, will have its local premiere this morning at Loew's Criterion. Featured in the story, which utilizes an aviation background, are Martha Raye, Carol Bruce, William Gargan and Dick Foran.

Frank Kovacs, runner-up to Bobby Riggs for the national tennis singles championship at Forest Hills last Summer, has been declared ineligible to compete in tournaments and matches of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, it was announced yesterday.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 25 -- British tanks have been rushed into action on the Moscow front for the first time, it was reported here today as the Germans maintained tremendous pressure in the Klin salient and managed to grind their way forward for a limited advance despite devastating Russian artillery fire, which exacted large losses.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 25 -- Lou Boudreau, 24-year-old shortstop, tonight was named field manager of the Indians on a two-year contract, becoming one of the youngest baseball pilots in major league history.

Two major secondary stock distributions were consummated yesterday after the close of the Stock Exchange. An underwriting group consisting of Glore, Forgan Co., Lee Higginson Corporation and Shields Co. offered 135,000 shares of common stock of Marshall Field Co. at $14.50 a share.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Richard Loveland asserted today in testimony before Judge Jesus B. Santos that Dr. Arthur F. Torrance murdered his mother, Mrs. Ada Loveland Torrance, the physician's bride of three weeks, to "get her money or for revenge after benefits to him in her will were revoked."

Not only during the period of the defense emergency but for the last few years this newspaper has frequently urged a careful and thoroughgoing revision of Federal and State labor laws and a reconsideration of Administration labor policy. It has more than once expressed the fear that "failure to act calmly in a lull can only lead to panicky and dangerous measures in a future crisis that such inaction tends to make inevitable."

State Senator Charles Muzzicato, chairman of the Senate Committee on Public Health, proposed yesterday an experimental medical plan for residents of the new East River houses at East River Drive and 102d Street. He said it was designed to provide good medical care for the 1,170 families in the development, whose income is between $1,000 and $1,100 a year.

ANNAPOLIS, Nov. 25 -- Five hundred and sixty-four first classmen of the Naval Academy due to graduate on Dec. 19 will have a regular "June Week," Rear Admiral Russall Wilson, Superintendent, announced today in disclosing the list of students due to be commissioned ensigns in the line or second lieutenants in the Marine Corps before Christmas.

A "low-cost rehabilitations program" designed to Bring new life and better housing conditions in the outmoded blocks surrounding St. Mark's Church on the lower East Side was suggested yesterday by the committee on housing of the Community Service Society.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- A small British patrol landed on the coast of Normandy Sunday night, it was announced today in reply to a Berlin communique, quoted by Reuters, in which the Germans asserted that such action had been attempted, but had been "repulsed by German coastal defenses with heavy losses."

On Fordham's practice field, Jimmy Crowley is bringing to a close one of the hardest coaching Jobs of the year. For more than two hours yesterday, the Ram football forces worked on attack and defense, and they are facing another scrimmage this afternoon.
Standardization of toothpicks and clothespins will be the subject of conferences to be held here next Wednesday under the auspices of the Government of the United States.

Police Commissioner Valentine denied yesterday that the policing of Harlem has suffered because of a reported policy of transferring policemen to Harlem precincts as punishment for drunkenness and other violation of rules.He said there was no such policy.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Eight colleges are represented on The United Press All-Southeastern football team, with the Crimson Tide of Alabama, twice beaten but powerful, placing three players on the mythical eleven.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- President Roosevelt announced today that he was sending William C. Bullitt, long his chief Ambassador in Europe, to the Near East battle area as special Presidential representative.

The Democratic campaign charges that a $1,000,000 campaign fund was being expended in the interest of the re-election of Mayor La Guardia were not substantiated in the campaign expense reports filed up to closing time yesterday with the Board of Elections, the final day for filing under the election law.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A bill embodying conclusions reached at last night's White House conference on steps to prevent defense strikes was ordered by the House Labor Committee today to be reported to the floor on Friday.

A retrospective exhibition of the architectural work of Eric Mendelsohn opens in one of the groundfloor galleries of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fiftythird Street, today. It will remain current until Jan. 4.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 26 -- Continuing the campaign for total national mobilization while the American - Japanese negotiations are still hanging fire. Premier Hideki Tojo delivered a speech yesterday before a mass rally of the Imperial Rule Assistance Association that was broadcast country a highly organized defense state wide.
BERLIN, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Today's German communique follows:

Export authorities, who are anxious to cement relationships with South American nations, are hoping that large American exporters will adopt the policy of institutional advertising for South America as they have done for the domestic market.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- As general debate on the Administration's Price Control Bill drew to a close today both Democrats and Republicans forecast freely that the House would reject a proposed "over-all" control plan as a substitute for the committee bill.

The Spring championship races of the Star International Class at Nassau, Bahamas, will be held in March again, it was learned yesterday. The competition will start on March 24 and wind up on March 30. It means that the Stars will have their southern events two months apart.

The twenty-first annual bazaar of the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York for the benefit of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women will be opened formally this afternoon in the main ball-room of the Biltmore by Lady Halifax, wife of the British Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Administration today served notice on Finland that her war against Russia, with the consequent threat to the Murmansk-Moscow supply line, was directly "harmful to the interests of the United States."

First prices on 1942 lines of electric refrigerators issued yesterday by two leading manufacturers showed a divergent trend, with one line practically unchanged from last prevailing quotations on 1941 models and the other line up sharply.

Gold Earmarkings The weekly Department of Commerce figures yesterday on gold imports and earmarkings here for foreign account, covering the week ended on Nov. 19, revealed that gold under earmark for foreign account rose $35,354,817.
BOSTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- For the second time in three nights the champion Boston Bruins overwhelmed the Detroit Red Wing's with a 7-1 victory tonight before 12,000 at the Boston Garden.

TRENTON, Nov. 25 -- Governor Charles Edison issued a statement today denying a charge made yesterday by E. Donald Sterner, State Highway Commissioner, that products of the Thomas A. Edison Industries, Inc., of which the Governor is president, on leave, had been sold extensively to New Jersey departments and contractors.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 25 -- Asserting that women were as responsible for the defense of their country as men, Mrs. DeForest Van Slyck, executive secretary of the Association of the Junior Leagues of America and consultant to the United States Office of Civilian Defense, declared here today that the civilian defense movement should be as important to a woman aa her family's income and health.
NORWALK, Calif., Nov. 25 (AP) -- John K. O'Meara, 32, a former glider champion, was killed today in the crash of a basic trainer monoplane he was testing for the Harlow Aircraft Company of Alhambra.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Richard R. Schmon of St. Catherines, Ontario, Canada, was elected captain of Princeton's 1942 football team at a meeting of varsity lettermen today. A regular starter for the first time this season, Schmon developed into one of the finest defensive ends Princeton has had in recent years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The indictment charging George Hill, assistant secretary to Representative Hamilton Fish, with perjury before a local Federal grand jury investigating Nazi activities, was upheld by Justice James W. Morris in the Federal District Court today.

Declaring that only a small percentage of strike pickets were legitimate workers, Albert W. Hawkes, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, urged yesterday that legislation be enacted to require the registration of all who participate in apicket line.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- The disappearance six days ago of Isabelle H. Perrin, 27, a member of a prominent Philadelphia family was reported to the police today by her mother, Mrs. Edward Osborne Troth.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 25 -- President Pedro Aguirre Cerda, the Western Hemisphere's first Popular Front Executive, died at 1:07 this afternoon in Moneda Palace, where he had been confined to bed for two weeks, suffering from acute bronchial and lung congestion.

A decline of a full point in the puerperal death rate in New York City last week brought that rate for the year down 25 per cent under any comparable figure on record for the city. Dr. John L. Rice,Health Commissioner, reported yesterday.

After a brief ownership, the C. H. D. Realty Company has sold to Lintex, Inc., the seventeen-story store and loft building at 257 West Thirty-eighth Street for cash above a ten-year first mortgage of $182,-771.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- From the arbitration of the captive coal mines dispute, which begins in New York City tomorrow, John L. Lewis will emerge either re-established as the strongest labor leader in the country or the twelfth-hour loser in one of the most dramatic struggles for union advantage ever waged in the United States.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 25 -- Horses representing Mrs. Frances D. Scully played a prominent part in today's racing. After Batter Up, at $35.50 for $2, had won the opening event, and Down Six, $34.20, had accounted for the fourth, Ponty tried to make it a perfect day for the stable.
BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- The text of the protocol renewing the Anti-Comintern Pact of 1936 follows:

Millstones -- to us cynical city folks -- are quaint, antiquated objets d'art which landscape architects adapt as bird-baths, fence posts or stepping-stones. But there is an ancient mill on a Jersey farm where millstones are still used to grind the wheat for homemade loaves of bread.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Congressional officials and high-ranking Army and Navy officers will witness the forty-second Army-Navy football classic, naval academy authorities announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A comprehensive plan for the liquidation of the United Light and Power Company, top holding concern in a system with more than $500,000,000 of utility assets, was filed today by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 25 (AP) -- America will probably have to restrict its own food consumption in order to feed the Allies within the next two years, Dean Carl E. Ladd of the New York State College of Agriculture and Home Economics declared tonight in an address prepared for the annual dinner of the State Farm Bureau, Home Bureau and 4-H Club Federations.

BOSTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- William Cardinal O'Connell, dean of Cardinal-priests in the highest council of the Roman Catholic Church, said today that America should beware lest it be strangled by the "creeping paralysis" of class hatred and atheistic propaganda.

A five-point price stabilization program for the liquor industry, under which deals and discounts would be welcomed so long as they were "open covenants, openly arrived at," was presented to the trade yesterday by the board of directors of the National Tavern Association, at a meeting at the Hotel Commodore.
CAIRO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command today issued this communique:

Expected rather earlier in the season, the first New York Ranger hockey victory at home finally came to pass last night. Rocked back on their heels in four previous attempts to show the home folks a winning, or even a tying, performance, Frank Boucher's Blue Shirts made a gallant spurt to come from behind in overtime and subdue the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 to 4.

The sunny South and the chill North fashionably rubbed shoulders on the runway yesterday. Macy was the guest exhibitor at the Salon d'Elegance luncheon held at the Ritz in the Oval room. The styles were for three types of Winter gaieties:

A series of meetings in various banking centers of the nation, designed to acquaint bankers with the complex Treasury regulations governing the control of foreign funds, will be held under the joint auspices of the American Bankers Association and the United States Treasury, it was announced yesterday by the A. B. A.

The military casualties in this war now run into millions. The scrap-heap of tanks and planes, towns, ships and soldiers has reached the heights of the Himalayas. But nobody has yet counted the other millions of hapless human beings blasted out of their homes and scattered like chaff by the advancing armies.

Trained employers and trained employes must cooperate to give dignity to household employment if "higher type" girls are to be attracted into servants' jobs rather than industrial work, was the concensus of a discussion meeting yesterday at the Essex House of the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women.

Without taking the witness stand in their own defense, Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, former ruler of the city's $1,000,000 industrial rackets, and his two henchmen, Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss and Louis Capone, through their attorneys rested their cases in Kings County Court yesterday in the eleventh week of trial on charges of first-degree murder.

The safe arrival in England of the largest convoy of Canadian troops to cross the Atlantic in this war is naturally the subject of rejoicing both in our neighbor Dominion and in Great Britain. It brings close to the 150,000 mark the number of Canadians now in military service overseas and includes the final contingent of the first armored division that the Dominion has sent out.

WEST BROMWICH, England, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- The severest earthquake ever recorded at the obvatory here rocked seismographs at 6:08 P. M. and the temblors continued so violently that they jolted levers on the instruments from their sockets.

TOKYO, Nov. 25 -- Drastic reorganization of the newspapers of Japan as "public utilities charged with a national mission under the wartime structure" was decided yesterday at a meeting of the board of directors of the Newspaper League, composed of representatives of all leading newspapers of Japan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The House Banking and Currency Committee, acting at the urging of the Administration, voted today to sponsor an amendment to the pending price control bill giving the Price Administrator the power to buy or sell commodities in any part of the world.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is increasingly astonishing and somewhat alarming to me that many otherwise intelligent people continue to quibble and cavil in the face of the crisis confronting our country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- President Roosevelt today denounced as "a disgusting lie" an article that appeared in the magazine Time Nov. 17 dealing with the temporary retirement from official life of President Pedro Aguirre Cerda of Chile, who died today.

Top honors and the pleasure (?) of facing either the Bears or Packers in the forthcoming play-off out West already belong to the Giants, but some unfinished business in the Eastern Division of the National Football League remains. There still is the little matter, of second place to be decided and that is giving the Dodgers food for thought.

Mrs. William Lafayette Burton 2d gave a tea yesterday at her home, 129 East Sixty-ninth Street, for members of the ticket committee serving in behalf of the Renoir Ball to be held on Dec. 17 at the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the Free French Relief Committee.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Scattered liquidation by holders of December wheat contracts developed today, commission houses being persistent sellers for customers who did not desire to take a delivery of the cash grain. This selling disclosed a lack of aggressive support, and at no time were prices above the finish of the previous day.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 25 -- Speaking in the Mexican Senate today on behalf of the Washington agreements. Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla hinted at defensive understandings to come when he said:

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 25 -- In a ceremony against a grim background of guns, turrets, torpedoes, shells, bombs and other elements of sea power, the Navy conferred today upon the Bethlehem Steel Company plant here and its 25,000 employes the Bureau of Ordnance flag and the Navy E, pennant, "as a recognition of outstanding effort in the production of ordnance materials vital to national defense."

Because the blind, victims of a continuous blackout, would be doubly imperiled during an emergency, the first air raid drill for the blind in New York City was held yesterday at the Lighthouse, six-story building of The New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Asserting that some means of financing small manufacturers must be found to save them from extinction, Senator Mead of New York appeared before the Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee today to urge approval of his bill permitting a relaxation of existing loan restrictions of the Federal Reserve System.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Nov. 26 -- Counter-attacking Russian troops in the Donets basin, supported by strong Cossack cavairy forces, have advanced more, than sixty-two miles against intense German resistance, the authorized Soviet military commentator declared in his broadcast from Moscow this morning.

The first organized manifestation of alumni displeasure with the current N.Y.U. football situation crystallized yesterday, almost on the eve of the traditional game with Fordham, when the executive committee of the university's Letter Club, an organization of former Violet athletes, announced a series of "conclusions" it had reached at a meeting Monday night at the Hotel Brittany.

AMSTERDAM, (Via Berlin), Nov. 25 -- Volume increased today on the Bourse and the market again had a decidedly strong tone, with the closing at the best levels of the day and the strength, continuing after the close. There was a keen demand for Royal Dutch, Unilever, the shippings and the plantations, and many reached new tops for the year.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Joseph D. Keenan, labor relations expert of the Office of Production Management, declared tonight that the strike of more than 8,500 machinists in the St. Louis area was "the most important and serious labor tie-up" in the country.

Mars the destroyer of cities and wrecker of men is not too proud to nibble at smaller things. As of March 15, 1942, he will nibble all the foil from our packages of cigarettes, chewing gum and certain other commodities. He wants it for his own purposes. Such is the interpretation of the Office of Production Management.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Maddox Rumbough of Lloyd Neck, Huntington, L. I., will give a dinner in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis on Dec. 5, before the first Junior Assembly, for their debutanteniece, Miss Grace Colgate Rumbough, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Wright Rumbough of this city and Oyster Bay.
ROME, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

HAVANA, Nov. 25 -- A declaration of principles condemning totalitarianism, asking a limitation on toleration for the protection of democracy and calling for active collaboration of all intellectual groups in the Americas to resist Nazi, Fascist and Falange penetration, was signed today by a group of twenty-five intellectuals at the meeting being held here under auspices of the Cuban National Committee on Intellectual Cooperation.

Buyer Registrations Off The number of out-of-town buyers registered in the market last week was 415, as against 644 in the previous week and 464 in the same period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Visiting buyers yesterday totaled 246, as against 256 for a week ago.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25 -- The Treasury's campaign to promote defense bonds and stamps has been notably successful in penetrating the public consciousness, but its chief problem is how to increase the sale of these bonds and stamps among, two particular groups in the country -- the low-income group and farmers.

MADRID, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- A "purge" of the Falange, the government party, has been ordered by General Jose Luis de Arrese, secretary general, and the consequences are expected to be farreaching, it was revealed today.
BERLIN, Wednesday, Nov. 26 (AP) -- German reserves have been hurled into a desperate, but still indecisive, struggle against the British in the Libyan Desert, Nazi military dispatches declared today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- In a move to avert the nation-wide railroad strike set to start Dec. 7, President Roosevelt has called his Emergency Fact-Finding Board of five men.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest your editorial "More Teachers Needed." It is quite true that in the expected "teaching boom" there is an obligation upon educational leaders to make certain that the influx of new teachers will not mean a decline in the present professional standards of competence and ability.
MONTREAL. Nov. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Familiar names are once again at the top of the list of scorers in the National Hockey League.

The Priorities Division of the Office of Production Management has so streamlined its system that applications for priorities are now clearing much more rapidly and complaints over the operation of the priorities system are getting answers more quickly, according to L. Edward Scriven, director of the Priorities Field Service.

There will come before the Senate Subcommittee on Finance tomorrow two dangerous bills intended to fasten upon the country a system of pensions to World War veterans and their dependents that would ultimately cost from $10,000,000,000 to $15,000,000,000.

Much had been anticipated of the concert that Sir Thomas Beecham gave last night in Carnegie Hall with the Philadelphia Orchestra. The brilliant concerts he had directed here in earlier seasons with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony were well remembered.

Conradin Otto Dold, a defendant in the Brooklyn espionage trial, readily admitted on the witness stand yesterday that he had carried "packages" abroad for influential clients while he was serving as chief steward aboard vessels of the American Export Line.

Declaring that no amount of negotiating between the United States and Japan could succeed because Japan's word and her Emperor's signature to an agreement were worth no more than Hitler's, Lin Yutang, Chinese novelist, said yesterday that this country must fight Japan as the only means of carrying out President Roosevelt's declared aims to defeat Hitler.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- New suggestions are under consideration for another conversation soon between Secretary of State Cordell Hull and the Japanese envoys, Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura and Saburo Kurusu, according to indications today.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- Between this town and the invisible line that marks the boundary of the Bear Mountain Park lie several wooded ridges that the natives call mountains, and after tramping over some of these ridges in search of deer we are almost willing to admit that the local definition is a true one.

As Minnesota, its season completed, perches with some confidence at the top of the list of the nation's college football teams as determined by The Associated Press poll, the No. 2 team selected by the 115 experts faces a future shadowed with doubt.

Procter Gamble The Procter Gamble Company voted a cash bonus equal to 4 per cent of the net annual wages or salaries of all regular employes who were in its employ prior to July 1, 1941, and whose wages or salaries do not exceed $3,000 a year.

ROME, Nov. 25 -- The Italian and German forces were still holding their own last evening at the same key points, in the Libyan battle where fighting has been going on for six days, it was announced in today's Italian war bulletin.

If the vanity publishing business is to be tolerated, it will have to do business legally, Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind declared yesterday as he ruled that a jury must decide whether Carlo M. Flumiani and his Fortuny's Publishers, Inc., had committed mail fraud.

A furnished apartment in 570 Park Avenue has been leased by Mrs. Ulysses S. Grant 3d, wife of Brig. Gen. Grant of the United States Army, from Mrs. James Mabon in a transaction negotiated by Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The resignation of Judge J. Warren Davis, retired member of the Third Circuit Court of Appeals, was accepted today by President Roosevelt, effective immediately.

A supper party with dancing and various other divertissements was given last night in the Viennese Roof and Penthouse Suite of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Lisa Day Nursery. The entertainment took the form of a tombola and drew a large attendance of members of society.

Controller Joseph V. O'Leary sold yesterday in competitive bidding various blocks of New York State municipal bonds, aggregating $1,818,000, in the portfolio of the State Sinking Fund. Proceeds from the sale will be applied to paying the State's canal debt No. 6, due on Jan. 1, amounting to $5,100,000.
Next time a stern parent places spinach in front of him with the demand: "Eat it!" the unwilling but wise child, after throwing the dish on the floor, can advise his progenitor to go study nutrition.

Stocks skimmed perilously close yesterday to the lows set last week as the market developed fresh sagging tendencies. The confusion surrounding the labor situation again acted as a brake on even the mildest buying effort, but it was evident there was no real pressure on the share list and prices wore away more from the lack of bids than outright liquidation.

Effective Jan. 1, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the world's second largest life insurance company, will change its reserve basis from 3 1/4 to 2 1/2 per cent and, in so doing, make an overall increase of about 8 per cent in premiums on new ordinary life insurance policies.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 4,336,850 barrels daily, a new record and 250,000 more than the 4,086,850 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 268,850 barrels more than the calculation of 4,070,000 daily by the Bureau of Mines for November.

This Curly "World" For the very reason that there were three of them it was easier in school to memorize the Guianas than any other section of the map of South America. Count them, all three, British, Dutch, French Guiana.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, FOURTH ARMY CORPS, Somewhere in the Carolinas, Nov. 25 -- A thin film of ice edged the still ponds in this Carolina pine country at dawn this morning as 295,000 troops of the First Army and the Fourth Army Corps started the second phase of the last great Army manoeuvres of 1941.

Holding over-all price and wage control is "too drastic" and that the country is unprepared for it at the present time, Donald M. Nelson, executive director of the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board, yesterday gave his support to the selective price control measure now before Congress.

Proposed amendments to the Federal labol laws designed to remedy the emergency strike situation and to insure a "more orderly procedure in peace times" were made public in an interim report yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- Mr. and Mrs. Morris H. Bannister of this city have announced the engagment of their daughter, Miss Bffie Hennen Bannister, to Charles Deane Evans, son of Professor Austin P. Evans of the History Department of Columbia University and Mrs. Evans of Montrose, N. Y.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 25 -- Capital importance is attached by competent neutral observers here to the operations in Cyrenaica. They do not hold with those who view the operations as a diversion or as a concession to Premier Joseph Stalin's appeal for "a second front."
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 26 Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast the following communique early today:

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and privates elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney yesterday renewed his demand for a meeting of the Tammany executive committee to oust Christopher D. Sullivan as leader of Tammany, if Mr. Sullivan does not resign, and to elect a new leader, not necessarily a member of the executive committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The United States, according to a defense official, has already outstripped Great Britain in the race of tank production. Moreover, military sources said, at least half of the tanks which roll off American assembly lines are being rushed to far-flung battle lines, under the lease-lend program, for service against the Axis.
BERLIN, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Text of the German regular communique today said:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Contracts totaling $6,430,111 were awarded by the War Department today. Awards to companies in New York were:

The Grand Mass in C minor by Mozart was the work performed, and repeated after its impressive New York premiere two seasons ago, by the Schola Cantorum, Hugh Ross conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. The Mass eminently deserves such repetition, as Mr. Ross and his forces deserve particular credit for having made it known in this city.

The city of Dallas, Texas, received bids yesterday for an issue of $893,000 of various purpose bonds, all of which will be dated Dec. 1, 1941, but officials announced that no award of the bonds will be made until tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Attorney General Biddle said today that he planned no investigation of "lobby contracts," suggested in several quarters following allegations and disclosures of large fees for obtaining contracts for national defense work.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Secretary Knox denied today that he had profited personally by the publication of articles signed by himself in several national magazines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox today verified reports originating in New York that two of the Reuben James own depth bombs exploded as the destroyer sank after being torpedoed by a German submarine, and while members of her crew were floundering in the water.

Recently authorized changes in the Neutrality Act and widening of the defense effort are having their effects upon the rental situation in downtown Manhattan, according to Sylvan L. Hanauer, secretary of the General Realty and Utilities Corporation, which controls a number of large buildings there.

BENDIX, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Frederic G. Coburn of New York City, chairman of the board of directors of the McLellan Stores Company and long a member of the industrial engineering firm of Sanderson Porter, has been elected president of Air Associates, Inc., to succeed F. Leroy Hill, who was forced to resign last week by the War Department's demand for a change in management before the plant would be restored to its owners.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- In the first action of the kind since President Roosevelt issued his executive order last Saturday authorizing defense agencies to requisition supplies whenever it is considered necessary, the Office of Export Control will move within the next few days to take over $65,000 to $100,000 worth of tin plate now in storage in New York warehouses, it was learned here tonight.

That great, big, happy family, the Packers of Green Bay, went through a brisk two-hour practice session at Travers Island yesterday as they speeded up work for Sunday's important conflict against the Redskins in Washington. Defense was the keynote of the session as the pachyderms who walk like men sought ways to stop the passes of Slingin' Sammy Baugh.

Business as Usual Although the Thanksgiving Day holiday will be observed today in sixteen States, with banks in these States remaining closed, all the important securities and commodity markets are in the thirty-two States that celebrated Thanksgiving one week ago.

The 140 metropolitan districts, outlined in the recent census, should be regarded by marketing men as concentrations of populations only and not as markets, Frank Coutant, vice president of Fact Finders, Inc., declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Commodore.

In a move without local precedent, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman condemned yesterday the soon-forthcoming Greta Garbo motion picture, "Two-Faced Woman." In a pastoral letter to be read at all masses in the' Archdiocese of New York next Sunday he warned faithful Catholics that the film is a danger to public morality and that witnessing it may be an occasion of sin.

Allocation of defense contracts to small business men in New York City was discussed at City Hall yesterday in a two-hour conference between Mayor La Guardia and fifty members of his business advisory committee.

The taxicab industry in New York City decided yesterday on an increased rate that would cost cab users 15 to 20 per cent more a ride. The City Council must amend rates fixed by the Haas bill in 1937 before the increase can be effective.

With liquidation in the near months apparently exhausted, the cotton market displayed yesterday a firm undertone in quiet dealings. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures closed with net gains of 2 to 17 points, with the December contract showing the most strength.

If Herr von Ribbentrop's speech can be regarded as a clue, the main purpose of the anti-Comintern meeting in Berlin was to provide a platform for a harangue addressed to the United States. The Nazi Foreign Minister's words were not directed to the immediate audience.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Facts about the world-wide Nazi organization trained for propaganda and espionage throughout the world were told by Attorney General Biddle today in advocating amendments pending in Congress to transfer enforcement of the Foreign Agents Registration Act from the State Department to the Department of Justice.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- Earl (Red)Blaik is an old hand at getting Army ready to play Navy a game of football and, while Major Swede Larson has never lost to che cadets, Blaik has never prepared a West Point eleven that failed to win from the midshipmen.

President Roosevelt on July 30 sent a special message to Congress warning that "we face inflation unless we act decisively and without delay." Two days later the Administration submitted its bill to control prices and on Aug. 5 the House Banking and Currency Committee began hearings.

Although Columbia football will see better days than it has in the 1941 season, it will never see a group of football players of which it can be more proud than the present squad, Coach Lou Little, Lion mentor, told 300 alumni, faculty and students gathered last night at the second annual Columbia Football Tribute Dinner held in John Jay Hall.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

With a patriotic motif combining national defense projects, and British-American unity and war relief, a gala Navy Ball was given last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, under the joint auspices of Bundles for Britain and the Navy League of the United States.

WASHINGTON. Nov. 26 -- Official circles considered it a foregone conclusion today that a substitute would be advanced for the Treasury's proposal of a 15 per cent income tax, withheld at the source. Higher taxation of individual incomes will be sugar coated, they said, by a plan or taking some of the individual income revenue in the form of compulsory savings, and that this will be supplemented by higher corporation taxation.

Punching sharply and stepping through his boxing workout at a lively gait, Tony Zale, Gary, Ind., middleweight, who is the National Boxing Association's champion, yesterday concluded training at Stillman'a Gymnasium for the fifteen-round battle tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden in which he will oppose Georgie Abrams, U.S. Navy, for undisputed possession of the 160-pound title.

Wholesalers Seek Dry Goods Although wholesalers already have booked the bulk of their holiday business and are going into a period which normally would be devoted to liquidation of inventory, many of them are in the market for various dry goods lines, selling agents said yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 26 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho is said to have no illusion that the Washington agreements did much to settle the oil question. Some of his friends express the hope that before the end of the five-month period for the new valuation of the properties the Mexican Government and the oil companies may settle the issue between themselves.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 25 (Delayed) -- The second wartime revenue-raising measure since the outbreak of hostilities has just been instituted by the Central Executive Committee of the Soviet Union. It is a tax on unmarried or childless persons, graded according to salary between 3 1/3 per cent and 5 per cent of earnings and retroactive to last Oct. 1.

Testimony which, counsel said was designed to prove there has been no agreement, conspiracy or combination to fix prices by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association and sixteen respondent power cable companies was barred yesterday by Webster Ballinger, trial examiner, at the hearing conducted by the Federal Trade Commission at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

BY this time a good many suburban householders, their garden rakes and lawnmowers stowed away for the season, must have read with astonishment a book by Frank E. Lutz called "A Lot of Insects."* More of them yet ought to read it, for it is as amusing as it is astonishing and a guide to a thousand Bergen, Morris, Rockland and Westchester County back yards.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 26 -- Racing over a track that was drying out after freezing for the second night in a row, G.R. Watkins's Clyde Tolson nosed out Victor Emnnuel's favored Omission today in the six-furlong W.P. Burch Memorial Handicap, last sprint stake of the Eastern season.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 25 (delayed) -- Effectively employing his armies, Marshal Semyon Timoshenko is gravely endangering Col. Gen. Paul Ludwig von Kleist's entire Axis force around Rostov by a so far strikingly successful fullscale counter-offensive across the flat Donets steppes.

John B. Flint. an executive of the F.W. Woolworth Company, has purchased from Everett V. Scott his colonial residence in the Flower Hill section of Manhasset, L.I., in a transaction arranged by Edgar Storms, Inc., broker. Completed about three years ago, the house contains eight rooms and three baths.

The police discovered yesterday something as rare as the philosopher's stone -- a system for "beating the horses" that worked. The only drawback was that the system was illegal and so they arrested Ralph E. Layman, 53 years old, said to be the originator of the scheme, and charged him with forgery.

ALBANY, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A shortage of sea-going vessels in coastwise trade because of the national emergency caused a net tonnage loss of about 272,000 tons on New York's 800-mile barge canal system this season, now near an end.

Sophie Treadwell has an idea that Americans should work. This unusual notion is the theme of her newest play, "Hope for a Harvest," which Mr. and Mrs. Fredric March helped to act at the Guild Theatre last evening. Instead of praising democracy, Miss Treadwell suggests that Americans ought to work at it the hard way, and that the sickness of the body politic is not the system but the lethargy of the people.
Somewhere in New York is a 25-year-old gunman with a Western drawl, a hold-up technique of his own and a penchant for robbing small midtown loan, companies.

It was a heavily nineteenth century evening at the Forty-fourtn Street Theatre last night when the Ballet Theatre presented the season's first "Giselle," with Alicia Markova in the title role, and the premiere of its new arrangement of excerpts from "The Sleeping Beauty" under the title of "Princess Aurora," with Irina Baronova as Aurora.

The U.S.S. Kitty Hawk, new type aircraft auxiliary vessel, was placed in commission at the Navy Yard, Brooklyn, late yesterday afternoon. The commissioning ceremony took place on the upper deck of the vessel in the presence of the fifteen officers and 200 members of the crew.

Oscar Serlin, producer of Ferenc Molnar's new play, "The King's Maid," suddenly decided yesterday to withdraw the production for extensive revisions at the conclusion of its current tryout at the Maryland Theatre, Baltimore, on Saturday.

Electric power output declined further last week. Since the decrease was contraseasonal, the adjusted index fell to 119.4 from 121.8 for the week ended Nov. 15. It stood at 109.5 for the week ended Nov. 23, 1940.

Gregor Piatigorsky's 'cello playing at his recital in Town Hall last night in the hall's Endowment Series exploited the color possibilities of the instrument to an extraordinary degree in a round of performances notable as well for technical perfection and interpretive skill.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 26 -- Free French reaction to the Washington decision to grant lease-lend aid to General Charles de Gaulle's forces Is marked by satisfaction. At the same time, had a further step been taken and General de Gaulle's National Committee officially recognized de facto there would have been jubilation.

Alcohol in the News Echoes out of an almost forgotten world come back. The problem of alcohol and industrial efficiency is once more in the news. The problem of Sunday beer was in the news the other day.

Net assets of Dividend Shares, Inc., on Oct. 31, the close of the fiscal year, were $35,423,532, according to a report signed by Calvin Bullock, president. This worked out at almost exactly $I for each of the shares outstanding, against 98 cents at the end of April.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The German Army plans to raze Belgrade, Yugoslav capital, in an attempt to smash the guerrilla campaign against Nazi occupation of the country, the White House said today it had been informed.

After refusing for many months to take obviously imperative action, Administration and Congressional forces are now planning to rush through "anti-strike" legislation at a speed that does not promise well for mature consideration. It would be altogether deplorable if a task so long neglected were now badly and lopsidedly done.

An investing client of Peter J. Braschoss Jr. has purchased through the Herman A. Acker Corporation from the Adams Operating Company the five-story apartment house at 2467 Valentine Avenue, near Fordham Road, the Bronx, paying cash above a first mortgage of $39,000.

If the Metropolitan Opera cannot attract the public to Gluck's "Orfeo" this time it might well be forgiven for not trying again in seasons to come. In the restudied version presented at the Opera House last night the Metropolitan has done much to give full stature to a noble work.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- Cap'n Joe O'Brien, pilot and master of the brick-red Wyoming, bore down hard on the old oaken wheel as the side-wheeler put out of Tarrytown at noon today for Nyack, three and one-quarter miles across Tappan Zee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, has discussed with President Roosevelt and State Department officials preparations for immediate requisitioning and putting into war service all eleven French merchant ships in American ports if closer collaboration between Vichy and Berlin makes the services of the French fleet available to Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Proposals looking to readjustment of relations between Japan and the United States were handed by Secretary of State Cordell Hull late today to Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, the Japanese Ambassador, and Saburo Kurusu, the special Japanese envoy.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, Outside Tobruk, Nov. 22 (Delayed) -- The British commanders have wisely refrained from predicting a victory until they have it actually in hand, but a tour of the fighting line at the hardest pressed points today and a study of the hourly changing map make it appear that the German armored units are facing a terrific battle.

Ernest Lapointe, outstanding spokesman for the French-speaking population of Canada, has been referred to as an "institution," because of his enduring popularity in the Dominion. As evidence of the esteem in which he was held, his friends cited his record as a member of the House of Commons.

Although the minor league convention is not slated to get under way until next Wednesday in Jacksonville, neither the world-champion Yankees nor the National League champion Dodgers intend to lose any time getting down on the scene of the Winter's first baseball confabs.
Half of twins was a wreck. He looked as if he had Just been in a fight. His hair was mussed. His collar streamed open and the cuffs of his trousers were turned down.

An immediate reduction of $2,000,000,000 in Federal non-defense spending is recommended in a report of the National Association of Manufacturers' government finance committee made public yesterday. The report will serve as the base for a major plank in the 1942 platform of the Congress of American Industry that meets here next week, according to Charles E. Wilson, chairman of the association's resolutions committee.

The Maryland Drydock Company filed late yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was announced, a registration statement covering the proposed offering of 112,740 shares of $1-par value common stock. Arrangements whereby Shields Co. purchased control of Maryland Drydock from the Koppers Company were announced earlier this month.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The British Middle East Command announced in Cairo today that strong British tank reinforcements had arrived at forward areas in Libya "where our armored formations are rapidly reorganizing, after five days of continuous fighting, to resume their part in the main operation around Rezegh."

Reports for October issued by the railroads yesterday showed that an increasing number of companies are allowing in current statements for the wage increases for September and October awarded by the President's Fact-Finding-Board.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A statement that "wars have always brought new responsibilities to women" and that "they have never failed" was made today by Lucille Foster McMillin, Federal Civil Service Commissioner, in a study of women's participation in defense activities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A suggestion that plans are afoot to have Air Corps pilots deliver combat airplanes across the oceans to combatant areas was given today in a review of the work of the Air Corps Ferrying Command.

A property that had been held without change of ownership for almost a century passed to new hands yesterday when Geoorge P. Gill and Julia Somarendyck Gill of San Antonio, Texas, sold the three-and-one-half-story building at 135 Bowery to a client of Hiram Rinaldo, broker in the deal.

IT was no shock to good old John Lobert when he was sentenced to manage the Phillies. He could see it coming and he didn't flinch. Man and boy, John has been around organized baseball for nigh onto forty years. Long ago he managed a club In Bridgeport. Handling the Phillies is not much different.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 26 -- Tecumseh, the Navy's "God of 2.5," wore war paint today as the middle football teams ran through their last hard practice before leaving for Philadelphia to meet Army in the Municipal Stadium Saturday.

The advertised "cricket on the hearth" (Gryllus domesticus) chirped greetings to visitors to the New York Book Fair that opened yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History, but not so loudly, perhaps, as some had expected.
Mrs. Leopold K. Simon, active in civic and political affairs for many years, has been named head of volunteer group activities In the Second Civilian Defense Region.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Your editorial "Guarding the Hemisphere" and other evidence of public and governmental opinion indicate that there is grave danger this country may ultimately face defeat as a result of a purely defensive psychology. If the present war has reinforced any military lesson, it is that wars are not won by defensive actions but only by seizing the initiative in military operations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Not often in the recent history of Congress has a piece of necessary legislation been obliged to run the gauntlet of so many enemies as the price-control proposals now pending in the House. If anything survives except a useless set of mild permissions, some leadership not yet developed must appear.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Nov. 26 (UP) -- Dr. Arthur F. Torrance, 54, scientist and explorer, charged with murdering his 65-year-old wife, the former Mrs. Ada Loveland, was described by his stepson today as a "promiscuous Lothario."

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company plans to become active again in the field of radio, particularly in the development of new uses for radio equipment for national defense, it was announced yesterday by A.W. Robertson, chairman of the board of directors.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The House rejected today by a teller vote of 218 to 63, with party lines obliterated, the Gore plan for "over-all" control of rents, price and wages during the emergency.
KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 25 (Delayed) -- Finland's adherence to the Anti-Comintern Pact obviously ends any lingering hope of an early separate peace between the Soviet Union and its Baltic neighbor.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- "Extensive" German gains have rolled the Red Army back onto Moscow's inner defense lines about twenty-five miles from the capital, the Nazis claimed tonight. But again they gave no place names.

Lady Halifax, wife of the British Ambassador to the United States, opened Ye Olde English Faire, the twenty-first annual bazaar sponsored by the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York, at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday afternoon.
MOSCOW (Distributed by The Associated Press), Nov. 26 -- The Moscow radio today broadcast the following communique of the Soviet Information Bureau:

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin) -- Nov. 26 -- After a lower opening on profit-taking, buying was renewed on the dip and the close showed some gains of 4 points. Royal Dutch was a fraction lower at 348 7/8 guilders after selling at 345 3/4 A.K.U. and Unilever were very active, the former rising 2 1/4 points to 154 guilders and the latter 4 5/8 points to 169 7/8 guilders.

The grim German threat to raze what is left of Belgrade to its foundations, reported in a statement from the White House, is a measure of the success of the Serbian patriot army against a foe which assumed too soon he had conquered. The Nazis are quite capable of carrying out such a reprisal against a helpless civilian population.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Associate Justice Jackson of the Supreme Court, appearing before a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee today, said that while he was Attorney General several judges should have been removed from office for misbehavior," but that he refrained from suggesting such action to the President for fear of political implications.

ISLAND PARK, L.I., Nov. 26 -- Announcement that plans were being considered for the erection of an $8,000,000 shipyard on Wreck Lead Island had residents of this village excited today as opposition to an application for rezoning the island for industrial purposes melted away.

The trustees of the National Gallery of Art in Washington have announced the acceptance of a gift of the portrait of the Spanish artist, Don Bartolome Sureda, by Francisco Goya. The painting has been presented by Mr. and Mrs. P. H.B. Frelinghuysen of Morristown, N.J., in memory of Mrs. Frelinghuysen's parents, Mr. and Mrs. H. O. Havemeyer.

At one of its stormiest sessions in recent months, the Board of Education ignored the objections of Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, only woman member, and affirmed yesterday its decision to reopen the New York City schools on Friday, Jan. 2, thus shortening the Christmas holiday by three days.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 -- A spokesman for the United Welders, Cutters and Helpers of America, an independent union, announced tonight that day and night shifts at local shipyards had voted unanimously "to support a strike if it becomes necessary."

District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Kings County revealed yesterday at a police departmental trial in Brooklyn Police Headquarters that the New York police broke up last March a plot to have three Western gunmen assassinate Abe Reles and three other informers who were being held as witnesses for a series of pending murder trials.

Following the Indictment of three Negro boys for murder the previous day, three more young Negroes were indicted for murder yesterday. The six prisoners were accused of the two killings early this month that brought about the present investigation of crime conditions and extra policing in lower Harlem, north Central Park, and adjacent streets and parks.
New York State and Rhode Island will soon have an official boundary for the first time.

HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 26 -- Twentieth Century-Fox signed Frank Capra today to an exclusive three-year contract as a producer-director under which his first picture is expected to be "The Flying Yorkshireman," a fantasy by Eric Knight, which Capra bought last May from Frank Lloyd for $44,000.

Miss N. May Karff of Boston, challenger, defeated Mrs. Donald Belcher of this city, woman chess champion of the United States, for the third time in succession at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday when they played to a conclusion the third game of the series, which was begun in Brooklyn last Sunday and adjourned after sixty-four moves.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Commodity Exchange Administration declared today that "excessive speculation" this season showed a need for greater government control of futures trading in soy beans.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : There must have been thousands who joined this writer in feeling that THE NEW YORK TIMES's announcement of its inauguration of newscasts, beginning Dec. 1, gives assurance of an unusually comprehensive and objective service of news dissemination by radio.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Sergeant Deimar Park of Phoenix, Ariz., a United States Army observer with the British tank forces in the Libyan desert campaign, was caught in a surprise thrust of German tanks yesterday and killed.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- The Phillies got a new manager today.

HONG KONG, Nov. 26 -- If it were not for the fact that President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull believed it was still possible to prevent a shooting war in the Pacific, with the prospect of a Sino-Japanese peace, the Washington talks with Saburo Kurusu and Ambassador Nomura would have been temporarily cut off last week.

Regardless of action by any employer groups in the dress industry, the union will stand on the terms of the collective agreement calling for the collection of onethird of 1 per cent on sales to promote the New York market, Julius Hochman, general manager of the Joint Board of the Dress and Waistmakers Union, declared yesterday.

The National Football League's record book, which already has undergone more changes this season than, ever before, is liable to further riddling before the curtain falls on the current campaign. Four players, three of them from Green Bay and the other of the Chicago Bears, are in positions to erase present standards, statistics released yesterday show.

With messages from President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia extolling the work of Palestine resettlement and refugee relief, the eighth annual "Night of Stars" was presented last night in Madison Square Garden before an audience of more than 20,000 persons.
