WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Nov. 25:

Asserting that good management was the most important device with which to fight inflation, Dr. John H. Williams, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, declared yesterday that he was opposed to an increase In taxes on low incomes now to head off inflation Because he believed that mass consumption did not yet constitute a danger to the country's resources.

Women's fraternity problems and the war work being done by fraternity women were the major subjects discussed at the opening sessions of the National Panhellenic Congress which began its twentyseventh biennial convention yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore.
VICHY, France, Nov. 26 -- Marshal Henri Phillppe Petain had a well-filled program today, but it had little to do with politics.

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, made public yesterday a statement signed by thirty Episcopal bishops, clergy and laymen, declaring that the type of isolationism which denies the concept of the family of nations "must be judged to be contrary to the Christian gospel."

Two hundred and fifty leading figures of the literary world met yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria to honor Ernest Hemingway for his winning the third gold medal offered by the Limited Editions Club for the book published in the three previous years that is most likely to become a classic.

First-run film fare in midtown theatres remains unchanged today as three of the major houses retain their current attractions for second weeks. The pictures are "Suspicion," at the Radio City Music Hall; "Shadow of the Thin Man," at the Capitol; and "They Died With Their Boots On," at the Strand.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in formal statements and personal appeals to President Roosevelt today voiced opposition to threatened bans on work stoppages in defense industries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Erie Railroad Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for approval of a $14,000,000 twelve-year loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation that will enable it to carry out a plan of reorganization approved by the commission and the courts.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. John Langdon Batchelder of Boston and Mr. and Mrs. Stirling Shattuck Adams of this city will give a dinner on Dec. 23 in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis to Introduce to society Miss Marian Hodges, granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Batchelder and sister of Mrs. Adams.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The House Judiciary Committee decided in an extraordinary meeting tonight to recommend legislation of its own to control defense strikes unless the Labor Committee approved a bill "with enough teeth in it."

Reports of growing economic cooperation, closer banking relations and increased reciprocal trade between the nations of the Western Hemisphere were heard yesterday from leaders in the field at a Pan-American luncheon program of the Kiwanis Club in the Hotel McAlpin.
COLLEGE STATION, Texas, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Texas A. and M. faces its greatest test along the gridiron trail tomorrow -- a rival that lives for victory in one game a year.

Establishment of a central clearing house for teachers, to provide information for those unemployed in New York City and elsewhere who are available for teaching posts, was recommended yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Powerful German forces have achieved a new break-through southeast of Moscow and have turned north in the opening phases of a developing battle of encirclement, official Soviet advices acknowledged tonight.

S. Sloan Colt, general chairman of the current membership campaign of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, announced yesterday a 64 per cent increase in individual memberships and an 80 per cent gain in funds raised as compared with the same day's total in last year's drive.

The special board of arbitration appointed by the President to settle the issue in the captive coal mines consists in effect of one man -- John R. Steelman. Each of the other two members, Mr. Lewis and Mr. Fairless, is a direct participant in the dispute. Mr. Lewis's decision is certainly known in advance: it will be for the closed shop.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Office of Production Management has found it necessary amid its other manifold duties to tell power companies in the Southeast that if Army generals during the current manoeuvres ask for a release of reserve water so that they can throw pontoon bridges across dried up streams, the matter must be referred to Washington.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 26 (AP) -- If the Army doesn't stake a prior claim on Pitcher Bob Feller, the Indians will finish in the first division next season.

An explosion, caused apparently by illuminating gas flowing from five open jets of a kitchen range, wrecked a ground-floor apartment at 333 West Twenty-sixth Street at 6:50 o'clock last night, killing the occupant, Thomas Quinn, 31 years old, a commercial artist, and injuring two persons in a tenement next door.

With only one more match to be played in the Westchester women's interclub Class C squash racquets tournament, the contest for first place is very close between the Ardsley and Apawamis Clubs. While Ardsley was taking the measure of the Field Club of Greenwich, 4-1, yesterday, its closest rival was losing to Sleepy Hollow, 4-1.

In October on an up-State farm the keepers of the bees pour the thick, sticky buckwheat honey into glistening glass jars. These are set side by side in prim rows on the cool shelves of long sheds, and quietly left to themselves for a good couple of weeks.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, addressing an anti-Hitler rally at New York University in her role as assistant director of the Office of Civilian Defense, yesterday warned against the danger of a peace with Hitler and told 450 college men and women that they "must not leave the action and planning entirely to the government and older people of the community."
East Side buildings continue to draw a good share of the new residential rentals, with many of the lessees going into Park Avenue structures.

The zest with which the Gourmet Society's annual dinner was stowed away last night at the Hotel Lafayette might have been attributed to the food connoisseurs' fear that they might not enjoy another such meal for a long time.
ROME, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique today said:

BEZENCHUK, Russia, Nov. 24 (Delayed) -- On the farm as in the factory the women of mobilized Russia are now doing an important share of the work and collectivized agriculture would appear to have made an adjustment to wartime conditions with marked adaptibility.

Adopting a "sticks and stones may break my bones, but names will never hurt me" attitude, Dr. Marvin (Mal) Steven, N.Y.U. coach, yesterday devoted himself exclusively to football as he went or with his preparations, for the game with Fordham at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- Two American observers as well as an unspecified number of war correspondents were captured by the Axis forces near Rezegh in Libya yesterday during the encirclement and annihilation of the British forces in that area, it was stated in today's Italian war bulletin.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : On Nov. 19 you published a report of the attach made by Chairman Martin Dies on my appointment as Chief Analyst of the Foreign Broadcast Monitoring Service. Two lines of evidence for my alleged communism were offered in the Dies letter.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Producers managed to cut down shipments of salable hogs into the livestock market today, but buyers were unable to see any return of strength in dressed quotations which would justify higher prices for live swine. General trade was steady to 10 cents a hundredweight lower with the top price declining to $10.05.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- In a sixtyfive-minute luncheon speech to the delegates of the Anti-Comintern Conference, Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop delivered today a scathing denunciation of "war-monger number one," President Roosevelt, and of British Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

A gruesome parody on a Brooklyn Dodgers baseball broadcast was offered to a Brooklyn blueribbon jury yesterday as part of a five-hour appeal by counsel defending Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, former ruler of the city's $1,000,000 industrial rackets, on charges of first-degree murder.

Warehousemen joined with foreign traders generally in expressing indignation yesterday over the disclosure of the memorandum by a government official setting forth a proposed extension of lease-lend practices which the traders have currently been protesting.

Two more top-ranking tennis players deserted the amateur game to become professionals yesterday. Bobby Riggs, national singles champion, and Frank Kovacs, holder of the indoor title, have signed contracts to appear in a series of eighty matches throughout the United States and Canada.

KENOSHA, Wis., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Protesting against the dismissal of six fellow workers and demanding removal of Le Roy Wolfe, the City Manager, municipal employes of Kenosha went on strike today, halting operations of all services save the water, sewage treatment, police and fire departments.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 27 (U.P.) -- Japanese quarters believed today that it was now up to the United States to advance concrete proposals in the Washington negotiations for a Pacific settlement, success or failure of which was expected to become apparent within the next few days.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS OF THE FOURTH ARMY CORPS, Somewhere in the Carolinas, Nov. 26 -- Two tactical units, new to the Army, participated today, the second day of the final phase of the Army manoeuvres, in the Red Fourth Army Corps aggressive defense against the numerically superior Blue First Army.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Finnish High Command issued this communique today:

Proving her interest in nutrition, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt participated yesterday in a ceremony held in observance of Nutrition Fortnight within the walls of her Own town house, 49 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Willard K. Rice of the Harvard Club scored an upset In the metropolitan Class A squash tennia interclub matches last night when he downed the national amateur titleholder, Joseph J. Lordi of the New York A.C.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The War Department revealed today that it had advanced $500,000 in capital funds to Air Associates, Inc., at Bendix, N.J., to enable the company to fulfill its defense contracts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Senate Defense Investigating Committee heard testimony today of alleged waste and extravagance in building the Wolf Creek shellloading plant at Milan, Tenn., which Chairman Truman termed "shocking" and Senator Mead said was "a sordid story."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Naval enlistments have dropped 15 per cent since the sinking of the destroyer Reuben James and the torpedoing of the Kearny, Secretary Knox revealed today. He added that as a consequence selective service men might be used by the Navy. The practice has been to depend upon volunteers for the Navy.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- Isaac Brown, New York insurance broker and husband of a State welfare worker, was placed on trial today in Westchester County court on charges of attempting to murder Miss Matilda Le Boyer, 17 years old, student and poet, to conceal from the world his alleged friendship with her.

Following up their recent decision to protect themselves against sudden loss of goods through government commandeering of stocks at the source, food wholesalers yesterday submitted a proposed new liability clause to canners. The National-American Wholesale Grocers Association here sponsors of the new "war clause," recently rejected a proposed revision of the present canned goods contract form submitted by the Canners League of California as being "entirely too broad."

The first American merchant vessel to be armed for service in the Atlantic under the recent revision of the Neutrality Law was outfitted with a deck gun and emplacements for three anti-aircraft guns yesterday at the Tietjen Lang Drydock at the foot of Seventeenth Street, Hoboken, N.J.

After approaching repeatedly in the last two weeks the lowest prices since the outbreak of tha war, the stock market finally broke through that resistance level yesterday and losses swept over, more than half of the active issues The decline was not great, how ever, since only an extra point on so were needed to establish a new depth.

One of the most critical trials of the hockey season lies just ahead for the Americans. Red Dutton's Brooklynites, in sixth position in the National Hockey League standing, face the task of battling two of the most powerful teams in the league in three games over a period of four days.

Ending a three-month tour that took her to twenty-two American and ten Canadian cities to explain the aims and functions of the various relief organizations operating in the United ngdom, Lady Louis Mountbatten, wife of Lord Louis Mountbatten, a captain in the royal navy, left for Lisbon yesterday morning on the Yankee Clipper.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell has been appointed assistant chief of staff in charge of the general staff's supply division. He has been on duty as assistant quartermaster general in charge of construction.

OAKDALE, L.I., Nov. 26 -- La Salle Military Academy bowed to the Manhattan freshmen, 19-7, in its final football game of the season today. The cadets tallied in the final period on a ten-yard pass from Al Munter to Captain Dan Logue after yielding three touch-downs to the heavier collegians.

Alfred A. Knopf announced yesterday that his firm had revised the rules for the recently announced competition for a firsthand story by an American aviator. Whereas the original requirements were that the competing writers should be actively engaged in either commercial, military or naval flying, the base of the contests has now been broadened, so that any American citizen who holds any kind of a pilot's license is eligible.

With the international tournament postponed for the "duration," officials of the Atlantic Tuna Tournament Conference are considering the idea of sponsoring a heavy-tackle tuna derby in Nova Scotia during the 1942 season, the event to precede the regular coastal tournament, held each year.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 26 -- Bernard M. Kellmurray, a graduate student at Yale; has had his sight restored, without scientific explanation, after five years of blindness. He has taken the special harness off his Seeing Eye dog and has him now as a companion instead of guide, much to the animal's puzzlement.

Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox gave his unequivocal endorsement yesterday to a statement that labor leaders Who put "petty personal benefits above the security of their country" should be treated as traitors and that workers whom they urged to strike should "ride them out of town on a rail as if they were wearing swastikas on their sleeves."

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Liquidation in December wheat futures was under way again today and while cash interests took the December and sold the May, there was sufficient selling of the near-by delivery to give the market a heavy undertone from the start.

The official canvass of election returns by the Board of Elections, completed yesterday, showed that Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, candidate of the Republican, American Labor, City Fusion and United City parties, defeated Lloyd Church, his Democratic opponent, by a plurality of 149,571, and that Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, Republican, Labor, City Fusion and United City candidate, led M. Maldwin Fertig, Democrat, by 124,018.

RIVER VALE, N.J., Nov. 26 (AP) -- The New York Rovers tallied their sixth straight Eastern Amateur League Hockey victory tonight by scoring twice in the final two minutes of play to defeat the Jersey Skeeters, 5 to 3.

The cavalry isn't what it used to be. It used to ride horses, which looked pretty on parade, however grim their appearance when they were being curried up for stable inspection. In a close decision the cavalrymen always got the girl, while the infantry went wistfully off, muttering, "Who ever saw a dead cavalryman?" Cavalry regiments had glittering histories.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- Applying to the Battle of the Libyan Desert its usual tactics of extreme reticence in regard to operations still in progress, the German High Command merely stated in today's communique that the North African counter-attacks of the German and Italian troops were continuing successfully.

With court approval, the trustees of Series B-K mortgage certificate issue have sold to Isidore Brown the twenty-seven-family apartment house at 81-91 Bay Twenty-second Street, Brooklyn, for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $61,000.
A drive for $300,000 with which to purchase and ship to the British seeds for backyard gardens was launched yesterday by the British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue.

The three largest and most luxurious liners of the United States Merchant Marine, the America, Manhattan and Washington, may be purchased outright by the Navy for permanent employment as auxiliaries, it was reported here yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW TORK TIMES: I would not annoy you and your readers if J.A. Goris, Commissioner of Information for Belgium, had not quoted me (THE NEW YORK TIMES, Nov. 22) as having "been misinformed," and furthermore, as insulting "the well-known hospitality of Belgium.

Seven basic principles on which successful, result-getting advertising is founding were outlined last night by Richard Manville of Newell-Emmett Company, Inc., in an address before the Association of Advertising Men at the Phi Gamma Delta Club. The principles are based on a six-year study of millions of dollars worth of keyed advertisements and are applicable to all types of ads in all media.
PATERSON. N.J., Nov. 27 -- Jules C. Levine had been ill for a long time before he left here for Florida on Saturday. His death was due to a heart attack.

Joyous tidings from the food front are reported this week by the Consumers Division of the Department of Markets. Both dairy and pork prices have shown pleasant reductions. Tub butter is quoted at an average of 40 cents a pound in contrast to last week's 41, while Grade A eggs are down 2 cents to sell at an average of 58 cents a dozen, with a range of 55 to 65.

Despite reports of increasing shortages in many industrial raw materials, inventories of manufacturers continued their rise in October, reaching a new high; shipments also advanced to a new peak and new orders resumed their upward trend after two months of moderate declines, according to compilations of the National Industrial Conference Board.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Treasury contradicted reports today that it might change the basis of 1941 taxes or suggest new imposts applicable to 1941 income, but remained silent about 1942taxes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (U.P.) -- I feel that the men in the last war had a clarity of understanding of what that war was about. There was more unity, and, accordingly, more patriotism, which means a better civilian morale.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Plans for establishing maximum prices on household furniture made of wood have been abandoned for the present because conditions in that market have undergone a change since price ceilings were first discussed on Nov. 10, Leon Henderson, administrator of the Office of Price Administration, announced today.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. John Tucker of 775 Park Avenue and Huntingdon, L. I., will give a dinner for their debutante daughter, Miss Phebe Tucker, next Friday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis before the first Junior Assembly at the Ritz-Carlton.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 27 -- The time has come for every man to "decide where he personally stands on the question of private versus socialistic public ownership," L. A. Chambliss, president of the New Jersey Bankers Association, declared today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today to the commission that the continued existence of the North American Light and Power Company, a registered holding company and subsidiary of the North American Company, unnecessarily complicated the structure of the holding company system of which it is a part and should be liquidated.

William J. Flynn, former Commissioner of Public Works and former Acting Borough President of the Bronx, died last night at his home, 35 McClellan Street, the Bronx, after an illness of two years. He was 62 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Joint government-industry action to speed production of high octane gasoline to provide fighting planes with uninterrupted supplies of this fuel, which increases the power of engines by 25 per cent, was announced today by Secretary Ickes, under a new program designed to meet the needs of the air forces of the United States and "other democratic nations."

Net profit of Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 30 was $5,429,302 after all charges and taxes, it was announced yesterday. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.36 a share on 3,701,090 common shares, comparing with $2,747,472, or 63 cents a share, in the preceding year, showing a virtual doubling of earnings in the last year.

TULSA, Okla., Nov. 27 -- Max Sallings, 160-pound second-string halfback, took charge in the moment of Arkansas' greatest peril today to lead the Razorbacks to a 13-6 triumph over Tulsa, its bitter Thanksgiving Day rival.

VICHY, France, Nov. 27 -- "Very important events, are preparing. At this time last year in the weeks between Montoire [where Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, French Chief of State, met Reichsfuehrer Hitler on Oct. 24] and Dec. 13 [when Pierre Laval was ousted from the Vichy government] we lived through the same hopes and same fears.

We and R.I. Take the first ten vacationists who last Summer went by car from this city to Cape Cod -- and there must have been tens of thousands of them -- and ask them how does it happen that New York and Rhode Island have just signed a boundary treaty.

VAN WYCK BROOKS haS just published a book called "Opinions of Oliver Allston,"* a character whose ideas on life and politics and letters are said to resemble those held by Mr. Brooks to a certain degree. By a coincidence we ourselves have just come upon a collection of papers left by Devereaux Drake, whose ideas on life and letters may be said to resemble our own to a certain degree.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- President Roosevelt has declined to accept the resignations from the National Defense Mediation Board of Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and Thomas Kennedy, secretary-treasurer of the C.I.O.'s United Mine Workers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- When the Treasury said today that It wanted no change in income taxes on this year's Income of either individuals or corporations, Secretary Morgenthau declined to express any opinion on suggestions for a compulsory savings program.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The general level of wholesale prices for the week ended Nov. 22 declined slightly from the peak reached the preceding week, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Representatives of the Eastern Steamship Lines announced yesterday that the liner Yarmouth would operate in regular cruise service from New York to Miami and Nassau beginning the latter part of next month and continuing through the Winter vacation season until April.

BENDIX, N.J., Nov. 27 -- Air Associates, which manufactures airplane parts and has $5,000,000 in defense orders, is expected to be back under private management within a week, following the election yestrday of Frederic G. Coburn as president to succeed F. Leroy Hill.

David Warfield, who celebrates his seventy-fifth birthday today, sat behind the desk in his living room, which is filled with souvenirs -- tapestries from Russia, statuettes from France -- and talked yesterday afternoon, of birthdays, the theatre and motion pictures.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I entertain the strongest possible conviction that even small errors of information concerning South America and especially Brazil should be cleared up. Topics of the Times, whose charming essays so often cast a ray of sunshine through the gloom of the news, speaks today of "Pernambuco, for which fashion, has substituted the hideous name of Recife."

Abbott Laboratories Abbott Laboratories declared yesterday an extra dividend of 25 cents and the regular quarterly of 40 cents a share on the common stock. Payments for the year total $2.15, the same as in 1940, The directors also authorized distribution of a bonus of approximately $40,000 to employes, except officers and directors.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 27 -- The New Jersey League of Women Voters has created a defense department under the chairmanship of Mrs. George H. Dwenger of Montclair, Mrs. Stuart L. Henderson of Ridgewood, president, announced here today.

A sharp attack on Board of Education members who engage in demagoguery, yearn for personal publicity and bring debates to the level of a "barroom brawl" was made yesterday by James G. McDonald, Brooklyn member. He spoke before the joint civic conference of the Public Education Association, meeting at the Bank of Manhattan Building, Sixty-fourth Street and Madison Avenue.
ROME, Nov. 27 -- The disposition of the two military observers and the American war correspondents captured by the Italian forces in Libya was being studied here today.

Neither new tax burdens nor any practicable form of price control are likely to have more than transitory effect upon the rising dollar volume of retail sales so long as national income continues to be increased by heavy government disbursements, Q. Forrest Walker, economist for R.H. Macy Co., Inc., said yesterday in an address before the New York Society of Security Analysts at the Block Hall Luncheon Club.

Striking contrast is afforded by two of the one-man shows that opened this week in neighboring Fifty-seventh Street galleries. The artists concerned are Marc Chagall at the Pierre Matisse Gallery (41 East) and Clarence H. Carter at the Ferargil (63 East).

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Port of New York Authority, which has assailed the whole railroad grain rate structure from Lake Erie points to North Atlantic ports on the ground that it discriminated in favor of Philadelphia and Baltimore, won only a partial victory in a decision handed down today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

When Artur Rodzinski conducted the Berlioz "Fantastic" symphony last night in Carnegie Hall the audience was thrilled as it seldom has been thrilled in late years by the genius of the music. For this was not a historically winded revival of a symphony that shook the world a hundred-odd years ago, but a masterly revelation of the spirit that flames in an eternally amazing creation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is a fact that a pendulum swings first in one direction, then in the other and so it seems with most things, including the labor movement. Be that as it may, I do believe that for a sound economic basis it would be in the best interests of the country that the pendulum effect be removed from the labor situation.
The eyes of more than Texas were on the Longhorns and Aggies yesterday as they battled In College Station.
Added cost to taxicab riders in New York City under 15 to 20 per cent higher fares proposed Wednesday by the industry would be at least $5,250,000 a year, it was estimated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 26:

BERLIN, Nov. 27 (U.P.) -- German armored armies slashing into both Moscow flanks have captured Klin, fifty-one miles to the northwest, and fourteen towns "lying to the rear of the Soviet lines and fortifications" in the Tula area anchoring the capital's southern defenses, Nazi sources claimed tonight.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS OF THE FIRST ARMY, SOMEWHERE IN THE CAROKENAS, Nov. 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum's Blue First Army was driving steadily southward toward Camden tonight as tank and antitank units of the Blue and Red Armies were locked in the swirling confusion of the battlefield.

Columbia's "You Belong to Me," which opens at the Roxy, is this morning's sole film newcomer. Produced and directed by Wesley Ruggles, the comedy stars Barbara Stanwyck and Henry Fonda, with Edgar Buchanan, Roger Clark, Ruth Donnelly, Maude Eburne and Melville Cooper in supporting roles.
BERLIN, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Nov. 22 shows the following changes for the week, in thousands of reichsmarks:

Credit Collections Off 0.78% Retail credit collections of local stores declined 0.78 per cent in October, according to the twentystore index issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. Eight stores had increases. The average collection percentage was 48.44: against 49.22 for October, 1940. For the ten months fifteen reporting stores had an increase of 0.10 per cent over the corresponding period of 1940.

ROME, Nov. 27 -- The Italian High Command today announced the retaking of Sidi Omar in the Battle of Libya. This operation, it indicated, was made possible by the Savona Division, which "smashed attacks of enemy tanks," thus facilitating the task of Italo-German armored units south of Solum.

OTTAWA, Nov. 27 -- With only two business days to go, Canada's Wartime Prices and Trade Board has the machinery for the application of an overall ceiling on prices in working order, it was reported here today. This was said to have been made possible by the cooperation of representatives of business of all kinds.

The First National Bank of Portland, Ore., and associates have received the award of an issue of $2,700,000 of refunding bonds of the Port of Astoria, Ore., on their bid of 100.055 for 3s. The bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1941, will mature in twenty-six years.

Crime conditions in Harlem occupied a good deal of Mayor La Guardia's attention yesterday. He spent an hour and a half at an Academy of Medicine conference on marihuana and about the same amount of time with Police Commissioner Valentine at Police Headquarters.

A cocktail party with dancing and entertainment, entitled "Cabaret des Petits Paquets," was given yesterday by the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, Inc., at their headquarters, 4 West Fifty-eighth Street, the Charles B. Alexander mansion.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- The Union of Dairy Plant Workers and Route Salesmen, whose strike shut off 85 per cent of the city's door-to-door milk and cream deliveries for three days early in October, have received substantial wage increases through the State Mediation Board, and it is expected that retail prices will be advanced 1 cent a quart next week.

Giant scouting expeditions Will hit three trails on Sunday, it became known yesterday When the recently crowned Eastern champions resumed practice at the Polo Grounds after a three-day holiday. Eagle-eyed play-watchers will observe the Dodgers against the Steelers at Ebbets Field, the Bears against the Eagles in Philadelphia and the Packers against the Redskins in Washington.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed Reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.
GIBRALTAR, Nov. 27 -- This is the first eyewitness account of Gibraltar's new defenses that has been released since its expansion program began.

The Board of Education was urged last night to end discrimination against Negroes in the city vocational schools and to open Harlem schools after hours for recreational and study purposes. An "emergency" conference of 200 teachers, parents and civic leaders of Harlem authorized a committee to call on the Board of Education to push the twofold program.

At a meeting of the board of directors held yesterday, Roger W. Straus, vice chairman, was elected president of the American Smelting and Refining Company. He also was appointed chairman of the executive committee. He succeeds as president Simon Guggenheim who died on Nov. 2. F.H. Brownell will remain as chairman of the board and chairman of the finance committee.

The Crown Zellerbach Corporation and its subsidiaries, in a statement covering the quarter ended on Oct. 31, issued for publication today, report a consolidated net profit of $2,224,233, equal, after preferred dividends, to 69 cents a share on 2,261,199 shares of common stock outstanding.

Mrs. Ford King gave a luncheon yesterday at La Salle du Bois for her debutante niece, Miss Patricia Tucker. Among the other guests were Mrs. John Tucker, the Misses Bessie Larkin Phebe Tucker and Judy Cutter.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 27 -- New Zealand forces smashed through Axis siege lines about Tobruk early today and joined forces with a section of the garrison besieged at that port for more than seven months, it was officially announced here.

TOKYO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The newspaper Asahi, in a special dispatch from Hanoi, accused French Indo-China today of a changed attitude toward Japan as a result of the negotiations between Japan and the United States and other factors.

Due chiefly to heavy government disbursements in this district, the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City rose $125,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $1,090,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York revealed yesterday.

The conversations between our State Department and the Japanese diplomats have not been broken off formally. But the basic positions of the two Governments are so far apart, and the gap between those positions is apparently so unbridgable, that we shall be vise if we anticipate the end of these discussions and prepare ourselves for the situation which will then arise.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- President Roosevelt took a personal hand in the negotiations with Japan today by inviting the Japanese envoys, Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura and Saburo Kurusu, to the White House for a long conversation.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 27 -- George S. Messersmith, nominated today as Ambassador to Mexico, is hardly known in this country and consequently few comments were forthcoming except the formal ones usual upon the appointment of a new Ambassador.

LONDON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Continuing its record-breaking climb, note circulation as reported by the Bank of England reached u710,043,000, an increase of u3,346,000 for the week ended yesterday. This was the thirteenth consecutive weekly advance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The American Legion and other veterans' organizations supported before a Senate sub-committee today two bills to broaden the World War pension program, but another witness said that the measures would involve enormous expenditures for "training camp heroes who never smelled gunpowder."

BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- Miss Nancy Holbrook Scott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Walmsley Scott of 61 Marlborough Street, this city, has completed plans for her marriage to David Robbins Lutkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Stevens Lutkins of 1120 Fifth Avenue, New York, which will take place here on Dec. 20 in Emmanuel Episcopal Church.

Nine owners of captive coal mines were asked yesterday by the arbitration board headed by Dr. John R. Steelman to say whether their mines would be "bound by the board's decision on the controversial "union shop" demand of John L. Lewis's United Mine Workers of America.

HORTENSE, Ga., Nov. 27 (AP) -- One passenger was killed and at least thirteen persons were injured today when the New York-to-Florida Tamiami Champion train of the Atlantic Coast Line was derailed near here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of George S. Messersmith to be Ambassador to Mexico. The career diplomat will succeed Josephus Daniels, who has asked to be relieved.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Brig. Gen. Hines told a Senate finance subcommittee today that he ques-

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 27 -- Yesterday's spontaneous demonstrations in Copenhagen against the adhesion of Denmark to the Anti-Comintern Pact were the first of their kind in that country, and their violence gives an idea of the usually suppressed feelings of the Danes toward their "protectors."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Finland must for her own security continue fighting against the Russians in East Karelia even if by so doing she inadvertently harms the interests of the United States, Hjalmar J. Procope, the Finnish Minister, declared today at a special press conference.

MONTEREY, Mexico, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Judge Jesus B. Santos said today there was enough evidence to hold Dr. Arthur Torrance for further investigation of charges that he beat to death his wealthy 67-year-old bride.

BERLIN, Nov. 27 -- One by one most of the "little statesmen" of Europe who met here this week to sign the renewed Anti-Comintern Pact were ushered into Adolf Hitler's office in the Chancellery today. One by one they were exposed to Herr Hitler's personality and to his views on the "new order" as it affects their respective countries.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Nov. 28 -- "Hold we must -- and will -- through these next few days of strain if we are to make of this final thrust of the enemy the turning point for his final defeat. We must check the enemy's offensive and bleed him white."

Today for the last time Thomas C. Walter win take his daily mile walk along the corridors of the huge Post Office Annex that stretches from Ninth to Tenth Avenues between Twenty-ninth and Thirtieth Streets.

VICHY, France., Nov. 27 -- Because of the dearth of coal for the production of electric current and illuminating gas, the "continuous day" may be adopted for workers in France. This means operation of workshops, offices and stores from 9 or 10 A.M. until 4:30 or 5:30 P.M. with elimination of the luncheon break.

APPALACHIA, Va., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Two 16-year-old boys, Paul Bernard Hoback of Bluefield, W. Va., and Tommie Peters of Washington, D.C., were arrested in a hotel here just before dawn today by officers trailing the robbery-slayers of Ward Loveles on his Leesburg estate Sunday night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Chairman Truman of the Senate Defense Investigating Committee, charged today that the War Department's quartermaster's division apparently promoted officers for "waste and extravagance" instead of court-martialing them.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Increases in major crimes, including murder and rape, are shown in a report for the nine months of 1941 compiled by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Nothing in today's developments on the legislative labor front offered much hope that the administration and Congress will adopt Edmund Burke's counsel that to change conditions the causes must be removed. Labor and industry joined in an effort to remove from the White House conference proposals of Monday night what can more fitly be called the poison-fangs than the teeth of those proposals: compulsory arbitration.

Colonel T.L. Crystal, the commanding officer of Fort Jay, said it was a cinch. He said it was "darn good training," and promptly got an officer to send out a call for more masks. They were meant for reporters and photographers sent over to Governors Island yesterday afternoon to watch a gas drill in, the Fort Jay gas-training center.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Fursales dropped off sharply during October in comparison with October, 1940, the Federal Reserve Board's monthly report of department store sales by departments shows. According to information from 247 stores, however, total sales rose 10 per cent over the corresponding month a year ago, while for the ten months period they were 16 per cent higher than in the like period of 1940.

A passive reaction toward Archbishop Francis J. Spellman's condemnation of the new Greta Garbo picture, "Two-Faced Woman," was evidenced yesterday in the local offices of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the producers. In the absence of Nicholas Schenck, president of the company, who is in Hollywood, Howard Dietz, director of advertising and publicity, issued the following statement:

At a signal from the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, a pair of gray curtains, sixty feet in height, swung apart yesterday afternoon between the nave and the crossing of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and revealed the unbroken vista from the golden west doors of the great edifice to the high altar, a tenth of a mile away.

South America will send a swimming team of six to the United States for competition in December and January, it was announced yesterday by Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the A.A.U. Five of the athletes will sail today from Rio de Janeiro and the other later from Guayaquil, Ecuador, and all will arrive in New York on Dec. 15.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Treasury will seek $1,500,000,000 of new money next week, and in January it will refund $1,075,000,000 of existing securities. This was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau, with the news that hereafter cash and refunding operations would be separated.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY CORPS, in Libya, Nov. 26 (Delayed) -- Orange gun flashes are intermittently flooding the night sky with bursts of light a few miles north of here. They mark the place where British guns, tanks and armored cars are harrying an Axis raiding column on the. frontier of Egypt and Libya.
VICHY, France, Nov. 27 -- The Paris press announced today the execution of two persons arrested in Nancy for illegal possession of arms.

A firm undertone continued to feature the cotton market yesterday, although trading held quiet and the volume small as eight of the cotton growing States observed the Thanksgiving Day holiday. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures moved within narrow ranges and closed near their best levels and at net gains of 4 to 9 points.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 27 -- The Arabs are watching the present offensive in Libya with greater interest than they displayed in the drive of a year ago. Last Winter's offensive was against the Italians, whom the Arabs knew well and with whose powers of resistance they had had previous experience.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 27 -- Showing burning speed over the recently frozen racing strip, Mrs. Veader Leonard's Happy Lark sped to a three-length victory in the six-furlong fifth event that featured Bowie's program this sunny day. Favorite at $5.30 for $2 in the field of eight high-class platers, Happy Lark whirled over a track that finally had dried out in 1:11 4-5, exceptional speed for Bowie.

ALBANY, Nov. 27 -- The Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company of New York was ordered to pay to the estate of David Fox money embezzled by Cheesman Kittredge, trustee of the estate, the Court of Appeals decided unanimously today. The court reversed the Appellate Division and sent the case back to the special term.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A smaller supply of hogs in the livestock market today, took some of the pressure off prices, and offerings sold steady to 10 centa a. hundredweight higher. Light weights were bought freely by Eastern shippers. Three Western markets were closed for the second Thanksgiving holiday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said here today that the capital gains tax was artificially depressing the stock markets and urged that the Treasury make a study looking toward revisions to encourage investment of risk-bearing capital in industry.

Lambert Brothers, the jewelers, are celebrating this week the sixty-fifth anniversary of the firm's founding. The concern has arranged a historic display of jewelry in its store, at Lexington Avenue and Sixtieth Street, in which quaint old pieces made during its first years of business are contrasted with their modern counterparts of today.

The Consolidated Edison System is planning the early construction of a high-tension power transmission line to link its Sherman Creek generating plant in the Bronx with its Dunwoodie substation near Yonkers to make available an additional 150,000 or 200,000 kilowatts for use north of Westchester, it was disclosed yesterday at a public hearing before the Public Service Commission at 80 Center Street.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force's daylight sweeps of the English Channel and the North Sea netted destruction yesterday of four German ships -- two supply vessels and a pair of anti-aircraft boats -- the Air Ministry announced.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Another step toward putting all Britain -- every man and woman in the country -- into the war effort was forecast today through the announcement that the government would introduce at the next sitting of Parliament a bill extending its present powers for compulsory national service.

Set down as a possibility for next season a musical show in which Ed Wynn is to resume his kingly role as The Perfect Fool, disporting himself as a clown in a work based upon "Three Sisters" by Oscar Hammerstein and Jerome Kern, which London saw in 1934.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 27 -- Gettysburg lost to Muhlenberg today, 28 to 13, and the Eastern Pennsylvania Football Conference championship race ended in a triple tie among Gettysburg, Muhlenberg and Franklin and Marshall.

A mother and her married daughter, who had attempted to defraud an insurance company by filing a false claim for $5,890 in a purported theft of furs and other garments from their automobile last January, got off with suspended sentences yesterday in General Sessions before Judge George L. Donnellan.
COLLEGE STATION, Texas; Nov. 27 -- Texas blasted Texas A. and M. off football's glory road today in a bewildering reversal of form and a repetition of Southwest Conference history.

After an existence of nearly two years, the Rapp-Coudert committee conducting an investigation of subversive activities in the New York City school system will suspend its inquiry on Dec. 31 and dismiss its staff of fifteen employes, Paul Windela, chief counsel, disclosed yesterday.

CAIRO, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Amending earlier reports, British military spokesmen said today that the New Zealanders had not taken Bardia in their coastal sweep, but had left artillery forces to besiege that stronghold as well as Solum. Both were said to be under heavy shellfire.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- After emphasizing "defensive" tactics for a year, the Army is now to base its training and reorganization upon the principle of taking and keeping "the offensive."

BERLIN, Nov. 27 -- Strongly reinforced German troops, supported by native "volunteer" units, are engaged in a major offensive against organized Serbian guerrillas in a wide area of Yugoslavia, reliable sources said today.

Christmas Present Somewhat wistfully the New York Stock Exchange is awaiting word from Washington on its suggestion that commissions be increased. The Exchange's own study of the problem began last Spring, and on July 1 the Securities and Exchange Commission announced that it was starting an intensive study of the matter of brokerage revenue.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 28 -- Domei, Japanese news agency, giving perhaps the first reaction in informed quarters here, says today that the only thing that can be said about the Washington negotiations is that the American attitude remains unchanged and, therefore, "there is little hope of bridging the gap between the opinions of Japan and the United States.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27 -- In the illumination of a giant bonfire touched off on Farragut Field, thousands of midshipmen sang and shouted their defiance to Army tonight, then marched on the railroad station for a roaring send-off to the last Navy football team that Major Emery E. Larson of the United States Marine Corps will lead to battle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- More than 100 growers, canners and extension specialists called into conference with the Department of Agriculture today to consider the government's plans for increased vegetable packs next year were dubious tonight about filling the Federal quotas, unless such problems as materials and supplies can be solved.

YREKA, Calif., Nov. 27 -- Bonfires blazed along the main north-south highway winding through the towering Siskiyous tonight as determined mining men, with pistols in their belts, stopped motorists and distributed yellow handbills proclaiming the "independence" of a group of Oregon and California border counties.

THOSE are wonderful human documents that roll off the Uncle Mike Jacobs mimeograph machines when a fight is afoot. The latest issue to arrive at this desk Is historical. That's right, historical; not hysterical. Amid the utmost excitement, Uncle Mike remains cool. If the house is a little slow in filling up, he may champ a little louder on a cigar with his store teeth, but that's his display limit in betraying his emotions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 22, which included Thanksgiving, totaled 799,386 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 84,453 cars or 9.6 percent fewer than for the preceding Week, although 65,898 cars or 9 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 126,273 cars or 18.8 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Valerie Bettis, who was formerly a member of Hanya Holm's dance group, made her local solo debut last night at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. It was a mere wisp of a program with which she undertook to come to grips with the general public for the first time, consisting of eight brief dances, and all over in an hour.

William L. Batt, Director of Materials of the Office of Production Management, warned labor last night that "a widespread national anger" was arising throughout the country because of strikes in defense productions, but contended that passage of anti-strike legislation by Congress was not the way to handle the situation.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 27 -- Minister of External Affairs Dr. H.V. Evatt, reviewing the international aituation in the House of Representatives, emphasized that the recent change in the government did not imply any vital change in foreign policy.

After a three-hour verbal battle in City Hall yesterday in which several hundred street peddlers lined up against spokesmen for real estate and retail interests, the Board of Estimate adopted a Council bill banning itinerant peddling from the streets of the city, with a limited number of exceptions.

Although England is not suffering now a "dramatic blitz," the present phase of the battle is just as difficult for the people there, Lady Halifax, wife of the British Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Red Wings kept the Black Hawks from the National Hockey League lead tonight by winning, 4 to 1, in a rough and tumble brawl before 6,436 spectators. There were fourteen penalties, but none of the goals came while the penalty box was occupied.

The British Government is taking an unprecedented step in asking for the conscription of all available woman power as well as man power for war service. The motion for this far-reaching measure was introduced by the Prime Minister in conjunction with the Ministers representing the Liberal and Labor parties in the war cabinet.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 27 -- The marriage of Miss Helen Hosford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Hosford of this community, to Lieutenant George Granger Bierwirth, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Bierwirth of Upper Montclair, took place tonight in the home of her parents.

Those who had planned to participate in the special "antlerless" deer season in Rockland County next month will have to get their buck during the present open season, for Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne has announced that plans for the season have been canceled.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 27 -- By an exchange of notes between Foreign Minister Dr. Enrique de Ruiz-Guinazu and United States Ambassador Norman Armour this evening, the United States Government undertakes to buy, through the Metals Reserve Company, all of Argentina's production of tungsten for three years up to a maximum of 3,000 short tons yearly of pure tungsten oxide.
ROME, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

The wishful thinkers among N. Y.U. followers -- those who hope the football team may manage an upset of Fordham tomorrow at the Yankee Stadium because underdogs have sprung surprises often in traditional games -- may be glossing over the disparity in the opposing elevens' strength, but not so Coach Mal Stevens and his players.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The fourteen non-operating railroad unions prepared tonight to join the five operating brotherhoods in going out on strike in the event of an adverse verdict by the President's emergency fact-finding board, which will open hearings tomorrow on the disputed new agreement between the carriers and labor.

ARDSLEY, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- Mrs. Stewart Iglehart of New York led her team to a close victory over Westchester, 3 to 2, in the first of a series of metropolitan Class A squash racquets matches played on the courts of the Ardsley Country Club today.

The marriage of Miss Florence Isabel Storer, daughter of Dr. John Hudson Storer of the Carlyle and of the late Mrs. Storer, to Robert Frank Mathews, also of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Ernest Mathews of Bloomington, Ind., took place yesterday noon in the Regency Room of the Carlyle.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- A distinguished congregation of friends, headed by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York, filled St. Bridget's Church, Framingham Center, this morning for the funeral service of Frank D. Comerford, president of the Boston Edison Company, who died on Monday.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden gave a warning in a speech in the House of Commons today that Adolf Hitler's "new order" involved plans for moving large sections of populations from one part of Europe to another and for using industry for the exclusive profit of the Reich.

The Downtown A.C. moved into a second-place tie with the Princeton Club in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A team matches yesterday by beating the Yale Club, 4-1, on the Downtown courts. At the same time the University Club halted the Cornell Club, 5-0, on the University courts.

Secretary Knox has given the expected answer to the charge that he made a personal profit out of magazine articles appearing under his name and revealing information which had come to him as the result of his official position. He caused the articles to be written, he says, because he considered it part of his job to "publicize and popularize the Navy."

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- While liquidation by holders of December wheat contracts continued today, the market showed a much firmer undertone, with professional traders showing a little more confidence as a result of the defeat of the Gore bill in the House yesterday, and reports from Washington forecasting the possibility that the Senate would not take up price-control legislation until next Spring.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Lease-Lend Administration was reported today to be "in process of arranging" for extensive construction of warehouses, docks, railway sidings and airplane landing facilities in the Red Sea area.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: During the past month various plans for curbing inflation through special added taxes levied at the income source of private individuals have been put forth by the Treasury Department. The Ways and Means Committee of the House has announced that it will give its attention to these suggestions in a short time.
America's first all-crochet fashion show was held yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria as a "Threads of Friendship" benefit for the British-American Ambulance Corps.

The muddle that has characterized the championship of the middleweight division for a decade will be cleared up tonight when Georgie Abrams, clever Washington campaigner, now in the U.S. Navy, opposes Tony Zale of Gary, Ind., in the star bout of fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden.

The claim of Doctors Hospital, East End Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street, to exemption from city real estate taxes as a charitable institution was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin, who declared that "there was no real public service here rendered, but the service that was rendered was for the select few."

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 27 -- As the House of Representatives wrestles this week with a price control bill to curb inflation, one question of special interest to students of economics is this: how many people throughout the country are laying in goods now to protect themselves against higher prices later on?

LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 27 (AP) -- A placement kick for an extra point by Captain Vince Daher, playing the final game of his college career, gave Franklin and Marshall a 14-to-13 victory over Ursinus and a three-way tie for the Eastern Pennsylvania Conference football championship today before 9,000 fans.

To handle the expected increase in mail over the Christmas holiday period, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday that between 6,000 and 7,000 extra men would be called, new substations would be opened and other postal stations would remain open for longer periods in Manhattan and the Bronx.

VICHY, France, Nov. 27 -- Because they are Jews and therefore excluded from elective assemblies by the law of June 2, 1941, three Senators and nine Deputies were declared by decree today to have forfeited their parliamentary man-dates. Prominent among them are Leon Blum, former Premier, and Georges Mandel, former Minister of the Interior, both of whom are "detained" at Portalet Fort in the Pyrenees.

Women's proverbial talkativeness should be turned to patriotic advantage, Mrs. Vincent Hilles Ober declared last night at the twenty-seventh biennial convention of the National Panhellenic Congress at the Hotel Biltmore.

The New York Post, the oldest continuously published daily newspaper in the city, celebrated yesterday its 140th anniversary with special exercises at 40 Pine Street, the site on which the first issue of the paper was produced 140 years ago this month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Speaker Rayburn and Representative McCormack, majority leader of the House, appeared before an unannounced meeting of the Banking and Currency Committee today and are said to have urged passage of a price control bill.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 27 -- Bob Hope and Victor Moore will be starred by Paramount in "Ready Money," James Montgomery's farce about a young man who becomes a financier by mistake. "Ready Money" was first produced on Broadway in 1912, and was staged again in 1918 as a musical comedy under the title "Oh, Look."

The performance of Strauss's "Der Rosenkavalier," given last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, possessed too little of the spontaneity, animation and sparkle that are required for a thoroughly satisfying presentation of the work.

The atmosphere of the Persian Room at the Praza Hotel was saturated with sweet scents at yesterday's luncheon hour as each woman who entered the room was sprayed with the Coty perfume best suited to her furs or tweeds.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Catholic diocese of Brooklyn received last night a portrait of Pope Pius XII, presented by Wendell L. Willkie in behalf of a group of Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders at a private dinner in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria commemorating the twentieth anniversary of his consecration as a Bishop.

Despite a decline from the previous week's high levels, substantial year-to-year gains reported at leading centers lifted total bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday 22.3 per cent above the corresponding period a year ago.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 27 (UP) -- The first scheduled stop of the President Madison with its contingent of 350 United States Marines is Manila. The President Harrison with 400 more is also scheduled to go first to Manila.

The contest for president of the National Democratic Club developed yesterday into a clash between the elder and younger members as a volunteer committee issued a pamphlet urging support for Thomas C. Meeks, candidate for re-election and the choice of the club's nominating committee.

George McAfee of the Chicago Bears, a very annoying player to enemy teams while on the offense, has considerable nuisance value to them on the defense as well. This was disclosed yesterday when the National Football League's defensive statistics were released.

After two years and eight months of hearings, the Federal Trade Commission yesterday ordered the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute to drop its system of classifying selling policies of manufacturers and listing" recognized wholesalers, holding that these are acts and practices tending to prevent competition within the meaning of the Federal Trade Commission Act.

The contest for president of the National Democratic Club developed yesterday into a clash between the elder and younger members as a volunteer committee issued a pamphlet urging support for Thomas C. Meeks, candidate for re-election and the choice of the club's nominating committee.

George McAfee of the Chicago Bears, a very annoying player to enemy teams while on the offense, has considerable nuisance value to them on the defense as well. This was disclosed yesterday when the National Football League's defensive statistics were released.

After two years and eight months of hearings, the Federal Trade Commission yesterday ordered the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute to drop its system of classifying selling policies of manufacturers and listing" recognized wholesalers, holding that these are acts and practices tending to prevent competition within the meaning of the Federal Trade Commission Act.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 27 (UP) -- The first scheduled stop of the President Madison with its contingent of 350 United States Marines is Manila. The President Harrison with 400 more is also scheduled to go first to Manila.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- The annual Boulder Brook Horse Show opened tonight before an excellent attendance of Westchester enthusiasts. Entries were light In the saddle division, with excellent competition among the hunters, while the local Jumpers turned lout in force.

Alexander Edgar George Robert Petrus Wahrient Hoyos Ten Eyck at the age of four and one-half yesterday sent a message to Santa Claus announcing that henceforth he and his grandmother, Mrs. W. Browning Smith, would handle the Christmas gift situation among needy children in the Southern mountains.

Ration cards and bombs were designated yesterday by Mrs. Beatrice Clough Rathbone, member of the British House of Commons, as the surest mediums for the removal of class barriers. In her country, she declared, their constant presence has reduced the lives of all persons to "a very low, common denominator -- to win the war and to win the peace."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Senate and House committees reported today two separate bills providing for government seizure and operation of plants to curb defense strikes, but differing widely in other provisions.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 28 -- The invaluable part that skiing, hitherto looked upon primarily from the recreational point of view, will play in our nation's defense was stressed today as the National Ski Association opened its thirty-seventh annual convention.

American colleges and universities and the fraternities and sororities on their campuses have a distinct duty in this time of national crisis to revive faith in the homely virtues on which this country was founded and to promote a better appreciation of the American form of government, representatives of fraternities and sororities were warned last night at a dinner in the Hotel Commodore.

To THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES : Every one recognizes that the corporate form of enterprise is undergoing an evolution. It is where this evolution is taking them that is worrying those carrying the final risk and responsibility of enterprise -- that of success or failure, profit or loss -- namely, the common stockholders.

school students discarded their school students discarded their textbooks yesterday afternoon at Brooklyn Technical High School, De Kalb Avenue and Fort Greene Place, Brooklyn, and heard a lively debate on what should be the role of the United States in the war.

The Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association has appointed a three-man committee to study the application of the Robinson-Patman act in the liquor field, and the group will meet with officials of the Federal Trade Commission on Monday to present a plan by which it would report existing violations to the commission, it was announced yesterday by the association.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 28 -- Colonel Draja Mikhailovitch, who is said to control at least three-quarters of Serbia, Hercegovenia, Bosnia and Montenegro, must be caught dead or alive, the German authorities in Yugoslavia have announced. At the same time they have increased the price on his head to 10,000,000 dinars, which at pre-war rates would be about $1,000,000.

Dr. William L. Leiserson, member of the National Labor Relations Board, told a panel of several hundred leaders in psychology at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday that "many of the problems of labor relations are primarily problems of psychology," arising because of fundamental differences between two types of mind -- the "management mind" and the "worker's mind."
BERLIN, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Wendell L. Willkie will represent William Schneiderman, secretary of the Communist party of California, before the United States Supreme Court when the highest court of the land meets during its January term to hear an appeal taken by the Communist leader against decisions of two lower Federal courts revoking his citizenship.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The British East African military and air headquarters issued this joint communique today:

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 28 -- Following official Berlin denials that the German Army plans the total destruction of Belgrade and other Serbian cities and villages by shellfire and bombing, save in cases of "military necessity," foreign military intelligence sources here reveal reports that German artillery and dive bombers are systematically reducing Central and Western Serbian villages to ashes and decimating the population.

Buffalo, X.Y. The city of Buffalo, N.Y., will enter the market on Dec. 5 with an issue of $2,900,000 of tax-anticipation certificates of indebtedness, for which bidders are asked to specify the rate of interest. The obligations, dated Dec. 15, 1941, will become payable on June 15, 1942.

A determined effort to swing at least one major deal and a thorough reorganization of the club's farm and scouting system are to be the prime matters of business for Giant officials when they gather next week for the annual minor league baseball convention in Jacksonville.

The appearance of two new public utility loans lifted the total of new bond offerings this week to $48,408,201, compared with $16,444,000 in new issues last week. In the comparable week last year new bond flotations aggregated $43,274,000.

The State Liquor Authority, which previously had declared its policy of permitting Sunday beer sales "unchanged" by a recent Court of Appeals decision banning the Sabbath sale of beer to take out, issued warnings yesterday to the thousands of retailers throughout the State that they were expected to obey the law.

JUNCTION CITY, Nov. 28 -- Brig. Gen. John B. Coulter, former commanding officer of the Fourth Cavalry Regiment, Fort Meade, S.D., assumed temporary command this week of the Third Brigade of the Second Cavalry Division, stationed at Camp Funston, Fort Riley, Kan., succeeding Brig. Gen. Terry Alien, now on duty in Carolina manoeuvres.

Mlscha Elman'a violin playing at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall, remarkable as it was in many respects, failed to average up to that heard from him at his recital in the same auditorium last January. Mr. Elman's bowing was never more extraordinary for lightness and elasticity than at this latest appearance, and his spiccato and staccato work left nothing to be desired.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 28 -- Communication by means of two-way frequency modulation radio, requiring no more special skill than is needed to operate an ordinary home radio receiver, was demonstrated in the Carolina manoeuvres this week by tank units of the Second Armored Division.

FORT DIX, N.J., Nov. 28 -- The first contingent of replacements for infantry regiments of the Forty-fourth Division are scheduled to arrive here tomorrow morning from Camp Croft, S.C., according to an announcement by Major Daniel Debrier, division rear detachment commander.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Big packers were reported bearish on hogs today, saying they were loaded with pork which was hard to move on a declining dressed market.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- Colonel Edwin Gunner, commander of Fort Slocum since 1936, will be transferred Dec. 15 to the field force of the Army recruiting service at Newark and will retire from Army service next June because of his age of 63, the War Department said this afternoon.

ROME, Nov. 28 -- Harold Denny of THE NEW YORK TIMES is one of two American newspaper men captured by the Axis forces in Libya, it was confirmed tonight by the Italian Ministry of Popular Culture. The other is Godfrey Anderson of The Associated Press.

A reprimand to women of the country for their lack of vision in the defense program was addressed yesterday to members of the Women's City Club of New York by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, secretary of the Voluntary Participation Committee of the Office of Civilian Defense.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- A reduction of 20 per cent in the basic freight rates for transportation of oil in tankers from Gulf or Caribbean ports to the East Coast was ordered today by the Maritime Commission.

Complete approval of Wendell L. Willkie's position in supporting President Roosevelt's policy of all-out aid to the nations fighting Hitler has been expressed by the Massachusetts Republican State Committee, Mr. Willkie was informed yesterday.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Nov. 28 -- Dr. Katharine McBride, dean off Radcliffe College, was elected president of Bryn Mawr today to succeed Dr. Marion Edwards Park, who is retiring after a tenure of twenty years. She will take office in July.

Racket Succeeds Graft On a higher level it would be called a link with the past. One of the men arrested the other day in a raid on an alleged gambling club in Harlem, was a witness almost thirty years ago in the trial of Police Lieutenant Becker for his share in the murder of the gambler Herman Rosenthal.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Charges of conspiracy to fix the price of livestock to be paid producers, and the price of meat to consumers, were made in indictments returned today against fourteen meat packing companies and the American Meat Institute and thirty-seven individuals.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Administration announced its support today of proposals to curb lobbying for defense contracts.

A committee for the New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway (Gulf Coast Lines) first mortgage and income bonds, headed by G.H. Walker, issued a statement yesterday urging holders of these securities to vote for the plan of reorganization certified to the courts by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- A secret welding process, perfected after months of experiment, will enable the United States to produce rivetless tanks at the rate of about 3,000 a month by mid-1942, it was revealed tonight in a report by Major Gen. Charles M. Wesson, Chief of Ordnance.

Dr. Caroline B. Zachry, noted child psychologist and progressive educator, was nominated yesterday by the Board of Superintendents for the post of director of the New York City school system's Bureau of Child Guidance. The post, one of the highly desirable ones in the local system, pays $12,000 annually.

BERLIN, Nov. 28 -- Throwing In ever more men, tanks and artillery in their new drive for Moscow, now in its eleventh day, the Germans are drawing steadily nearer to the capital. The Russians, however, are hotly contesting every foot of ground, and their stubborn defense once more has served to slow the Germans' progress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The House passed a price-control bill tonight after a combination of Republicans and Democrats had routed Administration forces and turned thumbs down on provisions which the House leaders said were essential if the anti-inflation legislation was to have any teeth.

Nine years ago Carlo M. Flumiani was a kind of multiple exponent of psycho-synthesis, but yesterday, on the witness stand in Federal Court, he had to admit that he couldn't even remember how to forecast a stock market trend by use of his theory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Price and production problems involved in meeting the government's requests for wide expansion in canned goods output next year occupied canners, growers and specialists from government departments who today attended the closing session of a two-day meeting called here by the Department of Agriculture.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Major provisions of the labor bills reported to the House and Senate today were as follows:

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Nov. 29 -- Late reports from Moscow this morning indicated a decided change for the better on the northwestern defenses of the capital, where Soviet troops at dawn yesterday launched the initial operations of an engagement that has since assumed the proportions of a full-scale counter-offensive, according to the authoritative Soviet military commentator.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Spokesmen for the nineteen railway labor unions offered today to call off nation-wide strike plans if all of the 1,200,000 railway employes received wage increases of at least $1 a day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The long-simmering quarrel within the Administration over defense housing broke out in Congress today when the House Public Buildings and Grounds Committee approved a bill authorizing another $300,000,000 but specifying that none of it should be spent by Nathan Straus's United States Housing Authority.

Appliance manufacturers, furniture stores and others affected by the installment regulations are becoming more and more concerned over the public's lack of knowledge of the new restrictions and numerous suggestions are being put forth that some sort of an advertising campaign be run to tell the facts.

The first steps in organization of a cooperative effort by ministers, physicians and other community leaders to promote the moral, spiritual and physical health of their community will be taken Thursday afternoon at West Orange, N.J.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Harcourt Johnstone, M.P., Secretary of the Department of Overseas Trade, has asked advertisers to engage in no impressive campaigns for business in the United States lest Americans "get the idea we are more interested in selling than in winning the war."

The Appellate Division sustained unanimously yesterday a ruling of License Commissioner Paul Moses revoking the 1940 license of the Corporate Employment Service, Inc., 20 Cortlandt Street, in a test case on the interpretation of the law governing fees which may be charged by employment agencies.

Aboard the President's Special Train, Nov. 28 -- In proclaiming Dec. 15 as Bill of Rights Day, President Roosevelt declared today that the loss of fundamental human liberties in other countries has given Americans "an unalterable determination" not to see them lost or curtailed in the United States.
FORT LEWIS, Wash., Nov. 28 -- An army of forgotten men they call them at Port Lewis, the 50,000 soldiers who may haye served in Uncle Sam's force all over the nation without credit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Despite opposition by the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice, a $5,000,000 merger of eight trucking corporations serving the Atlantic Seaboard which would constitute the largest single trucking unit in the United States was recommended today for approval to the Interstate Commerce Commission by Vernon V. Baker, examiner of the finance section of the commission's bureau of motor carriers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- In the face of protests aroused by its order curbing output of lead foil for use in the packaging of cigarettes, chewing gum and other products, the Office of Production Management suspended the effective date of the order for thirty days.

These surveys are made by a system of highly selective samplings in each of the forty-eight States in proportion to voting populations; thereby, the American Institute of Public Opinion holds, is obtained a result which would not vary from that of a much larger canvass.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Major General Henry H. Arnold reported today that the Army Air Force possessed 2,500 or more modern, combat type war planes, despite the diversion of Americanmade aircraft to Britain and elsewhere.

An organization to include all Protestant church women in the United States will be formed at a "constituting convention" to be held in Atlantic City, N.J., Dec. 11 to 13. One hundred delegates will be present from three interdenominational Protestant Church women's organizations.

Reflecting the growing tension in Japanese-American relations, the New York agencies of five Japanese banks have made plans for suspending their activities in case of necessity, but in the meanwhile will continue to do business as usual, it was stated yesterday by spokesmen for these institutions.

TRENTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- An increase of more than 300 per cent in New Jersey's official payroll in the last twenty years was disclosed today in a report of the State Civil Service Commission showing that State workers in the 1940-41 fiscal year received $26,675,584.

LONDON, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- Three newspaper men believed to have been captured by Axis forces In Libya were now known to be safe, the War Office announced tonight. They are Sam Brewer of the Chicago Tribune, Alaric Jacob of Reuters, British news agency, and M.H. Halton of the Toronto Star.

The Dodgers labored on their aerial offense yesterday in preparation for tomorrow's battle with Pittsburgh at Ebbets Field. The Steelers reportedly have been vulnerable to overhead assaults although with Ace Parker injured two weeks ago the Brooks could not capitalize on this and hence suffered an upset defeat.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Thurman W. Arnold, assistant attorney general, denounced "the grotesque and ludicrous labor practices known as 'feather-bedding'" in a speech today before the Executives Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Department store sales during the week ended Nov. 22 showed an increase of 11 per cent over the corresponding week of last year as against an increase of 14 per cent in the previous week's comparison, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
