CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 28 -- British Imperials widened their wedge through the main Axis battle line below Tobruk tonight and one British force pressed on west through Libya, paced by the Royal Air Force, which reported it had blown up with a well-placed load of bombs the whole field headquarters staff of one Italian division.
DETROIT, Nov. 28 -- A dispute over a non-union employe led to the closing of the Dodge main plant of the Chrysler Corporation this afternoon, making 12,000 employes idle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Opposition to the two veterans' pensions bills passed by the House and pending before the Senate Finance Committee was reaffirmed by the National Economy League today in a joint statement by H.G.W. Sundeloff, executive director, and Wil- lard D. Arant, research director.

Holiday Trade Called 'Spotty' The volume of sales today will tell the story of the week's retail trade here, merchants said yesterday. Business turned "soft" yesterday with the warm weather and holiday trade earlier in the week had been inclined to be spotty.

Encouragement with the way women throughout the nation were progressing in church work was expressed yesterday by two national field workers of the Woman's Auxiliary of the National Council, Protestant Episcopal Church.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 28 -- Challenging those who make "lugubrious predictions" of a devastating post-emergency collapse comparable to the collapse after the last war, Dr. Eugene E. Agger, director of the Bureau of Economic Research of Rutgers University, forecast here today a future in which the free enterprise system, "somewhat remodeled but retaining its essentials," would come into its own again.

Thailand, now facing possible Japanese attack to cut the Burma Road, "will defend itself against invasion," a Siamese gem mine owner and Vincent Sheean, foreign correspondent, declared yesterday at La Guardia Field when they arrived by plane from the West Coast.

Police Commissioner Valentine denied reports yesterday that Mayor La Guardia had held up appointments to the police force that have been authorized by appropriations in the 1941 budget and that would enable the Commissioner to send from 100 to 200 additional policemen to Harlem if the appointments were made.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I am sorry to see that disgruntled alumni and students of New York University are now beginning to raise the old Ohio State cry of "Fire the coach."

A doubled police guard of twenty-two uniformed patrolmen and thirty detectives was assigned yesterday to the first-degree murder trial in Kings County Court of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, industrial racketeer, giving rise to rumors of an underworld plot to free Lepke in the courtroom as his case reached the eve of completion.
Sales of residential parcels along the south and north shores In Queens and Nassau Counties featured the Long Island realty trading reported yesterday.

CAMP CROFT, S.C., Nov. 28 -- This infantry replacement training center approaches its full 18,000-man strength this week as well over 1,000 newly inducted selectees arrived to take their places in regimental units for thirteen weeks of basic training.

BUFFALO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Striking Great Lakes tugmen who walked out at several ports as the result of a dispute with the Great Lakes Towing Company will return to work under terms of a company-union truce, an official of the Tug, Firemen, Linesmen and Oilers Protective Association announced tonight.

Ensemble playing of refinement and perception was the order of the evening at the Town Hall last night when Celius Dougherty and Vincenz Ruzicka appeared in a program for two pianos. Their performances had the quality of a sensitively integrated string quartet, only, of course, in the piano milieu.

With "Plain Words," a recently published volume on venereal disease, Surgeon General Thomas Parran and his assistant, Dr. R.A. Vonderlehr, have thrown a bombshell into the Army and Navy. Around camps and defense industries venereal disease is increasing at an alarming rate.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- British armored forces, following up a bombing attack by the Royal Air Force yesterday, intercepted a column of German tanks and trucks moving westward from the Halfaya area and sent the Germans roaring off north toward Gambut after inflicting heavy casualties, it was announced here today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 28 -- The remains of President Fedro Aguirre Cerda were deposited in the family vault of the local cemetery at 1 P.M. today after funeral ceremonies, marked by full military honors, that commenced at 5 o'clock this morning.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- Foreign military intelligence reports told today of seventy transports moving southward carrying 30,000 Japanese troops from Central China and enormous quantities of war materials, including mechanized equipment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Houston Lighting and Power Company has filed an amendment with the Securities and Exchange Commission, setting forth the terms under which the 500,000 no-par shares of common stock of Houston Lighting and Power, all owned by the National Power and Light Company, will be issued in exchange for the outstanding 279,716 shares of $6 cumulative preferred stock, no par value, of National Power and Light.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- A less variety of United States canned foods will go on the British market next week when experimental points of the plan come into effect. Housewives who were advised by the government at the beginning of the war to put away their can openers against an emergency are now being invited to sample the new foods that should prove a valuable supplement to their diet.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- With the world aflame from shot and shell and hanging on the cables from Moscow, Libya and Thailand, the directing minds of the country's armed forces will gather here tomorrow for a game of football between young men who shortly may be on destroyer patrol in the Atlantic, in command of Panzer units or riding the air lanes in flying fortresses and pursuit planes.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Nov. 28 -- The first two United Service Organizations clubhouses in the United States, completed under the Federal Security Agency building program, were opened today in Fayetteville, twenty-one days ahead of schedule.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- With the purchase of sixty-eight carloads of cheese on the Wisconsin Cheese Exchange, Plymouth, Wis., today, the government set what is probably a record in cheese buying, officials of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange reported.

EDDYSTONE, Pa., Nov. 28 -- Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, spent several hours at the Baldwin Locomotive works today, saw twenty medium tanks built there for the British and told the 1,500 employes who faced him as he spoke that nothing was more urgent than tank production.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Awards today by the War Department totaled $12,649,667.42. The following, not previously published, went to the New York area:

Sermons will be preached tomorrow in observance of the first Sunday in Advent, marking the beginning of the new ecclesiastical year. In some of the larger churches on the main thoroughfares of Manhattan the Advent portions of the oratorio, "The Messiah," will be sung.

Matthew Woll, second vice president of the American Federation of Labor, ventured into a C.I.O. office yesterday for the first time since the split in the labor movement six years ago and joined with officers of Sidney Hillman's Amalgamated Clothing Workers in calling for immediate steps to reunite the A.F. of L. and the C.I.O.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 28 -- Germany is sending huge reinforcements of troops, munitions and planes to Salonika, Southern Italian ports and Sicily for transshipment to the Western Desert, foreign military intelligence sources in Ankara reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 28 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has scheduled "Then There Were Two," a screen story by John C. Higgins, for immediate production by Jack Chertok, with Van Heflin, Marsha Hunt and Lee Bowman in the leads. Fred Zinnemann will direct from a scenario by Higgins and Allen Rivkin.

As the Clock Ticks The closing of New York City mails last night saw the deadline for the extended time in which manufacturers of defense materials could apply to the United States War Department for amortization certificates under the tax-amortization bill, permitting the retirement of property built for specific national defense work over a sixty-month, period.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 29 -- The note outlining Washington's stand is the American-Japanese negotiations was presented to the Cabinet yesterday by Foreign Minister Shigenori Togo, who gave a detailed report regarding the developments leading up to it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Nov. 22 were 241,956,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented an increase of 1,557,000 barrels in the week, comprising increases of 1,450,000 and 107,000 in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Nov. 28 -- Trading on the Bourse was quiet today, with the public adopting a waiting attitude. There was some covering by shorts and prices were mostly higher. Royal Dutch gained 3 points to 344 3/8, Amsterdam Rubber 3 3/4 to 333 1/4, Amsterdam Trading 2 to 494 and Unilever 1 to 167 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull charged today that "every act of the Finnish Government" since the delivery or its note here on Nov. 11 politely refusing to stop its armies from carrying the war Into Russia "has confirmed our apprehensions that it is fully cooperating with the Hitler forces."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Counsel for the Ferguson-Oman Company, builders of the shell-loading plant at Milan, Tenn., charged today that witnesses who told the Senate Defense Investigating Committee of alleged waste and extravagance were prejudiced.

War conditions and the lengthened hours of work in defense industries have reversed the downward trend of tuberculosis, a movement which in recent years had given rise to the hope that this disease might join in the near future the group of maladies that no longer offer a serious menace to health.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I would like, in the fading uproar of the football season, to offer the names of two boys who will not be mentioned on any of the myriad "all" teams now blossoming.

Starting at 1:30 this atternoon at the Yankee Stadium, the football players of New York University will undertake a task which the majority of football followers regard as impossible. But because in football the impossible is accomplished every once in a while, approximately 35,000 will be on hand in the big stands to see whether the Violet can do anything toward stopping the highly favored Fordham team in the twenty-third meeting between these Bronx rivals.

Not all the good plays reach Broadway. One of the best of the plays that Broadway could find no room for is Frank Gabrielson's "The Days of Our Youth," which was acted last evening at the Studio Theatre of the New School Workshop.

BRENTWOOD, L.I., Nov. 28 -- Hobart A. Cook of Huntington, test pilot, and Gordon Israel of Great Neck, engineer, flying an experimental bomber for the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation, got to the ground in parachutes shortly after 2 o'clock this afternoon after the bomber caught fire 7,000 feet over Pilgrim State Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Application by the New York Curb Exchange to have unlisted trading privileges extended to Central Power and Light first-mortgage Series A 3 3/4s and Kentucky Utilities Company first-mortgage 4s and sinking-fund mortgage 4 1/2s was opposed before a Securities and Exchange Commission trial examiner today by the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc.

Magistrate William E. Ringel expressed the opinion in Washington Heights Court yesterday that one of the chief reasons for crime in Harlem is the lack of stringent home-relief laws. He contended that a vast majority of Harlem residents on relief have been making relief a career.
The waterfowl shooting from Connecticut to New Jersey seems to be showing a slight improvement, but is still adversely affected by weather conditions in most of the popular shooting areas.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The British tonight released the figures of four months' sinkings covering the Battle of the Mediterranean -- that curious and smaller editior of the Battle of the Atlantic, with the roles reversed.

A procession of members of the Episcopal hierarchy and clergymen of lesser rank, high Army and Navy officers and their aides, public officials and their staffs and representatives of the fields of architecture, education and the judiciary will precede services tomorrow morning in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 28 -- Don Meade, a busy young man here these days, took no chances on tossing off the long lead he has rolled up for the riding championship of the year, and added a triple to his total today.

Let us lament for the TarrytownNyack ferry, founded in 1839, in the Presidency of Martin Van Buren, destined to tie up for the last time at halfpast 9 tomorrow evening. Let us shed a silent tear for the old boats which set forth so valiantly in all sorts of weather, except when the Hudson was frozen, on the three-and-one-quartermile voyage from Nyack to Tarrytown.

If the proof of the pudding is in the eating, the present critical situation in the Far East at least provides overwhelming evidence of the wisdom of the foreign policy which this country has adopted under President Roosevelt's leadership -- the policy of giving American aid to nations resisting aggression by the Axis Powers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 28 -- As the first New Zealander on Wednesday shook hands with a British Tommy who had fought his way out of Tobruk, the nine months of isolation of the Tobruk garrison was finished. Much fighting lies ahead before the Tobruk communications are completely free, but from now on the friends of Tobruk are close at hand.

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 28 -- Confirmation of a perfect score in mine-laying was received at Fort Hancock this week when the War Department recognized efficiency of Battery A, Seventh Coast Artillery, in its drill of Aug. 27. The battery, commanded by Captain S.E. Welsh, scored 150 points, without penalties of deficienefes, and recorded a perfect score of direct hits under the eyes of visiting officer umpires.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, First Army, Wingate, N.C., Nov. 28 -- The War of the Carolinas ended at 4:20 P.M. today, and tired, bearded, but happy soldiers celebrated the end of the last great Army manoeuvre of 1941 by shouting, capering and shooting off their remaining blank ammunition.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The proposal to send a selected group of fourteen women of the United States to Great Britain to study the effort of women in national defense was discussed today at a meeting of representatives of seventeen women's organizations with Mrs. Roosevelt and Miss Eloise Davison, assistant director of the Office of Civilian Defense.

The revival of Donizetti's "L'Elisir d'Amore," as it was given last night by the Metropolitan Opera Association, is a refreshing item of the repertory. The opera had not been performed at Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street since the season of 1932-33, when the principal comic character, the quack, Dulcamara, was represented by Ezio Pinza.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 28 -- Members of the 122d Coast Artillery, A.A., the Federalized National Guard Regiment from Northern New Jersey and the New York metropolitan area, celebrated the first anniversary of active service Wednesday with a formal review, sports contests, a dinner and vaudeville show at Fort du Pont.

With President Roosevelt publicly stressing the gravity of the Far Eastern situation, and with the bolstering of the American fleet in the Pacific by the diverting of British battleships to the Japanese zone, the stock market yesterday again bogged down.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Alabama had to travel in high gear throughout tonight to turn back Miami's surprising football team, 21 to 7, in a hard-fought engagement played before 24,644 Orange Bowl Stadium spectators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- It was authoritatively stated today that the patience of the United States Government regarding Japan was nearing exhaustion and that another Japanese military move, whether into Thailand or elsewhere in the South, would be regarded as a Japanese attempt to dominate the whole Pacific area.

Leo Waalen, a defendant in the Brooklyn espionage trial, admitted yesterday that he had turned over to William G. Sebold, counter espionage agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and principal government witness, an FBI pamphlet containing instructions to American manufacturers on how to combat espionage and sabotage within their plants.

Vincent J. Ferris, secretary of the Allied Printing Trades Council and spokesman for some 50,000 A.F. of L. workers in the New York printing industry, disclosed yesterday that several union groups had been rebuffed for trying to help the Newsdealers Federal Labor Union, Local 22371, A.F. of L., to reach a settlement of its boycott against seven morning and afternoon newspapers.

An investor represented by Karelson Karelson, attorneys, has purchased from David W. Frankel, operator, the twelve-story loft property at 39-47 West Nineteenth Street for cash above a first mortgage of $207,000.

The No. 1 team of the year has produced the No. 1 player of the year. Bruce Smith, captain of Minnesota, yesterday was named the winner of the Heisman Trophy which annually goes to the man considered the "outstanding college football player in the United States."

A sheaf of letters received in a couple of days from places as far afield as Minnesota, Wisconsin, Ohio, Pennsylvania and points between prove how deeply interested the Midwest is in its own reactions to Europe and the war. Most of the correspondents agree that the mean temperature of their localities is not to be gauged by the heat of pro-war and anti-war groups.

A PESSIMIST might say that Hollywood's decline and fall must precede its true rise. And indeed the announcement that the place has at last grown up hag so often turned out to be somewhat premature that there may be a grain of truth in such a singularly uncharitable point of view. We'll leave the answer to Bosley Crowther and Howard Barnes.

CAMP UPTON, Nov. 28 -- Encouraged by the decision made at a conference several days ago of commanding officers and morale officers from Second Corps Area posts, called by Major Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, Second Corps Area commander, the Camp Upton morale unit is making extensive plans for this camp's "Opry House" which will reopen Dec. 8.

The Theatre Guild's "Papa Is All" -- this would be the folk comedy by Patterson Greene -- has decided to stay out on the road a bit longer, not braving Broadway until the week of Dec. 22, at the earliest. Originally it had been scheduled for Times Square on Dec. 10, after a fortnight in Boston, but yesterday the Boston engagement was extended to three weeks.

The New York Rangers, refreshed after a five-day rest, will oppose the Red Wings in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The contest will be the second of the season between the teams, the New Yorkers having taken the opener in Detroit three weeks ago, 3 to 1.

DOWNEY, Calif., Nov. 28 -- Vultee Aircraft, Inc., announced today an agreement to pay $10,945,000 for 440,000 shares of stock of Consolidated Aircraft Corporation to give it "working control" of the huge bomber-building concern.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Herr von Ribbentrop, Hitler's ersatz Bismarck, has discovered a soft spot in his heart for the American taxpayer.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 28 -- The United States must act swiftly to reduce the number of "innocent casualties" of its gigantic defense program and devise some economic cushion for the post-war period, Representative John H. Tolan of California said today.

BOSTON College vs. Holy Cross -- This mignt get down to a photo-finish. Remember last year? The Eagles were flying high and the Crusaders had lost four games. Gladchuk, O'Rourke and all those other stars were the talk of the town. The big B.C. team was bowl-bound and Holy Cross would be run over without much trouble.

Mrs. William Adams Kissam gave a luncheon, yesterday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Mrs. Thomas J. Walsh of Havana, Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly, Mrs. Edwin Gould, Mrs. Casimir de Rham, Mrs. Sewell T. Tyng, Mrs. Allen Thomas, Mrs. Russell Gilbert, Mrs. William McNair and Mrs. Montaigu La Montagne.

CAMP WHEELER, Nov. 28 -- New York selective service men, specializing in heavy infantry weapons, are nearing completion of their basic training at this replacement center more than two weeks in advance of original schedules, Brig. Gen. A.R. Emery, post commander, said today.

A definite announcement concerning a new airport for New York City will be made some time next week, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday before boarding a Washington-bound Eastern Air Lines plane at La Guardia Field.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In arranging a "day" for Tuffy Leemans at the Polo Grounds at the Brooklyn game a week from Sunday, the New York Football Giants are very properly expressing their appreciation to one of the finest players who ever performed on a local gridiron.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 27:
BERLIN, Nov. 28 (UP) -- The High Command said today that "numerous tanks again were destroyed" in heavy fighting, "and especially in repulsing enemy attempts to break out of Tobruk."
Active leasing of business quarters in buildings over a wide area in the city and in outlying sections was reported yesterday. Stores were among the locations taken for retail purposes.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 28 -- Acting on personal instructions from Acting President Ramon S. Castillo the police today forbade public meetings that, under the aegis of the pro-British Accion Argentina, were to be held tomorrow in Buenos Aires and in 5,000 other places, both large and small, throughout the length and breadth of Argentina, in support of the democratic cause.

MANILA, Nov. 28 -- China's Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek recently sent a strongly worded statement -- almost demands -- to President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull on an "either or" basis with regard to United States aid to China against Japanese aggression.

Word that the soldiers who man our defenses are well fed indeed has been spread far and wide -- by the soldiers themselves. Not many of us, however, know the various classifications of rations with which they are provided.

Sporty, the Ozone Park fox terrier condemned to death for having bitten three children, was saved from the lethal gas chamber yesterday when the parents of one victim repudiated the charge they had made more than a year and a half ago.

Like a fighting man worthy the mantle he now wears, Tony Zale of Gary, Ind., got up from the ring floor In Madison Square Garden last night to become the first undisputed world middleweight champion the ring has known in ten tong years.

In 1776 the First Continental Congress passed the first veterans' pension bill. It provided, quite properly, for payments to disabled soldiers. Sixty years later the process of expanding aid to veterans culminated in pensions for all widows of Revolutionary soldiers.

A group of leading Wall Street banks has petitioned the Treasur to amend its general licenses covering foreign trade transactions in order to overcome a growing refusal of foreign shippers to accept New York letters of credit, it was learned yesterday.

For about sixteen months a legislative subcommittee, under the chairmanship of State Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr., has been inquiring into subversive activities in New York City's public schools and colleges. It has obtained evidence that a small minority of teachers have been actively preaching communism.

A general membership meeting to take a strike vote has been called at the Manhattan Center next Tuesday evening by Walter Burke, president of the Gasoline Station and Parking Attendants Union, Local 917, A.F. of L.

Lower East Side children became the benefactors of boys and girls in London's East End yesterday when they presented funds sufficient to purchase two motorcycle ambulances and a supply of vitamin concentrates to Miss Margaret Bondfield, former British Minister of Labor, in a ceremony at University Settlement, 184 Eldridge Street.

A large group of water-colors by Margot Schmidt is included in the Peruvian exhibition on the seventh floor of W. J. Sloane's. In these remarkably deft water-colors Miss Schmidt has portrayed Peruvian costumes through the ages, from early eras to the present time.

MANILA, Saturday, Nov. 29 -- Should war strike the Philippines now it would find the civilian population unprepared and unprotected and thousands might be killed for lack of air-raid shelters, President Manuel Quezon told students of the University of the Philippines in an address last night that was broadcast to the nation.

In an effort to get silver to supply the industrial demand for that metal, diverting it from its flow to the Treasury Department, Handy Harman, bullion dealers at 82 Fulton Street, yesterday raised the price here to 35 1/8 cents an ounce. Since June 17, 1940, the firm has maintained a price of 34 3/4 cents for silver.

New writers throughout the country are becoming increasingly occupied with nonfiction books. This is the main general observation brought back by Harold S. Latham, vice president and editor of the general books at Macmillan, after a six-week tour of the nation in quest of new authors and their books.

"Sing for Your Supper," a Columbia comedy with music, which opens at the Central today, completes the list of new film arrivals this week. Jinx Falkenburg and Buddy Rogers are featured in the picture, which includes Eve Arden, Don Beddoe, Bert Gordon, Bernadine Hayes, Henry Kolker and Benny Baker in supporting roles.

A total of 6,128 persona representing 3,922 concerns have visited the Defense Special Clinic train which, having swung through many Eastern States displaying "bits and pieces" needed in defense production, will stop today at Poughkeepsie, the OPM's regional information office here reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission instituted proceedings today against the New York Water Service Corporation and the Federal Water and Gas Corporation under the corporate simplification clause of the Holding Company Act.

District Attorney Dewey, in a virtual valedictory yesterday on his return to private law practice on Jan. 1, entered a vigorous criticism of political "czars" selecting and electing judges in this city, protested against official oppression of ex-convicts like Waxey Gordon, after they had paid their debt to society, and declared he had brought about the "rebirth" of the administration of justice here "through the aid of the people."

NAIROBI, Kenya Colony, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Thousands of exhausted Italian troops hoisted a tiny banner of surrender yesterday at Gondar, in Northwestern Ethiopia, to mark the end of Premier Mussolini's East African Empire.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Traffic deaths in this country in ten months of the year reached a total of 31,620, an increase of 16 per cent over the corresponding period in 1940, the National Safety Council reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- A tattered remnant of the Administration's price-control bill was passed by the House tonight after President Roosevelt's forces, facing a complete rout, compromised on many points with a coalition of Republicans and Democrats.
Francis T. Dodge, president of Dodge Alcott, importers, has leased through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., a furnished apartment of seven rooms and three baths in the building at 784 Park Avenue.
ROME, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Interstate Commerce Commission reports showed today a substantial increase in train accidents this year over 1940, but officials of the Association of American Railroads said that it was not out of proportion to the increase in traffic.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 28 -- Yale University had a deficit of only $25,371 after a fiscal year in which the expenditures were $9,517,376 and the income $9,492,005, according to the annual report made by George P. Day, treasurer.
CAIRO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

With an issue of $15,000,000 grade crossing elimination bonds, New York State will head a list of thirty-four municipalities which will be in he field next week with new offerings amounting to $25,664,600. This compares with $18,198,201 this week and with a weekly average of $29,903,798 for the year to date.

The Ballet Theatre last night added to its season's repertory Anton Dolin's "Pas de Quatre," patterned after the memorable allstar divertissement produced by Benjamin Lumley at Her Majesty's Theatre, London, in 1845, with Marie Taglioni, Carlotti Grisi, Fanny Cerito and Lucile Grahn comprising its cast.
Anchor Hocking Glass The Anchor Hocking Glass Corporation voted yesterday a 60-cent dividend on its common stock, making a total of 90 cents this year, against 80 cents paid in 1940.

BERLIN, Nov. 28 -- Only one daily delivery of mail, restriction of Christmas shopping, 50 per cent fewer flowers, curtailed and fewer newspapers -- such are some of the minor inconveniences for the people of Berlin and of other German cities in Germany during the third war Winter, Moreover, the public must "keep smiling" when treated roughly by sales personnel or by waiters in restaurants, hotels and cafes.
When the bids were opened, the indictment averred, twenty-one of the forty-six were found to be identical, each offering to make the hats for 65 cents apiece.

VTCHY, France, Nov. 28 -- Another appeal was made today to the French consumer to be sparing in his use of electric power to husband coal. Otherwise he would suffer great hardship this Winter, he was warned. The appeal was made by a spokesman for Francois Lehideux, Secretary of State for Industrial Production.

The struggle Leonardo da Vinci endured to produce his two masterpieces, "The Mona Lisa" and "The Last Supper," is the theme of "The Face," a blank verse drama by Frances Grugnard Gibbes, presented last night by the Players Repertory Theatre at the Master Theatre, 310 Riverside Drive.

Confidence that none of the steel companies operating captive coal mines would refuse to abide by the decision of President Roosevelt's arbitration board on the union shop issue was expressed in circles close to the arbitrators last night after telegrams had been received from most of the companies involved in the dispute.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- A decrease in security issues in October and the large amount of securities issued to get new money in that month, compared with those proposed for refunding, were noted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- After inspecting his command on Tuesday in a review including all combat vehicles, the first of the kind since the force was activated last April, Major Gen. Henry W. Baird pronounced the Fourth Armored Division ready for manoeuvres, a declaration tantamount to accepting its primary training as complete.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Price-control legislation had relatively little effect on the wheat market today, prices of futures advancing around % cent a bushel at one time, more because of a lack of pressure than on aggressive buying. Spreading operations between the December and the deferred futures were again a feature of the trading.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Walter Binger of this city and Fairfield, Conn., will give a tea next Saturday at their home here, 182 East Seventy-fifth Street, to Introduce their daughter, Miss Charlotte Hunnewell Binger.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Nov. 28 -- John Stromick, 24, unemployed Carteret laborer, began serving a sentence of three to seven years in Trenton State Prison this afternoon for the theft of three paintings from the residence of Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell in the Duke estate, Hillsborough township.
The 1,650-ton destroyer Ellyson was commissioned yesterday at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn as the newest fighting unit of the Navy.
FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., Nov. 28 -- Preparations are being made for the return here of the Twenty-ninth Division from the manoeuvres in the Carolinas.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Representative Fish today told the Federal grand jury investigating Nazi propaganda that he would be willing to testify, and arrangements were made to hear him next Wednesday.

After holding steady and strong throughout the session as trade buying absorbed the scattered offerings, the cotton market eased near the close yesterday under a flurry of hedgre sales. On the New York Cotton Exchange final prices of active future consequently were at their low levels of the day and showed net losses of 2 to 3 points.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 29--The latest news from the front in Libya indicates that extremely heavy fighting is going on southeast of Rezegh between British armored forces and German tanks, armored cars and truck-borne troops that re-formed after one of...

Messages of congratulation have been sent to Bishop William T. Manning by President Roosevelt, Presiding Bishop Henry St. George Tucker, the Archbishops of Canterbury and York and primates of the Church of England in Canada, India, Burma and Ceylon, South Africa and Australia on the completion of the entire length of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, it was announced yesterday.

The farmers finally are getting a break. After years of trouble they have had good harvests which can be sold at profitable prices. Their wheat crop was the biggest since 1915. Their corn crop was 10 per cent larger than the past ten years' average.
MOSCOW, Nov. 29 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau tonight broadcast this special communique:

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 29 -- With election of a new President only sixty days off, political parties today began preparing for the campaign. The Rightists have not yet made public their intentions, but the Leftists are showing in- tense activity, with the Radicals in the foreground.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Andy Victor, The Citadel's flashy sophomore fullback, ripped Sewanee's defense to shreds today and led the Bulldog's to a 28-0 victory over the Tennesseeans.

Dense black smoke swirling from and around a forty-third floor tower atop the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, attracted the attention of thousands of persons in the midtown area at 4:30 P.M. yesterday when an accumulation of cooking grease caught fire in the kitchen range of the Norse Room grill on the hotel's main floor.

The recommendation made by Dr. Harold G. Campbell and endorsed by Dr. Alonzo F. Myers, for the establishment of a central clearing house in Washington to place unemployed teachers, is sensible and sound. In its nation-wide survey the Commission for the Defense of Democracy Through Education found that this country faces an acute shortage of teachers: in fact, it estimated that 50,000 instructors will be needed within a year or two.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: The letter of Mr. R. Langton Douglas in your issue of Nov. 9 as to Mr. Carl Van Doren's "The Secret History of the American Revolution," while interesting, is incorrect when he implies that Mr. Van Doren is the first historian in America to unearth and decipher the Arnold-Andre correspondence of the Treason Episode.

MR. BURKE'S guiding principle of criticism consists in regarding all literature as "symbolic action." To do something or live in a certain way is "practical action." To write about it, and therefore inevitably take some attitude toward it, is symbolic action.

The recent agreement with Mexico under which the United States Treasury Department will purchase up to 6,000,000 ounces of silver monthly from the Mexican Government is taken as an indication that the silver-buying program of the United States Government will be continued.

IN her novel Mrs. Prouty takes up the story of another member of the Vales of Boston about whom she has written before. To be quite frank, I have not read any of her preceding books. However, as the publishers reassure us on the flap, "no acquaintance with the former books is necessary for a clear understanding of all the events in 'Now, Voyager.' "

PANAMA, Nov. 29 -- Latin America has not reacted according to the desires and designs of Dr. Joseph Goebbels and Virginio Gayda, the Axis propagandists, with respect to the latest moves of the United States to improve hemisphere defenses by the establishment of military and naval bases, and particularly the transfer of American troops from Trinidad to protect the bauxite mines in Surinam (Dutch Guiana).

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 29--Because of tense Japanese-American relations President Roosevelt announced tonight that he might have to return to Washington tomorrow. The announcement was prompted by a statement attributed to Premier Tojo that Japan must take steps to wipe out United States and British "exploitation" in the Far East.

NOT quite a Western, nor yet a genre study. "Fighting Parson" is the story of a lonely little community, presumably on the east slope of the Rockies, which is haunted by the menace of outlaws. Up in the hills above Hanover, a certain Rufe Galyon has his secret lair and for years has been terrorizing the neighborhood.

After the emergency ends it will be necessary for the schools to take the lead in retraining men for the needs of a peacetime economy, speakers at the semi-annual convention of the Commercial Education Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania declared yesterday.
Final decision is expected at tomorrow's session of the Senate Judiciary Committee on a substitute for the Equal Rights Amendment which was first introduced eighteen years ago.

The three-man arbitration board appointed by President Roosevelt to decide the union shop dispute in the captive coal mines continued its work yesterday in the face of formal notice from the Crucible Steel Company that it would not commit itself to acceptance of any ruling under which its miners would be compelled to join the United Mine Workers as a condition of employment.
MADRID, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- A high churchman summoned the Spanish Falangist party today to put its efforts into solving Spain's internal difficulties and dispense with factional disputes.

IN COMMENTING last week upon Harry Scherman's fine piece of pamphleteering, "The Last Best Hope of Earth," this department referred in passing to Mr. Scherman's major public function as president of The Book-of-the-Month Club.

THE evolution of hotel life in the United States from about 1820 to the turn of the century can be traced in covers and reference material in the stamp collection of the late Edward S. Knapp, New York broker.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Special Delivery Edgar Jones carried the touchdown mail for the last time in Pitt livery today, delivering two 6-point missives as the Panthers swamped Carnegie Tech, 27 -- 0, in the twenty-eighth renewal of the Smoky City teams' intense "back yard rivalry."

ROME, Nov. 29 -- A strong attack against the tendency of "some European countries" to allow euthanasia, or the scientific killing of incurable people, is printed in today's Vatican newspaper, the Osservatore Romano. As is known, euthanasia is officially practiced in some countries, but no legislation to this effect has yet been passed in Italy.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 29 -- Tennessee's Volunteers rose to peak form to crush their traditional rival, Vanderbilt, 26 -- 7, before 30,000 fans today and thereby dash the Commodores' hopes for a post-season Bowl invitation.

TEL-AVIV. THE Palestine Symphony Orchestra has just announced the results of a competition open to composers in Palestine and the neighboring countries. Composers were asked to submit an overture, solo concerto or a symphony, and the prize was to consist in an early public perform- ance.

The peregrinations of the premier French liner, Ile de France (43,450 tons, Captain Herbert Fontaine), have been revealed and the identity of her flag--or rather flags--established for the first time, by a letter written by one of her officers off Durban, Port Natal, on the southeast coast of Africa, Oct. 13, to Adrien Rolland of the Vanderbilt Hotel of this city.

The formation of a community chest solely to meet the needs of Americans of Italian extraction was proposed yesterday by Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti, addressing 200 persons gathered for the first New York City Conference on Social Welfare Problems in the Italian Community.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Negotiations between the Bell Aircraft Company and the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers were resumed today with Thomas M. Finn, Federal labor conciliator, expressing hope a settlement would be reached to avert a threatened strike.

ACCORDING to Mrs. John Eliott, daughter of Julia Ward Howe, the manuscript of "The Battle-Hymn of the Republic" mentioned in this column two weeks agro could not have been the original. A number of manuscript copies of the famous hymn have appeared on the market at various times, but the original, written on a letterhead of the Hotel Willard, has been lost for years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Issuance by the White House tonight of hitherto confidential press conference remarks disclosed the fact that President Roosevelt as far back as April 21, 1938, favored amending the Wagner Labor Relations Act by a commission such as that created by England to improve social welfare laws periodically.

TABRIZ, Iran, Nov. 29 -- "Reichsfuehrer Hitler will not attack the Caucasus and the Baku oil fields before late Spring. He will attempt to destroy the Red Army by marching to Astrakhan," stated Red Army Major Gen. V.V. Novikoff, Commander in Chief in the Caucasus, to your correspondent in an interview.

With the celebration of the 150th anniversary of the Bill of Rights scheduled for Dec. 15, schools and other educational institutions throughout the country will join in a national program designed to promote public understanding of some of the fundamentals of our existence as a nation.

DETROIT -- With interest focussed on possible control of both new and used car prices, the automotive industry's attention will center this week on a meeting of sixty representative dealers with officials of the Office of Price Administration in Washington.

Several vessels have been ordered withdrawn from South American services and are now being outfitted with guns and the accompanying splinter-proofing and degaussing equipment, it was disclosed here yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am writing you in reference to the article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 23 in which there appeared a report of my address to the National Convention of Junior Hadassah in Boston.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A British Middle East headquarters communique today said:

Every phase of national defense production will be weighed by leaders of government and industry at the Forty-sixth Annual Congress of American Industry of the National Association of Manufacturers opening at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tomorrow morning.

IT may well be that while we are concerned with subversive groups in the United States, there is a menace in the Pacific Ocean of which we are not fully aware. The Hawaiian Islands are peopled with Americans from the States, with natives, with Chinese, with Japanese and with mixtures of all of these.

MANOEUVRES mean a lot to the new soldier. They mean action, the kind of action he looked for when he joined the Army, the kind of action that will turn him out a hardened, seasoned soldier, ready to take what is handed to him.

WITH the publication of this salty romance of a hundred years ago Triangle Books have added a worthy addition to their list. The Florida Keys a hundred years ago; Charleston, the elegant, in the heyday of the finest days of the South; the rich gambling center; Havana, at the zenith with its heavy gambling and slave trade; storms and ships and pirate wreckers, all these are here in abundance in this fascinating tale.

THE Yucatan bush, like a flat, waveless sea, spreads green below the plane that brings the traveler to the ancient, mysterious land of the Mayas. Once great cities flourished where now the thorn tangles with the lianas of the tropics.

The Metropolitan Opera of New York returned yesterday to the air waves of the Western Hemisphere for the eleventh consecutive season of broadcasting. The performance was Verdi's "La Traviata," and listeners throughout the length and breadth of North and South America heard the music.

Opening its forty-sixth year, the Public Education Association, in its first joint conference of civic organizations held last Thursday, outlined the crucial problems facing local education today, and mapped an energetic program for the improvement of the public school system.

ONLY two years old on Dec. 5. La Guardia Airport is one of the lustiest infants ever parented by the City of New York, and growing all the time. Join the 20,000 sightseers that jam the lounge and observation deck on a sunny week-end and see for yourself what an amazing spectacle this great crossroads of the air is.

In addition to the established rules for proper care of cut flowers -- rules which help the home gardener keep the blooms fresh over a longer period of time -- there is a helpful method newer than that of merely cutting the stems and changing the water daily.

A sizable fund for aiding talented musicians in distress is anticipated from the benefit opening performance of the Ice Follies of 1942 tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden. The Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Lytle Hull is president, again will be the beneficiary of the premiere.

ROME (By Wireless). WHILE the rest of the globe has de facto, if not juridically, abandoned neutrality, there is one tiny state that has refrained from taking sides -- a state small in territory but powerful in spiritual and moral fields.

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity declined 0.3 point during the week ended Nov. 22. The index for that period stood at 129.8, compared with 130.1 for the week ended Nov. 15 and 118.5 for the week ended Nov. 23, 1940.

Family anxieties of enlisted men in Uncle Sam's new Army account for an increase of 340 per cent in the last six months in the number of cases handled by the Home Service Bureau of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Nov. 30--The recapture of Rostov and the routing of Col. Gen. Paul Ludwig von Kleist's forces, which had been holding the city for almost seven days, were reported in a Russian High Command communique last night.

A statement by Magistrate William E. Ringel in the Washington Heights Court Friday that Harlem crime conditions might be corrected if it was harder for Harlem residents to get on relief was termed "very unfortunate" by Mayor La Guardia yesterday.

Using the term "economic illiteracy" to describe the attitudes of the British and French public after the first World War, Sir Norman Angell, British economist, asserted last night that the "major errors of the last twenty years" could have been avoided if the public had had a better idea of economic problems such as reparations.

SUPERLIQUIDS -- Drs. William D. Harkins, Lyle E. Copeland and George E. Boyd (University of Chicago) announce their discovery of a "superliquid" condition, in which a liquid film on the way to becoming solidified becomes more liquid than it was.

A sympathetic setting does much to insure the success of a room; it helps to make unity, and enhances the beauty of its furniture and accessories. Especially is this true when period styles are used, as Pennsylvania Dutch, colonial maple, or -- a fashion just now coming into wider favor -- French provincial.

TOKYO, Nov. 29--The Premier, General Hideki Tojo, declared today that American and British "exploitation" of Asiatic peoples must be "purged with vengeance," and the press warned of the growing danger of an armed clash if the United States attempts to patrol the Burma Road supply route to China.

TORONTO -- The National Patriotic Auction of the Canadian Philatelic Society for the Queen's Canadian Fund in Aid of Britain's War Victims, held here on Nov. 21 and 22, realized $2,703. The highest price paid for one item was $165 for a Canadian 1857 7 1/2 -pence stamp on cover, donated by Alfred Lichtenstein of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Although strikes were at their lowest ebb in the history of the defense program. President Roosevelt and the Congress gave unmistakable indications this week that they were prepared to go ahead on anti-strike legislation for the first time since the all-out defense effort began.

STUART, Fla. -- Along the more than 1,500 miles of Florida's coastal fishing front that stretches along the State's Atlantic seaboard, circles the picturesque islets of the Florida keys and bends in a great arc along the Gulf Coast, there is an awakening to the opening of another season of Florida's most colorful sport.

Caught in the vise of sharply increased taxes and operating costs on the one hand and virtually frozen rate structures on the other, the public utility industry is confronted with a serious earnings problem under the war-time economy conditions now facing the United States.

STATE boss J. Caesar Stagg has announced his candidacy for the Senatorship. He cracks down on the Governor and the Mayor of the big city to bring them into line. He controls the press, schools, university, art museum, as well as the political machinery of the city and State.

WHEN the New York Central's new Empire State Express goes into service within a few days between New York and Buffalo, Cleveland and Detroit, another page will have been turned in the exciting story of modern rail passenger travel.

A finely coordinated and deeply affecting performance of Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" was given last night at the Metropolitan with Ettore Panizza conducting the work here for the first time. Despite the fact that this opera was the third directed by Mr. Panizza within twenty-four hours at the opera house, he led with a zeal and fervor that had an inspiring effect on all the participants.

Class legislation -- and above all, pressure group legislation -- is nothing new in American history. Though it has grown alarmingly under the New Deal, it did not begin under the New Deal. Yet in recent months its effects have reached a point where they threaten our very security as a nation.

Yachtsmen in the New York district have far surpassed the expectations of the Coast Guard in turning over their cruisers for government service in the Reserves. The original quota was set at 50 boats for the New York district, and when early this month Lieutenant P.D. Mills found he had 83 boats on active patrol duty, the Washington headquarters ordered a temporary discontinuance of the enlistment of private yachts.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 29 -- The conference of Finnish leaders, with President Risto Ryti and Field Marshal Mannerheim heading the political and military groups, respectively, continued at Helsinki today.

In what foreign traders hope is a deliberate policy of relaxing lease-lend regulations with regard to the filling of orders as specified, the War Department is now awarding some contracts directly without requiring competitive bids, it was learned yesterday.
Eight bequests were made in the last twelve months to the Hun- dred Neediest Cases Fund, which is devoted to aiding those in greatest distress known to exist throughout the city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP)--The Navy asserted today that an organized campaign was being waged to undermine civilian morale by trading on the grief of survivors of American seamen lost in the Battle of the Atlantic.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 29 (AP) -- T.C. Munger, oldest Federal judge in the United States in point of service, died tonight from a heart ailment at the age of 80.

TORONTO, Nov. 29 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs took advantage of a wobbly Brooklyn defense to fatten their scoring averages and out the Americans, 8 -- 2, in a National Hockey League contest tonight. The leaders accounted for 6 scoring points.

WINTER tourists motoring through the vastness of New Mexico on U.S. Route 66 may, with a minimum of "pioneering," place themselves in surroundings identical with those that obtained over three centuries ago.

IN the final appraisal the chief value of Dr. Arthur Hobson Quinn's biography. "Edgar Allan Poe," will lie not in his exhaustive researches into the family of Poe, not in his meticulous analysis of the poet's works, but in the publi- cation of documents which occupy no more than ten of the 804 pages of the book.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 29 -- A petition to President Roosevelt, urging him to call in "the best brains" of the country to procure unified support for the nation's fight to crush Hitlerism, has been drafted by the Industrial Republican Club of Syracuse, composed of 4,200 factory workers.

Harry Wickey is 49 years old, has established himself as one of the finest etchers in America, and yet he's almost as nervous about his one-man show as he was in 1914, when he first came to New York City and was afraid to step out of Grand Central Terminal.
ROME, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- A "lost patrol" of fifty Italian soldiers, fighting in the mountains of Ethiopia, was all that remained today to defend Italy's East African empire.

"THE Viking Book of Poetry of the English Speaking World" is, at least in the purely English section, a noteworthy book: Richard Aldington is comprehensive and, in spite of a few lapses, discriminating, and the anthology he has made stands out from others in a special way.

Five hundred home economists of the metropolitan area will participate in a special conference next Friday and Saturday at the New York University School of Education to discuss "effective plans of action" in the defense program, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Dora S. Lewis, chairman of the department of home economics at the university.

LONDON. AT its latest session the B.B. C. Brains Trust was confronted with the question "Is debunking the chief characteristic of modern biography? What is the chief reason for Philip Guedalla the first member of this intellectual elite to reply, said that the answer must depend on what was meant by "modern".

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 29 -- President Roosevelt spent part of this afternoon driving around the grounds of the Warm Springs Foundation in his own car. He turned the radio on to listen in on the Army-Navy football game.

THE good news this morning is that the dance world is to have a new magazine, and one that differs altogether from all the others in the field. It will be entirely noncommercial, accept no advertising, attempt nothing in the way of current reporting, address itself to the public rather than to the "trade," and treat the subject with the seriousness it merits in monographs of permanent value.

THE Westminster Choir College will hold a Mozart festival this Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday at Princeton, N.J., in commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the composer's death. At the opening event, Tuesday night in the Westminster Choir College Chapel, the Westminster Orchestra, under Sandor Salgo, will be heard with Bronislaw Huberman, violinist, as soloist, and Dr. Paul Nettl will deliver an address.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 29 -- The Hofstra College eleven registered a 30-0 triumph over Panzer today on Hofstra Field, scoring all the points in the second half.

Debutantes of this season and former years will aid many underprivileged girls of this city through their own efforts at the benefit performance of "Theatre" on the night of Dec. 11 at the Hudson Theatre.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- There was the late-comer who checked into the Municipal Stadi- um for the Army-Navy debate, gazed at approximately 100,000 spectators around him and said: "Alone at last!" An isolationist.

MRS. APPLEYARD proves a happy excuse for this delightful collection of sketches about a number of things in that ample lady's abundant background. Mrs. Appleyard is "now old enough so that she still wears a hairnet" and yet "too young to wear a black velvet ribbon edged with steel beads around her neck."

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 29 -- The major Eastern racing season closed today with George D. Widener's filly Rosetown eking out a nose decision over Miss Helen Hickman's Aonbarr, while a crowd estimated at 16,000, one of Bowie's biggest, cheered the pair.

A vast safety program, guided by the Department of Labor, in cooperation with engineering colleges throughout the country and organizations affiliated with the National Safety Council, was revealed yesterday in an announcement by Dean Thorndike Saville of the New York University College of Engineering.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- Judge Jesus B. Santos said today he had a sworn statement from Highway Patrolman Andres Ruiz that Arthur F. Torrance, tropical disease specialist, had killed his bride of three weeks and then bribed Patrolman Ruiz into silence.

Possibilities for the profitable alteration of well-located Manhattan private houses despite "the erroneous impression in many quarters that this type of project cannot be safely undertaken now under priorities rules," were emphasized yesterday by James E. Casale, architect.

IT is rather remarkable with what fierceness controversial fires can rage when a museum puts on retrospective displays such as the Dali and Miro shows at the Modern. You might think that by this time surrealism would be accepted or repudiated in one's stride, without the risk of getting high blood pressure over one's response.

LONDON (By Wireless) DAVID LOW, the cartoonist who began war on the dictators long before Britain did, still thinks there is more stupidity than wickedness in human existence and he asserts that on balance he is still an optimist. Aside from purely nationalistic patriotism, he believes that democracy should stand up for itself no matter how great the odds against it.

A special prayer for the preservation of peace between the United States and Japan was offered yesterday by Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein in West Side Institutional Synagogue, 120 West Seventy-sixth Street.

Nazi mouthpieces in Berlin have an answer to those who describe their anti-Comintern vaudeville performance as a marionette show. They contend that the slave Governments whose Quislings have been tasting the dust at Hitler's feet are "real," whereas the Governments in exile are not.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 29 -- California, inspired to greatest heights, wrote a stunning climax to a streaky football season with a 16-to-0 upset victory today over the Pacific Coast Conference defending champion, Stanford.

AMERICA wines once an object of scorn are coming into their own. Since the war put a halt to most European imports the nation's vintners have increased their output and developed a faithful following of their own. Faithful as it may be, however, considerable confusion persists in its ranks as to the differences between the native and the foreign product.
AUBURN, Ala., Nov. 29 (AP) -- An underdog band of Auburn Tigers displayed amazing speed and versatility today to blast the bowl hopes of Clemson, 28 to 7, before 12,000 Homecoming Day fans.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 29 -- An editorial in the newspaper Excelsior today expresses grave concern regarding strikes in the United States and says that if the Roosevelt Administration is unable to maintain uninterrupted defense production in the present emergency, the United States can hardly expect its Latin-American neighbors to place full confidence in its leadership of this hemisphere or in its ability to defend the Americas.

CHINA has found, says Mme. Sun Yat-sen, "in the new mass singing movement a source of strength to resist the enemy." Some of the songs that the Chinese are singing are now at the disposal of Americans in a new album, Chee Lai (Keynote, three ten-inch records, $2.75).

MOSCOW, Nov. 29 (From official Russian sources, distributed by The Associated Press) -- Rostov, vital anchor in the defense of the Caucasus, has been delivered from the German invader and the army of Col. Gen. Paul Ludwig von Kleist has been broken, the Russians announced tonight.
About 200 members of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York are expected to meet in Albany on Friday for a one-day convention designed to launch the 1942 program of the organization.

If they are sufficiently astute, Columbia Collegre sophomores taking the second half of a two-year prescribed course in humanities will be able to "kill two courses with one set pf earphones" by listening to assigned musical recordings while studying another subject.
BERLIN, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler's field headquarters issued the following communique today:

BETWEEN Spring and Fall practice comes a pause in the day's occupation for football players everywhere but in Hollywood. Out there the land of eternal sunshine is also the land of eternal football practice, and if the squads aren't running through manoeuvres for their coaches they are working out for movie companies which in midsummer are busy turning out football epics for the Fall.

Final details for the national open all-age stake for retriever breeds were completed yesterday by the field trial committee, of which Morgan Belmont of this city is the chairman, the other members being A. McG. Schlesinger and Dr. Inglis F. Frost.

A MORE than usually mixed list of exhibitions with a predominance of one-man shows made up the calendar of openings last week. Old masters and new comers jostled each other and, if there was no epoch-making event in this reviewer's rounds a number of the offerings are of more than passing interest.

OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 29 (AP) -- A tackle by mistake probably cost Mississippi University a tie or possible victory over Mississippi State today as State won, 6 to 0, and annexed its first Southeastern Conference football championship before 26,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dispatches from London to sevaral American newspapers reported recently that soundings are being taken there by certain German groups, especially the German Army, as to the possibility of a negotiated peace in Europe if Hitler and the Nazis were to be overthrown from within.

"TO read your review 'A Composer States His Position,'" writes Aaron Copland from South America, "you would think that my book was an attempt to pass off as a picture of contemporary music some shopworn brand of European musical esthetics.

VICHY, France, Nov. 29 -- Reports published abroad today of the ceding to Germany of French African air and naval bases and of infiltration of German troops in French North Africa were flatly denied in official circles here.

FORT WORTH, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Texas Christian University Horned Frogs closed the season today with a 15-13 victory over Southern Methodist that served as a pleasing preview of 1942 football prospects.

TO THE EDITOR: Charles Poore in his article describing the work of sorting and classifying the Roosevelt archives in Hyde Park Library stimulated in this writer an exalted hopefulness and a feeling of triumph over a bit of correspondence that Candidate Roosevelt and I engaged in back in 1932.

BAGUIO, P.I. -- With most of the world's famous playgrounds -- from Biarritz to Kyoto -- closed to American tourists, the Philippines today is striving to popularize pine-scented Baguio as a year-round mountain resort for Americans who still want to find relaxation in another part of the world.

BEN GERSON, a Jewish-American sculptor who has achieved a distinguished reputation in Paris during a six-year stay, receives a commission from the French Colonial Ministry to sculpture in stone a colossal crucifix, the sole embellishment for a starkly modernistic church being built in one of the French West Indian islands to replace a church wrecked by a hurricane.

VICHY, France, Nov. 29 -- Two German soldiers of the occupying forces were killed and several other persons were injured in the bombing of another Paris restau- rant, it was announced by the Reich military authorities tonight.

To the Drama Editor: IN the name of all the tribe of country parsons, we hereby urge Maxwell Anderson to go the whole distance and beg the Bishop to certify him to the Standing Committee for ordination. "By Way of Preface: The Theatre as Religion" [published here, Sunday, Oct. 26].

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 29 -- Curricular changes which throw greater responsibility on the student by increasing his independence in choosing his course, and which emphasize the growing importance of elective work in medical education by establishing a two-to-one ratio between required and elective hours, have just been adopted at the Yale School of Medicine.

Japan is "bluffing" and in the event of war with the United States and Britain would go down to defeat in a year, Professor Pierre Laurin, who arrived here recently from Indo-China, where he taught for several years at the University of Hanoi, declared last week.
A story of life in poverty and sordid surroundings, transformed and transfigfured by the glow of friendship and human kindliness.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Five members of the House of Representatives who have been here for ten days said tonight that they would start their journey home tomorrow sadder but wiser men for their ex- perience. They remain divided as to how far the United States should carry its aid, but have reached agreement on the extent and sincerity of Britain's own war effort.

Swift and shrewd manoeuvre is as much the essence of desert warfare as it is of war at sea. Britain and her allies as well as the Axis have learned this lesson in North Africa. Both have sought to demonstrate their knowledge in the campaign now raging, though it has been the British, because they have held the initiative, who have been emphasizing the importance of swift manoeuvre, of sudden dashes across the desert terrain.

Smetana: Vltava. New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra conducted by Bruno Walter. (Columbia, two twelve-inch records, $2.50.) This work, best known of Smetana's Ma Vlast cycle of tone poems celebrating his beloved Bohemia, sings of the river which gives it its name.

Production problems of democracy in war and peace will be discussed at the annual conference of the Society for the Advancement of Management, Thursday and Friday at the Hotel Commodore. The theme will be "A Revaluation of Management in the Light of the Present Crisis."

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 29 (AP) -- William and Mary's hopes of sharing Southern Conference football championship honors with Duke were blasted by a keyed-up North Carolina State eleven today before 6,000 spectators. The score was 13 to 0.

LODI, N.J., Nov. 29 -- Six men were burned just before noon today by an explosion that seriously damaged a refuse incinerator operated on State Highway 6 in this borough by the Wright Aeronautical Corporation of near-by Paterson. Four of the men are patients at St. Joseph's Hospital, Paterson, where two are in critical condition.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 29 (AP) -- An alert Marquette football eleven capitalized on Iowa State errors and scored a 28-to-13 victory today in the season's final game for both teams before a crowd of 8,000.

"IN sweat, blood and tears," the Bible was written over a stretch of centuries and it still endures as the best guide-book for those bent on reaching the path that leads to peace, prosperity and contentment.

THE course on how to become a detective was really fun. But the course on self-improvement through occultism was certainly not to be recommended. The course on how to be a better foreman was good so far as it went, but since it charged $30 for what could have been got out of a few dependable modern textbooks its cost seemed excessive.

Christmas shoppers may find answers to some of their problems in an exhibition of inexpensive utilitarian objects of good design, to be opened at the Museum of Modern Art on Wednesday. This show, called "Useful Objects Under 10," has been assembled by the museum's department of industrial design under the direction of Eliot Noyes to emphasize the excellence of design which is available in the American market.

Now that the gardening season is drawing to a close, it is high time to begin thinking of Winter protection, and of planning surer easier and more efficacious methods than those usually employed for matching choice plants.

Stocks ended yesterday their fourth consecutive month of declining prices with the market at the lowest levels in three years. Industrial shares sagged all day and closed irregularly lower in the heaviest and broadest Saturday session of the year.

CAMERA annuals time is here again with the recent publication of the 1942 editions of U.S. Camera, the American Annual of Photography and Universal Photo Almanac. Each in its own way tells the story of photographic achievement in the United States for the period covered.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 29 -- Mr. and Mrs. Karl Dravo Pettit of Cherry Hill Farm, this place, gave an afternoon reception with dancing today at their home here to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Mary Estelle Pettit.

Outposts of Defense The Stars and Stripes waved last week over a land whose climate has been described as a cross between that of an orchid house and a Turkish bath. United States troops had landed in Surinam (Dutch Guiana), the Netherlands colony located on the eastern bulge of South America and flanked by British Guiana, French Guiana and Brazil.

MRS ROSS'S book on the Pacific Northwest fills a needed place in Western literature. She has worked hard to find the picturesque, to help us see the Northwest as the tourist used to see Europe, to write a fascinating, informative volume covering nearly 400 years and as many places and people.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, and Secretary of State Cordell Hull conferred for nearly an hour this morning on the Pacific crisis under circumstances that suggested that it was more than a routine meeting.

PROUDLY arrayed in gleaming modern dress, with everything new except its operating crew, the fifty-year-old Empire State Express of the New York Central will inaugurate next Sunday a new chapter of service as a deluxe stainless steel streamliner.

By offering to assist in preparation of a plea for classification as a "hardship" case, the local office of the Office of Production Management has turned what was originally scheduled as a mass protest meeting by the dry cleaning industry against priority limitations into a model session for joint industry and OPM approach to such problems.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Showing surprising ability to stop Bud Schwenk, the nation's leading passer and ground gainer, the St. Louis University Billikens upset Washington U., 25 to 0, in a Missouri Valley Conference football game today.

LONDON -- Amid murmurings of nationalization the British Government has just repelled another assault on its paper and board supplies by authors and publishers who, apart from suffering their own paper shortage, see in the government a new and all-powerful rival in the publishing field.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- House leaders predicted tonight passage next week of the Labor Committee bill to curb strikes in defense industries.

Eleven buildings, including three private homes, will receive awards in the 1941 architectural competition of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce in recognition of "excellence of design, construction and civic value."

THIS portrait of the first President Roosevelt hangs in the Red Room of the White House. It recently came into the news when the second President Roosevelt met Saburo Kurusu, special envoy from Japan, in the Red Room.

WITH Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia acting as official cake-cutter and master of ceremonies, New York's $50,000,000 municipal airport will celebrate the second anniversary of its active service next Tuesday.

Doda Conrad, Polish basso who was educated in France, gave his first solo recital in this city yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The young singer is the son of Marya Freund, mezzo-soprano, who sang here in the seasons of 1923, '24 and '26.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Line plunges and repeated reverse plays brought Penn State's Nittany Lions a 19-to-12 football victory today over a hard-striking South Carolina team before 12,000 fans in Indian summer weather. It was the closing game for both teams.

Teeth and Vitamins That there is some connection between lack of vitamins and decaying teeth has been suspected for years. Now come Dr. Herman Becks and Agnes Fay Morgan, both of the University of California, with some experimental proof that lack of the B vitamins Si the food given to dogs will result in dental disease.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Swede Larson's luck stayed with him today as a powerful Navy football team, demoralized in the second quarter, roared from behind in the third period to beat Army for the sixth straight year that the genial Larson had been associated with the middies as player and coach.

MONTREAL, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Boston retained its share of the top spot in the National Hockey League with Toronto by defeating the Canadiens, 3 -- 1, tonight. Two first-period goals by Milt Schmidt and Desse Smith put the game on ice for the Bruins, with the Canadiens' lone goal coming in the middle frame when Rookie Buddy O'Connor tallied.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Once-defeated Texas Tech closed its football season today with a 35-6 rout of Wake Forest and, some followers said, possibly insured themselves a bid to a Bowl.

IF Horace Walpole could visit America in 1941 it is likely that he would be made more of at Yale University and would feel more at home there than anywhere else in the country. He would not find more congenial devotees of Whig conservatism and civility or of witty antiquarianism anywhere than among the fellows of the Yale colleges. Shakespeare.

FIRST OPINION: Frank Duncan used to live in the Texas town of Spur (pop. 1899). He was jobless. That was in 1939, and his brother-in-law, Fred F. Edwards, a Californian, drove him out to the Golden State.
CHICAGO. FOR the third time since 1935 Jeeter Lester has stuck his head up above Chicago's city wall and loosed a decisive hoot at the puritanic caliph, Mayor Edward Kelly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- There appears to be little doubt here that a full Japanese attack on the Burma Road or a drive into Thailand would bring immediate action by the United States and Australia, Britain, China and the Netherlands Indies.

Armed with bicycles and camp equipment, story books and first-aid kits, 44,000 young volunteer recruits are gathering forces in their own program for civilian defense. Already surrendering their shiny brass badges, probably for felt insignia, in a gracious curtsy to the OPM, Girl Scouts of high-school age throughout the country working on advice obtained from Mrs.

State and Federal officials and leading figures in the National Association of Real Estate Boards will be among the speakers at the twenty-fifth annual convention of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards, which opens on Thursday in Atlantic City.

ONE of the most bitter commentaries on our time is perhaps the unconsciously ironic phrase in former Foreign Minister Koht's book, "Norway Neutral and Invaded," when he writes, without bitterness, "Such happenings are comprehensible in an army that had never known war."

A YEAR OF IT: Ethel Barrymore has known the lights of Broadway for better than a generation, and it is now forty-one years since she was first starred -- in "Captain Jinks." Back in 1926 she set a record for herself by playing 295 performances of "The Constant Wife."

TIMELINESS as well as comprehensiveness marks this new "Handbook of Necessary Information for Aliens, Refugees and New Citizens" (subtitle). Naturalization procedures and educational requirements are set forth in helpful detail, but immediately pressing problems in the newcomer's life are given equal emphasis.

THIS is the third book of a series which began with Edwin Corle's "Desert Country" and Haniei Long's "Pinon Country." Like the earlier volumes it emphasizes what is taken to be a natural region, with small respect for State lines.

Commenting yesterday on the indictment by a Federal grand jury in Philadelphia on Friday against the union, four of its locals and six of its officials as well as five corporations and thirty-one individual hat manufacturers charged with conspiring in restraint of trade to fix prices on hats sold to the War Department, Max Zaritsky, president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, yesterday declared the union was innocent.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Magruder Dent will give a dinner in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton on Friday, before the Junior Assembly, for their debutante daughter, Miss Edith D. Dent.
The dollar volume of construction in 1942 will probably be greater than that of any post-depression year except 1941, the F.W. Dodge Corporation predicts.

Fordham will go to the Sugar Bowl at New Orleans on Jan. 1 and Missouri is the probable opponent of the Rams. This was definitely indicated by information received from a reliable source early this morning, after news from the Coast appeared to point to the New York eleven as a likely rival of Oregon State in the Rose Bowl at Pasadena on the same date.

IN Hollywood they tell a little story which we often find it helpful to recall. It seems that the late Grover Jones, a script-writer from the purple silent days, was assigned to work on the screen play for the epic "Lives of a Bengal Lancer" in 1934.

IF to be an Englishman is ipso facto to be a phenomenon, what, pray, can be said of C. Aubrey Smith but that he is a phenomenal Englishman? Stamping and blowing about the stage in "Spring Again" at Henry Miller's these evenings he towers above Grace George, who is hardly taller than a sparrow anyway, like some figure from the age of myth.

A series of delightfully lively drawings presents the amazing career of Adolphus the Dolphin, who was left an orphan and was adopted by a school of porpoises. Adolphus, adventurous by nature, was determined not to shame the porpoise family; he was also conscious of the glorious past.

THE first du Pont to come to America was a physiocrat, holding, among other economic doctrines, that no value was added to raw materials by manufacture. This refugee from the French Revolution founded a family which developed in the new country an industrial dynasty; his descendants in every generation produced strong-willed, individualistic men and women who wove life in large patterns.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 29 -- Expressing the belief that new defense taxes are a direct threat to the higher education of students from families of moderate means, John N.
