Schlegel, treasurer of Lafayette College, has prepared a plan proposing educational credits on income tax, which has already been presented to the Middle Atlantic States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools and is being studied by the Association of American Colleges and Universities.
CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- William G. McCormick, retired banker and a member of the farm machinery manufacturing family, died today on his estate near Wheaton, Ill., at the age of 90.
DURING the building of the Suez Canal by the Universal Company of the Maritime Suez Canal (1859-69), some of the laborers were paid in metal checks which wore good for trade at the company's store.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- How high-frequency radio waves may be utilized to dry artificial silk filaments wound in hollow packages is disclosed in a patent (No. 2,263,681) awarded to George T. Hart Jr. of Lynn, Mass. The radio method gives a uniform drying long sought in the artificial silk industry.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Washington defeated Southern California's football team today, 14 -- 13.

The coastwise steamer New York of the Eastern Lines left New York last night for Boston on her last run of the year in the company's traditional daily service between the two ports. There she will be laid up along with the liner Boston, which made her final run the night before.

THIS is half a sea and half a land novel; and the sea part is better than the land. It has two dominant characters, a sailor on his ship and his lass on shore; again (so it seems to this reviewer), the sailor has the better part.

Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, one of the most powerful racketeers in the country's criminal annals, and his two henchmen, Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss and Louis Capone, were convicted in Kings County Court at 2:45 A.M. today of charges of first degree murder, carrying a mandatory penalty of death in the electric chair.
BLACKPOOL, England, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, said today that "Japan can expect nothing from Adolf Hitler except what the Italians got."

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 29 -- A 70yard touchdown run by a substitute fullback and a tackle's accurate placement conversion brought Nebraska a 7-to-6 victory over Oklahoma today. Nebraska thus tied Oklahoma for second place in the Big Six, each team having won three Conference games and lost two.

CHIMING in on the Latin-American chorus with the usual good-neighbor theme, the WOR-Mutual network will collaborate with Rotary International to present again "The Americas Speak" in eighteen weekly broadcasts, beginning Jan. 4 at 3 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--Declaring that a nation-wide railroad strike would be "unjustifiable" and must not be permitted, because the welfare of the nation was at stake, Wayne L. Morse, chairman of President Roosevelt's Emergency Fact-Finding Board, won agreement of rail management and labor representatives late today to new mediation efforts through tonight, Sunday and part of Monday to compromise their wage dispute.

In view of the fact that over twelve million persons will be required for the first time to file income tax returns next year, the interest awakened in income tax requirements affecting them is not surprising. The new optional form of return has also given rise to many inquiries as to how the choice between the two forms should be made.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Japanese have increased their air strength in Southern Indo-China in the past fortnight from fewer than 100 to more than 200 planes, informed sources said tonight. They asserted the Japanese were rushing preparation of naval facilities in southern waters, especially at Kompongsom Bay on the southern coast of Cambodia.

Mayor La Guardia opened the Harlem Center for Active Service Men yesterday afternoon at 2,348 Seventh Avenue, between 137th and 138th Streets, and dedicated it to the service men of the country. The exercises were conducted in the open in front of the building, before an audience of several thousand persons.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Major Emery E. (Swede) Larson of the United States Marine Corps completed his tour of coaching duty at the Naval Academy with a perfect record against Army today.

LAKELAND, Fla., Nov. 29 -- Warnings against illegal gambling in the Miami area have been issued by Florida Governors at the beginning of each Winter season, but gambling has continued to flourish and the cynics have smiled.

Japan's utter inability to understand the ideals of American foreign policy has brought that country to the verge of a needless war with the United States, Tyler Dennett, former State Department aide, and Wilfrid Fleisher, former Tokyo correspondent, told the Foreign Policy Association yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 29 -- Today's High Command communique reported that German troops had been withdrawn from the central district of Rostov so that "necessary measures" could be carried out against the Russian city's civilian population, which was charged with having violated international law by joining in the fighting and striking the Germans from behind.

In a year in which high taxes and rising prices have a fairly drastic effect upon the budget, women -- and men, too -- are considering ways of getting more service from the clothes they bought last year. In such an effort, shoes might well come first.

Christmas trade gained headway in the New York area last week, although sales results varied materially. Department store sales on the average held close to 1940 figures, but gains up to 18 per cent were reported in some instances. Variety and drug chains reported an increasing volume of holiday trade, with gain averaging 10 per cent over 1940.

NOW that he has his sleeves rolled up, Charlie Chaplin apparently intends to keep them that way for another year, at least. For some weeks now the comedian has been working on a revised edition of his 1925 comedy success, "The Gold Rush," and only the other day he let it be known that he already is at work on the script of a new comedy, tentatively labeled "Lady Killer."
"WRITING," said Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings, "is agony. I stay at my typewriter for eight hours every day when I'm working and keep as free as possible from all distractions for the rest of the day.

ALBANY, Nov. 29 -- A skilled labor shortage is giving the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance less concern than the prospects of curtailed production and lay-offs in New York City due to inability of manufacturing firms to obtain delivery of materials or priorities, according to Milton O. Loysen, director of the division.

America Stands Firm Over Tokyo last week was hanging the atmosphere of war. Shops and offices, their younger men called to the colors, were short of employes. Mass meetings, government-inspired, combined with a press campaign to arouse popular sentiment over the danger of a large-scale conflict in the Pacific.

So many influences have made women hungry for the latest nutrition knowledge that audiences are ready-made today for the instruction stemming from the New York State Dietetic Association through its defense committee. There are the shifting food prices that play havoc with established budgets.

A SPECTACULAR addition to the striking power of the British armed forces is the new Short Stirling bomber. Of great speed and long range, formidable in appearance even at rest on the ground, it is credited with great success in a number of recent missions.

TRAVEL LINES: Lots of fun for visitors are the dogies' races at the Moltacqua Cattlemen's racetrack at Tucson, Ariz., where weekly during the Winter cowboys put these wild little calves through their paces. ...For skiers the E. Fritz Loosli book, "Parallel Skiing," out tomorrow, promises secrets about his "revolutionary ski technique," which Loosli teaches at the ski school, Chateau Frontenac, Quebec....

To commemorate the forty-first anniversary this week of his entrance into the home-building industry on Long Island, W.R. Gibson, head of the corporation bearing his name, will open for inspection today two model home groups in his Long Island projects.

IT is cold in the North Woods these days, but the deer stalkers, as they take to the woods after the guides are already tingling with the heat of adventure. To the best of their tenderfoot ability, they keep up with the guides.

WILLIAM HENRY CHAMBERLIN, who looks like a small, merry, twinkling Buddha and writes with the resound- ing authority of a stern, tall Jove, has lived in Russia and Japan, in western Europe, China and America; and the list of his books bearing on detailed aspects of his many-faceted experience is a long and imposing one.

EUGENE, Ore., Nov. 29 -- Coming from behind in the final quarter, the orange-shirted Oregon State Beavers overcame a onepoint deficit today to defeat the University of Oregon, 12 to 7, win the Pacific Coast Conference football title and earn Oregon State its first trip to the Rose Bowl.

THE reason Gregory Ratoff has stopped acting is because he loves to act. It seems that Mr. Ratoff decided to devote himself to directing and producing because, as a character actor, he simply couldn't act enough.

NOW that he has returned in his entirety to his native shores, it is certain that Alexander Woollcott will be reporting further on his recent English junket -- that expedition which began, as only a Woollcott expedition could, with a British warship carrying him across "the perilous seas at the age of 55," bearing a box of chocolates for Lady Astor.

Special police guards have been placed over several plants in the industrial region of Northern New Jersey producing materials for defense, it was learned last night, and local officials said the action was taken as a result of a War Department warning of expected sabotage over the week-end.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: Mr. Langton Douglas is, of course, right. I did not know that he had been before me in examining the Arnold-Andre correspondence in the Clinton Papers now in the William L. Clem- ents Library in Ann Arbor.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At last the problem of France, a heart-wringing problem for Frenchmen in our country and for many friends of France on this side of the water, is solved. Loyalty to the soil of France, loyalty to the old Marshal, once of high renown, who leads his country there, has persisted in some minds amid doubts and moments of despair.

One of the most largely subscribed opera benefits of the new season will take place on Friday afternoon at the opening performance, this season, of "Don Giovanni" at the Metropolitan Opera House to aid the Manhattan School of Music.

IF "The White Cockade" is a first novel as one takes it to be -- it introduces a historical novelist with unusual qualities of imagination. Henry Farrand Griffin tells a flamboyant story here, one which covers a wide panorama of colorful scenes.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- The five judges of the Third Circuit Court of Appeals, sitting en banc, ordered today an investigation of an opinion written six years ago by J. Warren Davis, resigned member of that bench, in the Universal Oil Products Corporation case.
Hinde Dauch Paper The Hinde Dauch Paper Company has declared a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock. This brings payments for the year to $1.50, against $1 paid in 1940.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It may be assumed that every one is interested in a better organization and functioning of human society everywhere on earth. It ought to be obvious now that all aspects of human life are vitally related to the matter of world organization.

While sharply increased taxes have focused industry's attention in the last-in, first-out method of inventory valuation for income tax purposes, the apparently hostile attitude of the Treasury Department and the expressed or implied limitation on the application of the an forecast only a slow extension for its use, according to accountants last week.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Bobby Samson, a workhorse of a back for fifty-six minutes, today almost single handedly conducted the powerful White Plains High football team to a 31-to-13 triumph over a game but weakened Peabody (Mass.) High School eleven at the High School Stadium.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 29 -- A step to promote good-will between North and South America was taken today by the National Ski Association at its thirtyseventh annual convention.

Thurman Arnold, Assistant United States Attorney General, asked Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey here yesterday for an order to dispense with the filing of formal findings of fact and conclusions of law in the recent cases under the Sherman Anti-Trust Act against the Aluminum Company of America, Aluminum Limited of Canada, and sixty co-defendants.

WITH a touch as light as the pearly fluff from a milkwood pod, or white mist over a mountain pasture, Dorothy Lathrop has put together a tale delicately balanced between the real and the unreal. This author is at her best when she writes of shy creatures seldom seen in broad day but at home in moonlit woods and fields.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- America's "bridge of ships" is building fast. In steady procession from the hundreds of shipways along our Atlantic, Gulf and Pacific coasts, new merchant vessels of many different types are descending to the sea in token of America's pledge to move all-out aid to the powers fighting Axis aggression.

Why We Plan Ethelbert Smith said he certainly did believe in the planned life -- national planning, international planning, economic planning, political planning. He was convinced that without a plan of some kind the future of mankind was dark indeed.
AUTHORIZATION by Congress of the expenditure of $220,000,000 to bring the highways of the United States into some approximation of national defense needs focuses attention on emergency requirements.

VICHY, France, Nov. 29 -- Newsprint is becoming scarcer and scarcer and newspapers in the unoccupied zone were notified today that by some means or other they must reduce their consumption 38 per cent as compared with the previous three months.

Moscow, capital and symbol of the Russian cause, was by its own admission in grave danger last week as the German Army, clothed and equipped for a Winter campaign, broke into the city's outer defenses.

BERLIN, Nov. 29 -- The passage in today's German High Command communique that refers to Libya declares that strong British forces that "again thrust toward Tobruk from the southeast" are being concentrically attacked by Axis troops.

OTTAWA, Nov. 29 -- The death of Justice Minister Ernest Lapointe, whose funeral service was held amid sincere mourning in Quebec today, is a great loss to Canada and to the wartime government under the leadership of W.L. Mackenzie King.

Abner H. Ferguson, head of the FHA, reported yesterday that the number of financial institutions originating FHA-insured home mortgages continued to increase during the first three-quarters of the present year, while the number of institutions holding such mortgages in their portfolios increased at an even faster rate.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As Count Coudenhove-Kalergi said in his letter last Sunday, he created the "Paneuropaeische Bewegung" (Paneuropa Movement) in Vienna in 1922. One might say that the idea to put an end to the contrasts and antagonisms that have existed for thousands of years among the European peoples is about as obvious as, perhaps, the idea to put an end to the plague.

HOLLYWOOD. Greta Garbo had the local citizenry gasping on the ropes this week with the disclosure that she had requested a 50 per cent cut in salary before appearing in Metro's production of "Two-Faced Woman." Quite on her own Miss Garbo nearly put MGM officials in a swoon by suggesting that her salary be cut from the usual $250,000 to $125,000.

THESE two authors are particularly successful in describing the little animals of wood and field truthfully, and at the same time with an understanding of the young child's interests. For to little children the story is still all important and information is not sought for itself but is accepted and enjoyed as a background for the tale.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 29 (AP) -- With a third-quarter rally full of solid football, Michigan State's Spartans defeated West Virginia, 14 -- 12, today for another of the hard luck drubbings the Mountaineers have suffered in the final half of their season.

Although their rivals scored first with the game less than seven minutes old, the New York Rangers had little trouble disposing of the Detroit Red Wing's in a National Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden last night. Paced by Bryan Hextall, sharp-shooting right wing who accounted for two goals, the Blue Shirts reg-

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If previous reports have been correct, there has been a perceptible change in sentiment in some strategic sectors in the Middle West on the question of isolation versus intervention. Personal contact with groups of community leaders bears out the trend of recent Gallup polls toward a backing for a stronger American foreign policy.

TO this story of decay and disintegration following the Civil War Mr. Kelly could easily have given a title which has already been made famous. For his heroine, Florrie Evans, is pre-eminently a lost lady, needing only a Willa Gather to endow her with the distinction and authenticity which she somehow strangely lacks.

The Japanese Army, which has maintained a purchasing commission in offices in the General Motors Building, Broadway and Fifty-seventh Street, has not renewed its lease and will vacate the offices today, it was learned yesterday. No information was available from a girl telephone operator there, but at the Consulate General at 630 Fifth Avenue it was understood the office would not be reopened elsewhere.
ROME, Nov. 29 -- The destruction of another British motorized brigade in Libya and the capture of its general are claimed today in the Italian war bulletin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A hitherto secret statement by President Roosevelt upon our policy toward Japan in the Spring of 1938, when the "China Incident" brought relations between Washington and Tokyo to a critical point, was disclosed today by the White House in making public selected transcripts of President Roosevelt's press conferences during 1937 and 1938.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- The automobile industry closed the first four months of the 1942 model year today with production of passenger cars falling far short of the government-imposed quota of 816,801 units, chiefly because of labor trouble and shortages of defense-needed materials.

"WHAT has become of the fighting instinct?" ask worried citizens who realize that we are in a great crisis and notice that many young men seem uninterested in fighting. "Is there a fighting instinct which is ineradicable?" ask equally worried citizens with their eyes on the apparent speed with which German youth rallied to Hitlerism.

NOT so long ago a group of men met in New York -- they had been impressed with experiments in a new type of broadcasting -- a system that reduced radio noise and static to the irreducible minimum, and greatly enhanced the beauty of music.

LANCASTER, Pa. -- This is the feasting and merry-making season of the year for the Amish, and in this neighborhood of the "plain people" the traveler these days may glimpse hundreds of their carriages clustered at a farmhouse for, perhaps a wedding.

HINDEMITH'S Symphony in E flat, which received its world premiere earlier this month by the Minneapolis Symphony, under Dimitri Mitropoulos, will be heard for the first time in New York Dec. 25 and 26, when it will be performed by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall, with Mr. Mitropoulos conducting.

NEXT Friday is the 150th anniversary of Mozart's death and the observances will reach their peak at that time. The Metropolitan will give a special performance of "Don Giovanni" in the afternoon and during the week Mozart works will figure on the programs of symphony orchestras and other concerts and recitals all over the country.

President Justice and Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell gave a reception and dance yesterday afternoon at their home, 270 Park Avenue, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Ophelia Louise Bissell. The debutante and her mother received in the drawing room, which was decorated with palms and chrysanthemums.

"FRANCE D'Abord," official journal of the Free French published at Rue Liotard Brazzaville, French Equatorial Africa, discloses that four short-wave stations are now operating for the Free French in West Africa. Besides the Brazzaville station on 25.06 meters, "France D'Abord" states that "Radio Club," location undisclosed, operates on 24, 25, 30 and 36 meters at 1, 2, 3, 5:30, 6, 7:30, 8:30 A.M., and 1, 1:30. 3:30, 4 and 4:30 P.M.

TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 30 -- With American-Japanese negotiations deadlocked on the issue of rival principles and the question of war or peace precariously in the balance, Japan is observing today the first anniversary of the signing of the basic treaty between Tokyo and Nanking and the joint declaration for mutual collaboration issued by Japan, Nanking China and Manchukuo.

With New York and the Middle Atlantic region in general sharing in the gain, the national occupancy level for office buildings has continued this year to show the steady improvement which has been recorded in each semi-annual survey of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers since January, 1934.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 29 -- The dust has settled in the Dust Bowl, the sharp edge of the drought has been dulled and the green of growing things has replaced the gray-brown of the bare earth, but scars remain. There are physical scars in land stripped of tons of fertile top soil, in dirt-burried fences and landmarks, and in crops of hardy weeds, more tolerant of drought than grass and grain.

ALBEMARLE, N.C., Nov. 29 -- The roads of North and South Carolina were jammed today with long convoys of dust-covered vehicles as 295,000 men of the First Army and the Fourth Corps returned to bivouac areas after ending yesterday a period of two weeks of the most exacting manoeuvres in the country's history.

AN industry which, from the horseless carriage days as the new century opened, developed from the swaddling clothes era of the electric runabout and the chugging "gas buggy" with extraordinary precosity and vigor to a dominant position in the American indusrial scene is here broadly reviewed.

The teaching of English to the foreign-born should be handled as though it were a foreign language and should be taught through the use of the pupil's native tongue, it was asserted yesterday by Frank W. Thomas of the New York University School of Education, who conducts a course on the methods of teaching English to the children of foreign-born.

BERLIN, Nov. 29 -- The Anti-Comintern Pact of 1936, originally conceived by its signatories as a kind of "holy alliance" against international communism and theoretically open to all nations of both hemispheres which share its ideological premises, is evolving into one of the main instruments for the molding of the "New Europe."

Johnny Torrio, whose name meant a lot more in Chicago during the Capone era than it has since he pleaded guilty to income tax evasion in April, 1939, was freed in Brooklyn Week-End Court yesterday on a vagrancy charge after he had supplied a surety bond to meet his bail of $1,000.

A six-foot scale model of the Holland-America liner Statendam, which was destroyed at her Rotterdam pier during the invasion of Holland, has been accepted by President Roosevelt on behalf of the Smithsonian Institution. In a letter to Peter van den Toorn, managing director of the line in New York, the President said last week that he was happy to accept the model from the company's directors for permanent display in the national museum.

In the twenty-eight months that Hitler's juggernaut has been plowing across Europe, America's economy has been undergoing a slow but inexorable change. It would scarcely be too much to say that every shell from a Nazi field piece, every demolition bomb from a swastika-marked plane has reverberated in some form or other in the homes, the factories and the fields of this country.
ONE night six or seven months ago a few newspaper men and public opinion experts sat around a dinner table in Greenwich Village with a remarkable young French officer, recently arrived from Dakar.

Around a breakfast table whose decorations and linens were made by sightless men and women, leadera in sixteen women's organizations will gather tomorrow to open the annual display of handicrafts made by the blind and to be sold for their benefit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The high government authority who last Friday compared our Far Eastern sphere of interest to a 'horseshoe" -- the Philippines hanging under the top of it, Netherlands Indies and Thailand-Indo-China at the two ends -- spoke of the necessity of "keeping open" the space between the terminal points of this horseshoe.

The Brooklyn Dodgers will be driven by two motives when they square off against the Pittsburgh Steelers at Ebbets Field today. One will be to finish in second place in the Eastern Division of the National Football League and the other will be to revenge a 14-7 setback administered by the Steelers a fortnight ago that cost the Brooks their chance of overhauling the Giants.

AMERICAN art is more generously featured than ever before in this year's Christmas greeting-card program. The American Artists Group for several years now has been issuing a large portfolio of cards, in several sizes, reproducing, in color and in black and white, work by American artists.

Immigration inspectors here and throughout the nation are following closely the progress of a bill now on the calendar of the House of Representatives that would amend present legislation under which only half of the inspectors can advance beyond a $2,500 a year median salary grade.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The War De- partment released the following orders today dated Nov. 28:

A firm undertone continued to prevail yesterday in the cotton market, but trading held quiet and the volume small despite domestic developments which were considered to be constructive marketwise. On the New York Cotton Exchange, prices of active futures closed with net gains of 10 to 18 points.

RETAIL trade has closed a month with sales showing a somewhat better increase over last year than in October, but with dollar volume still running below the average gain for the year. Merchandise business, in fact, is scarcely ahead of 1940 unit figures, because the dollar increase represents little more than the rise in prices over twelve months.

LONDON (By Wireless). THESE are strenuous days for Prime Minister Churchill. They are also strenuous days for Mrs. Churchill. No woman in England, excepting the Queen, lives closer to the center of events nor under greater pressure.

The National Orchestral Association, under Leon Barzin's direction, launched its Winners Series yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. This series, presented as the orchestra's annual Gabrilowitsch Memorial Concerts for this season, is devoted to works by American composers who have won awards in composition contests conducted in this country by major organizations, and the soloists on the programs are prize winners of important competitions.

THE need for coordination of air and ground forces to carry out an attack, either to relieve pressure on one's own defensive positions or to break through the enemy's lines for a grand-scale offensive, has been demonstrated on the battlefields of Europe.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 29 -- Governor Enrique Mihura of the Province of Entre Rios openly defied today instructions sent him by the Ministry of the Interior at the instance of Acting President Ramon S. Castillo and allowed the pro-British organization, Accion Argentina, to hold public meetings to affirm Argentina's support of the democratic cause.

IN this collection of love letters of "famous men and women," the first of the famous men is that King who will always be famous for his many marriages. Henry VIII. He writes ardently to Anne Boleyn, and almost as ardently to Anne's successor, Jane Seymour.

AT this time of year children, like adults, seem to have a frantic social life. Preposterous as it sounds, a great many children we know actually keep a sort of scribbled date book and go to several parties a week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- War Department officials disclosed today that new instructions had been issued to prevent injustice to men who enlisted for a single year in the National Guard or other units and soon would return to civil life. The one-year volunteers, called "forgotten men" at some posts, numbered 30,620 at last reports.

Ways in which music is building civilian and industrial as well as military morale in the emergency will be described at a luncheon conference to be held on Friday by members of the New York Federation of Music Clubs.

THE Latin-American Stamp Section of the Pan American Union at Washington has made available a background story of the design of Dominican Republic's "Baluarte 27 de Febrero" (Bastion of the 27th of February) 5-centavos blue stamp, which was illustrated in these columns last Sunday.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- The Finnish Parliament passed tonight a bill re-incorporating into Finland under military occupation and administration a part of the territory won from Russia in the present hostilities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- When United States troops landed this week at Surinam, or Dutch Guiana, on the eastern coast of South America, by agreement with the Netherlands Government in London, another link was added to the farflung chain of American Atlantic bases established since the war began.
ANKARA, Turkey. SCRIBBLED in pencil on the scarred walls of an outlook tower above the bomb-shattered ruins of Tobruk, in the Western Desert, is a four-line message which reads:

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 29 -- In a decision filed here today, Supreme Court Justice Francis D. McGarey found a judgment for $387,020 and interest of $20,834, a total of $407,854, against the Nassau and Suffolk Lighting Company and the Long Island Lighting Company in favor of Chelrob, Inc., and other stockholders of the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company.

BLACKSBURG, Va., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Hard-running Bobby Smith, 170pound sophomore fullback from Charlottesville, Va., put the zip in an otherwise sluggish Virginia Tech offensive and scored two touchdowns to overcome a stubborn University of Richmond team, 13 to 0. today in the season's finale for both Southern Conference elevens.

"Deck the halls with boughs of holly," sang the carolers. And as long as time and the tune shall last, no decorations prettier or more expressive of the Christmas season will be found. However, each year the home owner seeks to discover new ways of using the old materials as well as new materials to combine with them.

HOUSTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Rice Institute moved into fourth place in the Southwest Conference standings today by burying Baylor, 28 -- 14, in a game which would have been remarkably dull except for a few freakish incidents.

Commander Gatti has led a number of expeditions to Africa and thus has gathered information at first hand about the country, and has gained an insight into the pygmy way of life which enables him to write of these little known people, with true understanding and enthusiasm.

"Taxes and heavy savings are going to be easier for us than high prices," Mrs. Chase Going Woodhouse, Secretary of State of Connecticut, warned the fraternity women of the country yesterday as she urged them to bend every effort to stop the current rise in prices.

ROME, Nov. 29 -- The use of gas in houses for cooking and heating water will be restricted to seven and one-half hours daily beginning Dec. 1, it was announced today. The reason, as for many similar restrictions, is the lack of coal.
ROME, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--An open investigation into charges, privately circulated in Congressional circles, that millions of dollars have been paid or promised to "defense brokers" to obtain contracts from the government, was ordered today to begin Wednesday by Representative May of Kentucky, chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt is inviting suggestions from New England Governors to help solve "some of the problems that are giving us concern in the field of employment security."
Fifty-eight of the nation's leading football coaches have voted that Frank William Leahy, who has just led Notre Dame through an undefeated season, is the coach of the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Encouragement was voiced by the United States today of the aspirations of the peoples of Syria and the Lebanon for independence, and the hope was expressed, through a State Department announcement, that, as soon as international conditions permit, negotiations of diplomatic instruments may be undertaken for formal recognition of Syria and the Lebanon.

At 12:45 A.M. (E.S.T.) on Monday, Dec. 22, the sun enters the sign of Capricornus and Winter commences. The longest nights then prevail and the best season for exploring the sky is at hand. Not only do the striking Winter constellations return but this year the sky is set with several bright planets, all of which are favorably placed for observation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Traders in grains on the Board of Trade placed today a bullish constructor on passage of the price-control bill by the House of Representatives late yesterday and fairly aggressive buying lifted prices of wheat about 2 cents a bushel before profit-taking and reports that 1,500,000 bushels of cash grain had been tendered on December contracts checked the bulge.

Contrary to the belief of many home owners it is not difficult to grow new boxwood plants from cuttings. No greenhouse facilities are needed -- nothing, in fact, but an old bush or two (on one's own place or a friend's) from which the cuttings can be taken, and abundant patience.

FARMER JONES, Dairyman Brown, Whittle the Egg Man, Mister Joe Thomas -- American farms and American farmers -- are participating in the 1942 farm defense program, and all are the special charge of one man on the spot, the County Agent.

A full moon rides the skies this week, a moon of loveliness in any peaceful country. But there are places on this earth where it is a moon of horror, a bomber's moon. There are places where the shadowy face of the moon has become a death's-head, and there are those who see the hooked cross in the night skies.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 29 -- One of the most controversial questions confronting American churches today is whether the clergy should discuss from the pulpit the question of American participation in the war, and if so, what course of action they should recommend.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A Petroleum Industry Council for National Defense, made up of representatives of both small and large interests in the industry, was set up today by Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator for National Defense.
Augmented by the declaration of numerous year-end payments, the total of dividends declared in November was tile largest for any month since November, 1936.

ATLANTA, Nov. 29 -- A new and thrilling chapter in the long and bitter football rivalry of Georgia and Georgia Tech was written into the turf of Grant Field today by the churning cleats of Frank Sinkwich.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Charges that the lease-lend Administration instigated the system by which the handling of freight movements to Britain under the lease-lend act was diverted from normal trade channels into the hands of the British Ministry of War Transport, were made here today by W.D. Davies, spokesman for freight forwarding associations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- To meet the problem of the rising cost of living and to prevent inflation during the emergency period the country is passing through, the House has just voted a grant of authority to a price control board whose decisions, if the measure is finally enacted, will affect every pocketbook in the nation.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Nov. 29 -- Attempting to suggest ways of bringing "order and restitution" to "The World in Turmoil," former European and American government officials who as attaches, Ministers and delegates are experienced in international affairs will join with, educators in the nineteenth session of the Institute of World Affairs at the Riverside Mission Inn., California, from Dec. 7 to 12.

CLYDE BEATTY, animal trainer, begins his memoirs with the excitement of an "outlaw" tiger's escape; and he keeps the note of excitement throughout his book. From the time he fell for a press agent's yarn at the age of 14 and went to look for a job in a circus where a performer had been -- he was assured -- bitten to death, excitement was lure and problem and stuff of the day's routine.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Play Girl, a bay mare owned by H.L. Norton and ridden throughout the show by Al Homewood of Orangeburg, N.Y., was awarded the jumping championship of the annual indoor horse show of the Boulder Brook Club, which was concluded tonight in the club's riding ring.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- Another New England football thriller was enacted before 40,000 at Fenway Park today as Boston College beat Holy Cross, 14 to 13, on a point after touchdown made with about ninety seconds to go.
HELSINKI, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Finnish High Command issued the following today:
THE forthcoming revival of Mozart's "Magic Flute" at the Metropolitan Opera House, in our English translation, seems to occasion a few observations on the problems of translating an opera libretto.
THE forthcoming revival of Mozart's "Magic Flute" at the Metropolitan Opera House, in our English translation, seems to occasion a few observations on the problems of translating an opera libretto.

The first of ten performances of the Ice Follies of 1942 will be presented tomorrow evening at Madison Square Garden. The show will be given every night this week through Saturday, as well as at a matinee on Saturday. There will be no performance on Sunday, but the schedule will be resumed a week from tomorrow and close with the performance of Dec. 10.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Pressing problems pertaining to national defense and America's foreign policy were shelved and briefly forgotten this mild, sunny afternoon while Washington dignitaries and military leaders min- gled among the 100,000 viewing the Army-Navy gridiron spectacle in Municipal Stadium.

Industrial purchasing agents must fit their buying policies to allocations, which are practically here as far as some critical defense materials are concerned, according to the monthly report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, issued yesterday.

JUST about the last "Fight! Fight! FIGHT!" has echoed in the Autumn air. The football experts are frowning over their Jobs of making All-America selections for the season. Letters are being awarded and new captains are being elected.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Operating in the Arctic Sea, two British submarines -- the Tigris and the Trident -- were reported tonight to have sunk eight German supply ships carrying men and material to the German armies in Northern Russia, and to have probably sunk four more, with heavy damage to an additional two.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Howard Kirk, former secretary of the Philadelphia Bar Association, who was a noted track star early in the century, died here today in Naval Hospital after a long illness. His age was 55.

A tragical event would have marred the pleasure of the audience, which attended an exceptionally interesting presentation of Verdi's "Traviata" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House, had those present known of the occurence.

UNIONTOWN, PA. A COAL miner may be stalwart or wiry, stolid or genial, unshaven or sleek. He may raise goats, like Mike Ieszek, or have a puppy named Hitler, like Bill Berish. He may prefer baseball to hunting but certainly prefers either to reading.

TO characterize her special distinction as a novelist Phyllis Bottome's publishers have used a word that has been far too often ascribed, without due precision and without substantial weight of evidence, to writers of conspicuous talent.

TOKYO, Nov. 29 -- An American statesman of isolationist persuasion recently announced that if President Roosevelt were willing to "save Japan's face" he could have peace in the Pacific. In saying this he gave expression to a universal notion of the Occident about the mental processes of the Orient and, applying it to the present Pacific situation, arrived at a simple solution, which has just enough truth in it to beguile the simple-minded.

Lieut. Col. Stanley J. Grosan, chief of the War Department press section who recently flew to Dutch Guiana to report on the initial stages of the American occupation of the country, indicated last night in a two-way broadcast to New York that the "American Army Task Force" on the scene is capable of defending the area against possible invasion or an attack on the bauxite mines.

A protest against the imprisonment of five French scientists, all members of the Academy of Science, by the Germans in France, has been sent to Marshal Petain by a group of American scientists and educators, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Franz Boas, Professor Emeritus of Anthropology at Columbia University.

THIS novel is a story of women in love, with the limelight turned on Amber Dean. Born in a small Middle Western town in the late Eighteen Nineties, Amber's young mind was early stirred by conflicting -- and sometimes harmonious -- aspirations toward love and literature.

LONDON. OUR theatres still are keeping up a rough average of one new opening each week. Recently these openings have had a curious tendency to cluster together, so that for a few days the drama, critics get the illusion that the good old days are back.

Legislation to control rents, wages and prices of various commodities with inflationary tendencies has been the subject of heated debate for some time. A bill embodying price regulation is now before Congress. It is of wide interest to real estate circles because of its possible effect on rents, particularly in crowded areas where defense industries are centered.

THOUGH the effect on the travel world is as yet uncertain, the basing of United States troops in Dutch Guiana is of interest to many persons who have thought of that tropical territory as a vacation possibility.

SLOWLY but surely the Pan-American Highway -- perhaps the greatest road ever projected -- is taking its place in the geographical pattern of two continents. It is more than a highway for tourists, more than an avenue of commerce; it is destined to knit together the social and political fabric of many nations and to help realize the dream of Pan American solidarity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The upward swing in trade volume which has characterized 1941 lost some of its momentum last month, the Department of Commerce reported today. Retail sales by independent stores in thirty-four States, the department reported, showed a gain of 9 per cent in sales of such stores in October compared with the corresponding month last year.

The thirtieth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America will convene today in the Hollywood Beach Hotel, Hollywood, Fla. Special trains originating here and in Chicago, with special cars carrying members from Cleveland, Detroit, Pittsburgh, St. Louis and Toledo added en route, are scheduled to arrive in the Florida resort late this morning.

IN COMMEMORATION of the 150th anniversary of Mozart's death, the Metropolitan will present a special benefit performance of "Don Giovanni" Friday afternoon. Other events of the second week of the opera season include the debuts of Mary Van Kirk, American contralto, and Maria Van Delden, Dutch soprano.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 -- Louisiana State's much-battered Tigers ended their season today with something that, will make their supporters almost forget four earlier defeats -- an incredible 19-0 victory over their arch-rivals from Tulane.

ONE of Gilbert Miller's offering's in the near future well may be "The Heart of a City" (temporary title), by Lesley Storm, the novelist, who last was represented in the Forties in 1939 by "Billy Draws a Horse." Mr. Miller conceded the other day that he is interested; he awaits only the arrival of a script, which should be here early in the month, tucked under the protecting arm of Eric Maschwitz.

To the Radio Editor: IN an article to which THE NEW YORK TIMES radio pages last Sunday gave prominence, a number of sweeping and serious accusations were made concerning the development of television by the radio industry.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 29 -- The rising groundswell of revolt in the Balkans and Central Europe, bursting in waves of armed rebellion in Grecian Thrace and furious warfare in Yugoslavia, rapidly is undermining the flimsy unity of the smaller Axis States and the trembling foundations of the Germans' enforced "New Order" in Southeastern Europe.

THE "Song of Ariran" is an ancient Korean lament which gives its name here to the life story of a Korean rebel. The Japanese seizure of Korea-initiating in 1910 the series of cynical aggressions against which civilization waited until 1939 to revolt -- added another verse to the song.

Beleaguered Moscow In the heart of a rolling countryside, where piney forests alternate with barren prairies, lies Moscow, "holy mother city of Russia" and capital of the Soviet regime. Stretched out like a giant spiderweb, with concentric boulevards linked by streets radiating outward to its periphery, it is the home of over 4,000,000 people, center of one-fourth of Russia's productive industries, the greatest railroad junction of the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Governor Lehman is expected to propose for 1942-43 a budget slightly above the current one of $385,000,- 000, but made to leave Republicans little oportunity to expand their "economy" claims for the 1942 Gubernatorial election.

BUT is "Junior Miss" true? Every one agrees that Sally Benson's stories of growing girls are vastly amusing in the play version that Jerome Chodorov and Joseph Fields have arranged and in the bouncing comedy of the performance.

IT isn't at all unlikely that the United States Army will soon place additional large orders for the flivver planes that are just about as typically American as the hot dog and the double feature. For the tiny putt-putts that have taught so many Americans how to fly have clearly demonstrated their value to a modern ground army.

Now that the deer season is over in New York, with the exception of the brief antlerless season in Steubon County, the fox hunters are getting groomed for a busy Winter. According to several letters received from various parts of the State, this has been a good fox year.

Another stage in the life of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine begins with the finishing of the choir and sanctuary. At the morning service today the curtains that part nave and crossing will be drawn back and the path from the west doors to the high altar will be seen in its full length.

THE 150th anniversary of the death, on Dec. 5, 1791, at Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Austrian composer, is being commemorated by Bohemia and Moravia with 30-haleru plus 30h, 60h plus 60h, 1.20-koruna plus 1.20k and 2.50k plus 2.50k stamps.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Alertly waiting for Tokyo's next move in the acute Japanese-United States crisis, President Rooseevlt warned other nations today that this country is united behind his foreign policy of opposition to aggression anywhere on earth.

You have to be very careful about what you give a boy in the Army for Christmas. Anything superfluous is a real burden, as all his possessions are inspected regularly and he won't want to take care of anything he doesn't absolutely need.

The New York Rovers and the Baltimore Orioles whaled away at each others' nets like so many punch-drunk heavyweights in Madison Square Garden yesterday, with the home forces coming off with the decision, 7 -- 5.

OF outstanding interest among the openings of the week is an exhibition called "The British Tradition," at the Pierpont organ Library in East Thirty-sixth Street. It is large and very diverse, containing in abundance medieval illuminated manuscripts, drawings, historical documents, armorial bindings and printed books.

With all the usual imports from Germany missing, the seventh annual Charity Bazaar and Christmas Fair of the German-American Conference opened yesterday afternoon in the basement of Madison Square Garrden. A market place in a German village is reproduced, with a village square and its bandstand in the center.

THE fifty-three prints that won awards in the Long Island Photographic Contest, together with 135 other entries, will be shown at the Garden City Hotel, Garden City, through Thursday. Lotte Jacobi will exhibit "Photo-Portraits and Compositions" at the Direction Gallery, 15 West Fifty-sixth Street, through Dec. 10.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A jury of eleven men and one woman, confronted with 2,400 type-written pages of testimony and hundreds of books and pamphlets of the Socialist Workers party, was deliberating tonight the case of twenty-three persons accused of seditious conspiracy against the United States Government.

A collection of 1,000 original water-colors by Joseph M. W. Turner, British landscape painter, was placed on exhibition yesterday among the art collections on the fifth floor of Gimbel Brothers. They will go on sale there tomorrow.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 -- The manner in which the contract signed six months ago between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) is working out is viewed here as important for the entire industry. The opinions of Ford officials about the contract are therefore of great significance.
THE more New York drivers learn of the new financial responsibility law under which they will operate next year, the more questions arise concerning applications of the law in special situations.

HOLLYWOOD. IN a day of essential military secrecy the public relations division of the War Department is facing a complicated task. Entirely apart from its duties as distributor of official press releases, the bureau now becomes a sort of co-producer of motion pictures.

Units of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs are discovering that to have an effective voice in both local and national affairs their memberships must be expanded to include the Industrial woman as well.

IN his introduction to this volume, Ellery Queen reminds us that the original form of the detective tale was the short story. He calls it also the "legitimate" form, which may come as a shock to those who consider the detective short story as a mere tabloid version of the detective novel.

A total of $16,600,000,000 in taxes during the fiscal year 1941 was collected by all units of government in the United States, it was estimated by the division of industrial economics of the National Industrial Conference Board in a press release yesterday.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review in its issue of Nov. 16 published an article signed by Frances R. Grant entitled "The Long Arm of Literary Coincidence" concerning Daphne du Maurier's novel "Rebecca" and Carolina Nabuco's novel in Portuguese, A Sucessora.

What its orgranizers say is the first prime defense contract awarded to a group of small manufacturers was announced yesterday by the Manufacturers Defense Association, Inc., 122 East Forty-second Street, for a pool of twelve New York City manufacturers, whose normal business had been hit by defense priorities.

So far $917,570 has been raised in the United Hospital Campaign for $1,784,292 for the seventy-five voluntary, non-profit, participating hospitals, it was announced yesterday by Roy E. Larsen, general chairman.

Arthur Garfield Hays, general counsel of the American Civil Liberties Union, publicly congratulated Wendell L. Willkie yesterday for his recent decision to represent without fee William Schneiderman, secretary of the Communist party in California, before the Supreme Court of the United States when the court hears in its January term an appeal brought by the Communist leader against two decisions of lower Federal courts revoking his citizenship because of his political beliefs.

VICHY, France, Nov. 29 -- Reviewing the meat situation in a speech at the Pacaudiere farm show today, Minister of Agriculture Pierre Caziot warned that there had been no improvement and that consumption would have to be more severely regulated during the Winter.
Alterations will be completed by next Sunday in the Fifth Avenue residences presented to the National Academy of Design by Archer M. Huntington, according to announcement yesterday by the Academy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 29 -- More flexible entrance requirements for Harvard College are revealed in a statement of the committee on admission, issued today. Dr. Richard M. Gummere is chairman of the committee.

Plans for retrenchment occasioned by the national defense program were discussed by Miss Helen M. Harris, Administrator of the National Youth Administration, at a closed meeting of 1,200 members of her staff yesterday at the Central High School of Needle Trades, 225 West Twenty-fifth Street.

HOLLYWOOD. HAVING reconciled John Steinbeck to the filming of "Tortilla Flat," Metro began production of the picture this week with more than ordinary confidence. Spencer Tracy is playing Pilon, with John Garfield as Danny, Hedy Lamarr as Dolores, Akim Tamiroff as Pablo and Frank Morgan as the Pirate.
The new battle cry is from Rose Hill to New Orleans. It's no longer the sire to a thought but the attainment of the highest goal in Fordham football history.

MONROE, N.C., Nov. 30 -- The United States Army, "given complete equipment," could "fight effectively" today, Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair, Chief of Staff, Army General Headquarters, and director of the Carolina manoeuvres just ended, declared at a manoeuvre critique and subsequent press conference this morning.

Disastrous effects on the national economy that might result from the Federal Government's continued accumulation of surpluses of raw materials beyond defense needs were cited yesterday by spokesmen for the nation's industries who arrived here from different sections of the country to attend the forty-sixth annual Congress of American Industry of the National Association of Manufacturers.

Cornelius V. Whitney, president of the American Arbitration Association, announced yesterday the award of a silver plaque to the Foreign Commerce Association of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce "for distinguished service in advancing arbitration as a means of settling foreign trade disputes."

With the horse already stolen, the Dodgers locked the barn door by thrashing the Pittsburgh Steelers before a crowd of 12,336 at Ebbets Field yesterday and thus took revenge for the 14-7 upset that the Steelers handed them a fortnight ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Nov. 22 to 28 are given in the appended tabulation:

Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman head the committee of sponsors for the theatre party in behalf of the Palestine Lighthouse to be held at the performance of "Let's Face It" on the night of Dec. 9 at the Imperial Theatre. Mrs. Samuel D. Friedman is president of the beneficiary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- In a complaint issued by the Federal Trade Commission, Sheffield Farms, Inc., of New York, one of the country's largest distributors of fluid milk, was charged today with unfair competitive practices in connection with its purchases of milk products from producer cooperative associations.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 30 -- Cotton futures edged up most of last week despite numerous depressing war cables, growing uneasiness over the Far Eastern situation and absence of any indicated direction for the price-control bill.

After a favorable start, which saw them go into the lead in less than three minutes of play, the Brooklyn Americans faltered last night and bowed in defeat to the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden. The fast-flying Canadians had things practically their own way through the last two periods of the National Hockey League game and set back Red Dutton's skaters by 5 to 1.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, said in his advent sermon yesterday morning that the Bible presents us with a view of history. He declared that this world is God's because He made it and He cares for it.

The publication of "Railways and Organized Labor," a book written by P. Harvey Middleton, secretary of the Railway Business Association, comes at a moment when the threat of a nation-wide railway strike has disturbed the minds of many persons.
The Brookhattans defeated the Baltimore Americans, 1 -- 0, before a crowd of 3,000 at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday to retain the lead in the American Soccer League.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Department of Justice cautioned aliens today that new travel regulations governing the entrance and departure of non-citizens become j effective tomorrow. The rules require all aliens, except those falling within specified categories, to obtain permits to enter or leave the country.

The possibility arose last night that President Roosevelt might have to intervene to permit the State to execute Louis (Lepke) Buchalter for the first-degree murder of which he was convicted at 2:45 o'clock yesterday morning, as reported in late editions of yesterday's NEW YORK TIMES.

A proposed offering of $26,000,000 in new convertible preferred stock to holders of common stock of the United Aircraft Corporation will be voted on at a special meeting of the stockholders late this month in East Hartford, Conn., the company announced yesterday.

VICHY, Nov. 30 -- A reduction in advances of the Bank of France to the State, shown in the bank's weekly balance sheet as of Oct. 31, demonstrates that the monetary circuit through which excess expenditures by the State return to the Treasury is functioning satisfactorily.

A sharp division of sentiment developed yesterday among members of the Newsdealers Federal Labor Union, Local 22,371, A.F. of L., on the advisability of continuing their sales boycott against seven morning and afternoon newspapers.

While the recipe for laughter is the same, "Sons O' Fun," opening tonight at the Winter Garden, owes nothing except allegiance to its successful predecessor, "Hellzapoppin," which won a jackpot for all concerned. The risibilities engendered by hare-brained stunts (not all the action is confined to the stage) are sufficient to tax any one's imagination, according to reports from Boston.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 1 -- In the first official statement on the American proposals for a settlement of the issues in the Pacific submitted to Japan, Foreign Minister Shigenori Togo today rejected the principles underlying them as "fantastic," and characterized the American attitude as unrealistic and regrettable.

BERLIN, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Slaughter of "fantastic proportions" was reported today in German dispatches regarding the fighting around Rostov and in the Donets River area, where hundreds of thousands of Russians were said to be battling desperately to save their Caucasus oil supplies.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 30 -- The National Ski Association of America, concluded its thirty-seventh annual convention today at the Hotel Plankinton with an agenda that embraced every phase of the sport.

VICHY, France, Nov. 30 --"One feels -- rather than one knows -- that certain events are about to occur. In any case, a sort of communicative intuition leads one in France today to believe that the daily monotony may be interrupted very soon."

An autograph campaign to top all such efforts will be launched today by Bundles for Britain, Inc., 475 Fifth Avenue, as it sends its volunteer workers out -- fountain pens in hand -- to obtain 1,000,000 signatures and contributions from the signers.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- Authoritative quarters said today that Japan desired to continue the Japanese-American discussions at least two weeks despite dissatisfaction with certain "important fundamental points" in Washington's peace terms.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Outplayed in the first half, the champion Chicago Bears of the National Football League put on an impressive display of power in the last two periods today to rout the Philadelphia Eagles, 49 to 14, before 32,608 spectators at Shibe Park.

The English version of Mozart's "The Magic Flute," the major new production of the season, will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time on Thursday evening, Dec. 11, General Manager Edward Johnson announced yesterday.

TOBRUK, Libya, Nov. 30 -- It is early morning and here there are only faint echoes of the fighting nine or ten miles outside the Tobruk perimeter, where New Zealanders, South Africans and British tanks are locked in a death grapple with the Axis forces.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 30 -- The career of Joaquin Marietta, Western outlaw, has become the subject of a story conflict between Twentieth Century-Fox and Paramount. Fox has revived "The Californian," a screen version of the life of Murietta by Sam Hellman, and assigned Dana Andrews to the leading sole, with filming scheduled for early next year.

A furnished apartment in the building at 142 East Seventy-first Street has been leased by Pauline Lord, the actress, according to an announcement by Frances R. Jaffin, broker, who also rented a large furnished suite in 580 Park Avenue to Mark F. Hughes and a furnished apartment in 414 East Fifty-second Street to Katherine Tomlinson.

If any one were ever to take a census of the United States to determine once and for all the favorite American dish, this column believes he would find it was Mulligan stew. Nothing -- not even baked beans or fried chicken or pancakes -- is so universally eaten from Maine to Missouri, from the Carolines to California.

BERLIN, Nov. 30 -- In pursuit of its campaign against excess purchasing power and war profits, the Reich Government has decided to reduce further the margin of industrial profits which it considers justified in time of war. Simultaneously the prices paid for arms, ammunition and other war supplies will be subjected to a sharp scrutiny and to downward revision, it has been announced.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 -- Richard Krebs, German-born author, who, under the pen name of Jan Valtin, wrote the best seller, "Out of the Night," was unconditionally pardoned by Governor Culbert L. Olson today from a prison sentence for assault.

The Mizrachi Organization of America, religious wing of the Zionist movement in this country, celebrated its thirtieth anniversary with a concert last night at Town Hall. An elaborate program, including orchestral and choral numbers as well as instrumental and vocal selections, was presented.

ABOARD THE PRESIDENT'S SPECIAL TRAIN, Nov. 30 -- President Roosevelt tonight is rushing back to Washington to deal personally with the Far Eastern crisis as Japan's belligerent attitude brought closer the possibility of war in the Pacific.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Dec. 1 -- The situation on the southern front continued to develop in Russia's favor throughout yesterday's fighting, according to the military commentator early this morning. Russian troops in the Rostov sector, he said, were continuing their pressure against the fleeing remnants of Col. Gen. Paul Ludwig von Kleist's effectives, who were stated to have made two vain attempts early yesterday morning to set up lines of defense.
The cotton market displayed a firmer tone last week and prices rose. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts showed net gains for the week of twenty-one to twenty-six points.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In answer to your editorial of Nov. 24, may I say that there are thousands of substitute teachers well qualified with years of experience who are eager and willing to work in any of the nation's schools. These teachers have passed the most rigid examinations that the New York City Board of Education gives.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Liquidation by holders of December corn contracts was a feature of trading in that grain last week on the Board of Trade, and while cash and elevator interests bought December and sold May and July to change over hedges, the spread widened slightly.

DETROIT, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Byron (Whizzer) White bade farewell to professional football today by leading the Detroit Lions to a 21-to-3 National League victory over the Chicago Cardinals before 17,051 spectators. White, soon to join the nation's armed forces, returned an intercepted pass 81 yards for one touchdown and passed for another.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- The Chicago Black Hawks suffered their first home defeat this season tonight when the New York Rangers mowed them down, 5-1, before? 18,511 spectators in the Stadium. The Rangers supplanted the Hawks in third place in the National Hockey League as a result of their brilliant victory.

A pair of third-period field goals by the veteran left-footed booter, Phil Martinovich, provided the winning margin as the New York Americans conquered the Cincinnatti Bengals, 13 -- 7, in the American League finale at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Nov. 30 -- Again the markets of small continental countries presented last week virtually a common front, though naturally differentiated according to local circumstances and influences. The week generally started firm to strong with considerable activity, while at the midweek there was a recession.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. E. Farrar Bateson will give a dinner on Friday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton before the Junior Assembly for their niece, Miss Mary Virginia More, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan B. More of Greenwich, Conn.

Unwanted defense housing developments are to be discussed by up-State municipal authorities at a conference here today with Federal and State housing officials, it was learned last night when officials of the town of Tonawanda set out for this city.
The torch atop the Statue of Liberty will burn brighter beginning Jan. 1.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- With Moscow's fate still in the balance and the absence of any decisive news from Libya, stock markets slowed down appreciably last week. The wait-and-see attitude that has been adopted has principally affected industrials, where the pace recently has been fairly rapid.

Gondar, Italy's last stronghold in Ethiopia, has surrendered to British forces, largely native, after six months' investment that became at the end a violent siege in which attack was almost continuous. Its defense has been one of the few bright spots illuminating Italian warfare in North Africa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Prompt action on shipping and priority problems to supplement the recent trade agreement between the United States and Argentina is necessary if the accord is to strengthen commercial and political ties in the Western Hemisphere, according to a survey published today by the Foreign Policy Association.

Advertising for Park Tilford domestic whiskies this month will exceed that of a year ago by 115 per cent. Along with this announcement, the company reported that sales were advancing at the most rapid rate in its 101-year-old history, with case sales during the first ten months running 49 per cent ahead of the 1940 period.

Joseph Schuster, the first 'cellist of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, appeared as the soloist with the orchestra yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall in Dvorak's B minor 'cello concerto. Artur Rodzinski conducted.
NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- With whistle and fog siren blowing, the sidewheeler Wyoming edged into her slip here at 9:30 tonight on the last trip of the Nyack-to-Tarry-town ferry line.

Construction work on three new playgrounds, two in Manhattan and the third in Queens, will be started today, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks. The playgrounds will be built by the Work Projects Administration from plans prepared by the Park Department.

The Bronxville Field Club began the defense of its title in the Westchester division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday by beating the Greenwich Country Club, 4-3. In the other match the Apawamis Club defeated the Ardsley Country Club, 6-1.

BERLIN, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The outline of a religious "new order" for Nazidom, replacing Catholic and Protestant churches with a national "German faith," is contained in an anonymous book circulating widely in Germany called "Gottund Volk" -- God and the People."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 30 -- In the midst of a number of incidents in which at least two persons were killed and many more wounded, the Province of San Juan today held a hotly contested election for Governor, Vice Governor and thirty Deputies.

OTTAWA, Nov. 30 -- Price control begins tomorrow throughout Canada, with the backing of what Donald Gordon, chairman of the Wartime Prices and Trade Board described today as a "remarkably fine public spirit."

People should be more "tomorrow-minded" and live in the expectation of good rather than of evil, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Atkins Eliot, minister emeritus of the Arlington Street Church, Boston, declared yesterday in a sermon at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The War Department today released the following radiogram from Paramaribo, Surinam [Dutch Guiana], sent by Lieut. Col. Stanley J. Grogan, chief of the Press Branch, Bureau of Public Relations:

As if a sluice gate had been dropped into place, the stream of books that has rushed from the presses in the last two months will now slow to a trickle and by mid-month the new-book situation will be virtually bone dry. Following, however, in the order of their appearance, are some of the featured titles saved for the early weeks of December.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 98.6 to 99.0 bringing it to a level only 0.1 per cent below the highest point for the period 1929 to date. There was a 0.9 per cent gain in the farm products group, as higher prices for eggs, cattle, poultry, and potatoes outweighed losses in grains, oranges and hogs.

Bill De Correvont flashed some of the form which gained him national acclaim in college football circles as he helped the Yankee All-Stars top the Colored All-Stars, 24 to 20, in a thrill-packed benefit game at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Thirty thousand tanks must roll off the assembly lines in Britain, the United States and Canada during the year beginning next July, Lord Beaverbrook, Minister of Supply, said today. That was the figure he gave as Premier Joseph Stalin's estimate of the present German strength in tanks.

The Ice Follies of 1942 will open at Madison Square Garden tonight for a series of ten performances. Showings of the ice extravaganza are scheduled for each evening this week. A Saturday matinee also is slated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Sales of all retail stores in October have been estimated at $4,651,000,000, the Department of Commerce said today. This was an increase of 12 per cent over last October and one of 4 per cent over September this year.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Deep in war problems, including preparation of a major speech to be given soon in the Commons on all-out conscription of men and women, Prime Minister Winaton Churchill took little part today in a world-wide observance of his sixty-seventh birthday.

The Brown Compny announced yesterday that its plan of reorganization, begun more than six years ago, has been consummated and that the new securities to be issued are now available for delivery. The company has drawn $4,500,000 of the $6,500,000 loan granted to it by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the balance of $2,000,000 has been reserved for capital improvements, the statement said.

The Maine deer season is over now, and according to the late reports received from Commissioner George J. Stobie the kill is expected to be at least 10 per cent larger than last year despite the unfavorable hunting conditions that have prevailed through most of the States since the opening.

Substitutes for a variety of scarce materials, such as aluminum paint, zinc pigment, imported china clay, tung oil, wool, olive oil, gum arabic and sponge rubber are described by Colonel George S. Brady, chief of the substitution division, Civilian Allocation Division of the Office of Production Management, in the seventh of a series of studies, prepared especially for the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

In the presence of the greatest throng that ever entered its portals, the entire length of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, largest church on this continent, was opened yesterday morning, the first Sunday in Advent, with a solemn service of thanksgiving.

It is possible that the earth is in travail again and that out of the suffering and cruelties of today a new world is being born, declared the Rev. Allen E. Claxton in his sermon yesterday in Broadway Temple Methodist Church, 174th Street and Broadway.

Four live reindeer of the very same breed that Santa Claus uses to pull his sleigh on Christmas Eve are coming to Rockefeller Center to take part in its grand Christmas display from Dec. 12 to Jan. 2. They will be the first live reindeer to come to New York in more than thirty years.
RANDOLPH FIELD, Texas, Nov. 30 -- One October morning in 1909, Lieutenant Frank Lahm stepped into a wire and bamboo contraption called an aeroplane.

MANILA, Monday, Dec. 1 (AP) -- In the near future the vital Burma Road supplying China will be defended from Japanese air attack by an all-American air unit composed of American planes flown by American pilots under the Chinese flag, it was disclosed here today.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, was asked yesterday by leaders of the union of "sandhogs" here to restrain the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union from proceeding with an expulsion action against the local group, which has been in the forefront of a movement to oust racketeers from positions of influence in the parent union.

KEARNY, N.J., Nov. 30 -- Routing the St. Mary's Celtic eleven of Brooklyn by 7-1 at Scots Field today, the champion Scots-Americans of the American Soccer League advanced to third place in this season's competition. Fisher, with three goals, led the scoring.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Passage of the Price-Control Bill by the House late last week was construed as bullish by the grain trade, especially on wheat and corn, as the ceiling prices on the two grains will be materially above the current open-market levels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Latin-American countries are cooperating with this nation by taking possession of 100 or more Axis vessels idle in their harbors, sending metals needed for defense to the United States, and taking over Axis airlines.
BERLIN, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The High Command communique issued from the Fuehrer's headquarters today follows:

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 30 Far-reaching developments in Franco-German collaboration are expected tomorrow morning, when Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, the French Chief of State, and Adolf Hitler are scheduled to meet near Orieans in occupied France for "final discussions" on Franco-German relations.

ROME, Nov. 30 -- The battle in North Africa has entered a vital phase and the impression here today is that the outcome of the operations now under way probably will determine the fate of Libya. The reticence of today's communique, the most laconic since the British offensive began, is believed to indicate that important developments are expected.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- Howard McMichael, Scotty Isdale and Cooch Maxwell were the winners today in the Larchmont Yacht Club dinghy regatta, but the most interesting point was the capsizing of one boat with neither skipper nor crew getting wet.

The demand for popular-pricecd dresses picked up somewhat in the wholesale market last week. Evening wear was freely purchased. There was a shortage of untrimmed coats. Fur skins remained strong and manufacturers of fur coats made few price concessions.

The Forty Hours Devotion, instituted four hundred and four years ago to pray for "peace and true concord" among Christian nations, was opened by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral after the solemn mass at 11 o'clock.

What's a King Without a Cat The cat upon the American hearth, full of milk, liver and contentment, independent, judicially affectionate, at times playful, conservative in its politics, cynical and tolerant at the same time, is an institution.

A performance of the important but seldom attempted Mendelssohn octet for strings gave special interest to the concert of the New Friends of Music given late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The Kolisch Quartet, which also was heard in Mozart's familiar "Hunt" quartet in B flat, was joined by the Galimir Quartet in the presentation of the octet.

Dr. Haven Emerson, the former Health Commissioner who lends the city a veteran's counsel as member of our Board of Health, has pronounced a timely and well-taken point in reproving drives by overzealous school officials for 100 per cent attendance records.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Nov. 30 -- Fort Monmouth's smooth-working football eleven defeated Fort Du Pont of Wilmington, Del., for the football championship of the United States Army Second Corps Area today, 28 to 0, before a crowd of 10,000. It was Mon-mouth's sixth straight victory without being scored upon.

Martha Daughn-Locker, soprano, who made her local debut as recitalist last March in Town Hall, was heard again in the same surroundings yesterday afternoon. At her previous appearance Miss Locker was handicapped by the fact that she was unable to divorce her work on the concert platform from that of her protracted experience as a singer in revues and light operas.

The President's sudden return to Washington indicates that the fateful turn in the Far Eastern crisis is more imminent than he expected when he left for Warm Springs. If this means that the last hope is lost of reconciling the views of the American and Japanese Governments, if there is no way out of the impasse in the Pacific except the tragic way of war, the public will be surprised too.

Chinatown unhesitatingly emptied its pockets yesterday as members of the American Red Cross canvassed its short, crowded streets. Americans and Chinese worked together and it was hoped that last year's record of $1,000 collected in three hours would be beaten.

ROME, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- Pope Pius appealed today to the world's scientists to direct their talents toward peace, rather than war, because God, "the supreme creator and legislator of the universe, did not create man to fight his fellow man."
