WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Maritime Commission today announced establishment of a scale of uniform maximum agency fees effective tomorrow for operating vessels under its ownership or 5charter. All agency fees on unfinished voyages are to continue under prior arrangements.

No "ghost towns" will succeed Federal defense housing after the present emergency has passed, according to Miss Gladys Miller, recently appointed consultant on the defense housing projects of the Public Buildings Administration.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 30 -- A coordinated Russian drive seems to be taking place northwest of Moscow all the way from Kalinin to Lake Seleger, according to reports here today, in an effort to bend in the left flank of Gen. Field Marshal Fedor von Bock's attacking German armies.

The women of Brazil's upper class have failed to learn from Europe how to make themselves useful to their own country, according to Mme. Sylvia Bettencourt, Brazilian writer who recently won the Cabot Prize for the civic reform she has accomplished through her daily column in the Rio de Janeiro newspaper Correio da Manha.

Continuing its new policy of including novelties in Its popular-priced "programs, the New York City Symphony Orchestra of the WPA Music Project introduced last night at Carnegie Hall its greatest novelty to date, a transcription of Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue," with the piano part arranged for solo violin.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 30 -- British mechanized patrols have advanced nearly 300 miles across the Libyan desert and reached the shore of the Gulf of Sidra at a point below Bengazi and above Agedabia, the British Middle East Command announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 30 -- Five million members of the American Federation of Labor have pledged themselves to aid the government in the successful completion of the national defense program, William Green, president of the Federation, told members of the Investment Bankers Association of America at the opening of its annual convention here today.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A Finnish communique today said:

Something just had to snap when the league-leading New York Rovers and the Jersey Skeeters collided in the Eastern Hockey League battle featuring the amateur double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Bruins scored twice in the last two minutes to gain a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Canadians before 12,000 tonight at the Boston Garden. As a result, Boston remained tied with Toronto for the National Hockey League lead.

OYSTER BAY. L.I., Nov. 20 -- Residents of this village turned out in full force today to inspect Raynham Hall, Revolutionary War landmark, upon which new interest has been focused by the deeding of the property by Miss Julia Coles and her sister, Mrs. David Halsted of Glen Cove, to the Oyster Bay Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- A fundamental study of the nature of fats and oils will be conducted by the University of Pittsburgh under the first of the fellowships in nutrition recently offered by Swift Co., meat-packing concern, it was made known today.

Although the volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month increased to the second largest of the year despite the fact the month, like February, had only twenty-two trading days, sales of 15,052,272 shares for November, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, were the smallest for a corresponding month in twenty-three years, or since 1918.

On Wednesday, Nov. 19, by THE TIMES averages, stocks went to the lowest figure of this war, passing for the first time the low level of June, 1940. On Wednesday of last week, the lowest average was touched since June, 1938, when reaction had seized upon our industrial position, the Nazis had seized Austria and when the stock average had fallen 16 points during the three months ending with March.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- In the event of war the United States could Increase its yearly catch of fish for food by 185,000,000 pounds "almost immediately," Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, director of the Fish and Wildlife Service, said today in submitting his annual report to Secretary Ickes.

In a colorful ceremony symbolizing the marriage of a priest to the church, the Rev. Germanos Polyzoides, pastor of St. Demetrios Greek Church in Astoria, Queens, was ordained Bishop of Nyssa, one of the highest posts in the Greek orthodox hierarchy, at morning services yesterday at the Hellenic Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, East Seventy-fourth Street, between First and Second Avenues.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 30 -- Tighter control over steel distribution, realization of the small but important losses in steel production due to the coal strike, a continuation of a volume of incoming business exceeding output and further intensification of the scrap shortage were highlights in news of the steel industry last week.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I question Anne O'Hare McCormick's statement that Middle Western isolationists are keenly aware of our stakes in this war. Look at the Ohio vote on the amendments to the Neutrality Law. I am an interventionist. I have talked with dozens of isolationists in Columbus.

American people believe that the maintenance of the Jewish national homeland in Palestine is just as much the obligation of the United States Government as of the British, Senator Claude Pepper of Florida declared yesterday at a Palestine "Land for Victory" conference in the Hotel Roosevelt.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Mutuel wagering at Maryland's four major tracks during the racing season which closed yesterday totaled $41,852,667 -- almost $10,000,000 more than last year and the highest since 1931.

WILMINGTON, DeI., Nov. 30 (AP) -- In a free-scoring American Football Association game today the Clippers knocked the Paterson Panthers out of first place with a 28-to-21 triumph before more than 6,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Manufacturing employment was virtually unchanged from mid-September to mid-October, but factory payrolls increased contra-seasonally, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today in its monthly study of employment and payrolls.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The United States, Great Britain, China and the Netherlands Indies were stated tonight to be "collaborating fully in preparation for any eventuality" in view of Japan's apparent decision to reject the State Department's proposals for a general settlement in the Pacific.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 30 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued the following comminique today:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- With three separate bills designed to curb defense strikes before it, the House will take up labor legislation tomorrow. Passage in some form during the week was in prospect.

Only four films are slated to open on Broadway this week, and two of them will arrive today. These are "Laburnum Grove," English-made transcription of the J. B. Priestley play featuring Edmund Gwenn, Sir Cedric Hardwicke and Victoria Hopper, opening at the World Theatre, and "The Kid From Kansas," with Leo Canillo, Dick Koran, Andy Devine and Ann Doran, which will be the Rialto's new tenant.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am one among many of those who have great respect and admiration for Anne O'Hare McCormick's keen powers of analysis. However, her Nov. 24 article, "As Viewed From the Other Side of the Hudson River," left me unusually cold.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- Acting President Ramon S. Castillo tonight reiterated his determination not to allow the Administration's foreign policy to be affected by any group.

MOST people have heard of Nathaniel Bowditch of Salem, but probably not one person in a hundred, except in darkest Massachusetts, knows exactly who he is, or was. Bowditch, Bowditch -- well, the name sounds familiar enough. He wrote a book, didn't he?

The Chase National Bank has been appointed dividend disbursing agent for the Joy Manufacturing Company's common stock and also transfer agent for the cumulative convertible preferred stock and registrar for the common stock of the Pennsylvania-Central Airlines Corporation.
A 14-year-old Negro was shot by a patrolman early yesterday morning when the boy was seen sawing the bars of a rear window of a grocery at 141 West 144th Street.

BUFFALO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- C.I.O. workers at the Bell Aircraft Corporation's warplane plants in Buffalo and Niagara Falls, seeking wage increases, a union shop and other concessions, voted today to strike Wednesday at 8 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- President Roosevelt, who is known to be greatly concerned over the lack of progress in the government's home-building for defense workers is expected to appeal to Congressional leaders soon for prompt appropriation of the additional $300,000,000 he has asked, high Administration officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Green Bay Packers struck through the air for three touchdowns in the second half to trounce Washington, 22 to 17, today as Don Hutson, the old Alabama flash, shattered three National Football League scoring records.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A definite prospect for settling the threatened nation-wide railway strike by a compromise wage increase was reported tonight as President Roosevelt's emergency fact-finding board worked against the clock in separate mediation conferences with the contending parties.

A composite portrait of the so-called "anti-strike" bills now under consideration in Congress is far from reassuring. Even after the appalling demonstration we have had in recent months of the present power of labor union leaders and the reckless use that some of them make of that power, there is evidently to be no real reform of the situation.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- A program to make possible the payment of State income taxes in four equal installments was announced today by Abbot Low Moffat, chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee. It would involve the change of the start of the State fiscal year from July 1 to April 1.

THOSE recent engagements on the gridiron practically closed the college books for the football season of 1941. The hero of the Autumn campaign in the East was the Weather Man. His work was wonderful. The hope here is that he isn't lost through graduation next June.

The great heroes of the Bible were politicians in the right sense of the term, said the Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw in his sermon yesterday in Fort Washington Presbyterian Church. Wadsworth Avenue and 174th Street.

WITH NEWZEALAND FORCES, Near Bir el-Hamed, Libya, Nov. 29 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- General von Ravenstein, commander of the Twenty-first German Panzer Division, was captured this morning by a British Bren-gun crew.

Miss N. May Karff of Boston, with four straight victories to her credit in her current match with Mrs. Donald Belcher, woman chess champion of the United States, is counted as practically a certain winner of the title, since she needs to draw only one game of the remaining four in order to clinch her claim to the honors.

At the points of a gigantic triangle three great battles are raging, the outcome of which may determine the future course of the war. Two of them are in Russia before Moscow and Rostov, 600 miles to the south. The third is in the Libyan Desert of Africa, double that distance away.

It has been apparent for a long time that the labor situation in the United States is drifting toward a crisis, according to the December letter of the National City Bank of New York, which adds that the cost of industrial disunity to the country was already heavy when the defense program was started.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Class I railroads had an estimated net income of 5408,625,472 in the first ten months of 1941, the Association of American Railroads reported today. The corresponding figure for 1940 was 5100,932,114. Net operating income amounted to 846,824,141, compared with $532,132,247 in the same period of 1940.
The members of the Ice Follies cast proved again last night that they knew how to provide enjoyable entertainment.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 1 -- Organized Housewives of Syracuse decided at a public meeting today to reduce consumption of milk as a protest against raising of the price from 14 to 15 cents a quart, effective this morning. They set a period of two weeks during which condensed milk or other substitutes would be used in an effort to have the milk companies rescind the price increase.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 1 -- Following the government's new interpretation of Argentine neutrality which consists of forbidding any public manifestation of sympathy for or aversion to either of the belligerents in the European war, the police today forbade a meeting of the Association of Anti-Nazi Journalists and Artists.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- The Russian High Command said tonight that the steadfast defenders of Moscow had beaten off powerful German attacks and that Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's Southern Army was driving westward on the heels of Axis forces in panicky retreat through the Eastern Ukraine.

Selling spinach is more exciting than practicing law. At least, that's the report of one enterprising young man who used to pore over briefs and append codicils in a musty Manhattan office. After five years of it, he suddenly "slammed the board and cried 'no more -- I will away.' "

Though the absence of an outstanding team on the Pacific Coast caused the average attendance to take an amazing tumble in that section, the rest of the country has just waded through the most prosperous football season on record. Athletic treasuries should be bulging.

Aided by an extra Sunday in comparison with November of last year, advertising linage for eight New York newspapers spurted 10.4 per cent last month, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. All classifications, except automotive, registered an increase, while only two of the eight dailies failed to show gains.
LONDON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique issued today:

Mr. and Mrs. E. Mortimer Ward and Mr. and Mrs. Abel I. Smith will give a reception on Dec. 23 at the clubhouse of the National Society of Colonial Dames, 215 East Seventy-first Street, to introduce to society Miss Mary Paige Cartmell, daughter of Mrs. Smith and granddaughter of Mrs. Ward.

A group of investors has purchased from David S. Meister, operator, after an ownership of but a few months, the ten-story loft building at 10 Waverly Place, on the southwest corner of Mercer Street, assessed for $56,000.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 1 -- The last of the delegates to the National Ski Association's three-day convention departed for their homes today.
MOSCOW, Dec. 1 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

Two men were talking across a luncheon table yesterday. Sam Goldwyn of Hollywood and Ed Barrow of New York. A double feature, with sound. They never had met before. But each knew what the other had been doing for years. Sam Goldwyn was doing all right in the moving picture industry. Ed Barrow was doing better than fair-to-middling in the baseball business.

The Woman's Auxiliary of the Episcopal Diocese of New York will meet in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine at 10:30 A.M. today, as part of the week-long program at the cathedral to celebrate the opening of the edifice in its entirety.

A new issue of $4,400,000 of city of Cincinnati, Ohio, rapid transit refunding bonds, due on Sept. 1, 1943 to 1966, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate headed by Lazard Freres Co. The price paid was 101,21999, with the bankers naming the interest rate as 1 1/4 per cent.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 30 (delayed) -- The recapture of Rostov, with the repulse of the Axis forces driving on the Caucasus, is looked upon here as the second decisive Russian victory of the war, and both are viewed as products of Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's administration and strategy.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A Finnish communique issued today:

Among the hitherto confidential remarks now revealed for the first time, with the publication of the second set of the President's public papers in book form, are those at one astonishing press conference on April 21, 1938. It was an off-the-record interview with members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Mrs. Roosevelt has received, and hopes some time to be able to accept, an invitation to visit all the countries of Central and South America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A threatened nation-wide railway strike of 1,200,000 workers was averted late today by agreement on a compromise wage increase which is reported to raise the carriers annual outlay by $300,000,000 to $325,000,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 -- Paramount acquired two story properties today for production next year. "Red Harvest," a novel by Dashiell Hammett, published in 1927, was purchased to replace the projected remake of Hammett's "The Glass Key" on the studio's schedule, and "Connie Goes Home," a magazine story written by Fannie Kilbourn in 1921 and later dramatized by Edward Childs Carpenter, was bought for early Spring filming.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Secretary Morgenthau issued a message to United States taxpayers today, three weeks before Christmas, urging them to consult their local banks, savings and loan associations or employers about arranging a savings plan to meet next year's income tax payments.

Lew Jenkins, the world lightweight champion, has been summoned to appear before the State Athletic Commission this afternoon for a thorough physical examination, the fourth to which he has been subjected by the board since his disappointing battle against Freddie (Red) Cochrane, world welterweight titleholder, on Oct. 6.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 1 -- Major Gen. George H. Brett, chief of the United States Army Air Corps, who arrived in Cairo from Britain early on Sunday as an observer, disclosed today that while en route he had become the first American general actually to have Axis guns fired in his direction.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 1 -- Henry Gornicki, lanky young righthanded pitcher who won one and lost none for the Cardinals last season, was bought tonight by the Pirates in a straight cash deal.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 1 -- A return to true capitalism is America's only salvation, Emmett F. Connely, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, declared here today.

The ways of German propaganda in this war are harder to fathom than those of the last war. There must be a purpose in the Nazi attacks on Christianity and in Berlin's willingness to have those attacks broadcast in this country. One can't readily grasp what the purpose is.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- British successes in the "war of the sands" and German reverses in Russia apparently combined today to ease slightly the American-Japanese tension.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- When railroad labor and management representatives settled their wage and vacations dispute tonight. Dean Wayne L. Morse, chairman of President Roosevelt's emergency fact-finding board, emphasized that the board had been sitting as a mediation agency since Saturday night, and that the board was acting in a mediating capacity, and not as a fact-finding body when the agreement was reached.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Prices of hogs were steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher in the livestock market today as producers curtailed shipments below expectations. Dressed markets improved slightly. Light loins were still quoted at 17 to 17 1/2 cents a pound, the low for several months, but pork trimmings sold strong to 50 cents higher.

The proposal of Abbot Low Moffat, chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, that the payment of New York State income taxes be permitted in four equal quarterly installments is a good one. As matters now stand one-half of the State income tax must be paid on April 15 and the balance in two equal installments, June 15 and Oct. 15.

Calling upon the legal profession to exert its influence in working for an immediate declaration of war against Germany, a Bishop and an economist yesterday launched a national lawyers division of the Fight for Freedom Committee.

TOBRUK, Libya, Nov. 30 (Delayed) -- Charging in the darkness with fixed bayonets, Australian, New Zealand and British infantry routed German machine-gunners from posts around Ed Duda early today and re-established the British hold on the position.

The exact number is a military secret, but it is known that there are more than 1,000 American-built tanks engaged in the fighting against Axis armies in the Western Desert. They represent the best that American inventive genius and industrial capacity can produce.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The General Shoe Corporation of Nash

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Provision of more money for badly needed defense housing met a serious check today when the House refused to suspend its rules and vote an additional $300,000,000 immediately. The appropriation bill, which was reported last week by the Public Buildings and Grounds Committee, now must wait until the Rules Committee decides to bring it up.

Salvatore Sabbatino, vice president of a stevedoring concern, who shot and killed Emil Camarada, vice president of the Atlantic Seaboard branch of the International Longshoremen's Association, was permitted yesterday to take a plea of guilty to first-degree manslaughter in General Sessions, thus escaping the possibility of a death penalty.

Fordham's football forces finally settled down yesterday from the excitement of the week-end, which saw them conclude their regular season with a victory over New York University and receive an invitation to meet Missouri in the Sugar Bowl at New Orleans on New Year's Day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President Roosevelt returned from Warm Springs and immediately conferred with officials on the crisis with Japan. Among those he saw were Secretary Hull, Admiral Stark, Harry Hopkins and Under - Secretary Welles.

The alarming nose-dive into which the Brooklyn Americans fell over the past week-end had its repercussions yesterday. Manager Red Button subjected his squad to one of the biggest shake-ups a National Hockey League combination has experienced in recent years.

Net profits of 167 representative commercial and industrial companies rose approximately 10 per cent in the third quarter of this year, the monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.

For the second time in little over a year a production of "Twelfth Night," by William Shakespeare, will open tonight on Broadway. The revival will be submitted by the Chekov Theatre Players at the Little Theatre in a production devised by Michael Chekov.

The premiere of the Ice Follies of 1942 at Madison Square Garden last night was the occasion for many prefatory dinner parties given by boxholders, patrons and patronesses and other subscribers actively interested in the beneficiary of the event -- the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Lytle Hull is president.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- War dispatches reported today that three Axis armored divisions in Libya, having failed in a concerted

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- The first "sudden death" provision in National Football League history was arranged today to settle the Western Division championship in case the Chicago Bears and Green Bay end the season in a tie and are deadlocked at the end of regulation playing time in their play-off game.

One hundred and eighteen years age today an American President formulated a doctrine which is still the keystone of our foreign policy. That doctrine, as it shaped itself with time, declared that the United States would oppose with all its force any extension of non-American sovereignty in the Western Hemisphere and equally oppose the transfer of any part of the Western Hemisphere from one non-American Power to another.

The first "Tannhaeuser" of the season, last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, had a deserved success. The opera can have inordinate longeurs, and not only in the too long-winded contest of song, which is now mercifully curtailed for us. We liked Mr. Leinsdorf's tempi, which move but are not hurried or spasmodic, and which impart true vitality, without undue theatricalism to the score.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A way of detecting the beginnings of cancer or tumor in brain cells even before the growth becomes large enough to be seen with an ordinary microscope was reported to the Radiological Society of North America today by Dr. E.R. Witwer of Detroit.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 1 -- Charles W. Holman of Washington, D.C., secretary of the National Cooperative Milk Producers Federation, labeled the House-approved price control bill tonight "a betrayal of agriculture produced by the time-honored method of picking upon the little fellow."

United Aircraft The stock market showed yesterday its customary reaction to new stock financing by bearing down heavily on United Aircraft, which fell two points to 32 1/2, which is 1 3/4 points under the former low point of 1941 and compares with a year's high of 44 3/8.

Dress Activity Expands Retailer response to initial showings of better-grade Spring dresses has been favorable and indications yesterday were that December showroom activity will be considerable. The Fashion Originators Guild of America announced yesterday that during the next two weeks all of its members will have available "authentic originations for Spring in sufficient diversity to provide retailers with wellrounded stocks."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The House began debate today on legislation designed to prevent work stoppages in defense industries under a rule so broad that at least four different bills will be considered before the final vote, expected Wednesday night.

ROME, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- Italy today shook up her air force command again and Premier Mussolini's newspaper, acknowledging that Italians were worried by the situation in Libya, predicted that the nation would have to face great sacrifices before the war is over.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 1 -- In a discussion of Pacific developments at an emergency meeting the War Cabinet today agreed upon an important message to the British Government, setting forth Australia's views on the situation. Afterward, Premier John Curtins announced that the War Cabinet meeting previously planned to be held in Canberra Thursday, would be transferred to Melbourne, apparently to be nearer the defense services' headquarters.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1-- Six Midwest Governors and representatives of eight other States were advised today by Mayor La Guardia of New York, Director of the Office of Civilian Defense, to induce factory managements to provide their own first aid, fire and repair squadrons against enemy attack.

A waltz fashion show enlisting several debutantes of the season and their escorts has been arranged as a novel feature of the December Ball to be given Thursday night in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton as the annual benefit dance for Grosvenor Neighborhood House.

ALBANY, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Southern Railway Company went before the Court of Appeals today asking judicial permission to discontinue payments on trust certificates issued forty years ago to stockholders of the now defund Mobile Ohio Railroad.

The proposal to split the National Broadcasting Company's WEAF Red anl WJZ Blue networks and incorporate the latter as a subsidiary of either NBC or the Radio Corporation of America, parent company of NBC, now awaits only the action of the organization's board of directors, it was learned yesterday.

As a result of the war, Argentina has realized the necessity for developing her own merchant marine and is taking steps which it is hoped will make shipping a major industry in that country after the conflict ends, Dr. Juan Cullen Crisol, general manager of the Argentine-Brazilian Chamber of Commerce, said yesterday when he arrived here on the American Republics liner Brazil.

The report of the Outboard, Marine and Manufacturing Company for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday by Ralph Evinrude, president, disclosed a consolidated net profit of $1,519,129 after write-down of inventories of refrigerators and parts, income and excess profits taxes and $216,864 special reserve for possible future losses on inventories, service to customers and other contingencies.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade today was the broadest in some time, with an expansion in public interest in the markets as a result of a Department of Agriculture prediction for higher prices next year, the tense Far Eastern situation and a let-up in liquidation by holders of December contracts.

DALLAS, Dec. 1 -- Colorful Alabama -- the famed Crimson Tide that swept to three Rose Bowl triumphs -- is coming to Dallas to play Texas A. and M., champion of the Southwest Conference. It will be a Cotton Bowl date Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Nov. 26 aggregated $10,027,OO0,000.

Christmas cards that have survived from the early days of printed Christmas greetings will be placed on exhibition today at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. The show, entitled "The Same Old Wish," consists of 200 Christmas cards dating from 1870 to 1905.

Anthony H. Marston, president of the Ramsey Business Systems, soon will join the tenantry of the Southgate apartment group, having taken quarters in the building at 424 East Fifty-second Street through the Gresham Realty Company, Inc.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The sinking of an armed merchant raider in the South Atlantic by the cruiser Devonshire was announced by the Admiralty tonight in a communique that was lacking in many details.

The second annual meeting of the Board of Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Church, which began on Nov. 24, held its first general session last night in the chapel of the Methodist Building at 150 Fifth Avenue. Attending were 200 delegates, representing every State and including forty Bishops.

THREE and a half years ago the first installment of Franklin D. Roosevelt's "Public Papers and Addresses" appeared in five large volumes. These covered his terms as Governor of New York State and the first term in the White House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- At the Office of Production Management the executive staff today is happily echoing something Co-Director Knudsen said very recently, after consulting his charts. "Everything is in production now."

After a brief pause for motionpicture high-jinks, Ole Olsen and Chic Johnson have returned to the scene of former triumph. "Sons o' Fun" is the title of their new cornshucking bee, which was played in most parts of the Winter Garden last evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Two House committees today projected investigations, to start Wednesday, into lobbying activities in connection with defense contracts, while Representative Jones (D.) of Ohio denounced on the House floor a publication which he accused of soliciting advertising from arms suppliers on the false representation that it was connected with the Democratic party.

Under orders from President Roosevelt, the medical and dental divisions of the Selective Service system are now mapping a program under which many men who have been rejected for unfitness will be rehabilitated and taken into the Army, it was reported here yesterday at the opening of the seventeenth annual Greater New York dental meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 1 -- A succession of developments in Singapore and Malaya today reflected the steadily growing menace of war between Japan and the democratic front. In a dramatic announcement this morning Governor Sir Shenton Thomas declared a state of emergency and issued a proclamation calling up army, navy and air force volunteers for active duty throughout Malaya.

A warning against any attempt by the government to make arbitration of labor disputes compulsory or to intervene in determining the process and naming the arbitrators is made by Miss Frances Kellor, executive vice president of the American Arbitration Association, in a foreword to the forthcoming number of the Arbitration Journal.

Continued apprehension over the situation in the Far East restrained cotton traders yesterday and as a result the cotton market was thin and quiet. Final prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 3 points lower to 1 point higher than on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 26; A decrease of $30,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans; increases of $173,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and $260,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $124,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

Leo Waalen, a defendant in the Brooklyn espionage trial, testified yesterday that he had turned over to William G. Sebold, counterespionage agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and principal government witness, a highly confidential pamphlet issued by the FBI on the protection of American industrial plants, although he had reason to believe that Sebold was a German espionage agent.

The failure of Federal officials to cooperate in planning defense housing developments was stressed by Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti at a conference yesterday in the office of State Housing Commissioner Edward Weinfeld at the State Building, 80 Center Street.

Substitution of new materials -- usually synthetics or combinations of synthetic with natural materials -- has become the major problem of industry as defense needs encroach increasingly further upon available resources, it was indicated yesterday when the vanguard of an estimated 50,000 chemical engineers, plant managers, researchers, technologists, operating executives, business administrators and chemists attended the opening of the Eighteenth Exposition of Chemical Industries at Grand Central Palace.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- A better understanding of Soviet Russia was not only important for the conduct of the war, but essential when Britain and her allies turned to the task of making peace, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said in a message wishing success to an exhibition of Russian war pictures that opened today at Belfast, Northern Ireland.

Moderate gains over a year ago have featured Christmas trade in this city thus far. Last week department stores in Manhattan and Brooklyn had an average increase of 3 per cent in sales over the corresponding period of 1940, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Price ceilings for the retailing of new and used passenger cars, trucks for civilian use, and replacement parts for cars are under consideration by the Office of Price Administration.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Here are National Football League records set or tied yesterday by Don Hutson of the Green Bay Packers against the Washington Redskins.

A chill east wind whipped along the Battery sea wall yesterday morning as Peter (Buck) McNeil, veteran dockmaster, arrived to take up his post for the last time in forty years of service for the Department of Docks.

ROME, Dec. 1 -- The Japanese-American crisis is watched here with intense interest, but there is no reason to suppose that even if hostilities should result the Axis would be involved. The Japanese, it is pointed out, set a precedent when Germany began the Russian campaign and Japan did nothing -- in fact has still done nothing, although the Tripartite pact remains in operation.

BERLIN, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Hordes of Russians are blocking the German path to the Caucasus at Rostov and in attacks of extreme recklessness are striking blow upon blow in a mighty effort to reach Taganrog, German military spokesmen admitted tonight.

The three-story apartment on a plot 57 by 100 feet at 330-32 Fairmount Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by the Pearlmount Holding Corporation to the Dandora Realty Company. The property is assessed for $46,000 and was sold subject to a mortgage of $42,500 held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The reorganization managers bought today the $330,000,000 Wabash Railroad at auction for $31,030,950, subject to the approval of the Federal District Court. Judge Charles B.Davis set the minimum price at the latter figure.

With their annual business meeting at Toots Shor's Restaurant, the Football Writers Association ended its season of weekly luncheons yesterday, elected officers for the coming year and received the announcement of twenty of the players who will be on the Eastern squad for the annual Shrine charity East-West game at San Francisco on New Year's Day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Brushing aside objections and warnings from President Roosevelt and Secretaries Hull and Wickard, the House suspended its rules by a 134-32 vote today and passed legislation to permit mainland cane and beet growers to supply more of the country's sugar.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President Roosevelt assumed direct command today of diplomatic and military moves relating to Japan as the lights of peace flickered low in the Orient and Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, the Japanese Ambassador, told reporters that "there must be wise statesmanship to save the situation."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The White House disclosed today that five months before Germany invaded Poland President Roosevelt expressed the belief that Adolf Hitler's Third Reich was committed to a program of "world dominance" without limit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Restrictions on consumer credit were tightened a notch today when new Federal Reserve Board rules concerning small bank loans became effective.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- America is the one hope of the oppressed people of Europe, said William S. Knudsen, director of the Office of Production Management, tonight, in accepting the Vermilye medal at the Franklin Institute. The citation accompanying the award said that it was given for Mr. Knudsen's "far-seeing vision and human understanding, culminating in invaluable service to his country in the administration of unprecedented production for national defense."
Acme Wire Declaration yesterday of an 85cent dividend on the common stock of the Acme Wire Company brings 1941 payments to $2,65 a share, or $1 more than1940 disbursements.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- The international agreement regulating world production and marketing of tin was shaken today with disclosure that Thailand had balked at signing a five-year extension of the quota plan suggested by Britain and the Netherlands East Indies and that Japanese-controlled French Indo-China was no longer a member of the cartel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A registration statement covering sale of 53,690 shares of 4 1/2 cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value and 30,000 shares of common stock of $1 par value was filed today by Merck Co., Inc., of Rahway, N.J., with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MIAMI, Dec. 1 -- Millions of Americans may some day be living in prefabricated and demountable homes, William V. Reed, director of standards division, Defense Housing Coordination, told the convention of the Society of Residential Appraisers here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Miss Mathilda Le Boyer, 17 years old, testified today in Westchester County Court that Isaac Brown, 41, New York insurance broker, had tried to murder her last Dec. 19 to conceal an assault upon her.

That the blind too have joined the "war on waste" was evidenced yesterday when the annual Christmas sale of articles made by the blind opened in the old Tiffany store, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street. Answering the con- servation challenge, the 1,500 sightless workers whose handicraft is represented have transformed old shoe buttons into salable costume jewelry, and ends of typewriter ribbons into durable rugs.

Challenging the notion that Latin America is Europe's natural economic partner, Warren Lee Pierson, president of the ExportImport Bank of Washington, told a gathering of New York bankers last night that it is unfortunate that many United States citizens "swallow" this "shibboleth" that "propagandists of the totalitarian States love to repeat."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Nov. 15 was 4,035,480 shares, compared with 3,440,230 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

WINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 1 -- The families of 135 defense workers the first of 700 that eventually will move into this $2,500,000 defense housing development, were welcomed as the new town, the first Federally owned community in the country, was formally opened here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt are preparing the White House for Christmas as usual, even though the star in the East may be Mars.

A lone robber who has been making the round of personal loan company offices for weeks, always using the same technique, continued to elude the police yesterday after getting $800 at the Personal Finance Company office on the third floor of 100 West Forty-second Street.

F.J. Andre, president of Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., denied flatly yesterday the complaint issued in Washington Sunday by the Federal Trade Commission that contended that Sheffield's was en- gaging in unfair competitive practices in its purchase of milk products from producer cooperative associations.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 1 -- According to information vouched for by the Yugoslav Consulate General here today, the German and Italian occupation authorities in Yugoslavia have uprooted nearly 1,000,000 persons from their homes and sent them by freight trains to other parts of the country in an effort to destroy the local culture and patriotism.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Postponement of the OPA plan for price ceilings and "frozen" designs in wood furniture means a recordbreaking buyer attendance at the Winter furniture market opening Jan. 5, Lawrence Whiting, president of the American Furniture Mart, said today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Carl H. Pforzheimer of Purchase, who has been in disagreement with Westchester County supervisors for several months regarding the board's determination to establish an airport in Purchase, resigned today as chairman and a member of the County Planning Commission.

Describing herself as an "Emily Post" for employers and labor leaders as they sit around conference tables shouting each other down, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, urged yesterday that both groups now concentrate on what she called "the art of collective bargaining."
CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 1 -- Crisp weather, a fast track and 6,000 racegoers who bet $103,108 greeted the opening of an eighteenday meeting at thsi track between the Potomac and Shenandoah Rivers.

VICHY, France, Dec. 1 -- "Acts, not words" will be the keynote of French - German collaboration henceforth, an official spokesman said tonight in commenting on a meeting today between Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, French Chief of State, and Reich Marshal Hermann Goering, who acted for Reichsfuehrer Hitler.

Christmas came early for some of the city's underprivileged horses yesterday when the Humane Society of New York presented blankets to their owners, all junk dealers, at the society's headquarters, 313 East Fifty-eighth Street.

Another steady but moderate deterioration of values occupied an otherwise dull session yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, while selling to establish tax losses, particularly among the lowerpriced shares, continued to hold the pace of business at the improved level.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 1 -- A Federal jury convicted eighteen defendants tonight on charges of conspiracy to create insubordination in the armed forces of the government, but acquitted all twenty-three accused of seditious conspiracy.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 2 -- The Japanese Cabinet met in extraordinary session yesterday morning and, after reviewing the situation on the basis of a long report by Foreign Minister Shigenori Togo, decided to continue the Washington negotiations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Production of the Allison liquid-cooled engine, which powers some of the speediest pursuit planes manufactured in the United States, will reach 1,000 units a month by Dec. 17.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- The government could raise up to $10,000,000,000 a year by requiring that one-fifth of all private debt repayments be invested in Federal securities, Professor Charles C. Abbott of the Graduate School of Business Administration at Harvard University told a symposium on national defense and taxation tonight.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 1 -- Chief Justice Griffin Smith of the Arkansas Supreme Court said today that all the State divorce law required was that a man "chase his wife from home with a baseball bat, and see that she does not tarry in the driveway" to obtain a decree.

The first edition of a new literary magazine called Trend will be published at the University of Chicago about the middle of this month under student editorship. The purpose of the journal, it is announced, is to publish the work of promising university students from all parts of the country.

Women in defense will be honored Thursday in a special program of the forty-sixth annual Congress of American Industry, being held here this week by the National Association of Manufacturers. The special program will be devoted to the achievements of seven women who hold industrial or technical posts in companies working on the defense program.
Full-floor leases by a number of apparel concerns featured the business leasing reported yesterday.

The nation is liable to revert to the unsanitary conditions of "the so-called Gay Nineties, when disease epidemics were commonplace," unless disinfectant manufacturers are permitted to obtain sufficient raw materials, despite defense needs, W.J. Zick, president of the National Association of Insecticide and Disinfectant Manufacturers, warned yesterday at the opening of the association's two-day convention at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The loan exhibition presented "in honor of Royal Cortissoz and his fifty years of criticism in The New York Herald Tribune," opened yesterday at Knoedler's, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street. It will be current until Dec. 20.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 2 (From Official Soviet Sources; Distributed by The Associated Press) -- A special Soviet communique today announced the destruction of 102 Nazi planes and the capture of at least 118 tanks and 210 cannon by Red Army forces pursuing the fleeing Germans westward from recaptured Rostov.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 1 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

Permission for a post-season charity football game between the undefeated and untied teams of Erasmus Hall and Abraham Lincoln High, both of Brooklyn, has been refused by the State Board of Regent, it was learned yesterday.

The Bach Circle of New York, now in its fifth year, gave last night the first of the two Town Hall concerts planned for this season. It was directed by Robert Hufstader and enlisted the services of three solo singers, twelve sopranos of the Choir of the Pius X School of Liturgical Music and the twenty-one instrumentalists of the Bach Circle Orchestra.

Because Long Island Dutchmen and Englishmen weren't always too sympathetic to one another, Oyster Bay has two main streets. On one stands the two-story white wooden house called Raynham Hall. Samuel Townsend built it in 1740. Two descendants have just given it to the local chapter of the D.A.R.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Contracts awarded today by the War Department totaled 18,024,213,89. Included were the following, not previously published, to companies in the New York area:

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Hamburg and five other Northwest German ports were pounded with British bombs by moonlight Sunday night in a renewal of heavy Royal Air Force raiding over the Reich after nearly a month's let-up because of bad weather.

More statutory authority to speed the defense program was urged yesterday by spokesmen for both government and industry at preliminary sessions of the fortysixth annual congress of American industry of the National Association of Manufacturers in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

That the Giants are not content to rest on their laurels was evident yesterday at the Polo Grounds. With the Eastern Division championship of the National Football League and a play-off berth already clinched, one might suppose that the men from Coogan's Bluff did not care too much what happened in the finale with the Dodgers on Sunday.

Japan has been cut off from about 75 per cent of her normal imports as a result of the allied blockade, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday. In an analysis entitled "The Effects of Allied Economic Blockade on Japan," the board asserted that despite the drastic restrictions imposed by that government to stretch out available supplies, the blockade may ultimately prove disastrous.

BERLIN, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- British planes raided the North German Coast Sunday night, killing and injuring civilians in Hamburg and Emden, according to the High Command, which said today that fifteen planes were shot down.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Rural Electrification Administration was accused today on the floor of the House of hoarding millions of pounds of copper, not for the purpose of employing this vital defense metal in the distribution of current to new farm homes but to further a program of socialization of the utility industry.

Medicine Too Strong The British people and the British cause would suffer no harm if a good deal less were said about how Hitler's bombs and torpedoes are cementing British unity. Certainly it is putting things pretty strongly to say that ration cards and bombs are the surest way of wiping out social barriers in Britain.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 1 -- German General Erwin Rommel threw tanks and infantry against the British yesterday in an attempt to break his Twenty-first Panzer Division out of a pocket east of the main British forces in the Rezegh area of Libya.

The question whether President Roosevelt would pardon or commute the sentence of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter on a Federal narcotics charge to permit his execution on first-degree murder charges by New York State will not be decided until the notorious racketeer has exhausted all his legal appeals, it was asserted yesterday at the Department of Justice in Washington.

A dramatic change of scene from the Central Park of the late nineteenth century to the Palestine of 7 B.C. -- covering almost 2,000 years and several thousand miles -- is made in six seconds in the presentation of "The Christmas Star," shown yesterday at the Hayden Planetarium, Central Park West and Eighty-first Street.

Add to the list of films opening this week, "Rise and Shine," Mark Hellinger's first production at Twentieth Century-Fox which will arrive at the Roxy on Friday. Jack Oakie, Linda Darnell, George Murphy, Milton Berle and Walter Brennan are featured in the picture, which is based on James Thurber's book, "My Life and Hard Times."

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 1 -- The people of the United States may well be confident that their army is being equipped with the finest tanks now in use by any army on any battlefront if the continued performance of the light type in the spearhead of the British offensive in Libya is any criterion. These tanks have met and repulsed most of a German Panzer division that included machines twice as heavy as themselves.

Rejecting the alternative proposals of the private utilities, President Roosevelt and the Federal Power Commission have approved the State Power Authority's plan for a publicly owned and operated transmission line to carry surplus electric power from the New York City area to the government's new aluminum plant at Massena, N.Y., pear the St. Lawrence River.
BERLIN, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- Twice-beaten and once-tied Texas Christian University, which has conquered seven major football teams this season, including Texas, will meet the University of Georgia in the Orange Bowl here New Year's Day, it was announced tonight.

COROLLA, N.C., Dec. 1 -- The wind is a mere breath, the temperature is 60 degrees, it is 9 P.M., and as we look from our room at the Whalehead Club we can see countless ducks, geese and swans in the moonpath across Currituck; but the prospects for a good day's shooting tomorrow are very poor.
Deaths Reported Retired Lieutenant Cornelius W. Travis, formerly a member of H. and L. Co. 143. residing at Sea Isle City, N.J., died Nov. 25.

After thirty-three years of service as chaplain of Columbia University, the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, 65-year-old "rowing preacher," disclosed last night that he would retire next Summer. As well known on the Morningside Heights campus for his enthusiasm for sculling, which took him to Poughkeepsie last June in a single shell, as he is revered for his promotion of religious tolerance, the Protestant Episcopal chaplain said he was resigning on "dead reckoning."

The first of two new high-speed streamlined trains to be operated as the Empire State Express by the New York Central Railroad was dedicated yesterday by Governor Lehman in a ceremony held in front of the 4,800-horsepower steam locomotive of the train at Grand Central Terminal.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a letter which appeared in THE TIMES of Nov. 24 headed "Emergency Drivers Advocated" the statement is made that "the Red Cross and the American Women's Volunteer Services both have motor corps, and to qualify as a driver one must have learned, among other things, first aid, there being almost no thought given to the driving qualifications of the applicant."

SHANGHAI, Dec. 1 -- The United States Consulate General here today circularized all American citizens, pointing out previous advice in regard to evacuation and reiterating official advice that such evacuation should be undertaken without further delay.

BERLIN, Nov. 30 -- The first trainload of Spanish workers has arrived in Germany to join their comrades from a score of other European countries already working on German farms and in the Reich's war industries, it was announced today.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 1 -- Seventythree Baltimore debutantes and a score from other cities were presented formally to society tonight when the historic Bachelors' Cotillon once more was carried out in gala fashion at the old Lyric Theatre.
Minnesota capped a successful season yesterday by finishing at the top in the final Associated Press football ranking poll of the regular campaign.

Nick Dean, the Chicago night club operator whose disappearance has been hampering United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa's investigations of the movie industry, was arrested in Chicago yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

So that steady public benefactor, the Museum of the City of New York, calls its exhibition, opened yesterday, of two hundred Christmas cards running from 1870 to 1905. Both as a foretaste of Christmas and a remembrancer of a kindly custom this show is worth thanking.

Serge Rubinstein, managing director of the Chosen Corporation, Ltd., a British holding company, declared yesterday at a hearing before Supreme Court Referee Richard P. Lydon that the former had brought $1,500,000 of the company's money to this country "before Munich," so that it could not be requisitioned.

The first of the biennial Yorkville dinner dances for this season took place last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The dances have been given for many years under the auspices of the Yorkville Community Association to aid its maintenance of a neigh- borhood center at 1639 York Avenue and Camp Yorkville in Harriman State Park, through which institutions the association fosters the welfare of underprivileged families of the upper East Side.

Special FBI agents seized thirty men in raids yesterday in New York, Detroit and Chicago in the theft of millions of dollars worth of automobile parts from plants of the Ford Motor Company. The agents said disposal of the loot was a $3,000,000-a-year business.

Early Spring was in the air as a mid-season collection of fashions was launched yesterday by Henri Bendel, Inc., 10 West Fifty-seventh Street. Splashy-print daytime dresses combined with flowing, fairylike evening gowns served to make the showing of frocks for both Northern and Southern wear an early morning treat.

Manhattan Company Meeting The second Tuesday in December has been annual meeting day for the shareholders of the Bank of the Manhattan Company ever since the institution was founded 142 years ago. And yesterday was annual meeting day.

VICHY, Dec. 2 (Renter) -- Following yesterday's meeting between Reichmarshal Hermann Goering and Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Vice Premier Francois Darlan's Secretary of State, Jacques Benoist-Mechin, read a statement to representatives of the press assembled at the German Embassy in Paris.

Eugene Loring will head a new ballet company, to be known as Dance Players, Inc., which begins rehearsals next Monday and plans to make its Broadway debut in April after a brief preliminary tour. Its purpose is to sponsor American theatre-dance productions, bringing together dancers, musicians, writers and painters.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- District Attorney Elbert T. Gallagher charged this afternoon at the trial of Isaac Brown in WestChester County Court that defense attorneys were using forged letters in an effort to acquit Brown of charges of attempted first-degree murder and felonious assault.

Up from Louisiana -- famed for the fatness and fineness of its pink shrimps -- comes a tin of shrimp bisque, as smooth as silk and as nourishing as cream. This good thick soup, which carries with it the tang of the fresh, salty sea, is augmented with crabs and spices and herbs.
VICHY, France, Dec. 2 -- It is not believed that yesterday's PetainGoering talk went beyond a general survey of France's situation. However, that alone has importance at the moment.

Separated from a convoy in which she was bound here from Reykjavik, the small Iceland freighter Dettifoss battled rough seas for fourteen days without any protective craft accompanying her, but sighted no hostile ships or submarines, it was reported yesterday when she docked at the foot of West Twenty-fifth Street.
CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 2 -- Since destroying an enemy raider some days ago, the Australian cruiser Sydney has been lost, Premier John Curtin announced today.
Adams Express Company A dividend of 30 cents a share was voted by the Adams Express Company making a total of 60 cents for 1941 or 20 cents more than last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Anti- strike legislation was admitted tonight by House leaders to be head- ing for an uncertain fate. Defeat or recommittal, were held possible, as the result of a number of fac- tors but chiefly uncertainty as to how many members would be in- clined to avoid the issue.

Donning heavy pads again out eliminating the live scrimmage that marked Monday's session, the Giants staged another brisk workout at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Their immediate objective being the return meeting with the Dodgers on Sunday, the New Yorkers concentrated on a new offense that it is hoped will knock the Brooks down and a defense that will keep them down.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The Royal Navy, as represented by Captain W.G. Agnew in the cruiser Aurora and with the surface force under his command, has made another contribution to the battle of Libya. Two Italian supply ships and one destroyer have been intercepted and sunk by this British naval force, the Admiralty announced today.

Mrs. Eugene Volt of the New York Junior League came from behind to win a hard-fought contest from Miss Suzanna Murray of the Rockaway Hunting Club, 11 -- 15, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 10, and lead her team to a 3-to-1 victory in the last of the women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B matches yesterday.

Clinton Brewer, 38 years old, a Negro, whose study of music while serving a term as a slayer in Trenton State Prison, N.J., led to his becoming a talented composer, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to second-degree murder in the stabbing of a Negro woman in Harlem last Sept. 25.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Dec. 3 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Moscow radio early today broadcast the following communique:

Christmas cheer for 5,000 New York families and an unestimated number of Chinese war orphans was made possible last evening when business and professional women from all parts of the city gathered at Franklin Simon's for a special chance to do their Christmas shopping.
"The Admiral Had a Wife," next week's sole arrival on Broadway, has advanced its premiere at the Playhouse one night -- to Wednesday.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Remnants of the elite German mechanized army routed from Rostov are fleeing "to their doom" in a Russian trap, and Russian counter-attacks from tip to tip of the Moscow defense crescent have turned the tide of the supreme battle for the capital, Soviet sources claimed tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (U.P.) -- A reorganization plan transforming the America First Committee into an active political agency in the pattern of major political parties was outlined today by General Robert E. Wood, national chairman.

HAVANA, Dec. 2 -- President Fulgencio Batista will ask Congress to declare a state of national emergency and to grant him special powers to organize the defense of the island, it was announced this morning after the executive had met with Congressional leaders and Cabinet members.

American lease-lend aid has been promised to India and the first shipments of goods under the lease-lend act probably have arrived in India already, Sir Girja Shankar Bajpai, Agent General for India in the United States, revealed yesterday in an interview in the offices of the India Government Trading Commission, 630 Fifth Avenue.

The old E.W. Bliss holdings in Second Avenue, Twenty-second and Twenty-third Streets have passed into the ownership of the Manon Realty Company, a corporation formed by Rosenfeld Herring, it was learned yesterday.

Colonel Joseph V. Kuznick, a retired Army officer who commanded combat troops in France, announced yesterday that he had resigned from the American Legion because "the Legion, as misrepresented by the hand-picked executive committeemen, who in most cases are not overseas combat veterans, has been surrendered to the New Deal and is now officially part and parcel of the un-American, hell-bent-for-war Administration."

The town of Klin keeps popping in and out of the war bulletins from the Moscow front like a recurrent phrase in Tchaikovsky's Sixth symphony, which was written in a rambling red frame house a couple of miles away. Klin was reported taken and left behind by the Germans more than two weeks ago.
BERLIN, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler's headquarters issued this communique today:
NEW YORK Crown Princess Martha of Norway, accompanied by Countess Ragni Ostgaard, has come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Bethesda, Md.

Federal legislation to curb strikes in defense industries which have become "a national menace" is urged in a resolution to be presented today to the forty-sixth Annual Congress of American Industry of the National Association of Manufacturers, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Representatives of Christian churches throughout the world offered special prayers last night for world-wide Christian unity and peace at a service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in connection with the week-long celebration marking the opening last Sunday of the entire interior of the edifice.

Supreme Court Justice James T. Hallinan, sitting in Brooklyn, granted yesterday a temporary injunction restraining Mayor La Guardia from appointing a citywide Sheriff to replace the five County Sheriffs. The court order also prohibited Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick from paying any salary to the new city-wide Sheriff.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- The National City Bank of New York purchased an issue of $15,000,000 long-term serial grade-crossing elimination bonds that mature in equal installments in the next forty years for 101.1099 for 1 1/2 per cent obligations.

Although disinfectant manufacturers are in direct competition with armaments makers for essential raw materials, defense agencies are aware of the public importance of maintaining the industry's operations and a special order giving it a defense priority rating is now under consideration, Dr. D. P. Morgan, assistant supervisor, Chemicals Section, OPM, declared yesterday.

COROLLA, N.C., Dec. 2 -- This has been a bluebird day, if ever we saw one, but when we made the tally of the birds after the decoys were taken up there were two geese and fifteen ducks for the three of us, which is not a bad day's bag, all things being considered.

F.W. Woolworth Co., five and ten cent store chain, signed yesterday an agreement with the Wholesale and Warehouse Workers Union, Local 65, C.I.O., providing for the payment of $40,000 in back wages to 100 union members discharged for union activity four years ago from the company's warehouse in the Port Authority Building 111 Eighth Avenue.

THOSE good neighbors with golf sticks, Slammin' Sam Snead and Jovial Jimmy Demaret, will never get elected to public office the way they have acted. In early October they started on what amounted to a mild Good Will tour of the Argentine with golf sticks. They played fifteen exhibition matches and engaged in three open tournaments down there.

The conviction that the war in Europe would be decided neither in Russia nor Libya but "along the banks of the Potomac" was expressed last night by Edward R. Murrow, chief of the Columbia Broadcasting System's European correspondents, who returned from London on furlough a week ago last Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Charles F. Palmer, Defense Housing Co- ordinator, declared today that de- fense workers might be billeted in private dwellings unless the new $300,000,000 appropriation was ap- proved quickly. He said that the defense program was facing a crisis for lack of housing.

VICHY, France, Dec. 2 -- "TO eliminate all Jewish influence in the national economy" and to make the laws of the occupied and unoccupied zones conform, the government today published a number of modifications in the Statute of the Jews in France.
LONDON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The text of an Admiralty communique today said:

BERLIN, Dec. 2 (AP) -- New optimism over the battle of Libya grew in Germany today as the High Command, after considerable silence, told the German public that more than 9,000 prisoners, including three British generals, had been taken so far in the operations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A $10,254,558 contract for guns, awarded to the High Standard Manufacturing Company of New Haven, helped bring the total of the War Department awards for the day to $$43,847,692.81. Other concerns in the New York area receiving contracts not previously published, were listed as follows:

BOSTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- After trailing for more than fifty-one minutes, the Boston Bruins uncorked a terrific closing drive to gain a 3-1 overtime victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs and undisputed possession of the National Hockey League lead tonight before an overflow crowd of 15,000 at the Boston Garden.

The eighth annual Little Sister Show, which was held yesterday at the Boys Club of New York, 321 East 111th Street, was more than just another beauty contest for lit- tle girls. It proved to be a test of strength between the club and the mothers of the contestants, and the mothers won.

The wave of whooping cough among New York children, that has been increasing gradually for almost two months, continued its upward course last week, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday. There were 309 new cases and one death from that disease last week, forty-eight more cases than in the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- In a demonstration of willingness to share existing stocks of critical materials with Latin-American nations, the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board put earmarks today on 218,600 metric tons of tin plate for export to those countries in the twelve months beginning Dec. 15.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Following the Japanese-American negotiations with vital interest and an intimate knowledge are the British Dominions of Canada, Australia and New Zealand.

In this war of mechanized monsters racing over the earth and speeding across the sky it seems strange to find the horse charging once more into battle. Yet it is to their cavalry that the Russians credit the still-spreading exploitation of their victory at Rostov. All along the line hard-riding Cossacks have been harrying the German retreat.

For its pioneering research in recovery of metallic magnesium from sea water the Dow Chemical Company last night received the 1941 Award for Chemical Engineering Achievement. The presentation was made at a dinner at the University Club, 1 West Fifty-fourth Street, by Colonel Alfred H. White, chairman of the award committee and head of the Department of Chemical and Metallurgical Engineering at the University of Michigan.

OTTAWA, Dec. 2 (Canadian Press) -- The Supreme Court's decision today, ruling that the Alberta Debt Adjustment Act of 1937, as amended, was unconstitutional, marked another step in the long controversy over Federal and Provincial powers that arose from the attempt of Alberta's Social Credit government to give effect to its financial policies.
AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Dec. 2 -- Stocks made a good recovery today on the Bourse due to hopes that tension in the Far East had eased. Closing prices were at the best levels of the day.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- All classes of cattle moved higher under aggressive buyins today as Eastern purchasers competed with local interests for steers weighing between 1,300 and 1,500 pounds. Fed steers and yearlings were 15 to 25 cents a hundred pounds higher. Livestock men said strength in dressed markets and a reduction In receipts were responsible for the upturn.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 2 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued the following communique today:

Eugene W. Stetson, president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, announced yesterday that Merrel P. Callaway would retire as vice president and head of the company's fiduciary department on Jan. 1. He will continue as chairman of the trust investment committee of the board of directors and in a general advisory capacity.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Compulsory conscription of women in Britain, a step provided in the conscription bill now before the British Parliament, is approved in principle by a substantial majority of British public opinion. The voters approve not only compelling women to serve in the auxiliary forces, but a surprising number -- more than one-fourth -- actually believe women should be allowed to become fighting members of the armed forces.

TULSA, Okla., Dec. 2 -- Platho P. Scott, who holds a patent on a design of "V for Victory" emblem, said today he would allow any charitable or war relief organization to use his exclusive privileges "Scott free."

Proudly leading the celebration of the second anniversary of the opening of the Municipal Airport in Queens yesterday, Mayor La Guardia inspected the Academy of Aeronautics, situated north of the landing area, and announced the formation of a civilian air corps to protect American non-military airports in the event of attack.
ATLANTA, Dec. 2 -- A middle-aged man walked up to the sergeant of the guard today at Fort McPherson to report "in" as they do after on Army leave.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- "The crisis of equipment" is largely over and "the crisis of man power and woman power" will dominate 1942, Prime Minister Winston Churchill told the House of Commons today. He asked authority to draft 3,000,000 more men for military duty and to require women to join the uniformed services.

Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, said last night that the cost of living has gone up 11 per cent since the war started, is still going up at the rate of 1 1/2 per cent a month, and will be up 20 per cent by Spring. He warned that the United States could not achieve victory without price control, and that maximum industrial production could not be maintained in a period of runaway inflation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 1:

In Room 316 at the New York Public Library may be seen, until the end of January, work in various media by Abraham Walkowitz, which the artist presented to the permanent collection last year. The work is classified according to me- dium, or, in one instance, to subject -- the Isadora Duncan series.
MONTREAL, Dec. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Gordie Drillon of Toronto and Bryan Hextall of the Rangers are leading the National Hockey League scoring parade, according to official statistics released today.

ROME, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Stefani, official Italian news agency, in reporting today's trial in Trieste, said the actual perpetrators of the sabotage against Italy's war industries were believed to be eleven persons still at large. Terroristic attacks attributed to them were blasts that killed and injured hundreds of Italians in munitions factories at Piacenza on Nov. 8, Bologna on Aug. 25 and at Clana on Feb. 25, 1940.

A special bonus covering warzone areas recently opened up to United States merchant vessels by revision of the Neutrality Act has been agreed upon by the National Maritime Union and the American Merchant Marine Institute, representing steamship companies having contracts with the union.

The country's college footbal coaches are in astonishingly strong accord on one point -- the revised football rules that went into effect this past season worked out handsomely, and particularly so the ruling which permits them to make unlimited substitutions.

Buyer Registrations Up in Week Visiting buyer registrations in the market last week numbered 562, as against 415 in the preceding week and 427 in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 251 as compared with 246 for last Tuesday.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 3 -- With reports pouring in that the American, British, Chinese and Netherland powers were clearing the decks to meet any armed Japanese move, the Cabinet met again yesterday to discuss the situation in general and the American-Japanese negotiations in particular.

Communist students in the New York City colleges and high schools are taught to lie, cheat and create disturbances in the classroom and on the campus, it was charged in the interim report of the Rapp-Coudert subcommittee, made public yesterday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 2 -- Marvelous Melvin Ott, "boy wonder" of the Polo Grounds these last sixteen years and the National League's foremost home-run clouter of all time, today became the new manager of the Giants, and Bill Terry, in vacating this post, took over his new duties as general manager of the club's minor league and scouting systems.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- New low marks in unemployment benefit payments and in the number of persons registered for work in October were reported by the Federal Security Agency. It was the third successive month that benefit payments dropped to a new low record, with fewer workers receiving payments than at any time since the program went into full operation.

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- The Royal Air Force raid on Hamburg on the night of Nov. 30 appears to have been one of the heaviest this city has suffered since the beginning of the war, according to a communique released by local party authorities.

Carrying on their precedent of first as well as last running, the owners of the International class of sloops on Long Island Sound held last night the initial of their two mid-Winter dinner meetings in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street, and from the general expression it was a sort of first in peace or war gathering.

For the first time since the founding of the award in 1910, two persons have been named to receive simultaneously the Charles Frederick Chandler Medal of Columbia University. The recipients, who also are brothers, are Dr. Robert R. Williams, chemical director of the Bell Telephone Laboratories of New York, and Professor Roger J. Williams of the University of Texas.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 2 -- German General Erwin Rommel has reunited his armored forces in the Rezegh region of Libya. Striking from the southwest [and capturing both Rezegh and Bir el-Hamed, according to The Associated Press], panzer units advanced yesterday and joined with an Axis force in the vicinity of Zaafran, about six miles northeast of Rezegh.

A sharp trend toward dispersal of defense contracts and industrial facilities away from the heavily industrialized regions of the country to under-industrialized areas was reported yesterday by the division of industrial economics of the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Full production of the ships included in the Navy and merchant marine building programs will require an additional 300,000 workmen, who must be trained and put to work by next November, when the schedule calls for peak building operations.

With many buyers in the market, Spring showings of corsets gained headway here yesterday. Close to 2,000 retail representatives attended the showing held by the Warner Brothers Company at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, while a good buyer attendance was also noted at the displays staged by about thirty manufacturers at the Vanderbilt and McAlpin hotels.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 -- Despite tax collections three times as great as those of the World War, Germany by next Spring will have accumulated an indebtedness as large as that shouldered at the close of hostilities in 1918, the Tax Institute of the University of Pennsylvania was told today by Otto Jeidels, former vice president of the Berliner Handelsgesellschaft, one of the largest banking houses in the Reich.

Stockholders of the Bank of the Manhattan Company at a special meeting yesterday that preceded by a few minutes the annual meeting adopted a new by-law that provides for reimbursement of directors and officers in suits brought against them in their official capacities.

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- In the absence of concrete information as to what Reichsmarshal Hermann Goering and Marshal Henri Philippe Petain discussed yesterday at Saint-Floradin in occupied France, political circles here confined themselves today to expressing the hope that the meeting would prove the first of a series placing France definitely within the Axis "New Order."

Seven young women of Latin America, chosen by the coffee growers of their respective nations as typical beauties, and representative of the leading families there, began their good-will tour of the United States yesterday afternoon as guests of honor at a reception held by the Pan-America Coffee Bureau at the Sherry-Netherlands Hotel.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 -- Fraud in the sale of income contracts was charged in a Federal indictment against the Fidelity Investment Association, four of its affiliates and thirteen individuals returned last night and revealed today by John C. Lehr, District Attorney.
