BERLIN, Dec. 2 (AP) -- German troops were reported officially tonight to have punched new holes in Moscow's arc of staggered defenses while fighting grimly on the southern front west of Rostov to stem the Red Army drive that pushed them out of that Caucasian gateway.

The development of institutional campaigns in recent months has apparently created some dissatisfaction in various quarters, both governmental and business, if the so-called confidential information circulated through the field is correct.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Roman Boy, long regarded as the sprint champion of the East's smaller tracKs, turned on his blinding speed today and won the fifth race. Racing in the silks of P.H. Faulconer, Virginia sportsman, the son of Ha Ha and Roman Girl defeated Hiblaze by a length and a quarter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- For the first two months -- October and November -- of the period during which this government promised to deliver to ports accessible to Soviet Russia a specified tonnage of materials of war the accomplishment has fallen far, far short of the promise.

Donald M. Nelson, executive director of the Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board, speaking last night at a dinner of the National Consumer-Retailer Council at the Hotel Roosevelt, urged retailers and manufacturers to eliminate "frills and gadgets" from their products to assist the defense program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Manufacturers increased the value of their inventories during October by the largest amount ever recorded for a single month, according to the Department of Commerce. Accumulations of approximately $450,000,000 were broadly distributed throughout industry generally and lifted the aggregate value of stocks held by manufacturers to an estimated record high of more than $14,000,000,000.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 2 -- A Memphis foursome led thirty-five teams of women after the first session of the national women's contract bridge team-of-four tournament today. The title will be decided in the final session tomorrow afternoon.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Now that such steps as circumstances permit have been taken for any eventuality in the Far East, it is the belief here -- and one that is likely to have been transmitted to Washington -- that there should be no relaxation in any particular of the economic blockade on Japan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Two defence construction companies, depicted recently in Congressional inquiries as having jointly run up to $51,000,000 the costs of an ordnance plant contracted for at $20,000,000 with a corresponding increase in profits, acknowledged today that costs had skyrocketed as alleged.
Fair in the Air Our news story yesterday spoke of Cupid's ravages among the airline hostesses. It was a happy metaphor, because Cupid is usually pic- tured as shooting his quarry on the wing.

J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, announced yesterday that he had requested the association members to restudy their needs for locomotives in 1942 to aid in determining the minimum plant capacity that will be required to meet their requirements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The popularity of the twenty-second letter of the alphabet as a symbol for victory over the Axis has brought a stream of "V" designs to the patent office, a check of recent records showed today.

Despite the illness which forced him to cancel two ring engagements, Ray Robinson, Harlem welterweight star, yesterday was assured consideration as a contender for the world championship now held by Freddie (Red) Cochrane.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 2 -- The Governor of Entre Rios again rose in defense of free speech in his province today. In another telegram to the Minister of the Interior he said:

The Actors Equity Association took yesterday another step toward the eradication of charges that its governing board has been under "Red control" as the council accepted the text of a proposed constitutional amendment barring members of the Communist, Nazi or Fascist parties or their sympathizers from holding office in or being employed by Equity.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The text of the report to President Roosevelt by his Emergency FactFinding Board, which averted a strike on the railroads, is as follows:

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has bought seven water-colors by contemporary American artists not represented hitherto in its collections. The pictures were selected from the Contemporary American Water Color Exhibition assembled by the Chicago Art Institute and recently shown as a loan at the Metropolitan.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Wednesday, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Frank Snyder of Liberty, Pa., a member of the Pennsylvania Legislature, was elected president of the Metropolitan Coop- erative Milk Producers Bargaining Agency early today following a turbulent meeting yesterday and last night, in which the board of directors was enlarged from seventeen to thirty.

MADRID, Dec. 2, (U.P.) -- Diplomatic reports from Berne tonight said that Germany might soon officially request Switzerland to expel all British nationals, including diplomats, within a certain fixed time, in the same manner that German and Italian nationals and diplomats were expelled from Syria, Iraq and Iran.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Following are excerpts from Prime Minister Churchill's speech in the House of Commons today:

Mr. Churchill asked Parliament yesterday to confer upon the Government the same powers of conscription of women for military service that it now has over men, as one of several measures to meet the crisis of man power which he predicted would dominate 1942 in the beleaguered British Isles.

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline along the Atlantic Seaboard at the close of last week were 19,435,000 barrels, an increase of 210,000 over the 19,225,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Light fuel oil stocks declined 124,000 barrels to 22,092,000, but heavy fuel oil supplies were up 608,000 to 12,539,000.

The forty-two-game schedule of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League, announced yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, will open on Jan. 9, when Cornell faces Harvard at Cambridge. This will be the thirty-ninth season for the seven-team circuit, the oldest organized group in basketball.

STILL another reassuring took about London. Diana Forbes-Robertson (Mrs. Vincent Sheean) spent several months there earlier this year and has brought back a graphic report now published with upward of 100 photographs by Robert Capa: "The Battle of Waterloo Road."*

Declaring that support for dental research has been ignored by the Federal Government and by philan- thropists, Dr. James T. Ivory, president-elect of the Dental Society of New York State, yesterday told the seventeenth annual session of the Greater New York Dental Meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania that dentistry needs financial aid if it is to become a powerful ally of national defense.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -- "The Courtship of Andy Hardy," the twelfth of Metro's Hardy family films, will go before the cameras tomorrow with Mickey Rooney, Lewis Stone, Cecelia Parker, Ann Rutherford, Fay Holden and Sara Haden, the regular players in the series, heading the cast.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a contemporary of Jack D. Roberts I want to emphasize that his letter ap- pearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 1 does not represent the thinking of our generation.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 2 -- A squadron of warships, the first units of Britain's new Far East Fleet to arrive here, slipped into the Singapore naval base today, creating a bulwark of sea power for Britain in the Orient at a time when the threat of war with Japan has reached its peak. The squadron was led by one of the newest and mightiest battleships afloat, the Prince of Wales, which was commissioned only this year.

Quarries in England that had teen abandoned for a hundred years or more have been converted into air-conditioned subterranean factories protected by eighty feet of solid rock against bombs and requiring no blackouts, it was reported here yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in the Hotel Astor.

Louis (Lepke) Buehalter, who ruled the country's major rackets for nearly two decades by ruthlessly ordering countless underworld executions, stood white-faced and shaken yesterday as he heard his own death sentence intoned by Judge Franklin Taylor in Kings County Court.
Children can be caustic critics, especially where books are concerned, it was demonstrated yesterday.

ROME, Dec. 2 -- A fourth British general and 1,500 more prisoners were captured in the fighting in Libya yesterday, Italy claimed in today's war communique. It stated nothing about the German breakthrough south of Tobruk for the simple reason that the Italian communiques have never admitted that the British relieved Tobruk and hence the Axis cannot now claim a victory when officially there was no defeat.
ROME, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today: ...

Although Shakespeare might have some difficulty in recognizing his romantic comedy in the version of "Twelfth Night" played at the Little last evening, he would doubtless be interested. "Or, What You Will," he obligingly scribbled on his manuscript for subtitle.

Pearl L. Bergoff, operator of a nationally known strike-breaking agency until that business was illegalized by Federal and State law several years ago, was arrested yesterday charged with practicing his old vocation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York and Mayor Kelly of Chicago told the Senate Naval Affairs Committee today that something must be done at once to save priorities-affected small businesses from extinction lest this country come out of the war the loser despite a victory over Hitler.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Sentiment for moderate anti-strike legislation based on a sixty-day cool- ing-off period developed in the House today against the back- ground of the railroad strike settlement.

Yesterday the British sent into Singapore the most powerful fleet they have ever assembled in Far Eastern waters, some great capital ships among them, stripped for action. These are Britain's answer, in which this country concurs, to threats of a Japanese thrust from Indo-China into Thailand.

Instead of appearing on the stage with the sole support of the concert grand, as moat pianists do, Sergei Barsoukoff surrounded himself with thirty-odd young musicians at the Town Hall last night. The musicians were members of the Alumni Orchestra of the National Orchestral Association, whose regular conductor is Richard Korn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- One of the largest consolidations in government history was effected today when President Roosevelt signed the bill passed by Congress to merge the Army Quartermaster Construction Corps with the Corps of Engineers.

Though the shop windows are twinkling with Christmas tree lights and the Santa Claus spirit is prevailing, Jay Thorpe delighted a large audience with enchantingly springlike clothes yesterday afternoon. Prints and chiffons, shantungs and gabardines placed a vivid color pallette before the interested onlookers that packed both sides of the second-floor showrooms, leaving only a narrow margin for the manikins.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 2 -- The Finance Ministry announced today that Ceferino Alonson Irigoyen, who is Under-Secretary of the Finance Ministry and economic attache of the Argentine Embassy at Washington, would leave for the United States by air tomorrow for a month's stay, during which he will exchange views with United States officials on various pending problems.

The cotton market turned more active yesterday and closed firm under a flurry of speculative and New Orleans buying, together with some commission-house purchases and covering operations. Final prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were at their best levels of the session and showed net gains of 10 to 17 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Plans for the 1942 campaign against infantile paralysis and for the "diamond jubilee" celebration on Jan. 30 of President Roosevelt's sixtieth birthday were formulated at the annual meeting today of national and State officials of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

Traffic officials from all the railroads will meet in Chicago today to decide on a blanket increase in freight and passenger rates to offset the $300,000,000 wage rise allowed to the railway unions following intervention by President Roosevelt.

The threatened nation-wide railroad strike, which would have crippled our entire defense effort, not to speak of ordinary economic life, has been averted. For this the nation may be duly grateful. But the strike has been bought off at a price, and nothing is gained by underestimating how heavy that price has been.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing here on Dec. 22 to consider whether the winding up of North American Light and Power Company or Illinois Traction Company or both and the distribution of their assets to their security holders should be required.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 2 -- American business cannot afford to sit back with a complacent "no-nothing" attitude and merely hope that the economic cycles, as we have known them in the past, will preserve the American way of life, delegates to the thirtieth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America were told here today.

The United States Trust Company of New York, as trustee for the estate of Julius Kayser, has sold the twelve-story loft building at 338-40 West Thirty-ninth Street to a client of Goodman Mabel, lawyers.

The New York Historical Society placed on view yesterday in its gal- leries at 170 Central Park West a large and imposing exhibition of early American portraits. This will be current until Jan. 25. The galleries are open to the public, daily, except Mondays, from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; on Sundays from 1 to 5.

Centuries-old traditions of Caucasian art and culture will be revivified Friday night at the eleventh annual Allaverdy Ball of the Caucasian Society Allaverdy, which will be held in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Planned as one of the colorful events of the new season, the event is expected to draw a large attendance, including many members of the former Russian nobility.

A strike against gasoline station owners in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens who have refused to accept a proposal for wage increases made yesterday by an arbitration board appointed by Mayor La Guardia was voted last night by the Gasoline Station Attendants Union, Local 917, A.F. of L., at a membership meeting in Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street near Eighth Avenue.

At this time last year a small-sized thin book was climbing up on the best-seller lists. The book had been rejected by one publisher and then published modestly by another who hoped it might be the "dark horse" of its season. "The White Cliffs," Alice Duer Miller's blank-verse poem, became the white steed of Coward-McCann's Fall and Christmas season and then con- tinued to sell through the Spring.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Dec. 3 -- The last news received from Moscow last evening indi cated that the Russian forces on the southern front were continuing their pressure against the fleeing German forces west of Taganrog, but also admitted that the Germans had made "considerable progress as a result of overwhelming pressure" against Moscow.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The taxicabs of New York are now seeking to raise rates. They will appeal to the City Council for authorization. The pedestrians, taxi-users and traffic police have an interest at stake. A brief analysis may help clarify the question.

"Marry the Boss's Daughter," a Twentieth Century - Fox comedy-romance, which opens at the Palace, is this morning's sole film newcomer. Brenda Joyce, Bruce Edwards, and George Barbier are among the featured players. "The Maltese Falcon" is the associate picture on the double-feature program . . . "Skylark" will enter its third and final week today at the Paramount . . . "Keep 'Em Flying" begins its second week today at Loew's Criterion.

An 18-year-old Negro, with a penchant for stealing automobiles even to the point of taking one so he would arrive at General Sessions Court at the time set for sentencing him for a similar charge, yesterday finally found himself in jail for that crime.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Buying of wheat futures by brokers who frequently act for mills was the mainstay of the market today, and while there was a dip at one time, the December showed a firm undertone and the close on the Board of Trade was 1/2 cent a bushel higher.

Because medical supplies are more urgently needed than food just now and as the United States Government is undertaking to provide armament and other military equipment, Russian War Relief, Inc., announced yesterday the immediate launching of a campaign to raise $3,000,000 in this country for the purchase of pharmaceutical products and surgical equipment to send to the Soviet Union.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 2 -- Rumors of trades today filled the lobbies of hotels housing baseball men here for the convention of the minor leagues.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Roosevelt announced that he formally asked the Japanese Government today why it was sending so many military, naval and air forces into Indo-China--jumping-off place for an attack on Thailand and the Burma Road -- and expressed hope for a very quick reply.

ROME, Dec. 2 -- Cardinal Vidal y Barraquer, who has been living in Rome since the start of the Spanish civil war, has received permission to return to Spain, it was learned today. It is recalled that he abstained from supporting General Francisco Franco and refused to sign a pastoral letter in favor of the Falangist movement published during the civil war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Maximum prices for certain types of second-hand railroad rail, sold for transportation use, are established in Price Schedule 46, covering relaying rail, issued today by Leon Henderson, Administrator, Office of Price Administration.

ROME, Dec. 2 -- A plot against the Fascist regime and Premier Mussolini, accompanied by important acts of sabotage, has been smashed and sixty persons appeared before the Special Tribunal for Defense of the State in Trieste this morning, it was officially announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A disbursement of $50,000,000, the fifth to date, on the $425,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan to Britain has bean made, Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, said today. The various disbursements make a total of $350,000,000 paid so far against British-owned securities, which are on deposit with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Repre- sentative Rankin of Mississippi dis- puted today charges made yesterday by Representative Winter of Kansas that the Rural Electrification Administration was "hoarding" millions of pounds of copper. Mr. Rankin called it "the most vicious and unjustified attack on rural electrification I have heard since I have been in Congress."

Fordham relaxed a bit yesterday following the campus excitement of the previous day, when announcement of the trip to New Orleans for the Sugar Bowl engagement with Missouri brought national spotlight to bear on the team which had just concluded its regular season.

The Missouri Pacific Railroad announced yesterday that replies from 12,651 of 40,000 bondholders of the company subjected to a "postcard survey" had indicated "certain rejection" for the plan of reorganization for the company backed by a committee headed by John W. Stedman, vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company.

Polo has only one ruler today with the announcement by the United States Polo Association of the new handicap list just approved by the board of governors. Stewart B. Iglehart is alone at 10 goals, the only active player in the world with this rating.

Relief work is "a nation-wide problem" in China, due partly to the large numbers of refugees not yet assimilated in Free China and the amount of suffering among war orphans, according to a report submitted yesterday at the second annual meeting of the Board of Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Church, now in session at the Methodist Building, 150 Ffth Avenue.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn, who began his public career as a uniformed patrolman on beat and was defeated last month as the Democratic candidate for Mayor against Fiorello H. La Guardia, split completely with the city administration last night and flatly refused to permit his confidential records to be made the subject of a report demanded by the Police Department.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A Finnish communique today said:
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

The Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies will mark its twentieth anniversary tonight with a benefit party at the performance of the Ice Follies of 1942 at Madison Square Garden. Many persons of prominence who are interested In the beneficiary have taken boxes for the occasion.

Trailing by 1 point, the Long Island University basketball team put on a scoring drive at the start of the fourth period and subdued a hard-driving Fort Monmouth quintet, 48 -- 39, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night.

The Western Public Service Company, controlled by the Engineers Public Service Company, will sell its utility properties in Nebraska to the Consumers Public Power District for approximately $6,800,000, it was announced yesterday. Five municipalities in Western Nebraska affected by the sale have agreed to proceed immediately with the formation of a public power district for the acquisition of the Western division of the property.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Retail volume may increase temporarily but should decrease when the present rate of 17 per cent of total production for national defense is doubled, "because retailers will have fewer things to sell," Major Benjamin H. Namm, chairman of the retailers for defense committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and head of the Namm Store, Brooklyn, said in an address here today before the Chicago Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A $1,500,000,000 new money issue of 2 1/2 per cent thirty-one-year and 2 per cent fourteen-year bonds on Dec. 15 with special provision for the small investor and new restrictions on speculators was announced today by the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Recent Japanese threats to cut the Burma Road, route over which China sends tungsten to the United States in exchange for lease-lend materials, was a major consideration in prompting the Office of Production Management to order sharper curtailment in the use of the commodity.

One of the fullest budgets of domestic news with an industrial bearing established yesterday a possible basis for activity in the stock and other markets, but apparently traders in securities were a bit timid after the sharp recovery of Tuesday.

Mink Users Not Ready to Buy Mink users are not yet ready to buy, it was evident yesterday at the mink sale conducted by Lampson, Fraser Huth. Attendance was good, but the general tendency appeared to be to observe the market rather than bid actively for goods.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A terrific explosion, apparently caused by a black powder bomb, late tonight damaged the home of P.J. Currier, president of the C.I.O.organized Currier Lumber Company, to whom recently was refused a government contract to build defense homes in Wayne.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 3 (AP) Production of $22,600,000 in cargo ships for the nation's rapidly expanding merchant marine was halted at the Pusey Jones Shipbuilding Corporation today after C.I.O. unionists called a strike to back up demands for a union shop and wage adjustments.

The need of "some realistic thinking and some definite planning" for the post-war period if this nation is to avoid fascism as a consequence of the dislocations produced by the present emergency was urged last night by William A. Hanley, president of the American Society of mechanical Engineers at a dinner in the Hotel Astor in connection with the annual meeting of the society now in progress.

With the presentation of the operetta, "Sunny River," tonight at the St. James, Max Gordon will have a quartet of shows on Broadway bearing his name as sponsor. The other local attractions under Mr. Gordon's protective custody are "Junior Miss."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 3 -- "Merton of the Movies," Harry Leon Wilson's novel of a cinematic genius, will be brought to the screen for the third time by Paramount, the studio announced today. Val Burton has been assigned to prepare a modernized scenario, and Sol C. Siegel will produce.

The disbarment of Alfred E. Smith Jr., former City Councilman and son of the former Governor, was requested yesterday by one of Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's extraordinary grand juries in Brooklyn on eleven charges involving professional misconduct, fraud, deceit, crime and misdemeanor and conduct prejudicial to the administration of justice.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 3 -- Within the last year the minor leagues have had 277 of their players inducted into the country's armed forces, but as yet have not been seriously hurt by the draft, baseball's leaders were told today.

ROME, Dec. 3 -- The links between the Trieste insurrectionaries seeking to overthrow the Fascist regime and a "Communist and terrorist association" in Italy were brought out today at the questioning of the third witness before the Special Tribunal for the Defense of the State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- President Roosevelt formalized today the shipment of the lease-lend supplies to neutral Turkey, which has been going on secretly and indirectly since last May, by issuing an announcement that "the defense of Turkey is vital to the defense of the United States."

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Trading today on the stock markets saw the conversion 3 1/2 per cent loan improve to u106 3/4, while others in the gilt-edge group were unchanged. Industrial issues were dull. In the tobaccos Carreras, Ltd., ordered a final dividend of 15 5-6 per cent on the ordinary A, ordinary and B ordinary, making 27 1/2 per cent for the year ended on Oct. 31.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Dec. 1 (Delayed) -- It was Napoleon who said, "Give me allies to fight." What the French conquerer meant was that national differences and the great difficulty in coordinating separate armies rendered their opponent's task far easier.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Dec. 3 -- The Bourse developed an uncertain tone today, with the close some losses of 5 points. AKU was a firm exception with a gain of 2 1/2 points to 156 7/8. Royal Dutch lost 3/4 point at 345; Amsterdam trading was 4 1/4 lower at 485 1/2 and Amsterdam Rubber off 3 1/2 at 330 3/4.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Alien Welsh Dulles and Hamilton Fish Armstrong will give a dinner dance tomorrow in The Cottage of Hampshire House for their debutante daughters, Miss Joan Dulles and Miss Gregor Armstrong.

VICHY, France, Dec. 3 -- French West Africa is morally and materially ready to defend its territory from any attack, Vice Admiral Charles Platon, the Minister of Colonies, reported today on his return from an inspection tour by plane.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- While only $78,000,000 of the total of the Supplemental Defense Appropriation Bill reported today was specifically allotted for aid to Russia, General Marshall said his "urgent advice" would be that as long as American ground forces are not involved in war, "many of the tanks for the production of which funds are requested might well be diverted in order to assist the Russian army to remain on its feet."

The United States is not bluffing in the present emergency, even though she was fooled in the last World War, Mayor La Guardia told 750 persons yesterday at the formal dedication of the Wallabout Houses, the city's first defense housing project, erected in the shadow of the Navy Yard in Brooklyn.

Leaving nothing to chance, the Dodgers yesterday covered just about all there is to cover in a football practice as they continued to prepare for Sunday's finale against their interborough rivals, the Giants, who will be encountered at the Polo Grounds.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

BERLIN, Dec. 3 -- Omitting all reference to the situation on the front west of Rostov, the German communique" today claimed further gains in the Moscow sector "despite stout resistance and local enemy counter-thrusts." German news agency dispatches admit that these counter-attacks have been successful at some points, but dismiss the Soviet successes as unimportant.

Dr. A. Posner Shoes, Inc., manufacturers of children's footwear, after a tenancy of more than a quarter of a century in West Broadway, will soon move its New York offices and salesrooms into 139 Duane Street, between West Broadway and Church Street, where it has leased-the store and basement, through Tankoos, Smith Co.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 -- Neutron rays created by the bombardment of beryllium atoms in the University of California's 225-ton cyclotron have given "encouraging results" in the treatment of cancer during the last three years, members of the university staff reported today to the Radiological Society of North America.

VICHY, France, Dec. 3 -- One of the problems facing the Petain government is the constant creation of new official posts, an inescapable consequence of authoritarian rule. Each new law, each new decree, brings its quota, and even when they do not entail new appointments the current expenses of new organizations have to be considered in a budget that in present conditions is difficult, if not impossible, to balance.

Despite the need for lumber in the defense program, there will be no curtailment of the American toothpick. The length will remain the same, 2.375 inches for the flat type and 2.5 inches for the round variety, and there will be just as much leverage as ever in the sliver.

In extending her plea for further community responsibility to 300 Henry Street nurses yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt urged the training and use of volunteers in their nursing work. Volunteers may be "a terrible nuisance," she said, but to her they represent the backbone of a permanent program of community protection.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: An editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES today, in discussing various proposals to provide relief for overburdened taxpayers, stresses the necessity for an amendment to the State Tax Law authorizing deductions of Federal income tax payments from State tax returns.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- The destroyer Kearny fought nearly thre hours against a pack of German submarines before she was hit by a torpedo, an official Navy report to Congress, revealed today.

LONDON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Grumbling about the British offensive in Libya was heard in the House of Commons today, and the Ministry of Information countered with a statement acknowledging stiff Axis opposition, but declaring that Rayal Air Force superiority "augurs well for the future."

The feud that has been smoldering between District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn and Mayor F.H. La Guardia, opponents in the recent municipal election, was brought into the open yesterday by both principals in a barrage of charges and countercharges featuring a grand jury inquiry, a promised drastic police shake-up, and old friends splitting over accusations of betrayal of public trust.

The consumers durable goods industries may have to revise their advertising budgets for 1942 upward if the sales trend that has developed in the last month or two is continued throughout next year, according to sales managers in various industries.

The eighty-seventh birthday of Mary Reed, missionary to lepers, now living in retirement in the leper village of Chandag, India, was observed yesterday by the American Mission to Lepers at its headquarters, 156 Fifth Avenue. Miss Reed's birthday is today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- In line with the policy of supporting Representatives and Senators, regardless of party lines, who have voted against the war, the America First Committee reported today a schedule of meetings in the East and Middle West during December.

The temptation to keep defense production going and avoid layoffs by paying more than the maximum government prices for scrap steel, either directly or through relaxing of grading rules, is proving irresistible on an increasing scale in both steel mill and foundry grades, according to Iron Age.

CHICAGO. Dec. 3 (AP) -- Buyers bid today for choice offerings in the cattle section and pushed prices on steers to the highest level since Summer. Fed steers and yearlings were up as much as 25 cents a hundredweight, with a top of S13-50. Cows gained 10 to 15 cents, and vealers 25 to 50 cents.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 3 -- Four women from Memphis, little known as contract bridge players outside of their own section, won the national women's team-of-four championship today by nosing out the most famous women players of the country and pre-tournament favorites, with 49 points against 44.
Leaders in the various races for individual honors in the National Football League maintained their positions last week, according to the statistics released yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- A broader outside interest combined with mill and professional buying advanced wheat prices around 1 1/2 cents a bushel at one time on the Board of Trade today with the December showing the most strength, and at its best level in about two months.

COROLLA, N.C., Dec. 3 -- Many of the hunters we met on Currituck Sound today expressed themselves quite forcibly on the weather, and many who had been hunting here since the opening a month ago pointed out that there had been only four days of real gunning weather during this period.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Judge Samuel I. Rosenman has outlined to President Roosevelt a plan for smoothing out the confusion and conflict among bureaus which have slowed up the defense housing program. No inkling of his recommendations has appeared hitherto because the President's confidant has discussed the matter informally instead of submitting a written report.
WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, in Libya, Dec. 2 (Delayed) (AP) -- Withdrawing from various scattered positions, British forces have established themselves along a solid line in the Bir el-Gobi area.

ARDEN, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- Lawrence MacQueen, popular New Jersey field trial trainer, closed the 1941 season in a blaze of glory today by winning the Tom Briggs Memorial Trophy with a victory in the Gamekeepers Association Stake on the E.R. Harriman estate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- As a reply was awaited today to President Roosevelt's inquiry concerning the heavy reinforcing of Japanese troops in French Indo-China with its threat to Thailand and the peace of the Far East, Secretary of State Cordell Hull outlined at his press conference the course of the exploratory conversations with Tokyo's envoys here.

The President's announcement of the extension of aid to Turkey under the Lease-Lend Act is a move obviously inspired by military developments in the Near East. Turkey lies like a strategic bridge suspended between the Battle of Rostov and the Battle of Libya.

The nation's armed forces face a serious problem in getting enough medical officers chiefly because young physicians who have received deferment while completing their education and internship since Selective Service began are disregarding their obligations to the country, Captain Dickinson S. Pepper of the Army Medical Corps warned yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Charles J. Hendley's statement in his letters to THE TIMES somewhat startled me. With particular reference to the dearth of teachers in rural areas, recently reported in the newspapers, Mr. Hendley said that thousands of New York City teachers are ready to go anywhere in the country.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The New York Rovers took first place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League with a 6-to-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight. The Red Shirts displaced the idle Johnstown six in the lead.

Vesta Kelling, 37-year-old feature writer of the Wide World News Service of The Associated Press, was found dead in her apartment on the eleventh floor of 400 East Fifty-second Street early yesterday morning, following an explosion of gas which shattered four windows of the two-room apartment and awakened about 150 residents in the eighteen-story building.

Besides announcing the sites and dates of the 1942 national championships, the United States Golf Association revealed yesterday several proposals, relating chiefly to public links golf, which will be presented for ratification at the annual meeting in New York on Jan. 10.

The appointment of Dr. Harry N. Wright to the $18,000-a-year post of president of City College has been unanimously recommended to the Board of Higher Education by its City College Administrative Committee, it was disclosed yesterday by Charles H. Tuttle, committee chairman.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 4 -- Japanese pressure on Thailand to join Japan continues. The newspaper Chugai Shogyo declared yesterday Thailand's neutrality must be safeguarded, come what may, but added that neutrality was merely the second-best course Thailand could take, being a passive, negative path, and that, therefore, "Thailand should work with us."
Duplexes, penthouses and terrace suites were selected by a number of the apartment lessees figuring in lists submitted yesterday by brokers and agents.

Gridiron Ousts Diamond? It is not exactly a silent revolution, but neither has it been a flaming revolution which seems to be changing America's national game from baseball to football, judging by the size of the crowds.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 3 -- Investment bankers must solve their own problems, adjust themselves to changing conditions, accept permanent, but perhaps modified, regulation, and "get down to work" if they are to survive successfully the period of transition from war to peacetime economy and play the part they should in post-war financing, delegates to the thirtieth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America were told today.

Elaine Lavender, 16 years old, first prize winner in the National Camp Fire Girls' photographic contest, received yesterday a $100 scholarship awarded by the School of Modern Photography, presented by William A. Lathrop, assistant director.
ROME, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- Yugoslavia was accused today at the trial of sixty alleged terrorists in Trieste of giving indirect financial support to a plot against Italy, fascism and Premier Mussolini.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would terminate unlisted trading privileges of the Chicago Rivet and Machine Company's common stock of $4 par value on the New York Curb Exchange unless the Exchange reduced the trading unit within ten days.

A mobile line with the speed to belie its 202-pound average from end to end and a compact backfield which combines straight power with a blend of passing good enough to bewilder any type of defense -- that's The United Press All-America football team for 1941.

Fordham's Sugar Bowl-bound, football team, honored with a Victory Dinner in the Dealy Hall dining room on the campus last night, received an additional accolade with the announcement that the Lambert Trophy had been voted to the Rams.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- First trials of the first full-sized "Sea Otter" type of small freighters indicated that the revolutionary craft was "very satisfactory," Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, said today.

ROME, Dec. 3 -- The Albanian Cabinet headed by Shevket Verlaci has resigned, it was announced this evening, and a new Cabinet was immediately appointed with Mustapha Merlika Kruja as Premier. No Verlaci Cabinet members were retained in the new Cabinet, which is composed chiefly of younger men.

The Pegasus, formerly the Danish freighter Rita Maersk, was commissioned as an auxiliary vessel by the Navy yesterday at the Sullivan Shipyards at Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn. The freighter was seized on March 30 in Boston Harbor when Axis vessels and other foreign ships in American waters were put under custody to prevent sabotage.

BERLIN, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- Reports from Belgium said today that Brussels University had begun a sitdown strike against German occupation authorities and that the Germans had served an ultimatum ordering the faculty to reopen the school tomorrow "or take the consequences."

VICHY, France, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- A German medical officer was shot down in the street in Paris last night while Reichmarshal Hermann Goering was playing host at a Franco - German "collaboration" dinner there.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Dec. 3 -- After a day of rest to shake off the effects of Monday's bruising scrimmage, the University of Missouri Tigers resumed work today in preparation for their New Year's Day engagement with the Fordham Rams in the Sugar Bowl at New Orleans.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 3 -- German bomber and fighter squadrons from the Southern Ukraine, Crimea and the huge reserve airdromes of Southern Austria are flying via Rumania, Bulgaria and Crete, and via Italy, to the German advance desert bases near Derne, Libya, it was reported here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A broad hint that the British and American navies have found an answer to the submarine menace in North Atlantic waters was given today by Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, in a few guarded remarks made at his weekly press conference.

"The millions of dollars being spent by our State Department in vast schemes for cultural relations with Latin America do not touch the group of Latin-American university women now struggling for recognition," declared Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College yesterday.

CHICAGO, Thursday, Dec. 4 -- With Franklin D. Roosevelt foremost among thousands or well-wishers, The Chicago Sun, the new morning newspaper here of Marshall Field 3d, ran off its first issue at midnight.

Ben Hogan and Sam Snead, top men among the nation's golf pros for 1941, will battle down a three-tournament, $20,000 home stretch in the next three weeks to decide who is No. 1 man for the year, according to The Associated Press.

Claude Bragdon, architect, stage designer, lecturer and author of sixteen books, at the age of 75, will hold his first exhibition of paintings at the Ferargil Galleries from Dec. 15 to 28. His watercolors, called "Mathematical abstractions," were first shown in Rochester.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The House passed today, by a record vote of 252 to 136, a defense antistrike measure more drastic in its terms than any legislation of its kind offered in Congress to date.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 3 -- Competent neutral observers here attach great political importance to the Russian evacuation of Hangoe saying it may be the last opportunity given the Finns to abandon military operations against the Soviet Union before a declaration of war by Britain.
The New York A.C. and Bayside Tennis Club Class A squash tennis teams continued to share first place in the metropolitan interclub series last night by remaining unbeaten.

Reflecting increased sales of armament, the American Car and Foundry Company reported yesterday a net income of $4,810,520, or 56.33 a common share, for the six months ended on Oct. 31. This compared with $823,655, or $2.85 a share, on the 7 per cent preferred stock, in the same period last year.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- A storm blew up in Parliament today over the government's proposals to widen its powers of conscription.

THIS is no place to stand on ceremony. Hence, in this corner, the eminent Albert B. Chandler, United States Senator from Kentucky, is simply an old acquaintance and a jolly good fellow named Happy Chandler. He used to be a football coach. That's how the fun started.

An investing client of Jay Winston, attorney, has bought from the Standard National Corporation for cash, above two first mortgages aggregating $217,800, the two sixstory apartment houses at 770-780 Garden Street, on the southeast corner of Prospect Avenue, the Bronx.

A wholesale purge of organizers and functionaries is under way in District 50, the coke, chemical and cosmetics division of the United Mine Workers, it became known yesterday after some of the ousted officials had charged that they were removed because they refused to support the isolationist policies of John L. Lewis, president of the C.I.O. union.

Strong support for the New York University Letter Club executive committee's recently announced series of conclusions concerning the N.Y.U.'s football situation exists among the rank-and-file members, according to John I. O'Neill, head of the organization and the 1925 Violet gridiron captain.
Dr. Robert T. Findlay picked up the telephone receiver at 9:30 A.M. yesterday, dialed the Beekman Hospital and said:

A steady stream of buying orders from the trade and Southern mill interests lifted cotton prices sharply yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The close was at the best levels of the day, with net gains of 25 to 33 points. The only selling was mostly in the form of hedges on a scale up.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 2 (Delayed) (AP) -- "If Thailand is forced to fight for her independence she will not be fighting alone." This statement, made repeatedly by the official Thai radio in recent weeks, assumes extraordinary significance now that the possibility of attack on this country is widely rumored abroad.

General denial that there has been any tightening of credit terms to South American purchasers was voiced yesterday by members of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the group's regular round-table conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Acute shortages of important drugs listed in the United States Pharmacopoeia and the National Formulary, which affect hundreds of medicinal products, were reported yesterday by E.C. Merrill of the United Drug Company, who recommended that under present emergency conditions action should be taken by revision committees in charge of these drugs and medicinal standards to permit substitutions or eliminations where specific drugs are unobtainable.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Asserting that "more than one dog has bitten the hand that fed it," Archbishop Michael J. Curley warned in an interview that Joseph Stalin was "quite capable of turning on the United States, were that to suit his purposes."

BERLIN, Dec. 3 -- It looks from here as if General Erwin Rommel has turned the tables on Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan Gordon Cunningham's forces in Libya, but official Nazi circles are cautious. They modestly claim "just one round," indicating that more rounds will follow, the outcome of which should ultimately depend on which side can produce the most reserves.

Exotic Touch There is a new atmosphere about the New York Curb Exchange these days. The building has been humming with activity ever since three firms of construction engineers took over four floors and started to hire help by wholesale, asking most applicants if they were willing to work outside the country.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- Japan is expected to tell the United States that Japanese forces have been sent to Indo-China because French authorities there are unable to maintain law and order and that these forces constitute no threat to Thailand, Tokyo papers hinted today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Dec. 4 -- Fighting on the Southern Front, which has been entirely in the Russians' favor since the rout of the German forces from Rostov, continued yesterday north and east of Taganrog, where fresh German reinforcements from the Perekop garrisons were reported to have met and strengthened fleeing units of Col. Gen. Paul Ludwig von Kleist's defeated armies.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Anne O'Hare McCormick, in her column of Nov. 29, rightly calls attention to the real peril now facing this nation, -- namely, "an apathy toward the value of what Americans stand to lose if Hitler wins the war."

Alter working for more than three months on clues consisting of two fingerprints and a hat and a pair of pliers found at the scene of the crime, detectives announced yesterday the arrest of a suspect in the murder of Patrolman Harold King in front of his home at 136 West Ninety-second Street in the early morning of Aug. 22.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 -- From this war must emerge a federation of the world, a great democracy in which all peoples might live in peace and prosperity, it was said today by Henry Ford, the man who first envisioned a country on wheels and lived to see his dream come true.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- Isaac Brown, 41 years old, New York insurance broker who is on trial in Westchester County Court on charges of felonious assault and attempted first degree murder, scored a tactical gain today when Miss Mathilde Le Boyer, 17, his accuser, admitted the authenticity of her signatures on letters which, the prosecution yesterday had branded as forgeries in entirety.

The arsenal of democracy has gained a mighty new weapon capable of shooting down anything that can fly and that is expected to prove a major factor in the war against Hitlerism, it was disclosed here yesterday.
Somebody in the White House probably will get two pairs of woolly sheepskin bedroom slippers, size twelve, for Christmas.

Testimony that the purported minutes of certain subsidiaries of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, which would vitally affect the status of the Re-cap Plan of 1933; were forgeries was presented yesterday before Frederick E. Crane, who is sitting as a special master in Federal court.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- A new development for the production of large quantities of high-octane aviation fuels has been perfected in the laboratories of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana at Whiting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The pessimistic mood of American government officials who have been conferring with the Japanese envoys is precisely as it has been reported in the press dispatches. This is to say the mood is real, and no part of a diplomatic front.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Dec. 1 (Delayed) -- General Wladyslaw Sikorski, Polish Premier, announced at a special press conference tonight that President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill had given definite assurance that "as many Polish soldiers as necessary" for the army of that occupied nation, now being re-formed, would be equipped by the United States and Great Britain.

BERLIN, Thursday, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Authorized German sources today ridiculed reports that the Germans had destroyed Rostov in reprisal for alleged guerrilla warfare. Without official confirmation, informed sources quoted Russian prisoners as saying Soviet mines planted earlier in Rostov had exploded, destroying many blocks in the heart of the city.
Substantial gains in earnings were revealed in the reports of three aircraft companies, according to the results made public yesterday.

Although Dorothy Maynor had appeared previously in Carnegie Hall as soloist with orchestra, the recital she gave last night was her first in that auditorium. The greatly talented Negro soprano was in much better vocal trim than when heard here early in the year.

Investigations indicating that the virus of infantile paralysis may enter the body through the bronchial tubes were presented here yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis by Dr. Harold K. Faber of San Francisco.

Max Schechter has purchased for investment from Sydney D. Robins through Weisberg Satler, brokers, the twenty-family apartment house at 2913 West Thirty-second Street, Brooklyn. The same brokers sold for a client to Michael Berr the property at 2857 West Thirtieth Street.

With stars of the cast of the Ice Follies featured, 10,000 spectators, practically all of whom were young boys and girls, attended the free instructive skating show in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. The program, lasting more than an hour, was held under the auspices of the National Physical Fitness Program In the Office of Civilian Defense.

Communists in New York City's public colleges and high schools run about three to the hundred, and through innocent-appearing subsidiary organizations influence about ten students out of every hundred. Such is the gist of the report of the Coudert committee, as shown in two sections released this week.
MOSCOW, Dec. 3 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet midday communique said today:

The trial at Trieste is sure to raise some of the same questions the Moscow trials never answered. No one will believe that the Ovra, Italian equivalent of the Gestapo and Ogpu, has just discovered a "vast" terroristic conspiracy against the Fascist regime that goes back as far as 1929.

BANGKOK, Dec. 2 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The Japanese Embassy spokesman here insisted today that the growing Japanese forces in French Indo-China were no threat to Thailand, but he said war was possible in East Asia unless the United States accepted Japan's conception of the "new order." Japan does not want war, he said, and any "outbreak depends on Washington."

De Pinna played to a full house yesterday noon in the Sert Room of the Hotel Waldorf. Fashion luncheons draw the crowds and those at the Waldorf are increasingly popular. Here one sees a goodly spicing of men mingling, unembarrassed, with the feminine spectators and thoroughly enjoying the display provided by the manikins, whose whirlwind changes offer considerable entertainment.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 2:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Lease-lend aid to arm China against Axis aggression has reached enormous volume, government officials said today, reporting that approximately 14,000 American-made trucks soon would be in operation over the Burma Road.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 3 -- British mobile patrols were active yesterday in clearing up certain battle areas in Libya, but a lull in major operations continued and no heavy fighting has been reported today. Some German guns were destroyed by a British patrol operating from Ed Duda, just outside the German-held area around Rezegh and Bir el-Hamed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Some of the reports of widespread starvation and deep suffering among the people of occupied France are "exaggerated," Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, recently told the House Appropriations Committee, it was disclosed today.
ROME, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:
Promoter Mike Jacobs's plans for a boxing show in Madison Square Garden Dec. 12 underwent another change yesterday.

Under a suspension of the rules there has been jammed through the House of Representatives new sugar legislation which provides among other things for: 1. Increased acreage for domestic cane and beet growers at the expense of decreased quotas for Cuba, Puerto Rico, Hawaii and the Philippines.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 3 -- The Government of India announced today that it had decided to release all passive resistance prisoners, including Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, president of the All-India Congress party, and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, former president.

ELEPHANTS, lions and rhinos are still charging Osa Johnson. On paper, at any rate, for the former Mrs. Martin Johnson (now Mrs. Clark H. Getts) is still writing up her African safaris and reporting her adventures, screams and escapes. Last year "I Married Adventure" offered certain details. More yet appear in "Four Years in Paradise."

Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Koch granted yesterday a temporary injunction restraining the Newsdealers Federal Labor Union, Local 22,371, from continuing its boycott against seven New York City daily newspapers. The injunction was asked by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. on charges that the union had violated the Donnelly act, which forbids combinations in restraint of trade.

A 31-year-old Negro, charged with threatening a woman school principal in Harlem with a knife, was so intoxicated when lie appeared in court yesterday afternoon that the case had to be adjourned until today.

Japan's diplomacy may veer from day to day with the fortunes of her Axis partners in the snows of Russia and the sands of Libya, but of far more fundamental consequence in the final outcome of affairs is the tightening economic pressure to which Japan is being subjected by those nations -- the United States among them -- which are no longer willing to supply the weapons of aggression.

Coinciding with the one hundredth anniversary on Jan. 7 of The Cleveland Plain Dealer's founding, a history of the newspaper will be published by Knopf as "The Plain Dealer: 100 Years in Cleveland." The author is Archer Shaw, a member of the paper's staff for thirty-nine years and its chief editorial writer during most of that period.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 3 -- Mrs. Mary Knieriem's Red Wrack galloped to the wire five lengths ahead of his nearest rival today in the Skyline Purse. The 4-year-old son of By-Pass II and Auburn moved to the outside and drew away with ease in the stretch.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 3 -- Lati, the Italian airline between Rome and Buenos Aires, will use Natal, Brazil, as a terminal in order to save gasoline, it is reported here. Lati officials will not confirm the report, though they declare that "at times" planes might find it justifiable to remain in Natal and let other Brazilian lines carry on from there to Rio de Janeiro.

Floyd B. Odlum, director of the Contract Distribution Division of the Office of Production Management, told the Congress of American Industry of the National Association of Manufacturers in session at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday that it would be impossible to win the defense effort "with a land full of corpses of little industry."

A Christmas gift of food may be as appealing and pretty as it is practical. The shops are full of an entrancing array of bottles and boxes and saucily beribboned packages -- rare and lovely ones for impressive presents and small perky ones for that "little remembrance."

"Smilin' Through," Metro's remake of the Jane Cowl-Jane Murfin play, will open this morning at the Capitol. Jeanette MacDonald, Brian Aherne, Gene Raymond and Ian Hunter head the cast of the romantic drama, which was filmed in Technicolor, under the direction of Frank Borzage.
Allied Chemical and Dye A special dividend of $2 was voted on the common stock by the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation. Payments this year total $8, the same as in 1940.

The New York City school system, for the first time in its history, is to oust a regular teacher, on the staff six years, because it was found that he misrepresented his working experience when applying for the school position, it was disclosed yesterday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Thursday, Dec. 4 -- Making his first deal since taking over his new duties as manager of the Giants, Melvin Ott early this morning succeeded in closing a player transaction with the Cubs that will bring Hank Leiber back to the Polo Grounds next Summer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A total of 189 additions were made through the State Department tonight to the blacklist of nationals having Axis ties in Latin America. The effeet is to withhold the benefits of American trade by forbidding American firms, under penalty of fines, from dealing with companies and individuals having dealings with Axis interests.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Finnish High Command issued this communique today:

The thirteen-story loft building, with stores, at 12-14 West Thirty-second Street has been sold by Loomis J. Grossman to the Wright-Haft Associates, Inc. The sale was subject to a $152,000 first mortgage.

A program to provide uniformed men in the armed forces visiting the city on Christmas furloughs and who are short of funds not only with theatre tickets, but also with "meal tickets" to hotels, restaurants and night clubs was outlined yesterday by leaders in the food and beverage industry in cooperation with the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Contracts totaling $5,678,948 were awarded by the War Department today. Awards to firms in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut follows:

The Pulitzer Building, a Park Row landmark famous for many years as the home of The New York World, has been sold by the estate of Joseph Pulitzer to Samuel B. Shankman, who intends to renovate it for investment. It is assessed for tax purposes at $2,375,000 and was sold for all cash in a deal negotiated by the Charles F. Noyes Company.

Because of the increasing tension in the Pacific and the apparently improved conditions in the South Atlantic, drastic revisions in cargo war-risk insurance rates between the Americas and Africa, the Persian Gulf, Australasia and the East and Far East were announced yesterday by marine underwriters here.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 3 -- Reconstructing the action fought between the Australian cruiser Sydney and the German raider that was known alternately as the Steiermark and the Kormoran, Premier John Curtin revealed today that the engagement had occurred at dusk 300 miles west of Carnarvon, Western Australia, while the Sydney was on patrol duty.

Two fine male singers and a lissom young prima donna who can be convincing to the eye should be enough to impart zest to Saint-Saens's "Samson et Dalila." The Metropolitan Opera, which has tried to revitalize the work, assembled precisely such a cast for the season's first performance of the opera last night.

The State of Tennessee sold yesterday through competitive bidding a new issue of $1,522,000 of various purpose bonds to a syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co., and inculding R.W. Pressprich Co.; Paine, Webber Co.; Otis Co., Inc., all of New York; Webster Gibson, Nashville, Term.; the Wells-Dickey Company of Minneapolis, and the Milwaukee Company.

Neither Japanese residents nor any other non-citizens of the United States need have "any anxiety" about possible deportation or internment in the event of war against their homelands, if they have had a good record in this country, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 3 -- The Women's New Jersey Golf Association held its annual meeting at the Montclair Golf Club today, with Mrs. Harold S. Ford of Ridgewood, president, presiding.

A defense of the Office of Price Administration's position in opposing inclusion of wage control in price control was presented yesterday before about 150 executives of large New York companies by John E. Hamm, deputy administrator, who also explained the OPA stand with respect co other features of the Price Control Bill now pending in Congress.
Aided chiefly by two pieces of helpful legislation, the nation's college football teams this season want on their biggest scoring spree since 1930.

The problem of labor migration will become more difficult within the next year, with women constituting the greater part of the increase, Miss Mary Dublin, coordinator of hearings for the House committee investigating national defense migration, warned yesterday.

A sumptuously bound copy of the first edition of William H. Ireland's "The Life of Napoleon Bonaparte" was sold for $2,850 last night at the auction of the library of the late William H. Woodin, former Secretary of the Treasury, at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc.
SEATTLE, Dec. 3 -- Bowl choices and undefeated teams generally did all right in this year's statistical chase over the gridiron yardage lines.
BERLIN, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The German High Command communique said today:

Dobbs is following the feminine trail. Always noted for the excellence of its classic hats, this well-known house, now celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary, is taking a fling with delightful soft treatments which add to rather than take away from the type of millinery on which they have made their reputation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Here are questions and answers concerning the future rights and status of unions and their members in defense industries under the drastic Anti-Strike Bill approved by the House today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A decrease of $9,000,000 in September and October in the accounts receivable of personal finance companies was cited today as an effect of the Federal Reserve Board's regulations to limit installment buying which became effective on Sept. 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The text of the Smith bill to curb labor disputes in defense industries, which the House adopted today, is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The House Appropriations Committee reported today its third Supplemental Defense Appropriation Bill for the current fiscal year, carrying $8,109,945,898 in appropriations and contract authorizations for the Army, Navy and civilian agencies engaged in defense work.

Following is the text of the address delivered yesterday fey William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, at the forty-sixth annual Congress of American Industry of the National Association of Manufacturers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel:

It may be said in favor of the anti-strike bill passed yesterday by the House by the heavy vote of 252 to 136 that at least it showed that Congress has a backbone and at last is not only willing but eager to act, and act drastically, to control the strike evil that has become so grave a menace to the country's defense program.

The Congress of American Industry of the National Association of Manufacturers unanimously voiced yesterday its demand for Federal legislation to control strikes in defense industries after William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management, had told the industrialists that laws should be passed, if necessary, to stop this "foolishness."

LONDON, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- The Germans are using Poland as a "testing ground" to prove that other European nations can be dominated under the new "Germanic culture," a Polish spokesman said tonight, as reports of violence and unrest reached here from all parts of the Continent.

KINGS PARK, L. I., Dec. 3 -- George Horn, 26 years old, a mental patient, was shot dead this afternoon at the Kings Park State Hospital by an older sister in the presence of their mother, according to District Attorney Fred J. Munder, who quoted the sister as saying she had decided to "put him out of his misery."

In an effort to trap a "dinnertime" thief who in the past month has robbed ten apartments in some of the finer midtown hotels, forty detectives in evening clothes have been assigned to mingle with guests in lobbies and near hotel dining rooms, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 29 totaled 866,189 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 66,803 cars, or 8.4 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 137,664 cars, or 18.9 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 180,693 cars, or 26.4 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The seventy-eight-family apartment house at 2504 Bronx Park East, on the corner of Mace Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Sarah Bernstein to Herlon Estates, Inc., for cash above a first mortgage of 5190,000. The total consideration is said to be more than 225,000.

Ralph Alonzo Sturges, New York attorney, who lives at Masury Point, Center Moriches, L.I., was elected president of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York at the annual meeting yesterday in Fraunces Tavern, Broad and Pearl Streets.

The last obstacle to full settlenent of the union shop dispute in the captive coal mines was removed yesterday when the Crucible Steel Company committed itself to abide by any decision of the three-man board appointed by President Roosevelt to arbitrate the issue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Passage of the $8,243,839,031 third supplemental defense appropriation bill was asked in the House today on the ground that it was "needed to win," and that by approving it the United States would be telling Japan "that we mean business."

Gabriel Gonzales-Videla, Chilean Minister to Vichy who arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday aboard the Pan American Airways Yankee Clipper on his way to take part in the Chilean election campaign, declared that all the South American countries were anxious to cooperate with the United States.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 4 -- Within twelve hours of the official announcement by the government of India of its decision to release passive-resistance prisoners it was announced today that 500 Congress party members had been released. They included Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, president of the All-India Congress party, and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, former president, two of the most important political personages in India to have been detained.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- House debate on the new $8,000,000,000 Army Appropriation Bill was held up for an hour and a half today as the result of the publication by The Chicago Tribune of a Washington dispatch asserting that the government had a plan calling for an American expeditionary force of 5,000,000 men and for total armed forces of 10,045,658 men.

LONDON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A nephew of Mrs. Winston Churchill, Flying Officer Esmond Marcus David Romilly, who has packed a variety of adventure into his 22 years, is reported missing in action on the eve of a planned reunion with his wife and their nine-month-old son.
A men's team of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association defeated a combination of women, 5 to 0, in the season's first match of its kind at the Junior League Club yesterday.

The annual "stag" party in honor of the opening of Bonwit Teller's 721 Club for men was staged last evening at the store at 721 Fifth Avenue. The rendezvous for the members and the gift fashion show was on the second floor, where the store assembles all the gifts men like to give women.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 5 -- Tokyo was struck as by a bombshell, in the words of the newspaper Asahi today, with the revelation of the substance of the Japanese-American negotiations by President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A public hearing, in which persons qualified to talk about copper production will be invited to give their views on the possibilities of expanding output, was ordered here today by the Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board.

VICHY, France, Dec. 4 -- At a press conference today Joseph Barthelemy, Minister of Justice, described the task of the French Government "in these difficult times" as twofold: to build institutions for the future and simultaneously to throw out temporary bridges to meet pressing emergencies as they arise.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A submarine that torpedoed but did not sink the United States Navy tanker Salinas on Oct. 30 was apparently damaged by shellfire from the tanker, the Navy Department reported tonight.

The comparatively new skiing technique, the parallel method, was explained by E. Fritz Loosli, chief exponent of the system, last night at Jaeger's Turn Hall before an overflow crowd of 1,000. The chief instructor of the Ski Hawk School in Lac Beauport, P.Q., making his first appearance in this country, used colored motion pictures in demonstrating this much-discussed technique.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I trust that members of the House and Senate, standing for America above all parties and special interests, will rise against the pension bill, which overtops all pension grabs to date. Congress must now act in all things in the interest of the nation if America is to be saved from her own foolish greed.
BERLIN, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The German High Command communique from the Fuehrer's headquarters today said:

Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. of the Baltusrol Golf Club was elected president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association as an entirely new slate took office at the annual meeting at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Standing In perplexity at the crossroads is not a posture of Japan only at this political conjuncture. Such is rather the typical and chronic attitude of the country since the time when, having grasped the apparent splendor of European culture, it failed to get rid of its traditional impetuosity.
Check transactions for the week ended on Wednesday increased 13.2 per cent over the total for the previous week and rose 20.4 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx engaged in a sharp-tongue row yesterday with Deputy Mayor Rufus E. McGahen over the latter's action in taking Mr. Lyons's request for a hearing on wage increases for city employes off the Board of Estimate calendar.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 4 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 3:

One of the worst fogs in recent years continued to envelop the city last night in a gloomy pall that will probably last until late this morning, slowing harbor, train, automobile and air traffic for the third day.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 4 -- The Finnish High Command announced tonight that the Russian evacuation of the Hangoe Naval Base had become a disastrous welter of exploding and surrendering naval transports, and newspapers viewed the episode as bringing closer "a victorious end" of Soviet-Finnish hostilities.

Markets Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. urged that the Federal Government provide $10,000,000 for a new wholesale market on lower West Street in the annual report of his department for 1940, sent to Mayor La Guardia on July 8, 1941, and made public by Mr. Morgan last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 4 -- The forces of labor and capital and industry in this country are going to be marshaled to bring about the defeat of Hitler just as the young men are being marshaled into military service, Edward C. Eicher, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, declared today in a prepared statement to the press issued during the thirtieth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America here.

The Congress of American Industry of the National Association of Manufacturers adopted unanimously yesterday a platform demanding a single agency with a single head to guide and speed the defense program. The platform, adopted at the association's forty-sixth annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, declared such an agency necessary to hold down the cost and to eliminate the confusion resulting from conflicting authority and the overlapping of governmental committees.

Mrs. James Norman Hill gave a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Mr. and Mrs. Beverley R. Robinson. Among the other guests were Mrs. Lyttleton Fox, Francis Potter, Blevin Davis and Lucius Humphreys.

In an atmosphere of Mexico, with native melodies being sung, an exhibit of Mexican jewelry designed by a young American woman was exhibited yesterday afternoon in the gown shop of Rose Gossert, 660 Fifth Avenue. The designer is Mary Contreras.

A comprehensive plan of recapitalization and physical integration designed to meet the requirements of the "death sentence" section of the Public Utility Holding Company Act was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission late yesterday by the Electric Power and Light Corporation, a $730,000,000 sub-holding unit in the Electric Bond and Share Company system.

As an aid to building morale of men in military service, members of the National Council of the (Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday urged that the War Department obtain a statement of the religious denomination of men inducted into service.

BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- For the first time since the latest drive against the Soviet capital began on Nov. 18, the daily communique of the German High Command does not mention the Moscow front today. The communique also omits reference to events in the Taganrog-Rostov sector, but claims that strong Soviet attacks in the Donets bend were repulsed with heavy losses for the attackers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The $1,500,000,000 medium and long term loan the Treasury floated this morning was so liberally subscribed by this evening that the books were closed except for individual offers up to $5,000 where the subscribers specify that delivery should be made in registered bonds ninety days after the issue date.

Day of the Horse It sounds more like a proud defiance than a sober statement of belief, but events give it timeliness. The head of the New Jersey State Grange says that the horse is staging a comeback on the farm.

Karl Decker, who was one of William Randolph Hearst's outstanding correspondents during the Spanish-American War, died Wednesday afternoon, after a twoweeks' illness, at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 73 years old.

A new type of pain killer which may transform the spirit of anxiety in which many patients approach the dentist's chair into a gay party mood, was described yesterday before several thousand dentists at the seventeenth annual session of the Greater New York Dental Meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Bidders for rare paintings paid the highest total realized in years at a single session of an art auction here last night. Fifty-six pictures from the collection of the late Mrs. B.F. Jones Jr., Sewickley Heights, Pa., brought $266,610 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc.

A revolutionary new treatment for infantile paralysis, developed during the last thirty years in Australia by Sister Elizabeth Kenny, a graduate nurse, and introduced by her in this country in June, 1940, was officially approved yesterday by a committee of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis at the second annual medical meeting of the foundation at the New York Academy of Medicine.

James E. Anderson, 20 years old, a tall, slender Texan, was held without bail in Homicide Court yesterday for a hearing next Thursday as a suspected confederate of his brother, Robert, since slain in Arkansas, in the fatal shooting of Traffic Patrolman Harold J. King on Aug. 22.

Walking to early mass half a block from her church and a block from a police station, Miss Dolores Infante, 25 years old, of 560 West 144th Street, was "mugged" toy a Negro in an, attempted robbery in the heavy fog at 6 o'clock yesterday morning on Amsterdam Avenue between 152d and 153d Streets.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Although wheat showed some strength in the early trading today, advancing around 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish to a new high on the current movement, there was not the snap to the buying which featured operations recently, and the market was called upon to absorb heavy profit-taking.
Navy and Harvard each placed two men on the 1941 All-Eastern football team selected yesterday for The Associated Press.

The great Whizzer White of the Detroit Lions may bow out of the professional football picture and into an Army uniform with the leadership in two defensive departments in the National Football League, it was disclosed yesterday in the release of individual defensive figures.
The twenty-sixth annual exhibition of the New York Society of Painters is being held at the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, until Dec. 18.
