DETROIT, Dec. 4 -- Modere (Mud) Bruneteau's goal in the last minute of play enabled the Red Wings to win a see-saw National Hockey League battle tonight, 4 to 3, from the Brooklyn Americans before 6,179 fans.

Repeal of the prohibition amendment to the Federal Constitution, which occurred eight years ago today, has resulted in substantial improvements in social and economic conditions, public morality and public finances, according to the United Brewers Industrial Foundation, 21 East Fortieth Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- The general executive board of Sidney Hillman's Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C.I.O., asserted today that enactment of the Smith bill would wipe out the major gains which labor has painfully won under the New Deal, regiment the workers of America with fascist restrictions and penalties and threaten the very existence of labor organizations."

Allied Products The Allied Products Corporation increased its total disbursements this year to $3.25 from $2 paid in 1940 with the declaration yesterday of a special dividend of $1.75 a share in addition to the regular quarterly of 25 cents on the common stock.

In fifteen New York City high schools Communist students, togather with their "front" organizations, have engaged in "widespread agitational activity" and have disrupted the orderly conduct of the classrooms, the Rapp-Coudert subcommittee charged yesterday in making public the second section of its three-part report on subversive activities.

Though Winter has come, Spring is not far behind in California. The vernal season has already been initiated on the West Coast-according to the week-end survey of the consumers division of the Department of Markets-with a resultant drop of 6 cents a dozen in the price of Grade A eggs in New York City.

LONDON, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- The Moscow radio said today that the Yugoslav patriots' army, reported to be opposing seven full German divisions in the Serbian mountain wildernesses, had captured the important towns of Cacak and Uzice, inflicting heavy losses on the Germans in a battle still under way.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Dec. 5 -- Along roads littered with wrecked tanks, burning gasoline trucks and discarded arms, Russian forces on the southern front continued their terrific pressure against Col. Gen. Paul Ludwig von Kleist's forces on the Taganrog Road, cleaning up isolated nests of resistance before the town of Taganrog, according to the military spokesman on the Moscow radio early this morning.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4 -- William Saroyan, playwright, has joined Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer under a contract as a producer, it was learned today. Details of the agreement were not disclosed, but it is understood that Saroyan will spend some time at the studio studying film technique before he makes a picture.

Councilman Louis Cohen, chairman of a committee holding a public hearing in City Hall yesterday on a proposal to abolish the proportional representation method of electing Councilmen, threw a heavy black gavel at A. David Benjamin, counsel of the Republican party in Brooklyn, when the latter criticized Mr. Cohen's record as a public official.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Japanese Government, will make its reply tomorrow to President Roosevelt's inquiry concerning the massing of Japanese troops in French Indo-China and may make a general statement of policy in answer in part or in whole to the document submitted by Secretary of State Cordell Hull last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Revising its original estimates in order to achieve the curtailment desired, the Office of Production Management today ordered mechanical refrigerator manufacturers to cut January and February production 30 to 52 par cent below the monthly average output for the twelve months ended June 30 last.

Senator George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, suggests that Federal taxes have now reached "nearmaximum" levels and cannot be increased much more without weakening the whole economy. A similar point of view has recently been expressed by several other authorities on taxation.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 4 -- Yoshiaki Maira, Japanese Minister to Mex-, ico, said tonight that he and the second secretary of the legation, Hitoshi Satoh, had been summoned to Tokyo and would probably leave on the Tatuta Maru, which has been asked to stop at Manzanillo Dec. 19 to take aboard the two diplomats and perhaps sixty Japanese subjects desiring to return home.

Insurance advertising should promote not only the welfare of the individual company but also the welfare of the institution of insurance, R.P. Barbour, United States manager for Northern Assurance Company and president of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, declared yesterday at the luncheon session of the one-day Insurance Advertising Conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Russian orchestral works, Russia having become not only sanctioned, but positively fashionable in these days of her magnificent battle against a common foe, made the burden of the orchestral part of the program given by Dr. Rodzinski and the Philharmonic-Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall, and a piano concerto by an immortal Pole, played by his living and brilliantly endowed countryman, Mr. Arthur Rubenstein, completed, the list.

An arbitration board, appointed under the provisions of the "Guildshop" agreement between The New York Daily Mirror and the New York Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., rejected yesterday a Guild demand for the dismissal of two Mirror employes who resigned from the Guild before the contract went into effect last May.

Another Treasury Call Even with its preoccupation with the new $1,500,000,000 financing, the Treasury is losing no time in calling for funds which it has on deposit with commercial banks throughout the nation. Yesterday, as the result of calls issued to depository banks on last Monday, it got in $71,631,000, of which $19,800,000 was from the New York Federal Reserve District.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Vast expansion of New Jersey's industries for defense purposes has brought increased activity not only in factory properties but also in the market for country homes and farms, members of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards were informed today at the opening of their annual convention here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- There are lions in the path of the House bill to eliminate those strikes in the defense Industries that attempt to use the national emergency to "advance the gains" of organized labor. The bill's enemies are pledged to modify it to a point of innocuousness, if they can; or, if they cannot, to draw as many of its teeth as possible by the several processes of obstruction, delay and alarmist warnings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The United States must spend from $120,000,000,000 to $150,000,000,000 to bring about the defeat of Nazi Germany, defense officials estimate in a report scheduled to be sent to President Roosevelt within the next few days.

A more comprehensive effort to conserve vision, with attention to industrial eye accidents, particularly in the defense program, and additional legislation to prevent causes of blindness, was called for yesterday by speakers at the biennial conference of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness in the Hotel Astor.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that a flat increase of $10 a month has been obtained in negotiations with six tanker operators, adding approximately $480,000 a year to the companies' payrolls. The increase, asked for to meet the rising cost of living, will affect 4,000 men employed on 120 bulk carriers.

A gambling house that is alleged to have mulcted prosperous business men of more than $50,000 since it started operations two months ago was raided yesterday by plainclothes policemen who had tried for more than two weeks to get into the premises on the third floor of the ten-story apartment house at 15 East Forty-eighth Street.

Serge Rubinstein, International financier, admitted yesterday that he had formed a corporation in Panama to which he intended to transfer assets now the subject of litigation in this country. This admission came in the course of a hearing before New York Supreme Court Referee Richard P. Lydon to determine whether the Chosen Corporation, Ltd., of which Mr. Rubinstein is managing director, is doing business in this jurisdiction.

A jury in Federal Court spent a little less than an hour and a quarter yesterday in reaching a verdict convicting Carlo M. Flumiani of mail fraud. He had been quoted at his trial as intending to make money out of his belief that the United States was "a fine country, full of peasants who think they can write."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 4 -- Having held the spotlight for the last three days, first by naming Mel Ott their new manager, then by acquiring Hank Leiber from the Cubs, the Giants today continued to hold the No. 1 position in interest among the assembled baseball clans by locking horns in a long conference with their arch foes, the Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A new system for the distribution of contracts was announced today by the Navy as a means of bringing help to the country's "depressed areas." A relaxing of specifications was being ordered wherever possible, it was stated, to spread the manufacture of defense materials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Large Air Corps contracts granted to Midwest bidders helped swell the total value of War Department awards today to $33,403,448. Companies in the New York area which received contracts, not previously published, were as follows:

In the interests of Pan-American cultural relations one hundred sets of the newly published four volumes of "The Public Papers and Addresses of Franklin D. Roosevelt" are being distributed by the publishers, Macmillan, the libraries in South America and Canada.

ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- Economic chaos under stress of mounting Federal, State and local government costs, unless non-defense expenditures were drastically cut, was pictured today at a meeting of 300 delegates, representing sixty-two civic or taxpayers' groups, which formed the New York State Emergency Committee on Non-Defense Spending.

YREKA, Calif., Dec. 4 -- While cannon boomed on the Court House lawn of this little mining town, Judge John L. Childs of Crescent City took over tonight as "Governor" of the new "State" of Jefferson, comprising the "secession" counties of Del Norte, Lassen, Trinity and Siskiyou in California and Curry in Oregon.

An eight-room suite with four baths in 320 East Seventy-second Street has been leased by Dr. Henry Hein, principal of the James Monroe High School, according to Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., who also reports the rental of an apartment in 80 West Fortieth Street to Antonio da Costa, European sculptor.

Left to care for themselves while their parents were at work, the three youngest children of John and Esther McEniry were felled by gas fumes yesterday in their home on the fourth floor of 401 Third Avenue, near Twenty-eighth Street.

The Downtown A.C. took undisputed possession of second place, breaking its tie with the Princeton Club, as a result of the Metropolitan Class A squash racquets matches yesterday afternoon. Downtown, tournament winner two years in succession, defeated the University Club, 4 -- 1, on the latter'a courts.

TORONTO, Ont., Dec. 4 -- Justice Middleton granted today the application of the Montreal Trust Company, Canadian trustee, to sell without reserve bid the assets, property and undertaking of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd.

The news of the Russian fighting yesterday-sifted through censorship and liable to exaggeration as it was-nevertheless indicated that in the future history of this conflict the name Rostov might be written in large letters upon the sanguinary pages of the war's greatest campaign.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Further testimony regarding the operations of Leon K. Shanack, alleged broker in national defense contracts, set forth to a House investigating committee today that, although the New Yorker had no manufacturing plant of his own, his actual and potential profits soared to $212,891.92 in thirteen months through oral agreements made with the two of the small machine and tool companies with which he dealt.

Weather Hits Men's Wear Sales The warm weather continued to put a damper on men's clothing sales this week and overcoats, which should be moving in brisk volume, are still slow, retailers reported yesterday. Gift buying has started on a small scale but it is too early as yet to determine any trends, retailers said.

NAIROBI, Kenya Colony, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- British troops will remove all Italians from Ethiopia, including colonists sent to Premier Benito Mussolini's "East African empire," and then will withdraw themselves, leaving the country to the Ethiopians, it was announced today.
THERE is an elusive analogy between the work of Steinbeck and the work of Hemingway that continues this morning with the publication of "Sea of Cortez."*
The New York University Letter Club, an organization of former Violet athletes, last night officially went on record as disapproving practically the entire football set-up at their alma mater.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Dec. 3 (Delayed) -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko, stocky, hard-bitten master tactician of the Soviet Army, is now engaged in completing the mopping up phases of his second important victory against the Wehrmacht -- the only major defeats Adolf Hitler has so far suffered on land since he instigated and began his world war, more than two years ago.

Six buildings containing stores and apartments at the northeast corner of Ninth Avenue and West Thirty-fifth Street have been sold by the Bank for Savings to Benjamin S. Goodman for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $99,900 for ten years.

Unusually warm, weather has been responsible, florists said yesterday, for phenomenal shipments of roses to the New York flower markets this week. A hundred thousand rose buds are arriving daily from greenhouses on Long Island, in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Connecticut and New Hampshire.

Profit-taking coupled with the realization that the Senate would tone down the anti-strike bill passed by the House tempered the upswing in prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday, but only after the list had attained new high levels for the current recovery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Vice President Wallace took a hand in the defense anti-strike legislative situation today as the drastic Smith bill, which was adopted by the House yesterday, came up to him as presiding officer of the Senate.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

A campaign to promote New York City as a style center is under consideration by the Industrial Committee of the City of New York, it was learned yesterday. This drive would be entirely separate from that now being conducted by the Dress Institute to promote apparel produced here.

RIOM, France, Dec. 4 -- Preparations are now well under way here for the trial scheduled to begin Jan. 15 of the men accused of responsibility for France's defeat! The building where the Supreme Court will sit is being put in condition, and an underground passage from the prison to the court is being reconditioned to permit the transfer of the prisoners without thier passing through the street.
ROME, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique today follows:

If the Administration many months ago had initiated or even consented to a careful and impartial study of the legislation needed to deal with the increasingly chaotic labor situation, it could have got from the House a more maturely considered and better balanced measure than the Smith bill.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Representatives from industrial and rural areas divided sharply in their votes yesterday on the Smith bill to cope with strikes and other labor troubles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Representative Engel of Michigan told the House today that the cost to the Postoffice Department of departmental franked mail during the past seven years was $236,156,000. He said in 1940 alone it amounted to $41,533,000, as compared with $42,701,000 for the four years of the Hoover Administration.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- Miss Marion Mason Colt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Sloan Colt of New York and Tuxedo Park, will be married in St. Mary's Episcopal Church here the day after Christmas to Lieutenant Maclean Williamson, U.S.A., of Fort Sill, Okla.

Excess reserves of the thirty-six member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City rose $40,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, it was revealed yesterday, marking the fourth, consecutive weekly gain. This rise, making a gain of $355,000,000, lifted the total to $1,130,000,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES is to be commended for opening its columns to an extended discussion of the merits of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project; for the importance of the proposed undertaking warrants its most careful and enlightened consideration by the American people and by Congress.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Dec. 4 -- Trading on the Bourse increased at the start today, with the opening prices strong. Heavy realizing, however, brought on a reaction, but the close generally was higher. A.K.U. advanced 2 points to 158 3/4 after selling at 161.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- With markets fluctuating narrowly, the general level of wholesale prices last week again climbed to the eleven-year peak reached two weeks ago, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Democratic human values and social gains can be preserved and defense production accelerated in this country through joint voluntary action of management and labor in formulating policies, more than 300 delegates to the annual conference of the Society for the Advancement of Management at the Hotel Commodore were told yesterday by representatives of British labor and American management authorities.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Finnish High Command issued this communique today:

MANILA, Dec. 4 -- A detachment of forty-six United States mechanical and trucking experts, assigned to improve the Burma Road to China under protection of United States planes and pilots, have arrived here en route to their new posts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The creation of an army of 200,000 Jews, to be recruited in the United States, Palestine and other countries, was urged tonight in a series of resolutions adopted at a conference called by Dr. Samuel Harden Church, president of Carnegie Institute and chairman of the new committee for a Jewish Army.
The Board of Education was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Harry E. Lewis to cease employing teachers in positions for which they are not licensed.

No people can make a musical comedy seem so much like a matter of duty as Sigmund Romberg and Oscar Hammerstein 2d. Following a venerable pattern they have put together a workmanlike item labeled "Sunny River," which was sung at the St. James last evening.

At Mayor La Guardia's suggestion a conference between him and District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn will be held at City Hall at 10:30 A. M. Monday in connection with the bitter controversy in which the opponents in the recent municipal election have split over the question of handling policemen engaged in a broad criminal inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Japan has jockeyed herself into a position from which she now finds it difficult to recede with good grace, even for the very important purpose of saving the Washington conversations from utter collapse. Ambassador Kichisaburo Nomura's remark that "there must be wise statesmanship to save the situation" sounds almost like sarcasm aimed at Tokyo itself.

Reporting the largest profit for any year since its merger in 1936, the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation announced a net profit of $4,617,052 for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, after all charges, including depreciation, reserves and taxes. The profit, which is equivalent to $1.07 a share on 4,291,235 outstanding common shares, held by 45,000 stockholders, compares with $1,505,151 earned in the previous fiscal year.
MOSCOW, Dec. 4 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique broadcast today by the Moscow radio follows:

HARTFORD, Dec. 4 -- Eight men are dead, six are missing, presumably drowned, and seventeen are in hospitals as a result of the collapse this afternoon of a huge steel girder and its temporary pier, part of the new bridge being built over the Connecticut River between Hartford and East Hartford.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations rallied their forces today in an effort to stop passage by the Senate of the antistrike bill in its present form.
DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 4 -- Detroit faced today a transportation shutdown ten days before Christmas like that of last August, in which workers and shoppers walked or hitch-hiked for five days.

Sanford Towers, the four-story garden apartment property at 4237 Union Street, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by Maccalco, Inc., to an investing client of Max Ringel, broker, for cash above a new first mortgage of $100,000.

CURRITUCK BEACH, N.C., Dec. 4 -- The outer banks here have quite a reputation as a place of violent storms and high winds, and from Currituck Light to Ocracoke Island there are many skeletons that were once fine ships, but unless this area is visited by one of these storms soon the shore will be lined with the specters of dispirited gunners.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 4 (AP) -- The minor baseball leagues voted unanimously today for an

ON THE GERMAN FRONTIER, Dec. 4 -- It is learned that the Vichy Government has agreed to give Germany all the naval and air bases she requires in French North Africa on condition that she occupy them without the assistance of the French Fleet.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Defying air and sea raiders, Santa Claus will take a merry-making sweep through war torn Britain this Christmas, distributing such rarities as new toys and American candy among many thousands of children who otherwise might have had to go without them, according to "communiques" issued today by London headquarters of the British War Relief Society of America and the American Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A five-man Congressional committee which recently returned from a tour of seventeen Latin-American countries today asked the State Department to survey British competition with United States firms in the light of the present aid-to-Britain program.
The adolescent girl of America was pictured yesterday by speakers at the annual luncheon of the Girls Service League held in the Hotel Plaza as neglected and in need of a new form of glorification.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 4 -- New Jersey members of the C.I.O. and A.F. of L. unions came to a public agreement tonight -- on Hitlerism.

"Rise and Shine," a Twentieth Century-Fox comedy produced by Mark Hellinger and based on the James Thurber work, "My Life and Hard Times," will be the new screen attraction opening today at the Roxy. Jack Oakie, George Murphy, Linda Darnell, Milton Berle and Walter Brennan head the film's cast.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The British East African Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Chairman Cannon of the House appropriations committee today told the House that Army officials appearing before that committee have made "no intimation or suggestion" of plans to use United States troops "anywhere outside the Western Hemisphere."

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 4 -- The national contract mixed pair championship went to a married pair, Mr. and Mrs. Jeff Glick of Miami Shores, Fla., in the American Contract Bridge League's tournament today.

Ruth St. Denis began a series of four dance performances at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall last night with the first New York presentation in more than a quarter of a century of "Radha," the work with which she won her fame thirty-five years ago.
The platform on "National Defense and America's Future," adopted yesterday by the Congress of American Industry of the National Association of Manufacturers, follows:

Cotton futures continued their rise in the early trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and at one time showed gains of 21 points or $1.05 a bale. Profit-taking and scattered selling, however, left the list with net advances of 5 to 11 points.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- A small fissure appeared today in the Churchill government coalition when the most drastic conscription bill ever offered in any democracy passed its first test by a vote of 326 to 10.
BERLIN, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Nov. 29 shows the following changes for the week -- in thousands of reichsmarks:

The greatest industrial era in this nation's history is reaching new high levels daily and will attain its greatest peak during 1942, according to reports presented yesterday to the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at the Hotel Astor.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation, in an address yesterday before the forty-sixth annual meeting of the National Association of Manufacturers in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, called upon American industry to take the initiative in planning for the post-war period, so we may "rebuild a foundation of confidence in the minds of men in the longterm future."
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed Reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

Declaring that labor, as well as capital, must realize that no personal gains are important enough to hamper national defense, United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa, who recently sent two labor officials to the penitentiary on racketeering charges, called on labor last night to expel its own "pirates" by setting up safeguards against dishonest union elections and mis-j use of union funds.

A five-point plan to achieve price stabilization in the liquor industry of this area was submitted to representatives of distillers, rectifiers and importers yesterday on behalf of the Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association, by Rudy Marwede, president.

The Treasury Department has assured Wall Street banks that it will take steps to relieve the grave situation that has arisen over the refusal of foreign shippers to accept New York letters of credit through fear of new "freezing" orders, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Fairly active trading developed in the market for hogs today at steady to 10 cents a hundred weight lower quotations as Eastern shippers and smaller killers took most offerings. The top of $10.15 equalled yesterday's high. Dressed pork firmed, light loins bringing 17 1/2, to 18 cents a pound, up 1/2 cent.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks set a season's high for scoring tonight when they defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 9 -- 2, before 8,103 spectators in the Chicago Stadium.

BEL AIR, Md., Dec. 4 (AD) -- Herbert H. Cox Jr., 16-year-old Alexandria (Va.) youth, was sentenced to twelve years in the Maryland Penitentiary today for second-degree murder in the slaying of Grainger O. Browning, 38-year-old North Carolina carpenter, on the night of Oct. 12.

Brokerage houses with ticker services have been receiving checks ranging from $250 to $1,000 from the New York Quotations Company, representing refunds of the Federal 5 per cent tax collected from Feb. 29, 1936, to Feb. 3, 1940, less 10 per cent to cover expenses of collection and distribution.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- Red Army forces on the southern front have occupied about 100 villages west of Rostov in the last twenty-four hours and Soviet troops to the north have started a big push through the Donets basin after crushing a German offensive in the Kharkov region, Russian radio reports claimed early today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 4 -- Although a continued lull in the land fighting in Libya was reported here today, it was announced that the British were rushing up reserves to attack German forces weakened by the many engagements of recent days.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Brooks have arrived from their place in Newport, and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The front page of this newspaper yesterday carried two Washington dispatches different in origin but logically related. Both were "jumped" to an inside page, on which appeared a third article, closely bound up with the other two. Dispatch No. 1 reported a Supplemental Defense Appropriation Bill of $8,109,945,898, which will bring the total of our defense appropriations to nearly $68,000,000,000.

The Giants were at full war strength yesterday when George Franck, Johnny Mellus, Bill Edwards and Chet Gladchuk returned to action after several days' absence. Except for the permanent departures of such stalwarts as Marion Pugh, Vince Dennery, Frank Reagan and Don Vosberg, the New Yorkers are close to a physical peak.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- With women taking greater part in the defense program by shifting to jobs in industry where the necessities for the battle and the home front are produced, the research division of the Women's Bureau has made a survey of how to dress for bench and machine and found, it reported today, that the well-dressed woman in industry is the safe worker.

Verdi's "Otello" received its first performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan. The magnificent work, which has lost none of its forcefulness and appeal with the passing of time, was unevenly presented, singing of consequence alternating with slumps in seesaw fashion.

With a cast of only five characters, the week's fourth and final offering, "Angel Street," opens tonight at the John Golden. This Victorian melodrama by Patrick Hamilton will unfold the story of a criminal husband who tries to drive his wife insane.

The problems of labor and industry, priorities and price-fixing were laid aside momentarily yesterday by 2,000 members of the National Association of Manufacturers, while honor was paid to eight women guests recognized by the association as leaders in defense industry.

The invincible armies that have overrun Europe from Narvik to the Sea of Azov are in full retreat for the first time in this war. At the farthest point they have reached in their onward march they have been obliged to turn back. This in itself is an omen that perhaps they have stretched their striking power beyond its limits.

The New York racing season of 1942 is likely to open on April 11 and run about 175 racing days, it was learned yesterday following a meeting of The Jockey Club, at which no statement was given out. It was known that The Jockey Club session was called to approve the schedule drawn up some time ago by the five associations.
ALBANY, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The speed-up of national defense is working Cupid overtime in upState New York, although the priorities problem recently threatened to slow him down.

Unlike the American Santa Claus, who travels in a sleigh drawn by four prancing reindeer, the good St. Nicholas of Holland came on a white horse to Holland House at 10 Rockefeller Plaza late yesterday afternoon, where he distributed toys and goodies to about 200 refugee children of Holland.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- Fort Slocum's observance of the holiday season will begin this weekend with athletic contests, dances, motion picture shows and vaudeville entertainments. There will be events for the entire garrison of troops, which include engineers, signalmen, quartermasters and a large contingent of recruits awaiting transfer to overseas posts.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial on the railway settlement is much in point. You are correct in stating that any increased expenses of the railroads are passed on to the public.

A program for improving Negro living conditions, including increased job opportunities, better housing and more extensive health, educational and recreational facilities, was advanced last night at a meeting of the West Harlem Council of Social Agencies in the Y.W. C.A. auditorium at 144 West 138th Street.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Dec. 4 (Delayed) -- According to Soviet war correspondents, the Red Army Command has noticed indications that Field Marshal Fedor von Bock again is seeking to regroup his forces on the Moscow front in an effort to narrow their sphere of activity still further and thus increase the pressure against General Gregory K. Zhukoff's defenses in depth.

A spirited debate on the position American educators should take on our entrance into the war took place yesterday at the tenth New York regional conference of the Progressive Education Association, attended by 1,000 teachers and administrators at the Hotel New Yorker.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 5 -- One of the most difficult tasks of health and nutrition experts has always been the problem of getting people to consume more milk.

The recital given by Robert Casadesus last night in Carnegie was another exhibition of the superior type of pianism one has learned to expect from him. Never has the wide range of tone color, the fascinating combination of masculine strength and extreme delicacy or the technical prowess of the distinguished French artist been employed here to better purpose than at this latest appearance.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Pat Petroski, sophomore guard, placekicked a field goal with only a minute to go tonight to give Miami a 10-to-7 victory over the V.M.I. football team before 19,534 spectators in the Orange Bowl Stadium.

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, said yesterday that he looked forward to the day when independent drives for charitable institutions would he eliminated in order to abolish the duplication of effort and time. He addressed a luncheon report meeting of women working for the $300,000 campaign of the Homeless Children's Committee of the Children's Aid Society, held in the Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

Motion pictures of hundreds of marching, shouting and gesticulating C.I.O. pickets in a mass demonstration in front of Gimbel Brothers department store last August were shown here yesterday to the Joint State Legislative Committee on Industrial Labor Conditions.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 5 -- The political temperature on the eve of Sunday's election in the Province of Buenos Aires was raised today by the discovery of what was represented as a widespread plot to secure by fraud the triumph of the conservative National Democratic party, which supports Acting President Ramon S. Castillo.

New bond financing in the amount of $25,368,000 was done this week in this market, all of it State and municipal. Last week new financing of all classifications aggregated $48,408,201. A year ago this week new bonds for $248,113,000 were marketed publicly.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We were chagrined to note the unfortunate emphasis given by the RappCoudert committee to its analysis of Communist activities among the students at City College. Instead of seeing a "real peril," the committee might well have given thanks that the vast majority of the student body, as observed by the committee itself, are serious-minded and patriotic young men and women.

ABOARD THE FLAGSHIP QUEEN ELIZABETH With the British Mediterranean Fleet, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The British Navy and Air Force are destroying or damaging more than 60 per cent of all fresh supplies and troops the Axis powers are desperately trying to deliver to Libya, the British asserted today.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced yesterday that he had called a meeting of the executive board of the union's Atlantic Coast district to map a campaign of opposition to legislation inimical to labor.

Trade Here Up 3 to 5% While unfavorable weather conditions retarded expansion of Christmas trade here this week, estimates indicated an average gain for department stores here of between 3 and 5 per cent over the corrsponding week last year.

A dispute over the wages of seven cleaning women in a Cleveland garage halted all service out of New York and Boston yesterday on buses of the Central and New England Greyhound Lines. The sympathy walkout affected 125 drivers and seventy mechanics in this city and 100 drivers in Boston.

ROME, Dec. 5 -- A document describing an Italo-Yugoslav irredentist organization in the VenetiaGiulia region of Northeastern Italy was read today by Fascist Judge Tringali Casanova at the trial in Trieste of sixty men accused of plotting against the regime.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 6 -- Britain announced today that she was declaring war on Finland, Rumania and Hungary because no satisfactory replies had been received to ultimatums sent a week ago demanding their cessation of hostilities against Russia.

The Columbia melodrama "Confessions of Boston Blackie," which arrives at the Rialto this morning, completes the week's list of film newcomers. Chester Morris, in the title role, heads the film's cast, and Richard Lane, Harriet Hilliard, George E. Stone, Lloyd Corrigan and Joan Woodbury are among the featured players. . . . "Swamp Water" will start its fourth week today at the Globe.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 5 -- Following receipt of news indicating a more serious trend of the Pacific situation, the War Cabinet, which had been in session all day, reassembled tonight instead of returning to Canberra as it had intended, and made two vital emergency decisions relating to the defense of the Commonwealth.
ALBANY, Dec. 5 -- Two new regiments of the New York Guard, to be known as the Twelfth and Twenty-second, have been reorganized in New York City, Governor Lehman announced today.

N.H. Kutner of the City A.C., second on the seeded list, advanced through a first-round match in the National Squash Tennis Association's Fall B and C tourney at the City A.C. courts yesterday. Kutner ranked among the B's, defeated O.C. Taylor of the Yale Club, C player, by 15 -- 11, 15 -- 8.

Some 8,000 persons in this country have lost both eyes and 80,000 one eye in industrial accidents. More than 25,000, approximately one-sixth of the entire blind population, have been blinded by syphilis and gonorrhea. About 300,000 students in American colleges, nearly 25 per cent of the entire enrollment, are handicapped by visual defects.

TRENTON, Dec. 5 -- New Jersey's "race hatred" law was held unconstitutional today by the State Supreme Court in an opinion which, though it declared that the defendants' statements were "not welcome to the ear of any good citizen," reversed convictions of nine men for making or promoting anti-Jewish speeches at a German-American Bund rally.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Persons "so wanting in loyalty and patriotism" as to publish "unfinished studies of our production requirements for national defense" were denounced today by Secretary Stimson.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Dec. 5 -- A four-day cavalcade from the Carolinas re-populated this Army center early in the week as the Second Armored and Fourth Motorized Divisions returned to brush up, preparatory to another largescale movement, this time on furloughs during the Christmas holidays.

Elizabeth Cusick, 17-year-old honor student of West Roxbury, Mass., who was identified by her father as an amnesia victim at Bellevue Hospital yesterday, was back in the hospital last night after a scene at Grand Central Station in which she refused to accompany her father home.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Wheat fluctuated in an erratic manner within a range of about 1 cent a bushel today. Futures declined early on scattered selling which disclosed a lack of aggressive support but when buying appeared the market rallied quickly.

POPLAR BRANCH, N.C., Dec. 5 -- As we write this the wind is howling about the eaves of the Whalehead Club for the first time in almost two weeks, and if it will only blow as hard and from the same quarter for the next twenty-four hours, tomorrow will be one of the red-letter days for the Currituck duck hunters.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Nancy Vanca, suffering from incurable cancer, moved from, her private room to a public ward at the University of Virginia Hospital and turned over her savings from twenty years of work as a State Health Department nurse to help others in a similar plight.
ROME, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Italian High Command today issued this communique:

In a plan to implement justice for the poor by making it possible to conciliate small claims controversies without litigation. President Justice Pelham St. George Bissell of the Municipal Court has started a conciliation service that had its second session yesterday in the First District Municipal Court, 6 Reade Street.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Dec. 6 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Moscow radio broadcast the following communique today:

A plea for the extension of the junior achievement program, initiated three years ago to encourage youth in industry and thus preserve the American system of free enterprise, was made yesterday by leading executives attending the current convention of the National Association of Manufacturers.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- The possibility that the Dodgers would acquire Chuck Aleno of the Reds to play third base was seen today as a factor in a prospective trade between the National League champions and the Giants. Should such a deal go through, Brooklyn would be in a position to trade Cookie Lavagetto, veteran third-sacker, to New York.

VICHY, France, Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- -- Three new outbreaks of violence, including a bombing and the shooting of a German major, were reported today from Paris and French authorities feared that the spread of terrorism might affect Franco-German collaboration negotiations.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 5 -- President Roosevelt's declaration pledging rapid assistance to Turkey under the lease-lend act has provoked widespread satisfaction in the Turkish capital.
BERLIN, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Seemingly endless waves of Russian attackers above the Sea of Azov are beating without gain against a solid German line, Nazi military authorities announced tonight.
Announcement was made yesterday that a knitting shop would be opened Monday at 686 Madison Avenue to encourage accelerated knitting efforts for Christmas gifts to enlisted men.

JUNCTION CITY, Kan., Dec. 5 -- The size of the authorized air force at Marshall Field, Fort Riley, was doubled this week with the transfer of headquarters and headquarters squadron, Seventy-second Observation Group, ordered from Little Rock, and the First Observation Squadron, already at Fort Riley as the air unit of the First Cavalry Division.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 6 -- Tomokazu Hori, spokesman of the Cabinet Information Board, announced at a press conference yesterday that the Washington negotiations would continue. He repudiated charges by the Japanese press that America lacked sincerity and was protracting the negotiations purposely.

The city of Buffalo, N.Y., sold yesterday to F.S. Moseley Co., a new issue of $2,900,000 of tax anticipation certificates of indebtedness, dated Dec. 15, 1941, and payable on June 15, 1942. The bankers bid 0.54 per cent plus a premium of $100.

At the second of her four programs at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall last night, Ruth St. Denis cut loose and had herself a time. Things started sedately enough with repetitions of the familiar "Kwan-Non," the "Japanese Flower Arrangement" and the always lovely Chinese "White Jade," but even in this early part of the evening there was one item that gave warning of high spirits to come.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Dec. 6 -- By-passing Taganrog to the north after breaking the Germans' rearguard line in a six-hour engagement, Russian forces on the southern front during yesterday's fighting continued their advance another eleven miles to the west of that important town, according to the military commentator on the Moscow radio this morning.

The new Production Requirements Plan of the OPM's priorities division provides the first opportunity for producers of essential civilian goods to get blanket priorities covering their needed materials, according to Sydney Hogerton, district manager of the Priorities Field Service, who called a press conference to explain the operation of the plan.

The word from India that Jawaharlal Nehru and 500 other imprisoned Indian nationalists have been released from prison and that more soon will be is good news for friends of Britain and bad news for the Axis. Politically, strategically and morally India could easily be a dangerous trouble spot.

A strike, called in the midst of the pre-Christmas shopping rush, shut down one unit in the W.T. Grant variety store chain yesterday and curtailed the sales force in ten others. The United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes, C.I.O., estimated that 450 salesgirls and shipping clerks had responded to the strike call in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Yonkers.

New York's bid to outdo London as the murky metropolis of the universe continued for the fourth consecutive day yesterday, although there were considerable variations in the hourly densities compared with Thursday.

Referring to popular music "as a morale builder without an equal," Mayor La Guardia, in a letter yesterday to members of the New York Federation of Music Clubs, said that popular music "must perform that function in connection with our all-out effort for national defense."

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 5 -- As a cold wind blowing over the drying desert sands whipped clouds of dust across the battle area in Libya yesterday, British, New Zealand and Indian troops met and defeated Axis forces in at least three separate actions, it was announced today.

The eleventh anniversary of the founding of the Caucasian Society Allaverdy was celebrated last night at the annual Allaverdy Ball, held in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The society aims to develop the understanding of Caucasian culture and traditions and to foster a closer social relationship with Americans.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 4:

After speeding in the wrong direction on the Willis Avenue Bridge four men were drowned at 4 P.M. yesterday when the car in which they were riding plunged forty feet into the East River. They had crashed through a tonand-a-half iron guard rail while the bridge was opened for a passing tugboat.
American Hard Rubber The American Hard Rubber Company voted yesterday a dividend of $3 a share to holders of its common stock. This is an increase of 50 cents over the previous payment in 1940.
FORT BRAGG, Dec. 5 -- Colonel John T. Kennedy, who organized and trained the First Army's tank attacker units during the Carolina manoeuvres, assumed command of Fort Bragg Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- President Roosevelt's Emergency Fact-Finding Board warned today of possible strikes by Railway Express Agency employes and called on President Roosevelt to urge the agency to accept a compromise wage increase of 10 cents an hour.

OTTAWA, Dec. 5 -- United State exporters who had feared that Canada's price control program would cut off a large part of their business were given assurance today that they would be able to maintain the bulk of their shipments to Canada.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Dec. 5 -- Trading on the Bourse today was listless, and some stocks declined as much as 5 points. Some resistance was met at the lower levels. Royal Dutch lost 1 1/4 points at 344 3/4 guilders; Amsterdam Rubber declined 5 to 328 guilders, and Philips 2 to 285 guilders.

Isabel and Silvio Scionti, duopianists who gave recitals at Carnegie Hall in 1938 and 1939, last night gave an all-Bach program in Town Hall. It included a Concerto in C major, a fugue from the "Art of the Fugue" and a number of transcriptions, including four new ones by Mr. Scionti.

VICHY, France, Dec. 5 -- Under an order of the occupying authorities yesterday all limited liability companies and business firms in the occupied zone must submit for approval the resolutions of their annual meetings to the German military command in Paris.

"Universal Bible Sunday" will be observed tomorrow, ushering in the First Annual Bible Week, to be celebrated under the auspices of the Laymen's National Committee, Inc., with headquarters at 112 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Chester C. Davis, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, has been chosen impartial chairman to conduct public hearings scheduled to start Friday for the Office of Production Management to determine copper production potentials of the nation, it was reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Dies Committee on Un-American Activities has undertaken to determine the extent to which subversive groups and individuals have attached themselves to country-wide isolationist and interventionist organizations, and to see whether they have taken posts of influence in national or local units.

FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., Dec. 5 -- After two months of participation in Southern war games, the Twenty-ninth Division, 6,000 strong, is due back home at the beginning of next week, with the last units expected by Tuesday evening. This is several days earlier than originally planned.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- Materiel, particularly vehicular, is coming in a steady stream to the Fourth Armored Division. More boxcar loads of light tanks arrived this week for the Thirty-fifth and Thirty-seventh Armored Regiments, while the Eightieth has nearly half its medium tanks.

Tomorrow will be Bible Sunday, ushering in Bible Week, and many pastors will preach sermons on the need of Bible distribution and Bible instruction in the present international situation. On the ecclesiastical calendar the day will be the second Sunday in Advent.

FORT CUSTER, Mich., Dec. 5 -- Still clad in Army khaki, Sergeant Henry Greenberg said goodbye today to the camp where he has been a soldier more than six months and set out "to make myself ready to take over the old job with the Detroit Tigers."

SINGAPORE, Dec. 5 -- Japan's next move is likely to be in Thailand, well-informed sources here believe. An attack on Malaya or the Philippines is not ruled out entirely, but recent Japanese activity in Indo-China is thought to point more in the direction of Thailand than anywhere else.

The grim, battle-packed exploits of a British man-of-war were revealed here yesterday by officers aboard the damaged cruiser Phoebe, which is now in the Navy Yard in Brooklyn for repairs after months of combat in the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Senate Defense Investigating Committee read into the record today a report criticizing "the almost complete lack" of recreational facilities at Army camps. The report was read while the committee was hearing Brig. Gen. Frederick H. Osborn, Army morale officer, who was questioned on what his department was doing to maintain morale.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The outcome of the Army-Navy game, in which sports experts seem generally to agree that the decision went to Navy because of its superior manpower, leads me to make a suggestion regarding intercollegiate football which is borrowed from the practice in professional baseball.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Japanese Government informed President Roosevelt today that Japan's reinforcement of her military forces in French Indo-China resulted from what she considered threatening movements of Chinese troops along the Northern IndoChina border and that the action was within the stipulations of Tokyo's treaty with Vichy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Permission to abandon its passenger service between Philadelphia and New York was asked today of the Interstate Commerce Commission by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company, chiefly for the reason that the State of New Jersey has increased its taxes on the road from about $213,000 a year to $285,000.

A line drawn from Ankara to Helsinki and from both those capitals to Tokyo forms a vast triangle which contains the Russian war. Turkey and Finland are at opposite ends of the long battlefront. They guard the western gate of the Soviet Union as Japan lies athwart the approaches to the eastern door at Vladivostok.

Collectors and dealers paid 5463,520 for 112 pictures in a two-session auction that ended last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc. The paintings formed the collection of the late Mrs. B.F. Jones Jr. of Sewickley Heights, Pa., widow of the chairman of the board of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation.

Adequate lighting in defense in dustries and the use of corrective glasses by employes with defective vision would reduce inefficiency and injuries and result in a "large increase" in the production of essential materials, the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness was told yesterday at its biennial conference in the Hotel Astor.

After weakening early, the cotton market advanced sharply yesterday under a flurry of buying orders that followed reports of a more favorable turn in the Far Eastern situation. Closing prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were near their best levels for the session and at net gains of 18 to 23 points.

Two weeks from tonight, "Hellzapoppin" will shoot off its last cannon and will depart from the Broadway that has been its home for the last three and a quarter years. Holder of the long distance record for musical shows -- the night of Dec. 20 will see its 1,400th performance -- it will be leaving town at about the time the screen version is scheduled to open at the Rivoli.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 5 -- With baseball men scurrying out of here as if an invading army were hammering at the city's gates, all eyes today were beginning to focus on Chicago, where the major league conclaves will be held next week.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 5 -- Fifteen dogs were started this morning in the first annual national open all-age stake and fifteen remained tonight as possible winners of the most important retriever event of the year. The competition was held in the covers of Penniman's Point in the village of Quogue.

Members of the City Council finance committee agreed yesterday to favor constructoin of a new city airport in the Idlewild section of Jamaica Bay after Major Elmer Haslett, director of La Guardia Field, had told them that the Federal Government had allocated $875,000 as an initial grant toward land-fill and runway construction at that site.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- The St. Andrews Golf Club's No. 1 and No. 2 teams, performing on their own indoor rink, were among the early victors in the first round of the Utica Cup curling bonspiel today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 4 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Thailand tightened up her defenses today as Premier Luang Bipul Songgram indicated he was devoting himself entirely to military affairs. It was announced that henceforth he will be known as Field Marshal Plaek Bipul Songgram and that his petition to the Regency for relinquishment of the title of Premier had been sanctioned.

The elaborate plans that Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. mapped last Tuesday at the meeting of the State Athletic Commission for welterweight class activity were threatened with a snag yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Mrs. Roosevelt gave a dinner tonight for members of the Open Road, an organization which arranged student travel to Soviet Russia. It is headed by Dr. William A. Neilson, president emeritus of Smith College.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Senator Thomas of Utah, chairman of the Education and Labor Committee, said late today that he thought the committee would report the Smith defense strike bill, passed by the House Wednesday, with the milder measure of Senator Ball offered as a substitute.

The Long Island University basketball team defeated American International College, 51 -- 21, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gym last night. It was the seventh straight victory for the Blackbirds and the opener for the losers.

With Christmas drawing on, hours in the kitchen are fewer, harder to crowd into domestic programs. Often the housewife has a hectic day when she wonders if her family's dinner will ever materialize. But the clan need never go hungry or dine solely on soup if the cook knows the tricks of her trade -- the short cuts that oil the culinary wheels.

Thurman W. Arnold, Assistant Attorney General, asserted that illegitimate practices of labor unions force consumers to pay a tribute of more than $1,000,000,000 a year, in an address last night at the annual dinner of the forty-sixth Congress of American Industry of the National Association of Manufacturers in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 5 -- The war in Serbia is raging with increased violence, according to reports received by foreign military intelligence sources here describing heavy fighting in the Morava Valley, south of Belgrade, in South and Western Serbia and across the reaches of the Danube lowlands east of Belgrade.

Subsidy payments to the two largest milk producer cooperatives in the New York milkshed have been suspended by N.J. Cladakis, administrator of the Metropolitan Milk Marketing Area, it was announced yesterday. Those affected are the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, Incorporated, and the Eastern Producers Cooperative Association, Incorporated.

WILMINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Lieut. Colonel Henry K. Roscoe of Dover, commanding officer of the 261st Coast Artillery stationed at Fort Miles and Fort Saulsbury, has been named coast artillery officer of the Delaware harbor defenses with offices at Fort Dupont.

Taking office as the new president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, James W. Parker, vice president in charge of engineering of the Detroit Edison Company, said yesterday that America should feel proud and encouraged by the achievements of industry and engineering in the battle to defeat Hitler.

The New York State Employment Bureau is completing a survey that will be published in a week regarding the availability of household employes, and the specific work for which they are suited. According to a statement released yesterday a shortage of trained domestic workers willing to accept "living-in" positions always has existed, while part-time workers are and always have been available.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Establishment of an air force separate from the United States Army and Navy would be a "mistake," Representative J. Buell Snyder, chairman of the Subcommittee on Military Appropriations, maintained today as he returned to the Capitol from a visit to the British Isles.

VICHY, France, Dec. 5 -- There is a feeling in competent neutral circles here that war operations have reached a turning point of exceeding importance in its repercussions. The German High Command seems to be modifying military theory elaborated at great pains during many years, and for the application of which the Wehrmacht in its every branch had been trained sedulously.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 5 -- "Excessive taxation on residential realty and over-valuation of this type of property for tax purposes in many cities has reached the point of legalized larceny," in the opinion of John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank board.

Taking another step to place control of the affairs of the General Aniline and Film Corporation unmistakably in the hands of American interests, a majority of directors of the company yesterday elected William C. Bullitt a member of the board, restoring its membership to twelve persons.

Another slight increase was recorded in the short interest on the New York Stock Exchange in November. The total rose from 444,745 to 453,244 shares, neither figure including the short positions in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers, which rose from 53,221 to 63,802 shares.

Mrs. Donald Belcher of New York, national women's chess champion, defeated Miss N. May Karff of Boston, the former titleholder, in the fifth game of their championship match last night. Mrs. Belcher triumphed after thirty-four moves.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5 -- The Mars, the Navy's seventy-ton aerial cruiser, was damaged today in the first of a series of water tests on Middle River when the failure of one of her four 2,000-horsepower engines threw the plane out of control. Her power plant was affected, causing a fire in an engine housing.

RICHMOND, VA., Dec. 5 -- All favored teams survived the qualifying rounds of the national contract bridge team-of-four tournament and entered the final rounds tonight. The starting field of forty-seven teams had been cut to twenty-four teams.

A seven-point program designed to acquaint the public with the dangers now confronting advertising will be started soon by the Advertising Federation of America through its affiliated clubs, it was announced yesterday. Clubs will be asked to confer with local civic and professional organizations to discuss ways of presenting the industry's case.

Fordham's swimming team registered a 55-20 victory over St. Peter's College of Jersey City yesterday in the Rose Hill pool. It was the first meet of the season for both teams. The Peacocks took only two first places, Ernest Koster in the 440-yard free style and a victory in the 200-yard relay event.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The War Department announced today award of contracts totaling $6,912,563, of which the following, not previously published, went to the New York area:

FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 5 -- The United Service Organization and the Fort Dix Community Service re arranging a home-coming celebration for 20,000 troops returning early next week after two months of manoeuvres in the Carolinas.

The members of the Investment Bankers Association in their annual convention this week have shown concern about the future of free enterprise. For this they and their president have just been roundly berated by Edward C. Eicher, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 5 -- The Investment Bankers Association of America, in the final session of its thirtieth, annual convention, adopted today a resolution offering "our services and facilities freely and wholeheartedly to the United States Treasury in its campaign to sell Defense Savings Bonds, in any manner or activity wherever and whenever we can serve."

The curtailment in the production of tetraethyl lead as recently ordered by the Office of Production Management in an effort to conserve lead and chlorine will cost the motorists of the country an additional $250,000,000 yearly for an inferior quality of gasoline, according to a survey just completed in the oil industry.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Dec. 5 -- Burlingtonians are planning a gala welcome for the boys of the 186th and 187th Regiments, 71st Field Artillery Brigade, when they return tomorrow to their permanent post at Fort Ethan Allen after spending the last two months in the Carolina manoeuvres.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The War Department disclosed today that fifty-two new tank-destroyer battalions had been ordered as the next step in modernizing the Army. Plans also were announced to double the force of fully motorized divisions, increasing such divisions from two to four in number and enlarging the personnel of this form of shock troops to about 60,000 men.

An invaluable aid for the business man or any one having official relations with the Government of the United States is the United States Government Manual, published by the Office of Government Reports, it was pointed out yesterday by Reed H. Harris, acting New York State director of the office.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 5 -- Two new mystery films, Edgar Allan Foe's "The Mystery of Marie Roget" and "The Ghost of Frankenstein," a photoplay by Eric Taylor and Scott Darling based on the characters of Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley, will go before the cameras on Wednesday at Universal, the studio announced today.

New Government Financing Trading in the new government 2 1/2 per cent bonds and the 2 per cent bonds got under way yesterday on a "when-issued" basis, but business was not brisk. After considerable jockeying, the new 2 1/2s closed in the over-the-counter market at 101 8-32 bid, 101 10-32 asked, which is considerably less premium than that quoted on the original issue of 2 1/2s in October.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., Dec. 5 -- Forty-two of the ninety-nine men in the first training company, a permanent personnel unit now engaged in a seven weeks' field training program, qualified as marksmen in a rifle firing, and one soldier received a sharpshooter's rating, Major W.G. Mackinnon reported to Lieut. Col. H.C. Brenizer, commanding officer.

LONDON, Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- Joseph Stalin, Soviet Premier, and General Wladislaw Sikorski, Premier of the Polish Government in exile, yesterday signed a declaration of friendship and mutual aid, according to a broadcast of the Moscow radio received here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The House passed today the Third Sup- plemental National Defense Appropriation Bill, carrying $8,243,839,031 to expand the Army to 2,000,- 000 men and provide equipment for an even larger number.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Elimination of the javelin throw from Big Ten competition in the future, because it is regarded as dangerous and harmful, was recommended by the Western Conference track coaches today.

No new developments came yesterday in the football controversy at New York University. Professor Philip O. Badger, chairman of the board of athletic control, against whom much of the criticism has been leveled, is in Washington until Monday, and Dr. Marvin A. Stevens, the head coach, who has come in for his share of attack, had nothing to say.

The Administration's decision to build a power-line between the metropolitan area and the northern part of the State is an astute political manoeuvre. To shoot the large excess of power generated in New York City as far north as Massena, where the aluminum works could use much of it, seems sensible enough.

CAMP CROFT, S.C., Dec. 5 -- A $150,000 landscaping project has been started on this reservation. W.A. Natrob of Cincinnati has a $38,167.50 contract to plant ground covering, shubbery and shade trees in the six regimental areas, the work to be completed by Spring.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Finnish High Command issued this communique today:

The possibilities of increasing defense production through better utilization of existing machinery and reduction of "machine-down" or inoperative periods were emphasized yesterday at the closing panel of the annual conference of the Society for the Advancement of Management at the Hotel Commodore.

AMERICUS, Ga., Dec. 5 (AP) -- On a fog-enveloped highway a soldier's automobile and a school bus crashed head-on early today, killing seven persons and injuring twelve. Five of those killed were Fort Benning soldiers.

Determination to fight for preservation of the private enterprise system was voiced by leading industrialists yesterday at the fortysixth annual Congress of American Industry of the National Association of Manufacturers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

As the result of a 26,000-mile aerial tour of Latin America, the four-man House Select Committee to Investigate Air Safety recommended last night that American aircraft manufacturers "be authorized to proceed forthwith on the construction of larger and more powerful planes" for international airline service, particularly between the United States and Latin America.
BERLIN, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Following are excerpts from the address on "The Bill of Rights Today" delivered by H.W. Prentis Jr., chairman of the executive board of the National Association of Manufacturers, at the association's meeting yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel:

The Japan Institute, established here three years ago to promote a better understanding of Japanese culture and stimulate studies of it in United States educational institutions, is closing and the director and four of his staff will leave for home the middle of the month, according to an announcement yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Re-examination of selective service registrants in Classes 2-A and 2-B is contemplated by the Army in readiness for any occasion "when our military man power needs multiply vastly," Lieut. Col. Joseph H. Battley, chief of the Labor Division in the Under-Secretary of War's office, said today at the first session of a three-day conference of Army and Navy officers and executives from the Office of Production Management's Labor Division.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: When is the kind of opposition football teams play going to be taken more seriously into consideration? New York writers have been derisive in their comments on the schedules of Duquesne and Duke, to mention only two teams.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- It is a remarkable fact that the Vichy Government has not lodged any protest against the landing in the southern part of Indo-China of numerous bodies of Japanese troops that must have brought the total strength of the army of occupation to perhaps 100,000 men.
